title: Scores Feared Dead as Two Jets Collide Over Southern Germany
description: BERLIN, Tuesday, July 2 -- A Russian passenger airliner collided with a Boeing 757 cargo plane over southern Germany late Monday night, exploding in a fireball and apparently killing everyone aboard both planes, the police said. The Russian plane, a Tupolev Tu-154, and the Boeing 757 crashed into one another at 11:43 p.m. over the state of Baden-WAurttemberg in southwest Germany, said Wolfgang Wenzel, a state police spokesman in TAubingen. Initial reports varied about how many passengers the Russian-built Tupolev was carrying, but at least 97 people are believed to have died in the huge fireball, which lit up the night skies over one of Germany's favorite summer vacation spots, Lake Constance, on the border with Switzerland. According to the German television channel NTV, the Tupolev, operated by Bashkirian Airlines, was traveling between Barcelona and Moscow with as many as 150 passengers aboard. The plane had just made a stop in Munich, the television reported. The TU-154, a mainstay of aviation in the former Soviet Union, can carry up to 164 passengers. It is used on both domestic and international flights. More than 1,000 were built and most are still being flown, with just a few converted to freight use. Other reports suggested that the Tupolev was carrying 95 people. The Boeing was reported to be carrying cargo from Bahrain to Brussels with two pilots as its crew. Both pilots, thought to be working for the DHL delivery service, are believed to have been killed. The planes were flying at about 40,000 feet over Lake Constance, and burning wreckage was strewn over a 20-mile area near AUberlingen, 135 miles south of Frankfurt. ``I saw a flash of light so enormous that it lit up everything,'' Alfred Knoedler, one witness, told German television. Early this morning, police officers with dogs and infrared cameras were searching the area in the dark looking for survivors, the police said. The area is mostly agricultural fields and patches of forest, with widely scattered towns and farmhouses. Dozens of people flooded police stations in the area with calls describing how they had seen a large ball of fire in the sky at the time of the crash, Mr. Wenzel said. Some told the police they had seen pieces of burning wreckage falling through the sky. Three bodies have been found, the police said, adding that several houses, a school and a farm were on fire.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Robbery At Closed Landfill
description: Armed men broke into a closed landfill near Kennedy International Airport yesterday, threatened a City Department of Environmental Protection security guard and fled with computer equipment owned by a private contractor, the authorities said. The incident, apparently raising the fear of possible terrorist activity, drew members of the Joint Terrorism Task Force -- along with city police -- to the site, a former landfill in Brooklyn, off Fountain Avenue and near the Belt Parkway. About 4:30 p.m., two armed men crawled under a locked gate at the landfill, which closed in the 1970's but is being cleaned up, said Charles Strucken, a department spokesman. He said the two threatened the guard with a gun before they were joined by two other intruders who entered a trailer operated by the private contractor. The four took two computers and a photocopy machine, and then broke into the contractor's Jeep Cherokee. Mr. Strucken said the four men then drove off, crashing through a locked gate. The authorities said last night that no arrests had been made. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

description: YOKOHAMA, Japan:  Soccer history and a wonderful personal comeback combined Sunday in Yokohama to give Brazil its record fifth World Cup, and to give Ronaldo back the prowess and peace of mind he lost in the last final, four summers ago.

title: Judges Catch Up, With Some Cramming
description: The crumbling yellow-brick building of the Moscow Regional Court is not what one might expect of the main courthouse of Russia's most important region. Chipped tile and peeling linoleum line the hallways. The smell of meat and potatoes cooking in the shabby cafeteria wafts up to the courtrooms.

title: The Best Memorial Is a Song
description: Certain musical styles age more gracefully than others, and in the realm of jazz none has proved more enduring than the romantic, blues-inflected post-Gershwin style that elevates the popular standard into a semi-improvisational art song. A number of musicians who spent decades polishing that style gathered last Monday evening at the Kaye Playhouse to pay tribute to the singer Teddi King, who died 25 years ago. King's one hit single, ''Mr. Wonderful,'' in 1956, was not one of her finest moments, although it showed off her sunny pop-jazz contralto with its lustrous vibrato. She is better remembered for the refined taste in songs shown in her albums.

title: Now Showing on Czech TV: Financial Battles
description: Boardroom battles do not usually attract more television viewers than the World Cup, but as financial and political power brokers in the Czech Republic struggle for control of the leading TV station, nearly a million viewers are tuning in to watch the fray.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAGUS, SUSAN (NEE CAMPULLI)
description: RAGUS-Susan (nee Campulli). Died quietly and peacefully in her bed at a nursing home in Mamaroneck, NY, at the age of 82 on Thursday, June 27, 2002. The cause of death was complications brought on by Parkinson's Disease. Her husband Joseph Ragus was at her side as she passed away. Susan was born and schooled in Manhattan. Shortly before World War II she went to work at the Saturday Review of Literature while attending the Cooper Union School of Art in NY City. At night on a four year scholarship she met her future husband at Cooper Union. Susan and then Lieutenant Joseph Ragus were married in 1944. Bearing and nurturing three children came next, including ''back to work'' to pay college tuitions. Sue did cost accounting for the firm of Gibbons, Heidtmann and Salvador Architects for the New White Plains, NY, Library during her stay. Later she did more cost accounting onsite for the entire construction of the New General Foods Headquarters in Rye Brook, NY. After retirement she volunteered at the Cooper Hewitt Museum in NY City and later for the Scarsdale Historical Society, Scarsdale, NY. She and her husband have lived in Scarsdale for 40 years. Susan is survived by her husband Joseph, her two sisters Rita and Eleanor, her two sons Christopher and Jeremy and her daughter Amy, as well as two grandchildren, Jennifer and Alexander.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: With the Lifestyle Comes the Access to Information

title: Judge Rules U.S. Death Penalty Violates the Constitution
description: Afederal judge in New York declared the death penalty unconstitutional today, saying evidence has shown that there is an "undue risk" that a meaningful number of innocent people have been executed.

title: Widger's Story Isn't Just About Baseball
description: There is a lot of time to think about life and baseball and how they intertwine when you are driving seven hours through the darkness from Columbus, Ohio, to New Jersey, which is what Chris Widger did early yesterday. For Widger, a minor leaguer who was becoming a major leaguer again with the Yankees, there is always a lot to ponder now. Everything changed drastically for him 13 months ago.

title: Footlights
description: Around the House

title: Ozzy Osbourne and his ilk breathe life into glam rocks : Gothic undead
description: LONDON  Madman of Metal" Ozzy Osbourne makes an unlikely fashion icon. Yet 2002 is shaping up as a Jubilee year for the former lead singer of Black Sabbath. Ozzy's fashion clout is thanks largely to his newfound cult status as King of MTV. "The Osbournes," a fly-on-the-wall show spying on mad dad Ozzy, banshee mother Sharon plus their teenage children, Kelly and Jack, is the network's most popular show of all time (attracting 8 million viewers in the United States alone).

title: Lawmakers In Hartford Send Budget To Governor
description: Six hours before the start of Connecticut's 2003 fiscal year, lawmakers approved a revised $13.2 billion state budget this evening that would cut spending, increase taxes and avoid potential layoffs and state-agency shutdowns that Gov. John G. Rowland had warned of two days ago.

title: Innocent but More Adult Than Her Faithless Lover
description: American Ballet Theater's production of ''Giselle'' is crammed with dramatic detail. Repeated performances do not dull the dancers' liveliness and feel for character, all the way back to the back of the corps. But there was surprisingly little rapport between two sets of principal dancers on Thursday and Friday nights at the Metropolitan Opera House. And that diminished dancing that was often inspired.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOULK, SAMUEL S.
description: FOULK-Samuel S. We regret to announce the death from a heart attack of Samuel S. Foulk on June 19 in San Francisco. Sam was a Managing Director at PricewaterhouseCoopers and enjoyed a national reputation as a tax consultant, particularly in the field of Mergers and Acquisitions, where he was a leading expert in ''golden parachutes.'' Sam is profoundly missed by his family and an enormous number of friends across the country and indeed across the world. Since Sam's body has been donated to science, there will be no funeral. A memorial fund has been established to create a fellowship named in his honor at the Martin Luther King Jr. School of Law, UC Davis. Those wishing to contribute should send their donations to: UC Davis Foundation/Samuel S. Foulk Memorial Fund, 508 2nd Street, Suite 203, Davis, CA 95616. A Memorial Celebration of Sam's life is planned for 2pm, Sunday, August 18, in the Carnelian Room, Bank of America Building, 555 California Street, San Francisco. All Sam's friends are invited to attend. Eileen M. Feild (nee Foulk) Nancy Foulk Margaret M. Foulk David A. Traill

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on June 21 about a surge in movie box-office revenue this year misstated the trend in sales of videocassettes and DVD's in 2002. They have increased considerably, not decreased, though rentals, which are easier to track, have indeed declined about 2 percent. The article also misidentified a trade publication cited. It is Video Business, not Video News.

title: Some Conservatives Question the Value of Reorganizing Domestic Security
description: He has no realistic hope of stopping the proposed Department of Homeland Security -- a reorganization of federal agencies that official Washington suddenly considers vital to the prevention of terrorism -- but John J. Duncan Jr. says he is seriously considering voting against it.

title: In the Cult of Business, Icons Fall
description: To the Editor:

title: Decisions, Decisions for a Book Publishing Dynasty
description: If some people around you try to squirm out of their skins during Thomas McCormack's ''Endpapers'' at the Variety Arts Theater, you might suspect they work in publishing. After all, when a man who was the chief executive of St. Martin's Press for many years writes a play about the book business in which characters are drawn in merciless detail, an audience should wonder who the originals are.

title: Corrections
description: The Metro Matters column on Thursday about the State Legislature misstated the title of Andrew S. Eristoff, who intends to run against Senator Liz Krueger. He is no longer chairman of the Manhattan Republican Party. He resigned on May 1 to run for the Senate.

title: E-Commerce Report; Amazon is said to be shopping for partners to offer more apparel on its Web site.
description: AMAZON is getting some new clothes.

title: Accounts
description: The Marine Corps ended a required review on its account by keeping the Atlanta office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group, as its agency. Billings were estimated at $40 million a year under a new five-year contract with Thompson, which has handled the account since 1946.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Officer Hit By Car
description: A car struck and injured a New York police officer yesterday as he was helping to direct traffic in Lower Manhattan, the police said. The officer, who is assigned to the Manhattan Traffic Task Force, was astride a two-wheel scooter at a traffic post at West Fourth Street and Eighth Avenue when he was hit around 10:20 a.m., the police said. The officer, whose name was not released, was treated for neck and back injuries at St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital and was discharged, the police said. No summonses were issued. Al Baker (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7

title: Corrections
description: A report by Reuters in the Company News column of Business Day on Friday about plans by Pitney Bowes, the maker of office equipment, to acquire the PSI Group, a mail presorting company, misstated the effect the deal will have on the work force. Pitney Bowes said no job cuts were expected.

title: More Battles Are Expected Over Vivendi
description: The Bronfman family, overruled by the Vivendi Universal board last week in its call for the resignation of the chairman, Jean-Marie Messier, has its lawyers looking for a loophole that would allow it to try again to oust Mr. Messier, according to a person close to the discussions.

title: Estimates Increase On '02 Ad Spending
description: Two forecasters have adjusted their estimates slightly upward for American advertising spending this year.

title: Timothy White, 50, Billboard Editor in Chief
description: Timothy White, the editor in chief of Billboard magazine, died on Thursday afternoon at the magazine's Manhattan offices. He was 50, lived in Boston and commuted to New York City.

title: In the Cult of Business, Icons Fall
description: To the Editor:

title: They're Young. They're Sexy. They're Targets.
description: On the slick pages of the new official magazine for the women's tennis tour, there are the ubiquitous images of Anna Kournikova in different stages of a hair toss, snapshots of the curvaceous sports cars preferred by the top stars and a glimpse of the luxury hotels frequented by the players on the road.

title: Tilting at Windmills, Only This One's a Bridge; Walkway Over Hudson Is One Man's Fixation
description: About a decade ago, Bill Sepe uncorked a doozy of an idea. The old Poughkeepsie Railroad Bridge -- an engineering marvel in 1888 but a delinquent eyesore ever since a spectacular fire closed it in 1974 -- should be transformed, he said, into a pedestrian skyway over the Hudson River.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERVIN, LOUIS E.
description: CHERVIN-Louis E. 92, beloved husband of Charlotte, predeceased by his beloved first wife Isabelle, mother of his children Sandra, Peter and Barbara, and grandfather to Jessica. Private service at Sharon Mem. Park, Mass.

title: Liberty at Loss for Both Words and Points
description: The Portland Fire had every right to be tired yesterday. The Fire had defeated the Washington Mystics at home Saturday night, and then flown across the country, arriving in New York early yesterday, while the Liberty players were still asleep.

title: THE COLLECTIONS / PARIS: MARGIELA
description: MARTIN Margiela's all-white store, (above) with its gargantuan chairs, shrouded chandelier (and water cooler), its wine bottle table lamps, at 200 ($199), and its vintage handbags covered with black or white cotton covers (from 673) is the hippest boutique in town. The newly-opened store (25 bis Rue Montpensier) offers the various Margiela lines, including one-off chiffon scarf tops (260) and menswear at the back of the store where windows are painted white.

title: Gay Pride, and More, Clearly on Display
description: Fifth Avenue was awash yesterday in balloons, feathers, leather, wigs, thongs, stilettos and lots of bare skin, as tens of thousands marched in and watched the 32nd annual gay pride parade in Manhattan. The parade began as a tiny and timid affair in 1970 to commemorate the anniversary of an uprising at the Stonewall Inn, a gay bar in Greenwich Village, and has evolved into an enormous, electric dance party in the streets, thundering yesterday from 52nd Street to the Village.

title: Metro Matters; Prometheus Unbound, Hot Off Copier
description: CLOSE readers of last week's state court decision on education, the one that calls an eighth-grade education good enough for New York City schoolchildren, will find language that leaps from the page. Sort of the way a mugger leaps out at a victim.

title: After Finishing Off Mercer, Klitschko Wants Lewis
description: With Ray Mercer behind him, plenty of new admirers with him and a future that is fixated on Lennox Lewis, Wladimir Klitschko now waits, wonders and longs for his chance to step into the ring for his idea of a blockbuster fight.

title: In Trenton, Budget Battle Keeps Legislators Working Into Morning
description: The New Jersey Legislature worked into the morning today in an effort to adopt the largest budget in the state's history and close its largest projected deficit ever.

title: India's Leader Names Hard-Line Nationalist as Heir Apparent
description: Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee's elevation of Lal Krishna Advani, a canny political strategist with a reputation for hawkishness on Pakistan, to the post of deputy prime minister on Saturday anoints him officially as the No. 2 man in the government and may mark him as the prime minister's successor.

title: Cigarettes Up To $7 a Pack With New Tax
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed a bill yesterday that will raise the city's cigarette tax to $1.50 a pack beginning today. City officials and opponents of smoking say the increase will give New York the highest cigarette tax in the nation and push the price of some brands to more than $7 a pack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILD, ANNE
description: WILD-Anne. On June 27, 2002, in Boca Raton. A devoted wife, mother and grandmother. A warmly dedicated teacher for 32 years. An inspiration to Walter, Madeleine, Jane and Philip and a dear sister to Lillian and Jack.

title: In Berlin, 2nd Place Isn't Awful
description: Germany did its duty and duly lost to Brazil today, but for most of the Germans who dabbed themselves with national colors to cheer on their team in Potsdamer Platz, second place to the deft guys in yellow was not so awful.

title: No. 4 Republican in House Will Not Seek Re-election
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 _ Declaring ``it is time for me to move on,'' Representative J.C. Watts of Oklahoma, the fourth-ranking member of the House Republican leadership and the only black Republican in Congress, said today that he would not seek re-election and would retire at the end of this term.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Veto Over Court

title: Painterly Sermons Mix Severe and Sensual; Bringing to Light an Artist and Preacher Rooted in Southern Culture
description: Atheists, secularists and rationalists might want to visit a museum show in Raleigh before deciding that there is no vengeful God who punishes the wicked with eternal suffering and rewards the righteous with heavenly bliss.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the On Stage and Off column on June 7 about the availability of tickets for ''The Phantom of the Opera'' at the TKTS booth for the first time since the musical opened in 1988 misstated the location of the 1987 opening of ''Les Misrables,'' which could be hurt by the increased competition at the booth. It was at the Broadway theater, not the Imperial, where it has been since 1990.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday with the television Highlights column misstated the location of a 1993 handshake between Yitzhak Rabin and Yasir Arafat, with President Clinton standing by. It was at the White House, not in Oslo.

title: Improving on 2001, Sorenstam Wins 6th Tournament in 12 Starts
description: At the beginning of the year, people asked Annika Sorenstam how she could possibly improve on 2001.

title: The Silence That Bred a Crime
description: The day after the guilty verdict came down in the Michael Skakel case, my sister and I, like so many others, couldn't help talking about it. The fact that Michael Skakel was married until recently to our first cousin and is the father of their child (a boy not yet 5) made the discussion a necessity. During the last few years we have had a nodding, passing acquaintance with all things Skakel, a ''look-there's-another-tabloid-isn't-it-sad-let's-not-get-any-closer'' kind of thing. But now that Michael Skakel is awaiting sentencing, we can't pretend anymore that he has nothing to do with us.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Information -- not all of it good, remember -- is passed from bedroom to boardroom to dinner table and back.''

title: Consider Pettitte's Comeback Complete
description: Andy Pettitte is the subway rider who caught the last train, making it to Yankee Stadium just in time for the end of the first half of the Yankees' season. He has been absent for much of it, working to strengthen his left elbow, and that was not really Pettitte who opened the first Subway Series at Shea Stadium 16 days ago, was it?

title: Recycling of Glass and Plastic Ends Today
description: The city's recycling program will be drastically scaled back starting today, as the Bloomberg administration, in a money-saving move, halts the recycling of glass and plastics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELIX, FREMONT
description: FELIX-Fremont. Age 98. On June 29, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Alice. Interment private.

title: Havana Elegance Meets New York Brass
description: The JVC Jazz Festival double bill at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night was something like the before-and-after photos in a bodybuilding ad. ''Before'' was Orquesta Aragn, the charanga group from Cuba that was founded in 1939 and popularized the cha-cha around the world. ''After'' was the pianist Eddie Palmieri and La Perfecta II, from New York, reviving the groundbreaking music of La Perfecta, the group Mr. Palmieri started four decades ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, DAVID O'D
description: KENNEDY-David O'D. Died on June 27, 2002 at the age of 95. He was president of Kentile Floors, served as Mayor of the Village of Centre Island from 1946-59, Commodore of Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club from 1973-75. He was also a member of the NY Yacht Club, The Union Club, and was instrumental in the development of the Beaver Dam winter sports club, and was involved in numerous America's Cup Campaigns. Mr. Kennedy was born in Manhattan, graduated from Princeton in 1929 and, during the war, served in the U.S. Coast Guard Temporary Reserve. He was predeceased by his wife Phyllis. He is survived by his son Andrew G. Kennedy of Bayville, NY, and two daughters Joan K. Earle of Carmel, CA and Carolyn Doran of Upper Brookville, NY, four grandchildren: Whitney Hanley, Christopher Cranis, Lisa Kennedy, and Tricia Kennedy; a great-grandaughter Parker Hanley. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, July 3, 2002, 11:00 a.m. at St. John's of Lattingtown Church. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to N.S.U. Hospital at Glen Cove 101 St. Andrew's Lane, Glen Cove, NY 11542. For further information, please contact the Francis P. DeVine Funeral Home Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREED, NANCY LEE
description: FREED-Nancy Lee. Born in New York City on December 11, 1923, died peacefully on Friday, June 28, 2002, in the company of her son Carl Freed, her daughter Jennifer Freed and her partner Rendy Freedman, her sister Jane Kalmus, nephew John Kalmus, her cousin Marie Patrick and her husband Michael Lofthus. She is also survived by her son Andrew Sutton, her niece Suzi Kalmus, her daughter-in-law Jennifer Freed, her sister-in-law Edith Penzner, and five grandchildren. Passionate wife of the late Bert Freed, she was a truly gracious and elegant woman. She touched the lives of so many with her zest for life and charisma, her strength and sensitivity, tough determination, wonderful sense of humor, endless generosity and compassion, and her spontaneous warmth and affection. Nancy was a lifelong activist in New York and California. Long a public relations consultant, she was a tireless and dedicated volunteer for the Venice Family Clinic and the Police Activities League. She was also tremendously proud of the accomplishments of OPICA, an adult day service and counseling center in Los Angeles, and treasured the friendships that developed over the years. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, July 2, 2002, at 11:00 a.m. at Leo Baeck Temple in Brentwood, Los Angeles, California. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Family Therapy Institute for the Academy of Healing Arts for Teens, 23 West Mission, Santa Barbara, California 93101.

title: Ronaldo's Sweetest Vindication
description: YOKOHAMA, Japan, June 30  Four years ago, Ronaldo entered the World Cup as a two-time international player of the year and left in mysterious failure as Brazil fell meekly to France in the final. In the intervening years, a ligament in his knee came unraveled, and so, it appeared, did his career.

title: Pro-Europe Leftists Gain in Old East Bloc
description: A new political divide has appeared in Europe: while Western Europe is moving to the right, the left has triumphed in former Soviet bloc lands that once rejected anything smacking of their Communist past.

title: In the Cult of Business, Icons Fall
description: To the Editor:

title: DoubleClick Sells Its Media Sales Business to L90
description: DoubleClick, the Internet advertising company, has sold its North American media sales business to L90, a former competitor in that business, for $9.4 million in cash and stock and possibly another $6 million if performance thresholds are met, the companies said on Sunday. In addition, L90 will change its name to MaxWorldwide when the deal closes, which the companies expect to happen early this month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, TIMOTHY T.A.
description: WHITE-Timothy T.A. Of Beacon Hill, Boston, on June 27, 2002. Editor in Chief of Billboard Magazine, journalist and author. Husband of Judy Garlan and father of twin sons, Christopher and Alexander, all of Boston. Brother of Douglas J. White and Amy J. Reiss of Florida, Denis T. White and David E. White of North Carolina, John R. White of Oklahoma, Gloriann Gallagher of New Jersey. The family will receive friends and relatives on Monday, July 1, 2002, from 5-8 at J.S. Waterman & Sons-Eastman-Waring, 495 Commonwealth Ave., Boston. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Tuesday morning at 10 at the Paulist Center, Five Park Street, Boston. If desired, memorial contributions may be made to the Timothy White Foundation, c/o Judy Garlan, 24 Temple Street, Boston, MA 02114. Visit www.MEM.com for memorial.

title: Londoners go up-country in fine English style
description: LONDON  When the American pop singer Madonna moved to England, it was assumed she'd bring a little Hollywood glamour to little old London. But instead, she went country. Her weekends were spent shooting clays with a shotgun wearing the British brand Dunhill rather than shooting tequilas at the Met Bar wearing Dolce & Gabbana. And the public finally got an explicit whiff of a trend that had been building for some time.

title: Clifford Possum, a Painter Of Aboriginal Masterworks
description: Clifford Possum, who painted some of the masterpieces of Australian aboriginal art, died on June 21 in Alice Springs in the Australian desert, an ancient landscape he depicted in the mythical terms central to his heritage. He was about 70, art historians said.

title: Trachsel Resembles Only a Shadow of Himself
description: Steve Trachsel held his glove to his face, concealing his mouth, but his facial muscles churned as he spoke to the pitching coach Charlie Hough. The Yankees had one out, a run in and men on first and third in the fourth inning last night and were already ahead, 3-0. Hough was trying to coax Trachsel through two more outs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HARA, CLIFFORD BRADLEY
description: O'HARA-Clifford Bradley. 84, died June 26, 2002, of complications from a systemic staphylococcus infection. Born January 2, 1918, survived by his wife of 61 years, Helen Hanford O'Hara; a brother, John Brangs O'Hara; his children, Hanford, Helen Elizabeth, Susan Bradley, Jane Loving, and Clifford Bradley, Jr.; 13 grandchildren; seven great - grandchildren. Gra duated Princeton University, A.B. 1939, M.B.A. New York University, 1956. Lt. J.G., U.S. Navy, Pacific Theater, 194446. Director of Port Commerce, Port of New York Authority, 1962-80, after a lifelong career in transportation management, promotion and development. Member, Board of Directors, Panama Canal Commission, 1980-82, reappointed 1994-99. Memorial service 2:00 P.M., July 2nd, St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Riverside, CT. Memorial donations may be made to Southbury Training School General Welfare Fund, P.O. Box 872, Southbury, CT 06488. For information, Gallagher & Son, Greenwich, CT, 203869-1513.

title: Waiting for Ground Zero Proposals
description: Those who care passionately about the rebuilding of downtown Manhattan now find themselves in an anxious limbo. The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation has promised that by mid-July, the public will see a half-dozen options for reclaiming ground zero. The waiting would be easier if we were totally confident that everyone else is waiting, too. The corporation chairman, John Whitehead, and Gov. George Pataki need to assure the public repeatedly that no developer, no advocate group, no politician is slipping through the back doors to wield insider clout while everyone else is standing quietly on the sidelines.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Israel Begins to Dismantle Unofficial Settler Outposts
description: The outposts, as they are called here, are often no more than a mobile home or two, sometimes not even occupied. Asahel's population is three: a trio of young Israelis on a desert hilltop with four dogs, a generator, a water tank, a television and a stuffed deer head, but not too much else.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZONE, MARTY
description: ZONE-Marty. Happy Birthday, my Marty. I miss you. Always will. Your Ton

title: 175 Million Brazilians Hold a Samba Celebration
description: When it was all over, after Germany had been vanquished and the natural order of things in the soccer universe had been restored, the jubilant fans poured onto streets and sidewalks here. Brazil had just won the World Cup for the record fifth time, and they were in a mood to celebrate.

title: Calling for Justice, Sweet and Defiant
description: On Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, Cassandra Wilson came out humming. There were a few gentle, warm notes, then she smiled, closed her eyes and cocked her head, mimicking the blissful reaction she aims to inspire.

title: History's Buffet: You Are What Your Ancestors Ate
description: NEAR A THOUSAND TABLES

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: California Officials Wrangle Over Plans for Great Park
description: It had always seemed a given that once the residents of the vast suburban stretches of Orange County decided what the shuttered El Toro Marine Corps Air Station here should become, a decade of epic battling would end and the workaday task of drawing up plans and calling in the earthmovers would begin.

title: Oklahoma Republican Weighs Whether to Retire
description: Representative J. C. Watts Jr., an Oklahoma Republican who has told colleagues he is strongly considering retiring at the end of the year, has scheduled a news conference for Monday in Norman, Okla., to announce his decision, Congressional officials said today.

title: Fiction and Fact Collide With Unexpected Consequences
description: After three nonfiction books and countless magazine articles, I developed the conviction that novels contained the real writing, in which the author didn't just take the world as he found it but actually imposed his own vision upon it. With each nonfiction book, I found myself creeping farther down the diving board toward fiction, as my journalistic accounts relied increasingly on narrative, setting and character. Finally, about 10 years ago, I took the plunge.

title: Your S.U.V., Our Cost
description: To the Editor:

title: Oilers Gain Richter's Rights
description: The Rangers traded the rights to goaltender Mike Richter to the Edmonton Oilers for an undisclosed draft pick, hours before the N.H.L.'s free-agency deadline.

title: Democracy in Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Tyco, its image and stock price tarnished, looks for relief with the pricing of the CIT Group.
description: TYCO International has not had a good day in awhile. Tomorrow it may win a temporary reprieve.

title: So Passionate in Love, But Icy in Her Madness
description: Two performances of ''Giselle'' at the Metropolitan Opera House suggested that American Ballet Theater's production of this 19th-century classic is in fine shape. Alessandra Ferri and Julio Bocca portrayed the leading roles of Giselle and Albrecht on Wednesday night. Amanda McKerrow and Maxim Belotserkovsky starred on Tuesday night. Both casts were eloquent.

title: Russia Glances to the West for Its New Legal Code
description: For 13 years, Pavel P. Khovrachyov has been a criminal prosecutor, investigating and convicting people for crimes large and small. Everything about his job is about to change.

title: MediaTalk; Random House Executive Will Step Down
description: The influential publisher Phyllis Grann is leaving her position as vice chairwoman of Random House after six months, complaining of boredom with her job, people close to Ms. Grann said on Friday.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: VENTNOR CITY: POLICE KILLER PICKETS POLICE Thomas Trantino, who served 38 years in prison for killing two police officers in New Jersey, attended a racial profiling demonstration at the police headquarters in Ventnor City. Organizers said that they had no idea Mr. Trantino was there, and that he had been invited by a protester from a Philadelphia Quaker group. "We would never have allowed him to be associated with us," J. David Alcantara, a lawyer, told The Star-Ledger of Newark. "It was a total surprise to us." City officials said they were angered to learn that Mr. Trantino picketed on Friday carrying a sign that read, "Racism is not patriotic." Mayor Timothy Kreischer said, "We are livid about it." (AP)

title: Suitable Schools
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Egyptian Treasures
Men's Suits and More From Paris
National Briefing | West: Nevada: Most Casinos Avert Strike
description: Negotiations led to tentative agreements that avoided a threatened strike by nearly 5,000 bartenders, maids and food-service workers at 10 hotel-casinos in downtown Las Vegas. Late last night, negotiations with the Golden Gate hotel-casino failed, and some 165 maids, bartenders, bellmen and food servers walked off their jobs. Another casino that failed to reach agreement, the Western Hotel and Bingo Parlor, said it would close after Sept. 1. Union officials would not disclose details of the agreements until they were ratified. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Olympic Officials Complete Visit
description: They toured potential sports facilities, met the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, dined with celebrities at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's private town house and paid their respects at ground zero. The United States Olympic Committee wrapped up an overnight trip to New York City yesterday, saying that the city remained in serious contention to be its choice to compete against other world cities for the 2012 Olympics, but making no promises. The city is now vying with Houston, Washington and San Francisco to be America's choice. A decision is expected in November. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Pataki's Surprising Limit On Ground Zero Design
description: When Gov. George E. Pataki said on Saturday that nothing would be built where the twin towers once stood, he all but took the pencils out of the hands of the urban planners hired to consider options for the site of the World Trade Center.

title: Doubling the Damage at the U.N.
description: The Bush administration's misguided campaign to demolish the International Criminal Court now threatens to undermine United Nations peacekeeping too, starting with Bosnia. This is remarkably petulant behavior for a country that played a decisive role in halting Bosnia's murderous ethnic conflict and helped pioneer the idea of international war crimes prosecutions at Nuremberg more than half a century ago. Washington's reckless course has isolated it from its closest allies, including Britain. The administration should accept a pragmatic compromise before the Bosnia peacekeeping mandate expires tomorrow night.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: CHIP SALES STRONGER IN MAY The Semiconductor Industry Association, a trade group, said yesterday that worldwide sales of computer chips rose 2.8 percent, to $11.37 billion, in May, with broad growth in almost all product sectors. Still, the semiconductor industry remains depressed from its highs. Sales in May were 10.5 percent lower than in the period a year earlier, when companies netted $12.7 billion from chip sales. The industry has only begun to rebound from two years of slumping sales. The trade group said that Asian chip makers, particularly those based in China, were benefiting from growth in contract manufacturing. The Asia-Pacific region, however, was the only one to experience growth from last year  a rise of 22.4 percent. Sales in the Americas, Europe and Japan declined more than 20 percent in each region, the group said. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Weighing Medical Ethics For Many Years to Come
description: Dr. Harold T. Shapiro, the economist and former university president, tackled some of the most contentious ethical issues in medicine, including stem cell research and the cloning of human cells, while heading the National Bioethics Advisory Commission from 1996 to 2001.

title: Whittle a Russian Down, He's Still Extravagant
description: The rapid rise and forward march of Russian music lead unavoidably through Rimsky-Korsakov, and yet the reputation that survives is curiously marginal. A handful of orchestra pieces remind us of his orientalism and exquisite ear for orchestration. History, on the other hand, seems more interested in Rimsky-Korsakov the sublime meddler: completer, renovator and redecorator for fallen comrades like Mussorgsky and Borodin. We know him, too, as the teacher of Stravinsky, Prokofiev, Glazunov and Respighi. There is something secondhand about this current fame, as if it had come down to us by a life led through others.

After his distinguished diplomatic career as Italian Ambassador to Ethiopia, Japan and Germany, and Deputy Secretary General of NATO, Ambassador Guidi joined the Gilman Paper Company as Howard Gilman's personal consultant and as a Director of the Foundation. His wise counsel over the years, critical to the development of the Foundation, and his friendship will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Gioia.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Rikers Prisoner Accused Of 1998 Rape
description: A Brooklyn man who is already serving a sentence at Rikers Island for stealing from a Macy's storeroom was indicted yesterday on separate charges that he raped and robbed a Macy's employee in January 1998. The man, Joe Felder, 39, surprised an employee who had gone into a stockroom looking for a sale-priced bathrobe at Macy's flagship store in Herald Square, officials said. During the attack, the employee stabbed Mr. Felder with her identity badge and he bled onto the bathrobe, the authorities said. Manhattan prosecutors said the DNA from the bathrobe linked Mr. Felder to the crime. Mr. Felder, in a statement to the police, said he was not guilty. Susan Saulny (NYT)

A Commerzbank spokesman, Dieter Schuetz, said the bank intended to hold the stake as an investment. Fiat sold shares in Ferrari to reduce its debt.

description: An off-duty New York police officer was arrested late Sunday on drunken driving charges after he crashed his minivan into a car on the Grand Central Parkway in Queens, the police said. The driver of the struck car, Hector Modesi, and two passengers complained of neck and back pain, the police said. The officer, Sgt. Juan A. Jimenez, 36, is a 10-year veteran who is assigned to the 33rd Precinct in Upper Manhattan. He was found to have a blood-alcohol content of 0.15 percent, according to court paperwork. He was suspended from duty without pay, the police said. Al Baker (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sony Now Expects A Profit
description: Sony, in a reversal, said yesterday that it had probably earned a profit in the business year's first quarter, bolstered by its record-setting ''Spider Man'' movie. Sony, whose shares lost a quarter of their value in the last year, faces slowing demand for hard-disk drives, chips and cathode-ray tube monitors. Its shares fell 2.8 percent in Japan and dropped about 2 percent in Europe.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: DnB Abandons Bid For Storebrand
description: DnB Holding, Norway's biggest bank, yesterday abandoned its $2 billion bid for Storebrand, the country's largest insurer, on concern that a slump in stock prices and an increase in risky loans had made the price too high. ''We saw a need for a substantial revision of the transaction,'' DnB's chairman, Jannik Lindbaek, said. Shares of Storebrand tumbled 7.9 percent, the biggest drop since Oct. 1. It was the second time in less than a year that a buyer backed away from purchasing Storebrand. Storebrand has struggled with bad loans at its Finansbanken unit, booking losses and provisions of almost $70 million over the last 18 months. The company's life insurance business has been hurt by slumping equities markets. DnB agreed to buy Storebrand on May 28. The company's stock then declined as much as 13 percent.

title: TYCO RAISES $4.6 BILLION WITH CIT GROUP OFFERING
description: Tyco International Ltd. raised $4.6 billion yesterday on the sale of the CIT Group, about half the amount the conglomerate paid for the finance business a year ago. Tyco sold 200 million CIT shares at $23 each, below the $25 to $29 range Tyco set two weeks ago and below the $25 investors expected as recently as yesterday. The Bermuda-based Tyco, needing the cash to help pay back more than $27 billion in debt and help revive a stock price that has dropped 76 percent this year, pressed ahead with the sale while other companies postponed their offerings because of faltering stock markets.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: PixelNet Seeks Debt Relief
description: PixelNet, a German processor of digital photographs, said yesterday that it filed for protection from creditors. The company filed the application at a local court in Dessau after its Photo Porst unit sought protection from creditors last week, PixelNet said in a statement to the Frankfurt exchange. Photo Porst is no longer able to repay loans it owes PixelNet on time, the company said. Photo Porst failed to find investors for the owner of photography stores that it acquired for a symbolic price of 1 deutsche mark (51 cents) last year. PixelNet shares fell about 11 percent, to 25 cents. The shares have lost 95 percent of their value this year.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Geneva: W.T.O. Gets White House Plan
description: The Bush administration sent the World Trade Organization a plan to eliminate a number of international trade barriers for a range of service industries including banking, computing, insurance, express delivery and telecommunications. Eliminating existing barriers to trade in services, the United States trade representative's office said, would help create more than $1 trillion in new commerce globally. The United States could win about half of that new business, it estimated. The W.T.O. is negotiating opening up markets for services as part of its new global trade round that was approved by its 144 member countries at Doha, Qatar. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Fledgling Business Owners Say They're Unemployed, Too

description: Network Associates, a maker of antivirus software that owns about 75 percent of McAfee.com, will buy the remaining McAfee Class A common shares. Shareholders of McAfee.com will each get 0.78 share of Network Associates for each share they own, Network Associates said. The terms are similar to those of an offer that Network Associates withdrew in April after finding errors in its accounting that resulted in a restatement of results for three years. Network Associates fell $1.65 yesterday to close at $17.62. McAfee, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., fell $1.04, to $13.60.

title: Everyone Is Outraged

George W. Bush replaced him with Harvey Pitt, who promised a ''kinder and gentler'' S.E.C. Even after Enron, the Bush administration steadfastly opposed any significant accounting reforms. For example, it rejected calls from the likes of Warren Buffett to require deduction of the cost of executive stock options from reported profits.

description: So your kids love trains, but you aren't going to Europe. VIA Rail Canada offers an option closer to home: Through Aug. 31, adults with a regular economy-class ticket can take a child age 2 to 11 free. Typical one-way fares from Montreal are $78 to Toronto and $42 to Quebec (at $1.56 Canadian to the U.S. dollar). Reservations must be made at least five days ahead, and other conditions apply; (888) 842-7245 or www.viarail.ca/offers .

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. To Sell An Old Site
description: The I.B.M. Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its operations in Endicott, N.Y., to a group of local investors as part of a retrenchment plan. The Endicott operation was one of the original installations of I.B.M.'s corporate predecessor, the Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company, founded by Thomas Watson Sr. in 1911. The local investor group, Endicott Interconnect Technologies, is buying the dozens of buildings on the upstate campus. I.B.M. will lease some of the buildings for its 2,000 sales and services workers there, who will remain with the company. Endicott Interconnect will also take over the local circuit-board assembly and chip-packaging operation, which employs another 2,000 workers. Endicott Interconnect said it would invest $100 million to buy and try to sustain the local operations. I.B.M. said the loss it would take for the sale was part of a $2 billion to $2.5 billion charge against earnings that was announced last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOSWELL, MORRIS LAFAY ETTE
description: DOSWELL - Morris Lafay ette, 84, Labor Leader and Activist, Vice President Emeritus of District 65, United Automobile Workers of America, AFL-CIO, died at his Bronx home of cardiac arrest, June 27. A labor leader for 42 years, he recruited blacks into the union and was instrumental in unionizing Revlon in 1945. From 1963 until his retirement, he directed an $8 million ''Development & Training Program for the Distributive Trades,'' training over 15,000, including exoffenders and ex-addicts. Active in Harlem politics for many years, he played a leadership role in electing Adam Clayton Powell to the City Council and to all of his congressional terms. As cochair of a Harlem Democratic District, he helped elect over 10 black judges. A native of Blackstone, Virginia, Mr. Doswell is survived by his wife of 55 years, Viola; brother, DeWitt, and sister-in-law, Gloria; & numerous cousins, nieces and nephews.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: PIXELNET SEEKS DEBT RELIEF PixelNet, a German processor of digital photographs, said yesterday that it filed for protection from creditors. The company filed the application at a local court in Dessau after its Photo Porst unit sought protection from creditors last week, PixelNet said in a statement to the Frankfurt exchange. Photo Porst is no longer able to repay loans it owes PixelNet on time, the company said. Photo Porst failed to find investors for the owner of photography stores that it acquired for a symbolic price of 1 deutsche mark (51 cents) last year. PixelNet shares fell about 11 percent, to 25 cents. The shares have lost 95 percent of their value this year. (Bloomberg News)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Kursk Conclusion
description: The Russian submarine Kursk sank in the Barents Sea nearly two years ago because the fuel inside a torpedo exploded and set off a second, catastrophic blast, the chairman of a government inquiry said. The official, Science Minister Ilya I. Klebanov, told the Interfax news agency that a leak of hydrogen peroxide used to fuel the torpedo caused the disaster, which killed all 118 men aboard during a naval exercise on Aug. 12, 2000. The commission presented its conclusions in a secret meeting in Moscow on Saturday. It remained unclear when, if ever, the commission would release details of its findings. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

description: Japan and South Korea lived the World Cup not so much as a global soccer tournament, but as a festival to change their countries for the better.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Catapult Forecast And Shares Drop
description: Shares of Catapult Communications plunged yesterday after the company cut its quarterly estimates because of weaker sales of its testing systems for the telecommunications industry in North America and Japan. The warning caught some analysts by surprise because of the scale of the expected miss. Catapult said that for its fiscal third quarter ended June 30, it would have revenue of $8 million and earnings of 10 cents a share. It had predicted revenue of $11 million and earnings per share of 20 cents. Catapult slumped 51 percent, or $11.19, to $10.69. Catapult's systems are used to test network components.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: OLYMPIC OFFICIALS COMPLETE VISIT They toured potential sports facilities, met the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, dined with celebrities at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's private town house and paid their respects at ground zero. The United States Olympic Committee wrapped up an overnight trip to New York City yesterday, saying that the city remained in serious contention to be its choice to compete against other world cities for the 2012 Olympics, but making no promises. The city is now vying with Houston, Washington and San Francisco to be America's choice. A decision is expected in November. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Budget Fight Forces a Standoff in Trenton
description: The governor threatened today to send state troopers to track down any lawmaker who fails to attend a special legislative session on his corporate tax plan. The mayor of Newark vowed to scuttle the state budget indefinitely if he did not get a long-awaited downtown hockey and basketball arena. The state treasurer was busy scrambling to come up with $1 billion in emergency spending cuts because Gov. James E. McGreevey's fellow Democrats refused to approve the cornerstone of his budget.

title: Volpe Repeats That Schwarz Wasn't There
description: Justin A. Volpe, the former police officer who attacked Abner Louima five years ago, testified yesterday that he alone sodomized Mr. Louima with a broken broomstick and that Charles Schwarz was not in the precinct station bathroom where the attack took place.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: COMPUWARE TO CUT 1,600 JOBS Shares of Compuware fell 19 percent yester- day after the company said it planned to cut 1,600 jobs and an analyst said its growth might be stymied. Compuware, which makes software to manage mainframe computers, fell $1.57, or 26 percent, to $4.50 in early afternoon trading of 3.15 million shares, less than the three-month daily average. Compuware, based in Farmington Hills, Mich., said in a recent filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had laid off 1,049 workers by May 31 and planned to eliminate 551 more jobs in its fiscal first quarter, which ended on Sunday. Officials could not immediately be reached for comment. Joseph Farley, a Morgan Stanley analyst, wrote in a report yesterday that Compuware's revenue might be less than expected as it cut prices to fend off competition from I.B.M. (Bloomberg News)

description: ''It's not what nationality they are. It's that they're stupid enough to start a fire.''

title: Pete Gray, Major Leaguer With One Arm, Dies at 87
description: Pete Gray, who became a major league outfielder despite the loss of his right arm in a childhood accident, appearing with the St. Louis Browns for a single season during World War II, died Sunday at a nursing home in Sheatown, Pa. He was 87.

title: Pump Extends Lives, and Raises Questions
description: With tens of thousands of Americans dying of heart failure each year, and a dire shortage of donated human hearts, cardiologists have long dreamed of a device that could be permanently implanted in people too old or sick for a heart transplant. Now, the Food and Drug Administration is considering just such a machine.

title: Crime Rate Increases Sharply In New York (State, Not City)
description: Though the crime rate continues to slide in New York City, the number of homicides, rapes and robberies rose sharply outside the five boroughs last year, particularly in a few upstate cities, according to new statistics recently posted on the Internet by state officials.

title: Distressed By the Taming Of the West
description: Denis Johnson belongs to the strain of male writer whose distinctly American milieu is a loopy and ominous squalor. Like, say, Barry Hannah and Sam Shepard, Mr. Johnson creates characters who are often articulate but connected to conventional society by a frayed tether, and he contrives for them a language of colorful metaphors and oblique or otherwise idiosyncratic logic. Such manipulative phrasemaking is a kind of literary muscle flex, a masculine display that at its best is bruisingly tough but that always risks being mere peacock feathers, literary plumage.

title: Let Us Do the Worrying About July 4 Security, and We Have, Bloomberg Says
description: With the Fourth of July holiday looming and nonspecific terror alerts trickling out of the federal government once again, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, took pains yesterday to assure New Yorkers that they were in charge and that everything would be fine.

title: TOYOTA TO START LEASING S.U.V.'S POWERED BY FUEL CELLS
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said yesterday that it would start leasing 20 sport utility vehicles powered by fuel cells to the private sector by the end of the year. Fuel cells are hydrogen-powered energy sources that the auto industry regards as environmentally friendly replacements for the internal combustion engine, though cars powered by fuel cells are not expected to be widely available for at least a decade. Toyota would be the first to offer such vehicles in any capacity. The Honda Motor Company plans to make some available next year, and all the other major automakers are developing their own. John Hanson, a Toyota spokesman, said half the vehicles would be versions of the company's Highlanger sport utility vehicle and would be available to businesses in California, where the company has set up hydrogen fueling stations. The other half will be available in Japan, he said. Danny Hakim (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABINOVE, SAMUEL
description: RABINOVE-Samuel. 1923-2002. ''The First Amendment guarantee of free exercise of religion means freedom from governmental impediment. It was never intended to mean freedom from private expense, any more than the constitutional guarantee of freedom of the press entitles indigent would-be newspaper publishers to government funding to publish their newspapers.'' Samuel Rabinove, 1992. The American Civil Liberties Union is deeply saddened by the death of our friend & ally Samuel Rabinove, legal director of the American Jewish Committee, who loved America and the American Constitution and worked to preserve the separation of church and state. His passing stills one of liberty's most eloquent voices, but his cause lives on.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Shorter Hours For Pet Shelters
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday signed into law a bill that reduced the number of hours during which the city's animal shelters will accept dogs and cats to 12 hours from 24 hours. The reduction was part of the city's budget for the fiscal year that began yesterday. In addition, the city's shelters will also now operate their adoption program five days a week, instead of seven. The bill also extends the period of time the city has to build full-service shelters in the Bronx and Queens to July 1, 2006 from July 1, 2002. The signing ceremony was held early in the morning, to the frustration of those who opposed it and wanted to come to City Hall to say so. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Exports Rise

Exports rose 3.7 percent, to 29.1 billion ringgit ($7.7 billion), from a year earlier, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said. In April, exports rose a revised 5.9 percent.

title: J. C. Watts, Into the Sunset

Bush has assembled the most racially diverse Republican administration in memory. The diversity of the executive branch, however, has underscored the whiteness of the Republican delegation in Congress, which has but one black member, Representative J. C. Watts of Oklahoma. He announced yesterday that he would not seek re-election in November. Mr. Watts, the fourth-ranking member of the House Republican leadership, said his goals in Congress had been accomplished and that he wished to spend more time with his family.

title: Critic's Notebook; Treasures To Rival King Tut's
description: Just over 25 years ago, ''The Treasures of Tutankhamen'' opened at the National Gallery of Art in Washington and set a model for the must-see museum event. The show came with sensational art, a sexy story line (teenage pharaoh, archaeological derring-do, a curse from beyond the grave) and a monumental dose of promotional spin. Attendance was staggering. The blockbuster was born.

title: Afghans Link Civilian Deaths To U.S. Bomb
description: A 2,000-pound satellite-guided bomb dropped from an Air Force B-52 strayed off course during an attack today in southern Afghanistan, and there were reports that scores of civilians had been killed or injured in that area, military officials said.

title: THE COLLECTIONS / PARIS : Stripes everywhere as Hermes captures the right balance
description: PARIS  With stars making a guest appearance and stripes every which way, the Paris menswear shows give a neat example of how fashion works. Contrary to public misconception, a bunch of designers never gets together to create one single diktat in order that consumers are encouraged to spend their money on what's new.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, ELIAS A.
description: COHEN-Elias A. Although 50 years have passed since our beloved founder, Elias A. Cohen passed away on July 2, 1952, he is still remembered with love and reverence by the thousands of boys and girls who were privileged to come to his Tranquillity Farm and Camp for a few fun-filled weeks each summer since July 1, 1919. In the spirit of ''Noblesse Oblige,'' his devoted family, his many loyal friends and a grateful Alumni are all helping to perpetuate his Tranquillity Camp as a living monument to this great American humanitarian. We are proud to announce that Tranquillity is now celebrating its 84th year. Tranquillity Camp, Inc. Earlton, NY Pearl C. Miller, President

title: Capturing Eclectic Energy And South Asia's Melodies
description: The Tate Ensemble, a quintet of young musicians from London, offered three world premieres as part of its New York debut program on Thursday evening at Weill Recital Hall. There were a couple of works from the standard repertory on the program as well -- Bartok's ''Contrasts'' and Dvorak's Piano Quartet in E flat major (Op. 87) -- plus revivals of modern scores by Iannis Xenakis and Thomas Ads.

title: Mets Move Closer To Last With Loss
description: Shawn Estes looked like a mess. He sat in the Mets' dugout, his face flushed, and not only from the muggy conditions. His hair looked as if he had just emerged from a monsoon.

title: Legal Quirk Gives Schools Flock of Lame-Duck Leaders
description: By 5 p.m. Friday the seven members of the much-reviled New York City Board of Education had packed up their files and souvenirs and vacated their offices on the 11th floor of 110 Livingston Street in Brooklyn. By yesterday, they thought, the mayor would be in control of the school system, and it would be the dawn of a new era.

title: Holik a Good Sign? Yes, but Let's See
description: Like mosquitoes and air-quality warnings, free-agent signings by the Rangers are part of the summer routine. Most of them do not work out that well. The recently ended Theo Fleury era comes to mind, and so does the Mike Keane experiment of 1997. Oh yes, and Vladimir Malakhov, too, is a work still in progress.

description: TITUS-James Gulden, age 50 suddenly on June 30, 2002. Beloved husband of Barbara, cherished father of Shire, loving stepfather of William and Robert Miller, dear son of Alice Stevens Titus and the late James, Sr., adored brother of Stephanie and Sandra. Loving friend and neighbor. Funeral service Wednesday 1 P.M. from the Peppler Funeral Home, 114 So. Main St., Allentown, NJ. Calling hours Wednesday 10 AM-1 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions to Allentown High School, Red Bird Band Parent's Assoc. C/O Kathy Shaffer, 5 Red Owl Ct. Perrineville, NJ 08535.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Sales Stronger In May
description: The Semiconductor Industry Association, a trade group, said yesterday that worldwide sales of computer chips rose 2.8 percent, to $11.37 billion, in May, with broad growth in almost all product sectors. Still, the semiconductor industry remains depressed from its highs. Sales in May were 10.5 percent lower than in the period a year earlier, when companies netted $12.7 billion from chip sales. The industry has only begun to rebound from two years of slumping sales. The trade group said that Asian chip makers, particularly those based in China, were benefiting from growth in contract manufacturing. The Asia-Pacific region, however, was the only one to experience growth from last year -- a rise of 22.4 percent. Sales in the Americas, Europe and Japan declined more than 20 percent in each region, the group said. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Arizona Fire Scars Apache-White Relations
description: On the first of every month, Bernice Caddo cashes her Social Security check and heads 35 miles north to Show Low to shop for food, clothing and other family needs.

title: A Debt Places Strains On a Political Alliance
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey and Mayor Sharpe James of Newark owe much to each other -- too much, perhaps, for a smooth relationship.

title: Berl Senofsky, 77, Violinist and Teacher
description: Berl Senofsky, a prize-winning violinist who became a respected music teacher, died on June 21 at his home in Baltimore. He was 77. The cause was complications from heart and lung disease, his family said. Born in Philadelphia to Russian immigrant parents, Mr. Senofsky studied at the Juilliard School and won the Walter W. Naumburg Competition in 1946. From 1951 to 1955 he was the assistant concertmaster of the Cleveland Orchestra, playing under George Szell. In 1955 he took first prize at the prestigious Queen Elisabeth Competition, held in Brussels. In 1965 Mr. Senofsky joined the Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore, and remained there for 31 years.

title: The Highs and Lows Of Interleague Play
description: The Mets are in Philadelphia, where they can commiserate with the Phillies about the season that was supposed to be. The Mets can grumble about the failure of the high-profile winter moves they made; the Phillies can lament the moves they didn't think they had to make, only to discover the race quickly passing them by.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASCARENAS, CRESCENCIO L.
description: MASCARENAS-Crescencio L., on June 28th, 2002. Beloved husband of Noemi (nee Herrera). Beloved father of Marites, Eloisa, Albert, Gertrude, Benny, Josephine, Crescencio Jr., Connie, and Dencie. Also survived by 7 brothers and sisters, and 14 grandchildren. Funeral from the Francis X. Hatton Funeral Home Inc., 36-46 Bell Blvd. Bayside, N.Y. on Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Robert Bellarmine R.C. Church, at 9:45 A.M. Interment at Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery.

title: Rumsfeld Says U.S. May Not Join Future Peacekeeping Missions
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld today warned that American forces may not join future peacekeeping missions without a grant of blanket immunity from the jurisdiction of the new International Criminal Court.

title: Amid Speculation, Mauresmo Wins
description: The uniqueness of Amlie Mauresmo goes beyond a one-handed backhand that she routinely rips through as if cranking a lawn mower.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Compuware To Cut 1,600 Jobs
description: Shares of Compuware fell 19 percent yesterday after the company said it planned to cut 1,600 jobs and an analyst said its growth might be stymied. Compuware, which makes software to manage mainframe computers, fell $1.57, or 26 percent, to $4.50 in early afternoon trading of 3.15 million shares, less than the three-month daily average. Compuware, based in Farmington Hills, Mich., said in a recent filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had laid off 1,049 workers by May 31 and planned to eliminate 551 more jobs in its fiscal first quarter, which ended on Sunday. Officials could not immediately be reached for comment. Joseph Farley, a Morgan Stanley analyst, wrote in a report yesterday that Compuware's revenue might be less than expected as it cut prices to fend off competition from I.B.M.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Saturday with an article about the loss of jobs in the telecommunications industry referred imprecisely to a protest by employees at Verizon Communications in late May. They were demonstrating against the company's declaration that it could lay off employees as a last resort, not an announcement of actual layoffs.

title: Baby 'Walkers,' in Name Only
description: They may be called walkers, but when it comes to developing babies' motor skills, they seem to have the opposite effect, a recent study has found.

title: Corrections
description: A picture with the continuation of a front-page article yesterday about the exchange of corporate information among the wealthy was published in error. It showed Jeffrey R. Leeds, the chief financial officer of the GreenPoint Financial Corporation, not Jeffrey T. Leeds, a former investment banker, who said information about companies was passed along at dinner parties and fund-raisers.

title: INSIDE
description: California Pollution Measure

title: The Death of Innocents
description: Defendants are sometimes convicted of crimes they did not commit. We know this because of new techniques like DNA testing and because re-examined evidence uncovers false eyewitness testimony and suppression of evidence. As a society, we try to remedy these shortcomings. And the wrongfully convicted sometimes get another trial -- unless, of course, they have been put to death. The executed innocent are out of luck.

title: America the Whimsical
description: In a stressful time it's hard to be patriotic without being solemn. But at least half the reason one loves this country is that it's a playful, quite nutty place, teeming with ridiculous notions and silly pronouncements.

title: Pettitte and Hernndez Encourage the Yankees
description: George Steinbrenner loves pep talks, so he stood nose to nose with the injured pitcher Sterling Hitchcock on Sunday and asked how his sprained back was feeling. Hitchcock said he was improving gradually and itching to get back on the mound.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Ban On Packaged Shrimp
description: The state's agriculture commissioner, Charles Bishop, barred the sale of six brands of packaged products that use shrimp imported from China after tests showed they contained traces of the antibiotic chloramphenicol. The drug is banned from use in American agriculture because it can cause leukemia in children and aplastic anemia, a blood disease that can be fatal, in adults. David M. Halbfinger (NYT)

title: People
description: * Jonathan Rodgers was named executive vice president and managing partner for creative at the Thunder Grey unit of Grey Worldwide, New York, part of the Grey Global Group. He succeeds Robbie Goolrick, who left. Mr. Rodgers had been senior vice president and senior creative director on the FedEx and Pepsi-Cola accounts at the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group. At Thunder Grey, Mr. Rodgers will oversee creative work for clients like Aetna and Dairy Queen.

title: US Airways, in Desperate Straits, Defers Payment on Debt
description: US Airways said yesterday that it would begin putting off the payment of bonds and other public debts backed by its Boeing planes, a decision that illustrates the increasingly desperate financial situation of the airline.

title: Frederick O'R. Hayes, 78, Top Lindsay Aide
description: Frederick O'R. Hayes, New York City's budget director for four years in the early, optimistic days of the administration of John V. Lindsay, died on Sunday in Utica, N.Y. He was 78 and lived in Utica.

title: A Man Used to Moving in Elite Business Circles
description: If Vivendi Universal names Jean-Ren Fourtou to succeed Jean-Marie Messier as chief executive, the board will be getting not only a proven international deal maker but -- perhaps as important -- an executive closely entwined with the coterie at the very top of French business.

title: U.S. Warns Web Sites To Label Sponsorships
description: The Federal Trade Commission has warned the operators of several major Internet search engines to make it clearer to their users when companies have paid to be included in Web search results.

title: Leise Opts to Stay At Nebraska
description: Junior outfielder Jeff Leise has turned down an offer from the Anaheim Angels and will return for another season of college baseball at Nebraska. Leise was drafted last month in the seventh round by the Angels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLEES, MARY W.
description: McLEES-Mary W. On June 28, 2002. Aged 98 years. Loving sister of the late Msgr. Archibald W. McLees, and the late William J. McLees. Graduate of Adelphi University, class of 1924. Retired teacher for 40 years at Richmond Hill High School, her alma mater. Funeral Tuesday morning. For information: The LeahyMcDonald Funeral Home, Richmond Hill, New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Chunghwa Sale Fails
description: Taiwan did not attract a single bid in its attempt to sell an $824 million stake in Chunghwa Telecom, the island's largest phone company. The government, which offered 5.7 percent of the company for a second time in less than a month, needs the money to help cover a budget deficit of 327 billion Taiwan dollars ($9.7 billion). Chunghwa's chairman, Mao Chi-kuo, said he hoped shares could be sold overseas as soon as the September quarter. ''That's still an ongoing process, although it's been postponed for some time,'' he said. Taiwan initially said it would sell two-thirds of Chunghwa by the end of last year. The initial public offer of a 15 percent stake in September 2000, at twice the current sale price, ended 98 percent unsold. A foreign sale of shares was canceled twice. In June 2001, only a third of a 5 percent stake offered was sold.

title: U.S. Allies in Mideast Voice Doubts on Bush Peace Plan
description: Two of the United States' main supporters in the Middle East urged the Bush administration today to clarify how it intends to pursue peace in the region, one week after President Bush called for the ouster of Yasir Arafat as a condition for any meaningful agreement.

title: Cingular Wireless arrives late in New York, but comes bearing orange umbrellas and M&M's.
description: CINGULAR WIRELESS is hoping that its risky and expensive effort to break into the crowded New York market will be received more like the return of the Dodgers to Brooklyn than the resumption of alternate-side-of-the-street parking after a holiday weekend.

title: 71 Die When Two Jets Collide High Above Southern Germany
description: A Russian passenger airliner collided late Monday night with a Boeing 757 cargo plane over southern Germany, exploding in a fireball and killing all 71 people aboard the planes, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the role of Dr. Joaqun Navarro-Valls as the papal spokesman referred incorrectly to the membership of the Catholic society Opus Dei, which he joined in his early 20's, building a reputation that caught the attention of Pope John Paul II. Its membership is not restricted to men, and, in fact, women participate in its membership worldwide.

title: Congress's Sole Black Republican Is Retiring
description: Declaring ''it has been a wonderful ride,'' Representative J. C. Watts of Oklahoma, the fourth-ranking member of the House Republican leadership and the only black Republican in Congress, said today that he would not seek re-election and would retire at the end of this term.

title: Review/Fashion; In Paris, Breathing New Life Into Men's Suits
description: In a crowded cafe opposite the Dior show today, a gruff barman watched with disdain as the worn tables suddenly filled up with an exotic species. ''Fashion people,'' he said under his breath. Then he uttered an expletive.

title: Democratic Senator to Bow Out, Fueling Hopes for a G.O.P. Gain
description: State Senator Richard A. Dollinger, an outspoken Rochester Democrat, said today that he would not seek re-election in the fall, increasing the likelihood that the Republicans might pick up a seat in Monroe County.

title: Balloonist Makes First Solo Global Flight
description: Steve Fossett, a former stockbroker from Chicago who has swum the English Channel and raced an Iditarod dog sled, today became the first person to fly around the world alone without a motor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, EDMUND L.
description: ANDERSON-Edmund L. Of Manhattan and Quogue, NY, on June 29th, died at his summer home. He is survived by his wife, Joan Bauer Uttal Anderson; 3 children, Wendy Swindell, Linda A. Rost and Wesson S. Anderson; two stepsons, Bro Uttal and Linn Uttal; seven grandchildren & a great grandson. A musician, lyricist, producer and the Director of the ''Midday Jazz'' music program of St. Peter's Lutheran Church. A lifelong friend to some of the most prominent (and lesser-so) jazz musicians of our era, his encyclopedic knowledge and wit touched the lives of many. Private interment. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Jazz Ministry of St. Peter's Lutheran Church, 619 Lexington Ave, New York, NY 10022-4610.

title: Julia Albrecht Apple
description: Julia Albrecht Apple, the granddaughter of the founder of an Ohio grocery store chain and the mother of R. W. Apple Jr., the associate editor of The New York Times, died on Sunday in Akron, Ohio. She was 92.
