description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: CMGI Buys Bankrupt Company
description: The technology holding company that owns the search engine AltaVista, CMGI, said yesterday that it would buy the assets of Software Logistics, a bankrupt company that does business as iLogistix, for $41 million. Software Logistics, based in Fremont, Calif., makes supply-chain management software. It had agreed to be bought by Zomax, but Zomax backed out. CMGI said the transaction should be completed this month, but it is subject to approval by the United States Bankruptcy Court and the Netherlands, which has jurisdiction over some iLogistix assets and operations. Most of the company's 500 employees will be offered jobs, CMGI said. Shares of CMGI, based in Andover, Mass., fell 2 cents to close at 46 cents. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: THE COLLECTIONS / PARIS : Graphic Dior menswear scores in summer season of stripes
description: PARIS  With incisive cutting and an androgynous, modern attitude, Dior menswear once again sent out a powerful message on the last day of the Paris summer season. Designer Hedi Slimane not only produced a strong show Monday, but also took a definitive stance on crucial menswear trends, especially the tailcoat reinvented as a short, cutaway jacket, rounded like a carved-up melon.

title: Study Warns of Stagnation in Arab Societies
description: A blunt new report by Arab intellectuals commissioned by the United Nations warns that Arab societies are being crippled by a lack of political freedom, the repression of women and an isolation from the world of ideas that stifles creativity.

title: BBDO Wins Job for Bank of America
description: The Bank of America has awarded a new assignment, without a review, to the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group . The assignment, with billings that have not been determined, is to create a campaign to introduce an investment service program early next year for the bank's asset management group, which is based in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTTMANN, JEANNE (SCHWARTZ)
description: GUTTMANN-Jeanne (Schwartz), 88, June 26, in Long Branch, NJ. Beloved wife of Irvin, mother of Margaret and Elizabeth. Dear grandmother of John & Johanna, great-grandmother of Hannah. Loving sister of the late Marian Manheimer.

title: ImClone Links With Stewart Also Include Venture Fund
description: ImClone Systems Inc. is not the only company in which Martha Stewart is involved with Dr. Samuel D. Waksal. She is also an investor, along with a host of Dr. Waksal's friends, business associates and relatives, in a venture fund formed by Dr. Waksal last year known as Scientia Health Group.

title: 143-Year-Old Problem Still Has Mathematicians Guessing
description: In the early years of the 20th century, the great British mathematician Godfrey Harold Hardy used to take out a peculiar form of travel insurance before boarding a boat to cross the North Sea. If the weather looked threatening he would send a postcard on which he announced the solution of the Riemann hypothesis. Hardy, wrote his biographer, Constance Reid, was convinced ''that God -- with whom he waged a very personal war -- would not let Hardy die with such glory.''

title: Contract Pays More to Teachers Hired From Elsewhere
description: In a little-noticed provision aimed at reducing New York City's teacher shortage, the new teachers' contract greatly increases -- to nearly $61,000 from $43,370 -- the maximum yearly salary the city can pay teachers hired from other school districts.

title: U.S. vs. U.N. Court: Two Worldviews
description: The showdown between the United States and other members of the United Nations Security Council was the latest and strongest confirmation that the international solidarity forged after the terror attacks on Sept. 11 was probably superficial and temporary.

title: A Citizen of the World With Few Allies
description: Jean-Marie Messier, who appears to have been forced out as chairman of Vivendi Universal, failed in his ambitious goal of turning a French water utility into a global media giant because of his own misjudgments and missteps as well as some incredibly bad timing.

title: Rootless But at Home In a Britannia All His Own
description: Stranded in jittery Los Angeles last September, the British novelist Hari Kunzru was reminded all over again of how awkward it can be to look like one thing, sound like another and be something else entirely.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Selden: Toddler Dies In Fire
description: A 2 1/2-year-old girl was killed when a fire broke out in her grandfather's house on Long Island early yesterday, officials said. The toddler, Ashley Arriaza, was sleeping in an upstairs bedroom when her mother heard a snapping noise that the authorities believe may have been a circuit breaker. Ashley's grandfather, Miguel Flores, ran upstairs, where he found the child's room engulfed in flames and smoke, officials said. He tried to rescue Ashley and perform CPR, but the child was pronounced dead at Stony Brook University Hospital at 1:17 a.m., said Detective Lt. Jack Fitzpatrick of the Suffolk County police. The authorities said the fire did not appear to have been suspicious. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Mexican Corruption Suspect Surrenders to U.S. in Houston
description: A crucial figure in a mushrooming Mexican corruption scandal, Rogelio Montemayor Seguy, surrendered to United States authorities here today, ending an international manhunt of nearly two months. His legal case has become a focal point in the struggle between President Vicente Fox and his powerful opposition in the Institutional Revolutionary Party.

Its membership is not restricted to men, and, in fact, women participate in its membership worldwide.

description: Not to put too fine a point on it, but this has not been a golden period in French sports.

title: Getting Under Your Skin
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Ousted Executive Sells Auto Stock
description: Brilliance China Automotive Holdings said its former chairman and chief executive, Yang Rong, sold all of his stock in the company after he was removed from his posts two weeks ago. The company, which makes shuttle vans, put his stake at 2.2 percent, worth $11 million, and said that it had all been sold on the open market. There had been a widespread impression until this spring that Mr. Yang, a former central bank official, owned most of the company, which would have made him the third-richest man in China. But it turned out that a nonprofit organization overseen by the central bank, the Chinese Financial Education Development Foundation, was the controlling shareholder. Mr. Yang was the chairman of the foundation and the automaker until his removal from the foundation as well two weeks ago; he remains a director of the automaker. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Monday about the annual gay pride parade in Manhattan on Sunday misstated the number of such parades. It was the 33rd, not the 32nd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBEL, ELY
description: SOBEL-Ely. On July 1, 2002. He was 71 years old. Beloved husband of Rosalie, cherished and adored father of Ira and Beth, devoted and loved stepfather of Alyssa and Jeffrey Fried, kindhearted and loving grandfather of Ashley, Justin, Adriana, Willie, Jessica, Jake, Jamie, Ali and Jonathan, brother of Lionel and loved by all. Shiva will be observed at his daughter's home in Wesley Hills, NY, Wednesday through Friday. For further information, please call Hellman Memorial Chapels, 845-356-8600.

title: Trachsel Is Forced To Go On D.L.
description: The Mets placed the right-hander Steve Trachsel on the 15-day disabled list today because of a strain in his right trapezius, a large muscle in the upper back.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Vandals Hit Jewish Sites
description: Vandals attacked a synagogue and a memorial to Holocaust victims in the western spa town of Karlovy Vary, the local rabbi reported. Red paint was daubed on the synagogue and the memorial, and posters and leaflets were found calling for a pogrom against Jews and labeling them the founders of capitalism. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Two Media Conglomerates Suffer a Vexing Day
description: Jean-Marie Messier packed his bags, defended his record and bid an emotional farewell to the employees of Vivendi Universal today. But his ouster as chairman and chief executive of the troubled French entertainment giant was overshadowed by disclosures about the company's accounting practices, which sent its stock crashing and dragged down the entire French market.

title: Corrections
description: Anews analysis article on June 25, about the Supreme Court's decision that juries must make the factual determinations supporting death sentences, misstated the record of judges' reversals in capital cases in Delaware. Judges there have overridden eight jury recommendations, not seven. In one of the cases, the judge changed the verdict from life to death; in the seven others, the verdict was changed from death to life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEROSA, THOMAS R.
description: DeROSA-Thomas R. A long term resident of Larchmont, NY, passed away on July 1, 2002 of complications from lung cancer. Mr. deRosa was born on October 16, 1947 to Donald J. and Louise Spinelli deRosa, of New Rochelle, New York. He is survived by his wife, Deborah Greene deRosa, and their daughters, Brooke and Paige deRosa, all residents of Windermere, FL, and two sisters, Marilyn L. Wilkie, of New Rochelle, NY, and Jeryl A. Hofmann, of Larchmont, New York. Mr. deRosa was a Partner with the national law firm of Baker & Hostetler, LLP, and had offices in the firm's Orlando, FL, Washington, D.C., and New York, NY offices. Mr. deRosa graduated Fordham Law School, cum laude, was on The Law Review, and was awarded the academic honors of The Graduating Class. His undergraduate degree was from Rensselear Polytechnic Institute, and he attended New York University, pursuing an MBA. Mr. deRosa was admitted to The State Bars of New York and Florida, The Federal District and Appellate Courts in both states, as well as appearances and trials in many other states. Mr. deRosa was a communicant of Saint Augustine's Catholic Church in Larchmont, New York, and of Mary Queen of The Universe Shrine in Orlando, FL. He was a member of The Larchmont Yacht Club. Visiting hours at The John J. Fox Funeral Home on Boston Post Road in Larchmont, NY will be on Friday, July 5th from 2-4 P.M. and from 7-9 P.M. He will have a Funeral Mass at Saint Augustine's, Larchmont Ave., Larchmont, NY at 10 A.M. on Saturday, July 6th. In lieu of flowers, the family wishes to encourage cash donations to The American Lung Association, in his name.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Aegis Research, London, a division of the Aegis Group, is being renamed Synovate.

title: GAYLORD AGREES TO SELL MUSIC PUBLISHING UNIT
description: The Gaylord Entertainment Company, owner of the Grand Ole Opry, agreed to sell its Acuff-Rose Music Publishing unit, including the songs ''Oh, Pretty Woman'' and ''Your Cheatin' Heart,'' to the Sony Corporation for $157 million in cash to pay down debt.

title: Elliott Wilk, Judge and Dry Wit, Dies at 60
description: Elliott Wilk, a state judge who mixed a leftist outlook, shrewd analysis and a dry wit to ride herd over cases from Woody Allen's custody battle to the rights of the homeless, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 60.

title: New U.S. Crews Give Henley a Go
description: Every American collegiate oarsman's hope is to be in a crew competitive enough to race at Britain's Henley Royal Regatta on the River Thames.

title: The Bold Red Berry With a Zest for Summer
description: THEY dance from their stems like Venetian glass beads. They glow from within. They wear their beauty lightly -- a spray of berries falls as languidly as a strand of pearls.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's remarks to Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly during a news conference about security measures for the Fourth of July holiday misquoted Mr. Bloomberg. In an aside picked up by reporters' tape recorders, about the heavily armed patrols that will be stationed around the city, he said of the weapons: ''They're big enough to blow away the press.'' He did not say of the patrols: ''They're going to have to blow away the press.''

title: A Year of Study Abroad, A Year of Great Danger
description: Had 19-year-old Ariella Marcus not told her friends, ''Hey, guys, my parents wouldn't want me to go,'' she would have been in a yogurt shop on the Ben Yehuda pedestrian mall in Jerusalem when two suicide bombers killed at least a dozen young people and injured more than 170 others on a moonlit night last December.

title: Arafat Replaces 2 Security Chiefs
description: Yasir Arafat began shaking up his security services on Tuesday, removing two of the top leaders in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, Palestinian officials said early today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Memorial Chief
description: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation appointed Anita F. Contini as vice president and director for its memorial, cultural and civic programs yesterday. Ms. Contini will be responsible for overseeing the development of a memorial for victims of the terrorist attack of Sept. 11 at the former site of the World Trade Center. In addition, she will coordinate efforts to bring cultural institutions to Lower Manhattan. Since 1999, she has served as a first vice president for global sponsorships and events marketing at Merrill Lynch. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORALNIK, ISRAEL
description: GORALNIK-Israel. The Officers, Boards of Directors and staff of American ORT and Women's American ORT deeply mourn the passing of Israel Goralnik, former Director-General of ORT Israel. During his tenure he contributed enormously to the development of vocational education in Israel, creating opportunities for needy students and developing new technologies. A visionary leader, he was the first recipient of the American ORT ''Yitzhak Rabin Award.'' Goralnik, who was wounded in the War of Independence, was Director-General of Israel's Ministry of Labor, and devoted himself to the education and training of Israel's youth. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to his family. Robert L. Sill, President Joe Cohen, First V.P. Paul B. Firstenberg, Executive Director, American ORT Carol Linch, President Judy Menikoff, First V.P. Alice Herman, Executive V.P., Women's American ORT

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Monday about the annual gay pride parade in Manhattan on Sunday misstated the number of such parades. It was the 33rd, not the 32nd.

title: Sports of The Times; Men's Play Is Foreign To the U.S. Viewer
description: FOR the life of me, I don't understand why nobody here seems to miss Pete Sampras or Andre Agassi. A men's draw depleted of seeded players and those who generate ratings on American television has not been canceled. Even one of our smartest talking heads, Mary Carillo, has refused to give in and has begun acting like one of those delusional Europeans.

title: For a Big, Big, Big Iced Tea Thirst
description: I NEVER quite got the iced-tea-by-the-glass thing. All those individually wrapped tea bags, all that boiling of water, all that ice, all those lemon wedges and sprigs of mint, all for a brief eight ounces of happiness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POGASH, HARRIET
description: POGASH-Harriet. On July 2, 2002. Beloved sister of Barry Pogash. Loving cousin of Donald Lester. Caring cousin of Gary Davidson. Longtime friend of health care aide Gracelyn.

title: So Young, So Tart, So Crunchy
description: Alongside the seared duck breast with toasted farro at Dry Creek Kitchen in Healdsburg, Calif., was a crunchy salad of julienned apple and rhubarb in an anise vinaigrette. The tartness of the rhubarb, which was raw, played off beautifully against the apple, and its pink color contrasted with the green of the Granny Smith. ''I got in this tender young rhubarb, and it seemed a shame to cook it,'' said Mark Purdy, the chef (right). ''It lends a refreshing high note to the earthiness of the dish.'' Young, pale stalks, which are available now in the Greenmarket, are essential; avoid the big woody things you find in supermarkets. No peeling is necessary. Use it in a salad, add thin sticks of it to a crudit platter or dice it fine over fresh, lightly sweetened strawberries.

title: Market Place; John C. Malone's shares in Sprint PCS are worth more than yours. No one's surprised.
description: CHALK up another victory for John C. Malone. While the downdraft in the wireless telecommunications sector has wiped out billions of dollars in other people's wealth, Mr. Malone is sitting pretty.

title: Recipe: Thai Coffee Crme Caramel
description: Adapted from AZ

title: Troubled Vivendi Replaces Its Ousted Chief Executive
description: LONDON, July 3 — Vivendi Universal appointed Jean-René Fourtou as interim chairman and chief executive today, succeeding Jean-Marie Messier, who resigned from that post earlier this week amid growing criticism of his management style.

title: Troubled Vivendi Replaces Its Ousted Chief Executive
description: LONDON, July 3  Vivendi Universal appointed Jean-Rene Fourtou as interim chairman and chief executive today, succeeding Jean-Marie Messier, who resigned from that post earlier this week amid growing criticism of his management style.

title: Holiday Tomorrow -- Independence Day
description: NEW YORK

title: From the Farm to the Show in an Afternoon
description: Tyler Walker was throwing in the bullpen in Class AAA Norfolk on Tuesday afternoon around 4 o'clock when Rick Waits, the Tides' pitching coach, told him to hurry up because he had a 5 p.m. flight to Philadelphia to join the Mets. Steve Trachsel had been placed on the disabled list, and the Mets needed a fresh arm for the bullpen. Walker, a right-handed starter, rushed and made it to Veterans Stadium in time to warm up during the second inning.

title: Corporate Tax Deal Ends Trenton Budget Standoff
description: An exhausted State Senate finally delivered a budget for New Jersey today, in a quick vote that approved a restructured corporate income tax that is expected to raise $1.8 billion, more than twice the amount collected this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLUSSER, RICHARD
description: FLUSSER-Richard. July 1, 2002. Opera impresario and founder of the After Dinner Opera Company, died in his sleep, at home. Beloved husband of Beth Flusser, Richard was father of Jennifer-jo Moyer and Matthew, fatherin-law to Daniel and Kathleen, beloved grandfather of Padraig and Myles, and sonin-law to Annette Leibowitz. Professor Emeritus of Music at Queensborough Community College. There will be a memorial service at St. Mark's Church, 10th Street and Second Avenue July 23, 7:30 PM.

title: Slamming Dunks, Thanks to Magic Sneakers
description: The N.B.A. isn't exactly getting a vote of confidence from the American cinemathque these days. In ''Juwanna Mann'' a spoiled N.B.A. star has to dress like a girl and join the W.N.B.A. to learn a lesson in maturity. And in ''Like Mike'' 13-year-old Calvin (Lil Bow Wow) turns around the Los Angeles franchise, courtesy of a pair of magic sneakers. (And yes, a self-absorbed basketball star is forced to grow up here, too.) We can only hope David Stern, the N.B.A. commissioner, isn't taking notes, especially since Michael Jordan, who may have owned the shoes that Calvin finds, may not return to the league next season.

title: Balloonist, No Quitter, Circles the World Solo on His Sixth Attempt
description: Steve Fossett, the 58-year-old Chicago investment executive whose six-year quest to circumnavigate the world in a balloon ended five times in frustration, succeeded yesterday on his sixth attempt. He became the first person to fly around the planet nonstop and alone without a motor.

title: A Museum Sings, 'Take Me Out to the Ballparks'
description: HOT DOGS and baseball have long had a special relationship, one that New Yorkers can savor this summer. In an inspired move, the American Museum of Natural History on West 79th Street and Central Park West has chosen to augment its ''Baseball as America'' exhibition (on display through Aug. 18) with a selection of 10 regional hot dogs at the museum's food court. Some of the offerings, like the Fenway Frank of Boston and the Dodger Dog of Los Angeles, are served at their namesake ballparks but are otherwise unremarkable. Several of the others, however, do their home regions proud, including a very respectable Chicago dog, complete with all the requisite toppings; a fine Cincinnati chili dog with a wonderfully complex chili sauce; and a Rochester white-hot, a savory delicacy from western New York State. Interestingly, the best dog of the batch is the museum's own creation, called the Natural after Bernard Malamud's baseball-themed novel. It consists of a certified Angus beef frank nestled in a cylinder of unsalted pretzel dough. The Natural is a bit odd-looking, but it is very, very good.

title: The Joys of Summer: From School to Pool
description: To the Editor:

title: If Someone Says, 'Hold the Coffee,' It's a Pleasure
description: This sleek chrome coffee pot is not only about the best-looking insulated pot I've ever seen, it is also the easiest to use. Instead of having to turn a lid, look for an arrow and so forth, you simply press down on the well-positioned, easily operated lever above the handle, and pour. The chrome is laid over plastic, so the pot is light.

title: Dow Jones Shuffles Officers; New Publisher at Journal
description: Dow Jones & Company shuffled its top management yesterday, elevating the chief financial officer, Richard F. Zannino, to chief operating officer and making Karen Elliott House, the president of the company's international publishing group, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, the company's flagship newspaper.

title: Congressman Won't Switch, But Will Fight Redistricting
description: Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, New York State's senior Republican in Congress, told supporters here tonight that he would not seek a 16th term this fall, quelling rumors that he would become a Democrat to avoid losing his seat under the state's new redistricting.

title: Hot-Air Heroics
description: Steve Fossett, a Chicago adventurer and commodities broker, earned his place in aviation history yesterday when he became the first balloonist to circumnavigate the globe solo. At first blush, this may seem a frivolous achievement, akin to sitting atop a flagpole longer than anyone else. This did not, after all, expand human horizons in any way comparable to reaching the South Pole, landing on the moon or flying solo across the Atlantic  la Charles Lindbergh. Yet there is something powerful and attractive in what Mr. Fossett did.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Ziff Davis To Close Magazine
description: Ziff Davis Media Inc., publisher of PC Magazine, said yesterday that it would close Yahoo Internet Life magazine and lay off 35 workers after the August issue because of a dearth of technology and Internet-related advertising. The monthly publication's ad revenue dropped 40 percent in May, to $2.16 million, according to Publishers Information Bureau, an industry group. Yahoo Internet Life's ads totaled $5.22 million in May 2000, the group said. The magazine has about 1.1 million subscribers, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations, an industry group that tracks newspaper and magazine circulation.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Foot-And-Mouth Culprit Sentenced
description: The Northumberland farmer whose pigs are thought to have started last year's outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease, which led to the slaughter of millions of animals in Britain, was banned by a court from keeping farm animals for 15 years and fined $15,000 in legal costs. A May hearing found Robert Waugh, 56, guilty of failing to notify authorities that his animals were infected, allowing the highly contagious disease to spread throughout the country. The disease had devastating effects on Britain's livestock industry, already damaged by the outbreak of mad cow disease in 1996 and the resulting three-year ban on exports. The agriculture ministry said Mr. Waugh's animals probably contracted the virus by being fed swill containing contaminated meat. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: New Mine Laws Weighed
description: South Africa will probably propose legislation forcing mining companies to cede at least a quarter of new projects to people disadvantaged during white rule, the mining ministry said.

title: In Alabama Politics, How New Kid Won the Bloc
description: The support of the Jefferson County Citizens Coalition, the most powerful local organization of black Democrats, once all but guaranteed the victory of its chosen candidate, from coroner to congressman.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CANTOR, BERNARD
description: CANTOR-Bernard. Missing you. Love, Iri

title: The Cherry Stands Alone
description: I AM not a born baker, so I cannot count the number of times over the years I had some nice fruit, thought about making a pie and failed to seize the opportunity. But recent experience with ravioli nudi (ravioli filling without the pasta) and pumpkin flan (pumpkin pie without the crust) led me to rethink the summer pie: in some cases, it's just about enjoying cooked fruit, usually with ice cream.

title: Trying to Turn Old Shopping Mall Inside Out
description: Laugh at the old shopping mall as it is torn down to make way for something strikingly different, but know the joke comes at Lakewood's expense. People were married here, and their parents exercised here, and their children had birthday parties here.

title: Stewart Broker Handled Shares For Her Friends
description: Martha Stewart turned to her stockbroker at Merrill Lynch, Peter E. Bacanovic, to handle more than $10 million worth of shares offered to friends and associates when her company went public in 1999, Wall Street officials said yesterday, highlighting their longstanding close personal and business relationship.

title: Technology Eases the Way for the Visually Impaired
description: Gerard Guarniero spent eighth grade using a Braille slate -- an eight-inch metal device that looks like a ruler with four rows of stencil spaces for lettering. He would place paper between the two sides and use a short pointer to punch holes in the paper. It would take him three or four times as long to write the same paper as his sighted classmates.

title: Shocked Afghans Criticize U.S. Strike; Toll Is Some 40 Dead and 100 Wounded
description: The Afghan government expressed dismay today at reports that about 140 civilians were killed or wounded in an American-led operation in southern Afghanistan on Monday and demanded a major review of American military operations here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEGENER, CAMILLA SOLM
description: DEGENER-Camilla Solm, 79, of Pennswood Village, Newtown, Pa. died on June 29, 2002. Retired Fieldston Lower School Teacher. Beloved wife of W. Glenn Degener. Services will be held Saturday, July 6, at 11 AM at the Chapel of Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY, For information Swartz/ Givnish Newtown, PA. 215968-3891. Family and friends may call at the chapel after 10:30 A.M. on Saturday.

title: Political Memo; Looking Anew at Value Of a Corporate Pedigree
description: George W. Bush is the first president with an M.B.A., and his administration once proudly promoted its corporate experience as evidence of how it could bring boardroom smarts to governance and policy.

title: Good for Saudis, Too?
description: To the Editor:

title: There Are Yankees, 'Damn Yankees,' and Losers
description: George Steinbrenner is proudly perched atop the baseball mountain with the Yankees, a position he commands obsessively. He has the best team, he has the most revenue, he has the highest payroll and he does not care if others get tired of watching the Yankees act and perform like the ''Damn Yankees.'' Simply call us the eternally ''Damn Yankees'' if you want, Steinbrenner might say.

title: Some Unfinished Business Remains for Legislature in Albany
description: State senators returned to Albany today for a one-day session, but left untouched several major pieces of proposed legislation, including increases in the minimum wage and workers' compensation, a revision of the Rockefeller drug laws, a requirement that priests report suspected child abuse and protection of gay men and lesbians from discrimination.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Executive Makes a Case For WorldCom's Survival

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHACHNOW, PEGGY
description: SHACHNOW-Peggy. In loving memory. Loving wife, mother, and grandmother. Peggy, your family and friends will have cherished memories of your grace, charm and dignity. Services Wednesday, 1 PM, at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Boulevard.

title: Recipe: Rose Water Cream
description: Time: 15 minutes, plus 4 hours' firming

title: PAXSON SHARES FALL AS RESULTS DROP BELOW FORECASTS
description: The Paxson Communications Corporation said quarterly results would be below its earlier forecast, setting off a 39 percent decline in its share price yesterday. Paxson shares fell $1.95, to $3. The stock had declined 53 percent this year. Profit for the quarter ended last month, excluding some costs like stock-based compensation, amortization and restructuring, was $3 million to $4 million and sales were ''relatively flat,'' according to a statement. The company had expected second-quarter profit by that measure of $8 million and revenue to increase in the ''mid-single digits.'' Paxson's results were crimped by slower-than-expected infomercial advertising sales partly because of increased competition for the ads, according to the statement.

title: SUNY Students Aid City
description: More than 300 students from the State University of New York are working in New York City summer schools as part of SUNY's efforts to interest its students in teaching in city schools. The students are assisting teachers, tutoring and conducting some lessons. They receive a $2,000 stipend, free housing in dorms at Long Island University and a MetroCard. They started last week and will work through Aug. 9.

title: Goma Journal; Freight on Board: Wheelchairs Deliver the Goods
description: Makeshift wheelchairs start lining up early at the border station here. Some teeter under their loads. The owners of the chairs do the steering but the power to navigate the rough roads to the market comes from children, who are paid to push with all their might.

title: U.S. MIGHT REFUSE NEW PEACE DUTIES WITHOUT IMMUNITY
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld warned today that America might not send its forces to join future peacekeeping missions without a grant of full immunity from the jurisdiction of the new International Criminal Court.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Prosecution In Child Killing Rests
description: The prosecution rested its case against David Westerfield, the man accused of killing Danielle van Dam, the 7-year-old girl who vanished from her bedroom in suburban San Diego on Feb. 1 and was found dead along a rural road weeks later. The last prosecution witness was a DNA expert who said that hairs found in Mr. Westerfield's laundry and motor home could have come from the van Dams' dog. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Spinoff Set in Australian Steel
description: After 87 years in steel making, BHP Billiton, Australia's largest industrial company, is leaving the industry to concentrate on mining, energy and minerals processing.

title: Now, at Least in Math, Those Who Can, Teach
description: By some standards, it seems a rather odd state of affairs. Schools cannot find enough mathematics teachers. Yet people proficient in math -- engineers, accountants, stockbrokers and others who want to teach math -- are often turned away because they did not major in the subject in college.

title: Bird Finally Has a Chance to Play in the Garden
description: There's a lot to get used to for Sue Bird, the No. 1 college player on the No. 1 college team last season, the first overall pick by the Seattle Storm in the Women's National Basketball Association draft this year, the playmaker with the sweet smile, the fluffy ponytail, the killer crossover and the assassin's pull-up jumper.

title: Recipe: Red-Berry Tapioca Pudding
description: Time: 20 minutes, plus resting time

title: Reforming the Auditors
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: Deadlock, But Talks Are Planned
description: Six months of peace talks between President Glafcos Clerides, right, and the Turkish Cypriot leader, Rauf Denktash, ended in deadlock with both sides failing to meet an end-of-June deadline to make progress in attempts to reunite the island. But the leaders agreed to resume negotiations on July 12 after the United Nations Security Council hears a report. Cyprus has been divided since 1974, when a coup in Nicosia was followed by an invasion by Turkey, which still controls the north of the island. Failure to settle the dispute could spoil Cyprus's chance to join the European Union next year. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Bypassed in N.B.A. Draft, Cooke Is Considering Plan B
description: Lenny Cooke says do not sell him short. The injured big toe on his right foot has healed, he wants to play in the N.B.A. and he is ''going to do whatever it takes to make it.''

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Rollout Complete
description: Sirius Radio said this week that it had finished rolling out its 100-channel satellite radio service. Sirius had at one time planned to begin service in 2000. The long-delayed rollout finished in a rush that may lead to a temporary shortage of receivers, the company said. The service features 60 advertising-free music channels and sports, talk radio and other features for $12.95 a month. Sirius is chasing XM satellite, which began signing up subscribers for its $9.95-a-month service last fall and said yesterday that it had 136,500 subscribers as of the end of June. XM projects 350,000 subscribers by the end of the year. Barnaby Feder (NYT)

title: Recipe: Iced Tea Concentrate
description: Time: 10 minutes, plus 30 minutes' steeping

Use it in a salad, add thin sticks of it to a crudite platter or dice it fine over fresh, lightly sweetened strawberries.

title: INSIDE
description: Dismay Over Afghan Deaths

title: Mets' Hitters Hold Pregame Meeting, Then Batter the Phillies
description: When the Mets crawled to the midpoint of their season Monday night with a lethargic loss to the Phillies -- who have had an even worse year -- players acknowledged that they were flat. They were merely stating the obvious; the Mets could not hit and their pitching unraveled.

title: Jets and Troops to Help Patrol City July 4
description: Detailing plans to safeguard the city against terror during the Fourth of July, officials say they will deploy about 4,000 police officers, including about 1,600 in civilian clothes, to join soldiers and fighter jets patrolling the streets, rivers and skies.

title: General Is Paid $183,372 For Domestic Security Role
description: If there was ever any doubt that there is money in security these days, just ask Maj. Gen. Bruce Lawlor.

title: Artists vs. Icons, With Woods in Middle
description: Little did Rick Rush know when he decided to paint Tiger Woods for a print called ''The Masters of Augusta'' that he would set into motion a major lawsuit involving the estates of some of the most prominent sports and entertainment figures in American popular culture: Frank Sinatra, Elvis Presley, Jimi Hendrix, Gene Autry and the legendary golfer Bobby Jones, all weighing in from the great beyond.

title: Where Drama and Farce Meet Like Old Friends
description: Two years ago the beguilingly entertaining absurdist comedy ''Songs From the Second Floor'' played the Cannes Film Festival, and scenes from the picture still float in my head. (It received a special prize from the festival jury.) ''Floor'' opens today at the Film Forum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ETTA (FEIN BERG)
description: GOLDSTEIN - Etta (Fein berg), 97. Of Stamford, CT on July 2, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Solon E. Mother of Jerome R. and grandmother of Bettina L. Decker. Services will be held at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St, Stamford on Wednesday, July 3 at 11 AM. Burial to follow at the Beth El Cemetery. Memorial contributions may be made to the Stamford Hospital.

title: Big Flood Of Offerings Stirs Hopes In India
description: Despite all the military, corporate and economic worries around the globe, excitement is building in India over a dozen major new stock offerings scheduled to take place in the next year or so.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Austria: Eurofighter Selected
description: The Austrian government selected the European-built Eurofighter Typhoon to replace its aging fleet of jet fighters. The contract could be worth up to $1.76 billion if Austria opts for the full order of 24 planes when it confirms the deal in six weeks. Eurofighter, built by a consortium of the French-German company EADS, BAE Systems of Britain, and Finmeccanica of Italy beat out the American F-16 built by Lockheed Martin and the Swedish-British Gripen, built by BAE and Saab. The order is the first confirmed export for the Eurofighter, which has 620 orders from the countries that are building it. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Escaping to Bryant Park, but Staying Connected to the Web
description: It was the perfect collision of technology and nature, at least the way Oren Eckhaus, a Brooklyn photographer, describes it. He was surfing the Internet on his Apple Titanium PowerBook one day last week and a leaf fluttered in a light breeze and landed on his keyboard.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: M.I.B., or M.I.B. Not

title: Warning Time Becomes Issue In Air Collision
description: With bodies and smoldering wreckage scattered across 20 square miles of fields and woodland here, Russian, German and Swiss authorities argued today about the causes of a midair collision that killed 71 people, 52 of them children headed to Spain for an end-of-school vacation.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Leader Of Piracy Group Sentenced
description: A leader of an international Internet software piracy group that involved students and staff members at some prestigious universities, John Sankus Jr., 29, began serving a 46-month prison sentence yesterday in a federal prison in Pennsylvania. Prosecutors said Mr. Sankus was one of the two leaders of a group called DrinkOrDie that was accused of pirating several million dollars of software. The Customs Service, which ran the investigation, said Mr. Sankus, a technician at a Gateway computer store in Philadelphia, had overseen a worldwide network of computer enthusiasts who used the Internet to steal and swap everything from the latest Windows software to software utilities. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: The Court's Troubling Term
description: President Bush was in Cleveland this week, shortly after the Supreme Court ended its term, basking in the glow of the court's school voucher ruling. Speaking at a downtown rally, Mr. Bush compared the case to Brown v. Board of Education, the 1954 decision striking down segregated schools. It was a reach, but Mr. Bush's use of the voucher ruling in a political stump speech reflected just how ideological this term's opinions were.

title: Adm. Robert Long, 82, Leader Of Inquiry in '83 Terrorist Attack
description: Adm. Robert L. J. Long, who led the commission that found senior military officials responsible for security lapses in the Beirut barracks attack that killed 241 marines in 1983, died on Thursday at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md. He was 82 and lived in Annapolis, Md.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Law Firm Plans Move to Times Square Skyscraper
description: A week after Arthur Andersen abandoned plans to move into new headquarters in Times Square, a major downtown law firm is negotiating to move into the same space in the skyscraper, which is under construction on 42nd Street.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the incentive for companies to disclose any problems with their accounting misidentified the auditor for Cisco Systems, whose stock has been punished by investors recently. It is PricewaterhouseCoopers, not Arthur Andersen.

title: Russia's Trial of Colonel Accused in Chechnya Shifts Course
description: The trial of a Russian army officer charged with killing a young Chechen woman took an unexpected turn today when a military judge ordered a new psychiatric evaluation of the defendant, extending a case that has been closely watched as a measure of Russia's willingness to prosecute military abuses in Chechnya.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: $1,000 Fine For Saudi Princess
description: A Saudi princess accused of pushing her maid down a flight of stairs was fined $1,000 after her lawyer entered a plea of no contest. The princess, Buniah al-Saud, did not attend the five-minute hearing. Prosecutors agreed to the plea after immigration officials barred the maid, Ismiyati Suryono, from returning from Indonesia -- where she had gone for her mother's funeral -- to testify at a trial. Ms. Suryono received a settlement from the princess. The terms were not released.

title: Schering-Plough Wins Dismissal Of F.T.C. Case on Generic Drug
description: In a defeat for consumer groups and federal antitrust investigators, an administrative law judge at the Federal Trade Commission has ruled that the Schering-Plough Corporation did not break any laws when it agreed to pay millions of dollars to delay a generic company's introduction of a lower-priced version of a medication for people being treated for high blood pressure.

title: Ex-Head of Hale House Pleads Guilty to Felony Grand Larceny
description: With her head bowed and her hands clasped behind her, the former head of Hale House, the nationally recognized Harlem children's shelter, pleaded guilty today to felony grand larceny and admitted stealing thousands of dollars that had been donated to the charity.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: School May Use Dancer's Name
description: The Martha Graham Center of Contemporary Dance and its school may legally use the choreographer's name and teach her dance technique, a federal appeals court ruled yesterday. The ruling upheld a trial judge's decision. The center, at 37 West 26th Street in Manhattan, describes its school as ''the only school primarily focused upon teaching the Graham technique and repertory.'' In a March 2001 lawsuit, Ronald Protas, Graham's sole heir and the licenser of her dances, challenged the center's rights to the Graham dances as well as the name. The trial court has not yet ruled on the rights to the dances. Judd Burstein, Mr. Protas's lawyer, said yesterday, ''If you have the right to use the name Martha Graham Center but are not permitted to dance her ballets, the value of having her name is greatly diminished.''

title: Arena Proposal Still Lives, But the Heartbeat Is Weak
description: The proposal to have the state help build a Newark arena for the New Jersey Nets and Devils is looking more and more like that proverbial cat with nine lives. But it may be running out of lives.

title: Visionaries Who Dream Of Dams and Highways
description: Like a determined construction crew, ''Great Projects'' has its work cut out for it. This earnest documentary series, beginning tonight on PBS, sets out to convince you that public works are fascinating and that the engineers who create them are as worthy of contemplation as warriors and poets. If that's not tough enough, the four-week series has among its heroes two men who had the courage and vision to champion historic projects: Herbert Hoover (himself an engineer) and Michael Dukakis.

title: A Gentleman Gets Even For a Life Interrupted
description: REVENGE

title: National Briefing: Science and Health
description: CANCER AND APPALACHIA

title: The Textbook According to Texas
description: To the Editor:

title: Troop Cuts in Chechnya
description: The commander of Russian troops in Chechnya said today that Russia had begun to reduce its military force in the republic, saying rebels there were no longer able to mount significant resistance. The commander, Col. Gen. Vladimir I. Moltenskoi, told the Interfax news agency that by the end of the year Russian military and security forces would total 22,000, down from about 80,000 today.

title: It's Hotter Than the Fourth of July, And the Third Could Be Even Warmer
description: Lulu Hill usually makes the walk from her bank at 86th Street and Columbus Avenue to her apartment on 91st Street in one go. But yesterday afternoon she decided to rest at the air-conditioned Goddard Riverside Senior Center at 88th Street, halfway home.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Compromise On Khmer Rouge Trial?
description: Prime Minister Hun Sen said a Cambodian law setting out procedures for a trial of former Khmer Rouge leaders could be amended if an agreement were reached with the United Nations. It was his refusal to consider compromise that led the United Nations to pull out of talks in February on setting up an international tribunal, fearing international standards of justice would not be met. Since requesting United Nations help in 1997 Mr. Hun Sen has repeatedly shifted back and forth between cooperation and stubbornness. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: To Build or Not At Ground Zero
description: To the Editor:

title: Monkey Named for Researcher
description: Dr. STEPHEN NASH, a research associate in the department of anatomical sciences at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, has had his name bestowed on a new kind of titi monkey that lives in the South American rain forest. The monkey, now known as Callicebus stephennashi -- Stephen Nash's titi monkey -- is silver and has a black forehead and red sideburns. MARC VAN ROOSMALEN, the scientist who identified it as a new species, credited Dr. Nash's colored pencil drawings with helping to make his work accessible to a large audience. Dr. Nash, who is also a scientific illustrator for Conservation International, said the naming of the new primate species sends ''a message that we all have a role to play, whatever our talents and station in life, in the work being done to hand future generations a world as rich in biological diversity as we ourselves inherited.'' Karen W. Arenson

title: Ovitz Bitterly Bares Soul, And Film Industry Reacts
description: Even as the chief executive of one global media conglomerate, Universal Vivendi, was being ousted, and the stocks of most of the others were taking a horrible beating, it was all anyone could do in Hollywood today to talk about anything but a magazine article that is not even out yet.

title: Interim Board Is Not in Works For Schools
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he would not replace the Board of Education with an interim group while the Justice Department examined the new law giving the mayor control of the school system and expanding the board.

title: Afghan Civilian Deaths
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Residential Real Estate column on June 14 about the downtown rental market after Sept. 11 misstated the starting month for a comparison of how the market had strengthened. It was last December, not February. It also misstated the number of buildings in the statistics for that month. It was 26, not 22. (The number was indeed 22 in May, the later month surveyed.)

title: How Do You Say Old Glory in Italian?
description: Farfalle for the Fourth, which is pretty enough to use for decoration, gets its red from tomatoes and beets. The blue is from blue Curaao liqueur. Fortunately, you get the color but not the taste. Boil the pasta, and dress it in a light cream sauce to keep the effect, or consider tossing it with berries, sugar and whipped cream for dessert. The farfalle, made by Vecchio Monlino Togni in Lucca, Italy, comes in 8.8-ounce bags; they cost $4.99 each at Citarella stores. You might keep the red, white and blue in mind for Bastille Day. Of course, the company also makes red, white and green to sell in Italy.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on June 25, about the Supreme Court's decision that juries must make the factual determinations supporting death sentences, misstated the record of judges' reversals in capital cases in Delaware. Judges there have overridden eight jury recommendations, not seven. In one of the cases, the judge changed the verdict from life to death; in the seven others, the verdict was changed from death to life.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Perot Systems In Deal
description: The computer services company founded by H. Ross Perot, the Perot Systems Corporation, has acquired the government consulting company ADI Technology for about $32 million in cash plus up to $15 million more in cash and stock if some performance goals are met. Perot Systems, which is based in Plano, Tex., will also assume $6 million in debt. ADI, with 600 employees, had revenue of $67 million last year and $30 million in the first five months of this year.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: National Briefing: South
description: ARKANSAS: ON SCHOOLS, THE STATE FIGHTS BACK

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Risks Seen At Centers For Aged
description: The city comptroller's office reported yesterday that some city-run centers for the elderly are operating with fire-safety hazards. The two-month audit covered 39 centers in the five boroughs. More than half had blocked fire exits and could not provide evidence of the required number of annual fire drills, the report said. Also, some centers lacked smoke detectors and current inspections for wheelchair lifts. The city's Department for the Aging, which oversees the centers, did not return telephone calls seeking comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: If It Wasn't for the Paychecks, Maybe They Did It for Love
description: There was reason to be apprehensive. Three of the biggest mainstream jazz instrumentalists on the Verve label, all sometimes involved in heavily overproduced recordings, started a touring and recording project to honor (or exploit) the 75th anniversary of the births of Miles Davis and John Coltrane.

title: Honeymoon Hotel Savings
description: For newlyweds who want to unwind after their wedding in Manhattan (perhaps awaiting the departure of a honeymoon cruise or flight), the 115-room Gorham Hotel has a two-night package in a penthouse suite with a garden terrace and whirlpool bath, daily breakfast and other extras. The rate, starting at $632, represents a 50 percent savings. The deal, good July 1 to Sept. 9, is also for couples celebrating an anniversary. The Gorham is at 136 West 55th Street. The rate is based on availability. It must be prepaid, with a cancellation penalty 15 days in advance; (800) 735-0710, www.gorhamhotel.com .

title: In Poor Nations, a New Will to Fight AIDS
description: On the eve of next week's International AIDS Conference in Barcelona, a new report from the United Nations AIDS program states that at current infection rates, AIDS, the deadliest epidemic in human history, will kill 68 million people in the 45 most affected countries over the next 20 years -- more than five times the number claimed by AIDS in those nations in the past 20 years. In some of these nations, AIDS could kill half of today's new mothers.

title: Recipe: Ginger Ketchup Sauce
description: Adapted from Cello

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADLER, ANNETTE
description: NADLER-Annette. On July 1, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Jacob Nadler. Devoted mother of David, Gail and the late James Nadler, and motherin-law of Christine. Dear grandmother of Adam and Peter. Adoring aunt to many nieces and nephews. Initial member and lifetime president of Manhattan Guild supporting the Childrens Center at the Chaim Sheba Medical Center in Israel. Funeral service on Wednesday, 12:00 PM, at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65th St. Interment, Mt. Pleasant Cemetery.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: AUSTRIA: EUROFIGHTER SELECTED The Austrian government selected the European-built Eurofighter Typhoon to replace its aging fleet of jet fighters. The contract could be worth up to $1.76 billion if Austria opts for the full order of 24 planes when it confirms the deal in six weeks. Eurofighter, built by a consortium of the French-German company EADS, BAE Systems of Britain, and Finmeccanica of Italy beat out the American F-16 built by Lockheed Martin and the Swedish-British Gripen, built by BAE and Saab. The order is the first confirmed export for the Eurofighter, which has 620 orders from the countries that are building it. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: MANTECH TO BUY AEGIS RESEARCH FOR $70 MILLION
description: The ManTech International Corporation, a military contractor that first sold shares to the public in February, has agreed to buy the closely held Aegis Research Corporation for $70 million in cash. Aegis Research provides technical support services for the Defense Department and the national intelligence community, ManTech said yesterday. The company is expected to have about $60 million in revenue this year. The acquisition will add about 2 cents a share to ManTech's 2002 earnings and about 13 cents next year, the company said. The acquisition is expected to close this month and will be paid for using the proceeds of ManTech's initial public offering, the company said.

title: National Briefing | Education: Side Effects Of Drinking
description: College students are not the only ones who suffer the ill effects of binge drinking. According to the Harvard School of Public Health College Alcohol Study, people who live within a mile of a college campus are more than twice as likely as those who live farther away to endure disturbances like vandalism, assault and litter. Tamar Lewin (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: On Schools, The State Fights Back
description: The state has appealed to the Arkansas Supreme Court a lower court's decision that the Arkansas public school system is unconstitutionally deficient in both financing and student achievement. The state attorney general, Mark Pryor, warned that the lower court's finding would, if sustained, mean huge tax increases and the forced consolidation of many of Arkansas's 310 school districts. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Defending Earth, With Worms and a Talking Pug
description: Five summers ago, Barry Sonnenfeld's ''Men in Black'' opened on Independence Day weekend and made a ton of money, beating heavily hyped franchise pictures like ''Batman and Robin'' and ''The Lost World: Jurassic Park.'' To celebrate the anniversary of his insurgent victory over those weary sequels to earlier hits, Mr. Sonnenfeld has reassembled much of the original ''Men in Black'' cast and crew -- Will Smith, Tommy Lee Jones, Rip Torn, Tony Shalhoub, a talking dog and, above all, the alien makeup maestro Rick Baker -- to create, of all things, a sequel.

title: Infectious Disease Expert Will Lead National Health Agency
description: Dr. Julie L. Gerberding, an infectious disease expert noted for her work against AIDS and anthrax, will be the next director of the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, administration officials said today.

title: U.S. Again Rejects Surrender of Mexican in a Corruption Case
description: In a strange twist in the multimillion-dollar corruption case in Mexico's state oil company, a prime suspect tried for a second time today to surrender to authorities in the United States, but they turned him away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONSTANTINER, DR. JAIME
description: CONSTANTINER-Dr. Jaime. The Board and staff of YIVO mourn the passing of Dr. Jaime Constantiner of Mexico City, a true friend to Yiddish and yidishkayt. His love for Jewish life, his East European ancestry and his commitment to preserve and teach the history and culture through programs at YIVO, are carried on by his son Arturo and his family. He was uniquely philanthropic and his generosity should be an example to us all. We extend our deepest sympathy to Arturo, his wife Caren, a member of YIVO's Leadership Forum, their children and other members of the Constantiner family. He will be sorely missed. Bruce Slovin, Chairman Dr. Carl J. Rheins, Executive Director Ella Levine, Director of Development

title: Fidelity and I.B.M. in Venture To Handle Worker Benefit Plans
description: Fidelity Investments and I.B.M. formed a venture yesterday to manage the employee benefit plans of other companies.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hynix Directors Named
description: Two former executives of the Korea Exchange Bank, lead creditor for Hynix Semiconductor, were appointed to top positions on the Hynix board. Woo Eui Jae, former vice president of the bank, takes over as one of two chief executives of Hynix while Chung Hyung Ryang, former credit officer at the bank, becomes chief financial officer. The appointments give creditors broad power over Hynix, whose previous board defied them by spurning a deal that would have let Micron Technology take over the debt-ridden company's memory chip operations for $3 billion in Micron stock. Park Sang Ho, appointed chief executive in May, will remain in charge of Hynix operations. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Dreams of Land Collide as Israeli Settlers Grow in Numbers
description: There is no discernible charm to this barren hilltop, but the young, Israeli settlers who have occupied it say they will do whatever they must to defend it.

title: Argentine Leader Moves Election Forward
description: With his political support crumbling and his country's economic crisis showing no signs of abating, Eduardo Duhalde, the caretaker president of Argentina, moved up the election to choose his successor by six months today so he could leave office early.

title: Liberty Ends A Cold Spell With a Victory
description: On Monday, the Liberty players had a closed-door meeting. They talked about pride and about letting themselves and their fans down.

title: Iranian-American Dancer Is on Trial in Tehran for 'Corruption'
description: Iran's hard-line judiciary has begun the trial of a popular Iranian-American dance instructor who lives and works in Los Angeles and was arrested at the airport last month after spending two months with his family on his first visit in 22 years.

title: O'Neill Return Was Debated By Yankees
description: Before the Yankees acquired right fielder Raul Mondesi from Toronto on Monday, George Steinbrenner said the team had internal discussions about asking Paul O'Neill to come out of retirement and help address the lack of outfield production.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALLMAN, MILDRED COX
description: KALLMAN-Mildred Cox died at home in Locust Valley, NY on June 29, with children beside her. Born in Irvine, KY., daughter of Walter Cox and Annie Allen Elgin. She attended Centre College and the University of Kentucky '41, Kappa Kappa Gamma. Predeceased by James Perry Patton she then married Raymond Kallman. She bore five children: James P. Patton Jr., Curtis Patton, Nancy Ann Patton, Laura Kallman, Peter M. Kallman and thirteen grandchildren. Loyal, loving, kind, she bestowed humility and generosity to all. Memorial service is Wednesday, July 3rd, 4:30 PM at Trinity Church, 1579 Northern Blvd., Roslyn Harbor. Donations can be made to the Nassau AHRC.

title: Little Sympathy for Vivendi's Ousted Chief (a 'Glutton,' and Overpaid)
description: France turned savagely against its former golden boy and his formerly glorious company today, with Jean-Marie Messier called a glutton in Parliament and portrayed as a crybaby in editorial cartoons, and with the value of his company's stock losing 40 percent in the opening hours of trading on the Bourse here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINHOLD, MEYER
description: REINHOLD-Meyer. Age 92, died July 1, 2002. Meyer Reinhold, a major figure in Greek and Roman classical studies, died in Nashville after a brief illness. Reinhold was born in Brooklyn, NY. A graduate of City College with a Ph.D. from Columbia University, Reinhold served on the faculties of Brooklyn College, Southern Illinois University, the University of Missouri, and Boston University. In his retirement he was a visiting scholar at Vanderbilt University. Reinhold was the author of 23 books. Dr. Reinhold was preceded in death by his wife of 59 years, Diane Roth Reinhold, and his son, Robert Reinhold, a leading reporter for the New York Times and the Los Angeles Times. He is survived by his daughter, Helen Reinhold Barrett, Dean of the Graduate School, Tennessee State University, and two grandsons, Matthew Reinhold Barrett of Rochester, NY, and Andrew Charlton Barrett of Chapel Hill, NC. Services will be conducted at 2PM on Thursday, July 4, at Congregation Micah, Rabbi Kenneth Kanter officiating. Burial will be at Temple Cemetery, Nashville, TN. Memorial contributions may be made to the Meyer Reinhold Fund, c/o Dept. of Classical Studies, Boston University, 735 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, MA 02215. Marshall/ Donnelly/Combs Funeral Home, 615-327-1111.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Kasparaitis Adds Grit To Rangers' Defense
description: A day after signing Bobby Holik, the Rangers' top priority in the free-agent market, Glen Sather, the club's president and general manager, outbid the Toronto Maple Leafs for Darius Kasparaitis.

title: Richard Flusser, 75, Founder Of a Chamber-Opera Company
description: Richard Flusser, an opera director and music teacher whose diminutive After Dinner Opera Company was a mainstay in the margins of the opera world for more than 50 years, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 75.

title: In Park Slope, Thai Rolls Easily Off the Tongue
description: I WAS the first of a party of three to arrive at Long Tan, and when I asked to be seated, the host, a man dressed all in black, pointed to the worst table. ''How about that booth?'' I asked, pointing in the opposite direction. ''I can't sit you there,'' he said, ''because I don't know that the rest of your party will show up. I mean, if it were a Friday or Saturday, I wouldn't seat you ahead of time at all.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISEN, STEPHEN EDWARD
description: WEISEN-Stephen Edward. 48, died on July 1, 2002. Beloved husband of Barbara (Friedman). Devoted father of Daniel and Carly. Cherished son of Cecile and Irving. Adored brother of Sheila Hoffer and Gail Gossert. ''My darling husband, our dear Daddy, you were stolen from us much too soon. You fought a valiant battle and will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved you.'' Services Wednesday, 1 PM at the Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza Great Neck, New York.

title: After Complaints, New York State Schedules Repeat of Regents Physics Exam
description: After receiving complaints from across the state that the Physics Regents exam was unusually difficult, the New York State Education Department announced yesterday that it would give any students who wished to another chance to take the test in August.

title: Hormone Therapy Study Finds Risk for Some
description: Hormone replacement does not prevent heart attacks -- or related problems -- in older women with heart disease, researchers are reporting. In addition, the treatment increases the risks of blood clots and gallbladder disease, they say.

title: They Have A Tantrum, Then Save The World
description: Aficionados of the Powerpuff Girls, those buggy-eyed 5-year-old triplets whose antics on the Cartoon Network have generated a billion-dollar marketing juggernaut, may not be entirely overjoyed by ''The Powerpuff Girls Movie,'' which opens nationally today. Although the film has the wham-bam kinetic fizz of a 60's Pop Art explosion, its hipness quotient is considerably below that of the smartest individual episodes, one of which had dialogue constructed entirely out of quotations from Beatles songs.

title: Impasse in Albany Stalls Financing for Superfund
description: For 15 months, the state program that is supposed to clean up toxic waste sites has not received a penny for investigating and sanitizing polluted ground because of a political standoff between Gov. George E. Pataki and Assembly Democrats.

title: Vivendi Troubles Reflect Change In Investors' Hopes for Big Media
description: Vivendi Universal, the troubled French media company, is expected to put parts of the company up for sale, but any auction is likely to be a tamer affair than it would have been just a few years ago. The corporate ambitions and market forces that spurred Vivendi and other media companies like AOL Time Warner to collect company after company in the pursuit of a digital future have been transformed.

title: G.M. Bucks Detroit Trend And Reports Higher Sales
description: A day after introducing an aggressive incentive plan, General Motors reported stronger June auto sales today even as sales by its Detroit-based rivals and the rest of the industry sagged.

title: Investors Fret As E.D.S. Plans 2,000 Layoffs
description: The recently fragile support among investors for Electronic Data Systems frayed a bit more yesterday when the company announced that it would lay off 2,000 workers to adjust to weak demand for some of its computer and consulting services.

title: Max Schneier, 85, Advocate Of Better Mental Treatment
description: Max Schneier, whose daughter's manic-depressive illness inspired him to wage a relentless crusade for better treatment for the mentally ill, died on June 17 in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 85 and lived in Lauderhill, Fla., and Rawdon, Quebec.

title: Nicotine-Laced Water Is a Drug, F.D.A. Rules
description: Federal regulators said yesterday that nicotine-laced bottled water, which is being marketed as a dietary supplement, is an unapproved drug and cannot be sold in the United States without federal clearance.

title: Sex as a Cosmic Joke, As Demons Are Routed
description: That old saying ''the personal is political'' certainly applies to the Korean-American comedian Margaret Cho, whose brilliant, over-the-edge concert film ''Notorious C.H.O.'' carries candid sexual humor into previously uncharted territory. It is a paradoxical film whose abundant sexual profanity is slung with a conversational casualness that divests it of anger and shock value. Like it or not, that's the way we think and talk in a sexually sophisticated society.

title: THREE SHELBOURNE REITS TO LIQUIDATE HOLDINGS
description: Three Shelbourne Properties real estate investment trusts, which sprang out of partnerships put together by the syndicator Integrated Resources, which is now defunct, said yesterday that they had approved a plan to liquidate their holdings. Shelbourne Properties I, II and III also reached a litigation settlement under which the shareholder Michael Ashner agreed to start a tender offer to bolster his stake in the REIT's to 42 percent from 12 percent. The tender is worth about $42 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILK, ELLIOTT
description: WILK-Elliott. On July 2. Compassionate judge, iconoclast, peace maker. Survived by his wife Betty Levinson, sons Daniel and David Levinson Wilk, sister Sondra Wilk. Memorial service Monday July 8, 3PM, ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, gifts to NYC Chapter, National Lawyers Guild, 162 University Place, New York City, or the Center for Battered Women's Legal Services, 67 Wall Street, Suite 2411, NYC 10005.

title: Preaching Everywhere, Even in Her Dreams
description: WHEN the Rev. Suzan Johnson Cook left her 13-year-old ministry at the Mariner's Temple in Lower Manhattan to found a new Baptist congregation in the Bronx neighborhood where she was raised, she recorded a television commercial. Its message: ''It's more than a church. It's an experience.''

title: The Nets' Jordan Talks With the Nuggets
description: The Nets assistant coach Eddie Jordan was interviewed by the Denver Nuggets on Monday for their open head-coaching job. He is one of five candidates for the position.

title: AOL Time Warner Under More Pressure
description: The efforts of AOL Time Warner's chief executive, Richard D. Parsons, to refurbish his company's battered credibility on Wall Street became a lot more difficult yesterday when its rival Vivendi Universal showed signs of falling apart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, PROFESSOR MARTIN
description: DEUTSCH-Professor Martin. The faculty of The Steinhardt School of Education of New York University mourns the death of our esteemed colleague Martin Deutsch, Professor Emeritus. Professor Deutsch was an eminent psychologist, early leader of research and evaluation of pioneering pre-school programs, and valued academic colleague. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife and longterm research partner, Cynthia Deutsch, his sons, Benjamin and Jonah, and his granddaughter Alexandra. Ann Marcus Dean, The Steinhardt School of Education New York University

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: NAVY CAN OPEN FIRE The defense ministry said naval vessels could now fire on enemy ships after firing warning shots and no longer had to wait to be fired on first. The ministry issued new guidelines as a result of the shootout Saturday in the Yellow Sea in which a North Korean patrol boat fired on a South Korean boat, killing 4 sailors and wounding 19 others with 1 missing as the vessel sank. The ministry said the guidelines would remain in force until the United States and South Korea formally revise rules of engagement as required by the mutual defense pact between the countries. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: U.N. Sees Big Rise In AIDS Death Toll
description: AIDS will claim 65 million more lives by 2020 unless more countries expand prevention programs, the United Nations says in its first long-range forecast of the epidemic. The report, issued in advance of the 14th International AIDS Conference, departs from earlier studies predicting that the epidemic may have reached its peak in some countries.

title: Mario's Kitchen Is (What Else?) Molto Unbound
description: THE first meal that Susi Cahn and her husband, Mario Batali, the celebrity chef, ever shared was Mr. Batali's foot in his mouth.

title: Henin Quells Her Nerves And Seles
description: There was a wicked wind rustling the Wimbledon ivy beneath the kind of ominous sky reserved for Vincent Price flicks -- as if Justine Henin needed any more props to unnerve her today.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Navy Can Open Fire
description: The defense ministry said naval vessels could now fire on enemy ships after firing warning shots and no longer had to wait to be fired on first. The ministry issued new guidelines as a result of the shootout Saturday in the Yellow Sea in which a North Korean patrol boat fired on a South Korean boat, killing 4 sailors and wounding 19 others with 1 missing as the vessel sank. The ministry said the guidelines would remain in force until the United States and South Korea formally revise rules of engagement as required by the mutual defense pact between the countries. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Energy Concerns Said to Be Near China Pipeline Pact
description: Some of the world's largest energy companies are in the final stages of negotiations with one another and the Chinese government to form a consortium that would build a natural gas pipeline across China, people close to the talks said today.

title: Lavender Sorbet Cuddles Up To Meringue
description: Provence en Bote, a bistro and shop at 8303 Third Avenue in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, has evolved since Jean-Jacques and Leslie Bernat opened it about a year and a half ago. This summer, Mr. Bernat has started selling homemade ice cream and sorbet, by the scoop ($2.50 to go), by the pint ($3.50) and to fill meringue vacherins, left, ($6 for a small one, $25 for one that serves four, $35 for eight servings).

title: The Complexities of Love: Gay, Straight and Familial
description: Ronald K. Brown has gradually become one of the most quietly profound choreographers of his modern-dance generation. He and his company, Evidence, founded in 1985, open the door wide onto the history and culture of black Americans. His dances are thoughtful yet impassioned, addressing loaded themes with a wonderful imperturbability. ''Who's going to tell your grandmother's stories?'' a friend once challenged him. And Mr. Brown has challenged himself, it seems, with further questions. Who, for instance, will tell the stories of his grandmother's ancestors? Or the stories of gay Americans like Mr. Brown?

title: Martha's Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Quicksand in Pakistan
description: The United States has no more important ally in the war against terrorism than Pakistan. Were Pakistan and its nuclear weapons to fall under the control of Islamic fundamentalists, American security would be gravely threatened. That is why it is critically important that Gen. Pervez Musharraf deal smartly with the rising challenge to his pro-Western, secular rule. Mounting criticism from Islamic militants and the mainstream press has started to focus on his decision to ally Pakistan with the United States, and on the recent American pressure on Pakistan to stop aiding the Islamic guerrillas in neighboring Kashmir. The general has also infuriated many political leaders by moving to consolidate and enhance his powers in spite of his earlier pledge to restore self-government. These are serious problems that could abruptly undercut Pakistan's role in the war on terrorism.

title: WorldCom Officer Sold Almost All His Shares
description: The former executive at the center of a fraud investigation into WorldCom sold nearly all of his shares in the company in recent years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECTOR, RENEE
description: SPECTOR-Renee. Beloved wife of the late Arnold; devoted mother of Joel; dear sister of Maya Dawson of Los Angeles and the late Rosita Azuero of Bogota, Colombia. Actress of the Yiddish and American stage. Services Wednesday, July 3, 2002 at 2:00 PM at the Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Op-Art
Free Spenders Clobber Cost-Cutters
description: The Yankees and the Cleveland Indians were American League powers in 1997 and 1998, waging fierce postseason battles and eliminating each other on the way to the World Series.

title: Bush Backs Religious Charity and a Shaky Incumbent
description: President Bush promoted a bill today to give federal money to religious charities as he campaigned for Gov. Scott McCallum, a Republican who White House officials think has a ''strong chance'' of losing to a Democrat in November.

title: Somewhere Over the Rainbow Drinks Are (Partly) Blue
description: The drink is called a Thai Dye, but it seems neither Asian nor hippie, with a layer of white floating on top, then a wide band of blue and deep red in the bottom of the glass.

title: Anguish Over a Flight's Deadly Delay
description: By Monday night, the children should have been basking in the sun on a beach in Spain. But they did not reach their destination because of a chance mistake, and their tour became tragedy.

title: From Stuyvesant to Korea
description: The principal of Stuyvesant High School, Stanley Teitel, will travel to South Korea for 10 days this month to learn about Korean culture, the culture of an increasing proportion of his students. Mr. Teitel's trip is sponsored by a Korean-American parents' association and the city's South Korean Consulate. He will visit schools and sit in on a few intensive Korean language sessions.

title: Shameless Secrets Of the Chefs
description: THE flat rice noodles with braised beef shin at AZ on West 17th Street raises the bar on a common dish. It is cool and stimulating with the precise flavor of fresh coriander, needle-thin slices of red pepper, lemon grass and lime juice. There is also a bit of sweetness, whispering in the background and echoing the sugars in the carrots. That sweetness brings the dish together, and it derives from a familiar flavor, but not one you expect to find in a lean Asian dish, let alone one prepared by a three-star chef. It is Coca-Cola.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Health Woes For Hispanic Children
description: A new study suggests that the nation's Hispanic children have disproportionate rates of health problems that are being poorly treated. The report, which appears today in the Journal of the American Medical Association, found that Hispanic children had the highest rates of asthma, tuberculosis, diabetes and obesity, but compared with children of other races were far less likely to receive effective medications. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

description: MANHATTAN: RISKS SEEN AT CENTERS FOR AGED

description: ''We've constantly underestimated the kind of levels the epidemic can reach.''

description: Some of the top players on the women's Tour are not comfortable with the idea of a lab technician's knocking on their front doors unannounced.

description: To the Editor:

title: Wines of the Week
description: For July's warm-weather parties, red, white and blue are the colors for decorating, but red, white and pink are for sipping. These wines serve up value and invite celebration.
