title: Tech Shares Lead Decline as Accounting Worries Mount
description: Stock prices continued their downward spiral yesterday as concerns about corporate accounting and the possibility of new terrorist attacks were compounded by worries about whether companies will be able to meet earnings estimates.

title: Reform School Girl And Best Actress
description: For a short and starry moment, the world seemed wide open to Aleksandra Gietner -- a reform school girl who by chance landed the lead role in a low-budget movie that became a surprise hit here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSHRY, HAROLD
description: OSHRY-Harold. The officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the passing of Harold Oshry, a cherished friend, major supporter, and founding leader of Long Island's South Shore Division. Harold was a member of UJA-Federation's Council of Overseers and was a past vice chair of United Jewish Appeal. An active supporter of many Jewish institutions in New York, Florida, nationally, and in Israel, he was a major force in the movement to help Soviet Jews immigrate to Israel in the 1970s and early 80s. Harold left a legacy of hope for thousands who have been touched by his extraordinary generosity, commitment to humanitarian causes, and passion for Israel and the Jewish people. He embraced the philanthropic traditions of ''tikkun olam'' and instilled these values in his children and grandchildren. His son, Michael, is a major supporter and current leader in the South Shore Division along with his wife, Pamela. We extend our deepest sympathies to Harold's wife, Claire, to Michael and Pamela and their children, & to Michael's sisters, Meryl & Suzanne, and their families. Harold's contributions to the worldwide Jewish community will be felt for generations to come and his memory will be honored by the continued caring and generosity of his family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Board Chair Erika Witover, LI Steering Committee Chair John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO Stuart Tauber, LI Regional Director

title: The Who Spring Back And Start Their Tour
description: A fan waved a hand-painted sign with a British flag and the scrawled words ''The Who Lives On.'' No one at the packed Hollywood Bowl Monday night would dispute him.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Charged With 9/11 Fraud
description: A Manhattan woman was charged yesterday with fraud, accused of filing false papers indicating that her father had been missing since the attack on the World Trade Center and receiving $75,000 from a relief fund established by the American Red Cross. The police said the woman, Rosalba Wild, 50, of 435 East 79th Street, was arrested at 8 a.m. and charged with grand larceny. The arrest followed dozens of others in recent months in which people have been charged with various schemes to defraud charities and government agencies working in Sept. 11 disaster relief.

title: Thinking Man's Prince, a Virtuosic Swan
description: American Ballet Theater followed up its ''Giselle'' marathon, which included a debut by Marcelo Gomes as Albrecht, with its first ''Swan Lake'' of the season on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: LEADER OF PIRACY GROUP SENTENCED A leader of an international Internet software piracy group that involved students and staff members at some prestigious universities, John Sankus Jr., 29, began serving a 46-month prison sentence yesterday in a federal prison in Pennsylvania. Prosecutors said Mr. Sankus was one of the two leaders of a group called DrinkOrDie that was accused of pirating several million dollars of software. The Customs Service, which ran the investigation, said Mr. Sankus, a technician at a Gateway computer store in Philadelphia, had overseen a worldwide network of computer enthusiasts who used the Internet to steal and swap everything from the latest Windows software to software utilities. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: The Joys of Summer: From School to Pool
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Patriotic Purpose

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, HANNAH
description: SILVERMAN-Hannah. Loving grandmother of Joanne and Stephen Friedman. Beloved great-grandmother of Demi DeGregory and Amy Friedman. Service Friday July 5 at Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Defining Failed Schools Is Harder Than It Sounds
description: THE Supreme Court ruled last week, in a case involving Cleveland schools, that public money in the form of vouchers could subsidize the tuition of students who choose to attend religious schools. It was only partly a legal judgment that such aid does not violate the separation of church and state. What propelled the court was also a policy conclusion that vouchers may be a way to rescue children from failing public schools.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: OUSTED EXECUTIVE SELLS AUTO STOCK Brilliance China Automotive Holdings said its former chairman and chief executive, Yang Rong, sold all of his stock in the company after he was removed from his posts two weeks ago. The company, which makes shuttle vans, put his stake at 2.2 percent, worth $11 million, and said that it had all been sold on the open market. There had been a widespread impression until this spring that Mr. Yang, a former central bank official, owned most of the company, which would have made him the third-richest man in China. But it turned out that a nonprofit organization overseen by the central bank, the Chinese Financial Education Development Foundation, was the controlling shareholder. Mr. Yang was the chairman of the foundation and the automaker until his removal from the foundation as well two weeks ago; he remains a director of the automaker.

title: 2 Republicans Join Ranks of S.E.C. Critics
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, under siege from Democrats who say that its chairman, Harvey L. Pitt, has not done enough to police corporate fraud, is now drawing scrutiny from Congressional Republicans who want to examine whether the agency missed clues to some big accounting scandals.

title: A Restored Hotel Banks On Opulence and Service
description: A name freighted with echoes of a vanished time on Manhattan's East Side disappeared on June 1 when the old Barbizon Hotel became the Melrose Hotel. But the refinement that was a hallmark of the old is very much a part of the hotel's current business plan.

title: Sports of The Times; The L.P.G.A.: Three Times As Much Fun
description: WOMEN'S golf has what men's golf would prefer to have -- a Big Three, rather than Tiger Woods and the seven dwarfs.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: An Acquisition By Symantec
description: The Symantec Corporation, the maker of Norton computer security programs, purchased Mountain Wave Inc. for $20 million to gain software that keeps track of potential threats across an entire network. Symantec plans to use technology developed by the company in security-management software it will begin selling later this year, said Helyn Corcos, a Symantec spokeswoman. Mountain Wave is a closely held company based in Falls Church, Va.

title: Martha's Way
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Poland: Finance Minister Resigns
description: Poland's finance minister, Marek Belka, left, resigned after he lost a battle with left-wing cabinet colleagues over restraining the country's budget deficit. Mr. Belka, an economist trained in the United States, was widely seen as a guarantor of the Socialist government's fiscal probity as it leads Poland to membership in the European Union, expected in 2004, and tries to tackle a slumping economy with 17 percent unemployment. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: CIT Shakes Off Tyco's Leash, but Its First Day Is Bumpy
description: The CIT Group gained its independence yesterday, but the process was painful.

title: Off-Season Losses Fail to Shake Devils
description: Losing a high-profile free agent is becoming an annual summer event for the Devils, like getting a bad sunburn. But General Manager Lou Lamoriello refuses to torture himself over those who get away.

title: Report, Reversing Estimates, Forecasts Big Increase in AIDS Death Toll
description: AIDS will claim an additional 65 million lives by 2020, more than triple the number who died in the first 20 years of the epidemic, unless more countries vastly expand their prevention programs, says the United Nations' first long-range forecast of the epidemic.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Food Operations Merger
description: A New Zealand farm cooperative, Fonterra, and a privately held Australian food company, Bonlac, have merged their food operations to form the region's largest dairy group. The new company, which will be called Australasian Food Holdings, will have annual sales of more than $1 billion. Fonterra, which already owns 18 percent of Australia's largest food company, National Foods, will own 75 percent of Australasian. John Shaw (NYT)

title: High Spots in a Nation of Hot-Dog Heavens
description: ''GIMME two, with mustard.''

title: A Reincarnation on the Upper West Side
description: TIME is a luxury that most restaurants don't have. Unless a restaurateur can fall back on a proven track record and a sterling reputation, early steps in the wrong direction can be fatal in this low-margin business.

title: Mondesi Is Forced To Follow New Rules
description: Raul Mondesi walked into Yankee Stadium yesterday and, like so many players donning pinstripes for the first time, realized that the ultimate opportunity had arrived.

title: For Smokers, Even the Open Air Isn't a Sure Refuge These Days
description: This densely settled town on Long Island's North Shore has become the latest beachhead in a campaign to ban smoking not just in restaurants and offices, but outdoors as well.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Kidnapping By Rebels Suspected
description: The military said it was searching for nine missing crewmen from a vessel servicing an ExxonMobil gas platform off the coast of the troubled northern province of Aceh. The crew of the Pelangi Frontier was apparently kidnapped on Sunday by a group of armed men, which the military said it suspects were separatist rebels. Dian Saputra (NYT)

title: Our Towns; State Senator, 5-Term Mayor And Star
description: FOR a glorious if brief 48 hours, the stage was all Sharpe's and all of Sharpe was on stage.

title: A Wealthy Family Humbled by Its Own Moves
description: The Bronfmans, one of the nation's richest families, have watched their fortune wither since they bought the film and music businesses of Universal in 1995 and later sold them to Vivendi. And the family that once controlled its own destiny is still subject to the whims of Vivendi Universal's new French management and possibly Barry Diller, the Vivendi executive who has a strained relationship with the Bronfmans.

title: The Way You Were
description: We are hopelessly mired in the age of the memoir. Literary navel-gazers of all prose styles have unveiled the dark secrets of their snake-handling daddies, soap-opera-addled mothers and their own sad addictions to airplane glue, Jell-O dust and double-entendre polkas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERGARI, BOHN C.
description: VERGARI - Bohn C. Our hearts are saddened by the untimely death of Bohn. Our love and sympathy to our very special friends, Carl and Genevieve, his beloved wife Jane and devoted sister Jeanne, and the entire family. Rita, Philip Rosen and family.

title: BERKSHIRE TO BUY MAKER OF GARANIMALS
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. yesterday agreed to buy Garan Inc., the maker of Garanimals children's clothing, for about $270.6 million in cash. Berkshire Hathaway, which is controlled by the investor Warren E. Buffett, will pay $60 a share for Garan, a 6.8 percent premium to yesterday's closing price, the companies said. Shares of Garan, which is based in New York, fell 35 cents, to $56.20, and have risen by a third this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, LILLIAN
description: WALKER-Lillian. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member and extends sincere sympathy to her family and friends. David S. Mack, President Michael Stein, Secretary

title: At the Front On Pollution
description: California has once again declared its intention to challenge the federal government for the lead in setting environmental policy in the United States.

title: Suddenly, It's Art For the City's Sake; Bloomberg's Hearty Embrace Signals A Whole New Approach at City Hall
description: Something out of the ordinary happened when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg presented the annual Art Commission Awards this May. It wasn't the mayor's proclamation that public spaces should be beautiful, or that he stood around for an hour after the awards were presented, sipping cocktails. Rather, it was that he was there at all.

title: State to Check Heat Precautions Taken by Homes for Mentally Ill
description: For the first time, the State Health Department is sending inspectors to adult homes across the New York City region to ensure that they are running air-conditioners and taking other precautions to prevent mentally ill residents from succumbing to heat-related illnesses.

title: David Pasternack
description: A SEAFOOD salad is a great summer dish. This mixture of seafood here is my ideal, but you can adjust the proportions, depending on what's in the market.

title: Schwarz Unlikely to Testify As Defense Prepares to Rest
description: Charles Schwarz's defense in the Abner Louima torture case is preparing to rest today, apparently without calling Mr. Schwarz to the witness stand.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Nobu Chez Vous

title: U.S. Changes Mind on Its Offer To Restart North Korea Talks
description: The Bush administration, citing last week's deadly gun battle between North and South Korean ships, said today that it had withdrawn a proposal to send a delegation to North Korea next week to restart negotiations on a range of issues, including the North's missile and nuclear weapons programs.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Elan Shares Fall
description: Shares of Elan, Ireland's biggest drug maker, fell 19 percent after the company said it might have to write down assets worth about half its market value. Elan might have a second-quarter expense of as much as $631 million because the value of some of its investments have declined, it said in its annual report. The announcement added to concern about the future of Elan, whose shares are off 92 percent this year.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Ex-Foe Visits Capital
description: Jos Alexandre Gusmo, who as leader of the East Timor independence movement was imprisoned by the Indonesian government for seven years, arrived in Jakarta on his first visit as president of the newly independent country. Mr. Gusmo was met with a 21-gun salute and a smiling President Megawati Sukarnoputri, who said Indonesia was ready to start a new relationship with East Timor. The two leaders signed an agreement to set up a joint commission to deal with Indonesian assets in East Timor and hundreds of thousands of East Timor refugees still in Indonesia. They agreed to open embassies in each other's countries. Dian Saputra (NYT)

title: Aloft on Bozoloft
description: The makers of antidepressants are going to have to start testing their own products.

title: Recipe: Quick Iced Tea
description: Time: 5 minutes

title: Harold L. Oshry; Businessman, 84
description: Harold L. Oshry, an early proponent of automobile leasing in the United States, died on June 29 at his home in Tamarac, Fla. He was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSE, MARGARET
description: LESSE-Margaret. Age 88, passed away on June 25. She had an early career on Broadway, later becoming an accomplished artist and sculptress. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Stanley Lesse, eminent neuro-psychiatrist. She will be dearly missed by her many friends and family for her compassion and wonderful sense of humor.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Mount Holly: Not Guilty Plea In 3 Killings
description: A man has pleaded not guilty to three shooting deaths earlier this year that were committed, prosecutors say, to eliminate witnesses to the robbery of $1,000 from a mobile home. Prosecutors are seeking the death penalty. The man, Brian J. Tykot, 35, of Monroe Township, entered his plea on Monday to the Jan. 5 shooting deaths of two brothers, Edward M. Nevius, 49, and Gary R. Nevius, 43, and the younger brother's friend, Jill Fort, 46. Mr. Tykot was arrested several days later in Ocean County on an unrelated domestic violence charge. Prosecutors say he shot Gary Nevius and Ms. Fort in a bedroom, then shot Edward Nevius in the living room of the two-bedroom mobile home.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hyundai Sales Fall
description: Hyundai Motor, Korea's dominant motor vehicle manufacturer, reported a 36 percent drop in sales last month from June 2001 as a result of disruptions caused by union protests as well as the World Cup soccer tournament, which it said had distracted the attention of workers given time off to watch South Korea's soccer team advance to the semifinals. Chung Mong Koo, left, chairman of Hyundai Motor and Kia Motor, owned by Hyundai, dismissed four top executives for having yielded too easily to worker demands and failing to meet sales targets. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Danbury: Carbide Headquarters Sold
description: A local investment group has bought the former Union Carbide headquarters, ending speculation that an Indian tribe would develop the property for a casino. The buyer, Woodlands II L.L.C., paid $27.5 million for the 455 acres of land surrounding Union Carbide's former headquarters, said Mayor Mark D. Boughton. Woodlands plans to have homes, offices, shops and a minor league baseball stadium built on the land, he said. The Schaghticoke Tribal Nation had considered building a casino there. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Milosevic Trial Resumes
description: The trial of Slobodan Milosevic resumed yesterday after being suspended for two weeks because Mr. Milosevic had what court officials said was the flu. The break was the second apparently caused by illness, and judges ordered a medical examination of the former Yugoslav president after prosecutors expressed skepticism last week. Mr. Milosevic and Wolfgang Petritsch, the former European Union envoy for Kosovo, clashed yesterday over attempts to hold off the NATO bombing there over Yugoslavia's repression of ethnic Albanians. Mr. Milosevic said the West had issued an ''ultimatum''; Mr. Petritsch said the former president had clearly not been interested in a peaceful settlement. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: More Changes at Columbia
description: The turnover in Columbia University's top administration continues. Last week the university named N. P. NARVEKAR, now managing director of the office of investments at the University of Pennsylvania, as its new vice president for investments. He will oversee Columbia's $4.3 billion endowment. Mr. Narvekar was previously managing director in the equity derivatives group at J. P. Morgan and Company.

title: Chief Says U.S. Security Needs Links To WorldCom
description: John W. Sidgmore, the chief executive of WorldCom, said yesterday that the survival of the company was a national security issue and that his management team was not responsible for the company's accounting problems. But he did not rule out a bankruptcy filing.

title: Gingerly, Arabs Question Suicide Bombings
description: It has been muffled by Israel's latest military offensive in the West Bank and the Bush administration's demands for the ouster of Yasir Arafat, but a debate is under way among Palestinians over suicide bombing.

title: Arabs at the Crossroads
description: President Bush was right to declare that the Palestinians need to produce decent governance before they can get a state. Too bad, however, that he didn't say that it's not only the Palestinians who need radical reform of their governance -- it's most of the Arab world.

title: Al Qaeda Paid For Car Bomb At U.S. Office, Pakistani Says
description: Al Qaeda paid for the car bombing outside the American Consulate in Karachi last month that killed 12 people, a senior Pakistani official said today.

title: Collision Alarm-System Was Off at Time of Crash, Swiss Say
description: UBERLINGEN, Germany, July 3  Swiss air traffic officials acknowledged today that a collision alarm-system in their control tower was out of operation and that one of two key controllers had taken a break at the time of an in-flight collision between two jets that killed 71 people on Monday night.

title: Judge Rejects Case Against Audit Firm
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission's audit-independence case against Ernst & Young was dismissed today by an administrative law judge who said the S.E.C.'s one-member vote violated federal rules.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: THE HAGUE: MILOSEVIC TRIAL RESUMES The trial of Slobodan Milosevic resumed yesterday after being suspended for two weeks because Mr. Milosevic had what court officials said was the flu. The break was the second apparently caused by illness, and judges ordered a medical examination of the former Yugoslav president after prosecutors expressed skepticism last week. Mr. Milosevic and Wolfgang Petritsch, the former European Union envoy for Kosovo, clashed yesterday over attempts to hold off the NATO bombing there over Yugoslavia's repression of ethnic Albanians. Mr. Milosevic said the West had issued an "ultimatum"; Mr. Petritsch said the former president had clearly not been interested in a peaceful settlement. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOOKER, JOAN F.
description: HOOKER - Joan F. Died peacefully on June 26, 2002 after a prolong illness. Scholar, author, educator, traveller, mother and friend. Former wife of the late Arthur Bowles Hooker. Survived by her son Sam Hooker of Norwalk, Ct., her daughters Wendy Hooker Swift and Martina Kearney Hooker both of Brooklyn, New York, and 4 grandchildren. She will greatly missed by so many whose lives she touched. The family is making arrangements for a service.

title: U.S. Companies Pay Penalties for Trade With Certain Nations
description: A number of prominent American companies and subsidiaries of foreign concerns have paid cash settlements during the last four years for violating sanctions on trade and investment in parts of Afghanistan under Taliban control and on North Korea, Libya, Cuba, Iraq and Iran, among others, according to government documents obtained by a trade publication.

title: A Florida Judge Upholds State Death-Sentence Law
description: Only a week after the Supreme Court held that juries and not judges must make the factual findings to support death sentences, a trial court here ruled today that Florida's capital sentencing statute, which relegates juries to an advisory role, is constitutional.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Textbook According to Texas
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VASTESAEGER, MARIA
description: VASTESAEGER-Maria. The entire Long Island College Hospital family mourns the passing of Maria Vastesaeger, beloved wife of devoted physician Balendu Vasavada, MD. She will be deeply missed. We extend our deepest sympathies to Dr. Vasavada, his family, loved ones and friends. John Wren Chairman of the Board, LICH Peter A. Kelly Acting President and CEO Mark McDougle Executive VP and COO Edmund Giegerich, MD Sr. VP of Medical Affairs Daniel D. Ricciardi, MD President, Medical Staff Terrence Sacchi, MD Chief, Division of Cardiology

title: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia: Empty Karadzic House Raided
description: Peacekeepers raided the empty home of Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb leader charged with war crimes, seizing forged documents and a few guns, NATO officials said, in what they called a crackdown on arms smugglers. Masked French soldiers blasted their way into the house, which has stood unoccupied for five years while Dr. Karadzic has been on the run. Officials said his capture was not the goal of the operation. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: PEROT SYSTEMS IN DEAL The computer services company founded by H. Ross Perot, the Perot Systems Corporation, has acquired the government consulting company ADI Technology for about $32 million in cash plus up to $15 million more in cash and stock if some performance goals are met. Perot Systems, which is based in Plano, Tex., will also assume $6 million in debt. ADI, with 600 employees, had revenue of $67 million last year and $30 million in the first five months of this year. (Bloomberg News)

title: In America, Growing Pains and Gains
description: I PLAN to open a couple of bottles of Chteau Loville-Barton 1970 in a few days for a little celebration: the 30th anniversary of this column, on July 7. Yes, I know, 30 years ago was 1972. Well, 1972 was a terrible year in Bordeaux, and 1970 was a good year. Can't be too rigid about these things.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Helping Uganda Fight Rebels
description: The government said it would join Uganda in rooting out the Lord's Resistance Army, a Ugandan rebel group that has used southern Sudan as a staging area for years in its effort to topple the Ugandan government. President Omar Hassan al-Bashir said his army would join with Ugandan forces to fight the group, which is headed by Joseph Kony, a self-proclaimed prophet. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHORE, ELEANOR (NEE GOODMAN)
description: SHORE-Eleanor (nee Goodman). Age 94, died on July 1, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Sanford Shore. Married for 68 years, longtime resident of Larchmont then New Rochelle. Wonderful mother of Vivian Zelvin, Alfred, Richard & Douglas Shore. Cherished grandmother of Lynn, Michael and Maritza, Diana and Jeffrey Harris, Robert and Karin, Adam, Allison, David, Jaime and Jonathan Shore. Great grandmother of Zachary Shore. Funeral to be held at George T. Davis Funeral Home, New Rochelle, on Wednesday at 1 P.M. family receiving guests, service to follow. Interment at Mount Hope Cemetery.

title: Mexico's Ex-President Testifies on Rights Abuse
description: For the first time ever, a former president of Mexico appeared before a special prosecutor this morning to face questions about his conduct in office -- specifically, his government's role in human rights abuses in the late 1960's and early 70's.

title: Recycle Rule Is Set, But the Trash Isn't
description: Even though new city recycling rules went into effect on Monday, not many residents and superintendents of apartment buildings in New York seem to know how to sort their trash properly, the city's sanitation commissioner said yesterday.

title: Construction Is to Start in Fall On Central Harlem Supermarket
description: Construction will finally begin this fall on central Harlem's first full-size supermarket, a long-delayed project that is expected to be a catalyst for further development in the Bradhurst section, city officials said yesterday.

title: On the Way to the Minors, Choate Makes a U-Turn
description: Randy Choate is not the kind of person who blends into a clubhouse. Choate bounces from teammate to coach to reporter to attendant, always with some kind of question or request. He runs a daily home run game with his fellow Yankee relievers, each player picking a teammate to hit a home run that day. Choate keeps a running tally on a hand-written sheet in his locker.

title: Around the World in 13 Days
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Alfresco Assistance
A Century of New York Photos
So Gallantly Streaming
description: The Star-Spangled Banner Flag House in Baltimore is about to expand.

title: Dallas Is Back
A Star's-Eye View
Fouling Our Own Nest
description: Do you remember the character Pig-Pen in the ''Peanuts'' cartoons? He was always covered with dirt and grime. He was cute, but he was a walking sludge heap, filthy and proud of it. He once told Charlie Brown, ''I have affixed to me the dirt and dust of countless ages. Who am I to disturb history?''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Girl, 15, Is Stabbed
description: A 15-year-old girl was stabbed in the neck by a 13-year-old girl last night in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the police said. The victim was taken to Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center in critical condition after the stabbing, which occurred about 8 p.m. behind a building on Quincy Street. The 13-year-old was arrested and charged with first-degree assault and criminal possession of a weapon. A kitchen knife was recovered at the scene, the police said. The girls' names were not released. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: NEW TENSION OVER KASHMIR Foreign Minister Yashwant Sinha said that after a drop, the infiltration of Islamic militants into Kashmir from Pakistani territory "has gone back to earlier levels" despite President Pervez Musharraf's pledge to stop it. He said India would make "whatever appropriate responses are necessary." The Defense Ministry says it has caught three groups of infiltrators since June 24, killing nine of them. Pakistan denies any infiltration is taking place; India says Pakistan is providing heavy military cover to help militants sneak into India. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Washington Allows a 12-Day Extension For U.N. Peacekeeping Mission in Bosnia
description: Faced with an unusually direct appeal from Secretary General Kofi Annan, the United States agreed today to another extension of the Bosnia peacekeeping mission without a provision placing American peacekeepers beyond the reach of the new International Criminal Court. The extension is through July 15.

title: Federal Law on Failing Schools Has States Scrambling to Comply
description: Letters arrived last month in the mailboxes of hundreds of parents in this district of dilapidated, failing schools. The one-page correspondence informed them that 16 of their neighborhood schools were ranked so poorly in a three-year review of test scores that the parents were entitled to move their children elsewhere rather than wait for improvements promised under a new law spearheaded by the Bush administration.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: After Battle, Phone Deal Is Off
description: Talks between the two Koreas on opening a mobile phone system in the North's capital, Pyongyang, were suspended as a result of the naval shootout on Saturday in the Yellow Sea for which the South blames the North. The Information and Communication Ministry said tensions would have to ease before it could hold talks on setting up the service, which would make it possible to talk by telephone between North and South Korea for the first time since the Korean War. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Surging Czech Currency Sets Records
description: It is not much solace to Czech manufacturers, but the country's long-derided currency, the koruna, has been among the strongest in the world this year.

title: Mayor Acknowledges M.T.A. May Have to Raise Fares in '03
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg acknowledged yesterday what some transportation experts and ratings agencies have been saying for some time: the Metropolitan Transportation Authority may need to raise fares next year.

title: Owners Can Talk Publicly On Issues
description: With the union's executive board poised to discuss setting a strike date at its meeting next Monday, owners have received a green light from Commissioner Bud Selig to talk about baseball's labor situation. The owners had previously been muted by the threat of a $1 million fine.

title: Krajicek Wins Marathon Duel Of Big Serves
description: There must have been times when Richard Krajicek thought that his comeback from elbow surgery was quicker and less torturous than his fourth-round match against Mark Philippoussis. The two big servers in the Wimbledon draw were scheduled to start their match on Monday, but were pushed to Tuesday because of rain. They played four sets, only to have their match full of tie breakers suspended again. With daylight fading today, they played for only five minutes and two games into the fifth set before a downpour brought out the tarps. A half-hour later, and after three days of trying, Krajicek finally put an end to the remarkable run of Philippoussis by extending his own dream scenario with a 6-7 (2), 7-6 (4), 6-7 (1), 7-6 (5), 6-4 victory, concluded at 9:15 tonight.

title: More Women Taking Leadership Roles at Colleges
description: Last year, Shirley M. Tilghman became the first woman to be president of Princeton University. A week later, she named a woman as provost. This May, she named a woman as dean of the Woodrow Wilson School. And last week, without fanfare, she named a woman as dean of the School of Engineering and Applied Science.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSHRAY, HAROLD L.
description: OSHRAY-Harold L. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Claire, his son Michael and his entire family. We mourn the passing of a good and dear friend. Dick & Hohn Maltz

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALLMAN, BEATRICE
description: HALLMAN - Beatrice. On July 2, 2002. Beloved wife of Louis. Devoted mother of Thea and Howard Lorber, and Frances and Kenneth Fox. Cherished grandmother of Brian and Ali, Michael, and Melanie. Services Thursday 12 noon at the Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: Rate Activity Is Mixed
description: Australia's central bank left its main interest rate unchanged while the bank in New Zealand raised rates there for the fourth time this year. The Australian bank took no action after raising rates in the prior two months. Economists said the bank might resume increasing rates as soon as next month after retail sales rose twice as much as expected in May. The Reserve Bank of Australia's governor, Ian Macfarlane, above, and his board left the overnight cash target rate at 4.75 percent, following quarter-point increases in May and June. A report released two hours later showed retail sales rose 1.1 percent in May from June, and building approvals fell less than expected. New Zealand's central bank raised its rate by a quarter-point, to 5.75 percent.

description: SHACHNOW - Peggy. We deeply mourn the loss of our Aunt Peggy Shachnow. She was the closest of Sisters to our mother and a loving Aunt and steadfast friend to us. Linda Smith Richard Lefkowitz

title: Gay Pride, Gay Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Como (as in Commotion) Over Emo (as in Emotion)
description: To a generation of kids who grew up on bands like Green Day and Blink-182, punk is a joke: a fast and funny offshoot of alternative rock. For kids who take their music (and perhaps themselves) more seriously, there's a punk subgenre called emo, which is a bit slower and a whole lot less funny.

title: Reimagining July 4
description: In ordinary times, most Americans can talk only so much about patriotism. Some of the genuine charm of Independence Day has often been the diffidence with which it is celebrated, more for the fireworks and parades than for the rhetoric of nationhood. Most of us would like to be celebrating just that kind of holiday today, one that touches only lightly on the emotions that bind us into one country. But today is likely to remind us instead how swiftly and profoundly the symbols and the words that define America get replenished from time to time. No one expects it to happen, but when it does, it is breathtaking, a reminder not of the power of one nation but of the power of the principles behind that nation. As principles go, they are generous to a fault, and that is the source of their strength.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurance Rule Eased
description: The Swiss government relaxed its minimum-yield requirement on pensions, which insurers had been complaining was too high in the current markets. The government said it would cut the mandated level to 3 percent from 4 percent. The change will take effect Oct. 1 and contributed to a rally in Swiss insurers' share prices, including that of the country's biggest insurer, Swiss Life, which has been among the companies dipping into reserves to make up the difference. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Economics, Politics and Vouchers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Wry Cuban Writer as Mysterious as His Plots
description: The most intriguing mysteries swirling about Daniel Chavarra are not in his crime novels, but in his life. How does a professor of Latin and Greek classics find fulfillment and fame writing about prostitutes? Why does he live in Cuba, where some people whisper that he arrived 33 years ago on a hijacked flight? And how can he slam back four double shots of smooth, amber rum before noon and not fall flat on his face?

title: Pop-Up Culprit
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Isn't the Only Way to Keep Up With the Tour de France Action
description: The arrival of live American television coverage of the Tour de France last year has not meant the end of regular text updates from the race on cycling Web sites.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Closing Parts Of Network
description: KPNQwest has started to close parts of its fiber optic network for fast Internet business access as it continues to look for buyers, a court-appointed trustee in its bankruptcy case, Jan van Apeldoorn, said. ''We had set a July 1 deadline,'' he said, adding, ''At the same time, we're still talking to a number of parties about selling parts of the network.''

title: SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA ELIMINATES 1,300 JOBS IN MEXICO
description: Scientific-Atlanta Inc. eliminated 1,300 jobs in Mexico, or 16 percent of its staff, because of declining demand for products of the company, the second-largest American maker of television set-top boxes. The company trimmed production at its plant in Juarez to lower the work force to 6,700 and may cut more jobs, a spokesman, Paul Sims, said. He would not provide details on a number or location of potential layoffs. Scientific-Atlanta, second to Motorola Inc. in the set-top box market, has experienced declines in sales of products that let viewers get digital TV, as cable operators sign up fewer subscribers for the service, which features hundreds of channels.

title: Harold Haley Haskin, 87; Specialized in Saving Oyster
description: Harold Haley Haskin, a marine biologist who championed the cause of the oyster, died June 23 at his home in Cape May Court House, N.J., on the banks of his beloved Delaware Bay. He was 87.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Leagues Seek Relief From Privacy Law
description: A new health privacy law could create enormous problems for professional sports teams when compliance is required next year, and lawyers acting in consultation with teams in the National Football League, Major League Baseball and other leagues are seeking regulatory relief.

title: Ray Brown, Master Jazz Bassist, Dies at 75
description: Ray Brown, whose feather-fingered, guitar-like virtuosity on the bass carried him to the summits of jazz peformance for a half century, died on Tuesday in Indianapolis. He was 75.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Genocide Acquittal Upheld
description: The appeals court for the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda upheld the acquittal of a Rwandan official accused of playing a leading role in the mass killings of 1994. Judge Claudia Jordan of France ordered the immediate release of Ignace Bagilishema, the former mayor of Mabanza, Rwanda. Prosecutors at the tribunal in Arusha, Tanzania, had sought a new trial after Mr. Bagilishema, in June 2001, became the first person acquitted by the tribunal. Eight senior officials have been convicted of genocide. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Footlights
description: Season's Greetings

title: House Panel to Study Ruling On Law School Admissions
description: The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee is investigating whether the chief judge of the federal appeals court in Cincinnati acted improperly in a recent decision upholding the admissions process at the law school at the University of Michigan.

title: Bush Faces Scrutiny Over Disclosing '90 Stock Sale Late
description: As President Bush prepared to make a major speech on Wall Street next week about corporate responsibility, the White House found itself on the defensive again today over the kind of action for which Mr. Bush is assailing corporate executives: his own failure in 1990 to disclose a stock sale as promptly as required by law.

title: Who won the Cup?Korea and Ronaldo
description: Once the ball has stopped rolling, and the Brazilians stop partying, we can begin to count the cost and the gains of World Cup 2002.

title: Mexico and Brazil Sign Bilateral Trade Pact
description: With prospects for global trade liberalization looking bleak at the moment, the presidents of Brazil and Mexico, Latin America's two biggest economies, signed a bilateral trade deal today instead, opening their markets to each other in 800 industrial and agricultural product categories.

description: THE 87th Nathan's Famous Hot Dog Eating Contest commences at noon today, and if you feel it a patriotic duty to wager on the Americans, don't.

description: FOR Vicki Huddleston, the Fourth of July is no day at the beach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINHOLD, MEYER
description: REINHOLD-Meyer. Age 92, died on July 1, 2002. Meyer Reinhold, a major figure in Greek and Roman classical studies, died in Nashville after a brief illness. Reinhold was born in Brooklyn, New York. A graduate of City College with a Ph.D. from Columbia University, Reinhold served on the faculties of Brooklyn College, Southern Illinois University, the University of Missouri, and Boston University. In his retirement he was a visiting scholar at Vanderbilt University. Reinhold was the author of 23 books. Dr. Reinhold was preceded in death by his wife of 59 years, Diane Roth Reinhold, and his son, Robert Reinhold, a leading reporter for the New York Times and the Los Angeles Times. He is survived by his daughter, Helen Reinhold Barrett, Dean of the Graduate School, Tennessee State University; 2 grandsons, Matthew Reinhold Barrett of Rochester, NY, and Andrew Charlton Barrett of Chapel Hill, NC; and brother, Louis E. Reinhold, of New York, NY. Services will be conducted at 2 PM on Thursday, July 4, at Congregation Micah, Rabbi Kenneth Kanter officiating. Burial will be at Temple Cemetery, Nashville, TN. Memorial contributions may be made to the Meyer Reinhold Fund, C/O Dept. of Classical Studies, Boston University, 735 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, MA. 02215. Marshall/ Donnelly/Combs Funeral Home, 615-327-1111.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORDAN, JOSEPH
description: JORDAN-Joseph. Of Manhattan on July 1. Born in NYC 96 years ago. Beloved father of Vance Jordan and Jill Jordan Spangler, both of Manhattan. He is also survived by twin grandsons, Ian and Noel Spangler. The first American Director of Boys' Towns of Italy and American Relief for Italy, later Public Relations Director for LAI (now Alitalia), Mr. Jordan raised funds for many similar charitable organizations in the 1940s and '50s. He also wrote scripts for several early television dramas, and in 1966 established a talent agency for children which still bears his name. Though he outlived most of his old friends, he found many new ones in recent years, and all deeply regret the loss of his humor and charm. No service is planned.

title: Palestinian Security Chiefs Deny Reports of Their Dismissal
description: The once-powerful Palestinian West Bank security chief reportedly fired by Yasir Arafat under pressure from the United States said tonight that he was still on the job, a sign of sharpening dissension among Palestinians.

title: Bewitching With the Irresistible Power of Blarney
description: You can trace a whole skein of playwrights from J. M. Synge, whose sweet-and-sour comedy, ''The Playboy of the Western World,'' set out the attitude of affectionate pity that Irish writers expressed for their countrymen throughout the 20th century.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Aspen Reports Loss
description: Aspen Technology Inc. shares fell 52 percent yesterday after the company, a maker of automation software for oil and chemical companies, said it had a fiscal fourth-quarter loss. Aspen had forecast a profit. The loss in the period ended Sunday, excluding restructuring and research and development costs, was $4 million to $6 million. ''Companies are being more cautious,'' said Lawrence Evans, the chairman and chief executive. ''We're not losing any deals, we're just seeing a delay.'' Shares of Aspen, based in Cambridge, Mass., fell $3.61, to $3.40, in trading of 4.44 million shares, almost six times the three-month daily average. The stock has fallen 85 percent in the last year.

description: MICHIGAN: SMOKING TAX MAY RISE

description: In percent

title: Hearst Drops Editor Of House Beautiful
description: IN a move that stunned many in the design field, Hearst Magazines announced Monday that the editor in chief of House Beautiful, Marian McEvoy, would be replaced by the editor in chief of Traditional Home, a Des Moines-based magazine owned by the Meredith Corporation.

title: I.R.S. Proposes End to Tax Benefit on Executives' Insurance
description: The Internal Revenue Service proposed rules today that would eliminate the tax benefit on life insurance policies used by corporations to pay their executives.

title: Hyatt Offer
description: Through August, 16 Hyatt resorts in the United States and the Caribbean have a variety of add-ons. At the Hyatt Regency Maui, the seventh night is free (rates start at $315 a night), or get a second room from $157.50. The Hyatt Regency Coconut Point near Naples, Fla., gives the third night free (rates from $200 a night), and a second room is $100. In Puerto Rico, the fifth night is free at the Hyatt Cerromar (rates from $210 a night), with a second room $105. Other extras are free meals for children under 12 dining with an adult and free golf for those under 17 with a paying adult. Details: www.hyatt.com ; reservations: (800) 554-9288.

title: Continental-US Airways Talks Break Off
description: Continental Airlines said yesterday that it was breaking off negotiations with US Airways about a partnership in which the two carriers would have booked passengers on each other's flights.

title: Inquiry Finds Effort at Delay At WorldCom
description: Before he was dismissed, the former chief financial officer of WorldCom urged an internal corporate auditor to suspend her review of certain company accounts that ultimately turned up almost $4 billion in misallocated expenses, people involved in the case said yesterday.

description: LONG after his simple home page made him an unlikely Web sensation, Mahir Cagri is still holding on to a fame that he knows he never really deserved.

title: Credit Suisse Announces Management Shake-Up
description: The Credit Suisse Group, facing waning investor confidence and a falling share price, announced today that Lukas Mhlemann would be stepping down as chairman next year, but would retain his job as chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SELVERNE, BETH B.
description: SELVERNE-Beth B. One fine lady! Remembered with love. Your Famil

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Airport Profit Rises
description: Hong Kong's airport operator said its annual profit more than tripled because its operating and financial costs fell. Profit rose to $30 million in the year through March from $9 million in the previous year, while sales rose to $676 million from $661 million, the Hong Kong Airport Authority said in its annual report.

title: NASA Engineers Find Crack In Fuel Line of a Third Shuttle
description: Engineers have found a tiny crack in a fuel line of the space shuttle Columbia very similar to those previously discovered in two other shuttles, NASA said today.

title: Macho Uno Returns To the Run for a Title
description: It's not that Macho Uno wasn't around last year. He just didn't make much of an impact. With one victory from four starts, that coming in a Grade III stakes race, he didn't exactly follow through on the promise he showed in a brilliant 2-year-old campaign that ended with a victory in the 2000 Breeders' Cup Juvenile. But a year later, he appears ready to rewrite the story of his career.

title: At the Bottom of Golf Ponds, A Big Business Is Lurking
description: It's not the three-foot snapping turtles or the underwater snakes, eels, crabs or spiny-backed catfish that spook Jimmy Lantz, professional golf ball diver. Lantz starts his day early, plunging into a dozen ponds or channels on an average Florida golf course, pawing the silt-covered bottoms and the rocky ledges with bare hands, feeling his way through water so black he can see only a few feet beyond his nose.

title: Toy Importer Settles Suit On Violating Safety Rules
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission reached a settlement yesterday with a California company that it had accused of deliberately trying to import toys, including miniature pool table sets, helicopters and party ribbon spray, that did not meet federal safety guidelines.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Thursday with an article about an alpine garden near Seattle misidentified a yellow flower growing along a walkway. It was basket-of-gold, not lewisia; lewisia was the pink and white flower nearby.

title: Clemens Is Hurting, and So Is the Yankees' Rotation
description: Roger Clemens answers questions about injuries as if he is being cross-examined in court, his short answers meant to provide as little information as possible. Clemens lasted only five innings in his start against Cleveland on Tuesday before leaving with a problem in his right leg.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Consumer Borrowing Soared In May
description: British consumers borrowed record amounts in May as mortgage lending soared. Consumer lending rose 8.3 billion ($12.7 billion) in May, up from April's revised increase of 7.8 billion. Mortgage loans surged by 6.8 billion, more than three-quarters of the total. Both amounts were the largest since the government began keeping records in April 1993. Britons are taking advantage of the lowest borrowing costs since 1964 to buy houses.

title: Origin of a Diamond
description: To the Editor:

title: WENDY'S RAISES ITS FULL-YEAR PROFIT FORECAST
description: Wendy's International Inc., the third-largest United States hamburger-restaurant chain, raised its full-year profit forecast yesterday after the company's Tim Hortons unit agreed to sell a cup-making business. Profit will be $1.87 to $1.92 a share, 2 cents more than the company's previous forecast, Wendy's said. The company earned $1.65 last year. Tim Hortons, a chain of coffee and doughnut shops, agreed to sell the cup business for $20 million to Dopaco Canada Inc. by the end of July. The sale will result in a gain of $3.9 million, or 2 cents a share, in the third quarter, Wendy's said. Wendy's shares fell $1.36, or 3.6 percent, to $38.94 in late trading. They had risen 57 percent in the last year.

title: Corrections
description: The Patents column in Business Day on Monday about a system for customer service centers that detects anger in callers and directs them to operators trained to handle such calls misstated the location of the headquarters of the Mitel Knowledge Corporation, on whose behalf the inventors won a patent for the system. It is based in Kanata, Ontario, not in California.

title: E-Commerce Executive Steps Down at Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that its top electronic commerce executive was resigning Aug. 1 as the company reduces e-commerce activities to concentrate on its main business of making cars and trucks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADY, MICHAEL JOHN
description: BRADY-Michael John. Michael John Brady died on July 3rd, 2002. He was born September 12, 1935 in NY, NY to the late John and Margaret Brady. He was educated at Harren High School in NY and SUNY - Stony Brook, where he graduated with a B.S. in Engineering and a M.S. in Materials Science. Michael was awarded 153 U.S. Patent Inventions and 137 Publications with IBM-TJ Watson Research Center and Intermec Technologies Corp. in the fields of Semiconductors, Fiber Optics, Cryogenics, Thin Film Vacuum Deposition and Radio Frequency Identification. Michael was a member of the Optical Society, Who's Who in Engineering, Knights of Columbus, North Salem Ambulance Corp, and the Emerald Society. He was also an Adjunct Professor at Stony Brook University. Michael is survived by his wife Patricia of 36 years; his 4 daughters, Maureen Brady Atinsky, Jennifer Fogle, Diana Brady Wright and Christina Trudell; 3 grandchildren, Michael John Wright, Kavic James Wright and Makenzie Brady Fogle. He also leaves behind 4 son-in-laws he considered sons: Lawrence Atinsky, Robert Fogle, Keith Wright and Paul-Jaymes Trudell. A sister, Nora Jacaruso and brothers, Gerald and Kenneth Brady, also survive him. Michael was predeceased by his beloved brother Patrick in 1994. We will all miss Michael's sense of humor, mathematical mind, unforgettable smile, blue eyes and his desire to be a part of everything in life. Visitation wll be at Beecher Funeral Home in Brewster, NY on July 4, 2002 from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. A funeral mass will be held at St. Lawrence O'Toole at 10 AM on July 5, 2002. Please call Beecher's at 845-279-3615 for further information regarding donations.

title: Russian Town's Heart Torn Out by Crash
description: The grief-stricken parents of the schoolchildren who died in a plane crash on Monday night moved like ghosts out of a white stone government building in this central Russian city.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Lottery Lifts School Aid
description: Lottery sales increased nearly $68 million this fiscal year, permitting the state to exceed its estimated contribution to education by $1.4 million. The state lottery commission said that Ohio brought in nearly $1.98 billion in sales in the year ending June 30, allowing the state to allocate $635.1 million to education. Ohio's recent participation in the nine-state Mega Millions game and the increasing popularity of the Super Lotto Plus jackpot contributed to the sales increase. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

description: MANHATTAN: WEST NILE VIRUS SURFACES

title: The Argonauts of 1776
description: ''You will see in a few days a Declaration setting forth the causes which have impelled us to this mighty revolution . . . .''

title: In the Arena League, Always Inside Looking Out
description: When two local professional football teams play on Saturday night, it will provide a through-the-looking-glass moment for fans.

title: Following the Flames At a Forest Fire Site
description: FIREFIGHTERS, particularly those who take on forest fires, are longtime users of Geographic Information Systems programs that marry database information with digital maps.

title: 3 Pakistanis Die Battling Group Linked To Al Qaeda
description: Four suspected members of Al Qaeda and three Pakistani police officers were killed today during a shootout in the rugged North-West Frontier Province, the second time in a week that Pakistani soldiers have died hunting suspected terrorists.

title: Man Charged in Terror Seeks to Meet Reporters
description: Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person charged in the Sept. 11 attacks, has asked the judge in the case to allow him to meet with reporters.

title: Prosecution And Defense Rest in Retrial Of Schwarz
description: Prosecutors and defense lawyers both completed the presentation of their evidence yesterday in the retrial of Charles Schwarz, the former police officer accused of taking part in the assault on Abner Louima. Jury deliberations are to begin next week.

title: Gifts to Sweeten a Sleep-Away Camp Summer
description: THE first two summers my two elder daughters spent in Maine, they said they agreed with my old-fashioned views about sleep-away camp. They said they fully supported my notion of bunks in rustic lakeside cabins devoid of modern conveniences like television, junk food and boys.

title: Marlin Holds Lead At Midpoint of Season
description: Sterling Marlin is definitely not one of stock car racing's young guns. He turned 45 on Sunday and goes way back in racing, to the days when he and his wife, Paula, would schedule most of their trips to racetracks in the dead of night. That way, they could sleep in the car and save money on a hotel room.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Poughkeepsie: Teenager Gets Jail In D.W.I.
description: A teenage boy has been sentenced to jail time for driving while intoxicated in an accident that killed his best friend, who was a passenger in the car. The accused, Christopher Smith, 18, of Red Hook, Brooklyn, had a blood-alcohol level over the legal limit during the Aug. 1 crash, the district attorney's office said. Although the victim's family asked the court not to impose jail time, Judge Gerald V. Hayes of Dutchess County Court sentenced Mr. Smith to 60 days in jail and five years' probation. Mr. Smith's friend, Andrew Byrne, 16, died after being propelled through a window in the crash. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: West Nile Virus Surfaces
description: The West Nile virus has surfaced in the city for the first time this year, Health Department officials said yesterday. The virus was discovered in a group of mosquitoes collected on June 25 in Saw Mill Marsh, Staten Island. The virus, which killed seven people in the New York metropolitan region in 1999, the first year it was found in the Western Hemisphere, has not been detected in humans in the city this year, but there have been reports of it in the region. To report a dead bird or standing water, New Yorkers can call (877) 968-4692 or visit the Health Department's Web site at nyc.gov/health. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Teaching Quilts How to Speak of Today's Pain
description: Lining the lobby of a Midtown tower, 65 quilts from around the world include richly colored, intricately sewn works as well as quilts with raw seams and even rawer themes: Victorian trim decorates photos of teenagers killed by gunfire; scraps of mattress ticking are appliqud with tiny jersey shirts. Gisela Hafer's ''Portraitvariationen II,'' above left, reflects her split self as an East German before and after the Berlin Wall came down. Joan Schultz's ''Cautionary Tale,'' above right, uses tape from earthquake sites near her home in California. Both women say they practice an art form that is increasingly international. The collection, assembled by the American Craft Museum, also reflects the merging of a craft and fine arts, said Ursula Ilse-Neuman, its curator. Some of the artists will speak on July 12. The show is open weekdays only (closed today) through Sept. 13 at UBS PaineWebber, 1285 Avenue of the Americas (52nd Street). DEBORAH BALDWIN

title: Back to Work for AmeriCorps
description: Today's fireworks and barbecues ought to put members of the House of Representatives in just the right patriotic mood to move forward with a bill reauthorizing AmeriCorps. The Citizen Service Act would increase funding for AmeriCorps and allow more Americans to partake of community service. A House committee approved the bill last month and the leadership should now bring it to the floor.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PINE, HELEN C.
description: PINE-Helen C. Happy Birthday, Muttie. Thanks for being you. Miss you every day. Love you always. Les

title: No Charges, But Plenty Of Concerns In Party Death
description: There was shock in this tightknit suburb in April after a 17-year-old student went into a coma; police officials said he had been punched by a classmate at an after-school party and fallen, fracturing his skull. There was sadness a week later when the student died and the authorities contemplated more serious charges against the classmate, who had already been charged with assault.

title: 14 of 19 U.S. Boats Advance at Henley
description: Amid drenching rains in Henley-on-Thames, England, 14 of the 19 United States boats competing yesterday advanced in the Henley Royal Regatta's format of straight knockout elimination heats.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Dell Opens Informational Kiosk
description: Dell Computer, the world's biggest direct seller of personal computers, opened an informational kiosk last week in its hometown of Austin, Tex., and plans to open 20 around the country in the next two months. The next two will open in Houston and Dallas. The kiosks, which will be placed in malls and shopping centers, are intended to give customers a chance to test Dell's products and services. To order the machines, however, potential customers need to place orders online or over the phone. Dell gets about 85 percent of its business from corporations, schools and governments, but is looking to increase direct sales to consumers. It has had some success -- consumer sales rose 26 percent in the first quarter compared with the year before. Shares in Dell rose 14 cents yesterday, to close at $24.68. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Economics, Politics and Vouchers
description: To the Editor:

title: Co-Star of 'The Osbournes' Undergoes Surgery for Cancer
description: Sharon Osbourne, the wife and manager of the rock star Ozzy Osbourne, who stars with her husband in the hit MTV family reality series ''The Osbournes,'' had surgery yesterday for a treatable form of cancer, a spokeswoman for the family said.

title: Sales Tax Defeats Income Tax in Tennessee Battle
description: The Tennessee Legislature ended a three-day-old government shutdown tonight by raising the sales tax, the state's main source of revenue.

title: The War Against Spam
description: To the Editor:

title: When City's an Oven, the Subway's a Broiler
description: The subway is a place of extremes. In a crowded city, it is more crowded. In a noisy city, it is deafening. In a smelly city, it is the source from which the original ferment seems to rise.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Compuware Profit Falls
description: The Compuware Corporation, a maker of software for mainframe computers, said yesterday that its fiscal first-quarter profit fell short of analysts' estimates because sales were less than expected. Earnings in the quarter ended June 30 were 5 cents to 6 cents a share on sales of $329 million to $341 million, the company said in statement. Compuware was expected to earn 7 cents on sales of $358 million, the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Compuware, based in Farmington Hills, Mich., is facing tougher competition from free or cheaper products made by I.B.M., analysts say.

title: Heat Gets the Best of Wells, but the Indians Don't
description: David Wells removed his cap as soon as he saw the Yankees' pitching coach, Mel Stottlemyre, walking to the mound in the fourth inning last night, and he held the cap at his side throughout the discussion, his shaved head gleaming with sweat. Maybe Wells listened to everything Stottlemyre told him, maybe he heard nothing. At the very least, Wells appreciated the chance to cool off.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Sunday and a news analysis article on Tuesday about remarks by Gov. George E. Pataki about a Sept. 11 memorial misstated the sponsor of the event where he spoke, a ceremony for victims' families at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. It was Give Your Voice, not the Coalition of 9/11 Families.

title: 100 Bottles of Beer in the Trash
description: New York City's programs to recycle plastic and glass were years in the making. But Mayor Michael Bloomberg abruptly suspended them this week as a budget-shaving measure. The change, imposed on people conditioned to recycle as automatically as they brush teeth, has triggered a crisis of conscience and left many New Yorkers cringing as they throw out milk jugs and beer bottles.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: LEANING TOWARD EMISSIONS BILL

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the daily performance of the stock market on Tuesday misstated how long Tyco International said it would be able to meet its debt payments. The company said it would pay down debts through November 2003, not through this coming November.

title: Audio to Go: Headphones Untethered
description: TECHNOLOGY has always affected the institution of marriage in fascinating ways. The earliest inventions brought couples closer together by buying them free time (like the washing machine, the microwave and the power mower). More recent advances have often had the opposite effect, breeding isolation and sometimes even conflict (like the remote control, the MP3 player and SportsIllustrated.com).

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Middletown: Silt Dumping Plan Opposed
description: The state environmental commissioner is objecting to the United States Navy's plan to dump silt with potentially carcinogenic PCB's in federal waters six miles off Sandy Hook. The silt would be dredged from alongside a pier in Middletown for the Naval Weapons Station Earle. The commissioner, Bradley Campbell, said that 78,000 cubic yards of the silt, about a quarter of the total, tested for PCB's at a rate of 123 parts per billion, or 10 parts above the permissible federal standard. Mr. Campbell and environmentalists want the silt disposed of on land, which would cost more. The Environmental Protection Agency's regional administrator has put the project on hold until July 10, when a federal judge is set to decide a similar case. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Let's be serious, not everybody looks at a murky, slimy, alligator-infested pond filled with golf course pesticide and fertilizer runoff and sees a business opportunity.''

title: Vivendi's Board Settles on Replacement for Chief
description: Ending days of rumors, Vivendi Universal named Jean-Ren Fourtou as its chairman and chief executive today, replacing Jean-Marie Messier, the ambitious would-be mogul who was forced out after his support on the company's board crumbled.

title: Finding Good Arms Close to Home
description: The search for high-quality arms has taken teams to new and exotic places over the last decade. The Chicago White Sox haven taken a more pedestrian journey, experimenting with their frustrated position players.

title: Taming Wild Things Under the Really Big Top
description: EVERYTHING tastes better out of doors, whether served under a clear blue sky or a canopy of twinkling stars. But gearing up for a feast is not always a picnic. Some new accouterments -- from a blue-light insect collector to a rolling water cooler -- can make dining alfresco a summer breeze.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Central Bank Raises Rates
description: Norway's central bank raised interest rates for the first time in almost two years on concern that pay increases will fuel inflation. The bank raised its benchmark deposit rate by half a point, to 7 percent, and suggested that it might raise rates further because inflation could exceed its 2.5 percent target in two years.

Pataki about a Sept. 11 memorial misstated the sponsor of the event where he spoke, a ceremony for victims' families at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. It was Give Your Voice, not the Coalition of 9/11 Families.

title: Learn the King's English (or Columbo's)
description: I AM viewing, for the fifth time, a multimedia CD-ROM with a video segment about a young English couple, Carol and Nigel. Carol informs her husband that she is ''just popping down to the shops'' to buy shampoo, then notices he is drooping with fever.

title: Chips of the Future, Wrought With Good Old Mechanics
description: FABRICATING computer chips is a complex, expensive process, all the more so as the semiconductor industry struggles to create ever faster circuits.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Concord Shares Plummet
description: The stock of Concord Communications plunged yesterday after the company issued a profit and revenue warning it attributed to recent ''disclosures from large U.S. corporations,'' which have affected information-technology spending. Shares in the company, based in Marlborough, Mass., which provides Internet-based performance analysis, closed down $3.31, or 22 percent, at $11.57 on the Nasdaq. Melissa Cruz, the chief executive, said customers had hesitated to place orders in the last week of June because they were afraid to make capital commitments amid the crisis in the markets caused by announcements from WorldCom, Tyco, Enron and Vivendi.

title: For Denver, a Film, a Latte, a Chat With the Director
description: For almost 30 years, Denver's movie buffs made do with eight movie screens for foreign and independent films. But since two theaters with a total of 12 screens for art films opened this spring, there are now 20 screens, and their theaters are promoting ways to enhance the moviegoing experience.

title: Corrections

Pataki about a Sept. 11 memorial misstated the sponsor of the event where he spoke, a ceremony for victims' families at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. It was Give Your Voice, not the Coalition of 9/11 Families.

title: Think Before You Scrub A Fragile L.C.D. Screen

My wife has all kinds of solvents that will remove the adhesive, but I'm afraid they will remove much more than that. What should I do?

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Government To Keep Utilities
description: Singapore's government will retain a majority stake in utilities and the airport and shed investments in the main port operator and biggest bank to enable the companies to expand beyond the island-state. Utilities are critical to the island's survival, Temasek Holdings, the government's investment arm, said as it released a charter on its role in some of the nation's biggest companies. Temasek will dilute stakes in other companies through share sales, mergers and acquisitions.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Jupiter May Leave Nasdaq
description: Jupiter Media Metrix Inc., whose reports on Web-site traffic once helped lift the stock of unprofitable Internet companies like Drkoop.com Inc., said yesterday that its shares might be removed from trading on the Nasdaq. Jupiter shares, which rose as high as $74 in 1999, have traded for less than $1 since February, falling below the minimum bid required by the Nasdaq. Media Metrix's reports were used by companies to attract investors and advertisers. Analysts including Mary Meeker of Morgan Stanley pointed to statistics on money-losing Internet companies like page views and ''stickiness,'' the amount of time spent on a site. Media Metrix acquired Jupiter Communications Inc. in 2000. Jupiter's directors approved a plan last week to sell off assets. The company, based in New York, has not had a profit since 1999, when it first sold shares to the public.

title: Blocks; In Downtown Brooklyn, Too Tall Suddenly Fits
description: UNDER the height limits for Downtown Brooklyn enacted last summer, buildings are measured in feet. It turns out that the height limits themselves, at least on one block, could be measured in months.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Independence Undone

title: VARCO BUYS ICO'S OIL FIELD SERVICES UNIT FOR $136 MILLION
description: Varco International Inc., the maker of oil-drilling equipment that operates in 49 nations, agreed yesterday to buy the oil-field-services arm of ICO Inc. for $136.7 million in cash and assumed debt. It was the second time Varco has agreed to buy the business. ICO's board rejected a $165 million offer recently, saying conditions would have reduced pretax profitability of the sale and produced a substantial tax burden and other liabilities. Since then, ICO shares have fallen 17 percent. Varco is adding ICO's well pipe inspection, coating and reconditioning services in North America, Asia and Europe to its line of oil field services. Both companies are based in Houston. Varco shares rose 38 cents, to $17.16, and ICO shares rose 24 cents, to $1.48.

title: Your Pie Chart, My Pie Recipe: Wirelessly Sharing a Printer
description: For most people setting up a home wireless network, sharing the household high-speed Internet connection among the family computers is the first goal after taking the base station out of the box. The next task is often giving everyone the ability to print on the wireless network. The WPS 11 Instant Wireless PrintServer from Linksys can simplify the process and even help you shed a cable or two.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Accident Kills 4 In Family
description: At least four members of a family of eight died after a swimming accident at Lake Isabella in Central California, about 50 miles northeast of Bakersfield. A spokesman for the Kern County Sheriff's Department speculated that the family had been on a sandbar when one child got into trouble, leading to an ill-fated rescue effort. Identities were being withheld, but the dead were identified as the parents, both 45, and two daughters, ages 8 and 12. A third daughter, 9, is missing, the authorities said, and a 5-year-old son is on life support in a hospital; two other sons, ages 12 and 14, did not attend the outing. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Mathis Loves Dallas; M.L.S. Another Story
description: Before the World Cup, Clint Mathis was one of the hottest American soccer players in the world. Forget the magazine covers, talks with Bayern Munich in Germany and Perugia in Italy held out the prospect the 25-year-old striker/midfielder would soon be leaving the MetroStars in a big-money transfer deal.

title: Yangon Journal; Trumpet the News: They've 2 White Elephants
description: In the sunshine its skin is a soft reddish brown. When it rains, it seems to turn a pale orange. Its name is Yaza Gaha Thiri Pissaya Gaza Yaza, which means ''Glorious Elephant King.''

title: Sports of The Times; Opposites Off the Court Meet on It
description: ONE woman won everything there was and had no endorsement income. The other wins nothing and pulls in about $10 million from commercial appeal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STUBENHAUS, JEROME
description: STUBENHAUS-Jerome. At age 77. Loving husband of Cheri. Devoted father of James (Beth) and Ellen (Andie). Adored grandfather of Jonathan and Sam. Dear brother of the late Harold and Martin Stubenhaus. Services Friday, July 5, 1 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite the LIRR), Great Neck, NY. title: Treated-Wood Precautions
description: AT the Home Depot in Decatur, Ga., the signs over stacks of pressure-treated lumber warn, ''Caution: Arsenic is in the pesticide applied to this wood.'' Arsenic is a poison known to cause cancer of the lungs, bladder and skin. Keith Forrester, a carpenter, paid little notice this week.

title: Agreement Would Allow Founder Of Hale House to Avoid Jail Term
description: With her head bowed and her hands clasped behind her, Lorraine E. Hale, the former president of the once-revered Harlem children's shelter that bears her name, pleaded guilty yesterday to felony grand larceny and admitted stealing thousands of dollars that had been donated to the charity.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: The Bronx: Three Shot By Man On Bicycle
description: A young man on a bicycle shot three people last evening in Mott Haven, the police said. About 7 p.m., the gunman shot a 19-year-old man in the neck and right shoulder, a 20-year-old man in the torso and a 24-year-old woman in the arm, the police said. All were taken to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center, where they were listed in critical condition last night. The gunman, who the police said was thought to be about 18, was chased by five people as he bicycled away after the shooting, at East 138th Street between Brook and St. Ann's Avenues, witnesses said. No arrests were made last night. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Corrections

He is John Fry, not Frye, and is chief executive of Fry's Electronics.

title: Isles Get Wiemer and Add Some Nastiness
description: The Islanders made what looked like a minor deal yesterday by sending the towering defenseman Branislav Mezei to the Florida Panthers in exchange for the journeyman center Jason Wiemer. But Wiemer is no ordinary journeyman center. Wiemer is a rambunctious journeyman center.

description: To the Editor:

title: Stewart Image And Company Built Upon It Take Battering
description: With three investigations under way into Martha Stewart's sale of shares of ImClone Systems, the price of having her at the helm of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia has become steeper.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Unlicensed Lawyer
description: Scores of criminal defendants in Erie County may be entitled to new trials or even to sue the government because their appointed public defender, Gustee Brown, was not licensed to practice law for more than a year. Mr. Brown did not pay the required annual $150 license fee in 2001. Mr. Brown, who could not be reached for comment, recently paid up and is back in good standing. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIEGELMEIER, ROBERT A.
description: ZIEGELMEIER - Robert A. Succumbed July 2, 2002 after elective surgery at New York University Medical Center. He was a graduate of Hotchkiss School and Columbia University. He served in the Intelligence Division of the Army in World War II. Owner and Chief Officer of Haggerty Millwork Corporation from 1949-2000. He received the prestigious Reinheimer's Award from the Architectural Woodworking Institute for dedicated service and achievements while serving as its Treasurer and on various committees. He also served on the Westchester County Construction Industry Board of Directors and the Westchester Council of Arts. He is survived by his loving wife Adele M. (Berbusse) Ziegelmeier, his children Regina Norum of Parkersburg, WV, Richard A. Ziegelmeier of Patterson, NY, Robert E. Ziegelmeier of Somers, NY and Rhonda Brooks of South Salem, NY. 11 grandchildren and two great grandchildren. His sons Robert and Richard along with his grandson Casey Ziegelmeier will carry on his business at Haggerty Millwork Corporation, formerly of Mount Kisco and now located in Poughkeepsie, NY. Friends and family may call from 3:00-5:00 P.M. and 7:009:00 P.M. on Friday, July 5th at Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home at 288 Main Street, Mount Kisco, New York (914) 666-4840. Service will be held at 10:00 AM on Saturday, July 6, 2002 at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, on Main Street, Mount Kisco, New York (914) 666-8058. Burial will be Saturday, July 6th at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. Donations to the Lighthouse in lieu of flowers: Lighthouse International, 111 East 59th Street, NY, NY 10022-1202.
