description: The annual selling rate of cars and light trucks in June was 16.6 million. Sales were down 1.5 percent compared with a year earlier.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Advanced Micro Lowers Forecast
description: Shares of Advanced Micro Devices fell 4.2 percent after the company, the world's second-biggest maker of personal-computer processors, said quarterly sales trailed a forecast reduced 15 days ago. Second-quarter sales were about $600 million, as much as 14 percent below the $620 million to $700 million range given June 18, Advanced Micro said in a statement. In April, the chairman, Jerry Sanders, predicted sales of as much as $900 million. Advanced Micro shares fell 37 cents, to $8.43; they have declined by 72 percent in the last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ADELE
description: GOLDSTEIN-Adele. Beloved wife of the late Matthew. Loving mother of Elaine and Steven Perlmutter, Carol and the late Jeffrey Goldstein, Steven and Marci Goldstein. Cherished grandmother of Alana, Jordan, Michael and Jaclyn. Services Friday, July 5, 2002, 10:15 a.m. at the Dix Hills Chapel of I.J. Morris, Inc., 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, Long Island.

title: Happy Ending for a Diner After a Mob Shootout
description: In the DreamWorks movie ''Road to Perdition,'' which opens next week, Tom Hanks and Jude Law play 1930's mobsters who first face off at the fictitious Englewood Diner in rural Illinois. The diner, famous for its peregrinations, has probably been moved more often than any other portable dining car, said Daniel Zilka, director of the American Diner Museum in Providence, R.I. The Englewood, built in 1941, was shifted around Massachusetts half a dozen times before the DreamWorks team spotted it on eBay, bought it for $35,000 and trucked it to Illinois. The diner's mahogany interior, said Dennis Gassner, the movie's production designer, suited the Depression-era plot. Sold twice again after the shoot, the Englewood rests in Eliot, Me., and is scheduled to open in the fall as the Down East Diner. ''We hope this is its permanent home now,'' said Andy Mantis, the manager of Down East. EVE M. KAHN

title: Avant-Garde Directors as Decorators
description: The room is a sculpture garden of chairs, one made from wire mesh and hanging from the ceiling, another doll-size and seemingly cemented to the floor, and a stainless steel sofa far too hard to sit on: chairs made for Einstein, Stalin and Kafka, and other figures from the imagination of the artist. All is silent except for murmuring voices, which seem to emerge from a storyboard scroll on the wall.

title: For Some Uptown Eagles, a Coming Out
description: It was a hot day to learn how to fly. But two of the four baby bald eagles that were brought to Inwood Hill Park on June 20 were doing just that yesterday, having been released on Sunday from their treehouse cage.

title: C'mon, Computer, Light My Fireworks
description: WHEN the sun sets on another Fourth of July, a phrase coined by Francis Scott Key takes on a meaning that he never intended. His ''rockets' red glare'' was a powerful reference to warfare. But to a modern audience, it describes the oooh and ahhh moments of a holiday fireworks display.

title: Economic Scene; New chips can keep a tight rein on consumers, even after they buy a product.
description: AS chips get cheaper, products get smarter. Sometimes they can get too smart for their own good.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FPL GROUP, Juno Beach, Fla., owner of Florida's largest utility, said it had secured $425 million in loans to cover the costs of building a 535-megawatt natural gas power plant in Johnston, R. I. The electricity, enough to power 535,000 homes, will be sold into the New England Power Pool.

title: Stanley Works Faulted Again By 2 Officials Of Connecticut
description: Stanley Works is misleading shareholders again as it seeks their approval, in a second vote, to acquire a Bermuda address as part of a strategy to avoid paying taxes in the United States, the attorney general and the treasurer of Connecticut said yesterday.

title: With Patriotism Renewed, July 4 Hits a Deeper Chord
description: Had terrorists not slammed jets into the World Trade Center last September, Beth and Pat Mahoney would have been in the Irish countryside for the Fourth of July. Instead, the Mahoneys, from Plano, Tex., were in muggy Times Square yesterday, waiting to buy tickets to a Broadway show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERGARI, BOHN
description: VERGARI-Bohn. The partners and employees of Herbert Mines Associates mourn the passing of Bohn Vergari, husband of our partner, Jane Vergari. Our deepest condolences to his children, Bohn Jr. and Carl Andrew, and to his parents and family members. Bohn was a warm, supportive and talented human being. We will miss him.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Girl Escapes Police, Briefly
description: A teenage girl who is a suspect in an armed robbery at a Jackson Heights jewelry store slipped out of her handcuffs and walked away from police custody on Tuesday night but was recaptured yesterday, the police said. The prisoner, Jennifer Marin, 16, had been taken to Elmhurst Hospital Center emergency room for treatment of heroin addiction, but escaped around 11 p.m., the police said. She was found at 10 a.m. yesterday in front of a relative's residence and taken into custody, the police said. The officer charged with safeguarding her will be disciplined after an investigation, the police said. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINIKOFF, SAMSON
description: WINIKOFF-Samson, 86. Child prodigy/educator, beloved husband, brother, father, grandfather. Deeply missed.

title: Americans Playing Catch-Up At Majors
description: In six of the last seven years, the United States Women's Open has been won by a foreign-born player. Juli Inkster, the last American to win the Open (1999), was asked on the eve of this tournament why American players have not been major factors in recent majors.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Speechworks To Cut Jobs
description: SpeechWorks International Inc., a maker of voice-recognition software, said it would eliminate 17 percent of its work force and trim expenses by 20 percent as it struggles to maintain sales. The work force reduction will cost about $2 million in the third quarter and will save as much as $15 million a year, SpeechWorks said in a statement. Customers include America Online, Microsoft and United Airlines.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Litchfield: Jail In Seduction Case
description: Francesca Romaniello, 29, of Winsted, was sentenced Tuesday to seven years in prison after pleading guilty to risk of injury to a minor. She was accused of enticing a 15-year-old girl into a sexual relationship last summer by posing as a 16-year-old boy. Ms. Romaniello was ordered to serve one year, followed by 10 years of probation, the state's attorney's office said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

He is Roger Daltrey, not Daltry. The article also misspelled the surname of the father of the Who's drummer, Zak Starkey, in some copies. He is Ringo Starr, not Star.

title: Signs of Growth in Economic Indicators
description: The services sector grew for a fifth consecutive month in June but at a slower pace, while factory orders in May rose more than expected, according to reports released yesterday. In addition, weekly jobless claims dropped to their lowest level since March 2001, the government said.

Eastern Europe chased out its Communist dictators. In Asia, countries like South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand are building new democracies. Africans in increasing numbers are exchanging despots for newly elected governments.

The first Amelia Island Chamber Music Festival had a two-week, 15-concert run, finished in the black and sold every ticket.

title: A Screen That Tags Along On Trips to the Water Cooler
description: Feeling office wanderlust? Now you can take your computer monitor with you. A new monitor that went on the market late last month is designed to be picked up and toted around the office while the PC stays at the desk. With a 10-inch touchscreen, Viewsonic's Airpanel 100 wireless monitor is not unlike a tablet computer or even an extra-large remote control, only in this case what you are controlling from across the cubicle farm is a desktop machine rather than a TV.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Genetics Rule Considered
description: Russia is considering a ban on genetically modified corn and soybean imports from the United States, according to a report on the Interfax news agency, citing a deputy agriculture minister. The ban would begin on Oct. 1, when a new law on the state registration of genetically modified products takes effect. The ban would be lifted as products are registered, said the minister, Sergei Dankvert. He also said that separate negotiations would be held with the United States regarding meat produced from animals raised on genetically modified feed. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

description: The Xerox Corporation's much publicized accounting problems cost the company more than a $10 million fine and a depressed share price.

title: Tracking an Outbreak Minute by Minute
description: COMPUTER networks have been used for years by public health officials to monitor outbreaks of disease. Typically, the networks compile a database of reports about sick patients from doctors or other health care workers and look for patterns of illness or symptoms. But the reporting and compiling can take a day or more, delaying detection of an outbreak.

description: The Justice Department has approved two of the four major components of a new state law that radically changes the way the city's public schools are run, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | Washington: New Low For Voters
description: Voter turnout for the spring primaries hit a new low, according to the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, a nonpartisan research group. The committee found turnout in the 16 states that had statewide primaries in both major parties averaged 16.2 percent of those eligible to vote, down from 17.6 percent in 1998. Even states with competitive races saw a decline, the committee found.

description: Major League Soccer waited for Independence Day to announce that its seventh All-Star Game would be a celebration of American soccer.

title: So Gallantly Streaming In Baked-On Ceramic
description: Oh, say, can you name the woman who sewed the Star-Spangled Banner, the flag that inspired Francis Scott Key to write the national anthem? No, it was not Betsy Ross. It was Mary Young Pickersgill, a professional flag maker who was hired by the United States Army to create a 30-by-42-foot flag in 1813. A year later, it flew over Fort McHenry during the Battle of Baltimore, inspiring Key to write the poem that became the anthem. Since 1927, Pickersgill's 1793 harborside house has been open to the public as the privately financed Star-Spangled Banner Flag House, and it is now expanding. On June 17, ground was broken for a $3.5 million War of 1812 Museum, designed as an extension of the house by RCG Architects of Baltimore. Its centerpiece will be a 30-by-42-foot glass wall with a baked-on ceramic pattern of 15 broad stripes and 15 bright stars. The Pickersgill flag belongs to the Smithsonian Institution, which is restoring it. There was talk of sewing a copy for the Baltimore museum, said Jonathan Fishman, the lead architect for RCG, but museums don't usually stock copies.

title: First Amendment No Shield For Church in Abuse Cases
description: Over the nine years since Leland White sued the Roman Catholic church in Rhode Island seeking damages, asserting that his parish priest sexually abused him in 1970, eight other men have lodged similar accusations against the same priest, who has pleaded guilty to criminal abuse charges. But the Diocese of Providence has given little quarter.

title: Netscape Unveils Mozilla 1.0, Another Window on the Web
description: In early 1998, Netscape Communications made the source code of its browser publicly available and created the Mozilla project, in which Netscape programmers and volunteers would use the code as the basis for what they hoped would be the ultimate browser. More than four years later, Mozilla 1.0 has finally been released.

title: The Treehouse as an Art Form And a Lot of Fun
description: The architect Thomas Pfifer was for years associated with Richard Meier. Now on his own, he has undertaken big jobs, including major new projects at the North Carolina Museum of Art in Raleigh and at Castle Clinton in Battery Park. But Mr. Pfifer, 49, is also a father of two and can think small. He describes the minimalist playhouse of wood and woven steel scrim, below, which he created this year for a family with a home on the South Shore of Long Island, as a garden folly. It seems to change, he said, with the time of day, the season and the color of the light, and its walls shift in the wind like a sail. The top two slabs, made of boatlike mahogany, are 12 by 16 feet and float on steel cables that climb to 18 feet. The ground floor is open, the middle level slightly enclosed, and the top, he said, is ''total release.'' Children love the ladders and trapdoors, while grown-ups scramble to the observation deck for postcard views of the lighthouse across Great South Bay on Fire Island. DEBORAH BALDWIN

title: Schizophrenia May Be Tied To 2 Genes, Research Finds
description: Despite years of false leads, setbacks and unsustained claims, researchers hope they are now starting to close in on some of the genes that go awry in schizophrenia, a devastating mental disease that affects two million Americans. Discovery of such genes would illuminate the fundamental mechanisms of the disease and might lead to new treatments.

description: Despite the unease in the air the inchoate threats of new terrorist attacks, the jitteriness at the airports, the State Department's admonition to Americans to ''remain vigilant'' -- Tom Haley, an American photographer who lives in France, said today that he was not particularly concerned about possible anti-American violence on July 4.

description: CORN FALLS. Corn prices fell for a second day as cooler weather in the Midwest eased concerns about crop losses. In Chicago, corn for delivery in December fell 4.25 cents, or 1.7 percent, to $2.4175 a bushel.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Smoking Tax May Rise
description: The State House of Representatives voted to raise the cigarette tax 50 cents a pack to help close a budget gap. The new tax, of $1.25, would be among the highest in the nation. The Senate is expected to approve the measure next week. The tax increase will help avert cuts in state revenue sharing to counties and municipalities.

description: If there weren't already enough choices for how best to enjoy music on the go, two major names in data storage electronics, Imation and TEAC, are offering new spins on the mini rewritable compact disc.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE RULES FOR ECHOSTAR IN PATENT CASE
description: The EchoStar Communications Corporation said a federal judge ruled yesterday that it did not infringe patents of Gemstar-TV Guide International Inc., the second such ruling in two weeks over on-screen program guides. EchoStar said that Judge Lacy H. Thornburg in Asheville, N.C., ruled that none of its current products infringed three Gemstar patents for program guide features. He requested more information before ruling on an EchoStar product that is no longer in production.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO DECLINES. The euro fell against the dollar as reports indicated a stronger recovery in the United States than in Europe. In New York, the euro settled at 98 cents, down from 98.41 cents on Tuesday.

title: Floats for Pools of All Sizes And the Pools for Them
description: Quality Inflatables offers almost 100 styles of inflatable pool toys, floats and tubes. The pillow back float, $6.95 (above), is 54 by 48 inches and comes in neon-pink or green. Jim Winters, a retired tugboat captain and an owner of the company, said that the float is also suitable for the lawn or patio. Other styles include a multicolor 78-inch fish-shape float ($6.49) and one that moves around the pool -- as long as its occupant keep pedaling ($14.95). A hand pump for the floats is $4.95. The company also sells aboveground pools from $519.95 for one that is 18 feet across and 3 feet deep to $1,195.95 for one 24 feet across and 4 feet deep; www.qualityinflatable.com, or (310) 257-9400. title: Alice Stewart, 95; Linked X-Rays to Diseases
description: Dr. Alice M. Stewart, an epidemiologist who first demonstrated the link between X-rays of pregnant women and disease in their children, a finding that changed medical practice, died on June 23 in Oxford, England. A resident of the countryside outside Oxford, she was 95.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Democrats Lose Map Fight
description: A panel of three federal judges has approved a new map of Congressional districts, rejecting Democratic charges of illegal gerrymandering by the Republican-controlled legislature. Republicans hold a 15-8 advantage in the delegation, and they expect two more seats under the new map.

title: Philadelphia's Most Famous Tenant Gets Room to Stretch Its Clapper
description: When Bernard Cywinski, an architect in Philadelphia, was asked to design a home in that city's historic district a few years ago for a client in cramped quarters, the wish list was pretty standard: more space, higher ceilings, a better view. The client, however, wasn't standard. It was the Liberty Bell.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Clerics Offended, Arrest Ordered
description: A court in the western city of Hamedan issued an arrest warrant for a politician who called on Muslims not to follow clergymen blindly, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. Hashem Aghajari's remarks set off such anger among both reformist and hard-line clerics that one prominent clergyman compared him to the British author Salman Rushdie, whose book ''The Satanic Verses,'' deemed insulting to Islam by some Muslims, prompted the Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini to issue an edict in 1989 calling for his killing. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest Rating Might Be Lowered Again
description: Moody's Investors Service, which rates about $26 billion in debt issued by Qwest Communications International and its subsidiaries as junk bonds, said yesterday that it might downgrade the securities even further. Moody's said its concerns included Qwest's ability to sell its telephone directories business quickly for a good price; the uncertainty surrounding the investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission of Qwest's accounting practices; and Qwest's operating outlook given industry conditions. As a result, Moody's said, Qwest might not be able to repay $3.4 billion in bank loans due next May. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Swiss Tell of Controller Error Before Air Crash
description: Swiss air traffic officials acknowledged today that a collision alarm system in their control network was out of operation and that one of two crucial controllers had taken a break at the time of a midair crash that killed 71 people on Monday night.

title: New Jersey Buys Time For a Budget Full of Risk
description: The budget adopted by the Legislature on Tuesday allows Gov. James E. McGreevey to claim credit for closing a projected multibillion-dollar deficit without resorting to the kinds of tax increases that doomed his Democratic predecessor, Jim Florio, to a single term.

title: Critic's Notebook; Off to the Fjords, Cellos in Hand
description: Discovering the Risor Festival of Chamber Music, held in this small coastal town of fishing boats and wood-framed houses situated between two gaping fjords in southeast Norway, is like stumbling upon a fabulous little out-of-the-way restaurant that you are almost reluctant to tell people about for fear it will be overrun and lose its character. But after experiencing four days here last week, a whirlwind of music, music and more music, with time out for a harbor cruise, a hilltop bike ride and some elegant meals, I am professionally compelled to share my excitement and spread the news.

title: Picking the Right Wine With the Help of a Hand-Held
description: IN any decent wine shop, the rows of costly bottles with confusing or obscure labels can seem as intimidating as they are alluring. Restaurants, where the wine lists lack even the labels that might serve as visual signposts, are even more challenging.

Wonderful mother of Vivian Zelvin, Alfred, Richard & Douglas Shore. description: Systemax Inc., a seller of personal computers and related supplies, said Tuesday that it would cut 50 employees as it combines two call and distribution centers to reduce costs. The centers are in Port Washington, N.Y., where the company is based. Systemax is also discontinuing the development of a software system.

title: Furniture to Complement the Almost Outdoors
description: THE right furniture helps make the screened porch an extra living room -- or an extra den, playroom or dining room. And nothing is more summery than a porch swing. Ikea's version (pictured on Page 1) was designed by Niels Gammelgaard of Sweden for the store's PS summer collection. It costs $499. For store locations, (800) 434-4532 or www.ikea.com. And for sitting still, Pier 1 has a 53-inch-long settee (top right), part of the Samba group of rattan furniture, for $400. Cushions in an off-white basketweave fabric over foam are $100 for a set of two (with feathers, $175). A matching armchair is $250. For more information: (800) 245-4595 or www.pier1.com. Sunset Cove rattan furniture is a new take on classic 1940's porch furniture. The 55-inch-long settee (left) costs $679; the set of cushions covered in cotton with a tropical print is $199. There is also a matching armchair for $499, an ottoman for $209 and an end table for $329. All from L. L. Bean, (800) 441-5713 or www.llbean.com. A more modern-looking high-backed wicker chair (right) is $139; its matching ottoman is $40. The designer is Carl Ojerstam of Sweden; the set can be found at Ikea stores. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: World Briefing | Europe: Hungary: Opposition Leader Quits
description: The country's struggle to come to terms with its Communist past claimed its first senior political victim when the leader of the main opposition party, Fidesz, resigned after confirming news reports that his father had been a Communist secret police informer. The leader, Zoltan Pokorni, had called last month for Prime Minister Peter Medgyessy to resign after Mr. Medgyessy admitted that he had been a Communist counterintelligence agent. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: U.S. Describes Ground Fire From Site in Afghan Village
description: The American air assault against targets in a string of villages in southern Afghanistan on Monday that residents say killed 40 civilians and injured 100 was the culmination of a larger, weeks-long mission to kill or capture pockets of dug-in Taliban fighters, Pentagon officials said today.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Treason Trial For Scientists
description: A prominent oceanographer and his deputy went on trial in Vladivostok, accused of treason for exporting acoustic equipment to China. Vladimir Shchurov, the director of the Pacific Oceanographic Institute, and his deputy, Yuri Khovorstov, were accused in August 1999 of trying to smuggle the equipment and technical documents, which the Federal Security Service said could be used in weapons production. The trial, being conducted in secret, is one of several treason cases brought in recent years against scientists and journalists for disclosing information that their supporters say is publicly available. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: New Tension Over Kashmir
description: Foreign Minister Yashwant Sinha said that after a drop, the infiltration of Islamic militants into Kashmir from Pakistani territory ''has gone back to earlier levels'' despite President Pervez Musharraf's pledge to stop it. He said India would make ''whatever appropriate responses are necessary.'' The Defense Ministry says it has caught three groups of infiltrators since June 24, killing nine of them. Pakistan denies any infiltration is taking place; India says Pakistan is providing heavy military cover to help militants sneak into India. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

That same day, a bidder broke records for an American flag at auction, paying $163,500 -- more than double the estimate -- for a hand-sewn Grand Union made around 1800.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILK, ELLIOTT
description: WILK-Elliott. The staff, the management and the Board of Directors of The Legal Aid Society mourn the loss of our beloved friend. As a Legal Aid Attorney in the Criminal Defense Division during the late 1960s and early 1970s, Elliott was a passionate advocate for his clients. Thereafter, he was a thoughtful and compassionate judge. He wrote landmark decisions on foster care and homelessness issues, always treating our clients with the respect and dignity they deserve. Elliott was a friend to many at the Society and he will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his wife Betty Levinson, a former Legal Aid Criminal Defense attorney, and to his sons, Daniel and David. Daniel L. Greenberg, President and Attorney-In-Chief

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: NORTH KOREA: WARM WORDS FOLLOW BULLETS The government called for dialogue in keeping with a joint communique signed by the two Koreas on July 4, 1972. The anniversary statement by the North's Committee for Peaceful Reunification of the Fatherland, reported by the official Korea Central News Agency, promised "every effort to proceed smoothly with dialogue and cooperation." It did not mention the naval skirmish last Saturday in the Yellow Sea in which 4 South Koreans were killed and 19 wounded. Nonetheless, it appeared to be an effort to reduce tensions caused by the episode, in which each side accuses the other of firing first.

title: Starting a New Cycle With the Youthfulness of Puccini

That's another feat. In practice, though, it adds up to exhilarating but uneven performances. On the one hand, you have all the stereotypes of low-budget opera: the aging leading man in the ill-fitting wig, feedback from the mikes at inopportune moments. On the other hand, you have a sense, albeit blurred, of the kind of excitement that makes opera lovers love opera.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Forecast Increased
description: The Bank of Korea forecast that the South Korean economy would grow 6.5 percent this year rather than the 5.7 percent that it had forecast earlier. The bank issued the more optimistic forecast even though Korea's currency, the won, is at its highest level since December 2000. Park Seung, governor of the Bank of Korea, said Korean products could still compete effectively abroad at slightly higher prices caused by the rising value of the won because Japanese products also cost more abroad with the yen also going up in value. title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: No Mercy For Killer Doctor
description: Harold Shipman, the 55-year-old country doctor who murdered 15 patients and is suspected of killing dozens more, will spend the rest of his life in prison, the government said. ''These were the most heinous of offenses and the grossest breach of the duty of trust he owed as a doctor to all the victims,'' said Home Secretary David Blunkett, who has the power to determine the length of Dr. Shipman's life sentence, adding that ''nothing less than a whole life tariff should apply in this case.'' Dr. Shipman was convicted in 2000; under British law, the case will be reviewed by the Home Office after 25 years. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Wimbledon Play Date For Williams Sisters
description: Serena Williams will face her sister Venus tomorrow in the Wimbledon women's final. In defeating Amlie Mauresmo in straight sets yesterday, Serena took the No. 1 world ranking from Venus, who advanced with a straight-set victory over Justine Henin. This will be the third all-Williams final in four tennis majors.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Ford To Open Car Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company will open a $150 million factory in Vsevolozhsk, Russia, next week to cut car prices, which are inflated by import duties. Oksana Khartonuk, a spokeswoman for Ford in Russia, said the factory would produce 8,000 Ford Focus models this year and would increase that to about 10,000 cars in 2003. The move is a sign that efforts by President Vladimir V. Putin to attract foreign investors are starting to pay off, as the country seeks to increase jobs and scrap Soviet-era factory technology.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Warm Words Follow Bullets
description: The government called for dialogue in keeping with a joint communiqu signed by the two Koreas on July 4, 1972. The anniversary statement by the North's Committee for Peaceful Reunification of the Fatherland, reported by the official Korea Central News Agency, promised ''every effort to proceed smoothly with dialogue and cooperation.'' It did not mention the naval skirmish last Saturday in the Yellow Sea in which 4 South Koreans were killed and 19 wounded. Nonetheless, it appeared to be an effort to reduce tensions caused by the episode, in which each side accuses the other of firing first. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: City Hall Goes to War
description: Americans have always looked to the federal government for protection from enemies abroad. But the terrorists who attacked on Sept. 11 did not strike from outside. They met in San Diego parks, trained in Florida flight schools and launched their operations from domestic airports. This new enemy lives among us and attacks from our own backyard. It is therefore crucial that antiterrorism efforts include local authorities.

title: The Making of a Partnership With Magic in It
description: With American Ballet Theater's spring season drawing to a close this weekend, it was tempting to take a slightly longer view of a new cast in ''Swan Lake'' on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The evening's stars, Paloma Herrera and Marcelo Gomes, were magical in the roles of Odette-Odile and the prince who falls in love with the good swan queen and her evil twin. This has been a terrific season for both dancers, who are well on their way toward becoming an inspired ballet partnership.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Radio Free Europe Pulls Plug
description: A half-century after its first broadcast to what was then Communist Czechoslovakia, Radio Free Europe has announced that it will end its Czech-language broadcasts on Sept. 30, after the ending of its Hungarian service in 1993 and its Polish broadcasts in 1997. Radio Free Europe, based in Prague, said money saved by ending the Czech broadcasts would be used to expand programs aimed at Central Asia, Iraq and Iran. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: The Cycle of Revenge Can Be Broken
description: We are all capable of learning hatred even the kind of hatred that produces suicide bombers. If conditions are ripe, and if no steps are regularly taken to inoculate us against this all too common human poison, it can make anyone kill without remorse. It is only by accepting this human truth that we can turn back violence in places like the Middle East today, as it was turned back in my homeland, South Africa, a decade ago.

A government official, Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, said one option was to reinstate the declaration of a military emergency that prevailed in Aceh from 1988 to 1998. The government and the rebels agreed in May to talk, but violence has continued. Dian Saputra (NYT)

description: ZIEGELMEIER - Robert A. Succumbed July 2, 2002 after elective surgery at New York University Medical Center. He was a graduate of Hotchkiss School and Columbia University. He served in the Intelligence Division of the Army in World War II. Owner and Chief Officer of Haggerty Millwork Corporation from 1949-2000. He received the prestigious Reinheimer's Award from the Architectural Woodworking Institute for dedicated service and achievements while serving as its Treasurer and on various committees. He also served on the Westchester County Construction Industry Board of Directors and the Westchester Council of Arts. He is survived by his loving wife Adele M. (Berbusse) Ziegelmeier, his children Regina Norum of Parkersburg, WV, Richard A. Ziegelmeier of Patterson, NY, Robert E. Ziegelmeier of Somers, NY and Rhonda Brooks of South Salem, NY. 11 grandchildren and two great grandchildren. His sons Robert and Richard along with his grandson Casey Ziegelmeier will carry on his business at Haggerty Millwork Corporation, formerly of Mount Kisco and now located in Poughkeepsie, NY. Friends and family may call from 3:00-5:00 P.M. and 7:009:00 P.M. on Friday, July 5th at Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home at 288 Main Street, Mount Kisco, New York (914) 666-4840. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Financing Eased On Acquisitions
description: Trying to bolster its privatization program, India said yesterday that it would permit companies that take over government stakes in businesses to finance the acquisitions, and the subsequent buybacks of publicly held shares, through external commercial borrowings. Under the country's takeover laws, a company that acquires a 15 percent or higher stake in a state-owned company must offer to buy an additional 20 percent from the remaining public shareholders. In recent months, privatization has gathered steam and has led to the sale of controlling stakes in India's largest overseas long distance provider, an oil marketing firm and a large automaker. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Apologies For Enron Comparison
description: The European Union has apologized to the Italian government for suggesting that its budget management tactics were similar to those used by Enron. ''In the opinion of the commission, no link can be established between the new rules on the treatment of securitization transactions and the recent accounting behavior of some international companies,'' the European Union's monetary commissioner, Pedro Solbes, above, said in a note to Italy's economy minister, Giulio Tremonti. On Wednesday, the union's statistics office said that asset-backed bonds and bonds backed by lottery tickets sold last year by Italy count as borrowing. The office's director compared their use for deficit reduction to Enron-style accounting, the Financial Times reported. ''The Enron comparison was offensive,'' Mr. Tremonti said.

Mrs. Hayes was born in New Jersey, graduated from Manhasset High, L.I., and Blackstone College, VA. Her husband, Richard R. Hayes, to whom she was married for 47 years, survives her. title: 36 Hours | Honolulu
description: SOME see Honolulu as a stop on the way to more glamorous destinations. But Hawaii's capital has a special history and it comes to life on practically every corner. Excellent Asian art collections, theaters that bubble with mainland and local productions, and a cuisine that varies from Pacific Rim to pot roast bespeak the city's ethnic diversity and its place at the crossroads of the Pacific. And how many other American cities have an actual palace in the middle of town? The exuberant clear skies and plumeria-tinged trade breezes of summer make it a delightful time to visit. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Settlement Houses Merge
description: Two of Europe's leading stock and bond settlement houses, Euroclear and Crest, said yesterday that they would merge to form the continent's biggest settlement system. Euroclear, based in Brussels, will control the combined group, in which Crest, based in London, will have a 19 percent stake. The new entity will be based in Brussels and take the Euroclear name. The deal will add to pressures on rival European stock markets to advance their own oft-delayed plans for a pan-European market. Euroclear's nearest rival is Clearstream, which is owned by the Deutsche Brse in Frankfurt. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: 'Just Drive,' Said the Road, And the Car Responded
description: IT was like a dream: the sun hung low over the Catskills, bathing hilly pastures in a warm Provenal glow. The road unfurled in a clear path of asphalt ribbon through a swath of brand new leafy green. The car's 24-valve engine hummed along with unflappable poise, taking hill after hill, carving curve after thrilling curve. My mind floated somewhere above the tree line and I rolled down the windows and let the early summer air blast through. I inhaled deeply and with great satisfaction and wondered: Is there a highway more perfect than this?

title: Seeing Red On Purpose
description: Selecting a color is often a car buyer's most daunting decision. Now, buyers may also have to choose their car's window glass color. Glass in vibrant hues well beyond the gray or green tints of the last decade is emerging as the next new fashion in automotive design.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Banks Hold Interest Rates Steady
description: The European and British central banks held interest rates steady for the eighth consecutive month as European economists remained skeptical about the prospects for a dramatic recovery from a slowdown and falling stock markets. The decision by the European Central Bank in Frankfurt to leave its benchmark borrowing rate for the 12-nation euro currency zone at 3.25 percent checked the euro's rise against the dollar. The Bank of England left its base rate at 4 percent. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLAVITO, WILLIAM V.
description: COLAVITO-William V. Age 74, of Roslyn Heights, passed away on July 3, 2002. Beloved husband of Madeline. Devoted father of Nick (Elaine), Terry DeMaria (Bob), Bill (Terri), and Steve (Katie). Cherished grandfather of Danielle, Bobby, Kristen, Nicky, Michelle, Jenny, Brittany, Kaleigh, Kimberly, Lauren and Ashley. Reposing at the Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Monday 11am, St. Mary's RC Church, Roslyn.

title: Los Angeles Airport Gunman Slays 2 and Is Killed by Guard
description: A man armed with two handguns and a knife killed two people today and injured several more in the main international ticketing area at Los Angeles International Airport before one El Al airline security guard seized him and another shot him dead.

title: Best Friends Who Are Also Worst Enemies Struggle in a Web of Emotions
description: Sandra Goldbacher's small, psychologically savvy film ''Me Without You'' is the story of a toxic friendship, established in early childhood, whose poisons continue to circulate and infect both partners well into their adult lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, BELLE
description: BAKER-Belle. On July 3, 2002. Beloved wife of Marvin. Devoted mother of Bill and Robin Baker, Penny and Michael Horgan, Laurie and Drew Rayman and Melissa Baker. Cherished grandmother of Max, Matthew, Zachary, Hayley. Loving sister of Jean Mascia and Sam Abrams. A gracious lady who loved and was loved by all who knew her. She will forever be in our hearts. Service Sunday, July 7th, 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Malawi: President Will Need New Job
description: Parliament rejected a constitutional amendment that would have eliminated presidential term limits. The proposed change, which fell three votes short of adoption, was supported by allies of President Bakili Muluzi, who must retire after his second five-year term ends in 2004. Critics describe the measure as a threat to democracy. Malawi emerged from 30 years of dictatorship in 1994 when Mr. Muluzi was elected in the country's first multiparty election. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Antidrug Campaign Keeps Ogilvy & Mather
description: In a surprise decision, the White House Office of National Drug Control Policy has kept the New York office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group, as its agency for media services, research and strategy. Ogilvy has handled the assignments, with billings estimated at $152 million, since December 1998.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights. ++ means discounted tickets were at the TKTS booth for last Friday night only.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Pinochet Quits Senate
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, 86 and increasingly ill, has resigned from the lifetime seat in the Senate that he established for himself when his 17-year dictatorship ended in 1990. His action came just days after the Supreme Court ruled that he was suffering from a state of dementia so severe that he is unable to stand trial for human rights abuses that occurred while he was in power. During the long legal battle that preceded the ruling General Pinochet's opponents argued that if he was incapable of facing a trial he was also unfit to hold public office. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Most of Field Struggles, Except for Three at Top
description: Even in calm weather, the first day of the United States Women's Open was no Fourth of July picnic.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BANKS HOLD INTEREST RATES STEADY The European and British central banks held interest rates steady for the eighth consecutive month as European economists remained skeptical about the prospects for a dramatic recovery from a slowdown and falling stock markets. The decision by the European Central Bank in Frankfurt to leave its benchmark borrowing rate for the 12-nation euro currency zone at 3.25 percent checked the euro's rise against the dollar. The Bank of England left its base rate at 4 percent.

title: Greece Reports First Breakthrough Against Terrorist Group That Killed C.I.A. Agent in '75
description: The Greek police announced their first breakthrough today in an inquiry into November 17, a terror group sought by the United States since the killing of a C.I.A. station chief here in 1975.

title: A Force in the House, a Soft Voice Back Home; An Upstate Conservative Republican Is Gaining National Prominence
description: Representative Thomas M. Reynolds seems strangely out of place within New York's Congressional delegation -- at first glance, anyway.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: BAE's Share Of Deal Revised
description: The European arms contractor, BAE Systems, said its share of an order to make radios for the United States military might be worth as much as $4 billion over the 20-year program, more than previous estimates. BAE is part of a group of companies led by the Boeing Company that have been chosen to supply new radios that will permit troops to transmit voice, data and video information more quickly, the company said in an e-mailed statement. The Defense Department has said orders may be worth $2 billion through 2008, the end of the program's first phase. That phase is expected to deliver more than 100,000 radios to the Army and Air Force, BAE said.

title: Capt. Ray Goldbach, Executive Assistant to Fire Commissioner
description: PAUL RADENBERG: Today's date is Oct. 24, 2001. I'm Paul Radenberg, Fire Department City of New York. The time is now 10:47 hours. Also present is Assistant Commissioner James Drury. We are conducting an interview with Capt. Ray Goldbach, executive assistant to Commissioner Von Essen. This interview is being conducted at fire department headquarters in relation to the events of the morning of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: U.S. PLAN FOR IRAQ IS SAID TO INCLUDE ATTACK ON 3 SIDES
description: An American military planning document calls for air, land and sea-based forces to attack Iraq from three directions -- the north, south and west -- in a campaign to topple President Saddam Hussein, according to a person familiar with the document.

title: Sports of The Times; Thoughts of Security, And Hydration, Too
description: WE had tickets to the Yankee game today -- my two boys, my husband and me -- and my husband, Lee, said, 'Do you think we should really go?' '' Raffaela Capozza, a homemaker from New Haven, recalled yesterday. ''Everybody's saying: 'Stay home. You don't know what the terrorists might be planning.' ''

title: Shareholder Group Sues Over Accounting at Reed Elsevier
description: Reed Elsevier, the Dutch half of the largest publisher of scientific journals, is being taken to court by a shareholder interest group contesting how the company accounted for takeover costs last year.

title: Facing Up to the Housing Crisis
description: Congress set out 50 years ago to alleviate a crippling national housing shortage that had forced American families to double up with relatives or take their chances in dangerous, substandard dwellings. The Federal Housing Act of 1949 never reached the ambitious goal of securing ''a decent home and suitable living environment for every American family.'' But the law and initiatives that followed put government at the very center of the housing business and created livable rental units for poor and working-class people. Federally backed mortgage programs made homeowners out of millions who would otherwise have spent their lives among the rent-poor.

title: One Poor Inning Renders Mets' Late Rally Moot
description: The Mets have anxiously waited for their pent-up offense to carry them back into the division race. The transition has occurred over the past week, with their weak-hitting offense morphing into a potent run producer. But just as Mike Piazza and the offense seem to be clicking, the pitching has gone haywire.

description: BROWN-Earle. We respected him, as did so many, for his humanity, his music, and his tenacity. Although his music has not yet been as widely appreciated as it deserves, Earle's legacy will live on, continuing to inspire all who come after him. We send our deepest sympathies to his wife, Susan Sollins, and to their families. Agnes Gund & Daniel Shapiro

title: Stalking Suspect Is Arrested
description: The German man accused of stalking Serena Williams over the past four months was arrested on Wednesday outside the gates of the All England Club and released from custody today, the police said.

title: If Work Doesn't Pay, There's Always Crime
description: Carla Bhem (Emmanuelle Devos), the heroine of Jacques Audiard's ''Read My Lips,'' is, at least by French movie-star standards, plain and almost hyperbolically nondescript. Her stooped shoulders draped in a drab brown cardigan, she bustles mousily around the offices of a big construction firm, where she works as a receptionist. Her desk, shoved into a corner near the copy machine and the restrooms, is a convenient place for her co-workers to leave their half-empty coffee cups. Carla, who is partially deaf, is a person who exists to be taken advantage of and ignored. Even her best friend is mostly interested in exploiting Carla for free babysitting and the use of her apartment for adulterous liaisons.

title: For Cuomo and McCall, Patriotism With a Bit of Politicking Thrown In, or Vice Versa
description: The heat of the day kept most everyone away from the Hudson River Fest. Except the Democratic candidates for governor.

title: Blair Vows to Halt Rioting in Northern Ireland
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair gave Northern Ireland's political leaders a pledge tonight that he would tackle an outbreak of street rioting after they told him in emergency talks that it was endangering the province's fragile peace agreement.

title: A Mexican Anti-Fiesta Full of Uneasy Realities
description: A few months ago, P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center announced a survey of contemporary art from Mexico City as its big summer show. It would include more than two dozen young artists, among them Gabriel Orozco, Damin Ortega and Daniela Rossell, who are already known in New York; in Mr. Orozco's case, well known.

description: Like goodies at an American Indian feast, more than 200 contemporary craft objects -- weavings, pottery, jewelry, glass, sculpture, paintings and tableware -- are spread out at the American Craft Museum in a highly appetizing show.

title: Dr. Martin Deutsch, an Innovator in Education, Dies at 76
description: Dr. Martin Deutsch, a pioneer in the preschool education of disadvantaged children who helped form the national Head Start program, died on June 26 at Norwalk Hospital in Connecticut. He was 76.

description: The MetroStars (6-7-2), fresh off Thursday's 2-0 loss in Dallas, will play their second straight game without Mamadou Diallo today. Major League Soccer's disciplinary committee suspended Diallo for this afternoon's nationally televised match against the Crew in Columbus, Ohio, and fined him $750.

title: Afghan Raid Leaves a Trail of Shock, Grief and Anger
description: There is a shocked silence in the women's ward of the city hospital here. Five children and a young woman, all victims of an American bombing of their village three days ago, lie dazed and tearful on their beds in one room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ITRI, DR. FRANCIS V.
description: ITRI-Dr. Francis V., 93. Of Westfield, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, Wednesday, July 3, 2002. Predeceased by his wife Mary Nitti Ihri in 1985. Survived by a daughter, Dr. Loretta M. Itri, two grandsons, Raymond F. and Eric R. Warrell and a sister, Teresa A. Itri. Visitation on Friday, July 5, from 2-4 and 7-9PM at Gray Funeral Home, 318 East Broad St., Westfield. A Funeral Mass will be held at Holy Trinity RC Church, 315 First St., Westfield on Saturday, July 6, at 9:30AM. Cremation and burial are private. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association, 7 Mill Brook Road, Wilton, NH 03086.

title: Rediscovering An Older Louis
description: If you plan to visit Paris by Monday, drop your bags the minute you arrive and proceed directly to the Grand Palais on the Champs-lyses. On that day the museum will close one of the most provocative decorative arts exhibitions in recent memory: ''A Time of Exuberance: The Decorative Arts Under Louis XIII and Anne of Austria,'' a show (with a 480-page catalog, in French) that explores the taste of the king who ruled France from 1610 to 1643. Later, you can go to the Chateau of Versailles to see a long-forgotten project created by his Bourbon successor, Louis XIV.

title: Burmese Dissident Strikes New Balance With Junta Leaders
description: For this country's pro-democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the road to Mandalay has been long and difficult. She tried to go by train and was turned back. She tried to go by car and was placed for 19 months under house arrest.

title: Helping Indonesia
description: To the Editor:

title: A Festival With Nudity Sues a Sex Web Site
description: Since it began here 15 years ago as a small beach party where a wooden effigy was burned for no particular reason, the annual Burning Man Festival has grown to an eight-day event in the Nevada desert with 25,000 participants. Some of them take their clothes off, and therein lies a problem.

title: Fly, Bug and the Cuban, All in a Pickle
description: The glossy and transcendentally silly romantic melodrama ''Tattoo Bar,'' which opens today in Manhattan, is undeniably confident. The director, Jo Sol, imbues the film with a daffy, lurid quality that's as delectable as that last piece of candy rattling around in the bag that you can't keep away from. The actors' skins glisten, and there's plenty of skin to see because one of the characters, Simona (Mercedes Ortega), is an illustrated woman, the girlfriend of a tattoo artist and rambling philosopher, Francis (Miguel Molina).

title: Editorial Observer; Gambling in Las Vegas Shouldn't Extend to Airport Security
description: They are, in gambling-town argot, unacceptable odds. As USA Today reported earlier this week, half the fake weapons that undercover officers tried to sneak past security checkpoints went undetected at Las Vegas's McCarran International Airport. That was one of the worst performances in a recent test conducted by the Transportation Security Administration. Nationwide, screeners at 32 major airports failed to detect the fake weapons one in four times.

title: String Between 2 Points, Take a Deep Breath and Fly
description: ISABELLE AUSTIN-GREEN, almost 6, first told me about zip lines and how much fun they can be. Isabelle uses a zip line at Kidfit, a gym in Brooklyn for the 16 and under set. But anyone who has ever served in the Marines, gone on an Outward Bound trip or secretly yearned to play Indiana Jones probably knows about zip lines.

title: Two Ways to See How It's Done
description: Can DVD's teach filmmaking? For a how-to on the blockbuster, we have Michael Bay's ''Pearl Harbor,'' released by Touchstone this week in a new four-disc package with enough extra features to explain a lot of things. If smaller explosive productions are of interest, try the Andy Sidaris Film School on DVD's of two Sidaris movies, ''Savage Beach'' and ''Guns,''to be released on Tuesday by Ventura.

title: 3 Sisters and 3 Firefighters Die as Roof Collapses in Blaze
description: Three firefighters and three young sisters were killed here today when a roof collapsed during an early-morning blaze, pinning a team of rescuers under a shower of bricks, flaming wood and debris.

title: Energy Companies Agree On Trans-China Pipeline
description: Eight large energy companies concluded a framework joint venture agreement today for the development of a natural gas field in western China and the construction of a pipeline to carry the gas across the country to Shanghai.

title: British Cable TV Operator Closer to Deal With Malone
description: The Liberty Media Corporation, headed by John C. Malone, came a step closer today to taking control of Telewest, a British cable operator, after Telewest said it would begin talks with bondholders about restructuring its debt.

description: GOODMAN-Suzanne C. The American Friends of The Hebrew University expresses profound regret on the loss of Suzanne C. Goodman. A Chicago Chapter Board Member, former member of the Council of Trustees and longtime supporter of The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, her dedication to the University and the Jewish community will be sorely missed. We extend our sincere condolences to her husband Charles H., children Richard (Leslie), Barbara Manilow and Leonard, grandchildren Daniel, Jordan and Lily Goodman, Aaron, Jackson and Maya Manilow and to the extended Goodman and Crown families. American Friends of The Hebrew University Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs, Chairman of the Board

title: U.S. Jobless Rate Rises to 5.9 Percent
description: Washington, July 5 -- The U.S. unemployment rate rose to 5.9 percent in June and job creation was half as much as expected, as demand for workers lags the economic recovery.

title: Looking to Flee the Crowd So the Crowd Can't Follow
description: BEFORE 1980, the handful of people who owned vacation homes on isolated Bald Head Island, off the North Carolina coast, called themselves the Generator Society, after the diesel generators that powered their homes. Owned by a single small developer, the barrier island had a golf course and a few paved roads, but no running water, and no access to the island except by private boat.

title: Nazi War Criminal Sentenced to 7 Years in Jail
description: BERLIN, July 5  In what could be one of Germany's last trials of Nazis, a Hamburg court today sentenced a former SS officer to seven years in prison for ordering the reprisal killings of 59 Italian prisoners in 1944.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: For those who know jazz, the name Django can't help but connote the groundbreaking excitement of Django Reinhardt, the Gypsy guitarist who dazzled audiences in the 1930's and 40's with the Quintette du Hot Club de France. To call a restaurant Django conjures up a similar sort of free-swinging spirit.

description: KREIDMANN - Leona. On July 3. Wife of the late Arthur. Mother of Kenneth. Sister of Robert Benjamin.

title: The Fall of Jean-Marie Messier
description: Jean-Marie Messier was France's answer to the charge that Europe couldn't produce nimble, entrepreneurial corporate leaders. He was a turbocharged replica of the American model. That may be why -- despite having been the object of much veneration on both sides of the Atlantic just two years ago -- he now finds himself unemployed. The crash of American business values has been that swift. Now French corporate elites may embrace Continental staidness with a renewed passion.

title: Let He Who Is Without Hip
description: FOR the last couple of years, the W San Francisco (181 Third Street; 415-777-5300) has held a largely unrivaled position as that city's premier modernist boutique hotel. But Ian Schrager's redesigned Clift Hotel (495 Geary Street; 415-775-4700) has launched a turf war for hipster dominance. Which design-intensive establishment is winning the Battle of the Bay Area?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEROSA, THOMAS R.
description: DeROSA-Thomas R. A long term resident of Larchmont, NY, passed away on July 1, 2002 of complications from lung cancer. Mr. deRosa was born on October 16, 1947 to Donald J. and Louise Spinelli deRosa, of New Rochelle, New York. He is survived by his wife, Deborah Greene deRosa, and their daughters, Brooke and Paige deRosa, all residents of Windermere, FL, and two sisters, Marilyn L. Wilkie, of New Rochelle, NY, and Jeryl A. Hofmann, of Larchmont, New York. Mr. deRosa was a Partner with the national law firm of Baker & Hostetler, LLP, and had offices in the firm's Orlando, FL, Washington, D.C., and New York, NY offices. Mr. deRosa graduated Fordham Law School, cum laude, was on The Law Review, and was awarded the academic honors of The Graduating Class. His undergraduate degree was from Rensselear Polytechnic Institute, and he attended New York University, pursuing an MBA. Mr. deRosa was admitted to The State Bars of New York and Florida, The Federal District and Appellate Courts in both states, as well as appearances and trials in many other states. Mr. deRosa was a communicant of Saint Augustine's Catholic Church in Larchmont, New York, and of Mary Queen of The Universe Shrine in Orlando, FL. He was a member of The Larchmont Yacht Club. Visiting hours at The John J. Fox Funeral Home on Boston Post Road in Larchmont, NY will be on Friday, July 5th from 2-4 P.M. and from 7-9 P.M. He will have a Funeral Mass at Saint Augustine's, Larchmont Ave., Larchmont, NY at 10 A.M. on Saturday, July 6th. In lieu of flowers, the family wishes to encourage cash donations to The American Lung Association, in his name.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: FORECAST INCREASED The Bank of Korea forecast that the South Korean economy would grow 6.5 percent this year rather than the 5.7 percent that it had forecast earlier. The bank issued the more optimistic forecast even though Korea's currency, the won, is at its highest level since December 2000. Park Seung, governor of the Bank of Korea, said Korean products could still compete effectively abroad at slightly higher prices caused by the rising value of the won because Japanese products also cost more abroad with the yen also going up in value.

title: Bates to Go Ahead On Optimedia Deal
description: Bates USA in New York is going ahead with a merger of its media operations with a sibling, Optimedia, after the departure of Bates's top media executive.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Decision Soon On Steel Tariffs
description: The European Union said yesterday that it would decide by July 19 whether to retaliate against American steel tariffs, keeping pressure on President Bush for more exemptions. The United States has received more than 1,200 requests for exemptions from steel import tariffs as high as 30 percent that Mr. Bush imposed on March 20. The European Union said the decision could lead to retaliatory duties as of Aug. 1. The European Union had threatened to levy tariffs worth $350 million on products including fruit and clothing as early as June 18.

title: Journalists and Justice at The Hague
description: The war-crimes tribunal in The Hague is supposed to put the bad guys behind bars. I never thought it would go after an American journalist. But last month the tribunal upheld a subpoena against Jonathan Randal, requiring him to testify about events he covered in Bosnia for The Washington Post. If the tribunal has any sense, it will rescind the subpoena and the threat of penalties that it implies.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about a debate in Canada over freedom of the press misstated the given name of the former publisher of The Ottawa Citizen, who was fired after the paper published an article and an editorial critical of Prime Minister Jean Chrtien. As the article noted correctly, he is Russell A. Mills, not Robert.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the arrest of two men after stray bullets injured bystanders in a crowd on a Bronx street misstated the legal status of the men, Stephen Williams and Tracy Dawson. They were on parole, not probation.

title: Frederic Mohs, 92, Inventor Of Cancer Surgery Technique
description: Frederic Mohs, a surgeon at the University of Wisconsin who invented a surgical technique for treating certain skin cancers that bears his name and is practiced worldwide, died on Monday at his home in Madison. He was 92.

title: Terrorism and Talk: The Cycle of Conflict in Ireland
description: In May a group of Israeli and Palestinian politicians met with the people who negotiated Northern Ireland's breakthrough peace accord of 1998, hoping to learn something from their experience.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Telecom Shares Fall
description: Shares of Philippine Long Distance Telephone fell to their lowest point in almost 11 years as investors weighed a credit downgrade by Moody's Investors Service and the company's fight to stop the First Pacific Company from selling control to a Manila tycoon, John Gokongwei. Shares of the Philippines' largest phone operator plunged 32.5 pesos (64 United States cents), to 307.5 pesos. The company filed a suit in New York on Wednesday, accusing the Hong Kong-based First Pacific of failing to publish details of its agreement to sell 24 percent of the company to a venture controlled by Mr. Gokongwei. On Wednesday, Moody's cut its credit outlook for Philippine Long Distance to negative from stable.

title: Bensonhurst Journal; Reassembling Another Bit of New York History
description: Carefully examining a dozen glazed clay shards, Jennifer Borishansky, a third-year archaeology student, saw her duty as the sorting out of a 200-year-old Revolutionary War-era jigsaw puzzle.

title: For Oklahoma's Teachers, Big D Is Dollars (and Dallas)
description: Donya Shaffer, fresh out of teachers college this spring, always imagined herself standing before a classroom in Chickasha, the Oklahoma town where she and her husband, both children of teachers, have roots almost as deep in the soil as in the schoolhouse.

title: Pennies an Hour, and No Way Up
description: In last week's meeting in Canada, the Group of Eight industrial nations grappled with the question of how to better economic conditions in poor nations. One powerful means would be to improve the conditions of workers in sweatshops. Two billion people in the world make less than two American dollars a day. As voters and consumers of sweatshop products, Americans can make a difference in ending the miserable conditions under which these people work.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Malawi: Term Limit Remains In Place
description: Parliament voted against eliminating the presidential term limit, which dealt a blow to backers of President Bakili Muluzi. They had pushed for a constitutional amendment to let him seek a third term. Under the Constitution, Mr. Muluzi must step down in 2004.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Journalist's Remains Recovered
description: More than a month after the disappearance of a crime reporter, Tim Lopes, caused a national outcry against drug lords and inept and corrupt police work, his charred remains were recovered from a clandestine cemetery. He vanished on June 2 while pursuing an undercover investigation into gangs that dominate the squatter slums of Rio de Janeiro and was reported to have been executed by a local drug boss nicknamed Elias the Madman, to shield his activities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIEDEMANN, JOAN
description: TIEDEMANN-Joan. Lifelong resident of Baldwin, on July 4, 2002. Beloved wife of the late John H. Tiedemann. Devoted mother of Catherine Squasoni and John C. Tiedemann. Loving grandmother of Douglas and Jenna Squasoni. Dear sister of Frederick Kopf. Reposing at WeigandPensa Funeral Home, 2283 Grand Avenue, Baldwin, LI. Visiting Saturday, 7-9 PM, and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Services Monday at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Baldwin, 10AM. Interment Greenfield Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Peter's Lutheran Church Memorial Fund, would be appreciated.

title: Jeter May Not Be Sidelined Long
description: Derek Jeter expected that he would be fine when he underwent a magnetic resonance imaging test on his left knee. But he could not be certain until he was told that the results were negative; when Jeter learned that yesterday, he was relieved.

title: One Nation Plays the Great Game Alone
description: WASHINGTON

title: Front Row For Bodine In Surprise At Daytona
description: Geoffrey Bodine was assigned a parking spot in the least trafficked corner of the garages at Daytona International Speedway, and his yellow and red Ford was wedged between stock cars driven by the other no-name part-timers who usually are thrilled simply to make a race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEMPER, JAMES S. JR.
description: KEMPER-James S. Jr. The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and members of Boys & Girls Clubs of America wish to express their profound sorrow over the passing of Mr. James S. Kemper Jr., member of our Board of Governors and a lifelong advocate for children. Mr. Kemper devoted 40 years of service to Boys & Girls Clubs; our Midwest headquarters, the Kemper Training and Service Center, is named in his honor. A recipient of the Herbert Hoover Humanitarian Award from Boys & Girls Clubs of America for his passionate commitment to America's youth, Mr. Kemper's positive influence will be felt for generations to come. We will miss him greatly. Boys & Girls Clubs of America Arnold I. Burns, Chairman Roxanne Spillett, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPER, HERMAN (HAL)
description: LIPPER-Herman (Hal). Loving and devoted husband of Edith for 56 years. Dearest father of Laura, Dana and Amy. Dear father-in-law of Bertil Arleij, John McCauley and Ken Hecht. Cherished grandfather of Mark and Kyle. Loving brother of Sol Lipper and Elsie Leighton. Special uncle of Joseph Leighton. Missed, loved and always in our hearts. Contribution in Hal's memory may be made to the Connecticut Hospice, 100 Double Beach Rd., Branford, CT 06405, and New York Weill Cornell Medical Center, 525 East 68 Street, Box 123, NY NY 10021.

title: Yanks Trade Lilly and Acquire Tigers' Weaver in 3-Team Deal
description: The Yankees do not have an opening in their starting rotation, and they do not have any teams ahead of them in the American League East. But that did not stop them from pulling off their second significant trade of the week last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, THEODORE H. (HERBERT)
description: LIEBERMAN-Theodore H. (Herbert), at age 72. Loving husband of Marjorie. Beloved brother of Gloria and brotherin-law of Stephen and Naomi. Cherished uncle of Geri and Roy, Andrew and Susan, Judy and Ray, Scott and Barbara. Adored by many great nieces and nephews. Retired from Grey Advertising as Sr. V.P. after 45 years of dedicated service, Herbert was loved by a large family and many friends. We will miss his presence. Funeral services Sunday, 10:30AM at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills.

description: ITRI-Dr. Francis V., 93. Of Westfield, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, Wednesday, July 3, 2002. Predeceased by his wife Mary Nitti Ihri in 1985. Survived by a daughter, Dr. Loretta M. Itri Warrell, a son John F. Itri, two grandsons, Raymond F. and Eric R. Warrell and a sister, Teresa A. Itri. A Funeral Mass will be held at Holy Trinity RC Church, 315 First St., Westfield on Saturday, July 6, at 9:30AM. Cremation and burial are private. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association, 7 Mill Brook Road, Wilton, N.H. 03086.

title: A Life Turned Around Is Abruptly Taken
description: Omain Gullette seemed to be in the midst of a life conversion, the kind that inspired his friends and family with hope and faith. He had been arrested four times as a teenager and could not stay out of trouble.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about an agreement by the United States to extend the United Nations peacekeeping mission in Bosnia by 12 days misstated when its mandate would have expired without the extension. It was midnight Wednesday, not midnight Thursday.

title: Longtime Madagascar Leader Flees as Rival Gains
description: With enemy troops closing in on his last remaining stronghold, the longtime leader of Madagascar, Didier Ratsiraka, left his country this morning and flew to the nearby island of Seychelles, officials said.

title: NUTRASWEET GETS F.D.A. APPROVAL FOR A NEW SWEETENER
description: The Nutrasweet Company won federal approval for a new sweetener, neotame, that's about 7,000 to 13,000 times as sweet as sugar and will carry no health warning on its label, the Food and Drug Administration said. Neotame can be used in baked goods, chewing gum, soda, jams and jellies and other foods, the F.D.A. said. The agency said it reviewed more than 113 animal and human studies, adding up to about 35,000 pages of study documents, before approving neotame. The F.D.A. checked for potential side effects like cancer or birth defects and other risks. Neotame is so sweet that very small amounts would be needed, said Alan Rulis, the director of the F.D.A.'s office of food additive safety. Nutrasweet, which is privately held, is based in Mount Prospect, Ill.

title: Pawns in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Crowded Airport Terminals Can Lead to Additional Security Problems, Experts Say
description: Scrutinizing passengers and bags more carefully before they are allowed near an airplane has resulted in a new security problem, creating vulnerable crowds outside the secure area, experts said today.

title: Former Nazi Convicted of Ordering Executions
description: In what could be one of Germany's last trials of Nazis, a Hamburg court today sentenced a former SS officer to seven years in prison for ordering the killing of 59 Italian prisoners in 1944.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UNIVERSAL EXPRESS INC., New York, said its subsidiary, Virtual Bellhop, a door-to-door transporter of checked baggage for airline travelers, would form a marketing partnership with Travel & Leisure Elite Traveler, a 65,000-member club and a brand extension of Travel & Leisure Magazine.

title: Renewed Ban on Chickens
description: Russia said today that it would reinstate a ban on imports of chickens from the United States because it contends the country has not guaranteed that they are safe. The ban will cut Tyson Foods off from its largest export market.

title: Universal Child Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Vote to Reopen Secret German Files
description: East German secret police files closed to the public by a judge are likely to be reopened to researchers under a law passed by the lower house of the German Parliament late Thursday night.

title: A Stark Political Fable of South Africa
description: Agreat commanding subject haunts the South African imagination, yet this subject can also turn into a kind of tyranny, close, oppressive, even destructive. Imagine what it must be like to live as a serious writer in South Africa: an endless clamor of news about racial injustice, the feeling that one's life is mortgaged to a society gone rotten with hatred, an indignation that exhausts itself into depression, the fear that one's anger may overwhelm and destroy one's fiction. And except for silence or emigration, there can be no relief.

title: Diallo Draws Additional Sanction
description: The MetroStars (6-7-2), fresh off Thursday's 2-0 loss in Dallas, will play their second straight game without Mamadou Diallo today. Major League Soccer's disciplinary committee suspended Diallo for this afternoon's nationally televised match against the Crew in Columbus, Ohio, and fined him $750.

title: Battle Plans for Iraq
description: President Bush has made no secret of his desire to drive Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq. What has been unclear is how Mr. Bush expects to strike. Partial answers to that question come now in the form of a preliminary Pentagon planning document described in The Times yesterday by Eric Schmitt. It suggests that the military brass is considering a large-scale air and ground assault involving as many as 250,000 American troops.

title: Boston Tips Its Cap on the Day the Legend Dies
description: The scoreboard at Fenway Park tonight bore a simple message. ''At bat, Number 9, batting .406.''

title: Inequity in Vouchers
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: CROATIA: PRIME MINISTER TO FORM NEW CABINET Croatia's reformist prime minister, Ivica Racan, resigned to rid himself of a troublesome coalition partner and is expected to form a new cabinet with the backing of minor parties. His decision ends a fractious 30-month relationship between two parties that united to defeat the nationalist party founded by Croatia's late president, Franjo Tudjman. The rift had been threatening to stymie reforms Croatia needs to undertake to join NATO and the European Union. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Learning From the Right Wing
description: The sound of money influencing politics and public policy reached a strange new pitch with news of the seemingly contradictory charitable practices of Steven T. Kirsch, a Silicon Valley entrepreneur turned venture philanthropist. With one hand he donated millions to reform campaign finance; with the other he gave more millions in soft money hoping to defeat George W. Bush in the 2000 election. Is this what we have to look forward to from a new generation of philanthropists?

title: Seeking Truth in Ulster
description: To the Editor:

title: After a Windy Battle, Three Share Open Lead
description: Annika Sorenstam and Juli Inkster were in familiar territory, and Laura Diaz was delighted to join them.

title: Batter Up
description: Four decades and hundreds of miles separate him from the action, but the baseball legend Ted Williams can still feel spring training in the Florida air.

title: From Llama Trails to the Corridors of Power
description: AFTER finishing third in the presidential election on Sunday, Evo Morales was cornered by supporters at a simple meeting hall in this gritty city perched 12,000 feet in the Andes. Miners with gnarled hands and weathered faces, tough truck drivers and poor indigenous women wearing traditional bowler hats -- they would not let him go. Instead, they hugged and kissed him, all the while beseeching him never to back down.

title: Armstrong Insists Race Will Have Excitement
description: It will not be a bland Tour de France, Lance Armstrong insisted, despite widespread fears to the contrary. He is such an overwhelming favorite to win his fourth successive Tour that the general expectation is for three weeks in Dullsville, not France.

title: An Old Amour, More Off Than On
description: Since the beginning of the year, Edward I. Koch, former mayor of New York City, has signed off most of his weekly radio broadcasts with a declaration of war loosely inspired by Julius Caesar: ''Omni Gaul delenda est!'' (''All Gaul must be destroyed!'')

title: Hernndez Keeps Showing More Healthy Signs in Victory
description: This is how it works sometimes in baseball: the Toronto Blue Jays virtually gave away a productive outfielder to the Yankees on Monday, then showed up in the Bronx last night and humbly tried to beat the team they had just helped. The Yankees, and especially Orlando Hernndez, were having nothing of it.
