description: CAHN-Chester B. So long, go get 'em! Love, Connie

title: A Card Allows U.S. Banks To Aid Mexican Immigrants
description: Before migrating illegally to the United States, many Mexicans throw away various forms of personal identification in an effort to avoid prosecution if caught by United States authorities. Recently, they have found an unexpected ally in their struggle to regain a legal identity once they are across the border: United States banks.

title: WEBMETHODS NARROWS ITS LOSSES FROM LAST YEAR
description: WebMethods Inc., whose software allows information to be shared between programs, will report a narrower fiscal first-quarter loss, helped by an accounting change. The net loss narrowed to about $2.5 million to $3.5 million, or 5 cents to 7 cents a share, in the quarter ended Sunday, from a loss of $19.9 million, or 41 cents, in the year-earlier period. Sales were $47 million to $48 million, the company, which is based in Fairfax, Va., said.

title: Pilots Charged With Flying Recklessly On July 4th
description: The pilots of two private planes that officials said flew dangerously close to a beach, a bridge, a cruise ship and a police helicopter on the Fourth of July were charged yesterday with felony reckless endangerment and could be sentenced to prison if convicted, officials said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Babcock Borsig On The Brink
description: Babcock Borsig, a German engineering company employing 22,000 people, filed for protection from creditors after two days of talks with banks and politicians broke down. Babcock needed 200 million euros ($196 million) to pay June salaries but banks are reluctant to extend more credit. Its debt amounted to 1.5 billion euros at the end of March. Chancellor Gerhard Schrder was still pursuing ways to avert the collapse, which would be the fourth major corporate failure this year. Babcock makes steam turbines, power plants and industrial boilers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEATING, EDWIN LAWRENCE, JR.
description: KEATING-Edwin Lawrence, Jr., on July 5, 2002, of Rye Brook, New York. Husband of Margaret, father of Edwin III, of Timonium, Maryland. Grandfather of Edwin IV and brother of Anne Hayden of Newport Beach, California. The family will receive friends on Monday, July 8, from 8:30-9:30am, at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Post Rd, Rye, NY. Funeral Mass at St. Paul's RC Church, Monday, 10 A.M., Greenwich, Connecticut. Intombment Calvary Cemetery, Queens, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to St. Jude's Childrens Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, Tennessee 38105.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose, rounding out its biggest weekly gain since January, as advancing stocks spurred buying of the currency. In New York, the euro settled at 97.34 cents, down from 98 cents on Wednesday.

title: Free Prozac in the Junk Mail Draws a Lawsuit
description: The unsolicited Prozac arrived in a hand-addressed manila envelope. It came from a Walgreens drugstore not far from here, and there was a ''Dear Patient'' form letter inside.

description: One player after another has joined a conga line for those experiencing Williams sister fatigue, each bored with the monotony of watching Venus and Serena turn the major finals into a family reunion.

title: Sales of PlayStation 2 Rise
description: The Sony Corporation's sales of PlayStation 2 in North America more than doubled in May, outpacing sales of video game machines made by its rivals, Microsoft and Nintendo, an industry report said.

title: Suliman S. Olayan, 83, Dies; One of the World's Wealthiest
description: Suliman S. Olayan, a Saudi billionaire whose energy, insurance and consumer goods businesses as well as investments made him one of the richest men in the world, died Thursday night at his home in Manhattan. He was 83.

description: COHEN-David. My beloved Grandpa, it's been over 30 years but I miss you every, every day. Freya

title: CREDIT SUISSE MAY SELL ITS FLAGGING INSURANCE UNIT
description: Continued losses from its insurance and investment banking arms could force the Credit Suisse Group to sell the United States-based property and casualty insurance unit of its Winterthur division, analysts said. The unit includes the Republic Underwriters Insurance Company in Dallas and could sell for as much as $1.2 billion, a big help to Winterthur, which is suffering from investment losses. Last month, the parent company infused $1.1 billion into Winterthur to ensure its ability to pay claims but said this week that it would take a loss from insurance unit costs in the second quarter. The announcement of a management shake-up failed to revive Credit Suisse's share price, raising expectations that insurance operations will go. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN RISES. Corn prices rose on expectations that a heat wave forecast for the Midwest will damage crops already stunted by late planting. In Chicago, corn for December delivery rose 4.75 cents, or 2 percent, to $2.465 a bushel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREIDMANN, LEONA F.
description: KREIDMANN-Leona F. Loving mother of Kenneth, beloved sister of Robert Benjamin. died peacefully on July 3rd, 2002 after a long illness. At last you are at peace with the world. Love, Bob, Betty, John and Richard

title: Japan Battles Bond Rating
description: Tacked up in banks and post offices across Japan, the posters of a fresh-faced beauty could be advertising a new financial thriller: Bond Girl vs. Botswana.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Standoff Delays Commuters
description: The police shut down one of two major southbound routes from San Francisco to San Jose yesterday during the morning rush hours. A high-speed chase resulted in a four-hour standoff on U.S. 101 that ended when the police sprayed the car with firefighting foam because they thought the driver had soaked himself with gasoline. The motorist was arrested and charged with evading arrest, reckless driving and delaying or resisting arrest. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Treasuring Blacks' Long Memories
description: Eight years ago, Camille Cosby used the Broadway stage to give two African-American centenarian sisters a chance to share their stories. The play, ''Having Our Say,'' based on the best-selling 1991 book about Sadie and Bessie Delaney, was a virtual oral history.

title: Push to Revise Term Limits Gains Ground
description: Just six months into the first year of the city's term-limits law, City Council Speaker Gifford Miller has marshaled considerable support among his colleagues to roll it back and give him and seven other council members an extra two years in office.

title: The Texas Edition
description: To the Editor:

title: Six Days of Confusion That Rearranged World Politics
description: ''Great wars in history,'' Michael B. Oren writes in this important chronicle of the Arab-Israeli war of 1967, ''invariably become great wars of history.'' The battles become intellectual battlefields: contested terrain over which historians wrestle, quarreling over the spoils of the past and the prospects for the future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHRMAN, HANNAH
description: LEHRMAN - Hannah. Be loved daughter, sister, aunt, friend. Funeral service on Sunday, July 7th, 9:30 AM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam at West 91st.

description: The Marist College varsity eight did yesterday what no other crew at this year's Henley Royal Regatta has achieved; it brought the finish line spectators at the Stewards Enclosure to a gaping silence.

title: E.ON, German Energy Giant, to Acquire Big Gas Distributor
description: The German government gave conditional approval today to a 10.3 billion euro ($10.09 billion) takeover bid by the energy giant E.ON for Ruhrgas, Germany's largest natural gas distributor, a decision that could result in a powerful new player in the global energy market.

title: Beliefs; Behind the concept of the separation of church and state, a scholar finds some unsettling origins.
description: How did the religious liberty clauses of the First Amendment, barring Congress from making any law ''respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof,'' become equated with language that appears nowhere in the Constitution: ''separation of church and state''?

title: Electricity Costs Double in West As Hotter Weather Is Forecast
description: Electricity prices in the western United States more than doubled today as new forecasts called for hotter weather, which will increase demand for power to run air-conditioners.

He is survived by his wife Sonia, son Bernard and grandchildren Cody and Karly. Donations in his memory can be made to any organization that helps poor urban children.

description: As he embarks on the daunting task of unseating Senator Robert G. Torricelli, Douglas R. Forrester is counting on a not-so-secret weapon: the senator himself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASSMAN, HARRIETT S.
description: GLASSMAN-Harriett S. Died on July 5 after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Loving wife of Jay Glassman. Mother of Mimi (David) Rukeyser & Julie Glassman. Sister of Susan (Ken) White. Adoring grandmother of Emily and Sara. Harriett was a devoted wife and wonderful mother. She always had time to listen, loved to cook, read and knit. In the summertime Harriett's favorite place to be was sitting on the dock at her summer home in Maine. Harriett's friends and family were lucky to have known her and will miss her terribly. Harriett devoted the last eighteen years of her career working at The Children's Rehabilitation Center at St. Agnes, where she was the Assistant Director of Education. Her passion was counseling the parents of disabled children. Because of her great love for the children's center her family strongly requests that any donations be sent to The Children's Rehabilitation Center at St. Agnes, 305 North Street, White Plains, New York 10605. Services will be held Sunday, July 7th, at 11:30 A.M., at the Zion Memorial Chapel, Mamaroneck, New York.

title: 2 Men Hurt as Fire Destroys Bar Basement
description: One man was seriously burned and another slightly hurt when an ether-based glue they were using caught fire yesterday afternoon, destroying the basement of a bar in the East Village, a Fire Department official said.

title: Emptiness in England As Henman Bows Out
description: Some empty beer cups and a stray Union Jack remained as the leftovers of lost hope on a grassy embankment known as Henman Hill on the Wimbledon grounds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLIN, EMANUEL
description: BERLIN-Emanuel. Passed away on June 26th, 2002, at the age of 81. He is survived by Doris, his beloved wife of fifty-three years, his children, Michael and Patricia to whom he was devoted, his adored grandson, Alexander, his sister, Rosetta, and other family members. Emanuel was self employed in the pharmaceutical industry and a law school graduate with a passion for justice. He was a devoted family man, who enjoyed life and lived it to the fullest. We will miss you. Service will be held on Sunday, July 7 at 12 noon at the family home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONSTANTINER, DR. JAIME
description: CONSTANTINER-Dr. Jaime. Our heartfelt condolences go out to good sons, Roberto, Arturo, Teddy, Victor, Leon and their families. A generous and loyal Zionist. A good and warm friend of ours. We will miss him. Charly Dimston Todd Dimston

title: A SLIGHT INCREASE
description: The unemployment rate rose slightly, to 5.9 percent, last month, the government reported yesterday. The economy appears to have fallen into a so-called jobless recovery that resembles the slow growth of the early 1990's, economists said.

title: A Skewed and Skewering Look at Finland
description: Around the world, the Finns, a nation of five million, are hardly known as funny folk -- or so conventional thinking goes. They live in semidarkness during the winter months, beat each other with birch sticks in their saunas and have one of the world's highest suicide rates.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Thursday about an investigation into drug trafficking at Camp Lejeune, N.C., misstated the number of military personnel who have been convicted in the inquiry. As the article noted correctly, it is 82, not 84.

title: At Camp, Grief Is Close By; Free Stays for Sept. 11 Children Aren't an Easy Sell
description: Christopher DaMota lay on his stomach on a pier, dipping his hand into the opaque waters of Sebago Lake as he and other boys in the 9-to-12 age group at Camp Sunshine waited for a boat to take them fishing. They had been on the go since breakfast and had already spent part of the morning kicking a giant soccer ball up and down a field.

title: Appellate Court Denies Attempt To Delay Giuliani Divorce Trial
description: A state appellate panel denied a motion yesterday seeking to postpone the divorce trial of former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his wife, Donna Hanover. With the motion swept away, the trial is expected to begin on Wednesday.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Mercosur Impasse
description: President Eduardo Duhalde has failed to persuade five neighboring countries in Mercosur, the South American common market, and Mexico to unite with Argentina in lobbying and negotiating with the International Monetary Fund and other international lenders for new credits. Meeting in Buenos Aires, presidents of the countries instead expressed solidarity with Argentina and stated their ''concern for the current behavior of the international financial and economic systems.''

title: Sports of The Times; For Ted, The Eyes Had It
description: AT a baseball dinner some years ago, Ted Williams kept squinting at his notes as he spoke, but at the lectern now, Joe DiMaggio put on glasses.

title: Lionel Bernstein, 82, Is Dead; On Trial With Mandela in '64
description: Lionel Bernstein, a white South African Communist and anti-apartheid campaigner who stood trial for treason in 1963 alongside Nelson Mandela and seven others, died June 23 in his home in the English village of Kidlington in Oxfordshire. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, DR. PAUL

title: Military Chief in Israel Sees No Withdrawal if Arafat Stays
description: Israel's departing military chief of staff said today that only the expulsion of Yasir Arafat or his replacement as Palestinian leader might prompt an Israeli withdrawal in the coming months from the seven West Bank cities it has placed under 24-hour curfew.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: June Employment Report Reflects a Jobless Recovery

title: Where Cherries Usually Abound, Bare Trees and Anxious Growers
description: On the eve of the National Cherry Festival here, organizers are making the best of a bad situation. There are, it seems, hardly any cherries this year, at least from around here.

title: Fans Let Lopez Know She Makes Their Cut
description: As Nancy Lopez made a tearful departure from the United States Women's Open, the gallery showered her with affection and appreciation.

title: AIRLINES RESCIND INCREASE IN COMPANION FARES
description: Major air carriers led by American Airlines dropped a $20 round-trip increase on some leisure fares, as Northwest Airlines balked. American, the operating unit of the AMR Corporation, confirmed it was rescinding the increase that it began Wednesday, in at least the fourth attempt to raise fares since mid-April. Northwest said it did not match the higher prices and declined to comment further. The UAL Corporation's United, Delta Air Lines, Continental Airlines and the US Airways Group said they dropped the increase. The increase applied to restricted fares for companion travel, said Tom Parsons, chief executive of the fare monitor Bestfares.com.

title: Inside Inquiry By WorldCom Is Continuing
description: An internal investigation at WorldCom into accounting irregularities is continuing despite a report that indicated the Justice Department was seeking to curtail its activities as it conducts its own investigation, according to the head of the company's internal inquiry.

title: Hercule Poirot Rides Again, And His Sidekick Kibitzes
description: Evidence that Hercule Poirot understood bridge is to be found in the Agatha Christie novel ''Cards on the Table.'' The great detective had to analyze the score pads to identify the murderer. He recently became involved in the game again when facing a diabolical gang known as ''The Fatal Five.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKENNA, REV. JOSEPH CHARLES, S.J.
description: McKENNA - Rev. Joseph Charles, S.J. Survived by beloved sister Irene, 14 loving nieces and nephews, and many grand nieces and nephews. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel, MurrayWeigel Hall, 515 E. Fordham Rd., Sunday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Jesuit Community Chapel, Loyola-Faber Hall, Fordham University, Monday, 11 AM. For information, contact Farenga Bros., Inc. Funeral Directors.

title: Is There a Gay Basis To Nietzsche's Ideas?
description: Does it matter that Nietzsche's landlady in Turin once peeked through his keyhole and saw him dancing stark naked? Or that Nietzsche put an end to one young woman's romantic intentions by presenting her with a toad wrapped in a blood-stained handkerchief? Or that Richard Wagner spread rumors that Nietzsche suffered from the side effects of excessive masturbation and, perhaps, pederasty? Or that Nietzsche may have enjoyed several weeks of homoerotic bliss in Sicily?

title: Mayor Opposes Parole for Man In 1971 Killings of Two Officers
description: In an unusual move, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has written to the chairman of the State Division of Parole to urge that a convicted killer of two police officers, Anthony Bottom, also known as Jalil Abdul Muntaqim, be denied parole. It is the first time Mr. Bloomberg has intervened in such a case, a spokesman said.

title: John Thompson, 84, a Professor and Poet
description: John Thompson, a professor, literary critic and poet, died on June 24 at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

title: Ted Williams, Red Sox Slugger And Last to Hit .400, Dies at 83
description: Ted Williams, the tempestuous slugger of the Boston Red Sox who was the last man to bat .400 and was perhaps the greatest hitter in baseball history, died yesterday in Inverness, Fla. He was 83.

title: Sports of The Times; For Williams, A Joy Found In the Debate
description: TED WILLIAMS was managing the Washington Senators in the spring of 1969, and I was a dewy-eyed young sports reporter given the assignment of following up on a thought that was growing more widespread around the country. That is: Is baseball doomed?

title: Editorial Notebook; A Global Gathering on the Mall
description: The ideal place in Washington to find the meaning of America during the nation's time of trial and terrorist threats the last two weeks has been the Smithsonian Folklife Festival on the Mall, where a series of temporary edifices have been erected to recreate the ancient Silk Route from Europe to the Far East. Security precautions have not deterred hundreds of thousands of visitors from examining crafts and attending performances and exhibits from one end, with a reproduction of the Basilica of San Marco in Venice, to the other with a replica of the Gateway at Nara, Japan. In between there are minarets from Istanbul, a mosque from Samarkand and yurts from Central Asia. The air is filled with song in Chinese, Urdu, Persian and Turkish.

title: Israel Rolls Out a New Long-Range Weapon: an Arabic-Language Satellite TV Station
description: Israel has unveiled a new weapon in the battle for hearts and minds that has always been part of the Middle East conflict: its own Arabic-language satellite television station.

title: States Split As U.S. Offers Drug Subsidy For Elderly
description: With Congressional passage of a Medicare drug benefit still far from certain, about half the states are at least considering joining a Bush administration program that will provide federal matching money to extend drug coverage to elderly people whose incomes are modest but too high for Medicaid.

title: Getting in the Mood for Four Personality Changes
description: Performers with the Pilobolus Dance Theater bent over backward to entertain at the Joyce Theater. These gymnastically agile dancers bent forward and sideways as well. Yet their program lacked choreographic spark.

title: The time is now to reshape France's economy, report says : Talking about a revolution
description: PARIS:  Offering a markedly optimistic view of the outlook for fundamental economic and social change in France, a leading French corporate figure has recruited 20 specialists to outline an ambitious center-right blueprint for reversing what many see as a prolonged period of national decline.

title: QWEST DENIES IT IS UNDER CRIMINAL INQUIRY
description: Qwest Communications International said it was unaware of a criminal investigation after The Wall Street Journal reported that the telephone company was being investigated by the Justice Department. ''We have no reason to believe that we are the subject of any investigation by the U.S. Department of Justice,'' Drake Tempest, Qwest's general counsel, said in a statement. The Justice Department declined to comment. The newspaper, citing unidentified sources, reported that the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States attorney's office in Denver were investigating Qwest. Qwest is under examination by the Securities and Exchange Commission for its accounting, which the company has said is proper.

title: Officials Puzzled About Motive Of Airport Gunman Who Killed 2
description: The man officials say opened fire at a crowded El Al airlines ticket counter on Thursday was an Egyptian-born owner of a limousine service who apparently went to the airport heavily armed and determined to kill, managing to take two lives before Israeli security guards shot him to death during a fierce, bloody struggle.

title: All the President's Enrons
description: George W. Bush is so peeved about corporate America's ''wrongdoers'' -- not to be confused with ''evildoers'' -- that last week he spoke out about them four times in four days. By the time he took a breather, the markets had hit their worst half-year finish since 1970, the Nasdaq was at a five-year low, the dollar was on the skids and, despite much evidence to the contrary, a majority of Americans had told CNN/USA Today pollsters that the country was in a recession.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Trading Bloc Closes Ranks
description: Placing responsibility for their countries' woes on the global economy and a rise in protectionism in rich industrialized nations, leaders of South America's main trading bloc, Mercosur, closed ranks behind Argentina, urging international aid for the country, whose economic collapse has sent neighboring markets into a tailspin. But they stopped short of forming a united front to negotiate with international agencies like the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, in case the Argentine fallout leaves the region in need of fresh I.M.F. aid. In a statement ending a meeting in Buenos Aires, the presidents of the Mercosur members Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay, along with the leaders of two associate countries, Bolivia and Chile, expressed their concern that the current state of the international economic and financial system was preventing sustainable, just and equitable economic development. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Power System Is Disrupted By a Fire, Con Ed Says
description: A fire at a Consolidated Edison substation in Yonkers disrupted the downstate power network yesterday, knocking out a transmission line that provides about one-tenth of Long Island's electricity.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: PHILIPPINES: TELECOM SHARES FALL Shares of Philippine Long Distance Telephone fell to their lowest point in almost 11 years as investors weighed a credit downgrade by Moody's Investors Service and the company's fight to stop the First Pacific Company from selling control to a Manila tycoon, John Gokongwei. Shares of the Philippines' largest phone operator plunged 32.5 pesos (64 United States cents), to 307.5 pesos. The company filed a suit in New York on Wednesday, accusing the Hong Kong-based First Pacific of failing to publish details of its agreement to sell 24 percent of the company to a venture controlled by Mr. Gokongwei. On Wednesday, Moody's cut its credit outlook for Philippine Long Distance to negative from stable. (Bloomberg News)

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: STANDOFF DELAYS COMMUTERS The police shut down one of two major southbound routes from San Francisco to San Jose yesterday during the morning rush hours. A high-speed chase resulted in a four-hour standoff on U.S. 101 that ended when the police sprayed the car with firefighting foam because they thought the driver had soaked himself with gasoline. The motorist was arrested and charged with evading arrest, reckless driving and delaying or resisting arrest.

title: Williams Leaves Behind An Unmatched Legacy

Anyone who ever heard the man talk about hitting stood or sat mesmerized, rapt, hanging on every one of Williams's words. To ask Williams about hitting was to invite the baseball equivalent of a lecture on the theory of relativity by Einstein or on the stars by Galileo.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Builder In Bankruptcy
description: Dai Nippon Construction, a general contractor, said it filed for bankruptcy protection with 271.2 billion yen ($2.3 billion) in debt, much of which went toward ill-timed golf course development. It was the second-largest failure of a publicly traded Japanese company this year and brings the total to 23; last year the figure was 14. Like other contractors, Dai Nippon got into trouble when real estate prices collapsed at the beginning of the 1990's.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Deaths In Skirmish
description: North Korea acknowledged for the first time that some of its sailors died in a Yellow Sea skirmish a week ago in which at least four South Koreans were killed. The North's Korea Central News Agency cited ''loss of human lives on both sides'' and described the shootout as ''an unexpected exchange of fire between naval vessels of the North and South'' in which a South Korean boat was sunk. South Korea's Defense Ministry has estimated that 30 North Koreans were killed or wounded. The North Korean commentary appeared as part of an effort to reduce tensions by making clear that the North's leaders had not ordered the shooting. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: LEVI STRAUSS RAISES ESTIMATE OF PLANT-CLOSING COSTS
description: Levi Strauss & Company expects to incur an additional $20 million to $25 million in restructuring-related expenses over the next 12 to 18 months, according to its quarterly report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Levi Strauss, based in San Francisco, recorded $150.2 million in charges in the second quarter, which ended May 26. According to the filing the additional costs will cover maintenance before the sale or other disposition of closed plants in the United States and Scotland. Levi Strauss also said it expected improved sales in the second half of fiscal 2002 because of current orders, product introductions, steps to improve margins for retailers and new promotional initiatives.

The report was late, the company said, because it had uncovered accounting irregularities, and correcting them meant A.& P. had to ad just its earnings statement for 2001 and restate results for the two previous years.

title: National Briefing: South
description: ARKANSAS: COURT UPHOLDS SAME-SEX RELATIONS The State Supreme Court ruled that a 1977 law barring sexual relations between people of the same sex was an unconstitutional invasion of privacy. A judge ruled in 2001 that the law was unconstitutional, but the state appealed. The law carried a penalty of a $1,000 fine and up to a year in jail.

description: Steve Phillips, the Mets' general manager, flew into town today on somewhat short notice. With his team in a tailspin, Phillips said he did not want to draw any attention, and he insisted his visit was because he did not want to miss the Mets' weeklong road trip before the All-Star Game break.

title: New Leaders Of Vivendi Likely to Win Bank Backing
description: Vivendi Universal is still deep in talks with its banks to arrange new lines of credit and avert a cash squeeze as some of its debts come due. But the outcome of those talks was effectively decided earlier this week when the company removed Jean-Marie Messier as chief executive and added a coterie of power brokers from the inner circles of French politics and finance, analysts said today.

title: Shortchanging Superfund
description: A report last week that the Bush administration plans to cut cleanup funds at 33 of the country's biggest toxic waste sites drew predictable howls from Democrats that the White House was again sabotaging the environment. It also drew strong denials from the Environmental Protection Agency, which said that no project would go unfunded. Meanwhile, an underlying truth went largely unnoticed: Superfund is in a precarious state, increasingly beholden to the budgetary whims of Congress and the administration. Indeed, much of the fault lies with Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUNNERSON, PAGE, MICK EY
description: GUNNERSON - PAGE - Mick ey. On Thursday July 4, 2002 died of natural causes after an extended illness. Born in Wilmington, NC, of Carl Gunnerson and Nettie Fern Ellis Gunnerson on February 11, 1932 and raised in New Bern, she attended the University of North Carolina where she began her study of dance. Her natural ability coupled with her earnestness at dance classes quickly made it evident that she was a dancer to be watched. In 1952, she ventured to move to New York City and studied with Muriel Stuart, Anatole Oboukof, Mme. Dubrovska and Mr. Vladimoroff at the School of American Ballet. Her dark Norwegian beauty coupled with her training soon began Mickey's extraordinary career. She appeared in 17 shows on Broadway including, ''How to Succeed in Business'', ''Sweet Charity'', ''Tenderloin'', ''Juno'', ''I Remember Mama'' and such revivals as ''The Pajama Game'', ''My Fair Lady'' and ''Brigadoon''. She performed for several summer seasons at the Guy Lombardo Jones Beach Theatre, at the New York City Center and in Las Vegas. Renowned choreographers Agnes DeMille, Michael Bennett, Jack Cole, Alvin Ailey, Bob Fosse, Joe Layton, Graziella Danielle and John Butler chose Mickey, not just for her talent, but for her professionalism and reliability. Television choreographer, Robert Pagent, needed dancers for the grueling weekly ''Voice of Firestone'' and ''Bell Telephone'' television shows. They needed to be versatile and able to adapt to the quick study and limited time required. Pagent hired Gunnerson consistently for those shows during what were called the ''Golden Years'' of television. Miss Gunnerson married Stanley Page and they would have celebrated their 47th wedding anniversary this year. Page's career as a singer spanned a similar lengthy period of performing on Broadway and around the country as well as on television. Many stage colleagues became her lifetime friends. Mickey's other interests included environmental concerns and a love for animals. Many stray or abandoned dog or cat was given a comforting and caring home by the Pages. She also volunteered as a tutor for immigrants to help them master English as their second language. Her hobbies included scuba diving and skiing. Mickey Gunnerson was the epitome of so many of those somewhat anonymous stage performers backing up the bright stars and musical numbers that make the magic of the theatre come alive for all of us. Her impressive career is what ''A Chorus Line'' was all about. In addition to her husband, Stan, her sister, Gunhilde Brandt of Morehead City, North Carolina survives her. Friends may call Monday July 8, 2002 and Tuesday July 9, 2002 from 2 to 4 & 7 to 9 PM at Joseph W. Sorce F.H. Inc., 728 West Nyack Rd., West Nyack, NY (845) 358-4433, www.sorcefuneralhome.com. A Memorial Service is planned for July 13, 2002 at 11:00 AM in the Clarkstown Reformed Church in West Nyack, Rockland County, New York. Should you wish to remember Mickey, a contribution to Hi-Tor Animal Care Center, 65 Firemans Memorial Drive, Pomona, New York 10970, would be appreciated.

title: Campaign Reform's Worst Enemy
description: The Federal Election Commission has embarked on a suicide mission. It has issued regulations that will undermine the centerpiece of the McCain-Feingold campaign-finance reform law: its ban on soft money. By taking this step, the commission will only succeed in making itself the next target of reform.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: BABCOCK BORSIG ON THE BRINK Babcock Borsig, a German engineering company employing 22,000 people, filed for protection from creditors after two days of talks with banks and politicians broke down. Babcock needed 200 million euros ($196 million) to pay June salaries but banks are reluctant to extend more credit. Its debt amounted to 1.5 billion euros at the end of March. Chancellor Gerhard Schroder was still pursuing ways to avert the collapse, which would be the fourth major corporate failure this year. Babcock makes steam turbines, power plants and industrial boilers. (Bloomberg News)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Croatia: Prime Minister To Form New Cabinet
description: Croatia's reformist prime minister, Ivica Racan, resigned to rid himself of a troublesome coalition partner and is expected to form a new cabinet with the backing of minor parties. His decision ends a fractious 30-month relationship between two parties that united to defeat the nationalist party founded by Croatia's late president, Franjo Tudjman. The rift had been threatening to stymie reforms Croatia needs to undertake to join NATO and the European Union. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Japan Clears Cancer Drug; AstraZeneca Scores Coup
description: AstraZeneca said yesterday that its new cancer drug, Iressa, had been approved to treat lung cancer in Japan, making it the first of a new class of cancer medicines to reach the market anywhere, beating Erbitux from ImClone Systems.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: AIDS Ruling
description: Upholding a lower-court decision, the Constitutional Court ruled that the government must provide AIDS drugs to pregnant women infected with H.I.V. to prevent its transmission to unborn babies. In April, government officials agreed to provide the drugs in public hospitals after months of wavering. But the court's decision was still cheered by advocates for AIDS patients. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Behind a Century of Photos, Was There a Jewish Eye?
description: TO be a great photographer, Garry Winogrand liked to claim during the 1970's, it was first of all necessary to be Jewish. The best ones, in his opinion -- past and present, himself included, naturally -- shared this birthright. Jewish photographers by his definition were nervy, ironic, disruptive of artistic norms and proud outsiders. Eugne Atget, he happily argued (on no genealogical grounds), must have been Jewish because his photographs of French life on the tattered fringes seemed so Jewish in spirit.

title: June 30-July 6: INTERNATIONAL; AVOIDING JUDGMENT
description: The birth of the International Criminal Court was accompanied by a spat in the U.N. Security Council. The U.S. -- fearing antagonistic countries might be politically motivated to punish American troops -- demanded that a renewal of the mandate for international peacekeepers in Bosnia include immunity for the force's soldiers. The Europeans, who with much of the rest of the world believe the court will help fight genocide and war crimes, refused. The U.S. vetoed the mandate, but agreed to one extension, then another. The second expires July 15. Serge Schmemann

Hough Jr., a United Church of Christ minister and the president of the Union Theological Seminary in New York, officiated at the home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Dr. Michael Lewis.

title: BackTalk; It's the Little Things That Made Williams Special
description: In the vastness of the void left by his passing -- all those achievements, all those contradictions -- I find myself lapsing into what would ordinarily be thought of as the incidentals of Ted Williams's life. The big things that meant so much to so many for so long are, happily, available to be cherished forever in sanctuaries like Cooperstown and Fenway Park, but for me it is the little things that emerge now to define him, the things that made him, in the end, so very dear.

title: Straw's The Boss
description: After several decades of carrying the same bag year-round, many women are once again carrying summer bags. A few are 1950's-vintage raffia-decorated beach totes now being carried in the city, including the elephant rattan bag, above, and the 1940's white chalk-beaded straw pouch, left.

title: An Iranian Musical Spectacle That Draws Audiences In
description: IN 1969 a young Iranian actor named Mohammad Ghaffari took the British director Peter Brook to the village of Neyshabur in northeastern Iran to watch a performance of ''Ta'ziyeh,'' an indigenous form of Persian music-theater. Part ritual, part spectacle, ''Ta'ziyeh'' is presented once a year to tell the story of the Battle of Kerbala, in which Muhammad's grandson, Hussein, and his followers were killed in A.D. 680.

title: Farah Kathwari, Mubashir Mohi-ud-Din
description: Farah Maryam Kathwari, the daughter of Farida and Farooq Kathwari of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married at her parents' house yesterday to Mubashir Mohi-ud-Din, a son of Sakina Mohi-ud-Din and Dr. Ghulam Mohi-ud-Din of Potomac, Md. Imam Feisal Abdul Rauf performed the Islamic ceremony.

title: Robyn Altman, Brendan Doherty
description: Robyn Michelle Altman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gene M. Altman of Niskayuna, N.Y., was married on Thursday to Brendan Joseph Doherty, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Doherty of Guilford, Conn. Rabbi Anna R. Sugarman officiated at the Glen Sanders Mansion, a historic house in Scotia, N.Y.

title: Re-engineering the Drug Business
description: As Matthew Brzezinski's article (June 23) makes clear, the reason illegal drugs cost so much is that they're illegal. And the cost to the buyer doesn't include the costs involved in keeping them illegal. It's the taxpayer who foots the bill for the border patrols, police narcotics squads and the court and prison employees directly involved in the enforcement of our drug laws -- and for the new prisons to accommodate the growing numbers of convicted dealers and users.

title: Advances on the Stem Cell Front
description: Congress remains stuck over whether and how to impose a ban on human cloning. Meanwhile, researchers have been reporting significant progress in experiments on stem cells, the key ingredient needed for therapeutic cloning and other cell therapies. The advances have been used by both sides in this fractious debate to support their arguments for and against a cloning ban. The real lesson is that cell therapy is a fast-moving, highly fluid field where all reasonable pathways to progress should be left open. Congress must tread very carefully lest it damage the prospects for important medical advances.

title: Complexity Made Simple
description: Q: In your new book, ''A New Kind of Science,'' you propose a radical notion about the development of the natural world. Could you try to explain your big idea?

title: Behind Each Stroke, The Art of Eloquence
description: DAVID DUNLOP'S stock of aphorisms, ideas and lore about art is roughly equal to the supplies that he takes with him on a trip to paint landscapes.

title: Q. & A.
description: To Wed in Vienna or Prague?

title: Police Arrest Two Pilots Over Incident On July 4
description: Two Florida pilots who led police helicopters and Air Force jets on a July 4 chase across the skies above Queens were arrested yesterday on charges of reckless endangerment after they ended another day of flying, the authorities said last night.

title: June 30-July 6; COMING UP
description: Congress returns from recess on Monday to consider accounting reforms and domestic security. President Bush speaks about corporate responsibility on Wall Street on Tuesday.

title: BackTalk; Maligned and Marginalized at Tennessee, a Whistle-Blower Endures
description: The last time I visited my favorite whistle-blower, Linda Bensel-Meyers, in Knoxville, her office window faced the University of Tennessee's 104,000-seat football stadium. She kept her back to the window so as not to be intimidated, although she did not dismiss my question about snipers. When I called last week, she said she had just been moved to a windowless office in the bowels of the building. Now she felt safer, but marginalized.

title: Liberating the Appetite
description: Next Sunday is Bastille Day and many French restaurants are offering menus of traditional dishes in honor of the holiday.

title: Gina Levine, Daniel Levy
description: Gina Robyn Levine, a daughter of Elise Levine and Cantor Elliot Levine of North Caldwell, N.J., was married on Thursday to Daniel Barry Levy, the son of Judy Levy and Dr. Stephen J. Levy of Nanuet, N.Y. The bride's father officiated at Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J.

title: More Than a Bed and Breakfast
description: WE needed sunshine. We needed bird song. And we needed to get them on the cheap. We found what we needed while sampling France's fast-growing network of B & Bs -- chambres d'htes -- and taking a meandering drive through the rolling countryside between Bordeaux and Toulouse.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Incumbents Win Support At Computer Associates

title: Family Planning
description: It started with a premonition from a friend who was crazy, though mostly in good ways. She was a storyteller with a hooting laugh, and one afternoon in front of my wife and daughters, she launched into a tale about how she'd once gotten a job when she showed the boss that she could fit her fist in her mouth. When my friend finished her tale, we all realized that my younger daughter, then 5, had her fist all the way inside her mouth. Out of nowhere, the friend said, ''That child is going to be pregnant by the time she's 15.'' I thought of those words the day my friend died. I thought of them again the day I learned that my daughter was pregnant. She was 15.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COWMAN, IRVING
description: COWMAN-Irving. Beloved husband of Janet. Loving father of Lacey. Dear brother of Roslyn. Retired, dedicated Art Director at Young and Rubicam for twenty-seven years. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: Momentum Is Fleeting. So How to Capture It in Funds?
description: THOSE who think mutual funds should be judged only over the long term will have trouble making sense of the top-performing mutual fund advisory newsletter of the last two decades.

title: Shocked by Scandals? These Are Nothing!
description: A LOT has been written lately about the collapse of corporate credibility, and no wonder. We've had the dot-com meltdown, accounting scandals and allegations of law-breaking by high-profile executives. Even Martha Stewart has been the subject of an insider-trading investigation.

title: Margaret Lynn, Led Army Theater, Dies at 81
description: Margaret E. Lynn, who directed the Army's extensive, worldwide theatrical program that encouraged participation by soldiers, officers and their dependents, died on June 11 at a hospital in Fairfax, Va. She was 81.

description: Weeks

title: How to Succeed in Texas by Really, Really Trying
description: Texas in the late 70's and early 80's was one big, baroque barbecue. Oil was $30 a barrel, real estate was booming and the savings and loans were riding high. I was in my 20's then, and all I really remember is an endless blur of parties, Champagne, lam and really big hair. I went through three tuxedos and 15 pairs of evening pumps. Then it was over. In 1986 oil prices plummeted, the banks collapsed and the savings-and-loan scandal finished off the romp. When some formerly rich friends of mine had a ''we are poor'' party, I knew it was time to return to New York.

title: Destination: Vietnam
description: SAIGON REPUBLIC opened just three months ago in a tiny, invitingly dark storefront at the leading edge of the wave of gentrification rolling down the East Hill of the Palisades through Englewood's central business district. Unlike the dozens of Vietnamese restaurants around the country that reflexively call themselves Saigon This or Saigon That, it comes by its name honestly.

title: Four Harvard Crews Reach Henley Royal Regatta Finals
description: All four Harvard entries in the semifinals of today's Henley Royal Regatta won their heats to advance to finals Sunday. The most anticipated semifinal, an all-American heat of the Temple Challenge Cup, matched Harvard's Eastern Sprint championship heavyweight freshmen eight against Marist College's varsity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLAVITO, WILLIAM V.
description: COLAVITO-William V. Age 74, of Roslyn Heights, passed away on July 3, 2002. Beloved husband of Madeline. Devoted father of Nick (Elaine), Terry DeMaria (Bob), Bill (Terri), and Steve (Katie). Cherished grandfather of Danielle, Bobby, Kristen, Nicky, Michelle, Jenny, Brittany, Kaleigh, Kimberly, Lauren and Ashley. Reposing at the Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Monday 11am, St. Mary's RC Church, Roslyn.

title: June 30-July 6: INTERNATIONAL; MIDEAST
description: Two weeks without a suicide bombing increased support for the Israeli occupation of seven major West Bank cities. Israel's departing chief of staff, Shaul Mofaz, said that troops would remain for months, and that only the expulsion or replacement of Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, might prompt a withdrawal. Mr. Arafat managed to dislodge two security chiefs, but days after he dismissed them. However, there were suspicions that Mr. Arafat was acting less in the spirit of reform and more in that of weakening potential rivals.

title: I Adore You, but Not Your Portfolio
description: AT least I didn't buy WorldCom. Or Tyco International. Or Enron. I'm relieved, but not because my portfolio has escaped the torments of those stocks. Instead, I'm cheered because sidestepping those disasters means that I won't have to be gently, but endlessly, ribbed about it by the one person who would never forget such an investment blunder: my husband, John.

description: Almost every day, it seems, one chief executive or another steps down. And sometimes the departures are amid accusations of scandal or fraud.

description: Northern California visitors can get a bird's-eye view of the region's glorious redwoods riding high above the forest floor.

description: WHITE-Timothy. We will miss your wisdom, your kindness and your bowtie. The music business will never be the same. Love, Chynna & Billy Baldwin

title: Elizabeth Velsquez, Jonathan Malkin
description: Elizabeth Del Rosario Velsquez, the daughter of Dr. Elizabeth Taboada Velsquez and Dr. Roger Velsquez of Gainesville, Fla., was married last evening to Jonathan David Malkin, a son of Cynthia Sharpe Malkin and Dr. Richard Malkin of Sarasota, Fla. The Rev. Sergio Soler performed the ceremony at La Asuncin Roman Catholic Cathedral in Len, Nicaragua.

description: Best Bet

title: Record Industry Is Attacked By a Top Star
description: Michael Jackson took a feud with his record company to the streets of Manhattan yesterday, charging the recording industry with racism and opportunism at the expense of minority performers.

title: What if It's All Been a Big Fat Lie?
description: If the members of the American medical establishment were to have a collective find-yourself-standing-naked-in-Times-Square-type nightmare, this might be it. They spend 30 years ridiculing Robert Atkins, author of the phenomenally-best-selling ''Dr. Atkins' Diet Revolution'' and ''Dr. Atkins' New Diet Revolution,'' accusing the Manhattan doctor of quackery and fraud, only to discover that the unrepentant Atkins was right all along. Or maybe it's this: they find that their very own dietary recommendations -- eat less fat and more carbohydrates -- are the cause of the rampaging epidemic of obesity in America. Or, just possibly this: they find out both of the above are true.

title: Sumer Reads
description: 'Dear Mr. Word Maven,'' writes Gary Hart of Troublesome Gulch, Colo. ''Given the great power you obviously possess over today's fashion in the American language, can you possibly stop book reviewers, including in your own estimable paper, from using the word read (as in 'this book is a great read') as a noun? Would we permit someone to describe an excellent meal as a good eat or a fine movie as a good see? No, of course not! This is wrong. It is course [sic]. It is -- illiterate.''

title: June 30-July 6: FRONT LINES; IRAQ PLANNING, SO FAR
description: A classified military planning document envisions air, land and sea-based forces attacking Iraq from the north, south and west -- in a campaign to topple President Saddam Hussein. It calls for a major offensive from Kuwait and air assault from bases in as many as eight different countries. The document, prepared by planners at the Central Command in Tampa, Fla., was described by someone who expressed frustration that it did not employ post-gulf war military innovations. The document does not specify timing for any attack or suggest that one is imminent. Eric Schmitt

title: Chiefs' Departures Decline From 2001
description: Almost every day, it seems, one chief executive or another steps down. And sometimes the departures are amid accusations of scandal or fraud.

title: $4 MILLION FOR BLACK TROOPERS
description: The state attorney general's office has settled a lawsuit for more than $4 million with 13 black state troopers who were among the first to raise the issue of racial profiling. The resolution of the suit, filed in 1993, means the troopers will receive payments of $225,000 to $500,000 for back pay and emotional distress. Karen DeMasters

title: 'On Whale Island'
description: We've been driving for 3,260 miles, two weeks through twelve states. Summer-hot blacktop, the whining of my off-road tires louder than my radio. I like to think that for the whole trip I've been dragging this enormous eraser behind my truck and it has eradicated all of my past, nothing but dust bunnies in my wake. Receding farther and farther in the distance is a twelve-by-thirty-foot storage garage, the tightly packed, stacked, and compressed mass of stuff I've been calling my life for too many years. I secretly pray for a fire.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Sunday about changing attitudes toward Prozac and other antidepressants misstated the chemical relationship between Allegra and Seldane, two anti-allergy medicines cited in the article as examples of drug companies' efforts to develop new drugs from older ones. Allegra was developed from a chemical formed when Seldane was metabolized in the body; it is not an enantiomer, or mirror-image isomer, of Seldane.

title: Handcuffed Man Escapes From Police Van
description: Aman arrested yesterday on charges of marijuana possession escaped from a police van outside a precinct station house in Brooklyn and fled in handcuffs, the police said.

description: Minnesota opens training camp on July 26 in Mankato, Minn. The 31 other N.F.L. teams open camp as early as July 20 (San Francisco and Houston) and no later than July 28 (Tampa Bay and Indianapolis).

title: Reaction to Fires Hurts Colorado Tourism
description: THE physical damage of fires plaguing Colorado since March has been bad enough, with the size of one blaze last month at about 140,000 acres, a record for the state. Now, officials are beginning to assess the economic damage, a large component of which is tourism and recreation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, THEODORE H.
description: LIEBERMAN-Theodore H. (Herbert), at age 72. Loving husband of Marjorie. Beloved brother of Gloria and brotherin-law of Stephen and Naomi. Cherished uncle of Geri and Roy, Andrew and Susan, Judy and Ray, Scott and Barbara. Adored by many great nieces and nephews. Retired from Grey Advertising as Sr. V.P. after 45 years of dedicated service, Herbert was loved by a large family and many friends. We will miss his presence. Funeral services Sunday, 10:30AM at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills.

title: Celeste Joseph, William Jennings
description: Celeste Dianne Joseph, the daughter of Coralie Dowdye Joseph of Larchmont, N.Y., and Warneford Joseph of the Bronx, was married on Thursday in Mamaroneck, N.Y., to William Irving Jennings, a son of Dr. Ann S. Jennings-Purnell and a stepson of the late George Purnell. The Rev. Pauline Wardell-Sankoh performed the ceremony at the Mamaroneck United Methodist Church.

title: From Wood And String, Crafting a Sound That's Vintage
description: GEORGE YOUNGBLOOD seldom picks up his business phone, even though he has no answering machine. He does not advertise and only has a small identifier, Youngblood Music Workshop, on the porch of his unassuming old farmhouse, which abuts the West Side Cemetery in Guilford.

title: I Say Yip-Yip, You Say Ruff-Ruff: Small Dogs Lobby for Own Dog Run
description: About two years ago, Aubrey Lees adopted a red wirehair dachshund she named Harry, and since then she has come to think of herself as a good judge of canine personality. Harry, for instance, is uncomfortable around large dogs, and prefers the company of small dogs because he is small, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEMPER, JAMES S. JR.
description: KEMPER-James S. Jr. The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and members of Boys & Girls Clubs of America wish to express their profound sorrow over the passing of Mr. James S. Kemper Jr., member of our Board of Governors and a lifelong advocate for children. Mr. Kemper devoted 40 years of service to Boys & Girls Clubs; our Midwest headquarters, the Kemper Training and Service Center, is named in his honor. A recipient of the Herbert Hoover Humanitarian Award from Boys & Girls Clubs of America for his passionate commitment to America's youth, Mr. Kemper's positive influence will be felt for generations to come. We will miss him greatly. Boys & Girls Clubs of America Arnold I. Burns, Chairman Roxanne Spillett, President

description: IT'S been a tough year for Trinidad and Tobago. Tourism is way down, and its members of parliament are still fighting over disputed elections last December. But worst of all is the alleged theft of their national symbol: the steel drum.

title: For Anne Heche, the Stage Is Another New Dimension
description: ANNE HECHE would prefer to talk about her new Broadway role replacing Jennifer Jason Leigh in David Auburn's Pulitzer Prize-winning play ''Proof.'' But there is one question that just keeps pressing on the mind: Does Ms. Heche still think she is ''Celestia,'' the half-sister of Jesus Christ come to spread her message of love to the world?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKS, LYDIA G.
description: FRANKS-Lydia G. Died peacefully on July 2, 2002 at the age of 90 years. She is survived by her beloved and devoted husband of 70 years of marriage, Andrew, her loving daughter, Joy Catapano, and loving son and daughterin-law, Andrew Jr. and Linda. Lydia was predeceased by her cherished daughter, Norma, and son-in-law, Frank Catapano. She is deeply missed by her adoring eleven grandchildren and eight greatgrandchildren. Lydia was a woman of elegance and conviction, completely devoted to her family, whose loving spirit will live on with us always. As she requested, services were private.

title: A Music Dictionary Tries to Remain Companionable
description: ''Man is the world's dictionary-making animal.'' So begins Percy A. Scholes's entry on dictionaries of music in The New Oxford Companion to Music, edited by Denis Arnold and published in two expansive volumes in 1983. Scholes, an English musicologist who died in 1958, was biased. In 1938, he himself wrote the prototype for that dictionary, a fattish volume geared toward nonspecialists.

title: On the Inside Looking Out
description: For Adrien Brody, the lead in Roman Polanski's top-prize-winning film, ''The Pianist,'' the limousine crawl through throngs of peering fans at Cannes was a little unsettling. ''I can now fully empathize with fish in an aquarium,'' he says. ''I felt like having a sign that said, 'Please Don't Tap on the Glass.''' But for his mother, the photojournalist Sylvia Plachy, it was a chance to turn celebrity inside out -- capturing the mad curiosity a star inspires rather than the star himself.

title: Mutual Funds Report; Variable Annuities Offer Safety, at a Price
description: AS if variable annuities, the insurance industry's version of mutual funds, were not bewildering enough, insurers have added a batch of features intended to protect investors from a stock market that lately has not seemed to know which way is up.

title: Beach Development Stirs New Fight
description: THE Southampton Town Board will revisit the old debate this week over how much development belongs on the beachfront -- home to some of the biggest and most fanciful summer homes in the Hamptons -- when it considers a six-month construction ban along the town's 25 miles of waterfront.

title: Afghan Official Is Assassinated; Blow to Karzai
description: A senior member of Afghanistan's government was assassinated by gunmen lurking outside his office in Kabul today, prompting confusion in the capital with the latest political attack on the American-backed government.

title: Mutual Funds Report; Best Ideas, Rethought
description: SEVERAL big investment firms offer mutual funds that show off their analysts' stock-picking prowess by buying their favorite stocks. But Morgan Stanley has come up with a better idea: dropping its ''best ideas'' fund after four years of subpar returns.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CORRIGAN, PAUL
description: CORRIGAN-Paul. In memory of our beloved son, Paul Corrigan, 1950-1999.

title: Untangling the Thicket
description: Round brushes -- and paddle brushes aren't the only tools out there for taming unruly locks. Beauty companies are offering brushes and combs engineered for every type of tress-stress imaginable. Bruno Meglio, a Los Angeles stylist, has unveiled the RevoStyler (center, $39), a rotating electronic brush with an anti-tangle system that is designed to straighten the curliest hair. The brush was introduced in an infomercial last month, and more than 300,000 sold within two weeks (www.revostyler). Frdric Fekkai's detangling tortoise comb (bottom) with wide round-edge teeth, smoothes out knots without scraping the scalp ($20 to $30 at his salon, 15 East 57th Street, 212-583-3350), while John Barrett's tortoise comb with curved, uneven teeth ($7.50 at the John Barrett salon at Bergdorf Goodman, 212-872-2000) is intended to be used in the shower to detangle hair and evenly distribute conditioner. At Bigelow Chemists, well-out brushes include the Widu (far left, $38), which has widely spaced wooden bristles to reduce hair breakage, and the Acca Kappa (left, $28), which has transparent bristles designed to massage and relax the scalp without causing split ends and flyaways. KAREN ROBINOVITZ

title: Decision Raises Questions About Discrimination Law
description: NICOLE ANNE THIBODEAU was single and 19 years old in 1997 when she learned that she was pregnant. Counting on the money she earned working as a secretary and bookkeeper for a small architectural firm in Chester, Ms. Thibodeau felt comfortable that she could support herself and her child.

title: On Steeds of Steel
description: POLICE Officer Richard Alaimo of Yonkers thought he had hit the lottery when he was tapped for the department's new bicycle corps four years ago. He liked bike riding because it evoked carefree childhood joy, until it became the daily grind. ''Now, I hate it,'' he said. ''I have a new bike at home; I don't even want to look at it.'' But he jests.

title: View of Pine Barrens Through Painterly Lens
description: TWO one-person exhibitions by Philadelphia artists at The Noyes Museum of Art offer a contemplative diversion to the frenetic summertime pace of the boardwalk and the gaming tables of nearby Atlantic City.

description: SOMEBODY up there likes the Westport Country Playhouse.

description: Other European governments are pressing Switzerland to ferret out tax cheats, a move the Swiss are resisting mightily because they fear it would frighten capital out of their banks.

title: Ubiquitous in Greenburgh
description: POLITICS has never been just a career for Paul J. Feiner. It is more like a compulsion.

title: Big Week in Amonte Stakes
description: If right wing Tony Amonte, the only remaining upper-tier unrestricted free agent, continues to spurn Toronto's reported offer of $32 million over five years, the Rangers and the Islanders will probably emerge as the favorites to sign him this week.

title: Word for Word/Wild Blue Yonder; Drinking and Flying: Nothing New Under the Sun
description: IN the aviation industry, there is zero tolerance for flying while drunk. In each of the last two years, only 9 of 10,000 airline crew members tested positive for alcohol in random tests by the Federal Aviation Administration, and none were pilots for major airlines. So it was startling news last week that two co-pilots for America West Airlines, taxiing a planeload of passengers about to take off for Phoenix, were ordered back to the gate in Miami and charged with being under the influence of alcohol. The pilots were quickly fired and lost their licenses.

title: Something Old Is Made New
description: A FAMILIAR old ballet may look unexpectedly new when the Kirov Ballet of St. Petersburg comes to the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday. The opening-night attraction is ''La Bayadre,'' the exotic tale of love and treachery that Marius Petipa choreographed in 1877.

description: Medical History

description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Property/Chelsea; A Building Used for Storage Now Houses Artists
description: THE remains of the High Line railroad over 25th Street between 10th and 11th Avenues is ample reminder of the industrial past of west Chelsea. But today buildings that once housed garment manufacturers and, later, moving and storage operations are being converted into spaces for artists' and photographers' studios and the galleries that exhibit their work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, BEN
description: KAPLAN-Ben. On June 26, 2002 at the age of 88, after a long life of adventure and public service. A great athlete in his youth, superb golfer, he served in the U.S. Army, 1942 to 1945, landed at Omaha Beach, June 6, 1944, and survived the Battle of the Bulge. In post-war Europe, he served with UNRRA, AJDC and the U.S. Displaced Persons Commission, Department of State. Subsequently, he joined the United Nations Congolese Mission and the World ORT in Mali. From 1968 to 1990, he was Director of Administration and Assistant Treasurer of the Jewish Association for Services for the Aged in New York. His wife Betty predeceased him. He is survived by his nieces Sharon Hutner Brown and Joan Hutner Marsteller, nephews Dennis and Robert Freeman, step daughter Margaret Fishman Erickson, stepson Robert Fishman and brother-in-law Mike Gladstone. He leaves a wide circle of friends and colleagues. A memorial service will be announced.

title: Vengeance in the Cotswolds And Other Intrigues
description: Where have all the mysteries gone? Was the death of Morse -- and, later, of John Thaw, the actor who created the role -- a sign of closure? For the past year, viewers of television mysteries have had to satisfy their appetite by judicious cable surfing, snaring a rerun of Morse or Poirot on A&E, catching a ''Cracker'' on BBCA, searching for a second ''Second Sight'' anywhere, anytime, while always wondering, haven't we seen this before? One could always fall back on ''C. S. I.'' Or rummaging behind the television set one might find a tape of an old forgotten Miss Marple. Where are you, Rumpole, when we need you?

title: Ideas & Trends; Science Needs a Healthy Negative Outlook
description: IT seems a fairly obvious idea: when science experiments are successful, the results are published in a well-respected journal for all to see and the body of human knowledge expands. But the sad truth about science is that most experiments fail and the hypotheses that seduced researchers turn out not to be true or, at least, the studies provide no evidence that they are true. Are such studies any less important, any less successful? And what happens to them?

title: Power Cable Is Restored
description: In time for the hottest days of summer, an electric cable under Long Island Sound that carried 600 megawatts of imported power to Nassau, Suffolk and Queens has been restored to service but will run at lower capacity, the Long Island Power Authority said last week.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday showing the administration of the death penalty state by state omitted one aspect of the situation in Delaware. Delaware is among the states in which judges can issue death sentences after a jury offers a recommendation.

title: July 1-6
description: DEAD-ENDY Jean-Marie Messier built Vivendi, a French water utility, into one of the world's largest media conglomerates, with acquisitions like the Universal film studio and music company, the USA Networks cable television network and the publisher Houghton Mifflin. He intended to make Vivendi a digital storehouse of media assets, delivered directly to cellphones, handhelds, personal computers and televisions. But the hoped-for future of digital convergence has yet to arrive, and investors have soured on such ungainly media conglomerates. Vivendi labored under huge debts as business slowed, and Mr. Messier, above, was finally ousted as chairman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORTEN, WALTER

Devoted father of Barbara Jonas and Kathleen Fuhr, son-in-law, Howard, and grandchildren, Jennifer, Kenneth and Nicole. Graduated Yale Class of 1939. Past Master of his Masonic Lodge and National Sojourners, President Emeritus of the National Arts Club, Chairman of the Art and Antique Seminar of Monmouth County. Funded the Walter Borten Distinguished Artist Award at the Ringling School of Art and Design in Sarasota, Fla., and member of the Ivy League and Yale Clubs, and helped restore the landmark building of the National Arts Club. He will be greatly missed by the many lives he touched. Services were private. Contributions in his name can be made to the National Arts Club.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Antidote Is Still Whispered
description: AT the 14th International AIDS conference, which opens today in Barcelona, the tone can be expected to be both optimistic (new drugs on the horizon) and bleak (the global epidemic). For the next six days, experts from around the world will discuss the latest advances in controlling AIDS, which now causes 14,000 new infections daily -- about 10 per minute. Scores of presentations will feature the still unproved AIDS vaccine, which is seen as the only chance to contain this epidemic.

title: June 30-July 6: ENVIRONMENT; DE-FUNDING THE SUPERFUND
description: The Bush administration is scaling back the Superfund program, rekindling criticism that the White House has bowed to corporate interests. Decontamination work had already begun on 33 sites in 18 states, including one in Edison, N.J., that manufactured Agent Orange during the Vietnam war, and others from Montana to Florida. But the fund is hundreds of millions of dollars short of what it needs to remain on schedule, and the administration has decided not to pay to continue those cleanups. By refusing to push for renewing the corporate taxes that supported the fund, Democrats said, the administration is abandoning the fundamental precept of the Superfund -- that the polluter pays -- and is unfairly shifting more of the cost of cleanups to taxpayers. Katharine Q. Seelye

title: June 30-July 6: NATIONAL; MORE EXECUTION DEBATE
description: A federal judge in Manhattan, citing the growing use of DNA to exonerate death row inmates, ruled that the federal death penalty law violates the constitutional right to due process because it irrevocably deprives innocent people of the opportunity to prove their innocence. The judge, Jed S. Rakoff, hearing a case involving a 1999 drug-related murder, said the death penalty was ''tantamount to foreseeable, state-sponsored murder of innocent human beings.'' The ruling is the first to find the federal death penalty unconstitutional, lawyers say; the government is expected to appeal. Benjamin Weiser

title: Picturing The Worst Happening
description: NO nuclear holocaust, biochemical plague, ecological disaster or terror from outer space. As far as post-apocalypse movies go, the latest, ''Reign of Fire,'' has a rather bizarre premise: a brood of fire-breathing dragons, inadvertently released from centuries of dormancy, reduce most of the earth to a cinder. And in true ''Road Warrior'' fashion, a hardy band of survivors is left to save humanity.

title: LANGUAGE REQUIREMENT SUSPENDED
description: The state Board of Education has decided to suspend foreign language requirements for high school students for a year because some school districts are having trouble providing classes. School districts can still choose to require proficiency in a foreign language. But the state will not require language classes as a requirement for graduation for all students, the Education Department announced last week. Public schools will still be required to provide foreign language classes from kindergarten through eighth grade. The Board of Education plans to review the language requirements, along with other standards for graduation, in December. John Sullivan

title: Naughty but Nice

An earthquake? No, it was showtime at Forty Deuce, a new nightclub where burlesque dancers strut their way down a horseshoe-shaped bar and the shelves are hydraulically lowered to make for a bigger stage.

''I don't exactly know why, but people always seem to see echoes of their own lives in my films. They really feel for me.''

title: Private Sector; In Shadow of Martha's Travails, A Small Competitor Is Smiling

Ms. Madden, the chief executive of Chris Madden Inc., said last week that her home-as-a-haven marketing message has recently attracted interest from more than 100 potential licensing partners, including Fieldcrest, Cannon and Lawrence Eyewear. In addition, she said, the Hearst Corporation has approached her for a magazine proposal and the American Express Publishing Corporation wants to discuss a similar project. She is preparing a prototype for Hearst, she said, and requests for speaking engagements have tripled.

title: The Wisecracks of Victory, the Punch Lines of Defeat
description: THERE'S something funny about television sports coverage these days. Literally. On ESPN's ''Mohr Sports'' this spring, the host, Jay Mohr, dressed up like Ricki Lake for a sketch about the National Football League draft. Over on TNT's ''Inside the N.B.A.,'' the producers played a practical joke on one of their own hosts, Charles Barkley -- it involved a suit of armor and a pillow -- and replayed it for viewers from five different angles.

title: New York Defined, Perhaps
description: From Paul Strand's solemn, luxurious 1915 platinum palladium print of workers walking on Wall Street to Sylvia Plachy's dreamy 1993 toy-camera image of an ecstatic crowd in Times Square, street photography in New York has been an essentially Jewish art form. As Max Kozloff writes in NEW YORK: Capital of Photography (The Jewish Museum, New York/Yale University, cloth, $50; paper, $35), the New York we know through photographs is an ''American city visualized by Jews,'' with gentiles like Berenice Abbott and Edward Steichen among the few distinguished exceptions. The book features more than 100 photographs of New York's inhabitants, but it is not truly a documentary project. It is more about the social and psychological essence of the city than about the details of specific historical moments. Kozloff, the former executive editor of Artforum, outlines the economic and cultural forces that drew Jews to photography. He also attempts to define the Jewish sensibility that he sees in the best of these photographs. His arguments can be hard to follow. He writes that Jewish photographers were especially sensitive to a feeling of alienation (or a feeling of community, depending on the picture), while most gentile photographers were not. The evidence he cites is difficult to see in the images themselves. The book's reproductions are thoughtfully arranged. The photographers made their pictures. Now we can argue about what it all might mean. Jake Miller

title: Addressing Corporate Abuses
description: George W. Bush is the first president with an M.B.A., and that training should make him especially well equipped to handle the growing anxiety over corporate scandals. Indeed, with questions still lingering over a 1990 sale by Mr. Bush of $848,560 worth of stock in a company on whose board he sat, the president should be eager to tackle the plague of accounting and insider-trading abuse. Yet the Bush team has been so slow to react to the need for higher standards of disclosure and tougher regulation of business practices that even Congress has moved fast enough to seize the initiative. When the president addresses these issues on Tuesday in a much-anticipated speech in New York City, he needs to lay out a vigorous agenda for reform.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORDAN, JOSEPH
description: JORDAN-Joseph. Of Manhattan on July 1. Born in NYC 96 years ago. Beloved father of Vance Jordan and Jill Jordan Spangler, both of Manhattan. He is also survived by twin grandsons, Ian and Noel Spangler. The first American Director of Boys' Towns of Italy and American Relief for Italy, later Public Relations Director for LAI (now Alitalia), Mr. Jordan raised funds for many similar charitable organizations in the 1940s and '50s. He also wrote scripts for several early television dramas, and in 1966 established a talent agency for children which still bears his name. Though he outlived most of his old friends, he found many new ones in recent years, and all deeply regret the loss of his humor and charm. No service is planned.

title: FINALLY, A STATE BUDGET

The budget does not give a green light for construction of a new sports stadium in Newark, a project dear to the heart of Mayor Sharpe James of Newark. But Mr. James, who is also a state senator, won a pledge from the governor for legislative hearings on the stadium this summer. State officials said the deal would provide enough money to close a $6 billion budget gap, the largest in state history. John Sullivan

title: 'The Black Veil'
description: So there's the matter of our crimes. The remembrance of our misdoings is grievous to us; the burden of them is intolerable. Lies, whispered, of friends' indiscretions; instances of envy — when we hate the people we love; peccadilloes; filched office supplies; inflated expense accounts; violent obsessions of all kinds; reckless speeding; a fender bender whose scene we left; the belt from Macy's we slipped into our own belt loops (they're the easiest thing to take); a copy of Montaigne, nineteenth-century edition, never returned to the library; a kiss stolen from someone else's lover; a night out of state upon a tanned mattress when the energy of adultery seemed so persuasive that we concealed from ourselves all memory of our spouses; gifts never sent; allegiances never acknowledged; inexplicable cruelties to people with bad luck; inexplicable cruelties to friends; the waiter we upbraided that time; we cheated at cards; we cheated at tennis; we cheated at backgammon or at chess or at some board game of our childhood; we tripped that guy in the backfield and then waltzed in for the goal; we took things for granted, took privileges for rights; we demanded things in no way due us. And then with some of us there are worse crimes, crimes unspeakable, though we might write of them, like robbery, battery, or rape. We fell into coercion or abuse or full-scale embezzlement or even murder, the murder of innocents, perhaps; we committed crimes of rage so that afterward we couldn't sleep, couldn't forget, couldn't think straight, and whispered to ourselves, revisiting these instances of our transgression. There's the matter of our crimes.

title: POLLUTION CLEANUP THREATENED
description: As many as 10 Superfund pollution projects in New Jersey may be affected by federal budget cuts proposed by the Bush administration last week. Five sites in Chester, Edison, Marlboro, Montgomery and Rocky Hill face severe funding reductions, according to an report from the Environmental Protection Agency, and another five sites could face lesser cuts. The projects include cleanups of landfills, wells, chemical factories and steel works. In all, some 33 Superfund projects nationwide requiring $450 million are under review, with final decisions on funding due in September. New Jersey leads the nation with 111 Superfund sites. Jeremy Pearce
