title: Personal Business; Companies Adding Benefits for Care of the Elderly
description: WHEN his elderly father fell on a snowy driveway last winter and had trouble getting up, William L'Hommedieu started to think about nursing homes. But he decided that his father could remain in his own home in Pleasant Valley, Mo., after a geriatric nurse made a detailed home evaluation and suggested a few modifications. He added a bathroom shower, for example, and an emergency call button.

title: Amtrak Must Die
description: The title of John Tierney's article (June 16) assumes that Amtrak was actually alive at some point. Congress has never allowed Amtrak to be more than the warmed-over remains of the private system it replaced.

title: That's His Wife Up There Kissing, And It's Not O.K.
description: AT the heart of Yvan Attal's film ''My Wife Is an Actress'' lies a simple question: when an actor and actress are shown kissing on screen, are they acting or are they really kissing? The stock answer from actors is that they are just doing a job (''someone has to do it'') and that sexual attraction plays no role. It is certainly what they tell their spouses. But Mr. Attal, writing and directing his first feature film after more than a decade as an actor, begs to differ.

title: 'Sea Room'
description: For the last twenty years I have owned some islands. They are called the Shiants: one definite, softened syllable, the Shant Isles, like a sea shanty but with the y trimmed away. The rest of the world thinks there is nothing much to them. Even on a map of the Hebrides the tip of your little finger would blot them out, and if their five hundred and fifty acres of grass and rock were buried deep in the mainland of Scotland as some unconsidered slice of moor on which a few sheep grazed, no one would ever have noticed them. But the Shiants are not like that. They are not modest. They stand out high and undoubtable, four miles or so off the coast of Lewis, surrounded by tide-rips in the Minch, with black cliffs five hundred feet tall dropping into a cold, dark, peppermint sea, with seals lounging at their feet, the lobsters picking their way between the boulders and the kelp and thousands upon thousands of sea birds wheeling above the rocks.

description: THE LOBSTER CHRONICLES

title: WORLDCOM OUSTED FROM E-ZPASS
description: New Jersey cancelled its contract last week with Worldcom, the troubled communications giant that has been running the state's E-ZPass toll system. Jamie Fox, the Transportation Commissioner, announced the decision Tuesday, saying, ''New Jersey will be best served by moving to a new vendor.'' He said there would be no service disruptions. Originally Worldcom was not responsible for the system, which was handled by companies that had split off from it after the contract was awarded. But Worldcom agreed to take over the system last year after the original contractor said it could not continue. Mr. Fox said he would name a new group to run the system within 10 days. ''This was a negotiated solution,'' said Peter Lucht, a spokesman for Worldcom. ''Worldcom will work with the state to ensure a smooth transition of operations to the new vendor.'' John Sullivan

His daring productions have challenged the Japanese theatrical status quo, which is, save for a few pockets of experimental work, conservative.

description: A forceful student movement is replacing President Mohammad Khatami as the leading engine for political reform in Iran. Activists at the country's vibrant, overflowing universities say their calls for change are gathering momentum and they are preparing to put delicate issues like renewing relations with the United States to a public vote for the first time.

The AOL Time Warner towers going up at Columbus Circle. Mohawks have worked on them all, and the list goes on.

Because Mr. Stasolla and his co-workers had been trained as part of a study on cardiac arrest, they knew exactly what to do: Mr. Stasolla hooked up a portable automated defibrillator and performed CPR, while Helene Busching and Denise Formisano helped clear the aisle. Another store employee called 911.

title: The Doctor Won't See You Now
description: This article seems like a description of professional misconduct by a physician who should have known better. Had the patient and her husband not exercised their own good judgment, Dr. Siegel might now be dealing with the trauma of contributing to the possible death of his patient. It's hard to imagine this doctor treating his wife, mother or child in the same lackadaisical way.

title: The Fashion Stylist
description: Being -- a fashion stylist, Erin Flanagan Lazard is anything but casual, favoring flourish over function when it comes to her closet. Twenty years ago, as a student at an all-girls school in Manhattan, she raided her mother's designer wardrobe before sneaking out to Xenon. Today, she will throw on a vintage Mexican wedding dress and feather earrings by Ralph Lauren when meeting with clients (among them, Jim Carrey, Geena Davis and the model Vendela), or for a playground jaunt with her 2-year-old daughter, short shorts from Scoop with high heels by Manolo Blahnik.

description: Inside most self-styled avant-gardists is a classicist's soul, and the rule extends to underground hip-hop. The best underground rappers and producers are making records that sound like dusty tapes from the late 80's -- the classic era of old-school hip-hop -- with surreal wordplay.

title: Business & Investing; Investor Angst Prompts Funds to Speak Up
description: MUTUAL funds used to avoid direct confrontation with the management of their portfolio companies when they were unhappy about, say, executive pay or director independence. Instead, the funds would quietly sell their shares.

title: A Powerful New Boarder In the 'Trenton Rowhouse'

As he wandered the legislative chambers and the governor's office -- inserting himself quite naturally into the politics of the budget stew -- nobody was confused.

title: Press '1' if You're Steamed
description: Few callers to customer service lines are surprised anymore to be put on hold for 5, 10 or 15 minutes. Most of us also expect that we will be bombarded with sales pitches rather than the soothing music that once played in the background. And we know that when a live person finally comes on, if they're in customer service, we will need billing, and if they're in billing, we will need shipping. Still, nothing prepared us for Patent 6,411,687, issued by the Patent and Trademark Office last week to Peter Bohacek of Dallas and Dieter Schulz of Kanata, Ontario.

Another driver scrimps and saves to buy his own truck. Then he buys another and hires a driver himself, in the belief that business ownership will lead to individual prosperity.

title: Venice vs. Venice
description: Jonathan Reynolds's (June 23) culinary gondola is headed in the right direction! My husband and I visited Venice last month and were amazed at the terrible food and horrendous prices. We had our best experiences at serendipitous choices, rather than following recommendations.

title: PATERSON EX-MAYOR CONVICTED
description: Martin G. Barnes, the former mayor of Paterson, pleaded guilty last week to charges of mail fraud and tax evasion. Appearing Tuesday in Federal District Court in Newark, Mr. Barnes admitted that he had accepted gifts including overseas trips, designer suits and a swimming pool from city contractors. Prosecutors charged the former mayor, a 54-year-old Republican, as part of an ongoing investigation into municipal corruption in New Jersey. Mr. Barnes, Paterson's first black mayor, entered the plea on his last day in office. He is scheduled to be sentenced Nov. 18 and faces from 24 to 37 months in prison. John Sullivan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMERANTZ, MORDECHAI (MOTKE)
description: POMERANTZ - Mordechai (Motke), April 19, 1936-June 27, 2002. Founder of Per Dev Perceptual Development Center in NYC. ''Follow the child and he will show you where he needs to go.'' The staff at PerDev mourns the loss of Motke. He gave the gift of a therapeutic approach that supported holistic development. His perceptual Development Therapy changed the lives of thousands of children and adults through the enhancement of their perceptual skills and performance potential. Motke previously taught at Tel Aviv University and Bar Ilan University, and was Chief of Pediatric Psychology at the Hospital in Nessziona. He is survived by his wife, children and grandchild in Israel and his beloved colleagues in Israel & NY. Condolences to Pomerantz C/O PerDev 441 West End Ave., NY, NY 10024. Donations in his honor can be made to FJC-PerDev, 130 East 59th Street, 14th Floor New York, New York 10022.

title: Some Merchants Tire of Going Hollywood
description: Standing last week outside his restaurant on narrow Pell Street, Danny Ng said he had nothing personal against Spike Lee. Mr. Ng even tried to be pleasant two weeks ago when Mr. Lee, the director, brought a fleet of trucks and camera crews to the neighborhood to film scenes of his new movie, ''25th Hour,'' in which Edward Norton spends a night wandering the city before starting a long prison sentence.

title: CRIME
description: Sharon McCone may have aged only 11 lunar cycles in the 25 years since she solved her first case in Marcia Muller's ''Edwin of the Iron Shoes,'' but this San Francisco private detective has never stopped growing. For that, she deserves a gold star, even though some of the more dramatic changes in her life -- like the time she went up against an international terrorist known as the Diplo-bomber -- now seem a bit desperate. More credit to her, McCone proves in DEAD MIDNIGHT (Mysterious Press/Warner, $24.95) that she has not lost touch with the social values that gave her direction when she was just starting out with All Souls Legal Cooperative.

title: Corrections
description: A time line last Sunday about the Bush administration's diplomatic efforts in the Middle East misstated the chronology of two events, both of which occurred in March 2002. The Passover suicide bombing in Netanya, an Israeli resort town, took place on March 27. Israeli raids that killed at least 40 Palestinians occurred on March 8 -- before, not after the Netanya attack. The time line also misstated the number of Israelis killed in the Netanya bombing. It was 29, not 22.

title: June 30-July 6: FRONT LINES; AFGHAN ASSASSINATED
description: Hajji Abdul Qadir, a vice president in Afghanistan's new government, was killed by gunmen who fired on his car as it left his office in Kabul. Mr. Qadir, an ethnic Pashtun, was an eastern warlord; his appointment by President Hamid Karzai, who is also Pashtun, was seen as a move to balance an administration otherwise dominated by Tajiks. It was unclear who among his many possible enemies might have been responsible. The attack came as U.S. and Afghan investigators tried to unravel the details of an Air Force assault on a village in southern Afghanistan that residents said left 40 dead. Mr. Karzai took the U.S. to task; President Bush called him to express sympathy for the casualties without assigning blame.

description: IT was, as Cliff Johnson, one of the members of the 1977 Yankee team, recalled yesterday, a dysfunctional functional team. It was as though the inmates had taken over the asylum, and the asylum became the paradigm. In baseball terms, despite fights, conflicts, jealousies, antagonisms and, it appeared at times, malice toward all, the Yankees won the championship.

title: For the Theater
description: To the Editor:

title: Check Your Racket At the Door
description: The yellow and blue signs affixed to the lamp posts in front of the Hudson Valley Health and Tennis Club in Hastings-on-Hudson mark the territory of Blu, a new American bistro that replaces Sun, Moon & Spoon on the club's top floor. Despite good reviews, Sun, Moon & Spoon ''was a destination restaurant, that was a problem,'' said Blu's co-chef Thomas Beres, formerly of Atlas in Manhattan. ''You put all your entrees in the $30 range, you're telling people 'come for your anniversary, come for something special, but don't come here every day.' ''

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Not as Rich as Boesky, But Luckier in Court

title: Just One Wheel Replaces 11 Locks in Scotland
description: The Falkirk Wheel, the centerpiece of a project to restore and reconnect the Forth & Clyde and Union canals, a 68-mile waterway linking Glasgow and Edinburgh, opened June 1.

title: Plants That Allergy Sufferers Should Avoid
description: GARDENERS and golfers beware, pollen is in the air. Although hay fever can indeed be caused by hay -- grasses -- there are other culprits, and there are steps a gardener can take to minimize suffering from allergies caused by plants.

title: Venice vs. Venice
description: It's a mistake to ask concierges where to eat; they figure you for a tourist and send you to places they think an American tourist would like. The next time Reynolds is in Venice, I suggest he walk the streets and follow the locals to their dining spots.

title: Mt. Vernon Dreams Buoyed by Empire Zone
description: IMAGINE that abandoned warehouses, brownfields and deteriorating businesses are hotels, a convention center and thriving commerce, and you join the ranks of Mount Vernon officials who believe New York State's Empire Zone program is the answer to the city's economic woes.

title: Caroline Cuthbert, Scott Laidlaw
description: Caroline Varennes Cuthbert, the daughter of Caroline W. B. Cuthbert and Richard I. Cuthbert of Wynnewood, Pa., was married yesterday to William Scott Laidlaw, the son of Donna Kuhn Laidlaw and William K. Laidlaw Jr. of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Robert Gregson, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony in Grafton, Vt.

title: Capitalism Depends on Character
description: When the late 19th-century counterparts of Enron, WorldCom and Global Crossing got into trouble, the investment banker J. Pierpont Morgan took over, allegedly growling at rogue managers, ''Your company belongs to my clients.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Gladiators Make a Point, and Then Another and Another
description: In an Arena Football League game featuring three fewer interceptions than running plays, the New Jersey Gladiators handed the New York Dragons their sixth consecutive loss, pounding them, 76-50, at Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORSBERG, BEATRICE MOORE
description: FORSBERG - Beatrice Moore. 86, of Old Greenwhich, CT, on June 16, 2002, of heart failure. Wife of the late Torsten Forsberg. Daughter of Charles and Josephine Engstrom Moore of Washington, DC, and Stockholm, Sweden. She was a founder of the Connecticut Branch of the Humane Society of the United States, and served on the Executive Board of the Woodycrest Children's Home and the Women's Bible Society of New York.

title: Tristan Borer, John Nugent
description: Dr. Tristan Anne Borer and Dr. John Douglas Nugent, who teach at Connecticut College in New London, are to be married there today. The Rev. Laurence A. M. LaPointe, a Roman Catholic priest, will perform the ceremony in the Harkness Chapel, on campus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, THEODORE MARKS (TEDDY)
description: COHEN - Theodore Marks (Teddy). 75, died June 29, 2002. Beloved son of the late Schmule and Eva Marks Cohen, loving brother of Robert M. and Michael Marks and sisters-in-law Zipty and Cantor Bette, devoted uncle of Margot and Daniel, caring friend of Eileen Reichel. His sweet soul will be remembered by his many friends forever. Donations may be made to UJA/Federation.

title: Women of the West Get Their Own Museum
description: The cowboy is enshrined as an icon at the 37-year-old National Cowboy and Western Heritage Museum in Oklahoma City. Now the cowgirl is getting her due at the National Cowgirl Museum and Hall of Fame, which opened in Fort Worth on June 9.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: AT SEA IN THE CITY

title: Grown, and Still at Home
description: CHERYL CARUSO says she once declared, ''I would rather live in a refrigerator box in Penn Station than move home.'' But a divorce, a broken engagement, foreclosure on her home, eviction from her apartment and insurmountable debt to the I.R.S., lawyers and creditors changed her mind. In November 1996 she moved back in with her parents, John and Therese Caruso, in Fort Salonga.

title: Open Contenders Left Chasing Sorenstam Again
description: Beating Annika Sorenstam is tough enough. Catching her from behind is even tougher.

title: Once Hot, Now Not, Cool Hunters Are in a Deep Freeze
description: ONLY a year ago Lauren Holden, the former director of design inspiration at Nike, speculated that mainstream American teenagers would soon be wearing organic love beads, flaunting these secular rosaries as an insignia of hip. Around the same time, a number of other trend watchers for top corporations suggested that tight, calf-clutching trousers would supplant their slouchy wide-legged counterparts in the wardrobes of urban youth.

title: A Veteran Spot Maintains High Standards
description: THE real news at Mirepoix in Glen Head is not its fifth anniversary celebration, its high rating (second in Nassau County) in the just-out (2002/03) Zagat Survey of Long Island Restaurants, nor the funky, right on the railroad tracks, outdoor dining patio, which is new this season. The major cause for huzzahs is the arrival of Scott Bradley as executive chef.

title: Aspiring to Work Magic With Seafood
description: AN irresistible force has met an immovable object in Rockville Centre. The proverbial force is Rudy's Seafood Restaurant, a South Shore mainstay that was started in 1946 by Rudy Schultz as a tiny fish and chips shack in Oceanside. It gradually became a 120-seat, full-scale neighborhood restaurant specializing in traditional fried seafood. In the early 1980's, it was sold to Gus and Pauline Kayantas, the parents of the present owners, Magda, Jane and John, who were forced to move their operation to Valley Stream.

title: Fighting the Darkness in the Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: Used Cop Cars? They're a Steal
description: PRIVATE citizens cannot order a new police car. But anyone -- collectors, performance enthusaists or just the thrifty -- can buy a used model at auction or through a dealer like Charles (Buz) Bowling of Southern Motor Company in Charlotte, N.C.

title: Comedy Central Meets CNBC
description: Corporate America may be grim from all the scandals, but Wall Street is laughing. E-mail messages making the rounds of hedge fund managers include these proposed new accounting acronyms:

title: Venice vs. Venice
description: Reynolds went to expensive tourist traps instead of restaurants that cater to people who know something of Venice. I lived there for a year, and I love food and wine; there is no way I could have survived without wonderful, inexpensive Venetian restaurants.

title: Amtrak Must Die
description: The Amtrak subsidy, which is minuscule compared to the bloated farm subsidy and the pork-ridden defense budget, is one of the few direct benefits I get from the federal taxes I pay. I have a neighbor who is a dairy farmer. He probably collects more in subsidy from the government than he pays in taxes. Not me. I am one of the folks who pick up the tab, and I need my train service.

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-8

title: Parties With Drug Use Are in No Way Safe
description: To the Editor:

title: By Gordon Parks, A View of Himself And, Yes, Pictures
description: GORDON PARKS had just arrived at the Hudson River Museum here for the opening of a retrospective exhibit of six decades of his photojournalism. The plan was to give a few interviews, sign some autographs and do some mingling. But Mr. Parks had been driven up from his apartment on the East Side of Manhattan in harrowing rush-hour traffic, so the first order of business was refreshment. Within about two minutes, a museum official slid a glass of Cabernet in front of Mr. Parks as he settled into a small back office in the museum.

title: For a Connoisseur's Favorite, a Rare Public Bow
description: NO painter who has fetched $3.8 million at Sotheby's quite qualifies as a secret. That was the price paid, after intense bidding, by the Los Angeles County Museum of Art in 1997 for ''Plague in an Ancient City,'' by the 17th-century Belgian painter Michael Sweerts (1618-64). Yet an exhibition of his work at the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam this spring was the first since a 1958 retrospective, seen only in Rotterdam and Rome. The current survey, four years in the making and on view at the Legion of Honor in San Francisco, is the first Sweerts show ever presented in the United States.

title: When The Glitz Gives Way To Gloom
description: THIS has not been an enjoyable time to be in the entertainment business.

title: Ideas & Trends: Fashion Replay; Imitation Is the Mother of Invention
description: DON'T mention that you heard it here, but the designers have been spotted in Gallagher's again. Gallagher Paper Collectibles, for those who do not follow the doings of the fashion flock, is a grungy subterranean Aladdin's cave in the East Village that stocks an astounding selection of vintage magazines: Vogue in all its editions; Harper's Bazaar going back 100 years; Marie Claire and Mademoiselle; and even more obscure publications like Nova and Twen.

title: Can Democrats Still Take Essex County in a Walk?
description: Candy Straight, a powerful Republican fund-raiser, is wasting no time engaging her Democratic opponent, Joseph DiVincenzo, in the race for Essex County executive.

title: The Nation; The Endless City vs. Its Closing Frontier
description: LOS ANGELES is the only big city built on the promise of the suburban dream. Unlike New York, where migrants move to be part of a continuing civic enterprise, the genius and fundamental weakness of Los Angeles is that you rarely feel obliged to be part of anything. Nothing short of cataclysmic events like riots, earthquakes or a Lakers championship can ignite a strong sense of civic unity.

title: In Defense Of Our Wicked, Wicked Ways
description: ''I CAN stand here and look at this for hours,'' said James B. Twitchell as he parked himself in front of the bottled water section in City Market, just past the jars of $30-per-pound teas and behind the eight-foot display of imported olive oils.

title: Jocelyn Wadsworth, Christopher Dimsey
description: Jocelyn Holmes Wadsworth, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Geoffrey H. Wadsworth of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Christopher Peel Mitchell Dimsey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter S. P. Dimsey of Madrid. The Rev. Dr. Richard E. Murdoch performed the ceremony at Rye Presbyterian Church.

title: Mutual Funds Report; That Sinking Feeling, Again
description: DISAPPOINTING corporate earnings, serial revelations of accounting debacles and fear of terrorism helped make the second quarter agonizing for mutual fund investors. The returns of the vast majority of stock funds were yet again in firmly negative territory.

title: Skirmishes Signal Rent Law Countdown
description: LEGISLATION to renew rent regulation a year early never made it onto the table in Albany during the recent legislative season, primarily because tenant advocates and Democrats in the Assembly wanted to force the gristly issue on Senate Republicans, who wouldn't bite.

title: Portfolios Depressed, Traders Seek Therapy
description: Picture a Wall Street trader striding through the doctor's waiting room and flopping down on the couch. He rages about the collapse of WorldCom, then falls silent.

title: Counting Sheep
description: In addition to an estimated 5,000 to 10,000 elves, the 280,000 citizens of Iceland share their pristine sub-Arctic island with some 500,000 sheep. These they consume at the astonishing annual rate of about 55 pounds per capita. This appetite for lamb -- Americans consumed a little more than a pound per capita in 1999 -- is more than mere culinary enthusiasm; it's a matter of ecological survival. For Iceland's sheep are rapidly depleting the fragile ground cover of grass, moss, sedge and berries that lends the lamb its unmatched flavor but also keeps the thin but irreplaceable topsoil from blowing out to sea and leaving the fertile coast as barren as the uninhabitable interior of volcanic rock and glacier.

title: The Nation: Judicial Intent; The Competing Visions of the Role of the Court
description: LABELS that once comfortably described the range of views on the Supreme Court don't work so well these days. ''Liberal'' versus ''conservative'' means less than it did back when old-fashioned liberals sat on the court. And the new judicial ''activism'' on the right has stripped much usefulness from a handy insult once flung exclusively at liberal judges.

title: Editors' Note; Editors' Note
description: An article beginning on Page 30 of The Times Magazine today describes the world of Richard Wallace, a computer scientist. It reports a dispute in which a former colleague, Ken Goldberg, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley, obtained a restraining order that barred Mr. Wallace from the Berkeley campus.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: E-Tickets
description: To the Editor: About ''Delta and US Airways Charge for Paper Ticket'' (Travel Advisory, June 2): Adding fees to restrict the use of paper tickets does not fluster fliers who know that a ticket in hand is worth a computer full of paperless duds.

title: Gen. Benjamin O. Davis Jr., 89, Dies; Dispelled Racial Myths as Leader of Pilots' Unit
description: Gen. Benjamin O. Davis Jr., who broke color barriers and shattered racial myths as the commander of the Tuskegee Airmen, the pioneering black fighter pilots of World War II, died on Thursday. He was 89.

title: Amtrak Must Die
description: Last Sept. 13, I rode Amtrak from Boston to Portland, Ore., on time, with an overflow load of very grateful air-travel refugees. There were no planes flying and no rental cars to be had. The train crew had put in long hours, some dealing with all manner of craziness while working on trains coming through New York City. Yes, there are duds working on Amtrak. But there are also dedicated men and women who delivered the goods during those terrible days of uncertainty and fear.

description: SPRING FLOWERS, SPRING FROST

title: Their Country 'Tis of Them
description: WHERE WE STAND

title: John Frankenheimer Is Dead at 72; Resilient Director of Feature Films and TV Movies
description: John Frankenheimer, one of the foremost directors of the 1960's with classic films like ''The Manchurian Candidate,'' ''Seven Days in May,'' ''Birdman of Alcatraz'' and ''The Train,'' died of a massive stroke today from complications after spinal surgery. He was 72.

title: Kavita Shah Nik Bafana
description: Kavita Shah, the daughter of Mridula Shah and Kumar Pal Shah of Cresskill, N.J., was married on Friday to Nakul Ravi Bafana, the son of Manju Mutha Bafana and Ravi R. Bafana of Dayton, Ohio. Pandit Anant Dixit, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J.

title: Christiansen Wins Match To Take New Championship
description: A new organization called the WorldChessNetwork.com has made its debut by Richmond, British Columbia, Canada, June 10 through 15.

title: Impressionist Visions
description: WHILE living in Paris some 10 years ago, I developed an obsession: visiting the homes and haunts of artists and writers, hoping, perhaps, to spark a little inspiration of my own. Soon, I happily discovered that my aesthetic indulgences need not be confined to the capital.

title: Copycats' Meow
description: Shoppers who scorn -- designer knockoffs are making an exception this summer. When Balenciaga's $1,000-plus drawstring cargo pants sold out early in the season, stylists and editors were moved to fill the sartorial void by raiding stores like Limited Express for close cousins below, $48 in black or olive). They also fell upon Urban Outfitters ($58 in seafoam green), H&M ($39 with elastic at the ankles) and Club Monaco ($99 for a flowing drawstring number in pewter).

title: Black Coffee Met 2 Sugars At a Crossroads of the World
description: One recent Friday morning at 8, Michael Neto, a construction worker in paint-spattered jeans, poked his head around the back of Faridallah Hamidi's coffee cart on the east side of Eighth Avenue between 42nd and 43rd Streets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOONAM, MARY E.
description: LOONAM-Mary E. On July 3, 2002. Former Public Relations Associate for over forty-five years for Blue Cross Blue Shield of greater New York. Beloved aunt of Ellen Frisch, John Loonam, James Loonam and Elizabeth Loonam. Also survived by many grandnieces and grandnephews. For more information please call Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4 Ave., Brooklyn, NY. Mass of Christian Burial was Saturday, July 6, 9:45, St. Andrews Church. Family requets donations in her memory to The Friends and Relatives of the Institutional Aged, 11 John Street, New York, New York 10038.

title: A Peony Is Queen of the Ball
description: The chic flower of the month -- is the single-petal peony, which has been brilliantly visible at fashionable galas, parties and weddings. Less frilly than the cotton-candylike garden variety, the single-petal breed comes in scarlets, pinks and hot corals with yellow centers; blossoms can open to the size of a luncheon plate. Recently, Avi Adler Designs flew 6,000 of the flowers to Venezuela for a party. The bright blooms have also been spotted in New York at House Beautiful's Giants of Design event, the Robin Hood Foundation's gala and the casino evening staged by the Design Industries Foundation Fighting AIDS.

title: Lindsay Gruber, Christopher Dunham
description: Lindsay deRoy Gruber, the daughter of Linda W. Gruber and Jon D. Gruber of Ross, Calif., was married at her parents' house yesterday to Christopher Dary Dunham, a son of Mary D. Twichell of Beaufort, S.C., and C. Dary Dunham of Lakeville, Conn. The Very Rev. William Rankin, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Manhattan Death March
description: AS the N train makes its wide arc in Long Island City, riders get a brief but splendid view of the Midtown skyline before plunging underground. My friend Justin, who proudly spends his days soaking in the L.A. sun, was unimpressed.

title: CD Central
description: For gadget-lovers who want to store -- and play MP3 files without the middleman of a computer, there is the Hercules II Digital Jukebox from Perception Digital. The Hercules II ($499 at www.perceptiondigital.com) resembles a CD player and houses a 20-gigabyte hard drive, enough to store nearly 500 albums, as well as an onboard database with track and title information for some 400,000 LP's. In the end, of course, all this high-tech lingo translates into one beautiful thing: no more CD cases cluttering up the house.

title: Traveling Music For the Hornets
description: If the headaches of ordering boxes, storage units, change of address labels, stationery and telephones are bad enough when people move to a new city, imagine relocating an entire franchise, piece by piece.

title: Mutual Funds Report; In a Battered Market, Optimism on Energy
description: DESPITE the collapse of Enron, energy stocks over all have moved modestly ahead this year, and many Wall Street analysts and fund managers are optimistic about the long-term outlook for the sector.

title: Amtrak Must Die
description: Perhaps Tierney regards Balkanization, with the prospects of a shutdown, as a terrific first step. But there is a strong case to be made for one national system (without condoning the mediocre service he endured on the Sunset Limited). One option, for example, would be to have a company like Marriott provide on-board services for long-distance runs.

title: Just-High-Enough Art
description: Sam Mendes loves games. Real games like cricket and soccer and backgammon, but also the subtler puzzles that take the form of plays and movies. He thinks about his work -- whether it be reconceiving a musical like ''Cabaret'' for the Donmar Warehouse, his London theater, or directing a movie like ''American Beauty,'' for which he won an Academy Award his first time out -- as a kind of contest, bound by rules of intelligence, insight and strategy. He is not an accidental person, hoping luck will win the day. Mixing instinct, research and some large thematic idea geared to resonate with a wide audience, Mendes carefully gauges everything from the mood-capturing potential of his new film, ''Road to Perdition'' (''I hadn't seen a gangster movie in a while'') to the best way to attract a crowd to the plays of Arthur Schnitzler (have the star, Nicole Kidman, be naked just long enough to be both appropriate to the character and still scandalous). Having run a theater for the last decade, Mendes, who is only 36, thinks like a studio head even when he's directing. Which means that he tries to win for both teams: commerce and art.

title: Homeland Insecurity
description: NO HEROES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STUBENHAUS, JEROME
description: STUBENHAUS-Jerome. We at Nassau Radiologic Group, P.C., and its affiliated companies, mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague, Jerome Stubenhaus. Jerry died on Wednesday, July 3, 2002. He was 77 years of age. Jerry worked with the Nassau Radiologic Group for 50 years and was a key component in the success of the group. As the central administrator and advisor, he has impacted ''NRG'' for the years during his tenure as well as for the years to come. His keen business skills, his creativity, his visionary talent, and above all his caring personality, have shaped one of the country's largest outpatient radiology and radiation therapy companies. He always remarked that one of his great accomplishments was convincing the physicians of NRG to accept credit cards throughout their offices. Jerry you will be missed greatly both professionally and personally. You will remain in the hearts of so many of your colleagues.

title: Venice vs. Venice
description: The idea that Jonathan Reynolds would go to a famously complicated city armed with a Michelin guide and the advice of the hotel staff is downright hilarious. Venice, like Vegas, knows how to take money from a chump; in fact, it has been doing it a lot longer.

title: Argentine Reaches the Final In His Debut at Wimbledon
description: One match point against Xavier Malisse sent tennis history into a giddy spin today when David Nalbandian became the first man in the Open era to reach a Wimbledon final in his debut at the event and the first Argentine man to have a shot at the championship.

title: Dodgers' Starters Excel, Even Without an Ace
description: We interrupt this best Los Angeles Dodgers season in years to bring you an ominous note. The last time the Dodgers were in first place at the All-Star Game was in 1994. Everyone knows what happened in 1994.

title: June 30-July 6: BUSINESS; DEAD-ENDY
description: Jean-Marie Messier built Vivendi, a French water utility, into one of the world's largest media conglomerates, with acquisitions like the Universal film studio and music company, the USA Networks cable television network and the publisher Houghton Mifflin. He intended to make Vivendi a digital storehouse of media assets, delivered directly to cellphones, handhelds, personal computers and televisions. But the hoped-for future of digital convergence has yet to arrive, and investors have soured on such ungainly media conglomerates. Vivendi labored under huge debts as business slowed, and Mr. Messier, above, was finally ousted as chairman. Steve Lohr

title: A Vase That Carries Itself With Grace
description: COURTNEY SLOANE is known for her bold, modernist interior designs -- furniture with strong silhouettes, surfaces covered with metal, leather or zebrawood -- for outsize personalities like Queen Latifah, Sean Combs and Mary J. Blige. For clients like Ms. Blige, whose home Ms. Sloane is now redoing, knotty pine will not do. So she designed built-ins with not one but three different woods -- beech, zebra and sycamore.

description: A Second Ave. School

description: Classical/Opera

title: Sheryl Sun, Jonathan Blum
description: Dr. Sheryl Lamb Sun, an internist, and Dr. Jonathan Howard Blum, a specialist on infectious disease, are to be married today in Stanford, Calif. Rabbi Susan Lippe is to officiate at the Stanford University Faculty Club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPER, HERMAN (HAL)
description: LIPPER-Herman (Hal). Loving and devoted husband of Edith for 56 years. Dearest father of Laura, Dana and Amy. Dear father-in-law of Bertil Arleij, John McCauley and Ken Hecht. Cherished grandfather of Mark and Kyle. Loving brother of Sol Lipper and Elsie Leighton. Special uncle of Joseph Leighton. Missed, loved and always in our hearts. Contribution in Hal's memory may be made to the Connecticut Hospice, 100 Double Beach Rd., Branford, CT 06405, and New York Weill Cornell Medical Center, 525 East 68 Street, Box 123, NY NY 10021.

title: Better With Age? It's Not That Simple
description: ROSEMARY CLOONEY'S obituaries all said pretty much the same thing: she got better as she got older. It wasn't quite that simple, but as one-sentence summaries go, this one isn't altogether misleading. Clooney became famous in the 1950's by singing idiot novelties. (''Come On-a My House,'' a ditty of fathomless stupidity, was the best known -- and worst -- of them.) After the rise of rock made it impossible for such an artist to attract a mass audience, she retooled her image, signing with Concord Jazz in 1977 and recording blue-chip standards accompanied by top jazz musicians. From then on, she was a class act.

title: What's Wrong at Amtrak
description: To the Editor:

title: Anything but Your Everyday Nerds
description: Forget the smirky innuendos and just about everything else you thought you knew about high school musicians. ''Totally in Tune,'' a half-hour reality series shown Sundays at noon on the Disney Channel, proves there is more to getting to a concert hall than just practice, practice, practice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERR, KATE PRITCHETT
description: HERR-Kate Pritchett. Died peacefully June 29, 2002, in Houston, TX, at age 98. A friend, a loving mother, and family matriarch, we will miss her. Son, George Pritchett Herr, and daughter-in-law, Eleanor A. Herr, of Playa del Rey, CA, and four generations survive her. Memorial service at University Place Retirement Community, Houston, TX, July 13, 2002. Donations to Christ United Methodist Church.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH -- Simon Cowell; How Do You Sound? Don't Ask
description: SUFFICE it to say he's just as tough on bars.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: YOUR feelings about MOULIN ROUGE (2001) may depend on your feelings about Baz Luhrmann, the filmmaker who also gave the world ''Strictly Ballroom'' and Leonardo DiCaprio as Romeo. This is the story of a beautiful but consumptive dancer (Nicole Kidman) in 1900 Paris and the writer who loves her (Ewan McGregor). The title nightclub is as frenzied as Studio 54 at its peak, with mostly 20th-century music, like ''Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend'' and ''I Will Always Love You.'' The film goes over the top all over the place -- as gaudy farce, operatic romance, Las Vegas stage spectacular -- but it's ravishing to look at and its comic tone is dangerously original -- Saturday at 10 p.m. on Cinemax.

title: For Sorenstam, Best Isn't Good Enough
description: Annika Sorenstam can still recall being 15 years old in her native Sweden, practicing with other junior golfers on a rainy day. It began to rain harder, so Sorenstam telephoned her father, Tom, and asked for a ride home. After her father arrived, Sorenstam got into the car, but her father noticed several other players still practicing in the rain.

title: 'What's So Great About America'
description: Before the terrorists destroyed the World Trade Center, crashed a plane into the Pentagon, and began their campaign to bring to America the horrors of the war-ravaged Middle East, life in the United States was placid and even a little boring. The dominant issue in politics was the Social Security lockbox, an especially curious subject of dispute since no such lockbox exists or has ever existed. For diversion and entertainment, Americans could follow the Gary Condit sex scandal or watch "reality TV" shows like Survivor . Newspapers devoted front-page reports to such issues as road rage, a man bitten by a shark, and the revelation that overage kids were playing Little League baseball. The biggest issue in the airline industry involved something called "economy class syndrome." Essentially this referred to rather obese people sitting in coach class and fretting that during long flights their legs became stiff.

title: 36 More Roads Make Scenic Byways List
description: Three dozen roads were added last month to the roster of America's Byways, roads designated by the federal government as particularly scenic, important historically or with considerable opportunities for recreation. They include six sections of U.S. Route 40, which stretches from Maryland to Illinois and was used during the early 1800's by settlers traveling to the Midwest.

title: No Particular Place to Go
description: THE best moment is swooping south on the F.D.R. Drive, just before the Manhattan Bridge, when the highway elevates again and it is like you are in a little airplane taking off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HITTNER, CHARLES
description: HITTNER-Charles. 79, of Cranbury, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn. Died Friday, July 5, at Princeton Medical Center, Princeton, NJ. Beloved husband of Marilyn (nee Levittin), devoted father of Jeffrey Hittner of Freehold and Elyse Hittner of Cherry Hill, dear brother of Seymour Hittner of Bayside, Queens, loving grandfather of Jonathan Hittner and wife Diane of Old Bridge, and Michael Hittner of Old Bridge, loving greatgrandfather of Christopher Hittner. Born in Brooklyn, NY where he lived most of his life, Mr. Hittner moved to Cranbury, NJ in 1994. Mr. Hittner was an Army Veteran of WW II. He was the owner of M.A. Hittner and Sons of Manhattan from 1945 until retiring in 1986. Graveside services will be today 2 PM, at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, NJ. For information, contact Bloomfield-Cooper Jewish Chapels, Manalapan, NJ.

title: Think Inside the Box
description: MARTIN SLOANE

title: Appetizer, Entre, Dessert, and There's the Bill
description: PEOPLE who put together satisfying programs of one-act dances often compare the process to arranging courses for a dinner. Each dance must be artistically tasty in itself and complement the others rather than clash with or overwhelm them.

title: Where Puck Casts a Spell Over Summer
description: I HAVE always been a New Yorker who loved spending my summers in the city. As soon as my parents released me from the torture of sleep-away camp, I opted for odd summer jobs in the days and for warm summer nights spent with friends. To some girls, the romantic ideal was starry nights on the beach; to me, it has always been seeing free Shakespeare in Central Park.

title: When Superheroes Sue: The Second Career of Birdman
description: IN the animated superhero universe, Birdman -- who got his powers from the sun and lived in a volcano with his giant eagle companion, Avenger -- seems an unlikely candidate for rebirth. His show, ''Birdman and the Galaxy Trio,'' lasted for just a year and a half beginning in 1967, and most viewers probably forgot about him 30 years ago.

title: Dance Listings

title: The Doctor Won't See You Now

Fortunately, the outcome was a good one for the patient. Yes, we are all thankful for the technology that exists today, but I am saddened that this doctor seemed more concerned about his interrupted sleep.

title: Sept. 11 Photo Exhibition Touches a Nerve in Berlin
description: An exhibition of photographs taken in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York City and Washington has opened here as part of a series of events to commemorate the date.

description: KAREN BLUMENFELD lost her job as general counsel to a small Manhattan publishing company in January, and she has been enjoying herself ever since.

description: BRAGUE-Virginia Perkins. 77, textile designer and culinary editor, on June 30, 2002, in Bogota, Colombia.

title: The View From/Fairfield; At Sacred Heart, a Receiver Finally Catches Up to Himself
description: IT has taken a long time for DeVeren Johnson to figure out what he is supposed to do with his life. As the son of a Navy man who is a single parent, Johnson has had a nomadic childhood.

title: Celebrating a Rabbi's 55 Years of Service
description: WHEN Mordecai Waxman came to Temple Israel of Great Neck 55 years ago, the six-year-old Conservative congregation's 100 members welcomed the debonair young rabbi and his wife, Ruth.

title: A New York Smoker? Considering a Second Mortgage?
description: A COUPLE of days after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed into law a $1.42 increase in the city's tax on cigarettes, I was at a bar with my friend Sara when an acquaintance of hers stopped to ask if he could bum a smoke. ''Nah,'' she shrugged. ''I'm all out.'' This clearly wasn't true. Sara's such an addict, she sleeps with a pack under her pillow. I asked her why she had lied. ''You know how much a pack costs these days?'' she asked. ''Seven bucks! I'm not going to waste one on a jerk like him.''

title: Want Privacy? Oh, Keep It to Yourself.
description: WE at the Jersey column know how important your privacy is to you, and we're committed to protecting it.

title: At White Nights, Music From Dark Days
description: IN a dazzling inversion, Sergei Prokofiev's Soviet operas, those embodying Stalinist ideology, are receiving serious attention in post-Soviet Russia. Last month, Valery Gergiev, the artistic director of the White Nights Festival here at the Maryinsky Theater, presented Prokofiev's ''Semyon Kotko'' (1939) on stage and ''The Story of a Real Man'' (1948) in concert. Even before the collapse of the Soviet Union, these works had been relegated to the graveyard of musical agitprop. Their revival thus constitutes a powerful cultural reckoning.

title: Corsica, Rough and Smooth
description: ''MOUNTAINS, at rush hour,'' was my first thought as I spotted the island of Corsica on the horizon through the plane window. I had never before seen so many peaks packed into such a small space. The pale blue, white-capped mountains rose in jagged layers, like shark's teeth, straight out of the Mediterranean.

title: Intrigue at the Palazzo Agnelli
description: AS Gianni Agnelli, the patriarch of Italian industry and dynastic head of the Fiat auto and industrial empire, lay in a New York hospital bed in May and early June, even some of his best friends had sadly given up hope that he would survive prostate cancer.

description: The clubhouse was stuffed with stars and thick with history yesterday. It was Old-Timers Day at Yankee Stadium, and generations of pinstriped heroes roamed the locker room, sharing laughs and memories with each other and the current players.

The soil, climate and temperature of Long Island's North Fork are similar to the famous wine-growing area and for that reason, he and his wife, Theresa, ''had a notion to buy land and put a vineyard on it,'' he said.

title: Less a Greek Neighborhood, More a Greek Destination

To put it in more empirical terms, how can two shiny new Greek supermarkets, their shelves and refrigerators bulging with honey, haloumi cheese and phyllo dough, open within a block near the Ditmars Boulevard subway station, while the surrounding neighborhood becomes less and less homogeneously Greek by the day?

description: THE best advice that the chief executive of Southwest Airlines, James F. Parker, says he ever received was that he could catch more flies with honey than vinegar. These days, Mr. Parker may need an entire beehive.

title: Keeping the Wildfires at Bay
description: The wildfires raging in Colorado and Arizona are not just a Western phenomenon. Concern about saving property and homes hit New Jersey along with out-of-control forest fires this spring in the central and southern parts of the state. There is a way to use landscaping to help protect homes, and Tom Castronovo, a horticulturist and educator from Warren Township, has developed a landscaping and agriculture Web site that details steps homeowners can take to slow a fire near their property. Shrubs and trees that resist rather than fuel fires, should be planted with space between them in a 30-foot zone around houses, he said. Such shrubs are easily maintained and can tolerate droughts. Dead tree limbs and any limbs growing near power lines, over roofs and near chimneys should be removed, Mr. Castronovo said. Additional tips on protecting property can be found on Mr. Castronovo's site, http://www.TheMasterGardnerShow.com. Karen DeMasters

The appeal of Conte's Fish Market is certainly not the dcor. But a no-nonsense, ocean-to-table approach to seafood has won it scads of fans, from groundskeepers to celebrities. This is the kind of place where you can shamelessly rip into a lobster -- cooked perfectly and of the highest quality -- knowing that the butter dribbling down your chin is no big deal.

title: Business & Investing; Tollbooth Technology Meets the Checkout Lane

The system has become so popular that the consortium of states that operates the technology has increased its projections for its use to 53 percent of vehicles, from 35 percent.

title: 'Why We Fight'
description: The ruins of the World Trade Center were still smoking, ash and soot lingered in the air, the odor of death lay everywhere. It was early October 2001, and one army—an army of police and firefighters and rescue workers and volunteers of every stripe—was hard at work clearing, searching, burying, shifting mortar, ministering to mortals. Another army, under the direction of the president and the secretary of defense, was readying itself to move against our attackers. The land was full of grief and full of anger, full of opinion.

description: AS I walk the humid streets of Midtown Manhattan, I find myself staring at the clusters of workers outside every building. They are the smokers, puffing languidly or frantically as their day allows, and I glance at them the way I glance at the homeless, my awkward interest mixing with pity.

title: Edie Falco's Endless Summer

(Paraphrased for the purposes of this publication, she asks rhetorically, ''If you're going to get drunk, why mess around?'') Gourevitch's nonfiction account is ''a sort of moral fable, in which the avenger nabs the killer,'' Luc Sante said in the Book Review last year.

title: June 30-July 6: INTERNATIONAL; MIDAIR CRASH
description: Switzerland's reputation for clockwork precision cracked after it became clear that lapses by Swiss air traffic controllers played a major role in the collision of two planes that killed 71 people over southern Germany. Swiss air traffic officials initially reacted by scornfully blaming the pilot of a Russian airliner, which was carrying 52 children to a holiday in Barcelona, for reacting slowly to their warnings. But then they admitted they issued the warning only 44 seconds before the crash. Worse, they admitted that one of two controllers on duty was taking a break while the control center's alarm system was turned off for maintenance. Swiss and German prosecutors opened a criminal investigation. Edmund L. Andrews

title: For Cendant's Travel Business, Ride Is Bumpier Than Expected
description: A year ago, travel reservations seemed like a lucrative new opportunity for the Cendant Corporation, the travel and real estate conglomerate. Last June, it agreed to buy Galileo, the second-largest reservations booking engine for travel agents (after the Sabre Group), for $2.9 billion. Then in August it bought Cheap Tickets Inc., a marketer of deeply discounted fares, for $425 million to combine the Cheap Tickets Web site with Galileo's Trip.com, part of a two-year-old effort to build a ''travel portal'' within Cendant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRENCHMAN, GERALD L.
description: FRENCHMAN-Gerald L. 68 years old, son of the late Mildred and Harold Frenchman, loving husband and father of four, died on Saturday after a long and courageous battle with complications following heart surgery this past October. He is survived by his wife Cynthia; his four children (and daughters-inlaw) Peter (Suzie), Robert (Geraldine), Kenneth (Raquelle), and Jill; his sister Harriet (Murray); and his four grandchildren Alexander, Phoebe, Tyler, and Ashley. Jerry was a devoted family man who supported his children in all their endeavors, spending many seasons coaching his children's teams while they were young. This support evolved into other forms of mentorship in later years. Utilizing his business expertise, as well as his strong moral fiber, Jerry set an example for his children that was unmatched by others. A tax accountant by trade, Jerry became one of a small nucleus of inside executives at Continental Grain Company, where he worked in excess of 35 years. Upon retiring in 1999, Jerry and Cindy relocated from Scarsdale, where they had lived 25 years, to Cordillera Colorado. In Cordillera, Jerry had planned to continue his consulting and investment activities, while taking the time to enjoy a life of skiing and golfing in the Colorado sunshine. Jerry was a fierce competitor who participated in a variety of athletic activities, including skiing, marathon running, triathlons, cycling, basketball and (belatedly) golf. Even after the onset of Parkinson's disease, Jerry continued to pursue those activities that defined him. Whether it be cheering for his beloved Colorado Buffaloes, running that 26th mile, or persevering beyond anyone's imagination, Jerry gave it his all. He will be missed by all. Services to be held at The Riverside Memorial, Amsterdam at 76th Street, New York, New York. Following services, the family will sit shiva through Friday at the Frenchman's home, 74 Jared Drive, White Plains, New York.

Leaves behind his wife Esther, of almost 59 years, his sons Dr. Martin Melman of Croton-on-Hudson, NY, Dr. Daniel Melman of Miami, FL, and Rabbi Baruch Melman of Newburgh, NY. He cherished his daughters-in-law Amy and Leah, and his grandchildren Anna, Jesse and Tifarah. He also leaves behind his sisters Marcelle Mandelbaum and Judith Herschberg. title: Critic's Notebook; Turning Paintings Into 3 Dimensions
description: Donald Judd is famous in several ways. As one of the major exemplars of Minimalism, a term and a concept that he detested and never used. As a tough and opinionated critic who wrote some of the most perceptively adamant art criticism of the postwar period. As the egomaniacal, litigious founder of one of America's greatest art pilgrimages: a sprawling, aesthetically controlled domain in the small West Texas town of Marfa. By the time of his death in 1994, Judd had amassed an assembly of houses and commercial buildings, as well as an entire army fort, which he refurbished as studios, residences and grand display spaces for a survey of his career and large-scale installations by artists like John Chamberlain and Dan Flavin.

title: California Leads on Warming
description: Despite heavy industry lobbying, California's Legislature approved a bill last week that for the first time would force automakers to limit emissions of carbon dioxide, the gas largely responsible for global warming. The bill is unquestionably the most important step taken in this country to control greenhouse emissions since 1998, when the Clinton administration signed the Kyoto Protocol, an agreement President Bush has since renounced. The bill contains no specific mandates beyond the model year (2009) when cleaner cars have to be on the road. Details will be worked out in negotiations between the companies and state regulatory authorities. Nevertheless, assuming Gov. Gray Davis signs the bill, as he apparently plans to do, it will inevitably drive Detroit and other automakers to manufacture more fuel-efficient vehicles.

title: Freire Wins Stage at Tour de France
description: SAARBRUCKEN, Germany, July 8  The day after Erik Zabel's 32d birthday turned out to be just as rotten for him as the real thing. Once again, he was barely denied a chance to wear the Tour de France yellow jersey before his fellow Germans.

title: City Curfews And Politics Strain Calm In West Bank
description: The Israeli Army continued to maintain full command of virtually all Palestinian areas of the West Bank today, with little sense on either side that the stalemate was near an end.

title: MSNBC Is Testing the Fox Formula
description: On July 15, MSNBC will begin its big push to escape third place in the cable-news ratings race using a formula similar to that of the No. 1 Fox News Channel: loud mouths, hot heads and lots of personality.

title: The Perfect Train
description: Electromagnets can levitate small metal objects. But can they propel a roller coaster? Lift a ten thousand ton train? What about launching a rocket into space? The answer is  they can: thanks to a technology called maglev, short for magnetic levitation.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Boy Hit By Fire Truck
description: A 7-year-old boy suffered head and leg injuries Saturday when he ran from between parked cars and was struck by a Fire Department truck returning from a Brooklyn fire, the police said. The boy, Dushane Jackson, was listed in guarded but stable condition yesterday at Kings County Hospital Center, said Sajjad Ahmed, a hospital administrator. The accident happened about 7:45 p.m. on Decatur Street near Ralph Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant. The truck, from Engine Company 234, was traveling the wrong way on Decatur, a one-way street, but it had its lights and siren on. No summonses were issued and no firefighters were disciplined. But the incident is still under investigation, the authorities said. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Recording Industry Questions a Bitter Attack by a Pop Star

Mottola, the chairman of the Sony Music Group, whose Epic label released Mr. Jackson's lackluster ''Invincible'' album, has turned particularly bitter and bizarre.

The huddled masses would seem to have been prime targets for Internet stamp providers, which allow customers to sit in the air-conditioned comfort of their homes and offices, pumping out new postage from inkjet printers.

title: Slowing the AIDS Plague
description: In 1993, the World Health Organization estimated that over the next seven years 20 million more people could become infected with the AIDS virus. It said, however, that by spending about $2 billion more a year, more than half those infections would be prevented. This would have slowed the epidemic and saved $90 billion in associated costs.

description: By all appearances, Seiji Ozawa's 29-year tenure as music director of the Boston Symphony ultimately became burdensome for everyone concerned. But no one should think that the orchestra, once relieved of that burden, will immediately blossom.

description: Scandals continue to crash through executive suites. The threat of terrorism hangs in the air. Stock markets have tumbled. And through it all, the economy has pushed forward.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCBRIDE, RITA
description: McBRIDE-Rita. 77, of New York City, died July 3, 2002, at Calvary Hospital in Bronx, NY. Born December 14, 1924, in Lynn, MA, she was the daughter of the late William and Annabelle Girardin McBride of Easton, PA. She was a graduate of Easton High School in 1942 and of the College of New Rochelle in New Rochelle, NY. After college she worked as a fashion model and subsequently was employed by Doubleday Book and Music clubs. Survivors are a sister-in law, Janet Herman McBride, and a nephew, Clement G. McBride Jr., of Easton. Burial will be private with a graveside service at Gethsemane Cemetery in Easton, PA.

title: At Lincoln Center, a Focus On Iran and the Middle East
description: Just one month ago, the Lincoln Center Festival -- which starts tonight with the Kirov Ballet's performance of ''La Bayadre'' and runs for three weeks -- received word that United States consular officials had denied visas to 10 members of a 28-member Iranian troupe whose open-air rendition of the legendary Persian epic ''Ta'ziyeh'' is the centerpiece of the festival's global ambitions.

title: Sept. 11 Attack, Depicted With Electronic 'Pigment'
description: After a day off, the Internet artist Eryk Salvaggio returned to the electronics superstore in Salem, N.H., where he was working as a television salesman. It was Sept. 12, and he was immediately immersed in a sea of TV screens -- 126 of them, by his count -- that were tuned to news reports of Sept. 11. Every few minutes, he was surrounded by scenes of a jet crashing into the World Trade Center.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Correction Officer Is Shot
description: An off-duty correction officer was shot in the stomach last night in a dispute that erupted about 9 p.m. after a soccer game in an East New York park. The victim, whose name was not disclosed, was taken to Brookdale Hospital Medical Center. Dozens of police officers searched the area for a man who was believed to have dropped a red bag after shooting the correction officer. The officer was among more than 1,000 spectators at the soccer game in Linden Park.

title: Pichon Proves Too Tough For the Power
description: Saskia Webber, playing against the team that traded her at the beginning of the season, was outstanding in goal for the Power tonight, but a hat trick by Philadelphia's Marinette Pichon late in the second half gave the Charge a 3-1 victory.

title: Sondheim Isn't Alone On Washington's Stages
description: What with all the hoopla over the Stephen Sondheim Celebration at the Kennedy Center, you might think the other theaters here were empty this summer. But there's plenty going on -- enough, anyway, to fill the unoccupied spaces of an otherwise Sondheimesque long weekend with the grandiosity of melodrama.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 3 Shows Of Musical Are Canceled
description: The first three performances of ''Harlem Song,'' a new musical at the Apollo Theater in Harlem, were canceled over the weekend after technical rehearsals took longer than expected. John Schreiber, one of the producers of the $4 million show, said yesterday that one performance Saturday evening and two yesterday had to be canceled because of continuing lighting and sound preparations. About 750 audience members were turned away from the Apollo, though every ticketholder was offered a refund and free tickets for any future performances. ''Harlem Song,'' written and directed by George C. Wolfe, the producer of the Joseph Papp Public Theater, tells the story of the neighborhood's artistic and social changes. The show's first performance is now expected to be tonight. Opening night is still scheduled for Aug. 4. Jesse McKinley (NYT)

title: The Free Market Needs New Rules
description: In a string of corporate failures and scandals from Enron to WorldCom, we have seen the first principles of free markets -- transparency and trust -- fall victim to corporate opportunists exploiting a climate of lax regulation. I have long opposed unnecessary regulation of business activity, mindful that the heavy hand of government can discourage innovation. But in the current climate only a restoration of the system of checks and balances that once protected the American investor -- and that has seriously deteriorated over the past 10 years -- can restore the confidence that makes financial markets work.

title: Reading All About Sept. 11
description: After Sept. 11, many book publishers were wary of moving too quickly to sell books on the tragedy. "Nobody wants to set up a lemonade stand at the nuclear bomb site," as David Rosenthal, publisher of Simon & Schuster, part of Viacom, put it at the time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, BENJAMIN JAMES
description: WALKER-Benjamin James. Of Airmont, died tragically and innocently at The WorldTrade Center on September 11, 2001. He was 41. Benjamin was born on August 2, 1960, in England, to David Walker and Mary Brown. Benjamin graduated Ashfolt Prep School and St. Edwards College in Oxford, England. On September 30, 1989, he married Laura Kenney in Queens, NY. At the time of his death, he was an insurance broker for Marsh & McLennan for over 20 years. He was a fan of many sports. His passion for sports led him to become a soccer coach for the Hal Block soccer league and the Ramapo little league. Survivors include his devoted wife Laura, of Airmont; three loving children Henry, Christopher, and Samantha; his beloved parents David Walker and Mary Brown of England; dear sisters Jane Chevis, Ruth Walker, and Anne Marie Mosley, all of England; cherished nieces Rebecca Chevis, and Rowena Mosley; and a nephew Mark Chevis. The family wil be present to receive friends on Friday, July 12, 2002, from 7-9 PM, only at Wanamaker & Carlough, 177 Rte 59 in Suffern, NY. Funeral services will be private at the family's request. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Walker Educational Fund, c/o Brian Praver, Ridgewood Financial Center, 1 E. Ridgewood Avenue, Ridgewood, NJ 07450.

title: From Justice Scalia, A Chilling Vision Of Religion's Authority In America
description: Earlier this year Antonin Scalia decided to share some aspects of his worldview with the public. His inspiration seems to have been the death penalty: recent debates with his colleagues on the Supreme Court and his general reflections on the legitimacy of the state taking to itself the power to kill a citizen. Justice Scalia spoke on these matters at the University of Chicago Divinity School in January, beginning with the ritual disclaimer that ''my views on the subject have nothing to do with how I vote in capital cases''; his remarks appeared in the May issue of First Things: The Journal of Religion and Public Life. They are supplemented by his dissent to the court's decision on June 20 that mentally retarded people should not be executed. Justice Scalia's remarks show bitterness against democracy, strong dislike for the Constitution's approach to religion and eager advocacy for the submission of the individual to the state. It is a chilling mixture for an American.
