title: A Week of Highs and Lows at the End of the Earth
description: The weather in Russia's Kola Peninsula, home to the world's greatest salmon run, can turn on a kopeck. So can the fishing. In a week on the Pana River, a two-hour helicopter flight from Murmansk, I had fishing for Atlantic salmon straight out of a daydream and, right alongside, rotten luck that had me questioning my karma.

title: Is the Slumber Over? Signs of Life Despite a Sluggish First Half
description: For those in the media world, the first half of 2002 was a time of dashed expectations. The turnaround that executives prayed for failed to show up. Instead, advertising spending remained depressed, stock prices continued to fall and the philosophy of digital synergy that drove a merger mania lost whatever luster it still had.

title: Afghanistan's Unintended Victims
description: Early last Monday, four Afghan villages were apparently hit by errant or mistargeted American fire, killing or injuring scores of people. The circumstances are still murky, but according to Afghan officials, a large number of the dead were members of an engagement party, including a family of 25. Those officials, who are pro-American, have warned that public outrage over the deaths could erode support for Washington's military campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIELL, NORMAN
description: KIELL-Norman. July 7, 2002. Husband of Adele. Father of Matthew and Jonathan. Grandfather of Saskia, Marina, Leah and Adam. In accordance with his wishes there will be no funeral or services.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Enron may have been making up profits, but most Americans are pretending that they are not spending on credit.''

title: Scientists in Barcelona Report on New AIDS Drug
description: BARCELONA, Spain, July 8  A novel experimental drug showed highly promising results in two large late-stage trials, offering new hope for thousands of patients who are infected with drug-resistant AIDS virus, scientists reported at the 14th International AIDS Conference here today.

title: Persuasive Pressures
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Science in Colonial Times
description: An exhibit by the American Philosophical Society in Philadelphia explores the embrace of science in colonial times.

title: Margaret E. Lynn, 81, Dies; Led Army Theater Program
description: Margaret E. Lynn, who directed the Army's extensive worldwide theatrical program, which encouraged participation by soldiers, officers and their dependents, died on June 11 at a hospital in Fairfax, Va. She was 81 and lived in Reston, Va.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Serb Convicted Of War Crime
description: In Serbia's first war crimes trial, a former Yugoslav Army reservist, Ivan Nikolic, 30, was sentenced to eight years in prison for killing two Kosovo Albanian brothers in 1999 during the Yugoslavia-NATO conflict over the Serbian province. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Old Business In New Light
description: If President Bush hoped to turn attention to the first topics he mentioned at the start of his news conference today, like military appropriations, trade and a review of the welfare system, he was in for a rude shock.

title: Stars Will Be Out. But for How Long?
description: If Major League Baseball officials could have scripted today's news conference to announce the starting pitchers and the lineups for Tuesday night's All-Star Game at Miller Park, they would have made sure that every question focused on the beauty of baseball.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIGHT, DAVID L.
description: HAIGHT-David L. Of Briarcliff Manor, died July 7, 2002, at home surrounded by his family. In 1949 he founded Haggerty Millwork Corporation in Mount Kisco, NY with two partners, now deceased. He retired January 31, 2001. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Elinor, his sons Douglas and Andrew and daughter Diane Angst, grandsons Andrew and Aaron and granddaughters Diana and Katherine Angst. Another son, David, died in 1970. Viewing hours 2-4 and 7-9pm, Wednesday, July 10, 2002, Waterbury and Kelly, Briarcliff Manor. Interment Friends Meeting House, Purchase, NY, Thursday at 10am.

title: Church's Chicken takes on the bigger chains by emphasizing its flavor and lower prices.
description: THE chicken wars can be brutal for the small fry.

title: Crossbreeding to Save Species and Create New Ones
description: In the 16th century, Calusa Indians on Marco Island, Fla., made a six-inch wooden carving of a kneeling panther-woman, her head and upper body feline, her lower body human. This hauntingly beautiful figurine is one of countless portrayals of human-animal and animal-animal hybrids -- among them satyrs and griffins -- found throughout the world for thousands of years.

title: Zabel Takes Over Yellow Jersey
description: REIMS, France, July 9  Happy belated birthday, Erik Zabel.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Store Manager Wounded
description: A grocery store manager in Crown Heights was shot in the face during a robbery in the store on Sunday, the police said. The manager, 25, whose identity was not released by the police, was listed in stable condition yesterday at Kings County Hospital. An armed man wearing a green mask entered the Troy Supermarket at 187 Troy Avenue about 6:05 p.m. on Sunday and demanded money, the police said. He then shot the manager and fled with an undetermined amount of cash. The police urged anyone with information about the incident to call (800) 577-8477. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSLER, JOHN E.
description: MOSLER-John E., on July 7, 2002, at age 79. Loving father of Bruce E. Mosler and his wife Wendy, John E. Mosler, Jr. and his wife Jennifer, and Michele A. Mosler. Devoted grandfather of David and Charlotte Mosler. Devoted brother of Janet Coleman and the late Edwin H. Mosler, Jr. Interment private. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Thursday, July 11, at 6PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to Fordham University.

title: Op-Art
Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, HARVEY
description: GREENFIELD-Harvey. The employees and Board of Directors of the Citizens State Bank, Sealy, TX are saddened by the passing of Harvey Greenfield, who was one of our shareholders. Mr. Greenfield was our good friend and we will always remember and appreciate the loyal support and guidance that he extended to us. Leroy Zapalac, President & Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Citizens State Bank, Sealy, TX

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Pharaoh Heading Home
description: An American university museum has agreed to return to Egypt a mummy believed to be Ramses I, a pharaoh who ruled in the 14th century B.C., according to Zahi Hawass, the secretary general of the Supreme Council of Antiquities. The mummy, discovered in 1860, was moved along with 10 others to the Niagara Falls Museum in Canada, which later sold it to the Michael C. Carlos Museum at Emory University in Atlanta. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Cold Fish
description: Q. How do arctic and antarctic fish survive where the water temperature is in the 40's or lower?

title: Cab Hits 2, Then Explodes, Near Brooklyn Bridge Ramp
description: A livery cab that lost its brakes on the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday careered off the Manhattan-bound lanes onto Centre Street and struck two men, leaving one of them in critical condition, the police said.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Merck's accounting raises questions about a stock offering.
description: DESPITE a series of surprising disclosures about the way it accounts for billions of dollars in revenue from its Medco managed care unit, Merck & Company plans to proceed today with the pricing and initial offering of Medco shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, HERBERT H.
description: JONES-Herbert H. On July 7, 2002. Beloved husband of Midge. Devoted father of Carol Stolow and William Henry Jones. Cherished grandfather of Kim, Jen, Jodi, and Jimmy. Unsung hero at Metro New York District of the Unitarian Universalist Church. Memorial services will be held at a later date.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Advertising Women of New York elected board members for 2002-2003. The officers are: first vice president, Celia Currin, director for marketing communications, The Wall Street Journal, part of Dow Jones & Company; second vice president, Carol Evans, president and chief executive, Working Mother Media; treasurer, Cyndi April, United States director for print strategy, OMD, part of the Omnicom Group; assistant treasurer, Margie Goldsmith, president, MG Productions; recording secretary, Jane Talcott, executive vice president and creative director, Young & Rubicam Advertising, part of the WPP Group; and corresponding secretary, Kathleen Ruane, senior partner and director for corporate communications, Bozell, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Jill Manee, vice president and publisher at the Ad Age Group, New York, owned by Crain Communications, continues as the club's president.

title: Science for All, 1750 to 1875
description: Once, before it became synonymous with geekiness in American popular culture, science was regarded as a pursuit for the average person, its accouterments as suitable for the living room as for the laboratory.

title: MetroStars' Williams Lands on His Feet
description: It would be hard not to think of midfielder ANDY WILLIAMS as an afterthought to the six-player trade in late May in which the MetroStars also acquired striker MAMADOU DIALLO and defender TED CHRONOPOULOS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERBER, RUSSELL
description: FERBER-Russell. December 31, 1980 to July 6, 2002. Adored son of David Ferber and Dorothy Jordon, beloved brother of Jordon, loving grandson of Sydelle Jordon, nephew of Lucie (Jordon) and Steve Kass, David and Madelyn Jordon and Marcia Hirtenstein; loved by Van Frederick and cousins Glenn and Amber, Corey and Shari, Michael and Penni, James and Denise, Haley, Jenny and Shelby. Our shining light, whose love of life, family and friends will live in our hearts forever. No words can ever express our great loss. We will continue to cherish the short time we had him in our lives. Services Wednesday, July 10, at The Village Temple, 5pm, 33 East 12th St. Contributions in Russell's memory to Village Community School, 272 West 10th St, New York City, 10004.

title: EBay to Buy PayPal, a Rival in Online Payments
description: The online auction giant eBay announced plans today to acquire PayPal, a rapidly growing start-up that lets people make payments via e-mail. The move will let eBay take a bigger share of many sales made on its own site, and to expand its business to earn money on tens of thousands of transactions made elsewhere on the Internet.

title: Bush Honors 12 With Presidential Medal of Freedom
description: In a White House ceremony today, President Bush awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian award, to a dozen prominent people, including Nelson R. Mandela and Nancy Reagan.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Identity-Theft Arrests
description: The police have arrested seven people who illegally obtained thousands of customer records at a Hollywood Video store in Mount Vernon and a CVS pharmacy in Pelham Manor and used the data to open charge accounts on the Internet, the Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, said. They then ordered more than $100,000 in computers and electronics that they sold to the Electronics Mart in the Bronx, the police said. Among those arrested are the manager of the Hollywood Video store and two employees of the Electronics Mart. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: UNIVERSAL TO PERMIT DOWNLOADING The Universal Music Group said yesterday that it planned to permit Internet users to download songs and make homemade compact discs from music contained in roughly 1,000 albums in its catalog. This is one of the first instances of a record company's making a large catalog of music available in the MP3 format, a popular file type that has become controversial because files can easily be shared via e-mail. Under the deal announced yesterday, the music will be available through emusic.com, a start-up company acquired last year by Vivendi Universal , which owns Universal; unlimited access will cost $120 a year. The music available will be drawn from the company's back catalog. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Wife Can't Explain Fatal Shootings at Airport
description: The wife of an Egyptian immigrant who fatally shot two people on the Fourth of July at Los Angeles International Airport said today that she could find no reason for the shooting.

title: Corrections
description: An opera review on Friday about ''Manon Lescaut,'' presented by New York Grand Opera at Central Park SummerStage, referred incorrectly to the work's history. It was Puccini's first success, not his first opera.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about attempts to rebuild a Sikh temple in Queens referred incorrectly in some copies to the casualties of the fire there in March. Although it did not kill anyone at the time, one priest later died of injuries.

title: Map Redrawn, an Incumbent Braces for a Fight
description: For the last several years, Eric T. Schneiderman has been the point man for the Democratic Party's effort to increase its numbers in the State Senate. In the last three years, Mr. Schneiderman's ritual has been to identify promising candidates throughout the state, raise money and help guide their campaigns.

title: A Critical Vote on Nuclear Waste
description: The Senate is facing a momentous vote this week that will determine whether a plan to bury nuclear waste at Yucca Mountain in Nevada moves to the next stage of regulatory scrutiny or dies prematurely. Any legislative delay now will be likely to terminate the project, and that must not be allowed to happen. If Yucca is abandoned, the nation will be right back where it was decades ago -- with spent nuclear fuel piling up at reactor sites around the country and no plan for its permanent disposal.

title: Bush, on Wall St., Offers Tough Stance
description: President Bush came to Wall Street yesterday vowing to ``end the days of cooking the books, shading the truth, and breaking our laws.'' But critics, including Senate Democrats, said the legal reforms he advocated - from longer prison sentences for fraud to a new task force to prosecute corporate malfeasance - were not as far-reaching as some of the proposals now gaining steam in Congress.

title: Seeking to Calm Investors, Vivendi Says It Is Near a Deal for New Credit
description: Seeking to soothe investors who have become increasingly alarmed by the company's dwindling levels of cash, Vivendi Universal said today that it was close to reaching an agreement with its banks to secure fresh loans.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GATES, JAMES BENEDICT
description: GATES - James Benedict. Memorial Mass Sat., July 13, 10AM, Saint Jean Baptiste Church, East 76 St and Lexington Ave, New York City.

title: Career Profiles of 9/11 Dead Arouse Anxiety
description: Among the families, it is called, quite simply, the Book. Prepared by the staff of Cantor Fitzgerald, and meant to arm families of Sept. 11 victims in their fight for federal compensation awards, the Book is a detailed accounting of the performances and prospects of the firm and its 658 lost employees.

title: Disclosure by Merck is latest scandal ahead of president's speech : A new jolt as Bush heads to Wall Street
description: WASHINGTON:  As President George W. Bush prepared a get-tough speech on the scandals buffeting corporate America and two former top executives of WorldCom Inc. refused to answer questions in Congress, investors got another jolt Monday as the drugmaker Merck & Co. revealed that one of its subsidiaries had overstated its revenues by billions of dollars.

title: Working His Way to the Top
description: Alfonso Soriano was leaning over and adjusting his cleats before a game in May when he was told that he had the second most votes in the early balloting for the American League All-Star team and was the leader among second basemen. He stopped fiddling with his footwear, looked up and displayed a mixture of innocence and confidence that defines him.

title: Biology of Deception
description: Can science find a foolproof way of uncovering truth? The inner workings of deception in our brains confront scientists with an almost insoluble mystery.

title: Anatomy as Art, Unsettling but Drawing Crowds
description: Forget the queen's tiaras. On display through Sept. 29 in the Atlantis Gallery here is ''Body Worlds,'' an exhibition unlike any other: it consists of human bodies that have been flayed, injected with a siliconelike substance and posed running, swimming, fencing and horseback riding. In spite of or because of its morbid pretext, the show has been a hit here, with more than 160,000 visitors in its first three months.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Soldiers Said To Smuggle Rare Birds
description: Indonesian soldiers have been accused of smuggling endangered birds from the eastern provinces of Maluku and Papua. Hundreds of birds, mainly the black-capped lory and the Halmahera cockatoo, were carried in warships transporting troops to Indonesia's main island, Java, and then smuggled to Singapore, Malaysia and Europe, according to the group Animal Conservation for Life. A senior official in the forestry department, Adi Susmianto, said the smuggling had been been encouraged by corruption in his agency and that it was under investigation. Dian Saputra (NYT)

title: Debating Diagnosis of a Sensory Malady in Children
description: Ever since his baby days, Alex, now nearly 4, has been a puzzle to his parents. As an infant, he screamed unless he was being rocked or held. He hated the feel of water; baths were a nightmare. By 3, he was covering his ears at loud noises. He loved the feel of the sandbox, but could not stand sock fuzz between his toes. Sleep came only in fits and starts.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Tribunal Tries To Cut Backlog
description: The International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda has agreed to hand over some of its cases to national courts in an effort to clear a backlog and wind up its work by 2008. Officials at the tribunal, which was created in November 1994 to try suspects in the genocide earlier that year, said some suspects would be tried in the countries where they were arrested rather than at the tribunal in Arusha, Tanzania. The tribunal will also allow written testimony by witnesses. Some cases have been delayed because witnesses have feared facing suspects. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Plan to Keep Israeli Arabs Off Some Land Is Backed
description: A cabinet vote endorsing a bill that would bar Israeli Arabs from buying homes in Jewish communities built on state land caused an uproar here today, with critics in and outside the government calling it racist.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Testing Medicine and Memory
description: A drug used to treat Alzheimer's disease slightly helped airline pilots retain their training in a complex flight test, a study published today has found.

title: BUSH DEFENDS SALE OF STOCK AND VOWS TO ENHANCE S.E.C.
description: President Bush defended himself today against a barrage of questions about his own corporate stock dealings even as he vowed to take a tougher line in a speech in New York on Tuesday against corrupt corporate executives.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Vignette Misses Estimates
description: The Vignette Corporation, a maker of Internet software, said second-quarter sales had missed analysts' estimates because of ''stagnant'' customer spending. Sales were $34 million to $35 million, according to a preliminary review of results, the chief financial officer, Charles Sansbury, said in a conference call. The analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had estimated sales of $45 million. In the second quarter last year, sales were $83.6 million. The loss, excluding things like acquisition costs and investment losses, was 5 cents a share, meeting the average First Call estimate, Vignette said.

title: Progress in the Hepatitis B Fight
description: In the 20 years since a vaccine against hepatitis B was introduced, new infections in the United States have dropped to 80,000 a year from more than 200,000, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta.

title: Iran Convicts American Dancer Of Corrupting Youths by Video
description: A court has convicted an Iranian-born American dancer, who came to Iran three months ago for the first time in 22 years, of promoting corruption and issued a 10-year jail sentence, which the court suspended.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WREN, MARGARET
description: WREN-Margaret. The Board of Trustees and administrative leadership of Continuum Health Partners acknowledges with sadness the passing of Margaret Wren, beloved mother of our dear friend and colleague John Wren, Vice Chairman of the Continuum Board and Chairman of the Board of Regents of our member hospital, Long Island College Hospital. She will be missed by all who knew and loved her. To John and the entire Wren family, we extend heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman Chairman, Board of Trustees Continuum Health Partners Peter A. Kelly President and CEO Continuum Health Partners

title: Senate Gives Final Approval to Nevada Nuclear Waste Site
description: WASHINGTON, July 9  The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to a nuclear waste repository deep inside Yucca Mountain in the Nevada desert, marking a pivotal moment in the 20-year search for a home for the radioactive byproducts of the nation's nuclear reactors.

title: Text: Bush's Speech on Wall Street
description: Following is the text of President Bush's speech today on Wall Street as transcribed by The New York Times.

title: The Charter Revision Addiction
description: New York City's elected officials have shown a strange obsession with charter revision in recent years. During the Giuliani administration, the mayor and City Council virtually arm-wrestled each other for a chance to get their proposals for change on the ballot. Now Mayor Michael Bloomberg wants to set up a charter revision commission this summer, with an eye toward the November election.

title: MEMO PAD
description: Another Fare Rise Fails to Take Hold

title: Joey Fatone of 'N Sync to Make His Broadway Debut in 'Rent'
description: In a move likely to thrill untold scores of teenage girls as well as a handful of Broadway producers, Joey Fatone, a member of the multiplatinum boy band 'N Sync, will join the cast of the long-running musical ''Rent'' next month, its producers said yesterday.

title: Humble Material Is Enlisted Against Deadly Red Tides
description: Every year, swaths of the United States coastline are attacked by poisonous enemies that massacre fish and shellfish, unnerve beachgoers and prompt scores of ''no fishing'' alerts.

title: Reining In Expectations On Lincoln Center Project
description: Bruce Crawford, the new chairman of Lincoln Center, suggested in a recent interview that putting the price tag of $1.2 billion on the center's ambitious redevelopment was premature and that the project's cost and scope may have to be more modest.

title: With Cryonics, Hope Runs Ahead of Reality
description: Even proponents will tell you that cryonics doesn't work. You can't freeze people, then revive them. But the hope that it may one day be possible lives on nonetheless, nurtured by the real successes in medical research into freezing and reviving cells and tissues.

title: New York Court Rules Inmate Cannot Be Executed
description: ALBANY, July 9  New York's highest court ruled today that the first man condemned to death under the 1995 death-penalty law cannot be executed because the statute included a constitutional flaw at the time of his trial.

title: Senators Declare Support for Waste Site
description: Several wavering senators from both parties rallied today to support President Bush's call for a nuclear waste disposal site at Yucca Mountain, prompting Republican aides to predict that Congress will give final passage this week to the plan to bury the nation's atomic waste in the Nevada desert.

title: John Mosler, 79, Former Chief Of World's Largest Safe Maker
description: John Mosler, a former chairman and chief executive of the Mosler Safe Company, which made vaults used for guarding the nation's wealth at Fort Knox and protecting the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution and the Bill of Rights in Washington, died on Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 79 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Sparring With the Old Boss, on Behalf of the New
description: THE nickname Teddy Bear was bestowed, allegedly in all sincerity, by his baby-faced new boss, Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, and it has been hard to shake. Rumor has it Forrest R. Taylor, chief of staff for the City Council and chief mouthpiece for Mr. Miller, would prefer to be known by a manlier moniker and even went so far as to suggest a replacement nickname: Turbo! But Teddy Bear it is. As Mr. Taylor, 40 and immaculately attired behind spiffy navy blue suspenders, is fond of reminding himself, what the speaker says, goes.

title: Critic's Notebook; Take a Jazzy New Opera, Add 'Eugene Onegin' and Mix in a Provenal July
description: As the last swallows settle down for the night and the first stars come out, opera at the highest international level is being presented in the courtyard of a former archiepiscopal palace. What more can one want? Czanne landscapes, fields striped with lavender and markets tumbling with fresh produce: they are here, too. And the Aix Festival, more than half a century old, is mixing luxury with a little provocation under Stphane Lissner, its general director since 1998.

title: Giambi Defeats Sosa In Home Run Derby
description: Jason Giambi vowed that he would swing from his heels during tonight's All-Star Game Home Run Derby and that is exactly what he did in the final round against Sammy Sosa. Giambi hit seven batting practice fastballs over the fence at Miller Park; Sosa managed to do it once.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Penalties For Uninsured Drivers
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey proposed a plan yesterday to seize the motor vehicles of residents who drive without insurance. Mr. McGreevey said there were 600,000 uninsured drivers in the state. Under his plan, drivers who cannot supply an insurance card will have 24 hours to prove they are insured. If a driver cannot provide proof, the vehicle will be seized and the driver will face a $150 fine as well as towing and storage costs and a $100 administrative fee. Impounded cars that are not retrieved within 30 days will be sold at auction.

title: Marketers: Don't Call Me. I'll Call You.
description: To the Editor:

title: Anger at Executives' Profits Fuels Support for Stock Curb
description: Restricting the ability of executives to sell company stock has quickly become a central part of efforts to change the rules under which corporate America does business.

title: CONTROLLER SENT JETS INTO A CRASH, FLIGHT DATA SHOW
description: Information from the flight recorders aboard the two planes that crashed into each other one week ago over southern Germany show that a Swiss air traffic controller in effect put the planes on a collision course by ordering the Russian pilot to descend at the same time that the plane's own collision-avoidance system was urging him to climb.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Ex-SS Officer To Appeal Conviction
description: A former SS officer convicted in Hamburg last week and sentenced to seven years in prison for overseeing the killing of 59 Italian prisoners in May 1944 will appeal his conviction, his lawyers said. Friedrich Engel, 93, contends he did not supervise the executions, though he admitted he had been present and approved the list of prisoners to be shot. Mr. Engel, who was convicted in absentia in Italy in 1999 for killing at least 246 prisoners in four incidents, is to undergo medical tests to see if he is fit to serve time in prison. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Bush and the Business Scandals
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Steel Maker Posts Results
description: Pohang Iron and Steel, known as Posco, reported a 1.1 percent increase in net profit for the first half of this year over the first half of 2001 despite a drop in both sales and operating profit. The company said net profit was up 358.6 billion won ($300 million) from January through June, but in the second quarter declined 8.1 percent, to 168.1 billion won, from 183 billion won in the quarter last year. The company attributed the decline to a drop in steel prices and losses incurred in the sale of an operation in Venezuela. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Head Start on a Road Trip

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Typhoon Ends Drought Crisis
description: Torrential rains over the last week, brought by Typhoon Rammasun, have refilled reservoirs in northern Taiwan that had been dangerously low. The government lifted water rationing rules on the main island and disbanded its cabinet-level drought crisis center. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Comparing Rulings
description: To the Editor:

title: Text: Bush's Speech on Corrupt Corporate Executives
description: The following are remarks President Bush made on Tuesday in a speech in New York against corrupt corporate executives, as transcribed by Federal News Service.

title: Protecting Monarchs by Trying to Protect Forests
description: For years, conservationists have watched, frustrated, as the Mexican government's declaration of no-logging zones in and around the winter retreats of the monarch butterfly have been ignored.

title: Tunnel Vision; When One New Train Equals One Less Express
description: People often complain about politics and diplomacy being vicious zero-sum games, in which one group's gain is achieved only by a painful loss for another. To cheer themselves up, these people should spend a little time aboard the New York City subway.

title: Schwarz Case Proves Guilt, U.S. Contends
description: In a closing statement to the jury yesterday, a prosecutor argued that a ''massive amount of evidence'' proved that Charles Schwarz, a twice-convicted former police officer, should be convicted again of assisting in the assault of Abner Louima five years ago and then lying about it at a trial two years ago.

title: Brazil to Share AIDS Drugs
description: In a new challenge to the pharmaceutical industry, the Brazilian government has offered to share its generic AIDS drugs and the technology used to produce them with some of the world's poorest countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, CHARLES L.
description: KRAMER-Charles L., on July 8, 2002, in his 85th year. Beloved husband of Dee. Devoted father of William and Elizabeth. Grandfather of Benjamin, Matthew and Asher. Loving father-in-law of Nora Kramer and Robert Reid. We will love him forever. Memorial service at 1:30pm on Wednesday, July 10, at Temple Beth El of Northern Westchester, 229 Bedford Rd, Chappaqua, NY.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TOWER AUTOMOTIVE INC., Grand Rapids, Mich., the world's biggest maker of stamped vehicle frames, said it paid off $200 million in debt and reduced the amount it can borrow because the company does not need the money.

title: How a Popular State Bill to Restrict Smoking in Restaurants Faltered
description: Among the many pieces of unfinished business at the end of the legislative session this year, a bill that would have restricted smoking in restaurants seemed among the most likely to succeed.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: RAIDS ON PAKISTANI-OWNED STORES Federal investigators are conducting raids nationwide on jewelry stores owned mostly by Pakistanis, hoping to break up fronts for terrorist groups or their financial backers, officials said. The raids have taken place over the last two weeks in several cities, including New York, Atlanta, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh. About 75 jewelry stores have been raided, a law enforcement official said. Tariq Hussain, 27, a recently discharged United States Army mechanic whose Intrigue Jewelers kiosk in suburban Pittsburgh was searched on June 26, said F.B.I. agents questioned him about connections to the Qaeda terrorist network or its leader, Osama bin Laden. (AP)

title: Big German Engineering Company Fails
description: After searching through the weekend for a way to persuade its banks to advance more cash and keep it afloat, Babcock Borsig, the giant German engineering company, came up empty today, making it the fourth major German company to fail this year.

title: Two Teams Left to Fight For Amonte
description: Both the Rangers and the Islanders, in the words of one National Hockey League official, have taken a wait-and-see approach in their pursuit of wing Tony Amonte, the last remaining upper-tier free agent this summer.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a visit by President Bush to Ripley, W.Va., misidentified the newspaper that first reported comments by the state Republican chairman, Kris Warner, on political reasons for the trip. It was The Charleston Daily Mail, not The Gazette.

title: US Air Reaches Deal to Reduce Pay of Pilots
description: US Airways and its pilots' union have reached a tentative agreement that would cut $465 million a year from the pilots' wages and benefits, the airline and the union said yesterday.

title: The Perfectionist at the Plate
description: In late August of 1946, when I was 12, I watched Ted Williams hit the most vicious drive I have ever seen. The ball, in my memory at least, was still soaring majestically when it hit the seats in the third tier in Yankee Stadium. Forty-two years later, when I was 54 and he was nearly 70, I spoke with Williams about the drive, both of us magically still boys on this date because of the subject matter. As I did, and as the details of that game all came back, I watched a smile spread over his face. ''Tiny Bonham,'' he said at the end, naming the Yankee pitcher. I am sure he remembered the exact quality of the light and what Bonham threw as well.

title: Bush and the Business Scandals
description: To the Editor:

title: A Love Affair With Afghanistan Continues at 74; Her Guidebook Inspired a Play, And She Fights for a Nation's Soul
description: When the playwright Tony Kushner came across ''An Historical Guide to Kabul'' by Nancy Hatch Dupree in the New York University library in 1997, it was, he said later, ''one of the happiest accidents of my life.'' Her book later became the literary centerpiece of his most recent play, ''Homebody/Kabul.''

title: In Russia, 31 Coffins, Flowers and Candles
description: Mourners flooded today into a central square in Ufa, about 700 miles east of Moscow, for a wake for victims of last week's collision between a Russian airliner and a cargo jet over southern Germany.

title: The Perfect Train
description: Electromagnets can levitate small metal objects. But can they propel a roller coaster? Lift a ten thousand ton train? What about launching a rocket into space? The answer is  they can: thanks to a technology called maglev, short for magnetic levitation.

title: Alomar Insists It's Not a Season in Purgatory
description: The beads of sweat on his forehead have evaporated, indoor batting practice having ended some 15 minutes earlier. Roberto Alomar, a 10-time Gold Glove winner at second base, a 12-time All-Star and a future Hall of Famer, is in cool-down mode, sitting by his locker in the visiting clubhouse at Pro Player Stadium in Miami. This is the laid-back Alomar, the one who lobs balls overhand to Mo Vaughn at first base or flips them backhanded to his double-play partner, Rey Ordez, grace without exertion.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Earthlink To Run Music Service
description: EarthLink, the third-largest Internet service provider, released an Internet music service yesterday that is intended to provide an alternative to illegal file-swapping services. The new service, EarthLink Digital Music -- unveiled with the privately held subscription service FullAudio -- will let users download up to 50 songs a month for $9.95, or 100 a month for $17.95. FullAudio offers music from BMG, EMI Recorded Music, the Warner Music Group and the Universal Music Group. The service may face an uphill battle, however, as few pay services for digital music delivery have done well. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECKETT, JACK
description: PECKETT-Jack. New York University grieves for the loss of Jack Peckett, the Associate Director of Athletics and a member of the NYU community for nearly three decades. A cherished friend, a valued colleague, and an unflagging booster of NYU, Jack was a principal architect of NYU's sports and recreations programs. We shall miss him greatly. Our thoughts are with his loved ones, and we share their sorrow. Christopher Bledsoe, Director, NYU Athletics

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest Names Finance Officer
description: Qwest Communications International, the telephone company whose shares were down 87 percent this year, said it had hired Oren G. Shaffer as chief financial officer to increase investor confidence. Mr. Shaffer, 59, worked for Qwest's new chief executive, Richard C. Notebaert, at the Ameritech Corporation, a local phone company bought by SBC Communications. Mr. Shaffer will also be vice chairman at Qwest, which is based in Denver and is the biggest local-phone-service operator in 14 Western states. He replaces Robin R. Szeliga, who will stay at Qwest and focus on reducing its $26.4 billion in debt. Last month, Joseph P. Nacchio stepped down as Qwest's chief executive after its shares plunged amid a Securities and Exchange Commission accounting inquiry and doubt about the company's ability to repay its debt.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Universal To Permit Downloading
description: The Universal Music Group said yesterday that it planned to permit Internet users to download songs and make homemade compact discs from music contained in roughly 1,000 albums in its catalog. This is one of the first instances of a record company's making a large catalog of music available in the MP3 format, a popular file type that has become controversial because files can easily be shared via e-mail. Under the deal announced yesterday, the music will be available through emusic.com, a start-up company acquired last year by Vivendi Universal, which owns Universal; unlimited access will cost $120 a year. The music available will be drawn from the company's back catalog. Matt Richtel (NYT)

description: Somewhere in the vast crowds that welcomed the Tour de France to Germany today, Jan Ullrich should have been watching and, sentimentalists can hope, wondering.

description: In the year since Medicare began paying for wider access to colonoscopy to look for colon cancer, the number of people having the test has greatly increased, and doctors say they are struggling to keep up with demand.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Benefits Plan For Ex-Paramilitaries
description: The government has proposed a special tax to provide cash and training programs for former members of paramilitary squads. More than 1,000 former members of the Civil Self-Defense Patrols, who were supported by the military and linked to human rights abuses during Guatemala's 36-year civil war, blocked roads near Mayan ruins during protests last month seeking $2,500 apiece. Some lawmakers said they would oppose the new tax, which could benefit as many as 250,000 former paramilitary troops -- a strong electoral base for the governing party. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: ALBERTO SAYS QUARTERLY SALES AND PROFITS ARE UP
description: The Alberto-Culver Company, the world's largest seller of beauty-salon products, said yesterday that quarterly profit and sales rose by at least 10 percent. Profit in the quarter, which ended June 30 and was the third quarter of the company's fiscal year, met or exceeded analysts' forecasts, the company said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected the company to earn 60 cents a share, up from 50 cents in the year-earlier period. The company plans to give final results on July 25. Alberto-Culver is based in Melrose Park, Ill.

Appearances, memorabilia shows or signings -- the moneymaking ventures that in his later years enriched Williams, the Boston Red Sox legend who died Friday -- could not happen without John Henry.

On Saturday night, as he sat in his Dior studio wearing a Vivienne Westood T-shirt from her old Seditionaries shop, he was asked if he thinks people would ever stop asking that question.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Initial Stock Offer Canceled
description: The Cantrell & Cochrane Group, an Irish food and beverage maker known for potato chips and soda, canceled its initial public offering on the Dublin and London exchanges just 48 hours before the new stock was scheduled to begin trading. The company cited market volatility as the reason for withdrawing the offer, which would have been the first on the Dublin market since 1999; the benchmark ISEQ index has fallen 21 percent since January. Cantrell & Cochrane had planned to sell 48 percent of its equity at a price of 2.60 to 3.60 euros a share, raising at least 923 million euros ($899.94 million) to help pay down 800 million euros of debt. The company can still meet its business agenda and pay for acquisitions without the share offering, the chairman, Anthony O'Brien, said. The group has exclusive Irish distribution rights for Pepsi and 7-Up, and owns Tayto potato chips. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, TED
description: WILLIAMS-Ted. The President, Board of Trustees, staff and extended family of Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, and its fund raising arm the Jimmy Fund, mourn the passing of Ted Williams, baseball's most famous hitter in the Jimmy Fund's legendary supporter. For thousands of children with cancer, Mr. Williams provided hope and inspiration, both at Fenway Park and during his countless visits to the Jimmy Fund Clinic at Dana-Farber. His tireless advocacy and generosity on behalf of the clinic have contributed to great advances in cancer research and care. At the start of his work with the Jimmy Fund in 1953, almost every child with cancer died. Today, therapies for adults advance with unprecedented success, andnearly four out of five children with cancer survive. Mr. Williams had a dream to beat cancer. At Dana-Farber his spirit and dedication will forever inspire our work to make that vision a reality. Edward J. Benz Jr., M.D. President, Dana-Farber Cancer Institute Michael J. Andrews, Chairman, The Jimmy Fund

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Sexual Abuse At Public Pool
description: A man was arrested yesterday after a 14-year-old girl and a 32-year-old woman were sexually abused at a public pool in Carroll Gardens, the police said. The victims told pool employees of the incident shortly after noon, and the police officer assigned to the pool was called. Kareen Corbet, 23, of Argyle Road in Brooklyn, was charged with misdemeanor sexual abuse, involving inappropriate touching, Detective Kevin Czartoryski said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Biographer of an Art Historian and Spy Finds Duplicity a Fascinating Subject
description: Miranda Carter's ''Anthony Blunt: His Lives'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux) is a kind of dual biography about a single subject. Of the four notorious Cambridge University graduates who became spies for the Soviet Union, Blunt, the so-called Fourth Man, was the unlikeliest to pursue a path of treason. While the others -- Guy Burgess, Donald Maclean and in particular Kim Philby -- seemed to be dedicated to their careers in espionage, Blunt was an erudite art historian, curator to the queen and a teacher who was admired by his students.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: TURKEY: POLITICAL TURMOIL GROWS The governing coalition of the ailing prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, appeared to be disintegrating yesterday and his party mutinying. His rightist coalition partner, the Nationalist Action Party, called for early elections, and Deputy Prime Minister Husamettin Ozkan quit both the government and the Democratic Left Party, which Mr. Ecevit helped to found. The state-run Anatolian news agency said about 15 of the party's members of Parliament had resigned, with more expected to follow. Calls for early elections have grown since Mr. Ecevit, 77, fell ill two months ago. (Reuters)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OGUS, DR. ALFRED
description: OGUS-Dr. Alfred. A distinguished surgeon and resident of Rancho Santa Fe for 25 years, died on June 24, after a lengthy illness. Born in Washington DC in 1912, he received his medical degree from George Washington University in 1935. Following his internship at Gallinger Hospital, he completed his residency in 1938, at the Baltimore Eye and Ear Hospital, acting as assistant surgeon to Dr. Lee Cohen, a pioneer in the field of reconstructive surgery. After an additional two year course of study at Bellevue Hospital in NYC, Dr. Ogus was selected as Chief of Plastic Surgery at Halloran Veterans Hospital in Staten Island, where he remained until joining the U.S. Air Force as a Flight Surgeon in 1942. Dr. Ogus began his private practice at offices at 502 Park Avenue, NYC, and established his home some blocks away at 993 Park Avenue. During the 26 years of his active practice, he was a member of the staff of the LeRoy Hospital, the Wickersham Hospital and the St. Clare Annex. Known for his generosity, Dr. Ogus served as consultant and surgeon to the St. Clare Free Clinic in addition to contributing to many medical charities. A career member of the American Academy of Facial Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery, Dr. Ogus was elected a Fellow of the American Society of Facial and Plastic Surgery in 1963. Upon his retirement, he continued his studies at the London School of Economics. During the following years, he and his beloved wife, Pat, maintained homes in both Rancho Santa Fe, CA and Cascais, Portugal, where they enjoyed memberships in both social and charitable groups. Sharing a thirst for adventure, he and Pat traveled extensively throughout the European and Asian continents. During his lifetime, Dr. Ogus was known for his generosity and caring manner. Many patients will recall both his great surgical skills and his concern for their well being. He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Patricia Ogus, a former child actress who appeared with Lionel Barrymore and Lew Ayres in the ''Dr. Kildare'' series; his nieces Dr. Norma Simon of Pelham, NY, Helen Albright of W. Los Angeles, Elena Paley of Arlington, VA, and Elaine Tepper of Washington, DC. A private memorial service was held on Friday, July 5 at the San Diego Hospice, 3rd Avenue, San Diego. Donations to the Hospice where Dr. Ogus received loving care, will be appreciated.

description: The Bank of China, which is selling as much as $3.2 billion of shares in its Hong Kong unit, is offering them for a cheaper price than expected to attract investors concerned about bad loans. Bank of China is offering shares in the unit at a price 12 to 16 times forecast earnings, according to its offer document, compared with about 18.4 times for HSBC Holdings, Hong Kong's biggest bank.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Kingfisher Gets Control Of Rival
description: Kingfisher secured victory in a battle for control of Castorama of France after the Rothschild & Cie investment bank approved the terms of combining the companies, both home improvement specialists. Kingfisher already owns 55 percent of Castorama but without full management control. Kingfisher said it would pay 2.4 billion euros ($2.34 billion) in cash and sell new shares worth $3 billion to finance the deal. The shares will be sold at 155 pence, half Friday's closing price. Kingfisher's stock fell 7.5 pence, to 302.5 pence a share. Castorama's stock rose 1.75 euros, to 65.85 euros. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: ANDRX SETTLES SUITS OVER GENERIC HEART DRUGS
description: The Andrx Corporation said yesterday that it had reached settlements with a rival, the Biovail Corporation, in their dispute over two heart drugs and with wholesalers and other purchasers of the Cardizem heart medicine in a separate case. The Biovail settlement ends disputes about Andrx's generic versions of Biovail's Tiazac and Cardizem heart drugs. Andrx, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said it also reached a preliminary settlement with buyers of Cardizem who had sued in United States District Court for the Southern District of Michigan. Wholesalers and other purchasers had claimed an agreement that Andrx had with a company that is now part of Aventis kept a less expensive generic version of Cardizem off the market. Andrx and Aventis agreed to pay an undisclosed amount of cash to the wholesalers. Andrx said it would have a $60 million litigation expense in the second quarter.

It left from Takahama on the Sea of Japan, in the western prefecture of Fukui, about 50 miles north of Osaka, not from the town of the same name on the Pacific Ocean in Aichi Prefecture.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Ecstasy Drug Seizures Down

Thomas E. Manifase, an assistant special agent for the Customs Service, said that inspectors at Newark International Airport, Kennedy International Airport and Miami International Airport had seized less Ecstasy. Newark seized 736,224 Ecstasy tablets between October 2001 and July 2002, down about 12 percent from the same period a year ago. Stacy Albin (NYT)

The 335-room Roosevelt Hotel, on Hollywood Boulevard and Orange, was the original home of the Oscar presentations. After 75 years, it is undergoing a major renovation. Until May 31, 2003, three nights will cost $199 for the first two nights and $2.75 or $4 (the prices in 1927) for the third; (800) 950-7667 or www.hollywoodroosevelt.com . description: A panel investigating possible scientific fraud at Lucent Technologies' Bell Labs has broadened the range and scope of its inquiry to include at least four papers on novel superconductivity experiments.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Juvenile-Justice Official Named
description: Howard L. Beyer, former administrator of the maximum-security New Jersey State Prison, has been appointed executive director for the state's Juvenile Justice Commission, which oversees youth facilities, rehabilitation and punishment policies. Mr. Beyer, who lives in Highland Park, was appointed deputy executive director to the commission in 1999. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Baseball's All-Stall Break
description: THE All-Star Game was once baseball at its innocent best: the best pitchers against the best hitters in a midsummer night's dream.

title: Nokia to Join With I.B.M. In 2 Ventures On Software
description: Nokia and I.B.M. will announce an agreement today to develop software to distribute music and other media securely to cellphones over wireless networks in a effort to broaden the market for wireless services beyond telephone service and simple text messages.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: MACHINERY ORDERS RISE Machinery orders placed by private companies, a crucial gauge of corporate capital spending, rose 0.2 percent in May compared with April. The numbers, which beat expectations of a 5 percent decline, follow an 8.4 percent gain last month. The positive results in April and May suggest that capital spending will probably start growing again this quarter. Capital spending makes up about 15 percent of the Japanese economy.

title: Study Is Halted Over Rise Seen In Cancer Risk
description: A large federal study of hormone replacement therapy in postmenopausal women was abruptly halted, researchers say, because the drugs caused a slight but significant increase in the risk of invasive breast cancer.

title: Falun Gong Is Accused of Disrupting Broadcasts
description: Chinese officials accused the outlawed Falun Gong spiritual movement today of ''launching a challenge against human civilization'' by disrupting satellite television transmissions in parts of the country for more than 12 hours last month.

title: Immigration Policy to Bar Canadian and Mexican Part-Time Students in U.S. Colleges
description: Government efforts to enforce immigration laws strictly since last year's terrorist attacks will bar thousands of Canadian and Mexican college students from returning to school in the fall and cost colleges and universities near the borders millions of dollars, college officials say.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Sunday and in some editions on Saturday about Benjamin O. Davis, who commanded the Tuskegee Airmen during World War II and was an advocate for an integrated military, misstated his rank in some copies. While he indeed retired as a lieutenant general, he was later promoted to full general by President Bill Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIMPLE, MORRIS
description: GIMPLE-Morris. After fighting in the Aleutians, he began a successful coin meter operating business. Later he owned and operated Gilbert's Hotel in South Fallsburg, NY. He is survived by his daughter Fredda and his long time companion and business partner Ann Gilbert.

title: Afghan Ally of U.S. Sees Pilot Error in Attack
description: America's main ally in southern Afghanistan, the governor of Kandahar, said today that he thought the American-led attack that killed and injured scores of villagers in Oruzgan Province last week would prove to have been caused by an error of the pilot of the AC-130 gunship involved.

description: The Islamic world represses women, spawns terrorism, is prone to war, resists democracy and has contributed remarkably few great scientists or writers to modern civilization. So it's time to defend Islam.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: BRAZIL: STEEL ALLIANCE TALKS Companhia Siderurgica Nacional, one of Latin America's largest steel producers, is in talks with the Corus Group , the British-Dutch steel giant, but will not be selling a controlling stake, a spokesman for the Brazilian company said. With a market capital of 3.3 billion reals ($1.15 billion), CSN produces four billion tons of steel yearly, generating sales of $2 billion. Corus has a market value of about $4 billion. One sticking point in the deal, which is said to involve an exchange of equity between the companies, could be $600 million in debt CSN owes to Brazil's development bank. A controlling share of the company was given as security for the loan. Tony Smith (NYT)

description: JOSEPH-Clara (nee Klein). On July 6, 2002 at age 95. Beloved wife of the late Herman, devoted mother of Lawrence and Susan. Cherished grandmother of Miranda, Harlan, and Galen. Loving mother-in-law of Ellen. We will miss and not forget her. Services Tuesday 10:30 A.M. at ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial'' Queens Blvd & 76th Rd, Forest Hills.

description: Like most golf tournaments lacking Tiger Woods in the field, the Lightpath Long Island Classic, a Senior PGA event that will be held at the Meadow Brook Club on the first weekend of August, is searching for ways to attract spectators.

description: A new class of 15 fellows has been appointed to the New York Public Library's Center for Scholars and Writers.

title: PLASTICS MAKER IS CONSIDERING PURCHASE OFFERS
description: Applied Extrusion Technologies Inc., a maker of plastics used for soda-bottle labels and snack-food packaging, said yesterday that it had hired J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. to assess inquiries from ''a number of parties'' to buy the company. Applied Extrusion said last month that it was receiving unsolicited expressions of interest in the company. The plastics maker did not disclose details about the potential buyers. The company is based in Peabody, Mass.

title: Corrections
description: Amap on Friday with an article about the shipment of 550 pounds of nuclear fuel from Japan to Britain showed an erroneous location for the port town where the cargo began its 18,000-mile voyage. It left from Takahama on the Sea of Japan, in the western prefecture of Fukui, about 50 miles north of Osaka, not from the town of the same name on the Pacific Ocean in Aichi Prefecture.

title: Despite Access, Star Analyst Missed WorldCom Trouble Signs
description: Jack Grubman, the influential telecommunications analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, missed signs of trouble at WorldCom that some other analysts spotted. And he missed them in spite of an extraordinarily close relationship with the company's management. He was so close to the company that he attended three WorldCom board meetings, he said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Arrest In Officer's Shooting
description: A man was arrested yesterday and charged with shooting an off-duty correction officer at an East New York park on Sunday, the police said. The man, Ronell Peterkin, 22, of Brooklyn, faces charges of attempted murder and possession of a weapon. The correction officer, Carlos Engleton, was in stable condition yesterday.

description: The French in Yohji Yamamoto, who has spent 20 years musing under this city's exquisite bell jar, came out last night in a beautiful ready-to-wear collection for spring, shown three months ahead of the usual timetable.

description: Cockfighting has mostly disappeared and bear baiting, once the rage of 19th-century America, has gone the way of the frontier.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about the National Visionary Leadership Project, an oral history archive for distinguished African-Americans, misspelled the surname of the centenarian sisters depicted in the 1995 Broadway play ''Having Our Say,'' which was presented in the style of oral history. They were Sadie and Bessie Delany, not Delaney. The article also referred erroneously to precedents for the archive. A similar project indeed exists -- the National Video Oral History Archives, established in Chicago in 1999.

title: A World Event Could Solve All-Star Blahs
description: Baseball's All-Star Game remains the best and most legitimate All-Star game of all of the major professional star-studded exhibition games, but officials are concerned that the game has lost luster. It needs something, they feel, to reinvigorate it so that it can regain its hold over fans. Television ratings, you know.

title: $12,000 a Night, but Negotiable; Hotels for Rich, Like Guests, Do Fine in Lean Times
description: True, economic troubles may be at hand. But it does not really matter quite so much when your hotel caters to clients who pay $10,000 a night and who tip a waiter more than most people pay to spend a night in a typical Manhattan hotel.

title: Sun and Smoke
description: When the heat broke late last week in the Northeast, it did so with a stiff wind out of the north. At first, pure white clouds brushed across a deep blue sky, the very epitome of summer's fair weather. But as the hours passed, that same southward current of air began to carry with it the smoke from dozens of lightning-started forest fires in northern Quebec, a part of Canada that has recently suffered extremely high temperatures. By the weekend, much of the Northeast was living in the sepia light of a smoke-dimmed sun.

Survived by Elizabeth, his wife of 54 years, his brother F. Parks Landis and his family. title: Turntable Artist as Master of the Trance
description: It was a sweltering Friday night at Exit 2, and the chant started before Paul Oakenfold even touched the turntables: ''Oakie! Oakie! Oakie!'' He responded with a wave and a grin, and for the next two hours, he kept the audience shouting and dancing. Mr. Oakenfold, a veteran D.J. from London, uses beats, not words, to get his message across: he never touched the microphone, and almost all the tracks he played were instrumentals.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: BOY STRUCK BY POLICE VAN A 13-year-old boy was critically injured yesterday in Harlem when he ran into a street between parked cars and was struck by an unmarked police van, the authorities said. The boy, identified as Keith McKissick, underwent surgery last night at Harlem Hospital, a spokeswoman said. Two officers from the warrant squad were driving west on 125th Street near Madison Avenue shortly after 12:30 p.m. when the van's passenger-side mirror struck the boy in the head, the police said. A videotape obtained from a shopkeeper and shown to reporters last night showed that the van had a green light and stopped when the boy was hit. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

description: More than 30 African leaders gathered today in this balmy port city to bury the Organization of African Unity, the venerable organization that championed the continent's long and successful struggle against white oppressors but stood mostly silent when black autocrats emerged in their wake.

The leadership and staff of The Workmen's Circle/Arbeter Ring mourn the passing of the President of the Workmen's Circle Multicare Center and former member of our National Executive Board, Sam Byer. His vision and devotion have been the guiding forces of the center for the past several years. His dedication to the dignity of our residents and excellence of care will be his lasting legacy. description: In rural India, treatment for mental illness is more likely to come in a ''healing temple'' than in a clinic or hospital.

description: As newly declassified archives begin to illuminate what happened to hundreds of leftists who disappeared during a ''dirty war'' waged by the government in the 1970's, a harsh spotlight is turning on Mexico's army.

description: The flooding that has brought death and devastating property damage to Central and North Texas moved southward today as swollen rivers forced highway closings and prompted evacuations in small towns, while officials kept watch on a new storm front developing in the Gulf of Mexico.

description: CHICAGO, July 8  Attorney General Jim Ryan, the Republican nominee for governor, said today that the incumbent, George Ryan, a fellow party member, should explain his role in a continuing driver's-licenses-for-bribes scandal or step down.

title: Under Centuries of Sand, a Trading Hub
description: South of Suez, the Egyptian shore of the Red Sea used to be sprinkled with ports that throbbed with life and commerce in antiquity, especially the heyday of the Roman Empire. But long ago, the relentless desert buried their remains so completely that it was almost beyond imagination that these places once were pivotal links in a maritime trade route that rivaled the better-known overland Silk Road.

description: Standing in the small kitchen of her rustic house in this remote community of Mazahua Indians, Celia Isidoro is singing the praises of her new, efficient wood-burning stove.

title: REGULATORS ALLOW RELIANT ENERGY TO RESTRUCTURE
description: Reliant Energy Inc., the biggest electricity company in Texas, said federal regulators approved a new holding company structure, a step needed to complete the spinoff of Reliant Resources, its energy-trading arm. Reliant Energy, which is based in Houston, will be renamed CenterPoint Energy, a natural gas and power-delivery company. Shares of Reliant Resources still held by its parent will be distributed to investors in coming weeks, completing a separation that began last year, the company said. Reliant Energy owns 83 percent of Reliant Resources. The chief executive, Steve Letbetter, has said that completing the spinoff quickly is Reliant Energy's top priority. The company has $4.7 billion in bank loans that expire Friday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Anti-Semitic Sign A Booby Trap
description: Two highway workers in the Siberian region of Tomsk suffered cuts and bruises after an anti-Semitic sign on a roadside exploded when they tried to tear it down. It was the third such incident since late May, when a woman was seriously wounded while trying to remove a similar sign near Moscow. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Dean of House Is Forced to Face Ex-Ally in Primary
description: John D. Dingell, dean of the House of Representatives, is talking a lot these days about mammograms, Pap smears and equal pay. His public events feature testimonials from women like Tina Abbott, a union official who praised Mr. Dingell the other day before an audience of women and declared, ''He doesn't have to wear a skirt to prove who he is.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABOFF, CELIA
description: ABOFF-Celia. Died in Ft. Lauderdale on July 4, 2002 at the age of 87. Beloved mother of Bruce and sister-in-law of Tess; cherished aunt of Stanley, Nancy, Stephen, and David, and great aunt of Jill and Michelle, Alexandra and Peter, Randy and Allison, and David; adoring great-great aunt of Taylor, Nicholas, Tyler and Emily, and Monica; special friend to Debbie, Ellie, John, and Henny, and good friend to so many others. She was greatly loved and admired, and she will be greatly missed. Contributions in her memory may be made to the New York Public Library where she enjoyed her many years as a volunteer.

title: Letters
description: Finding Cure for Colitis

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, EARLE
description: BROWN-Earle. Earle Brown was not only one of our great composers but an outstanding leader in the new music community. As a conductor, musical thinker, and as former president of the Board of the American Music Center, Earle Brown's contributions to the field will continue to resonate with everyone whom he has touched. And through his wonderful music, he will continue to inspire all of us. Our sympathies to his wife, Susan Sollins, sister, Marilyn Krysil, and the entire family. Earle was a superbly generous human being and we will miss him dearly. The American Music Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARKASH, SYLVIA
description: FARKASH-Sylvia. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Dr. Arthur and Lori Farkash. Cherished grandmother of Elijah. Services Tuesday 10am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation.

title: A New Hair Weave That Heals
description: A new study has concluded that for many scalp wounds, taking a few strands of hair from each side of the wound, twisting them together and gluing them into place may be a better treatment than stitching. The study, which was published in the July issue of The Annals of Emergency Medicine, found that the technique was not only less painful, it also allowed simple wounds to heal faster and with fewer side effects.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Rise
description: Machinery orders placed by private companies, a crucial gauge of corporate capital spending, rose 0.2 percent in May compared with April. The numbers, which beat expectations of a 5 percent decline, follow an 8.4 percent gain last month. The positive results in April and May suggest that capital spending will probably start growing again this quarter. Capital spending makes up about 15 percent of the Japanese economy. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Church Dispute Festers
description: A senior official of Russia's Orthodox Church, Archbishop Vsevelod Chaplin, deputy of the church's foreign relations division, accused a Roman Catholic bishop barred from the country earlier this year of trying to win converts. Bishop Jerzy Mazur, a native of Poland, headed the diocese of Eastern Siberia and the Far East until Russia stripped him of his visa in April, souring relations between the Vatican and the Orthodox Church. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Kicking Tires at the Tour: Ins, Outs, Ups and Downs
description: As the Tour de France spins its way around France during the next three weeks, American eyes will most likely be on Lance Armstrong, the Texan who rides for the United States Postal Service team.

title: Mourning Fallen Brothers, Familiar to Them or Not
description: No, Jim Butler said, he had never met James Sylvester, the young fire chief he had come to mourn. And no, he did not know the two other firefighters who died with the chief while trying to save three young sisters from a fire early Thursday morning.

title: Whitmore Dominates On the Inside
description: At 6 feet 2 inches and 190 pounds, Tamika Whitmore has the size to play the low post in the Women's National Basketball Association. Last night, she also had the moves, the positioning and the game plan as she led the Liberty to an impressive 77-71 victory over the Phoenix Mercury.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Financial Watchdog For Flint
description: The state appointed an emergency financial manager for Flint, the largest municipality ever to be taken over by the state. The city of 125,000 has been battered in the last two decades by high unemployment and the disappearance of auto industry jobs, but the problems have accelerated. Debt has grown to about $40 million, and in March, the mayor was recalled. The financial manager, Edward J. Kurtz, 59, is president of Baker College, a system of career colleges. He was recommended by Gov. John Engler. Danny Hakim (NYT)

title: How to Reform Palestinian Politics
description: In his recent speech on the Mideast, President Bush made any improvement in Palestinians' miserable life conditional not only on security for Israel but on the removal of Yasir Arafat, their elected president, and on the implementation of political reforms. Since most Palestinians have no confidence in the Bush administration, they took the president's remarks as a green light to Israel to remove Mr. Arafat and perhaps renew occupation. Israel's declaration of ''victory'' after the speech indicated that Israelis interpreted it similarly.

title: Adolescent Medicine, Made Accessible
description: ''The Teen Health Book: A Parents' Guide to Adolescent Health and Well-Being,'' Dr. Ralph I. Lopez, W. W. Norton & Company, $26.95

title: Phone Giants Draw Protest In Europe
description: Former telephone monopolies in Europe are engaged in ''methodological anticompetitive behavior,'' five of their largest rivals said today in a complaint letter sent to Mario Monti, the European Union's competition commissioner.

title: Auditor Gave Assurances Of Safeguards Against Fraud
description: Arthur Andersen assured WorldCom's audit committee in February that the company had strict procedures in place to prevent false statements in financial filings -- even in areas that proved to be central to the company's bookkeeping scandal, according to a copy of Andersen's report.

title: Technology Briefing | Work Force: Change Could Ease Hiring
description: The federal government is planning to change the rules for companies seeking to hire skilled foreign workers to reduce the wait for a work permit to about nine months. The acceleration would be a potential boon for technology companies, which must now wait five years for the department to process an application for a permanent work permit for someone from abroad. The proposed rule, from the Labor Department, would let companies, rather than government agencies, certify that there was a lack of qualified domestic workers to fill the jobs.

title: In Chicago
description: When the Boeing Company moved to Chicago from Seattle last year, it helped to revive the claim by some people in Illinois that Chicago is ''America's business city.'' The boast is based not only on the number of big companies based here -- Chicago and its suburbs are home to 32 members of the Fortune 500 -- but also on commodities and financial futures exchanges and on the city's convention industry. More than seven million people came here for conventions, trade shows and meetings last year, according to the Chicago Convention and Tourism Bureau.

description: Robert Wilson to the Windows

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUMANN, EDITH
description: NEUMANN-Edith. Microbiologist. 100. Passed away on June 29, 2002. She is survived by her cousins Hanna Beck of Zurich, Switzerland, Friedel David, of London, England, and many friends and distant relatives who will always remember her love, strength and inspiration. Interment is private. A memorial service will be held in the fall. Contributions in her memory may be made to Neighborhood Coalition for Shelter, Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, PAUL, M.D.
description: GOLDBERG-Paul, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center records with sorrow the death of Dr. Paul Goldberg. Dr Goldberg was affiliated with Maimonides Medical Center in the Department of Urology for many years. He also did his internship and residency at Maimonides. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Sincere condolences are extended to his family. S. Farber, M.D., Pres. H. Lehman, M.D., Pres. Elect. I. Mayer, M.D., Secy. W. Wexelman, M.D., Treas.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Silicon Graphics Sales Fall Short
description: Silicon Graphics, whose computers create digital images for training pilots and making movies, said that fourth-quarter sales had fallen short of forecasts as customers cut spending on its equipment. Sales were $280 million to $290 million, compared with an earlier estimate of $310 million to $330 million, the company said in a statement, citing a preliminary review. The loss in the period ended June 28 will be $20 million to $25 million. Silicon Graphics will report final fourth-quarter results on July 25.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: IRELAND: INITIAL STOCK OFFER CANCELED The Cantrell & Cochrane Group, an Irish food and beverage maker known for potato chips and soda, canceled its initial public offering on the Dublin and London exchanges just 48 hours before the new stock was scheduled to begin trading. The company cited market volatility as the reason for withdrawing the offer, which would have been the first on the Dublin market since 1999; the benchmark ISEQ index has fallen 21 percent since January. Cantrell & Cochrane had planned to sell 48 percent of its equity at a price of 2.60 to 3.60 euros a share, raising at least 923 million euros ($899.94 million) to help pay down 800 million euros of debt. The company can still meet its business agenda and pay for acquisitions without the share offering, the chairman, Anthony O'Brien, said. The group has exclusive Irish distribution rights for Pepsi and 7-Up, and owns Tayto potato chips. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: White Officer Suspended After Tape Shows Handcuffed Black Youth Was Punched
description: A white police officer in the Los Angeles suburb of Inglewood was relieved of duty today after a bystander videotaped a confrontation on Saturday evening in which a handcuffed black teenager was thrown against a police car and then punched in the jaw.

title: Ex-Tyco Counsel Changes Lawyers
description: Mark A. Belnick, the former chief counsel for Tyco International, has switched lawyers as inquiries continue into whether he improperly took millions of dollars from the company.

title: No Date Is Set, but a Strike by the Players Looms
description: The players union executive board met for five hours today without setting a strike date, but quietly let it be known that barring a new labor agreement, one will be set in the next few weeks for sometime between Aug. 15 and Sept. 30.

title: Beyond the Script: What Happens When the Heroine Faints
description: The common faint was enshrined in my adolescent imagination by movies. Remember the beautiful heroine -- fainters on film are always women -- overcome by shock, touching her brow with the back of her hand and falling limply into waiting arms. Her faint was stereotyped and contrived -- yet riveting. It made fainting seem benign, almost glamorous.

title: Russian Land Reform
description: The Russian attachment to land is so deep and visceral that efforts to sell off decaying collective farms unsettle even those who understand that the country would work far better with a private farming system. Many of the huge communal farms lie fallow, bankrupt remnants of a corrupt and clumsy system that was brutally engineered by Stalin over 70 years ago. Now President Vladimir Putin is pushing through important legislation that will allow the sale of farmland to Russian citizens or private companies. Without such basic land reform, Russian agriculture will remain mired in its Soviet lethargy.

title: Safeway Had Slight Gain in 2nd Quarter
description: Safeway Inc., the grocery chain, said today that its second-quarter profit rose less than 1 percent, meeting a reduced forecast.

title: Ad Revenue for Radio Increased 3% in May
description: Advertising revenue for radio is continuing to increase, the Radio Advertising Bureau in New York reported yesterday, offering another sign of a recovery in ad spending.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: QWEST NAMES FINANCE OFFICER Qwest Communications International , the telephone company whose shares were down 87 percent this year, said it had hired Oren G. Shaffer as chief financial officer to increase investor confidence. Mr. Shaffer, 59, worked for Qwest's new chief executive, Richard C. Notebaert, at the Ameritech Corporation, a local phone company bought by SBC Communications. Mr. Shaffer will also be vice chairman at Qwest, which is based in Denver and is the biggest local-phone-service operator in 14 Western states. He replaces Robin R. Szeliga, who will stay at Qwest and focus on reducing its $26.4 billion in debt. Last month, Joseph P. Nacchio stepped down as Qwest's chief executive after its shares plunged amid a Securities and Exchange Commission accounting inquiry and doubt about the company's ability to repay its debt.

title: Indonesia Top Court Decides Insurer Isn't Really Bankrupt
description: The Supreme Court of Indonesia ruled today that the Indonesian unit of Manulife Financial, one of Canada's dominant insurers, was not bankrupt after all.
