title: Europe by Rail
description: Kids love trains, and the faster the better. Rail Europe has two fare plans this summer that cater to them. On the high-speed Thalys train, which connects major cities in France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany, one adult traveling in first class can take along up to four children 12 or younger at no extra charge, from July 15 to Aug. 31. This applies to certain routes only, and tickets must be issued in North America by Aug. 31. One-way first-class fares include $116 between Paris and Brussels, $156 between Paris and Amsterdam. The other Rail Europe children's special is on the 186-mile-an-hour Eurostar, which links London with Paris and Brussels. Passengers younger than 18 can travel one way in first class for $50 when accompanied by an adult using a full-fare ($269) or Leisure fare ($219) first-class ticket. The regular first-class fare for ages 4 to 11 is $109 (children under 4 are free unless they occupy a seat). Tickets must be issued in North America by July 31 for travel through Aug. 31. Information: (800) 387-6782 or www.raileurope.com .

title: Senate Panel to Ask Bush Aides To Give Details on His Iraq Policy
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee plans to hold hearings later this summer to question senior administration officials on their Iraq policy, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the committee chairman, said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, ISADOR H.
description: FINKELSTEIN-Isador H. On July 8, 2002. Beloved husband of Matilda for over 70 years, devoted father of Herbert and Lois and daughter-in-law Iris and son-in-law Morton, cherished grandfather of Amy, Stacy & Sarah and their husbands Jeffrey, Michael & Mark. Loving great grandfather of David, Daniel and Brian. He was a practicing certified public accountant for over 65 years until his retirement in 1993. From humble beginnings he became an inspiring success story. We will all miss his presence. Services today 1 PM, Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York.

title: A Passing Fancy: A Bar Named for Putin
description: There may be many ways to flatter President Vladimir V. Putin. Opening a bar in his name is apparently not one of the better ideas.

title: Moody's Cuts Alcatel Rating As Phone Sector Woes Persist
description: The sour outlook in the telecommunications industry led Moody's Investors Service today to downgrade the credit rating of Alcatel, Europe's largest maker of telecommunications equipment, to below investment grade. Alcatel is at least the fourth major European blue-chip company to fall to junk status this month.

title: The Corporate Scandals; Cleaning Up
description: Reacting belatedly to the continual reports of malfeasance undermining investor confidence and threatening the economic recovery, President Bush came to Wall Street yesterday to deliver his ''clean up your act or else'' message to corporate America. He sounded at times like a sheriff, warning of jail time for crooks, and at other times like a preacher admonishing business executives to look deep into their souls before issuing their next quarterly reports. At its core, however, the president's address was disappointingly devoid of tough proposals to remedy underlying problems in accounting, corporate governance and the safety net of federal laws and regulations that is supposed to prevent abuses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSLER, JOHN E.
description: MOSLER-John E., on July 7, 2002, at age 79. Loving father of Bruce E. Mosler and his wife Wendy, John E. Mosler, Jr. and his wife Jennifer, and Michele A. Mosler. Devoted grandfather of David and Charlotte Mosler. Devoted brother of Janet Coleman and the late Edwin H. Mosler, Jr. Interment private. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Thursday, July 11, at 6PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to Fordham University.

title: Demonstrators, Ignoring a Ban, Clash With Riot Police in Tehran
description: In a powerful expression of popular frustration with repressive government, protesters clashed with the police at two sites today, marking the third anniversary of a violent crackdown on student protests at Tehran University.

title: ANDRX GETS TENTATIVE F.D.A. APPROVAL FOR GENERIC DRUG
description: The Andrx Corporation said that the Food and Drug Administration had granted tentative approval for its generic version of the extended-release allergy medicine Claritin, made by Schering-Plough. Schering's patent on the drug does not expire until Dec. 19, and Andrx cannot get final regulatory approval until Dec. 20, the company said. Schering-Plough has sued Andrx, claiming patent infringement, and that case is pending. Andrx, which is based in Davie, Fla., said it was the first generic-drug maker to seek approval of the 24-hour extended-release tablet.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: S.& P. 500 Is Dropping Seven Foreign Companies

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the online database version of an article in the Job Market section on Sunday about the employment market for lawyers included two firms erroneously among those that have had layoffs. (The error did not appear in the printed version.) The firms -- Sullivan & Cromwell and Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton -- say they did not lay off lawyers in the spring.

title: Lore Noto, 79, Producer of 'The Fantasticks'
description: Lore Noto, the theatrical producer who nurtured a little show called ''The Fantasticks'' and turned it into the world's longest-running musical, died on Monday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 79 and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: An Inquiry Confirms a Massacre Of Jews by Poles in World War II
description: Polish historians have concluded that a massacre of Jews during World War II in the little town of Jedwabne was carried out by Poles, not by the occupying Nazis.

title: First Death Sentence Imposed Under '95 Law Is Overturned
description: New York's highest court ruled today that the state cannot execute the first man condemned to die under the revised 1995 death penalty statute. The judges said the law at the time of the conviction unfairly threatened the man with capital punishment merely for exercising his right to a trial.

title: Premodern Splendor In a Vision of India
description: Lincoln Center Festival 2002, devoted in principle to the old as well as the new, opened its three-week season on Monday night with an emblematic production, the Kirov Ballet's very recent reconstruction of ''La Bayadre,'' choreographed in 1877 by Marius Petipa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONSTANTINER, DR. JAIME
description: CONSTANTINER-Dr. Jaime. The American Friends of Tel Aviv University deeply mourn the passing, in Mexico, of Dr. Jaime Constantiner, Deputy Chairman of Tel Aviv University's Board of Governors. Dr. Constantiner's dedication to Israel and his support of Tel Aviv University will always be remembered. American Friends of Tel Aviv University extends sincere condolences to his family. Alan Aufzien, Chairman Sam Witkin, Exec V.P.

title: Our Towns; Standing Up To Mr. Softee (Don't Laugh)
description: WILBUR TROUTMAN, a civic watchdog, might never have been known outside his neighborhood in southwest Hartford except that he took on Mister Softee. And Mister Softee, he says, was wielding a bat.

title: Latinos Still Call It Ftbol
description: Jorge Ramirez shouted himself hoarse as his soccer team, the Los Angeles Galaxy, trounced the Dallas Burn, 3-0, in late June. He left the Rose Bowl arm in arm with two friends, delighted by the victory, even though his primary sports allegiances lie elsewhere.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Dismissals At ABB
description: The Swiss engineering firm ABB, whose troubles with pension overpayments fostered interest in corporate accountability, said it had dismissed a group of managers in its London operation for having tried unsuccessfully to conceal losses in 1999 and 2000. ABB, which is based in Zurich, said it had already disclosed the losses in regulatory filings, and did not need to change its annual reports. An internal investigation discovered that the faulty accounting would have overstated the company's income by $30 million in 1999, and $10 million in 2000, the company said. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Senators Ask Bush Nominee About Record And Ability
description: Facing polite but persistent questioning from senators about his professional record and management ability, the White House nominee for surgeon general described himself today as an ''agent of change'' who may have rattled the status quo but never disrespected his colleagues.

title: Prigorodnoye Journal; Gas May Soon Replace Kelp as Sakhalin's Mainstay
description: All that is left of Prigorodnoye is three families and the ruins of a kelp processing plant.

title: Suicide Bombings
description: To the Editor:

title: Scores of Pakistanis Are Deported by U.S.
description: The Justice Department last month quietly deported 131 Pakistani citizens who had been swept up in the post-Sept. 11 crackdown on foreigners in the country illegally, officials said tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORTON, JANE B.
description: MORTON-Jane B. On July 6, 2002 at age 91. Wife of the late Paul Stillman Morton. Loving mother of Kathleen Stillman Morton and the late Jane Goldman. Grandmother of Christopher Morton Aberger and Daniel Paul Goldman. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. on Friday, July 12, 5-9PM. Interment to take place Saturday, July 13 at Cypress Hills Cemetery, Brooklyn, New York at 1 PM.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Koreas: Verbal Skirmishing
description: North Korea demanded that South Korea provide a detailed outline of any plans for salvaging a South Korean patrol boat that was sunk in a skirmish in the Yellow Sea on June 29 in which 4 South Koreans were killed and 19 wounded. The South Korean Navy rejected the demand, saying the boat sank on its side of the line below which it bans Northern boats. The government denied that President Kim Dae Jung's policy of reconciliation with the North had led Northern commanders to believe that they could challenge the South without fear of strong countermeasures, and the Defense Ministry charged the North with ''a deliberate armed provocation'' in the attack. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Giuliani and Hanover Reach $6.8 Million Divorce Settlement
description: After a bitter and very public 18-month battle, the divorce of former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York and the television personality and actress Donna Hanover ended almost quietly today with an out-of-court settlement that will bring Ms. Hanover $6.8 million tax free.

title: Sports of The Times; N.F.L. Shows Trust Is Won By Verifying
description: IN the early days of the N.F.L.'s steroid testing, players found some creative ways to cheat. One was a system in which a pouch of urine -- usually from a teammate who did not use a performance-enhancing drug -- was taped to the upper back of the player under his shirt. A tube ran from the pouch, down the middle of the shoulder blades, and ended between the player's legs. A switch at the bottom of the tube activated the device and -- presto -- steroid-free urine ready for testing.

title: CALENDER
description: Bastille Day Fetes

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYLE, THERESE GERALDINE
description: BOYLE-Therese Geraldine. Gerry Boyle, 68, of La Quinta, CA died Saturday, July 6, 2002, after a long and courageous fight against cancer. Gerry had a warm, pleasant nature and was a friend to everyone she met. She will be remembered for her generous love and kindness, and her inspiration of those qualities in her family. Gerry is survived by her husband of 43 years, Jack Boyle, daughter and son-inlaw: Helen and Robert Bristow of Cary, NC, son John Boyle of Torrance, CA, daughter and son-in-law Betsy and Daniel Eigen of New York, NY and son and daughter-in-law Brian and Mary Boyle of New York, NY, six grandchildren Meghan Boyle, Kelly Bristow, Jacqueline Bristow, Matthew Eigen, Liza Eigen and Kevin Boyle, and three sisters Mary Genay of Cupertino, CA, Margaret Maley of Smithville, NJ and Betsy Weber of Overland Park, KS. There will be a viewing on Friday, July 12th from 7pm-9pm at Fitzpatrick's Funeral Home, 425 Lyceum Avenue, Philadelphia, PA 19128. Funeral mass will be celebrated at St. John the Baptist Church, Rector Street, Philadelphia, PA at 10am on Saturday, July 13th. In lieu of flowers, a donation to the American Cancer Society is suggested. The American Cancer Society can be contacted via www.cancer.org or 1-800-ACS-2345.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOCTOROFF, HON. MARTIN M.
description: DOCTOROFF-Hon. Martin M. Beloved father of Daniel L. Doctoroff, a past Trustee and father-in-law of Alisa R. Doctoroff, our current vice president, died Tuesday, July 9th, in Troy, MI. after a long illness. The funeral will take place on Thursday, July 11 at the Ira Kaufman Funeral Home, Southfield, MI. at 11 AM. Up until the onset of his illness Martin was a very active, engaged and vital member of his community and his family. He was an Appeals Court Judge in the State of Michigan and was planning to retire on September 1. Our deepest sympathies go to Dan and Alisa, whose leadership has been, is and will continue to be so important to our school. We further express our condolences to their children, Jacob, Ariel and Jenna, who are all students at The Heschel School. To the entire Doctoroff family, particularly Dan's brothers Mark, Andrew and Thomas, their wives and children we send our heartfelt sympathies. The A.J. Heschel School Shira Nadich Levin, President, Board of Trustees Roanna Shorofsky, Head of School

title: Hard Talk, Softer Plans
description: His words were harsh, but his proposals were generally not.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It was just as I recognize a friend in the street or my wife across the breakfast table.''

title: Accounts
description: * WD-40 Co., San Diego, expanded its relationship with Carrafiello Diehl & Associates, Irvington, N.Y., by naming the agency to handle advertising for Spot Shot carpet-stain remover, with spending estimated at $8.5 million. WD-40 acquired the Heartland Corp., makers of Spot Shot, in May. Carrafiello Diehl also handles advertising for WD-40 brands like 2000 Flushes and Carpet Fresh.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Coke Acquisition
description: The Coca-Cola Company expanded its reach into Europe by buying Valser, a well-known Swiss bottled water company. The Hess Group sold its 50 percent stake to Coca-Cola; no price was disclosed. Valser was founded in 1961, and sold 122.5 million liters of mineral water last year. Coca-Cola, based in Atlanta, is expected to retain Valser's 96 employees. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: McGwire's Golfing Plans Are No Surprise to Giambi
description: Jason Giambi, who received a congratulatory call from Mark McGwire after winning the Home Run Derby on Monday night, unwittingly culled some interesting information from McGwire. Giambi asked McGwire how he was remaining busy in his first season in retirement, and McGwire said he played golf every day and was contemplating an attempt at becoming a professional golfer.

title: Williams Returns, at Least in Spirit
description: The All-Star Game was always one of Ted Williams's favorite events, and he was honored tonight at the position he played, with his familiar No. 9 from his Hall of Fame career with the Boston Red Sox being painted in white, red and blue in left field at Miller Park.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Church Tells Of Abusive Priests
description: The Roman Catholic Church has disclosed that about 200 priests have been investigated for sexual offenses in the last two decades. Archbishop Orlando Quevedo, president of the Catholic Bishops Conference of the Philippines, said most of the priests either had been dismissed or had left the church voluntarily. He apologized for the ''grave sins committed by some leaders on members of the flock'' in the predominantly Catholic country and said the church would draft a protocol for dealing with priests' misconduct. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: TB and AIDS: Warning
description: To the Editor:

title: Cipollini to Race or Retire
description: Mario Cipollini, the 35-year-old Italian who is regarded as the world's leading cycling road sprinter, has created a confusing immediate future.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BOSNIA: WAR CRIMES SUSPECT SEIZED French and German troops arrested a Bosnian Serb charged with the rape and sexual enslavement of women during the 1992 war. The man, Radovan Stankovic, a former militia member, was found by the troops under NATO command in the rugged mountains near the town of Foca, a center of Bosnian Serb nationalists. A NATO spokesman said he would be sent immediately to the war crimes tribunal in The Hague. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Police Say Man Used Machete To Chop Off Neighbor's Hand
description: It was a routine summer night on 124th Street in Richmond Hill, Queens: hot but tranquil. The neighborhood children had finished a game of basketball in the street; some were already playing video games inside.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Joint Trading Venture
description: The Royal Bank of Scotland has formed a joint venture with The Toronto-Dominion Bank under which the Canadian bank's discount brokerage unit, TD Waterhouse, will execute stock trades for customers of the Royal Bank and its brokerage unit, NatWest Stockbrokers. Under the deal, Toronto-Dominion will own 50 percent of NatWest's holding company, NatWest Personal Financial Management Ltd. Other terms were not disclosed. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: HIGH COURT WON'T HEAR DETAINEE CASE

title: With a Huge Jazz Festival, Montreal Is Understated
description: It is hard to grasp the Montreal International Jazz Festival, which began on June 27 and ended Sunday. Twenty-three years old and one of the biggest and most respected festivals of its kind, it attracted some 1.65 million people to some 500 free and paid concerts over two weeks. But unlike the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival, it did not necessarily celebrate a regional culture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUEALLY, ALFRED E.
description: QUEALLY-Alfred E. Of Cold Spring Harbor on July 7, 2002. Retired Col., U.S.A.F. Beloved husband of Catherine, devoted father of Dr. Sharon Tooze, Michael, Anne Marie Bechand, Elizabeth Kearns, Mary Anne Gaza. Loving grandfather of eleven, dear brother of Francis X. and the late Justin and Kevin.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Television Acquisition
description: Tom.com Ltd., an Internet and media company run by the Asian tycoon, Li Ka-shing, left, agreed to buy a one-third stake in Asia Television Ltd., Hong Kong's No. 2 television station. Tom.com will pay about 290 million Hong Kong dollars ($37 million) in new shares for Lai Sun Development's 32.75 percent stake in Asia Television, Tom.com said. Mr. Li is stepping in after Asia Television scrapped a public share sale last year as media stocks plunged on fading Internet profit hopes.

title: Agency Leaders Express Confidence About Shift
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 — The directors of four federal agencies assured a Congressional panel today that they could move to the proposed Homeland Security Department without losing their traditional functions, but not all their questioners seemed convinced.

title: Augusta Answers Critics On Policy
description: Augusta National Golf Club, the site of the Masters every April, has been singled out by a national women's group that finds it unacceptable that the club has no female members.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOTO, LORE
description: NOTO-Lore. The League of Off-Broadway Theatres and Producers mourns the loss of Lore Noto, whose faith, vision and commitment helped to create ''The Fantasticks,'' an Off-Broadway masterpiece which has brought joy to audiences all over the world. We send our deepest sympathy to his wife, Mary, to children, Janice, Tony, Thad and Jody, and to his grandchildren. Board of Directors, League of Off-Broadway Theatres and Producers

title: Scandals Begin to Tarnish Wisconsin's Political Luster
description: For most of the 20th century, Wisconsin was a showcase of clean government, and most of its politicians were paragons of integrity.

title: It's Balls, Strikes, And Talk Of a Strike
description: Should the All-Star Game be a celebration of baseball or an inquest into the sport's dysfunction? Last night in Milwaukee, Fox chose the latter approach, treading lightly on the labor stalemate and never mentioning possible steroid abuse by players or Ted Williams's corpse in the deep freeze in Arizona.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASHOW, JUDITH MAGILL
description: GLASHOW-Judith Magill. Of Saddle River, NJ, and Boca Raton, FL. She was a graduate of Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, NY. She is survived by her husband Dr. Jules, daughter Jamie Pardell, sons Dr. Jonathan and Jeffrey, grandchildren Logan and Connor Pardell. Services are Thursday, 11 A.M. at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Route 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: A Talk on Corporate Integrity Heard in the Street and the Suite
description: Chief executives widely praised President Bush's speech yesterday, saying it would help restore confidence in American business. But many Wall Streeters and those who run large pension funds that own billions of dollars in stocks expressed disappointment Mr. Bush did not offer more specific proposals to clean up corporate wrongdoing.

title: THE CHEF
description: BOTTARGA is the pressed and salted roe of many kinds of fish. It's important in the Mediterranean culture. In Sicily they eat slices of it on ripe tomatoes.

title: For Flint, Mich., Takeover Adds to the List of Woes
description: Even in a city used to hard knocks, this has been a bruising year.

title: The State According to Scalia
description: To the Editor:

title: Slouching Towards Populism
description: It must be frustrating for the George Bushes.

title: Union Rejects Cuts at United; Aid Is at Risk
description: The largest union at United Airlines has rejected the company's proposed 10 percent wage cut, a move that could jeopardize an application the carrier has filed for a federal loan guarantee and an agreement on concessions that the airline worked out last month with its pilots.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUERETTE, DONALD R.
description: GUERETTE-Donald R., 66. Died July 5 while scuba-diving in Belize, doing what he loved best, enjoying life with his family. He is survived by his loving wife Roberta, his sons Nathan and Marc, his daughter-in-law Katherine, his sister Lee Gidge, his nephews, grandnephew and niece, his sister-in-law and brothers-in-law, many cousins and countless friends. He will also be missed by his dog Max and 3 granddogs. Born in Nashua, NH he was a recently retired Vice President at Time Warner. Don had a laugh that was not only infectious, but thundering and overwhelming. His generosity was more than legendary among his friends and peers and his benevolence was known well beyond his circle. Integrity was not an accessory he wore on convenient occasions, it was an integral part of his constitution. The power of his word more reliable than ink on any contract often shocked and delighted his colleagues. Funeral Mass will be held at Saint Gregory the Great, 144 West 90th Street, Friday July 12, at 11 AM. Memorial reception to follow immediately at Union Theological Seminary, 3041 Broadway at 120th Street. Contributions can be sent to Doctors Without Borders, PO Box 1856, Merrifield, VA, 22116 or National Alliance For The Mentally Ill, PO Box 79972, Baltimore, Maryland 21279-0792.

title: From Justice Dept. to Fordham Dean
description: Fordham University this week named WILLIAM M. TREANOR, a deputy United States assistant attorney general from 1998 until 2001, as dean of its law school beginning Aug. 1. He succeeds JOHN D. FEERICK, who was dean for 20 years. A constitutional law scholar who has focused on limits the Bill of Rights places on government regulation of property, Mr. Treanor, 44, joined Fordham's law faculty in 1991. Before that, he was an associate counsel in the office of the Iran-Contra independent counsel in Washington. Late in the Clinton administration, he was in the office of legal counsel at the Justice Department, where he worked on the issue of whether the double jeopardy clause protected President Clinton from criminal prosecution after he was acquitted by the Senate. (The office said no.) Mr. Treanor earned a bachelor's degree and a law degree from Yale -- he was an articles and book review editor at The Yale Law Journal -- and also has a master's degree in history from Harvard. Karen W. Arenson

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Yonkers: Board Recommends Judge's Ouster
description: A state ethics commission has recommended that a Yonkers judge, Edmund G. Fitzgerald Jr., be removed from office. Mr. Fitzgerald was disbarred as a lawyer in December 2000 by the Appellate Division, Second Department, for financial improprieties. The July 1 recommendation by the New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct was released yesterday. Hal Lieberman, a lawyer for Mr. Fitzgerald, said he planned to appeal the recommendation. In 1990, Mr. Fitzgerald used $4,060 from an escrow account to pay for his son's college tuition, according to court papers. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Another Attempt to Legislate Corporate Honesty
description: How should we respond to the wave of scandals that have hit corporate America? Everyone in Washington seems to agree on the answer: more law. In particular, more criminal law.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; S.& P. 500 drops 7 foreigners, maybe aiding market over all.
description: THE Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is going all-American, and in the process it is producing a little bit of buying power for the struggling stock market.

title: Suspect Is Set Free By Posing as Another
description: A man charged with two drug felonies was mistakenly released from Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday after he pretended to be a prisoner who had been charged with panhandling, the police said.

title: Jack Daniel's takes the edge off with a flavored malt beverage to appeal to prime beer consumers.
description: JACK DANIEL'S ORIGINAL HARD COLA may be named for a famous Tennessee distillery, but it is not liquor. And though the new beverage contains the same kind of caramel coloring as Coke and Pepsi, it is not soda pop, either.

title: 8 Brownstones Evacuated
description: Eight brownstones in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, were evacuated last night after elevated levels of carbon monoxide were discovered on President Street, the authorities said.

title: The Grandfather of Video Art, Still a Bit Naughty
description: THE Korean-born video artist Nam June Paik never spoke English very well. It was fragmentary, with a heavy accent, and the stroke Mr. Paik suffered six years ago has made him even more difficult to understand. His left side is immobile; he requires a wheelchair and a nurse. Still, Mr. Paik insists, there has been an upside.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Kremlin Critic Throws In The Towel
description: In a move that signaled his surrender to the government, the media mogul Vladimir A. Gusinsky sold his remaining Russian media holdings. Gazprom, the state-controlled gas monopoly that took over Mr. Gusinsky's NTV television station in a boardroom coup last year, announced it had acquired all shares in Mr. Gusinsky's media assets, which include NTV, a radio station, and print media. Mr. Gusinsky, an outspoken critic of the Kremlin, fought hard against last year's takeover, which he said was perpetrated by the Kremlin. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Parents Of Truants Face Jail
description: Parents of children who miss more than 20 days of school in a year can be fined $630 and jailed for one month under a new law intended to prevent excessive truancy. The penalties will be used only as a last resort after consultation between parents and a new national Education Welfare Board, according to a spokesman from the Department of Education. The legislation, which replaces a 1926 law that made police officers responsible for enforcing school attendance, requires principals to inform the board if students are absent for 20 days. Nineteen percent of Irish students drop out before finishing high school. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOR, BELLE
description: SHOR-Belle. Beloved wife of the late Jeff. Devoted mother of Radie Nedlin, Aaron Shor, and the late Gail Berke and mother-in-law of Leonard and Emily. Also survived by five grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Loving sister of Helen Markowitz. Services on Wednesday, at 10:00 AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Stocks Drop Sharply Again, Hitting Lowest Point Since '97
description: The worst bear market in a generation deepened today as stocks fell sharply for their third straight session, leaving several of the leading market indexes at their lowest levels since 1997.

title: Search for New Chancellor Loses a Leading Candidate
description: Paul G. Vallas, the former schools chief in Chicago and one of the most visible candidates for New York City schools chancellor, instead took a job yesterday as head of the Philadelphia schools.

title: Role in Group Enhances Mbeki's Image
description: With cameras rolling, flags waving and fighter jets streaking through the sky, thousands of people here today celebrated the birth of the African Union, a new regional group that hopes to rejuvenate this impoverished continent.

title: MetroStars' Mathis Out for up to 5 Weeks
description: Clint Mathis's dream of soon playing for a top European club was badly compromised yesterday when an M.R.I. of his right knee found a torn meniscus and a sprain of the medial collateral ligament, which will keep him out of the MetroStars' lineup for three to five weeks.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, PAUL, MD.
description: GOLDBERG-Paul, MD. The Division of Urology at Maimonides Medical Center, notes with sadness the passing of an esteemed and revered colleague. Our condolences to his family. Gilbert J. Wise, MD, Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, MADLYN S. (NEE SHUB).
description: KAPLAN-Madlyn S. (nee Shub). Adored wife of Lawrence. Beloved mother of Bill (future mother-in-law of Susan Collum) and Rachel. Devoted grandmother of Patricia Lynn Kaplan. Loved and admired by all who knew her. The world is diminished by her passing. Services 2:15 PM at I.J. Morris, Inc., 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, NY. In lieu of flowers direct contributions to the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, or Canine Health FoundationAkita Directed Fund.

title: Merck Again Puts Off Stock Offering for Medco
description: Merck postponed an initial public offering for its Medco managed care unit for the third time yesterday as investors recoiled from falling share prices for drug makers and drug-related businesses.

title: Bowie Killed Ziggy in '73, But Here's A Premiere
description: The apotheosis of glam rock in the early 1970's, David Bowie's 1972-73 Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders From Mars tour has been memorialized in several independent films, notably Todd Haynes's 1998 ''Velvet Goldmine'' and John Cameron Mitchell's 2001 ''Hedwig and the Angry Inch.'' With boldly stated gender-bending, Mr. Bowie sang in character as Ziggy wearing heavy eye shadow, teased orange hair and costumes that accentuated his slender build and spectacular gams. All this apparently had a profound influence on today's generation of un-self-conscious and unapologetic gay filmmakers and performers.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia: War Crimes Suspect Seized
description: French and German troops arrested a Bosnian Serb charged with the rape and sexual enslavement of women during the 1992 war. The man, Radovan Stankovic, a former militia member, was found by the troops under NATO command in the rugged mountains near the town of Foca, a center of Bosnian Serb nationalists. A NATO spokesman said he would be sent immediately to the war crimes tribunal in The Hague. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Israelis Shut the Jerusalem Office of a Moderate Palestinian
description: Israel today shut down the office here of Sari Nusseibeh, the leading voice of moderation among Palestinians, accusing him of undermining Israeli sovereignty in Jerusalem by serving as an agent of Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority.

title: Enduringly Yankee, With a Modern Twist
description: NOT so long ago, lobsters and baked beans pretty well defined the parameters of Maine gastronomy -- at least for ''folk from away,'' as outsiders are called in the local lingo. The old reliables are still there: a traveler heading north along the coast from Kittery soon starts seeing signs advertising lobster pounds, and the B & M baked bean plant, a sentinel of Down East tradition, stands along Interstate 295 near downtown Portland.

title: Hormone Replacement Study A Shock to the Medical System
description: The announcement yesterday that a hormone replacement regimen taken by six million American women did more harm than good was met with puzzlement and disbelief by women and their doctors across the country.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Woman Charged With Setting Fires
description: A 50-year-old grocery store clerk has been arrested on charges that she started small fires in her subdivision outside Durango, where the 70,000-acre Missionary Ridge blaze has destroyed 56 homes. The largest of the fires was about two acres. They have all been set since June 9, the day the Missionary Ridge fire was started; its cause is being investigated. Investigators said they did not know why the fires were set by the woman, Annie Francis Johnson. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: How the Writer (Kipling) Got His (Literary) Stripes
description: THE LONG RECESSIONAL

title: The State According to Scalia
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Elizabeth: 2 Inmates Die Within 12 Hours
description: An investigation has begun over the hanging deaths of two inmates at the Union County jail last week. The hangings were within 12 hours of each other. The first inmate, Jacek Lazarski, 21, of Elizabeth, was found hanging by a bedsheet at noon on July 2, said the jail director, Frank Crose. Mr. Lazarski had been held since Monday on charges of driving with a revoked license. At 12:15 a.m. on July 3, the second inmate, Gregory Knable, 29, of Sayreville, was found hanging, also by a bedsheet, Mr. Crose said. Mr. Knable was being held on a drug possession charge. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Waterbury: Amusement Park Sued
description: The family of a maintenance worker killed by a roller coaster at Lake Compounce Theme Park in Bristol has sued the park, accusing it of inadequately training personnel in operating the roller coaster. The worker, Wilfredo Martinez, was struck last year by the roller coaster, the Boulder Dash, while cutting weeds underneath it. The suit, filed Friday in Superior Court in Waterbury on behalf of Mr. Martinez's estate, claims managers should have trained mechanics not to conduct tests while workers were under the tracks. Tom Wages, a park manager, said the suit was without merit. Mr. Martinez's death was the third at the park in three years. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: The Favorite Gets the Rail In a Rich Pace
description: Monte Gelrod, the fifth-leading trainer ever at the Meadowlands with $12 million in purses earned, has four horses in the field of 10 in Saturday's Meadowlands Pace. At the post position draw today, he said that he had no favorite, but everyone else involved is pointing toward Mach Three.

title: SUNGARD TO BUY BRUT TRADING SYSTEM FOR $100 MILLION
description: SunGard Data Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the electronic trading system Brut for $100 million to extend its reach into Nasdaq stock market trading. SunGard, which provides Wall Street firms and money managers with equity, bond and currency-processing technology, is acquiring the 78.5 percent of Brut it does not already own from 25 broker-dealers, including Merrill Lynch & Company, Morgan Stanley, and others that control it. SunGard already trades commercial paper and foreign currencies and created the technology Brut uses to match buy and sell orders.

title: FORD OPENS AN AUTOMOBILE ASSEMBLY PLANT IN RUSSIA
description: In another sign of increasing foreign investment in Russia, the Ford Motor Company announced the official opening of its assembly plant outside St. Petersburg. The factory will produce 25,000 Ford Focus cars a year for Russian consumers. The $150 million factory is the first car manufacturing plant in Russia that is fully owned by a foreign producer. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about variations in the sentences of minor offenders who perform community service in New York City quoted incompletely from a judge's description of the lawyers who can propose such an assignment. Although Judge Judy Harris Kluger of Manhattan Criminal Court said that privately hired lawyers could propose a sentence with a charity or a nonprofit group, she also said that court-appointed lawyers could do so.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Telefnica Loss
description: Telefnica said it lost 7.18 billion euros ($7.11 billion) in 2001 using United States accounting rules, compared with the profit it reported under Spanish rules, setting off a sharp decline in its share price. Stock in Telefnica, the biggest telecommunications company in the Spanish-speaking world, fell 0.29 euro, to 8.73 euros. The discrepancy reflects differences in the two countries' accounting regulations for good will, or the difference between the purchase price of an asset and its book value.

title: Suit Over Tax Havens
description: The government accused two accounting firms, KPMG and BDO Seidman, of helping clients avoid paying billions in taxes.

title: Baba, With Love From Naples
description: IT wasn't that I was surprised to see babas in a pastry shop in the village of Minori on the Amalfi coast of Italy. Ever since I stepped off the plane in Naples, babas, small briochelike cakes swimming in a syrup, were omnipresent: on menus at every little cafe, packed in jars lining the shelves of touristy shops along the beaches, even mixed into gelato in ice cream shops. Babas were as ubiquitous in Campanian pastry shops as molten chocolate cakes in New York City restaurants.

title: Federal Audit Faults Department's Meat and Poultry Inspection System
description: A draft report from government auditors finds that a new meat and poultry inspection program run by the Department of Agriculture is poorly designed, badly supervised and riddled with problems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFFER, LILO
description: SCHAEFFER-Lilo. On Monday, July 8, 2002, Lilo Schaeffer of Bethesda, MD formerly of Linden NJ. Beloved wife of the late Hans Schaeffer. Devoted mother of Barbara Schaeffer Dagger, Woodstock, VT, Monica Schaeffer Gorochow, Potomac, MD, and Edward Schaeffer, Wellesley, MA. Loving grandmother of Erica, Jackie, Ali, Olivia, Jodie, Lacey and Alex. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, July 10 at 10:30 A.M. at Temple Beth Ami, 14330 Travillah Road, Rockville, MD. Interment Judean Memorial Gardens. The family will be receiving friends at Monica and Mitch Gorochow's residence through Saturday evening, July 13. Memorial contributions may be made to The American Diabetes Association, Temple Beth Ami, or Woodstock Area Jewish Community, Post Office Box 526, Woodstock VT 05091. For information, contact Edward Sagel Funeral Direction, Inc., Rockville MD, 301-217-9400.

title: Police Shoot a Man Who Fired at Them
description: Police officers in Irvington, N.J., shot a man who fired at them yesterday during a robbery investigation, the police said.

title: Bush's Dance: Moral Outrage Without Pain To Loyalists
description: On Wall Street today President Bush carefully positioned himself, politically and economically, as a leader willing to come down hard on unscrupulous capitalists without alienating the business constituency that remains his party's financial and ideological base.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, RUTH
description: KRAMER-Ruth. Beloved mother of Paul, Bren, Michael, Mark, grandmother of David, Jeffrey, Nina, Brian, Elliot, Aurora, Arielle, Melinda, great grandmother of Kelsey, Lindsay, Michaela, mother-in-law of Jennifer, Helen, Steve, grandmotherin-law of Duncan and Sophia and wife of the late Harry Kramer, died on July 8, 2002 after a long illness. She was revered, adored & respected by her family, to whom she gave unconditional love all her years. She never lost her spark or spunk and was involved in all our lives in the most caring way. We will miss her always. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to the new York Times Neediest Cases Fund, 212-556-5851, ext. 7.

title: A History of the Mideast In the Humble Chickpea
description: THE last time you bit into a falafel sandwich you were probably thinking about nothing more than the warm spice and crunch of the chickpea fritters and the way they played against the soft bread, crisp vegetables and nutty tahini sauce.

title: Selig Wants To Avoid A Stoppage
description: The online question came from Troy of Tasmania, Australia, who began it in a friendly, colloquial manner. ''G'day from Down Under,'' Troy of Tasmania wrote. The person who read the greeting out loud promptly interrupted himself.

title: At Fancy Food Show, All the World's A Pantry
description: Can a palate that has sampled 1,000 mustards, oils, salsas and biscotti get excited by yet another condiment or cracker? At this year's Fancy Food Show in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, which ended its three-day run yesterday, there were more than a few new temptations among the 60,000 products displayed by 2,300 exhibitors from 50 countries. And many of them are already in shops in New York and elsewhere.

title: Top Forecaster Cuts Estimate for Growth in 2002 Ad
description: The executive considered the dean of advertising forecasters is cutting his estimate for ad spending in 2002.

title: Ford Consolidates Land Rover Account
description: The Ford Motor Company is expanding its relationship with Young & Rubicam Advertising by shifting the North American account for Land Rover vehicles to the Irvine, Calif., office of Y.& R. from GSD&M in Austin, Tex. Spending was estimated at $50 million.

title: Expert Spots a 'Michelangelo' in an Old Box
description: In the ultimate case of finding treasure in the attic, a visiting museum director from Scotland on a busman's holiday in New York sifted through old boxes of drawings of light fixtures at the Cooper-Hewitt design museum and has discovered what several experts agree is a work by Michelangelo.

title: Those Feeling the Pain Now Await a Remedy
description: As the president wrapped up his speech on corporate responsibility in a Wall Street ballroom yesterday, Arthur Urrows stared into a small television screen at a discount brokerage office near Rockefeller Center and slumped in his seat.

title: A New Act To Follow 'Nightline'
description: ''I'll be leaving halfway through tonight's show to go watch myself on Ted Koppel,'' David Letterman said at the start of his ''Late Show'' on Monday. A half-hour later, competing with himself, a completely different Letterman turned up for a one-on-one interview on a temporary ''Nightline'' spinoff, a series of profiles called ''Up Close.'' He joked that he was unfathomably put up on a split screen with Yasir Arafat, but he was really on a split screen with himself, the two Daves side by side.

title: STAPLES TO BUY MEDICAL ARTS FOR $385 MILLION
description: Staples Inc., the office-supplies retailer, agreed to buy a direct marketer, Medical Arts Press Inc., for $385 million to add products for health care customers. Medical Arts, a unit of a closely held equity investment firm, Freeman Spogli & Company, sells items like medical file folders, Staples said. Medical Arts, which had 670 employees and $168 million in revenue in 2001, will begin contributing to Staples' profit this year and may add 1 cent to 2 cents next year. The purchase, expected to close early in the third quarter, will become part of Staples' Quill unit, which sells office products to professionals and small businesses through catalogs and the Internet. Staples is based in Framingham, Mass., and Medical Arts is based in Minneapolis.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Public Access To Beaches
description: David Geffen, a founder of Dreamworks, and the City of Malibu are squaring off against environmentalists and state officials over a plan to open public access to beaches. In a civil lawsuit filed last week in California Superior Court, Mr. Geffen, whose Malibu property is adjacent to a closed easement, and the city seek to block the move citing concerns over public safety and the impact on homeowners. A spokeswoman with the state Coastal Commission, which was named in the lawsuit, said it appeared to be just another effort to undermine the public's right to use beaches. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: HEARING ON IMCLONE INSIDER TRADING CHARGES IS DELAYED
description: A court hearing that was to be held by Friday to consider charges against Samuel D. Waksal, the former chief executive of ImClone Systems, has been postponed, people close to the situation said yesterday. The delay could give Dr. Waksal, who was arrested last month on insider trading charges, more time to negotiate a deal with prosecutors. But postponement of such hearings is the rule rather than the exception, these people said, so the delay might have no significance other than that the government was not ready. The sides have had preliminary discussions about a deal in which Dr. Waksal would plead guilty to save family members from criminal prosecution, people close to the case have said. But the sides are described as far apart. The delay is for two weeks, one person said. Andrew Pollack (NYT)

title: Gifted High School Player Is Given Pause
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 9  The Blair Academy senior-to-be Charlie Villanueva is listed at 6 feet 10 inches, has great ball-handling skills for a player his size and has a perimeter game most shooting guards would envy. So why, in this age of prep stars declaring themselves eligible for the N.B.A. draft, is Villanueva not seriously considering jumping straight to the pros?

title: Puttin' On The Ice Cream At the Ritz
description: Do you need advice about which ice cream goes best with hot fudge or wet nuts? A new service at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Philadelphia is for you. Luis Caicedo, left, is on hand in the handsome rotunda on Tuesday afternoons to dispense scoops and sundaes ($6 for two scoops, $8 for three), with suggestions for the indecisive. He serves Ciao Bella, Bassett's, Jeremy's, Hagen-Dazs and Jack and Jill, as well as special white-wine-flavored and red-wine-flavored ice creams made by the hotel's pastry chef, Sebastien Thieffine. As an ice cream sommelier, Mr. Caicedo will steer you away from strawberry sorbet with the wet nuts, but believes that just about anything goes on vanilla.

title: Ex-Oil Executive to Head Business School
description: Fairleigh Dickinson University has named DAVID M. STEELE, a longtime Chevron executive who has worked in 25 countries, as dean of its Silberman College of Business. Dr. Steele, 60, was a vice president of finance for Chevron U.S.A. Production Company and later president of Chevron Latin America. He was also interim chief executive of Online Resolution Inc., a software company. He has a bachelor's degree and a Ph.D. in chemical engineering. Karen W. Arenson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DITON, BECKER, IVY SUE
description: DITON-BECKER-Ivy Sue, on July 8, 2002, at the age of 41. Ivy was the principal of W.T. Clarke Middle School, East Meadow, NY, founder of the NY Metropolitan Service Learning Institute, founding Board member of the National Service Learning Partnership, lead panelist for the Presidential Initiative on Education, advisor and staff developer for the National Helpers Network Inc. and chairperson of the East Meadow School District Alternative Committee on Education. Beloved wife of Paul Becker. Loving daughter of Roy and Helen Diton. Dear sister of Jeff Diton and sister-in-law of Liz Diton. Cherished aunt of Rob and Matt Diton. Reposing at Park Funeral Chapels, 2175 Jericho Tpk., Garden City Park, NY, Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Services will be offered Thursday, 8pm. There will be a private committal service Friday at Fresh Pond Crematory. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the W.T. Clarke Middle School, East Meadow S.D., 740 Edgewood Dr., Westbury NY 11590.

title: U.S. Accuses 2 Audit Firms Of Assisting Tax Violations
description: The government yesterday accused two accounting firms, KPMG and BDO Seidman, of flouting the tax laws by helping hundreds of people and companies escape billions of dollars in taxes through improper transactions that the firms designed to be hidden from tax auditors.

title: Ross Take Their Place in the Sun
description: ROS is like an embarrassing relative -- the feckless brother-in-law who is always broke or the cousin who gets drunk at parties. No one's ever quite sure what to do about him. If you believe that wine's principal role is to enhance food, which it is, ros won't seem to have any serious work to do. It might not go with the fish, and you're certainly not going to serve it with the roast.

title: Ward Kimball, Disney Animator, Dies at 88
description: Ward Kimball, a Disney animator who created Jiminy Cricket, updated Mickey Mouse and brought the crows to life in a famous scene in ''Dumbo,'' died on Monday in Arcadia, Calif. He was 88 and lived in San Gabriel, Calif.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Excelon Announces Additional Job Cuts
description: The Excelon Corporation, a maker of data-management software that cut 25 percent of its staff in January, said yesterday that it would eliminate another 30 percent of its jobs as second-quarter results fell short of expectations. The company had a net loss of 10 to 11 cents a share in the last quarter, it said in a preliminary earnings release distributed by Business Wire. Excluding certain expenses, it would have lost 7 to 8 cents. On that basis, the company had expected to report a loss of 2 to 5 cents a share. The company, based in Burlington, Mass., said second-quarter revenue was $9.5 million to $9.8 million, missing its previous estimate of $11 million to $13 million. Company officials could not be reached to comment. Shares of Excelon fell 10 cents, to 63 cents. The news was released after the close of regular trading.

title: A Real City's Court Dramas, Without Stars
description: The influential television cop shows of the 1990's, with their jittery, handheld camera work and fragmented story lines, were made to look like the cinma verit documentaries of the 80's, whose style was made possible by the development of extremely light, portable video equipment.

title: INSIDE
description: AIDS Protests in Spain

title: Where the Rio Grande Flows to the Brooklyn Waterfront
description: FROM Alma, Lower Manhattan appears like a stage backdrop. It is there for your pleasure, to take in during lulls in the meal, nothing more, it seems, than a facade. This is because it is difficult to grasp how such a good restaurant could be in such an odd place, amid a strip that includes a shipyard, car lots and a live poultry market on the edge of Carroll Gardens in Brooklyn.

title: Zabel Grabs The Overall Lead in Tour
description: Happy belated birthday, Erik Zabel.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Good Intentions

title: After the Cigars, a Simple Steakhouse
description: WHEN Patroon opened in Midtown in 1996, it revived a style of luxurious clubbiness that had come to seem threadbare and outmoded. With uniformed doormen, a richly appointed dining room and a menu that was among the most expensive in town, not to forget a sedate cigar bar upstairs and a list of bejeweled old Cognacs, Patroon charmed expense-account diners, who indulged themselves in the straightforward yet exquisite American cuisine.

title: Preparing to Take On His Church
description: His church has judged that the Rev. David H. Benke offended God, the Bible and all Christians. It says he ''dragged'' his faith, a conservative form of Lutheranism, to the level of Islam, committed heresy and violated two of the Ten Commandments.

title: Britain to Relax Marijuana Laws
description: LONDON, July 10  Britain said today that it would relax its laws on marijuana smoking, keeping the use of the drug theoretically illegal but no longer arresting people using it in discreet amounts in private.

title: U.S. Aid Foe Is in Runoff For President Of Bolivia
description: Evo Morales, an upstart Bolivian politician and indigenous leader who vows to end Washington-backed efforts to eradicate drug crops, will contend for the presidency after finishing second in the country's closest national election, electoral officials said.

title: Director Takes Flight With St. Francis's Birds
description: To judge from the plethora of reviews, Daniel Libeskind's production of Messiaen's ''St. Franois d'Assise,'' seen Tuesday night, was the event of the late 2001-2 opera season in Germany. Especially in Berlin, where it served to reinforce the position, in the ever soap-operatic crises of the city's cultural financing, of the Deutsche Oper in former West Berlin against the competing claims of the Staatsoper and Komische Oper in former East Berlin.

title: Giants Look to Add Depth to Roster
description: The Giants, set to open training camp in two weeks, continue to look for ways to bolster their roster.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Deporting Death Camp Guard
description: An 81-year-old retired aircraft worker is being deported to his native Romania after a judge found that he served as a guard at a concentration camp and a deportation point in the Holocaust. The man, Michael Negele of St. Peters, joins 56 others who have been deported, and 68 people stripped of their citizenship, through the Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations. Court records show that Mr. Negele, who became a citizen in 1955, was a guard at Sachsenhausen and Theresienstadt. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Transcript of President's Address Calling for New Era of Corporate Integrity
description: Following is a transcript of an address yesterday morning by President Bush in Manhattan on his proposals to better enforce ethical business practices, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Robertson Stephens Will Dismiss Half Its Staff to Prepare for Sale
description: Robertson Stephens, the investment-banking arm of the FleetBoston Financial Corporation, said today that it planned to lay off half of its staff to reduce costs and allow a sale to employees.

title: The State According to Scalia
description: To the Editor:

title: Counting Costs, It's the Worst In Hong Kong
description: Hong Kong has taken over from Tokyo as the world's most expensive city, London is the costliest capital in the European Union, and New York has the highest prices of any city in North America, according to an annual survey.

title: Amateur Hour in Zurich
description: Investigators looking into last week's midair collision over southern Germany have discovered evidence of a particularly disturbing kind of human error. It appears that mistaken instructions from a Swiss air traffic controller probably caused the disaster, which killed 52 children and 19 adults. The collision occurred when Zurich's air traffic control center was understaffed and plagued by technological breakdowns. Without the tower's wrong guidance, the Russian passenger plane's crash-avoidance system would probably have led its pilot to maneuver above the oncoming DHL cargo jet.

title: French Market Regulator Investigating Vivendi Financial Data
description: The French securities regulator said today that it had opened an investigation into financial information released by Vivendi Universal, potentially delivering a setback to the company as it scrambles to reach a rescue package with its banks.

title: Hundreds of 9/11 Families File for Right to Sue Port Authority
description: More than 450 families who lost relatives on Sept. 11 have filed legal papers preserving their right to sue the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey over alleged safety lapses and poor evacuation procedures at the World Trade Center.

title: Sept. 11 Tape Still Unheard By Fire Dept.
description: Ten months after the Sept. 11 attacks that left 343 firefighters dead, and five months after fire officials undertook a study of just what happened, the Fire Department has yet to review a potentially critical trove of information: a tape of radio transmissions among firefighters at the World Trade Center that morning.

title: The Manifestations of Valentine's Stress
description: Managers do not enjoy the physical outlets that players do to release their stress, so their moments of tension are alleviated in subtler ways. Bobby Valentine can be demonstrative, but after particularly tough losses he becomes as jittery as a 5-year-old.

title: AIDS Leaving Grim Legacy of Orphans, Report Says
description: BARCELONA, Spain, July 10  By 2010, 6 percent of all children in Africa will have lost at least one parent to the AIDS virus, United Nations and United States government officials said in a grim report issued at the 14th International AIDS Conference here today.

title: Philippines Arrests Suspect in Bombing
description: ZAMBOANGA, the Philippines, July 9  A man who reportedly supplied more than a ton of explosives intended to bomb the American Embassy and other buildings in Singapore last year has been arrested, Philippine authorities said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, an obituary on June 27 about Dr. Albert J. Solnit, psychiatrist and author, referred incompletely to his affiliation with Yale. Besides being a Sterling professor and Sterling professor emeritus, he was director of its Child Study Center from 1966 to 1983. The obituary also referred incompletely to his medical specialization. In addition to being a psychiatrist, he was a psychoanalyst.

title: 2 Top Officers Quit Elan, Troubled Irish Drug Maker
description: The two top executives of the Elan Corporation, the Irish drug maker, resigned today after six tumultuous months of questions about its accounting practices and a collapse of the company's stock price.

title: Schwarz Jury Asks a Question but Reaches No Verdict on First Day
description: The jury in the retrial of former police officer Charles Schwarz adjourned after its first day of deliberations yesterday without a verdict.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Retek Shares Plunge After Forecast Revision
description: Shares in Retek, a Minneapolis-based maker of retailing software, plunged yesterday after the company said that its quarterly revenue would not meet previous forecasts. For its third quarter the company said it now expected per-share operating earnings of 2 to 4 cents, software licensing revenue of $36 million to $38 million and total revenue of $52 million to $54 million. Wall Street analysts were expecting total revenue of $59.6 million. Steve Ladwig, chief executive of Retek, said in a statement, ''We are disappointed with the volume of new business signed in the second quarter, although we expect that most of the business that was pushed out of the second quarter will be closed later this year.'' In the wake of the announcement, SWS Securities, SunTrust, USB Piper Jaffray and CSFB downgraded the company's stock. Shares in Retek dropped $10.85, or 62.6 percent, to close at $6.46. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: 10 Arrested in Federal Investigation of Internet Child Pornography
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan and Brooklyn announced the arrests yesterday of 10 people in a continuing investigation of a child-pornography ring on the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERBER, RUSSELL
description: FERBER-Russell. Condolences to the Jordon-Ferber family on the untimely loss of their beloved son and brother Russell. The Village Temple of NYC Chava E. Koster, Rabbi S. Jones and L. Loren, Co-Presidents

title: Defying Hardships, British Minister Is in Spotlight
description: In five years in office, the Labor government has been a two-man show, with Gordon Brown, the strong-willed treasurer, exercising power independently of Prime Minister Tony Blair and positioning himself as Mr. Blair's sure successor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, EARLE
description: BROWN-Earle, July 2, 2002. A leading American composer of the New York School. Dear husband of Susan Sollins-Brown, survived also by his sister Marilyn Krysil, a niece Tanya Morrissey, nephews Steven Krysil, Stephen Sollins & Andrew Farnsworth, and four grand-nephews. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Earle Brown Music Foundation, 718 Broadway, Suite 2A, N.Y., N.Y. 10003. A memorial concert will be announced.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: McDonald's Cuts Prices
description: Eager to regain market share, the McDonald's Holdings Company, which runs Japan's largest chain of hamburger restaurants, will cut prices on its hallmark products. Starting Aug. 5, a McDonald's hamburger will cost 59 yen (50 cents), down 26 percent from its weekday price of 80 yen now. The price of a cheeseburger will fall by one-third, to 79 yen. McDonald's has been trying to win back customers after a scare over mad cow disease in beef stunted sales. Profits fell 42 percent last year as sales grew just 1.1 percent.

title: Complex Near J.F.K. to Get Building 3
description: With a November completion planned for the first of its two buildings, construction -- accompanied by the intermittent roar of jets taking off from Kennedy International Airport just across Rockaway Boulevard -- is set to begin next week on the third of what will be a four-building cargo and office complex.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Citrix Shares Fall To 5-Year Low
description: Shares of the software maker Citrix Systems Inc. fell to a five-year low after the company said its profits for the year would not meet expectations because of weakening demand for its products. Shares dropped 92 cents, or nearly 16 percent, to $5, after falling as low as $4.70 during the day. The company's stock has declined 84 percent in the last year after reaching $122 in March 2000. Citrix makes network products that enable desktop computers to operate from software installed on a central server. The company has said its distributors are changing orders because they have surplus Citrix software. Per-share earnings, excluding some expenses, will be 40 to 45 cents a share this year, the company said; industry analysts had estimated about 58 cents a share. Citrix, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., had said it planned to cut its work force about 10 percent to reduce costs. The company has about 1,900 employees.

title: Art Against the Odds: Creativity as Salve for Trauma
description: In these times of tell-all talk shows and gossip-magazine confessionals, in which politicians, princesses and folks next door routinely go public with stories of traumatic life-changing experiences, audiences may sometimes tire of all the woe.

title: Secretive Group Re-emerges With Advertising Hostile to Bush
description: A small, secretive group that used television advertisements to attack George W. Bush during his campaign for president has re-emerged to point to links between oil companies with questionable accounting practices and the Bush administration.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: ALBANY: DAVID BERKOWITZ DENIED PAROLE

description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Panel Votes to Require Insurers to Pay for Colonoscopies
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  A Senate committee voted today to require all private health insurance plans in the United States to pay for screening tests to detect colon cancer in people who have no symptoms of the disease.

title: Three Generations on 56th St., And It's Still Frank's Place
description: TONY BENNETT and Skitch Henderson sat at a table upstairs. Joe Franklin stood downstairs, helping himself to hors d'oeuvres. At the front door, Jerry Stiller and Anne Meara smiled for the cameras, while a few wiseguys inside -- no names, please -- hugged the walls. One woman surveyed the crowd with her husband, chagrined. ''Where's Cindy Adams?'' she whined. ''I thought you said she'd be here.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Hot Enough? Try Summer School, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: McGreevey to Nominate Political Supporter for New Jersey's Supreme Court
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey will nominate a longtime friend and political supporter, Barry T. Albin, to fill a pending vacancy on the State Supreme Court on Wednesday, people familiar with the appointment said.

title: For Giambi, Like Williams, the Pitch Is the Thing
description: Jason Giambi was probably the last member of the Yankees' organization to see Ted Williams. On his last stop before reporting to Yankees' camp in Tampa, Fla., this February, Giambi visited the Ted Williams Hitters Hall of Fame in Hernando, Fla. Giambi received an award and spent time with Williams at his home.

title: Finance Chief Tried in Vain To Raise Cash For WorldCom
description: In his final weeks as chief financial officer of WorldCom, Scott D. Sullivan was urgently trying to raise cash in the stock market even as accounting woes threatened to engulf his company.

title: 6 Coffee Brokers Are Charged on Trading
description: Federal commodity regulators charged six floor brokers on the New York Board of Trade with using unlawful practices in trading coffee futures at the expense of their customers.

description: To the Editor:

title: Mental Issue Keeps Grip on Sept. 11 Case
description: A month after finding Zacarias Moussaoui competent to defend himself against charges that he conspired with the Sept. 11 terrorists, the judge who will preside at his trial has opened the possibility of reversing that decision.

description: To the Editor:

title: Big Names but No Authority to Prosecute
description: President Bush said today that his Corporate Fraud Task Force would operate as a ''financial crimes SWAT team,'' but the group has no direct authority to investigate or prosecute cases and no new financial resources or added manpower for the effort, government officials said.

title: Senators Question Powell on Arms-Cut Treaty
description: Senators from both parties raised sharp questions today about the effectiveness of the recent Treaty of Moscow, which commits the United States and Russia to deep cuts in their nuclear arsenals over the coming decade but offers no guidelines for achieving the cuts or means of making sure that they have been made.

title: Money to Teach Teachers Better
description: The Carnegie Corporation of New York will spend $40 million on new teacher training programs at six universities across the country, including Bank Street College in Manhattan. The initiative, called Teachers for a New Era, will provide money to promote change in teacher training and to finance mentoring programs for new teachers. The Carnegie Corporation hopes the programs will become models for teacher instruction. Jennifer Medina

She was an inspiration to her many friends with her interests in human concerns, science, and the arts to the very end. She will be missed dearly. May she rest in peace. Trude, Madeleine, Fritzi

title: Clambake Without the Sand
description: THIS is a kind of portable clambake, a dead-easy system for cooking shellfish on the grill or, when the weather cools off, in the oven. It is based on the classic method of cooking en papillote -- in packages -- but with aluminum foil, instead of parchment paper, the packages can be placed directly on the grill. And with Asian seasonings, they become slightly exotic and really delicious.
