title: Raising School Standards And Cutting Budget: Huh?
description: CONGRESS and the president have demanded that states raise academic standards, and every state has now complied. Yet state leaders have also recognized that disadvantaged students need extra help to achieve these higher standards.

title: Free Speech and Campaign Reform Don't Conflict
description: There has long been a national consensus, the origins of which stretch back to Theodore Roosevelt, that corporate and union money and large individual contributions should have no place in our federal election system. Bans on corporate and union election spending and large individual campaign contributions have consistently been upheld by the Supreme Court as constitutional under the First Amendment.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FUERTH, NORMAN
description: FUERTH-Norman. We always will love and always will miss you. Joanee, Glenn, Tommy, Elyse, your Grandchildren

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about efforts by Silicon Valley executives to defend their boards from criticism of being inbred and beholden to managers misstated a former position of Joe Grundfest, a teacher of law and business at Stanford who defended the businesses. He is a former member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, not a former chairman.

title: Senate Approves Nuclear Waste Site in Nevada Mountain
description: The Senate gave final Congressional approval today for the establishment of a nuclear waste repository deep inside Nevada's Yucca Mountain, a pivotal moment in the 20-year search for a home for the radioactive byproducts from the nation's nuclear reactors.

title: Disaster Planner Has Lessons From 9/11 to Offer, and Boston Listens
description: As Ralph A. Blasi remembers it, the man who was trying to enter the World Financial Center on Sept. 11 as buildings burned nearby claimed to be a Verizon employee. The man would not take no for an answer, says Mr. Blasi, the director of security for Brookfield Financial Properties, manager of the World Financial Center.

title: No Matter What You're Serving, Make Sure the Wine Is Cold
description: WHEN it's hot out, a chilled ros, like a cold beer, supersedes any fussy pairing rules. It will complement lamb as well as a crisp salad. And that is its best quality: a ros has the fruit of white wines and the body of a light red, so it can adapt to either.

title: U.S. Official Is Jeered at AIDS Conference
description: Jeering protesters today drowned out Tommy G. Thompson, the United States secretary of health and human services, as he addressed the 14th International AIDS Conference here about the Bush administration's global prevention program.

title: Cuomo Calls for Restricting Corporate Political Contributions
description: Saying that scandal-plagued companies have penetrated ''the dimmer recesses of Albany's back rooms,'' Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democratic challenger in the governor's race, called for revamping state ethics laws yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Officers Found In Bar Are Suspended
description: Two police officers were suspended on Monday for drinking while on duty, the police said yesterday. The officers, Michael Toomey and John Busacco, are plainclothes officers assigned to the Transit Bureau's Manhattan task force. They were discovered in Smith's Bar and Restaurant at Eighth Avenue and 44th Street, at 9:10 p.m. on Monday when they should have been patrolling the subway, the police said. Officer Busacco, an eight-year veteran, had a bottle of beer in front of him. Officer Toomey, a nine-year veteran, had only a ginger ale in front of him, but he and Officer Busacco were not authorized to be in the bar, the police said. Each has been suspended for 30 days without pay, the police said. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WADE, JOSEPH H.
description: WADE-Joseph H. Of Whippany, NJ, on Monday, July 8, 2002. Retired banker for Marine Midland Bank, New York City. Funeral Mass on Friday, July 12, at St. Thomas More Church Convent, Station, NJ, at 10:30 A.M. Hours of Visitation at Doyle Funeral Home, 106 Maple Avenue, Morristown, NJ, Thursday 2-4 & 7-9.

title: House Passes Bill to Allow Airline Pilots to Carry Guns
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to let airline pilots carry guns in their cockpits. A similar proposal is gaining support in the Senate, making it likely that Congress will try to overrule an administration decision that pilots should not be armed.

title: Sony and Its Star Go to War Over the Promotion of Album
description: Without saying a word, Michael Jackson dashed to his black limousine in Harlem yesterday after a meeting of his newly formed coalition to further the rights of black musicians. He had been expected to address reporters but his silence raised even more questions about his recent behavior, particularly toward Thomas D. Mottola, chief executive of the Sony Music Group.

title: U.S. Considers Wary Jordan As Base for an Attack on Iraq
description: American military planners are considering using bases in Jordan to stage air and commando operations against Iraq in the event the United States decides to attack Iraq, senior defense officials said today.

title: With a Huge Jazz Festival, Montreal Is Understated
description: MONTREAL, July 7  It is hard to grasp the Montreal International Jazz Festival, which began on June 27 and ended Sunidth="468" align="left" valign="top">

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARBASH, PHYLLIS SUSEN
description: BARBASH - Phyllis Susen. The Board and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the death of Phyllis Susen Barbash, Director of Education at Carnegie Hall, 1994-2001. Phyllis led the educational work of Carnegie Hall to a level of activity and excellence unparalleled in its nonprofit history. She initiated music education programs that reached out to Head Start, nursery, elementary school children and families; led professional development of teachers; and spearheaded the drive to turn Carnegie Hall into a national forum for arts in education as expressed in music. Phyllis leaves behind thousands touched by her work, also as harpist with the Pittsburgh Symphony, Founder and Executive Director of the Three Rivers Young Peoples Orchestras, and Director of Education of The Philadelphia Orchestra. She leaves thousands more who knew her as a sparkling friend, and a person whose passion for, and faith in, arts education were inseparable from her personality. Her passion for the important things in life, her quick intelligence, vision and humor, and her ability to reach out to be a deeply understanding friend and colleague, were all rare qualities, and we will miss her deeply. Our condolences go to Steven, her gallant husband, her family, and to all those who benefited from her counsel, friendship, and inspiration. Sanford I. Weill, Chairman Robert J. Harth, Executive & Artistic Director

title: Adding Charm to Revolution; But Some Say Charles Barron Risks Going Too Far
description: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg recently publicized his opposition to parole for a man convicted of killing two police officers in 1971, it also sent a message to Councilman Charles Barron, a self-described black revolutionary who has made bales of hay out of annoying the leaders on both sides of City Hall.

title: Tax Increase Leads to Plan For Layoffs By Federated
description: Stung by the business-tax increase that New Jersey adopted last week, the corporate parent of Macy's and Bloomingdale's department stores announced today that it planned to scale back its operations in the state and lay off at least 50 workers.

title: Footlights
description: Traveling Salesmen

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Economic Slowdown
description: Battered by market turbulence, high interest and unemployment rates, and the slow global economy, industrial production in Brazil, Latin America's largest economy, fell 5.1 percent in May from April, the worst slide in seven years. The government IBGE statistics institute said the decline was the worst month-to-month result since May 1995, when the economy was stopped by an oil strike. According to analysts, high interest rates and market jitters ahead of the October elections are stifling corporate investment, while a growing jobless rate and falling real wages have seriously dented consumer spending. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Cleaning Up Deadly Soviet Debris
description: Russia, Norway and the European Union agreed on a $1.78 billion plan to clean up Soviet-era nuclear debris in the Baltic and Barents Seas. Hundreds of rusting nuclear submarines and old nuclear reactors lie abandoned, mainly on the Kola Peninsula near the border of the union's northernmost member, Finland. The debris poses an environmental threat to all countries in the region, the union's external relations commissioner, Chris Patten, warned. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Man Charged With Lying To the F.B.I.
description: A 31-year-old Somerset County man who maintained a Web site on terrorism and security issues was charged today with falsely telling F.B.I. agents that he had information about a plot to smuggle a radioactive bomb into the United States.

title: Overcoming Hatred
description: To the Editor:

title: A-Rod Is Bonus Baby; Hicks Was Born Yesterday
description: Alex Rodriguez was the starting shortstop for the American League last night and struck out in his two times at bat. Rodriguez earns an average of $25 million a year, well, $25.2 million to be exact. For being on the All-Star team, Rodriguez earned an extra $100,000. It should cover his clubhouse tips for the past two days.

title: Site for Nuclear Waste
description: The Senate approved plans to locate a nuclear waste repository inside Nevada's Yucca Mountain, a pivotal moment in the search for a home for radioactive byproducts. While hurdles remain, the vote was a victory for President Bush.

title: William B. Ruger, 86, Founder of Gun Company
description: William B. Ruger, an American gun designer who founded Sturm, Ruger & Company, the largest firearms manufacturer in the United States, died on Saturday at his home in Prescott, Ariz.. He was 86.

title: SEPT.11 HIJACKERS SAID TO FAKE DATA ON BANK ACCOUNTS
description: The Sept. 11 hijackers were able to open 35 American bank accounts without having legitimate Social Security numbers and opened some of the accounts with fabricated Social Security numbers that were never checked or questioned by bank officials, a senior F.B.I. official said today.

title: Recalling Grandma In Confections With Cuban Inflections
description: ''We left Cuba in 1961 and went to Miami, where the family would gather in my grandmother's kitchen,'' said Mary Arda, left, a former caterer who owns Mary's Off Jane, her new bright green, yellow and orange bakery and cafe at 34 Eighth Avenue (Jane Street). She designed it with that kitchen in mind. Some of her pastries, like creamy cheesecake with a tropical fruit topping, mojito cookies flavored with mint and lime, and coconut cake, are inspired by her heritage. She also bakes home-style chocolate chip cookies, cakes iced with dark or milk chocolate, pineapple upside-down cake, lemon squares, brownies, pound cakes and blueberry cream pie. Most cakes are $4.25 a slice, and start at $32 for a whole cake. Not to be missed is Ms. Arda's fresh limeade seasoned with mint ($2.50).

title: The Tough Life and Ugly Death Of a Troubled 13-Year-Old Boy
description: A 13-year-old boy who had a troubled home life and was apparently unable to sidestep the pitfalls of life on the streets was found killed late Monday in a squatters' building in Brooklyn, the police said yesterday.

title: Bush and Democrats Still Deeply Split on What Needs to Be Done
description: Democratic-sponsored accounting and corporate-reform proposals now under debate in the Senate go further than the plan offered today by President Bush. In fact, the White House released a statement of administration policy today indicating that Mr. Bush believed that some of the Senate proposals go too far.

title: Bankruptcy Lawyer to Join Investment Bank
description: Harvey R. Miller, the nation's most prominent bankruptcy lawyer, said yesterday that he was joining Greenhill & Company, an investment banking and money management firm, as a managing director and partner.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Defense Chief Sees Lower Tensions
description: Defense Minister George Fernandes said infiltration of militants from Pakistan into the Indian-controlled portion of Kashmir was undergoing ''ups and downs'' but that ''significant steps'' had been taken to reduce tensions between the nuclear-armed rivals. On a visit to Japan, he reiterated India's no-first-strike policy, saying of its nuclear arsenal, ''We are looking at it primarily as a deterrent.'' Asked about a nuclear arms control deal with Pakistan, he said, ''I don't think we have reached the point, through confidence-building measures, where both countries could talk and come to a conclusion.'' James Brooke (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PHILIPPINES: CHURCH TELLS OF ABUSIVE PRIESTS The Roman Catholic Church has disclosed that about 200 priests have been investigated for sexual offenses in the last two decades. Archbishop Orlando Quevedo, president of the Catholic Bishops Conference of the Philippines, said most of the priests either had been dismissed or had left the church voluntarily. He apologized for the "grave sins committed by some leaders on members of the flock" in the predominantly Catholic country and said the church would draft a protocol for dealing with priests' misconduct. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, BERNARD
description: GILBERT-Bernard, 79. Of West Palm Beach, FL, on July 5, 2002. Devoted husband of Ruth, father of Steven and Barry, grandfather of Steven T. & Anna. He will be deeply missed. His wisdom, guidance, logic and humor guided 3 generations. In accordance with his wishes, services will be private.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Wounded Man Helps Catch Suspect
description: A coin laundry owner shot in the stomach during a struggle with a robber chased the suspect and flagged down officers in a passing patrol car, the police said yesterday. The owner, Juan Fernandez, 51, was treated at St. Barnabas Hospital and released, the police said. The officers arrested Edgardo Ortiz-Rodriguez, 40, shortly after the shooting about 8:45 p.m. Monday in the Fordham section, the police said. He was charged with robbery, attempted murder and other crimes. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about high-technology amenities in hotels misspelled the surname of a partner with the travel services group of the Accenture consulting firm who commented on the trend. He is Alex Kristou, not Lristou.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: High Court Won't Hear Detainee Case
description: The American Civil Liberties Union lost a round yesterday in its effort to learn the names of foreigners who were arrested after Sept. 11 and detained in New Jersey jails. The New Jersey Supreme Court denied the group's appeal of a June appellate court ruling that said the federal government could pre-empt the state's right-to-know laws in the interest of national security. A.C.L.U. officials said they were considering an appeal to the United States Supreme Court. The Justice Department issued a statement saying that disclosing the detainees' names ''could provide terrorists a road map of the department's investigations.'' Susan Sachs (NYT)

title: Wyeth Stock Falls 24% After Report
description: Shares of Wyeth, the drug company that makes the top-selling drugs for hormone replacement therapies, tumbled more than 24 percent yesterday after news that a large study had found that women taking one of the company's drugs had a higher risk of breast cancer.

title: Bush, on Wall St., Offers Tough Stance
description: President Bush came to Wall Street yesterday vowing to ''end the days of cooking the books, shading the truth and breaking our laws.'' He advocated legal reforms ranging from longer prison sentences for fraud to a new task force to prosecute corporate malfeasance.

title: Patients Weigh Quitting Drug After Research Indicates Risk
description: The news that thousands of women in a national study were suddenly being taken off hormone replacement therapy ushered in a day of reckoning for the millions of other women who take hormones. They all had the same simple but vexing question: Should I quit, too?

title: Drivers' Possible Moves Are Making Heads Spin
description: Ricky Rudd could leave his team as early as next week and set off a chain reaction in which drivers bounce from job to job, but Robert Yates, one of the most powerful owners in stock car racing, tries not to worry too much about that. He took time yesterday to get a haircut.

title: Study Casts Doubt on Value of Popular Knee Surgery
description: Apopular and expensive knee operation for arthritis does not work, researchers report. Their study, comparing it to sham surgery, found that patients who got the real operation did no better than those who got a placebo procedure.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOTTY, DR. ROBERT
description: KOTTY-Dr. Robert. July 24, 1909-July 10, 2000. Gifted psychiatrist and beloved friend. Loved, remembered and missed more than ever. Norma and Sall

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Fire Island: Generators Help Restore Power
description: The Lower Island Power Authority said it had installed emergency generators at Captree State Park and Robert Moses State Park to provide additional electricity on Fire Island. Problems with underwater transmission lines caused power failures last weekend. The emergency generators will help increase power to the eastern portion of the island. Utility officials said that they were unable to restore all of the power knocked out when three transmission lines failed. One line was restored Sunday, but officials said they had yet to find out what caused the other two to fail. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Albany Senate Losing Budget Expert
description: ABRAHAM M. LACKMAN, secretary to the powerful New York State Senate Finance Committee, is leaving the Legislature to become president of the Commission on Independent Colleges and Universities, an advocacy group in Albany for private New York colleges and universities. He said that after 22 years in state government, most of that as an adviser to the Senate's Republican majority on budget matters, he was ready for a change. He was widely regarded in the capital, even by his Democratic adversaries, as a wily and creative budget-maker who was hard to outsmart and more often than not got his way at the negotiating table. He will leave the post on Nov. 1. James C. McKinley Jr.

title: The Corporate Scandals; Coming Clean
description: When George W. Bush speaks about corporate misbehavior and self-dealing by business insiders, he perches on a platform much weaker than the one from which he launched the war on terrorism. Instead of the sense of resolve and determination he showed after Sept. 11, the president is still struggling to prove that his past business dealings have not made him a product of the very system he now denounces. The president dismisses criticism of his record as political. But if he expects to restore confidence in corporate America, he needs to get his own house in order first.

title: Legal Journal; Not Answering Can Raise Lots of Questions
description: Whether Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chief executive of WorldCom, waived his Fifth Amendment rights by giving a little speech to a House committee on Monday is an open question. What is clear is that the speech, which followed a score of opening statements by members of the committee, ran afoul of a strictly enforced Congressional monopoly on grandstanding.

title: Even for the Last .400 Hitter, Cryonics Is the Longest Shot
description: In a few days, after chemicals have frozen the body of Ted Williams, it will be placed upside-down in a titanium-steel cylinder here, sharing space with as many as three other bodies and, perhaps, five heads.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Budget Cutting In The Works
description: Gov. Scott McCallum is reviewing for possible veto as many as 300 items in the budget passed by the Legislature, which uses $825 million from the state's share of a nationwide tobacco settlement to plug a $1.3 billion shortfall. The $23 billion, two-year budget, which squeaked through the Legislature, cuts $190 million from state programs, including $44 million from higher education, and reduces financing to local governments by $40 million as of 2004. It allows agencies to fill only 80 percent of vacancies and bans deficit spending. Governor McCallum must sign a budget by Aug. 1. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HATTERSLEY, VIRGINIA LUKE
description: HATTERSLEY - Virginia Luke. On June 27, 2002 at her home in Sarasota, FL. Born September 23, 1909. Longtime resident of Locust Valley, New York. Beloved wife of the late Robert C. Hattersley and mother of Julie Righter, Melissa Schnirring, Robert C. Jr. and the late John G. Grandmother of six, greatgrandmother of 4. Memorial services to be held in Sarasota on July 14 and at St. John's of Lattingtown, Lattingtown Road, Locust Valley Tuesday, July 30 at 11:30 AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to St. John's.

title: When Are Teachers Auto Workers? When They're N.Y.U. Adjuncts
description: The United Auto Workers defeated the American Federation of Teachers in an election to represent part-time adjunct professors at New York University, according to a vote tabulated yesterday by the National Labor Relations Board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAS, DOROTHY (BABS) MARSTON
description: HAAS-Dorothy (Babs) Marston. Wife of George C. Haas, Jr. of Lake Worth, FL died on July 9th after a long illness. She is survived by three daughters, Susan Orthwein of Stamford, CT, Judith Eshelman of Putney, VT and Sally Anne Colbert of Weston, CT as well as six grandchildren. Services will be held at St. David's in the Pines Episcopal Church in Wellington, Florida at 11 AM Saturday, July 13. In lieu of flowers please send donations to Hospice of Palm Beach County, Inc., 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL. 33407, or Children International, P.O. Box 219055, Kansas City, MO. 64121.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Foreign Minister Resigns
description: Foreign Minister Diego Garca-Sayn resigned, the second departure of a respected minister in a month and another setback for President Alejandro Toledo. The resignation of Mr. Garca-Sayn, who did not explain why he quit, comes as Mr. Toledo's popularity has dropped sharply because of the government's inability to address chronic poverty. Interior Minister Fernando Rospigliosi quit last month, and other resignations are expected soon. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Argentina in Scramble To Bolster Peso, Again
description: In a blow to efforts to end a seven-month-old freeze on bank withdrawals that has paralyzed the economy and generated unrest, Argentina's government has had to abandon its latest plan to persuade savers to exchange their savings for government bonds.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Cellphone Shipments Plunge
description: Shipments of mobile phones plunged in May as the Japanese market approached the saturation point. Japanese handset makers shipped 3.24 million units in May, 28 percent fewer than in May 2001. It was the 12th consecutive decline. NTT DoCoMo Inc. remains Japan's largest carrier with more than half of the market, but the company's third-generation phone technology has yet to catch on. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Privacy Officer Is Possibility at Security Dept.
description: Under Congressional pressure, the Bush administration said today that it was open to the idea of installing a chief privacy officer in a new Department of Homeland Security to make sure it weighed issues of confidentiality and the secure handling of personal information.

Collom was named director for operations, based in Dallas; she had been marketing manager at Divine, Irving, Tex. Elka G. Olsen was named associate creative director, based in Dallas; she had been creative director at Internet Exposure, Minneapolis. Kimberly Smith was named account supervisor on the Cingular Wireless account, based in Atlanta; she had been business director at Exile on Seventh, Atlanta. And Tina Vanopdorp was named account director on the Beringer account, based in Napa, Calif.; she had been account supervisor at Draft Worldwide, Chicago, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DELPHI CORP., Troy, Mich., an auto parts maker, said it had a multiyear contract with General Motors, Detroit, to supply brake systems for minivans. Terms were not disclosed.

title: No Winner, Loser or M.V.P., but Plenty of Boos
description: The All-Star Game is an exhibition, but it is obviously so much more. There were only a smattering of empty green seats at Miller Park as tonight's game dragged into extra innings and into its fourth hour. Everyone, from Commissioner Bud Selig to the bat boy, was waiting for someone, anyone, to be the last star in the game that was filled with so many stars.

title: Qwest Discloses U.S. Attorney Is Investigating the Company
description: Qwest Communications International , the nation's fourth-largest local telephone company, said today that it was the subject of a criminal investigation by the Justice Department.

title: Spanish Rider Takes Tour Lead
description: CHATEAU-THIERRY, France, July 10  The ONCE team from Spain, which has loudly made known its intention of carrying the battle to Lance Armstrong in this 89th Tour de France, won its first skirmish today by dominating a long team time trial and putting one of its riders into the leader's yellow jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRAKE, FRANKLIN
description: DRAKE-Franklin. In loving memory of Franklin Drake, who died July 10, 2001 in Woodstock, New York. Artist and beloved husband of Ruth Drake. ''Time passes with a heartbeat less.''

title: Many a Molehill Before Nuke Waste Finds Mountain
description: The political support for burying nuclear waste beneath Yucca Mountain in Nevada may be as strong now as in 1987, when Congress first picked the site. But the Senate's approval of the site today, while it lets the Energy Department proceed, is far from the last word.

title: Rod Steiger, 77, Oscar-Winning Character Actor Known for His Intensity and Versatility, Dies
description: Rod Steiger, whose taut and intensely personal approach to a wide variety of roles placed him among the finest character actors of the last 50 years and brought him an Academy Award in 1967 for his depiction of the bigoted Southern sheriff in the film ''In the Heat of the Night,'' died yesterday in Los Angeles. He was 77.

description: Bonny Doon Vin Gris de Cigare $11

title: Notes From Los Angeles; Reclaiming a Lost River, Building a Community
description: So much is breaking up Los Angeles from secession movements in the San Fernando Valley and Hollywood to the growing divide between the city's wealthy and working poor -- that it may come as a shock to learn there is something knitting the city together. Angelenos are gathering with a common purpose to bring life to the banks of the neglected Los Angeles River, a 51-mile-long, sunbaked concrete ditch best known as the location for fiery car chases in action movies.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: 60 Years In Prison For Molesting
description: A former public school teacher who molested eight boys was sentenced to 60 years in prison. The man, Peter Lawrence Adams, 44, was convicted of child enticement, sexual assault and exposure involving boys 9 to 11 years old. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Winnie Mandela Pleads Not Guilty
description: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela has pleaded not guilty to defrauding a local bank of about $100,000. Mrs. Madikizela-Mandela, who headed the African National Congress Women's League, is accused of signing letters accompanying loan applications for 60 people who falsely claimed to be employees of the league. Mrs. Madikizela-Mandela, the ex-wife of former President Nelson Mandela, denied that she had signed the letters. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

description: EUROPE

title: Nassau Property Taxes: Going Up, Going Down, and Getting Fairer
description: Nearly 12,000 letters were quietly dropped off at the Hicksville Post Office this afternoon, but they heralded a long-awaited reassessment that will affect almost every property-tax payer in Nassau County.

title: Pepsi Profit Is Up, but Stock Price Is Down
description: SOMERS, N.Y., July 9 (Bloomberg News) — The Pepsi Bottling Group, the nation's leading bottler of Pepsi Cola, said today that proft in its fiscal second quarter increased 14 percent, but its sales volume disappointed Wall Street and its stock price fell sharply.

title: Summer Games and Toys
description: Save good books for rainy days; sunny days are for lawn games and water toys.

title: Taking a Look Around the Future
description: The Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum of the Smithsonian Institution has announced its National Design Award finalists.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: U.S. Can Search For Downed Pilots
description: The government has said it will allow American military officials to come to China to search for servicemen shot down during the cold war. The militaries from both sides are taking tentative steps to re-establish exchanges that were severed after a United States spy plane collided with a tailing Chinese jet off the coast of China in April 2001. The first mission involves a search for the bodies of two pilots shot down near the China-Korea border during the Korean War. Elisabeth Rosenthal (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Swats and Swings and Scooby Doo
description: MISTER MOSQUITO

title: Congressional Panels Recast Homeland Security Dept.
description: Members of Congress today began shaping a Department of Homeland Security that would differ substantially from the one President Bush proposed last month, moving to transfer into the department only some of the agencies Mr. Bush wanted there and putting others elsewhere.

title: Sea Explorer Uncovers Kennedy's PT 109
description: Dr. Robert D. Ballard, who discovered the Titanic, the Bismarck and dozens of other lost ships, yesterday announced his latest find: PT 109, John F. Kennedy's wartime boat, which a Japanese destroyer rammed and sank in the South Pacific in 1943.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: BIG DAY FOR GREAT ROBBER With 28 years of a prison term still to serve, Ronald Biggs, 72, one of Britain's "Great Train Robbers," married Raimunda Rothen, 52, a onetime samba dancer and companion from his days on the run in Brazil. The ceremony, in the Belmarsh high-security prison in London, was attended by their son, Michael Biggs, 27, who is resisting deportation from Britain. Officials say his parents' marriage could help him secure a British passport. Now partly paralyzed and barely able to speak after a series of strokes, Ronald Biggs was jailed in the mid-1960's for his part in a dramatic train robbery in 1963. He soon escaped, but returned to Britain last year. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: It's (a) a Carport, (b) a Garage, (c) a Garport or (d) a . . .
description: Steven Schappacher helped design a cross between a carport and a garage, above, for a client in Southampton, N.Y., and he coined a word for it: carage. Mr. Schappacher, who runs SchappacherWhite, a design firm, with his wife, Rhea White, said their garage ''looks delicate, but it's tough.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: 3 Arrested In Counterfeiting
description: Three people were arrested and accused of running a million-dollar operation counterfeiting small consumer goods like watches, as well as operating a side business laundering money, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said yesterday. The police raided the Flushing home and office of the three people -- John A. Chen, 27, Emily Chen, 29, and Zhiying He, 29 -- three times in the past week and recovered more than $1 million in cash in small-denomination bills, business and banking records and more than 5,000 watches, pens and sunglasses with fake designer labels, Mr. Brown said. Each defendant faces up to 25 years in prison if convicted. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: The View From Wall Street, and Main Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Phone Stocks Causing Pain For Investors In Europe, Too
description: As investors and politicians in the United States recoil from the collapse of WorldCom and other telecommunications companies, Europeans are nursing their own feelings of outrage and betrayal.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Hot Night, in All Ways

title: A Spanish Team Sends a Message
description: The ONCE team from Spain, which has loudly made known its intention to carry the battle to Lance Armstrong in this 89th Tour de France, won its first skirmish today by dominating a long team time trial and putting one of its riders into the leader's yellow jersey.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Justice Minister Quits
description: Justice Minister Miguel Reale Jr. resigned to protest a ruling by the solicitor general against federal intervention to replace the crime-ridden government of Espirito Santo State. The director of the Federal Police, Itanor Carneiro, and other senior officials have also stepped down rather than accept the decision, which overturned a recommendation made by the federal government's Human Rights Council after lawyers combatting corrupt officials in the state were assassinated. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Pirates on the Web, Spoils on the Street
description: LAST week, at age 29, John Sankus Jr. moved out of his parents' house for the first time. He and his parents drove 150 miles from their home in suburban Philadelphia to his new one: a federal penitentiary in Allenwood, Pa.

title: New Jersey Reviews and Fines Long-Term Care Center After an Autistic Boy, 14, Dies
description: State regulators have fined a center that treats patients with severe neurological illnesses $127,700 -- the largest fine in state history for a long-term care center -- citing lapses that the state says led to neglect and physical and sexual abuse of patients.

title: National Briefing | Mid-West: Kansas: Felons Become Ethics Teachers
description: Two Kansas businessmen who tried to bribe Costa Rican officials to expedite a land purchase have been sentenced by a federal judge to lecture students and other groups about the problem of corporate fraud. The two, Richard K. Halford, 67, and Albert F. Reitz, 50, pleaded guilty last August to conspiracy. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Freezing Time; Ted Williams
description: On the home page of its Web site, the Alcor Life Extension Foundation, a cryonics lab in Scottsdale, Ariz., describes its efforts to overcome, through science and wishful thinking, ''the event we now refer to as 'death.' '' That event came to Ted Williams last week, at the age of 83, and to him, one suspects, death needed no quotation marks. He was a man who knew how to play by the rules, and dying is every bit as much a rule in life as the foul lines are in baseball. It seems doubly bizarre, then, that Mr. Williams's body has been shipped to Alcor to hang upside down, frozen, until science comes up with a cure for old age.

title: Economic Scene; Bush is talking tough on corporate ethics, but where is the regulatory bite?
description: AT bottom, President Bush's speech on Tuesday reflects the belief that the current corporate scandals are merely the handiwork of a few bad apples. If we enforce existing laws more strongly, he essentially told us, the mess will be cleaned up. He called for longer prison sentences and a federal SWAT team to combat fraud.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on June 27 about the 17th Duke of Norfolk, who held the oldest dukedom in Britain, referred incompletely to the title's origin and the religious affiliations of some of the titleholders. The title originated in the 14th century, not the 15th. It was created in 1397 by Richard II and conferred on Thomas Mowbray. After the Mowbray line died out, it was re-established in 1483 by Richard III and bestowed on John Howard. At various times over the centuries, the Howards renounced their Roman Catholic faith for the Church of England; they did not remain Catholic when Henry VIII broke with Rome in the 16th century.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on June 16 about climate change in Alaska misstated the rise in temperatures there in the last 30 years. (The error was repeated in an editorial on Monday and in the Bob Herbert column on the Op-Ed page of June 24.) According to an assessment by the University of Alaska's Center for Global Change and Arctic System Research, the annual mean temperature has risen 5.4 degrees Fahrenheit over 30 years, not 7 degrees.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column last Thursday about Quality Inflatables, which sells swimming pool toys and floats, misstated its Web address. It is www.qualityinflatables.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERBER, RUSSELL
description: FERBER-Russell. The staff, past and present, of the Village Community School extends its heartfelt sympathy to David, Dorothy and Jordon on the tragic and untimely passing of their son and brother and our beloved alumnus Russell. His spirit was larger than life and will continue to fill the hearts, the halls, and the basketball courts of VCS. He will be deeply missed. Eve Kleger, Director

title: One More Misstep For a Battered Sport
description: At a promotional news conference Tuesday morning, Major League Baseball unveiled its selections for the 30 most memorable moments in its history. The All-Star Game played that night will not be No. 31.

title: S.E.C. Opens Inquiry Into How Bristol-Myers Reported Revenue
description: Federal securities regulators have begun an investigation of whether Bristol-Myers Squibb overstated its revenue last year by giving wholesalers incentives to buy extraordinary amounts of the company's prescription drugs, the company said today.

title: A New (Election Year) Vigilance on Corporations
description: Only a month ago, Senator Phil Gramm, a critic of many Democratic proposals for tightening oversight of the accounting industry, said ''the feeding frenzy is pretty much over.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Postal Job Cuts
description: Deutsche Post may cut 10,000 jobs, or 3 percent of its work force, as an order from regulators to lower postage rates erodes profits. The lower rates will cut earnings by 1.5 billion euros ($1.5 billion) through 2007, Deutsche Post said. The company said most job cuts would be among mail delivery workers. The postal workers union said it would fight the cuts.

title: Amonte's Price May Keep Him Adrift
description: While the National Hockey League announced yesterday that the Rangers would kick off the N.H.L.'s 86th season in Raleigh, N.C., Wednesday evening, Oct. 9, against the defending Eastern Conference champion Carolina Hurricanes, it is still anybody's guess as to where Tony Amonte will be that day.

title: Battling Buffoonery in Albany (It's Full-Time Work)
description: LET'S take a moment to check Blair Horner's legislative to-do list. Ban on smoking in restaurants? No. Competitive voting districts? Nope. Curb on predatory lending? Superfund money? Report cards that rank hospitals?

title: Cubicle Crimes
description: Apparently, without anyone's noticing, our entire universe collapsed into a black hole and emerged in another dimension where everything is backward: Bill Gates (who used to be evil) is spending billions to vaccinate children in third-world countries, while the Catholic Church (which used to be good) is defending priests accused of molesting children. The stock market (which used to go up) now only drifts downward. And the surest way to lose respect is to mention you started a dot-com.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: VeriSign Posts Lower-Than-Expected Sales
description: VeriSign Inc., which manages the database of all Internet sites with dot-com addresses, said yesterday that second-quarter sales rose less than forecast as companies cut spending and fewer users renewed Internet names. Second-quarter profit, excluding certain costs, was 14 cents to 15 cents a share, less than the 18 cents to 20 cents the company expected, VeriSign said in a statement, citing a preliminary review. Sales were $315 million to $317 million, compared with a prior estimate of $320 million to $330 million. VeriSign's shares have tumbled 91 percent in the last year as the number of Internet names in its database declined. Shares of VeriSign rose 76 cents, to $5.75 in after-hours trading following the announcement. The stock rose 16 cents, to $4.99 during regular trading hours, after dropping 21 percent in the first two days of the week.

title: Mortgage Applications Up
description: An index measuring applications for mortgages rose last week to the highest level since November as more people took advantage of low interest rates to buy homes.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: VERDICT IN PEARL CASE DUE SOON A verdict is expected as early as Monday in the case against four men accused of killing Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter who disappeared in Karachi in January. The three-month trial ended yesterday with prosecutors demanding the death penalty. Lawyers for Ahmed Omar Sheikh, an Islamic militant born in Britain, and his three co-defendants deny their clients had any involvement with Mr. Pearl's kidnapping and killing. The case will be decided by the judge, Ali Ashraf Shah. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Suffer the Children
description: This year's N.A.A.C.P. convention may be in the president's home state of Texas, but anyone who expected a courtesy call from George W. Bush was mistaken.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Counting Infiltrators
description: The Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, Nirupama Rao, said infiltration of Islamic militants from Pakistani territory into Indian-controlled Kashmir dropped 30 percent between May 27 and June 23 but rose in the last week of June. It was the first time India had quantified the decline in infiltration, one of India's main demands in its confrontation with Pakistan. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Flash Cards Add Memory to Grow
description: Is separation anxiety keeping you distracted? Can't bear the thought of leaving your data home alone? The Cruzer, a new portable storage device from SanDisk, promises to put your mind at ease by taking your files out of your hard drive's hands and putting them squarely in your own.

title: A New Outlet for the Urge To Fill Your Space
description: Crate & Barrel has opened its first outlet store in the New York City area, with discounts of 30 to 70 percent. The 6,000-square-foot store, at the Woodbury Common Premium Outlets mall in Central Valley, N.Y., 60 miles north of the city, offers a folding wooden picnic table and two-bench set at $169 (right; formerly $249); galvanized metal pails for plants or for chilling drinks, $24.95 (from $32.95); and acrylic tumblers, $1.25 (from $2.50). Hammocks are $59.95, and Marimekko cotton fabric in bold bright prints is $8.95 a yard (normally $32 a yard). For travel directions as well as bus information: (845) 928-4000. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: INSIDE
description: Britain Easing Up on Pot Law

title: Siamese, if You Please: Finding the Right Pet
description: I CAME home one day last summer to find a cat in the vestibule. It was a pretty, purring thing with brindled fur and a remarkable face, half dark, half light, like a tragicomic mask. It rubbed against my legs.

title: Bush Failed To Stress Need To Rein In Stock Options
description: George W. Bush wants to run corporate criminals out of town on a rail. But he is not trying to confiscate perhaps their most powerful weapon.

title: Pilot Program Seeks to Deter Escapes From Police Custody
description: After a series of escapes by prisoners from police custody, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that he would begin a pilot program in 30 days to outfit prisoners with plastic wristbands bearing photographs and other identifying information.

title: Master Architect Is Building Giants' Line
description: The phone calls sometimes came when others would normally be sleeping, but Anthony Munoz understood that Jim McNally's enthusiasm could never be constricted by a clock. ''I've got something,'' McNally said, his voice filled with discovery. ''Get down in your stance.''

title: A Forest Helps Deal With Difference
description: Charm may be a devalued word, but it retains its most positive resonance when applied to ''Shadow's Child,'' a joyful fable that the American modern-dance company Urban Bush Women has created in collaboration with the National Song and Dance Company of Mozambique.

title: Manhattan Prosecutors to Lead Case Against WorldCom
description: The Justice Department formally decided the makeup of the legal team handling the fraud investigation into WorldCom yesterday, assigning the United States attorney's office in Manhattan to lead the effort, according to government officials and other people involved in the case.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column last Thursday about a children's playhouse made of wood and woven steel scrim for a home on Long Island misspelled the surname of its architect. He is Thomas Phifer, not Pfifer.

title: S.&P. 500 and Nasdaq Fall to Levels Last Seen in 1997
description: The worst bear market in a generation deepened yesterday as stocks plunged for the second day, leaving two major indexes at their lowest levels since 1997.

title: Profit Declines 1% At SunTrust Banks
description: SunTrust Banks Inc. said today that profit fell 1 percent in the second quarter after it increased its provision for bad loans.

title: Governor Says Tax Increase Is Not Cause Of Layoffs
description: Trying to ease fears that the business-tax increase New Jersey enacted last week may lead to higher unemployment, a defiant Gov. James E. McGreevey today disputed claims by executives of a major department store chain who said higher state taxes had forced them to lay off 50 workers.

title: Ad Resurgence Helps Buoy Latest Figures from Yahoo
description: Yahoo Inc., the search engine turned Internet advertising hub, posted quarterly sales and profit figures today that exceeded the projections of Wall Street analysts.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Big Day For Great Robber
description: With 28 years of a prison term still to serve, Ronald Biggs, 72, one of Britain's ''Great Train Robbers,'' married Raimunda Rothen, 52, a onetime samba dancer and companion from his days on the run in Brazil. title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; After some hostility, AT&T shareholders approve a breakup.
description: AT&T shareholders gave their approval yesterday to the breakup of what is left of the company into three pieces. But one part of that breakup may never happen.

title: Colon Cancer Screening Bill Advances in Senate Panel
description: A Senate committee voted today to require all private health insurance plans in the United States to pay for screening tests to detect colon cancer in people who are 50 or older or have a high risk of developing the disease.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Conviction Upheld
description: The country's highest court dismissed the appeal of a corruption conviction by the former deputy prime minister, Anwar Ibrahim, dashing his hopes for freedom and a political comeback. The court ruled unanimously that Mr. Anwar, the former heir apparent to Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, was properly convicted in 1999 on four counts of corruption for abusing his powers to prevent the police from investigating charges of sexual misconduct. Mr. Anwar, who has been sentenced to six years in prison, told the court after the ruling that the proceeding was a charade; opposition politicians and human rights groups have condemned his prosecution. Baradan Kuppusamy (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: BMW Increases Sales
description: BMW's vehicle sales for the first half of the year rose 18 percent as the company headed for a third consecutive year of record profits. Sales rose to 543,742 vehicles from 459,835 in the year-earlier period on demand for the new Mini car, the midsize 3-Series model and the X-5 sport utility vehicle. BMW-brand sales rose 4.7 percent in the first six months, but the rate of growth slowed to 1.1 percent in June, the company said. BMW, which is based in Munich, expects to sell more than a million cars this year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Ex-Democratic Official Sentenced
description: Paul W. Adler, the former chairman of the Rockland County Democratic Party, was sentenced yesterday to 19 months in federal prison and ordered to pay a $4,000 fine for his conviction on mail fraud and tax fraud conspiracy charges. He pleaded guilty last year to the charges and will begin serving his term on Sept. 18. Mr. Adler, 43, a real estate agent from New City, N.Y., was one of the most prominent Democrats in the Hudson Valley and had advised and raised money for Hillary Rodham Clinton during her 2000 senatorial campaign. Mr. Adler admitted accepting cash from developers in exchange for using his political influence to further a project. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: Uncle Sam Wants You (To Play This Game)
description: ''BE all you can be''? Ancient history. ''An army of one''? Last year's news. The military's newest promotional campaign is not even televised; it is America's Army, a free computer game produced by the military and aimed at winning the hearts and minds of tech-minded teenagers.

title: Friends Say Williams Wanted to Be Cremated
description: When the writer John Underwood and his family visited Ted Williams in Hernando, Fla., a little more than a year ago, Williams, the ailing Boston Red Sox legend, moved with the aid of a walker, but his spirits were soaring. He had not seen the Underwoods' teenage children, Josh and Caroline, since he had bounced them on his knees.

title: Nassau Homeowners Sort Pains and Gains Of Tax Reassessment
description: Residents of Sea Cliff are starting to experience sticker shock over their new property assessments. Residents of Roosevelt are expecting just the reverse: notices showing that the assessed values on their homes are going down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, HELEN BLATTE
description: ZIMMERMAN-Helen Blatte. On July 10, 2002, of Somers, NY, after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Loving mother of Marc Blatte, David Blatte and Lisa Blatte Ennis. Grandmother of Hayley Blatte and Bryce Ennis. She was an avid tennis player and lover of classical music, mysteries, travel and a devotee of The New York Times crossword puzzles. Funeral service on Friday, July 12, at 12 Noon, Hawthorne Funeral Home, 21 Stevens Ave, Hawthorne, NY. Interment Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to UJA Planned Parenthood and Ballet Hispanico in Manhattan.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Newspapers Acquired
description: The GTC Transcontinental Group agreed to pay 255 million Canadian dollars ($167 million) to the CanWest Global Communications Corporation, Canada's biggest media company, for all its smaller newspapers in Atlantic Canada and Saskatchewan. The transaction, GTC's biggest acquisition, involves 10 dailies, including those in St. John's, Newfoundland, and Halifax, Nova Scotia. The publications, with 100 million Canadian dollars in sales, will double the newspaper business for the Montreal-based GTC, the company said.

title: Road Signs for Vagabond Computer Users
description: HOBOES were willing to work for food, but they preferred it free. When they found a good mark (a friendly homemaker prone to handouts), or a place to avoid (an angry man with a gun), they would chalk a symbol out of a large vocabulary on a nearby post or surface to let their colleagues know.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JANIFER, LAURENCE M.
description: JANIFER-Laurence M., 69. Noted science fiction writer, of congestive heart failure in Oakland, California. Father of Meg, Seth, Kathleen. Grandfather of Kyle. Brother of Jeff Steve Harris.

title: Move to Oust Chief Seen at Phone Giant
description: Whatever may happen next to Ron Sommer, the embattled chief executive of the German telephone giant Deutsche Telekom, few analysts expect him to willingly part company with VoiceStream Wireless, the American cellular company whose $24 billion acquisition Mr. Sommer oversaw last year.

title: A Stereo That's Small And Digital
description: YOU know how some people resent Microsoft for its size and ambition? Well, here's a conversation starter: Why don't people resent Sony?

title: The Spook Awards
description: How fare the espionage agencies? Who's hot and who's not? Most agents and spymasters resolutely refuse to talk about their own agencies, but cheerfully rat on each other's intelligence gathering, evaluation and tradecraft. Time now for the Golden Cloak & Dagger Awards, based on professional assessments by a half-dozen of my spooky sources around the world.

title: Cord Uses Computer's Power To Charge Cellphone Batteries
description: Sounding suspiciously like a high-technology version of robbing Peter to pay Paul, a new accessory cord allows you to recharge a mobile phone using power from your computer. The cord, made by American Power Conversion and other manufacturers, plugs into the U.S.B. port of a desktop PC or a battery-powered laptop. Once the computer is switched on, the port yields 5 volts of power, more than the 3.6 to 4.5 volts needed to charge most phones, said Jane Morgan, mobile products manager for American Power Conversion, based in Providence, R.I.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bush Used Insider Benefits That He Now Wants to Ban

title: Arthritis Surgery In Ailing Knees Is Cited as Sham
description: A popular operation for arthritis of the knee worked no better than a sham procedure in which patients were sedated while surgeons pretended to operate, researchers are reporting today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Boy Hit By Police Van Dies
description: The 13-year-old boy who was struck by an unmarked police van in Harlem on Monday died of his injuries yesterday, a hospital spokeswoman said. The boy, Keith McKissick, was pronounced dead at 5:15 p.m. at Harlem Hospital Center, said Renelda Higgins Walker, the hospital spokeswoman. Two officers from the warrant squad were driving west on 125th Street near Madison Avenue shortly after 12:30 p.m. when the van's passenger-side mirror struck the boy in the head, the police said. The authorities said the boy ran into the street between parked cars, and the accident was recorded on a videotape at a nearby shop. The videotape, which was released to reporters after the accident, showed that the van had a green light and stopped when the boy was hit. The accident is still under investigation. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Pacing, and Worrying; Hard Times Overtake New York's Harness Tracks
description: At the end of another long afternoon at the track, John Stubits found his assistant trainer sitting stiffly on a bucket in the stable. His back hurt, and so did his wallet.

title: A Fossil Unearthed in Africa Pushes Back Human Origins
description: French scientists digging in Central Africa have uncovered a skull, virtually complete and almost seven million years old, that belonged to an individual about the size of a chimpanzee. It is, they say, the earliest known member of the human family, by perhaps as much as a million years.

title: HOME DEPOT SETTLES MICHIGAN CHALLENGE ON ITEM PRICING
description: Home Depot, the world's largest home-improvement store chain, will pay as much as $500,000 to settle claims that it violated a Michigan law requiring retailers to mark individual prices on goods. Home Depot also agreed to put in place policies at its 45 Michigan stores to make it easier for customers to make sure they are charged the correct prices at the cash register, Michigan's attorney general, Jennifer M. Granholm, said. The agreement settles the fourth legal challenge by Michigan to the way Home Depot marks prices on its products. An earlier dispute resulted in a $250,000 fine in June 1998. The company, based in Atlanta, said it was pleased to have reached the agreement.

title: Bloomberg Signs Budget Bills, Including New Taxes on Phones
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed several bills into law yesterday to help the city balance its budget by raising fees on cellphones and regular telephones, changing the way the city calculates its business tax, and offering early retirement to some city workers.

title: Casting a Cool Eye on Cryonics
description: Sometimes art, like hitting, is all in the timing.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DONNELLY, KEVIN
description: DONNELLY-Kevin. The sun, the center of my universe, and a true American. I love you and I miss you. Happy Birthday.

title: Genuinely Ugly Americans, As Viewed by the Japanese
description: The barbarians are indeed at the gate, and they are awful to behold. Their feral, matted hair is as wild as a Gorgon's, their faces distorted by the kinds of growths found on exotic baboons. Their leader, who stands at least seven feet tall, towers like doom incarnate. Tremble and recoil, citizens of the land: the Americans have arrived.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBOW, MIRIAM
description: LUBOW-Miriam. Formerly of Brooklyn, New York and West Palm Beach, Florida, on July 8th, 2002 in Nashville, Tennessee. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, sister, dear friend and relative who will be deeply missed by those who knew her.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: The Call of Summer, Thwack, Slap, Pong
description: SAVE good books for rainy days; sunny days are for lawn games and water toys. This season there is a game for everyone, from magnetic playing cards to table tennis for the pool.

title: By 2010, AIDS May Leave 20 Million African Orphans
description: BARCELONA, Spain, July 10  AIDS will leave 20 million children in Africa without one or both parents by 2010, the 14th International AIDS Conference was told here today. That is nearly double the current number, 11 million.

title: ICAHN RAISES BID IN CONTEST FOR MORTON'S RESTAURANTS
description: The billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn raised his bid yesterday for the Morton's Restaurant Group to $71.2 million, topping Castle Harlan's agreement to buy the company for $67 million. Mr. Icahn's High River raised its bid 6.3 percent, to $17 a share, in a letter disclosed in a shareholder filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The offer is Mr. Icahn's fourth attempt to outbid Castle Harlan. Morton's said it had referred the offer to a committee of the board. Castle Harlan, a private buyout firm based in New York, agreed in March to buy Morton's for $12.60 a share. It has raised its bid three times to match those of Mr. Icahn. Morton's, based in New Hyde Park, N.Y., operates 61 Morton's of Chicago steakhouses and 4 Bertolini's Authentic Trattorias. Mr. Icahn bought a 6.8 percent stake in May.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Nursing Homes To Repay Medicaid
description: Four nursing homes have agreed to repay more than $930,000 for which they overbilled Medicaid, Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer announced yesterday. According to Medicaid regulations, only when occupancy is high can nursing homes bill Medicaid for the beds of residents who are temporarily sent to a hospital, in effect reserving their spots until they are ready to return. But officials said that an investigation by the attorney general's Medicaid Fraud Control Unit discovered that between 1994 and 2000, three nursing homes on Long Island and one in the Bronx had improperly billed Medicaid for hospitalized residents' beds when occupancy rates were lower than the allowable threshold. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: A Fossil Unearthed in Africa Pushes Back Human Origins
description: French scientists digging in Central Africa have uncovered a skull, virtually complete and almost seven million years old, that belonged to an individual about the size of a chimpanzee. It is, they say, the earliest known member of the human family, by perhaps as much as a million years.

title: Book Parties With Togas
description: Close your eyes and think of being somewhere else when it's 90-plus degrees in steamy New York, or anywhere. Why not, for instance, ancient Rome? Which is synonymous with romance and conspiracy, sex and poisonings, philosophy and gladiators, things grand and profane. Writers think these thoughts, and create genres. Although it's not yet a publishing trend, there are at least a handful of recent books of fiction and nonfiction about ancient Rome in the bookstores, with more on the way.

title: Israel to Try Leading Palestinian in Civilian Court for Attacks
description: JERUSALEM, July 11  Israel will put Marwan Barghouti, the most prominent of the emerging Palestinian leaders, on trial in a civilian court on charges of orchestrating attacks on Israelis, a Justice Ministry official said today.

title: Are Gadgets Already Too Small?
description: In general, few people are less interested in predicting the future of technology than I am. The high-tech business is inherently unpredictable--almost random. Just as nobody in 1980 could have seen Microsoft or the Internet coming, so nobody can imagine whatever huge development is being hatched in a garage somewhere at this very moment. Whatever any pundit tells you about technology even five years from now should be taken with a grain of salt the size of Canada. In fact, the whole exercise should be considered slightly less scientific than the horoscope column at the back of a teen fashion magazine.

title: Close Look at Iraq on Poison Gas and bin Laden
description: ''Many people were collapsing around us and dying,'' says a Kurdish man who survived a poison gas attack. ''The gas smelled of garlic and rotten apples.'' As he recalls that day, we see videotape shot immediately after the attack. The gas -- a combination including the nerve gas sarin and cyanide -- caused paralysis and death so fast that the stonelike corpses littering the ground look flash-frozen, fists clenched, one child's arm still lifted in the air.

title: French Justice Minister's Move Revives AIDS Contamination Case
description: Ludovic Boucher's public high school was forced, against the principal's will, to admit him, he said. But he was still forbidden to eat in the cafeteria, go to shop class or work in the biology lab. Mr. Boucher, 26, a hemophiliac, was infected with AIDS through tainted blood products when he was 8.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Verdict In Pearl Case Due Soon
description: A verdict is expected as early as Monday in the case against four men accused of killing Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter who disappeared in Karachi in January. The three-month trial ended yesterday with prosecutors demanding the death penalty. Lawyers for Ahmed Omar Sheikh, an Islamic militant born in Britain, and his three co-defendants deny their clients had any involvement with Mr. Pearl's kidnapping and killing. The case will be decided by the judge, Ali Ashraf Shah. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ODENCE, LOIS BECKER
description: ODENCE-Lois Becker. The benisons of true friendship from so many and devotion to one another have given support and strength to your grieving family during this difficult year. Your flame, darling Mother, burns brightly in each of us and guides us in our daily lives. You would be particularly proud of dear Charles, Alan & Carole, your wonderful grandchildren and your great-grandchildren. We will always adore you. Barbara and Ruth

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: NURSING HOMES TO REPAY MEDICAID

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Tackling the Teacher Shortage
description: A consultant to the state's Education Department has warned that its teacher shortage will probably increase to 1,000 from 600 within three years, unless salaries are increased and recruiting is expanded to people in other occupations. Arkansas public school instructors earn, on average, $34,000 annually.

title: Survivors Of 3 Officers Sue Union Over Charity
description: The families of three police officers who died in the attack on the World Trade Center are suing the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association in an escalation of a dispute over the union's handling of the millions of dollars in donations it received after Sept. 11.

title: Verizon May Not Make Global Crossing Bid
description: Verizon Communications, the nation's largest local phone company, has decided not to submit a bid for Global Crossing, limiting the company's chances of being acquired out of bankruptcy to a bid from two buyout firms, people involved in the bidding process said yesterday.

title: The Joy of Shredding
description: To the Editor:

title: 6 Plans for Ground Zero Share Striking Similarities
description: Born of a tragedy, the redevelopment of the World Trade Center was supposed to be a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for some of the brightest urban planners to come up with breathtaking innovations and urban solutions to fix what has been wrong with Lower Manhattan for decades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSLER, JOHN E.
description: MOSLER-John E., on July 7, 2002, at age 79. Loving father of Bruce E. Mosler and his wife Wendy, John E. Mosler, Jr. and his wife Jennifer, and Michele A. Mosler. Devoted grandfather of David and Charlotte Mosler. Devoted brother of Janet Coleman and the late Edwin H. Mosler, Jr. Interment private. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Thursday, July 11, at 6PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to Fordham University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, THEODORE LUD WIG
description: JOHNSON - Theodore Lud wig. Died June 26, 2002 in San Diego, CA. Born in Brooklyn on January 17, 1910 to Swedish immigrants, he is survived by a son David of San Diego and a daughter Beej of Manhattan & two grandsons.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about jury deliberations in the trial of former Police Officer Charles Schwarz misidentified the man shown in the foreground. He was Alan Vinegrad, chief prosecutor in the case. (Jack Smith, another prosecutor, was pictured behind Mr. Vinegrad's right shoulder, his face partly obscured.)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: TV Sales Help Retailer
description: The World Cup soccer tournament, held from May 31 to June 30 in South Korea and Japan, helped to drive sales at LG Electronics to $4.2 billion in the second quarter, up 15 percent from the second quarter of 2001. LG Electronics said the increase was helped by strong sales of digital television sets for watching World Cup matches. Earnings before interest and taxes soared to $363 million, more than double that for the second quarter of 2001. The company said net income for the second quarter was $380 million, down 66 percent from the period a year earlier when the net reflected an asset sale of nearly $1 billion to Royal Philips Electronics. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: The View From Wall Street, and Main Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Ruby Is No Secretariat
description: To say that Black Ruby is the Secretariat of mules is a bit unfair. Secretariat never won 57 races, nor was he named the champion of his breed five straight times. He did not hold the world record at three distances. Black Ruby has done all that and more.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORTON, JANE B.
description: MORTON-Jane B. On July 6, 2002 at age 91. Wife of the late Paul Stillman Morton. Loving mother of Kathleen Stillman Morton and the late Jane Goldman. Grandmother of Christopher Morton Aberger and Daniel Paul Goldman. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. on Friday, July 12, 5-9PM. Interment to take place Saturday, July 13 at Cypress Hills Cemetery, Brooklyn, New York at 1 PM.

title: U.S. Backs Off Immunity Fight Involving Court
description: Under severe criticism from some of its closest allies for demanding immunity for American peacekeepers from the new International Criminal Court, the United States offered a compromise today that would safeguard its troops and officials from prosecution for one year.

title: A War of Robots, All Chattering on the Western Front
description: SINCE the United States military campaign began in Afghanistan, the unmanned spy plane has gone from a bit player to a starring role in Pentagon planning. Rather than the handful of ''autonomous vehicles,'' or A.V.'s, that snooped on Al Qaeda hideouts, commanders are envisioning wars involving vast robotic fleets on the ground, in the air and on the seas -- swarms of drones that will not just find their foes, but fight them, too.

title: N.J. Transit Adopts Budget That Imperils Improvements
description: New Jersey Transit adopted a $1.22 billion operating budget and a $1.19 billion capital budget for the new fiscal year today, but officials warned that the plans were balanced at the expense of long-term investment in system improvements.

title: National Briefing: Mid-West
description: MICHIGAN: JAIL FOR SUICIDE PACT SURVIVOR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASSO, VINCENT
description: NASSO - Vincent. Beloved husband of Theresa nee Basile, devoted father of Norma Nasso Deraska, cherished grandfather of Diane Deraska Malinowski and Donald J. Deraska, M.D., loving great grandfather of three and dear father-in-law of Donald J. Deraska. Reposing Scarpaci Funeral Home, 1401 86th Street, Brooklyn until Saturday, 10AM. Mass St. Frances de Chantel, 10:15AM. Viewing hours 2-5, 7-9:30 P.M.

title: Union Head Seeks Changes In Principals' Merit Awards
description: The president of the union representing 5,300 New York City school principals and other administrators said yesterday that in forthcoming contract talks she would insist on changing the merit pay system that rewards administrators on the basis of test scores at their schools.

title: Metro Matters; Drug Laws And the Habits Of Politics
description: MORE than seven years after Gov. George E. Pataki first said he wanted to revise the Rockefeller-era drug laws, it is beginning to feel like one of those all-or-nothing moments. Something has to happen. Or nothing will.

title: Britain to Stop Arresting Most Private Users of Marijuana
description: Britain, which has one of the highest rates of cannabis use in Europe, said today that it was relaxing its laws on marijuana smoking, keeping the practice theoretically illegal but making private use in discreet amounts no longer subject to arrest.

title: U.S. Is Critical of Israel's Closing Of Moderate Palestinian's Office
description: The White House today criticized Israel for shutting down the East Jerusalem office of Sari Nusseibeh, a moderate Palestinian leader who has urged his compatriots to halt suicide missions against Israelis.

title: Bethlehem Journal; A City Ancient, Glorious, All Shuttered and Glum
description: Semiautomatic rifle at the ready, the Israeli soldier commanded the high ground near here today, pacing a Palestinian ''Martyrs' Cemetery.''

title: The 9/11 Inquest: Now Americans Say Germans Bungled
description: In the eyes of some American officials, the German police and intelligence agencies missed signals about the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States, failed to push hard enough beforehand to unravel the plot and, more recently, refused to arrest men suspected of being accomplices of the conspirators.

title: By 2010, AIDS May Leave 20 Million African Orphans
description: AIDS will leave 20 million children in Africa without one or both parents by 2010, the 14th International AIDS Conference was told here today. That is nearly double the current number, 11 million.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: ADC Predicts Sales Slump
description: ADC Telecommunications Inc., which makes products for high-speed Internet and voice lines, said yesterday that third-quarter sales would not meet expectations because of a continued decline in capital spending in the telecommunications industry. Shares of ADC fell 14 cents, to $2.08; they have dropped 66 percent in the last year. The company said it planned to cut its work force, close plants and stop making certain products to reduce costs. Sales in the quarter ending July 31 will be $235 million to $245 million, the company said. The company said it would have a loss, excluding some costs, of 5 cents to 7 cents a share. ADC, based in Eden Prairie, Minn., has cut about 12,500 jobs since 2000. Richard R. Roscitt, the chief executive, said the company would lower expenses in an effort to break even by October. ''Given continued industry weakness, we are redoubling our efforts to further gain market share in our key products, continue to lower our break-even point and further strengthen our balance sheet,'' Mr. Roscitt said.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Senior Ayatollah Quits In Protest
description: A prominent senior cleric, Ayatollah Jalaledin Taheri, announced his resignation as the leader of Friday Prayer in Isfahan. In an open letter of protest against the hard-line policies of the supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, he blamed the ayatollah for what he called the betrayal of the revolution's promises. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Qwest Communications Under Criminal Investigation by U.S.
description: The burdens confronting Qwest Communications International, which provides local phone service in 14 Western states, increased yesterday when the company disclosed that it was under criminal investigation by the Justice Department.

title: The View From Wall Street, and Main Street
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Inflation Tame
description: Driven by increases in gasoline prices and public transport fares, Brazil's inflation rose 0.42 percent in June, double May's increase but below market expectations, leaving room for a possible cut in the high interest rates choking growth in Brazil, South America's largest economy. The government said cumulative inflation for the first half was 2.94 percent, while the year-to-year rate in June was 7.66 percent. The government originally set a 3.25 percent inflation target for 2003 but has revised the target to 4 percent because of currency weakness. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Bartholomew Gill, 58, Author of Irish Whodunits
description: Mark McGarrity, who wrote a popular series of richly detailed mystery novels set in Ireland under the pen name Bartholomew Gill, died in a fall late last Wednesday night or early last Thursday morning outside his home in Morristown, N.J. He was 58.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: UNITED PARCEL SHIPMENTS FELL, BUT IT MET ESTIMATES
description: United Parcel Service's shipments in the United States fell 2.6 percent in the second quarter as customers began shifting business to rivals in case there is a Teamsters union strike at United Parcel. The carrier will still earn the 50 cents to 55 cents a share it forecast earlier for the quarter, in line with the average analyst estimate, United Parcel said. United Parcel, based in Atlanta, may lose more business as it moves closer to a July 31 deadline to reach a contract with its 210,000 employees who are Teamsters. A 15-day Teamsters strike in 1997 cost United Parcel $750 million in revenue and snarled shipments across the country.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: E-Zpass Criminal Inquiry Is Sought
description: The Democratic members of the State Assembly Transportation Committee released a report yesterday that recommended an investigation into possible criminal wrongdoing in the running of the E-ZPass system. The report said that poor planning and inadequate financing had hurt the program and estimated that the state would have to pay more than $460 million between now and 2008 to pay off E-ZPass bonds.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Tuesday about New Yorkers' penchant for predatory pets misstated the identification of a snake breed in some copies. It was a garter snake, not Gardner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRITCHEY, MARY KNOWLES
description: FRITCHEY-Mary Knowles. On July 9, 2002, at her home in Washington D.C. Born June 28, 1912. Beloved wife to Frank Gardiner Wisner and later to Clayton Willis Fritchey. Mother to Frank, Ellis and Graham Wisner and to Elizabeth Hazard. She is also survived by seven grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. Valued friend to many in Washington, New York, and around the world. Board member or trustee at the Phillip's Collection, St. Timothy's School, The Shakespeare Theatre, All Hallows Guild of the Washington National Cathedral, The Women's Campaign Fund, Arts in Embassies, Anacostia Development Corp., Women's National Bank and first Chairwoman of the Kennedy Center. Memorial services will be held at the Bethleham Chapel of the National Cathedral on September 4, 2002 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Phillip's Collection, 1600 21st Street, N.W., Washington, DC 20009, or St. Timothy's School, 8400 Greenspring Avenue, Stevenson, MD. 21153, or the Shakespeare Theatre, 516 8th Street, S.E., Washington, D.C. 20003-2834.

title: Dhirajlal Ambani, 69, a Leading Entrepreneur in India, Dies
description: Dhirajlal Ambani, one of India's most successful entrepreneurs, who built up the Reliance Group into the country's largest industrial concern, died on Saturday in Bombay. He was 69.
