description: To the Editor:

title: JONES APPAREL TO BUY L.E.I. JEANS FOR $310 MILLION
description: The Jones Apparel Group, the maker of Jones New York clothing, said yesterday that it would buy the closely held RSV Sport, the maker of l.e.i. jeans for women and girls, for $310 million. RSV Sport will receive $272.5 million in cash and $37.5 million in stock, Jones Apparel said. Selling shareholders and some employees of RSV Sport could also receive as much as $70 million in cash or stock if certain profit targets are met. Jones, based in Bristol, Pa., will assume $75 million of debt. RSV Sport, based in Los Angeles, had $248 million in revenue last year. Mel Geliebter, the chief executive of RSV, will become chief executive of Jones' Sun Apparel private-label division.

title: Woman at Heart of Swiss Scandal Denies Affair With Envoy
description: The woman whose tales of risqu escapades with a top Swiss diplomat caused him to lose his post and stirred a fierce debate over the influence of the popular press has reignited the controversy by recanting her story, according to widespread reports.

title: Giuliani Marriage Ends With $6.8 Million Deal
description: After an acrimonious and very public 18-month divorce battle, the marriage of former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Donna Hanover, the television personality and actress, ended yesterday with a settlement that will bring Ms. Hanover $6.8 million tax free.

title: Critic's Notebook/London Summer, Alive With Art; Amid Big Events, Small Gems
description: London this summer is, as always, besotted by art in a way that only New York rivals. On a peak Saturday afternoon you may wander through the biggest museums in Germany and you'll come across about as many visitors as I did at a little gem of a Caspar David Friedrich show here at the Hermitage Rooms in Somerset House on a recent Thursday morning.

title: Japan Carves Out Major Role in China's Auto Future
description: In what may be the first big step toward China's emergence as a major source of automobiles, Honda Motor of Japan announced today that it would build the first car plant there dedicated to exports.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Another Sign Explodes
description: A man died and a woman was seriously wounded when a booby-trapped sign blew up in Baltiisk, a navy town in Kaliningrad, when the man tried to remove it. His death was the first in a string of such incidents since May, when a woman was wounded by explosives after pulling down a sign on a Moscow highway that read ''Death to Yids.'' Other signs also had anti-Semitic slogans, but the police said the Baltiisk sign had someone's name on it and an expletive. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a television commercial highlighting the Bush administration's links to companies involved in accounting investigations included one political strategist erroneously among those involved with American Family Voices, the group that produced it. James Carville said he had not participated.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: A.C.L.U. Faults Cable Providers
description: The American Civil Liberties Union said yesterday that cable providers had too much control over the Internet use of their subscribers. The group called on the federal government to ''protect the Internet from the power of monopolistic cable providers.'' In March, the Federal Communications Commission said it considered cable broadband to be an ''information service,'' and would not be subject to the same requirements as Internet service providers that deliver services over telephone lines. The agency is working to determine what rules should apply to cable broadband, officials said. The A.C.L.U. released two reports examining technical and policy issues concerning dial-up and cable Internet services. With dial-up Internet access, the telephone system provides open, equal access, the group said. But as consumers shift to cable, the A.C.L.U. said, Internet access may be subject to more centralized, perhaps private, control. The cable industry has vigorously resisted any regulation of its networks.

title: A Brooklyn Star Fails to Impress
description: From the time he was only in the seventh grade and rated one of the top point guards for his age in the country, Sebastian Telfair of Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn has had all eyes on him.

title: Assailing Corporate Scandals, McCain Offers Tough Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  With a biting indictment of "morally challenged executives," Senator John McCain put himself at the leading edge of the drive against corporate wrongdoing today, laying out proposals for broad new regulation of business that go far beyond those of President Bush and leading Democrats.

title: On a Slope of Dune, A Big Mixed Salad
description: LAST week, Mark Perlbinder, who stands 5 feet 5 inches tall without his socks, hopped as nimbly as a mountain goat onto the ledge of his vegetable garden, which is raised three feet off the ground.

title: Company Sends Letter to Retain Hormone Sales
description: Moving quickly to try to prevent women from stopping their hormone replacement treatments because of fear of breast cancer, the Wyeth company has sent 500,000 letters to doctors and other health care providers urging them to consider when they talk to patients the ''critical role'' that one of its products, Prempro, has in relieving the symptoms of menopause.

title: With By-the-Numbers Radio, Requests Are a Dying Breed
description: Few executives better reflect the changes in the music industry these days than Tom Poleman, program director for Z-100 (WHTZ-FM), the top pop radio station in New York City and one of 1,200 stations owned by the conglomerate Clear Channel Communications.

title: The Sleepless Nights Of a B-Movie Temptress
description: When Marian Seldes strikes a pose, it reverberates like a gong. Slouching in a slinky, well-worn nightgown with a plunging backline, Ms. Seldes keeps her face hidden for the opening moments of ''Play Yourself,'' the rambling but delightfully acted metaphysical soap opera by Harry Kondoleon that opened last night at the Century Center for the Performing Arts.

title: National Briefing | Mid-West: Ohio: New Drug Law
description: Nonviolent drug offenders may no longer face jail time if voters approve a constitutional amendment that would place such people in treatment, not prison cells, upon their first drug arrest. The Ohio Campaign for New Drug Policies is gathering signatures to put the issue on the November ballot. Gov. Bob Taft, a Republican, opposes the amendment, saying it would undermine law enforcement efforts to curb illegal drug use. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
description: MALL OWNERS END NET VENTURE Taubman Centers Inc., the Simon Property Group and three other United States mall owners will shut down a money-losing telecommunications and Internet services joint venture after failing to find a buyer. A sale of MerchantWired L.L.C. was not completed as planned and the venture will be discontinued, Taubman Centers said yesterday in a news release. A spokeswoman was not available for comment. Taubman, which invested about $6 million, said it expected to take a charge against second-quarter net income for the shutdown. Taubman shares fell 30 cents, to $14.50. MerchantWired, formed in 2000 to sell Internet-based services to mall tenants, lost $25 million last year as too few retailers adopted the technology in a slowing economy. Simon Property, the lead investor, told shareholders in April that a sale of the venture was "in the final stages." Simon, Taubman and the other partners put about $60 million into MerchantWired. The other members of the venture were the Macerich Company , the Rouse Company and Westfield America Inc. (Bloomberg News)

title: Canadians Stick to Bid for AurionGold of Australia
description: Still smarting from two humbling adventures in North and South America, Placer Dome Inc. of Canada has turned to Australia in a bid to salvage its reputation and remain in the top ranks of the world's gold producers.

title: Belgian Cyclist Drops Out of Tour de France
description: ROUEN, France, July 11  Tom Steels put himself out of his misery and out of the Tour de France today, gliding to the side of the road in the feeding zone halfway through the stage and getting off his bicycle.

title: When Art Nouveau Flowered in Budapest
description: The buildings of Budapest glitter with Art Nouveau ornaments by the Zsolnay company, a Hungarian ceramics maker. In its heyday, around 1900, Zsolnay (pronounced ZHAWL-noy) offered thousands of architectural details, including vine-laced balconies and roof tiles (for the zoo, below). It also exported smaller objects like vases in biomorphic shapes, above, or painted with gauzy landscapes.

title: HOUSE PASSES BILL PERMITTING PILOTS TO CARRY FIREARMS
description: The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to let airline pilots carry guns in their cockpits, a move that the new Transportation Security Administration said six weeks ago it would not allow.

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: IRAN: SENIOR AYATOLLAH QUITS IN PROTEST A prominent senior cleric, Ayatollah Jalaledin Taheri, announced his resignation as the leader of Friday Prayer in Isfahan. In an open letter of protest against the hard-line policies of the supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, he blamed the ayatollah for what he called the betrayal of the revolution's promises. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Staples Selects Martin/Williams
description: Staples, the office-supply retail chain, said yesterday that it had selected Martin/Williams Advertising in Minneapolis to handle its broadcast creative account. Billings were estimated at $50 million to $70 million.

title: Watchdog Group Is Suing Cheney And Halliburton
description: A public interest group best known for its litigation efforts against President Bill Clinton filed a lawsuit today accusing Vice President Cheney and the company he ran for five years, the Halliburton Company, of engaging in accounting fraud.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: A.C.L.U. FAULTS CABLE PROVIDERS The American Civil Liberties Union said yesterday that cable providers had too much control over the Internet use of their subscribers. The group called on the federal government to "protect the Internet from the power of monopolistic cable providers." In March, the Federal Communications Commission said it considered cable broadband to be an "information service," and would not be subject to the same requirements as Internet service providers that deliver services over telephone lines. The agency is working to determine what rules should apply to cable broadband, officials said. The A.C.L.U. released two reports examining technical and policy issues concerning dial-up and cable Internet services. With dial-up Internet access, the telephone system provides open, equal access, the group said. But as consumers shift to cable, the A.C.L.U. said, Internet access may be subject to more centralized, perhaps private, control. The cable industry has vigorously resisted any regulation of its networks. (NYT)

title: A Celebration of L.A.'s Valley As Archetype of the Suburb
description: In November, Los Angeles voters will decide whether the San Fernando Valley, that vast expanse of suburbia known simply as the Valley, should be permitted to secede from the rest of the city. The Web site AmericasSuburb.com is both a primer on this fervently debated issue and a celebration of the valley itself.

title: Hormone Therapy Woes
description: The news keeps getting worse about the value of hormone replacement therapies for postmenopausal women. Less than three months ago an international panel concluded that there was little evidence to support many of the presumed benefits of the treatments. Now federal health officials have halted a large study of hormone replacement therapy because the regimen used, a combination of estrogen and progestin, was doing more harm than good when taken for several years. The action has been met with shock and disbelief by many women and their doctors.

title: Bush's Bioethics Advisory Panel Recommends a Moratorium, Not a Ban, on Cloning Research
description: Cloning for biomedical research should not be banned outright, but rather prohibited during a four-year moratorium that would allow time for more public debate, according to a long-awaited report by President Bush's bioethics advisers.

title: CALENDAR
description: Folk Art Highlights

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Trailer Falls 60 Feet
description: A tractor-trailer traveling on a slick section of Interstate 95 yesterday morning crashed through a guard rail and a concrete wall and caught fire, then fell more than 60 feet into the West River below, the state police said. The driver, whose name was not immediately released, escaped. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: On the Street, It's 1997
description: The worst bear market in a generation deepened yesterday as shares fell sharply, leaving two indexes at their lowest levels since 1997. The bear market, an investor said ''has started to take on a life of its own.'' The technology-heavy Nasdaq has now lost three-quarters of its value.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Software Profit Rises
description: India's second-largest software exporter, the NASDAQ-listed Infosys Technologies, said its first-quarter profit rose 14 percent from the period a year earlier. The company's results reflected volume growth. Infosys's chief executive, Nandan Nilekani, left, said in a statement, ''We continue to remain cautious due to delays in client and prospect visits arising from adverse travel advisories and due to a challenging global business environment.'' Infosys builds software for several top American companies. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Multiplayer Servers Provide Portals to Far-Flung Fun
description: FOR Captain Lint and Shinny Skins, it's now or never. These two players of the game EverQuest are facing some of this digital world's most formidable beasts: a monstrous gang of Crushbone Orcs. So Captain Lint unleashes fire bolts, while Shinny Skins moves in with a splintering club.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Wal-Mart Closings
description: Wal-Mart Stores plans to close two stores in Germany, the first since the retail company entered the nation, Europe's biggest consumer market, in 1997. A store in Ingolstadt will be shut this year and two stores in Wilhelmshaven will be merged into one. The company does not release earnings figures for its 95 German operations, but analysts say they have been losing money from the start. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Argentina Charges Ex-Dictator and Others in 'Dirty War' Deaths
description: An investigative judge today ordered the arrest of Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri, Argentina's former military dictator, and more than 30 other military officers on charges that they abused human rights during the ''dirty war'' against leftists here more than 20 years ago.

Proud grandmother of Gilad, Hannah, Leetol and Jake. Daughter of Arthur Kessler. Sister of Melvin Kessler. She was a quality & gifted teacher and a consummate parent, wife and friend whose love and kindness was always present. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 11:30 A.M. Friday.

title: Boeing Is Combining Its Satellite and Military Businesses
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it was combining its space and communications business with its military manufacturing unit to form a single division, allowing the company to streamline operations and better compete for contracts.

title: Now, the Synchronized Family
description: WAS a mutiny afoot in the Tanner family when 15-year-old Melissa began deleting appointments from her father's datebook? No, explained John Tanner, Melissa's father. The Tanners, who live in Pasadena, Calif., had recently begun using a shared calendar program for the Palm computers that he, his wife and Melissa use.

title: The View From Wall Street, and Main Street
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Law Imperils Colombia Coca Spraying
description: Even as the Bush administration is trying to increase the aerial spraying of drug crops in Colombia with herbicides, an American law enacted in January threatens to disrupt the strategy and possibly even halt it.

title: An Affinity of Reputations In Both Cards and Business
description: Throughout bridge history there have been enthusiasts with big reputations in the corporate and financial worlds. First there was Charles Schwab of Bethlehem Steel, who in 1933 presented the Schwab Cup for international competition, now awarded to the winners of the World Pairs. Second came Ira G. Corn Jr., chief executive of Michigan General, a major conglomerate, and founder of the Aces team, which won several world team titles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLIS, JAMES TUREAUD
description: WALLIS-James Tureaud. On July 6, 2002 in Scarborough, Maine after a long illness. Brother of George R., John & Robert C. Memorial service Friday July 19 at 4 PM at St. Mary's Episcopal Church, Northeast Harbor, Maine. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Maine Coast Heritage Trust, 1 Main Street, Topsham, Maine 04086

title: Can or Bottle, Bill Wants Makers to Pay For Recycling
description: The first Congressional hearings on recycling in at least a decade begin today as environmental advocates in the Senate push to hold the beverage industry, not states, cities or consumers, responsible for salvaging the billions of bottles and cans thrown away every year.

title: Bush Calls for End to Loans Of a Type He Once Received
description: President Bush received two low-interest loans to buy stock from an oil company where he served as a board member in the late 1980's. He then benefited from the company's relaxation of the terms of one loan in 1989 as he was engaged in the most important business deal of his career.

title: 71 Obtained Fraudulent Visas at American Embassy in Qatar
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  An investigation by the State Department has found that 71 people obtained fraudulent visas from the United States Embassy in Qatar in 2000 and 2001, in some cases in exchange for bribes of more than $10,000, Bush administration officials said today.

title: FLORIDA DROPS 2 INQUIRIES ON ECKERD, COMPANY SAYS
description: The Eckerd drugstore chain said yesterday that Florida had ended two investigations of the company, one into its handling of customers' medical information and one into its prescription drug pricing. One inquiry centered on whether the company had adequately informed customers that they were authorizing the release of information for marketing purposes by signing prescription pickup forms, the Florida attorney general, Bob Butterworth, said. The company, based in Clearwater, Fla., did not admit any wrongdoing but changed its handling of the forms. The attorney general also dropped an investigation of claims that Eckerd had overcharged customers for prescriptions, the company said. Some consumers accused Eckerd of rounding up the quantity of medicine on labels, then charging for the higher amount. Eckerd, a unit of the J. C. Penney Company, said its handling of the medicine followed approved industry standards.

title: Mobile Home Owners Remain House Hungry
description: On a muggy afternoon, James Gandy, 38, cleared debris from the installation of his new $55,000 Fleetwood double-wide mobile home. He has a side-by-side refrigerator; wood-burning fireplace; two bathrooms, with his-and-her sinks; and a game room with a pool table and a wet bar. Mr. Gandy, who is divorced and is a sales manager for a company nearly an hour away in Brunswick, lives there with his two teenage sons.

title: The View From Wall Street, and Main Street
description: To the Editor:

title: The View From Wall Street, and Main Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Reading Scores Drop Sharply In 8th Grade
description: The proportion of New York State middle-school students passing the state's reading and writing test dropped strikingly this year, falling well below the levels of four years ago, except in the most affluent suburban school districts.

title: Jury Studies Ex-Officer's Version Of Who Led Louima to Restroom
description: The jury in the retrial of former Police Officer Charles Schwarz in the Abner Louima torture case deliberated for a second day yesterday without reaching a verdict.

title: U.S. Deports Most of Those Arrested in Sweeps After 9/11
description: As legal challenges to its policy of secret detentions advance slowly through the courts, the government has managed to deport most of the Sept. 11 detainees at the center of the lawsuits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEPSON, HANS G., COLONEL
description: JEPSON-Hans G., Colonel, U.S. Army, Retired, at age 94. On Tuesday, July 9, 2002 at Mt. Vernon Hospital. Beloved husband of Juanita I. Jepson. Father of Hans G. Jepson II of New York City. Brother of Norma T. Bartlett of Tacoma, WA. Father-in-law of Barbara G. Jepson of New York City. Interment will be at Arlington National Cemetery. Contributions to Word of Life Assembly of God, 5225 Backlick Road, Springfield, VA 22151.

title: Fat Forward
description: Weekly highlights from 150 forums  from remembering Ted Williams to the discussion on fat vs. carbs.

title: An Obsessive Detective With Compulsive Traits
description: Tony Shalhoub is not the only reason to watch ''Monk,'' a smart new detective series on USA, but the intriguing character he and the show's writers have created might have been enough.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Term Limit For Imprisoned Politician
description: A parole board ruled that Aryeh Deri, the former leader of the strictly Orthodox Shas party who has been serving a three-year jail term for corruption, can go free on Monday. The board took a year off Mr. Deri's sentence, citing good behavior, but barred him from politics until September 2003. For years an influential power broker who could make or break government coalitions, Mr. Deri told reporters that he would devote himself to public service ''to help those on the margins of society.'' Joel Greenberg (NYT)

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Shoofly in Name Only

title: Two People Are Arrested In Boy's Killing in Brooklyn
description: A 20-year-old woman and an 18-year-old man were arrested in the killing of a 13-year-old boy whose stabbed and bludgeoned corpse was found Monday night in a squatters' building in Brooklyn, the police said early today.

title: Papier-Mch Gets a Real Job
description: Pulp Stools, made of molded recycled paper, provide comfortable summer seating, convenient for a backyard barbecue, a beach party or an outdoor concert -- unless it rains. The stools are by Eric Janssen, a New York designer known for using ordinary materials. They are lightweight, easy to carry and stackable, supporting up to 400 pounds. They are 18 inches high, come in cardboard gray only and cost $40 each at the MoMA Design Store, 44 West 53rd Street and 81 Spring Street (at Crosby Street) or www.momastore.org. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: N.B.A. and AOL Drop Plan For an All-Sports Network
description: The National Basketball Association has decided not to start an all-sports network with AOL Time Warner. Instead, AOL Time Warner will pay $45 million for a 10 percent stake in NBA TV, the league's existing digital cable channel.

title: Shaggy, or Not So Shaggy
description: In hot equatorial climates that are within 1,000 feet of sea level, lions often have hardly any mane at all. By contrast, lions at higher elevations and in colder climates have full, thick manes. At middle elevations, mane size tended to be intermediate, resembling Christmas wreaths extending from cheeks to shoulders.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Welcome

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 2nd Suspect In Officer's Shooting
description: Detectives in Brooklyn have arrested a second suspect in connection with the shooting of an off-duty New York city correction officer, the police said yesterday. On Tuesday, the police arrested Kamal Reese, 16, of Brooklyn on charges of attempted murder, weapons possession and other crimes. The officer, Carlos Engleton, 37, was shot in the stomach on Sunday in front of Linden Park in East New York during an argument after a soccer game. Officer Engleton argued with a group of men and several attacked him, the police said. On Monday, Ronell Peterkin of Brooklyn was arrested in the shooting. It was not immediately clear what roles Mr. Peterkin and Mr. Reese are suspected of playing. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: A 'Mouse' for Organizers Makes the Stylus Dispensable
description: With more than 10 million hand-held computers sold each year, it is only reasonable to suppose that plenty of users never master Graffiti -- the Palm operating system's handwriting recognition program -- and that many enter information solely by synchronizing the organizer with a computer. What if some of those people want a mouse, not a stylus?

title: Sports of The Times; This Ship Needs to Find A Lifeguard
description: BASEBALL is the Titanic.

title: A Multifaceted Machine Handles (Nearly) Everything
description: Looking for a digital music appliance that will do everything short of teaching you to play guitar? The FireBall, from Escient, can recognize and organize thousands of CD's, hundreds of MP3 files and dozens of Internet and satellite radio stations.

title: Monroe Wall, 85, Discoverer Of Drugs That Fight Cancer
description: Dr. Monroe E. Wall, a chemist who helped discover the cancer drugs Taxol and camptothecin, died on Saturday at a hospital in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 85.

title: Frustrated, Bud? There Are Ways to Avoid a Repeat
description: As Commissioner Bud Selig searched for a solution that would help him end the All-Star Game on Tuesday night in any manner but a dreadful tie, he raised his hands above his shoulders in exasperation. He looked like a driver who put his foot on the brakes of a rusted economy car, but was still propelled into his neighbor's new luxury sedan. What should I do now?

title: Sept. 11 Tape Heard in Secret In Fire Inquiry
description: Amid concern about the scope and depth of an inquiry by the Fire Department into its Sept. 11 response, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that fire officials would immediately listen to taped radio transmissions among firefighters at the World Trade Center that were discovered five or six months ago but never played.

title: Senate Backs Tough Measures To Punish Corporate Misdeeds
description: The Senate endorsed broad new criminal penalties today for corporate officers who cheat investors or harm employee pensions, highlighted by a penalty of up to 10 years in prison for executives who recklessly or willfully allow their companies to publish misleading financial statements.

title: The Wrong Target
description: Sari Nusseibeh seems an odd focus for Israeli anger. Dr. Nusseibeh, the Palestinian Authority's representative in Jerusalem, is the leading voice of moderation within mainstream Palestinian politics. In a breathtakingly wrongheaded move, Israel shut down his office at Al-Quds University on Tuesday. Prime Minister Ariel Sharon should limit the damage by quickly reversing the decision.

title: Change in Leadership at Marks & Spencer
description: Luc Vandevelde, a Belgian executive who is credited with turning around Marks & Spencer, the British retailer, said today that he would step aside as chief executive in favor of his protg, Roger Holmes. The company also reported its fourth consecutive increase in quarterly sales today.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: EMC And Accenture Team Up On Storage Networks
description: The EMC Corporation, the world's largest maker of computer data-storage systems, said yesterday that it would team up with Accenture to sell corporate-consulting services for storage networks. Financial terms of the five-year agreement were not disclosed. The companies will form a business unit under the direction of EMC's global-services organization. Accenture, the world's largest computer consultant, will provide consulting and management expertise, the companies said in a statement.

title: Police Hunt For Suspect In Killing Of Sister
description: The police said yesterday that they were looking for a man suspected of killing his sister and then disappearing with his former girlfriend, whose life may be in danger.

title: The Star of Elm Street Stages a Comeback
description: ROGER W. HOLLOWAY approaches elm trees with a proselytizer's prose and a planter's gentle hand. His green thumb comes from the five generations of gardeners in his family who have run the Michler Florist and Greenhouse in Lexington, Ky., where he was born. His reverence for trees was instilled in him when his family moved to Ontario in the 1960's to run a tobacco farm. That was when he first saw elms disappear.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on June 16 about climate change in Alaska misstated the rise in temperatures there in the last 30 years. (The error was repeated in an editorial on Monday and in the Bob Herbert column on the Op-Ed page of June 24.) According to an assessment by the University of Alaska's Center for Global Change and Arctic System Research, the annual mean temperature has risen 5.4 degrees Fahrenheit over 30 years, not 7 degrees.

title: Lessons From '92 Keep an Angry City Calm
description: James Hicks, wearing a Malcolm X T-shirt and carrying a ''Power to the People'' placard, said he was outraged by a videotape showing a white police officer here beating a handcuffed black teenager, and he warned that the community might explode if the officer was not punished.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Leisure on Sunday about the Portuguese fado singer Msia, and a Pop/Jazz listing in the section, misstated the time of her concert this Saturday at the Society for Ethical Culture in Manhattan. It is 8 p.m., not 7.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Man Sentenced For 3 Murders
description: A man convicted of three murders more than a decade after they took place after DNA evidence linked him to the crime scenes was sentenced to 75 years to life yesterday. The man, Patrick Baxter, 33, was convicted of the murders of three Westchester women who were also sexually assaulted and robbed, in 1987, 1988 and 1990. Mr. Baxter was ordered to serve three 25-year sentences consecutively in state prison before becoming eligible for parole. His lawyer, Robert Tendy, said he would appeal the jury's verdict. Relatives of the victims who were in the courtroom for the sentencing said justice had been done, according to David Hebert, a spokesman for the Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro.

title: Torre's New Math Problem: Divide 6 Starters Into 5 Spots
description: What do you get for the team that has everything? That is what Brian Cashman is asking himself as the Yankees begin the second half of their season in Cleveland tonight. He thinks he has the answer: nothing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALAMARI, JOSEPH
description: CALAMARI-Joseph. Loving brother of Andrew & Teresa Ugolino. Dear brother-in-law of Madeline Calamari and Alfred Ugolino. Survived by many nieces and nephews. Reposing at Farenga Bros. Funeral Home, 920 Allerton Avenue, Bronx, NY, Saturday 2-5 PM, on Sunday 2-5 and 79:30 PM. Mass of Christian burial on Monday 10 A.M. at St. Lucy's Church.

title: A Gadget King Lives By His Own Devices
description: JANE AUSTEN wrote, ''It is a truth universally acknowledged that a single man in possession of a good fortune must be in want of a wife.'' Perhaps so. But these days, the chances are that he is also in want of some nifty gizmos and gadgets.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Mall Owners End Net Venture
description: Taubman Centers Inc., the Simon Property Group and three other United States mall owners will shut down a money-losing telecommunications and Internet services joint venture after failing to find a buyer. A sale of MerchantWired L.L.C. was not completed as planned and the venture will be discontinued, Taubman Centers said yesterday in a news release. A spokeswoman was not available for comment. Taubman, which invested about $6 million, said it expected to take a charge against second-quarter net income for the shutdown. Taubman shares fell 30 cents, to $14.50. MerchantWired, formed in 2000 to sell Internet-based services to mall tenants, lost $25 million last year as too few retailers adopted the technology in a slowing economy. Simon Property, the lead investor, told shareholders in April that a sale of the venture was ''in the final stages.'' Simon, Taubman and the other partners put about $60 million into MerchantWired. The other members of the venture were the Macerich Company, the Rouse Company and Westfield America Inc.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Beefing Up the Police
description: The new interior minister, Nicolas Sarkozy, who has a broad mandate to crack down on the country's rising crime rate, said he wants to hire 18,000 more police officers. Police budgets would eventually triple under his bill, new stations would be built in high-crime suburbs and retired officers would serve in a reserve. The police would have new powers to seize assets and would carry rubber-bullet stun-guns as well as service pistols. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

title: Freezing Time; Michael Jackson
description: Those of us who are accustomed to seeing Michael Jackson arm in arm with Elizabeth Taylor and Liza Minnelli were understandably surprised to see him hobnobbing with one of the non-glitterati, the Rev. Al Sharpton, in Harlem last week. Mr. Jackson's sojourn into the black community was part of his campaign of blaming Sony Records for the disappointing sales that have hobbled his most recent record, ''Invincible,'' which has proven to be anything but.

title: An advertising forecaster revises his predictions for 2002 downward, pricking a bubble of hope.
description: THE media executive widely deemed the dean of ad-spending forecasters yesterday deflated some of the growing optimism about a recovery this year.

title: Council Introduces Bill to Alter Unequal Part of Term-Limit Law
description: The City Council took its first official step yesterday toward rewriting a term limits law that has been approved twice by voters, with the introduction of a bill sponsored by 46 of its 51 members, including the speaker, Gifford Miller.

title: Report Disputes Bush Approach to Bridging 'Digital Divide'
description: Earlier this year, the Bush administration announced good news: The ''digital divide'' between those who had access to computer and Internet technology and those who did not was narrowing. Then it proposed deleting two major programs that were designed in part to bridge the divide.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Panel Asserts Reduced Space Station Plans Will Limit Scientific Work
description: If the International Space Station is to be considered a scientific project that produces first-rate research, it will have to grow beyond current plans, which reduced its original size and scope, a review panel said today.

title: Police Make Their Case For Arrest of Iverson
description: The Philadelphia police said today that they were confident they had presented enough evidence in a three-and-a-half-hour meeting with a panel of city prosecutors to have criminal charges filed against Allen Iverson.

title: Study Finds Steady Overruns in Public Projects
description: Cost overruns for large public works projects have stayed largely constant for most of the last century, according to a study of 258 projects published this week in The Journal of the American Planning Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOCTOROFF, MARTIN M.
description: DOCTOROFF - Martin M. The officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the passing of Martin M. Doctoroff, a prominent appeals court judge in Michigan. We extend our sincerest condolences to his son, Daniel L. Doctoroff, a leader in the Jewish community, and his wife Alisa, who is a member of our board and our Commission on Jewish Identity and Renewal. Dan & Alisa have demonstrated their concern and caring for Jewish learning and are generous supporters of UJA-Federation and its beneficiary agencies. Mr. Doctoroff's legacy lives on through his family's extraordinary contributions to the Jewish community. We also express our sympathy to Mr. Doctoroff's sons Mark, Andrew and Thomas, and the entire Doctoroff family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Executive V.P. and CEO

title: The Essence of Brevity: S.M.S. Text Messages
description: Q. What is the difference between S.M.S. messages and the regular e-mail messages that you can send to people's cellphones with America Online and other companies?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DITON, BECKER, IVY SUE
description: DITON-BECKER-Ivy Sue, on July 8, 2002, at the age of 41. Ivy was the principal of W.T. Clarke Middle School, East Meadow, NY, founder of the NY Metropolitan Service Learning Institute, founding Board member of the National Service Learning Partnership, lead panelist for the Presidential Initiative on Education, advisor and staff developer for the National Helpers Network Inc. and chairperson of the East Meadow School District Alternative Committee on Education. Beloved wife of Paul Becker. Loving daughter of Roy and Helen Diton. Dear sister of Jeff Diton and sister-in-law of Liz Diton. Cherished aunt of Rob and Matt Diton. Reposing at Park Funeral Chapels, 2175 Jericho Tpk., Garden City Park, NY, Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Services will be offered Thursday, 8pm. There will be a private committal service Friday at Fresh Pond Crematory. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the W.T. Clarke Middle School, East Meadow S.D., 740 Edgewood Dr., Westbury NY 11590.

title: 71 Obtained Fraudulent Visas At American Embassy in Qatar
description: An investigation by the State Department has found that 71 people obtained fraudulent visas from the United States Embassy in Qatar in 2000 and 2001, in some cases in exchange for bribes of more than $10,000, Bush administration officials said today.

title: Selig Says It's Unfortunate But He Had No Choice
description: The chants of ''Let them play!'' had not been so prominent since the Bad News Bears frolicked around the Astrodome in a cute movie 25 years ago. It was funny then, but it was an angry, frustrating chant at an All-Star Game that ended in a tie Tuesday night in Milwaukee.

title: A Rubens Brings $76.7 Million at London Auction
description: A recently rediscovered Rubens that had been hanging in the dark hallway of a monastery in Austria sold at Sotheby's in London last night for $76.7 million, the third-highest price ever paid for a painting at auction and the highest auction price ever for an old master painting.

title: Revisiting the Death Penalty and School Vouchers
description: Q. For many years, the standard for submitting papers to the Supreme Court was the same standard applied to the other federal courts: 8 1/2 by 11 inches. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist changed this requirement for the U.S. Supreme Court to 8 1/2 by 13 inches. Do you know what was the rationale for such a dramatic change?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, EARLE
description: BROWN-Earle. The Directors and staff of the Foundation for Contemporary Performance Arts, Inc., mourn the loss of Earle Brown, who received a grant for his music the first year of the organization's operations in 1963, and was awarded The John Cage Award for Music in 1998. He was a much-admired friend. Our sympathies to his wife, Susan Sollins, and the family.

title: Ritz Times Two
description: Two new Ritz-Carltons have discounted pricing. The 277-room Ritz-Carlton New York, which opened April 29 on Central Park South, has two-night packages that include a choice of a one-hour massage or a facial at its La Prairie spa. Rates per night, double, are $395 to $595 (plus tax and tip), a 40 percent discount. Through Sept. 18, the 295-room Ritz-Carlton in Naples, Fla., which opened in January, is offering a golf package for $159 with a night's accommodations and two rounds on the adjacent Greg Norman-designed Tiburon golf course. The regular greens fees would be about $80 a person in the morning, and the room rate separately would be $139. This Ritz-Carlton joins the existing one in Naples; the new one  three miles from the Gulf  is called the Ritz-Carlton Golf Resort; (800) 241-3333 or www.ritzcarlton.com .

title: Caucus Seeks More Aid for Black Farmers
description: The Congressional Black Caucus demanded today that the secretary of agriculture do more to promote the civil rights of black farmers and ensure that they receive agriculture loans as easily as other farmers.

title: Sitting Pretty for a Lot Less
description: J. Robert Scott, who is usually a furniture maker for decorators only, has a new line, Scott Classics, available to the public. The line, of sofas and club chairs, offers the same quality as Scott custom-made pieces, but with fewer options and lower prices. There is still a choice of 100 upholstery fabrics, including silks and wools. The 72-inch-long Jeffry sofa, left, is $1,960 (similar custom pieces start at $3,240). Sofas that are 90 inches long are $2,850 and $3,160. Scott Classics can be ordered through 15 showrooms, with one at 979 Third Avenue; for information on others:www.jrobertscott

title: Taking a Look Around the Future
description: The winners of the third National Design Awards will not be named until Oct. 22, but the finalists were announced yesterday in Washington. They reflect ''a move away from the theoretical to the real,'' said Richard Gluckman, a juror. The competition, sponsored by the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum of the Smithsonian Institution, seeks out fresh ideas in architecture, communications and commercial design. One finalist is SHoP/Sharples Holden Pasquarelli, a New York architectural firm, whose design for the Museum of Sex in Manhattan, not yet built, has a skin of translucent undulating layers. Reed Krakoff, a juror, said of the firm's carousel building in Greenport, N.Y., above, ''They took something rooted in traditional architecture and with glass made it new again.'' The firm's partners (inset, from left) are William Sharples, Coren Sharples, Christopher Sharples, Gregg Pasquarelli and Kimberly Holden. Steven Holl of Manhattan and Rick Joy of Tucson, Ariz., are also finalists.

title: The Death of bin Ladenism
description: Osama bin Laden is dead. The news first came from sources in Afghanistan and Pakistan almost six months ago: the fugitive died in December and was buried in the mountains of southeast Afghanistan. Pakistan's president, Pervez Musharraf, echoed the information. The remnants of Osama's gang, however, have mostly stayed silent, either to keep Osama's ghost alive or because they have no means of communication.

title: Seizing The Throne Of Good Taste
description: CHRISTMAS can be a rough season, and Chris Lehrecke, a 44-year-old furniture designer, sledded into blackness six years ago at Troy, an expensive home furnishings store in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SORIA, DORLE
description: SORIA-Dorle. The Board and Staff of The Metropolitan Opera Guild are deeply saddened by the death of Dorle Soria. As a press representative, writer, and recording executive, Dorle was a keen participant in the musical life of New York. The wife of our late Managing Director, Dario Soria, she was a friend and valued counselor to The Guild, whose members extend their sincere condolences to her family. Winthrop Rutherfurd, Jr, Chairman Susan S. Braddock, President Rudolph S. Rauch, Managing Director

title: U.S. Grants Initial Backing To US Airways For Guarantee
description: The federal government gave conditional support yesterday to a $900 million loan guarantee that US Airways is seeking for $1 billion in private financing. The guarantee is only the second granted to a carrier after the Sept. 11 attacks severely damaged the industry, and it is the larger one.

title: Criticizing Islam
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Mid-West: Michigan: Higher Cigarette Tax
description: The State Senate approved a 50-cent increase in the state's cigarette tax to help cover an anticipated $700 million budget shortfall for this year and next. The House has already approved the measure, and Gov. John Engler is expected to sign it. The tax increase, which would take effect on Aug. 1, is part of a compromise between Democrats and Republicans that prevents severe cuts to programs like community health. Jeremy W. Peters (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAYZEL, RUTH
description: GRAYZEL-Ruth. On July 9, 2002. A painter's eye, a witty mind, an ethical heart. Widow of Harold; mother of Rhoda and John; grandmother of Harold, Roland & Anna; mother-in-law of Richard & Mary; sister of Pearl, David & Martha. Services Sunday July 14, 11 AM, Plaza Jewish Chapel, 91st & Amsterdam, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLAZER, WILFRED
description: GLAZER-Wilfred. The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member, and extend their heartfelt sympathy to the family. Kenneth R. Orr, President

title: The View From Wall Street, and Main Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Mideast Strife Loudly Echoed in Academia
description: For most of the decade they have known each other, Mona Baker and Miriam Shlesinger have parked their political differences at scholarship's door. Professor Baker, an Egyptian-born professor in Manchester, England, believes Israel is a scar on the map of the Arab world. Professor Shlesinger, an Israeli who teaches at Bar Ilan University in Tel Aviv, has fought for Palestinian rights but believes in her country's right to exist.

title: MUNICH RE PUTS $2 BILLION MORE INTO ITS AMERICAN RE UNIT
description: The world's largest reinsurer, Munich Re, said yesterday that it had put $2 billion into its unprofitable American Re unit, the second time in eight months that it has had to shore up the business. American Re, which has lost money for three consecutive years, is in the ''deep red,'' Munich Re's chief financial officer, Jrg Schneider, said on a conference call with reporters. The parent company also set aside $500 million for potential losses from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and said that it saw no need to put more cash into the American unit. Munich Re put $1 billion into American Re in November.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINSTON, JOHN J.
description: WINSTON-John J., 71 years old. Owner of the Charles J. Winston Co., died Wednesday, July 10, after a courageous battle with cancer. He is survived by his devoted wife Carol, his cherished daughter Nicole, his loving brothers and sister, Jerry, Richard and Carol. He was greatly loved and will be deeply missed. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street, Thursday, July 11, 7-9 P.M. Service Friday, July 12, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Cabrini Medical Center, or a charity of your choice.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Here we are doing all this surgery on people and it's all a sham.''

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Ideas, Fanciful to Desperate, for Tons of Trash
description: One proposal calls for using mammoth semi-submersible ships, like the one that brought the destroyer Cole back from the Gulf of Aden after it was attacked, to ship thousands of tons of New York City's garbage to out-of-state landfills.

title: The View From Wall Street, and Main Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Houston Says Team Still Needs A Big Man
description: Allan Houston has endured many nights of looking at his undersized teammates and wondering what life would be like with a true center. Like many of the Knicks, Houston was encouraged by the team's draft-day acquisition of power forward Antonio McDyess from Denver.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Cuts By Foreign Employers
description: The number of people in Ireland working for international employers fell last year for the first time in a decade, because of the global slowdown in the information technologies sector, according to the Industrial Development Authority. Overseas companies supported by the authority created 13,500 jobs in 2001 and cut 17,500 jobs. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: European Union to Tackle Overhaul of Farm Subsidies
description: The European Commission today approved proposals to overhaul a 40-year-old system of farm subsidies that eats up nearly 45 percent of its budget, but the plan faces strong opposition from France, the system's leading beneficiary.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on June 16 about climate change in Alaska misstated the rise in temperatures there in the last 30 years. (The error was repeated in an editorial on Monday and in the Bob Herbert column on the Op-Ed page of June 24.) According to an assessment by the University of Alaska's Center for Global Change and Arctic System Research, the annual mean temperature has risen 5.4 degrees Fahrenheit over 30 years, not 7 degrees.

title: Dance This Dress Around
Behind the Scenes of 'Metropolis'
The Story of Civilization, A Hands-On Folk Art
Accountable Terms
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: How a Clear Strategy Got Muddy Results
description: When President Bush went to Wall Street on Tuesday to promise a crackdown on executives who cook the books, the White House had a clear strategy: The President would use the authoritative voice he honed after Sept. 11 to calm another sort of fear and keep Congress from overreacting.

title: Refighting the Fires of Sept. 11
description: One way to honor the city firefighters who died on Sept. 11 is to make sure the kind of catastrophic losses suffered at the World Trade Center never happen again. In that spirit, New York City's fire commissioner, Nicholas Scoppetta, deserves credit for launching an independent review of the Fire Department's performance on the day the towers collapsed. The report, due in August, will undoubtedly elaborate on some of the deadly lapses in command, communication and control that have been outlined this week by reporters for The Times.

title: Corning by the Book: Utopian or Orwellian?
description: People in other cities may all be reading the same book, but here they are living the same life. And what a charmed life it is: free from nagging, threatening, blaming, criticizing, complaining, bribing -- and full of loving, encouraging, accepting and negotiating.

It is not intended to determine the future border between Israel and the Palestinian Authority.

description: The Bush administration plan to clean up highly radioactive military wastes more quickly may actually be an effort to reduce the government's work sharply, two senators and the attorney general of Washington State said today at a Senate hearing.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Novelist Faces Pornography Charge
description: Moscow investigators have charged Vladimir Sorokin, a popular post-modernist writer, with pornography over a 1999 novel that depicts a homosexual act between clones of Stalin and Khrushchev. A youth group that supports President Vladimir V. Putin filed a criminal complaint after demonstrating last month against the novel, ''Goluboye Salo,'' whose title can be translated as ''Blue Lard'' or ''Gay Pork Fat.'' Free-speech advocates expressed alarm and a government official said the charge was misguided. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

description: Most auto executives say that they know what makes a good site for an auto assembly plant: plenty of land and labor, superb road and rail links and lots of high-volume auto parts suppliers nearby.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on July 5 about women who devote their adulthood largely to careers but take time out while their children are young misstated the background of Susan De Ritis of Family and Home Network, a group that supports parents who cut back employment to spend more time caring for their children. While she was an early volunteer in the organization, she was not a founder. Before leaving her job, she worked in the library at the Smithsonian Institution and was a volunteer tour guide; she was not an art expert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASSER, SIDNEY
description: GLASSER-Sidney. In his 90th year, on July 11, of complications developed during hospitalization for an injury. Born on March 9, 1913 on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, he had a long and productive career in the glass industry, primarily as a labor activist. As chief executive of Local 1087 of the Glaziers' Union in NYC, he instituted a broad and progressive benefits program and initiated one of the first apprenticeship training programs for racial minorities in the construction trades. In his mid-60's, after retiring from the union, he became president of the Knickerbocker Plate Glass Corp., and developed the business into one of the largest plate glass replacement companies in NY, continuing in an active management role until his death. During this period he was also a Trustee of the Pension Fund of the International Union of Painters and Allied Trades, a position he also retained until his death. He is survived by his wife Anne, with whom he recently and lovingly celebrated their 65th wedding anniversary, his son Ira and daughter Cora, his favorite daughter - in - law Trude, son-in-law Al, six grandchildren, David, Andy, Peter, Mark, Sally and Jud, their partners and spouses, Cathy, Gloria, Rachel, Julie, Michael and Susan, and nine great-grandchildren, Ashley, Shelby, Corey, Rachel, Aiden, Nealie, William, Hannah Rose and Jack. He leaves them all with a legacy of generosity, shrewdness, humor, toughness and devotion. He made the most of what little was given to him and as one of his grandchildren said, he had a lot to be proud of at the end. Services will be at 1 PM today at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York, 718-263-7600.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: ONLY GRADUATES CAN RUN The supreme court upheld a new rule requiring members of Parliament to hold university degrees, which opposition leaders say disqualifies more than 98 percent of the population. The rule is one in a long list of changes and proposals from the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, who says he is trying to set the conditions for a stable democracy. The opposition says he is trying to consolidate his power before elections, which he has scheduled for Oct. 10. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: DoubleClick Posts Profit

Net income came to 3 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $37.9 million, or 29 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales in the three months ended June 30 declined 26 percent, to $75.7 million from $101.9 million. DoubleClick forecast that its profit in the third quarter, excluding some items, would be lower than previously expected. Allison Fass (NYT)

title: A Restored German Classic of Futuristic Angst
description: On Jan. 10, 1927, Fritz Lang's ''Metropolis,'' a wildly ambitious, hugely expensive science fiction allegory of filial revolt, romantic love, alienated labor and dehumanizing technology opened at the Ufa Palast theater in Berlin. Lang's film, of course, went on to become one of the touchstones of 20th-century cinema, exhaustively studied and endlessly imitated, but apart from its brief theatrical run in Berlin and Nuremberg 75 years ago, the movie as Lang made it has never really been seen.

Plenty exciting itself, Vinod Chopra's ''Mission Kashmir,'' issued on disc and videocassette last month by Columbia TriStar, is more or less obliged to take a breather now and then for a song and dance routine.

description: Roberto Alomar led off the Mets' first inning with a double to right field, driving the first pitch he saw last night from Phillies left-hander Randy Wolf to the opposite field at Shea Stadium. An out later, Mike Piazza broke his bat, a splinter landing in front of the plate, as he blooped a 1-2 pitch to short right-center. Alomar ran on contact, chancing that the ball would drop, which it did, and scored without a throw.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Data On U.S. Bombing
description: A United States military contractor has provided the government with computerized information on thousands of American bombing raids near the Vietnam border in the late 1960's and early 1970's. The information from the Federal Resources Corporation of Fairfax, Va., based on pilot reports in the National Archives, will be useful in searching for thousands of unexploded bombs scattered through the country. Seth Mydans (NYT)

The workers will get 60-day layoff notices on July 19, a company spokesman, Al Stewart, said. A reduction in the number of parts the plant will supply for Boeing's C-17 transport plane and lower prices negotiated by the Air Force for those planes also forced the reductions, Mr. Stewart said.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: TELECOM JOINT VENTURE Pacific Century CyberWorks Ltd., Hong Kong's biggest phone company, and China Telecom, which operates most of the fixed-line phones in China, announced a joint venture to offer computer and telecommunications services for the back offices of banks, insurers and securities firms in mainland China. Pacific Century will initially have a 48.5 percent stake in the joint venture, while China Telecom will have a 51.5 percent stake. The companies are, however, discussing making it a 50-50 venture. Pacific Century will have management control of the venture, which will have a modest initial capitalization estimated by HSBC at $23 million. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: ICAHN SAYS HE'S WILLING TO KEEP TRYING FOR MORTON'S
description: The financier Carl C. Icahn, rebuffed by the Morton's Restaurant Group in a $71.2 million takeover offer, said he was still willing to outbid Castle Harlan's $67 million takeover of the company. Morton's declined to waive its takeover defenses against Mr. Icahn on Wednesday, failing to meet a condition of his $17-a-share offer, the financier said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The $17 bid, 6.3 percent more than Castle Harlan's current proposal of $16 a share, was Mr. Icahn's fourth attempt to top the private buyout firm, which has raised its price three times since first offering $12.60 a share in March.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: MobilCom Buyout

Mr. Schmid, who holds a 49.9 percent stake in MobilCom, said he and minority shareholders were entitled to at least 14.50 euros a share, the 90-day average price on June 21, the day he was ousted.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Juniper, Its Revenue Declining, Cuts Jobs
description: Juniper Networks, the second-largest maker of Internet equipment behind Cisco Systems, reported yesterday that its earnings declined 42 percent in the second quarter from the period a year ago. Juniper, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said it had revenue of $117 million in the quarter, compared with $202.2 million a year earlier. Excluding acquisition-related costs and a gain on deferred compensation, the company had earnings of $421,000, breaking even on a per-share basis. It had earnings of $29.3 million, or 9 cents a share, a year earlier. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had expected a loss of 1 cent a share in the latest quarter. Juniper also said it would eliminate the jobs of about 10 percent of its employees, about 180 people, as a result of its July acquisition of Unisphere Networks. The total savings will be $7 million a quarter, it said. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Destroying 'Poisonous' Discs
description: In an attack on what it calls ''poisonous cultural products,'' Vietnam has destroyed more than 44,000 CD's, videodiscs and CD-roms, 2,833 books and 570 advertising banners, according to a newspaper report. The report did not define the products, which it said had been confiscated from shops in the Hanoi area. Other campaigns have attacked pornographic videos, most of which are smuggled in from Cambodia and China. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Brooklyn Gets a Zagat Guide to Call Its Very Own

Bars in Williamsburg, once a haven for artists on a budget, serve the same $10 cosmopolitans found in Manhattan nightspots. So it should come as no surprise that Tim and Nina Zagat, publishers of the ubiquitous Zagat Survey, have released their first guide to the borough's restaurants, bars, nightclubs and food markets.

Family members of the woman, Dana Ho, 28, called the police at 7:24 p.m. Tuesday to report the lightning strike. The family refused an autopsy but the appearance of Ms. Ho's body was consistent with electrocution from a lightning strike, a spokesman from the prosecutor's office said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

description: A teenager who is suspected of killing a witness to an earlier killing has been arrested, the police said early today. Trevis Ragsdale, 19, whom investigators described as a member of the Bloods street gang, turned himself in at the Tompkins Avenue station house yesterday, the police said. He was charged with first degree murder, according to Detective Robert Price. Mr. Ragsdale was wanted in the shooting death of Bobby Gibson, 21, in Bedford-Stuyvesant last Saturday. title: Transposing the Power of 'Tosca' to the Big Screen
description: The great Italian operas of the 19th century were the Hollywood movies of their time: grand popular spectacles brimming with sex, violence and outsize emotion, and dedicated to the passionate marriage of sight and sound. Perhaps because of their close genetic relationship, the two art forms have rarely mixed well. The bold theatrical gestures and distended, improbable plots of opera often look disproportionate -- either shrunken or grotesque -- when captured on camera. With notable exceptions, like Ingmar Bergman's 1975 adaptation of ''The Magic Flute'' (which in any case is neither 19th century nor, strictly speaking, Italian), filmmakers have trouble negotiating the distance between the singers and the audience. At opera performances, we view the action from a fixed distance (usually determined by how much we can pay for a ticket) and are drawn into the action by means of a series of aural and visual illusions: the perspectives of the set, the volume of the orchestra, the modulation of the singers' voices.

title: MILD WEATHER TRIMS PROFITS FOR NEW JERSEY UTILITY
description: The Public Service Enterprise Group, owner of New Jersey's largest utility, said profit this year would rise less than the company expected because of a decline in energy trading. Profit before the cost of writing down overseas assets will be as much as 5 percent less than a May forecast of $3.90 to $4.10 a share, a spokesman said. The revision reflects declines in energy trades, investment income and sales of power and natural gas during mild New Jersey weather, he said. Stock in Public Service rose $1.06, or 2.9 percent, to $37.20 a share. The stock has fallen 24 percent in the last year.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Mercy Killing Of Addicted Elephant
description: Veterinarians at an elephant hospital in northern Thailand said they had put to death an elephant that went blind and suffered years of pain as a result of an addiction to amphetamines. It is common for owners of elephants to give them stimulants to boost their work in illegal logging. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Outlook Improves For Magazine Ads
description: The decline in advertising pages in magazines slowed in June, falling by the smallest amount for any month so far this year, according to data released yesterday by the Publishers Information Bureau.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: The Marlins Give Up Two Stars but Not Hope, They Say
description: The Florida Marlins were prepared to trade Cliff Floyd, one of their best run producers, and Ryan Dempster, one of their good young pitchers, to the Montreal Expos, the upstart team in the National League East. But the Expos declined to pay the price in players for both, so they settled for Floyd, and the Marlins traded Dempster to the Cincinnati Reds yesterday.

title: Iverson Faces Felony Charges In Trespassing and Gun Case
description: Allen Iverson, the Philadelphia 76ers' All-Star guard, was charged today with criminal trespassing, carrying an unlicensed gun and seven other counts, District Attorney Lynne Abraham said. Prosecutors accused him of threatening two men after forcing his way into an apartment in the middle of the night with a gun in search of his wife.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Expedia Snubs Buyout Offer
description: The travel Web site Expedia has ''excellent'' prospects as a stand-alone company, a committee of its directors said yesterday, rebuffing a tentative buyout offer by its majority shareholder, USA Interactive. ''The special committee is highly confident in both the near-term and long-term prospects for Expedia as a stand-alone company,'' the committee chairman, Gregory B. Maffei, said. Mr. Maffei said the committee also thought that Expedia's stock price ''significantly undervalues'' the company's long-term prospects and ''has inappropriately become linked'' to USA Interactive's stock price, based on recent statements by USA Interactive. USA Interactive, a media company based in New York, announced on June 3 that it would offer its own shares in exchange for the shares it did not own of Expedia, based in Bellevue, Wash.,; Ticketmaster and Hotels.com. The shares of the units rose and USA Interactive shares fell. Two days later, USA Interactive tabled its plans for a formal exchange offer.

description: Following is an excerpt of "Postmodern Warfare: The Ingnorance of Our Warrior Intellectuals" by Stanley Fish, from the July issue of Harper's.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Oil Exploration
description: The Heritage Oil Corporation of Canada said after a four-year review of reserves in western Uganda that it would begin exploratory oil drilling in August. The company, working with Energy Africa of South Africa, is also in talks to drill in an adjacent area in Congo, which has been gripped by civil war for four years. A partial peace agreement between Congo's government and the Uganda-backed Congolese Liberation Movement made the exploration possible, company officials said. Justo Casal (NYT)

description: The Jets have renewed contract talks with the free-agent defensive tackle Josh Evans, now that his appeal of an indefinite suspension for violating the National Football League's substance-abuse policy has been upheld.

description: Lawyers for Jose Padilla, the former Chicago gang member accused of plotting to explode a radioactive bomb in the United States, said yesterday that prosecutors were engaged in improper legal tactics to move his case from New York to South Carolina, where courts are thought to be more favorable to the government.

title: Questions, but No Answer Yet, As Schwarz Jury Ends Third Day
description: The jury in the retrial of Charles Schwarz, the former police officer charged with taking part in the assault of Abner Louima, finished its third day of deliberations yesterday by requesting dictionary definitions of pivotal terms in the indictment.

description: The Republican and Democratic Parties broke fund-raising records in the first six months of the year, together pulling in more than $115 million, with Republicans firmly in the lead, party officials said today.

description: The response to President Bush's trip to Wall Street says a lot about why presidents and the markets have trouble speaking the same language. White House Memo, Page C1.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Rowland Has Raised $2.6 Million
description: Though he formally announced his bid for re-election only 11 days ago, Gov. John G. Rowland's campaign committee has raised $1.6 million from April 5 to July 5, records show. The governor has a $2.6 million war chest four months before Election Day. The Friends of John Rowland group has raised more than $3 million to date and spent $425,243.70, according to papers filed yesterday. His presumed Democratic rival, William E. Curry Jr., raised $280,000 during that same period and has $328,000 on hand. Mr. Rowland is expected to raise $6 million or more for his campaign; Mr. Curry hopes to raise more than $3 million. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Pettitte Bounces Back as Yanks Hold On to Win
description: Andy Pettitte sounded apologetic but proud. No, he was not worried when the Yankees acquired a sixth starting pitcher last week. Seven successful seasons have made him secure.

title: Youths Try the Luge As Olympians Watch
description: The metal ramp stood less than five feet high and the cone-lined track extended a few harmless yards into the parking lot, but to about 40 kids who had signed up to ride down the ramp on a wheeled luge sled for the first time, it seemed scary enough.

title: An Unexpected Face
description: Most of us don't think of evolution as a ''very elaborate bush,'' to use the words of the late Stephen Jay Gould. Especially where our own, human origins are concerned, we like to think of evolution as a highway leading from the past to the present with as few lanes as possible. We also tend to model ideas of evolutionary success after our own example, which is the survival of a single species in a genus rather than the survival of many closely related species. But the ways we think of human evolution and, more intimately, of ourselves will probably have to change, thanks to the skull of a creature that scientists call, familiarly, Toumai and, formally, Sahelanthropus tchadensis.

title: 2 Missing, 6 Hurt in Queens Boat Collision
description: Two people were hospitalized last night and two other people were missing after two boats collided in Little Neck Bay in Queens, the authorities said. One of the vessels, which were described as power boats about 15 feet long, carried six teenagers; the other carried a man and a woman.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Only Graduates Can Run
description: The supreme court upheld a new rule requiring members of Parliament to hold university degrees, which opposition leaders say disqualifies more than 98 percent of the population. The rule is one in a long list of changes and proposals from the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, who says he is trying to set the conditions for a stable democracy. The opposition says he is trying to consolidate his power before elections, which he has scheduled for Oct. 10. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: 36 Hours | Cape Ann, Mass.
description: IN some New England fishing towns, the seascape painters far outnumber the fishermen. But though the red fishing warehouse in Cape Ann, affectionately called Motif No. 1, is kept up primarily for its proven ability to draw out the watercolors (and cameras), the lobster traps and colorful buoys are more for work than for show. Part of the joy of Cape Ann is just driving around, looking in on the lives of the seafarers and catching glimpses of tidal estuaries and coves. On foot, you can explore its dozen or so beaches, or stop in for a reiki massage or aromatherapy with one of the holistic health practitioners attracted here by the salt air. And yes, the artists are here, too. JULIE FLAHERTY

title: Two Ball Clubs Had a Close Call on Payrolls
description: As baseball officials and owners paint an increasingly bleaker picture of baseball's economics, two teams have stepped forward as Exhibits A and B. The Tampa Bay Devil Rays and the Detroit Tigers recently experienced payroll problems and needed bank loans to pay their players, people in baseball familiar with the problems said yesterday.

title: Two Thrillers, Two Traditions
description: As political thrillers go, they couldn't be more divergent. "One of the fastest, most exciting melodramas ever made," the critic Pauline Kael wrote about Constantin Costa-Gavras's "Z" (1969), released last week on DVD by Wellspring. Plenty exciting itself, Vinod Chopra's "Mission Kashmir," issued on disc and videocassette last month by Columbia TriStar, is more or less obliged to take a breather now and then for a song and dance routine.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Man Loses A Best Friend
description: A state appeals court refused to allow a divorced husband to visit his dog. As part of their divorce, the couple agreed that Lynda Hurley Pritchard would have custody of the dog, Barney, but that Anthony Desanctis could visit it. The court said the deal was void because dogs are personal property. Mr. Desanctis, the court held, ''appears to treat Barney, a dog, as a child.'' Legally, though, the court ruled, he might as well have been seeking ''a visitation schedule for a table or a lamp.'' Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: U.S. Attorney Is Said to Join Wall Street Inquiry
description: The Justice Department has joined state officials and federal securities regulators in investigating whether research by Wall Street analysts was tainted by conflicts of interest, Morgan Stanley indicated yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Wrongfully Convicted Man Sues
description: A man who spent 17 years in prison for a murder he did not commit has filed a $50 million lawsuit against the state. In 1985 the man, Angelo Martinez, left, was convicted of killing Rudolph Marasco, 70, outside a bingo hall in Queens. A State Supreme Court judge last month vacated the verdict, citing another man's confession and supporting evidence. Mr. Martinez's lawyer, Oscar Michelen, said his client, now 36, met the state criteria for compensation under the Unjust Conviction Statute. Mr. Martinez is still serving time for dealing drugs in prison but Mr. Michelen said he hoped to have a judge reduce his sentence to time served. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Electronics Plant Closes
description: One of the Czech Republic's more prominent foreign investors, the Singapore-based Flextronics International, said it would shut a newly built telecommunications equipment factory near the city of Brno and lay off about 1,000 workers. Production will be moved to Hungary where Flextronics already has a plant. Economists say the move may signal a new trend.

Mrs. Bowditch had stocked the kitchen with local strawberries and turkey potpies, a family favorite bought from a local store. All was ready for the annual arrival of the grandchildren at Hancock Point, Me.

description: As WorldCom struggles to avoid a bankruptcy filing and regain the trust of investors worried about its accounting lapses, its new chief executive may have an accountability problem of his own.

title: A Warm Story of Cerebral Palsy, but Unsentimental
description: With reddish hair, enormous jug ears and a big goofy grin, William H. Macy looks like Howdy Doody come to life -- an irreverent association for a character who has cerebral palsy. But the irreverence suits the tone of ''Door to Door,'' a warmhearted yet unsentimental drama based on a true story.

title: Textiles: A Hands-On Folk Art
description: I'M probably not the only one who sometimes forgets how much of the history on view at the American Museum of Natural History is man-made. Sustained exposure to the quantities of art, artifact, dioramic simulacra and cultural information found in the vast halls devoted to the different peoples of the world can trigger aesthetic vertigo. Although one could sometimes use a little more label information, the displays are often magnificent to the point of being overwhelming. And nowhere more than in the sprawling category of the weaving arts. I was especially struck by the frequency, beauty and variety of woven fabrics, objects and wearable things: textiles, articles of clothing, baskets and mats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, ALVIN J.
description: GORDON-Alvin J., M.D. Died on July 10, 2002 at age 87 after a short illness. He died at Mount Sinai Hospital where he worked as a cardiologist from 1938-2001, heading the Cardiac Catheterization Team for 25 years and serving as Clinical Professor of Medicine. He was also Chief of Cardiology at Doctor's Hospital, later Beth Israel North, and maintained a private practice in cardiology for over 50 years. During his lifetime, he published over 50 medical papers and was a pioneer in cardiac catheterization research. He also served as a Naval Medical Officer in the South Pacific during W.W. II. Dr. Gordon loved the outdoors and enjoyed tinkering in his workshop. He is survived by Elaine, his wife of 62 years, his children, Melissa (and Chris), Todd (and Susan), three grandchildren, Camilla, Sam and Basia, and his sister and brother-in-law, Charlotte and Paul Kirschner. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Cardiovascular Institute, 1 Gustave L. Levy Place, Box 1030, NY NY 10029. A memorial service will be announced shortly.

title: SERONO AND PFIZER TEAM UP TO MARKET NEW DRUG
description: The biotechnology company Serono S.A. has teamed up with Pfizer Inc. to promote its multiple sclerosis treatment, Rebif, in the United States. Pfizer will pay Serono $200 million and the two companies will share the cost for Rebif's development until 2013. Serono, which is based in Geneva, had been gearing up its sales force after Rebif won Food and Drug Administration approval earlier this year, but has only 70 people compared with Pfizer's 8,000-person sales force, the largest in the United States. Pfizer is based in New York. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)
