title: Making an Exotic Circus of a Shakespearean Farce
description: The Aquila Theater Company, an 11-year-old part-American, part-British troupe devoted to reimagining classic plays, is inclined to exuberant stagecraft. In its new production of Shakespeare's ''Comedy of Errors,'' no moment is deemed complete without a bit of fizzy stage business by the actors or a madcap tweak by the director, Robert Richmond. It's the kind of high-energy effort that encourages the audience to hoot and holler and overlook the fact that the rapid-fire stage antics are only intermittently inspired. The show sets the bar of invention high and grows ever more frantic in trying to leap over it.

title: Companies Rethink What to Shred, and When
description: Spurred by repeated scandals and the specter of legislation, companies are examining their document-retention policies, making sure that the procedures are up to date and that employees are complying with them, according to lawyers who advise corporations. Companies are also struggling with questions of what to do about electronic documents.

title: Discount Stores Aided Rise In Retail Sales Last Month
description: Retail sales rose in June, led by discount stores like Wal-Mart Stores and the Target Corporation. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 4.5 percent last month, according to Goldman, Sachs retail composite index.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Network Associates' Shares Fall
description: Despite a report by Network Associates of a profit for the second quarter, its stock tumbled 18 percent yesterday after the company said 2002 sales would be at the low end of estimates. Shares fell $3.25, to $14.45, and shares of McAfee.com, which makes computer-security software and is 75 percent owned by Network Associates, dropped 16 percent, to $11.68. Network Associates said it expected 2002 sales, excluding McAfee.com, to be at the low end of its previous estimate of $875 million to $900 million. For 2002, Network Associates, based in Santa Clara, Calif., forecast earnings of 50 cents to 55 cents a share. In the third quarter, it expects to earn 11 cents to 13 cents. For the second quarter, net income was $21.2 million, or 12 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $37.2 million, or 27 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 21 percent, to $233 million.

title: How Stock Options Lead to Scandal
description: In his speech about corporate fraud and abuse, President Bush mentioned stock options only once -- and then to endorse an existing proposal to require shareholder approval of all options plans. His endorsement is welcome, but it is woefully inadequate: the stock-options culture is at the root of the current scandals on Wall Street.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Economic Slowdown
description: France's economy slowed significantly in May and June, but was showing signs of recovery, according to the French national statistics institute, or Insee. Industrial production fell 0.3 percent and manufacturing output fell 0.7 percent. The sharpest drops were in automobile output, down 2 percent each month, and consumer goods, down 1.4 percent each month. However, food production rose 1.5 percent while energy production rose 0.9 percent. A separate survey, done by the European Commission, showed that consumers became more pessimistic in June. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Spencer Has Lost His Job And Edge

The doctor, Wulf Utian, who is also executive director of the North American Menopause Society, answered patients' calls to his office at the Cleveland Clinic; it was only calls made to him at the society that he let go to his answering machine.

title: VEECO, A MAKER OF SEMICONDUCTOR EQUIPMENT, BUYS FEI
description: Veeco Instruments, whose equipment is used by makers of computer chips and data-storage devices, agreed to buy the FEI Company for about $1 billion in stock. Veeco will pay 1.355 shares for each share of FEI, the companies said in a statement. Based on Veeco's closing price of $22.49 Thursday, the bid values FEI at $30.47 a share, 38 percent more than its closing price of $22.06 Thursday. The transaction will create the sixth-largest maker of semiconductor equipment, based on combined sales of $825 million in 2001, the companies said. FEI, based in Hillsboro, Ore., develops ion beams used to design and analyze chips. Veeco, which is based in Woodbury, N.Y., makes measuring and testing tools.

title: F.T.C. CLEARS AMGEN PURCHASE OF IMMUNEX
description: Amgen Inc., the world's largest biotechnology company, won antitrust clearance to complete its $9.6 billion purchase of the Immunex Corporation, maker of a leading rheumatoid arthritis drug. Amgen and Immunex received Federal Trade Commission approval for the takeover after agreeing to sell Immunex's Leukine infection-fighting drug to Schering A.G. The companies will also grant patent licenses to allow development of two rival anti-arthritis drugs to address the F.T.C.'s concerns that the acquisition would hurt competition and lead to higher drug prices. As part of the purchase, Amgen will receive Immunex's Enbrel, a rheumatoid arthritis drug that it predicts will have sales of at least $3 billion. Amgen will market Enbrel along with its own arthritis medication, Kineret.

description: Robert Arnold has spent much of his young life on boats. He started sailing at an early age, and knew boat safety like the back of his hand, always insisting on life vests for his passengers, his sailing coach said.

description: Burberry, the British fashion company known for its distinctive plaid pattern, took its first tentative steps today as a public company in a turbulent market that posted steep declines and dragged Burberry's shares down 2.2 percent.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bankruptcies Decline
description: Corporate bankruptcies slipped 4.7 percent in June from the month a year ago, the first decline in 10 months, according to a private research firm. In all, 1,439 companies closed their doors last month leaving behind 674 billion yen ($5.8 billion) in debts, Tokyo Shoko Research said. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Banks Move To Put Curbs On WorldCom
description: An aggressive effort yesterday by a group of banks to protect billions of dollars that they lent to WorldCom greatly increases the likelihood that the company will have to seek bankruptcy protection.

title: Deal on Liability Allows Trauma Center to Reopen
description: Ten days after it closed, this city's only trauma center is to reopen on Saturday morning under an agreement that temporarily limits the liability of its doctors to malpractice lawsuits.

title: Ira Eaker, 80, Co-Founder of Back Stage, the Actors' Bible
description: Ira Eaker, a founder of Back Stage, the weekly theatrical newspaper that is a must-read for many actors seeking work, union news and reviews, died on June 26 at a hospital in Tamarac, Fla. He was 80.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bid For Gold Miner Extended
description: The Canadian gold producer Placer Dome Inc. said it was extending its unsolicited all-stock bid for AurionGold Ltd. of Australia to Aug. 7 from July 24. The move, Placer said, would give AurionGold shareholders time to digest temporary distortions in Placer's share price caused by its pending removal from the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. S.& P. said earlier this week that it would drop Placer and six other Canadian and European companies from the index on July 19, replacing them with seven companies with headquarters in the United States. Placer's share price, and thus the value of its bid for AurionGold, have fallen since S.& P.'s announcement. The stock closed yesterday at $10.88, down 9 cents. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: MERCATOR SOFTWARE ANNOUNCES LAYOFF OF 15% OF STAFF
description: Mercator Software Inc., a maker of products that link computer systems, said yesterday that it would lay off more than 90 employees, or about 15 percent of its staff, to save about $10 million a year. Mercator will cut the jobs this year, leaving 540 employees worldwide, a spokesman, Jonathan Cohen, said. The cuts will cost $1.7 million pretax in the third quarter. Mercator said it had second-quarter revenue of $27 million, compared with its forecast of $27.4 million. Mercator, based in Wilton, Conn., also said it expected a second-quarter loss of 10 cents to 12 cents a share, excluding one-time items.

title: World Briefing: European Union
description: BALKANS MONEY GOING BEGGING A senior European Union diplomat said Western donors had been unable to spend more than $5 million in aid pledged to the needy states of the Balkans because workable aid projects had yet to be presented. The official, Erhard Busek, special coordinator for the Stability Pact for South Eastern Europe, said the funds were granted only to projects whose progress could be verified. "We only believe things if we can see them," he said. "The money exists; processing it is the difficulty." (Reuters)

title: COST-CUTTING LEADS TO HIGHER PROFITS AT ACCENTURE
description: Profit at Accenture Ltd. rose 9.3 percent in its most recent quarter after the company cut jobs and bonuses. Net income rose to $114.5 million, or 27 cents a share, from $104.8 million, or 25 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales in the period, which ended May 31, rose less than 1 percent, to $2.98 billion. Accenture cut $66 million in costs, including $30 million in bonuses, to increase profit as customers bought fewer computer services. Revenue in the fourth quarter will probably fall by 1 percent to 5 percent, and some large consulting contracts failed to close as expected in June, officials said. Accenture's stock fell $1.45, or 9.3 percent, to $14.10 a share.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Quarter-Ton Of Cocaine Seized
description: The police arrested a major drug distributor and two Colombian men in Queens on Wednesday and seized more than 525 pounds of cocaine, the authorities said. The distributor, identified as John Freddy Valencia, 33, of Elmhurst, had been under surveillance for the last five months, the police said. Detectives followed his van to a warehouse in the Bronx on Wednesday and then to an apartment building in Elmhurst. There, they seized cocaine with a street value of $7 million and apprehended Jaime Carlos Gallo, 45, and Javier Mafla, 30, they said. Mr. Valencia was arrested later that day at home, the police said. Jacob Fries (NYT)

description: With two of the borough's most prominent officials on hand, the Bronx Democratic Party's nominee to oppose State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. officially announced her candidacy yesterday in a long-smoldering feud.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Officers' Suspension
description: The president of the largest police union yesterday criticized Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly's decision to suspend three officers after two suspects escaped from their custody last week. Patrick Lynch, the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, which represents about 23,000 officers, said that the officers were scapegoats for a department that lacked enough officers and equipment. Commissioner Kelly announced on Thursday that he was creating a task force to review the department's handling of suspects in custody and to figure out ways to improve their handling. Mr. Kelly responded to Mr. Lynch's remarks yesterday, saying, ''It's a serious issue, and discipline is part of my role.'' Jacob Fries (NYT)

description: In the wake of the World Trade Center collapse, the House today approved a measure that would give the federal government new authority to investigate building disasters and determine how other buildings might be better protected.

title: Continuing Slump Lands Burnitz on Bench
description: Shortly before 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, as workers finished preparing Shea Stadium for batting practice, Jeromy Burnitz wandered alone in right field with a fielder's glove in his left hand and a bat in his right. With those tools, Burnitz walked like a man who had lost his way.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: WNBC-TV President Resigns
description: Dennis Swanson, the president and general manager of WNBC-TV, announced yesterday that he would retire on Aug. 1, station executives said. Mr. Swanson, 64, who is credited with helping start Oprah Winfrey's talk-show career, took over at WNBC in 1996 after serving as president of ABC Sports, and helped WNBC overtake WABC to lead the New York market. Mr. Swanson also served as co-chairman of NBC's Olympics coverage. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: The Bronx: Arrests In Burglary-Assaults
description: Two Bronx men have been arrested in connection with a string of burglaries and sexual assaults across the city, the police said yesterday. The men, identified as Julian Delacruz, 36, and Roberto Morales, 34, have been linked to 10 cases dating back to March 4, the police said. The men generally forced their way into apartments, where they stole cash, jewelry and electronics. In four cases, they bound the hands of their female victims and raped them, the police said. When the men struck last, in Brooklyn on July 2, a tip led investigators to Mr. Delacruz, who later implicated Mr. Morales, they said. DNA evidence connected Mr. Morales to three of the four sexual assaults, the police said. Jacob Fries (NYT)

title: Making Extra-Golden Oldies His Own
description: Set an artist loose amid his predecessors, and he's likely to find reflections of himself. Richard Thompson, the English songwriter who helped initiate British folk-rock as a member of Fairport Convention in the 1960's, is at Joe's Pub (425 Lafayette Street, East Village) through tonight with ''1,000 Years of Popular Music,'' his idiosyncratic selection of songs that, on Tuesday night, dated back as far as circa 1080. He joked that he was being ''unbelievably pretentious'' as he annotated his songs like a waggish don. ''Let's get past the Black Death,'' he said, skipping three centuries.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: BMW EXPANSION LIKELY The German automaker BMW said the Chinese government had agreed to let it and a domestic partner do a feasibility study to expand an auto factory for the production of BMW cars in China. The government generally does not approve feasibility studies unless it is virtually certain to give final approval and licensing to a factory. The factory, in the northeastern Chinese city of Shenyang, is controlled by BMW's partner, Brilliance China Automotive Holdings , China's largest manufacturer of shuttle vans. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about hormone replacement therapy referred imprecisely to a doctor's response to patients' concerns over a study questioning the value of the drugs for certain conditions. The doctor, Wulf Utian, who is also executive director of the North American Menopause Society, answered patients' calls to his office at the Cleveland Clinic; it was only calls made to him at the society that he let go to his answering machine.

title: Note Reveals Disagreement In Schwarz Jury
description: The jury in Charles Schwarz's retrial in the Abner Louima torture case ended its fourth day of deliberations yesterday in disarray, with one juror charging that others had a ''pre-existing bias based on their previous knowledge of the case.''

title: Union Budges on Draft But Differences Remain
description: A bargaining session between representatives of Major League Baseball's owners and players produced no agreement yesterday, but short of that, the owners' chief labor lawyer was pleased.

title: 'Swan Lake' Dazzles Without the Details
description: The Kirov Ballet's ''Swan Lake,'' presented for the first time this season on Thursday night as part of Lincoln Center Festival 2002, evokes memories of great performances more past than present. Yet on the surface it remains a splendid theatrical spectacle fleshed out with a superb full-bodied performance from the Kirov corps.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Shuttles Will Remain Grounded
description: The nation's four space shuttles will remain grounded for at least two more months because of mysterious fuel-line fractures, but the tiny cracks are now considered less of a safety concern than when first discovered, a NASA official said. Ron Dittemore, the space agency's shuttle program manager, said all four shuttles had apparently been flying for years with small fractures in metal sheets that line some fuel pipes. NASA fears that the cracks could lead to rupture of a liner, sending pieces of metal into a running engine and setting off a catastrophic failure. Warren E. Leary (NYT)

title: In Ecuador's Banana Fields, Child Labor Is Key to Profits
description: At Los lamos plantation, it would appear that no expense was spared to produce the Bonita brand Cavendish bananas sold in the United States.

title: Pilots' Accord At US Airways
description: Pilots at US Airways would receive as much as a 20 percent stake in the carrier in return for pay and benefit concessions under terms of a tentative agreement, their union said.

title: The Expanding Smallpox Plan
description: The federal government will be taking an important step forward if it vaccinates half a million or more health care workers and emergency personnel with smallpox vaccine to protect them against a possible terrorist attack. That number of vaccinations, now being discussed by federal health officials, would be a giant leap beyond the 10,000 to 20,000 recently envisioned by the government's top vaccine advisory committee.

title: Vivendi's Top Financial Officer Is Expected to Resign

title: This Once, a David of the Art World Does Goliath a Favor
description: It is perhaps a sweet irony that Sir Timothy Clifford is the art expert who unearthed the previously unknown drawing of a candelabrum attributed to Michelangelo at the Cooper-Hewitt, the National Design Museum of the Smithsonian Institution. For most of his career, Sir Timothy, the director of the National Galleries of Scotland in Edinburgh, has focused on American museums in a different way -- to thwart their efforts to export British-owned artworks.

title: A Boy Lost in the City's Schools
description: We often read that the New York City school system is failing our children, but we rarely have a sense of what that means. Perhaps it means that they're not learning enough, or learning too slowly, or learning what we don't want them to. I'm a social worker, and recently I learned that it can mean something much worse: that some kids whose problems cry out for attention are being ignored.

description: New York City's ubiquitous trash -- 11,000 tons of it daily from residences alone -- has traveled to Pennsylvania and Virginia, and there's even talk of sending it to a Caribbean island. It is seeing more of the world than some New Yorkers do, and it could threaten to overtake culture as the city's most notable export.

title: Corrections

It is ''The American Spirit,'' not ''Portraits of a Nation.''

title: 'Retreat' Seems to Fit Mood Of Media's Big Gathering
description: Dozens of private jets filled the tarmac at the tiny airport in nearby Hailey, Idaho, this week as top communications industry executives gathered for golf, river rafting and outdoor ice skating here at the annual retreat held by the investment banker Herbert Allen, a summer camp for media moguls.

title: Slivers of Support for Shackling Corporate Pay
description: When James L. Dimon, the chief executive of Bank One, explains his rationale for prohibiting the company's top executives from selling most of their Bank One stock, he often ends up talking about food. ''Management,'' Mr. Dimon says, ''should eat its own home cooking.''

title: National Briefing | Plains: South Dakota: H.I.V. Exposure Conviction
description: A student at Si Tanka Huron University has become the first person in the state to be convicted of intentionally exposing someone to the virus that causes AIDS. The student, Nikko Briteramos, pleaded guilty on Thursday to having unprotected sex a month after he was notified that he was infected with the virus, H.I.V. Mr. Briteramos faces up to 15 years in prison when he is sentenced on Aug. 20. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Mexican Farmers Seize Officials
description: Armed with machetes and homemade firebombs, hundreds of farmers seized control of government offices here on Thursday night and abducted several local officials, demanding that the government abandon plans to take their land to build a new airport.

title: Mystics Finally Learn to Make the Most of Their Talent
description: No one expected the Washington Mystics to turn themselves around so quickly. Not their fans, their peers in the Women's National Basketball Association or even the Mystics, a team that lacked cohesiveness and chemistry on the court and off.

description: GUILFORD MILLS INC., Greensboro, N.C., a maker of textiles, said it filed a reorganization plan that would eliminate $120 million in debt and give its senior lenders control of the company, which sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in March.

title: CHINA'S PRESIDENT MAY BE RELUCTANT TO CEDE HIS POWER
description: In what are supposed to be his final months as China's president and Communist Party chief, Jiang Zemin is being lionized in the official media as never before, provoking intense speculation about his ambitions to hold on to power in the years ahead.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: ECONOMIC SLOWDOWN France's economy slowed significantly in May and June, but was showing signs of recovery, according to the French national statistics institute, or Insee. Industrial production fell 0.3 percent and manufacturing output fell 0.7 percent. The sharpest drops were in automobile output, down 2 percent each month, and consumer goods, down 1.4 percent each month. However, food production rose 1.5 percent while energy production rose 0.9 percent. A separate survey, done by the European Commission, showed that consumers became more pessimistic in June. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Pennsylvania Struggles to Repair Model Prescription Aid Program
description: Pennsylvania's program to help low-income elderly people buy prescription drugs, the largest in the nation, provides invaluable assistance to tens of thousands of people and is immensely popular, but it also shows the problems that could become endemic if Congress adds drug benefits to Medicare.

title: Democrats See Scandals as Chance to Attack Privatizing Social Security
description: Seizing on the Wall Street scandals to press their agenda on Social Security, Democratic leaders in Congress demanded today that President Bush and his party renounce efforts to shift part of Social Security into private investment accounts.

title: POOR COMPUTER SALES LEAD TO LAYOFFS AT READ-RITE
description: The Read-Rite Corporation, which makes recording heads for computer disk drives, said it laid off about 500 employees, or 5 percent of its work force, as weak sales of computers have left it with mounting losses. The company, which is based in Fremont, Calif., predicted that the step will save $30 million to $40 million a year. Read-Rite, whose sales dwindled from $1.16 billion in 1997 to $712.9 million in 2001, has lost money for the last three quarters.

title: Former Presidents Urge Leadership on AIDS
description: Two former presidents, Nelson Mandela of South Africa and Bill Clinton of the United States, today urged current heads of state and business executives to exert stronger leadership in galvanizing programs to stop the AIDS epidemic.

title: Using American Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Silencing a Palestinian Moderate
description: Why would Israel shut down the office of the leading Palestinian moderate? Many asked that question when Israeli police acted this week against Sari Nusseibeh, president of Al Quds University and the Palestine Liberation Organization's designated representative in Jerusalem. They carted off his files and changed the lock on the door.

title: Other Teams Give Chase, But Coyotes Sign Amonte
description: Tony Amonte, the National Hockey League's last remaining top-level free agent in this summer's market, ended nearly two weeks of speculation yesterday by agreeing to a four-year, $24 million deal with the Phoenix Coyotes.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS IT EXPECTS DEFICIT TO HIT $165 BILLION
description: The Bush administration said today that the federal government would run a deficit of $165 billion this year, a sharp turn for the worse after four years of surpluses and further evidence of how the stock market's long slide is rippling through the economy.

title: Just Off the Expressway, Ancient New York; Remnants of Virgin Forests Still Stand, Even in the Bronx and Queens
description: Once you know what to look for, a very old tree is nearly as easy to spot as a very old human.

title: Clemens and Mondesi Hurt, And Cleveland Capitalizes
description: The Yankees reduced their supply of healthy starting pitchers to five tonight, and they did not need to trade or demote anybody to do it. By the end of the game, Roger Clemens was not the only casualty of a bizarre 2-1 loss in 10 innings to the Cleveland Indians. Raul Mondesi, the new right fielder, was carted off the field after crashing into the wall chasing Omar Vizquel's game-winning triple.

title: New Pentagon Report Sees Rapid Buildup by China
description: China is rapidly modernizing its military with the goal of countering American power in the Pacific and pressing Taiwan to accept unification, according to a Pentagon study released today.

Professor Zweig is also the author of ''The Working Class Majority: America's Best Kept Secret'' (Cornell University Press, 2000). Felicia R. Lee spoke with him.

description: Despite steep losses on WorldCom bonds and in its insurance businesses, the General Electric Company reported a 14 percent increase in earnings for the second quarter yesterday, in line with analysts' expectations. The company also promised a robust third quarter.

title: A Hero Of Angola Warms Up A Hot Night
description: Bonga has lived outside his native Angola since 1972, when his songs about oppression and freedom led to a warrant for his arrest by the Portuguese colonial authorities. Since its independence in 1975, Angola has been scarred by civil war; after years in Paris, Bonga now lives in Lisbon. But he still sings about Angolan identity and a longing for peace -- and a contingent of flag-waving Angolans was overjoyed to see him perform at Central Park SummerStage on Wednesday night in his first New York concert since 1989.

title: Both Sides Say Talk About Baseball's Problems Is One
description: So much negative talk has engulfed Major League Baseball over the past week that it would seem Commissioner Bud Selig would be reeling from it and swimming desperately against the tide, trying to keep his head above the rising murky waters. But Selig himself has contributed to the talk, and he acknowledged yesterday the mixed feelings he has about that contribution.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Schools Appointment
description: Staten Island became the first borough to appoint a member to the Panel for Education Policy, which replaces the Board of Education under the state law that gave Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg control of city schools. James P. Molinaro, the Staten Island borough president, named a longtime parent leader in the public schools, Joan McKeever-Thomas, to be his representative. Each of the five borough presidents is to appoint a parent of a public school student to the 13-member panel, and the mayor is to appoint 8 members. Mr. Bloomberg has not yet named anyone to the group. Anemona Hartocollis (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Morocco: The Spanish Acquisition
description: Tensions between Morocco and Spain have hit a new high since a dozen Moroccan soldiers seized a disputed islet just off the Moroccan coast on Thursday, and Spain issued a diplomatic protest and reinforced its troops in the area. The islet, called Perejil, which means parsley, is a half-mile in diameter and has been held by Spain since 1668 -- one of several territories, along with the coastal enclaves of Ceuta and Melilla, that it has never relinquished. Morocco, which disputes the claim, said it sent the troops to fight terrorism, drug-trafficking and illegal migration. The soldiers put up Moroccan flags and some tents. Tim Golden (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: CLOSING DATE FOR MIGRANT CENTER France and Britain agreed to close a refugee center near the Channel Tunnel if Britain passes new laws giving fewer rights and benefits to illegal immigrants seeking political asylum. The center in Sangatte, France, which refugees use as a jumping-off point to run into the tunnel or smuggle themselves aboard trains or ferries, has been a bone of contention between the countries for years. The French and British interior ministers jointly announced that it could close as early as December. France said it had accepted a United Nations offer to mediate the dispute. Donald G. McNeill Jr. (NYT)

title: New Proposal For Ending Bus Strike In Queens
description: The Queens borough president has proposed a resolution to the four-weeklong bus strike in Queens. Under the proposal, 1,500 striking drivers, mechanics and cleaners would receive increases in health benefits that would be paid for by savings in the bus companies' budgets.

title: Mexico's Quest for Justice
description: Meticulously typed notes on millions of index cards are confirming Mexicans' worst suspicions about their nation's recent past. The cards, part of secret archives opened this year by President Vicente Fox, reveal that during the 1960's and 70's Mexico's ostensibly democratic government waged a ''dirty war'' against leftist student activists, peasant organizers and other dissenters, one as ruthless as those prosecuted by South America's military dictatorships.

description: In Woody Allen's movie ''Sleeper,'' a man wakes up 200 years in the future to find that science has proved deep-fried foods to be healthy. Is the future here already?

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industry Expands
description: India's industrial production rose 3.8 percent in May from the month a year earlier, helped by a spurt in manufacturing and mining, the government said. The government revised its April industrial growth figures to 3.9 percent from 2.9 percent. Meanwhile, India's new finance minister, Jaswant Singh, said in New Delhi that there was an upswing in all sectors of the Indian economy. The government would step up efforts to sustain the growth, Mr. Singh said. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Religion Journal; It's Summertime, and the Pews Are Empty Again

title: In Speech, Pakistan's President Outlines His Plan for Democracy
description: Swamped by charges that he wants a permanent grip on power, Pakistan's military leader, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, outlined his vision for a return to democracy in a nationwide television address with the promise, ''I assure you, we respect your views.''

description: Alan Shulman, a composer and cellist whose works were performed by orchestras, chamber groups and jazz ensembles, died on Wednesday at a nursing home in Hudson, N.Y. He was 86.

title: Citigroup Trims Bond Unit
description: The money-management unit of Citigroup laid off 12 people in its taxable bond department this week, including the fund managers James Conroy and John Bianchi, to cut costs, a company spokeswoman said. The 12 managed about $7 billion in 14 Smith Barney mutual funds, the company said. A team led by Peter Wilby, formerly of Salomon Brothers, will manage the funds. Asset Management employs managers from Salomon Brothers and Smith Barney, which merged in 1997 to form the Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup.

title: Records of Two Utilities Are Subpoenaed
description: The Duke Energy Corporation and the El Paso Corporation said today that they had received subpoenas for trading records from authorities looking into sham transactions in natural gas and electricity.

title: VISX, A MAKER OF LASERS, EXPECTS PROFITS TO FALL SHORT
description: Visx Inc. shares fell 18 percent after the company, the biggest maker of lasers used to correct vision, said profit for the rest of the year would not meet forecasts. The shares fell $1.70, to $7.60 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange, where Visx led the list of percentage losers. A slow economy has hurt demand for vision-correction surgery, and sales and profit are expected to decline the rest of this year, Visx said. The company forecast earnings of 15 cents to 18 cents a share in the second half, lower than the 27 cents expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Visx, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it earned $5.92 million, or 11 cents a share, in the second quarter, reversing a year-earlier loss of $10.7 million, or 19 cents a share. Sales fell 24 percent, to $36.6 million from $48.3 million.

title: In the Game of the Father
description: Andrew M. Cuomo lives with his wife, Kerry, and their three young daughters in a 100-year-old clapboard house in Bedford, in the northern suburbs of New York. The Cuomo home abuts a 600-acre nature preserve, so that except for the roar of Interstate 684 to the west -- a constant annoyance to Andrew, though not to Kerry, who found the house in less than a week while Andrew stayed in Washington -- it has the feeling of a retreat, far from everybody and everything. The Cuomos were gathered in the dining room there a few Sunday mornings ago, five of them seated around a long platform of a table, large enough to seat 15 people, covered with platters of scrambled eggs, French toast and bacon. It was 9 a.m. Cuomo appeared to have just awakened, and he poked at his scrambled eggs and swirled his cup of coffee while Kerry tended to the girls. The house itself is remarkable, not only for its rustic charm, which is considerable, but also for what it displays: the walls along the stairway to the upstairs bedrooms are lined with the kind of historical artifacts you might expect to find under glass at the National Archives. There is the handwritten letter to Kerry, signed ''Grandma,'' from Rose Kennedy. There is another one from Uncle Jack, written from the Oval Office. ''This one is great, from my father to me,'' Kerry said, narrowing her eyes as she tried to make out the scrunched handwriting of Robert F. Kennedy. ''This is June 1963. 'Dear Kerry. Thank you for coming to the office this morning. It was a historical day not just because of your visit, but because 2 negroes over the opposition of Governor Wallace were registered at the university -- it happened just a few minutes ago. I hope these events will be long past when you have your pretty little head at college. Love and kisses, Daddy.'''

It's true that some of his characters were ghoulish, with a raw, over-the-edge physicality. But Mr. Maro also has an impish side and can throw in a prank for a mid-nightmare chuckle.

A sign over the counter reads ''God, Guns and Guts Made America, Let's Keep All Three.''

title: Bidding the Interstate Goodbye
description: THE day started early with a cacophony of warblers and robins, followed by a car alarm erupting briefly in a distant part of the campground. Gray-haired power walkers started padding past in tennis shoes. The owner of the neighboring recreational vehicle set off to patrol its perimeter armed with a bottle of spray cleanser and a rag, touching up hubcaps and brake lights and anything else that might have gathered a faint patina of dust. (''If I'm not polishing, I'm not happy,'' he had announced to me the night before.) Then the aroma of bacon mixed with wood smoke drifted in from a few sites down. And that's when I got up.

Nick Drake and his chamber accompaniments, the Pentangle and their jazzy arrangements of traditional English ballads, Van Morrison and his ethereally acoustic ''Astral Weeks'' LP: this is Orton's roots music. Like them, she is yanking folk from the clutches of the folkloric.

title: One Good Tale Deserves Another
description: Not only is Stephen Fry a first-rate comic actor, he is also an accomplished and talented light novelist. His new novel, REVENGE (Random House, $23.95), set between 1980 and the present day, is a retelling of the swashbuckling classic ''The Count of Monte Cristo.'' Dumas's chestnut might not be the greatest novel ever written, but it certainly has one of literature's greatest plots, and Fry takes full advantage of it, using the elements that work and altering the narrative to suit his own thematic purposes. The 17-year-old Ned Maddstone is, at the story's opening, almost disgustingly perfect. The adored only son of an old-school Conservative politician, he is in his last year at Harrow. He is a star cricket player, his school's ''head boy,'' bound for Oxford; newly in love with a beautiful and brilliant girl, he is a powerful focus of envy among his fellows, although he is far too modest and diffident to realize it. Three jealous rivals arrange to have him arrested for marijuana possession. In police custody, he finds himself at the center of a political scheme involving I.R.A. terrorists. A scandal is impending, and a poisonous government agent, to save his own career, arranges for Ned to be spirited away to an insane asylum on a distant Scandinavian island. There he languishes for many a long year. But as readers of Dumas will predict, he eventually makes a dramatic escape, returns to London in disguise and descends on the terrified men responsible for wrecking his life. Fry has worked in any number of clever references to Dumas -- some of the characters' names, for example, are anagrams or near anagrams for their counterparts in ''Monte Cristo'' -- but the book is both a highly readable thriller and a viable novel in its own right. Fry has his own ideas about revenge, ideas that diverge from those of Dumas, and he keeps us guessing right up to the story's unpredictable ending. Brooke Allen

Zimmerman, wrote a letter to Governor McGreevey saying the company would probably close some of its 37 stores in the state and trim its work force of roughly 10,000 because of the tax. Federated says it paid $4.4 million in corporate taxes to the state last year and that under the new plan it will have to pay $10 million. Mr. McGreevey responded by accusing Federated of using accounting maneuvers to avoid state taxes in the past. John Holl

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENSTERHEIM, ESTHER
description: FENSTERHEIM-Esther. On July 12, 2002. Beloved wife of Jack (Kelly). Devoted mother of Aaron and Lester. Adored grandmother of Sari, Lauren & Howard. Cherished sister of Sam, Max, Nat & Mike Lederman. Graveside ceremony Sunday, July 14, 1:30PM, Unionfield Cemetery. Directions: 718-366-3748.

title: July 7-13: INTERNATIONAL; AIDS WARNINGS
description: The danger of ignorance was a main topic of the 14th International AIDS Conference, in Barcelona. Up to a half million Americans are either unaware that they are infected with the AIDS virus, not receiving treatment for it, or both. The figures pale compared to the 90 percent of the 40 million infected people elsewhere, mostly in Africa, who do not know and have little chance of receiving the powerful anti-viral drugs available in developed countries. One result: the number of children orphaned by AIDS in Africa will double by 2010 to about 20 million, or nearly 6 percent of all those under age 15. One small ray of hope: studies of T-20, a member of a new class of drugs known as fusion inhibitors, showed the experimental drug held promise for those in whom the AIDS virus has developed resistance to standard drugs. Lawrence K. Altman

title: Coolness, Cubed
description: Just about everything qualifies as a fashion accessory in New York, and restaurants, hosts and hostesses are sprucing up cocktails and entrees with novelty ice cubes in all shapes, sizes, colors and materials. At That Bar in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn, bartenders are using mineral eggs -- frozen egg-shaped chunks of rose quartz, turquoise, coral, hematite and other stones and crystals -- to chill mixed drinks. At Suba, a stylish hangout at 109 Ludlow Street, gazpacho is enhanced by cubes of frozen tomato juice. Compass, the fashionable Upper West Side restaurant and lounge at 208 West 70th Street, keeps gin and vodka martinis cool with frozen squares of lime-shiso jelly.

title: Second Language
description: TEN and a half years ago I came to Jewish Vocational Service as a substitute teacher. I never left. During that time, I have watched my friends and my husband change careers, get promotions, take lavish business trips, make a lot of money and gain the respect and recognition from society that everyone craves.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the fashion industry's periodic recycling of older designs misstated the surname of a postmodernist art critic who was an influential theorist on the uses of appropriation. He was Craig Owens, not Wright.

title: Is That an Echo In My Shoe?
description: If matching one's shoes to one's handbags is pass, coordination buffs can be sated with a new breed of pedicure. The Buff Spa's nail salon, at the plaza level of Bergdorf Goodman, 754 Fifth Avenue, offers a Choo-Choo pedicure ($90), where scraps of the paisley, floral and pink-striped fabrics from Jimmy Choo's summer collection are cut to size, affixed to the top of each nail, and covered with a high-gloss top coat. At Haven, at 150 Mercer Street in SoHo, patrons bring their shoes and pocketbooks to coordinate polish ranging from mock-crocodile to plaids ($65 to $90). For some similarly fancy footwork, Warren-Tricomi uses airbrushes, stencils and fabric, and will even draw a Gucci logo ($65 to $80 at 16 West 57th Street). Next month, the designer Lulu Guinness will team up with Eve, a salon at 400 Bleecker Street in the West Village, next to Ms. Guinness's boutique, to do a purple-and-white striped job ($35) that matches the summer line of LG handbags. KAREN ROBINOVITZ

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAREL, RAY (NEE SCHNITZER)
description: MAREL-Ray (nee Schnitzer). On July 11, 2002. Beloved wife of William for 64 wonderful years. Adored mother of Marjorie Cahn and Dr. Rozanne Pollack. Dear motherin-law of Dr. Dean Saluti and William Pollack. Cherished grandmother of Nancy and Susannah Cahn and Andrea & Rebecca Pollack. Devoted sister-in-law of Martha Grosof and Renee Potecha. She will be missed more than words can express. Service Sunday 1:30 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: A visiting museum director identified a drawing in the archives of the Cooper-Hewitt design museum as a work by Michelangelo last week. The sketch of a candelabrum had been bought in 1942 as part of a lot of design drawings from a London dealer for $60.

description: Q: You are arguably the least-known candidate running for the Democratic presidential nomination, even though you've served longer than any standing Democratic governor -- 11 years -- and according to a longtime observer of Vermont politics, you've been ''running for president since you were 15.''

description: NEVER mind that the calendar says July. Or that many of the county's children are away on vacation or at camp. Or that most teachers have temporarily resumed their identities apart from their classrooms. Simply because it's summer vacation doesn't mean that schools are in suspended animation. Administrators clean up this year's problems and prepare for the next academic year. Here are some programs and changes in the works:

title: A Great Leap Backward: No Cars
description: The five City Council members whose districts surround Prospect Park have voiced support for a proposed three-month trial during which cars would be banned completely from the park's roads.

title: Ethical Shredding
description: A new generation is slashing T-shirts and jeans. The torn look echoes the rage of 30 years ago that evolved into punk couture with the addition of safety pins. Today, the do-it-yourselfers and the designers have added ribbon lacing. Below, the look as it appears on the street and at Yves Saint Laurent's show for fall 2002 (below, top right). Some jeans are cut in lacy eyelet patterns and then richly embroidered. Others have whole blocks scissored out and contrasting fabric sewn in. Still others resemble disintegrating window swags. And some T-shirts have become an art form.

title: Deus Ex Machina; To Err Is Human
description: THEY knew all along that human fallibility had contributed to the deaths of their children. There was the well-meaning tour operator in Moscow who had delivered the students to the wrong airport, causing them to miss an earlier flight to Spain. There was the Swiss air traffic controller who happened to take a break at just the wrong moment, leaving an overworked colleague struggling to guide five different planes through his small piece of sky.

title: July 7-13: INTERNATIONAL; PLANE CRASH
description: Mistaken instructions from a Swiss air traffic controller probably caused the July 1 midair collision of a Russian passenger plane and a DHL cargo plane, which killed 52 children and 19 adults. Flight recorders showed that both planes' collision-avoidance systems engaged, telling the DHL plane to descend and the Russian plane to climb about 44 seconds before impact. But the Russian pilot followed a Swiss controller's urgent order to descend.

title: McGreevey Ran, And Now He's Trying to Hide
description: Governor McGreevey has such an unquenchable appetite for ceremonies, marathon schmooze sessions and other public displays of governance, that there was something odd, and slightly ominous, about the stealthy way his administration enacted a document known as Executive Order 21.

title: In Beach Safety Survey, Belgium Fares Best
description: Almost all Europe's beaches are safe for swimming, according to the Environment Commission of the European Union. Its most recent survey, the 2001 Bathing Water Report, released in May, found that 97 percent of coastal beaches and 93 percent of freshwater beaches complied with the commission's standards for safety and pollution.

title: Golden Oldies in 2054
description: To the Editor:

title: This Cable Story Offers a Lesson (And a Happy Ending)
description: HINDSIGHT, of course, brings great clarity. We look back at the technological advances of the late 18th and 19th centuries -- from the steam engine and the railroad to the telephone and the automobile -- and speak of the Industrial Revolution without hesitation. The economic and social legacy of the innovations of the industrial era is apparent, while the doubts, boom-bust cycles and investment schemes are mostly forgotten. History has long since sorted out the winners from the losers, the visionaries from the charlatans.

title: Lessons of a Humanist Who Can Disturb the Peace
description: RENZO PIANO wants to turn me into a project. ''We have to teach you to appreciate serenity more,'' he says. Piano is preaching to the converted. I dream of spending my days staring at ocean waves. This is not a sign of personal strength but reflects my dissolute appetite for vacation values. Life is struggle, without conflict organisms die, and one of the greatest virtues of the city is its capacity to tolerate the cultural tensions that generate art.

title: The Nation; Seeing Business Through Hollywood's Lens
description: EVEN as the Enron scandal was unfolding last October, there was already a movie in the nation's theaters about an evil energy company that increased its profits by creating a false scarcity for its products.

title: How Fairy-Tale Color Saved The Subways From Gloom
description: Squire Joseph Vickers, son of a farmer in Middlefield, N.Y., came to New York City in 1900. He found a wife, had a child, and slowly began spinning a double life.

title: In Hastings, Views of Garden and River
description: ON a balmy summer night, one could not do better than stroll through Harvest-on-Hudson's riverside gardens, neat plots of herbs -- sage, mint, rosemary -- plucked for the kitchen now, and corn, squash, peppers and eggplant showing promise for harvest in August.

title: An Idea Gone Haywire: Linking Executive Pay to Sales
description: WHY would Bristol-Myers Squibb use incentives to induce its wholesale customers to buy more products than they needed last year, a practice that may have resulted in overstated revenue at the company? The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating the company, which has said that its sales practices are proper.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE WAR AGAINST CLICH: Essays and Reviews, 1971-2000, by Martin Amis. (Vintage International, $16.) Among the highlights of this collection of book reviews and longer essays by the British author are a spirited defense of the poet Philip Larkin and celebrations of writers as varied as Elmore Leonard and Saul Bellow. ''Amis's work is distinguished by its hothouse intensity, its singleness of purpose, its nippy aggression -- and its stylishness,'' Jenny Turner wrote here last year.

title: Berlin
description: Berlin is not beautiful. Exciting, eccentric, self-absorbed, certainly. And certainly, still, divided. There is a kind of psychological wall that persists in this reunited city, stuck together again by history -- with three airports, three opera houses, two zoos, two television towers and scores of museums.

title: Court Rules Antennas Subject to Local Zoning Codes
description: Telecommunications companies will now have to demonstrate a need for wireless antennas by establishing that a gap in coverage exists, and will also be subject to aesthetic considerations, as a result of a court decision late last month.

title: Where Sun Eclipses Stars
description: THE 6-foot-5 man quietly strode through the gates onto the 96th Street basketball court. He was in early middle age and was wearing white, from shirt down to sneakers, looking more like a country club member heading for a tennis game than a summer shore guy ready to play hoops.

title: QUICK BITE/Montclair; For Busy Eaters, Burritos Instead of Egg Rolls
description: Tinga Taqueria, which opened last month, is giving Montclair an option for fast food and takeout besides the pizza and Chinese that everyone tires of. It even delivers. Billing itself as ''fresh Mexican doing the Cal-Tex twist,'' it's a far cry from what my Mexican-American mother cooked in Texas. But I've been there three times, and have every intention of going back. The chicken Tinga burrito ($6.45) is generous and filled with grilled breast of chicken with chipotles, tomatoes and onions. There was enough left over for lunch the next day. The place will make nachos with almost any topping you want ($2.95 plus 90 cents for each topping, black beans and chopped cactus among them). My daughter, Carmen, asked for nachos with rice, even though I told her they're just not done that way, but they did them that way for her. ''We had someone come in and ask for a quesadilla with the cheese on the side the other day,'' said Dana Crowe, one of the owners. You can eat in at about 10 formica tables, and you can bring your own liquor. There is a bright mural on the wall in the style of Diego Rivera, with figures from Carmen Miranda to pre-Columbian men and women. Neither Mr. Crowe nor his partner, David Fishman, had previous restaurant experience, which shows in occasionally uneven service or long waits for takeout. But they are getting help from Ken Sofer, owners of Benny's Burritos in Manhattan, who went to art school with Mr. Crowe, and his influence shows in the fresh ingredients and the attention to authentic Mexican flavors like cilantro and the Habanera hot sauce from Mexico at the tables. Maria Newman

It wasn't the summer evening fare that most people had in mind, and after 10 minutes nearly half the audience cleared out.

After a few hours of closed-door talks, Ms. Hanover, 52, was looking cheerier. Mr. Giuliani, 58, had agreed to a settlement giving her $6.8 million. title: Jungle Perch With a View Of the Pacific
description: THE year had fewer than 12 hours remaining, and I was standing in a Costa Rican rain forest, as wet as I would have been in a shower. My wife, Laura, and I had set out early on the morning of Dec. 31, with two other couples and a guide, hoping to spend a day hiking and monkey-spotting during the so-called dry season. By 2 p.m., one of the other couples had called it quits, our clothes were soaked and we had seen none of the region's famous howler monkeys.

title: A Philosopher Shows Dance Also Has a Brain
description: AS the philosopher-in-residence at the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C., Gerald E. Myers has an intriguing job title. But what exactly does he do? ''What I do is spend most of my time answering the question, 'What does a philosopher-in-residence do?' '' he said.

title: 'The Monk Downstairs'
description: Rebecca finally finished painting the in-law apartment on a Friday night, and on Saturday morning she rented it to some poor guy who had just left a monastery. The ad had not even appeared in the papers yet, but she had tucked a tiny Apt. for Rent sign in the front window and he just wandered by and rang the bell. His name was Michael Christopher.

title: Increasingly, It's the Economy That Scares Us
description: In the course of 24 hours last week President Bush gave a major speech calling for business reforms that will ''usher in a new era of integrity in corporate America'' and held a press conference that dealt more with Mr. Bush's conduct when he was a Harken Energy board member than with the whereabouts of Osama bin Laden. Meanwhile, the House of Representatives was grilling former and current WorldCom executives about accounting irregularities, and senators were voting unanimously to support tough new corporate-reform legislation.

title: Innovative Songs That Illuminate a Poet's Abyss
description: ''THERE are still songs to be sung on the other side of mankind.'' The words are those of the exiled French-Romanian poet Paul Celan, and they come singing now near the start of a magnificent hourlong sequence of songs and interludes by Harrison Birtwistle, collectively titled ''Pulse Shadows'' and newly available on a Teldec CD.

title: The Tiger Files
description: On Thursday, when play begins in Muirfield, Scotland, site of this year's British Open, Tiger Woods will resume his quest to capture golf's Grand Slam -- winning all four major tournaments in one year. It has never been done. By winning the Masters and United States Open this year, Woods became the first golfer since Jack Nicklaus, 30 years ago, to get even halfway there. Woods did win four consecutive majors, but over two years (2000 and 2001), in what has become known as the Tiger Slam. As a golfer, Woods has no peer.

title: Career Move By Tillman Is a Bold One

description: THE line dividing opera and musical theater has never been clear. But in recent times both forms have been expanding, and crossovers are increasingly common. In fact, some people deny that any distinction exists.

title: The Shadow of Circumstance
description: Ben Yehuda Street in Jerusalem, where the American students used to stand around Sbarro's pizza, chatting each other up, is all but deserted these days. The tourists who regularly thronged the tiny shops where you can buy souvenirs like khaki T-shirts with the insignia of the Israeli Army have fled to more peaceful destinations. The few people around seem to be locals resolutely going about their errands, carrying the ubiquitous little plastic bags in which everything from fruits to cosmetics is sold. There is not one eye-catching shopping bag anywhere to be found in Jerusalem; for that, like so much else that is historically trivial but culturally telling, you have to go to Tel Aviv.

title: SUPREME COURT NOMINATION
description: Governor McGreevey last week announced his nomination of Barry T. Albin to serve on the State Supreme Court. Mr. Albin, 50, has been a partner at the Woodbridge law firm of Wilentz, Goldman & Spitzer since 1986. He worked as a deputy attorney general during the Byrne Administration and had also served as an assistant prosecutor in Passaic and Middlesex Counties. Mr. Albin, who would replace Justice Gary S. Stein, who retires in September, is the governor's first nomination to the seven-member court. He must be approved by the State Senate. John Holl

title: The Sweeps Baby: An Argument for Abstinence
description: ON the season finale of NBC's ''Friends,'' the unhappily single Rachel -- whose accidental pregnancy was revealed at the close of the previous season -- finally gave birth to a baby daughter. Now, as Rachel's belly expands again in reruns, you can't help wondering: how badly is this baby going to wreck the show? Not to put too much pressure on the ''Friends'' writers, but has any show ever gotten better after the birth of its season-ending bundle of joy?

title: When a Tenant Must Break a Lease

title: Documenting Newark's Poor
description: The Library of Congress recently acquired 24 photographs taken by Helen M. Stummer of Metuchen during her 25-year career documenting the effects of poverty. Sixteen of the works were photographed in Newark, the remainder in Manhattan's East Village. Carol Marie Johnson, a curator for photography at the Library of Congress, wrote, ''Whether photographing the spontaneity of children playing on inner-city streets and litter-strewn vacant lots, or the reality of the elderly struggling to survive on a fixed income, Stummer's photographs portray her subjects with respect and compassion.'' A New York-based photo researcher, Anne Burns, first recommended Ms. Stummer's work to the library. ''I've been doing this for 12 years and I've never seen anything like it,'' Ms. Burns said. Ms. Stummer, 66, said, ''I feel the need to document a world where people are trying to survive in a violent environment,'' she said. Michelle Falkenstein

title: The Young and the Restless

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for MONA DOYLE; How Long Will the Shopping Spree Last?
description: MAYBE it was just the warm weather, but consumers went on a shopping spree last month at America's malls and stores, giving major retailers a healthy sales gain after a soft spring. The big discount chains like Wal-Mart, Kohl's and Target all exceeded Wall Street estimates of June sales. Whether shoppers will continue to spend at a relatively robust rate is unclear. Many economic forecasters have said the plummeting stock market and the loss of investor confidence from the barrage of corporate scandals will inevitably catch up to the consumer, who will feel more insecure, less wealthy and less inclined to shop.

title: BackTalk; First Kicks for the Next Generation

The eight little boys and girls finished the 10-game season with less than a handful of goals. They never really got the hang of passing or dribbling the ball. And at least as much as their time on the field, they loved their time on the sideline eating snacks, messing with water bottles and playing with the action figures and tea sets brought along for younger siblings.

title: THE CLOSE READER

The tourists who regularly thronged the tiny shops where you can buy souvenirs like khaki T-shirts with the insignia of the Israeli Army have fled to more peaceful destinations. The few people around seem to be locals resolutely going about their errands, carrying the ubiquitous little plastic bags in which everything from fruits to cosmetics is sold. There is not one eye-catching shopping bag anywhere to be found in Jerusalem; for that, like so much else that is historically trivial but culturally telling, you have to go to Tel Aviv.

title: Upending the Expectations of Science
description: Our earliest known hominid ancestor, Sahelanthropus tchadensis, was introduced to the public last week under the name Toumai, which means ''hope of life'' in the Goran language of the Sahel desert. (The name is given to babies born near the end of the dry season.) The skull, a portion of the jaw and tooth fragments are the only evidence of a species that lived in central Africa between six million and seven million years ago. The skull is unquestionably one of the most important fossil finds in the last 100 years, in part because it provides the best glimpse we've had of the origins of the human lineage.

title: Getting Dad Off the Road
description: WE all knew the next car crash was coming, and could only hope my father wouldn't injure someone's daughter, son, parent or friend when it happened. Short of handcuffing my 77-year-old father to a bedpost, there seemed no way to discourage him from getting behind the wheel of his increasingly battered, smashed and scraped Nissan. He had had at least five crashes in recent years, all involving his inability to stay awake or otherwise focus his attention on the busy highway beyond the driveway of my parents' house in northern Westchester. Miraculously, he had never been hurt save for a black eye and the occasional sore rib.

title: 'The Whore's Child'
description: Sister Ursula belonged to an all but extinct order of Belgian nuns who conducted what little spiritual business remained to them in a decrepit old house purchased by the diocese seemingly because it was unlikely to outlast them. Since it was on Forest Avenue, a block from our house, I'd seen Sister Ursula many times before the night she turned up in class, but we never had spoken. She drove a rusted-out station wagon that was always crowded with elderly nuns who needed assistance getting in and out. Though St. Francis Church was only a few blocks away, that was too far to walk for any of them except Sister Ursula, her gait awkward but relentless. "You should go over there and introduce yourself someday," Gail, my wife, suggested more than once. "Those old women have been left all alone." Her suspicion was later confirmed by Sister Ursula herself. "They are waiting for us to die," she confessed. "Impatient of how we clutch to our miserable existences."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSBORNE, ELIZABETH BEAM
description: OSBORNE-Elizabeth Beam. Age 96, died July 10, 2002 in Lenox, MA. Born Mary Elizabeth Beam in New Jersey on October 13, 1905, Mrs. Osborne graduated with honors from Smith College in 1926, where she was President of her class, and from Yale Law School in 1930. She was the first woman employed as a lawyer by Sullivan & Cromwell, a law firm in New York, where she continued to work during the Second World War. In 1949 she moved to Geneva, IL. when her husband, John S. Osborne, was made President of Central and Southwest Corporation, a public utility holding company. During the years that she lived in the midwest, Mrs. Osborne was an active volunteer, serving as an elected member of the school board in Geneva, IL, a Chicago suburb, and on the board of the Chicago Art Institute, among other positions. Following her husband's death in 1965, she returned to the New York area, where she resumed work as a lawyer, first at the Vera Institute in New York and later at the Legal Aid offices in Bridgeport, CT. She lived for many years in nearby Southport where she also served as a volunteer at the Pequot Library. Mrs. Osborne is survived by her sons John S. Osborne, Jr., of NY and Salisbury, CT., and David Beam Osborne, of Brunswick, ME, and by their wives, and by her granddaughter and namesake, Elizabeth Beam Osborne of NY. A memorial service will be announced and burial will follow on the grounds of Williams College, where Mr. Osborne was a member of the Board of Trustees.

description: Another financial gauge is looking a bit flaky these days, but nobody is accused of cooking the books.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about diminishing interest in summer travel tours for teenagers misstated the name of a tour company that provides such trips. It is Westcoast Connection Travel, not West Coast Connections. The article also misidentified the company's director. He is Mark Segal; Howard Fox is the director of American Trails West, another agency in that business.

title: The World; Palestinian Voices: A Deep Despair
description: EARLIER this month, President Bush tried to go over the heads of the Palestinian leadership to appeal to Palestinian people to turn away from Yasir Arafat, pledging American help in their quest for nationhood if they installed a more democratic leadership.

title: Whose Neighborhood?
description: IT was a serene barbecue in the back garden of a town house on West 141st Street. The roses were magenta. Chicken sizzled. A toddler giggled as he tasted his first mulberry. But the talk quickly turned to the unwanted visitors who haunted the stoop. As birds cheeped, the host described his two-year battle to get the men to move.

title: From China, Ancient Tales In Modern Dress
description: Chinese music and theater, traditional and modern, has made significant headway in New York over the last decade, with an influx of composers, performers and directors. Now the Lincoln Center Festival, which became a major player in the field with its epic production of the 16th-century Chinese opera ''The Peony Pavilion'' in 1999, offers two contemporary counterparts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, JACOB M.
description: LEVY-Jacob M., 95. On July 11th, 2002. Husband of the late Celia, father of Naomi and Harold, grandfather of Stacie and Matthew. A retired accountant, a lover of books and history who retained his sharp mind, will and wit till the end. He was truly unique and will be missed.

title: Commercial Property/New Jersey; Influx of Drug and Biotech Firms Is Seen Continuing
description: THERE is a rule of thumb about marketing commercial real estate that goes something like this: attract one tenant and more will come, which will attract more.

title: An Affair to Remember
description: IN April 1977, Janine, a Palestinian friend who worked for a travel agency in Paris, asked me whether I wanted a free charter-jet ticket to spend Easter weekend in New York.

title: The Beach Is All Very Well, But They Miss the Movies
description: When Kate Judge was a teenager in the early 1980's, she walked over to the Jerry Lewis movie theater on Beach 105th Street and saw ''Jaws'' with her brother Patrick. Having swum a lot in the ocean as a kid, she was terrified at the Technicolor spectacle of the placid Atlantic punctured by the maw of a rampaging shark. She screamed and dumped her popcorn in her brother's lap.
