description: MEET JOHN TROW

title: A Cozy Italian Spot Suited for Big Appetites
description: AS each enormous portion arrived at our table at Pasta Cosi in Branford, I thought of this admonition: Never eat more than you can lift.

title: A Store Lures Guys Who Are Graduating From Chinos
description: TO the uninitiated, walking into the Diesel jeans store on Union Square West feels a lot like stumbling into a rave. Techno music pounds at a mind-rattling level. A television plays a videotape of a Japanese boxing match, inexplicably. There are no helpful signs pointing to men's or women's departments, and no obvious staff members in sight.

title: The Nation: Mass Markets; Is Today's New Investor Tomorrow's New Populist?
description: IMAGINE that the cryonics lab that took custody of the deceased baseball slugger Ted Williams last week had also managed to keep William Jennings Bryan on ice. The famous populist, who failed three times as a presidential candidate, might like his political chances if he could somehow wake up right now.

title: Bankruptcy Doctors Are Most Definitely In
description: ENRON. Global Crossing. Kmart. Soon, probably WorldCom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, GEORGE TOWNE
description: BAKER-George Towne, Coronado, CA., June 8, age 88. Fearless seaman. USNA, '35. Obituary: www.gtbaker.org

title: Fishermen Take Their Chances on Bay After Fatal Boating Accident
description: At 10 p.m., the only sounds on Little Neck Bay were the inky swells slapping against moored sailboats and the whisper of traffic on the Cross Island Parkway. The moon emitted only a sliver of white light on Friday; the shimmering Throgs Neck Bridge easily outshone it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARDINER, ETHEL (EDIE)
description: KARDINER-Ethel (Edie). On July 8. Age 85, of cancer. Widow of Dr. Abram Kardiner. Beloved mother of Ellin Kaiser. Devoted grandmother of David and Sarah Kaiser. Therapist in New York City for over 45 years. Active in AIPAC and Citizens Committee for Children. Contributions to Sloan-Kettering.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: COAL MINER'S HOLIDAY

title: 7 Reach a First-Place Tie At the Annual Chicago Open
description: At the 11th annual Chicago Open Tournament, held at the Hyatt Regency Oak Brook Hotel over the Memorial Day Weekend, seven grandmasters tied for first place with 5 1/2-1 1/2 scores in the seven-round Swiss-system competition. Grigory Kaidanov of Lexington, Ky.; Jaan Ehlvest of Estonia; Alexander Shabalov of Pittsburgh; Leonid Yudasin of Israel; Ildar Ibragimov of Russia; Giorgi Kacheishvili of Georgia; and Alex Yermolinsky of San Francisco each won $2,971.43.

title: Nicole Porcaro, Christopher Nolan
description: Nicole Laura Porcaro, a daughter of Laura Sarno Porcaro and Peter M. Porcaro of Franklin Lakes, N.J., was married there yesterday to Christopher John Nolan, the son of Donna M. Nolan and John B. Nolan of Colonia, N.J. The Rev. Peter J. Palmisano performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Blessed Sacrament.

title: Editorial Observer; Black and White Bird Turns Humans Green
description: Some kinds of wildlife inspire more human support than others. Imperiled suckerfish, woodpeckers and red-legged frogs have managed to stall developments and spare wilderness around the country, but their advocates tend to be environmental lawyers, not ordinary nature lovers. The majestic loon, however, is another story.

title: Writing the Pledge: The Original Intent
description: To the Editor:

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mercedes-Benz SL500 and BMW Z8; 50's Couture, Neatly Refashioned
description: INSPIRED by a classic roadster of the 1950's, the BMW Z8 stands out from the retro-design pack: it is not simply evocative, it is visually elegant in a modern way. The design has continuity from the sleek nose to the truncated tail and avoids unnecessary embellishment.

title: Of Punishment and Prevention
description: Many people angered by the recent spate of corporate and financial misdeeds are calling for jail time for the executives responsible. A federal judge in Kansas City, Mo., has another punishment in mind: lecturing to student groups on the evils of financial fraud.

title: Magazine Protests Writer's Treatment By State Department
description: The editor of the conservative magazine National Review today protested the State Department's interrogation of a reporter who had criticized the ease with which Saudis had been granted visas.

title: NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA
description: New Jersey's more than 200 Revolutionary War battlefields and other historic Revolutionary War sites would be included in an American Revolution National Heritage Area under federal legislation proposed by Representatives Rodney Frelinghuysen and Rush Holt. The area, which would be the 23rd such designation in the country, would be part of the National Park Service and would be coordinated by the Morristown National Historical Park, site of Washington's headquarters in the winter of 1779-80. The legislation would provide seed money for local historical organizations to preserve the sites, many of which are now poorly marked or remain unmarked, and technical help in preserving and promoting the areas. General Washington's troops and British and Hessian troops crisscrossed the state many times between 1776 and 1784, but only the most well-known sites are preserved. Karen DeMasters

title: In Paris, Discipline, Decadence And the Old Order Changes
description: Subversive minds apparently think alike. With strict tailoring, wit and a stir of petticoats, Jean Paul Gaultier and Karl Lagerfeld took control of couture's pretty seams this week and slowly released a steam of sex and sin.

title: Survivor
description: We lived in Riverdale, Ga., me and my dad and my mother and my two brothers. We didn't know nothing about Huntington's disease back then -- even the doctors didn't know much. We didn't know the chances of us getting it till later on. Now it feels like a family curse. My dad's brother had it. He shot and killed himself. My grandmother got put in a sanitarium and died there.

title: Liberty Gives the Mystics a Rough Time at Home
description: The Liberty, a savvy veteran team, was not expected to beat the younger, stronger Washington Mystics today. After all, the Mystics began the day in first place in the Eastern Conference, the Liberty in fourth. The Mystics were 8-0 at home. There were questions whether the Liberty had the game, the legs, the rebounding or the bench to beat the Mystics.

title: BackTalk; For Fragile Racehorses, Too Much and Too Soon
description: Every picture tells a story.

title: July 7-13
description: BOTTOM LINE President Bush, addressing the wave of corporate wrongdoing that has gripped the nation for months, called for more aggressive policing of big business and longer prison sentences for wrongdoers in a speech on Wall Street. But his proposals did little to restore confidence among investors, who sent stock prices down further. And it was followed by bipartisan votes in the Senate for measures that would go well beyond anything the president is seeking.

title: Tchotchkes for a Cause
description: Martha Stewart has spent two decades developing books, paints, linens and lamps that bear her name. But it took someone else, and a government inquiry into her sale of ImClone Systems shares, to come up with beach hats, coolers, T-shirts and tank tops imprinted with ''Save Martha!''

title: Stephanie Brugler, Christopher Dauer
description: Stephanie Carol Brugler and Christopher Scott Dauer were married yesterday by the Rev. Scott Hayashi at Christ Church Episcopal in Portola Valley, Calif.

title: Honors for Huntington, But Failure on Housing
description: Re ''Huntington Named 'All-America City' '' [June 23]: Recognition of the Town of Huntington's honor as one of 10 all-America cities, where all of 40 communitites competed, is not indicative of either success or good intentions in meeting its challenges. The award does not reflect the fact that low-income residents continue to live in substandard, overcrowded housing, or the widespread belief that acts and omissions of the town contribute to this situation.

title: With Bears in the Street, Municipal Bonds Gather Strength
description: AS the stock market sank last week to its lowest level since 1997, even the most fervent stock investors were surveying the alternatives, looking as far across the spectrum of investment risk as tax-free bonds. That same swing in sentiment has helped municipal bond funds, the proverbial tortoise of investment categories, to outperform almost all other fund categories so far this year.

title: 3 Youths, Adrift in Life and a Play
description: THEATER savants know that Keith Bunin is a brainy young playwright with the mighty mission of combatting mindlessness. From titles of lyric grace (''The Principality of Sorrows'') to positively cosmic and mythic themes, Mr. Bunin's works reveal a boundless sense of wonder.

title: City Smarts
'The Fly Swatter'
description: To the Editor:

title: Cavort
description: 'Don't laugh at the expression,'' wrote John Steele, a former congressman from North Carolina, in 1794. ''It suits the idea I meant to convey.'' He had just described a colleague as having cavauted, a variant of cavaulted and probably a corruption of curvetted.

title: Drought-Tolerant Plants Get Their Turn
description: IT had to happen on the Upper West Side of Manhattan: drought-tolerant wedding bouquets.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Evening Hours column last Sunday about the opening night of the International Music Festival at Caramoor in Katonah, N.Y., misspelled the surname of a guest. She is Sandy Moreinis, not Morcinis.

title: Make Companies Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Streetscapes/86th Street Between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues; A Regal West Side Block Regains a Bit of Its Glory
description: IN 1890, 86th Street between Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues was advertised as ''that queen of all West Side streets,'' but by the middle of the 20th century its private-house legacy had unraveled. In the last two decades, however, incremental improvements have recaptured a fragmentary sense of what the block must have meant to its original planner, the architect and yacht designer John G. Prague.

title: A Story of Two Wines
description: Raphael's 2001 sauvignon blanc displays the finesse routinely expected of work by Richard Olsen-Harbich, the winemaker. You can sense intuitively, from the pale-brass body in the transparent bottle, how refreshing and easy to drink it is.

title: The Shadow of Circumstance
description: Ben Yehuda Street in Jerusalem, where the American students used to stand around Sbarro's pizza, chatting each other up, is all but deserted these days. The tourists who regularly thronged the tiny shops where you can buy souvenirs like khaki T-shirts with the insignia of the Israeli Army have fled to more peaceful destinations. The few people around seem to be locals resolutely going about their errands, carrying the ubiquitous little plastic bags in which everything from fruits to cosmetics is sold. There is not one eye-catching shopping bag anywhere to be found in Jerusalem; for that, like so much else that is historically trivial but culturally telling, you have to go to Tel Aviv.

title: And a T-Bone for My Date
description: As the weather gets warmer and diners move outdoors, it seems that many New York City women are trading in their two-legged dinner partners for four-legged ones. Far from desperate, these women simply prefer to sit with a trusty dog rather than suffering through another blind date. Jill Lenney, who frequents the Upper East Side restaurant scene with Barney, a mixed breed, said, ''My dog is great company -- much better than many dates I've had.''

title: In Aisles of Specialty Items, Filling a Cart as Chefs Do
description: Now you can shop like a chef in Westchester. Gourmet Garage, long a resource for Manhattan cooks, has opened its doors in Scarsdale. The 25,000-square-foot store features fresh produce, meat, fish, baked goods, prepared foods and hundreds of other specialty items.

title: Yousuf Karsh, Who Photographed Famous And Infamous of 20th Century, Dies at 93
description: Yousuf Karsh, whose photographic portraits of the famous and the powerful are known to millions throughout the world, died yesterday at 93.

title: Anne Cloherty, Timothy Fortune
description: Anne Elizabeth Cloherty, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John P. Cloherty of Westwood, Mass., was married yesterday to Timothy Michael Fortune, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Fortune of Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Francis J. Cloherty, an uncle of the bride and a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Denis Church in Westwood.

title: A Permit to Carry, but the Gun Stays Home
description: FOR the growing number of state residents licensed to carry a handgun, there are plenty of new, used and antique retail options in Connecticut, the birthplace of Colt, Mossberg, Marlin, Winchester and Sturm, Ruger. I went to Hoffman's Gun Center -- ''Guns for the Good Guys'' -- in Newington

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUBER, FRANCINE
description: HUBER-Francine. 93. Beloved wife of the late Albert. For many years, a resident of Brooklyn and an interior designer.

title: Taking Off on a Field Trip
description: FOR some of us, the perfect bathing suit is the Holy Grail. Lycra origami to tuck, hide, slim and otherwise morph the average suburban blob into a bodacious bod -- or, better yet, to make it disappear altogether.

title: July 7-13: THE TALK OF ...; Egypt: Deviant Dentist
description: On the front pages of Egypt's sensational newspapers, in the crime sections of its more staid papers and on the lips of uncountable Egyptians was the story of a dentist in an upper-class neighborhood accused of having put female patients under general anesthetic, sexually assaulting them and videotaping the crime.

title: Canada Geese: It's Love and Hate
description: LEE HENDRICKSON'S tone was full of disbelief. ''Where are the geese?'' the Farmingdale woman asked. ''I usually bring my two daughters here, but today we came to feed the geese and they're gone.''

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: WHILE Alan Cumming was still playing the emcee in the Broadway revival of ''Cabaret,'' Jennifer Jason Leigh came in to replace Natasha Richardson as Sally Bowles. The new co-stars became friends; then they wrote and directed a movie together. THE ANNIVERSARY PARTY(2001) is a sexy, caustic look at a recently reconciled couple who invite a small Hollywood group over to celebrate. Gwyneth Paltrow, Kevin Kline and Parker Posey are among the guests, who play charades, try to repress their personal and professional jealousies and try a little Ecstasy --Saturday at 8 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 3:40 p.m. on Starz.

description: To the Editor:

title: Ignoring the Call of the Catskills (Not to Mention the Hamptons)
description: IT started five years ago. Friends of long standing, who live on the Upper West Side, announced they were getting a weekend place up near Albany. Soon after, another friend called to say he and his spouse had purchased a home in the Catskills. Within a month, a TriBeCa couple had found a home with a garden in some Hampton.

description: To the Editor:

title: Right Conduct Never Hurts
description: Great truths are presented most easily through stories, for children as well as adults. Rabbis, imams and priests have long known that the best way to instruct people about good conduct and right thinking is through an engaging story. The story must be appealing and entertaining, and the author must never lecture. Such are the parables of the Bible, the fables of Aesop, and the traditional tales of the Sufi.

description: MORAN-James. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of James Moran, associated with The Times from 1976 until retiring in 1990.

description: THE center strip that separates opposing lanes on Queens Boulevard from 84th Drive to 87th Avenue used to be a ribbon of bare concrete.

title: Business; Paper or Plastic? Currency Making Is in Flux
description: PAPER money first appeared in China more than 13 centuries ago, and the counterfeiting industry was born soon after. But now a growing number of countries, worried about inexpensive technology that enables a counterfeiter armed with little more than a computer inkjet printer to create real-looking fakes to the untrained eye, are switching to plastic.

description: For a moment last week, I wondered if Monique Harwell and her son, Reginald Harwell II, could be the people I've been searching for, the corrupters of big-time college sports.

title: July 7-13: SCIENCE/HEALTH; KNEE SURGERY USELESS
description: A popular and expensive knee operation for arthritis pain is no better than a fake operation, a study found. Patients whose arthritic joints were arthroscopically scraped and/or washed did no better than those whose surgeons simply pretended to operate; most of the 180 patients in the study reported that their knee pain had improved. At least 225,000 patients have such operations each year, at a cost of more than $1 billion to private insurers, Medicare and the Department of Veterans Affairs.

title: No Spike Lee? No Ramones?; Horns Blare, Brakes Screech On Yet Another Street
description: To the Editor:

title: The View From/Cromwell; Older, Wiser and Seeking a New Walk of Life: the Priesthood
description: JIM DOWNS is a 70-year-old grandfather of 17 who became a Roman Catholic priest last month. At the Holy Apostles Seminary in Cromwell, where he had been studying for the last five years, this is not considered unusual.

description: For some people, it just isn't vacation if there isn't a little work involved.

description: The bill passed by the House of Representatives to give guns to pilots would have effects far beyond the cockpits and cabins of jetliners, legal experts said.

title: The Most Wanted Palestinian
description: As the father of a young American woman murdered in a suicide bombing in 1995, I found the depiction of Qeis Adwan to be revolting. Qeis Adwan was a terrorist whose ultimate goal in life was to kill Jews. And if a few Israeli Arabs died in the process, too, so be it.

title: At Impasse, Haiti's Leader Talks of Bypassing Opposition
description: President Jean-Bertrand Aristide of Haiti has proposed holding parliamentary elections with outside monitors next year even if the opposition rejects talks, saying he has made ''major sacrifices'' to comply with international requirements to end a political impasse.

title: Kathleen Eads, Ron Orbach
description: Kathleen Eads and Ron Orbach were married yesterday in the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion at the Los Angeles Music Center. Larry Moss, appointed by Los Angeles County as a deputy commissioner of civil marriages for this wedding, officiated.

title: Habitats/East 64th Street; A Backyard Hot Tub On the 43rd Floor
description: MANHATTAN is many things, but it is not hot-tub territory. For Barry Skolnick, however, the city's natural barriers were merely an obstacle to overcome. And although many hurdles can be surmounted by will and creativity, Mr. Skolnick, an Upper East Sider, found that when it comes to hoisting a hot tub at a high-rise, money is crucial.

title: Defining Limit Of Generosity For 9/11 Fund
description: Within the next two weeks, the man responsible for distributing billions of taxpayer dollars to thousands of families who lost relatives in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks will decide two dozen test cases that will at last establish the rough boundaries for the sizes of the awards.

title: Squaring Off Over Energy
description: CLOSE down Indian Point, one side says, and we will be faced with a grim electric future of soaring energy prices and flickering lights, with brownouts and blackouts part of the fabric of daily life. Categorically false, says the other side, with claims of their own: that Indian Point is superfluous and could be shuttered with little effect on energy supply or cost.

title: Earthen Vessels
description: BETRAYAL

title: New Reasons To Wonder If the Worst Is Over
description: HOW much worse could the worst bear market in a generation get? A lot.

title: A Retro Robot Who's Big for His Age
description: JUNIOR high isn't easy for anyone, but it's especially uncomfortable for Robot Jones. That's because he is, as one might guess, a robot, a three-foot-eight, 500-pound sixth grader with a 9,468-megavolt memory who lives in a big metal box in the suburbs with his mother (a gas pump) and his father (a big welding arm). And he's the only robot at school.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mercedes-Benz SL500 and BMW Z8; That Six-Figure Swagger
description: FOR a car to be worth $100,000 it ought to provide equal parts of style, prestige and mechanical sophistication. When I dropped my daughter off at a fancy athletic club in a red Mercedes-Benz 500SL, the other dads assumed that I had won the lottery, inherited a fortune or helped win a divorce settlement from a former big-city mayor.

title: A Photograph Goes Digital. Its Subject Is Not Amused.
description: How did D Magazine of Dallas snap that July cover photograph?

title: Is Arming Pilots a Good Idea?
description: To the Editor:

title: Gale Warnings in Washington
description: It is always risky to proclaim a shift in the political landscape, but lately the tremors have been too big to ignore. Congress, which spent the 90's worshiping at the altar of big business, is now grumbling about what Theodore Roosevelt called the ''malefactors of great wealth.'' The debt clock, which was turned off in New York City when the nation started posting budget surpluses, is back on, ticking up each American family's share of the country's red ink. On Friday the federal deficit for this year was estimated at a new high of $165 billion. A president who so confidently responded to terrorist attacks is looking less sure-footed in coping with the loss of confidence in the stock market, preventing future corporate excesses and handling questions about his own business record.

title: Translating for Patients Not Just in Spanish
description: Re ''Critics Fault Hospital on Failure to Hire Spanish Translators'' [July 7]: Why is it only Spanish translators should be hired? People speaking more then 180 languages and dialects immigrate to this country. Would it not be discriminatory to have translators for one group and not another? A hospital should not be blamed because it does not provide special service for a particular group. People who immigrate to this country legally or otherwise should not expect others to be responsible for their shortcomings in communication skills.

title: Reel Change
description: We are now in the thick of the summer movie season, when opening-weekend box-office grosses tend to generate more excitement and suspense than the movies themselves. Since the summer season officially began back in early May, there have been some astonishing numbers: $114 million for a computer-enhanced crime-fighting Spider-Man; $54.2 million for a computer-generated crime-fighting dog; and so on.

title: July 7-13: FRONT LINES; VIRUS RE-CREATED
description: Raising new fears about bioterrorism, scientists at the State University of New York at Stony Brook have synthesized live polio virus using publicly available genetic information and mail-order DNA. It is the first time a virus has been made from scratch. One implication: bioterrorists might be able to make pathogens when they can't obtain a natural one. Another: polio vaccinations might have to continue even after the disease is eradicated, which is expected in the next few years. Andrew Pollack

title: Don't Expect the Governor To Make a Clemency Call
description: They trespass on our golf courses, foul our pools and squabble in the yard, but do they actually deserve the gas chamber?

title: From Buds to Bouquets, Blooms of Inspiration
description: IF there's anything like a sure popular hit where art exhibitions are concerned, it's a show devoted to flowers. The Center for Contemporary Printmaking in Norwalk, which has changed its name from the Connecticut Graphic Arts Center, has gathered a nice large armful. It's called ''Bouquet'' and contains 42 prints by as many artists.

title: INVESTING WITH: Charles Sheedy and Fayez Sarofim; Dreyfus Premier Core Equity Fund
description: CHARLES SHEEDY, co-manager of the $53.6 million Dreyfus Premier Core Equity fund, hews to what he calls the Darwinian theory of investing.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Stripping a Soviet Overlay Off the Classics
description: MAKHARBEK VAZIEV, the dynamic and opinionated 41-year-old director of the legendary Kirov Ballet, represents something of a break with the past.

title: Lawyer Is Said To Have Sold ImClone Shares
description: A top lawyer at ImClone Systems sold more than $2 million of company stock last December, about three weeks before the company announced unfavorable news, people involved in the matter said yesterday.

title: Union to Meet Tonight to Discuss Plan to End Bus Strike in Queens
description: A day after the Queens borough president proposed a resolution to the four-week strike by workers for three private bus companies in Queens, union officials were still weighing the proposal and had not called an end to the strike, a union spokesman said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULMAN, ALAN
description: SHULMAN-Alan. The Violoncello Society of New York mourns the loss of our esteemed colleague Alan Shulman, Founding Member and Past President. Cellist and composer, his dedication to the art of cello playing and his contribution to its literature is legendary. Zara Nelsova, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROHMAN, DR. MICHAEL
description: ROHMAN - Dr. Michael. Professor of cardio-thoracic surgery, a resident of White Plains, NY, on July 12, 2002. Husband of Joelyn Rohman, father of Lisa R. Singer, Debra Gasperini, brother of Linda Rohman Schwartz, grandfather of four. Funeral service 11:30 AM, Monday, July 15, 2002, at Congregation Kol Ami, Soundview Ave., White Plains, NY. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: KEEPING RECORDS SECRET
description: Citing a need to protect the state against terrorism, Governor McGreevey signed an order last week that would allow many government documents to remain secret. Attorney General David Samson and a state panel studying antiterror efforts will decide which records should remain private. Critics point out that the restrictions would include charter school applications, building permits and applications for farmland acquisition, whose connection with antiterrorism is hard to fathom. Jo Piazza

title: Unwelcome Summer Homework: Reading Robert's Rules
description: Where there is no law, but every man does what is right in his own eyes, there is the least of real liberty.

title: The British Supply Lamppost Goo To Fight That Insidious Sticker Shock
description: They crop up like flies drawn to dirty streets: little stickers affixed to lampposts, phone booths and any patch of real estate too small to accommodate a billboard.

title: Life on E Street: From Sessions to `The Sopranos'
description: Though "The Rising" is Bruce Springsteen's first studio recording with the E Street Band in 15 years, the makeup of the group has changed little over time. Some members have been with Mr. Springsteen since the beginning of his career. Here are its current members and sketches of what they've been doing.

title: For the Pampered Tummy
description: Body-conscious diners who stock their handbags with appetite-suppressing tea bags and salad dressings may want to make room for the latest. Now there's the pre-dinner mint, pills to aid digestion by We Care, the holistic health spa in Palm Springs, Calif., where many celebrities flock for juice fasting, to load up on enzymes, and to get daily colonics. The spa's carryout line ($13 to $30 at www.wecarespa.com or 800-888-2523) includes digestive enzymes, acidophilus, energy pills with kyo green and power green, and fiber regulators, all of which are said to promote digestion, purify the blood, detoxify the liver and replenish the intestines with beneficial bacteria. ''The pills are selling like hot cakes,'' said Susy Lombardi, the owner of the spa. In New York, similar digestive aids can be found at Whole Foods in Chelsea (250 Seventh Avenue). Consider it a little insurance for fitting into those low-rise Seven jeans. KAREN ROBINOVITZ

title: Stocks' Slide Is Playing Havoc With Older Americans' Dreams
description: As the owners of an Atlanta advertising agency that billed $40 million a year, Jim and Jan Pringle were featured in a cover article in Inc. magazine asking, ''What's the best time to retire?''

title: Customers' Dramas, Salesman's Story
description: MANY screen buffs would assume that a television movie studded with award-winning independent film stars like William H. Macy, Helen Mirren, Kyra Sedgwick and Kathy Baker would be quirky, dark and definitely adults-only.

title: Before They Were Stars, They Were Star-Quality
description: ''LANGRISHE, GO DOWN,'' a 1978 movie made for British television and belatedly having its American theatrical premiere on Wednesday in New York, is one of those buried treasures that are unearthed for reasons that have as much to do with star power as with quality. The stars in question are the 29-year-old Jeremy Irons and the 43-year-old Judi Dench, who play lovers. Unlike so many early screen performances by not-yet-stars, both Mr. Irons, who affects an impeccable German accent, and Dame Judi, who is almost unrecognizable as the actress of today, are already in full possession of their talents.

title: Correction

Little Walter's real name was Marion Walter Jacobs; Big Walter, whose real name was Walter Horton, continued to work with Waters after Little Walter's death in 1968.

title: Everyone Into the Pool? Some Say It's Not So

title: The Art of the Gaffe

One paragraph restricted the role of an employee who had been with me 15 years. I refused to sign; I said the deal was not about money, it was about people. The 40-some people in the room were horrified. They redrafted the paragraph, though.

No one knows where Thailand is. The most popular girl in the class tells Oy to bring her beautiful silk dancing dress to the playground for the others to try on if she wants to be in their club. Here's a fine novel for early independent readers that conveys lots of information -- about Thailand and making friends -- in a familiar kind of classroom story.

title: A Good Time, Even With Grandma
description: ONCE you've had a good time somewhere you're eager to go back, so when our grandchildren were left with us one weekend last July, I suggested a return trip to Belmont Lake State Park in Babylon. On a visit there the summer before, we built a fire, roasted hot dogs and marshmallows, spent 20 minutes or so at the playground and, best of all, went for a ride in a pedal boat. We would do it all over again with one small revision -- this time around Grandma would be with us.

title: July 7-13: SCIENCE/HEALTH; HORMONE STUDY HALTED
description: In a stunning decision, federal scientists announced they were halting a large study of combination hormone replacement therapy for menopausal women because the harm associated with estrogen and progestin exceeded the benefit. The risks -- of breast cancer, blood clots, heart attack and stroke -- were tiny. But so were the benefits: slightly fewer hip fractures and colorectal cancers. The study, involving 16,000 healthy women, was asking if the combination of estrogen and progestin could prevent disease. Another part of the study, involving women who have had hysterectomies and who are taking estrogen alone, is continuing: data have not yet shown evidence of net benefit or net harm. Gina Kolata

title: Taking the Low-Risk Road

At a New York Stock Exchange dinner where he received Chief Executive magazine's Chief Executive of the Year award, he spoke on the touchy topic of corporate responsibility. In several respects, Mr. Weill went further than President Bush did on Tuesday in calling for measures to restore confidence, like requiring companies to count stock options for their top five officers as expenses. ''It is clear that excessive use of stock options can exacerbate a short-term focus,'' he said.

title: Corrections
description: Tables last Sunday in the Mutual Funds Report, Part 2 of this section, carried some outdated performance ratings from Morningstar Inc. Although all the figures should have been up to date for June 30, the right-hand numeral in each pair was from May 31. Corrected ratings can be found at nytimes.com/mutualfunds. Mr. Bush recently talked of looking for inspiration in another president who led the nation in an era of corporate wrongdoing: Theodore Roosevelt. But Mr. Bush might not realize that Roosevelt was far more radical than any Republican of today. In fact, Roosevelt advocated a restructuring of government-business relations more radical than most Democrats now seek.

Over the last few years, they have changed their style by changing their emphasis. After a brief hiatus, the guitarist John Frusciante rejoined the group for its 1999 album ''Californication,'' and his lucid, labyrinthine riffs helped the Red Hot Chili Peppers evolve into a mellow progressive-rock act.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, HARVEY
description: GREENFIELD-Harvey. Distinguished New York attorney Harvey Greenfield died in his home of natural causes on July 5, 2002. He was an advocate of stock investors, tirelessly fighting corporate fraud on their behalf through his firm, the Law Firm of Harvey Greenfield. He was an active litigator right up until his death. Mr Greenfield was born June 5, 1928, received his A.B. degree from New York University in 1947, and his J.D. degree from Harvard Law School in 1950. He practiced securities, tax and corporate law with various firms in New York City until 1965 when he founded his own firm. In 1960-1961 he served as President of the Federal Bar Council, and remains the youngest president in that organization's history. Since 1965, he has specialized in securities and corporate law, concentrating in the area of class action secuities and derivative litigation. In 2000, he arranged for the formation of the Harvey Greenfield Chair in Securities Litigation at Harvard Law School, to be funded by an endowment of $3 million. Contributions in Mr. Greenfield's memory may be made to Harvard Law School. Harvey Grenfield is survived by his aunt, Esther Goodman, his cousin, Isabel Friedman, her husband Arnold Friedman and their two daughters. His law firm will continue to operate under the direction of Laura M. Perrone, Esq., 60 East 42nd Street, Suite 2001, New York, New York 10165, 212-949-5500.

title: Challenging the Accepted Wisdom
description: These have not been good times for established medical practices. In realms as disparate as breast cancer, menopause, arthritis and weight control, the prevailing orthodoxy finds itself under attack. For the past several months a controversy has raged over whether mammograms to detect tiny tumors in the breast have any proven value in reducing breast cancer mortality. Last week a federal study of hormone pills to treat postmenopausal women for a wide range of ailments was terminated when prolonged use of the pills was found to do more harm than good. A day or so later researchers reported that a popular operation for arthritis of the knee worked no better than a sham procedure that left patients thinking they had received treatment when in fact they had not.

Jefferson Smurfit had held talks with another buyout firm, the Texas Pacific Group, people close to the negotiations said in June. Jefferson Smurfit is the largest maker of containerboard, used to make packaging. Madison Dearborn, based in Chicago, believes profit from packaging will rise as the world economy grows.

When night comes, the seventy-four members of the Argonne National Laboratory Pool League trade their computers for cue sticks, to do battle with Newtons laws. And their most fearsome warrior... is Ron Shepard.

title: Putting Rail Back on Track

The United States cannot afford to continue like this, cutting its national railroad a check for one hundred million dollars here, a quarter-billion there, merely enabling it to hobble along, from one funding crisis to the next. The nation should be looking at the big picture, investing in an efficient network of passenger rail as a cost-effective means of meeting pressing national transportation needs. This is the crucial, if seemingly odd, point often lost on both sides of the Washington debate over Amtrak's future -- the issue is larger than trains.

title: The Student; A Tantalizing View Of a Bright Future
description: About six million young Chinese are attending universities and it is to these people that the future holds the most promise and the gravest risks. The current generation of college students is far more concerned with career prospects than with the politics that preoccupied their counterparts in the 1980's. Nationalistic sentiments run high in this group and the Communist Party's leadership goes largely unquestioned. The students' greatest fear, in fact, is political instability that might interfere with their seemingly bright future.

title: The City's Precious Watershed

However, this happy state of affairs can survive only if the city, working with the state and upstate towns, can keep its reservoirs uncontaminated and water quality at a level that satisfies federal standards. Otherwise, the federal Environmental Protection Agency is likely to require the construction of a massive filtration plant with an up-front cost of $5 billion. This is not a burden the city needs, now or in the future.

title: Editorial Observer; To Prevent Conflicts, Look to Commodities Like Diamonds

Angola's guerrillas carried on in large part for booty -- control of the country's diamond fields, which then bought the arms and paid the salaries that allowed the war to continue. Military advantage tipped back and forth depending on who held the diamond fields and how much the government could get for its oil. The cease-fire signed in March stemmed from $30-a-barrel oil and an international blockade of diamonds mined in rebel areas. The embargo weakened the guerrillas, leading to the death of their leader, Jonas Savimbi.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: DEATH SENTENCE OVERTURNED The New Jersey Supreme Court, citing a trial judge's error, reversed a Camden man's death sentence yesterday, but upheld his conviction for murder. The man, Daron Josephs, now 30, was convicted in April 2000 of murdering two other members of a marijuana-distribution ring in 1995. The unanimous ruling by the seven-member court threw out the death sentence because the judge improperly instructed the jury. Under state law, an accomplice cannot be sentenced to death. Yet the jury was told to consider first whether Mr. Josephs committed the murders directly, and then consider whether he was an accomplice. The high court decision said the jury should have been instructed to consider those issues at the same time, which Mr. Josephs' lawyer argued could have reduced the likelihood of his client receiving the death penalty.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Clothier's Sales Rise
description: The Swedish clothing retailer Hennes & Mauritz said sales in June rose 19 percent, compared with the month last year. The increase was the biggest monthly rise this year, as the company's formula of selling trendy clothes, like peasant blouses and hip-hugging jeans, for a fraction of designer prices paid off. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: SWEDEN: CLOTHIER'S SALES RISE The Swedish clothing retailer Hennes & Mauritz said sales in June rose 19 percent, compared with the month last year. The increase was the biggest monthly rise this year, as the company's formula of selling trendy clothes, like peasant blouses and hip-hugging jeans, for a fraction of designer prices paid off. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Whoever the Lyricist, Songs So Hard to Forget
description: THE RICHARD RODGERS READER

title: Beyond Temporary 'Miracles'
description: A cynic wandering through the 17,000-person international AIDS conference here last week might have been tempted to point out that there were actually two conferences taking place under one roof, with remarkably contradictory messages.

title: Results Take Opposite Paths at 2 Large Banks
description: FleetBoston Financial posted a second-quarter loss yesterday after writing off $1.3 billion to shut its investment bank and cover defaulted debt in Argentina, while Bank of America said profit climbed 10 percent on an increase in deposits and home mortgages.

title: Accounts
description: E-Loan, Dublin, Calif., to Pickett Advertising, San Francisco, to handle the account of the online loan company. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $20 million. The account had been handled by the San Francisco office of Saatchi & Saatchi, part of the Publicis Groupe, which closed.

title: Cellphone Records Of Stewart's Broker Provided to Congress
description: Lawyers for Martha Stewart's stockbroker submitted records yesterday from his cellphone to the Congressional committee looking into Ms. Stewart's sale of shares of ImClone Systems Inc., a spokesman for the committee said.

title: Pimlico Becomes New Plum For Magna
description: The Magna Entertainment Corporation added Pimlico Race Course, home of the Preakness Stakes, to its rapidly expanding racetrack holdings yesterday by announcing an agreement to purchase a majority interest in the Maryland Jockey Club.

title: Hughes Loss Narrowed in Its 2nd Quarter
description: The Hughes Electronics Corporation said today that it had a narrower second-quarter loss compared with last year as sales rose 11 percent and the cost of acquiring customers for its DirecTV satellite-television service fell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, NAOMI
description: ROTHSTEIN-Naomi. Of Fair Lawn, New Jersey, formerly of Paterson, NJ. Survived by daughters Elaine Harvey, Louise Birnberg and Harriet Rothman, sister Evelyn Hirschfeld, 14 grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren. Services are today 11:30am Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Route 4, Paramus, NJ.

title: Comfort and Refuge in Black Hamptons Enclave
description: Someday, 9-week-old Synthia Terry Richards will build sand castles on the edge of Gardiners Bay here and dig clams with her toes, just steps from the yellow shingle house that her great-great-grandmother built 55 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAPLOW, ALVIN
description: CAPLOW-Alvin. Talisker on the rocks, double steak rare, Gigi salad.....Happy Birthday with love, Mil.

title: User-Friendly Food Labels
description: People who are allergic to milk products know they should check the ingredients of packaged foods in the grocery store. But not all of them know, for example, that ''whey'' is a synonym for milk, and the food industry is not required to describe ingredients in everyday English -- even though 30,000 people are rushed every year to emergency rooms because of food allergies. That could change if Congress passes a clear-language bill now before the Senate's Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions.

title: Silber Redux
description: To the Editor:

title: Cruise Line, In Bid to Buy Rival, Faces A Deadline
description: The Carnival Corporation is facing a decision this week: Whether to make concessions in its offer for P&O Princess Cruises to appease European antitrust regulators, and bring the long running battle for control of P&O Princess one step closer to fruition.

title: Taking Hold Of the Wheel
description: At one point yesterday afternoon, George W. Bush was beginning to look like the president with perhaps the worst market touch since Herbert Hoover. Every time he tried to sound reassuring, a few hundred points vanished from the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: An Icelandic Battle of Wildlife Versus Voltage
description: This is Europe's second-largest wilderness, a high plateau of lakes and virgin rivers, jagged canyons and snowy former volcanoes linked by swards of treeless tundra inhabited by thousands of reindeer and geese.

title: Pataki Bests 2 Main Rivals on Donations
description: Gov. George E. Pataki, already leading in polls, far outpaced his Democratic rivals in fund-raising over the last six months, taking in about $12.7 million in contributions, according to campaign filings.

title: Woman Gets 4-Year Term in Fatal Dog Attack
description: Marjorie Knoller, whose second-degree-murder conviction in the fatal dog mauling of a neighbor was thrown out last month, was sentenced today to four years in prison for involuntary manslaughter.

title: A Plea Suited To Both Sides
description: When John Walker Lindh was charged in January with conspiring with the Taliban to kill Americans, Attorney General John Ashcroft pronounced it a critical case in the nation's fight against terrorism. He asserted that Mr. Lindh chose to become a fanatical follower of the Taliban and never wavered in his allegiance to terrorism.

title: Market Place; New Prospects for the Battered Drug Stocks
description: Some money managers are beginning to say that the pharmaceutical industry has suffered enough. At beaten-down prices, the stocks are likely to be good long-term investments, they say, whether or not the industry quickly benefits from a wave of mergers.

title: Man Convicted in Murder of Reporter Calls for Retaliation by Other Muslims
description: With security heavy and officials bracing for a retaliatory attack, the man condemned today to death for the kidnapping and murder of the American reporter Daniel Pearl called on fellow Muslims to take revenge for the sentence.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on July 3 with an Arts Abroad article about a low-budget Polish hit film, ''Hi, Tereska,'' reversed the identities of two actresses. Aleksandra Gietner, a reform school girl who played the title role, was at the left; Karolina Sobczak was at the right.

title: Michael Jackson's Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: I.R.A. Apologizes for Civilian Deaths
description: DUBLIN, July 16  For the first time in its 30-year campaign of guerrilla warfare, the Irish Republican Army issued a straight, unmitigated apology this afternoon to the relatives of civilians killed in its violent efforts to unite Northern Ireland with the Irish Republic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPPELMAN, SARAH LEVY
description: KOPPELMAN-Sarah Levy. Of Tenafly, NJ. Five days shy of her 70th birthday. Died after a valiant eight year battle with ovarian cancer on July 13. Beloved mother of Lisa Tames, Suzanne Koppelman and Janet Koppelman. Devoted grandmother to Emma Tames, Jacqueline Tames, and Jenna Katz. A dedicated nurse for 30 years at Englewood Hospital, she was truly unique and we will miss her. We were honored to have her as our mother.

title: Property Owners Challenge Nassau Reassessments in Opening Round of Legal Process
description: For Albert and Dorothy Breusch, the big question is whether they will keep their partial property tax exemption for his service in World War II. For William and Dorothy Taylor, the worry is that their home may be overassessed, especially since, unlike many houses in their neighborhood, it does not have a basement or dormer addition.

title: Food; Monsieur Vrinat's Monument
description: MOST of my favorite restaurants, and most great ones everywhere, are run by chefs. Taillevent, the understated Michelin three-star in Paris's glossy Eighth Arrondissement, is different. Its owner, Jean-Claude Vrinat, works the front of the house, like his father, from whom he inherited the place. His taste, his panache and his meticulous attention to detail have lifted it to its present eminence. He is the Tiger Woods of restaurateurs, a Cesar Ritz for our times, and Taillevent is his monument. Superb in all respects -- dcor, atmosphere, welcome, service, menu, wine list -- it epitomizes the glory of French dining.

title: Video Vividly Captures Prelude to Fortress Revolt
description: They are mostly the faces of men now dead: wild-haired Taliban fighters sitting in rows, their arms tied at the elbow behind their backs, shown on videotape minutes before one of the most desperate battles of the war in Afghanistan.

title: Pessimism On Meeting Bag Deadline
description: Airport executives told the Transportation Security Administration today that the Dec. 31 deadline for searching all checked baggage for explosives was impossible to meet and that trying to do so could make security worse.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Harrison: Tainted Water Warning
description: More than 8,000 residents in Water District No. 1, in the northwestern part of Harrison, were warned yesterday to boil their drinking water for at least two minutes. Town officials said that an undetermined amount of untreated water may have been released into the supply in the previous 24 hours because of a breakdown in the disinfection system at the Rye Lake pumping station. No illnesses have been reported so far, but health officials in Harrison and in Westchester County are continuing to test for possible contamination by E. coli bacteria. Workers have repaired the equipment and opened fire hydrants to flush the untreated water out of the system. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Trips; Sheer and Exhilarating
description: LONGS PEAK, the highest mountain in Rocky Mountain National Park, looks like it was cleaved with a chisel. The eastern aspect of the summit tower appears to have been sheared away in one clean blow, leaving a facet of smooth, pale granite that glows in the morning sun as if lit from within. Stretching from 13,000 feet to just below the 14,255-foot summit, this huge, astonishingly steep plane of rock is known as the Diamond.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Senate Unanimously Passes Corporate Overhaul Bill

title: Trips; Thunderstruck in Quemado, N.M.
description: I HAVE no favorite artist, favorite work of art or favorite museum, but my favorite memories of looking at art usually involve some effort made to see that art. Jaded by the traveling blockbuster, people today seem to expect all art to be readily available. I enjoy making a pilgrimage, which among other things means coping with the unexpected -- thunder, for instance, or what sounded to me like thunder when it should have been lightning. Let me explain.

title: Yielding to Political Pressure, Deutsche Telekom's Chief Quits
description: FRANKFURT, July 16  Yielding to intense political pressure and a stubbornly depressed stock price, the chief executive of Deutsche Telekom , Ron Sommer, resigned today as the head of a company he had sought to transform from a state monopoly into a global communications colossus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, ANN VIRGINIA WATSON
description: WALSH-Ann Virginia Watson. Beloved mother of Gloria, Brooke, Hughes deWitt and Thomas deWitt, died suddenly on Saturday, July 13, 2002, at the age of 70. She was preceded in death by her husband, Thomas deWitt Walsh. She is survived by her grandchildren, Brisa, Julian, Jonothan and Martin. She graduated from Smith College in 1953 and moved to New York to pursue a career in the business world. For many years she worked in New York in the cosmetics industry, where she rose to Executive Vice President at Germaine Monteil Cosmetics, at a time when most women were home. She later moved into the real estate industry, and was a real estate broker for Brown Harris Stevens at the time of her untimely death. She loved the opera, symphony, theater, and spent many hours with her dear friends playing bridge. Many people have described her as a saint for her selfless care of others in their time of need and was often involved in many causes, especially her alma mater, Smith College. There was no one like her-her sharp mind, thoughtful ways and poised disposition. We will miss her terribly. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, July 18, at 1 PM, at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St. and 5th Ave.

title: New York Takes Out the Trash
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, MAXINE
description: RUBIN-Maxine, 78. Died at home in Lawrenceville, NJ. Formerly of Englewood, NJ. Devoted wife of Leonard for over 52 years. Beloved mother of William A. (Susan), Brian F., Deborah A. (fiance Eric). Maxine touched us all with her grace and dignity, and set the loving tone for our family life. Adored sister of Dorothy. Fond aunt of Jack (Patricia), Jon (Diane), Bernice, Eric (Anna), Barbara, Bruce (Sarah). Graveside services at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI, NY, on Wednesday, July 17th, at 12:30 PM. Contributions to American Cancer Society.

title: AT&T to Offer Local Service in New Jersey
description: After a favorable action yesterday by New Jersey telephone regulators, AT&T said it would begin offering local service to millions of residents and businesses in the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOASI, VERONICA
description: BOASI-Veronica. On July 13. Esteemed professional and volunteer. Known for sharp wit, dignity and the help she gave to everyone. Beloved by friends, sister of Rita and Claire, deceased parents and brother, Louis. Visitation July 16 at Guido Funeral Home, 440 Clinton St., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, July 17, at 10:30 AM, St. Charles Borromeo Church, 21 Sidney Place, Brooklyn. She will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Alzheimer's Association, 100 North 17 St., Philadelphia, PA 19103

title: Avis Is Courting Leisure Travelers
description: Avis Rent a Car Systems, reacting to a sluggish business-travel market, is shifting its focus to leisure travelers.

title: Older Americans, Hurt by the Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Where the Bears and the Wolverines Prey
description: The paved road, such as it is, peters out here at the last outpost of commercial civilization, a log cabin saloon and barely stocked general store. From here a heavily washboarded gravel road slices through thick pine and spruce forest along the North Fork of the Flathead River, a forgotten corner near Glacier National Park and the Canadian border.

title: Texas Democrat Walks Fine Line in Senate Run
description: As he hurried away from a luncheon last week with members of organized labor and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Ron Kirk was asked if he had noticed that the ballroom filled with Democratic loyalists was named for former President George Bush.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Marketing Concern Names New Strategy Officer
description: Peter Sealey was named to the new post of chief strategy officer at MaxWorldwide, an online marketing company formerly named L90. Mr. Sealey, 61, who has held top marketing posts at the Coca-Cola Company and Columbia Pictures, is chief executive at the Los Altos Group in Los Altos, Calif., a consulting company specializing in business and marketing strategy. At MaxWorldwide, he will be based in Los Altos and New York. He will also continue as an adjunct professor of marketing at the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley. Allison Fass (NYT)

title: Swallows on the Hunt
description: Q. Do swallows hunt insects the way bats do, using sound waves, or echo location?

title: Recurring Back Pain Puts Piazza on the Outside Looking In
description: Though Mike Piazza appears immune from the trade discussions involving the Mets recently, he is still susceptible to injuries. For the second time in nine days, Piazza was scratched from the lineup with soreness in his lower back, this time against the Florida Marlins last night.

title: Lawmakers Say Files Show Flagrant WorldCom Fraud
description: Lawmakers investigating financial improprieties at WorldCom said today that their continuing examination of company documents had convinced them that the company had engaged in flagrant fraud.

title: Washington Post Follows Coke's Lead
description: The Washington Post Company will follow the advice of the investor Warren E. Buffett, its largest outside shareholder, by accounting for stock options as an operating expense.

title: For Children, Tastier Calcium
description: Many parents look askance at flavored milk, concerned that the last thing their children need is more sugar. But a recent study suggests that those boxes of orange, vanilla and chocolate milk may be part of a solution to a serious nutritional problem.

title: Firm Alters Stock Ratings
description: Credit Suisse First Boston will simplify its stock-rating system and compare equities with specific industries instead of with the broad market. The system, to take effect in September, will rate stocks outperform, neutral or underperform, replacing a four-tier system. The move is in response to criticism that Wall Street research is too optimistic.

title: Gotham; When Thirst Calls
description: ASK any famous chef what he really likes to eat and 5 will get you 10 he'll say, ''Roast chicken.'' Ask somebody, like me, whose work leads him into lots of tony places around town, where he really likes to go for a drink and 5 will get you 10 he'll say, ''Some place like Joe Allen.'' I don't even use the ''some place.'' Joe Allen is casual, it's cool, the beer is good and -- location, location -- it's on West 46th Street, right around the corner from the office.

title: Fed Chief Blames Corporate Greed for Investor Woes
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 - Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, pointed today to a corporate culture blighted by ``infectious greed'' as the cause of the breakdown in confidence among investors. With political pressure growing and the stock market falling, the House hurriedly passed a measure that would toughen criminal fraud penalties to curb corporate wrongdoing.

title: MEMO PAD
description: New Flight Guide Is Easier on the Eyes

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Journalist Ordered Out
description: In the first test of the country's stringent new press law, an American reporter accused of publishing false information was acquitted, but minutes later, the immigration agency ordered the journalist, Andrew Meldrum, left, to leave the country within 24 hours. Mr. Meldrum, the Zimbabwe correspondent for The Guardian, has permanent resident status. His lawyers were attempting to file an emergency appeal with the High Court. Mr. Meldrum was charged earlier this year with publishing false information after he reported that an opposition supporter had been beheaded. The account, which was also reported by other news organizations, turned out to be untrue. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYLVESTER, ARNOLD E.
description: SYLVESTER - Arnold E., Freeport, NY, July 13, age 89. Past President of Long Island Humanist Society, NY Ethical Culture Society & American Ethical Union. Survived by beloved wife, Belle, loving son, Robert, daughter Vicki, daughter-in-law Jane, and grandsons, Jonas, Sylvester and Nicholas Granat.

title: Gap Closes, but West Wins All-Star Game Again
description: The big question during tonight's Women's National Basketball Association All-Star Game was whether the Eastern Conference All-Stars would finally break through and win one against the Western Conference. Since the league held its first All-Star Game three years ago, the West had been a perfect 3-0.

title: Making an Impression on Smokers
description: Even when smokers were told they had a genetic predisposition to smoking-related cancers, they were no more likely to quit than their counterparts who had no such tendency, researchers at the Duke University Medical Center say.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about Pfizer's plan to acquire the Pharmacia Corporation misstated the surname of Pfizer's chief executive. He is Henry A. McKinnell, not Kinnell.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: ANTI-PIRACY EXECUTIVE CHOSEN The Universal Music Group, a unit of Vivendi Universal , named David Benjamin senior vice president for anti-piracy yesterday. In a news release, Universal Music said Mr. Benjamin would work closely with the company's record and publishing companies and their artists and songwriters, as well as the various departments within the company. He will also work in cooperation with sister companies within Vivendi Universal and the music industry's trade groups. (Dow Jones)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a Brookings Institution report that called plans for a Homeland Security Department too ambitious misspelled the surname of one of its authors in some copies. He is James M. Lindsay, not Linday.

title: Talks Weigh Big Project On Wireless Internet Link
description: Several leading computer and telecommunications companies are discussing the joint creation of a wireless data network that would make it possible for users of hand-held and portable computers to have access to the Internet at high speeds nationwide.

title: Dreaming Up Summer's Breed of TV Hits
description: Once the Sahara of television, an utterly arid desert landscape fit only for reruns and throwaway programs, the summer has become, improbably, an oasis of hits for the broadcast networks.

title: Admitting He Fought in Taliban, American Agrees to 20-Year Term
description: John Walker Lindh, the 21-year-old Californian who fought with the Taliban in Afghanistan, pleaded guilty today to two felony charges in a surprise deal with prosecutors and agreed to serve 20 years in prison.

title: Lawmaker Flashes Bravado at Start of House Panel's Hearing on His Racketeering Conviction
description: Representative James A. Traficant Jr., convicted in April of racketeering, bribery and fraud, strode into a House ethics hearing today and asked loudly, ''Do you expect to have this lynching done by tonight or what?''

title: Older Americans, Hurt by the Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Notable Constellation, Canada Embraces Its Star
description: It's hard to say who the real star is at the Vancouver Art Gallery exhibition of ''Carr, O'Keeffe, Kahlo: Places of Their Own.''

title: Bush and The Texas Land Grab
description: Democrats and media hounds are baying under the wrong tree. The point in President Bush's business career where he took outrageous shortcuts was not at Harken Energy, but rather when he was grabbing land for a new baseball stadium in Arlington for his Texas Rangers baseball team.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOBENFELD, RUTH
description: LOBENFELD-Ruth. It's 16 years, Babe, and you're still the one and only. Love, Your Hone

title: Gunman Who Fired at French Leader Is in Mental Hospital
description: A neo-Nazi gunman who tried to kill President Jacques Chirac during the Bastille Day parade on Sunday was committed to a psychiatric hospital today pending the outcome of a judicial investigation to determine whether he was ''criminally responsible for his actions'' at the moment of the shooting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, GEORGE JAMES, JR.
description: LAWRENCE-George James, Jr. On July 11, 2002 of Little Neck, NY. Son of Deborah A. (Lewendoski) and George J. Lawrence, Sr. Brother of Jessica, Michael and Catherine Lawrence. Grandson of Anne and the late William F. Lawrence, and William J. and the late Bertha Lewendoski. Visiting in the Doyle B. Shaffer Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Parkway and Northern Boulevard, Little Neck, New York, on Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered in St. Anastasia RC Church on Friday at 10:45 AM. Interment, St. Anastasia Cemetery, Harriman, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the: Benjamin N. Cordoza High School, attention George J. Lawrence Jr. Memorial Scholarship Fund, 57-00 223 St., Bayside, New York 11364, would be appreciated.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Gay Minister Faces Removal
description: A month after being ordained, a gay Protestant minister in Kalamazoo, the Rev. Matthew Smucker, faces removal from his post in the Church of Brethren. Church delegates from across the nation who met this month in Louisville, Ky., voted against letting gays preach. State church officials are to meet next month to review that ruling. It is unclear whether they can counter the decision. The vote confirms a decree in 1983 that gays should not be ministers. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Promising Irish Player Lands With Dallas
description: Playing only 21 minutes in his debut for the Dallas Burn, RONNIE O'BRIEN scored a goal. His next goal is simply to stay cool.

title: Hormone Therapy: One Size, Clearly, No Longer Fits All
description: Menopause is not a disease, as doctors often point out, only an inevitability of middle age. But for most women, it does come with symptoms, as the body is weaned from its customary diet of estrogen. Some of these can be more than a little annoying: sudden spikes in temperature that make the face flush and the sweat flow; soaked sheets at 3 a.m.; vaginal dryness that causes incessant pain and itching.

title: All the Variety of Africa, Played at a Genteel Pace
description: Half a century of West African rock -- assimilating the exotic and transforming local resources -- was summed up on Sunday in the Summerstage double bill of Orchestra Baobab, from Senegal, and the Super Rail Band, from neighboring Mali.

title: Letters
description: Butterflies Are Inspiring

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Woman Arrested On Drug Smuggling Charges
description: A woman was arrested Saturday at Newark International Airport and accused of trying to smuggle $1 million worth of Ecstasy pills secreted in hidden luggage compartments. The woman, Johanny Reynoso-Mercedes, a Dominican citizen living in Italy, was the third international traveler in three weeks to be arrested on charges of smuggling the club drug Ecstasy. The two others arrested used similar luggage, and all three had pills marked ''VW.'' Officials declined to say whether the three suspects were from the same group. A routine search of Ms. Reynoso-Mercedes's luggage turned up some 34,000 pills, the authorities said. Like the two other suspects, she had traveled from Milan to Paris en route to Newark. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: J. Carter Brown Memorial
description: A memorial service for J. Carter Brown, director emeritus of the National Gallery of Art, is scheduled for 3:30 p.m. tomorrow at Washington National Cathedral. Mr. Brown died of cancer on June 17.

title: National Briefing | Washington: The Senator and The Mouse
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican who threw his political support to groups like CuresNow, a therapeutic cloning advocacy group founded by Hollywood producers, worked with some of the same producers on a film project. Senator Hatch has written a song for the soundtrack of ''Stuart Little 2,'' produced by Doug Wick and Lucy Fisher, who with the producer Janet Zucker and the director Jerry Zucker founded the cloning advocacy group. Senator Hatch's song, ''Little Angel of Mine,'' is performed by the group No Secrets. Mr. Hatch also had a song on the soundtrack of the first Stuart Little movie.

title: They've Seen the Future and Intend to Live It
description: Dr. Ralph C. Merkle is celebrated as an inventor of the encryption technology that allows secure transactions over the Internet. But that was a long time ago. These days, he is better known as a leading theorist of molecular nanotechnology, the still unperfected art of building machines that are little bigger than atoms.

title: Trips; The F Train Rises
description: IN two years of constant riding and writing about the New York subway, I have noticed something interesting: whenever people talk about their favorite stretches, they rarely talk about the sub part. Instead, they sing love songs to the other half of the system, where trains don't run through tunnels but atop trestles, above the streets, rattling over rooftops and threading through tenements so closely that you can almost tell what the people inside are eating for breakfast.

title: The Kirov, Showing Its Youthful Side
description: There will be those who insist that the Kirov Ballet, known again in Russia by its old name as the Maryinsky, has always been a ballerina's company. Yet it was also the home of Vaslav Nijinsky, Vakhtang Chabukiani, Rudolf Nureyev, Yuri Soloviev and Mikhail Baryshnikov.

title: Duke Places a Trading Manager on Leave
description: The Duke Energy Corporation said today that it had placed a manager it did not identify on leave amid government investigations of sham energy trades.

title: Former BET Officer Can Continue Suit
description: A Washington judge has allowed to go forward a lawsuit contending that Black Entertainment Television went to extensive lengths to avoid paying some taxes.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GLAZER, SIMON
description: GLAZER-Simon. Tim dear, I miss you more with every passing year. Love, Val

title: 2 Who Queried Pastor's Past Are Forced Off Parish Board
description: Two members of the governing board of an old-line Episcopal parish in Manhattan have been forced to resign because they raised questions about their pastor's decade-old conviction on charges of possessing child pornography.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITAN, FRED F.
description: LEVITAN-Fred F. Beloved husband of Helen. Devoted father of Barbara and Michael and father-in-law of Steven Abrams. Cherished grandfather of Samantha. Services Tuesday, 2 PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau No. Chapels,'' 55 No. Station Plaza, Great Neck. Contributions in his name may be made to the Capital Fund of Temple Beth El, Great Neck, New York.

title: No Will Is Filed for Estate of Williams
description: Ted Williams's estate did not file his will for probate yesterday, the 10th day since his death, as required by Florida law. But delays are commonplace and there is no penalty for filing late.

title: The Dow Plunges 440 Points, Then Roars Back
description: Stocks plunged yesterday, then recovered most of their losses, in a volatile trading session that offered scant comfort for investors hoping for an end to a bitter bear market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVAK, MAE LAVITT
description: NOVAK-Mae Lavitt, 95. Of Springfield, MA, died July 14, 2002 after a long illness. Survived by son, Joseph, of Santa Fe, NM, and daughter, Judith Gorlick, of Worcester, MA, 3 grandchildren, Jeffrey, Laurie and David Gorlick, and four great-grandchildren. Memorial donations may be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

title: Pointers on Beethoven's Art, Early, Middle and Late
description: The faculty of Mannes College of Music's annual Beethoven Institute faces a rather difficult task every year in its two faculty concerts. In the context of a week of intense work with students on the solo pieces and the chamber music of one of Western music's greatest composers, the faculty performances take on an air of authority: the teachers are offering their own experienced views of the way these works are supposed to go.

title: Bush Is to Propose Broad New Powers In Domestic Security
description: The Bush administration's broad new proposal for domestic security, to be made public on Tuesday, calls for sweeping changes that include the creation of a top-secret plan to protect the nation's critical infrastructure and a review of the law that could allow the military to operate more aggressively within the United States.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: AVNET PLANS TO CUT 775 JOBS Avnet Inc., the second-largest distributor of electronic parts in the United States, said yesterday that it planned to cut 775 jobs, or 5 percent of its work force, because of faltering sales of microprocessors and disk drives to personal computer makers. The company also said that its fourth-quarter results would be less than expected. Avnet said revenue for the fourth quarter, ended June 28, would be down about $70 million, or 3 percent, from third-quarter revenue of $2.21 billion. Analysts expect revenue of $2.25 billion for the June quarter, according to Thomson First Call. Avnet shares fell 64 cents, or 3.1 percent, to close at $19.48. Shares have fallen 21 percent this year.   Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHER, SYLVIA
description: SCHER-Sylvia. Beloved wife of Bob for nearly 61 years. Adored mother of Ellen and Moshe. Loving Grandma to Avi and Ricky. Devoted sister to Esther and Harold. A very special aunt and friend to all. She died peacefully in her sleep on July 15, 2002 after a long and valiant struggle with Alzheimer's and heart disease. She remained, to the end, a gentle soul who always had a smile for all. Funeral service Beth El Synagogue, New Rochelle, N.Y., 10 A.M. Tuesday, July 16th. Shiva will be observed at the home of her daughter. Contributions in her name to UJA-Federation would be greatly appreciated.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Conagra Foods, Omaha, signed a multiyear agreement with ESPN Regional Television, part of the ESPN division of the Walt Disney Company, to become the title sponsor of a new college football bowl game, the Hawaii Bowl, effective with the 2002 game, scheduled for Dec. 25. Terms were not disclosed. The deal includes advertising for Conagra during the game as well as on ESPN networks like ESPNews, ESPN Radio, the ESPN Web site and in ESPN Magazine.

title: By Yonder Blessed Moon, Sleuths Decode Life and Art
description: On its way back from the Pacific island of Tinian, where it had delivered the uranium core for the atomic bomb that destroyed Hiroshima, the heavy cruiser Indianapolis was torpedoed by the Japanese submarine I-58 and sent to the bottom of the Philippine Sea. It was one of the worst disasters in American naval history; only 317 of its nearly 1,200 crew members survived.

title: Man Tied to Boating Deaths Was Not Drunk, Test Finds
description: A teenager charged with operating his boat while intoxicated after a crash that killed two people last week in Little Neck Bay had a blood-alcohol level well below the legal threshold for drunkenness, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Locales; A Villa in Capri
description: MY ideal villa is suspended between sea and sky. Earth and solid building materials are secondary. Azure is the primary feature. Color and light. South winds blow through the air. Waves and ripples stir the water's surface in overlaid, syncopated rhythms. Sunlight sparkles over the sea. In the sky, depth -- intensity of color -- takes prominence over the source of radiance. In the sea, the situation is reversed: the eye is seduced by shallowness and lightness of tone. The shift occurs at the horizon, a geometric line, sometimes sharp, sometimes hazy, drawn through where all is otherwise liquefied, etherealized, evanescent.

title: An Absence of Acrimony As the Devils Re-Sign Elias
description: Lou Lamoriello and the agent Mark Gandler are steely contract negotiators, but Patrik Elias did not seem to think it was a problem that the two had to meet to decide his salary.

title: No Sign of Rift as Schwarz Jury Finishes 5th Day
description: The jury in Charles Schwarz's retrial in the Abner Louima torture case deliberated for a fifth day yesterday with no sign of the dissension a juror reported to the judge Friday.

title: HOME DEPOT PLANS TO BUY BACK UP TO $2 BILLION IN STOCK
description: Home Depot Inc., with its shares having fallen to their lowest level in almost four years, plans to buy back as much as $2 billion in common stock. The company, the world's biggest home-improvement chain, may repurchase as many as 66.7 million shares, based on yesterday's closing price of $30 a share. The purchases will be made in the open market from time to time, the Atlanta-based company said in a statement. The shares rose 3.1 percent. Home Depot's stock had declined 43 percent this year on concern the retailer may have trouble driving sales growth as it faces competition from its smaller rival, Lowe's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, ALVIN J., M.D.
description: GORDON-Alvin J., M.D. It is with profound sorrow that The Mount Sinai Alumni mourns the passing of our friend and colleague, Dr. Alvin Gordon, a highly esteemed physician whose remarkable career at Mount Sinai covered almost half a century. A pioneer in cardiac catheterization, Dr. Gordon headed the Cardiac Catheterization Team at Mount Sinai from 1946-1970. Devoted to medicine, Mount Sinai and its Alumni, Dr. Gordon served as President of the Association in 1966 and, in 1973. The Mount Sinai Alumni presented its most coveted award, the Jacobi Medallion, to Dr. Gordon in acknowledgment of his profound professional achievements and his extraordinary service to the Medical Center and The Alumni. He will be remembered for his exceptional skills, special warmth, and outstanding commitment to Mount Sinai. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. Jeffrey S. Freed, M.D., Pres. But it is also infamous among parents, who know that the path abuts a stretch of Long Island Rail Road tracks where, eight years ago, two teenagers were hit by a train and killed.
