description: OFTEN enough when I awake in the morning to the patter of Welsh drizzle on my roof, and reluctantly bestir myself to plod downstairs and make breakfast, I like to imagine that instead I am snugly waiting for room service in one of my favorite hotels. The one most likely to figure in this forlorn fantasy is the Hotel Beau-Rivage Weggis in Switzerland.

title: Memorial Park Plays Large Part In Preliminary Trade Center Plans
description: All the competing plans for redeveloping the World Trade Center site include a memorial park as the centerpiece, covering as much as a third to two-thirds of the 16-acre site, according to people who have seen the six preliminary designs.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Green Light For Lethal Air Force
description: The government adopted new measures to prevent hijackings that would allow its air-defense forces to shoot down aircraft like those used in the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington on Sept. 11, the Interfax news agency reported. Under new rules outlined in a government decree signed last week, the military would only resort to lethal force if it could not identify aircraft that crossed into its territory without authorization, and only then after firing warning shots. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Private Groups in Pittsburgh Halt Millions in School Aid
description: In a stunning and rare example of philanthropy publicly flexing its muscles, three foundations have precipitated a crisis in the Pittsburgh public school system.

title: MORTON'S ACCEPTS CASTLE HARLAN TAKEOVER BID
description: The Morton's Restaurant Group agreed to a $71.2 million takeover offer by Castle Harlan Inc. yesterday after the private buyout firm matched a bid of $17 a share from Carl C. Icahn. Castle Harlan raised its bid for the steakhouse chain 6.3 percent from $16 a share, or $67 million, to keep pace with Mr. Icahn's renewed bid of $17 a share. After first agreeing in March to buy Morton's for $12.60 a share, Castle Harlan, a privately held buyout firm in New York, has now raised its offer four times to match bids by Mr. Icahn's High River L.P. Morton's, based in New Hyde Park, N.Y., operates 62 Morton's of Chicago steakhouses and 4 Bertolini's Italian restaurants.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Woodstock: Anti-Casino Group Organized
description: A new citizens group is protesting the development of more casinos in Connecticut, citing concerns that the state may become the ''Las Vegas of the East'' after the recent federal recognition of two Indian tribes. MaryBeth Gorke-Felice, chairwoman of the group, Connecticut Citizens Against Casinos, said yesterday that it opposed casinos because they lowered state tax revenue and reduced quality of life. Like the two Indian-run casinos in the state, Mohegan Sun and Foxwoods Resort Casino, casinos run by the newly recognized tribes would not be subject to state tax. On June 24, the Eastern Pequot and the Paucatuck Eastern Pequot were recognized as one tribe. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Song & Laughter; Billie Steals His Heart
description: IT was her record of ''Easy Living'' that made me fall in love with Billie Holiday. This was in the era of 78's, when we absorbed our take-home music very differently from LP's and CD's, repeated hearings leading to intimate acquaintance. It was Lester Young's buoyant, dancing tenor sax that grabbed me on the flip side, ''When You're Smiling.'' But on ''Easy Living,'' eight haunting tenor bars notwithstanding, it was Billie: the husky warmth of her sound, the lilting thrust of her phrasing (oh, that bridge!), the impassioned identification she brought to Leo Robin's lyrics, making it poetry, and all aided and abetted by Buck Clayton's muted trumpet obbligato -- two voices melding into one musical stream. That was some 55 years ago, the disc long since worn out, but after many reincarnations (classic Holiday has seldom been out of catalog) and hundreds of hearings, the thrill is not gone.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: East Rutherford: Meadowlands Redevelopment

Attendees included the Kushner Companies and the Hartz Mountain Company, both based in New Jersey, and national developers like Forest City Ratner Companies and the Mills Corporation. The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority's conference was intended to let potential bidders ask questions about what the authority wanted in proposals for the 104-acre site. A second conference is scheduled for next Tuesday. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Mafia Suspects Arrested
description: The police arrested 15 suspected mobsters as they gathered in a country house in western Sicily, champagne at the ready, to elect a new regional godfather, Italian law enforcement officials said. One of the 15 men arrested, Giuseppe Nobile, is a local government official who belongs to the Forza Italia party of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi. The party has long faced -- and denied -- accusations that its Sicilian branch has ties to organized crime. The police determined the location of the meeting by attaching a bugging device to Mr. Nobile's car. Frank Bruni (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Death Sentence Overturned
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court, citing a trial judge's error, reversed a Camden man's death sentence yesterday, but upheld his conviction for murder. The man, Daron Josephs, now 30, was convicted in April 2000 of murdering two other members of a marijuana-distribution ring in 1995. The unanimous ruling by the seven-member court threw out the death sentence because the judge improperly instructed the jury. Under state law, an accomplice cannot be sentenced to death. Yet the jury was told to consider first whether Mr. Josephs committed the murders directly, and then consider whether he was an accomplice. The high court decision said the jury should have been instructed to consider those issues at the same time, which Mr. Josephs' lawyer argued could have reduced the likelihood of his client receiving the death penalty. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: SENATE APPROVES A BROAD OVERHAUL OF BUSINESS LAWS
description: The Senate tonight unanimously passed a broad overhaul of corporate fraud, securities and accounting laws to curb the abuses that have rocked Wall Street, and President Bush strongly hinted that he was inclined to sign almost any bill that emerged from negotiations by the Senate and the House.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia: Balkan Leaders Meet
description: The presidents of Yugoslavia, Bosnia and Croatia held a summit meeting in Sarajevo, pledging to rebuild trust and trade among three states torn apart by the Balkan wars of the 1990's. But there were lingering signs of the gulf still dividing them in a refusal by the Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, above, to apologize for Serb atrocities, or demand that the former Bosnian Serb political leader, Radovan Karadzic, surrender to the United Nations war crimes tribunal. Cooperation between the three has been patchy since the wars ended in 1995, particularly over helping more than a million refugees return home.

title: Gotham; The Great Liberator
description: IT wasn't love at first sight when the MetroCard made its debut in the mid-1990's. Far from it. What were the managers of the subways thinking when they foisted this flimsy, magnetic-stripped slice of plastic on New York? No way would true New Yorkers abandon the metallic disc known as the token to gain entry to the city's vast mass-transit network. The token had history, even a touch of romance. The MetroCard had none of that. It would be laughed out of town faster than a Broadway flop.

title: A Hard Year of Adjustment Has Altered Cook's Outlook
description: A year ago, Omar Cook might have bristled at the idea of spending his summer like this. Dressing in the cramped locker room at the University of Massachusetts-Boston among players who have little hope of seeing a minute in the N.B.A. seemed a far cry from what some, notably Cook himself, believed he was capable of.

title: Song & Laughter; Frank's Longest Song
description: FOR me, Frank Sinatra's 1955 album, ''In the Wee Small Hours of the Morning'' was, and continues to be, one intense song of considerable length, sung with a wrenching candor, without sentiment. It is a disturbing masterpiece that goes to the heart of romantic obsession; a novel in 16 chapters; a melancholy, intelligent work of art that in 47 years has never been equaled by anyone, including Sinatra. The understated flow of Nelson Riddle's arrangements adds a credibility that suggests the strength of literature. The nearly 50 minutes of music, heard continuously over decades, still yield surprising new feelings, shaking them out from the really private stuff that no one will ever get to know.

title: It's the Real Thing
description: With President Bush digging in his heels in defense of accounting tricks that hide the true cost of stock options, and Congress equivocating under intense corporate lobbying, reform has come from an unexpected place -- the Coca-Cola Company. Coke announced this week that it would start counting against its yearly earnings the options it grants employees. It is a bold commitment to reform, and one that, particularly given the meltdown in the stock market in recent days, the White House and Congress should take to heart.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: INITIATIVE ON RACIAL CATEGORIES An initiative to bar the state from racially classifying students and state employees has qualified for the March 2004 primary election ballot. The constitutional amendment, proposed by a regent of the University of California, Ward Connerly, would prohibit separating, sorting or organizing individuals based on their race. It does not prohibit classification by sex, and includes exemptions for law enforcement and maintaining federal financing. In April, Mr. Connerly's American Civil Rights Coalition submitted more than 980,000 signatures. It needed 670,000 to qualify for the ballot. (AP)

title: 7 Killed, 17 Hurt in Ambush of Bus by Palestinians
description: IMMANUEL, West Bank, July 16  In a brazen daytime ambush today, Palestinians in Israeli Army uniforms set off a roadside bomb near a bus approaching this Jewish settlement, then hurled grenades and raked the vehicle with gunfire, killing seven people and wounding 17 before escaping.

The company, which had changed its corporate name to the Dr. Koop LifeCare Corporation, was bought by Vitacost.com, a closely held company based in Boynton Beach, Fla., that sells wholesale health products over the Internet. DrKoop.com was founded in 1997 with more than $200 million, Vitacost.com said. The shares, sold to the public in June 1999, rose as high as $45.75 three years ago, before falling with the collapse of the Internet stock bubble. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOROG, WILLIAM F. WILLIAM F. GOROG
description: GOROG-William F. William F. Gorog, one of America's most successful entrepreneurs who often noted that an almost warped sense of optimism, ''a refusal to accept reality'' was required to succeed in bringing pioneering technologies into mainstream use, died of complications from lung cancer on July 14, 2002 surrounded by his family in McLean, Virginia. Mr. Gorog was 76, and is survived by his wife of 53 years, Gretchen Meister Gorog, six children, and 21 grandchildren. Mr. Gorog's forty plus years in business included Co-Founding both Data Corporation and InteliData and serving as Chairman and CEO. During his career he also served as President of the Magazine Publishers Association, Chairman of the Chief Executives Organization, participated in the creation of VeriFone and served in President Ford's White House as head of the Council on International Economic Policy. In community affairs, Mr. Gorog served as chairman of The Board of Visitors of the Georgetown University School of Business; and as Chairman of The Washington Campus, a consortium of sixteen university business schools that provides student exposure to the workings of the Federal Government. Mr. Gorog most recently CoFounder and Chairman of InteliData (NASDAQ: ''INTD'') where he helped pioneer the Electronic Banking and Bill Payment (EBPP) technology. Mr. Gorog was born in Warren, Ohio on September 2, 1925. He graduated from the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1949, attended Carnegie Mellon and achieved his Master of Science Degree in Industrial Engineering from the Ohio State University Graduate School. Mr. Gorog served both in World War II and the Korean War. Shortly after the Korean War, he Co-Founded and served as Chairman and CEO of Data Corporation, a high technology research and development company where he conceived of and developed the computerized law and news information systems known as LEXIS/ NEXIS now in use by thousands of law firms, courts, federal agencies, and corporations throughout the United States. Mr. Gorog's company also worked extensively with NASA and developed the photo-optics and systems for the Apollo Mission to the Moon. In 1969 Data Corporation was merged with the Mead Corporation and he became a director of Mead and remained Data's Chairman and CEO. In 1975 Mr. Gorog joined the Ford Administration as the Deputy Director of President's Economic Policy Board and in 1976 was made Executive Director of the Council on International Economic Policy. In this capacity, he was a member of the White House Senior Staff and reported directly to the President. Mr. Gorog left the White House after the change in administration in 1977 and established a trading company primarily involved in the export of U.S. computer products to the Far East. During this period, he also acted as managing partner of an investment group and advisor to foreign investors in Europe, the Middle East, and Latin America. From 1983 to 1987, he was President of the Magazine Publishers of America, an association composed of the principal consumer magazine publishers such as Time Warner, Conde Nast, and Hearst. In 1987, Mr. Gorog became Chairman and CEO of Arbor International, an investment management company involved in financing energy, high technology, and real estate ventures. The InteliData project was started at Arbor and the corporation was formed in 1990. During these periods, Mr. Gorog served as a director of VeriFone, the California-based transaction automation company and of Fiskars, a Helsinki-based worldwide manufacturer. He served in the banking industry as a Director of Commerce Union Bank of Nashville, Sovran Bank of Norfolk, C&S Sovran of Atlanta, and NationsBank, VA. In 1949, Mr. Gorog, an only child, married Gretchen Meister, also an only child and together they had six children: Robin Gorog, Jonathan Gorog, Christopher Gorog, Lesley Gorog Harris, Jennifer Gorog Nichols, Peter Gorog, and twenty-one grandchildren. Gretchen and all his children and grandchildren survive him. Many of Mr. Gorog's six children and twenty-one grandchildren share his pioneering, entrepreneurial spirit, and are successful business executives, entrepreneurs and Olympians in their own rights. Mr. Gorog was a member of the Knights of Malta since 1976, a lay order of the Roman Catholic Church, and is a member of St. Luke Catholic Church in McLean, Virginia. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society specified for lung cancer research.

The surplus grew 108 percent from the comparable month a year ago, hitting 1.04 trillion yen ($9 billion). Exports grew 8.7 percent while imports fell 4.6 percent. It was the fastest growth in exports since November 2000. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: At the Country Club, He's the New Lilly
description: Of all the anecdotes that speckle the history of modern fashion, the one about how Lilly Pulitzer came to produce pretty cotton dresses with images of seashells and merry-looking amphibians seems among the most amusingly doctored (even if it is in fact the unadulterated truth). The story is this: In the early 1960's, Lilly Pulitzer, then the wife of the publishing heir Peter Pulitzer, was looking for something to keep her occupied, so she opened a juice stand on Worth Avenue in Palm Beach. Because the work spotted her clothes, she had her seamstress whip up a brightly colored shift on which the stains would go unnoticed. Friends admired the dress; Ms. Pulitzer manufactured versions of it, and thus another symbol of East Coast establishment life was born.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Avnet Plans To Cut 775 Jobs
description: Avnet Inc., the second-largest distributor of electronic parts in the United States, said yesterday that it planned to cut 775 jobs, or 5 percent of its work force, because of faltering sales of microprocessors and disk drives to personal computer makers. The company also said that its fourth-quarter results would be less than expected. Avnet said revenue for the fourth quarter, ended June 28, would be down about $70 million, or 3 percent, from third-quarter revenue of $2.21 billion. Analysts expect revenue of $2.25 billion for the June quarter, according to Thomson First Call. Avnet shares fell 64 cents, or 3.1 percent, to close at $19.48. Shares have fallen 21 percent this year. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Celluloid; Fast Times at Lombardi High
description: FOR as long as there have been teenagers -- about 50 years, give or take -- there have been movies designed to soothe their misery, give vent to their frustration and lay claim to their hard-won allowances and after-school minimum wages. Some of these, from ''Rebel Without a Cause'' to ''Rushmore,'' have also been interesting, insightful and even important movies. But the tradition survives most vibrantly in the line of joyous, guiltless trash that runs from ''Rock Around the Clock'' through the ''Porky's'' movies to ''American Pie.'' These artifacts of pop culture are designed to be disposable, and they therefore become, almost instantly, objects of fond, antiquarian nostalgia, like aluminum lunchboxes or Pez dispensers.

description: A five-day standoff between the government and villagers protesting the expropriation of their lands to build Mexico City's new international airport ended peacefully as both sides released the remaining detainees. Hundreds of soldiers and riot police officers guarding the outskirts of San Salvador Atenco have been removed, as well as a roadblock of charred vehicles that had paralyzed local traffic. The villagers claimed victory and said they were even more determined not to sell their land to the state. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: A Mission For Fiat
description: Fiat is on a ''holy mission'' to fix its unprofitable car unit and is unlikely to sell it all to General Motors, said Robert Lutz, left, G.M.'s vice chairman. Fiat, Italy's largest manufacturer, sold 20 percent of its auto business, made up of the Fiat, Alfa Romeo and Lancia brands, to G.M. in 2000 for $2.4 billion in stock. Fiat can force G.M. to buy the rest from 2004 to 2009. ''They want to remain autonomous and frankly, I hope they do, although I must confess I would love to see Alfa in the family,'' Mr. Lutz said in an interview.

description: TURKEY: PREMIER AIMS TO STEM DEFECTIONS Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit planned to meet disaffected deputies today in a bid to stem the flood of defections from his party that threatens to erode the governing coalition's majority. But moves to convene a special session of Parliament, now in recess, could hasten the rickety coalition's demise if the assembly decides to hold early elections or a no-confidence vote in the government. Seven cabinet ministers and 46 lawmakers have deserted Mr. Ecevit's Democratic Left Party after both of its coalition partners called for early elections. (Reuters)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Lawyer Fights To Stay On Case
description: A longtime lawyer who helped a death row inmate win a new trial is fighting to stay on the case. For 15 years, the lawyer, Robert McGlasson of Atlanta, argued that his client, Calvin Burdine, deserved a new trial because his original lawyer, Joe Cannon, slept though parts of his trial. In August, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ordered the new trial. But last month, a Texas judge refused to appoint Mr. McGlasson to the case, because he was not on a list of approved lawyers. Lawyers for Mr. McGlasson, citing his 15 years of work on the case, appealed. Jim Yardley (NYT)

description: In August 2000, when Henry A. McKinnell was named heir to the retiring chief executive of Pfizer, William C. Steere Jr., many industry experts wondered how he could top the act he was following. After all, during Mr. Steere's nine-year tenure, Pfizer became the world's largest drug company, one whose sales -- and stock price -- kept going up, up and up some more.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Suit Over Computer System
description: The former state technology director said in a federal suit that Gov. Mike Huckabee ousted him for refusing to remain silent about problems in the state's new $52 million master computer system. The governor has said the former official, Randall Bradford, was fired for refusing to cooperate with other officials. Mr. Bradford's suit names Mr. Huckabee, his chief of staff and three other senior assistants as defendants.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Second Paterson Official Pleads  Guilty
description: The former director of Paterson's public works projects pleaded guilty in federal court here yesterday to extorting about $7,500 from a vendor who sought to do business with the city. The former director, Conway Mangullo, 67, is the second Paterson official to plead guilty this month to accepting bribes. Prosecutors said that if Mr. Mangullo's case had gone to trial, their evidence would have shown that $3,500 of the $7,500 that Mr. Mangullo admitted accepting had gone to former Mayor Martin G. Barnes for his criminal defense fund. On July 1, Mr. Barnes pleaded guilty to accepting more than $200,000 in cash and gifts. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: A Plea Suited to Both Sides
description: WASHINGTON, July 15  When John Walker Lindh was charged in January with conspiring with the Taliban to kill Americans, Attorney General John Ashcroft pronounced it a critical case in the nation's fight against terrorism. He asserted that Mr. Lindh chose to become a fanatical follower of the Taliban and never wavered in his allegiance to terrorism.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: ECONOMIC GROWTH Economic growth in China accelerated slightly in the second quarter from a 7.6 percent annual rate in the first quarter, according to a government report, as foreign investment, exports and government spending more than offset weak consumer spending. Government investments in roads and other long-term projects rose 24.4 percent in the first half of the year. Many economists, however, question whether China can sustain the spending, which has caused chronic budget deficits financed by large bond sales. Economic statistics in China are not always reliable, because officials sometimes exaggerate successes for political reasons. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Steps To Wealth
description: Why are George W. Bush's business dealings relevant? Given that his aides tout his ''character,'' the public deserves to know that he became wealthy entirely through patronage and connections. But more important, those dealings foreshadow many characteristics of his administration, such as its obsession with secrecy and its intermingling of public policy with private interest.

title: Justice and John Walker Lindh
description: The government and John Walker Lindh, the American captured in Afghanistan last year, brought his prosecution to a reasonable conclusion yesterday when Mr. Lindh unexpectedly pleaded guilty to two felony offenses. In return the government dropped the gravest charges against him, including conspiring to kill Americans and engaging in terrorism. The plea bargain reflects the unfolding realities of the Lindh case, which had more to do with the criminal conduct of a foolish young man than the actions of a hardened terrorist. The decision honors the demands of criminal justice, national security and America's commitment to constitutional rights.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Telecom Profit
description: South Korea's largest mobile phone operator, the SK Telecom Company, said its second-quarter profit almost doubled as it added subscribers and more of them used their phones to connect to the Internet. Net income rose 97 percent from a year earlier, to 457 billion won ($386 million), as sales grew 42 percent, to 2.1 trillion won. SK Telecom has doubled the number of its users whose phones have high-speed Internet access this year, helping it sell new services even as subscriber growth slows because almost two-thirds of South Koreans already own a cellphone.

title: Videotaped Violence in Inglewood
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft sent the right message when he ordered the Justice Department's top civil rights official to investigate a police brutality case that has been smoldering in Inglewood, Calif., for more than a week. The visit by the assistant attorney general for civil rights, Ralph Boyd, should show concerned citizens and law enforcement officials alike that the federal government intends to see this case fully and promptly investigated.

title: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
description: DRKOOP.COM IS SOLD FOR $186,000 DrKoop.com, the medical information Web site that was once valued at over $1 billion, was sold yesterday to a Florida company for $186,000 in cash. Founded in 1997 by C. Everett Koop, the former United States surgeon general, the site went bankrupt last December. The company, which had changed its corporate name to the Dr. Koop LifeCare Corporation, was bought by Vitacost.com, a closely held company based in Boynton Beach, Fla., that sells wholesale health products over the Internet. DrKoop.com was founded in 1997 with more than $200 million, Vitacost.com said. The shares, sold to the public in June 1999, rose as high as $45.75 three years ago, before falling with the collapse of the Internet stock bubble.

title: Song & Laughter; The Tao of Steve
description: STEVE MARTIN is the best late-night-talk-show guest ever. He walks on smiling and sincere like any other star with something to plug, but before long turns the spot into a tongue-in-cheek performance that spoofs the whole talk-show routine. He comes prepared. He makes videos. He has charts!

title: Proposed Successor at Deutsche Telekom Chills Market
description: The German government's trouble-prone campaign to oust Ron Sommer as the chief executive of Deutsche Telekom hit a new snag today as investors reacted harshly to his proposed replacement.

title: CMS ENERGY, A MICHIGAN UTILITY, WILL REDUCE DIVIDEND
description: The CMS Energy Corporation, the owner of Michigan's largest utility, will cut its dividend by more than half to secure $1.3 billion in bank credit and loans it needs to operate while the company investigates sham electricity trades. The company, based in Dearborn, Mich., reduced its quarterly dividend to 18 cents from 36.5 cents to meet the lender's terms, the chief financial officer, Alan Wright, said in a conference call. It must raise $250 million by selling stock or equity-backed securities by year's end, with some loans secured by proceeds from asset sales. Barclays, Citigroup and Bank One organized the financing, which is being provided by 21 banks and will be repaid from asset and securities sales, Mr. Wright said on the call.

title: A Prince Plagued by Doubt And a Crumbling Empire
description: Nothing less than the wellsprings of World War I, the decline of the Austro-Hungarian empire, the scandalous mystery of the 1889 royal murder-suicide at Mayerling, the clash of generations and the birth pangs of modern technology, art and psychiatry are plumbed in the laudably ambitious new musical ''City of Dreams.''

description: Economic growth in China accelerated slightly in the second quarter from a 7.6 percent annual rate in the first quarter, according to a government report, as foreign investment, exports and government spending more than offset weak consumer spending. Government investments in roads and other long-term projects rose 24.4 percent in the first half of the year. Economic statistics in China are not always reliable, because officials sometimes exaggerate successes for political reasons. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Prosecuting the War and Its Terrorists
description: The announcement yesterday that John Walker Lindh, the ''American Taliban,'' had pleaded guilty to two counts of aiding our enemies can hardly be viewed as a victory for the Justice Department, which had once claimed that the case against Mr. Lindh could put him in prison for life. The government's statement that Mr. Lindh's maximum sentence of 20 years was proof, in the words of United States Attorney Paul McNulty, of the ''strength of our case'' defies logic. More likely, the federal government never had a very sound case against Mr. Lindh. Now, as the Justice Department prepares for what will likely be dozens of potential terrorism cases, there are mixed lessons to be learned from this case.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Legislation On Digital TV Being Drafted
description: Frustrated by the failure of the entertainment and technology industries to agree on a copy-protection standard for digital television broadcasts, Representative Billy Tauzin, Republican of Louisiana, said his staff had begun drafting broad legislation that would impose the standard as well as other rules aimed at creating demand for digital television services. Mr. Tauzin, the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, has been urging the two industries to come to terms for more than a year. The move comes as a group of technology leaders including Steve Ballmer, the chief executive of Microsoft, and Michael Dell, chairman of Dell Computer, responded to a request from the major movie studios to explore solutions to digital piracy. In a letter, the technology executives said that any discussions would need to include education campaigns and business opportunities presented by the Internet. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Brokerage Profits Fall
description: Profits for brokerage firms fell 22 percent in the first quarter from the period a year earlier, the Financial Supervisory Service said. The total pretax profit of 61 Korean and foreign firms was 216.3 billion won ($183.6 million) from April 1 through June 30, compared with 971.3 billion won ($821 million) in the year-earlier period. The drop came alongside a 17.1 percent decline in the same period in the Kospi, the composite index of shares listed on the Korean Stock Exchange. Don Kirk (NYT)

Three airplanes will be delivered to the FedEx Express unit annually in 2008 through 2010, with one aircraft in 2011, FedEx said. FedEx, the biggest overnight delivery company, declined to disclose further terms of the agreement pending a ceremony today at Airbus headquarters in Toulouse, France. FedEx now operates 647 aircraft, including 87 Airbus A300's and A310's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHENIX, DR. PHILIP HENRY
description: PHENIX-Dr. Philip Henry, 87. Longtime resident of the Bridgewater Retirement Community, died after a short illness on July 13, 2002 in Stanley, Virginia, where he lived with family the final months of his life. He is survived by his wife of 59 years, Gena Tenney Phenix, and two sons, Roger Branscombe Phenix, of Stony Point, New York, and Morgan Scott Phenix, of Stanley, Virginia. He also is survived by a nephew, Robert Manning Phenix, of Boston, Massachusetts, and nieces Carlota Phenix Striffler, of Fort Collins, Colorado, Laura Phenix Smith, of Tumwater, Washington, and a cousin, Marion Manning Sears, of Boise, Idaho. Philip Phenix was born on March 1, 1915, in Denver, Colorado, son of Henry Vinton and Bessie Manning Phenix. He studied Mathematical Physics at Princeton University and graduated summa cum laude in 1934, at the age of nineteen. He earned a Master's of Divinity in Theology magna cum laude from Union Theological Seminary, in New York City in 1942 and a Ph.D. in Philosophy from Columbia University in 1950. He served as Chaplain in the United States Army during World War II, lectured in Philosophy at Columbia in 1949, was Chaplain, Professor of Religion and Dean at Carleton College in Northfield, Minnesota, and later was Professor of Philosophy and Education at Teachers College, Columbia University in New York, until his retirement in 1982. Dr. Phenix reached beyond the classrooms of Columbia and Carleton, spending summers teaching in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, and leading courses in the philosophy of curriculum in Spanish in Santiago and Copiapo, Chile. He traveled, studied and taught extensively in the U.S., South America, Mexico, Spain and Europe. He also taught history and western philosophy under the Amity Foundation, at Nanjing University in the People's Republic of China during 1985-86. He has served as president of the Philosophy of Education Society, was elected to the National Academy of Education in 1983 and is a member of Phi Beta Kappa and a life member of the National Education Association. An accom plished author, Philip Phenix wrote numerous articles and eight books, including Intelligible Religion, Education and the Common Good and Education and the Worship of God. His seminal work, Realms of Meaning, delineated a concise framework both of knowledge and of the process of knowing, and examined classes of disciplines for their particular conceptual dynamics. His love and understanding of knowledge, education and teaching influenced generations of teachers and education policy-makers, here and abroad. Philip and Gena Phenix moved in 1982 from New York City to the Bridgewater Retirement Community. They took part in many community activities and enterprises and were members of the Bridgewater Church of the Brethren. Phil Phenix served on Bridgewater College's Long-Range Planning Committee and received the College's Outstanding Service Award. He was cited as a man of deep religious faith, a gifted teacher and a devoted community servant. As well, he was well known for his wide-ranging walks in and around Bridgewater and Rockingham County. A memorial service will be held 11:00 A.M. Monday, July 22, 2002 at the Lantz Chapel, Bridgewater Home, in Bridgewater, Virginia. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Bridgewater Church of the Brethren, to the Bridgewater Home, or to the Bridgewater College. For information, contact Johnson Funeral Service, Inc., Bridgewater.

Chemical exports rose 26.5 percent.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Reports Its First Profit
description: Bucking a downward trend among telecommunications companies, shares of Nextel Communications, one of the largest wireless telephone companies in the United States, rose yesterday after the company reported the first profit in its history. Nextel, based in Reston, Va., reported net income of $325 million, or 37 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $426 million, or 56 cents a share, a year earlier. Nextel was expected to lose 24 cents, according to analysts surveyed by Thompson First Call. Total sales rose 25 percent, to $2.15 billion. The company also said it had added 471,000 customers in the quarter to its United States service, for a total of 9.64 million. Jim Mooney, Nextel's chief operating officer, said the company expected to end the year with 10.7 million customers. Shares ended the day at $6.53, up $1.53. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: DUKE ENERGY SAYS WASH TRADES DID NOT AFFECT PROFIT
description: The Duke Energy Corporation, under investigation for sham energy transactions, said 23 ''round trip'' trades on the Intercontinental Exchange's Internet market added $126 million to 2001 revenue but did not affect its profit. The trades accounted for a quarter of a percent of $51.4 billion in revenue from natural gas and power trading last year, Duke said in response to an informal request for data from the Securities and Exchange Commission. In round-trip or ''wash'' trades, companies simultaneously buy and sell the same amount of power or gas at an identical price. The transactions usually have little use except to increase trading figures.

Mr. Trichet was the head of the French Treasury in the early 1990's and served as a government representative on the bank's board. The Paris prosecutor's office, which recommended that Mr. Trichet be cleared, has five days to appeal the decision, but has not yet announced its plans. Kerry Shaw (NYT)
