title: Shares Fall as Investors Ignore Greenspan's Assurances on the Economy
description: Prices of blue-chip stocks fell for the seventh consecutive session yesterday, as investors and traders ignored generally reassuring comments from the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and data that strongly suggested that manufacturing activity was recovering.

title: Money Transfers by Hijackers Did Not Set Off Alarms for Banking Regulators
description: Even as the Sept. 11 hijackers pumped hundreds of thousands of dollars into commercial banks to finance the terrorist operation, they never tripped any of the American banking system's alarms intended to warn federal regulators of the suspicious movement of cash, investigators have said.

title: CORPORATE CONDUCT: THE IMPACT -- Brokers' Lament; No One Wants To Buy Stocks
description: On the front lines of the struggle to prevent a complete loss of faith in American business, stockbrokers are talking as fast as they can in the calmest, most reassuring tones they can muster. Their problem, they said, is not that too many people are selling stocks; it is that nobody wants to buy.

title: Department's Employees May Lose Role In Civil Service
description: House Republican leaders managing the creation of a new Homeland Security Department have decided not to extend full civil service protection to the department's workers, Republican officials said today.

title: What Just Crawled Out Of the Pond
description: There's a moment in ''Eight-Legged Freaks'' that's truly frightening; Mike (Scott Terra), the young son of the town sheriff Sam Parker (Kari Wuhrer), is out hitchhiking and gets in a car with a stranger. Now, the stranger turns out to be the hero, nice-guy Chris McCormack (David Arquette), but it's a bizarre scene to put in a picture. And ''Freaks'' strains to succeed as a piece of well-intentioned camp, but those sweat stains in the armpits and that dew dammed up over its eyebrows is more evident than the laughs it produces.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The consumer division of Bates Healthworld, New York, hired three employees. William A. Mulligan was named executive vice president and general manager; he had been senior partner and director in charge for North America at J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group. Andrea Gasparo and Matthew A. Hartney were named account supervisors. Ms. Gasparo had been senior account manager at Nethod Euro-Interactive, New York, the interactive unit of Lally McFarland & Pantello Euro RSCG, which is part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide division of Havas. Mr. Hartney had been manager for the healthcare practice at Burson-Marsteller, New York. Also, in the professional division at Bates Healthworld, Scott J. Baxter and Heather Lee Clark were named senior account executives. Mr. Baxter had been product manager in the medical marketing division at the Adeza Biomedical Corporation, based in New York. And Ms. Clark had been account executive at Lyons Lavey Nickel Swift, New York, part of TBWA World Health, a division of TBWA Worldwide, which is owned by the Omnicom Group. Bates Healthworld is part of the Bates Worldwide division of the Cordiant Communications Group.

title: From Ashes And Loss, Firehouse 10 Will Return
description: Rarely do city and state officials gather to announce a family reunion. But few have been through the ordeal suffered by the family of firefighters who occupied what was known as 10 House.

title: Village Says, 'Yes, in My Backyard,' to Rail Center
description: John S. Gates Jr. harbors no delusions about the railroad industrial parks that his company builds, with their seven-day-a-week operations and streams of heavy truck traffic on neighboring highways.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: CAMERAMAN CALLS ARREST RETRIBUTION

title: Iverson Freed on Bond After Plea of Not Guilty
description: Amid what the police commissioner called unprecedented news media attention, Allen Iverson turned himself in to the authorities today and pleaded not guilty to accusations that he broke into his cousin's apartment with a gun in his waistband and made threats while searching for his wife after a domestic dispute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOVNANIAN, ALTON
description: HOVNANIAN - Alton. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of The City of New York mourn the tragic death of Alton Hovnanian. We extend our deepest sympathies to his entire family. Newton P.S. Merrill, Chairman Robert R. Macdonald, Director

title: Dr. Greenspan's Prescription
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, memorably defined an economic moment when he declared in late 1996 that the fast-rising stock market was caught up in ''irrational exuberance.'' He did so again yesterday when he warned Congress that the business world had been gripped by an ''infectious greed'' and that government must take strong steps to clean up corporate leadership. With Congress divided on how to proceed -- the Senate passed a tough corporate fraud bill this week, while the House adopted a weaker one -- Mr. Greenspan's words give powerful ammunition to those arguing for a hard line.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: UNEMPLOYMENT RISES The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate in Hong Kong increased to 7.7 percent for the three-month period from April through June, compared with 7.4 percent for March through May, as the Hong Kong economy remained stagnant.

title: The March of Science, and Science Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON PROFIT RISES 12%
description: Johnson & Johnson's second-quarter profit rose 12 percent on increased sales of drugs to treat anemia and arthritis and devices used in heart procedures. Net income rose to $1.65 billion, or 54 cents a share, from $1.48 billion, or 48 cents a share, a year earlier, Johnson & Johnson said. Sales rose 11 percent, to $9.07 billion. Accelerating sales of medical devices, which account for a third of Johnson & Johnson's revenue, are helping the company weather a slowdown in pharmaceutical sales growth that has decreased profit at rivals focused mainly on drugs. Sales of medical tests and devices rose 14 percent, to $3.2 billion. Drug sales rose 10 percent, to $4.3 billion, a slowdown from 20 percent in the first quarter, as wholesalers reduced orders after stocking up ahead of a price increase.

title: CALENDAR
description: Beer on the Agenda

title: A Foolish Affair in a Frustrated Life
description: ''It was a German who discovered parthenogenesis in bees.''

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Sept. 28 about a World Trade Center victim, Edward Calderon, an operations manager for the Port Authority, misstated his age. His wife notified The Times recently that he was 44, not 43.

title: Take Pity on the Poor Risotto
description: Noted, as ''an environmental advisory,'' on the menu at Harry Cipriani, 781 Fifth Avenue (59th Street): ''The use of cellular phones interferes with preparation of risotto.''

title: There's something to celebrate for the cable TV networks as preseason ad sales beat expectations.
description: IN another indication that the advertising economy is turning upward after its long recession, cable television networks are taking in more advertising dollars ahead of the 2002-03 season than had been expected even a month ago.

title: Leiter Waits For Sign From Mets
description: The discussion about Al Leiter's future with the Mets occurred before the All-Star Game break and Leiter, the passionate, reliable pitcher, suddenly sounded like a high school kid whose steady girlfriend told him she needed a few months before deciding whether they would attend the prom together. You must be joking.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict referred incorrectly to a 44-page report by Amnesty International that criticized the actions of Palestinians. It was the organization's seventh report  not its first  criticizing the role of Palestinians in the current uprising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, FRANCES SIEGMAN
description: ROSENTHAL-Frances Siegman, on July 12, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Jack Siegman & the late Michael Rosenthal, devoted mother of Rochelle, Jerry, the late Alfred and their spouses Stephen, Kathy and Elayne, devoted grandmother and greatgrandmother. Contributions to Alzheimer Foundation.

title: Presses New and Old Prove That Panini Aren't Picky
description: PANINI grills have been around for more than 100 years, but were generally ignored in the United States until the Italian grilled sandwiches made with them began to show up in carryout shops and on restaurant menus. Now these grills are set to become the Belgian-waffle irons of the 21st century. Two years ago, I couldn't find anything called a panini grill. Suddenly, there are all kinds of possibilities. Eat your heart out, Dagwood.

title: Power Failure Snarls Subway Service in Evening Rush
description: A power failure that darkened a Downtown Brooklyn subway station yesterday afternoon tangled subway service during the evening rush, with no trains running on the A and C lines between Bedford-Stuyvesant and Lower Manhattan for about two and a half hours. Other lines were also affected.

title: Duval Knows He's Done It Before
description: Since winning the British Open last year, David Duval has not won a tournament, and he has only one top-10 finish this year. Not only has he missed the cut in his last three tournaments, but he has also missed six cuts this year.

title: Funny, It Doesn't Look Like Soy Sauce
description: There's a new soy sauce to add to the pantry shelf: white soy, which has long been used in Japan. It is actually amber in color, like cider vinegar, but is called white or sometimes clear soy because it will not darken as it seasons. This feature is especially good for white-fleshed fish, rice, salads, vegetables and some marinades. White soy is brewed mostly from wheat, not soybeans, and it has a clean, salty flavor but less nuttiness than dark soy sauce. Jansal Valley white soy comes in 10.5-ounce bottles and costs about $11 at Zabar's, Grace's Marketplace, ABC Carpet & Home, Eli's Manhattan and the Vinegar Factory. It can also be ordered from the importer, Sid Wainer & Son of New Bedford, Mass.: (800) 249-0447.

title: Remembrances of a Champion of the Champagne World
description: Christian Bizot was a Parisian by birth but a true Champenois by nature. Warm and generous when you came to know him, he was outwardly formal and even a bit austere, like the Champagne country itself.

title: Yeas and Nays for Bush's Security Wish List
description: President Bush's new plan for domestic security won some praise today as a comprehensive strategy for protecting the country against terrorist attacks, but it also raised concerns that some of the proposals could undermine civil liberties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, CAROL GAIL
description: HELLER-Carol Gail, beloved wife of Sig. Devoted mother of Joanne and the late Jack and mother-in-law of Janis. Cherished grandmother of Sloane. Services Thursday 12 noon at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: No More Strikes for America's Pastime
description: In the last 30 years, the owners and players of Major League Baseball have negotiated eight different labor agreements. Each time the negotiations have ended in a work stoppage. In this dubious statistical category, baseball is batting 1.000. Now it's time for both players and owners to learn from the past, share the blame for their old errors and work out a serious agreement that ensures the game's fiscal health.

title: Karsay Sets a Trap
description: Steve Karsay bounced around the clubhouse at Jacobs Field last Friday, grinning mischievously, whispering to teammates excitedly. Everybody could tell that Karsay, the Yankees reliever, was up to something.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, MURRAY
description: SILVERMAN-Murray. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed member, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Ira Leon Rennert, Chairman J. Ezra Merkin, President

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column in Science Times yesterday about healthful ways of dining out misstated the amount of sodium found in a typical entree of kung pao chicken, as determined by the Center for Science in the Public Interest. It is 2,600 milligrams, not grams.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Water Bottler Acquired
description: In a further signal of rising foreign investment in Russia, Nestl, the Swiss food producer, announced its purchase of a Russian bottled water company called Saint Springs. The water bottler, one of Russia's first when it started in 1993, was owned privately by American and Russian entrepreneurs. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: RIVERHEAD: CHILD MOLESTER TO BE MONITORED

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COLMAN, GERALD S.
description: COLMAN-Gerald S. July, 17, 2000. Two years seem like yesterday. We miss you more than ever. Your devoted family and friends

title: Leading Climber in Tour Faces Steep Challenges Ahead
description: PAU, France, July 17  More than halfway through today's Tour de France stage, in a field in the village of Cledes, stood a cow decked out in a green points jersey, another cow in the white jersey of the best young rider and two cows that were naked  if that is the word. A donkey was wearing a version of the polka dot jersey that is worn by the best climber. Christophe Mengin was undoubtedly not amused.

title: Irish Memorial's Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYLVESTER, ARNOLD E.
description: SYLVESTER - Arnold E., Freeport, NY, July 13, age 89. Past President of Long Island Humanist Society, NY Ethical Culture Society & American Ethical Union. Survived by beloved wife, Belle, loving son, Robert, daughter Vicki, daughter-in-law Jane, and grandsons, Jonas Sylvester and Nicholas Granat.

title: Bush Meets With Polish Leader, but Focus Is on Economy
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  President Bush said again today that he is optimistic about the economy, and he insisted that neither he nor Vice President Dick Cheney has anything to hide in their past business dealings.

title: Biologist Is College Dean at Stony Brook
description: Stony Brook University has named JAMES V. STAROS, the chairman of the biology department at Vanderbilt University, as the new dean of its college of arts and sciences. Dr. Staros, 55, earned a bachelor's degree in biology/chemistry at Dartmouth College and a Ph.D. in molecular biophysics and biochemistry at Yale. He succeeds PAUL ARMSTRONG. ROBERT LIEBERMAN served as interim dean for more than a year. Karen W. Arenson

title: Ice That Won't Water the Wine
description: What's a gin and tonic without the clink of ice cubes? But a glass of white or ros wine is another matter. When the wine is not quite chilled, you could do what French chefs do: drop in an ice cube, leave it for a minute or two, then scoop it out.

title: Tsaura Journal; Tiny Hamlet Watches a Big Standoff
description: Rival warships prowl across the calm, turquoise sea, sent by the navies of Spain and Morocco to assert competing claims to a barren, rocky island a half a mile in diameter occupied since Thursday by Moroccan troops.

title: CORPORATE CONDUCT: THE IMPACT -- A Haven No More; America Is Losing Aura of Invincibility
description: The one place that always seemed safe for the world's investors -- America -- is slowly losing its aura of invincibility.

title: Sports of The Times; A Case Of Arrested Development
description: YOU couldn't make this story up: an African-American high school football and basketball star is convicted of a crime, sentenced to five years in prison. As his final act in office, the nation's first black governor steps in and grants him clemency. The athlete sits out sports for a year as a condition of clemency and receives a scholarship to play basketball at a prestigious university. He becomes an all-American, leaves college after his second season, becomes the first player taken in the N.B.A. draft, is voted rookie of the year and earns millions of dollars.

title: Grand Jury Is Investigating United Way in Washington
description: A federal grand jury is investigating how the Washington, D.C., chapter of the United Way spent donations, the charity's lawyer said yesterday, just four months after the charity announced that a special audit had found nothing significant amiss with its finances or management practices.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Mosquito Spraying Resumes
description: A second round of larvicide will be dropped today on marshes and swamps in northwestern Staten Island, where officials detected a growing population of mosquitoes that can carry the West Nile virus, the City Department of Health said yesterday. The larvicide, VectoLex CG, is a natural bacterial agent. It will be applied between 5:30 a.m. and 9 p.m. today through Friday, north and south of the Staten Island Expressway, south of Richmond Terrace, west of South Avenue and along the West Shore Expressway to Victory Boulevard. Mosquitoes from four samplings in Staten Island this year have tested positive for West Nile virus, which can spread to birds and humans. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: MCAFEE.COM REJECTS BID FOR 25% STAKE The McAfee.com Corporation, a maker of security software for personal computers, told its shareholders yesterday to reject Network Associates' latest offer to acquire the 25 percent of the company it does not already own. A special committee convened by McAfee.com, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., determined that the offer of 0.9 share of Network Associates for each McAfee.com share was inadequate. Among its reasons, the committee said that McAfee.com's subscription business is growing while Network Associates' prospects are declining because corporate information technology spending is falling. Network Associates of Santa Clara, Calif., makes antivirus and antispam software. Network Associates made a previous offer of 0.78 share for each McAfee.com shares.   Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Whitman Cleared of Conflict Over Cleanups
description: The inspector general of the Environmental Protection Agency has cleared the administrator, Christie Whitman, of wrongdoing in relation to three environmental cleanup sites in which she had an indirect financial interest.

title: The Myth of the Low-Fat Diet
description: To the Editor:

title: Indonesia's Unreformed Military
description: American military cooperation with Jakarta, suspended during the Suharto dictatorship over the Indonesian Army's human rights abuses, should not be resumed without strict conditions and careful controls. Unfortunately, the Bush administration is in a hurry to restore ties with the Indonesian military and seems willing to overlook misconduct in the name of strengthening the war against terrorism. The Senate Appropriations Committee, which is planning to consider the administration's request tomorrow, should block it, as urged by Senator Patrick Leahy and other critics.

title: Honoring a Father of Labor Economics
description: More than 100 of JACOB MINCER'S students and colleagues gathered at Columbia University on Monday to honor the professor, who is considered a father of labor economics. The occasion was his 80th birthday -- and a surprise award of a new annual prize ($50,000) in labor economics, from the Institute for the Study of Labor, based in Bonn, Germany. KLAUS F. ZIMMERMANN, the institute's director, billed it as a belated Nobel for a giant in the field.

title: Videotape Is the Last Resort for Karsay
description: Steve Karsay arrived at the Skydome at 2 p.m. today, five hours before game time. He was eager to watch video to find out what he had been doing wrong lately. Karsay does not consult videotape often. ''Only when I'm pitching like this,'' he said.

title: Good Defense Not Enough for East
description: Lisa Leslie of the Los Angeles Sparks pointed to the six-inch welt on her right shoulder to show how physical things were during the Women's National Basketball Association All-Star Game on Monday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANTINE, ANTHONY
description: ANTINE-Anthony. Of Fort Lee, NJ, passed away on Sunday July 14, 2002. He is survived by Ho Shin, Lorraine, his sister, and beloved family and friends. An internationally renowned designer for over twenty years with commercial and private accomplishments including The Point Hotel, Saranac Lake, NY, and Hart Mountain Industries, and private residences of Robert Redford, Mountain House Atom, Japan, Neo Classical House, Tokyo, and a private yacht in Monte Carlo. Mr. Antine has been a frequent participant in the Kips Bay Show House, included Small Wonders Auction, as well as, Abigail Adams Museum Vingnette. Mr. Antine has achieved eight cover features and has been published in leading design publications including Interior Design, Design Time, House Beautiful, The New York Times, British H & G, and French Elle Decor. He also appeared nationally on The Today Show, CNN Style, and Regis and Cathy Lee Show. Mr. Antine was trained as Couturier at The Fashion Institute of Technology, and created wardrobes for many of the most fashionable and discriminating women in the world, such as, Barbra Streisand, and Betsy Palmer. Family will receive friends at The A.K. Macagna Funeral Home, 495 Anderson Avenue, Cliffside Park, NJ, on Wednesday, July 17 from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Interment on Thursday at 11:30 A.M. at Fairview Cemetery, Fairview, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory are requested to: American Diabetes Association Memorial Honor Program-Call Center, PO Box 2680, North Canton, OH 44720.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Shake-Up By Central Committee
description: The 150-member Central Committee of the ruling Communist Party fired two senior party officials linked to a widely publicized corruption scandal. At a 10-day meeting, it also changed at least six cabinet ministers and promoted to deputy prime minister the man who negotiated a far-reaching trade agreement with the United States, Trade Minister Vu Khoan. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Mary Knowles Fritchey, 90, Philanthropist
description: Mary Knowles Fritchey, whose fund-raising and support for the Kennedy Center, the Phillips Collection and other cultural institutions helped make Washington a center for the arts, died on July 9 at her home in Washington. She was 90.

title: Poland's Solidarity With America
description: When President Bush spoke at Warsaw University last year, he said that the question was no longer what others can do for Poland, but what America and Poland and all of Europe can do for the rest of the world. His words are more true now than ever. The tragedy of Sept. 11 emphasized the importance of trans-Atlantic solidarity and the need to accomplish the ''European project'' that was started with the first round of NATO enlargement only three years ago and will continue this fall with further expansion of NATO and then the enlargement of the European Union.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Move To Block Immigration Law
description: Conservatives have asked the country's highest court to block a new law that eases immigration restrictions for skilled foreign workers. The lawsuit was filed by conservative-led regional governments from 6 of Germany's 16 federal states including Bavaria, which is led by Edmund Stoiber, the opposition candidate for chancellor. The court is not expected to rule on the case before the Sept. 22 national election. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: U.P.S. and Teamsters Reach Deal for a 25% Raise
description: Facing the threat of another crippling strike, the United Parcel Service announced yesterday that it had reached a tentative six-year pact that will give 210,000 Teamsters a 25 percent increase in wages and benefits.

title: 9/11 Tape: Families May Hear It, but Not Tell of It
description: Fire officials said yesterday that the families of the 343 firefighters who died on Sept. 11 would be allowed to listen to radio transmissions that were recorded in the World Trade Center on the morning of the attack.

title: Social Security Jitters
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Vote Ahead for Cornell Assistants
description: Cornell University agreed last week to let graduate student assistants vote on whether they wanted union representation; it also agreed to negotiate with a union if the students approved it. Cornell graduate students, who have worked with the United Automobile Workers on an organizing campaign, applauded Cornell's position at a time when Brown, Columbia and Tufts have all opposed unionization on their campuses. The Cornell vote is tentatively set for late October. MARY G. OPPERMAN, Cornell's vice president for human resources, said that the agreement ''avoids a long and expensive series of administrative hearings to determine the scope of the proposed bargaining unit,'' but that Cornell still reserved the right to address ''the appropriateness of union representation.'' Karen W. Arenson

title: In New Jersey, Nuclear Fears Have to Stand in Line
description: The talk was of terrorists and the possibility that they might strike 15 miles from here at Oyster Creek, the nation's oldest operating commercial nuclear plant. But as she stood in line last weekend to collect federally issued potassium iodide tablets -- a precaution in case of radiation exposure -- Marcie Ekelmann said that in the event of an attack, she would most likely opt for something less medicinal, but perhaps more soothing.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Jogger Critically Hurt
description: A man out for a morning run near the F.D.R. Drive yesterday was struck and critically injured by the boom of a construction crane, the police said. The man, Roger Schwartz, 68, was listed in critical condition at Bellevue Hospital Center last night, suffering from head and internal injuries, a hospital spokesman said. Mr. Schwartz was jogging in the East River Park along the F.D.R. Drive in the East Village when a cable on a crane split, causing a part of the crane known as the dolly boom to swing free and hit him. North Star Contracting Corporation of New Rochelle, N.Y., was operating the crane on a nearby ramp, the police said. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Foot-And-Mouth Strategy
description: The government should use a combination of vaccination and culling as a way to combat any future outbreaks of foot-and-mouth disease, a government-appointed inquiry concluded. But the inquiry, by the Royal Society, stopped short of recommending mass vaccinations, saying instead that vaccinations should be used ''as a major tool of first resort'' when foot-and-mouth has already appeared, to prevent it from spreading to healthy animals. Last year, Britain suffered its worst outbreak of the highly contagious disease in decades, eventually slaughtering some six million animals at risk of infection, but ruling out vaccinations, which makes animals ineligible for export. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: A Saudi Teacher
description: To the Editor:

title: Bank One Profit Rose 27% on Credit Card Fees
description: Bank One said today that its second-quarter profit rose 27 percent as it added credit card customers and as fees from deposits and credit cards jumped.

title: Grilled Cheese Puts On an Italian Suit
description: ONE of the wonders of cooking is that the tiniest adjustment to what you are making, the addition of a single ingredient or the execution of a technique, can entirely change a dish and the visceral response you get from eating it.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict referred incorrectly to a 44-page report by Amnesty International that criticized the actions of Palestinians. It was the organization's seventh report -- not its first -- criticizing the role of Palestinians in the current uprising.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Staying Two Wings Ahead Of Creditor
description: The maker of Russia's military fighter jets said the company would not send its aircraft to one of the world's premier arms fairs, in Britain, because it feared that a Swiss company would try to seize them as part of a dispute over unpaid debt. Mikhail A. Pogosyan, general director of Sukhoi Aircraft, said the decision was made because of the risk that the Swiss trading company Noga would again try to impound the jets, as it nearly succeeded in doing at the Paris Air Show last year. The company's dogged legal efforts to force Russia to pay more than $60 million it is owed has forced Russian officials to cancel several appearances at trade and air shows and even a trip to the United States earlier this year. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Saint-Sans and Grilled Salmon Under the Stars
description: Amanda Pilar Smith, above, an author of ''Paris in a Basket'' (Konemann, 2000), a survey of Parisian markets, has started a catering company, Good Food in a Basket. She is preparing picnic sacks that can be ordered two days in advance for the New York Philharmonic concerts in Central Park on July 24 and Aug. 1. Her three menus offer herb-crusted filet mignon, roast tarragon chicken or citrus-marinated grilled salmon, with salads, dessert, fruit, snacks, bottled water, hibiscus iced tea and utensils. All that's missing is the blanket. A children's menu offers chicken fingers. Each bright Mexican-made sack holds two to eight meals ($28 each), with a minimum of two meals to an order. Orders may be made from www.goodfoodinabasket.com. Pickup is from Ms. Smith's trucks at Columbus Avenue and 85th Street, and Madison Avenue and 80th Street.

title: Excerpts From Report By Greenspan at Senate
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, gave his semiannual report on the economy to the Senate Banking Committee yesterday. Following are excerpts from his testimony and from an exchange between Mr. Greenspan and Senator Thomas R. Carper, Democrat of Delaware, in a question-and-answer session after the testimony, as recorded by the Federal News Service Inc. A full transcript of Mr. Greenspan's testimony can be found online at nytimes.com.

title: Blackstone Amasses a Record Equity Fund
description: The Blackstone Group announced yesterday that it had raised $6.45 billion for its latest private investment fund -- the largest private equity fund ever raised.

title: In Westchester, a New High School Builds on Diversity
description: Under most circumstances, David Distant and David Gallagher probably would never have met each other.

title: AT&T's President to Succeed Chief Executive by Next Year
description: The AT&T Corporation, the nation's largest long-distance carrier, announced today that David W. Dorman, the company's president, will succeed C. Michael Armstrong as chief executive by the beginning of next year.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Violence In Muslim Regions
description: The government said it was setting up a special security force to police its largely Muslim southern provinces after a series of attacks that included bombings and the assassination of 13 police officers. The motive for the attacks is not known, but some Thai officials fear that the violence is a new flare-up of Muslim separatism that was suppressed a decade ago. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Accounting Layoffs
description: KPMG International, the world's third-biggest accounting firm, plans to cut 810 jobs in Britain, or about 7 percent of its local work force, as business slows with the drop in stock prices. About 50 of the company's 600 partners are being cut along with 700 other employees and 62 people at the KLegal law firm, a KPMG spokeswoman, Louise Harvey, said.

title: Big Pataki Donors Include Real Estate Developers
description: Newly released financial records show that one of the biggest contributors to Gov. George E. Pataki's re-election campaign is a subsidiary of an Australian real estate company that is seeking to redevelop the World Trade Center site.

title: Recipe: Goat Cheese, Figs and Ginger-Honey Panini
description: Time: 15 minutes

title: Study Links Working Mothers to Slower Learning
description: Adding fuel to the debate over mothers who work, a new analysis of the largest government child-care study has found that early maternal employment has negative effects on children's intellectual development.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOOLAN, REV. DAVID STUART, SJ
description: TOOLAN-Rev. David Stuart, SJ. Died July 16. Priest, author, journalist, editor at America, formerly at Commonweal. Son of the late Sen and Mrs. John E. Toolan, Fair Haven, N.J., brother of Maureen and the late John Toolan, brother-in-law of Carol, uncle of Devin, John, Christopher. At St. Ignatius Loyola 980 Park Avenue. Wake Thursday 3-5, 7-9 Friday 3-5. Funeral Mass 8 P.M. Friday.

title: CORPORATE CONDUCT: THE IMPACT -- The Chief Executives; Trying to Deflect The Tough Reforms
description: Eric Schmidt, the chief executive of Google, the Internet search company, has been spending a lot of time listening to talk-radio shows lately. The investors and other callers sound none too happy.

title: One Question, Not Simple
description: The defense strategy for Charles Schwarz was essentially to repeat one line like a mantra: He wasn't in the police station bathroom where an unthinkable assault took place.

title: British Workers Strike, Closing Schools and Museums
description: LONDON, July 17  Hundreds of thousands of local government workers went on strike across much of Britain today, shutting down schools, leaving garbage uncollected and closing libraries, museums and recreation centers in a bitter dispute over pay.

title: Commercial Space Mix Could Affect Revenues And Race for Governor
description: John C. Whitehead, chairman of the organization overseeing the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan, brought a long-simmering backroom debate into the open yesterday when he said the group might scrap the six plans for the World Trade Center site, and with them, the Port Authority's demand for dense commercial development.

title: A Group's Racketeering Suit Brings Baseball to Full Bristle
description: Linking the baseball commissioner and his chief aide to violations of a federal racketeering statute, 14 Canadian companies that were former limited partners of the Montreal Expos drew an angry response yesterday as they sued Bud Selig and others while charging they conspired in a fraudulent scheme to eliminate the Expos.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online Job Hunting Rises
description: Fifty-two million Americans have looked online for information about jobs, and more than four million do so on a typical day, according to a report to be released this week by the Pew Internet and American Life Project. Up to one-third of those who surf for new jobs do so from their current workplace. The figures represent an increase of more than 60 percent in the number of online job hunters from March 2000, the report said, reflecting an increase in Internet use and ''turmoil and tightening of the job market.'' In the survey, which was conducted in January among 2,259 Internet users, eight million Americans who had changed jobs in the last two years said that the Internet was ''a vital resource'' for finding new work. Bob Tedeschi (NYT)

title: U.S. Panel Says Man Can't Sue In '67 Police Beating Incident
description: A federal appeals panel in Manhattan has ruled that a man who said he was the victim of a 1967 police beating in Long Beach, N.Y., cannot sue the city or the police, even though an officer came forward three years ago to say that the man had been beaten and that the incident had been covered up.

title: Mets' Prospect a Long Way From Home
description: Most minor leaguers have fans in their hometowns who follow their progress through the professional ranks, but JUSTIN HUBER, a top catching prospect in the Mets' organization, merely has a lot of confused friends back home in Melbourne, Australia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORDEN, BARBARA ZIMMER DE JURENEV
description: BORDEN-Barbara Zimmer de Jurenev. Of Tryon, NC passed away peacefully in her sleep on July 11, 2002 in her 98th year. Barbara is survived by her daughter, Nicole de Jurenev of Santa Fe, NM, her niece, Virginia Zimmer of New York City, and her stepsons, Phillip Borden of Laughlin, NV, & Christopher Borden of Pioneer, CA. For information, contact McFarland Funeral Chapel, Tryon, NC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, ANN WATSON
description: WALSH-Ann Watson. The officers & employees of Brown Harris Stevens are deeply saddened by the death of our colleague, Ann Watson Walsh, on Saturday, July 13, 2002. Our sincerest condolences to her 4 children, Gloria, Hughes, Brooke & Thomas; her 4 grandchildren; & her sister Lorraine Dietz. Services: Thursday 1:00 PM, at Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th Street, New York, New York.

title: The Simplest Syrup of All
description: THERE are two key ingredients to great summer drinks: ice and sugar syrup. Undoubtedly, you are a connoisseur of ice.

title: FED CHIEF BLAMES CORPORATE GREED; HOUSE REVISES BILL
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, pointed today to a corporate culture blighted by ''infectious greed'' as the cause of the breakdown in confidence among investors. With political pressure growing and the stock market falling, the House hurriedly passed a measure that would toughen criminal fraud penalties to curb corporate wrongdoing.

title: Union Vote Ahead for Cornell Assistants
description: Cornell University agreed last week to let graduate student assistants vote on whether they wanted union representation; it also agreed to negotiate with a union if the students approved it. Cornell graduate students, who have worked with the United Automobile Workers on an organizing campaign, applauded Cornell's position at a time when Brown, Columbia and Tufts have all opposed unionization on their campuses. The Cornell vote is tentatively set for late October. MARY G. OPPERMAN, Cornell's vice president for human resources, said that the agreement "avoids a long and expensive series of administrative hearings to determine the scope of the proposed bargaining unit," but that Cornell still reserved the right to address "the appropriateness of union representation."

title: Tapes of U.S. Sites Seized in Terror Case
description: The Spanish police have arrested three men suspected of being operatives of Al Qaeda, and officials said one of them had five-year-old videotapes with surveillance images of the World Trade Center.

title: National Briefing: South
description: NORTH CAROLINA: A PRIMARY FOUR MONTHS LATE

title: The Bomb Was Fake, The Handcuffs Real
description: A decade ago, it seemed no more than a harmless gimmick. As an 18-year-old student at Syracuse University, Craig Cimmino says, he designed several fake time bombs to promote an advertising business for a class project. His design -- which combined the bombs with a note asking: ''Are your ideas starting to bomb? Call Craig Cimmino!'' -- impressed his professor, who gave him an A.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JATKOFF, HYMAN
description: JATKOFF-Hyman. 76. Of Boynton Beach, FL., died July 15, 2002. Interment will be at Beth-El Cemetery in Paramus, N.J. Graveside services will be held on Thursday, July 18th at 10:30 A.M.

title: Sharp Turn In Investigation Of Boat Crash
description: For all the apparent mayhem surrounding a late night boating accident that took the lives of two people in Queens on Thursday, the authorities had a simple explanation: a drunken teenager had turned his father's boat around in fast circles for fun and then slammed it into another one.

title: Africa's Economy Grew 4.3% Last Year
description: Africa's economy sidestepped the worst effects of the global slowdown last year, growing by more than 4 percent, but the outlook for this year is uneven and uncertain, the United Nations said in a report released today.

title: Rapt Look At a Holistic Medical Art From India
description: ''We call this a mud scan,'' says a practitioner of the ancient holistic medicine called Ayurveda, as he slathers a silent volunteer with dark brown clay. The clay hardens and flakes off, revealing spots of skin discoloration that, to the practitioner, indicate the presence of hidden abrasions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLARD, LISELOTTE (NEE FLEMMING) (VON FALKENHAYN)
description: MILLARD - Liselotte (nee Flemming) (von Falkenhayn). Our beloved mother, most cherished grandmother, dear mother-in-law and grandmother-in-law passed after a long and courageous fight against Multiple Myeloma on Monday evening, July 15, 2002. The service will be held at 11 AM Saturday, July 20th in Southampton, Long Island, Dune Church. We are very much saddened by her loss, yet relieved that her suffering has come to an end. Marina Baroness von Richter nee von Falkenhayn Vanessa Countess Radicati di Primeglio nee Baroness von Richter Georg Baron von Richter Count Manfredo Radicati di Primeglio Marsha Crawford nee Millard (von Mueffling) and family

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Child Molester To Be Monitored
description: Salvatore Inghilleri, who was convicted 10 years ago for the sex abuse of Katie Beers, left, his wife's 9-year-old goddaughter, is set to be released soon on parole. He has been given a Level 3 assessment under Megan's Law, which means at the highest risk of committing similar crimes. His attorney, Mary Elizabeth Abbate, said she would appeal the Monday ruling by Judge Ralph T. Gazzilo of Suffolk County Court. Under the ruling, Mr. Inghilleri will have to report to the authorities every 90 days for the rest of his life, and his address and the details of his crime will be available to his neighbors on the Internet. He was convicted in 1994 of molesting the girl while she was held in a basement bunker for 16 days by a neighbor, who is serving a 15-year prison term. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Proxy Tells of Computer Associates Bad Year
description: By almost any measure, the year ended March 31 was not a good one for Computer Associates International.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Hispanics' Use Of Web Surges
description: Hispanics' use of the World Wide Web at home is growing faster than that of any other ethnic group in the United States, according to Nielsen/NetRatings. The online Hispanic population grew 13 percent, to nearly 7.6 million, Nielsen/NetRatings found, compared with an overall Web population growth of 3 percent, to almost 105 million. The percentage of Web users who identified themselves as Asian or Pacific Islander grew 6 percent, to nearly 2.4 million; the Caucasian group grew 4 percent, to more than 94 million; and African-American users increased 3 percent, to nearly 7.8 million. The online growth of the Hispanic population is ''a great opportunity for marketers and businesses,'' said Carolyn Clark, a media analyst at Nielsen/NetRatings, based in New York.

title: An Irish Castle For Religious Manuscripts
description: For decades one of the world's great collections of ancient religious manuscripts lay slumbering, relatively forgotten, down a quiet leafy avenue in a wealthy residential neighborhood here. It opened to the public with great fanfare in 1957 as the Chester Beatty Library, but in recent years it had become an unappreciated hidden treasure. Only dedicated students and diligent tourists ventured in to see its delicate Egyptian papyri and its beautiful illuminated Korans. On dismal winter days perhaps one or two visitors came through the doors.

title: 'Authentic' Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles Burton, 59, a Pole-to-Pole Explorer
description: Charles Burton, a British explorer who took part in the first expedition to circumnavigate the globe from pole to pole, died on Monday at his family home in the English village of Framfield in Sussex. He was 59 and had suffered a heart attack, said his brother, Richard.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Sun and At&t In Joint Venture
description: AT&T and Sun Microsystems will jointly market and sell Web site operating and network-management services for global communication networks. AT&T will provide database, storage and security services using Sun technology, while Sun, whose servers run corporate networks and Web sites, will provide technical support to build and protect the networks, AT&T said yesterday. AT&T has 18 Internet data centers that operate computer servers for thousands of customers, and the joint marketing ''just makes it a whole lot easier not only to sell to those folks but to accommodate whatever their needs are,'' said Kate Rankin, an AT&T spokeswoman. AT&T and Sun already have sales agreements and a multiyear agreement for engineering and managing Sun's communications networks. AT&T is not disclosing the value of the contract, Ms. Rankin said.

title: Athletics' Place At U.S. Colleges
description: THIRTY-EIGHT university teachers and administrators from South Africa were here this spring, studying American higher education at Vanderbilt University and visiting other Tennessee colleges as well. They were seeking lessons that might apply to their own institutions, initially black-only colleges that are growing rapidly in the post-apartheid era.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: HISPANICS' USE OF WEB SURGES Hispanics' use of the World Wide Web at home is growing faster than that of any other ethnic group in the United States, according to Nielsen/NetRatings. The online Hispanic population grew 13 percent, to nearly 7.6 million, Nielsen/NetRatings found, compared with an overall Web population growth of 3 percent, to almost 105 million. The percentage of Web users who identified themselves as Asian or Pacific Islander grew 6 percent, to nearly 2.4 million; the Caucasian group grew 4 percent, to more than 94 million; and African-American users increased 3 percent, to nearly 7.8 million. The online growth of the Hispanic population is "a great opportunity for marketers and businesses," said Carolyn Clark, a media analyst at Nielsen/NetRatings, based in New York.

title: A Tall Order of Fiery Flavor Calls for a Drink
description: DECIDING where to go for drinks often has more to do with the look of the crowd at the bar than the appeal of the snacks. But the tall, crisp, ultra-spiced breadsticks at the bar at Compass, a contemporary American brasserie on the Upper West Side, may change that.

title: Tax Breaks Are in Bill Closing Bermuda Loophole
description: A proposal to close a loophole that lets companies avoid taxes by acquiring a mailbox in Bermuda would force Boeing, Kodak, Disney and other large exporters to pay higher taxes, while giving new breaks to General Motors, Ford and other companies with factories overseas, supporters and critics of the plan said yesterday.

title: Yes to Guns for Pilots
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Firefighter Is Elected President of Union
description: The Uniformed Firefighters Association, the 9,000-member union representing New York City firefighters, elected a 14-year department veteran yesterday as its president, ending a rancorous campaign.

title: Too Slow on Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: IRELAND: CRACKDOWN ON ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS In a new crackdown on illegal immigration, more than 200 police officers raided homes in Dublin and arrested 39 people. The searches are to be extended nationwide in an effort to find and deport the 2,610 people who have not left the country since their applications for asylum were rejected. Some 310 people have been deported since January; about 10,000 people, mostly from Africa and Eastern Europe, request asylum in Ireland each year.

title: Blair Risks A Grilling, But Emerges Unburned
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair, combating accusations that he has taken on presidential airs and given short shrift to Parliament, today became the first British leader in history to subject himself to interrogation by a panel from the House of Commons.

title: Shop and Stay
description: The 220-store Woodbury Commons outlet center in Central Valley, N.Y., off Exit 16 of the New York State Thruway, has Shop and Stay packages for Hudson Valley lodging. The 13-room Cromwell Manor Inn in Cornwall, N.Y., (845) 534-7136, has a room with a fireplace for $140 a night (regularly $245 to $336) and a suite with fireplace and whirlpool for $160 (regularly $370) Sunday to Thursday night. The 130-room Thayer Hotel in West Point, (845) 446-4731, has rooms with buffet breakfast for $179 double weekdays, $149 Sunday, $209 Saturday; taxes are extra, blackout dates apply. Other hotels are available; www.premiumoutlets.com .

title: CONTINENTAL REPORTS QUARTERLY LOSS OF $139 MILLION
description: Continental Airlines reported a second-quarter loss of $139 million yesterday, signaling the start of what may be a dark week for the airline industry. Continental was the first carrier to report earnings this week. Its loss was $2.18 a share, in contrast to a profit of $42 million, or 74 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding one-time charges, Continental lost $35 million, or 55 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had forecast a loss of 76 cents a share. Revenue was $2.1 billion. ''We don't see profitability before the end of the year,'' Gordon M. Bethune, the chief executive, said. ''I don't see any signs on the horizon. I'm looking for them, but it's kind of dark.'' Edward Wong (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Not-Guilty Plea In 3 Killings
description: A Maryland man who was accused of killing three people during a drug- and alcohol-induced rampage on the Lower East Side last month pleaded not guilty yesterday to three counts of first-degree murder, among other charges, at his arraignment in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The police said the man, Steven Santos, 20, fatally shot an elderly couple, Sara and Larry Sprung, and their neighbor, Raymond D'Amelio, on June 12 after using fire escapes and open windows to enter their apartments. Mr. Santos told the police that he had been drinking and using drugs, and that he shot the victims while searching for valuables. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Trial On Racist Attack Starts
description: A Moscow court opened a trial of five young Russian men accused of leading a racist rampage in a Moscow market last year that killed three people. The defendants, aged 18 to 23, charged with conspiracy to murder, deny they took part in the mob attack. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: New Chairman at New School
description: The trustees of New School University have elected PHILIP SCATURRO as chairman of its board, succeeding JOHN L. TISHMAN, who held the post since 1995. Mr. Scaturro, executive vice president and managing director of the investment banking firm of Allen & Company, was chancellor of the university from 1999 to June 2002, a period of transition between presidents JONATHAN F. FANTON and BOB KERREY. Karen W. Arenson

title: Wines of the Week
description: Zinfandel is a versatile grape. Though currently revered as a making rustic red with port-like alcohol level as high as 15 or 16 percent, zinfandel is not a one-note wine. Many producers choose to highlight zin's expressive personality by crafting wines from lighter-bodied (relatively speaking) to full-bodied, smooth to chewy and vibrant to ultra-ripe. Depending upon what you like, there's a style of zinfandel to please every wine drinker.

title: Jets Sign Draft Pick to Three-Year Deal
description: The Jets yesterday signed their third-round draft choice, tight end Chris Baker of Michigan State, to a three-year deal worth $1,340,000.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  O'DONNELL, JOE
description: O'DONNELL-Joe. Joe, you're still top shelf. We miss you. The O'Donnell Family

title: Saint-Sans and Grilled Salmon Under the Stars
description: Amanda Pilar Smith, an author of "Paris in a Basket" (Konemann, 2000), a survey of Parisian markets, has started a catering company, Good Food in a Basket. She is preparing picnic sacks that can be ordered two days in advance for the New York Philharmonic concerts in Central Park on July 24 and Aug. 1. Her three menus offer herb-crusted filet mignon, roast tarragon chicken or citrus-marinated grilled salmon, with salads, dessert, fruit, snacks, bottled water, hibiscus iced tea and utensils. All that's missing is the blanket. A children's menu offers chicken fingers. Each bright Mexican-made sack holds two to eight meals ($28 each), with a minimum of two meals to an order. Orders may be made from www.goodfoodinabasket.com. Pickup is from Ms. Smith's trucks at Columbus Avenue and 85th Street, and Madison Avenue and 80th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDEN, RAY REIDER
description: GOLDEN-Ray Reider. Beloved mother of Eric and Rachel Golden, daughter of Sidney and the late Shirley Reider, sister of Franklin Reider, on July 15th, 2002. Services to be held at the Congregation B'Nai Jeshurin, 257 West 88th Street, NYC, on July 18, 1 PM. Contributions to the charity of one's choice.

title: To Dance on a Dugout, A Guy's Gotta Eat
description: THAT'S him, there, the guy running around the field and jumping on top of the dugout between innings to dance the cha-cha slide with the ladies. After he finally gets a wave going, yelling so hard you wonder if he'll ever speak again, he takes off through the crowd, slapping high fives on a sea of raised hands. Two burly men watch him go. ''What a gig,'' one says, bemused.

title: G.M. Profit Doubles, but Worries on Pensions Hurt Stock
description: Profit at General Motors more than doubled in the second quarter, the company said today, but its pension liabilities and its investment in Fiat continued to pull down its stock price.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Unemployment Rises
description: The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate in Hong Kong increased to 7.7 percent for the three-month period from April through June, compared with 7.4 percent for March through May, as the Hong Kong economy remained stagnant.

title: Armstrong Guard Sees All, Except Sights
description: Lance Armstrong was leaning forward in his chair on the ground floor of his hotel, chatting with reporters, when a fan peered in from an open window and pointed a big camera at him. Quickly, Erwin Ballarta, who had been standing in a corner and looking every which way, shooed the fan away and slid the window closed.

title: Southern Snacks, Freshly Dug
description: Late July is the peak season for freshly dug peanuts from Florida and Georgia. Though once scarce north of the Mason-Dixon line, these straw-color peanuts (called green peanuts) are available for about $1.50 a pound at vegetable stands on Mulberry and Mott Streets in Chinatown from June through September. Fresh raw peanuts should still be slightly damp to the touch and will smell like earth and new-mown hay. Like their close cousin, edamame, green peanuts should be boiled in salted water until soft, about 45 minutes. Shelled, they make a refreshingly different summer nibble with a flavor between a chickpea and a sweet English pea, with a tannic kick. In the Southeast, they are popular at outdoor events like minor league baseball games, where spent shells and dribbles of peanut brine are not much of a problem. MATT LEE and TED LEE

title: Mayor Indicates Budget Fixes Could Be Sooner Than Usual
description: As the skittish stock market threatens to further deplete New York City's finances, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signaled yesterday that his administration might move to modify the city's month-old $42.3 billion budget sooner rather than later.

title: MetroStars Advance In U.S. Open Cup, 1-0~
description: A goal by Rodrigo Faria in the 76th minute, off a rebound of his own shot, gave the MetroStars of Major League Soccer a 1-0 victory over the Hampton Roads Mariners of the A-League in Virginia Beach last night.

title: Donated Advertising Set a Record in 2001
description: The Advertising Council in New York, which coordinates public service campaigns on behalf of the advertising industry, received a record $1.58 billion in donated media time and space in 2001, an increase of 2 percent from the $1.55 billion donated in 2000.

title: Survey Halted, Drug Makers Seek to Protect Hormone Sales
description: When female patients have asked in recent days whether they should continue taking Prempro, the hormone replacement therapy, doctors have told roughly half of them to stop taking the drug or to switch to an alternative treatment, a survey of doctors has found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMER, JOEL D.
description: HAMMER-Joel D. Age 65. Beloved husband of Jeannie. Loving father of Aaron (Allison) and Jennifer. Adored son of Sarah (the late Alfred) Hammer. Dear brother of Lola (the late Sidney) Greene. Funeral information, 1-800-288-5701.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Interest Rate Raised
description: Responding to unexpectedly strong domestic growth, the Bank of Canada raised its trend-setting overnight rate yesterday for the third time this year, to 2.75 percent from 2.5 percent. The central bank said the Canadian economy had been moving toward full production capacity more quickly than anticipated. The core inflation rate, which excludes the volatile food and energy categories, was 2.2 percent in May, slightly higher than the bank's 2 percent target. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Smith Still Open

title: CORPORATE CONDUCT: THE IMPACT -- The Fine Print; Trust Must Begin With the Reports
description: For some investors, a return of trust will have to begin in the same place that many of the recent problems did: companies' financial statements.

title: The Cycles of Financial Scandal
description: America is at a turning point. Corporate scandals, the fall of the stock markets, the sudden mobilizations in Washington of the last few weeks to legislate against some of the more egregious corporate abuses: they all indicate that the nation's attitude toward business is changing. It is potentially a bigger change than many politicians realize. What's unnerving them is that the payback from the market bubble of the late 1990's is becoming apparent to Main Street. The charts of the downside since March 2000 are starting to match the slope of the earlier three-year upside.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARSEL, NORMAN
description: BARSEL-Norman. An accomplished scientist with the soul of a poet, died July 15, 2002. Husband of the late Ann (nee Stolberg). Father of Sara-Ellen Barsel, Julie Barsel Bergman and Deborah Kay Barsel. Grandfather of Aaron Bergman & Hannah Neprash. Relatives and friends are invited to memorial services Thursday, 2 PM, Goldstein's Rosenberg's Raphael-Sacks, 6410 North Broad St, Phila, PA. 19126. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the University of Pennsylvania Cancer Center, C/O Dr. John Glick, 1225 Penn Tower, 3400 Spruce Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19104-4283.

title: The Game Is All Business to Woods
description: If Tiger Woods avoids the rough at Muirfield as deftly as he avoided controversy today, his chances at the British Open will be excellent.

title: Executor Says Williams's Will Doesn't Give His True Wishes
description: Ted Williams's will was filed in a Florida court yesterday and although it states that he wanted to be cremated, the executor of his estate said that Williams had changed his mind. The executor, Albert Cassidy Jr., said that Williams had decided he wished to be cryonically preserved.

title: John J. Gilbert Is Dead at 88; Gadfly at Corporate Meetings
description: John J. Gilbert, one of the earliest and most persistent gadflies to speak out at annual meetings on behalf of small shareholders -- dramatizing his demands with such attention-getting props as a red clown's nose -- died on Monday at his daughter's home in Denver. He was 88.

title: Orthopedics Maker Ousts Chief In a Dispute Over Management
description: Centerpulse, Europe's biggest maker of orthopedic products, dismissed its chief executive, Stephan Rietiker, today because of clashes with the chairman and other managers over how to run the company.

title: His Global Empire in Disarray, Deutsche Telekom Chief Resigns
description: Yielding to intense political pressure and a stubbornly depressed stock price, the chief executive of Deutsche Telekom, Ron Sommer, resigned today as the head of a company he had sought to transform from a state monopoly into a global communications colossus.

title: New English Cuisine on the Road to Mandalay
description: AT Nahm, you are surrounded by blond wood, gold leaf and slightly too many slightly too skinny women. You eat authentic Thai dishes with names like miang som oo and hoi shenn pat khaa orn, some of them stunningly spicy, most of them challenging to pedestrian palates. You drink the best of wines from California, New Zealand, Australia and South Africa, or Thai beer.

title: A Master Plan for Homeland Security
description: The importance of strengthening domestic defenses against terrorism is incontestable, yet the formal unveiling yesterday of President Bush's National Strategy for Homeland Security seemed almost perfunctory. The reason is that decision-making on these matters in Washington is already far advanced. The 88-page plan is for the most part fine, but what the country urgently needs today is constructive action by the White House and Congress.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Drought Worries Continue
description: The state's commissioner of environmental protection, Bradley M. Campbell, urged New Jersey residents yesterday to conserve water as a dry July begins to undo progress from a wet June. Despite the easing of some restrictions in June, the state remains in a drought emergency. Mr. Campbell said that although reservoirs were at 86.8 percent capacity, less than 1 percent below normal, ground and surface levels were ''significantly'' below normal. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Prosecutors Cite Mob Efforts To Terrorize Union and Actor
description: They called one enforcer the Lump.

title: Bank One Jumps on Bandwagon To Count Options as Expenses
description: The trend toward treating the value of stock options as an expense grew yesterday, as Bank One became the third major company to announce plans to do so this week and as an international accounting panel directed its staff members to draw up a rule to require such accounting treatment.

description: AMERICAS

title: 3 Are Left Dead by Suicide Blasts in Tel Aviv Street
description: TEL AVIV, July 17 - Two Palestinian suicide bombers killed three people here tonight, a day after a West Bank bus ambush that took eight Israeli lives. The attacks have shattered a period of calm that began nearly a month ago when the Israeli Army took over the West Bank.

title: Iverson Jail Time Is Termed Unlikely
description: Three prominent lawyers agreed yesterday that Allen Iverson was unlikely to go to prison or even go to trial in the Philadelphia case in which he is charged with three felonies and various misdemeanors. A fourth lawyer said Iverson's fame as a pro basketball star might work against him.

description: Expenses-Paid Honeymoon

title: Senate Votes to Allow Easier Import of Prescription Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  The Senate approved a proposal today that would make it easier for Americans to import prescription drugs from Canada, where drug prices are often lower than in the United States.

title: A Contest More About Bombast Than News
description: With the arrival of ''Donahue'' on Monday night, the cable news competition at 8 came to resemble a three-headed dragon roaring all over the place. Just picture it: Phil Donahue as the white-haired contrarian dragon on the left; Bill O'Reilly as the fire-breathing dragon on the right; poor little Connie Chung as the awkward, unopinionated dragon in the middle. Fairy tale heroes destroy that kind of creature, but in real life, it represents the bluster that dominates cable news.

title: Bush Selects A Texas Ally As Ambassador To Mexico
description: President Bush announced today that he would nominate Antonio O. Garza, a longtime Texas political ally, as ambassador to Mexico.

title: Once Secret, And Now On Display; Declassified: A Spy Museum Opens This Week in Washington
description: ''We were Q,'' said Jonna Mendez, a former chief of disguise for the Central Intelligence Agency, referring to the British technical expert who came up with whiz-bang weaponry for Agent 007. Mrs. Mendez and her husband, Antonio J. Mendez, are alumni of the C.I.A. Office of Technical Affairs. At what they sometimes call ''the Magic Kingdom,'' they devised spy gadgets, bogus documents and disguises.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALB, HARRIET M.
description: FALB-Harriet M. Died July 14. There is a great loss of a lifelong campaigner for human rights and world peace. Much loved by her family and friends, who will have a memorial in celebration of her life at Long Beach Terrace, 430 Shore Road, Long Beach, at 1 PM, on Thursday, July 18. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Sloan-Kettering, or Amnesty International.

title: William Gorog, 76, Businessman With a Bent for High Technology
description: William F. Gorog, a technology entrepreneur who was one of the first to develop the public's ability to pay over the phone with credit cards and later via the Internet, died Sunday at a hospital in Falls Church, Va. He was 76 and lived in nearby McLean.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUTMAN, CHARLES H.
description: TUTMAN-Charles H. On July 8, 2002, in New York City. Survived by one brother, Dr. William L. Tutman, three sisters, Isis T. Teal, Viola O. Lewis and Patricia T. Quarles, nieces, nephews, two sistersin-law, Elaine B. and Joyce Tutman, other relatives andfriends. Memorial services will be held on Saturday, 11 A.M. at Nutter Funeral Home Inc, 2501 Gwynns Falls Parkway, Baltimore, MD.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Loss At Philips
description: The consumer electronics giant Royal Philips Electronics had a record loss in the second quarter after writing down its stake in Vivendi Universal. Royal Philips, which makes light bulbs, televisions and semiconductors, said it lost 1.36 billion euros ($1.37 billion) after it reduced the value of its 3.5 percent holding in Vivendi by 1.52 billion euros.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: A Stake In Rome Airports

The Australian company bought the stake from Leonardo Holdings S.A. The Italian airports handled 26 million passengers last year. John Shaw (NYT)

He wears shorts, a collared shirt and a red tie. SpongeBob normally lives in a pineapple at the bottom of the Pacific Ocean in a place called Bikini Bottom, with his pet snail Gary. But SpongeBob has been turning up elsewhere recently, in the Mets clubhouse.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Compuware Posts First-Quarter Profit
description: The Compuware Corporation, a maker of software for mainframe computers, posted a first-quarter profit but said it was smaller than the previous year's because sales of software and consulting services declined. Net income in the quarter ended June 30 was $22.5 million, or 6 cents a share, compared with $34.4 million, or 9 cents, a year earlier, the company said in a statement yesterday. Sales fell 23 percent, to $346.6 million, from $450.5 million. Compuware, which cut 1,600 jobs last quarter, has cut prices to compete with free or cheaper software from I.B.M., analysts said. Compuware exceeded analysts' reduced estimates of 5 cents a share on sales of $324.1 million.

title: An Agency's Ideology Is Unsuited to Its Task
description: Six plans for redeveloping the World Trade Center site are now on view at Federal Hall, the landmark Greek Revival building on Wall Street half a block north of the New York Stock Exchange. Except as a starting point for public discussion, the plans have little to recommend them.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Workers Protest In Capital
description: Several thousand workers clashed with the riot police outside the Ministry of Labor and the government Welfare Organzation in Tehran, protesting poor working conditions, low pay and insufficient welfare services. The police clubbed them and used tear gas to disperse them after they threw rocks and smashed windows. The protest followed one last Tuesday, when thousands of people clashed with the police in Tehran and Isfahan in defiance of a ban on demonstrations to mark the third anniversary of a crackdown against students. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Mcafee.Com Rejects Bid For 25% Stake
description: The McAfee.com Corporation, a maker of security software for personal computers, told its shareholders yesterday to reject Network Associates' latest offer to acquire the 25 percent of the company it does not already own. A special committee convened by McAfee.com, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., determined that the offer of 0.9 share of Network Associates for each McAfee.com share was inadequate. Among its reasons, the committee said that McAfee.com's subscription business is growing while Network Associates' prospects are declining because corporate information technology spending is falling. Network Associates of Santa Clara, Calif., makes antivirus and antispam software. Network Associates made a previous offer of 0.78 share for each McAfee.com shares. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: INTEREST RATE RAISED Responding to unexpectedly strong domestic growth, the Bank of Canada raised its trend-setting overnight rate yesterday for the third time this year, to 2.75 percent from 2.5 percent. The central bank said the Canadian economy had been moving toward full production capacity more quickly than anticipated. The core inflation rate, which excludes the volatile food and energy categories, was 2.2 percent in May, slightly higher than the bank's 2 percent target. Bernard Simon (NYT)

He ran for a City Council seat in the 35th District in Brooklyn last year, bowing out early when an opening for his current position came along. He says he couldn't walk away from AIDS work.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Crackdown On Illegal Immigrants
description: In a new crackdown on illegal immigration, more than 200 police officers raided homes in Dublin and arrested 39 people. The searches are to be extended nationwide in an effort to find and deport the 2,610 people who have not left the country since their applications for asylum were rejected. Some 310 people have been deported since January; about 10,000 people, mostly from Africa and Eastern Europe, request asylum in Ireland each year. Brian Lavery (NYT)

description: Shares of the Veritas Software Corporation, a storage software maker, rose 11 percent yesterday on news that the company, based in Mountain View, Calif., had met analysts' expectations for the second quarter. The company reported second-quarter revenue of $365 million, down from $370 million for the first quarter. Excluding certain charges, the company earned $58.3 million, or 14 cents a share, meeting analysts' estimates but still down from $80.5 million, or 20 cents a share, in the period last year. At the same time, the company remained cautious and warned that third-quarter earnings would decline. Shares rose $1.90, to $18.89. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Province Won't Appeal Same-Sex Ruling
description: The Ontario provincial government announced that it would not appeal a Superior Court ruling last week that the province must extend marriage rights to same-sex couples. The federal government still has a week to decide whether to appeal the decision, in which the court suspended enforcement while giving the national Parliament two years to change marriage regulations for the entire country. If Parliament refuses, the court said, marriage rights for same-sex couples will go into effect in Ontario. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

description: Brazil's central bank lowered its crucial interest rate to 18 percent from 18.5 percent, dropping its anti-inflationary posture and saying it believed that inflation next year would remain below its 4 percent target. Analysts had not expected the cut, and some said the move might have been political to help the government candidate for president, Jos Serra, who is trailing in polls. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Allied Domecq Leaves BBDO Worldwide

title: World Briefing | Americas: Paraguay: Emergency Lifted
description: President Luis Gonzlez Macchi lifted the five-day state of emergency he decreed on Monday after violent protests against his government's economic policies left two people dead, dozens injured and more than a hundred under arrest. In a televised speech, Mr. Gonzlez Macchi rejected demands that he step down, saying he will hand over power only to an elected successor next year. He attributed what he called ''a plan for destabilization'' to an exiled general, Lino Oviedo, ''and certain sectors of the political opposition'' led by his own vice president, Julio Csar Franco. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: REGULATORY MOVE CAUSES DROP IN CAPITAL ONE SHARES
description: The Capital One Financial Corporation, a leading issuer of Visa and MasterCard credit cards, said regulators required it to increase reserves for loan losses, setting off a sharp decline in its stock and that of its rivals. Capital One shares fell $20.12, or 39.8 percent, to $30.48. There were also losses in the stocks of the Providian Financial Corporation and Household International Inc., rivals that, like Capital One, have lent to clients with a history of bad credit. Although Capital One has had fewer unpaid bills than rivals, regulators said they were concerned that the company had grown too fast. Capital One said yesterday that it added $247 million in reserves in the second quarter to meet federal requirements.

title: BOEING'S PROFIT IS DOWN, BUT SHARES ARE UP
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that profit fell 7.3 percent in the second quarter as airliner deliveries slowed. The decline was less than investors expected, and the shares rose 5.1 percent. Net income fell to $779 million, or 96 cents a share, from $840 million, or 99 cents, a year earlier. Sales fell 11 percent, to $13.9 billion from $15.5 billion, Boeing said. In the airliner business, which accounts for 60 percent of Boeing's sales, profit fell 17 percent, to $790 million. Sales fell 18 percent, to $7.7 billion, as deliveries to airlines, hurt by declining travel since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, fell 21 percent, for a total of 112 planes delivered during the quarter. Profit in Boeing's military unit rose 12 percent, to $458 million, as deliveries of Apache helicopters and jet fighters rose. Profit in the space unit jumped 39 percent to $181 million.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Suit In Bungled Embryo Case
description: A case in which bungling at a fertility clinic left a white couple with black twins was taken to Britain's highest court. It is unclear who is suing whom in the case, in which details are being kept secret by court order, but it could have important ramifications in the murky area of fertility law and result in a reform of the regulations governing state-run fertility clinics. Under current British law, a woman who bears a child through in-vitro fertilization is considered its legal mother, even if the egg is not hers. Sarah Lyall (NYT)
