description: The Ford Motor Company reported better-than-expected second-quarter earnings today and a return to profitability after four quarters in the red.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EMMET, VIVIAN
description: EMMET-Vivian. Loved by four generations of family and friends. Respected for her brilliance, wit and leadership by a grateful community. Adored by the three men in her life-Harry, Richard & Walter-and by her children Judith and Morton Sloan, Joan Wexler, Jeffrey Silverson; grandchildren Douglas and Paul Wexler, Elizabeth and Avi Kaner, David Sloan; and her great-grandchildren Julia, Jack and Jonathan Kaner. Services Friday A.M. at Zion Memorial Chapel in Mamaroneck. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Education Fund of Beth Emeth Synagogue in Larchmont, would be greatly appreciated.

title: Plan to Import Drugs From Canada Passes In Senate, but Bush Declines to Carry It Out
description: The Senate today approved a proposal that could make it easier for Americans to import prescription drugs from Canada, where drug prices are often lower than in the United States. But the Bush administration said it would not carry out the plan because it would endanger public health.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GENSER, RUTH & SIDNEY
description: GENSER-Ruth & Sidney. Happy 55th Anniversary. Dance together in the stars. I miss you both. Love, Barbara

title: Lessons of 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: Robinson Upset With Selfish Play
description: MONTREAL, July 17 -- The Expos are one of baseball's best stories this season, entering last night's game with the Mets in second place in the National League East and strengthening a solid core of young players with blockbuster deals over the past month. But that does not mean they are free of frustration.

title: Congressional Cowardice
description: While a panicky Congress has rushed in recent days to reform the business world, it has not entirely lost its well-developed instinct for catering to special interests. On two issues critical to cleaning up corporate malfeasance, Congress has opted to put the preferences of big business -- and big campaign contributors -- ahead of the public good.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 8 about Israelis who are wounded in bomb attacks misstated the specialty of Dr. Ricardo Segal of Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem, who discussed the varying degrees of rehabilitation. He is a neurosurgeon, not a neurologist.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: ACCOUNTING QUESTIONS AT SONY Shares in the Sony Corporation, Japan's largest consumer electronics manufacturer, hit their lowest point in a year, falling 4.1 percent amid talk the company had engaged in questionable accounting practices. Sony strongly denied the accusations, but only after Hong Kong's South China Morning Post quoted Howard Schilit, a former accounting professor who testified to Congress in the Enron scandal, as saying Sony had potential problems on its books. Mr. Schilit said Sony's sales to its affiliates rose 133 percent last fiscal year, suggesting that the company inflated revenue. Sony said the jump in sales came after Sony formed a venture with Ericsson of Sweden in October 2001. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Treating Knee Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: Stock Options Said Not to Be As Widespread As Backers Say
description: Campaigning against legislation that would force companies to account for the cost of stock options, corporate executives, lobbyists and sympathetic lawmakers have proclaimed options to be a pillar of the middle class.

title: Piece by Piece, the Civil War's Monitor Is Pulled From the Atlantic's Depths
description: Two hundred thirty feet below the surface, clouds of silt are rising from the remains of the Civil War ironclad Monitor as a Navy diver vacuums up 140 years of mud and debris inside its gun turret.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMILTON, WALTER THOMAS
description: HAMILTON-Walter Thomas. On July 15, 2002. Husband of the late Esther and father of the late Michael. Survived by his sister, Frances Rosemary. Visitation Friday, 10-11 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Interment L.I. National Cemetery.

title: A Showcase for Contemporary California Design
description: Yes, there's the Getty Center, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and the Museum of Contemporary Art. But what the area has lacked is a museum that focuses on California art and design. That void was filled with the recent opening of the Pasadena Museum of California Art just north of Los Angeles. The $5 million museum was the brainchild of Robert and Arlene Oltman, art enthusiasts who live in a 5,000-square-foot penthouse over the museum. The building was designed by MDA Johnson Favaro Architecture and Urban Design of Culver City, which kept the exhibit spaces simple and concentrated the architectural flourishes on the public areas and entrance, or northern facade. That entrance, above, has folds ''like drapery,'' said Jim Favaro, giving a hint of the sculptural stairway with open skylight inside, right. The museum's current exhibition is ''On-Ramps: Transitional Moments in California Art,'' an exploration of 20th-century California art. Next year it will inaugurate a biennial of contemporary California design. The gift shop is offering the Air Chair by Jasper Morrison (right, $100) and will stock California designers like the lighting artist Pablo Pardo.

title: Red Wings Sign Lewis To Succeed Bowman
description: Dave Lewis knows that becoming the head coach of the Detroit Red Wings will be scrutinized because he succeeds Scotty Bowman, who has won more games than any other coach in N.H.L. history.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BORTOLUZZI, DOMINICK
description: BORTOLUZZI-Dominick. After 20 years our memories of you have not faded. You are in our thoughts always. Your loving family, Shirley, Maria and Larry

title: Charges Brought In Boat Crash To Be Dropped
description: Charges of boating while intoxicated that were brought against the 18-year-old driver of a boat that collided with another last Thursday, killing two people, will be dropped in the next day or two, a law enforcement official said last night. The lawyer for Robert Arnold, the driver, said a test showed that he did not have drugs in his system.

title: Mickelson Is Planning An Aggressive Attack
description: After finishing second at the United States Open and third at the Masters this year, Phil Mickelson plans to take a more aggressive approach at the British Open to try to beat Tiger Woods.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROULET, JEAN
description: ROULET-Jean. 10 years later and we still grieve, but also, and especially today, we celebrate your life with gratitude. Dulcie and Suzanne

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Gas Agreements
description: The European Commission has agreed to drop cartel proceedings against major Norwegian gas companies including Statoil and Norsk Hydro in exchange for their commitment to sell their gas separately in the future, and to make available additional supplies to the European Union. Meanwhile, the commissioner for competition, Mario Monti, said Gazprom, the Russian gas producer, had agreed to the commission's demands that it drop territorial restriction clauses in future contracts with European Union importers. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bayer Sells Food Unit
description: The German chemicals and pharmaceuticals company Bayer, under pressure to cut debt, agreed to sell Haarmann & Reimer, its fragrance and food additives unit, for $1.67 billion to EQT Private Equity Funds, which is backed by the Wallenberg family of Sweden. Analysts said Bayer had done well, as market expectations ranged from $1.2 billion to $1.5 billion. Haarmann & Reimer will be merged with Dragoco, a privately held local competitor, to form a new company. Bayer's divestment program, aimed at shedding noncore operations, is set to continue. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Ghity Lindenbaum Stern, 94, Philanthropist
description: Ghity Lindenbaum Stern, whose philanthropy benefited educational institutions in the United States and Israel, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 94.

title: Diamond Icons, Leopard-Skin Frames: Dressing Up Windows XP
description: Shedding skins -- changing the look and user interface of a software program -- isn't just for multimedia software anymore. SkinStudio XP, a Windows XP version of the WindowBlinds program made by the Stardock Corporation, can change the look of dialog boxes, windows and other visual features of the operating system.

title: 'Infectious Greed' and the 'Binge'
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Fine On France Sought In Beef Dispute
description: Stepping up pressure on France to lift its ban on British beef, the European Commission is demanding that France pay a fine of almost $160,000 for every day it continues to defy an earlier ruling authorizing British beef to be sold throughout the European Union. The union lifted its own ban on British beef in August 1999 after concluding that mad cow disease had been wiped out in Britain, but France ignored the ruling. Alan Riding (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GREECE: POLICE HAVE GUN FROM TERROR ATTACKS The police said they had found the second of two guns used by the November 17 terror group in a string of high-profile assassinations, including that of a British military attache two years ago in Athens. The .45-caliber Colt pistol was found in a weapons den raided recently by the police after a botched bombing attempt by a member of the group. The police also said they were holding three people suspected of links to the group, which is responsible for at least 23 killings since the 1975 assassination of the C.I.A. station chief in Athens, Richard Welch. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Armstrong Takes Lead in Tour
description: LA MONGIE, France, July 18  With a huge assist from his team, Lance Armstrong settled most questions today about his form in the Tour de France as he won the first mountain stage and gained the yellow jersey of the race's overall leader.

title: Struts and Stuff At Apple Show
description: YOU can have your Springsteen concert, your big Vegas magic show, your East River fireworks. For the true-blue Macintosh fan, they pale next to the greatest show on earth: the keynote speech at the annual Macworld Expo in New York.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stamford: Officer Charged With Theft, Again
description: A Stamford police officer has been accused of theft for the second time, the police said yesterday. The officer, Robert Velme, 36, was accused of stealing more than $800 in home furnishings from an Ethan Allen store while responding to a burglary-alarm call in January. Officer Velme and a woman, Kristine Rizzo, 33, were charged Tuesday with possession of stolen property, burglary, larceny and conspiracy after investigators found stolen home furnishings in Ms. Rizzo's New York home, the police said. Police Chief Louis A. DeCarlo said Officer Velme, a seven-year veteran, is on paid leave after being charged in June with shoplifting more than $3,400 in merchandise from a White Plains store. Officer Velme did not return a call for comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Big Inning Helps Mets Tie for 2nd in N.L. East
description: The Mets spent the first three months of the season waiting for their offense to come to life. The recent wait lasts fewer than nine innings.

title: Parent of American Airlines Reports Loss of $495 Million
description: AMR, the parent of American Airlines, reported a net loss of $495 million for the second quarter yesterday, reflecting three months of lagging recovery for the airline industry as business travelers continued to stay away from high-priced tickets.

title: House Panel Finds Congressman Guilty of Ethics Violations
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  A defiant Representative James A. Traficant Jr. was found guilty by a House panel today of ethics violations arising from his recent conviction on bribery, fraud and tax-evasion charges.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: No Vote On Same-Sex Marriage
description: The Legislature killed a proposed ballot initiative to make same-sex marriages unconstitutional. Proponents had hoped the initiative would be put on the ballot in November 2004. Instead, a joint session of the House and Senate voted to adjourn immediately after convening without taking a vote on the initiative, effectively killing it. The measure, which would also prohibit marriage benefits for same-sex unions, received 130,000 petition signatures last year, requiring the legislature to consider putting it on the ballot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARSH, YOUSUF
description: KARSH-Yousuf. We mourn the passing of a dear friend and monumental force in photography, whose long distinguished career touched the lives of major figures of contemporary history. He will also be missed for his innate charm and keen insight. We extend our deep condolences to Estrellita, his wife and partner for many years. With profound thanks for his lasting images and memories, we bid him a fond farewell!! Cornell Capa, Fndng Director Willis Hartshorn, Director Int'l Center of Photography

title: Congo's Longtime Plight
description: To the Editor:

title: Major League Hassles
description: Weekly highlights from 150 forums  from comments on the red wine headache to worries over a baseball strike.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Write-Down At Grocer
description: Ahold, the large Dutch food retailer, said a write-down related to a joint venture in Argentina would reduce 2002 earnings estimates by as much as two-thirds. The charge of 350 million euros to 450 million euros ($354.17 million to $455.36 million) in the second quarter would have the effect of reducing earnings growth to 5 percent to 8 percent, compared with the 15 percent growth originally predicted. Velox Retail Holdings, Ahold's partner, defaulted on its bank loans, activating an agreement that required Ahold to pay $490 million to cover those loans and buy Velox's stake, a South American supermarket chain known as Disco Ahold International Holdings. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Taxi Driver Dragged After Cab Is Stolen
description: A taxi driver tried to prevent a man from stealing his cab near the Port Authority Bus terminal last night, and was dragged from 41st Street and Ninth Avenue to just outside Pennsylvania Station, the authorities said.

title: Designs for Trade Center Raise Financing Questions
description: The proposals unveiled Tuesday to rebuild Lower Manhattan include a number of high-cost projects, including the burying of West Street, the acquisition of surrounding properties for residential use and the creation of a new subway and commuter rail hub. But how those projects -- which will require the investment of hundreds of millions, if not billions, of dollars -- will be paid for remains unclear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGLAR, HELEN
description: HAGLAR-Helen. Beloved wife of the late Raphael (Ralph), loving mother of Susan Cain, and Judith and Michael Schumacher, grandmother of Jennifer and Michael Block, Elizabeth Schumacher, Tracy and Stephen Foohey, David Cain, and Julie Cain. Great grandmother of Kimberly, Ryan, and Michael Foohey. Funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Friday, July 19th, at 11 A.M. Interment is to follow at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: Manufacturers lose monopoly on sales : EU tells car industry to widen competition
description: The European Commission adopted new measures Wednesday designed to make the continent's car industry more competitive, and consumer groups predicted that the rules could reduce the price of cars in Europe over the next few years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, CAROL G.
description: HELLER-Carol G. Sister, aunt, daughter to the late Rhoda and Meyer Sabsevitz. You put up a valiant fight. Your courage was an inspiration to all who knew you. You will be missed. Marilyn, Jonathan, Rachel and Josiah

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Wine.com Raises $9 Million In Financing
description: Wine.com, formerly known as eVineyard, announced yesterday that it had raised $9 million in financing, with the option to raise another $1 million within 60 days, bringing the total raised to $39.8 million. Peter Ekman, a wine industry veteran who became chief executive of Wine.com in March, said the latest round of financing would be the last the company would need in order to become profitable. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Is Another Alf Perry Out There?
description: TIGER WOODS has not already won the British Open that begins today. It just seems that way.

title: Worker Found Beaten to Death in Queens Theater
description: The bludgeoned body of a cleaning woman was found early yesterday in a rear aisle of a movie theater in Ridgewood, Queens, the authorities said.

title: Lawsuit Says Salomon Gave Special Deals to Rich Clients
description: During the market boom, a handful of top executives at telecommunications companies received big allotments of hot new stocks from Salomon Smith Barney, according to a former broker who has filed a lawsuit accusing the firm of unfair business practices. Jack B. Grubman, the firm's star analyst covering these businesses, played a central role in deciding which executives got how many shares, the broker said in an interview this week.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Ocean City: New Bridge
description: Transportation officials opened a $55 million bridge yesterday that connects the north end of Ocean City with Egg Harbor Township. Under construction for the past year, the bridge replaces a 72-year-old drawbridge considered antiquated and inadequate for an increasingly heavy volume of traffic. Drivers bound for Ocean City will pay $1 to cross the bridge but nothing on the return trip. The new bridge, the only link between the communities, was built 65 feet high, eliminating the need for bridge openings. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: Sponsors Sidestep Debate
description: Two of the three companies that advertise on CBS's broadcasts of the Masters are distancing themselves from a campaign to open the Augusta National Golf Club's membership to women before next April's tournament by saying they do not sponsor the club.

title: The Best Stealer List
description: Certainly not the most compelling reading in Princeton's Micawber Books, but perhaps the most startling are the signs scattered about the store that read: ''To our loyal customers Please help us solve our increasing theft problem by reporting any suspicious behavior to a staff member. -- thank you.''

title: A Hindu God in Limestone For Inspiration and Luck
description: Buddhism and Hinduism have long attracted Westerners seeking spiritual answers. Small wonder that Courtney Cox, Donna Karan, Elton John and Giselle Bundchen have bought David Raney's 32-inch-high statues of the Hindu elephant-headed god Ganesh (the god of auspicious beginnings). The depiction by Mr. Raney, a New York-based artist, yogi and feng-shui consultant, is made of limestone by a Balinese carver, Master Agung, in series of 36. Hindus typically offer food and prayers to Ganesh and keep the god protected, but Mr. Raney's clients, he said, ''can do what they like with them.'' Above, one of the 300-pound statues, with a green apple, at the Connecticut home of John Frieda, the hair stylist. Each Ganesh costs $3,600, plus shipping; (212) 533-2122 or www.graciouspace.com.

title: Dealing With Dictators
description: Saddam Hussein and Kim Jong Il have something in common: not the so-called axis of evil, but the fact that neither can take yes for an answer. Faced with an offer of United Nations inspectors rather than probable extinction, Saddam Hussein, even after the urging of Arab states, cannot say yes. And on the threshold of re-engagement with the United States, Kim Jong Il decided to have a gun battle with South Korea, ensuring that North Korea's progress with the outside world would pause if not halt.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Free Your Books

title: House Leaders Back President's Homeland Security Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  The Republican leaders of the House said today that they planned to give the Bush Administration most of what it asked for in a new Department of Homeland Security, restoring to the department most of the agencies that committees had voted to remove.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FEINSTEIN, HARRY
description: FEINSTEIN-Harry, 7/18/80. Dearest husband and father, you are with us always. Francine, Nina, Beth, David

title: Report Faults C.I.A.'s Recruitment Rules
description: The Central Intelligence Agency's failure to penetrate the leadership of Al Qaeda before Sept. 11 was due to a risk-averse culture that made the agency hesitant to aggressively recruit informers inside the terrorist network, leaders of a Congressional inquiry into the American intelligence community said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Profit Up At LVMH
description: The luxury group LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton said first-half operating profit rose 15 percent as it kept costs down. Sales grew 2 percent, to 5.82 billion euros ($5.89 billion), as consumers, wary of an economic slowdown and the threat of terrorist attacks, reined in spending. LVMH is forecasting a 15 percent rise in operating profit in the second half. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Kidnapping Thwarted
description: A woman who has been arrested five times on charges she tried to kidnap children, and who was imprisoned for more than a year on a 1997 kidnapping conviction, tried to take an 8-month-old baby from her mother in Brooklyn Heights, the police said yesterday. The woman, Tara Anne McDonald, 35, was charged with attempted kidnapping in the incident, which occurred just before 5 p.m. on Tuesday at Clinton and Montague Streets, the police said. Ms. McDonald, who gave the police an address in Daytona Beach, Fla., had been picked up by the police on July 4 and taken to Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center for psychiatric evaluation. But the hospital released her, the police said. Hospital officials said, however, that they had no record of her being brought there. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: A Wireless 911 System Finds Those in Need
description: AS an elderly couple drove through southwestern Illinois last fall, their car suddenly caught fire. They had no idea where they were, even what county they were in, said the local director of 911 services, Norm Forshee. Luckily, though, they were in St. Clair County, the first county in the nation to install an advanced cellphone-locator system for its emergency service. When the couple called 911, dispatchers pinpointed where they were, and help arrived a few minutes later.

title: Pataki Critics Are Kicked Out Of a Parade
description: A group of unemployed workers who distributed fliers critical of Gov. George E. Pataki were ejected from the Dominican Day Parade in the Bronx on Sunday, after the governor's re-election campaign questioned the workers' presence.

title: Top AOL Executive Resigns in Management Shake-Up
description: Robert W. Pittman resigned today as chief operating officer of AOL Time Warner Inc. after coming under pressure from company's executives and its board in the most public repudiation yet of the promises behind the merger between America Online and Time Warner .

title: A Meeting Of Worlds Earthly And Divine
description: The mythical Chinese folk tale of the thwarted but enduring love between the beautiful Goddess-Weaver, whose task it is to weave stars for the firmament from the enchanted Silver River, and a good-hearted cowherd has inspired depictions and retellings for some 4,000 years. The tale is so beguiling and resonant, it's easy to understand why the Shanghai-born composer Bright Sheng, a prominent American musician for the last 20 years, and the playwright David Henry Hwang, an American of Chinese descent, were drawn to the legend.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: COURT UPHOLDS BAN ON WATER SCOOTERS

title: Princeton University Is Sued Over Control of Foundation
description: The family that donated what has become a $550 million endowment fund for the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University yesterday filed suit, seeking to take the foundation away from the university.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: REPORTER'S KILLERS FILE APPEALS Three Pakistani men appealed the life sentences handed down against them this week for the kidnapping and killing of the American reporter Daniel Pearl, who disappeared from Karachi in January. The convicted men, Salman Saqib, Fahad Naseem and Shaikh Adil, face up to 25 years in prison. Lawyers for the fourth man convicted, Ahmed Omar Sheikh, who received the death penalty, said they would file an appeal later this week. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Peace Gains by the Catholics Embitter Ulster Protestants
description: Paving stones and gasoline bombs were raining in on a working-class Protestant neighborhood over the high wall separating it from a Catholic enclave. A roof caught fire, boarded-up windows clattered and shook from direct hits, and two residents, Raymond and Patsy Laverty, talked about how the Northern Ireland peace movement they once supported had sold out their people.

title: From Mail Order and a Web Site To Up-to-Date Studio Stores
description: Design Within Reach, the mail-order and Web site source for affordable Modern classic and contemporary furniture (www.dwr.com), is opening brick-and-mortar ''studios'' in California. A new 2,500-square-foot space, below, is in Oakland at the company's headquarters, formerly the Allied Paper Company building (283 Fourth Street; (510) 763-0712). Another studio will open next month in Santa Monica (at 332A Santa Monica Boulevard) and four more are planned this year to join the roster of existing stores in Palo Alto and San Francisco.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Delay In Ruling On Espada
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday delayed until Wednesday a hearing to decide whether the Democratic Party here can remove State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. from its rolls. But that delay didn't prevent the senator and lawyers for the party from making their cases. Before the hearing, Mr. Espada held a rally with about 75 supporters on the steps of the Bronx County Courthouse, saying that the party's move to oust him was a ''voting rights violation.'' Lawyers for the party contended that because Mr. Espada announced in February his intention to become a Republican, he should not be allowed to run as a Democrat. Jonathan P. Hicks (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Names Financial Officer
description: The second-biggest maker of telephone equipment in North America, Nortel Networks, has appointed Douglas C. Beatty, 47, as its new chief financial officer. Mr. Beatty, a Nortel insider who is not well known in the financial community, will have his work cut out for him as the once-high-flying telecommunications equipment supplier struggles with slowing demand, a big debt load and fading investor confidence. Mr. Beatty takes over from Frank Dunn, Nortel's chief executive, who has held the jobs of both chief financial officer and chief executive since February. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Strike Shuts Down Government Services Across Britain
description: Hundreds of thousands of local government workers went on strike across much of Britain today, shutting down schools, leaving garbage uncollected and closing libraries, museums and recreation centers in a bitter dispute over pay.

title: PAIR OF BOMBERS STRIKE IN TEL AVIV, KILLING 3 IN STREET
description: Two Palestinian suicide bombers killed three people here tonight, a day after a West Bank bus ambush that took eight Israeli lives. The attacks have shattered a period of calm that began nearly a month ago when Israeli troops took over the West Bank.

title: Hal Simms; Announcer, 83
description: Hal Simms, for decades one of the most frequently heard announcers on CBS television, died on July 2 in a nursing home in Brookline, Mass., his family said. He was 83.

title: Disabled Man Sues Club Over Privacy Of Lap Dance
description: A man who uses a wheelchair has sued a strip club in West Palm Beach, Fla., because an area where private lap dances are performed is up a flight of stairs.

title: Using Corn-Based Plastic, A Laptop Starts to Go Green
description: Finally, an affordable solution to the landfill problem: Fujitsu and Sony have figured out how to use biodegradable plastics in their high-tech gear. This fall Sony will reintroduce that classic from the 1980's, the Walkman tape player, with 90 percent of its casing made from vegetable-based plastic. Fujitsu plans to use the same plastic in the shell of its Biblo laptop computers starting in 2004.

title: Mixed Signals on AIDS
description: The 14th annual AIDS conference, held last week in Barcelona, Spain, was notable mainly for its disturbing dual message, offering hope for AIDS patients in nations able to afford expensive new drugs and despair for victims elsewhere. Of those afflicted with the AIDS virus, 95 percent live in countries where the new therapies discussed are unavailable. Today these people are found mainly in Africa, but this will change; research presented at the conference indicates that Asia and the former Communist bloc may also become overwhelmed by the disease and its attendant hunger and chaos. Bridging the gap between rich and poor AIDS sufferers is imperative.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Prescription Survey
description: County Executive Andrew J. Spano said yesterday that a government-sponsored survey showed wide price swings for commonly prescribed medicines. In a pharmacy in Jefferson Valley, for example, the cholesterol-lowering drug Lipitor cost $276.50 for 90 tablets of 10 milligrams each, but at a Kmart pharmacy in Greenburgh, the same prescription cost $173.99, or more than a third less. In June the county's Department of Consumer Protection surveyed the price of 25 prescription drugs at 40 pharmacies, using lists posted in the pharmacies. The results are posted at www.westchestergov .com/consumer. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOVNANIAN, ALTON
description: HOVNANIAN - Alton. The Board of Trustees and The Women's Committee of The Central Park Conservancy express their profound condolences and sympathy to Rachel and Ara Hovnanian on the tragic loss of their son, Alton. Our thoughts and prayers are with the family. Ian Smith, Chairman Regina Peruggi, President Suzanne Cochran, President, Women's Committee

title: Coke Says Profit Rose 15% Despite Weak Markets Abroad
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings increased 15 percent despite weak economic conditions in several of its international markets. It attributed the increase primarily to product innovation and strong sales in North America and Asia.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BURGER KING CORP., the world's second largest restaurant chain and a unit of Diageo, London, said it had bought 20 restaurants in Norfolk, Va., from Cimm's Inc., a privately held owner of restaurants. Burger King now has 598 restaurants. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Brief Power Failure
description: More than 1,000 customers of Public Service Electric and Gas in the Trenton area lost power when a power line fell on two lower lines yesterday morning. There was no immediate explanation for what caused the line to fall at about 10 a.m. The operations of one business customer, the Trenton Water Works, were disrupted and the Department of Environmental Protection asked Water Works customers to conserve water, even though water remained available throughout the day. Power was restored early in the afternoon.

title: In Backyards, Starry Appeal
description: THERE is more to amateur astronomy than squinting through a thick lens at shimmery pinpricks on the far side of time.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 8 about Israelis who are wounded in bomb attacks misstated the specialty of Dr. Ricardo Segal of Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem, who discussed the varying degrees of rehabilitation. He is a neurosurgeon, not a neurologist.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Court Upholds Ban On Water Scooters
description: A state appeals court in San Francisco ruled that Marin County officials may ban motorized water scooters like Jet Skis, reversing a lower court decision which held that the county ordinance was unconstitutionally vague. The lower court ruled two years ago that the ordinance did not give users enough guidance about where the ban applied. Conceding that ''Marin's shoreline is a checkerboard of jurisdictions,'' the appeals court said the ordinance ''is not so resistant to comprehension that it runs afoul of due process.'' Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Reprieve For American Reporter
description: A judge ruled that Andrew Meldrum, the American journalist who was ordered out of the country this week, may remain while he appeals to the Supreme Court. Mr. Meldrum, a permanent resident of Zimbabwe who writes for the British newspaper The Guardian and was accused by prosecutors of publishing falsehoods, was acquitted of the charge on Monday. Moments later, officials told him he had 24 hours to leave the country. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: The Case Against Lindh
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Russia: An Accord On Poultry
description: Russia and the United States are within days of resolving a dispute over American poultry exports to Russia, said Mary B. Warlick, economic minister-counselor at the American Embassy in Moscow. Russia imposed a ban on American poultry in March, citing health concerns that American officials say are groundless. Russia later lifted the ban, but a new disruption in shipments looms as a required health certificate, set to expire on Aug. 1, has not been renewed. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: From a Crate of Potatoes, a Noteworthy Gift Emerges
description: A version of Kasimir Malevich's ''Black Square'' with a history so complex one Russian magazine dubbed it a Suprematist detective story -- was unveiled at St. Petersburg's State Hermitage Museum last month, bringing to a close a long saga in the history of the Russian avant-garde. It also opened a new chapter in the relationship to art of Russia's nouveau-riche oligarchs.

title: Diamond Visions: End of Baseball?
description: To the Editor:

title: Synthetic Bioterror
description: Nobody who studies viruses and their genomes seemed surprised last week when researchers announced that they had synthesized a polio virus by using publicly available genetic information and chemical sequences ordered by mail. Even so, the feat points to yet another avenue that sophisticated terrorists might take to threaten unprotected civilians. The danger should not be exaggerated -- it is not imminent -- but the fact that bio-weapons might eventually be synthesized from off-the-shelf chemicals suggests the need for additional safeguards against malicious use of biotechnology.

title: PricewaterhouseCoopers to Pay $5 Million to End S.E.C. Case
description: The accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers will pay $5 million to settle charges that it violated rules requiring auditors to remain independent of their clients, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: PARAGUAY: EMERGENCY LIFTED President Luis Gonzalez Macchi lifted the five-day state of emergency he decreed on Monday after violent protests against his government's economic policies left two people dead, dozens injured and more than a hundred under arrest. In a televised speech, Mr. Gonzalez Macchi rejected demands that he step down, saying he will hand over power only to an elected successor next year. He attributed what he called "a plan for destabilization" to an exiled general, Lino Oviedo, "and certain sectors of the political opposition" led by his own vice president, Julio Cesar Franco. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: San Salvador Atenco Journal; Cornfields or Runways? Zapata's Ghost Watches
description: Peasant farmers fighting the construction of a multibillion-dollar airport might seem a wildly lopsided struggle. But here the little guys have the power of history on their side.

title: Father Charged With Murder of 2-Month-Old Girl
description: A Brooklyn man was charged with murder yesterday in the death of his 2-month-old daughter, who was found dead in her crib on Monday night with a fractured skull and three broken ribs.

description: WHAT'S your age? Your salary?

Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street, Friday, July 19, 2-5 and 7-9PM, with service Saturday, July 20, at 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell.

title: Historic Spring Gets Lift But Tourists Don't Notice
description: The Pipe Spring National Monument is part oasis and part mirage.

title: Prospect Is Far Away From Home
description: Most minor leaguers have fans in their hometowns who follow their progress through the professional ranks, but JUSTIN HUBER, a top catching prospect in the Mets' organization, merely has a lot of confused friends back home in Melbourne, Australia.

title: Three-Way Tie at British Open
description: GULLANE, Scotland, July 18 - Through one round, the British Open had an unpredictable feel, the type of tournament that could unfold in 100 different ways.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTZ, LEAH, NEE SCHLOSS

title: Senate Panel Backs Bill to Improve Defense in Capital Cases
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  The Senate Judiciary Committee today endorsed a bill meant to raise the standards of defense lawyers and make DNA testing more available in capital punishment cases, thereby minimizing the chances of innocent people being put to death.

title: Limiting Possibilities Downtown
description: WITH the curtain up on six remarkably similar concepts for the World Trade Center superblock, it has become graphically evident that the planning of its future rests on one day in its past: April 26, 2001.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Police Have Gun From Terror Attacks
description: The police said they had found the second of two guns used by the November 17 terror group in a string of high-profile assassinations, including that of a British military attach two years ago in Athens. The .45-caliber Colt pistol was found in a weapons den raided recently by the police after a botched bombing attempt by a member of the group. The police also said they were holding three people suspected of links to the group, which is responsible for at least 23 killings since the 1975 assassination of the C.I.A. station chief in Athens, Richard Welch. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: North Koreans in China Now Live in Fear of Dragnet
description: Since March, four North Korean teenage girls have not left the back room of Mr. Piao's low brick hovel here, for fear they will be caught and deported. They eat, sleep and pass long boring days crouched on an orange linoleum floor. The only visible sliver of the outside world is a crude ladder outside the back door.

title: Mayor Hints City May Cut M.T.A. Funds
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg tried to brace New Yorkers yesterday for a new round of mid-year budget cuts and raised the possibility for the first time that the city might scale back its subsidies to the mass transit system.

title: The Easter Bunny Lives: Treats in Your Software
description: Q. How can I find out whether any Easter eggs are hidden in my software?

title: Teenage Drug Use at an 8-Year Low
description: Drug use among high school and junior high school students has dropped to its lowest level in eight years despite fears that drugs and alcohol use would rise to deal with added stress after the Sept. 11 attacks, drug policy officials said today.

title: More Cafes May Sprout on Sidewalks
description: The sidewalk cafe -- that seasonal fixture suggesting summer in the city, leisurely lunches, Paris on the Hudson -- could become even more visible in New York's streetscape under a Bloomberg administration plan.

description: RULNICK-Hyman. July 18, 1993. In our thoughts. Miss you. Your loving daughter, Joyc

title: A Chair Made of Steel With a Waterfall in Its Past
description: Dani Stoller, a Swiss prototype machinist, and Roz Hayes, who studied engineering, formed Lush Life (www.lushlifedesign.com) in 1998 to make custom furniture. Valentine, above, is a steel-framed chair of polyurethane foam on a chrome-plated steel base. Mr. Stoller said it was inspired by an image of a narrowing waterfall. It is $2,800 at Art and Industrial Design, 399 Lafayette Street (East Fourth Street), New York, (212) 477-0116; and at Twentieth, 8057 Beverly Boulevard, Los Angeles, (323) 904-1200.

title: China Cracks Down On Korean Refugees
description: More than 60 North Koreans have gained political asylum in South Korea this year by storming China's foreign embassies, prompting Beijing to tighten the border.

title: Chat, Record, Play: A Colorful Handset Redefines Multitasking
description: For customers who are not satisfied with a bright faceplate or colorful flip cover on their wireless phones, Nextel has introduced a model with a color screen. Manufactured by Motorola, the i95cl is a flip phone modeled after a predecessor, the i90c, with the added attraction of a 1.9-inch liquid crystal display screen.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: U.S. Orders Equipment From InVision
description: InVision Technologies said yesterday that the Transportation Security Administration had ordered 50 of its explosives-detection devices for installation in baggage-handling systems at major airports by the end of the year. The agency also ordered parts for 50 more of the devices and adjusted its previous order for free-standing InVision equipment that inspects carry-on luggage to include more large-capacity models in the mix. InVision said the new and amended orders were valued at $106.8 million. Barnaby Feder (NYT)

title: Spanish Armada Takes Isle, Ejecting Morocco Force of 6
description: Spanish special forces backed by helicopters and warships stormed the disputed islet of Perejil at dawn today, taking prisoner its six occupying Moroccan soldiers in a bloodless operation to restore Spanish rule.

title: 4 Hurt as Van Mounts Brooklyn Sidewalk
description: Aminivan swerved to avoid another van around noon yesterday and skidded onto the sidewalk along a busy stretch of Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, striking four people, including a 6-year-old girl and a 10-year-old boy whose leg was severed, the police said.

title: The True and Only Slam
description: Anyone not obsessed by golf, its traditions and its statistical rituals might wonder why so much is being made of Tiger Woods's quest for the Holy Grail of professional golf, a k a the Grand Slam. Woods resumes the hunt today when he and the rest of the world's best golfers tee off at the British Open at Muirfield in Scotland. After all, as Woods himself notes, he has not only won all four of the tournaments that make up the modern Grand Slam but has won them all in a row -- the United States Open, the British Open and the P.G.A. in 2000, followed by the Masters in 2001. Isn't that enough? It is for Woods, who said last week when somebody asked him whether he could win the slam, ''It's certainly doable, because I've done it.''

title: Posada Foils Tigers, Making Pettitte a Winner
description: As Mark Redman bounded for the mound before the bottom of the ninth inning last night, a new feature appeared on the Yankee Stadium scoreboard. Instead of the usual clip of John Belushi rallying the boys in ''Animal House,'' a fan in the bleachers did his own Belushi routine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, GHITY
description: STERN-Ghity. The Board and staff of the Wildlife Conservation Society extend their deepest sympathies to Allison and Leonard Stern and their family on the passing of Ghity Stern. David T. Schiff, Chairman Steven E. Sanderson, President and CEO

title: With Help of Teammates, Armstrong Takes Lead in Tour
description: LA MONGIE, France, July 18  With a huge assist from his team, Lance Armstrong settled most questions today about his form in the Tour de France as he won the first mountain stage and gained the yellow jersey of the race's overall leader.

title: Attention Is Lavished on Every Detail for State Dinner for Polish Leader
description: The White House pulled out all the stops to make sure that the president of Poland, one of the strongest European allies in President Bush's war on terror, felt right at home at the state dinner in his honor tonight. Well, almost all the stops.

title: I.B.M. Beats Forecasts but With Signs of Weakness
description: I.B.M. reported declining revenue and profit in the second quarter yesterday but fared better on both scores than Wall Street had expected.

title: Albany Chosen as Research Hub For the Next Generation of Chips
description: The world's largest computer chip makers plan to build a major center for research and development on the next generation of chips here, at the State University of New York, a plan that state officials hope will bring thousands of jobs to the Hudson Valley.

title: Catskill Old or Catskill New?
description: PRESERVATIONISTS here are feeling desperate, as county officials make final plans to demolish a group of antique Main Street buildings and replace them with a $15 million county office building and more than 500 parking spaces.

title: New Allegations Lead to Ouster of German Defense Minister
description: BERLIN, July 18  The German chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, an underdog for reelection in September, fired his defense minister today following allegations of financial improprities.

title: Nowhere to Go
description: In the 1940's there were more than 1,500 public restrooms in New York's subway and train stations, and they were inspected weekly. Today there are fewer than 100.

title: Producing Rooms With Plot Twists
description: IN an East Village apartment, John Lindell was talking about the ''social sculpture'' he had made, and it was a piece of work to figure out just what he meant. There were silver lines on the floor, a square of yellow canvas on one wall, and what appeared to be a red-enameled monolith anchoring a couch.

title: Corus to Buy Steel Maker In Brazil for $2.1 Billion
description: The Corus Group, the British-Dutch steel-making giant, said today that it had agreed to acquire Companhia Siderurgica Nacional of Brazil, one of Latin America's leading steel producers, for $2.1 billion in stock. Corus will also assume $2.1 billion in C.S.N.'s debts.

description: Falstaff Alfresco

title: New Citizen Is Accused of Plot To Smuggle $650,000 to Egypt
description: A recently naturalized United States citizen who was born in Egypt was arrested today and held on charges of plotting to smuggle more than $650,000 to Egypt in violation of currency reporting requirements.

title: Call in Congress For Full Airing Of Iraq Policy
description: Concerned that the United States is rushing headlong toward a full-scale military confrontation with Iraq, many Congressional Democrats and a growing number of Republicans are urging the Bush administration to provide a public accounting of its plans.

title: In Midst of a PC Slump, Apple Still Aims for Growth
description: For Apple Computer, a product innovator with an anemic market share, a prosperous future depends on persuading some of the legions of people who use personal computers running the Microsoft Windows operating system to switch to Apple's Macintosh technology.

title: Sheriff Issues Alert After California Girl Is Found Killed
description: Confirming the worst fears about the latest widely publicized child abduction case and warning of an assailant who was likely to strike again, possibly within 24 hours, the authorities said today that the body of a child discovered on Tuesday afternoon beside a rural California highway was the 5-year-old girl who was snatched kicking and screaming on Monday.

title: Polymath Selects Polymath to Direct Bard Arts Center
description: Jonathan Levi, 46, an arts educator, editor and writer, today was named director of the new $62 million Bard Performing Arts Center, designed by Frank O. Gehry as a kind of Bilbao on the Hudson. The center is to be completed in January and open in April as a home for music, theater and dance. The building's two theaters will be used both for academic purposes and as a public space for international cultural events.

Mass 11 AM at St. Benedict's Church. If desired, memorials may be made to Father Baker's Home, 780 Ridge Road, Lackawanna, N.Y 14218.

title: Watercolors and Flowers, Both by His Hand
description: ON summer afternoons, Manabu Saito can be found outdoors under a wide-brimmed hat, focusing intently on painting a single plant. He often sits with an open box of watercolors by his side. His lap is his easel, his garden is his studio.

title: F. J. Thompson, 69, Longtime P.O.W., Dies
description: Col. Floyd J. Thompson, who for almost nine years endured cold cells, jungle cages and torture in Vietnam, becoming the longest-serving American prisoner of war in any conflict, died on Tuesday at his home in Key West, Fla. He was 69.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESTRIN, ABE
description: ESTRIN-Abe. July 14, 2002, at the age of 93, in Richmond, Virginia, his home since 1958. Formerly of Brooklyn, New York. Predeceased by his beloved wife of 60 years, Clara. Adored father of Mark and daughter-in-law Barbara, of Providence, RI; and Rosalie (Arthur) Matz, of Baltimore, MD. Cherished grandfather of Robin Estrin and her husband Seamus Kelly. Loving grandfather of Sharon and Ann Matz. Proud greatgrandfather of Margot Clara Kelly. Devoted brother of Edith Dorfman and Gertrude Geller. Admired uncle. title: New Arrest in Spain
description: The Spanish police yesterday arrested a fourth Syrian they called part of a Qaeda cell, less than 24 hours after arresting three men accused of working with Osama bin Laden's terrorism network.

title: MIDWAY AIRLINES TO OPERATE AS AFFILIATE OF US AIRWAYS
description: The Midway Airlines Corporation, which filed for bankruptcy in August 2001 and suspended most of its operations after Sept. 11, agreed last night to become an affiliate of the US Airways Group. US Airways said that Midway, based in Raleigh, N.C., would operate as US Airways Express, flying a regional jet fleet starting in October. The eight-year agreement is subject to conditions, including Midway's securing $5 million in additional capital, acquiring more planes and reaching agreements with unions. The agreement requires that 50 percent of the pilot positions be reserved for furloughed US Airways pilots.

title: With Upgrade To Software, MSN May Nip At AOL's Heels
description: Microsoft, which has yet to find a formula to compete profitably with America Online in the Internet market, is preparing to roll out this fall a new version of its Internet access software that is meant to exploit the perceived weakness of its rival's parent, AOL Time Warner.

title: Yankees Tell Dolan Hard Work Is the Key
description: George Steinbrenner fired back yesterday at Larry Dolan, the owner of the Cleveland Indians, with a nearly 300-word statement asserting that hard work, not inherent advantages under baseball's current economic climate, had made the Yankees so successful.

title: Market Place; Results were solid at Citigroup and J. P. Morgan, but they're not switching off the yellow light, yet.
description: CITIGROUP and J. P. Morgan Chase reported increased profits for the second quarter yesterday, with strength in consumer banking and credit cards compensating for continued weakness in investment banking.

title: World Business Briefing: Global Trade
description: RUSSIA: AN ACCORD ON POULTRY Russia and the United States are within days of resolving a dispute over American poultry exports to Russia, said Mary B. Warlick, economic minister-counselor at the American embassy in Moscow. Russia imposed a ban on American poultry in March, citing health concerns that American officials say are groundless. Russia later lifted the ban, but a new disruption in shipments looms as a required health certificate, set to expire on Aug. 1, has not been renewed. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Signs Of Economic Upturn
description: The Bank of Japan said the country's economy, the second largest in the world, ''has almost stabilized'' because of growing exports and improving corporate profits. The bank, however, stopped short of calling an official end to the nearly two-year-old recession because capital and consumer spending, which make up about 70 percent of the economy, remain weak. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: An Industrial City's Architectural Rebirth; New Museums Brighten Manchester
description: For the better part of a century, this city was the industrial and commercial engine of Britain's imperial might, a place as proud as it was powerful. Then came the bombing of World War II, the loss of colonial markets, the closing of the cotton mills and a prolonged slide into economic depression. The final blow was struck on June 15, 1996, when an I.R.A. bomb flattened a large area of downtown Manchester.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENEDEK, LEONORE, NEE FRIEDMAN
description: BENEDEK - Leonore, nee Friedman. Beloved wife of the late Martin Benedek. Devoted mother of Richard and Barry Benedek and cherished grandmother of Jessica, Melissa, Michael, Elizabeth, Stephen and Joshua. Died at peace at the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale. There will be private services for the family today. Shiva will be held at the home of Richard and Laura Benedek and at the home of Ellen and Barry Benedek this evening. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Multiple Sclerosis Society.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bike Sales Seen Rising
description: Kawasaki Heavy Industries said yesterday that it expected its motorcycle sales to jump as much as 20 percent this year because of a new model lineup. Kawasaki, Japan's fourth-largest motorcycle manufacturer, said the additional models would increase sales by nearly one-fifth, to 180 billion yen ($1.55 billion). Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Women Take Over More Oil Sites
description: Four oil pumping stations belonging to Chevron in the Niger Delta have been taken over by women demanding jobs and investments in their communities, according to the police. The seizures came after another Chevron oil station was seized by several hundred women, who have agreed to leave in exchange for promises of jobs and investment, the company said. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Ken Weaver, whose only son died in a wildfire last year and who is promoting legislation to let an outside agency investigate the Forest Service after fire deaths, misspelled the name of the city where he has a floral business. It is Moxee, Wash., not Moxie.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Robert M. Greenberg, chairman and chief creative officer at R/GA, New York, was named president of the board of the Art Directors Club, succeeding Richard Wilde, chairman of the advertising and graphic design departments at the School of Visual Arts, New York. R/GA is part of the FCB Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

description: To the Editor:

title: House Conservatives Budge on Arts Spending
description: After a brief rebellion by conservative Republicans, the House today approved a $19.8 billion spending measure for public lands and cultural programs after increasing spending for a once-divisive arts programs. The final vote was 377 to 46.

title: New Yorker Gets the Assignment: Revamp a Natural History Museum
description: The Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County is joining the museum building craze: it has selected the New York architect Steven Holl to remodel its home at Exposition Park in Los Angeles. Mr. Holl, below, was chosen from a group that included Norman Foster of London and Herzog & de Meuron of Switzerland. The project is expected to cost $200 million to $300 million. The existing 410,000- square-foot mishmash of buildings will be reconfigured into a blend of old and new, preserving the original 1913 Beaux Arts building, left. Four wood-paneled exhibition halls with dioramas painted in the 1920's may not be kept. Mr. Holl, who designed the Kiasma Museum of Contemporary Art in Helsinki, wants the design to express a relationship with nature. Elements might include a 60-foot screen that would show images of events like tsunamis. Jane Pisano, director of the Natural History Museum, said the remodeling would broaden the appeal of the museum, which has a substantial collection but is visited mostly by schoolchildren. She expects to raise the money and begin construction in 2006.

title: VIVENDI CHOOSES A CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER
description: Vivendi Universal appointed Jacques Espinasse, a satellite television executive, as chief financial officer in the second shuffling of a top executive at the company in recent weeks. Mr. Espinasse will replace Guillaume Hannezo, a close ally of Jean-Marie Messier, the company's former chief executive, who resigned last month amid mounting criticism of his management. Mr. Hannezo will spend the next six months advising Vivendi's new chief executive, Jean-Ren Fourtou, to help smooth the transition, the company said. Since 1999, Mr. Espinasse has served as chief financial officer of TPS, a French satellite television channel. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: LeMond Says Armstrong Will Probably Win Again
description: Greg LeMond and Lance Armstrong are the only Americans to have won the Tour de France, and each has done it three times. Armstrong is in France trying for his fourth straight triumph there, and LeMond thinks he will succeed, but maybe not easily.

title: Senate Panel Backs Bill to Improve Defense in Capital Cases
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  The Senate Judiciary Committee today endorsed a bill meant to raise the standards of defense lawyers and make DNA testing more available in capital punishment cases, thereby minimizing the chances of innocent people being put to death.

title: W.T.O. Says U.S. Tariff Law Violates Rules
description: The World Trade Organization said today that the United States was violating trade rules with a law that has allowed the government to turn over almost $500 million in import duties to companies like U.S. Steel and Hershey Foods.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Dutch Chip Maker Predicts Sales Increase
description: Europe's biggest maker of semiconductor equipment, ASML Holding, predicted yesterday that sales would rebound in the second half as the chip industry begins to recover from its worst-ever slump. ''After five quarters of dismal news we can say that the market has turned,'' the chief executive, Douglas J. Dunn, said. ASML's backlog of orders at the end of the first half was 35 percent higher than at the end of 2001. In the first half, ASML said it lost 98 million euros ($99.17 million), or 21 cents a share, compared with a loss of 96 million euros, or 20 cents, a year earlier. Sales fell a more-than-expected 19 percent, to 823 million euros.

title: Making Theater Accessible to People With Trouble Hearing
description: It was 2:10 on a Wednesday afternoon, and the lights had gone down at the Palace Theater for the first act of ''Aida.'' In a museum of Egyptian antiquities, a statue of Amneris, daughter of the pharaoh, was announcing in song ''the story of a love that flourished in a time of hate.'' To the right of the stage, just beyond the proscenium, on a black screen 14 inches high and a little more than 4 feet long, Amneris's words were being displayed in three rows of bright red electronic letters.

title: Knicks' Rookie Guard To Have Wrist Surgery
description: Frank Williams, a first-round draft pick who was expected to challenge for the Knicks' starting point guard job, broke a bone in his left wrist Tuesday and will have surgery Thursday to repair it.

title: New Yorkers Accurately Bid and Play Teams Hands
description: Once each decade for the last half century, the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals have been played in Washington. Nine years ago the table count was 18,270, still a record for the East Coast. That number may be exceeded in the next 10 days, with an abundance of events, ranging from the Spingold Knockout Teams, lasting a week, to one-session games for beginners.

title: Joystick Shooters Take Aim at Big Money Prizes
description: Thousands of hard-core gamers will converge on the Hyatt Regency hotel in Dallas on Saturday to match their rec-room joystick skills with those of like-minded fanatics. The Cyberathlete Professional League expects 3,500 players from 70 countries to compete in the first C.P.L. Pentium 4 Processor Summer Championship. The five-day event will pit some of the world's best gamers against one another in a single game called Counter-Strike, and they won't be playing for pizza and soda. With more than $100,000 in prize money to be doled out, the C.P.L. Pentium 4 championship is the United States Open of gaming tournaments.
