Ellis, Chicago, IL 60637; or West Point Fund, United States Military Academy, West Point, New York 10996.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Symantec Will Acquire 3 Security Concerns
description: Symantec, a computer security company best known for antivirus products, announced yesterday that it would acquire three security companies to beef up its business offerings. It will purchase Riptech, which manages computer security for companies, for $145 million in cash, and Recourse Technologies, which provides high-speed detection of computer intrusion, for $135 million in cash. Symantec said it would pay $75 million for SecurityFocus, a company that sells network protection software and operates the popular Web site SecurityFocus.com. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Jumping Ship (or Not); In a Rare Limited Offer, AT&T Waives Its Cancellation Fee
description: TUCKED into every AT&T Wireless subscriber's latest bill was a notice announcing two rate increases. In the fine print was an unusual exit clause: because of the changes, customers have until the end of July to drop their phone plans without paying the customary cancellation fee.

title: Confession to A.A. Members Is Not Protected, Appeals Court Rules
description: A federal appeals court panel ruled yesterday that a man's confession to members of his Alcoholics Anonymous group that he killed a married couple in Westchester in 1988 is not protected by that group's quasi-religious status.

title: Jewish Settlers Accused of Selling Bullets to Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM, July 18  Five Jewish settlers, four of them soldiers, and a reserve army officer have been arrested on suspicion of selling thousands of rounds of stolen military ammunition to Palestinians, the police said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Child Reports Sex Abuse
description: A man was arrested and charged with sexual abuse yesterday after a 7-year-old girl reported she had been attacked inside St. Thomas Roman Catholic Church on Amboy Road, the police said. The girl said she was using the restroom about 5:30 p.m. on Tuesday when the man sexually abused her, the police said. The Rev. Gil Suaybaguio of St. Thomas said the church is open for prayer at that time, and the girl was in the church with her mother. The girl reported the abuse to her mother, he said. The police identified the suspect as Maximiliano Gonzalez, 26, of Targee Street. Father Suaybaguio said he did not know why the suspect was in the church. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Chief of S.E.C. Is Set to Pursue Former Clients
description: Harvey L. Pitt, the embattled head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that with the expiration of ethics restrictions that have bound him during his first year in office, he would play a direct role in enforcement cases involving companies and accounting firms that were once his law clients.

title: Test for Aptitude, Not for Speed
description: Changes in educational policy invariably evoke strong and contrary reactions. The College Board's announcement this week that it will no longer tell colleges and universities which students have been given extra time to complete the SAT is no exception. Some see this decision, which came as a result of a legal settlement with a student who had a physical disability, as fair and overdue. Others see it as unfairly handicapping those students who do not request or receive such accommodations and say it will deprive admissions officers of pertinent information.

title: Turkey Says Debt Negotiations Aren't Linked to Stand on Iraq
description: Turkey wants the United States to write off more than $4 billion in debt, but government officials said today that they were not naming a price for their support of military action to topple President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

title: Knicks' Rookie Guard to Have Surgery
description: BOSTON, July 17  Frank Williams, a first-round draft pick who was expected to challenge for the Knicks' starting point guard job, broke a bone in his left wrist Tuesday and will have surgery Thursday to repair it.

title: Plastic Gold: Recyclers Find Profit in Printer Ink Cartridges
description: AN increasing number of schools and nonprofit groups are collecting empty ink cartridges from computer printers for recycling. But the trend is being driven by more than environmental friendliness. There is a surprising amount of money in those hunks of plastic, some of which ends up paying for things like school computers and famine relief.

title: Britain Plans Criminal Justice Changes to Favor the Victims
description: Britain announced sweeping changes today in its criminal justice system, scrapping the ancient double-jeopardy rule that prevents people from being tried twice for the same crime, making hearsay evidence admissible in court and letting jurors know of suspects' previous crimes.

title: State Dinner From Bass to Cookies
description: The menu for the state dinner last night in honor of Aleksander Kwasniewski, the president of the Republic of Poland, as provided by the White House:

title: Factory Dispute Tests China's Loyalty to Workers Rights
description: As many as 2,000 former workers from a closed brick and tile factory in the Chinese province of Inner Mongolia have clashed with the police, and hundreds are occupying the factory, demanding pension benefits.

title: People
description: * Brian Brooker, president and chief creative officer at Barkley Evergreen & Partners Advertising, Kansas City, Mo., part of Barkley Evergeen & Partners, was named to the added post of chief executive at the parent, succeeding Scott Aylward, who continues as chairman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, RICHARD M.
description: WASSERMAN-Richard M. Of Livingston, NJ on Tuesday, July 16, 2002. Beloved husband of Marjorie; devoted father of Mark, Barry and Jill; loving father-in-law of Nancy and Stacey; cherished son of Rita and the late Irving; dear brother of David; adoring grandfather of Samuel, Melissa, Taylor, Andrew and the late Jessica. Funeral from the Bernheim - Apter - Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, New Jersey, Thursday, July 18 at 11 A.M. Contributions may be made to the St. Barnabas Medical Center Foundation-Cancer Center.

title: AT&T Says Its President Will Take Over Top Spot
description: AT&T announced yesterday that David W. Dorman, its president, would succeed C. Michael Armstrong as chairman and chief executive beginning next year.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Accounting Questions At Sony
description: Shares in Sony, Japan's largest consumer electronics maker, hit their lowest point in a year, falling 4.1 percent on talk that the company had engaged in questionable accounting practices. Sony denied the accusations, but only after The South China Morning Post of Hong Kong quoted Howard Schilit, a former accounting professor who testified to Congress in the Enron scandal, as saying Sony had potential problems. Mr. Schilit said Sony's sales to its affiliates rose 133 percent last fiscal year, suggesting that the company inflated revenue. Sony said the jump in sales came after it formed a venture with Ericsson of Sweden in 2001. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Bomb Kills 3 In Kashmir
description: Three members of a pro-Indian militia were killed in Kashmir when a bomb exploded in their barracks. Nine others were wounded. The Indian police blamed Islamic militants. The blast followed an attack Saturday night on a camp of Hindu laborers that left 29 dead and that has once again ratcheted up tensions between India and Pakistan, which both claim Kashmir. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This will inevitably sound self-serving, but the fact is it is an enormous advantage to the public to have somebody who knows about the securities business and the securities law as I do, and it would be unthinkable to deprive people of my expertise.''

title: 'Six Feet Under' Leads Emmy Nominations
description: LOS ANGELES, July 18 — "Six Feet Under," the darkly comic series on HBO about a troubled family running a funeral business, earned a leading 23 Emmy nominations today, a signal once again of the creative strength of cable over the networks. The 54th annual Emmy Awards will be shown on NBC on Sept. 22.

title: Poll Finds Concerns That Bush Is Overly Influenced by Business
description: Americans worry that President Bush and his administration are too heavily influenced by big business, fear that Mr. Bush is hiding something about his own corporate past and judge the economy to be in its worst shape since 1994, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Archival Discs Turn Your Living Room Into Mission Control
description: When HBO broadcast ''From the Earth to the Moon,'' its miniseries about the Apollo program, some critics and viewers thought it was too long. For true space aficionados, however, even a 12-hour series was nowhere near long enough. For these fans, a small company in Charlotte, N.C., has the answer: hours and hours of archival films and television transmissions from Apollo missions, digitally transferred from NASA's originals and assembled on sets of DVD's.

title: Williams's Children Seek Court's Help
description: A lawyer for two of Ted Williams's children asked a court in two filings today to help resolve the question of whether Williams's remains should be cremated or cryonically preserved.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: 5th Season, 2 Pregnancies

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSEN, MICHAEL
description: ROSEN-Michael. July 18, 1980. A special man. Lovingly remembered always. Your family

title: Bush Picks Safety Board Chief to Lead F.A.A.
description: President Bush announced today that he intended to nominate Marion C. Blakey, the chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board, to run the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the sentencing of Marjorie Knoller for involuntary manslaughter resulting from her dogs' mauling of her neighbor Diane Whipple, misstated the year of the attack. It was 2001, not 2000.

title: Compromise Is Urged on Coast Guard Role
description: A veteran House committee chairman indicated a willingness today to consider a compromise that would allow the Coast Guard to be moved to the proposed Department of Homeland Security.

title: Social Security Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BRONX: DELAY IN RULING ON ESPADA

title: Still Thinking Outside the Box
description: BECAUSE the world is three-dimensional, there are those who believe that every representation of it should be in 3-D as well. Entrepreneurs and enthusiasts have long tried to convince the public that 3-D photographs, films and television shows are the next best thing to being there.

title: Olympic Site Committee Denies New York Is Out of the Running
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the United States Olympic Committee denied reports yesterday that New York City was losing out in the bidding to serve as host of the 2012 Summer Olympics.

title: Europeans Are About to See A New Kind of Car Dealership
description: Car buyers in the European Union may soon be able to compare vehicles made by different carmakers in the same dealer's showroom and have them serviced in the same dealer's repair shop, after the adoption of new regulations on auto distribution today by the European Commission, the union's executive body.

title: In a Shift, Republicans Pledge to Pass Accounting Bill
description: In an abrupt about-face, Republicans in the House pledged today to reach final agreement by next week with the Senate on a sweeping overhaul of laws concerning accounting and corporate behavior.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on July 12 about Bill Clinton's efforts to fight AIDS while president misstated the year he refused to lift a ban on federal financing for clean needles to drug addicts. It was 1998, not 1988.

title: The Judge Who Put Asunder the Giulianis
description: NOW that the divorce of former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is settled, let us zoom in on Judith J. Gische, the judge who so often said ''No'' to the mayor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHESER, SOLOMON M.
description: CHESER-Solomon M. Age 93, beloved husband of Dolly. Loving father of Ana (Joel), & Nancy. Devoted grandfather of Sarah and Ruth. Funeral at I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, N.Y. on Friday, July 19 at 11 A.M.

title: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
description: WINE.COM RAISES $9 MILLION IN FINANCING Wine.com, formerly known as eVineyard, announced yesterday that it had raised $9 million in financing, with the option to raise another $1 million within 60 days, bringing the total raised to $39.8 million. Peter Ekman, a wine industry veteran who became chief executive of Wine.com in March, said the latest round of financing would be the last the company would need in order to become profitable.

title: After Roll Call, Baguette Class; Baking School Offers Job Skills in an Old Specialty
description: Give a man a loaf of bread, and he'll eat for a day. Teach a man to bake bread, in, say, a converted pajama factory in Queens, and his prospects will brighten considerably.

title: Scantily Clothed With Humorous Intent, Butoh Returns
description: Dairakudakan (which translates as the Great Camel Battleship) has not performed in New York City since 1987. Since then the Tokyo-based company, founded 30 years ago by Akaji Maro, has produced an impressive new generation of choreographers and performers whose work is being presented in a five-performance season that opened on Tuesday night at the Japan Society.

title: In Its New House, Apple Goes Bauhaus
description: CONSUMER products are the stars of the new Apple retail store in SoHo. The store's design is fairly bland compared with the suave styling that has won Apple's products legions of loyal fans over the years. But the shop's minimalist forms and neutral palette nonetheless go far toward establishing the claim that Apple's products are today's modern classics.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Rebuff To Providence Mayor
description: A judge refused to throw out a racketeering conspiracy conviction against Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr., left, of Providence. The judge, Ernest C. Torres of Federal District Court, ruled there was ''sufficient evidence'' for a jury to find that such a conspiracy existed in City Hall. Mr. Cianci, 61, faces up to 20 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. He said he would probably appeal the verdict, and planned to stay in office until he was sentenced on Sept. 6.

title: Think Small
description: Regional tours to France and Italy for groups of no more than 18 people (the average size is 8) are being discounted by $600 a couple by Great Travels, a Washington, D.C., tour operator. A nine-day Sicily tour Oct. 3 to 11 is $1,695 a person, double occupancy; the Bay of Naples Aug. 11 to 22 and Sept. 15 to 26 is $2,195 a person, double. Provence, the Riviera and Cinque Terre is $2,295 a person, double, Sept. 4 to 13. Other itineraries are available. Accommodations are in small hotels and pensiones, and transportation is by car or minivan. Rates include accommodations, all meals (except the Sicily tour), wine with meals, guide services, some admission fees, airport transfers and hotel taxes. Air fare is extra. Reservations must be made by Aug. 30; (800) 411-3728 or www.great-travels.com .

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: THE NETHERLANDS: WRITE-DOWN AT GROCER Ahold, the large Dutch food retailer, said a write-down related to a joint venture in Argentina would reduce 2002 earnings estimates by as much as two-thirds. The charge of 350 million euros to 450 million euros ($354.17 million to $455.36 million) in the second quarter would have the effect of reducing earnings growth to 5 percent to 8 percent, compared with the 15 percent growth originally predicted. Velox Retail Holdings, Ahold's partner, defaulted on its bank loans, activating an agreement that required Ahold to pay $490 million to cover those loans and buy Velox's stake, a South American supermarket chain known as Disco Ahold International Holdings. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Michael A. McCarthy, 68, Architect of Mosque on Upper East Side
description: Michael A. McCarthy, an architect who blended a cool sense of modernism with traditional Muslim forms to create New York's most significant new house of worship in recent decades, the Islamic Cultural Center mosque on the Upper East Side, was found dead in his Manhattan apartment Tuesday. He was 68.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: DUTCH CHIP MAKER PREDICTS SALES INCREASE Europe's biggest maker of semiconductor equipment, ASML Holding, predicted yesterday that sales would rebound in the second half as the chip industry begins to recover from its worst-ever slump. "After five quarters of dismal news we can say that the market has turned," the chief executive, Douglas J. Dunn, said. ASML's backlog of orders at the end of the first half was 35 percent higher than at the end of 2001. In the first half, ASML said it lost 98 million euros ($99.17 million), or 21 cents a share, compared with a loss of 96 million euros, or 20 cents, a year earlier. Sales fell a more-than-expected 19 percent, to 823 million euros.

title: Heartbreak Awaits on an Incline
description: In each of the last three years, Lance Armstrong took a giant step toward winning the Tour de France on the first day that riders reached the high mountains of the Pyrenees or the Alps. In the 2002 Tour, today is that day.

title: AUTO PARTS MAKER SETTLES DISABILITY DISCRIMINATION SUIT
description: The Visteon Corporation, a leading maker of auto parts, agreed to pay $415,000 to settle a disability discrimination lawsuit by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. The payment resolves E.E.O.C. claims that Visteon and its former parent, Ford Motor, refused to hire 11 job applicants based on pre-employment physical exams in violation of the Americans With Disabilities Act. The applicants had sought jobs at two Visteon plants in Michigan. Visteon was spun off from Ford in 2000. Visteon also agreed to spend $200,000 over the next five years to train employees on disability policies.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about Ralph Pucci, who represents furniture designers, misstated his age. He was not 7 in 1954; he was born that year.

title: Joseph Luns, 90, NATO Chief In Crucial Cold War Decades
description: Joseph Marie Antoine Hubert Luns, a former Dutch foreign minister and NATO secretary general, died yesterday, Dutch government officials said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the negative publicity surrounding ''Pluto Nash,'' a coming movie starring Eddie Murphy, misidentified the studio that is suffering from a string of poorly performing films like ''The Majestic'' and ''Murder by Numbers.'' It is Castle Rock, which is a producer of ''Pluto Nash''; Warner Brothers, a sister company, is releasing the movie.

title: INSIDE
description: Unfounded Fears on Plane

title: Editors' Note; Editors' Note
description: The White House Memo column on Monday, about the workings of President Bush's inner circle after the resignation of his adviser Karen P. Hughes, reported that Andrew H. Card Jr., the president's chief of staff, had considered leaving the White House but that Vice President Dick Cheney helped persuade him to stay. The article should have carried a response from the White House.

title: Working Class
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Wardrobe Between the Sexes
description: Masculine? Feminine? You decide. This fall, designers on both coasts of the Atlantic took up the subject of gender studies  starkly defining his-and-her looks for the woman who can't make up her mind.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Norwalk: Skakel Sentencing Won't Be Broadcast
description: A judge has denied a request by Court TV to broadcast the murder sentencing of Michael C. Skakel on Aug. 9. In a ruling on Tuesday, Judge John F. Kavanewsky Jr. denied the cable-television network's request. Michael Sherman, Mr. Skakel's lawyer, said he would not have objected to televising the trial or the sentencing. ''We've never asked that this case be tried in the dark,'' he said. Mr. Skakel, who was convicted of the 1975 murder of his neighbor Martha Moxley, faces a sentence of 10 years to life in prison.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint Units Report Earnings
description: Both the long-distance and wireless units of Sprint reported earnings yesterday. The main telephone unit of Sprint reported quarterly earnings of $103 million, or 12 cents a share, compared with $291 million, or 33 cents, a year earlier. Revenues of $3.9 billion were 8 percent below last year and slightly below Wall Street's expectations. Sprint PCS, the wireless business of the telecommunications company Sprint, reported a net loss of $173 million, or 17 cents a share. Shares jumped as investors approved of the company's holding to its previous growth outlook. Shares of Sprint FON, Sprint's main long-distance unit, rose 56 cents, or 4.79 percent, to $12.26 on the news. Shares in Sprint PCS ended the day at $5.50, up 50 cents, or 10 percent. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

description: BECKER-Philip. The Members, Board of Governors and Officers of the Preakness Hills Country Club mourn the loss of a good friend and fellow member of long standing, and extend their deepest sympathy to his family. Morton Klein, President

description: The government is conducting a criminal investigation into a Johnson & Johnson factory that makes an anemia drug that has been linked to a spate of serious illnesses in Europe and Canada, according to court documents and people close to the situation.

description: Zacarias Moussaoui's effort to plead guilty today confuses an already complex legal situation and may compel the trial judge to move quickly to reconsider whether Mr. Moussaoui is competent to defend himself.

title: Shares of Eli Lilly Decline On Worry Over Drug Plants
description: Shares of Eli Lilly & Company tumbled yesterday after the company said that the approval of several promising new drugs could be delayed because federal inspectors had found widespread problems in two of its factories.

title: Seymour Solomon, 80, Record Label Founder
description: Seymour SolomonSeymour Solomon, who with his brother, Maynard, founded Vanguard Records in 1950 and turned it into the dominant label for American folk music, recording such artists as Joan Baez, Odetta, Buffy Sainte-Marie and Ian & Sylvia, died yesterday at his summer home in Lenox, Mass. He was 80 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Questioning $1 Million Fee in a Needle Deal
description: A group that buys medical supplies for a third of the nation's hospitals received two highly unusual payments totaling $1.1 million from a company that had received the exclusive right to market hypodermic needles and other products to the group's hospitals.

title: Coln and Guerrero End Mets' Mini-Streak
description: The Mets spent most of this afternoon scraping for an offense against Bartolo Coln, finally coming through for a run in the top of the eighth that tied the score at 1-1. The rookie Mark Corey then entered the game to pitch the bottom of the eighth and got the first out on a fly ball by Jose Vidro.

title: Politics and Poland Take Bush to Michigan
description: In a blend of domestic politics and foreign policy, President Bush took Poland's president, Aleksander Kwasniewski, to a Midwest community where ancestral ties to Poland run deep and celebrated America's alliance with one of NATO's newest members and a strong supporter of Mr. Bush's battle against terrorists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLENSON, BERNICE
description: GILLENSON-Bernice. On July 18, 2002. Survived by her children Wendy, Josh and Amy. Grandchildren Katharine and Jonathan.

title: LOCKHEED MARTIN'S PROFITS DOUBLED IN 2ND QUARTER
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation, the world's largest military contractor, said second-quarter profit more than doubled on increased sales of aircraft like the C-130J transport plane and because of a tax credit. Net income rose to $339 million, or 75 cents a share, from $144 million, or 33 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales increased to $6.29 billion from $5.7 billion, the company said. Sales at Lockheed's Space Systems unit, which makes and launches commercial and government satellites, fell 1 percent, to $1.78 billion. Sales at Lockheed's aeronautics business rose 46 percent, helped by an increase in deliveries of C-130J's, as well as work on the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter and F-22 combat aircraft programs.

title: In the Neighborhood, Bets On Name of Lotto Winner
description: At the sprawling Winston Towers 300, which rises 31 floors into the air, neighbors are starting to eye each other a bit suspiciously -- not out of trepidation, but curiosity.

title: Bush Tells Arab Ministers U.S. Wants Mideast Peace
description: President Bush reassured skeptical Arab allies today that his administration would press forward with efforts to reach peace in the Middle East despite continued attacks on Israel and disagreements over the role of Yasir Arafat as Palestinian leader.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEER, MORTON D.
description: BEER-Morton D. On July 18, 2002. Devoted son of the late Sam and Essie Beer. Beloved father of Mindy (Ron) Horowitz and Robert (Tracie) Beer. Adoring grandfather of Dari, Eric, Perri, Madison and Ryder. Loving brother to Sandy (Roger) Stern and proud uncle to Jordan, Andrew and Edward Stern. Graveside service Sunday, July 21st, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N.Y., at 1 PM.

title: A Light, Quick Anne Heche Makes 'Proof' a New Play
description: The new cast of ''Proof,'' led by the film actress Anne Heche, is putting on quite a snappy show at the Walter Kerr Theater. I haven't timed it, but my guess is that nearly two years into its Broadway run, David Auburn's Tony Award and Pulitzer Prize-winning play, about a young woman who has evidently inherited from her father both his mathematical genius and his madness, is running a few minutes shorter.

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER REDUCES PROFIT OUTLOOK
description: The American Electric Power Company reduced its 2002 profit outlook by 10 percent as the company, the biggest utility owner in the nation, warned that its second-quarter profit would fall short of analysts' estimates. Second-quarter profit was 52 cents to 57 cents a share, excluding one-time items, the company said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected 75 cents. The company said a slump in trading and cool weather held down its income. Shares of American Electric fell $3.14, or 9 percent, to $31.31 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, BARBARA S.
description: GOODMAN-Barbara S. Fifty-one years old, after a valiant fight against pancreatic cancer. Beloved wife of 25 years to Kenneth. Devoted and adored mother of Nicole and Eric. Dedicated daughter of Thelma Gartner, daughterin-law of Dorothy Goodman, sister-in-law of Linda and Robert Blum. Much loved aunt and great aunt. Her life was dedicated to her family and friends who will miss her immensely. Services Friday July 19, 1:00 PM, Bet Torah, Mount Kisco, New York. In lieu of baskets donations in her memory to Israel Cancer Research Fund, 1290 Avenue of the Americas, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGMAN, CHARLOTTE
description: BERGMAN-Charlotte. The Officers and Directors of The American Friends of the David Yellin College of Education record with deep sorrow the death of a great lady, patron of the arts, and major supporter of The College in Jerusalem. She has left us a lasting memorial which will live on in the years to come, and we are deeply grateful for her association with us. Elias Strum, President Marjorie G. Price Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, JAMES DENEALE
description: GRANT-James Deneale. On July 13th, 2002, at age 70. Former Deputy Commissioner of the US Food and Drug Administration. Retired Chairman and CEO of T Cell Sciences. Director of several biotech boards. Beloved husband of Bonnie J. Grant. Loving father of Glenn, Bruce Scott and grandfather of four grandchildren and two step grandchildren. Interment private. Memorial service October 5th, 2 PM, at Fifth Ave. Presbyterian Church, 5th Ave. at 55th St., NY, NY 10019. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Church.

title: A Spiritual Trek For Salt in Tibet
description: Nothing beats a good trek movie. On Tuesday Zeitgeist is to release Ulrike Koch's documentary ''The Saltmen of Tibet'' on cassette and DVD. At the outset a song tells us that we are in the Kingdom of Ling, at the center of the world, a blue-turquoise place. Nomads are preparing to drive 160 yaks on a monthlong pilgrimage to Lake Tsentso to collect salt to trade for grain.

title: Senate Votes To Expand Drug Cost Cuts Of Medicaid
description: The Senate voted today to help states try to reduce prescription drug prices, despite fierce opposition from the pharmaceutical industry, which is locked in litigation with several states.

title: Alarm Bells Louder Than Even Selig's
description: If only Major League Baseball could blame its financial woes on illegally inflating losses from the sale of corked bats, disguising billions of dollars in profits as clubhouse catering costs or burying revenues in off-balance-sheet limited partnerships called ''Mo Vaughn's Diet'' and ''Goes Well to His Right.''

title: A Hero Who Sees Marilyn and Elvis
description: If you look back at Christopher Walken's film career, it's clear that Johnny Smith is one of his least weird characters. Johnny, the young protagonist of Stephen King's novel ''The Dead Zone'' and of the 1983 film, directed by David Cronenberg, is a happy-go-lucky small-town schoolteacher who is getting married soon to a fellow teacher (Brooke Adams). Then he's in a serious car accident and falls into a coma. When he wakes up, six years later, a lot of things have changed.

title: INSIDE
description: Expel Traficant, Panel Urges

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Level 3 Loss Narrows In 2nd Quarter
description: A second-quarter loss at Level 3 Communications narrowed as sales almost doubled at the company, a fiber optic network operator. The net loss fell to $156 million, or 39 cents a share, from a loss of $731 million, or $1.99, a year earlier. Revenue rose to $750 million from $387 million, the company, based in Broomfield, Colo., said in a news release. Level 3 said the loss included a $76 million gain from debt repurchases and a $102 million gain from a stock sale. Excluding the gain from the debt repurchases, the loss was $232 million, or 58 cents a share. Company officials could not be reached for comment.

title: Editors' Note; On Stage and Off
description: The On Stage and Off column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: National Briefing | West: Glaciers Melting More Quickly
description: In a sharply accelerating meltdown, Alaska's glaciers are losing 24 cubic miles of ice a year and contributing far more to a slow rise in sea levels than scientists had estimated, a new study in the journal Science concludes. Using airborne laser systems, researchers from the University of Alaska at Fairbanks created the first precise survey of changes in glacier volumes in the region, which has experienced substantial warming in recent years. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: House Takes Up, but Drops, Bermuda Corporation Issue
description: The House yesterday took up the first measure that touched on corporations that use a Bermuda mailbox to avoid paying taxes, but rather than moving toward tightening the loophole, House Republicans allowed Democrats to lambaste them as the ''allies of corporate traitors.''

title: Agency Chief Loses His Job Over Airport Security Issues
description: The leader of the Transportation Security Administration, which was established last winter to protect travelers after Sept. 11, was forced out of his job today as questions intensified about whether the agency had moved quickly enough to improve airport security.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: GROWTH IN SOFTWARE India's software industry continued to grow at a healthy pace despite the global technology slowdown and cutbacks by businesses after Sept. 11. Software revenue rose to $12.3 billion in the April 2001 to March 2002 period, according to the leading software industry trade body, the National Association of Software and Service Companies. Exports rose to $9.6 billion this year from $7.7 billion a year earlier. More than 60 percent of India's software exports are to North America. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: U.S.D.A. Announces Wider Recall of Beef That May Be Tainted
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 — The Agriculture Department said today that 18 million pounds of hamburger-grade beef are being recalled because the beef may have been contaminated with potentially deadly E. coli bacteria.

title: California Manhunt Grows, but It Produces No Arrests in Killing of Girl, 5
description: Local, state and federal law enforcement officials here said today that they had unleashed a huge arsenal of investigative weapons in their joint efforts to find the man who kidnapped a screaming 5-year-old girl from this Orange County suburb, then sexually assaulted and killed her.

title: 'Something, Anything'
description: Matthew Marks Gallery

title: Coherent Homeland Security
description: President Bush is right to seek a broadly inclusive Homeland Security Department that incorporates border security, bioterrorism defenses and disaster management functions now scattered across the government. As the plan works its way through Congress, Republican and Democratic leaders need to keep a tight rein on committee chairmen seeking to gut the reorganization plan so they can preserve their sway over large agencies and budgets. Encouragingly, House Republican leaders took a firm line yesterday as the proposal heads for floor consideration next week.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: 360networks Accepts Reorganization Plan
description: The 360networks company, owner of a 25,000-mile fiber optic network linking 48 major North American cities, said yesterday that it had agreed with creditors on a reorganization plan that should allow it to emerge from bankruptcy in September. Banks and other secured lenders, led by J. P. Morgan Chase, will own about 80 percent of the reorganized company, according to Greg Maffei, its president and chief executive. Under the plan, 360networks will have $215 million in debt and more than $50 million in cash. Mr. Maffei said the company's goal was to gain enough new business to begin covering its operating costs from cash flow in the first half of next year. Barnaby Feder (NYT)

title: Waterfront Homes: Whether Pond, Lake or Ocean, Always a View
description: WHO -- Martha Peterson, a retired sales manager for an airline, and Ted Peterson, a retired lawyer.

title: Corrections
description: The contents listing of the Arts section yesterday included an erroneous entry in some copies. The reference was to an article about the 25th anniversary of the Cornelia Street Cafe in Greenwich Village, to be published later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOVNANIAN, ALTON ARA.
description: HOVNANIAN-Alton Ara. It is with deep sympathy and profound sadness that we mourn the passing of Alton Ara Hovnanian, beloved son of Ara and Rachel Hovnanian and grandson of Kevork and Sirwart Hovnanian. Your corporate family grieves with you and our prayers go out to you. The 2,500 Associates of K. Hovnanian Companies

title: 36 Hours | Jackson, Wyo.
description: WITH its spectacular setting at the edge of the Tetons, Jackson was probably destined to be transformed from the fur-trading town of the early 1800's to the collection of celebrity second homes, upscale restaurants and shops both stylish and kitschy that much of it is today. A town of about 8,500 permanent residents, Jackson is the commercial center for Jackson Hole, the 48-mile valley of the Snake River that is famed for its ski resorts. The only mountain men you're likely to see on Jackson's streets today are the climbers who come from near and far to scale the jagged peaks. But look beyond the Gap and the Ripley's Believe It or Not museum, and you'll see men still sauntering in Wranglers, Western boots and ivory Stetsons and paddlers hauling their boats toward the Snake. And rising above both the trophy ranches and the minimarts is the signature scenery of what may be the most ruggedly beautiful state in the union. WENDY KNIGHT

title: Interacting Without Words And Separated by a Duck
description: The East Village and New York's other centers of avant-garde theater need to get cracking. They're in danger of being passed on the weirdness scale by -- who knew? -- Iranians.

title: Senators Question Credibility of Army Secretary on Enron
description: Thomas E. White, the Army secretary and a former top executive for the Enron Corporation, told a Senate committee today that he was unaware of any efforts by Enron to manipulate energy prices in the California power crisis of 2000 and 2001.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Ethics Panel Votes to Oust Ohio Democrat
description: The House ethics committee called tonight for the expulsion of Representative James A. Traficant Jr. of Ohio on charges stemming from his April conviction for bribery, corruption and racketeering.

title: Cain and Abel Played Out in a Run-Down Amazon Port
description: THE BROTHERS

title: Not Your Usual Roadside Rest Stop
description: Once the pride of a nation, the vast majority of great American lodges have been lost to fire, neglect or the ravages of time. The following resorts survive intact, and have been designated national historic landmarks.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Economy Down, Kidnappings Up
description: Responding to a growing clamor about an increase in violent crime after the collapse of the economy, the government has announced the formation of a special antikidnapping brigade. Felipe Sol, governor of Buenos Aires Province, said the measure was needed because the regular police in the metropolitan area that is home to one-third of Argentina's 37 million people were being overwhelmed by crime, especially so-called ''express kidnappings'' in which victims are held briefly for small ransoms. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Nokia Reports a Surge in Profit but a Drop in Sales
description: Nokia, the world's largest maker of mobile phones, reported a surge in second-quarter profit, but it said that sales for the period fell, as fresh demand for new mobile phones and other telecommunications equipment failed to materialize.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on Monday about the Ozzfest 2002 pop music tour and the MTV program ''The Osbournes'' referred incorrectly to the nationality of the children on the cable television show. Although they have long lived in the United States, they are British, not American.

title: Images of Devastating Grief And the Courage to Go On
description: ''Offering'' would be impressive in any outdoor location. But this work, collaboratively choreographed by the Japanese-born dancers known as Eiko and Koma, gained special poignancy on Tuesday night when it was presented at Battery Park City under auspices of Dancing in the Streets and the Hudson River Festival.

title: Politics Absent As Mayor Picks School Panelists
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg revealed his appointees to a new educational policy panel yesterday that is a central element of mayoral control of the New York City schools, selecting a group that is distinctly less political than the old Board of Education.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about talks in New York on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict misstated the title of Javier Solana, a European Union official who took part. He is the high representative for common foreign and security policy, not the national security chief. The article also misidentified the location of a bombing attack on a bus that coincided with the talks. It was near the Immanuel settlement in the West Bank, not inside Israel's pre-1967 borders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENLEY, WALTER L., M.D.
description: HENLEY-Walter L., M.D. On July 18, 2002. Beloved and devoted husband, father, sibling, physician, friend. He is survived and missed by Edith, his wife of 50 years, daughters Madeline and Elizabeth, son-in-law Joseph N. Kaster and siblings Ernest, and Renee Stein. We will always cherish and be inspired by his compassion, integrity and gentleness. Services on Sunday, July 21, 2 PM, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue & 91 St.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Trading a Crown For a Lily Pad

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Americans Threatened
description: A militant group warned in a radio broadcast that it would attack Americans and United States' interests in the Philippines. The threat came from Abu Solaiman, a spokesman of the Abu Sayyaf group, which killed an American hostage last year and held two American missionaries until one was rescued last month while her husband was killed in the rescue effort. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEISS, BEATRICE
description: GEISS-Beatrice. Devoted wife of the late Maurice. Beloved mother of Dr. Alan C. and Annette. Cherished grandmother of Suzanne Geiss, Dr. Christopher and Terri Sforzo and Jennifer and Edward Burfeindt. Loving great-grandmother of Sydney. Services today 12 noon at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Union and Companies in Queens Bus Strike Turn to City Hall
description: Since the Queens bus strike began a month ago, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has insisted that the dispute should be settled by the workers and the bus companies and not by City Hall.

title: Two Critics of Forced Synergy Are in Charge of It
description: Don Logan of Time Inc. and Jeff Bewkes of HBO, two allies who were critical of forced tries at cooperation after AOL merged with Time Warner, are now charged with deciding just how much synergy is enough.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Dave Chapman was named to head a new New York office of Wolfe/Doyle Advertising as vice president and director for client services. He had been vice president and account director at Foote, Cone & Belding, part of the FCB Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: 'Six Feet Under' Tops Emmy Contenders
description: ''Six Feet Under,'' the darkly comic series on HBO about a troubled family running a funeral business, earned a leading 23 Emmy nominations today, a signal once again of the creative strength of cable over the networks. The 54th annual Emmy Awards will be shown on NBC on Sept. 22.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Appliance Maker's Outlook
description: The world's largest maker of home appliances, Electrolux A.B., said full-year earnings would rise after cost cuts brought a 59 percent gain in second-quarter profit. Net income at the company, which is based in Stockholm, rose to 1.85 billion kronor ($200 million) from 1.16 billion kronor ($125 million) a year earlier. Sales declined 0.6 percent, to 37.2 billion kronor ($4 billion). Electrolux, which makes Frigidaire and Eureka appliances, takes in 40 percent of its revenue from the United States. The company has cut 5,000 jobs to reduce costs.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: EMC Reports Profit Decline
description: The EMC Corporation, the world's largest maker of computer data-storage systems, reported yesterday that it had second-quarter income of $808,000, breaking even per share; that income is down 99 percent from $108.9 million, or 5 cents a share, a year earlier. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected a loss of 2 cents a share for the quarter. The company, based in Hopkinton, Mass., reported a decline in quarterly profit and a 31 percent drop in revenue as companies continued to be reluctant to spend money on information technology. ''The hard cold fact is that I do not see the information-technology spending environment improving in 2002,'' said EMC's chief executive, Joe Tucci, in a conference call. ''Customers are extremely tight with their dollars right now.'' EMC's products include the hardware and software that store information for data-heavy companies like airlines, banks and insurance companies. Shares in the company fell 23 cents, or 2.7 percent, to $8.40. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Actress's Detainment Upsets Indians in U.S. and Abroad
description: For Jose Panachi, the editor of the popular daily newspaper Malayala Manorama in southern India, there was no question about the appropriate size for the headline on an article about one of the region's biggest movie stars being detained in New York as a suspected terrorist.

title: SEARS HAS BETTER-THAN-EXPECTED 2ND QUARTER
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company had a higher-than-expected second-quarter profit and raised its 2002 forecast as the company cut costs and expanded its credit card business. Net income was $420 million, or $1.31 a share, in contrast to a net loss of $197 million, or 60 cents, a year earlier. Sears had about $513 million in one-time costs in the year-earlier quarter. Sales fell less than 1 percent, to $10.14 billion. Sears, based in Hoffman Estates, Ill., raised its full-year profit forecast to about $5.15 a share.

title: Sneakers With M.J. on Them? A Good Sign, Little Hoopster
description: Like Mike

title: Smyth, 49, Maintains A Positive Attitude
description: A nap in a car almost cost Des Smyth a spot in the British Open.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Upholds Dismissal Of Officers
description: A state judge has upheld the dismissal of two police officers who admitted drinking alcohol with Joseph Gray, the former officer found guilty of manslaughter after his car struck a pregnant woman and her family. Both officers were on departmental probation, one of them for alcohol offenses. The officers, Edward Sills and John Welsh, admitted that they were drinking on Aug. 4 with Mr. Gray, who later struck the Brooklyn family, killing four members. Mr. Sills was placed on probation in June 2000 after pleading guilty to driving under the influence of alcohol and Mr. Welsh was 17 months into his two-year probationary term as a new officer, according to the city's corporation counsel. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cable Bond Offer Withdrawn
description: The Liberty Media Corporation, controlled by John C. Malone, withdrew an offer to buy the bonds of Telewest Communications, a British cable provider that is widely expected to restructure its debt later this year. Liberty blamed falling securities prices, including a decline in its own stock price, for its decision. The company also said it was withdrawing three directors from Telewest's board. The directors -- Robert R. Bennett, Graham Hollis and Miranda Curtis -- are the subjects of a lawsuit filed in the United States by Telewest bondholders, who claim Liberty Media had the potential to use insider knowledge to secure control of the company. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about plans by a consortium of computer chip makers to build a research and development center in Albany misidentified the headquarters country of STMicroelectronics, one maker. Though the company was formerly based in France and keeps many operations there, its headquarters are in Switzerland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOERTZEL, DR. GERALD
description: GOERTZEL-Dr. Gerald. Beloved husband of the late Martha Bendheim Goertzel for fifty-five years, died at the age of 82, July 17, 2002, in his home in White Plains. Dr. Goertzel retired in 1992 from a distinguished career as a computer scientist, nuclear engineer, and physicist, including work on the Manhattan Project, for the Nuclear Development Corporation of America, for Sage Instruments (a company he started to develop scientific instruments for medical research) and for 28 years in IBMs research division where he worked in the areas of design automation, data compression and digital printing technology. Developer of the Goertzel Algorithm and holder of numerous patents, he received his B.S. and M.S. from the Stevens Institute of Technology and his Ph.D. in theoretical physics from New York University. Jerry is survived by his loving brother and sister, Herbert Goertzel and Bernice ''Susie'' Goertzel Arnold; his 3 daughters: Fran G. Gustavson, Susan G. Sandman & Marion G. Stern; five grandchildren, Alison, Lisa, Jennifer, Mark and David; three nieces and nephews, Ken, Doug, Karen, their spouses and many others. Family and friends will be gathering Saturday, July 20th, 2002, from 1-4 in the afternoon at Fran Gustavson's home.

title: Nearly 40 Jewish Graves Are Desecrated in a Rome Cemetery
description: Visitors to the Jewish section of a historic cemetery here today found smashed headstones, toppled columns and overturned earth, a chilling scene that marked the arrival in Italy of a wave of anti-Semitic attacks across Europe.

title: Developing a Complicated Taste for (Older) Women
description: Oscar Grubman (Aaron Stanford), the intellectually precocious 15-year-old protagonist of ''Tadpole,'' is about as close to a contemporary descendant of J. D. Salinger's beloved preppie misfit, Holden Caulfield, as has ever been brought to the screen. A fragile wisp of a movie (it's only 77 minutes long), ''Tadpole,'' whose title refers to Oscar's boyish nickname, observes his romantic growing pains during an emotionally fraught Thanksgiving break from private school.

title: Overlooking a Shy Mr. Right Until It's Almost Too Late
description: ''I specialize in playing Holocaust victims,'' says Claudine Bloomberg (Justine Litchman), the tiny, wide-eyed actress who is the central figure in I-fan Quirk's independent feature ''Being Claudine.'' Though she's joking, it's not hard to see why such roles would settle on her. A young single girl at the mercy of the Manhattan dating scene, she's no stranger to suffering, and she has developed a rueful humor to combat her frequent romantic disappointments.

title: With an Eye On Election, Schrder Fires Defense Chief
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder, an underdog for re-election in September, dismissed his defense minister today after allegations of financial improprieties.

title: DATA SOUGHT ON GLOBAL CROSSING'S SHREDDING POLICIES
description: Lawmakers asked Global Crossing yesterday to provide information about its document-destruction policies. Workers have accused the company, which sought bankruptcy protection in January, of shredding files. Representatives Billy Tauzin, a Louisiana Republican and chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, and James C. Greenwood, a Pennsylvania Republican, asked Global Crossing's chief executive, John J. Legere, to turn over the company's document-retention rules and details on the author of the policy. They also want the company to make seven employees available for interviews, the lawmakers said in a letter released to reporters.

title: Daimler Profit Up 52%; Restrained Optimism for Rest of Year
description: DaimlerChrysler reported today that its second-quarter profit jumped 52 percent, buoyed by cost-cutting at Chrysler that is running ahead of the company's turnaround plan.

title: A Spectacle, Moving Yet Mysterious
description: Some crucial elements are missing from the three samples of Ta'ziyeh, the Iranian musical theater form, that are being offered as a highlight of the Lincoln Center Festival. First, the shows are being presented with a skeleton ensemble; 10 of the 28 company members were denied visas and kept from entering the United States, so the productions are smaller.

title: Better Development Through Democracy
description: African leaders meeting in Durban, South Africa, recently dissolved the moribund Organization of African Unity and replaced it with a new and purportedly more powerful body called the African Union. By pledging to conduct democratic elections and respect the rule of law -- and to intervene when member states violate human rights -- these leaders hope to attract more than $60 billion annually in new trade and investment from wealthy countries. Their efforts to link politics and economic growth, spearheaded by President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa, have received widespread praise.

title: Knicks' Priority Now Is Landing a Point Guard
description: Much has been made since July 1 of the Knicks' interest in this summer's middling crop of free-agent centers, but Scott Layden, the team's president and general manager, is focused on making a far more significant transaction. While no deals are imminent, Layden hopes to pull off a trade before training camp begins in October that would rival the magnitude of the Knicks' draft-night acquisition of Antonio McDyess.

title: EBay Earnings Up as Revenue Sets Record
description: The online auction giant eBay Inc. continued its lonesome Internet success story, announcing higher second-quarter sales and profits yesterday, with strong growth in the United States and overseas markets.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New York Aid Package Advances
description: The final installment of the roughly $21.5 billion aid package President Bush pledged to New York after the Sept. 11 terror attack appears headed for approval, the staffs of United States Senators Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton said yesterday. House and Senate negotiators have agreed to provide $5.5 billion for the package. The package includes $2.7 billion for disaster relief through the Federal Emergency Management Agency, $1.8 billion to build a new transit hub in Lower Manhattan, and $750 million to help major utilities rebuild equipment damaged in the attack. The aid package is included in a larger spending bill that both houses of Congress are expected to pass next week, according to Mr. Schumer's aides. Raymond Hernandez (NYT)

title: Lloyd's Plans Big Changes In Financing Of Insurance
description: Lloyd's of London, which suffered heavy losses in the World Trade Center attacks, said yesterday that it soon hoped to end its more than 300-year practice of financing insurance through individual investors who risked their entire net worth, but often reaped fabulous profits.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Weekender | North Stonington, Conn.
description: STRANGERS wandering through southeastern Connecticut sometimes mistake the sleepy village of North Stonington for Stonington Borough, its busier, pricier and famously quaint cousin to the south. Laurie Pepin, owner of the Watermark, a cafe and art gallery that makes up a large percentage of North Stonington's business district, recalls a visitor who had made this error asking her in a rather flabbergasted tone, ''Is this it?''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: BASF Names Executive
description: The chemicals maker BASF named a management board member, Jrgen Hambrecht, left, as chief executive to replace Jrgen Strube, who will retire next May. Mr. Hambrecht, who turns 56 in August, joined the company in 1976 and has worked in various areas of the company, including polymers, coatings and plastics. He has been head of the East Asia division and joined the management board in 1997.

title: Torricelli to Go Before Ethics Panel Over Gifts
description: Senator Robert G. Torricelli is scheduled to appear before a closed session of the Senate Ethics Committee Monday to respond to charges that he accepted illegal gifts from David Chang, a commodities trader, for helping him on various business deals.

title: Summer at 12: The Pool Grows, the Mystery Deepens
description: IT is 2 in the afternoon. Christie Aizen and her best friend, Allison Carey, and three other friends, all 12 years old, are playing in an Olympic-size pool in Lower Makefield Township, a Philadelphia suburb.

title: Downtown Visions: Remembrance and Resolve; An Aching Sadness
description: To the Editor:

title: An Apology at Court for S.U.V. Crash in the Hamptons
description: Elizabeth S. Grubman, the Manhattan publicist, made a tearful apology today after a judge said he would soon set a date for her trial in the crash that injured 16 people outside a Southampton nightclub a year ago.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: CABLE BOND OFFER WITHDRAWN The Liberty Media Corporation , controlled by John C. Malone, withdrew an offer to buy the bonds of Telewest Communications , a British cable provider that is widely expected to restructure its debt later this year. Liberty blamed falling securities prices, including a decline in its own stock price, for its decision. The company also said it was withdrawing three directors from Telewest's board. The directors  Robert R. Bennett, Graham Hollis and Miranda Curtis  are the subjects of a lawsuit filed in the United States by Telewest bondholders, who claim Liberty Media had the potential to use insider knowledge to secure control of the company.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Xerox Investigation
description: India's income tax department searched 23 offices of the Indian unit of the Xerox Corporation after the company's admission that it bribed government officials to win sales orders. Earlier this month, Xerox said in an annual filing that its Indian subsidiary, Xerox ModiCorp Ltd., had made ''improper payments'' of about $700,000 up to the year 2000. The tax department is trying to determine whether the company evaded Indian taxes by misrepresenting payments. The searches will be followed by corruption and corporate misconduct investigations by the government's Department of Company Affairs, which sought permission on Thursday to investigate Xerox ModiCorp.

title: Pressure Building on the Chairman To Take Lead at AOL Time Warner
description: Meanwhile, where is Steve Case?

title: HOUSE LEADERSHIP BOWS TO PRESIDENT ON SECURITY DEPT.
description: The Republican leaders of the House said today that they planned to give the Bush administration almost all of what it wanted in a new Department of Homeland Security, proposing to restore to the department most of the agencies that committees had voted to remove.

title: Downtown Visions: Remembrance and Resolve; For All of Us
description: To the Editor:

title: New Videos Resonate Darkly
description: FOR at least half a century, video has been the art form of the future, where the technological vanguard meets the cultural avant-garde. It therefore seems strange, even a little perverse, that the centerpiece of this year's New York Video Festival, which opens tonight at Lincoln Center, is not a collage of digital imagery or information-age self-reflection, but a silent, black-and-white adaptation of Bram Stoker's ''Dracula.'' Made for Canadian television by the Winnipeg-based experimental filmmaker Guy Maddin, ''Dracula: Pages From a Virgin's Diary,'' which will be shown at the Walter Reade Theater tonight at 9, is less a remake of the earlier cinematic versions of the vampire story than a pre-make, an attempt to imagine what the tale might have looked like before F. W. Murnau, before Bela Lugosi, before Francis Ford Coppola.

title: Edmund Anderson, 89, a Muse to Ellington
description: Edmund Anderson, a former stockbroker with an interest in music who became a producer and also influenced the career of his friend Duke Ellington, died on June 29 at his home in Quogue, N.Y. He was 89.

title: Power Failure Shuts Court
description: A short circuit led to a power failure in the Brooklyn Criminal Court building early yesterday and forced the evacuation of 113 prisoners awaiting arraignment, the authorities said. The prisoners were relocated without incident to nearby police precincts and other holding centers and arraigned at a Red Hook community court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVERNE, HARRY
description: AVERNE - Harry. Passed away July 17, 2002. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Harvey and Robert. Father - in - law to Paula. Grandfather of David. Uncle and friend to many. Services are at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island, Friday, July 19, at 11 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSES, ANITA
description: MOSES-Anita. After a long illness, passed away at the age of 67, on July 18, 2002. Beloved mother of Marc and Elan, daughter of the late Leah and Henry Krochmal. Sister of Helen Klein and Stanley Krochmal. A well known educational consultant, she was a Co-Founder in 1968 of the Children's Community Workshop School. In 1977 founded the Educational Planning Institute; a painter, art collector, member of the Minyan Ma'At Congregation. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her. Burial will be in Israel. Services here at the Plaza Funeral Home, 10 AM, Friday, July 19th.

title: Editorial Observer; This Generation Needs a Paranoid's Paranoid
description: The distance between the world we live in and the world depicted in science fiction has narrowed dramatically in recent years. Novels that once seemed futuristic because they featured pocket computers, palm-sized phones and genetically enhanced people have become dated -- artifacts from a recent past. Minuscule by tradition, the science fiction market has contracted further, making it even more difficult for writers to find an audience.

title: Downtown Visions: Remembrance and Resolve
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Reuters on Tuesday about the fatal stabbing of an Orthodox Jew in Toronto on Sunday referred incorrectly to the police account. The police said the attack occurred after two men and a woman, who had left a kosher pizzeria after arguing and insulting the patrons and employees, returned. They did not say that the victim, who was stabbed in the back, was involved in a quarrel with the suspects.

title: John Cocke, a Chip Wizard From I.B.M., Is Dead at 77
description: John Cocke, a leading computer scientist whose inventions spanned an uncommon range of computing technology from software to microprocessors, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 77.

title: Five Share Lead at British Open
description: GULLANE, Scotland, July 19  At the British Open, it was far from lonely at the top.

title: DNA Tests Confirm Body In Karachi Is Reporter's
description: Results of DNA tests confirm that a body found in a shallow grave in the southern city of Karachi is that of Daniel Pearl, the American reporter who disappeared there in January, several officials said here today.

title: Despite Not Having the Title, Mosley Garners Attention
description: This city is relatively new to big-time boxing, but Shane Mosley is noticed almost everywhere he goes.

title: Sustaining Asian Roots in American Soil
description: In 1999, Tony Bui directed ''Three Seasons,'' and wrote it with his brother, Timothy Linh Bui. The first American film to be shot in Vietnam, the Buis' three-part tale of the repercussions of the Vietnam War in the present-day Ho Chi Minh City attracted a lot of critical attention and became an art-house hit.

title: Name Game Is Messy, Really Messy
description: JUST in case anyone might get the wrong idea, all six blueprints for rebuilding the World Trade Center site bore the word ''Memorial'' in their titles when they were unveiled the other day. There were Memorial Plaza, Memorial Triangle, Memorial Garden, Memorial Square, Memorial Park and Memorial Promenade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, HELLMUT
description: LEWIN-Hellmut. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Hellmut Lewin. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Lucille, and their family. Richard J. Bornstein, President Leon Fassler, Secretary

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Old English Gems Of Gentry Living

title: Canadian Bank Retreats From Some Lending
description: Bruised by heavy loan losses, the TD Bank Financial Group of Canada said today that it was retreating from a 30-year drive to be a global leader in lending to the telecommunications and cable television sectors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIARD, ROBERT J. JR.
description: GIARD-Robert J. Jr. Suddenly, unbelievably on July 16, 2002. Passionate photographer, loving partner, and loyal friend-Bob will be sorely missed by the many who cherished his quiet, steady and thoughtful ways.

title: Stranded In a Place Satellites Can't See
description: ON Easter Sunday, our Mercedes-Benz sport utility vehicle -- the all-wheel drive, all-purpose insurance against disaster my companion and I acquired last year -- became hopelessly stuck in a foot of snow in the forested wilderness near our cabin in northeastern California.

title: British Doctor Killed at Least 215 People, Inquiry Reports
description: HYDE, England, July 19  Dr. Harold Shipman, the suburban family doctor convicted two years ago of murdering 15 of his patients, actually killed at least 215 of them, an official investigation reported today.

title: Losing Ground in Guatemala
description: Last month Guatemala suffered an unusual mini-coup. The province of Petn was taken over by former members of the Civil Defense Patrols, groups that worked in tandem with the army during the civil war and are accused of countless crimes. For three days they blockaded the roads, controlled the airport and sealed off access to the Mayan ruins of Tikal, stranding tourists. Instead of arresting them, Guatemala's government negotiated with them and then announced it would try to levy a new tax to pay them for their ''services'' during the war.

title: By the Bay in Queens, the Sting of a Fatal Boat Crash Lingers
description: Shortly after sunset on a steamy summer night a week ago, Robert Arnold finished his shift as a waiter at the neighborhood swim club, gathered five of his friends and took his family's speedboat for a ride in the still waters of Little Neck Bay in Queens.

title: When Revolutionaries Mature and Have to Face Up
description: ''What to Do in Case of Fire'' is metallic and inhuman, and its bone-deep willingness to do anything to entertain is exhausting. The attempt at social (and socialist) satire, which starts in mid-1980's Berlin, uses the energy of anarchy to propel it forward. The briskness that ''Fire'' generates as it sets up its story -- a band of fight-the-power squatters cause civil unrest by planting bombs in abandoned buildings -- shows that the German director Gregor Schnitzer has the skills to develop his narrative with coercive aplomb.

title: Tapes Show Pilots in German Air Crash Saw Each Other
description: FRANKFURT, July 19  The pilots of the American and Russian planes that crashed in the night sky above Germany earlier this month, killing 71 people, saw each other in the last seconds before the collision and maneuvered to avoid a crash, according to an analysis of the cockpit voice recorders and flight data recorders released today by German investigators.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Slow-Motion Protest
description: Demonstrating against a government plan to build an eight-lane highway on the north side of Seoul, about 100 Buddhist monks and nuns marched nearly two miles through the capital, walking three steps at a time, then flattening themselves on the street or sidewalk before taking three more steps. The four-hour protest, by the Buddhist Environment Asssociation, was intended to persuade the government to abandon the plan for the highway through the crags formed by Mount Pukak. The monks said the highway would ruin the environment of a region that is crisscrossed by trails, many of which lead to Buddhist pagodas and temples hidden away in the mountains. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Teo-Ashoo Pass Journal; Here's to the Horse! A Good Reason to Drink to It
description: Got horse milk?

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: 360NETWORKS ACCEPTS REORGANIZATION PLAN 360networks, owner of a 25,000-mile fiber optic network linking 48 major North American cities, said yesterday that it had agreed with creditors on a reorganization plan that should allow it to emerge from bankruptcy in September. Banks and other secured lenders, led by J. P. Morgan Chase , will own about 80 percent of the reorganized company, according to Greg Maffei, its president and chief executive. Under the plan, 360networks will have $215 million in debt and more than $50 million in cash. Mr. Maffei said the company's goal was to gain enough new business to begin covering its operating costs from cash flow in the first half of next year.

title: Mild Weather, Little Wind, Many Players Under Par
description: Through one round, the British Open had an unpredictable feel, the type of tournament that could unfold in 100 different ways.

description: Buoyed by strong revenue across a range of its businesses, Microsoft reported fourth-quarter financial results today that slightly exceeded analysts' expectations.

description: POPOVIC-ANA. We mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend and colleague. Ana was a vibrant personality and dedicated professional. We shall miss her greatly. H.F. International Realty Ltd. Helene Fields, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELMAESTRO, LOUIS ''GIGI''
description: DELMAESTRO-Louis ''Gigi'' died July 13, 2002, of cancer, at the home of his daughter, Madeline Tugentman, in Maplewood, NJ. He was 66. Gigi became the quintessential Hollywood restaurateur after 27 years at the Los Angeles Palm Restaurant. Gigi is also survived by daughter, Elizabeth Salituri of Maplewood, NJ; sister, Angela Delmaestro of Queens, NY; and granddaughters, Michelle, Allison and Gianna. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Louis ''Gigi'' Delmaestro Memorial Fund, C/O the USC/ Norris Comprehensive Cancer Center, 1441 Eastlake Ave., Los Angeles, CA 90033; Attention: Debbi Cordano.

title: S.&P. 500 Index Drops to Its Lowest Level Since 1997
description: Stocks fell yesterday, driving the Standard & Poor's to its lowest level since 1997, as companies including Automatic Data Processing, Eli Lilly and PNC Financial Services lowered profit forecasts and executives said there was little sign of a rebound in technology spending by businesses.

title: Say What? Subway Riders Still Aren't Really Sure
description: The happy news for New York subway riders is that basic announcements naming stations and transfer points continue to improve. But when the train is suddenly stopped and riders are wondering what is happening -- attenshunagarblamufflabuzug. Thank you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, GHITY LINDENBAUM
description: STERN-Ghity Lindenbaum. Yeshiva University Women's Organization (YUWO) expresses sorrow upon the passing of its devoted friend and honorary National Board member Ghity Stern. A generous and dedicated supporter, she was honored by YUWO at its 63rd Annual Spring Luncheon in 1991. Proceeds helped to refurbish the auditorium at the University's Stern College for Women, established in 1954 with a major gift from her husband, the late Max Stern. Heartfelt condolences to her children, YUWO member Maidy (and Maurice) Jeger, Armand (and YUWO National Board member Jean) Lindenbaum, Marcel (and Belda) Lindenbaum, Leonard (and Allison) Stern, and Gloria Kisch, and to grandchildren, Amiel (and Jessica) Lindenbaum and Michelle (& Paul) Grobman, officers in The Future Builders young leadership group and to all members of the Stern and Lindenbaum families. Dinah Pinczower National Chairman of the Board Harriet Muss Maguy Naparstek Gabrielle Propp National Presidium, YUWO

description: NORWALK: SKAKEL SENTENCING WON'T BE BROADCAST

title: In New Home, a Museum Gets to Show Its Stuff
description: There are so many good things in Part 2 of ''American Anthem: Masterworks From the American Folk Art Museum'' that even the most ardent folk-art grinch would need more hands than two to count them on. The last in a trio of shows celebrating the American Folk Art Museum's new building on West 53rd Street, ''Anthem'' displays more than 250 objects acquired since the museum began 40 years ago. And in the museum's cleverly designed new digs, the show really comes on strong.

title: EARNINGS ROSE 80% AT FARMER MAC IN SECOND QUARTER
description: The Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation, the government-sponsored buyer of agricultural loans known as Farmer Mac, said last night that its second-quarter earnings had risen 80 percent as its loan portfolio had grown. Farmer Mac's net income rose to $6.68 million, or 52 cents a share, compared with $3.72 million, or 32 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Farmer Mac's stock has plummeted 53 percent since April after reports suggested the company did not disclose enough information to investors. Shares of Farmer Mac closed at $20.80, down 30 cents, before the earnings announcement.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Eases Some Water Limits
description: The city's Department of Environmental Protection has eased some water restrictions for health reasons, but said the Stage I drought emergency continues with reservoir levels about 84 percent rather than the usual 93 percent. Commissioner Christopher O. Ward also said that the high heat and humidity had worsened the health and safety risks from garbage on the streets. Officials are allowing some water use for washing sidewalks, streets, driveways and outdoor areas. ''This is not carte blanche to hose down the whole sidewalk,'' said Geoff Ryan, a department spokesman, but is intended to allow the removal of feces, garbage and other public health risks. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Armstrong Starts His Ascent in the Mountains
description: Hugely assisted by his team, Lance Armstrong settled most questions today about his form in the Tour de France, winning the first mountain stage and gaining the yellow jersey of the race's overall leader.

title: Spencer Makes the Most of a Rare Start
description: Shane Spencer never turned around from the on-deck circle to peer into the dugout in the eighth inning at Yankee Stadium yesterday. If you look back, Spencer said later, it is a defeatist approach. Might as well not even stroll to the plate if there is any doubt about whether the manager wants you to hit.

description: Talwar Gallery

title: The Fading Fortunes of AOL's 'Bob Pitchman'
description: On his ascent to the No. 3 position in the world's largest media company, Robert W. Pittman earned the nickname ''Bob Pitchman,'' the best marketer of his time.

title: Fare Drama Alters Cast, But the Plot Is Familiar
description: The mayor of New York City, desperately looking for ways to repair his broken budget, decides to give less help to subways and buses. Transit advocates fear a fare increase as a result. Both the mayor and the governor -- the man who ultimately decides whether to raise fares and knows the political risks -- decry the very idea of an increase.

title: After Criticism, C.I.A. Eases Policy on Recruiting Informers
description: The Central Intelligence Agency today rescinded its seven-year-old guidelines requiring case officers in the field to obtain approval from top management before trying to recruit informers with questionable backgrounds, officials said.
