description: SCHACHTER - Ruth, 94. Passed away peacefully on July 18, 2002. Survived by her loving family, Barbara and Jerry Shefsky, grandchildren and great - grandchildren. Graveside services will be held Friday, July 19, 2002 at 2:00 P.M., at Mount Moriah Cemetery, in Fairview, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLMES, HENRY H.
description: HOLMES-Henry H. Beloved husband of Joan H. Holmes, loving father of Leslie Holmes Williams and Gordon W. Holmes, doting grandfather of Orli Van Mourik, died at home in Wilton, CT on July 17, 2002. Memorial service will be held at Wilton Congregational Church, on Sunday, July 21, at 11 A.M. Contributions to the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLIGHTLY, HENRY O.
description: GOLIGHTLY-Henry O. July 17, 2002. He is survived by his several Texas relatives, including Gene Richardson, Marilyn Bonner Lane, Maxine Jarrett, George and John Golightly. He headed the well-known consulting firm Golightly & Company International and served many leading US and foreign companies from offices in New York, London and Houston. Prior to founding Golightly International in 1960, Mr. Golightly was a Principal with McKinsey and Company. Memorial Service to be held Thursday, August 1, 11 AM, Christ Church United Methodist, 520 Park Avenue at 60th Street. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Just One Break Inc, 120 Wall Street, NY, NY 10025.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on July 3 about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's promotion of art in public places referred imprecisely to ''The Gates,'' a project proposed by the artist Christo and supported by the mayor. It would festoon 26 miles of Central Park's walkways in swatches of translucent saffron fabric supported by thousands of metal gates; it would not drape trees in the fabric.

title: Priest Is Pressed for Names in Pornography Case
description: After initially minimizing allegations of wrongdoing by an Episcopal pastor involved in a bitter dispute with leaders of his Manhattan parish, officials of the Episcopal Diocese of New York this week acknowledged the priest's criminal record and said he would be required to identify any other priests involved in producing child pornography.

title: Philip Morris Profit Up 14%, Helped by Foreign Sales
description: Despite a constant erosion in the national demand for its cigarettes, the Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that its profits grew 14 percent in the second quarter, primarily because its prices continue to climb and the appetite for American cigarettes remains particularly strong overseas.

title: Talks on Draft Go Nowhere
description: The amateur draft was the topic of discussion between representatives of the owners and the players yesterday, but they did not get too far in solving that element of their attempt to negotiate a new collective bargaining agreement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUFRO, SARA
description: SHUFRO-Sara. In her 95th year. Beloved wife of the late Jacob (Yock). Devoted mother of Joan and Paul Rosenblatt, Leslie and Bernard Friedman. Dear sister of Mary Kantrowitz and the late Irving, Lee, Ethel, Peggy and Ralph. Loving grandmother of Abram and Kathryn, David and Celia, Teri and John, Michael and Monica, David and Rachel. Adoring great grandmother of Michael, Kieran and Jane. Services Sunday, 1 PM, ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'', 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Mario Juruna, 58, Only Indian To Serve in Congress in Brazil
description: Mario Juruna, a chief of the Xavante Indians of central Brazil and the only Indian to serve in the Brazilian Congress, died on Tuesday in Braslia. He was 58.

title: Jordan Continues to Wait On Vacant Coaching Jobs
description: As Eddie Jordan waits to find out if he will be selected to coach an N.B.A. team, he has become concerned not only with his own ambitions, but also with the uncertainty in which he has left the Nets.

title: Bush Replacing AIDS Adviser Who Drew Fire
description: President Bush's top adviser on AIDS, an openly gay Republican who has rankled conservatives by advocating the use of condoms and supporting contentious AIDS prevention workshops, is being replaced, senior administration officials said today.

title: Residential Real Estate; Turning 23 Homes Into a Mansion
description: It's right there in Section 26-511(c)(9)(b) of the New York City Rent Stabilization Law: the owner of a rental building can claim ''one or more dwelling units for his or her own personal use.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOPOL, RUTH TEDI
description: TOPOL-Ruth Tedi. Mrs. E. Raymond Topol known to all as Tedi passed away Monday morning, July 15 2002. Tedi, wife of Dr. E. Raymond Topol, was known for her sense of humor and her love of life. She was a member of the Elmwood Country Club, a former president of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, and the Women's Tri County Golf Association. Tedi graduated from New York University and was named the most beautiful coed of NYU in 1941. Her brother Ed, daughter Jane and son John survive her. She will be deeply missed by her grandchildren Casey, William and Jason who lovingly called her Grandma Tedi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, MICHAEL A.
description: McCARTHY - Michael A., July 16, 2002. Son of the late Joseph W. & Mary Pellegrini McCarthy. Dear brother of Susan C. McCarthy. Cousin of William McCarthy. He was a partner of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, LLP., and was honored as a foremost benefactor of Cornell in 1993. Friends may call at the Schlager Funeral Home Inc., 4614 Main St., Snyder, NY, where the family will be present Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Prayers Monday, 10:30 AM. Mass 11 AM at St. Benedict's Church. If desired, memorials may be made to Father Baker's Home, 780 Ridge Road, Lackawanna, N.Y 14218.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Divided by a Call for a Common Language
description: One board member called the resolution the ''least significant document'' to cross his desk in a decade on the Brown County Board of Supervisors. Yet Nancy Nusbaum, the county executive, said it would most likely prompt her first veto in 15 years.

title: Case of the Missing Anthrax
description: It's bad enough that we can't find anthrax hidden in the Iraqi desert. But it turns out that we also misplaced anthrax and Ebola kept in a lab outside Washington D.C.

title: In Hometown of Slain Girl, a Veiled Fear Lurks
description: Motel pools here are enclosed by 10-foot iron fences. So are the preschool yards and McDonald's play areas that line Beach Boulevard. Cat flaps have latches that lock.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: 17 Die In Kashmir
description: Eight Indian soldiers and nine suspected Islamic militants were killed in a series of attacks and clashes in Kashmir Wednesday and yesterday in what Indian officials believe may signal a rise in violence in the disputed territory before state elections this fall. Security has been stepped up in anticipation of the annual Hindu pilgrimage to the Amarnath cave in the Himalayas, which begins today, and will draw tens of thousands of people to the area. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Large Scale
description: Baumgartner Gallery

title: Still Poor, Latin Americans Protest Push for Open Markets
description: The protest that shook this colonial city last month was very much like others in Latin America recently. There were Marxists shouting 60's-era slogans, and hard-bitten unionists. But there was also Fanny Puntaca, 64, a shopkeeper and grandmother of six.

description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Warns of More Belt Tightening
description: Just 18 days after his first budget took effect, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg called yesterday for city agencies to gird themselves for another round of cuts to make sure that the budget stays balanced and to save money to offset next year's deep deficit.

title: QUICK ESCAPES
description: Minneapolis

title: Car Gear: In Case of Emergency
description: YOU are heading toward your second home, or the idyllic retreat of generous hosts. You are driving on a road as desolate as a Bergman movie, thinking only of the carefree weekend ahead, when suddenly -- bam -- disaster strikes. The thump- thump-thump of a very flat tire. The spinning whir and then sudden stop as the battery goes dead. The hissing of steam from a leaking radiator. The possibilities -- and the frightening scenarios -- are endless.

title: WorldCom Bankruptcy Filing Is Said to Be Set for Next Week
description: WorldCom Inc. is planning to file for bankruptcy protection from its creditors by early next week, people briefed on the matter said last night.

title: START-UP CHIP MAKER LAYS OFF 40 % OF WORKERS
description: Transmeta, a start-up manufacturer of microprocessors , said yesterday that it is laying off 200 workers, or 40 percent of its work force. Transmeta, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it lost $35.6 million on sales of $7.5 million in the second quarter. The company went public two years ago, setting out to challenge Intel's dominance of microprocessors for personal computers with a novel power-saving design. But the company's prospects have dimmed in the last year. Its shares fell 12.5 percent, to close at $1.88 yesterday. Barnaby Feder (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: ECONOMY MAY BE STABILIZING

title: Pete Rose Makes Appearance
description: Say what you will about Pete Rose. That he might have disgraced the national pastime by betting on games. That he deserved the lifetime ban handed down nearly 13 years ago.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column yesterday about ''The Floral Art of Pierre-Joseph Redout,'' an exhibition at the Bruce Museum of Arts and Science in Greenwich, Conn., misidentified the Fort Worth museum that helped organize the show and will be its next home. It is the Kimbell Art Museum, not the Bruce Museum.

title: Enjoying Nature's Magic Act
description: One noon in late spring I went to the Lake in Central Park and rented a boat. I glided leisurely on the water. Mallards swam in pairs. Often little fish would jump. My oars made tiny whirlpools. The woods around me seemed 10,000 shades of green; wisps of clouds floated on a perfectly blue sky. Almost hidden in the rushes, I saw a pair of swans: the female purposefully gathered twigs for a nest, even as the male behind her appeared to be trying to mate.

title: Registration Lagging for Pope's Canada Visit
description: Organizers of World Youth Day, the gathering of international Roman Catholic youth, estimated last year that 750,000 people would attend the weeklong festivities this month, which will include a gala morning Mass attended by Pope John Paul II.

title: Shift at AOL Puts Time Warner at Helm
description: Robert W. Pittman, chief operating officer of AOL Time Warner, resigned under pressure yesterday in the most public repudiation yet of the promises behind the $165 billion merger of AOL and Time Warner.

title: For an S.U.V., A Leg Up
description: Running boards -- steps alongside a vehicle to help riders climb into the cabin -- were introduced on stagecoaches, adapted to horseless carriages and added to glamour cars of the 1930's, pickup trucks and hot rods of the 50's. Now, the Ford Motor Company has added power to this standby.

title: At the Guggenheim, Selected Short Subjects
description: Not bad for a stopgap measure. Forced by money woes to postpone the Kasimir Malevich exhibition until 2003, the Guggenheim Museum gave the slot to new art and invited a hot young designer-architect to orchestrate the installation. The result, ''Moving Pictures,'' is a lively exhibition of photographs, films, video and related installations from the museum's permanent collection.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Economy May Be Stabilizing
description: New York City's economy is showing signs of stabilizing, if not recovering, according to economic data released yesterday by state and city agencies. The unemployment rate, which had risen sharply over the last year, was unchanged in June at 8 percent, the New York State Department of Labor said. And while the total number of jobs in the city dropped last month because of a decline in government employment, private companies added about 1,500 employees, according to William C. Thompson Jr., the city comptroller. Both reports are adjusted for seasonal variations in employment. The city and state budget gaps will continue to hurt the outlook for government jobs, Mr. Thompson said in a statement. ''In the near future, to increase jobs we will have to rely on the private sector,'' he said. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Deadline for Explanation
description: Government lawyers have a week to explain why an American captured with Taliban fighters is being held without any charges filed against him, Judge Robert G. Doumar of Federal District Court ordered today. The detainee, Yasser Esam Hamdi, 21, was born in Louisiana. Justice Department lawyers say ''enemy combatants'' may be held without charges as long as the United States is at war. The judge indicated he thought that position, given the continuing battle against terrorism, meant Mr. Hamdi could be held forever.

title: Run Soviet, Run Deep: Testosterone Put to a Test
description: The latest evidence that the cold war has faded into history is ''K-19: The Widowmaker,'' in which Harrison Ford, the very embodiment of can-do American heroism -- Indiana Jones, Jack Ryan, the square-jawed action-hero commander in chief -- plays a Russian. Not just any Russian, mind you, but a high-ranking officer in the Soviet Navy who is willing to sacrifice everything -- his crew, his submarine, his own life -- in the service of the Motherland. Times sure have changed.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank's Profit Falls
description: France's biggest bank, BNP Paribas, said profit for the second quarter fell 13 percent, citing ''exceptional turbulences affecting financial markets.'' The bank rushed out partial results two weeks ahead of schedule and warned that it expected profit to fall to 1 billion euros ($1.01 billion) from 1.16 billion euros a year ago and revenue to fall 6 percent, to 4.1 billion euros. The bank, which is based in Paris, is expected to post losses because of its dealings with France Tlcom and Vivendi, which may not be able to repay their increasing debts. The group said it would release full second-quarter results Aug. 1.

title: Lincoln Center Festival 2002
description: Lincoln Center Festival 2002 runs through Aug. 1. Sites include Damrosch Park, Alice Tully Hall, the Walter Reade Theater, the Metropolitan Opera House and the Rose Building, all at Lincoln Center; John Jay College Theater, Amsterdam Avenue, between 58th and 59th Streets; and La Guardia Concert Hall, 65th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Tickets: $10 to $90. Free passes for symposiums at the Kaplan Penthouse in the Rose Building will be distributed an hour and a half before the events at the Avery Fisher Hall box office. Information: (212) 875-5928 or www.lincolncenter.org. Tickets: (212) 721-6500. (The schedule for the New York Video Festival, part of the Lincoln Center Festival, is on Page 5.) The schedule of the main Lincoln Center Festival events this weekend:

title: National Briefing | Plains: Kansas: Guilty Verdict In Libel Case
description: A Kansas City jury this week convicted the editor and the publisher of a weekly newspaper of criminal defamation. The verdict was the first of its kind against a newspaper in more than a quarter of a century, said Jeremy Feigelson, a New York libel lawyer. Observer Publications; David Carson, publisher of the weekly News Observer; and Edward H. Powers Jr., its editor, had published articles suggesting -- wrongly and maliciously, prosecutors said -- that Carol Marinovich, the mayor of the Unified Government of Wyandotte County, did not live in the county, as required by law. Felicity Barringer (NYT)

title: Jets Expand Their Reach
description: The Jets expanded their radio and television vistas yesterday by announcing that their radio broadcasts would be heard locally on WABC-AM and simulcast on ESPN radio.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PAN PACIFIC RETAIL PROPERTIES INC., Vista, Calif., a REIT which owns or has a stake in 111 properties in the Western U.S., said it had bought two grocery-anchored shopping centers in Southern California. The company paid $28.5 million for Larwin Square in Tustin and $18.6 million for Gordon Ranch Marketplace in Chino Hills.

title: Downtown Visions: Remembrance and Resolve; Master Builders
description: To the Editor:

title: Ball Used In Larsen's Series Gem Is for Sale
description: For nearly 46 years, Don Larsen held onto the final physical piece of evidence that he pitched a perfect game in the 1956 World Series: the ball he used to strike out Brooklyn's Dale Mitchell.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about talks in New York on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict misstated the title of Javier Solana, a European Union official who took part. He is the high representative for common foreign and security policy, not the national security chief. The article also misidentified the location of a bombing attack on a bus that coincided with the talks. It was near the Immanuel settlement in the West Bank, not inside Israel's pre-1967 borders.

title: Cordial Hearing for 2 S.E.C. Nominees
description: The Senate moved closer today to filling crucial vacancies at the top of the Securities and Exchange Commission, giving a warm reception to nominees for two of the four open seats as commissioners.

title: U.S. Defends Decision to Move Suspect in 'Dirty Bomb' Case
description: The government last night defended its decision to move Jose Padilla, the former Chicago gang member accused of plotting to explode a radioactive bomb in the United States, to a Navy brig in South Carolina.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNAN, JOSEPH L.
description: BRENNAN-Joseph L. On July 17, 2002. Beloved husband of Madeleine (nee Dee). Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends on Friday, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 61-40 Woodhaven Boulevard, Rego Park. Funeral Mass Saturday, at 10 AM, Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Forest Hills. Interment is in St. John's Cemetery.

title: Downtown Visions: Remembrance and Resolve; A Sense of Eternity
description: To the Editor:

title: Guggenheim Sampler
description: ''Insurrection!'' (2000) by Kara Walker, right, is part of ''Moving Pictures,'' an exhibition of photographs, films and videos by 55 contemporary artists at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Growth In Software
description: India's software industry continued to grow at a healthy pace despite the global technology slowdown and cutbacks by businesses after Sept. 11. Software revenue rose to $12.3 billion in the April 2001 to March 2002 period, according to the leading software industry trade body, the National Association of Software and Service Companies. Exports rose to $9.6 billion this year from $7.7 billion a year earlier. More than 60 percent of India's software exports are to North America. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLARD, LISELOTTE
description: MILLARD-Liselotte. July 15, 2002 in New York. We mourn the passing of Liselotte after a long and courageous fight. Her will to live has been an inspiration to us all. George and Marsha Crawford, stepdaughter; Dini, William and Charles von Mueffling, stepchildren; and Tatiana, step granddaughter. Services will be held Saturday, July 20th at Saint Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton at 12 Noon.

title: 9/11 Defendant In Guilty Plea; Judge Rejects It
description: Zacarias Moussaoui tried today to plead guilty to conspiring in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and acknowledged in court that he was a member of the Qaeda network, had joined in plans for terrorist acts and was loyal to Osama bin Laden.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Death Sentence For Blasphemy
description: A Pakistani Catholic who wrote letters questioning a central tenet of Islam was convicted of blasphemy and sentenced to death. The man, Anwar Kenneth, 45, had pleaded guilty in the northeastern city of Lahore to writing letters -- to Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations, among others -- saying that Muhammad was not the last prophet of God. Executions are not carried out in blasphemy cases in Pakistan, though Catholics say that the laws remain in force to harass Christians. The man's lawyers contend that he suffers from mental illness. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Pharmacists Mull Strike at Pathmark
description: Pharmacy workers at 47 Pathmark stores in New York City and four suburban counties may strike on Monday if they fail to get higher wages in current contract talks, union officials said yesterday.

title: S.E.C. Chairman Vows Vigorous Halliburton Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  Harvey L. Pitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, vowed today to conduct an aggressive examination of the accounting practices of Halliburton, the company once headed by Vice President Dick Cheney.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Offer Made To Withdraw Troops
description: The government offered to withdraw troops occupying the disputed islet of Perejil, claimed by Morocco, in exchange for guarantees that Morocco would not reoccupy the uninhabited rock. Neither country maintained a presence there before a dozen Moroccan gendarmes set up camp on the islet, some 200 yards from Morocco's northern coast, last week. Morocco, which described the Spanish action to evict the Moroccans on Tuesday as ''equivalent to a declaration of war'' did not respond publicly to the offer. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Next Step on Reform Bill
description: Negotiators from the House and Senate will meet on Friday morning to begin working out differences in their bills to overhaul accounting and corporate-behavior laws.

title: A Spiritual Trek for Salt in Tibet
description: Nothing beats a good trek movie. On Tuesday Zeitgeist is to release Ulrike Koch's documentary "The Saltmen of Tibet" on cassette and DVD. At the outset a song tells us that we are in the Kingdom of Ling, at the center of the world, a blue-turquoise place. Nomads are preparing to drive 160 yaks on a monthlong pilgrimage to Lake Tsentso to collect salt to trade for grain.

title: Viennese Tales From the Berkshire Woods
description: VIENNA in the Berkshires in the summertime sounds like a publicist's dream. And in a sense the series of cultural events called the Vienna Project, under way this summer in western Massachusetts, is exactly that. Nearly a dozen local museums, theaters and musical institutions are offering 20th-century Viennese fare, which means Strauss lieder, paintings of alpine landscapes and a ''Sound of Music'' singalong.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Victory For Gays And Lesbians
description: Gays and lesbians scored a legal victory when the Constitutional Court rejected a complaint by some conservative-governed states that argued that gay marriages contradicted family values enshrined in the Constitution. Under the law, which came into force last August, gays and lesbians are allowed to marry in state registry offices and share common surnames. Their relationships are officially called ''registered life partnerships'' rather than marriages and the law gives couples rights in areas like inheritance and health insurance. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: A Toy Metropolis Filled With Whiz-Bang Action
description: Although it's anybody's guess what E. B. White, the author of ''Stuart Little,'' would have made of Hollywood's franchising of his 1945 children's classic, I'm betting that he would have appreciated the scrupulous balance between 40's staidness and whiz-bang action that the director Rob Minkoff and his collaborators have brought to its two screen incarnations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, SYLVIA
description: KAPLAN-Sylvia. Died on July 18, 2002, at her home in Palm Beach, FL. She was 100 years old. Born in New York, she spent most of her life in New Jersey before moving to Florida 30 years ago. Sylvia was the greatly loved wife of the late Harold Kaplan for 68 years; the beloved mother of Harold, Jr. (Bud) and Ulla and of Irene and the late Erwin Leiwant; the cherished grandmother of Sherry and Barry Leiwant, Carol and Charles Leiwant, and Aurora and David Leiwant; and the adored great-grandmother of Sarah, Zachary, Molly, Elizabeth, Benjamin, Matthew, Isabella, and Olivia Leiwant. Sylvia inspired us all with her love of family and her generous devotion to her community. Her good humor, loving kindness, and sweet smile will long be remembered with love. Her life blessed us all. Funeral services private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory to the Israel Cancer Assoc-USA, 230 Royal Palm Way, Palm Beach, FL. 33480, would be appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday about a decision by Allied Domecq Spirits and Wines USA and BBDO Worldwide to stop working together on advertisements referred incorrectly at one point to the BBDO office involved. It is in Chicago, not New York.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: When a Crop Becomes King
description: Here in southern New England the corn is already waist high and growing so avidly you can almost hear the creak of stalk and leaf as the plants stretch toward the sun. The ears of sweet corn are just starting to show up on local farm stands, inaugurating one of the ceremonies of an American summer. These days the nation's nearly 80 million-acre field of corn rolls across the countryside like a second great lawn, but this wholesome, all-American image obscures a decidedly more dubious reality.

title: Diary of a Mad Hostess: Vacations From Scratch
description: LITTLE did I know, when my husband and I bought a weekend house in Easton, Conn., a decade ago, that God's little acreage would bring out my inner Martha Stewart. (Actually, on contemplation of the ImClone imbroglio, let's scratch the Martha comparison.) O.K., then, my inner Betty Crocker. (On second thought, scratch that, too. Betty traffics in convenience, in pastries made from a box, as unlikely an occurrence in my Connecticut kitchen as Lance Armstrong's relying on training wheels for the Tour de France.)

title: Downtown Visions: Remembrance and Resolve; Leaves of Grass
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Great Lodges, Life at a Slower Pace
description: I MADE it. I am standing on the summit known as Sky Top, high in New York's Shawangunk Mountains, and a dozen other sweating strangers -- my companions on a six-mile power hike on this warm summer morning -- are scrambling up the rocks behind me to marvel at a panoramic view of the Hudson Valley.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Waterbury: Driver In Crash Is Indicted
description: A grand jury in New York has indicted a Connecticut-based driver of a bus that veered off the highway and crashed near Rochester, N.Y., last month, killing five members of a Waterbury church group. The indictment of William Hovan, 49, of Trumbull, Conn., came after the grand jury heard testimony from some of the 45 passengers who were injured in the rollover crash. The indictment was sealed because Mr. Hovan had not yet been arrested, said District Attorney R. Michael Tantillo of Ontario County. The state police said Mr. Hovan, fatigued from extended periods of casino gambling, fell asleep as he drove three church groups back to Waterbury from Niagara Falls. Mr. Hovan denied falling asleep and blamed a road bump or blown tire. He will remain free until his arraignment in county court on July 30, when the charges will be unsealed. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Charter Revision Opponents Prepare to Battle Bloomberg
description: Opponents of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to make broad changes to the New York City Charter are mobilizing to stop the process, or, failing that, to defeat his proposals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENZWEIG, WILLIAM
description: ROSENZWEIG-William. On July 17, 2002. Resident of Florida for 20 years, formerly of Queens, NY. Beloved husband of the late Helen. Loving mother of Laura and Ardie, Mickey and Barbara. Cherished grandfather of Joshua, Melissa and Brett, Stacie and Steven. Dear brother of Howard, Eve Feinberg and Muriel Korn. Service Friday, 12:15 PM at ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: French Cyclist Ousted for Holding on to Team Car
description: PLATEAU DE BEILLE, France, July 19  In a series of penalties after the hard mountain stage in the Tour de France today, Jacky Durand, a French rider with fdjeux.com and a nonstop attacking rider, was ousted from the race for holding onto a team car during a climb.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Investigation Of Oil Company
description: S-Oil, Korea's third largest oil company, is the target of an investigation in which police have requested arrest warrants for five senior executives and said they were investigating five others. The police said the executives engaged in manipulation of stock prices and unfairly earned about $70 million. The company reported a net profit last year of more than $22 million, police said, when it actually lost about $6.5 million. The company in which Aramco, the Saudi company, holds a 35 percent stake, expressed confidence that ''a thorough investigation by authorities will find us innocent.''

title: Linden Mayor Is Fined for Ethics Violations
description: A state panel has found that the mayor of Linden, N.J., violated ethical rules for local officials by using his influence, if not his votes, to advance a waterfront trash transfer station in which his son-in-law had a financial interest.

title: Pair Accused of Posing as Doctors After Injections Injure 9 Patients
description: A couple has been charged with assault and performing medical treatments without a license, after two people who came to them to enhance the appearance of their skin suffered life-threatening infections and disfigurement, the authorities said.

title: Red Sox Keeping Wild Card In Mind
description: The blue T-shirts arrived at Yankee Stadium yesterday, in time for Mike Mussina's pivotal start against the Boston Red Sox tonight. The shirts say ''Moose'' -- Mussina's nickname -- across the chest in white capital letters with his number, 35, underneath. Since Mussina will oppose Pedro Martnez tonight, he was asked if he had ordered the shirts especially for facing the Red Sox.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Electoral Reform Approved
description: The lower house of Parliament approved a bill that would sharply reduce the longstanding disparity in the country's proportional representation voting system, which favors rural electoral districts. Under the plan, which requires approval by the upper house, the number of urban electoral districts where one vote is worth less than half that in the most sparsely populated districts would fall to 9 from 95. Critics of the current system say it helps perpetuate huge government subsidies for agriculture and rural development and impedes political reform. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Civil Service Union Puts Its Political Muscle Behind McCall
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall picked up the endorsement of a powerful union today in his quest for the governor's office: the Civil Service Employees Association.

title: Downtown Visions: Remembrance and Resolve; Beautiful Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: Child-Agency Troubles Rise for Gov. Bush
description: Pressure is mounting on Gov. Jeb Bush, from fellow Republicans as well as Democrats, to take drastic steps to overhaul Florida's troubled child welfare system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGLAR, HELEN
description: HAGLAR-Helen. Beloved wife of the late Raphael (Ralph), loving mother of Susan Cain, and Judith and Michael Schumacher, grandmother of Jennifer and Michael Block, Elizabeth Schumacher, Tracy and Stephen Foohey, David Cain, and Julie Cain. Great grandmother of Kimberly, Ryan, and Michael Foohey. Funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Friday, July 19th, at 11 A.M. Interment is to follow at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Search For Missing Girl
description: The police said last night that they are looking for a 2-year-old girl and the woman her mother left her with on Tuesday. The girl, Kenya Banks, was left at 8 a.m. at her home on West 27th Street in Coney Island with Sharon Cooper, 32, who the police described as a family friend. When the girl's mother, Elisa Owens, came to pick up the girl, Ms. Cooper and Kenya were missing and they have not been seen since, the authorities said. The police did not know what time the mother tried to pick up the little girl, Officer Louis Camacho said, but she reported Kenya missing early yesterday morning. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Bill to Prevent Errant Executions Gains in Senate
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today endorsed a bill that is meant to raise the quality of lawyers for indigent defendants in capital cases and make DNA testing more readily available to death-row inmates, thereby minimizing the chances that innocent people will be executed.

description: Just Dancing Into Character

title: Run Soviet, Run Deep
description: Harrison Ford, above right, and Liam Neeson are Soviet officers on a nuclear submarine in ''K-19: The Widowmaker,'' Kathryn Bigelow's cold war drama.

title: How Pitt Could Make Fraud Less Tempting
description: WHEN Republicans are demanding the kind of prison terms for accounting shenanigans that used to be reserved for drug dealers, you know you're seeing what a British prime minister once called ''the unacceptable face of capitalism.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GORDON, ALVIN J., M.D.
description: GORDON-Alvin J., M.D. Died on July 10, 2002 at age 87 after a short illness. A memorial service in his honor will be held on Monday, July 29 at 4 P.M. at the Mark Hotel, Madison Avenue at East 77th St. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Cardiovascular Institute, 1 Gustave L. Levy Place, Box 1030, New York, New York 10029.

title: Mexico to Close Once Celebrated Agency Aiding Mexican Immigrants in U.S.
description: President Vicente Fox, who has heralded some 18 million Mexican immigrants in the United States as ''national heroes,'' will close an office that had been specially created to represent their interests in the federal government, officials said.

title: Japanese Energy Drink Is in Need of a Boost
description: For four decades, Lipovitan D, the pep drink made by the Taisho Pharmaceutical Company, has been the pick-me-up of choice for legions of salarymen working late, partying hard or battling a hangover. Almost by itself, the elixir -- packed with vitamins, amino acids and a jolt of caffeine -- created an ''energy drink'' market now worth $1.7 billion in annual sales.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Aside from the young women wearing little black dresses or less, the first thing you notice at Jimmy's Downtown is a long, long bar on one side of a narrow, low-slung room, and an equally long leather banquette with boxy tables on the other. Get used to it, because even with dinner reservations, you may be waiting for your table in the loud, smoky lounge for quite a while.

title: CITIGROUP'S BIGGEST SHAREHOLDER, A SAUDI, BUYS MORE
description: Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia, the biggest shareholder of Citigroup Inc., bought $500 million of its stock, saying the shares are ''very tempting'' after losing 27 percent of their value this year. ''Citigroup is very cheap, too cheap at current prices,'' said the prince, the 45-year-old nephew of King Fahd. The prince first invested in Citigroup's predecessor, Citicorp, in 1991 when the bank was reeling from loan losses in Latin America and real estate. The investment is the second this year in Citigroup by Prince Walid. The prince said the value of his Citigroup holding now exceeds $10 billion, representing a stake of 5.2 percent based on yesterday's $36.93 share price.

title: Beyond Broken Promises
description: As the smoke lifts, it has become clear that the company that resulted from America Online's acquisition of Time Warner is very much like the old Time Warner. AOL Time Warner has strong brands but is dependent on the fickle advertising market. It has an experienced management, but one with a penchant for corporate infighting at Olympian levels.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Court Cancels Referendum
description: The State Supreme Court ruled that the Legislature had erred when it placed a measure on the Aug. 6 ballot asking Detroit voters if they want to elect City Council members by districts rather than at large. The court said the Legislature needed a two-thirds majority to place the proposal on the ballot. The House vote fell just short of the necessary votes. Jeremy W. Peters (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the questioning of an Indian movie star, Samyuktha Verma, and her family, after they aroused suspicions on a plane to New York, misstated the meaning of the term Bollywood. It refers to the flamboyant Hindi films made in Bombay, not to the entire Indian film industry. The article also referred imprecisely to Ms. Verma's Malayalam-language films, made in southern India. While in the style of Bollywood, they are not Bollywood films.

title: Albany No Longer a Secret In High-Tech Chip World
description: It sounded forced when, a few years ago, local officials took to calling the verdant Hudson River basin Tech Valley. More people scoffed at the nickname, and the strained boosterism it represented, than used it.

title: Rebuff for Shoe-Bomb Defendant
description: A federal judge denied a motion today to throw out statements made to investigators by Richard C. Reid, the man accused of trying to blow up a Paris-to-Miami flight with bombs hidden in his sneakers.

title: Sports of The Times; How Tiger Turned a 6 Into a 4
description: THIS was not the Black Course at Bethpage State Park, where the New York galleries at the United States Open last month put the word ''raucous'' into golf's vocabulary. This was the cathedral silence of the 131st British Open, especially here at Muirfield, where you can hear a tee drop on the grass.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Lawsuit Against Pirro Dismissed
description: A federal judge has dismissed claims against the Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, left, and other county officials filed by a woman who said that officials failed to carry out an order of protection before her ex-boyfriend shot her. The woman, Joy Thomas, 20, of Mount Vernon, was shot in the head on her way to class on Feb. 7, 2000, by Olonzo Davis, who then fatally shot himself. The judge, Colleen McMahon, found the county not liable under federal law and gave the other defendants, which include the city of Mount Vernon, 20 days to seek a similar dismissal. A state lawsuit against the county and Mount Vernon is pending. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: Robinson Almost Quit
description: Frank Robinson, his frustration growing over his team's losses and the attitude of some of his players, decided to quit as the Montreal Expos manager Tuesday night, then changed his mind the next day, a baseball official said yesterday.

title: SHOCK AT CHARGES ARABS WERE SOLD ISRAELI MUNITIONS
description: Israelis buried more victims of a Palestinian attack today as the nation grappled with police accusations that Jewish settlers had stolen army ammunition and sold it to Palestinians.

title: What They're Reading About in Moscow
description: The latest literary cause clbre in the making is exploding in Moscow, where the postmodernist writer Vladimir Sorokin was charged last week by prosecutors with writing an allegedly pornographic novel, ''Blue Lard.'' Accusations came first from Moving Together, a youth group with an aggressively conservative cultural agenda.

title: WITH TRAVEL RECOVERY SLOW, SABRE CUTS PROFIT FORECAST
description: The Sabre Holdings Corporation, the biggest travel-reservation company in the nation and owner of Travelocity.com, cut 2002 profit and revenue forecasts because of a slower-than-anticipated recovery in consumer travel. Profit will be $1.85 to $1.95 a share, down from an earlier forecast of $1.93 to $2.03, Sabre said. Revenue will be $2 billion to $2.1 billion, down from the $2.1 billion to $2.2 billion previously forecast. Its stock fell $4.05, or 14 percent, to $24.45 a share. Sabre said it would eliminate incentives paid to corporations that make reservations online through its GetThere business and to travel agents. Sabre also reported second-quarter results and said it earned $68 million, or 47 cents a share, up from $27.7 million, or 20 cents, a year earlier. Sales fell to $533 million from $582 million.

title: A Lab of Dying Mice, and a Virus in His Recipe Box
description: GUESTS take the sofa, the host gets the razorback chair: Dr. Eckard A. F. Wimmer insists on protocol, and since Dr. Wimmer is a scientist with a laboratory full of deadly pathogens, not to mention scads of dead or dying mice, best let him control the seating arrangement. It's his office.

description: Anton Kern Gallery

title: Forget Options. Where Do I Put My Coffee?
description: IT began so simply, almost as an afterthought. Back in the 1950's, the cup holder was nothing more than a slight indentation, barely discernible to the naked eye. In fact, most of these early incarnations didn't do a very good job of actually holding the cup in place; if the car lurched suddenly, a dose of hot coffee would likely end up in the passenger's lap.

title: If You Go, and the Dog Stays
description: LIKE children, animals present us with complicated relationships, deep dependence and non-negotiable needs. Also like children, they inflict searing guilt as their first and last line of defense when they think they are being denied some fabulous experience.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PHILIPPINES: AMERICANS THREATENED A militant group warned in a radio broadcast that it would attack Americans and United States' interests in the Philippines. The threat came from Abu Solaiman, a spokesman of the Abu Sayyaf group, which killed an American hostage last year and held two American missionaries until one was rescued last month while her husband was killed in the rescue effort.    Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: West Point-Style Scholarships Are Set for Maritime College
description: For years, officials at the small State University of New York Maritime College in the Bronx eyed West Point and the other federal military academies and wished that they, too, had a program under which government officials would nominate students and the government would pay their way through the college.

title: Nuclear Scientist, 70, a Folk Hero, Is Elected India's President
description: An exuberant and eccentric 70-year-old scientist who is considered the father of India's nuclear missile program was overwhelmingly elected president today by legislators.

title: Lloyd's Fate to be Determined Soon
description: Before the 2000 season Jeffrey Loria, the Montreal Expos owner, signed relief pitcher Graeme Lloyd as a free agent to a three-year, $9 million contract. It was considered a very good contract for the 35-year-old left-hander. But now Lloyd doesn't want to play for Loria and went before an arbitrator last Wednesday to challenge his trade last week to the Florida Marlins, the team Loria now owns.

title: Missing Girl, 2, Is Reunited With Mother
description: A 2-year-old Brooklyn girl who was reported missing on Thursday morning was reunited with her mother early yesterday, the police said.

title: Els Stands Out in a Crowd at the British Open
description: At the British Open, it is far from lonely at the top.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, GHITY
description: STERN-Ghity. Erica Jesselson and family are saddened by the passing of our life long friend, Ghity Stern. We fondly remember working with her, Luddy and Max on many good causes together. We will always remember her elegance & style. We extend our heartfelt wishes of condolence to the entire Lindenbaum & Stern family.

title: Reputed Leader of Greek Guerrillas Is Charged in Murders
description: A 58-year-old mathematician believed to be a ringleader of the guerrilla group November 17 was charged today with crimes including murders, bomb attacks and bank robberies carried out during the 1980's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHOON, JUDITH A.
description: CAHOON-Judith A. To have known her is to be enriched with the joys of life. Judy Cahoon, of Chappaqua, NY, died at home at the age of 58 on July 17, 2002. Judy was the beloved wife of Will Cahoon. She was born May 20, 1944, in Mineola, NY, to the late Marion and Ed Wunneke. A creative designer and writer, Judy had a long and successful career with Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline/Young & Rubicon and Reinke Graphics. A devoted wife, daughter, mother, grandmother and friend to many, we will miss her dearly. She is survived by her loving husband, Will Cahoon, and his five children; sister, Joan Weigand; one niece, and six grandsons. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Donations may be sent to Hospice Care of Westchester and Putnam.

title: Armstrong Adds to His Lead With Help From His Friends
description: Back in the familiar yellow jersey of the Tour de France's leader, Lance Armstrong took another major step today toward his fourth successive overall victory.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Chip Maker's Loss Narrows
description: Chartered Semiconductor Manufacturing Ltd., a leading maker of computer chips, said its second-quarter loss narrowed as demand rebounded. The stock fell as the company said the market recovery would be slower than it expected. The net loss was $90.7 million, or 65 cents for each American depository share, compared with a loss of $107.6 million, or 78 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 27 percent, to $127.5 million from $100.7 million a year earlier.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Yahoo's Profit Doubles
description: Yahoo Japan said profit nearly doubled in the April-June period as installations from the company's broadband Internet service grew. Yahoo, Japan's largest Internet portal, earned 2.2 billion yen ($18.9 million), 98 percent more than in the period a year ago. Sales more than doubled, thanks to income from a subsidiary, BB Technologies, which now has 660,000 subscribers for its high-speed Internet connections. Yahoo Japan is trying to reduce its reliance on advertising fees and now generates 35 percent of its revenue from selling broadband connections. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Merrill Shuts More Branches
description: Merrill Lynch & Company will shut five of its remaining eight retail branches in Japan as part of its global retrenchment. After the closings, the firm will maintain storefronts just in Tokyo, Osaka and Fukuoka. None of the 370 employees will be affected, nor will the asset management or investment management businesses. In the year that ended March 31, Merrill Lynch Japan's retail unit lost more than $500 million after shutting two dozen branches and laying off about three-quarters of its staff. The company said, however, that the operation probably turned a profit in the April-June period. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: More Illegal Botox-Like Injections Suspected
description: Inside their apartment on the East Side of Manhattan and in another in a two-story home in Queens, Iris and Eliezer Fernandez made grand promises -- youth, delivered in a series of injections -- and generally asked for only a small amount of cash in return, the authorities said. Men and women came to their door seeking fewer wrinkles, pouty lips, larger breasts.

title: U.S. to Punish 10 Businesses For Iran Sales
description: The Bush administration has imposed trade sanctions on nine Chinese companies and an Indian businessman that it says sold goods or technology to Iran, where they were put to use by that country's chemical and conventional weapons programs, administration officials said today.

description: INTERNATIONAL A2-6

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHANKER, BEATRICE
description: SHANKER - Beatrice. This would have been your 100th Birthday, my wonderful, precious Mother. You sacrificed so many years of your life taking care of me while I was bedridden. You found a surgeon to help me walk so I would not spend my life in a wheelchair. Beloved Mother, my husband and I tried to return your love and devotion by taking care of you in your frail years. I miss you every day of my life. My Mother, my dear friend, know that I love and treasure you alway

title: Israel Threatens to Deport Relatives of 2 Fugitive Militants
description: In a change of tactics, the Israeli Army today rounded up 21 male relatives of two fugitive Palestinian militants whom it blamed for attacks this week and threatened to deport them. The fugitives' houses were also destroyed.

description: To the Editor:

title: Mondesi Is Scheduled to Undergo Another Round of Testing
description: The Yankees will examine outfielder Raul Mondesi today to see for themselves what might have caused Mondesi's hospitalization Thursday night, the team doctor, Stuart Hershon, said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There hasn't been any news in the last 12 weeks that has made anybody feel confident. There is nothing that has made people say there is a great opportunity here.''

title: This Barge Is for the Birds: Terns' Return Ruffles Harbor
description: When Alan Dorfman tried to step aboard a 300-foot garbage barge in the New York Harbor about a month ago to inspect it for some planned repairs, he got a nasty surprise. Angry white birds with flaming red beaks, more than a hundred of them, swarmed around his head in a sudden, unprovoked attack.

title: Talk to the Man in Charge
description: Gov. George Pataki has been having a good year as he runs for a third term. His poll numbers are way up, his campaign bank account is extremely healthy, and he just announced a new computer research center that will be very good news for the Albany region. However, the most important test of Mr. Pataki's success as New York's governor will be what happens in the restoration of Lower Manhattan in the wake of Sept. 11. The buck stops at his desk. If ground zero becomes a spectacular public place, a soaring memorial, a thriving section of a thriving city, the governor will have earned a place in New York history. But if it winds up a colossal mess, that mess will have Mr. Pataki's name on it.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Senator Robert G. Torricelli's plan to appear before the Senate Ethics Committee to answer accusations of having accepted illegal gifts misidentified the forum where Richard Detore, former chief operating officer of the Cafaro Company, gave details about his claim that his company had charged expensive women's jewelry at Neiman Marcus for a friend of Mr. Torricelli's. It was in an interview with the newspaper Roll Call that Mr. Detore named the store and described the jewelry and its cost. It was not in his sworn testimony in an unrelated case before the House Ethics Committee, where he referred only to ''concerns I had heard in reference to a large purchase of an item on the Cafaro Company credit card for Mr. Torricelli's girlfriend.'' (The senator's spokeswoman has denied the allegations.)

title: Scutaro Replaces Injured McEwing
description: Bobby Valentine was having lunch today at the restaurant at the hotel where the Mets are staying, watching television, when a stranger came up and sat next to him.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Opposition Seeks Dialogue
description: ''Time and tide wait for no man,'' said the pro-democracy party led by Daw Aung San Suu Kyi in a statement. The party, the National League for Democracy, called for the opening of a dialogue with the government ''as soon as possible.'' The group appears to be seeking formal talks in addition to the private meetings Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi has been holding with top government officials since before her release from house arrest in May. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Bloomberg Pushes More Housing at Site
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took critical aim again yesterday at the recently released plans for the redevelopment of the World Trade Center site, saying that a significantly greater portion of whatever is built there should be devoted to housing.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend yesterday about the Vienna Project, a series of joint cultural endeavors in western Massachusetts this summer, misspelled the middle name of the curator of the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art in North Adams. She is Laura Steward Heon, not Stewart.

title: Transfusions Infect Two In Florida With H.I.V.
description: Two people have contracted H.I.V. infections from blood transfusions in Florida, the blood collection agency involved said yesterday.

title: Costs and Generic Competition Cut Into Merck's Quarterly Profit
description: Merck & Company said today that its second-quarter profit fell 3.6 percent as costs rose faster than sales, which were hurt by competition from generic copies of its hypertension and heartburn drugs.

title: McCain Assails W.B.C.'s Role
description: Senator John McCain, a vocal critic of the way boxing is run, issued a strongly worded letter today condemning the World Boxing Council for interfering in the process of choosing officials for Saturday's W.B.C. welterweight championship bout between Vernon Forrest and Shane Mosley.

description: The metropolitan Washington United Way, whose handling of donor funds is being investigated by a federal grand jury, is now without the business leader who was elected board president on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUFRO, SARA
description: SHUFRO-Sara. In her 95th year. Beloved wife of the late Jacob (Yock). Devoted mother of Joan and Paul Rosenblatt, Leslie and Bernard Friedman. Dear sister of Mary Kantrowitz and the late Irving, Lee, Ethel, Peggy and Ralph. Loving grandmother of Abram and Kathryn, David and Celia, Teri and John, Michael and Monica, David and Rachel. Adoring great grandmother of Michael, Kieran and Jane. Services Sunday, 1 PM, ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'', 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Editorial Notebook; More Than Just Sex and the City
description: The HBO show ''Sex and the City,'' the cable network's most popular comedy series, returns to the air tomorrow. Most people already know the story line: four women friends, New York City, lots of men, an abundance of sex and even more talk about it. The women are beautiful and successful and further benefit by comparison with the men they meet. The show has been described as raunchy and frank, but the truth is, ''Sex and the City'' is worth watching for anything but the sex. There is the city, with its share of postcard moments. There are the designer clothes and fabulous apartments, which by themselves can send the average New Yorker into a different kind of excited state.

title: 2 Pilots in Fatal Crash in Europe Saw Each Other as They Collided
description: The pilots of a Russian passenger jet and a cargo plane that crashed in the night sky above Germany this month, killing 71 people, saw each other in the last seconds before the collision and maneuvered to avoid a crash, German investigators said today.

title: Umpire's Injury Gives Mets a Break
description: Any day on which Pedro Astacio has pitched this season has usually been a good day for the Mets. Tonight was no different as the Mets beat the Cincinnati Reds, 4-2. But Astacio needed some help escaping the fifth inning, and he got it in the form of a fluke injury to home plate umpire Bill Miller an inning earlier.

title: The AOL Time Warner Shuffle
description: When President Bush declared on Monday that the nation was waking up with a hangover after the economic boom of the last decade, he could not have known how much more pain was on the way. By week's end the stock market had plunged a further 7 percent, reaching lows it had not seen since 1998. One of the week's biggest losers was AOL Time Warner, a company whose stock has been in virtual free fall all year. In an attempt to turn around its own flagging fortunes, AOL Time Warner announced a major management shake-up, designed to take the company in a new direction and undo the damage of a merger that now stands as one of the biggest blunders in corporate history.

title: Beliefs; As sainthood approaches for Juan Diego, some scholars call his story a ''pious fiction.''
description: On July 31, Pope John Paul II is scheduled to declare Juan Diego Cuauhtlahtoatzin, a humble Aztec better known simply as Juan Diego, to be a saint.

title: Insurance Adjuster Charged With Arson
description: A Trenton-area insurance adjuster and former investigator for the Mercer County prosecutor's office was indicted yesterday on charges that he masterminded an arson-for-profit ring. The state attorney general's office said the adjuster, Marc Rossi of Hamilton Township, netted nearly $500,000 from several fire insurance settlement claims.

title: The Jets Expand Their Reach
description: The Jets have expanded their radio and television vistas by announcing on Thursday that their radio broadcasts would be heard in the New York area on WABC-AM and simulcast on ESPN radio.

title: Mercedes Faces U.S. Inquiry on Possible Price Fixing
description: The Justice Department has begun a criminal investigation into accusations that Mercedes-Benz conspired with 27 dealers to fix prices in the metropolitan New York area, DaimlerChrysler, the parent of Mercedes, said yesterday.

title: New in SoHo: 'For Rent' Signs; Cartier, Saint Laurent and Other Retailers Move On
description: No baubles are displayed in Cartier's window on Prince Street in SoHo. Instead, a huge bright-red sign advises passers-by, ''Please Visit Our Other Locations.''

title: INSIDE
description: A New Tactic by Israel

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Resignations Over Trade Deal
description: Two executives in the administration of President Kim Dae Jung have been forced to resign over a dispute involving tariffs on garlic imports from China. The executives, Han Duk Soo, economic secretary, and Suh Kyu Yong, deputy agriculture minister, above, were forced to resign after disclosure of a secret agreement they made with China for ending tariffs on garlic imports effective next year. Under the agreement, China said it would not block the import of $500 million worth of mobile phones while South Korea said it would not stand in the way of $9 million of garlic imports. Park Sun Sook, a spokesman for Mr. Kim, said the government would devise measures to ensure the livelihood of the nation's half million garlic farmers, who were angered by the tariff deal. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Scientists and Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: Cars Can Get Much Cleaner
description: On Monday, Governor Gray Davis of California is expected to sign into law legislation to reduce greenhouse gas pollution, the prime contributor to global warming, from automobiles sold in California. Cars account for 40 percent of the greenhouse gas emissions in that state. Under the federal Clean Air Act, the other 49 states have the option of following suit, and California's example may well spur them to do so. The question now is: What will the car companies do?

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Favorites section on Tuesday about the F train of the New York subway misstated the elevated part of the train's route through Brooklyn to Coney Island. After emerging from underground after leaving the Carroll Street station, the train submerges again between the Seventh Avenue and Church Avenue stations. It does not run aboveground from Carroll Street all the way to Coney Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROTKI, CARL
description: KROTKI-Carl, 87. Beloved husband of the late Shirley, father of Saul Krotki and Isaac and Judith Putterman, devoted grandfather of Amanda Krotki, Chad and Jessica Haller, and Karen Putterman, great-grandfather of Leila. CPA, attorney, controller of Permag Corporation, and passionate bibliophile. Past president of the NY Mineralogical Club and for 14 years treasurer of the Eastern Federation of Gem and Mineral Societies. His library was a landmark resource for mineralogists the world over. Shiva through Wednesday at the Putterman home.

title: Losing My Stake in the Economy
description: I work operating industrial machinery at a paper mill that is owned by a global corporation. My mill was built in the 1920's, when the stock market was soaring, F. Scott Fitzgerald was writing about the rich and Babe Ruth was hitting home runs for the Yankees. I get paid by the hour and do not understand the markets. I do not belong to a country club or own a suit. I just want to work at the mill until I retire.

title: Alan Lomax, Who Raised Voice Of Folk Music in U.S., Dies at 87
description: Alan Lomax, the legendary collector of folk music who was the first to record towering figures like Leadbelly, Muddy Waters and Woody Guthrie, died yesterday at a nursing home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 87.

title: Chief Dismissed At Hydro One
description: Hydro One Inc., Canada's biggest power distribution company, dismissed its chief executive, Eleanor Clitheroe, today, saying she engaged in ''inappropriate behavior'' in repeatedly using company assets for personal gain.

title: Ex-Teacher Admits Sex Abuse of 3 Girls
description: A former science teacher and coach at a century-old private girls' school in Summit, N.J., pleaded guilty today to sexually assaulting three students in classrooms during the spring and fall of 2000.

title: A Gap Between Cultures Crying Out for a Bridge
description: Before children are martyred in the Iranian Ta'ziyeh dramas at the Lincoln Center Festival (the last performances are tonight and tomorrow night), they are stripped half naked. Villains then grab them from behind, lift them off the ground and slit their throats. The children's arms flail. Blood pours. Their bodies shake with spastic tremors and drop to the ground.

title: To Remain on Top, Yanks Need Mussina
description: Mike Mussina grew up and still lives in Montoursville, Pa., which is about four miles from the home of Little League Baseball in Williamsport. When Mussina was playing youth baseball, the thought of pitching in the Little League World Series was the most important thing in his cozy, uncomplicated world.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Clinton Library Seeks Tax Breaks
description: The nonprofit foundation supporting the development of Bill Clinton's presidential library has sued the State of Arkansas, accusing the state of withholding tax benefits that it gives to for-profit businesses. The foundation contends that the $200 million Clinton library complex will generate jobs and tourism that will add $10.7 million a year to the Arkansas economy. It is seeking $3.6 million in tax credits and rebates under a program created when Mr. Clinton was governor to retain business and attract investment. Jim Pickens, the official who heads the program, said the state did not believe that nonprofit organizations were eligible. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

title: Beef Processor's Parent No Stranger to Troubles
description: Running afoul of federal inspectors as they pick their way through meat plants is far from unheard of at ConAgra Foods Inc., one of the world's largest food companies.

title: Fierce Storms Wreak Havoc In Northeast
description: A wild system of thunderstorms whipped across the Northeast yesterday evening, knocking out power to nearly 90,000 people in the region around New York City and dumping as much as six inches of rain on far-flung suburbs.

title: If Media Is Really AOL's Oyster, Its Biggest Pearl Is Clearly HBO
description: The same day that Jeff Bewkes moved up to become the chief operating officer and chairman of the newly formed entertainment group at AOL Time Warner, HBO, the division that he formerly ran, was putting an exclamation point on its recent domination of television entertainment by racking up an industry-high 93 nominations for the Emmy Awards.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Jewish Restitution Talks
description: German and Jewish officials have finished a first round of talks on Berlin land seized by the Nazi regime before World War II. The property was owned by the Wertheim family, Jewish entrepreneurs who ran a grand department store near the Potsdamer Platz, now restored. Finance Ministry officials said the talks were exploratory and would resume early next month. The ministry said last week that it was suspending plans to appeal the compensation claims and would seek a settlement -- either a payment or return of the property, which is now worth more than $200 million. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEER, MORTON D.
description: BEER-Morton D. On July 18, 2002. Devoted son of the late Sam and Essie Beer. Beloved father of Mindy (Ron) Horowitz and Robert (Tracie) Beer. Adoring grandfather of Dari, Eric, Perri, Madison and Ryder. Loving brother to Sandy (Roger) Stern and proud uncle to Jordan, Andrew and Edward Stern. Graveside service Sunday, July 21st, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N.Y., at 1 PM.

title: Bloomberg And Pataki Share a Bond (Sometimes)
description: From the beginning, it seemed that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. George E. Pataki would transcend the institutional acrimony that has defined the relationship between New York State's most powerful leaders for decades.

title: Man Arrested in California Case Of Child's Abduction and Killing
description: A man who was acquitted of molesting two girls two years ago was arrested today in connection with the abduction and killing of Samantha Runnion, the 5-year-old girl whose abused body was left in a gruesome pose in the hills southeast of this suburban city.

description: GOODMAN-Barbara. We'll miss our best friend-the good times and laughter-we grieve for Kenny, Nicole and Eric. The Acard Family

title: Developer's Lawyer Denies Claim That Client Bought Jewelry for Torricelli
description: The lawyer for a real estate developer who has admitted bribing a Democratic congressman from Ohio said today that an allegation his client bought more than $100,000 in jewelry for Senator Robert G. Torricelli was ''totally unfounded.'' And a Justice Department official confirmed the lawyer's account that federal authorities had investigated the charge thoroughly and found no evidence it was true.

description: SANDERS-Karola on July 19, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Frank Sanders, and much beloved special aunt. Graveside service Monday, 11AM at Beth El Cemetery, NJ.

title: Dow below Sept. 11; Europe also dives : Stocks crumble amid new gloom
description: An infectious gloom gripped world stock markets Friday, as the Dow Jones industrial average plunged nearly 400 points, pushing decisively below its post-Sept. 11 lows for the first time.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Advertising Outlook
description: Europe's biggest commercial TV company, the RTL Group of Luxembourg, said that advertising revenue from Britain and the Netherlands would allow it to reach its financial targets for the year. It added, however, that the advertising market still looked bleak, with continued weakness predicted for the German TV market, the largest in Europe, and flat returns from France. The assurance from RTL's chief executive, Didier Bellens, comes after the company's core earnings fell 35 percent last year. RTL is controlled by the private German publishing company Bertelsmann.

title: Twellman Finds His Niche Closer to Home in M.L.S.
description: This may not quite be Taylor Twellman's dream season, his first in Major League Soccer, but it is a long way from his European nightmare.

title: 19 MILLION POUNDS OF MEAT RECALLED AFTER 19 FALL ILL
description: The Agriculture Department announced today a recall of 19 million pounds of ground beef that might be contaminated by the E. coli pathogen and that has found its way to grocery store shelves and home freezers around the country.

title: Chief of British Mortgage Bank Quits Under Pressure
description: Ian Harley, chief executive of Abbey National, one of Britain's largest mortgage lenders, resigned under pressure today, six weeks after he disclosed that a string of bad loans would sharply depress profits for the year.

title: In Party-Line Vote, House Panel Approves Security Dept.
description: Only the Republicans on a special House committee voted to create a new Department of Homeland Security tonight, after the panel's Democrats failed to get their way on a variety of issues, including protections for the department's workers. The party-line vote presages a similar struggle in the full House next week on an anti-terrorism agency once seen as nonpartisan.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SPAIN: AIRLINER ATTACK A Colombian jet carrying 144 passengers and 11 crew members was forced to make an emergency landing near Madrid after a drunken man wielding a box-cutter attacked an attendant during a flight from Bogota. The man, a Cuban-born Spaniard identified as Perfecto Manuel Vasquez Esposito, was arrested after Spanish soldiers stormed the aircraft, which had been diverted to the military airfield at Torrejon de Ardoz. The interior minister, Mariano Rajoy, called the incident "a case of public disturbance." Emma Daly (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Discount For Phone Shares
description: Ericsson, the Swedish mobile phone maker, said it would raise $3.3 billion by selling stock to existing investors as it fights to stem losses caused by a downward spiral of demand for mobile handsets and infrastructure. To persuade investors to put up more money, Ericsson was forced to discount the offering deeply. The company said it would sell shares at 3.80 kronor (41 cents), which is about a quarter of the closing price on Thursday, the day before the deal was announced. Ericsson also lowered its forecasts for industry sales and said the company would eliminate an additional 5,000 jobs, bringing the total job cuts to two-thirds of the work force.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, FREDI SCHIFF
description: LEVIN-Fredi Schiff. Artist and psychic medium, mother of John R. Levin and Nancy L. Retzlaff, resident of NYC and Provincetown, MA. died July 17th, 2002. Graduate of Columbus, OH College of Art and Design and studied at the Sorbonne in Paris with Ostrowski. Board member of the Columbus Gallery of Fine Arts, ordained minister with the Universalist Spiritualist Association and a Dame in the Knights of Malta. Visiting hours Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 at Beecher Funeral Home, Brewster, NY. Contributions to the Alzheimer's Association or your favorite charity.

description: Two good rounds of putting may be all that Tiger Woods needs to continue his Grand Slam run.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Official In Riot-Torn State Quits
description: The chief minister of Gujarat State in western India resigned, to force early elections widely anticipated as a referendum on the handling of recent sectarian riots. The minister, Narendra Modi, left, belongs to the governing Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, which also controls the national government. He has been accused of turning a blind eye to rampaging Hindu militants who killed hundreds of Muslim civilians last spring. National party leaders including Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee have stood by Mr. Modi, who will run again for chief minister. David Rohde (NYT)

description: Jacky Durand, a French rider with fdjeux.com and a nonstop attacking rider, was ousted from the Tour de France today for holding onto a team car during a climb.

title: Music of the Mideast In a 9/11 Response
description: It was encore time on Wednesday night at La Guardia High School, and the band was playing a funk vamp. The sweaty rocker onstage had his purple shirt half-unbuttoned as he swung his microphone on its cord and then bumped hips with a backup singer. But the singer, Malika Mahjoubi, was a hefty woman in a long green dress, a member of B'net Marrakech, a traditionalist Berber group from Morocco. And the rocker was Rachid Taha, a leader in this generation of Algerian rai singers.

title: Pentagon Pursues Leak of Anti-Iraq Plan
description: The Pentagon has opened an inquiry to determine who leaked a document outlining how the United States might attack Iraq to topple President Saddam Hussein, officials said today.

title: MARKET CONTINUES FOUR-MONTH ROUT; DOW PLUNGES 390
description: Stocks continued their plunge yesterday in a four-month rout that has sent the major indexes below their lows of last September and to levels that, if they hold, will make this the worst year for the market since the 1970's.

title: The Road to Perdition
description: Wagging the dog no longer cuts it. If the Bush administration wants to distract Americans from watching their 401(k)'s go down the toilet, it will have to unleash the whole kennel.

title: Schumacher close to tying once-invincible record : The Red Baron of auto racing
description: MAGNY-COURS, France:  When Michael Schumacher climbs out of the cockpit of his Ferrari after parking it on the starting grid before the French Grand Prix on Sunday, he will look, as usual, in that tense, anticipatory moment before the race, like the Red Baron preparing for another kill.

title: SOFTWARE MAKER FIRES CHIEF AND EXAMINES ITS BOOKS
description: HPL Technologies, a software maker, is investigating financial and accounting irregularities and has fired its chief executive, David Lepejian. The company, which is based in San Jose, Calif., said that a ''material amount'' of revenue may have been improperly recognized during one or more earlier periods. HPL informed the Securities and Exchange Commission of this possibility and said that no reliance should be placed on its previously issued financial statements. Elie Antoun, president and chief executive of the closely held MediaQ, has been elected chairman and will serve as interim chief executive, HPL said. The improperly recognized revenue was in connection with sales to an international distributor, HPL said. The company's stock fell 72 percent, to a low of $4 a share, before trading was halted.

title: G.O.P. LAWMAKERS BOLT BUSH'S HERD
description: Less than four months before the midterm elections, nervous rank-and-file Republicans are going their own way on issue after issue in Congress, fearful about the economy and no longer counting on President Bush's wartime approval ratings to carry them back into office.

title: DUPONT PHOTOMASKS EXPECTS WEAKER FIRST QUARTER
description: DuPont Photomasks Inc., a maker of equipment used to produce computer chips, expects fiscal first-quarter results to fall short of analysts' estimates. The shares fell 6.2 percent. Results in the quarter, which ends Sept. 30, will range from a loss of 20 cents a share to profit of 2 cents, the company said. DuPont Photomasks, which is based in Round Rock, Tex., was expected to earn 9 cents a share by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article yesterday about budget pressures that could lead to fare increases at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority misstated the view of analysts at the state comptroller's office. While they say a fare increase might be needed, they have not said an increase is inevitable.

title: PepsiCo Profits Rise 14%, but Revenue Disappoints Investors
description: PepsiCo Inc. posted a 14 percent increase in second-quarter earnings yesterday, but its stock tumbled more than 10 percent to a two-year low because the company missed its revenue expectations. The company linked the shortfall to overspending on its Frito-Lay brands and to volume losses at Tropicana.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: SWEDEN: DISCOUNT FOR PHONE SHARES Ericsson , the Swedish mobile phone maker, said it would raise $3.3 billion by selling stock to existing investors as it fights to stem losses caused by a downward spiral of demand for mobile handsets and infrastructure. title: Cavs' Miller Is a Tough Deal for the Knicks
description: Several officials in the National Basketball Association were surprised by Scott Layden's ability to bring Antonio McDyess to the Knicks on draft night. If Layden, the Knicks' president and general manager, is able to add to that success this summer by trading for the Cleveland Cavaliers' Andre Miller, his N.B.A. counterparts would be no less shocked.

title: Samsung Sings Happy Song As Profit Sets A Record
description: Technology companies elsewhere may be scrimping and suffering, but in South Korea, the second quarter was bountiful.
