title: Help for Working Parents
description: In a nation of 25 million working mothers, the competing pulls of family and work have never been greater. Where the job is a matter of economic necessity, child care is essential. But that does not erase fears over how it will affect the well-being of an infant. For every report that reassures parents, another casts doubt.

title: U.S. Inquiry And Lawsuit Draw Reaction Of Drug Maker
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that accusations made by a former worker at a factory in Puerto Rico have ''no connection'' to a recent spate of illnesses in patients using the drug produced at that factory. It also said that the factory had been inspected twice in the last year by health authorities, who found only minor problems.

title: Umps Oppose Computer That Tracks Their Calls
description: Last season it was ''hunt for strikes.'' This season it's QuesTec strikes.

title: Martnez Ensures Bad Night For Posada and the Yanks
description: It rained all over the Bronx for a few hours last night, but the skies eventually cleared. Jorge Posada might not have been able to tell the difference.

title: A Ballpark Where Yogurt and Fresh Fruit Vie With Tradition
description: In this city of gastronomic perfection, it was probably inevitable that organic tree-ripened peaches and white nectarines would storm the hallowed realm of peanuts and Cracker Jack.

title: Europeans Delay Sanctions In Battle Over U.S. Tariffs
description: The European Union stepped back from a potential trade war with Washington today by delaying a decision to impose sanctions on more than $300 million worth of United States products in retaliation for United States steel tariffs.

title: The Kirov Sparkles in a New Turn With Balanchine
description: ''Jewels,'' capped by an astonishingly magical performance by Svetlana Zakharova on Thursday night, is the latest work by George Balanchine to be performed by the Kirov Ballet in New York.

title: A Boyhood Friendship in a Divided Valley
description: The carnage from Palestinian suicide bombings in Tel Aviv and the ambush of a bus in the West Bank this week make hope for peace between Israel and the Palestinians seem impossible. Yet each outrage, followed by unending grief and fierce response, makes me think even more about a little dialogue I had long ago with a Palestinian neighbor of mine.

title: EX-OFFICERS' USE OF FUNDS IS UNDER INQUIRY AT SEITEL
description: Seitel Inc. said that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating whether two former executives wrongly obtained more than $4 million in company funds for personal use. Seitel, which is based in Houston and sells seismic data to oil companies, was notified of an informal inquiry by the agency's Fort Worth office, a spokesman, Joel Weiden, said. The company disclosed the possible misuse of funds in an internal investigation. Seitel is demanding that the former chief executive, Paul Frame, who quit last month, repay $2.6 million in bonuses and $750,000 in legal fees. The company has asked the former chief financial officer, Debra Valice, to repay ''unearned'' advances. Ms. Valice said she ''adamantly denies'' the accusations. Mr. Frame could not be reached for comment.

title: Chairman Defends Independence of Agency
description: Harvey L. Pitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, vowed today to examine aggressively the accounting practices of Halliburton, the company once led by Vice President Dick Cheney. But he also dismissed as a partisan diversion the calls to reopen an inquiry into President Bush's stock transactions at Harken Energy, where he once served as a director and consultant.

title: COAL PRODUCER SEES SMALLER PROFITS AND LESS DEMAND
description: The Peabody Energy Corporation, the nation's largest coal producer, said profits would be less than expected this year after cutting its output forecast because of weak demand from utilities. Profit this year will be $1.15 to $1.50 a share, down from an April forecast of $1.60 to $2, Peabody said. The company, which is based in St. Louis, will produce 180 million tons of coal this year, down from the 199 million it estimated in October. Peabody stock fell $2.80, or 12 percent, to $21.30 a share.

title: Indicted Lawyer Wants U.S. To Tell if Her Phone Is Tapped
description: Lawyers for a prominent New York lawyer charged with supporting terrorism asked a federal judge yesterday to order the government to disclose whether it was covertly monitoring their conversations with their client.

title: Pair Charged With Killing, Then Burning 7-Month-Old
description: A South Jersey couple are being held in Florida on charges that they fatally beat their 7-month-old boy, then burned the body in their fireplace, the authorities said today.

title: Constantine Leventis, 64, Businessman and Art Benefactor
description: Constantine Leventis, head of a London-based Greek Cypriot business dynasty and a major benefactor of Hellenic art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and other museums around the world, died on July 11 in London. He was 64.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIERMAN, MERWYN I.
description: FIERMAN-Merwyn I. All of us at Greiner-Maltz are terribly saddened by the loss of Mike, our dear friend and associate for over forty years. He was the consummate deal maker and an inspiring and dynamic force in our firm. We shall deeply miss his leadership, creativity and sense of humor. His absence will leave a permanent void in our hearts. We all extend our deepest condolences to his wife Mary and his children. Bill Greiner, Dick Maltz, John Maltz, Larry Reiff, and all the staff and associates at Greiner-Maltz Real Estate.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CONSECO INC., Carmel, Ind., an insurance and finance company, said it would sell its variable annuity business to privately held Inviva Inc., owner of the American Life Insurance Company of New York. Terms were not disclosed. The operation is one of six it plans to sell to pay down debt.

title: Making History Her Story, Too
description: As a historian, Gerda Lerner has learned to take the long view. It is a perspective that applies equally to her work and her life. At 82, Dr. Lerner is considered a godmother of women's history. Yet she certainly did not arrive on the scene as a full-blown feminist historian. As she recently set her table for lunch in her small brown house surrounded by trees here, she recalled years of contradictory realities: of being a housewife and a scholar, a victim of anti-Semitism and a powerful women's rights advocate, at times prosperous and at times poor.

title: Declarer Avoids Clever Trap In Summer Nationals Play
description: Both semifinals of the Grand National Teams played here today were clashes between the East Coast and the West Coast.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: YAHOO' S PROFIT DOUBLES Yahoo Japan said profit nearly doubled in the April-June period as installations from the company's broadband Internet service grew. Yahoo, Japan's largest Internet portal, earned 2.2 billion yen ($18.9 million), 98 percent more than in the period a year ago. Sales more than doubled, thanks to income from a subsidiary, BB Technologies, which now has 660,000 subscribers for its high-speed Internet connections. Yahoo Japan is trying to reduce its reliance on advertising fees and now generates 35 percent of its revenue from selling broadband connections. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Administration Promotes Effort on Homeless
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  The Bush administration outlined a $35 million plan today to help end chronic homelessness in the next decade, pledging services to people with addictions and disabilities who have lived on the street for more than a year.

title: Forrest Is Lean and Mean, and Ready
description: A tall fighter is not supposed to move the way the 6-foot-1 Vernon Forrest does, gliding effortlessly around the ring, beating smaller fighters to the punch, firing a heavy left jab and then bringing heavier mayhem with his right.

title: $12 Million Arrest Reported at Detroit Airport
description: Federal and local officials are investigating whether a man who was detained on Wednesday night at Detroit Metropolitan Airport after the authorities said they found $12 million worth of fraudulent checks in his luggage had any terrorist ties.

title: The Show Trial: A Larger Justice?
description: HANNAH ARENDT couldn't have imagined that her scathing critique of Adolf Eichmann's trial would echo 40 years later in the words of Slobodan Milosevic. But when Mr. Milosevic, the former Serb strongman, finally landed in the dock at the United Nations court in The Hague in February, he, like Arendt, charged the court with essentially holding a show trial.

title: His old bluntness isn't always welcome : Businessman makes waves as Seoul's newest mayor
description: SEOUL:  In the old days, Lee Myung Bak, as chairman of Hyundai Engineering and Construction Co., banged a fist on a desk, barked an order and got the job done. Nowadays as mayor of Seoul, he is learning the need for diplomacy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLIGHTLY, HENRY O.
description: GOLIGHTLY-Henry O. Just One Break (JOB) mourns the passing of Mr. Henry O. Golightly, our esteemed long-term Board member and friend. We extend our sincerest condolences to the Golightly family. Orin Lehman Chairman of the Board Board of Trustees, Business Advisory Committee & Staff of Just One Break

title: Bratton Seeks Chief's Post In Los Angeles Police Dept.
description: William J. Bratton, the former New York City police commissioner who clashed with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over credit for the record decline in crime during his two-year tenure, said yesterday that he had applied for the chief's job at the Los Angeles Police Department.

title: Bush Renews Pledge to Strike First to Counter Terror Threats
description: President Bush today used a visit to the troops that battled Al Qaeda fighters in Afghanistan to renew his vow that the United States will strike pre-emptively against countries developing weapons of mass destruction, telling 2,000 cheering troops that ''America must act against these terrible threats before they're fully formed.''

title: British Inquiry Finds Doctor Killed 215 of His Patients
description: Dr. Harold Shipman, the suburban family doctor convicted two years ago of murdering 15 of his patients, actually killed at least 215 of them, an official investigation reported today.

title: Power Failure Stops Subways At Rush Hour
description: A series of power failures that darkened a Lower Manhattan subway station late Thursday and early yesterday morning forced the shutdown of service on the A, C and E trains for several hours, snarling the morning rush for many commuters.

title: A Pops Concert by Masur (and Why Not?)
description: Protracted farewells are traditionally the province of opera singers, but as he has geared up to leave the directorship of the New York Philharmonic, Kurt Masur has become the Barry Bonds of goodbyes. After a string of farewells at the end of the season, a few weeks ago, Mr. Masur took the Philharmonic on a valedictory Asian tour, and on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, the Lincoln Center Festival gave Mr. Masur and his players an opportunity to celebrate Mr. Masur's 75th birthday, and to say goodbye again. As Beverly Sills put it when she introduced the concert, the performance was Mr. Masur's ''75th going-away birthday party,'' although she probably didn't mean it quite the way it sounds.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Blacklist Critique
description: The Committee to Protect Journalists, a New York-based advocacy group, condemned a round of tit-for-tat blacklisting of journalists that is the latest skirmish in a period of tense relations between Thailand and neighboring Myanmar, the former Burma. On June 28, Thailand barred entry to two Burmese journalists who had written vitriolic columns. On July 12, Myanmar responded by blacklisting 13 Thai journalists and a historian. Thailand has also banned foreign journalists and international aid groups from entering refugee camps along its border with Myanmar. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METCALF, NATALIE (IVES)
description: METCALF-Natalie (Ives). Of Boston, formerly of Reading, MA, July 16, 2002. Wife of the late Albion E. Metcalf. Mother of Karen Metcalf of New York, NY, and the late Albion E. Metcalf II. Loving grandmother of Meredith Thompson of Keene, NH, and Douglas E. Metcalf of Swanzey, NH. Also survived by five great-grandchildren. Sister of Barbara (Ives) Weeks of Southport, ME. A Funeral Service will be held Saturday, July 20, at 1:30 PM, at the Trinity Church, 206 Clarendon St., Boston. Relatives and friends invited to attend. There are no calling hours. Burial in Forest Glen Cemetery, Reading. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Mass General Hospital, Development & Major Gifts, 100 Charles River Plaza, 6th Floor, Boston, MA. 02114, or to the charity of one's choice. (For information, directions and Register Book, visit www.legacy.com.)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Modern Touchstone
description: To the Editor:

title: Lobbyists Still Pushing to Alter Corporate-Overhaul Bills
description: With so much momentum to overcome, lobbyists and corporate executives are not holding out much hope of substantially changing much in the accounting and corporate-governance overhaul legislation on Capitol Hill. But they are trying.

title: Nursing Homes Report a Loss
description: Beverly Enterprises said today that it had a second-quarter loss because patient-care liability costs rose, setting off a 40 percent decline in its share price.

title: Delay Likely for Shuttle Mission With Israeli
description: NASA officials said today that it was highly likely that the first shuttle mission to include an Israeli astronaut would have to be delayed until at least the end of the year.

title: National Briefing | Education: On Second Thought, No Second Thoughts
description: Closing a potential loophole in a new admissions policy by the National Association for College Admission Counseling, Harvard University said it would refuse to enroll any applicant who has been admitted to another institution with a binding early decision program. Harvard had initially said it was considering permitting an applicant who had made an early promise to attend another college to break that pledge if the applicant was also admitted to Harvard. Before the adoption of the new policy, someone who applied to a binding early program like Yale's was not permitted to apply to nonbinding programs like Harvard's. Jacques Steinberg (NYT)

title: Giants Sign Third-Round Pick
description: Tackle Jeff Hatch, the Giants' third-round draft pick, agreed to terms yesterday. And it appears the Giants may have at least six of their seven picks under contract when training camp opens in five days.

title: Evidence Against Suspect From 9/11 Is Called Weak
description: Since December, when the government indicted Zacarias Moussaoui as the first man charged in the Sept. 11 attacks, an unusual gulf has opened between what prosecutors have charged in court and what investigators are saying privately about what they can prove about him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONG, MARY T.
description: LONG-Mary T. On July 15, 2002. Retired employee of Chase Manhattan Bank. Loving sister of John, James, Norman, Josephine and Patricia, all of Ireland. Visiting hours Monday, July 22, 7-9 PM, Neufeld Funeral Home, 88-04 43rd Ave., Elmhurst. Mass and burial in Ireland.

title: One Woman's Story of Goings-On in Camelot
description: Camelot, shmamelot. Anyone still holding the belief that John F. Kennedy's White House years were some kind of golden age may feel less starry-eyed after viewing ''Power and Beauty,'' a film offered tomorrow on Showtime that gives us J.F.K. as seen by Judith Campbell Exner.

title: Abortion Rights Group Backs Torricelli
description: National abortion rights advocates will begin running a radio advertisement in New Jersey this weekend supporting Senator Robert G. Torricelli's re-election bid.

title: A Forum on Rebuilding Lower Manhattan
description: When more than 5,000 people gather today at the Javits Convention Center to talk about the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan, plenty of people, Gov. George E. Pataki among them, are likely to be listening closely.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Airliner Attack
description: A Colombian jet carrying 144 passengers and 11 crew members was forced to make an emergency landing near Madrid after a drunken man wielding a box-cutter attacked an attendant during a flight from Bogot. The man, a Cuban-born Spaniard identified as Perfecto Manuel Vsquez Esposito, was arrested after Spanish soldiers stormed the aircraft, which had been diverted to the military airfield at Torrejn de Ardoz. The interior minister, Mariano Rajoy, called the incident ''a case of public disturbance.'' Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Inside Liszt's Landscapes and Schumann's Fever Dreams
description: The International Keyboard Institute and Festival, at the Mannes College of Music, is now in its fourth year and has become a staple of the summer concert calendar. It has also taken its place in procession of institutes at Mannes that in recent years has started with weeks devoted to the guitar and to Beethoven, and continues with a vocal seminar. Its offerings include master classes, lectures, symposiums, a competition and concerts, all open to the public through July 28.

title: North Korea Ending Rationing, Diplomats Report
description: North Korea is transforming its Marxist economic policy to cope with chronic shortages, disease and starvation, according to reports reaching here.

title: S.E.C. Is Suffering From Nonbenign Neglect
description: At his debut appearance before the National Press Club today, Harvey L. Pitt proudly rattled off an impressive list of accomplishments in his first year as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, from the record number of cases and temporary restraining orders to his increased efforts to throw unfit officers and directors out of corporate boardrooms.

title: No Budging But Talks Are Still Productive
description: The subject was revenue sharing. Neither side made a new proposal or even budged from its long-held position. Yet representatives of both major league baseball's owners and players viewed yesterday's bargaining session as constructive.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about plans by Poland and Lithuania to impose border controls on Kaliningrad, a Russian enclave situated between them, referred incorrectly to NATO's proposed expansion, another issue that has irritated Russian officials. NATO already includes countries -- Poland and Norway -- that border on Russian territory. The proposed expansion, while including other countries that border Russia, would not bring NATO to Russia's border for the first time.

title: Tighter Rules For Options Fall Victim To Lobbying
description: For all the talk of corporate scandal, one leading proposal for change -- tightening the rules on stock options -- was brushed aside in Congress this week, thanks in part to a powerful business lobbying coalition that has long fought to protect these rich pay packages.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Moscow Official Wounded
description: A midlevel official in the city's property division was the second Moscow official in a month to be the victim of what the police are calling an assassination attempt. Two gunmen attacked the man, Aleksi Busalov, outside his apartment building in Moscow. He was reported to be in critical condition, with four bullet wounds. In June, Iosif Ordzhonokidze, a deputy mayor overseeing casinos and hotels, escaped injury when gunmen opened fire on his car. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, SEYMOUR
description: SOLOMON-Seymour. Beloved husband of Pearl Solomon, father of Susan Solomon (Paul Goldberger), Gail Cote (Robert Cote), and Carol Solomon, step-father of Andrew Chesler (Amanda Robb); grandfather of Adam Hirsh, Julia Cote, Matthew Cote, Daniel Cote, Rebecca Cote, Ben Goldberger, Alex Goldberger, Jake Solomon, and Daisy Chesler; brother of Mildred Gelbloom, and Maynard Solomon. Died on July 18, 2002, at his summer home in Lenox, MA. The founder of Vanguard Records, The Bach Guild and Omega Record Classics, he was a key figure in building the modern recording business. Seymour spent more than half a century recording the music he loved, and his devotion to quality set a standard that has not been surpassed. Services Monday, July 22, 11:45 AM at ''the Riverside'', 76 Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: U.S. Combs Indochina For Clues to the Missing
description: Three decades have passed, and often now the payoff is little more than a handful of what American investigators call ''possible osseous material.'' Sometimes they get lucky and find a tooth, the hardest and most durable bone in the body.

description: ERBER - Marcia. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Sigmund Erber. Loving mother of Bill and Ingrid, Susan and Abraham Sagiv, and Barry and Susan. title: Farmers in Short Supply at Farmers' Markets
description: Tony Mannetta does not worry about having enough customers at the hugely popular farmers' market in Union Square in Manhattan, or at most of the 27 other markets scattered across the city that he oversees for the Greenmarket program.

title: Madison Ave. Reconsidering Package Deals In Buying Ads
description: They say good things come in small packages, but does anything good come from ''one-stop shopping'' advertising packages?

title: Aleksandr I. Ginzburg, 65, Poet Who Challenged Soviet System
description: Aleksandr I. Ginzburg, a poet and a frequently jailed dissident in the Soviet Union who fought for human rights during the Khrushchev and Brezhnev eras, died yesterday in his adopted city of Paris. He was 65. No cause of death was given.

title: Sports of The Times; Don't Stretch A Course; Tighten It
description: JUDGING by what's happening at Muirfield in the 131st British Open, the Masters and the United States Open made a mistake this year in adding length for the sake of length.

title: A Former Deputy Mayor Emerges as Front-Runner for Schools Chancellor
description: Stanley Brezenoff, a former deputy mayor and city hospitals chief with a reputation as a skilled administrator and a troubleshooter, has emerged as a leading contender for the job of New York City schools chancellor.

title: Corrections
description: A grouping of biographical sketches yesterday for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's appointees to a new educational policy panel misstated a former title of one appointee, Dr. Augusta Souza Kappner. She was an assistant federal education secretary, not an assistant housing secretary. The sketches also misstated the location of El Museo del Barrio, where another appointee, Susana Torruella Leval, is director emeritus. It is in East Harlem, not the Bronx. The sketches also referred incorrectly to the tenure of Philip A. Berry, another appointee, as a trustee on the City University of New York Construction Fund. He still serves there.

title: State to Offer SUNY Maritime Scholarships
description: For years, officials at the small State University of New York Maritime College in the Bronx eyed West Point and the other federal military academies and wished that they, too, had a program under which government officials nominated students and the government paid their way through school.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Profit For Truckmaker
description: Scania, the truckmaker, said profit rose sharply in the second quarter, helped by cost-cutting at its European and Latin American operations and the sale of car distribution units. Second-quarter net income was 1.08 billion kronor ($117 million), including a one-time gain of 550 million kronor ($59.7 million) from the sale of the Din Bil and Svenska Volkswagen car-distribution companies in Sweden, Scania said. Sales fell 20 percent. The company said sales in South America, its largest market outside Europe, were particularly weak.

title: A Legacy of Misery
description: The American air campaign in Afghanistan has produced a pattern of mistakes that have killed hundreds of Afghan civilians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLARD, LISELOTTE
description: MILLARD-Liselotte. We extend deepest sympathies to the family of Liselotte Millard. We will all miss our elegant, esteemed, and caring friend. The President and Trustees of the American Associates of the Royal Academy Trust

title: Morning In New York
description: 5:30 A.M. Awakened by sounds of garbage truck and shouting sanitation workers. Sigh. Try to go back to sleep. Just about to drift off as car alarm goes off. Go to gym.

title: July 14-20: FRONT LINES; LINDH PLEA DEAL
description: John Walker Lindh, the Californian who was a soldier with the Taliban in Afghanistan, avoided a trial set to begin next month after he pleaded guilty to two felony charges and agreed to serve a 20-year sentence. Mr. Lindh, 21 years old, escaped the possibility of a life sentence in jail when prosecutors dropped several charges that accused him of conspiring to engage in terrorism and kill Americans. The government said the 20-year sentence was appropriately steep; Mr. Lindh's relatives said he would devote himself to studying Islam in prison. Neil A. Lewis

title: Investing; A Bet on Drugstores, If Not Drug Makers
description: DRUGSTORES expect a strong tail wind from an aging population that will take more pills. Like-minded investors see the sector as a handy way to invest in health care, a contrast to pharmaceuticals, an industry where uncertainties abound about new products and political pressures.

title: New Political Wisdom: Write If You Don't Find Work
description: It's not exactly good beach reading material, but the missives traded last week between Steve Asycue, a Democrat strategist, and any number of conservative Republicans provide some sinister subplots and descriptions vaguely akin to a dime-store novel. The subject: the relevance of the party's standard bearer in the last election, Bret Schundler.

description: REFLECTIONS AND SHADOWS

title: For Whom Is Bridge Toll? No One, Residents Say
description: If you build it, they might not come. Residents of the Rockaways are worried that the $3.50 round trip toll on the Cross Bay Veterans Memorial Bridge might keep customers away from the nearly 200,000 square feet of retail space that is planned for a redevelopment project scheduled to open in 2004.

title: Suicide Squeeze Play
description: Major League Baseball is on the verge of another meltdown. Given declining attendance, an aging fan base and reports of rampant steroid use, the last thing the game needs is a strike. Yet ballparks could well be shuttered by September if Bud Selig, the commissioner, and Donald Fehr, the head of the players' union, fail to resolve their differences. A walkout would jeopardize the playoffs, the World Series and what remains of the patience of baseball's long-suffering fans.

title: Sweet Equity: A Museum of Candy
description: DYLAN LAUREN, the 28-year-old co-owner of Dylan's Candy Bar on the Upper East Side, a shop known for 10-pound Hershey's bars and lollipops two feet in diameter, has not lost touch with the child within. She has a girlish way of speaking and pads around barefoot in an apartment filled with 100 toy rabbits. They come furry and large, furry and small. A three-foot-high rabbit topiary stands by a window, and a plaster White Rabbit clock ticks in the foyer. Family lore has it that the obsession began when she was 3, and her father, Ralph Lauren, gave her a pink rabbit. The First Bunny, 25 years old and raggedy, lives with 2,900 others of its kind in her parents' home in Manhattan, snuggled in her childhood bedroom -- an old-age home for bunnies.

title: Investing; Is the P/E Ratio Becoming Irrelevant?
description: IN the stock listings in many newspapers, only one calculated statistic appears next to the trading activity for every issue: the price-to-earnings ratio. But lately, an avalanche of earnings restatements has made the denominator of the ratio, earnings, a flimsy indicator of real money-making at a growing number of the country's biggest businesses -- tarnishing the ratio, too.

title: Midair Crash Opens Debate On Air Safety Over Europe
description: Europeans can drive from Stockholm to Seville without stopping at a border post or showing a passport. But if they fly across the Continent, their pilot must deal with a long succession of national air traffic authorities, some calling on different radio frequencies, as the plane streaks across the borders that divide the skies of one country from the next.

title: Debra Winkler, Erin McCann,
description: Debra Lynn Winkler, a daughter of Patricia and Stanley Winkler of Bridgewater, N.J., was married yesterday to Erin Bartlett McCann, the son of Irene Lape of Huntington, N.Y., and John Alan McCann of Cary, N.C. The Rev. Allen Abadines, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Shrine of St. Joseph in Stirling, N.J.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Boonton; Community With Deep Roots in the Past
description: IF you want to make connections in the town of Boonton,'' said Edward Marlatt, president of the Boonton Historical Society and Museum, ''join the Republican Party and the fire department.''

title: July 14-20: FRONT LINES; BUSH'S SECURITY BLUEPRINT
description: President Bush unveiled his strategy for domestic security, promising sweeping changes like the creation of a secret protection plan for the country's critical infrastructure and a legal review to see whether the military should operate more aggressively within the United States. While most of the dozens of goals are new, some were a surprise, like the creation of a national standard for state drivers' licenses, which critics fear could become a national identification card. Elizabeth Becker

After all, that now-infamous bubble popped more than two years ago, and the market has been struggling with a sluggish economy, myriad accounting scandals, and understandably weak-kneed investors ever since.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Condo Apartments Grow in Popularity in Suffolk
description: IT used to be that home buyers who came as far east as Suffolk County wanted their dream house to be detached and on its own plot of land. Later, attached town houses gradually gained acceptance, starting in the 1980's. Now, a combination of an aging population and the relentless upward spiral of house prices has made apartments, both rentals and condominiums, a growing alternative.

title: Family Planning
description: If the goal of this father was to teach his daughter something, I believe he succeeded. He taught her convenience over responsibility and coercion over support. He made a difficult choice for his daughter by making an easy one for himself.

description: WHILE politicians and even chief executives make righteous speeches and advocate tougher penalties for corporate misdeeds, Sister Patricia Daly is smiling. For three decades, she has been quietly forcing changes her own way. Or perhaps not so quietly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, LEON
description: HERMAN-Leon. Artist, psychotherapist, photographer, theatre director, Korean War veteran, builder, farmer, teacher, columnist, citizen of the world, native New Yorker, loving husband, father and grandfather. Died of a heart attack on Saturday, July 6 at his beach home in Cape Hatteras, N.C. at age 72. Survived by his wife, and loving lifelong companion of 48 years, Cheryl, his brother Murray and sister Edith Deutsch both of New York City, his sons Steven and Phillip, his daughters Dominique and Andrea and his granddaughter Zoe. The funeral was on Monday, July 8 at Beth Shalom Cemetery in Florida, N.Y. where he is buried beside his son Daniel who died in 1989. An abstract expressionist oil painter and landscape watercolorist, he began painting at age 18 and studied summers at the Art Student's League. A lifelong love affair with ''the city'' revealed itself in his paintings and photographic works. His education began at Adelphi University, B.A. 1950, Cornell University, Master's in City Planning at the College of Architecture, 1953, Ph.d. candidate at University of Aix-Marsailles, France, 1959-60, Regents Certificate from Washington Square Institute for Psychoanalytic Psychotherapy 1970 and Postgraduate Center for Mental Health, 1973. In the 1960s he directed and produced an Equity summer stock theatre, the Warwick Playhouse, in a converted barn on their 100 acre farm in Warwick, N.Y. for five years. He was a program director and consultant at Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminally Insane and, later, Director of the Goshen Secure Center for Boys in 1974-5. He conducted an extensive private psychotherapy practice in New York City and Orange County, N.Y. for 25 years. During retirement in N.C., he wrote a weekly newspaper Psychotherapy - Problem Solving column called ''Brief Encounter'', which appeared in the Outer Banks Sentinal of Nags Head, N.C. and the St. John's Evening Telegram of St. John's Newfoundland for 2-3 years. In the last decade or two of his life, he and his wife, who were living in an oceanfront house on the outer banks of N.C. which he designed and built himself as a hurricaine - proof structure, would travel abroad most often to Greece and the Mediterranen. While traveling he would do watercolors and photographs of the scenes he loved and the people he met. A uniquely devoted, loving husband and father, he thought always about and for the family. He lived and died in the bosom of his family and their love and thoughts will always follow him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, GHITY LINDENBAUM
description: STERN-Ghity Lindenbaum. The organization's request, also presented to the state attorney general's office, seeks the names of any people or documents involved in the governor's decision. Paul Aronsohn, Mr. McGreevey's spokesman, said the governor remained committed to his executive order. John Holl

title: QUICK BITE/Wall Township; The Skates Are Gone, but a Drive-In Rolls On
description: The movie ''American Graffiti'' is itself an oldie, released in 1973. The movie reached a few years further back, to 1962, when a date meant cheeseburgers and malts served curbside by a waitress on roller skates. But there is no need for manufactured nostalgia, as the real thing is still there, at the Circus on Route 35 in Wall, a few miles inland from Spring Lake. It has been owned since its founding in 1954 (as shown here) by Richard Friedel and his wife, Barbara. The food is fast, but it is cooked to order with top-notch ingredients: real roast beef, soft-shell crabs from Maryland ($7.59, served on a soft roll). All baking is done by Barbara Friedel, who says that her chocolate cream pie and fudge cake (both are $2.79 a slice) are the two most popular desserts. From the classic cheesesteak on garlic bread ($4.39) to a club sandwich made with the Jersey classic, pork roll ($4.39), there is something for everyone on this menu; if your children cannot find something to eat here, you are in trouble. Don't drive away without sampling the onion rings ($2.89). They are crispy, greasy, salty and real, not the onion-flavored Styrofoam rings found most places. On a busy summer weekend the Circus crew slices up more than 200 pounds of Spanish onions each day. The only disappointment with the dining experience here may be with your waitress's footwear: no wheels, just ordinary white sneakers. ''Girls on skates lose more food than they serve,'' Mr. Friedel said. Even so, your food will be served on an orange wire tray hooked over the driver's side window; it's fun to dine this way at least once a decade. Beverly Savage

title: Looking for Your 15 Minutes? All You Need Is Infidelity
description: AS anyone familiar with the collected works of Frank Sinatra can tell you, the very best time to reflect on love gone wrong is at a quarter to three, when there's no one in the place except for you and Joe the bartender. But should you be doing your drinking at two a.m. on a Thursday night in New York, in a joint with a television at the end of the bar, you might consider asking Joe to switch to Channel 9, where you can watch ''Cheaters,'' a nightmare version of ''Candid Camera'' in which private detectives armed with video gear burst in on unsuspecting men and women who are cheating on their significant others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBMAN, SIDNEY
description: LEIBMAN-Sidney. Age 92, on July 15, 2002, after a brief illness. Dearly beloved husband of Frances Moskin Leibman for 56 years and uncle of many. He was born in New York City, February 23, 1910, graduated from Syracuse University and the Harvard University Law School, and, as a captain in the United States Army, commanded a Signal Corps company attached to the Air Force in the European Theater of Operations during World War II.

title: July 14-20: NATIONAL; VERDICT IN LOUIMA CASE
description: A federal court jury in Brooklyn convicted a former police officer, Charles Schwarz, of perjury in the Abner Louima torture case. But the jurors said they could not reach a verdict on another perjury count and two civil rights charges that asserted Mr. Schwarz assisted another officer, Justin A. Volpe, in sodomizing Mr. Louima with a broken broomstick in 1997. It was the third trial for Mr. Schwarz, whose two prior convictions were overturned on appeal. William Glaberson

description: NANCY HALL-DUNCAN, the art curator at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, says by way of introduction to her savvy, rich and often sexy historical survey ''The Great American Nude'' that the nude has been a ''constant and enduring theme despite our country's Puritan beginnings.''

Director of several biotech boards. Beloved husband of Bonnie J. Grant. Loving father of Glenn, Bruce Scott and grandfather of four grandchildren and two step grandchildren. Interment private. Memorial service October 5th, 2 PM, at Fifth Ave. Presbyterian Church, 5th Ave. at 55th St., NY, NY 10019. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Church.

title: Articulated Buses Keep Rumbling, Despite a Litany of Complaints

To the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, they are a cost-effective answer to the city's increasing load of mass transit users. Two years of hearings, meetings, petitions and studies have failed to resolve that difference of opinion.

title: July 14-20: FRONT LINES; 4 GUILTY IN PEARL CASE
description: A Pakistani anti-terrorism court sentenced to death Ahmed Omar Sheikh for his role in organizing the kidnapping and murder of The Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl. Three other men convicted for taking part in the kidnapping were given life terms. Mr. Pearl, 38, disappeared on Jan. 23 while reporting on Islamic extremist groups, and a videotape delivered to American diplomats showed his murder. DNA testing confirmed that a body found in Karachi in May was that of Mr. Pearl. Dexter Filkins

description: Armando Benitez, the Mets' closer, stood on the mound, his face glazed with sweat. He was glassy-eyed after surrendering a home run on the first pitch he threw tonight and putting the tying run on with two out in the ninth inning on his glaring throwing error.

title: Explosion at Transformer Cuts Power to Lower Manhattan
description: An electrical transformer at a Consolidated Edison plant on the East River exploded in flames yesterday, knocking out power for nearly eight hours to a large swath of Lower Manhattan. Before electricity was restored early last night, about 63,500 customers were left without lights, air-conditioning and refrigeration on a warm summer day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEIDRINGHAUS, CHARLES

description: GRONOWETTER - Adeline. Died peacefully on Thursday, July 18, 2002, at the age of 91. Loving wife of the late Frank Gronowetter. Mother of Arlene, Rita and son-in-law Fred. Grandmother of Debbie Edelstein, and the late David Silberman. Greatgrandmother of Alex, Spencer and Danielle. Sister of Hazel Wallock, and the late Estelle Siegel. Her sweet, kind and gentle way will always be remembered.

Survived by children JoAnn Baum, Nancy Austin and Richard Blumberg, grandchildren Elizabeth, Gary, Elana and Erica, and greatgrandson Milo. Graveside service at Union Field Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY, Monday, July 22, at 10:30 AM.

title: Corrections
description: A restaurant review of Saigon Republic in Englewood on July 7 referred incorrectly to wheelchair access. The dining room is two steps up from the sidewalk; everything is not on one level.

title: Toronto
description: In the 19th century, when the city was a staunch outpost of Empire, it was known as Toronto the Good. Churches occupied a remarkable number of corners, and Sunday restrictions were serious. As recently as the 1960's, curtains were drawn on Eatons department store windows on Sunday, so no one would covet worldly goods on the Sabbath.

description: IF I must fly, I prefer to fly out of the smallest and closest airport that I can find. This usually means Islip's MacArthur.

description: BROWNE-Maura I. On July 18, 2002. Beloved daughter of the late Peter and Mary. Cherished sister of Sheila, Robert and Peter. Beloved aunt to all her nieces and nephews. Extraordinary friend. A memorial mass will be said at 11AM, August 24th at Saint Joseph's Church of Yorkville, 404 East 87th Street, NYC. We miss you, Maura.

title: Dew Point
In a Jittery Downtown, Fears Rise as Power Fails
description: Nick Clemente was in the bathroom, combing his hair. His wife, Stacey Mayer, was in the living room of their West Village apartment, looking for her sunglasses. Suddenly the lights went out. It seemed like a minor enough matter, perhaps a short circuit. But then the two looked out a window and saw in the distance a thick black plume of smoke rising into the sky.

title: Florida on the Gulf
description: Abbott Resorts, with over 3,000 rental units on the northwestern coast of Florida from Pensacola to Panama City, has rates of $86 a night in a one-bedroom condo in Destin Aug. 10 to Sept. 1, with a three-night minimum. It's $119 a night before Aug. 10. Guests arriving on Sunday, Monday or Tuesday save 20 percent on minimum three-night stays through September at other Abbott properties. Restrictions apply; (866) 478-3307 or www.abbott-resorts.com .

title: More Binds Jews Than Divides Them
description: Five years ago, my husband and I were members of Rabbi Waxman's tour of Israel to mark his 50th year on the pulpit. This was not the usual trip. He set out to create, to educate, to make us aware of much of our heritage that we were not familiar with. We all live under the same sky, but each one's horizon is different. Yet he brought our group together in a very personal way.

title: July 14-20: ECONOMY; A ROCKY MARRIAGE
description: In a boardroom shakeup that seemed to signal the trumping of the new media by the old, the chief operating officer of AOL Time Warner resigned under pressure. The departure of Robert W. Pittman, 48, left the company largely in the hands of executives of Time Warner's media businesses, and was seen as a repudiation of the promises behind the $165 billion acquisition of Time Warner by American Online.

title: Burke Adds Center in Purchase For Sports Medicine
description: The Burke Rehabilitation Hospital in White Plains, Westchester County's only free-standing convalescence center, has added another center to its network. On July 9, the Burke Rehabilitation and Sports Center opened in Purchase.

title: INVESTING WITH/Jeffrey L. Rippey and Kurt M. Havnaer; Columbia High Yield Fund
description: THE difference in yields between junk bonds and United States Treasury securities has grown wider -- sometimes to eight percentage points or more. But that does not mean that all junk bonds are necessarily bargains, say Jeffrey L. Rippey and Kurt M. Havnaer, the co-managers of the $415 million Columbia High Yield fund.

title: All the Ingredients
description: YOU might think the many-splendored, many-hued streets of grand old Cape May couldn't hold a single extra high-end restaurant. Harry A. Gleason evidently thought so. When he decided to leave his family's restaurant outside of Philadelphia a few years ago and put down stakes in the resort that calls itself ''the restaurant capital of New Jersey,'' he searched and searched before coming to rest in a sprawling mansion at a crossroads in the next town.

title: The Best Way to Spread the Wealth
description: One popular solution to the current crisis of corporate crime is to fix the accounting rules for stock options. Force companies to count those whopping stock option packages as expenses when they are granted, many say, and the fraud will recede. I wish it were that easy.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Other Dolly Parton, The Songwriting One
description: MENTION Dolly Parton's name, and images of her blond bouffant, her hourglass figure and her glitzy wardrobe leap to the minds of most people. Some might also think of Ms. Parton's silvery soprano, her movie and television roles, even Dollywood, her theme park in the Great Smoky Mountains. Few people, though, will give much thought to what is perhaps Ms. Parton's greatest gift -- her songwriting, a legacy that's long been obscured by her flashier attributes.

title: Test Flight Advances Plan for Regular Inter-Korean Air Link
description: A North Korean passenger jet flew today from North Korea to South Korea and then back to the North in a flight that may portend the first regular inter-Korean passenger service, as well as a step forward in the arduous process of dialogue between the North and the South.

title: Riverside Minister Faces an Internal Challenge, Again
description: Ten years after weathering a challenge to his leadership, the senior minister of Riverside Church is looking forward, his optimism unchecked by another attack on his stewardship.

title: Britain Tries To Ease Enmity Over Kashmir
description: The British foreign secretary, Jack Straw, came here today and to India for talks aimed at containing a recent rise in tension over the disputed region of Kashmir, and he said afterward that he was ''happy'' with discussions so far.

title: The Decibel Level Rises Over Off-Road Vehicles
description: THE midsummer whine comes not from mosquitoes, but from the angry buzzing of hundreds of two-stroke engines filling the air.

title: China Again Wins a Match Against the U.S. Team
description: For the second time, the United States-China Chess Summit Match has been decided in favor of the Chinese. In this year's running of the series, held in Shanghai, July 10 to 15, their winning score was 20 1/2-19 1/2. Last year when the match was in Seattle, Team China won by 21-19.

title: Collecting Matches
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Those Tiny Soaps? Memories, My Dear,'' by Debra A. Klein (June 9): Just a note of warning to those who collect match books. I had the good fortune of accompanying my husband on many business trips to the Far East. I had the greatest collection of unusual match books from some of the most exotic places.

description: There was a time when Omar Abahira, a Palestinian from the West Bank, earned a decent living in Israel, putting up poles and cables for the Israeli telephone company, Bezek.

title: Gehry Sculpture Atop Museum Gets Six-Year Reprieve
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission has voted unanimously to allow the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum to keep an undulating titanium sculpture by Frank Gehry on its roof for six more years.

title: An American Face, Rough Edges and All
description: FRANCE has a face -- an official, government-sanctioned face. It belongs to a young woman known as Marianne, who, in the form of a plaster bust, adorns most of the country's city halls and law courts. She is the personification of the French Republic, and she changes to suit the times. In the last 30 years, she has been modeled successively on Brigitte Bardot, Catherine Deneuve and the model Ins de la Fressange. Today, she has the features of Laetitia Casta, a model and aspiring movie star.

title: Gold Standard
description: The style that -- Gurmit, a jewelry designer, calls her own reflects her life's journey. Born in Singapore, where she studied art, Gurmit moved to Brussels at 19 to escape an arranged marriage, worked as an international runway model and finally settled in New York, where she began designing jewelry that is as organic as her look.

title: More People Are Flying But Short Routes Suffer
description: THE number of passengers flying on airline routes in the United States -- particularly long-haul flights -- continues to rise from the depths that it reached in the months following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, but short-haul routes continue to suffer. Many people, particularly business travelers, are unwilling to risk long lines at check-in counters or security scanners for quick flights, airline officials say. Some are simply skipping trips, while others are driving or taking trains.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Enjoying The Stars, On Screen And Off
description: Cars kicked up dust from the gravel road to the ticket booth at the Overlook Drive-In movie theater in LaGrange, N.Y. They drove at the pace of the summer evening around the field, where families placed coolers, lounge chairs and back seats from their minivans by their cars for the double feature: ''Crocodile Hunter: Collision Course'' and ''Men in Black II.''

description: JAMES CANFIELD has his own way of doing everything -- even quitting.

title: Music That Switches Its Gaze, From Future to Past
description: MUSICAL scores are not monuments fixed for all time. They behave more like living beings, constantly in change, revealing new facets of themselves not only because of what fresh performers bring to them but also by virtue of their inner potential. As conditions around them alter, so they adapt.

title: She Walks Through Walls
description: Every day at 3:30 a.m., Mary Jo Copeland gets up and goes to church. St. Alphonsus in Brooklyn Center, Minn., isn't open, but Copeland has a key, and she lets herself in, lights a candle and begins her daily two-and-a-half-hour prayer regimen. She prays to the Virgin Mary, does the Stations of the Cross and power-walks around the abbey as she says the rosary. When she turns to the Liturgy of the Hours, Copeland adds the Office of Readings because she's too busy to recite it at midday. ''It's a very special grace I've been given,'' she says. ''I wake up running to God.''

title: POSTINGS: A Switch to 280 Broadway, at Chambers; Buildings Dept. Moving Offices
description: The city's Department of Buildings is moving its headquarters -- including its executive office at 60 Hudson Street in Manhattan and its Enforcement Unit at Metrotech in Brooklyn -- in two shifts in the next two weeks to 280 Broadway, a newly renovated landmark structure known as the Sun Building, for the newspaper that was published there until 1950. The department is to occupy floors three to seven.

description: Erika Moo-En Lam and Joel John Radtke were married yesterday by the Rev. Blane Ellsworth, a minister of the Acceptance Fellowship, at Hans Fahden Vineyards in Calistoga, Calif.

description: Emerging from the Pyrenees with a snug if not overwhelming lead in the Tour de France, Lance Armstrong said he was happy with the way the race has unfolded but that his opposition was strong and there might be some tough times ahead.

description: THESE are tough times for the travel industry. Concerns about the stock market, the economy and potential terrorism have led many people to rethink or even forgo their travel plans, leaving some airlines, hotels, cruise lines and tour operators scrambling to fill vacancies.

description: No pro football team gained a quicker jump on training camp than the Houston Texans. Of course, no team required more work.

description: Wanting a second child, Gary and Kristen Tyler, both 41, thought the best thing would be to borrow $20,000 from his 401(k) to pay for in vitro fertilization. But with the stock market plunging, taking that much out of Mr. Tyler's retirement account has suddenly become very problematic.

title: Alexis Ohls, Clifford Finkle IV

title: Not on My Sidewalk: The Battle Over Street Trees
description: Trees grow almost everywhere in this city, some in pits of earth between slabs of sidewalk. Councilwoman Margarita Lopz, who represents the Lower East Side, has seen many such trees grow to the point of cracking their concrete confinements, and she knows better than to blame them for the damage.

title: Third Round Drops Mickelson From Contention
description: Phil Mickelson will leave another major championship disappointed, after a five-over-par 76 today dropped him out of contention at seven over for the tournament. The British Open continued to be the toughest major for Mickelson, who has never posted a top-10 finish in the world's oldest major championship.

title: A Last-Minute Mistake Is Costly for the Lowly Power
description: There was less than a minute left in regulation of a scoreless game when the ball reached Ronnie Fair at the edge of the penalty area. Fair, a defender for the New York Power, failed to control the ball, allowing Julie Fleeting of the San Diego Spirit to take it and beat goalkeeper Saskia Webber.

description: ANYONE who has lived in a co-op knows what happens when a committee is formed to decorate the lobby. Months of meetings ensue, and in the end the results are usually less than stunning.

title: When Lady and Troubadour Become One
description: JUST a few years ago, the works of the Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho were heard largely by diehard new-music aficionados. If her name was known more widely, it was probably linked to the thorny modernist rigors of the Darmstadt school in Germany or the spiky electronic riffs of Ircam, the computer-music mecca here, where she trained during the 1980's.

title: New for Under the Sun
description: This summer, cosmetics manufacturers -- are thinking outside the bottle with untraditional sunblocks. Completely Bare's Solar Shield pads ($32 at Completely Bare Salon, 212-717-9300) are saturated in an SPF 30 sunscreen. Solar Protection Pads by Stallex ($30 at www.parkavenueskincare.com) offer the same single-swipe convenience; created by a dermatologist, they ward off both sunburn and acne. Kiehl's All-Sport Non-Freeze Face Protector ($15) puts a four-season, water-resistant sunscreen in a flat, palm-sized disk of balm, while Clinique's Sun Care Body Spray ($16.50 at www.clinique.com) covers maximum surface area with a targeted spray nozzle and comes in SPF 15 or 30. AquaVedic's adjustable face and body lotion ($35 at Bigelow Chemists in New York, 800-793-5433) is housed in a bottle that allows users to dial their own level of protection, from 2 to 30. For more cosmetic sun safety, Laboratoire Remede's Translucent UV Coat ($36 at Barneys New York) is a liquid-to-powder matte foundation that is also a facial sunblock. And DuWop's Revolotion body shimmer moisturizer ($19 at Henri Bendel) and Este Lauder's Shimmering Shield stick ($18 at Macy's) have iridescent properties that leave skin shining, without feeling the burn.

title: Addicted to Prisons

title: Seasons Change: She's December and He's May
description: THERE'S a scene in Nicole Holofcener's recent film ''Lovely and Amazing'' in which Catherine Keener, playing a dispirited, disillusioned and, incidentally, married 36-year-old woman named Michelle, gets caught making out in her car with her 17-year-old boyfriend -- by his mother. It's late; mom has rushed out of the house in her nightclothes to rescue her child from the clutches of this wicked seductress.

title: July 14-20
description: LINDH PLEA DEAL John Walker Lindh, the Californian who was a soldier with the Taliban in Afghanistan, avoided a trial set to begin next month after he pleaded guilty to two felony charges and agreed to serve a 20-year sentence. Mr. Lindh, 21 years old, escaped the possibility of a life sentence in jail when prosecutors dropped several charges that accused him of conspiring to engage in terrorism and kill Americans. The government said the 20-year sentence was appropriately steep; Mr. Lindh's relatives said he would devote himself to studying Islam in prison.

title: A Roman Amphitheater in the Heart of London
description: The remains of London's Roman amphitheater are now open to the public after a $6 million, 11-year excavation. The second-century A.D. structure was discovered in 1988 during construction of new quarters for the Guildhall Art Gallery in the City of London. As a result, the plans were altered to incorporate the amphitheater ruins into a lower level of the gallery.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Executive Life; Is a Red-Carpet Medical Exam Better?
description: FOR decades, many top executives have received the royal treatment at their annual medical examinations -- compliments of their companies. Hospitals and medical centers that offer these so-called executive physicals pamper their patients with breakfast buffets and waiting rooms with many of the trappings of their corner offices: plush carpets, wide-screen televisions, computers and even secretarial help.

title: My Fault
description: Five years ago, at the urging of a market guru known for his folksy approach to stock picking and his prematurely snow white hair, I divided my economic self into two theoretical entities: an innocent middle-American consumer who roamed the malls in search of new sensations and a second, analytic self who monitored the first self's purchases in the hope of spotting smart investments. The idea, as outlined in Peter Lynch's book ''One Up on Wall Street,'' was to unleash my inner market genius by setting aside all those fancy charts and graphs and concentrating on the world around me. Was I drinking a lot of espresso? Buy stock in Starbucks. Were all of my friends on Prozac? Buy Eli Lilly.

description: With a dazzling par 71 in today's windy, wet weather, Sergio Garca was answering questions in the warmth of the interview tent of the 131st British Open while most of the other golfers were battling the elements at Muirfield.

The company acted after 19 people became ill in Colorado, South Dakota, California, Michigan, Washington State and Wyoming when they ate tainted hamburger traced to the company's plant in Greeley, Colo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLIGHTLY, HENRY O.
description: GOLIGHTLY-Henry O. July 17, 2002. He is survived by his several Texas relatives, including Gene Richardson, Marilyn Bonner Lane, Maxine Jarrett, George and John Golightly. He headed the well-known consulting firm Golightly & Company International and served many leading US and foreign companies from offices in New York, London and Houston. Prior to founding Golightly International in 1960, Mr. Golightly was a Principal with McKinsey and Company. Memorial Service to be held Thursday, August 1, 11 AM, Christ Church United Methodist, 520 Park Avenue at 60th Street. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Just One Break Inc, 120 Wall Street, NY, NY 10025.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEMSER, ERIC J.
description: ZEMSER-Eric J. Loving son of Richard and the late Sandra and devoted stepson of Cathy, and stepbrother of Adam and Danny. title: With DVD's, A Box Seat On the Sofa
description: SOMETIME next year, by present plans, three of the leading producers of opera recordings -- Decca, Deutsche Grammophon and Philips -- will stop releasing new full-length operas on CD and switch exclusively to video production on DVD. For one thing, the superb picture and surround sound of digital video discs can deliver a deeply engaging likeness of opera as theater. For another, says the national sales director for the three labels (all part of Universal Classics), collectors are apparently making the shift to DVD on their own. Opera sales on the little video discs have matched the demand for full-length audio recordings and in some cases outpaced it.

Carolyn Brown and Robert Swinston had original dancers' notes as well as memories, films and photographs to draw on in their reconstruction of Merce Cunningham's ''Suite for Five.'' But notes get lost, memories are not always reliable and films and photographs often chronicle a dance as it looked in a particular season, changed, often, by a choreographer's tinkering and dancers' adjustments. Mr. Swinston, a longtime Cunningham dancer who has been helping to revive pieces for a decade, described the process as ''finding the 'new old' version'' of a dance. Ms. Brown said of Mr. Swinston: ''He's like an archaeologist, a sleuth. He won't give up.''

Visible on deck were half a dozen men in Maltese costume; above them fluttered a British flag. At bars like the Breakers, in the famous hotel in Palm Beach, Fla., and Bungalow 8 in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan, bartenders use nozzle-tip squeeze bottles filled with black raspberry honey and Chambord to monogram cocktails. Williams-Sonoma offers steak branders for searing initials on barbecued meats ($34.95 for double or triple initials at www.williams-sonoma.com). At Fred Segal in Los Angeles, Priorities, a company that specializes in hip monogramming, offers boy tanks and baby T's that can be monogrammed in several font styles and embroidery hues. ($58 to $62, also at www.prioritiesnyc.com). Kleinberg Sherrill makes handbags, including a $25,500 alligator bag with pav diamond initials (at www.kleinbergsherrill.com). ''The Hit Men and the Kid Who Batted Ninth'' (Diamond Communications, $26.95), by David Siroty, director of public affairs for St. Peter's College and a Westfield resident, traces the stories of the four. Robinson, who grew up in Newark, was drafted by the Oakland A's. But he was released from the minors in 1991 and became a police officer in Arizona (where he applied lessons from his college coach, Mike Sheppard, that, he says, he should have remembered when trying to make the majors).
