description: FOR all the talk about golf's having become a sport of inclusion, events last week exposed some rents in the theory.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm constantly amazed that anybody cares what I do.''

title: An Island of American History
description: WHY spend $20,000 on a job when it can just as easily be done for $250,000? Case in point: the renovation of the boathouse on Constitution Island, 287 acres, owned by West Point, that sits 300 yards out in the Hudson River. At the landing, teetering on a dilapidated stone seawall, is the ramshackle, one-dinghy clapboard boathouse, barely bigger than a garden shed.

title: A High Flier Among High Rollers
description: HER eggs should have hatched on April 24, four and a half weeks after she laid them on the 23rd-floor ledge of an Atlantic City casino hotel. But the peregrine falcon, whose bicolor leg band indicates she was hatched four years ago in coastal Virginia, steadfastly incubated her eggs into the summer. Her eggs never hatched because they were infertile, which isn't unusual for a falcon's first nesting attempt. Her marathon incubation, though, showed a tenacity that should serve her well in her new urban home.

title: Els May Have Found The Key to Winning
description: Before the British Open, someone asked Ernie Els what it would take to win.

title: Beating the Tax Increase, One Cigarette at a Time
description: Shana, a 14-year-old who lives in the Alphabet City housing projects, did not flinch when local cigarette prices jumped to $7.50 a pack this month. Her nicotine fix would cost only an extra nickel.

title: Village People
description: REPUBLIC OF DREAMS

title: Enforcing the Party Line
description: I turned a blind eye to the under-age drinking at my 16-year-old son's keg party. When the police showed up, my son pleaded with me to say that I just got home so I would not be held liable for the drinking. I told the cops the truth, but now wonder if I should have dissembled. If some parent doesn't allow these events, the kids will find a house with no parent home. Anonymous, Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: El Salvador Embraces Foreign Investors
description: The timing, to put it mildly, was odd. Across Latin America in recent weeks, protests have sprouted up against foreign investment and sales of state-owned businesses  a dalliance with free markets that critics say is stealing local wealth and enriching corrupt officials. But El Salvador has chosen this moment to shout out a welcome to foreign investors, initiating its first promotional effort ever to promote itself abroad.

title: Private Sector; It's Cheaper and Cleaner Up There
description: Add American movie crews to the victims of Enron's collapse. Robert Greenwald Productions of Los Angeles, which is shooting ''The Crooked E,'' a television film chronicling the final days of Enron, is joining the ranks of Hollywood producers heading to Canada, where crew and location costs are cheaper. The company's choice was the prairie city of Winnipeg, Manitoba, population 650,000, described by its mayor, Glen Murray, as ''Winnipeg the Good.'' With turn-of-the-century architecture, spacious parks and modern office towers, ''we can easily be Dallas, Chicago or New York, without the traffic congestion,'' Mr. Murray said. ''We don't really care about content. We have a reputation for pretty incredible integrity.'' Bernard Simon

title: Should the SAT Be a Time Trial?
description: To the Editor:

title: July 14-20: FRONT LINES; SPANISH ROUNDUP
description: The Spanish police rounded up four more men suspected of belonging to Al Qaeda cells in Spain. In a pile of homemade videos taken from one of the suspects, the police found hours of what they described as surveillance tapes filmed in 1997 at the World Trade Center and other American landmarks. The tapes were taken at the Statue of Liberty, Disneyland and other sites, and were shot from various angles and distances, with an unusual interest in structures and access. Tim Golden

title: The Invention Of the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: No Question
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, SUSAN ENGEL
description: LEVY-Susan Engel. Of Maplewood, NJ, on Friday, July 19, 2002; beloved wife of Richard W. Levy, M.D., devoted mother of Eric E. Levy and Warren M. Levy. Memorial service Sunday, July 21, at 2 PM, in the Bernheim-ApterKreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Friends of St. Alphonsus, P.O. Box 57143, New Orleans, LA 70157-7143. A memorial service shall be held in New Orleans in September.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the ''What They're Reading'' feature last Sunday referred imprecisely to the physicist who wrote one of the books, ''Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman,'' and misstated his middle initial. He was Richard P. Feynman, not Richard D., and he died in 1988.

title: Soriano Delivers On an Afternoon Filled With Tension
description: Rondell White had barely spoken his prediction before it came true. On the Yankees' bench in the bottom of the 11th inning yesterday, White said to Enrique Wilson, ''Home run or double.'' With Alfonso Soriano at the plate, there was conviction behind White's words.

title: New York Embraces Commerce, as It Always Has
description: As New Yorkers eyed the official plans to rebuild Lower Manhattan that were released last week, almost nobody had a kind word to say about them. Insufficiently reverent, some critics said. Unimaginative. Dense. Ugly. Dull.

title: To Be Young, Talented, Hard-Working and Latina
description: WATCH OUT, Jennifer Lopez.

title: What if You Don't Have a Garage?
description: PEG GRIMES has lived in the same set of simple rooms in Stuyvesant Town since 1990. Her couches are covered with flannel sheets, and her carpet is nubby. She is galled by the idea of her two sons, 13 and 6, gallivanting around her all-white living room. She has spent years trying to conquer clutter without a garage and only recently came to terms with her midcentury light fixtures. She finds her kitchen awkward, her paint-encrusted pipes grotty, and the space above her window underused. Peg Grimes, in other words, has issues, which she says can't be solved by a traditional decorator.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Hudson Journal; Where Daylight's a Risk, Dark Is a Time to Shine
description: As wisps of cloud drifted across a half moon, 9-year-old Mary Begg, in helmet and harness, climbed the 10 rungs of a ladder toward the lowest foot grips on a soaring climbing wall.

title: Private Sector; Teaching Them How to Blow the Whistle
description: Sherron S. Watkins, the Enron vice president who warned top executives about the company's accounting problems and impending collapse months before it happened, is taking a message to college campuses.

title: El Salvador Embraces Foreign Investors
description: The timing, to put it mildly, was odd. Across Latin America in recent weeks, protests have sprouted up against foreign investment and sales of state-owned businesses -- a dalliance with free markets that critics say is stealing local wealth and enriching corrupt officials. But El Salvador has chosen this moment to shout out a welcome to foreign investors, initiating its first promotional effort ever to promote itself abroad.

title: Bilge Ogut, Haro Cumbusyan
description: A. Bilge Ogut and Haro Cumbusyan were married at the New York City Municipal Building on Friday by Victor L. Robles, a city clerk. Yesterday, David Martin, a colleague of the bridegroom, led a celebration of the couple's marriage at the Rainbow Room in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEFFERY, PETER TURNER
description: JEFFERY - Peter Turner. Writer. On July 15, 2002, one day shy of his 73rd birthday, Peter died in Toronto. He is survived by Heidi Jeffery, his children Carmen, Christine, and Cowell.

title: At Small Cooperatives, the Name Is Apt
description: OURS isn't a commune, but we still have a need to get along, and we do,'' said Ira Inemer, the treasurer of his four-apartment co-op building in Brooklyn Heights. For Mr. Inemer and others who live in small co-op buildings -- many of them brownstones that, in a different era, were homes to only one family, perhaps with servants -- the term ''cooperative'' takes on a more intimate meaning than it might for residents of large buildings with the luxuries of staffs and managing agents.

title: July 14-20: NATIONAL; BAD NEWS FOR TRAFICANT
description: The House ethics committee recommended unanimously that Representative James A. Traficant Jr., convicted of taking bribes, kickbacks of staff salaries, and of racketeering, be removed from office. Proclaiming his innocence, Mr. Traficant promises the speech of his life when the House takes up his case. Mr. Traficant, Democrat of Ohio, is seeking re-election as an independent. Alison Mitchell

title: Don't Drink the Water, (And Don't Eat the Fish)
description: Striped bass, bluefish and other fish caught in city waters are ending up on the dinner table, sometimes without the cook's knowledge.

title: A Son of Bassiano
description: To the Editor: Frederika Randall's idyllic report of her day trip to Ninfa, ''A Secret Garden'' (June 16), included a delighted surprise for this bibliophile. The lunch she and her husband enjoyed in Sermoneta included ''prosciutto from nearby Bassiano,'' so good still comes from this tiny and forgotten hillside town. Bassiano was the birthplace, in about 1450, of the most famous scholar printer of the Renaissance, Aldus Manutius.

title: July 14-20: FRONT LINES; SURPRISE PLEA
description: Zacarias Moussaoui, the so-called 20th hijacker in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, acknowledged in a Virginia court that he was part of the Qaeda network and tried to plead guilty to conspiring in the attacks. Mr. Moussaoui offered his plea even as he repeated his contention that he was not directly involved in the plot. The judge refused his surprise request, saying she would give him a week to reconsider a decision that could guarantee his execution. Philip Shenon

title: New Mexico Greens Go From Gadflies to Players
description: A third political party seldom rises to a level much beyond annoyance to Republicans and Democrats.

title: A Murder in Russia, And Dance Is Bereft
description: YEVGENY PANFILOV was a charismatic and popular modern-dance choreographer in Russia, largely unknown in this country. But the news, read on the Internet Monday morning, that at the age of 47 he had been stabbed to death last weekend in his apartment in the Urals city of Perm came as a personal shock.

title: At a Pharmacy Near You, Natural Hormones
description: When the Journal of the American Medical Association reported earlier this month that synthetic hormone therapy for women may be less helpful than doctors originally believed, the timing could not have been better for the Natural Hormone Pharmacy, which offers natural hormones as an alternative to synthetic hormones.

title: Poison in the Water
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite Recent Floods, Texans Fight Over Rights to Precious Water of the Guadalupe River
description: The Guadalupe River has receded here, its fury abated. The devastating flooding this month washed away riverfront homes like bobbing corks and left this central Texas city's tourist economy so crippled that officials have begun an emergency advertising campaign.

title: BackTalk; A Season With an N.F.L. Salary-Cap Analyst
description: Last January, the Jets organization was reeling from a crushing first-round playoff loss and the knowledge that it had to cut $20 million from its payroll by March. In the ensuing weeks, the club not only accomplished the payroll purge, but also did so without stripping the team of a chance to compete. Six months later, the Jets are poised for another run at the postseason.

title: Brenda Grassey, Richard Woollams Jr.
description: Brenda Gay Grassey, an English teacher, was married yesterday to Richard Carl Woollams Jr., an insurance executive. The Rev. Charlotte Sommers, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Tuxedo Club in Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: A credit last Sunday for a cartoon about Rudolph W. Giuliani's divorce settlement misstated the cartoonist's given name. He is Walt Handelsman, not Matt.

title: Vanessa Noel, Innkeeper
description: For tourists in Nantucket -- who crave accommodations that are more hip than quaint, VNH, Vanessa Noel Hotel, may fit the bill. Owned by the shoe designer Vanessa Noel, the inn, which opened earlier this month, mixes a traditional New England seaside escape with all the accouterments of a boutique hotel.

title: Business; The Struggle to Sell A 'Green' Wrapper
description: SIMON K. HODSON, chief executive of EarthShell, is not the first entrepreneur to come up with an environmentally friendly alternative to the paper and plastic foam used in food packaging. But because of the steadfast backing of EarthShell's chairman and largest shareholder, Essam Khashoggi, Mr. Hodson looks as if he has pulled off a rare achievement: staying solvent long enough to gain a realistic shot at breaking into this $12 billion market.

title: Now at the Hedgerow, Graffiti Vandals
description: HOMEOWNERS here have been plagued for generations by mailbox marauders. Armed with baseball bats and the occasional small explosive, they rampage down one street and up the next in the middle of the night, leaving a trail of tilted posts and battered boxes. In the morning, the police dutifully jot down the owners' complaints, but the marauders remain at large.

title: Introduction
description: Hundreds of readers responded to our cover article making the case that fat has gotten a bad rap. The mail was full of low-carb success stories and caveats about the Atkins diet. A father's story of his teenage daughter's unwanted pregnancy prompted many to say their ''choice'' would be adoption, not abortion.

title: An Innovator's Hardy Roses Get Their Day
description: GRIFFITH BUCK of Iowa, a professor of horticulture, lived from 1915 to 1991, but was not fashionable during that time. Dr. Buck spent his entire career teaching at Iowa State University. His real passion, though, was hybridizing roses, and many of the ones he developed are extraordinary for their hardiness and beauty, bringing Dr. Buck posthumous renown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOTT, BASIL J.F., PHD.
description: MOTT-Basil J.F., PhD. Dean Emeritus of the School of Health and Human Services at the University of New Hampshire, died at his home in Durham, NH. He was 78 years old. Dr. Mott graduated from Amherst College and received his doctorate from Harvard. Mott spent 40 years studying, teaching, and writing about the politics of health care. Mott directed a study of the NY State Coordinating Commission for Inter-Departmental Health and Hospital issues and produced a book entitled ''Anatomy of A Coordinating Council''. Dr. Mott leaves his wife Ruth, a sister, three children, and two granddaughters.

title: The Relevance Of 'Sex' in a City That's Changed
description: ''SEX and the City'' sashayed into public consciousness in the summer of 1998, when sex had become, if not the national pastime, the reigning political story. Monica Lewinsky had just been featured on the cover of Vanity Fair, and her name was regularly mentioned on the front pages of major newspapers. The Clinton-Lewinsky affair had made lewd gossip an acceptable form of political commentary, and ''Sex and the City'' quickly became part of the pundit glossary.

title: AOL's 'To Do' List
description: AOL's new chief executive -- the search is under way -- will have much to do to make the company grow again. These are among the necessary tasks that experts suggest.

title: Fathers and Sons And Hollywood Law
description: NATURAL law: sons are put on this earth to trouble their fathers.'' This line, spoken by John Rooney, the gangster patriarch played by Paul Newman in ''Road to Perdition,'' has become one of the summer's most frequently quoted bits of cinematic dialogue. There is a touch of blarney in Mr. Newman's delivery, but it is undeniable that, at least in recent movies, fatherhood is a troubled state indeed. From ancient Rome (''Gladiator'') to colonial America (''The Patriot''), from late-20th-century Maine (''In the Bedroom'') to mid-21st-century Washington (''Minority Report''), to be a dad is to be tormented by guilt, menaced by grief and, more often than not, driven to righteous, murderous violence.

title: POSTINGS: 374 Rental Apartments Atop Commercial Condominium; Mixed-Use Tower for Midtown
description: When the 47-story mixed-use building Atlas New York opened recently at 66 West 38th Street, it brought something relatively unusual to this area on the fringe of the garment district: rental apartments.

title: The Confidence Crisis
description: Wall Street's alarming dive in recent weeks, capped by the 390-point drop in the Dow on Friday, may just be another example of the irrationality that can sometimes grip the markets. The recovery, after all, has been progressing fairly well, and Alan Greenspan advised Congress last week that the economic outlook was reasonably promising. But economic fundamentals are being overrun by a host of uncertainties, which begin with doubt about America's corporate elite and end with concern about shaky leadership in Washington.

title: Corporate Bad Guys Make Many Seek the Road Less Traveled
description: JUST three years ago, Ameet Shah, 24, was successfully laying the groundwork for life as a corporate titan. After graduating from Duke University, he had landed a $50,000-a-year job in New York at J. P. Morgan Chase, working 100-hour weeks on deals involving companies like Enron and Kmart. But no sooner had Mr. Shah settled into the perks of his new career -- expense accounts, car services and enough cash to support an apartment in a doorman building -- than his world was shaken by a market downturn and a stream of stories about corporate malfeasance. The deals -- and the perks -- dried up, many of his colleagues were fired, and Mr. Shah got a peek at capitalism's dark side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDEN, RAY REIDER
description: GOLDEN-Ray Reider. Wise, generous, thoughtful, caring friend and neighbor; loving and nurturing mother to Rachel and Eric; caring friend and teacher to budding artists who experienced the joy of creating with Ray. We are grateful for the privilege of sharing her beauty, truth, dignity and energy for life. Her spirit, intellectual drive, creativity, ambition, love of family, children and friends were contagious and will always be with us both in our hearts and through our love for her extraordinary children, Eric and Rachel. Her Riverdale Neighbors and Friends

title: Enjoying Canada Geese; At Least I Thought So
description: Re ''Canada Geese: It's Love and Hate'' [July 14]: They have invaded my property, too. At first, I was thrilled to see this species of wildlife in my backyard, even to the point of videotaping them. Little did I realize that these creatures are incredibly territorial, mean-spirited, ungrateful and leave more droppings than a mature pachyderm. Their squawking is ear-piercing, particularly at sunrise. Now I am seeking outside opinions on how to deal with the problem. I have thought about lobbying for an open goose season on Long Island, buying a Rottweiler, throwing firecrackers at them, installing an invisible electric shock fence or filling the yard with their natural enemies.

title: A Tale Of Two Cities
description: It was the numbers, the arithmetic of her vulnerability on police posters around town, that broke your heart.

title: It Only Looks Like Vietnam
description: Basilan Island should be a tourist paradise, one of the world's most visited beach destinations. Just a dot on the map -- 10 miles off the southernmost Philippine state of Mindanao -- Basilan has cathedral-like rain forests, volcanic highlands draped in misty waterfalls and white-sand beaches so clean they appear sifted from confectioners' sugar.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LASKY, ESTELLE AND CHARLES
description: LASKY-Estelle and Charles. July 18th and 20th. On your birthdays, and every day, remembered and loved... always. George and Joyce

title: Massage, Aromatherapy, Oils and a Root Canal
description: YOU don't usually see people smiling in the dentist's chair, but the woman at the Madison Avenue office of Dr. Paul Tanners looked, well, happy. The dentist had just completed the last of a full reconstruction on her upper and lower teeth, and the patient was enjoying a foot rub from the massage therapist on his staff.

title: 'Nonrefundable' Wiggle Room
description: WHEN nonrefundable airline tickets became a staple of the travel industry in the 1980's, passengers who had to change their plans usually forfeited the entire fare. Nowadays the penalties are less draconian, though often more complicated.

title: CRIME
description: Minette Walters goes for a walk on the wild side in ACID ROW (Putnam, $24.95), departing from the sinuous storytelling of her novels of psychological suspense to take a more dynamic approach to the spectacle of mob violence in a low-income, crime-infested housing development on the outskirts of London. There is no ambiguity about the events in this urban thriller, which are based on actual incidents of community vigilantism gone haywire. A neglected child disappears from home, presumably lured away by a child molester. Alerted to the presence of a convicted pedophile on their home ground, outraged mothers at a nearby project mount a protest that is co-opted by a savage element of local teenagers fueled by drink and fury. The rampage spreads until some 2,000 people are caught up in the riot, which claims three lives and injures scores.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIERMAN, MICHAEL
description: FIERMAN-Michael. We will miss our wise and funny, beloved friend. He will live in our hearts forever. Susan and Harris Amster

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOODMAN, BARBARA
description: GOODMAN-Barbara. We love you and miss you. We grieve for Kenny, Nicole and Eric. The Siegel Family

title: Face to Face With Milosevic
description: When I stepped into the forest, what struck me most was the smell. Seven bodies -- five women and two children -- were lying in a small gully where they had apparently been killed. Their bodies were bloody, contorted and covered with wet leaves. Seven other relatives lay nearby. As researchers for Human Rights Watch in Kosovo, we solemnly went about our work, taking photographs and interviewing surviving members of the Delijaj family. Journalists in the Balkans often asked me whether there would be justice for murders like these. I had always assured them there would be, hoping my enthusiasm would make it a reality. But in truth, I never let myself believe that Slobodan Milosevic would be arrested. I never thought then, standing in the forest, that one day I would face Yugoslavia's former president in court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINKOFF, DR. MARVIN W.
description: SINKOFF-Dr. Marvin W. Preceded in death by his beloved wife Alice. Wonderful father to Martin, Richard, Nancy and James. Loving grandfather to Ezra, Miriam, Reuben, Noah and Emma. Services Monday, 11 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Contributions may be made to the Dr. Marvin W. Sinkoff Endocrinology Fund, c/o Mt. Sinai Medical Center, NY, NY 10029.

title: Thank Heaven for Little Parties
description: ''I LOVE mink. It's my passion!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, MICHAEL A.
description: McCARTHY - Michael A., July 16, 2002. Son of the late Joseph W. & Mary Pellegrini McCarthy. Dear brother of Susan C. McCarthy. Cousin of William McCarthy. He was a partner of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, LLP., and was honored as a foremost benefactor of Cornell in 1993. Friends may call at the Schlager Funeral Home Inc., 4614 Main St., Snyder, NY, where the family will be present Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Prayers Monday, 10:30 AM. Mass 11 AM at St. Benedict's Church. If desired, memorials may be made to Father Baker's Home, 780 Ridge Road, Lackawanna, N.Y 14218.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLI, EDMUND F.
description: KOLI-Edmund F. July 9, 2002. Of Rockaway Beach, N.Y. Age 85. WWII Prisoner of War Oflag 64. N.Y.C. Department of Personnel, 1955-1982.

title: What if It's All Been a Big Fat Lie?
description: As a sports physician, I subscribe to Gary Taubes's counterintuitive conclusions regarding the overemphasis on fat intake as the cause of obesity and heart disease. But I was disappointed to see how casually he dismissed, in one brief reference, the greater importance of exercise in overall fitness and health. Syndrome X has as much to do with the loss of the insulin-resistance-lowering effects of exercise as to the overconsumption of carbohydrates.

title: French Feast, and Aura, at a Price, in Rye
description: AS travelers enter the patrician realm of Rye, a sign proclaims, Home of Girls Field Hockey Champions, 2000 and 2001. I propose a second sign, one that would boast of La Panetire, a beautifully appointed, breathtakingly expensive French restaurant whose triple threat of chef, patissier, and sommelier puts it too in a league of its own.

title: Mosquitoes Out? Check the Weather
description: IF there was a silver lining to the last winter's drought it was the promise of fewer mosquitoes this summer.

title: What if It's All Been a Big Fat Lie?
description: High-protein diets are based on a half-truth. People in this country eat too many simple carbohydrates (sugar, white flour, white rice). These are absorbed quickly, causing blood sugar to spike, provoking an insulin response that accelerates the conversion of carbohydrates to fat. However, the solution is not to go from simple carbohydrates to pork rinds but from simple to complex carbohydrates: whole wheat, brown rice, fruits, vegetables, grains and legumes in their natural forms. These are high in fiber, which slows their absorption, preventing a rapid rise in blood sugar. You get the weight-loss benefits of a high-protein diet while enhancing rather than mortgaging your health.

title: Recording the Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: July 14-20: ECONOMY; OVERHAULING
description: When the Senate votes 97-0 to overhaul the way American corporations and accounting firms are regulated, it means something big is about to happen, right? Well, maybe. The huge vote on the bill, which creates an autonomous accounting oversight board and would require hefty jail sentences for corporate officers who cook the books, hid disagreements about what the final legislation should look like. House and Senate members began meeting in conference to debate how to reconcile their separate bills. David E. Sanger

title: Corrections
description: A brief article last Sunday introducing a photo essay about Palestinians and their views about the United States and reform in the Palestinian Authority misstated the date Yasir Arafat was elected as the Palestinians' president. It was 1996, not 1997.

title: Ideas & Trends: Cleaning Up; How to Succeed Without Attitude
description: A pop-culture quiz: ''Do you smell it? That smell? That kind of smelly smell? The smelly smell that smells . . . smelly?'' A good number of children in the 2-to-11 range, as the Nielsen ratings group them, will know the smell. So will many of their parents, a fair number of college students, and assorted hipsters of indeterminate age who surfed or stumbled into the undersea universe of a yellow kitchen sponge and got hooked.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: GEORGE and Derek are elated by the success of their new business. ''It's going to take us longer to count it than it did to sell it,'' says Derek (Paul Reubens). He and George (Johnny Depp) are admiring the pile of cash they've amassed selling marijuana to Southern Californians in Ted Demme's BLOW (2001). But is that enough for George? No, he's not going to be a worn-down wage slave like his father (Ray Liotta), so he moves ''up'' to selling Colombian cocaine and marries a gorgeous but cold drug-family princess (Penlope Cruz). Eventually both his work and his wife do him wrong -- Sunday at 10 p.m. and Thursday at 11:35 p.m. on Starz.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 22 of The Times Magazine today about the composer Marc Shaiman misidentifies the director of the film "My Man Godfrey," which Mr. Shaiman considered adapting for Broadway. It was Gregory La Cava, not Preston Sturges.

title: Stages Change, but the Music Endures
description: RICHARD KAPP, music director of the Dobbs Ferry-based chamber orchestra, Philharmonia Virtuosi, was pondering the idea of permanence. ''How many years before you're considered permanent?'' He smiled wryly. ''Twenty-five years aren't enough?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGMAN, CHARLOTTE
description: BERGMAN-Charlotte. A woman of valor passed away at her home in Jerusalem on July 17, 2002 after an extended illness. Charlotte exemplified a unique combination of dignity, philanthropy and enthusiastic advocacy of the arts together with love and respect for her extended family of numerous friends and fellow art enthusiasts. She, together with her husband Louis, of blessed memory traveled extensively throughout the world pursuing their love of art. Charlotte became known as a hostess par excellence to patrons of the arts among others in Jerusalem. Her regal personality, advocacy of the arts and support of Israel and its cultural and medical institutions epitomized a life of rare values to be emulated. Sanford L. Batkin Seymour N. Chesir

title: What if It's All Been a Big Fat Lie?
description: Before I spend one more (miserable) hour on the treadmill at my gym, please let me know if you are planning a cover story on the deleterious effects of exercise.

title: They're Mellower Now, but There It Is: That Bomb
description: LIKE a German version of ''The Big Chill,'' ''What to Do in Case of Fire'' brings together a group of once-close friends who are suddenly forced to examine their lives. They laugh and they cry and they dance, all to a propulsive rock soundtrack.

title: When Kids Are Away, Parents Will Play
description: THIS is the first summer that my boys have gone to sleep-away camp. I knew I would miss them. In fact, I planned on it.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Race for Staten Island

title: D.M.V. PRIVATIZATION
description: The state transportation commissioner, Jamie Fox, said last week that he opposed the operation of motor vehicles offices by private companies, a practice begun during the Whitman administration. Instead, Mr. Fox said, the Division of Motor Vehicles should return to being fully run by state employees. Earlier this year, the state formed a commission to review charges of inefficiency and security problems within the agency, which has 45 local offices run by private contractors and costs the state $17 million each year. Results of the review are expected in the next few months. Jeremy Pearce

title: High Thoughts, Low Behavior And Tiger Bites
description: JUST when you thought it was safe to take a summer dip in the sea of moral turpitude, it's time once again for a visit from the Jersey Ethicist.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: MERVYN PEAKE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPOVIC, ANA
description: POPOVIC-Ana. Suddenly on July 16, 2002. Beloved sister of Sanja. Loving aunt of Marco. Best friend to Yaga. Good friend to so many. Celebration of her life service on Monday, July 22, 6PM at the Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 E. 88 St, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations to North Shore Animal League of America, Lewyt St, Port Washington, New York 11050, would be appreciated.

title: Our Towns; 3 Bedrooms, a Big Backyard, and Now, No Poison Arrows
description: THE people at Hovnanian Enterprises, a leading suburban homebuilder, figured they had heard every possible objection to a house. Too cramped. Not enough bathrooms. Too close to in-laws. Too far from in-laws.

title: The Battle To Get Us To Pipe Down
description: IN the cool breezes of summer, people open their windows to the music of summer. The wind through trees, birds chirping, children shouting in the distance. Then the windows slam down again, as the ruckus kicks in: music pounding in passing cars, corn cannons roaring through farmers' fields, Jet Skis roaring through lakes. For some Hartford residents, ice cream trucks jangling a loud tune, was the last straw. It's not music, they complained: It's cloying -- and annoying.

title: A 'Museo' Moves Away From Its Barrio Identity
description: The neighborhood north of East 96th Street is sometimes called East Harlem or Spanish Harlem, but local Puerto Ricans affectionately call it El Barrio. title: Steiger: An Actor Looking Within
description: ROD STEIGER, who died on July 9 at the age of 77, belonged to the first generation of Method actors to leave the New York theater world for Hollywood. He made his movie debut as a psychiatrist in ''Teresa,'' a 1951 film directed by Fred Zinnemann, who one year before had introduced Marlon Brando to the world in ''The Men.'' Fellow students at the Actors Studio in New York, Mr. Steiger and Mr. Brando were cast together in 1954 in Elia Kazan's ''On the Waterfront,'' in which Mr. Steiger, playing a shady union lawyer, was on the receiving end of Mr. Brando's celebrated ''I coulda been a contendah'' speech.

title: Word for Word/'Greenspan Shrugged'; When Greed Was a Virtue And Regulation the Enemy
description: IN 1996, he questioned the ''irrational exuberance'' of the American investor. Last Tuesday, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, brought that era to a definitive end with his diagnosis that ''an infectious greed seemed to grip much of our business community.'' Acknowledging he was wrong in his long-held belief that the government should not regulate the accounting industry, Mr. Greenspan also said: ''It is not that humans have become any more greedy than in generations past. It is that the avenues to express greed had grown so enormously.''

title: PHARMACIA TO BE BOUGHT
description: Pharmacia, a drug manufacturer with headquarters in Peapack, is being taken over by Pfizer Inc., already the world's largest drug company, in a $60 billion stock deal, officials from both companies announced last week. Pfizer, which manufacturers Viagra and cholesterol-lowering Lipitor, and Pharmacia already have worked together to develop several products including the popular Celebrex, for arthritis pain. Pharmacia, which moved from London to New Jersey four years ago, has 2,000 employees in New Jersey, while Pfizer, based in New York, has 4,200 employees in the state. It is not known how many of those employees might lose their jobs because of the merger. Pharmacia, which manufactures the hair care product Rogaine, will proceed with a planned spin-off of Monsanto, but it is not known if the company will continue a proposed move to Basking Ridge. The agreement must be approved by regulators and stockholders. Karen DeMasters

title: A Ranch for Those on the Fence

As we rode farther, I looked up at the unmarred blue Wyoming sky and mused that all that was missing from this perfect Western moment was a bald eagle wheeling overhead.

title: Where The West Was Lurid
description: THERE are ghosts aplenty in Virginia City and Nevada City, the southwest Montana gold rush towns that gave birth to the dreaded Vigilantes. But the two sister communities of Alder Gulch under the Tobacco Root Mountains are no ghost towns. Ghost towns are dead places, abandoned to the ravages of time. Virginia City and Nevada City, mile-high remnants of a frontier metropolis that grew out of a fabulous gold strike in 1863 and quickly went bust when the action shifted to Helena, today draw tourists to one of the nation's most ambitious preservation projects and the heritage of the West at its most violent and heroic.

title: Corrections

Club Monaco's white-on-white blouse ($89) is embellished with delicate embroidery, while Katayone Adeli's lace peasant top has a stand-up collar and an open V-neck ($168 at www.shopbop.com). Welkin's breezy cotton tunics come in either a modified peasant style with placket smocking (below, $114) or a more classic collar-and-cuffs pullover ($109, both at Gatsbys in Great Barrington, Mass., 413-528-9455).

title: MEADOWLANDS RENOVATION
description: More than 40 developers interested in bidding to renovate the Meadowlands sports complex met last week in response to an invitation from the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority. The authority said it wanted bids on plans to redesign what is now the Continental Airlines Arena, which loses about $5 million a year, and to make it profitable. Authority officials said they would probably choose a plan, and a developer, later this year. The conference came as a proposal to build a sports arena in Newark seemed weaker, as the company that owns the Nets and the Devils said it was ending efforts to move the teams to Newark and was considering moving them out of state. Like Nesselrode pie and Danish pudding, Judge Crater, Salinger's talent and the friendship between Woody and Jean, malted milk has disappeared. Well, almost. title: Corrections

Quadrifoglio refers to the maker's racing logo, a four-leaf clover, not to the car's four-cylinder engine. Graduate refers to the movie ''The Graduate,'' in which Dustin Hoffman drove an Alfa Romeo; it does not designate a step up from a less expensive model. The column also misstated the number of valves in the engine. It is eight, not four.

The African reserve features black rhinos that weigh more than a ton; Nile hippos; cheetahs; spotted hyenas; and dwarf mongooses, the smallest African carnivores, which feed on rodents and insects.

description: Real Wisconsin

title: Taking the Rough Out of Riding
description: IF my two children had not been watching, I would have gotten off the horse. More accurately, if my children had not been watching and I had known how to get off, that's what I would have done. My last riding experience, if you can call it that, occurred when I was 6 years old and someone led my aged pony around in a circle. Now, more than three decades later, I was perched on a behemoth named Dirty Harry, about to blaze new trails through the wilds of Wyoming. The ground suddenly seemed very far away.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 22 of The Times Magazine today about the composer Marc Shaiman misidentifies the director of the film ''My Man Godfrey,'' which Mr. Shaiman considered adapting for Broadway. It was Gregory La Cava, not Preston Sturges.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Fairfield House Prices Jump, but Rentals Mark Time
description: WITH interest rates lingering at attractively low levels and little land available for new development, the demand for Fairfield County houses continues to be strong, except for homes at the extreme high end of the price scale.

title: Ideas & Trends; A Child Study Is a Peek. It's Not the Whole Picture.
description: FOR some parents, the new research finding that children of mothers who worked full-time scored lower on school readiness tests may evoke the old story about the blind men who tried to describe an elephant: One told of touching the smooth hard ivory tusk, another the snake-like trunk, a third the leathery skin and a fourth the ropy tail -- but none captured anything like the whole picture.

title: A Question Of Accounting Has No Easy Answer
description: WASHINGTON and Wall Street are buzzing with speculation that companies may soon be required to treat stock options as expenses. The options are worth something, because they give employees a chance to buy company stock at a discount in the future. Calling them expenses, of course, would take a bite out of reported earnings. Yet much of the debate has lacked careful consideration of the question that matters most: How would the decision affect the economy as a whole?

title: Beautiful Objects, Meant to Be Used
description: IT is not news to report that at the crafts portion of the New Jersey Fine Arts Annual, it is often difficult to understand why a certain piece should not be classified as art rather than crafts. The two domains, once exclusive and sometimes antagonistic, have been moving closer together for decades.

title: Remembering a Teacher, and Lessons Taught
description: IT had been years since I visited the gracefully shabby house at 211 West Street in White Plains, but I went back in the spring for a memorial service for the man I called Mr. J, my cello teacher who died a few days earlier at the age of 91. His real name was Heinrich Joachim, a refugee from Hitler's Europe, who started life anew in postwar America as a cellist with several major orchestras including the New York Philharmonic.

title: July 14-20: ECONOMY; NIGHTMARE ON WALL STREET
description: Accounting inquiries and government investigations overshadowed positive remarks from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, and set off another steep plunge in the stock market. Compared to their peaks, the Standard & Poor's 500 index is down nearly 45 percent, the Dow 32 percent and the Nasdaq 74 percent. On Friday, the three major stock indexes were off 2 percent or more, with the Dow Jones industrial average down 3 percent, pushing it below the level it closed at on Sept. 21, in the wake of the terrorist attack.

title: Keisha Sutton and Michael James
description: TALK to anyone about Keisha Aquina Sutton, and they will tell you two things: she is beautiful and she is tardy. ''If you want Keisha on time, you have to invite her at least an hour earlier,'' said Serena Benedetti, a childhood friend.

description: I LIKE to think of myself as a fairly intelligent, financially sophisticated person. I know that big businesses don't always have my best interests at heart, that the customer is rarely right. I pride myself on not being a sucker.

title: Mets Put Aside Trade Talks and Look to Playoffs
description: The Mets have scouted the high-priced Detroit Tigers outfielder Bobby Higginson recently, but they do not anticipate making a trade for him.

title: July 14-20: INTERNATIONAL; RENEWED MIDEAST VIOLENCE
description: After a lull of nearly a month in Palestinian attacks during Israel's reoccupation of most West Bank cities, militants renewed their violence against Israelis. Gunmen ambushed a bus near the Jewish settlement of Immanuel in the West Bank, killing nine people, and two suicide bombers struck in Tel Aviv, killing three. With its forces already inside Palestinian towns, Israel did not retaliate, but said it would suspend planned steps to ease economic and travel restrictions on ordinary Palestinians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RISK, JAMES V.
description: RISK-James V. Passed away July 18, at home in Metuchen, NJ. Husband, father, international businessman, friend. Born in Uniontown, PA, he grew up during the Great Depression. In 1953 he moved to New Jersey and married Marjorie Hay, his best friend for the next 34 years until her death in 1987. They raised children Mark and Susan. In 1966 he joined Rheem International (later, City Investing International) in the management of businesses throughout the developed world. He later became its President. He made hundreds of trips to Europe, Asia, Australia, South Africa, Latin America. After retirement in 1985, he remained active in business, and served as Vice Chairman of Golden Gate Bank of San Francisco. Deeply grateful for his blessings, understanding of the difficulties of others. Many smiles and much laughter. Unconditional love. Private family funeral, memorial service to be held on date to be announced. Family will receive visitors July 22, from 2 to 4 PM, and 7 to 9 PM, at Costello Runyon Funeral Home, 568 Middlesex Avenue, Metuchen, NJ.

description: Not long ago, United States investors were true believers. They trusted corporate executives to be truthful about their companies' performance and prospects. They felt sure that the stock market was the only path to a prosperous future. And they trusted Alan Greenspan to steer the economy through any storm.

title: A Match Made In Heaven (I.e., Mozart)
description: Probably not everything the English tenor Ian Bostridge's voice touches turns to gold, but so far most things have. In Bach's ''St. Mat thew Passion'' (as the Evangelist), Schubert's ''Schne Mllerin,'' Janacek's ''Diary of One Who Vanished'' and Britten's ''War Requiem,'' on records or in concert, he has proved well-nigh ideal.

description: More than 4,000 people concerned about the future of the World Trade Center site attended ''Listening to the City'' at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, where there were, said Renee Nalitt, a participant, ''as many opinions as there were people.''

title: 'Trail of Feathers'
description: The trail began at an auction of shrunken heads. Anxious with greed, a pack of dealers and curiosity-hunters pushed into the library where the sale was about to begin. They had come by strict invitation, as the learned British society was eager to avoid the press. In the current climate of political correctness trophy heads are regarded as an embarrassment, something to be disposed of as quietly as possible. For years I had been an admirer of this unusual handicraft, and was desperate to start a collection of my own. Even though I'd managed to squirm my way onto the underground auction lists, I was lacking the funds of a serious collector. The shrunken head business is a small one, with only a few major players world-wide. I recognised most of them, as they lolled back on their chairs, their wax jackets wet with rain, their hands damp with sweat. All were well aware that such exquisite tsantsas are rarely put up for sale.

title: Martha Harris, Richard Lee
description: Martha Jane Harris and Richard Henry Lee are to be married today at the Stone House Club in Little Compton, R.I. David Lewis Stokes, a former Episcopal priest who is now a Roman Catholic deacon, officiated.

title: A City of Islands Enjoys Riding the Waves
description: WATER, water everywhere. It doesn't take more than a few minutes in Stockholm to feel the full force of this charming city's slogan: ''Beauty on Water.'' Built on 14 islands, 4 of which essentially constitute the city center, and shot through with a series of canals that lead to the 24,000 islands of Sweden's archipelago and eventually to the Baltic Sea, Stockholm offers a fantastic variety of aquatic activity.

title: Editorial Observer; The Great Irish Hunger and the Art of Honoring Memory
description: Last week the Irish Hunger Memorial opened at the west end of Vesey Street in Lower Manhattan's Battery Park City. It opened several months late, largely because the area was off limits for so long after Sept. 11. In those intervening months, the meaning of the memorial, dedicated to those who died in that Irish famine, has inevitably changed.

title: A Matter of Attitude
description: Harold Lloyd (1893-1971) will always be remembered as the surprised-looking fellow hanging from the clock in ''Safety Last.'' For many that's all he is; Lloyd comes in last in the holy trinity of silent film comedians, after Charlie Chaplin and Buster Keaton. HAROLD LLOYD: Master Comedian (Abrams, $45) seeks to restore his reputation. Jeffrey Vance, co-author of this book, is not only an ardent fan but also a good critic; he notes, for instance, that despite the signature round horn-rimmed glasses, Lloyd never played exactly the same character. What linked his roles in films like ''The Freshman'' and ''The Kid Brother'' was ''a comic attitude'' that combined ''determination, optimism, ambition and ingenuity.'' Lloyd's hits in the 1920's made him richer than the loopy millionaires he sometimes portrayed, though his appeal quickly waned in the era of sound. The book, written with Suzanne Lloyd, the star's granddaughter, includes a fascinating interview from 1969 in which Lloyd discusses his methods and motives. The book's photographic editor, Manoah Bowman, has chosen astutely from Lloyd's personal trove of crisp black-and-white images. Even in stills, his decency and charm come through. Ted Loos

title: A Comeback at Age 60 Starts With a '58 Chevy
description: Morgan Shepherd worked on restoring the 1958 Chevrolet for three years, or long enough to fall in love with it. But he really still wanted to race a stock car, and he realized that the '58 Chevy would be his only ticket to ride.

title: For Rocky Path and Car Trunk
description: Bike Friday's -- new Pocket Gnu folding bike marries performance with convenience, and has become a preferred cycle for triathletes and weekend warriors. The first dual-suspension mountain bike that can be collapsed without removing any bolts, the Pocket Gnu weighs about 25 pounds and folds up small enough to fit into the trunk of a compact car. Each bike is custom-built to suit the owner's height, weight and riding style. From $1,595 to $2,730 at www.bikefriday.com.

title: What if It's All Been a Big Fat Lie?
description: Thank you for running Gary Taubes's article (July 7) and having the guts to go against the established wisdom. I've been low-carbing since March, lost 20 pounds and never felt better in my life. All my blood work has improved over the last year. I want everyone to feel this great.

title: Ideas & Trends; For Great Buildings, Get a Great Client
description: NOW that the Woolworth Building has renewed prominence in downtown Manhattan's skyline, it's worth thinking about just what makes that 90-year-old skyscraper such a great building. Or better yet, who made it such a great building?

title: More Binds Jews Than Divides Them
description: As members of an Orthodox synagogue in Great Neck, we are disturbed by the derogatory remarks toward Orthodox Jews by Rabbi Mordecai Waxman in your article ''Celebrating a Rabbi's 55 Years of Service'' [July 7]. Rabbi Waxman is troubled by the prohibition of Conservative and Reform conversions in the ritual bath, or mikvah, at the Great Neck Synagogue, an Orthodox temple, and by the lack of dialogue with the Orthodox Jewish community. While well over 99 percent of the Jews who use the mikwah are Orthodox, the mikwah is open to any member of the Jewish faith for individual purposes. It is hard to fault the administrators' desire to maintain Orthodox standards. Rabbi Waxman was always free to build a mikvah on his own synagogue grounds.

title: Family Planning
description: As a staunch pro-choice advocate, despite my own personal discomfort with abortion, I read your Lives column (July 7) with growing alarm at the heavy-handed efforts of adults on all sides to influence the decisions of a teenager who obviously had more than a few qualms about ending her pregnancy. Her searing words, ''I don't have a choice,'' spoke volumes both about her ambivalence regarding the decision and her sense of entrapment.

title: A Pioneer Develops Cold-Weather Roses
description: GRIFFITH BUCK of Iowa, a professor of horticulture, lived from 1915 to 1991, but was not fashionable during that time. Dr. Buck spent his entire career teaching at Iowa State University. His real passion, though, was hybridizing roses, and many of the ones he developed are extraordinary for their hardiness and beauty, bringing Dr. Buck posthumous renown.

description: Evelyn Kyung Kim, a designer, and Paolo Timoni, a management consultant, were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. David Stout performed the ceremony.

title: Stocks Are Only Part of the Story
description: King Canute could not command the tides, and apparently neither George W. Bush nor Alan Greenspan can command the stock market. In recent days, both the M.B.A. president and the oracular Federal Reserve chairman have tried to calm the markets with reassuring words about the economy. But the stock market has kept on falling: on Friday it had one of its worst days ever, losing 390 points. Since President Bush addressed Wall Street July 9, the Dow Jones industrial average has declined more than 10 percent, to its lowest level in almost four years.

title: Ideas & Trends: Honor and Islands; Why Nations Fight for Land Only a Goat Could Love
description: GIVEN that they are goats and lizards, the only permanent inhabitants of the tiny island of Perejil probably did not appreciate the magnitude of the rescue mission launched by Spain last week, which deployed an armada of helicopters, warships and special forces to liberate their home from an occupying force of six Moroccans and a flag.

title: Alarming Portents on Frontier of Russia's AIDS Crisis
description: As the cafes and clubs began to course with night life one recent evening, Andrei V. Bykovsky and Yuliya B. Sokolova cruised around in a white van, patrolling the newest front of Russia's AIDS epidemic.

title: Love's Labors
description: It was so feverish-hot, so sticky and infested, that Celia Maguire would have risked anything to dive into the river. Her husband, the famed botanist Bassett Maguire, would test the water first, poking the bottom to scare up any stingrays. All manner of poisonous creatures lurked below the murk in that uncharted waterway in Guyana.

title: Oniomaniacs Come Out of The Closet
description: ELIZABETH ROACH lost her get-out-of-jail-free card last week. In June 2000, Ms. Roach, a Chicago management consultant, pleaded guilty to wire fraud, having embezzled $241,061 from her employer to support her out-of-control shopping habit. She falsified hundreds of expense account documents in order to finance trips to Marshall Fields and Barneys to buy clothes and jewels.

title: Anticipating Angkor, A Dream Deferred
description: SOME people are suckers for lost cities. I am. I've sought out, among others, Machu Picchu, Pompeii, Petra, Ephesus, Karnak and Uxmal. But Angkor, the jungle-covered capital of the ancient Khmer civilization in Cambodia, has always seemed to me the Mother of All Lost Cities. Imagine Manhattan, a thousand years from now, deserted for centuries, overgrown with the native cattails and sumacs of New York Harbor, the great skyscrapers half-swamped by water. Angkor, constructed between the 9th and the 15th centuries, is comparable. One of its palaces covers 500 acres; its temple mountains reach 200 feet; carved stone giants guard its gateways; the roots of giant banyans pry apart its walls.

The accounts are now monitored by employees of the state Division of Investments. Their current value has slipped to about $73 billion, from a high of $95.4 billion recorded in 2000. Mr. McCormac said last week that he planned to audit the division and solicit proposals from outside financial managers. Jeremy Pearce

title: 'Pasadena'
description: ON A DECEMBER MORNING in 1944, Mr. Andrew Jackson Blackwood—a young-faced, self-made man who had been in California twelve or fourteen years, depending on whom you asked—was making his way down El Camino Real. He was driving his yellow Imperial Victoria on his way to a real-estate convention in San Diego. At present he was somewhere between Dana Point and Oceanside, but many miles back his Automobile Club map had flown out the window, the wings of its paper-folds extending and flapping away. The fluttery movement—and the car’s sudden swerve as he lunged for the accordioned map—made him think of a large, ancient bird lifting itself into extinction. This was a more morose thought than Blackwood was used to, and it didn’t stay with him, flitting away like the map itself. But Blackwood had a sense of direction, he liked to tell himself, and he continued on his way.

title: New Places to Hike In the Outback

It is divided into a dozen sections that can be hiked individually or in combinations; hiking the entire trail requires between eight days and two weeks.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: WOMAN DIES IN HIT-AND-RUN ACCIDENT An intoxicated driver killed a woman crossing a street in Lower Manhattan early yesterday in a hit-and-run accident, the police said. They said the woman, Nahema Abney, 20, of the Bronx, was crossing West Street at 10th Street about 4:15 a.m. when a 1999 BMW driven by Enrique Made, 29, ran a red light and struck her in the crosswalk, severing one of her legs. The driver sped away, but friends of Ms. Abney immediately flagged down a patrol car, and officers captured Mr. Made when he was slowed by heavy traffic at West 14th Street, the police said. Mr. Made was charged with one count of second-degree murder, driving while intoxicated and leaving the scene of an accident, said Sgt. Mike Wysokowski, a police spokesman. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Editorial Notebook; In the Heart of a Hard Season
description: If you look at the most recent United States Drought Monitor map, you'll notice that most of the American West is shaded in one or another of the unpleasant colors that the government weather services use to indicate lack of water. Nearly every state from Nebraska westward, excluding only Texas, Oklahoma and Washington, is experiencing conditions that range from abnormally dry to exceptional drought. Southern Wyoming, eastern Idaho, western Colorado and the northern portions of New Mexico and Arizona are joined in the worst of the suffering. What exceptional drought means is that people deep into middle age, lifelong residents of the area, have never ever seen it so dry.

title: Informant Fever

But it is more likely that you are being engaged by some of the early participants in the Terrorism Information and Prevention System, or TIPS. The Bush administration plans to enlist millions of Americans to spy on their fellow Americans, and to feed that information into a centralized database. This ill-considered domestic spying program should be stopped before it starts.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Island Park: 2 Off-Duty Officers In Bar Scuffle
description: A New York City police sergeant was arrested and suspended yesterday after being accused of attacking another police sergeant in a Long Island bar when both were off duty, the police said. The accused officer, Sgt. John Rogan, 33, did not know the other man was a police officer, the police said. The incident took place after 2:30 a.m. Saturday at the Montego Bay bar in Island Park. The other sergeant, who was not immediately identified, suffered injuries to his eye, the police said. It is unclear what prompted the dispute. Sergeant Rogan, who was charged with assault, has been suspended for 30 days without pay, the police said. He is assigned to the Internal Affairs Bureau and joined the department in 1992. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Voter Registration Forms Limited
description: Few of the 20 city agencies required to make voter registration forms available to New Yorkers do so, according to a survey by the office of the Manhattan borough president, C. Virginia Fields. The survey, conducted last month, found that only one agency, the Department of Citywide Administrative Services, attaches voter registration forms to applications given to the public, as required by law. And only four agencies had the forms available in their offices. Ms. Fields said voter registration was especially urgent in view of Mayor Michael R. title: Mafia Songs Break a Code Of Silence; A Gory Italian Folk Form Attracts Fans, and Critics
description: In the markets of small mountain towns surrounding this city on the Southern tip of Italy, a musician named Mimmo Siclari can often be found selling cassettes from the back of his van, as he has for decades. The tapes, many of which he produced himself, are emblazoned with explicit covers that depict men shot in the heart, grieving widows and monkeys in the ''hear no evil, see no evil, speak no evil'' pose over pools of blood. The cassettes themselves are transparent, because only see-through models are allowed in Italian prisons, where many of the fans of this music can be found.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: 2 Children Struck By Car
description: Two children, a sister and brother, were critically injured when a car hit their bicycle as they rode through an intersection in Queens late Saturday, the police said. The children, LaTalia Ashe, 14, and her brother, Tyrell Ashe, 10, were in critical condition yesterday at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, the police said. The children were riding together on one bicycle against traffic on 215th Place, when they glided downhill into the intersection with Hillside Avenue, in Queens Village, and were unable to stop, the police said. A car being driven by Jesus Chilon, 38, struck them as he drove through a green light, the police said. No criminal charges were issued against the driver, the police said. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, BEVERLY POTTER NAVARRO
description: MILLER-Beverly Potter Navarro. 72, San Francisco. Beverly Potter Navarro Miller, a respected member of the fashion and jewelry industries, died at the Jewish Home for the Aged in San Francisco on July 18, 2002, after a long illness of Alzheimer's Disease. She was born Beverly Lubinsky on June 22, 1930, in Brooklyn, NY. In 1973 she moved from New York City to San Francisco with her second husband David Navarro. Together they founded the jewelry design firm Navarro Alternatives, which became highly respected and widely renowned in the fashion industry for its design originality and innovation. The highly recognizable designs were worn by numerous celebrities and prominent socialites worldwide. She is survived by her husband David Potter Navarro of San Francisco, a sister Silvia Marks of East Haven, CT, a brother Paul Lawrence of New York City and Boca Raton, FL, two daughters Francine Fiesel of Sebastopol, CA, Jennifer Miller Ehret of New York City, two grandchildren Sierra and Cody Fiesel and her former husband Jock Miller of Tampa, FL. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be made in memory of Beverly Potter Navarro Miller to the National Alzheimer's Association, 919 North Michigan Avenue, Suite 1100, Chicago, IL 60611. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, July 24, at 5 PM, at The City Club of San Francisco in the Pacific Coast Stock Exchange Tower, 155 Sansome St, 10th Floor, San Francisco, CA. For information, The San Franciso Neptune Society, 415-771-0717.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Vernon: Ex-Deputy Sentenced For Firing Shots Into Car

Mr. Avery received a 13-year sentence on two counts of criminal attempt to commit assault and one count of criminal mischief. He was driving along Route 6 in Brooklyn, Conn., when a car passed him, the state's attorney said. The deputy began a high-speed chase, ramming into the back of the car and firing several shots at the occupants, the state's attorney said. No one was reported injured. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RISK, JAMES V.
description: RISK-James V. Passed away July 18, at home in Metuchen, NJ. Husband, father, international businessman, friend. Born in Uniontown, PA, he grew up during the Great Depression. In 1953 he moved to New Jersey and married Marjorie Hay, his best friend for the next 34 years until her death in 1987. They raised children Mark and Susan. In 1966 he joined Rheem International (later, City Investing International) in the management of businesses throughout the developed world. He later became its President. He made hundreds of trips to Europe, Asia, Australia, South Africa, Latin America. After retirement in 1985, he remained active in business, and served as Vice Chairman of Golden Gate Bank of San Francisco. Deeply grateful for his blessings, understanding of the difficulties of others. Many smiles and much laughter. Unconditional love. Private family funeral, memorial service to be held on date to be announced. Family will receive visitors July 22, from 2 to 4 PM, and 7 to 9 PM, at Costello Runyon Funeral Home, 568 Middlesex Avenue, Metuchen, NJ.

It stands on the north edge of Fordham University, just 150 feet from the garden's property.

title: Finding Cure for Hearts Broken Sept. 11 Is as Difficult as Explaining the Cost
description: The Sept. 11 Fund will spend as much as $55 million to provide mental health care to those traumatized by the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. The American Red Cross is also expected to spend tens of millions of dollars to help provide similar kinds of counseling. And the Robin Hood Foundation has dedicated about $2 million to treat the grieving and the distressed, including a $50,000 grant to Big Brothers Big Sisters of New York City to aid children who lost a parent in the trade center attack or who saw it take place.

title: Addiction
description: For millions of people around the world, addiction is a living hell. Addiction can destroy careers, families, lives. Today, scientists are fighting addiction  with new technologies and therapies. And they may be winning the battle. According to leading American scientists, nearly one million Americans are addicted to heroin. Between one and two million are addicted to cocaine. Approximately 3 million are compulsive gamblers. More than 7 million are alcohol dependent. And aproximately 48 million are addicted to smoking. Why do so many people get hooked on these self-destructive behaviors?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Dies In Hit-and-Run Accident
description: An intoxicated driver killed a woman crossing a street in Lower Manhattan early yesterday in a hit-and-run accident, the police said. They said the woman, Nahema Abney, 20, of the Bronx, was crossing West Street at 10th Street about 4:15 a.m. when a 1999 BMW driven by Enrique Made, 29, ran a red light and struck her in the crosswalk, severing one of her legs. The driver sped away, but friends of Ms. Abney immediately flagged down a patrol car, and officers captured Mr. Made when he was slowed by heavy traffic at West 14th Street, the police said. Mr. Made was charged with one count of second-degree murder, driving while intoxicated and leaving the scene of an accident, said Sgt. Mike Wysokowski, a police spokesman. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Handel Hero With Touch Of 'Messiah'

''Deidamia'' still isn't an audience draw: there were plenty of empty seats in the Venetian Theater at Caramoor tonight.

title: AMGEN GAINS APPROVAL FOR WIDER USE OF ANEMIA DRUG
description: Amgen said yesterday that it had won federal approval to market its drug Aranesp for cancer patients who develop anemia after chemotherapy, putting it in direct competition with Johnson & Johnson's biggest seller, Procrit. Aranesp, intended to require fewer injections than Amgen's older therapy, Epogen, won initial approval in September for treating anemia stemming from chronic kidney disease. The two drugs provided a combined $2.2 billion in revenue last year for Amgen, the world's biggest biotechnology company. Studies have shown that Aranesp could be taken once every two weeks, while Procrit is taken once a week.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Soybean Processer Acquired
description: Bunge Ltd. said it would buy 55 percent of Cereol S.A. of France from Edison Sp.A of Italy, making Bunge the world's largest soybean processor. The deal will enable Bunge, which is based in White Plains, to create a processing capacity in Europe, where demand for soybean-based livestock feed has risen since the epidemic of mad cow disease. Bunge paid $454 million for its stake in Cereol and will assume its debt and offer to buy the remaining 45 percent of the company that is publicly traded, at 32 euros a share, if the deal is approved by both European and American regulators. Shares in Cereol rose 0.1 euro, to 31.5 euros. Separately, Bunge reported second-quarter profit more than doubled because of increased sales to feed and food makers, and declines in the value of the Brazilian real and Argentine peso that lowered production costs in those countries. Fertilizer sales also increased in Brazil. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Profit At Bank
description: The Bank of China, which sold $2.5 billion of shares in its Hong Kong unit this month, said that first-half pretax profit fell 37 percent as it wrote off more bad loans at home. The bank, China's oldest lender, earned 7.02 billion yuan ($848 million) as pretax profit from Chinese branches fell 79 percent, to 961 million yuan. Profit from overseas, including from the investment bank BOCI Asia Ltd. and Bank of China (Hong Kong) Ltd., the subject of Asia's biggest initial stock sale this year, rose 6 percent, to $733 million. The lender's nonperforming loan ratio fell 2.12 percentage points, to 25.39 percent of total loans, after the bank wrote off 8.6 billion yuan of loans.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Garlic Farmers Protest
description: The ''garlic war'' heated up as about 1,000 farmers parading through central Seoul burned copies of a secret agreement between South Korea and China that opens the way to annual imports of $9 million worth of garlic from China beginning next year. The farmers shouted slogans against President Kim Dae Jung, forced last week to accept the resignation of the economic secretary responsible for negotiating the deal under which China promised not to thwart the import of $500 million in electronic equipment from South Korea. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Back to the Drawing Board
description: The six plans proposed for rebuilding the World Trade Center site in Lower Manhattan go on display tomorrow in Federal Hall at Wall and Nassau Streets. In this historic place, where George Washington took the oath as our first president, visitors can study the proposals drawn up by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Both these organizations -- having been treated to worldwide editorial derision since the plans became available last week, plus a day of public contempt (live at the Javits Center) on the weekend -- have decided to rethink their efforts. It isn't hard to see why.

title: Finding the Scary in the Merely Messy; First Warning of Mass Threat May Come From Garbage Police
description: It was the third time this month: radiation was detected on a New York City garbage truck.

description: Fear of Slowdown Seems To Drive Stock Markets

description: When people speak of having a bad subway day, it is generally understood that the day in question took place in the subway.

description: To the Editor:

title: Armstrong's Success Translates At the Tour
description: The excited fans who line the route of the Tour de France can give the wrong impression: not all the French care about the world's most prestigious bicycle race. Yet, even many of those indifferent to the sight of wiry men peddling furiously seem to have time for Lance Armstrong, the three-time Tour champion who is now well placed for a fourth successive victory at the finish line in Paris on Sunday.

title: The Home Front: Reform Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Common Ideas on Rebuilding

title: HASBRO LOSS WIDENS AFTER WRITE-DOWN ON FRENCH ASSET
description: The toy maker Hasbro said its second-quarter loss widened as it wrote down the value of its investment in a French computer game maker. Toys like the G.I. Joe action figures lifted sales for the first time in nine quarters. The loss widened to $25.9 million, or 15 cents a share, from $18.3 million, or 11 cents, a year earlier. Sales increased 6.9 percent, to $546 million from $511 million. Hasbro, which is based in Pawtucket, R.I., reduced the value of its stake in the computer game maker Infogrames Entertainment by $28.6 million, or 17 cents a share. Excluding the expense, profit was more than forecast.

description: Beyond the Big Bang

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New London: Plan To Promote Fishing
description: A group that promotes maritime development urged the state government to help expand commercial fishing by developing an existing pier in New London and thereby creating a second commercial fishing fleet of as many as two dozen vessels. Greg Belanger, executive director of the group, the Thames River Seafood Cooperative, said the pier and fleet would be an economic boon to New London. Connecticut currently has one fleet, based in Stonington. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Even Critics Say Some Designs For Downtown Aren't So Bad
description: Even as the six initial designs for the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site have come under fire in the past week as unimaginative, certain design elements appear to have captured the imagination of a diverse public audience.

title: Main Carrier in India Bracing for Damage
description: The bankruptcy filing by WorldCom on Sunday dealt a blow that analysts say may cripple India's main international long-distance and Internet provider.

title: Corrections
description: The State of the Art column in Circuits on Thursday, about developments at the Macworld trade show, misstated the availability of Version 3 of iTunes, Apple's music library software. It was released last week, not scheduled for release in two weeks.

title: Petrobras Paying $1.1 Billion For Argentine Oil Company
description: Petrleo Brasileiro S.A., Brazil's state-controlled oil company, said today that it had agreed to acquire a controlling stake in Perez Companc, the second-largest oil company in Argentina, for about $1.1 billion.

title: East 72nd St., Low Rent
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Jewish settlers suspected of selling Israeli army ammunition to Palestinians misstated the location of Adora and Telem, West Bank villages where the suspects lived. They are west of Hebron, not east.

title: Use of Antibiotics in Children Is Down, but Enough?
description: When Dr. Bonnie Fass-Offit joined a pediatric practice in suburban Philadelphia 12 years ago, she tried to follow her conviction that children should not take antibiotics or over-the-counter medications unless they were necessary.

title: Listening to the City
description: The TV cameras at the Javits Convention Center last Saturday showed a cavernous room filled with more than 4,000 New Yorkers, many shaking their heads or nodding or sketching towers in the air with their hands. What a television picture could not show was how these participants were breathing life into the process of rebuilding Lower Manhattan.

title: Two Inquiries Are Reported On Stock Picks Of Analyst
description: Jack B. Grubman, the telecommunications analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, is under scrutiny by the United States attorney in the Southern District of New York and is also under investigation by the National Association of Securities Dealers, according to an industry official close to the investigation.

title: A Hotel Stephen King Might Find Just Right
description: For the weary business traveler, the new executive retreat and inn on the old Berry Hill plantation here has it all: meeting rooms, a fitness center, a dining room with world-class cuisine, a swimming pool, tennis courts, a jogging trail on 700 bucolic acres and a renovated 160-year-old Greek Revival mansion with 19th-century chandeliers.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an erroneous version of Page A1 - prepared for other regions - appeared on Sunday in copies distributed in and around Arizona. As a result, the front-page sections of some articles did not match the continuations, and a few articles were omitted or duplicated. The affected articles may be found here today through Sunday. The page may also be requested from Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@nytimes.com. (Include a postal address.)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Court Refuses Archer Appeal
description: Jeffrey Archer, the millionaire author, former Conservative party deputy leader and member of the House of Lords, lost bids before the Court of Appeal to reconsider his conviction for perjury and reduce his four-year sentence. Lord Archer, left, was found guilty a year ago of lying and forging his diary to conceal paying a prostitute for sex in 1987. He subsequently used the false story to win a libel judgment for $780,000 from a newspaper that reported the tryst. The trial judge called it the most serious case of perjury in English criminal history. In denying the appeal, Lord Justice Rose cited ''the persistence of dishonest conduct.'' Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Lawmakers Seek Rules to Stop Redistribution of Digital TV
description: Leading members of Congress are urging the Federal Communications Commission to intervene in a dispute between the entertainment and technology industries over how to prevent television viewers from redistributing digital broadcasts over the Internet.

title: U.S. BANCORP BUYS 57 BAY VIEW BRANCHES IN CALIFORNIA
description: U.S. Bancorp said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 57 branches from the Bay View Capital Corporation for $429 million. The purchase includes $3 billion in consumer and small-business deposits and $376 million in loans, a U.S. Bancorp spokesman said. The final price will be based on the value of the consumer deposits when the deal closes by the end of the year. U.S. Bancorp has been making small purchases in California to expand its consumer business on the West Coast. In September, the bank bought 20 branches in Southern California from the Pacific Century Financial Corporation. With the Bay View branches, the company will have 215 offices in the state.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Suspicious Death
description: A woman died under suspicious circumstances at her home in Bay Ridge yesterday, the police said. The woman's death has not yet been classified as a homicide, but the woman had marks on her neck indicating she may have been strangled, the police said. The woman, whom the police identified as Paola Matos, 31, was discovered fully clothed in her second-floor apartment on 96th Street about 2:30 a.m. yesterday by her boyfriend, who then dialed 911, the police said. An autopsy was scheduled for today, said Ellen S. Borakove, a spokeswoman for the city medical examiner's office. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Death Penalty Amendments Urged
description: A state assemblyman has introduced legislation to require a stricter standard of proof for the death penalty. The assemblyman, Dr. Herb Conaway, Democrat of Delran, plans three bills that would ban imposition of the death penalty based solely on one eyewitness or on the testimony of an informer in police custody. Dr. Conaway, who is a physician, would also give the state attorney general, rather than local prosecutors, the sole power of deciding in which cases to seek the death penalty. Dr. Conaway said yesterday the measures would correct defects often cited by death penalty critics. An inmate faces execution as soon as December, he said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Man Accused of Killing Girl In California Postpones Plea
description: Unshaven and subdued, the man accused of kidnapping, sexually assaulting and murdering Samantha Runnion, 5, a week ago made his first court appearance today as prosecutors began studying whether to seek the death penalty.
