title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHALEN, MARGUERITE MOORE (NEE MAHON)
description: WHALEN - Marguerite Moore (nee Mahon), on July 21, 2002. Resident of Stamford, CT. Beloved wife of the late Robert G. Whalen. Loving mother of Barbara Decker of Stamford, CT, Cynthia Orlando of New Rochelle, NY, and Wendy Whalen of Humarock, MA. Also survived by five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Funeral service will be held at Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch St, Greenwich, CT, Wednesday, July 24, at 10am. Relatives and friends may call at the funeral home Tuesday, from 5-8:30 PM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: A HAMAS CHIEFTAIN DIES WHEN ISRAELIS ATTACK HIS HOME
description: An Israeli warplane fired a missile early this morning into the Gaza City home of a top leader of the violent group Hamas, killing at least 11 people, including several children, Hamas and hospital officials in Gaza said. Officials said more than 100 people were wounded in the attack.

description: To the Editor:

title: Liberty Finally Ends Rockers' Domination
description: Over the last two seasons, the Cleveland Rockers had beaten the Liberty five straight times by margins of 18, 5, 15, 11 and 9 points. That domination was difficult to explain because the Liberty was one of the better teams in the Women's National Basketball Association.

title: Company Offers to Buy Land In Linden for a Waste Station
description: Less than a week after a New Jersey panel ruled that the mayor of Linden improperly influenced approval of a plan for a garbage transfer station on waterfront land partly owned by the mayor's son-in-law, the waste hauling company that is seeking to operate the station said it would buy the land outright to eliminate any ethical problem.

title: Congo and Rwanda Reach Tentative Peace Pact
description: African officials announced tonight that they had reached a tentative agreement that might end the four-year war that has ravaged Congo.

title: Arbitrator Upholds Expos' Right to Trade Lloyd
description: Contrary to his wishes, Graeme Lloyd has to continue pitching for the Florida Marlins instead of returning to the Montreal Expos.

title: Gephardt Is Preparing a Measure to Legalize Illegal Immigrants
description: Seeking advantage in the contest for the political allegiance of Hispanics, House Democrats are preparing legislation that would grant permanent residency status to millions of illegal immigrants.

title: Swiss Drug Maker Has Profit and Big Hopes for a Product
description: The giant Swiss-based drug maker Novartis A.G. surprised investors today with a positive earnings report that broke away from the generally dreary trend in the market and with word that a potential billion-dollar drug may come to market sooner than expected.

title: About 3.6 Million to Be Taken Out to Ballgames in the Bronx
description: For those who believe the Yankees have too much of everything, consider this exasperating news: they are on a pace to attract nearly 3.6 million fans to the Bronx, more than any other team in major league baseball.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend on Friday with the continuation of a Critic's Notebook article about Ta'ziyeh, the Iranian musical theater tradition, misidentified the actor who played the shepherd in ''The Ta'ziyeh of the Children of Moslem'' at Lincoln Center Festival 2002. He was Hassan Aliabassi Jazi, not Morteza Saffarianrezai.

title: Baker Goes to Boston In a Five-Player Trade
description: In a five-player trade that shook up their most successful team of the past 10 years, the Boston Celtics acquired Vin Baker from the Seattle SuperSonics yesterday, returning Baker to the East Coast and to the conference of his glory.

title: Guilty Verdict For Father Of Dead Child
description: Six years ago, little Nadine Lockwood died just shy of her fifth birthday, weighing only 15 1/2 pounds. Her mother, Carla Lockwood, was imprisoned on murder charges in what was determined to be a starvation death, and the city child welfare agency came under fire for failing to respond adequately to reports of neglect at the Lockwood home.

title: FIRST NIAGARA FINANCIAL TO BUY FINGER LAKES BANCORP
description: The First Niagara Financial Group, the parent of First Niagara Bank, Cayuga Bank and Cortland Savings Bank, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Finger Lakes Bancorp for $67 million in cash and stock to add customers in three counties in Western and Central New York. First Niagara will pay $20 for each of the shares outstanding of Finger Lakes, the holding company of the Savings Bank of the Finger Lakes. Half will be in cash and the other half in stock, First Niagara said. The offer is 49 percent higher than the Finger Lakes closing price of $13.38 on Friday. First Niagara is based in Lockport, N.Y. Finger Lakes is based in Geneva, N.Y.

title: World Business Briefing | Hardware: Book-To-Bill Ratio Rose In June
description: The Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International book-to-bill ratio, which gauges demand for chip-equipment tools made in North America, rose to 1.28 in June. A ratio of 1.28 means that North American semiconductor equipment makers took $128 of new orders for every $100 of products shipped, the association said in a news release distributed yesterday. A ratio above 1 indicates an expanding market. June's ratio was higher than the 1.27 of May. Orders have been ahead of shipments since March, a sign revenue for the industry will improve in the months ahead. Sales of semiconductors and the equipment used to make them were hurt last year as the economy fell into a recession.

title: In the Death Of a Doctor, A Lesson
description: There's an old saying among doctors and nurses who become seriously ill: don't get your medical care at the hospital where you work. It brings too much embarrassment and not enough privacy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINNERTY, THOMAS P.
description: FINNERTY-Thomas P. On July 12, 2002. Mourns the loss of a dear friend and treasured associate. Memorial service Monday, July 29, at 6:00 pm, Marble Collegiate Church, 1 West 29th Street. Valerie Wilson Travel

title: Finding Refuge in Pop Culture's Version of Friendship
description: Maybe it's the heat, but something about summer makes the usual pop culture hypocrisies even more glaring. It has been clear for some time that retro womanhood is all the rage. Look at the books and articles about women who work too hard at their careers, jeopardize their marriage possibilities, have children too late and conduct themselves too wantonly while single.

title: White House Rebukes Israel for Attack, Calls It 'Heavy-Handed'
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 — President Bush issued one of his sharpest rebukes against Israel today, denouncing as "heavy-handed" the attack that killed a Hamas leader and expressing regret over "the loss of innocent life."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, MARION GARDNER
description: ALLEN - Marion Gardner. Age 88, of Port Washington, LI, on July 19, 2002. Beloved wife of Bertram Frank Allen Jr. Loving aunt of Lynn Savalas and Ruth Selig. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Funeral Home, 128 Main St., Port Washington. Visiting hours Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Religious service at funeral home Thursday 10:30 AM. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: Debate Over Whether to Defend Animal Tests
description: There are no more cats in cages in the basement animal experiment rooms at the Ohio State University veterinary hospital here, but the angry letters still pour in. From Swarthmore, Pa.: ''Cat torture.'' From West Palm Beach, Fla.: ''Cat killer.'' From Austin, Tex.: ''Despicable torture and murder.''

title: A Legendary Collector
description: In 1910, five years before Alan Lomax was born, his father, John Lomax, published a collection called ''Cowboy Songs.'' The book was dedicated to Theodore Roosevelt, who, in praising it, wrote, ''Under modern conditions . . . the native ballad is speedily killed by competition with the music-hall songs.'' The music-hall song was itself killed long ago, but the process Roosevelt describes still goes on. The amateur feels defeated by the professional. Local music dies at the hand of a national and now international music industry. We have all become like the cowboys Roosevelt described, ''ashamed to sing the crude homespun ballads.''

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: PROFIT AT BANK The Bank of China, which sold $2.5 billion of shares in its Hong Kong unit this month, said that first-half pretax profit fell 37 percent as it wrote off more bad loans at home. The bank, China's oldest lender, earned 7.02 billion yuan ($848 million) as pretax profit from Chinese branches fell 79 percent, to 961 million yuan. Profit from overseas, including from the investment bank BOCI Asia Ltd. and Bank of China (Hong Kong) Ltd., the subject of Asia's biggest initial stock sale this year, rose 6 percent, to $733 million. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAURICE, DAVID, PH.D.
description: MAURICE-David, Ph.D. July 20, 2002. We mourn the loss of an esteemed colleage, Dr. David Maurice, Professor of Ophthalmology and former Professor, Sanford University. David's love for visual sciences led to seminal contributions. He developed the confocal specular microscope, and was awarded the prestigious Friedenwald Medal at ARVO, among other honors. He was a founding editorial board member of Experimental Eye Research. We will miss his dry humor and innovative and creative intellectual power. Deepest sympathies to the family, Anna, Carlotta, Celia, Julia, Ruth and grandchildren. Stanley Chang, M.D., Chairman Edward Harkness Eye Institute Columbia University

title: Yangon Journal; Burmese Jew Shoulders Burden of His Heritage
description: The moss-covered tombstones in the Jewish cemetery here present a collective epitaph for a once-thriving population that has shrunk to just eight families and is now on the edge of extinction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS PASCAL, BILLIE
description: KRAUS PASCAL-Billie. On July 22, 2002. Of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of NYC and Westchester. Beloved wife of the late Alvin S. Kraus and the late Oscar Pascal. Loving mother of Lawrence and Howard. Dear mother-inlaw of Miriam and Kathy. Adoring grandmother of Aimee, Stacey, Alexis and Dana. Cherished brother of Bert Mehl. We will love you forever. Services on Tuesday, July 23rd, 11 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY 914-664-6800.

title: Investors Keep Jittery Watch, Some Grasping For Humor
description: In what has been a grueling summer for the stock market, shares sank further yesterday. But many investors remained calm and held their ground, resigned to the possibility that the market had yet to reach a bottom.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Brazilian Chosen For Rights Post
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan nominated Sergio Vieira de Mello, left, a career United Nations official, to succeed Mary Robinson as the High Commissioner for Human Rights. Mr. Vieira de Mello, a Brazilian, has spent most of his 33-year career in the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, and recently directed the United Nations operation overseeing East Timor's transition to independence from Indonesia. The 189-member General Assembly is expected to approve Mr. Vieira de Mello's appointment today. Ms. Robinson, the former president of Ireland, will leave the Geneva-based office in September, after five years. Daniel B. Schneider (NYT)

title: QUOTATIONS OF THE DAY
description: ''The doom and gloom on the news is enough to scare anybody.''

title: Network of Waterways Traced to Ancient Florida Culture
description: The casual visitor to this small rural community about 15 miles west of Lake Okeechobee might barely notice the broad indentations that run for seven miles from a cluster of oak-shaded mounds through scrub pine and palmetto to the Caloosahatchee River.

title: Britain Names a Liberal as Archbishop of Canterbury
description: LONDON, July 23  Britain today named Rowan Williams, a Welsh churchman outspokenly in favor of gay clergy and women priests and opposed to Western militarism, to be the new spiritual leader of the world's 70 million Anglicans.

title: A Catholic Is Shot to Death As Violence Flares in Ulster
description: A series of shootings in Belfast, the Northern Ireland capital, on Sunday night left one man dead and two seriously wounded, illustrating how quickly the province's sectarian divisions can turn violent.

title: Sometimes, the March of Science Goes Backward
description: No one is quite sure why they call themselves the Sheiks, but according to one theory the name was coined by Glenn T. Seaborg, the great nuclear chemist, as a whimsical acronym for Super-Heavy Element International Kollaboration.

title: WorldCom Tremors Are Muted in Japan
description: When Enron declared bankruptcy last year, Japanese investors were shaken because Japanese banks and supposedly low-risk money-market funds had big positions in Enron bonds.

title: ON THE GROUND: In Phoenix; Technology and Rapid Growth in the Valley of the Sun
description: Phoenix is the leading contender to become the home of the International Genomics Center, a collaborative effort by industry and universities to use the human genome to find cures for specific cancers. City leaders say that winning the nationwide contest to be the host of the center will make Phoenix a major locus for genetic research.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Insurer Expects Loss
description: A leading Dutch insurer, Aegon N.V., said profit this year would be 30 to 35 percent lower than expected, setting off a sharp decline in its stock price. The company predicted in May that its profit would reach the 2.4 billion euros ($2.4 billion) it earned in 2001. The company said the lower forecast was a result of the falling United States dollar and the weak bond market. Compared with its European rivals, Aegon has the largest exposure to earnings and investment portfolios in the United States, including a $200 million exposure to WorldCom. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: BOOK-TO-BILL RATIO ROSE IN JUNE The Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International book-to-bill ratio, which gauges demand for chip-equipment tools made in North America, rose to 1.28 in June. A ratio of 1.28 means that North American semiconductor equipment makers took $128 of new orders for every $100 of products shipped, the association said in a news release distributed yesterday. A ratio above 1 indicates an expanding market. June's ratio was higher than the 1.27 of May. Orders have been ahead of shipments since March, a sign revenue for the industry will improve in the months ahead. Sales of semiconductors and the equipment used to make them were hurt last year as the economy fell into a recession.

title: Disorder Makes Hunger a Constant Companion
description: If you think you have trouble controlling your caloric intake when food seems to be everywhere you turn, think what it must be like for children born constantly hungry, unable to feel full or satisfied and, as a result, constantly obsessed with food and eating.

title: Turkish Party Balks at Call From Premier To Delay Vote
description: The biggest party in Turkey's fragile governing coalition threatened today to bring down the government unless Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit stuck to an agreement to hold early elections in November.

title: African Traditions Meet Dance-Floor Electronica
description: It was only a matter of time before dance-music and electronica producers latched on to African music. Both use the power of pattern and repetition to get people moving; both are willing to assimilate whatever comes along. And while the prospect of an African band with prerecorded rhythm tracks might seem about as savory as microwave popcorn, Issa Bagayogo, the Malian bandleader who performed at Joe's Pub on Thursday, made vibrant music with a digital foundation.

title: Officer Accused of Ecstasy Sales Counseled Students About Drugs
description: A police officer from Bayonne, N.J. who once served as a drug-abuse-prevention instructor for schoolchildren was one of two officers who were charged in the sale of Ecstasy to undercover officers, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Avaya Cuts Jobs After Quarterly Loss
description: Avaya Inc., a leading maker of office telephone equipment, said today that it was cutting jobs after reporting a fiscal third-quarter loss of $37 million and a 29 percent decline in sales.

title: Bloomberg Sees Need for More Power Plants in the City
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city was in desperate need of more power plants after the major explosion and fire on Saturday at an electrical transformer on the East River.

title: New Import From Japan That's Loaded With Sugar
description: The story of Puffy Amiyumi sounds like the story of any other pre-fab pop group. The two women were put together by music-industry executives in Tokyo; their first single, ''Asia No Junshin,'' was a smash hit; over the next few years they conquered Japan with a television show and a blizzard of merchandise.

title: Prince Ahmed bin Salman, Top Horse Owner, Dies at 43
description: Prince Ahmed bin Salman, the Saudi Arabian businessman who owned War Emblem, the winner of this year's Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes, and Point Given, thoroughbred racing's 2001 horse of the year, died yesterday at a hospital in Riyadh. He was 43.

title: Afghanistan's National Army Receives First Troops
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 23  Afghanistan's fledgling National Army came into being today with the graduation of its first battalion of soldiers from training program run by United States special forces.

title: Civil Rights Commissioner Under Fire for Comments on Arabs
description: Leaders of some Arab-American and civil rights group called for the removal today of a conservative member of the United States Commission on Civil Rights after he made comments that the groups say suggested tolerance for interning Arab-Americans in the effort against terrorism.

title: Looking at the Realities Of a Damaged Industry
description: AS business and leisure travel are among the most important industries in the United States, let us look at four recent developments that help to explain what is really happening in the huge segment of the American transportation system that depends on airplanes and airports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, FRED
description: KLEIN - Fred. 1913 - 2002. Adored husband of Marilynn for 35 years, caring uncle of Michael, Patti and Sally, and sister-in-law Dorothy Klein. Born in Hungary, Fred had a stellar 57 year career as a French horn player with CBS Symphony, Rochester Philharmonic, Mexico Symphony, Goldman Band, New York Philharmonic, Broadway shows and TV. He played the first performance in the US of Britten's Serenade for Horn, Tenor and Strings. Fred and Marilynn shared an avid interest in transatlantic ship travel and a passion for New York City. He was unforgettable to all who knew him. Fred was proud to donate his body for research to Columbia University. There will be a celebration of Fred's life in September.

title: Diallo Is Comfortable With the MetroStars
description: MAMADOU DIALLO was, perhaps he still is, the man the MetroStars and their fans have loved to loathe. Now, as unpalatable as it might be for some, Diallo just wants to be loved.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOLF, ANTHONY LEWIS (TONY)
description: WOLF-Anthony Lewis (Tony) 11/1/62-7/23/82. Endless sorrow-eternal love. Mom and Sash

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: ZIMBABWE: 2 MORE JOURNALISTS ON TRIAL Two Zimbabwean journalists, who went on trial on charges of publishing falsehoods in breach of tough new media legislation, called for sections the law to be declared unconstitutional. Geoff Nyarota, editor of The Daily News, the country's sole independent daily, and a reporter, Lloyd Mudiwa, face charges of publishing falsehoods and abusing journalistic privileges. The case follows that of the journalist Andrew Meldrum, who was acquitted last week and is fighting an expulsion order. Since the law took effect on March 15, 12 journalists have been arrested  some of them more than once.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Protesting U.S. Penalties
description: The Foreign Ministry issued a statement protesting penalties imposed by the United States on nine Chinese companies accused of selling equipment with possible military applications to Iran. The ministry said China opposed the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and had abided by pledges to stop their spread. The penalties bar the nine companies plus a businessman from India from doing business with the United States government and limit their ability to trade with the United States. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Regional Bell Giants No Longer Invulnerable
description: Shortly after BellSouth, the nation's No. 3 local phone company, sent its stock plunging yesterday by saying it would fail to meet its financial targets for 2002, one analyst released a report titled, ''It's Official -- There Is No Place to Hide.''

title: Virgin's Chairman Perks Up Air Show
description: Leave it to Richard Branson to bring the party supplies to a wake.

title: Bush Gets Counterterror Tour And Pushes His Security Plan
description: President Bush came today to a national laboratory that is a direct descendant of the one where scientists pioneered the work that led to the development of the atomic bomb. There he declared that new technologies to detect anthrax, sniff biological attacks in buildings and help contain panic after an attack would help win ''the defining conflict of the 21st century.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: A Restriction On Old Cash
description: No one knows quite how much old European cash has yet to be converted into euros, but one thing is definite: it will not be any help to strained national budgets. The European statistics institute, Eurostat, announced yesterday that the 12 nations in the euro zone cannot use figures for unredeemed cash to reduce their deficits. The institution said that the member states and the European Central Bank had agreed to the decision. The euro has been in place in 12 countries since Jan. 1 and bankers estimate that the equivalent of several billion euros worth of marks, francs and other former national currencies remains unchanged. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Spraying For West Nile Virus
description: For the first time this year, parts of New York City will be sprayed tomorrow night for mosquitoes that carry the West Nile virus. Health officials said yesterday that Anvil, a pesticide first used by the city in 1999, will be sprayed from trucks from 9 p.m. Wednesday until 2 a.m. Thursday, unless there is rain or high wind. Areas to be sprayed include Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn and a section of Staten Island bounded by Forest Avenue, Richmond Avenue, Victory Boulevard and land just west of the West Shore Expressway. Although the city has experienced no cases of human infection this year, health officials said 17 mosquito samples and one bird tested positive for the virus. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Revised View of 2nd Amendment Is Cited as Defense in Gun Cases
description: Scores of criminal defendants around the nation have asked federal courts to dismiss gun charges against them based on the Justice Department's recently revised position on the scope of the Second Amendment.

title: Centralia Journal; For 40 Years and Counting, Fire Down Below and Dogged Persistence Above
description: Forty years and $42 million later, the fire in an abandoned mine under this hard-coal hamlet still burns down below as doggedly as the 86-year-old mayor, Lemar Mervine, holds out here above, refusing to vacate the wasted landscape of a condemned ghost town.

title: Flamingo Paradise Is Losing Its Luster
description: A thriving population of Caribbean flamingos in Mexico, once on the verge of extinction, is threatened anew by environmental changes that could reverse the gains of recent years.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: COMVERSE TECHNOLOGY WILL LAY OFF 1,200 Comverse Technology Inc., a maker of software and systems for wireless communications and Internet services, said yesterday that it planned to lay off approximately 1,200 people, or 21 percent of its work force, because of continued weakness in telecommunications capital spending. The company, based in Woodbury, N.Y., will have about 4,500 employees after the layoffs. Almost half of Comverse's employees are based in Israel where its research headquarters are situated. Comverse announced last month that first-quarter revenues decreased 42 percent, to $211.2 million, from $365 million in the first quarter of 2001. An analyst at Merrill Lynch, however, upgraded his rating on the company for the second time in three weeks. Shares fell 3 cents, to $8.51. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: AT&T and Sprint try to lure business from MCI customers by emphasizing their longevity.
description: AS MCI remains mum about future campaigns to reassure customers that service will not be affected by the bankruptcy filing of its parent, WorldCom, competitors are already making subtle marketing moves to snatch away some of that business.

title: D'AGOSTINO TO BUY BRITISH-OWNED MARKETS IN NORTHEAST
description: The Marks & Spencer Group, the British clothing retailer, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Kings Super Markets chain in the United States to D'Agostino Supermarkets for $160 million, completing a planned withdrawal from most international businesses. Kings has 25 grocery stores in Northern New Jersey and 2 in New York. The closely held D'Agostino operates stores in New York City and Westchester County. In November, Marks & Spencer sold Brooks Brothers to Retail Brand Alliance for $225 million.

title: Edison Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about the growth of the hip-hop format among radio stations that previously emphasized rhythm and blues misstated the surname of a program host at WWPR-FM in New York City, which switched its format in March. He is Curt Flirt, not Flint. The caption also rendered the name of another host incorrectly. He is Doctor Dre -- not to be confused with the rap musician Dr. Dre.

title: In the Beginning...
description: It has always been easy to make fun of cosmologists, confined to a dust mote lost in space, pronouncing judgment on the fate of the universe or the behavior of galaxies billions of light-years away, with only a few scraps of light as evidence.

title: Washington Talk; In Briar Patch of Advise and Consent, Safety First
description: When President Bush nominated Dr. Richard H. Carmona to be the nation's next surgeon general, gay rights organizations put out the usual calls to check out his views on AIDS. The effort proved fruitless.

title: More Than Just a Faint
description: To the Editor:

title: New Church Home for Priest Who Sued a Bishop
description: THE Episcopal priest assumes a robotic voice: ''Pin Bot. Circuits. Are. Activated.'' She presses the start button and a pinball machine jangles to life in a rectory sitting room.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Comverse Technology Will Lay Off 1,200
description: Comverse Technology Inc., a maker of software and systems for wireless communications and Internet services, said yesterday that it planned to lay off approximately 1,200 people, or 21 percent of its work force, because of continued weakness in telecommunications capital spending. The company, based in Woodbury, N.Y., will have about 4,500 employees after the layoffs. Almost half of Comverse's employees are based in Israel where its research headquarters are situated. Comverse announced last month that first-quarter revenues decreased 42 percent, to $211.2 million, from $365 million in the first quarter of 2001. An analyst at Merrill Lynch, however, upgraded his rating on the company for the second time in three weeks. Shares fell 3 cents, to $8.51. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

description: Orderly Ant Corpses

title: Israel to Let Arab Moderate Reopen Office
description: Israeli security officials reached a face-saving compromise today with a leading Palestinian moderate, Sari Nusseibeh, to allow him to reopen his office here. Its closing brought Israel a rare rebuke from the Bush administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALAWER, SYLVIA
description: MALAWER-Sylvia, age 98, on Sunday July 21 at her home in Silver Spring, MD, after a long and enriched life. Beloved wife of the late Jack Malawer. Loving mother of the late Sidney J. Malawer (Carol) and Donald (Susan) Malawer. Cherished grandmother of Judith (Kyle) Walker, Leslie (Chris) Keenan of Maryland, Steven (Nicole) Malawer of Connecticut, and David (Michelle) Malawer of NY; and five great-grandchildren. Services today 12 noon at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to the National Kidney Foundation.

title: Henry Thornberry, 76, Former Times Editor
description: Henry Thornberry, a former executive editor of The New York Times News Service, died Sunday in Coxsackie, N.Y. He was 76.

title: Ashland Inc. Reports $65 Million Profit
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 22 (AP)  Ashland Inc. reported a $65 million third-quarter profit today, down sharply from a year ago as slumping gasoline refining operations dragged earnings below analysts' expectations.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: CAMDEN: GUILTY PLEA IN BABY'S DEATH A 16-year-old girl pleaded guilty yesterday to smothering her 8-month-old daughter last January, the Camden County prosecutor's office said yesterday. The girl, Stephanie Fitzgerald, of Pennsauken, will be sentenced to 12 years and will become eligible for parole in about 10 years. She faced 30 years if her case had gone to trial. Ms. Fitzgerald told Judge Linda G. Baxter of Superior Court that she held her hand over the mouth of her baby, Isabella Steele, for one minute, then waited 10 minutes to call for help. The baby died four days later. Prosecutors are to release further details of the case later. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Since the 70's, a Greenwich Village Cafe Has Nurtured the Spirit of the 60's
description: For 25 years Robin Hirsch has guided the Cornelia Street Cafe in Greenwich Village with the notion that all artists should have a public forum for their particular passion, whether they might ever earn a dollar from it.

title: Vivendi Chief Said to Weigh Overhaul of Canal Plus
description: As a step toward sorting out the problems facing Vivendi Universal, the new chief executive, Jean-Ren Fourtou, is considering an overhaul of the Canal Plus Group, the money-losing French pay television unit, including the sale of some assets and the creation of a company that could be floated on the stock market, people who have been briefed on the plan said today.

title: Drug-Free Menopause
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEHR, REV. FR. JAMES P., S.J.
description: STEHR-Rev. Fr. James P., S.J., on July 20th, 2002. Reposing at America House, 106 West 56 St., Tuesday, July 23rd, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Also reposing at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave. at 84 St., Wednesday, 10-11 AM, with Mass of Christian Burial to follow at 11:30 AM.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: PROTESTING U.S. PENALTIES The Foreign Ministry issued a statement protesting penalties imposed by the United States on nine Chinese companies accused of selling equipment with possible military applications to Iran. The ministry said China opposed the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and had abided by pledges to stop their spread. The penalties bar the nine companies plus a businessman from India from doing business with the United States government and limit their ability to trade with the United States.

title: Ways to Treat Common Childhood Maladies
description: Anumber of misconceptions surround many of the most common childhood ailments and how or whether they should be treated with over-the-counter remedies. The following are common maladies and experts' recommendations for treating them.

title: Frank Shea, 81, Yankee Pitcher in '47 Series
description: Frank Shea, the Yankees pitcher who beat the Brooklyn Dodgers twice in the 1947 World Series to highlight a remarkable rookie season, died last Friday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 81.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Raising A School Tax
description: Gov. Don Siegelman said he planned a tax on big companies to raise $200 million annually for schools. Mr. Siegelman, a Democrat seeking re-election this year, said some big companies were ''cooking their books'' to avoid paying income taxes. William O'Connor, president of the Business Council of Alabama, said there was no evidence for the accusation. Dana Beyerle (NYT)

title: Taking Medication
description: To the Editor:

title: Soriano and 'M.V.P.' Starting to Go Together
description: Alfonso Soriano heard the three magical letters associated with his name for the first time while he was waiting in the on-deck circle last month: M.V.P. A fan shouted that Soriano was the most valuable player in the American League and Soriano, his eyes and his smile growing wider as he recounted the moment, said he had not pondered himself in that stratosphere until then.

title: Demand Up for Treasury Bonds
description: Treasury prices rose for a third day yesterday as a decline in stocks fueled demand for government securities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOUCEY, WALTER C.
description: TOUCEY-Walter C. A former financial executive in New York City and a resident of Rye Brook, N.Y. died July 22, 2002. He was 91. He graduated the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. He received his New York CPA Certificate in 1937. Funeral and burial services are private. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Summerfield United Methodist Church, 225 King St, Port Chester, N.Y. 10573. Inquires Craft Memorial Home, Inc., Port Chester, N.Y.

title: An 1836 Plot Kept Afloat By Devices From Today
description: Attention all cryonics labs: if you have any 200-year-old Germans in the racks, now is a good time to thaw them out, because only they are likely to appreciate fully ''Leonce & Lena,'' the 1836 comedy by Georg Bchner now receiving a colorful staging at the Connelly Theater.

title: Mayor Hints He May Turn To Layoffs
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg hinted yesterday that he might resort to layoffs to ease what he now calls a ''budget crisis,'' and his administration has taken the first step by inviting city commissioners to consider layoffs to cut the city payroll.

title: Washington Mayor's Campaign Is Its Own Worst Enemy
description: Mayor Anthony A. Williams, the supposedly nonpolitical, definitely nonflamboyant technocrat who delivered the capital city from the chronic embarrassment of the Marion Barry years, is suddenly learning harsh lessons about the political nuts and bolts of re-election.

title: U.S.-Europe Group Wants to Build Nuclear Fuel Plant in U.S.
description: A consortium of European and United States nuclear companies said today that it would apply soon for a license from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to build a $1.1 billion plant for processing reactor fuel, the first in this country in half a century and one of the largest private nuclear projects here since the 1980's.

title: Extension For Leiter Is Close
description: Al Leiter was in a Manhattan doctor's office yesterday, receiving a physical as part of the process to complete a contract extension. Leiter would not comment, but physicals are standard procedure for players signing new contracts.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Substitute For Tainted Post Office
description: The United States Postal Service plans to open a temporary mail-sorting center off the New Jersey Turnpike in Monroe while the Hamilton mail center, closed Oct. 18 because of anthrax contamination, continues to be decontaminated, Representative Christopher H. Smith said yesterday. Mr. Smith, Republican of Robbinsville, said he would meet with Postal Service management to ensure that the new center does not delay reopening of the Hamilton site, whose 1,100 workers have been reassigned. Iver Peterson (NYT)

title: The Afghan Front: Errant Bombs
description: To the Editor:

title: Scutaro Makes a Name for Himself
description: Bobby Valentine did not recognize Marco Scutaro the first time he saw him, thinking he was a friendly fan when Scutaro introduced himself last Friday at a Cincinnati restaurant, where the Mets were playing. Scutaro mumbled his name and Valentine could not understand him, perhaps because of Scutaro's Venezuelan accent or perhaps because he was unfamiliar with the name.

title: Rumsfeld Calls Civilian Deaths Relatively Low
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that the American bombing campaign in Afghanistan might have been the most accurate ever undertaken, resulting in fewer deaths of innocent civilians than any air war in history.

title: Earnings Up at U.S. Steel
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the largest steel maker in the country, said today that it earned $27 million in the second quarter, reversing a loss a year earlier.

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday with an article about the cleanup of the Passaic River reversed the labels for two New Jersey counties. Union County is south of Essex.

title: Mixed Pair Wins at Bridge Tournament
description: The Life Master Pair Championship was won here Sunday night, after six sessions of play, by Tobi Sokolow of Austin, Tex., and Leonard Holtz of Los Angeles. Only six other mixed pairs have won this title in 73 years, and this time there was a unique feature: the second- and third-place finishers were also mixed partnerships.

title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: PENNSYLVANIA: A MONEY PIT Despite an infusion of money, Archbald Pothole State Park has not turned into the tourist attraction that local officials hoped. The park near Scranton, centered around a 38-foot-deep glacial pothole, reopened five years ago after a $170,000 facelift. Instead of attracting tourists, officials said, it has become a prime location for trash dumping. The world's largest such pothole, it was formed by glacial movements during the last Ice Age about 18,000 years ago. (AP)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Interview With a Humanoid
description: In a secret, locked barn near DeForest, five black-and-white calves look up from their hay with huge, friendly eyes. No. 313 approaches, as if to grant an interview, for these are not the ordinary bovines they seem -- all five are part human.

title: Fever Phobia, and Other Parental Bugaboos
description: A number of misconceptions surround many of the most common childhood ailments and how or whether they should be treated with over-the-counter remedies. The following are common maladies and experts' recommendations for treating them.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a review of the Kirov Ballet's ''Don Quixote'' misidentified the dancers shown. They were Islom Baimuradov and Lira Khuslamova, supporting players, not Anton Korsakov and Irina Golub, the principals.

title: Radical Union Leaders Are Threatening a Hot British Summer
description: A resurgent British labor-union movement, egged on by a new generation of radical leaders, is threatening a summer of strikes in what would be the biggest show of worker militancy in Britain in two decades.

title: AMC Movie Chain Reports Wider Loss
description: AMC Entertainment said today that its fiscal first-quarter loss was wider than estimates and that it had forgiven $19.8 million in loans to two executives. Its shares fell as much as 30 percent.

title: Charges by Halliburton Will Mean Quarterly Loss
description: Two days before issuing its second-quarter results, the Halliburton Company warned investors yesterday that it would have to take several one-time charges that will result in a loss for the quarter. The news touched off a drop of nearly 14 percent in the company's stock.

title: Camden Recovery Bill Signed, But School Board Challenges It
description: As Gov. James E. McGreevey signed into law today a $175 million bill to revitalize Camden, New Jersey's poorest city, the Camden Board of Education filed a lawsuit to block parts of the recovery package that it considers unconstitutional.

title: EARNINGS MORE THAN DOUBLED FOR 3M IN 2ND QUARTER
description: The 3M Company, which makes a wide range of products, including medical inhalers and Post-It Notes, reported yesterday that earnings more than doubled in the second quarter, aided by cost cuts in the United States and higher prices for goods sold overseas. Net income rose to $466 million, or $1.18 a share, from $202 million, or 50 cents, a year earlier, 3M said. Sales rose 2.2 percent, to $4.16 billion. 3M, which changed its name in April from the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, said sales volume in the Asia-Pacific region rose 15 percent while sales dropped 3 percent in Europe and 1.8 percent in the United States.

title: Stocks Tumble, And the Fallout Is Going Global
description: The United States stock market fell sharply again yesterday. Investors seemed to fear a slowdown in the world economy and shrugged off President Bush's statement that ''there is value in the market'' now.

title: Why We're So Nice: We're Wired to Cooperate
description: What feels as good as chocolate on the tongue or money in the bank but won't make you fat or risk a subpoena from the Securities and Exchange Commission?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDT, WILLIAM K., PH.D.
description: BRANDT-William K., Ph.D., 59, an internationally known management consultant to Fortune 500 companies worldwide, died Friday July 19, at Greenwich Hospital. Survived by his wife Catherine, daughter Carleson, son Brooks, stepdaughter Caroline, and his mother Helen. Services will be held at the Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Rd., Greenwich, CT on Wednesday July 24, at 3:00 P.M.

title: Some Streets Are Made for Walking
description: Some people think older houses have more charm. A study being published today suggests that they may also offer a healthful benefit: people in cities and suburbs who live in houses built before 1974 are almost 50 percent more likely to walk a lot for pleasure, it found.

title: Giants Plan to Be Cautious, Easing In Zeigler and Sehorn
description: The Giants report to training camp in Albany tomorrow and begin workouts Thursday, and as expected, neither center Dusty Zeigler nor cornerback Jason Sehorn -- each had off-season knee surgery -- will participate in the first practices. Coach Jim Fassel indicated yesterday that the Giants' medical staff figured Zeigler and Sehorn were about 90 percent along in their recoveries and should join teammates soon after the beginning of workouts.

title: Schumer Endorses McCall as Clinton Remains Neutral
description: United States Senator Charles E. Schumer took the unusual step yesterday of jumping into the hotly contested Democratic primary for governor, endorsing H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, over his opponent, Andrew M. Cuomo.

title: Safeco Swings to Profit for Second Quarter
description: The Safeco Corporation, a property-casualty and life insurer, returned to profitability in the second quarter on price increases, lower claims and cost-cutting.

title: Needing Vacation After a Vacation
description: Americans are wearier after their vacations than before them, a Gallup poll has found.

title: The Girls Are All Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Population-Control Politics
description: There is a mind-bending illogic behind the Bush administration's decision yesterday to withhold $34 million from the United Nations Population Fund, which is working in China despite continued practices there of coerced abortion and sterilization. It is precisely because of China's reprehensible policies that the U.N. presence is important. Cutting off funds to the agency is an inexcusable sop to right-wing anti-abortion activists in an election year. It will increase the number of abortions worldwide by depriving poor women of the education and help they need and that the U.N. agency provides.

title: Colombian Wins Time Trial; Armstrong Holds Overall Lead
description: LES DEUX ALPES, France, July 23  Santiago Botero, a strong climber and time trialer from Colombia, is rarely accused of consistency and today he showed why. One mountain stage after he was glued to the road and lost more than 15 minutes, Botero left six companions far behind in a long breakaway in the Alps and easily won the 15th of 20 stages in the Tour de France.

title: The Battle Over Drug Coverage
description: The struggle over prescription drug coverage for the elderly through Medicare is heading toward a showdown in the Senate today with no likelihood that either of two major bills will gather enough support to pass. A failure to act this session would be a blow to the Democrats, who desperately need to pass something to show that the chamber they control can do as well as or better than the Republican-controlled House, which passed a weak prescription drug bill last month. More important, it would be a blow to millions of elderly people who lack insurance coverage for their costly medicines.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Anthrax Possession Charge
description: Federal officials charged a graduate student yesterday with possession of an anthrax sample he kept in his campus laboratory refrigerator, but officials deferred prosecution in light of the student's cooperation. The anthrax sample is 40-year-old cow tissue that is not infectious because it has not been processed to produce dangerous spores. The University of Connecticut student, Tomas Foral, 26, of West Hartford, above, was charged with one count of possessing a biological agent, punishable by up to 10 years in prison. The anthrax sample was discovered in November as part of the investigation of the anthrax death of Ottilie Lundgren, a Connecticut resident. Officials said they would defer prosecuting Mr. Foral, a student in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources, if he completes a pretrial program, possibly involving community service. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Taiwan's Tobacco Monopoly Loses Its Key Props
description: The future has rarely been so cloudy for Taiwan's sprawling century-old tobacco and alcohol monopoly, which the government has begun converting into a publicly traded company competing in a free market.

title: Q & A
description: Honking Geese

title: Front Row
description: If you are not a stranger to certain byways of the Metropolitan Transit Authority -- the Flatbush Avenue subway line in Brooklyn, say -- you may be familiar with one of the summer's most inventive fashion statements.

title: Hipoisie and Chic-oisie And London Had the Mojo
description: READY, STEADY, GO!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPAPORT, BERNICE (BUNNY)
description: RAPPAPORT-Bernice (Bunny). It is with deep sadness that we announce the untimely passing of Bunny. She was loved and adored by husband Arnold, daughter Lynn, son Jay, daughter-in-law Harriet, granddaughters Julie and Katie and countless friends and family. We are all deeply affected by this huge loss which took us all by surprise, and she fought her sudden illness bravely and with dignity. The center of so many loving family and friends, she had great style, and will be remembered for her warmth, loyalty, caring and concern for all those who knew her. Services at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, 1PM today.

title: Behind the Grandeur, Turmoil at the British Museum; Financial Troubles, Staff Cuts and Low Morale Plague a Top Tourist Attraction
description: From the outside, the British Museum looks the same as ever. An average 400,000 visitors come and go each month, drawn by special new exhibitions -- currently, the big-ticket show is a celebration of the life of the Queen of Sheba -- and by perennial favorites like the Elgin Marbles and the collections of Egyptian antiquities. Norman Foster's soaring $145 million Great Court, completed in 2000, provides a gleaming modern centerpiece to a doughty institution nearing its 250th birthday.

title: A Professor's Activism Leads Investigators to Look Into Possible Terrorism Links
description: To his family and friends, Sami Al-Arian, a Palestinian professor of computer engineering at the University of South Florida, is an innocent victim of a government witch hunt. News reports based on a lengthy F.B.I. inquiry into his support for Islamic causes prompted the college to suspend him from his tenured post last fall, and this year, to begin a process to fire him.

title: Lost in Sweden: A Kurdish Daughter Is Sacrificed
description: For a while, Fadime Sahindal seemed an ideal symbol of second-generation immigrant success in a country that prides itself on its openness and tolerance.

title: Government Can't Make the Market Fair
description: Anyone who thinks the current round of corporate scandal could have been prevented with new rules and regulations simply does not understand American capitalism. The Enrons, WorldComs and Tycos are not abnormalities in a ''basically sound system.'' Scandals are endemic to capitalism. The best any government can do is contain the damage, and the best any individual investor can do is get out of harm's way.

title: Complex El Paso Partnerships Puzzle Analysts
description: While other energy companies rush to simplify their businesses and balance sheets in hopes of escaping Enron's taint, one industry giant, the El Paso Corporation, is growing ever more reliant on deals so complex that securities experts call them incomprehensible.

title: Westchester Leader Is Seeking To Raise Sales Tax to 7.75%
description: Westchester County Executive Andrew J. Spano called today for a 1-percent increase in the county sales tax after releasing midyear figures that showed a $328,625 shortfall in sales tax revenue, the first decline since 1998.

title: Palm Inc. Says I.B.M. Deal Will Aid Sales To Businesses
description: Palm Inc. is announcing today a deal for joint technology development and marketing with I.B.M. intended to increase the use of Palm hand-held computers in corporations and broaden the use of I.B.M.'s software development tools in the hand-held business.

title: Mineta Says Congress Is Hindering Aviation Security
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Congress has "dramatically undermined" the Transportation Department's ability to meet aviation security deadlines, the Secretary of Transportation complained today, because it has waited too long to provide the money and put too many restrictions on how it could be spent.

title: F.A.A. Cancels Licenses of Pilots in July 4 Incident in Queens
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has revoked the flying licenses of two Florida pilots who are charged with flying recklessly over Queens on the Fourth of July, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIDERMAN, GEORGE
description: BIDERMAN-George. Writer, activist, conservationist, progressive humanist. After a long illness, and caring for his beloved wife and partner, Beth, to the end, George died peacefully and on his own terms at home July 20, 2002. Trained as a social scientist, worked as a journalist and creative PR man, a master of the written word and eloquent persuasion. Reporter for Advertising Age 1946-47, PR director for Bantam Books 1948-52, ran his own agency 1952-71 with a long list of notable clients. Political strategist and spokesman for the Fire Island Association (president 1972-81), he led the fight against a four-lane highway and spearheaded creation of the National Seashore, preserving the island for generations to come. Founding member, Gateway Citizens Committee, establishing the National Recreation Area. Past board member, Regional Plan Association. Avid fisherman, enthralled fan of jazz, entertaining raconteur and incorrigible punster. Cherished by brother, Albert, admired and loved by daughter, Tina Vartanian, and son, John. Grandfather to Alexandre Vartanian and Lauren Scharf. In activity large and small he tried to make the world a better place and his likes will not again be seen. Donations in memory of George and Beth to The Nation Associates, attn: P. Randall, 33 Irving Pl., NYC 10003.

title: Midwestern Storms Mean Delays, Lots of Them, for Air Travelers
description: A line of thunderstorms from Ottawa to New Orleans snagged air traffic around the country today, closing off air routes and then briefly, tantalizingly, opening them again, leaving passengers on east-west flights in limbo, sometimes for hours.

title: Olympic Fame Proves Fleeting
description: For nearly a month before, during and after the Salt Lake Olympics, their faces were everywhere.

title: Torricelli Faces 4-Hour Inquiry By Ethics Panel About Gifts
description: Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey appeared at a closed hearing of the Senate Select Committee on Ethics today to give sworn testimony about allegations that he accepted tens of thousands of dollars in cash and gifts from a wealthy campaign contributor in exchange for political favors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIL, IRVING G.
description: WEIL-Irving G. on July 20, 2002 at Andrus Retirement Community, Hastings - on Hudson at the age of 97. He was the widower of Anne Mary Feldmar Weil. He was retired from Studio Weil, a continuation of the business of F. Weil & Co. Vienna, Austria, first in Paris and then for many years in NYC. Until recently he was an active member of Humanitas Lodge #

title: In Racing and Business, Prince Hit His Stride
description: He discovered America's most famous race as a boy in Riyadh and dreamed about it as a college student in California. When Prince Ahmed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia watched his 11th-hour purchase, a colt named War Emblem, bounce from the gate at Churchill Downs on the first Saturday of last May and lead every step of the way, the prince turned to his trainer, Bob Baffert, and in a high-pitched squeal, asked him to pinch him, ''right there in the grandstand.''

title: Fehr Says Strike Date Has Not Been Set
description: Strike date? What strike date?

title: Student Pleads Guilty to Lying About Sept. 11 Defendant
description: An Oklahoma college student pleaded guilty yesterday to lying when he was asked by the F.B.I. about Zacarias Moussaoui, who was later charged in the Sept. 11 terrorist conspiracy.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: New Government Takes Office
description: A new center-right Dutch government took office, with key positions going to the party of Pim Fortuyn, the political leader who was assassinated just before the elections in May. Jan Peter Balkenende, a Christian Democrat and a former professor of economics and ethics, became the new prime minister. He took over from Wim Kok, the Labor Party leader who had headed the government since 1994. The new, largely conservative government has said it intends to cut back the welfare state and restrict immigration. Marlise Simons (NYT)

The baby died four days later. Prosecutors are to release further details of the case later. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Columbia Suspends Search for Dean of Journalism School
description: Lee C. Bollinger, Columbia University's new president, said today that he was suspending the search for a new dean of the university's graduate journalism school — long regarded as a leader in its profession — until he and the school can rethink its mission and curriculum.

title: Citigroup Is Linked to a Deal That Let Enron Skirt Rules
description: Senior credit officers of Citigroup misrepresented the full nature of a 1999 transaction with Enron in the records of the deal so that the energy company could ignore accounting requirements and hide its true financial condition, according to internal bank documents and government investigators.

title: G.I.'s to Guard Afghan Leader Amid Concerns
description: American soldiers, including Special Forces, will move into the presidential palace and take over responsibility for the security of President Hamid Karzai, illustrating concern for his safety after the assassination of a vice president this month, a presidential spokesman said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WADSWORTH, EUGENE D.
description: WADSWORTH-Eugene D. age 89, of Manchester, VT. and Syosset, NY died July 20 in VT. He is survived by his wife Elizabeth and his daughter Wendy Roberts, and grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Monday July 29, 11:00 am at St. John's Chapel in Manchester Village. Donations to the Ekwanok Scholarship Fund C/O Brewster Funeral Service PO Box 885 Manchester Center, VT 05255. To send e-mail condolences please consult www.nsm.org/covey

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Loss Narrows For Computer Associates
description: Computer Associates International Inc., the world's fifth-largest software maker, reported a smaller first-quarter loss yesterday as sales rose 7.4 percent. The net loss narrowed to $65 million, or 11 cents a share, from $342 million, or 59 cents, a year earlier, the company, based in Islandia, N.Y., said. Sales in the period ended June 30 rose to $765 million from $712 million. The maker of software for managing corporate networks said it kept sales in Europe steady while they sagged for some other software companies. Sales from maintenance and services contracts declined. Stock of Computer Associates has suffered, losing 70 percent of its value this year, as investors await the outcome of a federal inquiry into its accounting practices. The company reduced its fiscal 2003 sales forecast, saying it expects revenue to be $3.10 billion to $3.20 billion, compared with an earlier forecast of $3.20 billion to $3.26 billion. Shares of Computer Associates rose as high as $10.40 in after-hours trading. They fell 4 cents, to $10.21 in regular trading before the announcement was made. That was their lowest close since May 1994.

title: As the Dow Falls, Couture Turns Contrarian
description: As the Dow Jones industrial average was beginning to tumble, the fashion world gathered in Paris to look at clothes whose costs would equal the value of a modest portfolio. The haute couture, once described as ''a degenerate institution propped up by a sycophantic press,'' may still seem depraved and the fashion press capable of the usual ballyhoo, but this time there was reason to pay attention to what a handful of designers did.

title: Primedia Is Expected to Name an Editorial Director
description: Primedia Inc. is expected to announce Wednesday morning that Elizabeth Crow, a well-traveled magazine executive, has become editorial director of the company's consumer magazine and media group, which includes Seventeen and New York Magazine, along with such hobbyist magazines as Kitplanes and Car Craft.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: New Jobs At MBNA
description: The credit card issuer MBNA will double the size of its Irish operations over the next five years at a cost of 32 million euros ($32.2 million) and with the support of the Irish government, expanding its presence with 500 new jobs in County Leitrim, a depressed rural area. The company already employs 450 people in Leitrim and at its Dublin headquarters for marketing, customer service and administration. The deputy prime minister, Mary Harney, called the investment ''an important statement of confidence in the continued competitiveness of the Irish economy.'' Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Extended Family Unites in Tribute
description: HIS family paid tribute to Ted Williams last night his extended family, old teammates and Red Sox fans from all over New England, some of whom had seen him play, most of whom merely marveled at who he was.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRTZ, LESLIE
description: HIRTZ-Leslie. Congregation Beth Sholom records the passing of our esteemed member, Leslie Hirtz. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Rabbi Kenneth N. Hain Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, Rabbi Emeritus Danny Hiller, President Gary Miller, Chairman of the Board

title: O'Donnell and Her Publisher Are in Clash Over Magazine
description: Rosie O'Donnell and Gruner & Jahr USA, who jointly publish Rosie magazine, are in a pitched battle over editorial direction that has escalated into threats of legal action by Ms. O'Donnell.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: SOYBEAN PROCESSER ACQUIRED Bunge Ltd. said it would buy 55 percent of Cereol S.A. of France from Edison Sp.A of Italy, making Bunge the world's largest soybean processor. The deal will enable Bunge, which is based in White Plains, to create a processing capacity in Europe, where demand for soybean-based livestock feed has risen since the epidemic of mad cow disease. Bunge paid $454 million for its stake in Cereol and will assume its debt and offer to buy the remaining 45 percent of the company that is publicly traded, at 32 euros a share, if the deal is approved by both European and American regulators. Shares in Cereol rose 0.1 euro, to 31.5 euros. Separately, Bunge reported second-quarter profit more than doubled because of increased sales to feed and food makers, and declines in the value of the Brazilian real and Argentine peso that lowered production costs in those countries. Fertilizer sales also increased in Brazil.

title: World Business Briefing | Telecommunications: Texas Instruments Posts Profit
description: Texas Instruments Inc., whose chips power two-thirds of the world's cellular telephones, had second-quarter net income of $95 million, or 5 cents a share. The net loss a year earlier was $197 million, or 11 cents a share. Sales rose 6.1 percent to $2.16 billion from $2.04 billion, the Dallas-based company said in a news release distributed yesterday. Sales picked up from the March quarter, and analysts said orders from wireless-equipment manufacturers have improved as customers work through excess chip inventory. The Dallas-based company yesterday said third-quarter earnings will be 9 cents a share as sales rise 5 percent from the quarter that ended in June. The chip maker said second-quarter profit would have been $109 million, or 6 cents a share, excluding some costs. Texas Instruments shares rose to $23.70 after the report. The shares fell $1.46 to $23.39 in regular U.S. trading and have dropped 26 percent in the last year.

title: After 9/11, Searching For Way to Stay in U.S.
description: The newlyweds were flying to New York City, and as the plane descended out of the clouds Ganesh Ladkat pointed to the two massive towers in Lower Manhattan. He told his wife, Sonia Gawas, that he would work there one day. And so he did.

title: Spain and Morocco Reach Deal To Vacate Uninhabited Islet
description: Spain and Morocco formally ended their military standoff over the uninhabited islet of Perejil, or Leila, today as their two foreign ministers, prodded by the United States, agreed to improve the highly charged relations between the two countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINKOFF, MARVIN W., MD.
description: SINKOFF-Marvin W., MD. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of our long-standing colleague, teacher, and friend. Dr. Sinkoff graduated from the New York University School of Medicine. He began his long affiliation with Mount Sinai in the Department of Medicine in 1950. He devoted the next several decades to superb medical practice and teaching in the field of Endocrinology. He will be fondly remembered for his intelligence, compassion, and diligence. He was loved by his patients and respected by his colleagues, who knew him as ''the quintessence of a physician.'' The AAS salutes Dr. Sinkoff's outstanding commitment and his many years of service. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Anthony Squire, MD, Prsident Vicki Lopachin, MD, Secretary Amy Weinstein, Administrator

title: In France, Don't Ask
description: To the Editor:

title: Gangster Films, Coolly Revisited
description: Who but Mark Morris would take a George Balanchine standard and turn it into a hip bit of entertainment that both alludes to and turns its back on the original? Mr. Morris's new ''Resurrection,'' a world premiere commissioned by the American Dance Festival here, is a sleek retooling of the American gangster movie, set, like Balanchine's ''Slaughter on Tenth Avenue,'' to that number from the Richard Rodgers musical ''On Your Toes.'' It is also the perfect cool, sweet treat for a very hot summer.

title: At Last, Els Muscles In on the Woods Era
description: As great as Tiger Woods is, there is an opportunity for other golfers to shine during his era.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Celebrating Latin Culture

description: To the Editor:

title: In Defense of the Banks
description: To the Editor:

title: Rivera Has Shoulder Strain
description: Yankees closer Mariano Rivera has a mild muscle strain in his right shoulder and will probably not pitch in the two-game series at Cleveland beginning tonight. The strain was detected after a magnetic resonance imaging scan yesterday.

title: Goodman Signs With Israeli Team
description: Tamir Goodman, a 6-foot-3-inch point guard, who received national attention for his basketball ability at Talmudical Academy in Baltimore and later played for Towson State, signed a contract yesterday with Maccabi Tel Aviv, a top-rated professional team in Israel.

title: Auto Insurance Rates Decrease for Drivers, but Insurers Warn of Some Trouble Ahead
description: For the first time in at least six years, the average cost of insuring a car in New Jersey has dropped below $1,000, the nation's insurance regulators said yesterday.

title: A First And a Finale, Along With A Birthday
description: It seemed going into the weekend that the only major news at the Tanglewood Festival here would be the start of the annual Festival of Contemporary Music under a new director, the composer Bright Sheng. This six-day event, which capitalizes on the presence of so many brilliantly talented musicians studying at the Tanglewood Music Center, is devoting itself entirely to American music for the first time in several decades.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Allied Domecq Spirits and Wines USA, Westport, Conn., part of Allied Domecq, signed a sponsorship agreement for its Beefeater gin brand with People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, the advocacy organization. Terms were not disclosed. Beefeater is helping the organization, known as Peta, promote an effort carrying the theme ``Have a heart. Go vegetarian.'' Dan Mathews, media director for Peta, said that initially Allied Domecq executives thought he was contacting them to ask that the Beefeater brand be renamed, adding that they appreciated the humor in the idea of a brand called Beefeater supporting a campaign to promote vegetarianism.

title: Baseball Says Umps Requested Tool They Now Criticize
description: The dispute between the umpires and the baseball commissioner's office took a new turn yesterday over what the umpires themselves decided about the use of the computerized system that tracks balls and strikes at some parks.

title: Archdiocese to Refuse Gifts That Thwart Bishop's Power
description: The Archdiocese of Boston said today that it would refuse donations from a charitable fund set up to let people give to Roman Catholic causes while bypassing the archdiocese's financial control.

title: The Bookworm Who Stole From Himself
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Tuesday about Gov. George E. Pataki's campaign finances misstated the amount spent by the campaign since January on advertising to reach Hispanic voters. It was $400,000; the total for all advertising was $2.4 million. The article also misstated the language used in the ads for Hispanic voters. It was Spanish; none of the ads were in English.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PROCTER & GAMBLE, Cincinnati, said it would increase the level of common shares to be bought under its stock repurchase plan. The number of shares to be repurchased was not disclosed.

title: U.S. BLOCKS MONEY FOR FAMILY CLINICS PROMOTED BY U.N.
description: In a rebuff to Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, the Bush administration said today that it would not contribute to a United Nations agency that it contends provides aid to Chinese government agencies that force women to have abortions.

title: A Date With Chemistry
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: BUSH DENOUNCES ISRAELI AIRSTRIKE AS 'HEAVY HANDED'
description: The Bush administration today condemned as ''heavy handed'' the Israeli bombing attack that killed a Hamas leader in Gaza City and 14 civilians, saying that the government of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon was aware that the apartment building struck was filled with ordinary Palestinians, including children.

title: California's Message to George Pataki
description: Gov. Gray Davis of California signed a landmark bill on Monday that for the first time will require automakers to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide, the greenhouse gas believed to be largely responsible for global warming. Though the law applies only to cars sold in California, it will force the manufacturers to develop fuel-efficient technologies that all cars can use. This ripple effect will be even greater if other states follow California's lead, as the Clean Air Act allows them to do.

title: MARKETS CONTINUE DOWNWARD TREND; BANKS LEAD WAY
description: Stocks fell again yesterday as concerns grew about the fate of telecommunications and energy trading companies and as Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill traveled to Wall Street to discuss the markets and economy with senior brokerage executives.

title: A Homey Greeting With a Pedigreed Menu
description: ON an unlovely commercial strip of East 57th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues, Teodora stands out like a non sequitur. A restaurant this sweet and hospitable ought to throw open its door on a neighborly street with families on stoops, or at least on a piazza in Ravenna, since its specialties hail from Emilia-Romagna.

description: To the Editor:

title: Official Moves Between Euro RSCG Units
description: Atop executive at one agency unit of Euro RSCG Worldwide, part of Havas , is moving to another.
