description: FLORIDA: 2 PILOTS IN REHABILITATION

title: Power Stage Rally to Top Charge
description: Before her game-winning shot had even crossed the goal line, Power striker Tiffeny Milbrett had a fist in the air and a smile on her face bright enough to light Villanova Stadium. In perhaps the most unlikely of ways, and in the most unlikely of places, the Power's nine game losing streak came to an end last night.

title: Donation for a Student Lounge
description: When the Borough of Manhattan Community College lost a large classroom building adjacent to the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, it was forced to create new classrooms wherever it could. It brought in trailers. Now J. P. Morgan Chase has given the college $500,000 to transform a little-used outdoor space into a 4,800-square-foot, glass-covered atrium to serve as a student lounge. Karen W. Arenson

title: Chaim Potok, 73, Dies; Novelist Illumined the World of Hasidic Judaism
description: Chaim Potok, a scholar and ordained rabbi whose best-selling novels about Hasidic Judaism explored the wrenching decision to forsake a close-knit parochial community for the world outside, died yesterday at his home in Merion, Pa. He was 73.

title: 28 Are Charged With Staging Accidents in Insurance Fraud
description: The state attorney general's office today announced the indictment of 28 people who it contends were part of an insurance fraud ring that staged nearly 100 accidents over a two-year period and bilked insurance companies out of $2 million.

title: Recipe: Barbecued Rib Roast
description: Adapted from Kreuz Market, Lockhart, Tex.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Sinking Feeling Is Now Settling Over Citigroup
description: Now it is Citigroup's turn. The nation's largest financial services company is the latest giant to fall from grace among investors, as Congress examines its deals with Enron and market participants grow concerned that its broad swath of businesses pose a dizzying array of risks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTOK, CHAIM
description: POTOK-Chaim. The Jewish Publication Society extends condolences to the family of Dr. Chaim Potok, Bible translator, former JPS Editor-inChief, and long-time JPS Editorial Chairman. For almost four decades, Dr. Potok guided the Society through his notable scholarship, far-reaching vision, and incisive counsel. May his memory be for a blessing. Allan R. Frank, President Dr. Ellen Frankel, CEO and Editor-in-Chief

title: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
description: DISNEY ENTERS CONSUMER ELECTRONICS MARKET The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that it was entering the consumer electronics market for the first time with a line of two-way radios and cordless telephones featuring popular Disney characters like Mickey Mouse and Buzz Lightyear. Motorola will manufacture the products, which will be available in North America and Britain next fall. The two-way radios, sold in pairs, will be geared toward children 6 to 12 years old, will cost $59.99 and will have a two-mile range. The cordless phones, which will also cost $59.99, will use the voices of Disney characters like Cinderella instead of a conventional ringer. Andy Mooney, president of Disney Consumer Products Worldwide, said that the company hoped to aim at the $9 billion market for children's consumer electronics. Shares in Disney fell 27 cents, to $15.63.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Monday with an article about the Democratic primary in the 57th State Assembly District in Brooklyn was published in error. It showed the current boundaries of the district, not those that will take effect in January, after the general election. The correct map appears above.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Term-Limits Bill Advances
description: A City Council committee, voting 9 to 0, brought an effort to rewrite the city's term-limits law one step closer to reality yesterday, passing a bill that would give eight council members an extra two years in office. Under current law, some council members are limited to six years, rather than eight like most elected officials. Council terms periodically run in sets of two shorter terms to accommodate redistricting after the census. The measure, which would define two consecutive two-year terms as the equivalent of one term, is scheduled to come before the full Council for a vote today. The bill appears to have enough support to override a possible veto by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Daewoo Deal Endorsed
description: The European Union endorsed the takeover of the bankrupt Daewoo Motor by General Motors, saying it would have no anti-competitive effect in Europe. In Seoul, the government-owned Korea Development Bank, Daewoo's lead creditor, denied a report that four creditor banks refused to extend $2 billion in credit as part of the deal to form G.M.-Daewoo Auto Technology, the name of the company that G.M. is putting together from Daewoo's major entities. The deal calls for G.M. and allied companies, notably Suzuki Motor of Japan, to invest $400 million for a controlling stake in the company. The creditor banks will hold the remainder in hopes some day of recovering more than $19 billion in liabilities from Daewoo Motor. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Wheat Beer, the Antidote to Summer Heat
description: I DON'T know about Ernie Gallo or Eric de Rothschild, but offhand I can't think of a serious wine lover who hasn't said, at one time in his life, ''You know, what I'd really like is a cold beer.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALB, HAROLD
description: KALB-Harold. We will miss you, dear friend. Our deepest sympathy to the Kalb family. Leah and Harry Brochstein

title: Black Festival Aims For More in Atlanta
description: Jennifer Holliday's troubles in the years before she returned to the stage at the National Black Arts Festival on Friday mirror those of the festival itself. Organizers hope the festival can overcome problems as successfully as she has.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: TERM-LIMITS BILL ADVANCES

title: San Francisco to Vote on City's Growing Medicinal Marijuana
description: The city that helped create the proposition in 1996 that made California the first state to legalize medical marijuana may start growing its own.

title: HICKS, MUSE WANTS DELAY OF JOINT VENTURE WITH CONAGRA
description: After holding its tongue during the second-largest meat recall ever last week, Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, the investment group leading the purchase of the bulk of ConAgra's fresh beef and pork processing business, called yesterday for a ''brief delay'' in the creation of a joint venture between the companies. Hicks, Muse, which reached an agreement to buy 54 percent of the business for $1.4 billion last May, said that it remained ''fully committed'' to the deal, but called for a delay to allow ConAgra to focus on the recall and allay consumer concerns about 19 million pounds of tainted meat it processed in a Colorado plant. The initial arrangement to establish a joint venture, called Swift & Company, was expected to be completed in August. Greg Winter (NYT)

title: Matt Dennis, 88, Big Band-Era Songwriter
description: Matt Dennis, a singer and songwriter who wrote ''Let's Get Away From It All,'' ''Everything Happens to Me,'' ''Angel Eyes'' and other big-band-era standards, died on June 21 in a hospital in Riverside, Calif. He was 88 and lived in Riverside.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an erroneous version of Page A1 - prepared for other regions - appeared on Sunday in copies distributed in and around Arizona. As a result, the front-page sections of some articles did not match the continuations, and a few articles were omitted or duplicated. The affected articles may be found here today through Sunday. The page may also be requested from Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@nytimes.com. (Include a postal address.)

title: Ashcroft's Words Clash With Staff on Checks
description: Congressional testimony by Attorney General John Ashcroft last December that the F.B.I. could not legally use records of gun background checks to investigate terrorism suspects conflicted with a formal opinion by his own legal staff, a report issued yesterday by the General Accounting Office shows.

title: Deal Is Seen For Acquisition Of Burger King
description: Diageo, the world's largest liquor company, is near a deal to sell its restaurant chain, Burger King, to a consortium led by the private equity firm Texas Pacific Group of San Francisco for more than $2.2 billion, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Citigroup and Chase Defend Their Enron Roles
description: Officials for two of the nation's largest financial institutions, Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase, told Senators today that they did not improperly help Enron disguise portions of the enormous debt that contributed to the company's collapse last fall.

title: Spotting the Sane and Insane in a Topsy-Turvy World
description: In a nation gone crazy, the sane are outlaws. But they have a kind of immunity since it is almost impossible to determine who belongs in which category. This situation has given rise to comedies for a few thousand years, and Jacobo Langsner's aptly named ''Happily Mad'' (''Locos de Contento'') proves that it remains marvelously robust.

title: Study Calls Rescue at Pentagon Chaotic
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  The rescue response to the Sept. 11 attack on the Pentagon was plagued by communication lapses and poor organization among local rescue workers, a study has concluded.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column yesterday about an exhibition at the New-York Historical Society misstated the diameter of a plexiglass sphere bearing a painted panoramic view of the city as seen from the World Trade Center. It is 24 inches, not 24 feet.

title: Husbands: Does a Woman Need One?
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Is Slain Outside Party On Docked Ship on Hudson
description: A Brooklyn man was shot to death early yesterday morning while he was standing near a pier on the West Side of Manhattan where 300 people had gathered for a party on a lightship, the authorities said.

title: Torture Victims In El Salvador Are Awarded $54 Million
description: A federal jury ordered two retired Salvadoran generals today to pay $54.6 million in damages to three civilians who were tortured by security forces during El Salvador's civil war more than 20 years ago.

title: Husbands: Does a Woman Need One?
description: To the Editor:

title: D'Amico Gives Victory And Good Vibrations
description: About two hours before last night's game, the Mets' Jeff D'Amico, trying to be as inconspicuous as a 6-foot-7 pitcher can be, stuck his head into Manager Bobby Valentine's office. D'Amico said nothing, and Valentine replied, ''We don't know yet.''

title: Missing the 90's Bubble Looks Prescient in 2002
description: At the time, they must have felt left out at cocktail parties and dismissed as slightly crazy by many of their neighbors. But those who ignored stocks in the mid- and late-1990's -- and all the hype that was swirling around them at the time -- are now significantly better off than those who put their money to work on Wall Street.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Disney Enters Consumer Electronics Market
description: The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that it was entering the consumer electronics market for the first time with a line of two-way radios and cordless telephones featuring popular Disney characters like Mickey Mouse and Buzz Lightyear. Motorola will manufacture the products, which will be available in North America and Britain next fall. The two-way radios, sold in pairs, will be geared toward children 6 to 12 years old, will cost $59.99 and will have a two-mile range. The cordless phones, which will also cost $59.99, will use the voices of Disney characters like Cinderella instead of a conventional ringer. Andy Mooney, president of Disney Consumer Products Worldwide, said that the company hoped to aim at the $9 billion market for children's consumer electronics. Shares in Disney fell 27 cents, to $15.63. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Accusation Of Murder In Chechnya
description: An international human rights group accused the Russian military of conducting a deliberate campaign of murder among Chechen civilians, killing between 50 and 80 people a month. The International Helsinki Federation for Human Rights said Russian forces attack young Chechen men in what appears to be a process of reducing the male population, a charge a Russian official vigorously denied. The killings are claiming more lives than Russian bombing in previous military campaigns against separatist rebels in the republic, the group said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: The Death of a Hamas Leader
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Fields Of Green
description: The state attorney general, Patricia Madrid, said there was no evidence to suggest that John Dendahl, the chairman of the state Republican Party, violated a state law when he offered a large sum of money -- he said ''at least $100,000'' -- to the New Mexico Green Party if the Greens fielded candidates in two Congressional races. The request was an apparent effort to draw votes away from Democrats. Ms. Madrid, a Democrat, said her investigation found that it seemed ''apparent that Mr. Dendahl's actions were an attempt to manipulate the election process'' but that his offer was not illegal under state law. She said that only the Justice Department and the Federal Election Commission could determine if Mr. Dendahl had violated any federal laws. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: A Slicer to Hold Its Edge Through Thick and Thin
description: A new vegetable peeler from Japan has several virtues that, to the discriminating cook, might make it worth its $25 cost. The blade is extra-sharp and, because it is ceramic, never needs sharpening. The parer is also very light and easy to clean.

title: National Briefing | Washington: New Food Safety Director
description: Just days after the second largest beef recall in the nation's history, Garry L. McKee, director of Wyoming's health department, was named the new administrator of the Food Safety and Inspection Service for the Agriculture Department. Dr. McKee, who has a doctorate in microbiology, will run the department that inspects the country's meat, poulty and egg production. Consumer advocate groups praised his selection, saying it reflected a commitment to consumer safety at a time of renewed criticism of the department's meat inspection system. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: Among WorldCom Puzzles, Future of UUNet Service
description: One of the biggest questions in the WorldCom bankruptcy -- for creditors, businesses and consumers -- is what will become of one of WorldCom's least visible divisions, UUNet, a big wholesale Internet service provider.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRUNSKY, LUCY STAMPLEMAN
description: STRUNSKY-Lucy Stampleman. 91. Died on July 22, 2002 in San Francisco, CA. Long time resident of New York City and political activist for left wing causes. Wife of William English. Mother of Michael. Mother-in-law of Jean Zimmerman. Grandmother of Lara-Joelle and Burke. Memorials are being planned. Contributions can be made to The Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Ave, Montgomery, AL 36104

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: A Loss At Reuters
description: Reuters Group, the provider of financial news and information, posted its first loss as a public company as sales slumped and it paid for cutting jobs. The company's net loss for the six months through June was 73 million ($114 million), or 5.2 pence a share, in contrast to net income of 269 million, or 19 pence a share, a year earlier. Revenue fell 5.3 percent, to 1.84 billion. The chief executive, Tom Glocer, reiterated that revenue at the information and news division would fall as much as 6 percent in the second half of the year.

title: Green Zebras Are Back, Down From the Roof And Ready for Salad
description: Green zebra tomatoes, which have juicy flesh and nice acidity, have ripened on the roof of the Vinegar Factory, 431 East 91st Street. They are being sold at the store and at Eli's Manhattan, 1411 Third Avenue (80th Street), long before they will show up in the Greenmarkets. And they are in better condition than many heirloom tomatoes shipped from California.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASHBURN, ALAN L.
description: WASHBURN-Alan L. Of New York and Easthampton, died unexpectedly on July 22, 2002 at the age of 76. Beloved husband of Joan for nearly 49 years, father of Brian and Susan, brother of Doris W. Angst and her husband Charles and father-in-law of Kerry Greene. Born in Mt. Kisco, NY in 1926 and grew up in Pleasantville, NY. He proudly served his country in WW II as a paratrooper with the 11th Airborne and in the occupational forces in Japan, graduated from the University of Denver and married Joan Thomas in 1953. After a 30 year career in production at Time Magazine, he retired and became VP of the Joan T. Washburn Gallery, NY. His winning smile, irreverant wit and dogged determination captured everyone's hearts. The animals he so loved, Missy, Satra, Whitney, Tweedy, Mac and Page are with him now. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Phelps Memorial Hospital, Sleepy Hollow, NY. A private memorial in Easthampton will be held on a date to be announced.

title: Democratic Legislator Resigns, Creating a Stalemate in Nassau
description: The Democrats are losing their one-vote majority in the Nassau County Legislature because an indicted member of their delegation has resigned from office effective on Wednesday.

title: William Pierce, 69, Neo-Nazi Leader, Dies
description: William Luther Pierce, an ascetic physics professor who built an organization of young supporters for George Wallace for president into the nation's largest neo-Nazi group, and whose novel ''The Turner Diaries'' was credited by Timothy J. McVeigh with inspiring the Oklahoma City bombing, died yesterday. He was 69.

title: S.E.C. Chief Seeks Promotion; Chances Look Dim
description: Harvey L. Pitt, who barely goes a week without new calls for him to step down as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission because of his handling of the crisis in the markets, is asking Congress for a raise and more respect.

title: In the Village, Savory Italian Fare Staggers to the Table
description: MOST restaurants contain two cultures, like two peoples living on shared land. There is the wait staff and the kitchen staff, known, respectively, to insiders as the front of the house and the back of the house. They rarely blend and mingle, but they do learn to tolerate one another and to present, usually, a united front.

title: For Safer Hamburger, Grind It Yourself
description: LAST Friday's announcement of the recall of 19 million pounds of ground beef from ConAgra has many hamburger aficionados wondering, once more, whether they should give up their favorite summer grilling dish.

title: Accounts
description: J. W. Childs Associates, Boston, expanded its relationship with the Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network, New York, by naming the agencies owned by the network to handle assignments for the Hartz Mountain pet-supply company, with billings estimated at $10 million. Hartz Mountain had been handled by Gianettino & Meredith Advertising, Short Hills, N.J. Kirshenbaum Bond, which will handle assignments including advertising, media buying, promotions, interactive marketing and public relations, also works for a Hartz Mountain sibling, the Meow Mix Company.

title: Former PGA Player Leads at Bethpage
description: Charlie Bolling of Fresh Meadow, a former player on the PGA Tour, shot the best round of the day, a one-under-par 70, in the MONY/New York State Open yesterday at the Bethpage State Park Black Course in Farmingdale.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: More Arts Funding Pledged
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey pledged yesterday to increase financing for the arts community in next year's budget and to make up the 10 percent cuts that reduced this year's budget to $18 million from $20 million. A large budget deficit led to cuts in many programs. The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra will receive the largest portion of this year's arts money, receiving a $1.4 million grant for the coming year. Various arts organizations may apply for a share of next year's arts budget to finance programs, enrich endowments or build facilities.

title: Tasting Report: Beers With the Complexities of Wines
description: Weihenstephaner Hefe Weissbier $2

title: 2 Teenagers Die in D.W.I. Crash, Police Say
description: Two Long Island teenagers were killed and a third was seriously injured when a 16-year-old driver lost control of his speeding car early yesterday morning, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SALZER, WILLIAM M.
description: SALZER-William M. March 22, 1917-July 24, 1977. Forever loved. Elizabet

title: Hearing Starts With Judicial Nominee in Defensive Mode
description: Priscilla R. Owen, President Bush's nominee to a federal appeals court, began her testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee today in a defensive posture. She complained that she had been unfairly characterized by ''special interest groups.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cholesterol Drug Setback
description: AstraZeneca asked doctors to stop using the highest dose of its experimental Crestor cholesterol medicine after two patients taking that concentration in studies suffered kidney damage. AstraZeneca sent letters asking doctors participating in research to switch from 80-milligram versions to a lower dosage, a spokesman, Gary Bruell, said. The company, based in London, has tests showing that higher levels of Crestor can lower cholesterol more effectively than Lipitor from Pfizer Inc., the best-selling treatment. Crestor loses some of that benefit as patients take less of the drug, erasing AstraZeneca's potential marketing advantage, analysts said.

title: Classics and Curiosities Of American Composition
description: Steven Mayer's contribution to the International Keyboard Institute and Festival at the Mannes College of Music was a concert on Saturday evening devoted to 19th- and early 20th-century American music.

title: Another 7,000 Jobs to Be Cut As Lucent Reports More Loses
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. announced a $7.91 billion loss for the fiscal third quarter and 7,000 more layoffs yesterday, adding another chapter to the seemingly unending tale of the telecommunications industry's woes.

title: Thomas Pink? Ted Baker? They're on the Menu
description: IT'S not easy to date the moment when CliffsNotes became necessary to parse a menu, or when discreet food listings (or ''descriptors,'' to use the industry lingo) became anxious little gastronomic biographies. There is reason to wonder why it ever became necessary to know the name of the guy who dredged your scallops from the seabed, the earnest truck farmer who gathered your microgreens, the nut in Solano County who has a specialty business in minced peacock tongues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPILLANE, MARGARET (NEE KINNEAVY)
description: SPILLANE-Margaret (nee Kinneavy). On July 22, 2002. Native of Dooras, Galway. Beloved wife of the late Patrick Joseph Spillane, former chief of operations for the IND subway. Mother of Sr. Patricia Spillane, MSC, Assistant General of the Missionary Sisters of the Sacred Heart of Jesus (Cabrini), Rome. Survived by many nieces and nephews in Ireland and the New York area, especially Patricia Joyce Ward and Stephen Joyce. Family will receive friends on Thursday from 2-5 and 7-9pm at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway, (232nd St), Bronx. Funeral St. John's Church, Kingsbridge, Friday at 10am. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne.

title: Big Deals on Campus: Special-Purpose Entities
description: Alison Flader lives on the campus of Arizona State University here in the Alpha Delta Pi house, part of an open complex of 12 buildings that a private developer erected last year. She prefers these quarters, with each sorority having its own building, to the dormitory floors that the sororities previously occupied.

title: Don't Plan To Drink From The Slippers
description: Say you'll take it black, and you can mean coffee or a pair of high-heel sling-backs at Mix, a new shoe store and coffee bar at 191 Spring Street (Sullivan Street) in SoHo.

title: Study Finds Bias on the Job Is Still Common
description: Women and minorities appear to be benefiting from greater employment opportunities in the United States, but discrimination remains a significant problem, according to a study to be released today by two professors at the Rutgers School of Law in Newark.

title: As Private School Nears, Outreach Thrives at Columbia
description: From the steps of Low Library at the center of Columbia University's campus, the clattering subway trains and honking taxis are about a block away, but they are often drowned out by the chirps of birds and the cheers of touch football games.

title: CLEAR CHANNEL RADIO CHIEF IS OUSTED, AND SHARES FALL
description: Shares of Clear Channel Communications Inc. fell about 17 percent after the company, the leading owner of radio stations in the country, said it had removed the chief executive of its radio division. Shares of Clear Channel fell $4.94, to $25. Mark Mays, the Clear Channel president and chief operating officer, will be acting chief executive of the radio unit until a new chief is found, the company said. He succeeds Randy Michaels, who was removed and will take over a new technologies division.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOMAX, ALAN
description: LOMAX-Alan. The Hunter College Community mourns the passing of the esteemed musicologist & folklorist, Alan Lomax, who established The Association for Cultural Equity at Hunter in 1989. He also moved his vast research and archival collection of audio and video tapes, photographs, and scholarly notes to Hunter and shared his wealth of scholarly information with Hunter's faculty and student body. An inspiration to legions of folk music lovers and scholars, he will be greatly missed but his legacy will continue for generations to come. We extend our deepest condolences to his daughter, Dr. Anna Chairetakis, and family. Jennifer J. Raab, President Hunter College, CUNY

description: RICKEY-George. A wonderful artist, teacher and writer. Our working relationship extended over 30 years; I was proud to publish his book on constructivism. His warmth and smile will be missed. George Braziller, Publisher

title: Compromise Offer From YES Is Rejected by Cablevision
description: The head of the YES Network said yesterday that Cablevision had recently rejected a compromise that would have ended the impasse over carrying the Yankees' cable channel, as well as an offer to let a mediator or arbitrator settle the dispute.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Sportsline Picks GSI To Run Online Store
description: SportsLine.com said yesterday that it had chosen GSI Commerce to operate its online store, MVP.com. Financial terms were not disclosed, but the companies said that GSI, which also operates online stores on behalf of Kmart, the Sports Authority and others, would start operating the MVP.com store later this month or in early August. As part of the announcement, SportsLine said it had terminated its agreement with USA Interactive's USA Electronic Commerce Solutions unit, which had operated MVP.com since January 2001. At that time, MVP, whose founders included John Elway, Wayne Gretzky and Michael Jordan, sold its Web address and other assets to SportsLine. CBS, part of Viacom, owns about 30 percent of SportsLine and shares billing on the CBSSportsLine.com site. Bob Tedeschi (NYT)

title: Stalking 4-Star Barbecue In the Lone Star State
description: LIKE cowboy boots and the Alamo, barbecue lies at the very heart of the Texas psyche. No two Texans can agree on what the perfect barbecue is, of course, but they'll fight for all they're worth to defend it against all others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHMAN, YASSKY, IDA.
description: ROTHMAN - YASSKY - Ida. Ida, companion of Al, mother of Sheila Wayman, Jack Wayman, Lester and Harriet Yassky, and Beth and Richard Hazlett. Grandmother of Jessica, Johanna, David, Evan, Rachel, Ian, Colin and Dylan. Great grandmother, wonderful aunt and friend. Died at home July 22, 2002 in Tamarac, FL. Donations may be made to Sloan-Kettering Memorial Center.

title: Senators Confirm Surgeon General
description: President Bush's nominee to be surgeon general, Dr. Richard H. Carmona, easily won confirmation in the Senate yesterday. Members approved him by a unanimous voice vote, after voting 98 to 0 to limit debate on his confirmation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOBODKINA URQUHARTESPHYR
description: SLOBODKINA URQUHARTEsphyr, a founding member of the American Abstract Artists, and renowned author/illustrator, died in her home at the age of 93 of natural causes on Sunday, July 21, 2002. A memorial service will be held this fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYLER, MARJORIE GOLDWASSER
description: WYLER-Marjorie Goldwasser, 86, of New York City and Westport, CT. Beloved mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother, died July 22, 2002 at Norwalk Hospital of respiratory failure. A distinguished public relations professional, she was a pioneer in the presentation of Judaism to the American public and a strong advocate for the ethics of social justice inherent to Judaism. Marjorie served the Jewish Theological Seminary of America for more thatn half a century as its Director of Public Relations. She produced the renowned Eternal Light show, was an expert in Jewish radio and television, and on the Board of Odyssey, a faithbased cable channel. She also represented the Jewish Museum in its early years. She was an active member and former president of the Boards of Surprise Lake Camp and the Jewish Child Care Association, among others. Bryn Mawr College, '36, BA and MA in Philosophy, graduate studies, New School University in Exile. Recent widow of Wilfred Wyler, she is survived by her daughters, Ruth W. Messinger, of New York and Barbara W. Gold of Philadelphia; her sons-in-law, Eli Messinger, Stephen Gold and Andrew Lachman; her five grandchildren, Daniel, Miriam and Adam Messinger and Rachel and Russell Gold and their partners, Batya Elbaum, Felicia Hayes, Kira Plagge, Justin Auld and Laura Hernandez Gold; a sister, Joan Schine and a brother Edwin L. Goldwasser; and five great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Thursday July 25th at 2 p.m. ''The Riverside'', 76th and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Surprise Lake Camp, 307 Seventh Ave. Shiva will be observed at the home of Ruth Messinger, 91 Central Park West, (69th St.) on Thursday, 6-9 pm, Friday 2-6 pm, Sunday and Monday 4-8 pm.

title: Grounds for Marriage
description: I THINK I've consumed more watermelon this year than I have in the rest of my years combined. It certainly seems so, anyway. By seeing watermelon's potential as an ingredient as against simply a fruit eaten unadulterated and out of hand, I've gained a new appreciation for it.

title: Armstrong Builds on Tour Lead
description: LA PLAGNE, France, July 24 - In his bid for a fourth consecutive victory in the Tour de France, Lance Armstrong relied once again on his formidable team today, then launched an attack on the last of three climbs that left all his major rivals behind. While there might be no defining moment to his overall victory, as there was in the first three, this was a defining day.

description: KLEIN-Fred. The clockmaker, the captain of the tall ships, the illuminator of the City Spire, the dog lover and brilliant friend. Susan & Rodger Cahn Cleveland, OH

description: A 7-year-old girl who was abducted kicking and screaming on Monday a few feet from her home escaped from her captors tonight, less than 24 hours after kidnappers had demanded a $150,000 ransom.

description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 23  The board of the University of Alabama voted unanimously today to name the acting president of the University of Louisville, Carol Z. Garrison, president of the University of Alabama at Birmingham.

title: Valentin's Glove Nears Retirement
description: The glove has been around for 10 years, as far as John Valentin can recall, although it appears to be from another era. Worn and deep brown, a quick glance and you would think Honus Wagner used it when he was fielding grounders for the Pittsburgh Pirates in the early 20th century.

title: The Truth Behind the 'Market Menu'
description: AROUND this time last summer I was in northern Italy, staying for three meals with a couple who lived no more than three minutes' walk from the market in Padua. In the morning, the wife strolled there, not a recipe on her mind. Whatever turned up on her rough-hewn table was whatever perfection had caught her eye: eggplant or zucchini, rabbit or fish, peaches or figs. Next day, she got up and did it again.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: A New Look For Tories
description: The Conservative leader, Iain Duncan Smith, replaced the party's chairman with Theresa May, the first woman to hold the post. Mr. Duncan Smith was reportedly irritated with the unwillingness of the chairman, David Davis, to support his effort to modernize the party, which has lost two successive landslide elections. Mrs. May, 45, is a former banking official who became a member of Parliament only in 1997. Tory officials said the appointment symbolized the changes Mr. Duncan Smith wanted to make in creating a more open and inclusive party, accessible to women and minority groups. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: IRELAND: 98 ARRESTS IN IMMIGRANT CRACKDOWN The police arrested 98 people across the country in a continuing crackdown on illegal immigration. The raids were aimed at immigrants whose applications for asylum had been rejected but who had not yet left the country, and included refugees from China, Thailand, Nigeria, Russia and Estonia. A similar effort last week netted 39 people. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: U.S. Indicts 5 Filipino Men In Kidnapping of Americans
description: The Justice Department announced today the indictment of five leaders of the militant Islamic group Abu Sayyaf for kidnappings that led to the death of an American missionary in a gunbattle in the Philippines on June 7.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: U.S. AND BRITAIN LIFT TRAVEL WARNINGS The United States and Britain have rescinded travel advisories they issued last month urging their citizens not to visit India because of the threat of war with neighboring Pakistan. But the United States Embassy in New Delhi cautioned American citizens not to travel in parts of India bordering Pakistan. The warnings were issued in early June at the peak of fears that tensions over the disputed region of Kashmir would lead the nuclear-armed rivals to fight their fourth all-out war since gaining independence from Britain 54 years ago.

title: Preserving the Jury's Privacy
description: The other night on TV, I saw an actual jury deliberating in a real case. It happened in an Arizona court that allowed discreetly placed cameras and microphones to record ''the secret world of jury deliberations,'' as they were described on the court's Web site. Drastically edited (three days down to 15 minutes), the deliberations were a dramatic highlight in each episode of ''State v.,'' an ABC series, produced by the news division, that aired nationwide for five weeks this summer.

description: KUBERSKY-Max of Ft. Lee, NJ, on July 23, 2002. Husband of the late Sonia, father of Edward and the late Arthur. Brother of Abraham and Marvin. Father-in-law of Malka. Grandfather of Seth and Lee. Graveside Service 11am Thursday at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Steady Rates
description: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, said that it would hold interest rates unchanged, ending speculation that it might cut rates by half a percentage point to stimulate the domestic economy. But while household consumption has been flat and consumer prices have dropped 0.8 percent over the last year, exports and foreign investment have been surging. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Ex-Mobster Says He Influenced Yankees
description: Michael Franzese, once a capo in the Colombo crime family, has done freelance work for Major League Baseball's security department, but baseball's security chief said yesterday that Franzese had never told him that he conspired with Yankees players to fix games 20 or more years ago.

description: HOGARTY-Gerard W. 7/24/91 We continue to celebrate the joy of your life. Mother, Tim, family & friends

title: Resolute Pope, In Canada, Addresses Young People
description: Starting an 11-day trip that promises to test his strength, Pope John Paul II arrived here today and, in a voice steadier than it has recently been, called on young Roman Catholics to do their part in making a better world.

title: In the West, Hot Weather Fuels Wildfires in 8 States
description: With conditions relentlessly dry and the weather growing hotter, firefighters today battled 34 significant fires in eight Western states, the most dramatic of which creeped menacingly toward the giant, centuries-old trees of Sequoia National Forest.

title: State Seeks Adult Home Fines For Resident Care Violations
description: The State Health Department announced yesterday that it would seek to fine two more adult homes for the mentally ill in New York City after uncovering what it described as serious violations in distribution of psychotropic drugs, supervision of residents and other areas.

title: House Passes Recovery Bill, Including New York Payment
description: The House approved a $28.5 billion emergency spending bill today to pay for military operations, domestic security and New York's recovery effort from the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Turning the Wrath of Political Correctness Into a Mine of Audience Approval
description: As long as people hate him, Eminem will have material. His set at the Continental Airlines Arena here tonight, headlining a rock and hip-hop package called the Anger Management Tour, began with sound bites from congressional hearings and newscasts describing him as, among other things, vulgar, degenerate, antisocial, misogynistic and ''noise and mind pollution.'' His audience, full of teenage girls and of boys with close-cropped, dyed-blonde hair imitating Eminem, laughed and applauded each denunciation.

title: Wearied by Reality, Television Returns To a 1980's Mind-Set
description: David Morse, a television star of the 1980's, is returning to prime time this fall. In CBS's ''Hack,'' he will play an ex-corrupt cop turned cabdriver who atones by helping strangers. The show is a moody drama that closely resembles ''The Equalizer,'' an 80's series on CBS about a disillusioned ex-secret agent who atones by helping strangers.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: U.S. and Britain Lift Travel Warnings
description: The United States and Britain have rescinded travel advisories they issued last month urging their citizens not to visit India because of the threat of war with neighboring Pakistan. But the United States Embassy in New Delhi cautioned American citizens not to travel in parts of India bordering Pakistan. The warnings were issued in early June at the peak of fears that tensions over the disputed region of Kashmir would lead the nuclear-armed rivals to fight their fourth all-out war since gaining independence from Britain 54 years ago.

title: Vermont Inn
description: The 41-room Mountain Top Inn and Resort in Chittenden, Vt., 11 miles west of Killington, has packages with 20 percent savings on rooms through Sept. 19. The Family First package, for two nights, includes two connecting rooms, daily breakfast, one dinner, a one-hour trail ride and a picnic lunch starting at $895 for a family of three. A two-night package with up to six hours of riding lessons per person, daily breakfast and one dinner, starts at $695 a couple. Plans include tax and tips; (800) 445-2100 or www.mountaintopinn.com .

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Midtown Manhattan; A Hrmes Headquarters With a Designer Touch
description: When Hrmes, the French luxury retailer and designer, decided to consolidate its North American headquarters in Manhattan, it bought the second and third floors in the 24-story Delmonico Plaza condominium building at 55 East 59th Street in October 2000 from Christie's auction house, which had moved its headquarters to Rockefeller Center that spring. In addition to the 21,122 square feet that comprised the two floors, Hrmes bought another 7,791 square feet in the basement.

title: Primedia to name an editorial director of sweeping scope.
description: PRIMEDIA is expected to announce this morning that Elizabeth Crow, a well-traveled magazine executive, has become editorial director of the company's consumer magazine and media group, which includes Seventeen and New York magazine, along with such hobbyist magazines as Kitplanes and Car Craft.

title: Science: Where the Girls Aren't
description: New Jersey Institute of Technology is hoping to persuade more girls -- especially underrepresented minorities -- to enter science and engineering through a summer program that includes rocket launches, boat building, the chemistry of chocolate and other hands-on projects, at the college's Newark campus. One hundred and twenty girls in the fourth through eighth grades are enrolled in the program, which spans aeronautical, biomedical and mechanical engineering. All of the teachers are women.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Teacher Charged With Sexual Abuse
description: An intermediate school teacher was arrested yesterday and charged with sexually abusing a student, the police said. Michael Ostraw, 26, of Knapp Street in Brooklyn, was charged with third-degree sexual abuse, public lewdness and two counts of endangering the welfare of a child. A 15-year-old girl said that in February, he had exposed himself to her inside Intermediate School 390 in Crown Heights, the police said. The girl also reported that on June 26, Mr. Ostraw kissed her. That day, she went to the police. No one from the Board of Education could be reached late last night for comment. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Getting Their Vibe Across In Unconventional Ways
description: If a band wants to transmit energy from the stage to the audience, perhaps tunes and lyrics and songs merely get in the way. That seems to be the conclusion reached by Arab on Radar, Lightning Bolt and the Locust, three noise-rock groups that came to Northsix, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Thursday night.

title: A Yellow House? Well, We Can't Have That
description: The property values police here had just resolved a case of a flagrantly yellow house when they found themselves with another one, hiding in plain sight on Woedee Drive.

title: A Fresh Start, and a Visor, For the Redskins' Spurrier
description: With one helicopter whirring in the background, one visor remaining firmly in place, endless comparisons to the Florida Gators and the Southeastern Conference and no Oklahoma blocking drill, the Steve Spurrier era began here this morning as the Washington Redskins opened training camp.

description: TRENTON: MORE ARTS FUNDING PLEDGED

title: Europe Arms Makers and Boeing in Talks
description: Boeing and three of Europe's largest military contractors said today that they had agreed to conduct joint research on a global missile defense program. But governments in Europe, which have generally been cool to missile defense, would first have to reach an agreement with Washington on how such cooperative ventures should proceed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHEL, HELEN P.
description: MICHEL-Helen P., of Shelter Island (formerly of Brooklyn and N.Y.C.) on July 21, 2002. Beloved wife of George W. Michel. Loving mother of Joseph Sweeney. Fond sister of William Manning and Ruth Kostic. Cherished grandmother of Laura Riker, David Sweeney and Robin Beecher and great grandmother of Jonathan Riker. Friends may visit at the Shelter Island Funeral Home, 23 West Neck Road, Shelter Island on Wednesday from 6-9 P.M. only. Liturgy of Christian Burial, Thursday at 2 PM, Our Lady of the Isle R.C. Church, Shelter Island. Interment Our Lady of the Isle Cemetery.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Utility Posts Profit
description: Net profit for the government-controlled Korea Electric Power Corporation, known as Kepco, increased sharply in the first half and in the second quarter of this year despite protests by workers fearful of the impact of privatization. Kepco, which provides South Korea with most of its electrical power, said profit in the first half was 1.5 trillion won ($1.3 billion) compared with 890 billion won in the first half of 2001. Profit for the second quarter was 718 billion won ($613 million) compared with 481 billion won last year. The company said sales for the quarter totaled 4.9 trillion won, up 8 percent from the second quarter of last year. A six-week strike forced Kepco, more than 50 percent government-owned, to abandon plans to sell six thermal power plants, but the company still hopes to sell at least one of its major subsidiaries in the next few months. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Budget Cut, a Many-Layered Thing
description: The New York City school system's share of the latest 7.5-percent contingency cuts imposed by the Bloomberg administration will come to $379.2 million, school officials said yesterday. The chancellor has been asked to present a list of suggested cuts by Sept. 4. The system already has a hiring freeze in place, school officials said, and the contingency cuts come on top of a series of ongoing cuts to administration. Last year, the system absorbed $290 million in reductions, in a series of trims that are continuing. After Sept. 11, the Giuliani administration asked for an additional $115 million in cuts, which were carried out primarily with one-time actions. Assemblyman James F. Brennan, who represents the Flatbush and Park Slope sections of Brooklyn, said yesterday that ''the impact of $380 million in the context of what they just did is pretty substantial.'' Chancellor Harold O. Levy declined comment.

title: Out of Stocks and Into What? Land, Cash and Bonds, That's What
description: Some people have temporarily turned to cash as a safe haven. Others are hoping that real estate or bonds will be the coming decade's version of a can't-miss investment.

title: U.N. Report Says New Democracies Falter
description: The United Nations is warning this week that gains made with the emergence of dozens of democracies over the past decade now risk being reversed, with authoritarian leaders manipulating elections and millions losing faith in democratic systems.

title: Chocolate Mousse
description: Requiring only a handful of ingredients, mousse is one of the easier chocolate desserts for the home cook. You do not need to temper the chocolate here; just melt it over a hot water bath to about 125 degrees. You will, however, need a pastry bag or cornet if you want to put the mousse on a cake or in a cup.

title: Police Say Suicide; Family Says Murder
description: This much, at least, is certain about Stanley Forestal: On the night he died earlier this month -- hanged in a barn on his family's property here -- he was a very busy man. But much else about that night is in dispute. Investigators say Mr. Forestal committed suicide. His family and friends insist he was murdered.

title: Misusing the Military
description: Some Bush administration officials would like to clear the way for American military forces to play a larger role in protecting the home front from terror attacks. That's not a step to be taken lightly. The idea of military forces roaming the nation enforcing the laws sounds like a bad Hollywood script -- or life in a totalitarian society.

title: Lack of Money Is Called a Bar To Air Security
description: Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta told Congress today that he would be hard-pressed to meet aviation security deadlines this year because Congress had not given him enough money to get the job done.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Insurer Warns On Results
description: The Belgian banking and insurance group Fortis warned that if poor equity market conditions persist, it will not meet the full-year profit forecasts it made in the first quarter of this year. Insurance units have been hit hardest by the slide in share prices, it said. Fortis's warning comes a day after the Dutch insurer Aegon warned that its 2002 profit would be 30 percent to 35 percent lower than last year. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Judge Suspends Law Limiting Ballot Access In Connecticut
description: A Federal District Court judge today temporarily suspended a Connecticut law barring political candidates for statewide office from appearing on a party's primary ballot if they are supported by less than 15 percent of the party's delegates. State officials and lawmakers called the ruling ambiguous.

description: Parliament passed a bill today that exempts thousands of rigorously Orthodox yeshiva students from compulsory military service, touching a raw nerve in relations between strictly religious and secular Israelis.

title: Miscellany
