title: Corrections
description: A dance listing in the Arts & Leisure Guide on Sunday misstated the dates for some Manhattan performances this week in the Japan Society's Dancing in the Streets series. Eiko and Koma will perform ''Offering'' at Dag Hammarskjold Plaza on 47th Street between First and Second Avenues at 8 tonight (it was not yesterday); at Tudor City Green South Park, 41st Street and Second Avenue, at 6 p.m. tomorrow (not today); and at Clinton Community Garden, 48th Street between Ninth and 10th Avenues, at 6:30 on Friday (not tomorrow).

title: UMPQUA TO BUY CENTENNIAL BANCORP FOR $215 MILLION
description: The Umpqua Holdings Corporation agreed to buy Centennial Bancorp for $215 million in cash and stock to add 23 bank offices, most near Portland, Ore. Centennial holders will receive either $9.35 a share, which is 34 percent more than yesterday's closing price, or 0.5343 Umpqua shares for each Centennial share they own. Umpqua will issue 8.6 million shares for 65 percent of Centennial, and pay $81 million in cash for the other 35 percent. The transaction will create a company with assets of about $2.3 billion and deposits of about $2 billion, Umpqua said.

title: Yankees Take Their Lumps In Cleveland
description: Andy Pettitte's back was to the plate as he flipped the ground ball desperately in that direction, trying to stop another run from scoring. In that frantic moment in the fifth inning at Jacobs Field tonight, Pettitte had no way of knowing nobody was home.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Shots At Planned Parenthood
description: Women visiting Planned Parenthood at Grand Rapids, stepped through broken glass and debris to seek medical care after six shots were fired at the facility at 3:30 a.m on Monday; a similar incident occurred at the Brainerd branch on July 4. No one was hurt in either incident. Meg Friese, chief operating officer of Planned Parenthood of Minnesota/South Dakota, said the shots hit the front door and window of the Grand Rapids center, causing $5,000 to $6,000 in damage. Abortions are not performed at either clinic.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the finances of the El Paso Corporation and its dealings with investment bankers misidentified the Senate panel that is looking into ties between bankers and Enron, another energy company. It is the Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, not the Finance Committee.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KATZ, LEONARD W.
description: KATZ-Leonard W. We will never stop loving you. Mildred

title: New Effort Is Begun to Save Dolphins and Whales
description: It was over a decade ago that Pacific tuna fisheries, pressured by public outcry in the United States, rushed to label their cans ''dolphin safe,'' a guarantee that their fishing practices would not harm the intelligent marine animals that Americans had come to love.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 15 about a study by the Air Bag & Seat Belt Safety Campaign included an erroneous comparison from the study's sponsor on the risk to teenage drivers in Rhode Island, where seat belt use is low, and California, where it is high. Teenage drivers in serious crashes are 60 percent more likely to die in Rhode Island than in California, not five times as likely. The article also referred incorrectly to New Hampshire's seat belt requirement. The state requires people under 18, including 16- and 17-year-old drivers, to wear belts; it is not without a belt law.

title: Introduction and Tempering
description: Chocolate is one of those magical items that nearly everyone likes and for which some develop a serious passion (listen up, you chocoholics). Indeed, chocolate originates with the cocoa bean, Theobroma cacao , Greek for "food of the gods." Who better to guide us through this exploration than Chef Jacques Torres, the Dean of Pastry Studies at the French Culinary Institute and one of the world's top experts on chocolate? We will be delving into chocolate in three ways: with a large chocolate balloon centerpiece and with small white chocolate cups, which we will fill with chocolate mousse.

title: Ben & Jerry & Me
description: I HAD never imagined that my big breakthrough as a writer would be a two-word masterpiece. It was an accident, as life-changing events tend to be.

title: Men: Too Emotional?
description: Talking about his latest show about thin, sexy lawyers with good legs and bad dates, ''girls club,'' David E. Kelley was asked why he has such empathy for women characters.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More West Nile Virus Detected
description: Health officials said yesterday they had found mosquitoes infected with the West Nile virus in the southern half of Central Park, Hamilton Heights and in College Point, Queens. This means the virus has been detected in all five boroughs this year. The city plans to spray the pesticide Anvil in Brooklyn's Green-Wood Cemetery and in a section of Staten Island from 9 p.m. until 2 a.m. tonight, unless there is rain or high wind. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMINOFF, LOUIS
description: SIMINOFF - Louis. Loving husband of Ethel (nee Cohn). Devoted father of Nadine Liese, Carol Siminoff, and Judy and Henry Zablow. Cherished grandfather of Jillian and Ryan Liese, Michael and Evan Zablow; brother of Adele Greenman. Served his country during World War II in Itlay. Lifelong Yankee fan. Funeral services Thursday, 10 AM, at I.J. Morris, Inc., 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead Village, NY.

title: CREDIT RATING OF WILLIAMS COMPANIES REDUCED TO JUNK
description: The credit rating of the Williams Companies, a leading pipeline concern, was reduced to BB, or junk status, by Standard & Poor's because less cash is available to the company. The senior unsecured debt was lowered two levels from BBB-, S.& P. said. Williams's failure to renew its $2.2 billion revolving loan is ''not commensurate with an investment-grade rating,'' S. &P. said. The drop in Williams's stock price, along with a cut in its dividend, reduces the company's ability to sell shares to raise cash and pay off debt, S.& P. said.

title: Latin Companies Are Bargain Hunting in Argentina
description: Many North American and European companies in Argentina are still licking the wounds they suffered as the country's economy, South America's second largest, collapsed around them. But some Brazilian and Mexican companies have been waiting for the dust to settle and have slowly begun to seek out bargains that could increase their regional presence.

title: Expos' Trade of Lloyd Upheld
description: Contrary to his wishes, Graeme Lloyd has to continue pitching for the Florida Marlins instead of returning to the Montreal Expos.

title: Aucoin and Islanders Agree to a 2-Year Deal
description: Adrian Aucoin, the Islanders' sturdy and relentless defenseman, avoided salary arbitration yesterday by agreeing with the team on a two-year contract believed to be worth $6.2 million. He sounded glad to have the negotiations out of the way.

title: Witness Links Milosevic to a Plan to Cover Up Crimes in Kosovo
description: It happened, the witness here said, in March 1999, as NATO bombs were falling on Serbia and President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia had called a meeting in his office of some of his most trusted men.

title: A Good Bottle Can Show Its Stuff in an Asian Face-Off
description: AN excellent wheat beer can be much like a very good cabernet sauvignon. Both can have a lot of body and complexity and a parade of vivid flavors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REILLY, THOMAS J.
description: REILLY-Thomas J. On July 22, 2002. Retired photo engraver, New York Times. Beloved husband of Catherine, loving father of Matthew, Theresa, Jeanne, Maryann, Peter and Thomas. Also survived by five grandchildren. Family will receive friends Wednesday 2-5, 7-9pm, Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway, Bronx. Mass St. Margaret's Church, Thursday, 9:45am. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Crying Over the Victims of the Stalingrad Siege
description: ''The Battle of Stalingrad: A Requiem,'' a puppet theater production imported from Tbilisi in the country of Georgia, had its New York premiere last night at the Lincoln Center Festival. Additional performances are at 6:30 and 9 p.m. tonight and tomorrow night at the Clark Studio Theater. Following are excerpts from Bruce Weber's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Dec. 1, 2000, of the show as it appeared at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: 98 Arrests In Immigrant Crackdown
description: The police arrested 98 people across the country in a continuing crackdown on illegal immigration. The raids were aimed at immigrants whose applications for asylum had been rejected but who had not yet left the country, and included refugees from China, Thailand, Nigeria, Russia and Estonia. A similar effort last week netted 39 people. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: You're Too Kind, Firefighters Say, Truly Meaning It; Gifts Pour In, but Space For Them Grows Scarce
description: The New York City Fire Department is asking for help:

title: Who Really Cooks the Books?
description: There is a crisis of confidence today about corporate earnings reports and the credibility of chief executives. And it's justified.

title: INSIDE
description: A New Anglican Leader

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MORTON'S RESTAURANT GROUP, New Hyde Park, N.Y., a steakhouse chain at the center of a takeover fight, said its shareholders approved a $71.2 million offer from Castle Harlan Inc., New York.

title: Bloomberg Talks of Layoffs, but Some Hear Negotiation Tactic
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg raised the specter of layoffs this week just as his administration enters a crucial new phase with the city's labor unions.

title: A Place to Share Tea With a Coffeepot-Head
description: Teany, a whitewashed storefront with a pocket-size terrace a few steps down from the street, is an unusual addition to the list of teahouses that have opened in Manhattan recently. And not just because of its Lower East Side address: 90 Rivington Street (Orchard Street).

title: Corrections
description: A map on Monday with an article about the Democratic primary in the 57th State Assembly District in Brooklyn was published in error. It showed the current boundaries of the district, not those that will take effect in January, after the general election. The correct map appears today, on Page B2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIFORD, CATHERINE
description: WILLIFORD-Catherine, age 73, died Sunday, July 21 at Long Island College Hospital. She is survived by her daughters, Lois, Karen and Alvina; her sons, Wayne, Dennis and John; her stepmother Ruth, eight grandchildren and countless other loving family and friends.

title: Downtown, An Exodus That Cash Can't Stop
description: No amount of money will keep some businesses downtown.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Markets Fall Again; Dow at Its Lowest Since '98

title: Chocolate Balloon Centerpiece
description: You will need two people for this operation, since one has to hold and rotate the balloon. You will also need lots of room in your fridge, and a piping bag. If you can find the strong punching bag type balloon, choose that one. An important safety note: Some people are allergic to latex, an ingredient in most balloons.

title: Looking for a Haven
description: Bonds, real estate and even savings accounts have become more attractive. Business Day, Page C1.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRENNAN, WILLIAM J., JR.
description: BRENNAN-William J., Jr. April 25, 1906 to July 24, 1997. In fondest memory of William Joseph Brennan, Jr. Associate Justice, United States Supreme Court, 1956-1990. A beautiful man with a beautiful and compassionate mind and heart.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Bread That Includes the Major Food Groups: Walnuts, Wheat and Figs
description: In Spain and Italy, ''logs'' of pressed figs and walnuts are sliced and served with cheese. That image comes to mind when you bite into a slice of the new fig bread made by Royal Crown Bakery, 6512 14th Avenue in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Figs and walnuts are studded throughout the wheaty oval loaves.

title: Tainted Beef
description: The huge recall of ground beef announced last week, the second-largest in American history, offers disturbing evidence that the nation's food safety system for meat may be misfiring.

title: CBS Sports Hires Channel 2's Petitti
description: Tony Petitti, who has been the general manager of Channel 2 since August 1999, was named executive producer of CBS Sports yesterday. He is returning to the sports divsion, where he was once a senior vice president. He replaces Terry Ewert, the executive producer since 1997.

title: 2 Key Figures Try to Ally in Tense New AOL Time Warner
description: One of the first face-to-face meetings Jeff Bewkes had after being elevated to the executive floor of AOL Time Warner last week was with Jamie Kellner, the executive given control of Ted Turner's cable empire a year and a half ago.

title: Durres Journal; From This Poisoned Place, the Poor Can't Escape
description: Five years ago, Flutorime Jani and her extended family settled on the grounds of an abandoned chemical plant. Fleeing from the barren, lawless mountains, they found a spot a few miles from this city, Albania's main port. At first they thought they were lucky. ''The land was free,'' Mrs. Jani said.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Starve a Cold, Feed a Fever?

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Imprisonment Sought For Teacher
description: A prosecutor yesterday told an appellate court that a trial judge was wrong to sentence a teacher to only five years' probation for having sex with a 13-year-old student. The Bergen County prosecutor requested that the appellate court consider harm inflicted on the student and give the teacher, Pamela Diehl-Moore, jail time instead. The trial judge, Bruce A. Gaeta, sentenced Ms. Diehl-Moore in May to probation, saying the relationship might have satisfied the boy's ''sexual needs.'' He also cited Ms. Diehl-Moore's suicide attempt as an argument against imprisonment. A state judicial-conduct committee is reviewing his comments. The appellate court is expected to issue its decision by next week. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Connecticut Utility Seeks More Money for Suppliers
description: Connecticut Light and Power, the state's largest electric company, has demanded that utility regulators allow an emergency rate increase to prevent one of its suppliers from shutting down three generating plants next week. The utility, which provides electricity to 1.1 million customers, said a shutdown could create a dangerous shortage of energy in southwestern Connecticut just as heavy summer demand is at or near its peak.

title: Decision Near On Course Of Inquiry On Torricelli
description: A United States Senate committee is expected to meet later this week to decide whether to end or expand its investigation into allegations that Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey accepted gifts from a wealthy donor for political favors, according to a televised report.

title: Democrats Say G.O.P. Add-ons Threaten Bill for Security Dept.
description: A substantial number of Democrats say they are considering voting against the proposed Department of Homeland Security when it reaches the House floor on Thursday, complaining that Republicans had larded the bill with pet ideological projects.

title: AT&T, Writing Down Cable Assets, Posts Big Loss
description: AT&T announced quarterly financial results yesterday that it said modestly exceeded analysts' expectations, amid signs that the trends that have devastated parts of its business, if not getting better, are at least not growing worse.

title: A Dancer's Imagination Outpaces His Feet; Celebrating the Vision Of Merce Cunningham
description: Merce Cunningham can no longer move as easily as he once did. At 83, stricken worse than most with the dancer's curse of arthritis, he has trouble walking. Adjusting to this setback, he has revisited a dance form he knew as a child. ''In airports, I have to be pushed around in a wheelchair because it's 10 miles to anywhere, so you have to sit around a lot,'' Mr. Cunningham said. ''So I've realized I could go back to tap-dancing in a wheelchair. It's marvelous! I've relearned the waltz clog. I'm not too good yet on the time step.''

title: The Kirov Polishes Gems And Nurtures a Sad Swan
description: The Kirov Ballet has closed its by and large successful season as part of Lincoln Center Festival 2002 and left for home in Russia. There was room, however, for last-minute major debuts.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Peter Campbell was named executive vice president and creative director at the SKM Group, Williamsville, N.Y. He had been partner and creative director at Campbell & Company, Westport, Conn.

title: The Death of a Hamas Leader
description: To the Editor:

title: Elite Women to Start First in New York
description: Officials of the New York City Marathon made a major change yesterday to assure more attention for the elite female runners in this year's race, on Nov. 3. They decided that instead of having all men and all women start at the same time, the elite women would start earlier, at 10:40 a.m., with the men and the rest of the women starting at 11:15.

title: Sports of The Times; It's Time For Augusta To Change
description: ALONG the journey to Amen Corner, a foursome of women come upon a group of gentlemen who are searching the pine needles on an egg hunt for a lost Titleist.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Mayor Pays His Own Legal Fees
description: Mayor John O. Norquist of Milwaukee must use at least $95,000 of his own money to settle a sexual harassment claim by a former aide. Mayor Norquist, now in his fourth term, decided earlier this year not to run for re-election and to use his campaign funds to cover the $375,000 payment to the former aide, Marilyn Figueroa, with whom he has admitted having an affair. His campaign chest had only $279,160, according to finance reports. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: A Place to Share Tea With a Coffeepot-Head
description: Teany, a whitewashed storefront with a pocket-size terrace a few steps down from the street, is an unusual addition to the list of teahouses that have opened in Manhattan recently. And not just because of its Lower East Side address: 90 Rivington Street (Orchard Street).

title: Saratoga Opener Today Has History and Horses
description: Nellie Bly didn't much care for horse racing paradise. In 1894, a headline in The New York World summed up the feelings the famous muckraking reporter had for the epicenter of the sport: ''Wild Vortex of Gambling and Betting by Men, Women and Children.''

title: Forcing the Transit-Fare Issue, McCall Says Pataki Is Hiding
description: The possibility of a transit fare increase after the election in November has been in the air for almost a month now, ever since Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg began to mention the issue in interviews.

title: Tracing Bad Meat
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER / London : The whodunit that did it right
description: There could be no better tribute to the thriller writer Anthony Shaffer, who died all too soon and suddenly last November, than the new Bill Kenwright revival of "Sleuth" at the Apollo Shaftesbury.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Computer Associates Shares Tumble
description: Shares of Computer Associates International dropped 21 percent yesterday to a nine-year low after the company, the world's fifth-largest software maker, said orders slowed in the June quarter and it trimmed its full-year sales estimate. Shares fell $2.13, to $8.08. The shares have dropped 70 percent this year as investors have awaited the outcome of a federal inquiry into past accounting practices. They traded as low as $8 in July 1993. Bookings slowed and some large orders did not close by the end of June, the company said. Spending on computer products is not likely to pick up this year as the economy takes longer to recover from the slowdown, said the chief executive, Sanjay Kumar, in a conference call yesterday. In the previous four quarters, the company's backlog of sales grew an average of $342 million. In the June quarter, the backlog grew by $30 million. Computer Associates sells some software on a subscription model; customers pay month to month.

title: DUPONT TO ACQUIRE CHEMFIRST FOR $408 MILLION
description: The DuPont Company, the second-largest chemical maker in the country, agreed to buy ChemFirst Inc. for $408 million to add chemicals and materials used in electronics and semiconductors. DuPont will pay $29.20 a share for the specialty chemicals maker, a 28 percent premium over its closing share price yesterday. Purchasing ChemFirst, which sells a polymer used to make images of integrated circuits, will help DuPont expand its smallest business unit, called electronic and communication technologies. The acquisition also expands DuPont's aniline business, a DuPont spokesman, Irv Lipp, said. Aniline, a chemical used in insulation in construction, is ChemFirst's top-selling product, a ChemFirst spokesman, Jim McArthur, said.

title: The Torricelli Bob-and-Weave
description: Quietly, maybe too quietly, the Senate Select Committee on Ethics has spent the last six months mulling evidence that Senator Robert Torricelli improperly accepted gifts and cash from a supporter. Not until this week did the senator make his first appearance, behind closed doors, to answer questions, and not before senators on the committee but members of their staffs.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: After Fire, Some Internet Cafes Reopen
description: More than a month after a deadly fire in Beijing killed 25 people and led officials to close all the city's Internet cafes, the authorities have allowed 30 to reopen. Before the fire, an estimated 2,400 Web bars operated in the city, only 200 of them authorized. The 30 newly reopened ones made new pledges to bar minors, follow fire codes, keep records of computer use for 60 days and install software to filter out ''unhealthy'' content like pornography or politically subversive messages. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: European Clearance Seen For Merger of Cruise Lines
description: Setting aside what it said in April were ''serious concerns'' about a proposed merger of cruise lines, the European Commission will probably approve the Carnival Corporation's $5.5 billion bid to acquire P&O Princess Cruises on Wednesday and impose few if any conditions, people close to the commission said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSHAN, STANLEY ''BOB''
description: HIRSHAN-Stanley ''Bob''. 76, of Boynton Beach, FL, OOn July 23, 2002. Served 32 years as teacher and principal in NYC schools. Survived by wife of 53 years Marjorie, brother Malcolm, son Adam, daughter Jennifer Cline and 6 granddaughters. Services Thursday, 2:15 PM, Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Delray Beach, FL.

title: THE CHEF
description: THERE'S nothing like bringing in a couple of nice blues in the summertime. I can do that when I take my little dory out in Hewlett Harbor, near my house in Long Beach. I call it my backyard. Sometimes I'll get fluke, sometimes weakfish. Except for the green flies, I love being out there on the water, especially at the tide line where the sea meets the bay, watching the terns and the cormorants diving for fish.

title: Blair Warns of Tougher Stance Against Irish Paramilitary Groups
description: LONDON, July 24  Prime Minister Tony Blair, decrying the persistence of violence in Northern Ireland, today called on the province's paramilitary groups to disband and warned that the government would become more "rigorous" in punishing them for violating their ceasefire claims.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Delay In Utility Acquisition
description: The $10.6 billion acquisition by E.ON of Ruhrgas, Germany's biggest natural gas distributor, may be delayed by months, lawyers said. A regional court in Dsseldorf is expected to grant an injunction against the purchase. On July 13, it unexpectedly blocked the acquisition, after appeals from two energy brokers. A delay would affect not only E.ON, Europe's second-biggest utility, but also the companies that count on the proceeds of their Ruhrgas stakes and that are part of the transaction, analysts say. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: CALENDAR
description: Ice Cream Saturday

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAUCHER, MARY KATHRYN
description: RAUCHER-Mary Kathryn. Beloved wife of Herman, adored mother of Jacqueline Leigh Salkin and Jennifer Brooke Raucher, revered grandmother of Samantha Raucher Salkin and Jamie Leigh Salkin, devoted mother-in-law of Will Salkin, left us on July 21, fighting her cancer to the final bell. A superlative dancer with an illustrious career, she charmed, provoked, amazed and dazzled all who came within her embracing perimeter. The first to answer the call of friends in trouble or disarray, ''M.K.'s'' compassion, wit and spirit was treasured by all who knew her. Her dance is ended but her radiance lingers on. Memorial service Thursday, August 1, 2002 from 3-5pm at the Field Club of Greenwich.

title: Vivendi Sets Big Overhaul Of Pay TV And Film Unit
description: Vivendi Universal announced plans today for a sweeping overhaul of the Canal Plus Group, its French pay television and film company, in an attempt to stem losses and raise money to reduce debt.

title: Cingular in Move On WorldCom
description: WorldCom's bankruptcy filing could interrupt cellular phone service to several hundred thousand people if the company does not honor the terms of a contract with Cingular Wireless, Cingular warned in a filing yesterday with the federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan.

title: Leo McKern, 82, Veteran Actor Who Gave Voice to 'Rumpole'
description: Leo McKern, the veteran stage and screen actor who became best known for his television role as the shrewd and exasperating British barrister ''Rumpole of the Bailey,'' died yesterday at a nursing home near his home in Bath, England. He was 82.

title: French Striker Has Scoring Touch
description: The last time they played Philadelphia, New York Power players got an unexpected French lesson.

title: Jets Sign Fifth-Round Pick
description: The Jets, who report to training camp tomorrow, signed their fifth-round draft pick, offensive lineman Jonathan Goodwin, yesterday and agreed to terms with their fourth-round pick, defensive tackle Alan Harper. That leaves only a second-rounder, safety Jon McGraw, unsigned among their draftees.

title: Ice Rink Adds New Game To Lineup
description: Aaron Davis of the Bronx overcame a 17-month layoff to win a majority 10-round decision over Ross Thompson of Buffalo in their supermiddleweight main event on a melted public ice rink tonight.

title: Ex-President of Argentina Denies Cover-Up in '94 Bombing
description: Carlos Sal Menem, a former president of Argentina, denied today that he had covered up the bombing in 1994 of a Jewish community center here, contending that aides to the current President, Eduardo Duhalde, had planted a report that appeared in The New York Times on Monday in order to damage him politically.

title: An Old Warehouse? To This Art Lover, It's a Canvas
description: ANNE PASTERNAK, the executive director of Creative Time, is stepping gingerly in beaded flip-flops inside the roofless shell of a 19th-century tobacco warehouse on the Brooklyn waterfront. The vast structure of brick walls, with its open-air arches, looks like a Roman aqueduct, except this ruin has the Brooklyn Bridge soaring overhead.

title: A Narrow View Of Family Planning
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Fishermen Warned of Mercury Levels in Some Fish
description: The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection warned today about high levels of mercury in 21 species of freshwater fish in the state's waterways. It said young children and pregnant women in particular should avoid eating certain fish from particular waters, or at least limit their consumption.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Leaps To Escape Robbers
description: Two robbers held up a handbag store yesterday, and when they put guns to the head of an employee, he jumped out a fifth-floor window, apparently in fear, the police said. The employee, who the police said was in his 20's, was taken to St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital in critical condition. The robbery occurred at AMC Inc., at 336 West 37th Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, about 3 p.m., the police said. The owner and another employee, who were also in the store, were not hurt. The suspects left the building without any goods or money. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: IRAQ: IT WON'T BE AS TIGHT AS FLORIDA As the United States continues to talk about the need for a change of leadership, President Saddam Hussein plans to hold a referendum to endorse his presidency in mid-October, the country's newspapers reported. Mr. Hussein won 99.96 percent of the vote in a referendum in October 1995, according to government figures. (Reuters)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inflation Edges Higher
description: Canada's inflation rate, measured by the consumer price index, rose 1.3 percent in the year to June, with a sharp rise in cigarette prices partly offset by lower gasoline and natural gas costs, Statistics Canada said. The index advanced 1 percent in the year to May. Excluding energy prices, which were 10.4 percent lower than a year ago, the index rose 2.6 percent in June. Statistics Canada said lower mortgage rates also dampened the increase. Higher tobacco taxes made up more than half of the rise, with cigarette prices up 32.1 percent from a year earlier. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Commemorating 9/11 in Art
description: The School of Visual Arts announced this week that it would mount an exhibition of more than 50 works by its students and faculty members to commemorate Sept. 11. An outside jury recently selected the works, including ''Patriotism Begins in the Home'' (shown at right) by STEVEN DANA, a graduate of the school who now teaches design there. Works will include photography, paintings, sculptures, video and mixed media, and will be shown at the school's Visual Arts Museum at 209 East 23rd Street from Sept. 11 to Oct. 9. The jurors were: ANNE ELLEGOOD, associate curator at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in New York; MOUKHTAR KOCACHE, the director of visual and media arts at the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council; DUANE MICHALS, a fine-art and commercial photographer; and GEORGE TSCHERNY, a designer whose posters are represented in the permanent collection of the Library of Congress and the Museum of Modern Art in New York. Karen W. Arenson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIL, IRVING G.
description: WEIL-Irving G. on July 20, 2002 at Andrus Retirement Community, Hastings - on Hudson at the age of 97. He was the widower of Anne Mary Feldmar Weil. He was retired from Studio Weil, a continuation of the business of F. Weil & Co. Vienna, Austria, first in Paris and then for many years in NYC. Until recently he was an active member of Humanitas Lodge #

title: 2 Parties' Plans On Drug Costs Falter in Senate
description: Competing Democratic and Republican proposals to help elderly people with the soaring cost of prescription drugs failed today on the Senate floor, and members of both parties said they would carry the issue into this fall's elections if they could not cobble together a compromise.

title: A Food Magazine's Second Course
description: EATING WELL, a food magazine, disappeared from newsstands, supermarket racks and mailboxes in 1999 despite having a circulation of about 700,000. Now it's back, and with a difference: it has no advertising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DODNICK, ESTHER
description: DODNICK-Esther,. At the age of 87. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence. Loving mother of Barbara and Fred. Cherished grandmother of Alexandra. Good friend to many and will be sorely missed. Graveside services Thursday, 12:30 at the Mt. Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale, Long Island, NY.

title: A Beaten Liberty Rues the Whistles That Never Sounded
description: The Liberty made no excuse over having to play its fourth game in six days tonight. Nor for having to fly into town today on a short night's sleep. The quality of tonight's officiating, however, left some players feeling shortchanged.

title: U.P.S. SAYS IT WILL MISS THIRD-QUARTER ESTIMATE
description: United Parcel Service Inc. said third-quarter profit would be less than forecast because customers shifted orders to rivals before the largest package delivery company reached an accord to avoid a Teamsters strike. The company will earn 50 to 55 cents a share because July shipments fell before last week's agreement on a tentative union contract covering 230,000 workers, a spokesman, Norman Black, said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected the company to earn 56 cents. Shares of U.P.S. fell $2.81, to $60.30.

title: Gaza Mourns Bombing Victims; Israel Hastens to Explain
description: ''Revenge, revenge!'' cried tens of thousands of mourners streaming in a three-mile procession today through Gaza City's bleak streets for the funeral of the Hamas military chieftain, Sheik Salah Shehada, the flags of Palestinian factions rippling in unity, the fevered emotion punctuated by bursts of gunfire in the air. ''God is great!''

title: OFF THE MENU
description: A Switch to Sandwiches

title: A New Kind of New Yorker, One With 82 Legs
description: Scientists have discovered an altogether new creature in Central Park.

title: Ashcroft's Terrorism Policies Dismay Some Conservatives
description: Many religious conservatives who were most instrumental in pressing President Bush to appoint John Ashcroft as attorney general now say they have become deeply troubled by his actions as the leading public figure in the law enforcement drive against terrorism.

title: Sharpton Says F.B.I. Tape Distorts Truth
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton, who is hoping to take his local brand of politics national, instead found himself on the defensive yesterday as he explained his actions in a 1983 F.B.I. surveillance video that depicted him listening to an undercover F.B.I. agent trying to entice Mr. Sharpton into making a drug deal.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel May Hasten Shipping Of New Chips
description: The Intel Corporation will ship two faster Pentium 4 chips to personal computer makers earlier than forecast and cut prices on older chips to try to increase sales in the holiday season, a person close to the planning said yesterday. Intel, the world's biggest maker of semiconductors, said on July 16 that PC sales in the last quarter had extended a decline that began in late 2000. Intel said earlier this year that the Pentium 4 chips would be available by the end of 2002. A company spokesman, Robert Manetta, declined to comment on the production schedule.

title: Paul Weiss, 101, Philosopher And Challenger of Age Bias
description: Paul Weiss, an indefatigable philosopher who kept teaching despite the efforts of some of the best American universities to stop him because of his advancing age, died on July 5 at his home in Washington. He was 101.

title: Audits Scrutinized at Operator of Hospital-Supplies Web Site
description: Hundreds of nonprofit hospitals that invested in a specialized electronic commerce company had their holdings shrink by about $44 million yesterday after the company announced that it was reviewing certain accounting methods and might have to restate its financial reports going back two years.

title: Rivera Watches, Waits And Plays Some Cards
description: Yankees closer Mariano Rivera sat at a clubhouse table today with a bag of ice wrapped around his right shoulder, playing cards with David Wells. That was the only game Rivera played. He will not participate in a baseball game until Friday at the earliest and may need to go on the disabled list.

title: Miramax Buys Out Tina Brown For an Estimated $1 Million
description: The strained collaboration between Harvey Weinstein and Tina Brown ended yesterday after six months of often rancorous negotiations. Mr. Weinstein and his partners bought out the two years remaining on Ms. Brown's contract for an estimated $1 million, people close to the talks said.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Storms Cut Power
description: More than 18,000 businesses and homes in Connecticut lost power yesterday after storms damaged electrical lines, utility officials said. Officials at Connecticut Light and Power said that most of the 18,644 customers who were affected lost power because electrical lines were knocked down by falling trees, high winds or lightning. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Official Moves Between Euro RSCG Units
description: A top executive at one agency unit of Euro RSCG Worldwide, part of Havas, is moving to another.

title: Learning to Lead
description: NATALIE TRAN, a 20-year-old sophomore at McGill University in Montreal, dreams of living in New York and working on Wall Street. Last week she got a taste of Manhattan when she participated in the Goldman Sachs Global Leadership Institute, a week of seminars aimed at increasing college students' leadership skills, global awareness and ability to network across cultures. Fifty students from 22 countries participated in the program, which was also sponsored by the Institute of International Education. They attended international business seminars and workshops on finance and public policy. They also toured the United Nations and went swing dancing. ''The best thing about the program was linking myself to different areas of the world,'' Ms. Tran said. ''I am now able to transcend my own views and take other people's values and customs into consideration.'' Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the killing of Samantha Runnion, a 5-year-old girl who was abducted outside her home in California, referred incorrectly to the findings of a study on children who were kidnapped and killed. The study, quoted by an expert in the article to explain the urgent need for quick action, found that 74 percent of the children's deaths occurred within three hours of their abductions. It did not find that 74 percent of all kidnapped children were killed within three hours.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Swimming Ban
description: The Chicago Park District banned swimming at the city's 31 lakefront beaches for the fifth time this summer because of elevated levels of E. coli in the water. The prohibition will last at least through Wednesday. The park district tests samples of Lake Michigan water every day and bans swimming whenever the bacteria levels rise to more than 235 organisms per 100 milliliters two days in a row. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Citing Its Price Strategy, Amazon Pares Loss
description: Amazon.com posted slightly better-than-expected financial results yesterday, as its operations continued to stabilize. Amazon, the largest online retailer, lost $94 million in the second quarter, compared with a loss of $168 million a year earlier.

description: There are certain things that every New York City mayor feels compelled to do at one point or another: hold a news conference on or near a large bridge that is under repair; visit Puerto Rico; and try to reform the scandal-plagued Buildings Department.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Catholic Quota Upheld
description: A High Court judge in Belfast upheld the affirmative action policy of the new Police Service of Northern Ireland, which mandates that 50 percent of new recruits must be Catholic. Mark Parsons, 19, a Protestant, had sought judicial review of the policy after he was refused entry to the force despite scoring higher in the entrance tests than some Catholics who were accepted. Dismissing the application, Justice Brian Kerr ruled, ''The need to correct the imbalance in the police service was undeniable.'' The Royal Ulster Constabulary, the precursor to the new police force, was 92 percent Protestant.

description: RIKER-Anne T. ''Nancy'' (Cox). 91, of Weston, MA, formerly of NYC, July 21, 2002. Wife of the late Samuel Riker who died in 1970. She is survived by her daughter Anne T. Buttrick of Concord, MA and sons, Samuel of Tuckers Town, Bermuda and Robert T. of Sarasota, FL. She also leaves her sister Frances B. Cox of Sarasota, FL, eight grandchildren and ten greatgrandchildren. A celebration of her life will be held in late September in Concord followed by burial in Bermuda. Gifts in her memory may be made to the Massachusetts Audubon Society, 208 South Great Road, Lincoln, MA 01773.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WING, WILLIS (BUD)
description: WING-Willis (Bud). Age 82, of Brookville, LI on July 22, 2002. Retired in 1984 from Sperry Gyroscope as Division Scientist after 43 years of employment. He had over 30 patents in his name for Sperry. His field was Gyroscopes in Inertial Guidance Systems. Beloved husband of Betty. Adored step-father of Wendy Drewes (Glenn). Cherished Papa of Glenn, Daniel and Harrison Drewes. Also survived by brother William of Pella, Iowa & sister Evelyn Sproul of Cato, NY and several nieces and nephews. There will be a celebration of Bud's life on Saturday at 3:00 pm at Whitting Funeral Home, 300 Glen Cove Ave., Glen Head. Bud's family will greet friends prior to the service from 2-3 pm. Please no flowers, contributions to American Cancer Society would be greatly appreciated.

description: The Congressional investigation into the trading of stock in ImClone Systems widened yesterday when the House Energy and Commerce Committee demanded additional records from Merrill Lynch, where two stockbrokers have been suspended in connection with the investigation.

description: The House of Representatives voted tonight to ease restrictions on Americans traveling to Cuba and sending money there, as lawmakers discounted concerns about Havana's role in state-sponsored terrorism.

title: Wyeth Criticizes Media Coverage of Hormone Replacement Drugs
description: The chief executive of Wyeth, Robert A. Essner, criticized the media yesterday for what he termed its ''sensationalizing'' of a study that found that the company's hormone replacement therapy, Prempro, did more harm than good.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Charity Dispute Reviewed By Court
description: Relatives of a police officer killed in the Sept. 11 terror attack have asked a judge to order the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to provide an accounting of how money donated since Sept. 11 to the Widow's and Children's Fund has been paid out. Justice Ira Gammerman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan will decide whether the association will have to open its books. Frank J. Dominguez, whose brother, Officer Jerome Dominguez, died in the attack, said, ''Every single time they mention the numbers, the numbers change.'' The pension consultant for the association, Joseph Maccone, said the families had received adequate accounting and all of the donated money earmarked for them. He called the demand for more information ''a witch hunt.'' Susan Saulny (NYT)

description: Britain announced today that Rowan Williams, a Welsh churchman outspokenly in favor of gays and women as clerics and opposed to Western militarism, would be the new spiritual leader of the world's 70 million Anglicans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, HENRY WALLACE
description: FISCHER-Henry Wallace. A renowned civil engineer died on July 3, 2002. He was 84. Mr. Fischer began his career with Hardesty & Hanover in 1946 as a Structural Engineer. He quickly rose within the company and was named Partner in 1958. In this position Mr. Fischer was responsible for the design of movable and fixed bridges, highways and special projects. Among his most notable projects was the 1050 ft Lewiston-Queenston Bridge connecting The United States and Canada across The Niagara River. At the time of its completion, The Lewiston - Queenston Bridge was the longest fixed arch bridge in the world, and named The Most Beautiful Bridge of 1962 by The American Institute of Steel Construction. The second record span credited to Mr. Fischer is The Vertical Lift Bridge over Burrard Inlet in Vancouver, British Columbia. The Bridge has a 500 ft lift span, the longest in Canada. He also designed the Southeast Fourth Avenue Bridge in Miami, one of only three Hanover Skew Bascule Bridges in The United States, and an AISC Best Movable Bridge Award Winner. Mr. Fischer's recent works include the design of The I-264 Berkley Bascule Bridge, The Norfolk Interchange in Virginia, and The Youngmann Memorial Expressway in Buffalo. In 1967, Mr. Fischer served as a Member of The Structural Analysis and Tests Working Group which investigated the collapse of The Point Pleasant Bridge over The Ohio River. Mr. Fischer graduated from NYU with both Bachelors and Masters degrees in Civil Engineering. During World War II, he served in The U.S. Army in Burma and China. He retired from Hardesty & Hanover in 1996 after fifty years, the second longest tenured partner in the firm's 115 year history. Mr. Fischer was also a member in several prestigious engineering societies and co-authored ''A Fifty Year History of Movable Bridge Construction.'' His wife, Lillian, predeceased him in 2001. He is survived by his nieces, June Schweizer, Susan Tate, Beverly Fischer, and Joyce Sposato.

title: Corrections
description: The Eating Well column last Wednesday, about a syndrome known as Red Wine Headache, misidentified the grape in a wine that Dr. Fred Freitag of the Diamond Headache Clinic in Chicago said he could not drink. The grape, used in red Burgundy, is pinot noir, not cabernet sauvignon.

title: Mortgage Agencies Shift on Accounting
description: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the two biggest buyers of home mortgages in the country, have decided to treat stock options as an expense in their quarterly statements.

title: Commemorating 9/11 in Art
description: The School of Visual Arts announced this week that it would mount an exhibition of more than 50 works by its students and faculty members to commemorate Sept. 11. An outside jury recently selected the works, including "Patriotism Begins in the Home" (shown at right) by STEVEN DANA, a graduate of the school who now teaches design there. Works will include photography, paintings, scultures, video and mixed media, and will be shown at the school's Visual Arts Museum at 209 East 23rd Street from Sept. 11 to Oct. 9. The jurors were: ANNE ELLEGOOD, associate curator at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in New York; MOUKHTAR KOCACHE, the director of visual and media arts at the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council; DUANE MICHALS, a fine-art and commercial photographer; and GEORGE TSCHERNY, a designer whose posters are represented in the permanent collection of the Library of Congress and the Museum of Modern Art in New York.

description: Chocolate and port is a culinary match made in heaven. Both are rich and intense. When served together, they indulge our desire for a little decadent pleasure.

The men are brothers-in-law to each other, not brothers of the columnist's wife.

title: Productive Payton Reclaims His Spot
description: Quietly, Jay Payton has again become the Mets' regular center fielder. Because Manager Bobby Valentine detests that term, it is better to observe how he plays his players than to ask him for a label. But over the past two weeks, which predates the Mets' recent turnaround, Payton has become a fixture in center and in the lineup.

title: Wells the Card Shark
description: David Wells proved he is a savvy negotiator last winter, when he made a deal with the Arizona Diamondbacks a few days before Christmas but accepted a better offer from George Steinbrenner over lunch on Christmas Eve. Wells knew that no deal was official with Arizona until he had signed something, and the first contract he signed was the richer one, with his preferred team.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Charter Group To Meet
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's Charter Revision Commission, which is weighing the abolition of party primaries in New York City and a change in mayoral succession, is set to hold its first public hearing tomorrow at 5 p.m. at the offices of the city's Economic Development Corporation, on the fourth floor at 110 William Street in Lower Manhattan. The commission has until the first week of September to propose changes to the City Charter if it wants to put proposals on the ballot in November. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: A Summer Treat in Bite-Size Pieces
description: LOBSTER rolls are not just for the shore. They're on the menu at a number of places around the city, including Kitchenette in TriBeCa and on the Upper West Side and Mary's Fish Camp in Greenwich Village. Lobster rolls like the ones served on the big terrace at Cafe St. Bart's in Midtown define a summer lunch: they are easy to eat outdoors on a sunny day.

title: Columbia President, Rethinking Journalism School's Mission, Suspends Search for New Dean
description: The search for a new dean to lead Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism was abruptly suspended yesterday by the university's new president. He said the school, long regarded as a leader in its field, needed to rethink its mission and curriculum and place less emphasis on teaching skills like reporting and editing.

title: For Botero, Tomorrow Is Another Stage
description: Santiago Botero, a strong climber and time-trial racer from Colombia, is rarely accused of consistency, and today he showed why. One mountain stage after he was glued to the road and lost more than 15 minutes, Botero left six companions far behind in a long breakaway in the Alps and easily won the 15th of 20 stages in the Tour de France.

title: Joint Meeting Of Congress In New York
description: The House Republican leader, Dick Armey of Texas, said today he expected the House to vote this week on a resolution to hold a joint meeting of Congress in New York City on Sept. 6.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: A LOSS AT REUTERS Reuters Group , the provider of financial news and information, posted its first loss as a public company as sales slumped and it paid for cutting jobs. The company's net loss for the six months through June was 73 million ($114 million), or 5.2 pence a share, in contrast to net income of 269 million, or 19 pence a share, a year earlier. Revenue fell 5.3 percent, to 1.84 billion. The chief executive, Tom Glocer, reiterated that revenue at the information and news division would fall as much as 6 percent in the second half of the year.

description: The world is in need of major surgery, but here at least on Monday night was the traveling arm of the Ravenna Festival to apply some soothing first aid. The festival's five-year-old project uses a different metaphor, calling its annual musical visits to troubled places ''Roads to Friendship.'' Since 1997 the stops have been Sarajevo, Beirut, Jerusalem, Moscow and Istanbul; and given the events of the last year, New York was the inevitable choice for 2002.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Hotels.com Posts Surge In Profit
description: Hotels.com, an Internet travel company controlled by Barry Diller's USA Interactive, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit more than quadrupled as it sold more discounted hotel rooms on the Web. Net income rose to $18.8 million, or 32 cents a share, from $4.65 million, or 8 cents, for the quarter a year earlier, the company said in a statement. Sales rose 66 percent, to $229.7 million from $138.3 million. Hotels.com said its revenue had grown because more customers were using its hotels.com reservation site, which the company started in March. The company, based in Dallas, sells hotel rooms on its own Web site and on sites run by AOL Time Warner's America Online Internet service and Yahoo.

title: A Hard Drive for the Hip Pocket
Bin There, Done That
description: My recycling bin is purple. It is of modest dimensions -- 8 inches by 11 inches by 12 inches -- but for the past five years it has fulfilled its duty as the final resting place for my glass and plastic bottles, Vietnamese food containers and the occasional can of vegetarian baked beans. But since the city changed the recycling regulations last month and one no longer has to recycle glass and plastic (just metal and paper), my recycling bin has essentially lost its purpose. I can offer it no solace after all its years of service.

title: Sports of The Times; Brooklyn Royalty Comes Home Again
description: FROM time to time, Duke Snider returns to Brooklyn. He and his wife, Bev, have friends out on Staten Island, and as he drives out along the Gowanus Expressway toward the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, he occasionally makes a detour to Bay Ridge, where he spent a lot of very good summers.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: ARGENTINA: MENEM ACKNOWLEDGES SWISS ACCOUNT Former President Carlos Saul Menem acknowledged that he has a bank account in Switzerland, confirming a point in the sealed testimony of an Iranian defector who said that Iran paid the Argentine leader $10 million to cover up a terrorist bombing in Buenos Aires eight years ago. Mr. Menem said he opened the account in 1986, using it to deposit a $200,000 indemnity from the Argentine government for jailing him during a military dictatorship. He had previously denied having accounts in foreign countries. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer Raises Reserves
description: Prudential became the latest insurance company to shore up reserves after experiencing losses incurred by rising corporate bond defaults. The company said it would funnel 300 million ($473 million) into Jackson National, its American subsidiary, to cover losses related to corporate bonds. The Credit Suisse Group and Abbey National both recently raised reserves at their insurance units. Aegon and Fortis warned this week that profit for all of 2002 would fall short of expectations. Prudential, Britain's second- largest insurer, also reported a 15 percent decline in first-half profit. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Arrest Made in Wildfire in Sequoia Forest
description: A woman was arrested today after law enforcement officials concluded that she was the person who announced in a convenience store on Sunday that she had just set a wildfire that threatens some of the world's oldest trees.

title: BAYER SAYS F.D.A. SEEKS MORE STUDIES ON DRUG
description: The German pharmaceuticals company Bayer said the Food and Drug Administration had asked for more studies of the anti-impotence drug it is developing to compete with Viagra from Pfizer. The studies will delay introduction of the drug until next year instead of later this year, as previously planned. The drug, Vardenafil, is to be marketed by the British drug company GlaxoSmithKline. Victor Homola (NYT)

description: In ''Hidden Hills,'' a new NBC sitcom, all the suburban dads are besotted with Porn Mom, a mother in the neighborhood who helps coach Little League and has her own erotic Web site. Except perhaps for Brad, who is happily married with children, but flaunts the sibilant speech and arch mannerisms of Jack, the gay sidekick on ''Will & Grace.''

description: Until recently, only people with Yahoo's instant messaging service or Windows XP users with MSN Messenger could add live video to their online chats, essentially turning them into videophone conference calls. This week, however, the Web-camera maker Logitech released free software that extends that ability to people who favor America Online's Instant Messenger and MSN Messenger users without Windows XP.

He is Prince Sattam bin Abdul Aziz, not Abel Aziz.

title: Msgr. Richard Curtin, 86, Choir Conductor
description: Msgr. Richard B. Curtin, who conducted choirs for two papal visits to Yankee Stadium and produced several records of religious choral music, died on Sunday in Riverdale, the Bronx. He was 86.

description: Oregon Ballet Theater brought lots of pep to the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night, as it bounded through a program called ''James Canfield Signatures.''

description: The triple-wide trailer is gone, and the Huckabees have moved back into the Arkansas governor's mansion, but the hard hats are still swarming all over the place.

title: U.S. Fails in Effort to Block Vote On U.N. Convention on Torture
description: The United States lost a bid today to rewrite a United Nations plan intended to reinforce the 1989 convention against torture. The Bush administration, continuing to review international agreements binding on the United States, feared that the new plan would lead to demands by monitors to gain access to American prisoners and detainees.

title: Nazi Collaborator Wins Court Challenge on French Trial
description: PARIS, July 25  The European Court of Human Rights ruled today that an aged Nazi collaborator, Maurice Papon, was denied a fair trial when France refused to allow him to appeal a 1998 conviction for war crimes stemming from his involvement in the wartime deportation of Jews to German death camps.

title: 108-Year-Old Schooner Lives to Sail Another Day
description: In its storied history, the schooner Ernestina, a 108-year-old tall ship, has survived trips to the Arctic, a fire that sank it in 1947, a storm that tore off a mast in 1976 and even Hurricane Grace, which collided with a northeaster in October 1991 to form the so-called Perfect Storm. Yesterday, the ship survived yet another ordeal, when the Coast Guard saved it from sinking in Block Island Sound.

title: Making the Rocks Speak; Harriman Park Becoming Center for Geology Tourism
description: ''This is my Rosetta stone,'' Dr. Alexander E. Gates was saying as he stood before a vast chunk of rock near Lake Tiorati in Harriman State Park. A video crew was capturing his every syllable.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Echoes Of World War II
description: German prosecutors in the southern city of Hof have opened an inquiry into a reported massacre of dozens of ethnic Germans by Czechoslovaks in the summer of 1945. A historian who filed a complaint said the Germans were some of the nearly three million from the Sudetenland region of Czechoslovakia who were accused of collaborating with the Nazis and expelled. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: The Central Park Centipede
description: New Yorkers like to pretend, almost biblically, that there is nothing new under the sun. But then along comes the discovery of a new species -- a new genus, in fact -- of centipede living in Central Park, a place we thought we knew down to the least of its organisms. This centipede is only about four-tenths of an inch long, making it one of the smallest in the world. The creature is called Nannarrup hoffmani, which honors the man who recognized that he didn't recognize it. It lives in the park's leaf litter, the crumbling organic debris that accumulates under the trees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPKIN, HELEN

Survived by daughters Arlene and Erica Popkin, son-inlaw Stephen Hirschberg, and Lawrence Schoenbach; grandchildren David, Daniel and Laura Hirschberg and Sarah, Beth and Hannah Schoenbach. Services Friday 11:30AM, Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, 150 Hicks Lane, Interment at Beth Moses Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICKEY, GEORGE
description: RICKEY-George. 95. Passed away peacefully on July 17, 2002, at his home in St. Paul, MN. While the world of art will miss an illustrious figure, his family mourns the loss of a generous and supportive father and grandfather. He is survived by his sons, Stuart, San Francisco (Virginia), Philip, St. Paul (Mary), and grandchildren, Owen and Eleanora. A future memorial is planned. In lieu of flowers, contributions in memory of George Rickey for care of those in need may be sent to: Hospice of The Twin Cities, 10405 Sixth Ave. North Suite 250, Plymouth, MN 55441.

title: Ashcroft Defends Plan for National Hotline on Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  Brushing off Congressional complaints about creating a "snitch system," Attorney General John D. Ashcroft said today the Administration would go ahead with a plan to use truck and bus drivers, port workers, meter readers and letter carriers to report suspicious activities around the nation.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Avon: Man Charged With Hate Crime

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBSON, GEORGE WARNER
description: GIBSON - George Warner. Died on July 18, 2002 at his home in Hallowell, Maine. He was 93. He was the beloved husband of the late Diana Gibson of Hallowell. George Gibson was born on February 19, 1909 in Chestnut Hill, MA, the son of Kirkland Hopkins Gibson and Florence Warner. He attended Rivers School and graduated from Milton Academy in 1927, from Harvard University in 1931, and from Harvard Business School in 1933. After his graduation, Mr. Gibson apprenticed in the textile trade, working in Nashua, New Hampshire for the operators of a garneting machine. He then worked for the textile firm founded by his great grandfather, William Skinner and Sons, for which he traveled widely throughout New England selling patented satin silk to shoe companies. Mr. Gibson loved the sea and was an avid sailor. He joined the US Naval Reserve during World World II and rose to the rank of Lieutenant Commander. After the war in the Pacific ended, he was Executive Officer of Radio Tokyo in Japan. Following the war, Mr. Gibson moved to New York City and re-joined the firm of William Skinner and Sons, where he ultimately became a vice president. He married Diana Vaughan Marvin on November 15, 1947 and they lived in New York City, summering in Hallowell, Maine. In the mid-1960s he joined a textile consulting firm, soon becoming a partner, from which he retired in 1974. At the time, the Gibsons changed their primary residence to Hallowell, spending winter months in New York. Mr. Gibson was a member of the Harvard Club and a director of the English Speaking Union. He also served as his Harvard class agent. He became a Director and served a term as President of the Pine Tree State Arboretum, a nonprofit organization in Augusta, Maine. He was a generous benefactor of that organization and volunteered many hours of his time there. He was also a member of the Hallowell Tree Board, among other voluntary activities. The Gibsons were active stewards of the family property known as the Vaughan Woods. They donated a conservation easement to the Kennebec Land Trust that forever protects the woods. George Gibson is survived by his three children, George L. Gibson and his wife, Linda Johns, of New York City, Ellen Vaughan Gibson of Roslindale, MA and David Hallowell Gibson and Susan Gibson of Ballston Lake, New York; and his sister and brother-in-law, Eleanor and Amor Hollingsworth, of Westwood, MA; and by a number of nephews and nieces. Memorial contributions may be made to the Pine Tree State Arboretum or the Kennebec Land Trust. A memorial will be held at a later date. For information Knowlton & Hewins Funeral Home, One Church Street, Augusta, ME 04330. www.khrfuneralhomes.com

The surplus hit 1.3 trillion yen ($11.1 billion) in June, 71.4 percent above June 2001 and almost twice the growth that economists expected. Exports were up 8.9 percent in June, the third consecutive rise, while imports slipped 5.1 percent. Last year, it earned $39.6 million in the period. The company said that excluding one-time items and noncash charges, its cash net income had been $96 million, up 57 percent from a year ago. The company benefited from strong revenue and profit growth in its majority-owned online travel units, Expedia and hotels.com, and its online personal service, Match.com. title: A Skateboarder's Paradise With a Shakespearean Slant
description: The set for ''Twelfth Night'' in Central Park seems designed by skateboarders who have seen Frank Gehry's Guggenheim in Bilbao, Spain. The actors (above left, Julia Stiles) enter by sliding down a 20-foot slope on carpets; one showoff does it standing up. The voluptuous blue waves (note the boat wreck, above right) look like blobitecture: architecture created by computer modeling. ''I've noticed Frank Gehry, and the Koolhaas Prada store downtown,'' said Walt Spangler, the set designer. When he saw a Gehry exhibit, he said, ''the thing I related to was: his work starts out as this cut-and-paste gesture, with hot glue and tape and paper.'' Mr. Spangler, with a crew of 10, had to turn ''a big stack of wood'' into a set in three weeks. No computer modeling was involved. The slide's incline was set by Mr. Spangler. ''I was having panic attacks, and the crew was trying it out, and I thought the actors might say, 'I can't do this during the middle of a show,' '' he said. ''But they were completely excited about it. Especially Julia.''

On Tuesday, Transportation Secretary Norman Mineta warned a House committee that Congress had failed to provide the government with adequate resources to meet the mandates it imposed in last year's aviation security legislation. Meanwhile, prodded by local airport operators, some House Republicans are trying to push back the law's tough deadlines for instituting new security measures.

A singer named Tina handed her demo CD to him between songs, and when he came back for an encore, he had it played over the sound system while he strummed along. When the harmony veered unexpectedly, he grinned. ''You put in that tricky chord,'' he said. ''You've been listening to my songs.'' He then brought Tina onstage to sing harmony on ''Fall at Your Feet,'' and like a good part of the audience, she knew every word.

Sigma, based in Toronto, provides high-speed voice and data services to cable TV companies. Liberate's technology allows cable companies to offer interactive digital services like enhanced TV broadcasts, electronic program guides, video-on-demand service and digital video recording. With Sigma, Liberate will be able to offer more advanced network management services to its customers to help them reduce costs and simplify their operations, the company said. He was in critical condition last night at Jersey Shore Medical Center last night. The second driver, Thomas Patock, 57, suffered internal injuries and was in stable condition at the hospital.
