Kelly and senior officials at two police unions yesterday criticized a Manhattan judge who has ruled that three undercover narcotics detectives must identify themselves in court, saying that the order could put the detectives' lives at risk and undermine the department's ability to fight crime.

title: Developer Pleads Guilty In Corruption In Bridgeport
description: A Connecticut developer pleaded guilty today to a federal conspiracy charge that he installed a chimney at no cost in the home of Joseph P. Ganim, the indicted mayor of Bridgeport, in return for Mr. Ganim's support in winning city contracts.

title: Bishops Select Lay Board On Sexual Abuse Review
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops announced yesterday the appointment of a sexual abuse review board composed entirely of active Catholic laypeople, including some who work for church organizations, but no one from the victims' advocacy groups that have been most critical of the church.

title: American Capitalism's Other Side
description: Andy Grove, a founder of Intel, summed up the mood of recent weeks when he said he is ''embarrassed and ashamed'' to be a corporate executive in America today.

title: Armstrong Is Cruising Downhill to Paris
description: In the 16th stage of what will almost certainly be his fourth consecutive victory in the Tour de France, Lance Armstrong relied once again on his formidable team today, then launched an attack on the last of three climbs that left all his major rivals behind. While there might be no defining moment to his overall victory, as there was in the first three, this was a defining day.

title: Accounts
description: * Kansas Lottery, Topeka, Kan., retained Barkley Evergreen & Partners, Kansas City, Mo., for six more years, with total spending estimated at $18 million. Barkley Evergreen also handles advertising for the Missouri Lottery.

title: Bottom Still Far Off for Energy Traders
description: Just when it seems that things cannot become worse in the electricity marketing and trading business, they do.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Insurers Investigated
description: The German property and casualty insurance units of Allianz A.G., AXA and Munich Re were raided by the German cartel office and local police in a nationwide price-fixing investigation, the companies said. The companies were raided along with 10 rivals amid suspicion they colluded to raise the prices that industrial companies pay for liability, casualty and property insurance, the cartel office said. Allianz and rivals started raising premiums for industrial insurance after the Sept. 11 attacks. The increases included insuring companies against events like fire and business shutdowns. The German insurance association said the price increases were necessary to cover the costs of potential damages.

title: White House Moves to Limit Corporate Scandals' Fallout
description: Responding to criticism from Republicans in Congress and nationwide that President Bush has not acted aggressively enough against corporate corruption, White House officials moved on several fronts today to demonstrate the administration's efforts.

title: Killings From Taliban's Era Still Haunt a Valley
description: Hussein Jan, a 51-year-old farmer, tossed a stone into a shallow pit dug on a slope above this town. ''They shot us here, 76 people, they killed everyone, and only I survived,'' he said.

title: A 19-Year-Old F.B.I. Videotape Keeps Pulling Sharpton Back to the Past
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton once said he was created with no reverse in his transmission, but if so, he has shown he can brake suddenly and make U-turns.

title: At Grocery Checkout, No Wallet Needed
description: A HANDFUL of grocery stores in the United States are testing fingerprint imaging machines that enable shoppers to pay for their purchases simply by putting a finger to an electronic pad.

title: Progress Seen in Labor Talks
description: While strike talk rages around them, negotiators for baseball's club owners and the players continue having talks they consider productive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, DOROTHY CUMMINGS
description: RYAN-Dorothy Cummings. Age 84, of Rockville Centre, LI on July 19, 2002. Mother of Tom, Mary Ryan-Smith, Peter. Grandmother of Christopher and Molly. Service Thursday, 1:00 PM at Christ Episcopal Church, Garden City, NY.

title: Dating Mr. Right Next Door
description: WHEN Liz Cohen spotted Jimmy Hausman in the hallway of her building, her first reaction was to duck and hide. ''I really had no interest in getting to know him,'' she said. ''I thought he was a big dork.''

title: Russia Still Set on Selling a Stake in Lukoil
description: The Russian government is moving forward with a public sale of a 5.9 percent stake in Lukoil, Russia's biggest oil producer, despite sharp declines in world markets.

title: The Macintosh and Elegance Bigotry
description: Man -- if your e-mail Inbox is ever feeling lonely, just write a column about Macs versus PC's, as I did last week. You'll need the Jaws of Life to extricate yourself from the avalanche of responses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, JOHN F.
description: COLLINS-John F. Died July 24, 2002. Devoted husband of Patricia Collins (nee Russell), beloved father of John, Kathleen, James, Michael, Anne Collins Hardgrove, Margaret Collins Stoop, Stephen, Daniel and William. Loving grandfather of Michael, Ivo, Sophia, Aidan and Olivia. Dearest brother of Joan LaChance and Kevin Collins. Valued colleague and treasured teacher to many. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, N.Y., Thursday and Friday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass Saturday 9a.m., St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Under the Stars
description: To the Editor:

title: Rustling Up Fans of the Western, Over at the O.K. Corral
description: Sometime in 1877, legend here has it, a prospector named Ed Schieffelin thought he saw silver gleaming from distant hills in Apache territory. Cavalrymen warned Schieffelin not to dig there, saying, ''All you'll find is your own tombstone.''

title: E.D.S. Says Profit Rose Despite WorldCom Ties
description: Electronic Data Systems reported yesterday that earnings rose slightly in the second quarter even after it set aside $101 million to cover bills that may never be paid by WorldCom, which declared bankruptcy earlier this week.

title: City Council Passes Measure On Term-Limits Disparity
description: The City Council voted overwhelmingly yesterday to revise the term-limits law, eliminating a provision that held some council members to a maximum of only six years in office, rather than eight.

title: A Hard Drive For the Hip Pocket
description: IF you live in an apartment, you must occasionally get the urge to knock down a wall, boot your neighbor and double the size of your place. Maybe it is human nature or Manifest Destiny, or that you simply have too much stuff. There is no painless way to expand your personal space, but if your storage problem extends to a PC overflowing with MP3 songs, PowerPoint presentations and digital video, an external hard drive may be the solution.

title: Maker of Educational Toys to Test the Public Offering Market
description: LeapFrog Enterprises, a manufacturer of educational toys, is scheduled to brave the volatile equities market today and offer nine million of its shares in an initial public offering.

title: Senate Defeats Plan to Limit What Elderly Pay for Drugs
description: Having rejected two ambitious proposals to offer prescription drug benefits to everyone on Medicare, the Senate today scuttled a more modest plan to limit the amount of money that elderly people would have to spend on medicines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, MARTHA
description: LEWIS-Martha. Age 81. Died on Tuesday, just after noon, July 23, 2002. She was the Financial Director of the Child Welfare League of America and a New York City school teacher. She is survived by her children Edward and Deborah, and her sister Flora, at whose home a memorial service will be held at a later date. Please contact Flora at 212-929-1488 to attend.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The 3-D Intruder

title: Palestinian Cease-Fire Was in Works Before Israeli Strike
description: Tanzim, the Palestinian militia connected to Yasir Arafat's Fatah faction, was preparing to announce a unilateral cease-fire with Israel before an Israeli warplane dropped a one-ton bomb early Tuesday on a Hamas leader's home in Gaza City, Palestinian officials and Western diplomats said today.

title: Bioterror's New Frontier
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Wings, Rugged Rivals to an Aging Memory Standard
description: THIRTY-TWO years ago, Gordon Moore, co-founder of the Intel Corporation, and a Michigan inventor named Stanford Ovshinsky collaborated on a technical article about a promising new type of computer memory that did not rely on silicon but rather on a thin film of germanium, tin, tungsten and other elements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRUNSKY, LUCY STAMPLEMAN
description: STRUNSKY-Lucy Stampleman. 91. Died on July 22, 2002 in San Francisco, CA. Long time resident of New York City and political activist for left wing causes. Wife of William English. Mother of Michael. Mother-in-law of Jean Zimmerman. Grandmother of Lara-Joelle and Burke. Memorials are being planned. Contributions can be made to The Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Ave, Montgomery, AL 36104

title: Armstrong Still in Charge as Tour Leaves the Alps
description: CLUSES, France, July 25  The Tour de France finished its stay in the Alps today and, as far as Mario Aerts is concerned, good riddance to those mountains.

title: High-Tech Tools Turn Private Cockpits Into Toy Fairs
description: CRUISING 3,000 feet above the rocky Massachusetts coast in early July, Harlan Hamlin sat in the pilot's seat and complained about the weather. The sky was postcard blue, the sun was blazing, and not a whitecap could be seen in the Atlantic below.

title: Diaz's Goal of Being the Top Money-Winner Leads Her to Wykagyl
description: It seemed as if it was only a matter of time before Laura Diaz broke into the limelight on the L.P.G.A. Tour. Diaz has two victories this season after four second-place finishes last year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Woman Accused In Husband's Office Fire
description: A woman has been accused of setting fire to her husband's medical office inside a 400-apartment high-rise building in Forest Hills, endangering hundreds of tenants. The fire, which occurred in March, was quickly put out, and no one was reported injured. The damage has been estimated at $600,000. Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said yesterday that the woman, Leena Levin, 41, of Syosset, was charged with arson, criminal mischief and reckless endangerment. The police said she started the fire because her husband, Dr. Allan Levin, wanted to collect the $250,000 insurance policy. Mr. Brown said the police were looking into Dr. Levin's possible participation. His lawyer did not immediately return a phone call for comment. If convicted, Mrs. Levin could be sentenced to 25 years to life in prison, Mr. Brown said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Seeing Far for Less
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the fire at a Consolidated Edison plant that caused a blackout misstated the name of a residential complex in the East Village where buildings were evacuated. It is Haven Plaza, not Haven Place.

title: Is Fighting Iraq Worth the Risks?
description: For months, President Bush has been asserting his intention to remove Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq. That goal appears to have broad support from the American people and Congress. Through careful diplomacy, he can probably also gain at least the acquiescence -- if not the active support -- of a number of European and Arab allies.

title: Hard Drive for the Car Lets You Rip CD's on the Way to Work
description: With its hard drive for storing music, the Sony MEX-HD1 is a bit like a built-in Apple iPod for the car. But unlike an iPod or other similar portable music players, the MEX-HD1 can download music from CD's without a computer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THORNBERRY, HENRY
description: THORNBERRY-Henry. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Henry Thornberry, associated with The Times from 1974 until retiring in 1988.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Central Islip: Ex-Lawmaker Pleads Guilty
description: A former Nassau County legislator pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiracy charges stemming from his work as a loan officer before he was elected. The former legislator, Patrick C. Williams, a Democrat from Uniondale, resigned his post on Tuesday, leaving the Legislature evenly split between Republicans and Democrats. A special election for Mr. Williams's district is scheduled for Sept. 10. Under Mr. Williams's plea agreement with federal prosecutors, he admitted inflating the incomes of home mortgage applicants while working as a loan officer for Amerifirst Mortgage Corporation, and he agreed to pay $51,000 in restitution. He faces 6 to 12 months in prison at sentencing on Nov. 15.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPINSLEY, ALVIN
description: SAPINSLEY-Alvin. July 13th, aged 80 at the Motion Picture Retirement Home in Los Angeles. Television script writer since the start of television and twice an award winner. Survived by his sister Barbara. A memorial service will be held at the Writers Guild of America in Beverly Hills, Sunday August 4th, at 1PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, CECILE
description: SHERMAN-Cecile. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Cecile Sherman, associated with The Times from 1952 until retiring in 1971.

title: Clinton Says Republicans Blocked His Audit Reforms
description: Former President Bill Clinton today hailed his own efforts to increase the oversight of corporate governance and criticized Republicans and Harvey L. Pitt, currently the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, saying they had frustrated Mr. Clinton's efforts at reform.

title: Afghan Officials Say Aid Has Been Too Slow
description: A group of senior officials from Afghanistan said today that international donors, including the United States, had been slow to deliver reconstruction aid to their country, and they warned of social unrest if assistance is not increased by winter.

title: 100 Years of Vroooooooom, As Harley-Davidson Hits the Road
description: Harley-Davidson is celebrating the 100th anniversary of its founding with Open Road Tour, a traveling exhibition that includes Elvis Presley's 1956 model KH. Pentagram, a New York studio, designed the exhibition, which began last week in Atlanta. Three tents showcase Harley history, Harley fashion and Harleys themselves (at right, 100 gas tanks). The show will be in Baltimore from Aug. 16 to 18, then it will hopscotch to Los Angeles, Toronto, Dallas, Mexico City, Sydney, Tokyo, Barcelona and Hamburg. The $55 admission in Baltimore will include a concert with the Neville Brothers or Hootie and the Blowfish or Bob Dylan, and demonstration rides (bring your motorcycle license). For information, www.harley-davidson.com. ELAINE LOUIE

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: VIVENDI TO OBTAIN CREDIT Vivendi Universal's new chief executive, Jean-Rene Fourtou, left, said the company would secure new credit lines from banks by the end of August to eliminate any doubts about the company's ability to meet loan repayments. Even so, he continued, Vivendi would still need to sell assets to reduce its debt. Mr. Fourtou said a 1 billion euro credit line that Vivendi negotiated with its banks this month had not been drawn upon and would probably be only partly used by the end of August. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: New Department Inches Forward in the Senate
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman backed away today from his insistence that a new Department of Homeland Security be allowed to issue directives to the C.I.A. and the F.B.I., improving the chances that the Senate and the House will reach agreement with President Bush on the department's intelligence functions.

title: P.B.A. Names Black Officer to No. 3 Post
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, which has often played a divisive role in the Police Department's sometimes difficult relations with minority communities around the city, has for the first time elevated an African-American officer to the union's five-member governing board.

title: Arnold Weinstock, Top British Industrialist, Is Dead at 77
description: Arnold Weinstock, who for 30 years dominated Britain's electrical and electronics industries with his giant General Electric Company, only to be ousted by critics who then virtually bankrupted the company, died on Tuesday at his home in Wiltshire. He was 77.

title: In  California, Blue Skies Fade For Republican
description: It was a clear morning in Los Angeles, and Gov. Gray Davis, smiling tightly and wearing a starched blue shirt, was standing at one of the city's highest spots, the observatory at Griffith Park. As a clutch of environmental activists and Hollywood actors applauded, Mr. Davis signed a bill establishing emission guidelines for automobiles sold in California, proclaiming it an environmental milestone.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Court Orders Groton Prep School to Give Grand Jury Files in Sex Abuse Cases
description: The Groton School, one of the nation's most prestigious prep schools, must turn over to a grand jury files from an internal investigation into sexual abuse of students by fellow students, the Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled late Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILICI, FRANCES MARIE D'AMATO
description: MILICI-Frances Marie D'Amato. 73, beloved wife of Anthony J. Milici, Sr., of Wallingford, CT. Beloved mother of Anthony J. Milici, Jr., David J. Milici, Janet Marie Milici Lewis and Robert R. Lewis, adoring grandmother of Rand, Marjorie, Anthony and Helen, loving sister of Agnes Chartier, John D'Amato and Lawrence D'Amato. Her family will receive relatives and friends at The Wallingford Funeral Home, 809 North Main Street Extension, Wallingford, Thursday from 4 p.m. to 8 p.m. Funeral services will be held Friday at 9:30 a.m. from The Wallingford Funeral Home, when the funeral cortege will proceed to Most Holy Trinity Church, where a Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at 10:30 a.m. Interment will be in St. John Cemetery. Gifts in her memory may be sent to the American Liver Foundation, CT Chapter, 110 Washington Avenue, North Haven, CT 06473.

title: Arnell Group Gets Bank of America Job
description: The Bank of America has expanded its relationship with the Omnicom Group by selecting the Arnell Group in New York to handle a new worldwide identity assignment, integrating such things as the appearance of locations, bank statements and technology. Terms were not disclosed.

title: VISA REDUCES FEES IN RESPONSE TO INQUIRY IN EUROPE
description: The credit card company Visa International Inc. agreed to reduce and cap certain fees charged for cross-border transactions in Europe to end an antitrust investigation into the fees by the European Commission. The commission was investigating a charge that Visa's fees, which were charged to retailers, abused its dominant position in the credit card market. In return for restricting the fees, Visa received an exemption from European Union rules intended to prevent dominant players like Visa from charging such fees. The commission is also investigating fees charged by MasterCard International Inc. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: No Place Like Home? Try Finding One
description: IT'S probably too late for an apology to all the real estate brokers who witnessed my recent frenzied attempts to buy a house in the insanely competitive San Francisco Bay area market.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hynix Board Installed
description: A new board representing the creditor institutions that have taken over Hynix Semiconductor was installed at a shareholders meeting at the Hynix headquarters in Ichon, south of Seoul. The meeting was turbulent, according to the Yonhap news agency, as small shareholders mounted a successful filibuster. Small shareholders delayed the meeting for 90 minutes but could not prevent the creditors from completing their takeover of the company, which owes them more than $6 billion. Nor could the small shareholders persuade the new board to give favorable terms for recouping part of their losses from the steep drop in the value of Hynix shares, which fell another 9.7 percent yesterday. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Prescription Drug Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Doctor Faces Murder Charge
description: A doctor was charged with felony murder and drug dealing by investigators who said he used his clinic in Gary as a front to prescribe unnecessary pain medication and other drugs, leading to two deaths. The doctor, Jong Bek of Chicago, 61, was arrested after law enforcement officials posed as patients. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, ROBERT J.
description: WILLIAMS-Robert J. On July 23, 2002 of Garden City. Beloved husband of Mary. Loving father of Jaclyn and Stefanie; also Maureen and Christine. Brother of Warren, Joyce, Eileen, Ronald, Richard, Mary Ann and Dennis. Survived by nieces, nephews and grandchildren. Retired partner at Bigham, Englar. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave., at 12th Street, Garden City Thursday and Friday. Mass at St. Joseph's Church 9:45 AM Saturday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to CMTA Foundation, 2700 Chestnut St., Chester, PA. Remember BobWhat a great guy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYLER, MARJORIE GOLDWASSER
description: WYLER-Marjorie Goldwasser, 86, of New York City and Westport, CT. Beloved mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother, died July 22, 2002 at Norwalk Hospital of respiratory failure. A distinguished public relations professional, she was a pioneer in the presentation of Judaism to the American public and a strong advocate for the ethics of social justice inherent to Judaism. Marjorie served the Jewish Theological Seminary of America for more thatn half a century as its Director of Public Relations. She produced the renowned Eternal Light show, was an expert in Jewish radio and television, and on the Board of Odyssey, a faithbased cable channel. She also represented the Jewish Museum in its early years. She was an active member and former president of the Boards of Surprise Lake Camp and the Jewish Child Care Association, among others. Bryn Mawr College, '36, BA and MA in Philosophy, graduate studies, New School University in Exile. Recent widow of Wilfred Wyler, she is survived by her daughters, Ruth W. Messinger, of New York and Barbara W. Gold of Philadelphia; her sons-in-law, Eli Messinger, Stephen Gold and Andrew Lachman; her five grandchildren, Daniel, Miriam and Adam Messinger and Rachel and Russell Gold and their partners, Batya Elbaum, Felicia Hayes, Kira Plagge, Justin Auld and Laura Hernandez Gold; a sister, Joan Schine and a brother Edwin L. Goldwasser; and five great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Thursday July 25th at 2 p.m. ''The Riverside'', 76th and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Surprise Lake Camp, 307 Seventh Ave. Shiva will be observed at the home of Ruth Messinger, 91 Central Park West, (69th St.) on Thursday, 6-9 pm, Friday 2-6 pm, Sunday and Monday 4-8 pm.

title: ABBOTT LABORATORIES' THYROID DRUG IS APPROVED
description: Abbott Laboratories said it won Food and Drug Administration approval to keep selling its drug Synthroid, taken by about eight million people in the United States for thyroid disorders. Synthroid has been on the market for more than 40 years, Abbott said. The F.D.A. asked in 1997 that companies submit new applications for Synthroid and rival medicines because they were introduced before the agency established drug regulations. Abbott filed the application after acquiring Synthroid with its $6.9 billion purchase of Knoll in 2001.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Norwalk: Skakel Seeks Sentencing Delay
description: Lawyers for Michael Skakel, who was convicted last month of murdering his neighbor Martha Moxley in 1975, have again sought a 30-day delay in his sentencing hearing, now scheduled for Aug. 9. Mr. Skakel faces 10 years to life in prison. One of his lawyers, Michael Sherman, said that the State Probation Department needed more time to prepare its presentencing report. Judge John F. Kavenewsky is expected to confer with prosecutors before making his ruling on the motion. A sentencing delay was granted last month.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Salon Media Introduces Weblog Service
description: The Salon Media Group, publisher of the online magazine Salon, has introduced a service that allows users to publish their own Weblogs. Subscribers to the Salon Blogs service will use tools from UserLand Software to build and maintain Weblogs, an increasingly popular form of personal site built around Web links and commentary. Salon said Scott Rosenberg, its managing editor, would use his new Weblog to point readers toward users' pages. The service, which includes putting each user's Weblog up on blogs.salon.com, will cost $39.95 a year after a 30-day free trial. David F. Gallagher (NYT)

title: Solemn Ground, Soaring Visions
description: To the Editor:

title: Victorian Ease On a Poof Of Many Colors
description: Zuzana Kurtz says her star-shaped Victorian ottoman, right, invites sprawling and is popular with celebrities like the actress Clare Danes and also with owners of shoe stores. The ottoman, 24 inches across and 17 inches high, has been sold at ABC Carpet & Home; it is now available from Ms. Kurtz's showroom for $895 -- about half the retail cost. Two of them fit together like a puzzle. Zuzka for Fabricology, 37 East 18th Street; (212) 260-1876. DEBORAH BALDWIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTOK, RABBI CHAIM
description: POTOK-Rabbi Chaim. We mourn with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague. After ordination, he was the director of the leadership Training Fellowship at JTS and then became director of Camp Ramah in California before embarking upon his illustrious career as a writer. Author of The Chosen, The Promise and My Name is Asher Lev, he was devoted to Judaic scholarship and was the editor of the fivevolume JPS Torah Commentary and one of the editors of the Conservative Movement's Etz Hayim Torah Commentary. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Adena, children, Akiva, Naama and Rena, sisters Bella Sobolofsky and Charlotte (Rabbi Lester) Hering and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Reuven Hammer, Pres Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Executive Vice President The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Up, Down and All Around
description: The Bush administration was angry about cable TV news networks' displaying stock market movements at the bottom of the screen while President Bush was giving a speech. There were no complaints yesterday, however, that the arrows were being shown as Mr. Bush commented on the arrest of a C.E.O. charged with treating his company's treasury as a personal piggy bank. The Dow industrial average rose nearly 500 points, and although any politician would have given an arm to take credit for finally giving Wall Street a day of good news, most were wise enough to realize that the market's current wild ride is too scary for anyone to try to claim he's in control.

title: Rule Affects New Futures
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved a 20 percent margin rule yesterday for the trading of single-stock futures contracts. This is the last major legal step before these contracts can be traded. Tom Asher, the chief executive of Nasdaq Liffe Markets, one of the exchanges that will trade these stock futures, said he expected to open for business by early October.

title: Ned Martin, 78, Broadcaster for Red Sox
description: Ned Martin, a radio and television broadcaster for the Boston Red Sox for three decades, died Tuesday, a day after he appeared at Fenway Park for the team's tribute to Ted Williams. He was 78.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CINEMARK INC., Plano, Tex., a chain of movie theaters, postponed its initial public offering indefinitely because of market conditions. Cinemark had planned to raise $199 million through the sale of 11.1 million shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, HAROLD (HAL)
description: ROSENBERG-Harold (Hal), 86, of New York City, devoted husband of Dorothy and brother of Martin, died July 2, 2002. A decorated First Lt. in the Army Air Force in WWII. He later helped establish U.S. Postal Service employee assistance programs. A wellknown and beloved member of Alcoholics Anonymous, he celebrated 40 years of continuous sobriety on January 14, 2002. A memorial service in celebration of Hal's life will be held Tuesday, July 30, 6pm, Marble Collegiate Church, 29th Street and Fifth Avenue, New York City.

title: Sports Fantasy Is Catching Up With Reality
description: ''THE sun is setting,'' the announcer said, ''but we're just getting started.'' It's time for N.F.L. football at Raymond James Stadium in Tampa, Fla., and the bleachers are throbbing with fans. As the palm trees sway in the breeze, players for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Miami Dolphins gather at the 50-yard line for the coin toss.

title: S.E.C. Chief Draws Ridicule In Quest for Higher Status
description: Democratic and Republican members of Congress joined administration officials today in ridiculing Harvey L. Pitt's request that his pay be increased and his job as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission be elevated to cabinet rank.

title: NEGOTIATORS AGREE ON BROAD CHANGES IN BUSINESS LAWS
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed today on a broad overhaul of corporate fraud, accounting and securities laws aimed at curbing the rampant abuses that have shaken Wall Street. Final approval in Congress is expected within days, and President Bush has said he will sign the bill into law.

title: Jets Sign 5th-Round Pick
description: The Jets, who report to training camp tomorrow, signed their fifth-round draft pick, offensive lineman Jonathan Goodwin, yesterday and agreed to terms with their fourth-round pick, defensive tackle Alan Harper. That leaves only a second-rounder, safety Jon McGraw, unsigned among their draftees.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KURMAN, BERNARD
description: KURMAN-Bernard. Happy First Birthday in Heaven. Forever in our hearts. Frank and Ra

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: One Freed, Three Missing
description: Human Rights in China, an advocacy group, said that Fang Jue, a pro-democracy activist, had been released from prison after a four-year term but remained under close police surveillance. The Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said that three other democracy advocates had been missing since June 26 when, traveling in Vietnam, they visited the Chinese border. One is Wang Bingzhang a Chinese citizen who is a permanent resident of the United States, living in San Francisco. He became the subject of a nationwide manhunt after he sneaked back into China in February 1998; he was soon caught and deported. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Redistricting Panel Meets
description: The city's redistricting commission met for the first time yesterday. The panel will begin reviewing demographic changes recorded in the 2000 census to redraw the boundaries of the Council's 51 districts by the fall. The commission, which must reflect a certain political and geographic balance, elected Henry M. Calderon, a Republican mayoral appointee, as chairman. The commission adopted its rules of procedure and elected William S. Floyd, a director at Verizon and a Democrat, as executive director. He said he would take a leave from his post to serve on the panel. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Population Highest Since 1871
description: The population reached 3.9 million people in April, its highest level since 1871 and an 8 percent increase since 1996, according to preliminary figures from a national census. The influx of immigrants and returning Irish emigrants accounted for more of the population growth than births for the first time. After peaking at around 8 million in the early 19th century, Ireland's population fell to around 4 million during the potato famine of the 1840's because of emigration and starvation, and reached a low of 2.8 million in 1961. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAULSON, ALFRED G.
description: PAULSON-Alfred G., of Forest Hills, NY, on July 24, 2002. Survived by beloved wife Jacqueline; children Theodora, William, John and Julia; brothers Albert and Juan; brother-in-law Ted Boklan; and grandchildren Boaz, Yoav, Tamar and Dina. Funeral services Friday 11:30AM, Frank E. CampbellThe Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.

title: On the Seine, A St.-Tropez Tan
description: In a city that has never been embarrassed by its own exhibitionism, the display of lithe young bodies toasting on a beach beside the Seine here could be seen as just another sales pitch to tourists. Why go as far as the Cte d'Azur, Paris seems to be saying, when you can have more or less the same sand, deck chairs, parasols, even palm trees in the heart of Paris?

title: Jimmy Maxwell, 85, a Lead Trumpeter With the Top Big Bands
description: Jimmy Maxwell, who played trumpet with many of the best-known big bands in jazz and was also a mainstay of the radio and television studios, died on Saturday at his home in Great Neck, N.Y. He was 85.

title: Exhaust Fumes From Possible Suicide Go On to Poison Five

title: Stock Exchange May Move Some Operations to New Site
description: The New York Stock Exchange may move some of its operations to a new trading floor in Westchester County, N.Y. -- or elsewhere in the metropolitan region -- to prevent the market from shutting down in the event of another terrorist attack or disaster in Manhattan, exchange officials said yesterday.

title: Mets Must Justify The Spin
description: Steve Phillips praised Al Leiter profusely after finally signing him to a two-year contract extension yesterday, calling him a great pitcher who has represented the Mets as well as anyone else and almost behaving as if he were at a roast. The only thing the Mets' general manager would not discuss was why it took so long to sign Leiter when he has basically been begging for a new deal for months. The agreement was delayed, but Phillips used the timing to spin it positively.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi To Obtain Credit
description: Vivendi Universal's new chief executive, Jean-Ren Fourtou, left, said the company would secure new credit lines from banks by the end of August to eliminate any doubts about the company's ability to meet loan repayments. Even so, he continued, Vivendi would still need to sell assets to reduce its debt. Mr. Fourtou said a 1 billion euro credit line that Vivendi negotiated with its banks this month had not been drawn upon and would probably be only partly used by the end of August. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

Buttrick of Concord, MA and sons, Samuel of Tuckers Town, Bermuda and Robert T. of Sarasota, FL. She also leaves her sister Frances B. Cox of Sarasota, FL, eight grandchildren and ten greatgrandchildren. A celebration of her life will be held in late September in Concord followed by burial in Bermuda. Gifts in her memory may be made to the Massachusetts Audubon Society, 208 South Great Road, Lincoln, MA 01773.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Saturday about the recall of 19 million pounds of beef produced by the ConAgra Beef Company referred incorrectly to worker representation at the company's slaughterhouse in Greeley, Colo. The employees are indeed organized, by the United Food and Commercial Workers Union.

title: BARKLEY RE-SIGNS FOR TNT SHOW
description: Charles Barkley has re-signed with TNT to continue as a commentator on the network's ''Inside the N.B.A.'' studio program. The deal will be announced today. Barkley's contract could last as long as TNT's new six-year deal with the league. Richard Sandomir

title: Economic Scene; Accounting for bad apples: Investors in the stock market render their verdicts.
description: A STRING of scandals and investigations involving aggressive accounting practices has shaken confidence in corporate America and helped cause the stock market to sink to new lows despite a recovering economy.

title: A Musical Dream Come True; Thou Shalt Learn to Play Without Being Tortured
description: Nobody skips Video Night. Campers sprawl on the floor of the boys' dormitory, counselors and teachers straddle chairs, as their heroes perform on the big-screen television. They applaud and cheer as if Glenn Gould, Jascha Heifetz and Vladimir Horowitz were in the room.

title: LOCKHEED AWARDED CONTRACT FROM SOUTH KOREAN NAVY
description: Lockheed Martin has won a $1 billion contract to build antimissile radar systems for the South Korean Navy. The defense ministry said Lockheed Martin's Aegis system, on the basis of field tests, was viewed as superior to a system offered by Thales of the Netherlands. The Lockheed Martin system, capable of detecting enemy missiles and aircraft and starting a counterattack at the same time, will be deployed on three destroyers that the ministry has ordered for delivery in 6 to 10 years. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Article 2002072592653773730 -- No Title
description: A newly-discovered centipede, which may be the world's smallest, is the first new animal species found in Central Park in more than a century. A newly-discovered centipede, which may be the world's smallest, is the first new animal species found in Central Park in more than a century.

title: NYCA, a New Agency, Opens in California
description: Michael Mark, formerly president and creative director at Matthews/Mark in San Diego, has opened an agency, NYCA in Encinitas, Calif.

title: SMURFIT-STONE TO BUY SOME ASSETS FROM MEADWESTVACO
description: The Smurfit-Stone Container Corporation, the largest packaging company in the nation, agreed to pay $375 million for the MeadWestvaco Corporation's Stevenson, Ala., mill and the seven plants and 82,000 timberland acres that supply it. Smurfit-Stone said it would pay $350 million for the assets and another $25 million within the next year. The Stevenson operations, which make corrugated boxes and containers, employ about 1,200 people, the companies said. MeadWestvaco, which is based in Stamford, Conn., said this week that it was in discussions to sell the mill. Today, the company said it expected to record a loss of about $25 million based on the sale's proceeds and the $400 million book value of the assets being sold.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: SALON MEDIA INTRODUCES WEBLOG SERVICE The Salon Media Group , publisher of the online magazine Salon, has introduced a service that allows users to publish their own Weblogs. Subscribers to the Salon Blogs service will use tools from UserLand Software to build and maintain Weblogs, an increasingly popular form of personal site built around Web links and commentary. Salon said Scott Rosenberg, its managing editor, would use his new Weblog to point readers toward users' pages. The service, which includes putting each user's Weblog up on blogs.salon.com, will cost $39.95 a year after a 30-day free trial. David F. Gallagher (NYT)

title: Will the C.E.O.'s Do the Right Thing?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Milford: Autistic Boy Wanders From Bus
description: A 4-year-old autistic boy was left unattended on a private company's bus on Tuesday and wandered off while the bus drove away without him, the police said yesterday. It was the second time this summer that the company, Winkle Bus Company, was accused of leaving a small child unsupervised. The boy, unhurt, was found peeking into mailboxes, the police said. No charges have been filed against the driver, whose name was not released. The police said the driver was buckling in a camper who uses a wheelchair when the autistic boy unbuckled his seat belt and walked off. The driver went back after realizing the boy was missing. Last month, another Winkle Bus driver was charged with risk of injury to a minor when she left a 3-year-old on a bus. No one responded to a message left at the bus company office yesterday. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLVIN, RICHARD RILEY
description: COLVIN-Richard Riley. 64, of Katonah, NY died on July 21, 2002. Beloved husband of Jane and father of Zachary, brother of William. He was an innovative entrepreneur, inventor, landscape architect and gifted craftsman. He will be fondly remembered for his generous spirit and sensitivity to others. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, July 30, 3pm, First Presbyterian Church, Katonah,NY

title: He's Famous (Briefly), Therefore He Is (Briefly)
description: Don DeLillo, a first-rank novelist, isn't a natural playwright. He has a predilection for brusque, lancing observations delivered like literate jabs, with a strident, declarative torque. But the writing isn't spare. In all his work Mr. DeLillo effuses; the momentum of his sentences carries past the periods and his paragraphs seem to roll downhill, throwing off blunt metaphors like sparks.

title: David Asseo, 88, of Turkey, Europe's Senior Chief Rabbi
description: David Asseo, the chief rabbi of the tiny Jewish community in Turkey, who strove for decades to buttress tolerance among the different religions there, died on July 14 in Istanbul, where he lived. He was 88.

title: Cuomo and McCall Look Ahead, Taking Aim at Pataki
description: Andrew M. Cuomo and H. Carl McCall looked beyond September yesterday, spending the day campaigning against the man that only one of them is likely to face in November, Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: At Airport X-Ray Machines, a Mountain of Forgotten Laptops
description: MACK STRASSER was catching a flight home to Dayton, Ohio, from Washington in March when he was pulled aside at a security checkpoint at Dulles International Airport. Agents waved a magnetic wand over him, asked him to remove his belt and searched his shoes, all while his carry-on luggage sat on the X-ray conveyor belt.

title: Two Top-Seeded Teams Lose In Spingold Knockout Event
description: The Spingold Knockout Team Championship continued here today at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals. Among the 32 survivors are almost all the top seeds, with two notable exceptions. Reese Milner's team, which won the Vanderbilt Knockout in Houston in March, lost in the first round on Monday.

title: Battered for Weeks, Dow Enjoys Its Biggest Daily Gain Since '87
description: Stocks broke their losing streak yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average up 488.95 points, or 6.4 percent, in its biggest one-day rally since the rebound after the 1987 market crash.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 6 Charged In Courthouse Kickbacks
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn unsealed charges yesterday against six men they said had taken part in a bribery and kickback scheme in connection with maintenance and construction projects at the Brooklyn Federal Courthouse and other government buildings. Five of the men were private contractors and one, John DiFrancesco of Staten Island, is an 11-year veteran of the United States General Services Administration. His responsibilities included managing the courthouse in Brooklyn and awarding contracts for work on that building and others. The unsealed documents said that he pleaded guilty in June to receiving bribes of approximately $20,000. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Lead Shrinking In Governor's Race
description: Lt. Gov. Kathleen Kennedy Townsend's lead over Representative Robert L. Ehrlich Jr. has slipped in the race for governor, a new poll shows. The poll, conducted by Potomac Survey Research of Bethesda, found that Mrs. Townsend, a Democrat, led Mr. Ehrlich, a Republican, 47 percent to 44 percent among likely voters, with 10 percent undecided. The telephone poll of 1,200 people had a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points. In January, a Potomac Survey Research poll showed Mrs. Townsend held a fifteen-point lead over Mr. Ehrlich. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Pletcher and Velazquez Escaping Big Shadows
description: This was about more than sending out a filly named Freedom's Daughter today to win the Schuylerville, the first stakes race of the meet at Saratoga Race Course. For the trainer Todd Pletcher and for the jockey John Velazquez, it was about creeping out of the shadows of two Hall of Famers.

description: The stock market took a wild ride in very busy trading today as it struggled to hold on to some of Wednesday's big gains after two weeks of severe losses.

description: A newly found asteroid, large enough to wreak worldwide destruction, will cross Earth's path in 2019, and although the chance of a collision is slim, astronomers cannot yet rule it out.

title: Murmuring, 'Move Over, EBay,' The U.S. Empties Its Closets
description: Are you looking to buy a limousine? A Gucci watch? How about a decommissioned Coast Guard cutter? The federal government wants to use the Internet to unload its vast stores of seized and surplus property. FirstGov, which runs the federal Web portal at www.firstgov.gov, recently created a page where shoppers can link to every auction of vehicles, aircraft and real estate listed by government agencies as well as souvenirs, savings bonds and surplus equipment (www.firstgov.gov/shopping/shopping).

title: Manning and Dungy A Not-So-Odd Couple
description: When Peyton Manning was a teenager, he used to keep files in his drawer on every college football team that was recruiting him. ''From Alabama to X, Y, Z,'' is how his high school coach, Tony Reginelli, described it.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Agere Posts Narrowed Net Loss
description: Agere Systems, the communications chip maker, spun off from Lucent Technologies, said its third-quarter loss had narrowed because of cost reductions. Sales fell 40 percent. Its shares tumbled as much as 16 percent. The net loss narrowed to $332 million, or 20 cents a share, from $1.11 billion, or 68 cents, a year earlier. Sales in the quarter ended June 30 fell to $560 million from $927 million, the company said. Agere, the top supplier of chips, lasers and other components used in communications gear, is shedding businesses, factories and about 8,400 jobs to reduce expenses amid a slump in demand for networking equipment. The company expects fiscal fourth-quarter revenue to decline 5 percent from the third quarter. Shares of Agere fell 10 cents, or 5 percent, to $1.90. The stock had fallen 65 percent this year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about legislative grants to a community group associated with State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. referred imprecisely to the outcome of a criminal case last year against an associate of his. The associate was accused of having illegally diverted a state grant from a theater group to Mr. Espada's organization, Soundview Health Center, but she pleaded guilty only to having filed a false document with the state about where the money went. She did not plead guilty to diversion of the grant.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Europeans To Make Up For U.S. Cut
description: The European Union will cover most of the shortfall in financing for the United Nations Population Fund created by the Bush administration's decision to withhold its $34 million annual payment, the European commissioner for aid, Poul Nielson, said in Brussels. The union will donate an extra 32 million euros, roughly $31.8 million, to fill the void Washington created. ''The decision to cut funding,'' he said, ''may well lead to more unwanted pregnancies, unsafe abortions and increased dangers for mothers and infants.'' The money will be earmarked for programs in 22 developing countries. None will go to China, which forces many women to have abortions after a single child. In withholding its contribution, the United States said the population fund provides aid to Chinese government agencies that force women to have abortions. Steven Erlanger (NYT)

description: I AM a self-taught curtain maker,'' Mary Bright said, standing in black Birkenstocks and braced on a walker. Her firm voice occasionally sprouts tall patches of a Scottish accent. Ms. Bright was born in Edinburgh.

Interment Mt. Olivet Cemetery, Maspeth, NY. Friends may call at the Bailey Funeral Home Inc., 8 Hilltop Road, Mendham NJ, on Friday 2-4, 7-9PM.

title: In Times Square, a Small Place Among the Giants
description: Hotel 41, a new boutique hotel next door to the musical ''Rent,'' has retained only the shell of a 100-year-old building, vacant for 25 years. The 47-room hotel, below right, in the Boutique Hotel Management Group, is an anomaly for the Times Square area, which is dominated by large chains. ''The idea was to make a European-style hotel where, when guests walk in, they will be instantly recognized by the staff,'' said Benjamin Soleimani, an owner, who designed the tiny but luxurious guest rooms, which start at $129.The amenities include down comforters, Belgian sheets, bathrooms clad in subway tile, high-speed Internet access and DVD players. There are two penthouse suites -- one, below left, has a large private deck ideal for parties ($489). The bar is scheduled to open in October. Hotel 41, 206 West 41st Street; (877) 847-4444. PILAR GUZMAN

title: Telecom Crisis? Take 2 Aspirin and No One Will Call You in the Morning
description: Congress and the Bush administration have rushed to get tough on dishonest executives, but policy makers appear to be frozen in place when it comes to stabilizing telecommunications, the industry that has given rise to some of the worst examples of corporate misconduct.

title: Hard Terms in Biting Incident But at Least It's a Dog's Life
description: A Long Island pit bull that made headlines after a man said he bit him to defend his own dog could be spared the canine death penalty under the terms of an agreement being negotiated yesterday. Instead, the pit bull, Dutch, would receive something akin to life without parole.

description: Just over a month ago, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and members of the City Council, all smiles, crowded into the rotunda of City Hall to announce an amicable agreement on a $42.3 billion city budget that avoided layoffs, raised few taxes and restored $175 million in services at the Council's request. Now the city's budget makers are going back to their drawing boards.

He walked over to Coach Jim Fassel, who lifted his own hands to talk about what the quarterback might have done wrong.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Danube Bridge To Be Rebuilt
description: The European Union has signed a $33.8 million agreement to pay for rebuilding the main bridge over the Danube in Novi Sad, Yugoslavia. The six-lane bridge was destroyed in 1999 by NATO bombs during the Kosovo war; two other bridges in Novi Sad were also destroyed. Under the deal between Serbia and the European Agency for Reconstruction, rebuilding will begin in the autumn once debris, which blocked shipping, has been removed from the river. Steven Erlanger (NYT)

title: Taking the Plunge Into the Great Beyond
description: AT 10,000 feet above Sonoma County, the parallel lines of vineyards curving through the wineries below looked like the fingerprint of Northern California. Hills with knuckled bunches of trees sloped down to the blue vein of the Russian River as shafts of sun entered the Cessna's windows. It was a serene view and I felt calm, even as my fingers maniacally rubbed my seat belt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYLER, MARJORIE
description: WYLER-Marjorie. The Jewish Theological Seminary of America mourns the passing of Marjorie Goldwasser Wyler, who served with distinction for more than fifty years. Her intellectual vigor and dedicated work as head of the communications department helped position JTS as a force for Jewish life in the larger community, bringing Judaism to the American public and giving Jews a better appreciation of their own heritage. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire family and pray that her memory be for a blessing. Ismar Schorsch, Chancellor Gershon Kekst, Chairman

title: In Puerto Rico, a Milestone; in New York City, Not Much Celebrating
description: In Puerto Rico's capital, San Juan, thousands gathered yesterday to mark the 50th anniversary of the island's status as a commonwealth of the United States at a three-hour ceremony with speeches, flag-waving and even a visit from the mayor of the other capital of Puerto Rican life -- New York.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: NCR DISCLOSES ACCOUNTING ERRORS Shares of the NCR Corporation fell as much as 14 percent after the company, the largest maker of automated teller machines, reduced third-quarter and 2002 profit forecasts and said a service division in Canada had made accounting errors. The unit failed to record some costs, NCR executives said, and the unidentified person responsible was fired. Costs for correcting the errors pared second-quarter net income by $10 million. Controls have been tightened, said the chief financial officer, Earl Shanks, who called the situation "pretty isolated." Investors and corporations are paying closer attention to accounting issues amid revelations of botched accounting at companies like Enron and WorldCom . "I am extremely disappointed that we did not identify it before this quarter," Mr. Shanks said in a conference call. No similar errors were found in about five similar units after recent checks, he said. (Bloomberg News)

title: Middletown Teachers Edge Closer to Contract
description: Almost eight months after a contentious strike in which 228 teachers were jailed in Middletown, N.J., the Board of Education and its teachers still do not have a new contract, although they inched closer to one on Tuesday night when the board approved a new salary guideline.

title: A Chair Hoist With Mobility
description: Gary Talbot, 46, is fit enough to toss his folded wheelchair handily into the back of any car he happens to be driving, including his favorite Camaro. But in the 22 years since an auto accident left him without the use of his legs, he has watched other people struggle to load and secure motorized wheelchairs and electric scooters -- which can weigh up to 300 pounds -- into specially equipped vehicles, usually vans.

title: Member of Sex Abuse Panel Upsets Some
description: With memories, some from long ago, at the heart of many reports that priests committed sexual abuse, the appointment to a national lay board of a prominent psychiatrist who has crusaded against the validity of repressed memories has upset victims' groups and reignited a fierce debate among psychiatric professionals.

title: Gunman Fatally Shoots Motorist in Harlem
description: A man in a sport utility vehicle was fatally shot early yesterday evening as he drove in Harlem, the police said.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Checks And Balances
description: With the state four weeks into a new fiscal year and without a budget, State Controller Kathleen Connell, left, has given legislators an incentive to act by withholding their paychecks. While Ms. Connell said she would continue to make all payments ''for which there is legal justification,'' she also said she would withhold her own pay and that of legislators, Gov. Gray Davis and other elected and appointed officials. The state faces a $23.6 million budget shortfall and the State Assembly has not reached a compromise to bridge the gap. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Fix Needed For Epidemic Of Violence
description: EARLIER this month Miami Dolphins linebacker Derrick Rodgers was told that his wife was seeing another man. Now, such talk might merit a conversation or two with a spouse, but Rodgers evidently decided to do more than have a little chat. According to the police, he stormed into a restaurant in Miami Beach last week, picked up a metal chair and slammed it into the head of the man he believed was having an affair with his wife. He followed that W.W.F. move by punching and kicking her in the midsection, witnesses told the police.

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: CHALLENGE FOR MANATEE ZONES The Bush administration wants a federal judge to scuttle a settlement with environmentalists for protecting manatees from Florida boaters. Government court papers filed Tuesday said the Fish and Wildlife Service cannot require 16 manatee sanctuaries and reduced speed zones specified in the settlement without a formal regulatory process. The judge, Emmet Sullivan of Federal District Court in Miami, had ruled that delays in establishing 14 of the sanctuaries violated the settlement and directed the agency to set a new timetable.

title: Baseball Sees Progress in Talks, but the Union Isn't So Sure
description: When talk of a baseball strike date first surfaced about two months ago, owners reacted angrily, suggesting such talk was detrimental to the likelihood of working out a new labor agreement. But as the setting of a date looms, a greater sense of urgency seems to have worked its way into the talks.

title: Mob on His Back, Movies on His Brain
description: ''Have you ever been to a movie?'' Tim Allen asks Christian Slater in the vaporous crime comedy ''Who is Cletis Tout?,'' a picture that makes you wonder if the writer and director Chris Ver Wiel has done anything but go to the movies. This mistaken-identity picture is so film-culture referential that the final product is a ghost.

title: North Korea Regrets Naval Clash With Seoul and Seeks Talks
description: North Korea issued a surprising expression of regret today over a naval skirmish in the Yellow Sea last month in which five South Koreans were killed, and called for cabinet-level talks with South Korea along with steps to revive measures to reconcile the two countries.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: YUGOSLAVIA: DANUBE BRIDGE TO BE REBUILT The European Union has signed a $33.8 million agreement to pay for rebuilding the main bridge over the Danube in Novi Sad, Yugoslavia. The six-lane bridge was destroyed in 1999 by NATO bombs during the Kosovo war; two other bridges in Novi Sad were also destroyed. Under the deal between Serbia and the European Agency for Reconstruction, rebuilding will begin in the autumn once debris, which blocked shipping, has been removed from the river. Steven Erlanger (NYT)

title: Sony Reports A Profit But Is Hurt By Yen's Rise
description: Buoyed by game sales and hit movies, the Sony Corporation returned to profitability in the first fiscal quarter, but the rising value of the yen put a dent in the company's forecast for the rest of the year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about accusations of forgeries in the petition drive for the re-election of Anthony A. Williams as mayor of Washington misspelled the name of the television show that stars Kelsey Grammer, whose name was among those that drew scrutiny to the signatures. It is ''Frasier,'' not ''Frazier.''

title: Protecting Capitalism From Itself
description: Back when financial markets were soaring, analysts marveled at the phenomenon of ''panic buying'' on Wall Street -- the desperate snatching up of any stocks within reach by investors who felt they could not afford to stay on the sidelines. Yesterday's nearly unanimous passage by both houses of Congress of sweeping corporate governance reform legislation was the political equivalent of panic buying. We are in a bull market for reform, and even the most adamant foes of regulation realized they could not afford to stay on the sidelines.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Toothy Smiles, Dental Character

title: Insurer's Chief Sees No Relief On Premiums For Businesses
description: Prices for business insurance are continuing to soar in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks and Maurice R. Greenberg, the chief executive of the American International Group, said yesterday that he expected no letup at least through next year.

title: McCall Faults Nursing Home Investigations
description: Thousands of complaints about poor care at nursing homes in New York were ignored or not properly investigated by the State Health Department last year, according to an audit released yesterday by State Comptroller H. Carl McCall.

title: French Skating Judge Decides to Drop Her Appeal of 3-Year Suspension
description: Faced with an organization unlikely to embarrass itself with a reversal, and with the potential for financial hardship looming, the French skating judge Marie Reine Le Gougne has decided to drop an appeal of her three-year suspension resulting from the pairs controversy at the Salt Lake Winter Games.

title: Health Care, in the Right Doses
description: To the Editor:

title: Car 54, Prepare To Make A 180
description: IMAGINE a pelting downpour. You're driving at high speed, threading through congested intersections to avoid skids, other vehicles and pedestrians dashing through the puddles. Your radio and in-car computer are screaming for attention, and you're on edge about what you'll be up against when you get where you're going. You've been in this car for seven hours, and what you'd really like to see is a rest stop.

title: China Bank Shares Fall in Initial Offering
description: In one of the biggest stock market debuts anywhere in the world this year, shares of the Hong Kong unit of the Bank of China began trading publicly today. They promptly fell 4.7 percent on heavy selling by Hong Kong residents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANN, NANCY N.
description: DANN-Nancy N. Of Sag Harbor, NY, formerly of New York City, on July 21, 2002. Wife of the late Robert Roy Dann. Survived by her sister, N. Cyril Herzfeld and her nieces, Elizabeth L. Herzfeld and Suzanne Ferguson. Interment private.

title: Health Care, in the Right Doses
description: To the Editor:

title: Palestinian Gunmen Kill Four Israelis in West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, July 26  Palestinian gunmen ambushed two Israeli cars today on a highway south of the West Bank city of Hebron, killing four Jewish settlers and wounding two others. A couple and their son were among the dead.

title: Close Semifinal in Bridge Tournament
description: Favorites prevailed in play here on Wednesday at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer National Championships.

title: ABC and ESPN Name N.B.A. Lineup
description: Brad Nessler and Bill Walton were named the lead National Basketball Association announcers for ABC Sports and ESPN yesterday, and will call ABC's Sunday afternoon and ESPN's Wednesday night games.

title: Race Within a Race For the Top Rookie
description: Ryan Newman has a bachelor's degree in vehicle structural engineering from Purdue University, but that did not help him much when he tried to poke around the cluttered infields at Nascar Winston Cup racetracks early this year.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Election Upheld
description: The Law Lords of the House of Lords, England's highest court, ruled against an action brought by hard-line Ulster Protestants seeking to invalidate last year's election of David Trimble, the province's senior Protestant politician, as first minister of the Northern Ireland Assembly and Mark Durkan, a Roman Catholic leader, as his deputy. The appeal was lodged by the Democratic Unionist Party of the Rev. Ian Paisley, which opposes the arrangements under which Catholics and Protestants share power. The party argued that the voting was held after a six-week time limit had expired, but the Lords, by a 3-to-2 margin, ruled the technicality of election law was outweighed by a vote aimed at forging ''reconciliation, tolerance and mutual trust.'' Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: The two faces of athlete's foot cream: one product marketed separately to men and women.
description: SOME well-known consumer products are successful today because their makers took a chance and tweaked the brand's marketing strategy to sell the item to the opposite gender.

title: Yeo Takes Advantage of Her Opportunity
description: Minny Yeo of South Korea is an alternate on the L.P.G.A. Tour, which means that she can play when someone withdraws. When Se Ri Pak withdrew from this week's Sybase Big Apple Classic, Yeo took her place. Yeo made the most of the opportunity today, shooting a three-under-par 68 for a share of the opening-round lead with Kathryn Marshall of Scotland.

title: Hedging Learned at the Family Farm
description: John Henry is a complicated man.

title: Fly-In Food: Movable Feasts
description: ALMOST as good as having Jeeves waiting for you at your summer lodgings is having a box of fly-in food waiting. What a gorgeous welcome: a big box of delectables to devour without having to run around assembling it yourself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DU BAIN, MYRON
description: Du BAIN-Myron. Former Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of Fireman's Fund Corporation, and a Director of American Express Corporation, passed away on July 18, 2002 at California Pacific Medical Center in San Francisco, at the age of 79 years; survivors include his wife, Alice; daughter, Cynthia and son, Donald. Memorial services will be held Monday, July 29th, 2002, 4PM at Grace Cathedral, 1100 California St, San Francisco. The family suggests that any donations be made to the San Francisco Opera Association, 301 Van Ness Ave, San Francisco, CA 94102-4509. Halsted N. Gray-Carew & English, San Francisco, CA.

title: Campbell-Ewald Wins Postal Service Account
description: The United States Postal Service in Washington said yesterday that it had selected Campbell-Ewald in Warren, Mich., as the lead creative agency on its account, with annual billings estimated at $100 million.

title: Stocks Struggle at End of a Wild Week on Wall St.
description: Stocks rallied in the last hour and a half yesterday and the push was enough to assure that both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose for the day and finished higher for the week.

title: TWEETER HOME ENTERTAINMENT SAYS IT CUT 240 JOBS
description: Tweeter Home Entertainment, an electronic retailer, said yesterday that it cut about 240 jobs, or 6 percent of its work force, as its third-quarter profit fell 96 percent because of higher costs. The positions were eliminated through attrition and layoffs that took place last week, the company said. Net income for the quarter, which ended June 30, fell to $103,000, or break-even on a per-share basis, from $2.47 million, or 13 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 59 percent, to $175.3 million from $110 million. Selling expenses climbed to 28.8 percent of sales from 26.2 percent because of increases in compensation and insurance costs, Tweeter said.

title: A Fallen Movie Maestro, Still Addicted to Himself
description: ''I think that from the very start my literary ambitions were mixed up with the feeling of being isolated and undervalued,'' George Orwell theorized in his essay ''Why I Write.'' Robert Evans -- a failed actor and fashion executive who went on to run Paramount Pictures when the studio released a storied cluster of hits like ''Rosemary's Baby'' and ''The Godfather'' -- does not specifically iterate Orwell's sentiment in his ribald trench of an autobiography, ''The Kid Stays in the Picture.'' But both the book and the film version of ''Kid,'' from the directors Brett Morgen and Nanette Burstein, flow from similar motivations.

title: Richard Liddicoat, 84, Creator Of Diamond Rating Technique
description: Richard T. Liddicoat, an executive of the Gemological Institute of America who was behind the four C's method of grading diamonds now familiar to couples around the world, died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 84.

title: Lions and Obies Honor Ad Work
description: Two organizations have presented advertising awards.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Tougher Sentence For Pedophilia
description: An Italian man was sentenced to 10 years in prison for having sex with boys age 14 and under. It was by far the harshest sentence handed down by a Cambodian court for pedophilia, a growing problem among foreign visitors. Two other Westerners, both British, have been convicted for pedophilia; one served less than a year in prison and the other is in the middle of a three-year sentence. Many cases have been publicized but there has been little legal action. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Survey on Youths And Ads for Alcohol
description: Teenagers remember commercials for the growing number of alcoholic beverages that are brewed and sold like beer, according to a survey by an advocacy group seeking to curb marketing of the products, known as malternatives or alcopops.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The Advertising Council, New York, promoted three employees. Elizabeth Kilcline, administrative assistant for corporate development, was named associate manager. Abha Palmer, media analyst for the media measurement department, was named manager. And Chris Villarreal, assistant campaign manager, was promoted to campaign manager.

title: Hungary's Buried Past
description: To the Editor:

title: McGraw-Hill Reports Profit Rise of 14%
description: The McGraw-Hill Companies, owner of Business Week magazine and the Standard & Poor's financial-rating service, said yesterday that second-quarter profit had increased 14 percent as sales rose in its financial and education units and interest costs fell.

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: IRAN: TV DISPLAYS A DISSIDENT'S CONFESSION State television broadcast what it called confessions of espionage by a liberal dissident jailed serving an 11-year jail sentence for trying to undermine the Islamic Republic. The dissident, Siamak Pourzand, was arrested last year and convicted of having ties to opposition groups in the United States, trying to spread corruption and poisoning the minds of young people. Mr. Pourzand, 73, appeared frail but animated during an interview with journalists from state media. Human Rights Watch has called Mr. Pourzand's trial "a continuation of a pattern of repression against reformist and independent figures."

title: Weighing the Costs Of Invading Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawmakers Turn to Other Efforts to Deal With Scandals
description: With the passage today of broad new laws to make auditors and executives more accountable, House and Senate lawmakers are turning their attention to other measures to address the spate of corporate scandals.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cisco To Buy Rest Of Stake In Ayr
description: Cisco Systems, the No. 1 maker of equipment that directs Internet traffic, announced a definitive agreement yesterday to buy the rest of Ayr Networks it does not own for Cisco common stock worth up to $113 million. It is the third small company this year that Cisco has said it would buy. The chief executive, John Chambers, has said that this year, the company plans to buy 8 to 12 small to medium-size companies, mostly private concerns in emerging technology areas. Ayr Networks, a privately held company based in Palo Alto, Calif., develops networking services and routing software, said Cisco, which currently holds a 16.6 percent stake in Ayr Networks. Cisco's shares closed down $1.48, to $11.61 in trading on Nasdaq.

title: U.S. Investors Agree to Buy Burger King From Diageo for $2.26 Billion
description: Diageo P.L.C., the British liquor giant with brands including Johnnie Walker, Guinness, Smirnoff and Captain Morgan, said yesterday that it would sell the Burger King fast-food chain to a group of American investors led by the Texas Pacific Group for $2.26 billion.

title: House Votes for Independent Inquiry on Intelligence Agencies' Actions on Sept. 11
description: The House voted early today, over the opposition of the White House, to create an independent commission to investigate the performance of the nation's intelligence agencies surrounding the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATSKY, DR. HOWARD F. ''POPPY''
description: WATSKY-Dr. Howard F. ''Poppy'' of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Lawrence, LI on July 24, 2002; Beloved husband of Rhoda and now joins the late Francine to whom he was married 50 years; Loving father of Dr. Steven (Sharon) and Claude Watsky; Cherished grandfather of six and great-grandfather of one; Dear brother-in-law of Muriel and Max Switkes. Services private. Information ''Gutterman's'' 800-992-9262.

title: Russian Oil Producer Is Haunted by Its Past
description: A public relations maneuver by a Russian oil company went awry last week when a lawsuit over a seven-year-old debt surfaced in a Texas court.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: New York's Cutest Chefs

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: House and Senate Reach Initial Deal on Trade Powers for Bush
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed late tonight on the details of legislation that would give President Bush authority to make international trade deals that could be approved or rejected -- but not amended -- by Congress.

title: An Olympics Ever So Human
description: When Kon Ichikawa was asked to make a documentary of the 1964 Olympic Games in Tokyo, the Japanese authorities from the emperor on down expected his cameras to stick to business on the track or in the pool and not go wandering off at every little distraction. Yet no sooner does Billy Mills of the United States win the 10,000-meter run than Mr. Ichikawa moves off into the crowd for a close look at the wattles of 60-something men.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the effects of Martha Stewart's legal problems on the business that bears her name, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, misstated the plans for the magazine Martha Stewart Living. It is being redesigned in October, not restarted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUGER, MARTIN
description: ZUGER - Martin. Beloved husband of Rosalind (Roz), brother of Joel, devoted nephew of Miriam Zuger. Will be sorely missed by relatives and friends. Funeral Friday, July 26, 10 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: CHECKS AND BALANCES

title: In New Jersey, Art From Asia On a Comfortably Human Scale
description: Count on New Jersey museums for stimulating, offbeat summertime fare. This year the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers University in New Brunswick makes a substantial contribution to our knowledge of contemporary Asian culture with an important survey of post-independence Indian painting. The Jersey City Museum is showing off its suave new digs with three photography exhibitions that would do any institution proud.

title: Wall Bursts and Water Pours In, Trapping 9 Miners 240 Feet Down
description: Nine miners were trapped 240 feet down in the earth today after a wall burst and they were inundated with tons of water from an abandoned mine, sending them to crouch desperately through the night Wednesday in an air pocket in a four-foot-high coal seam.

title: How a Band Turned a Crisis Into a Triumph
description: A music documentary with an unusually strong narrative drive, Sam Jones's ''I Am Trying to Break Your Heart'' follows the Chicago-based rock band Wilco through the recording of its critically acclaimed fourth album, ''Yankee Hotel Foxtrot.'' The group's style, at once infectious and alienating, is an imaginative blend of country music twanginess and aggressive industrial noise.

title: Blessed With Corn
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, SYLVIA
description: KAPLAN-Sylvia. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member and extends sincere sympathy to her family and friends. David S. Mack, President Michael Stein, Secretary

title: Terror Suspect Changes Mind On Guilty Plea
description: After trying to plead guilty to charges that he conspired in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, Zacarias Moussaoui withdrew the guilty plea today and insisted again that he was not involved in the hijackings.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Congress Reaches a Deal To Rewrite Bankruptcy Law

title: Reuniting An Ensemble Of Bears. Yes, Bears.
description: This summer has yielded a bumper crop of children's movies, based on classic works of children's literature, popular television shows, previous movies and even, occasionally, an original idea. ''The Country Bears,'' which opens today nationwide, has the distinction of being the only current movie (and, so far as I can recall, the only one ever) to be based on a theme-park attraction. Since 1971, the Country Bears Jamboree has been a fixture of Disney World in Orlando, Fla., and clearly its down-home brand of ursine animatronic entertainment was crying out for adaptation into a big-screen feature.

title: Argentine to Head Group Seeking to Ban Chemical Weapons
description: The international organization charged with ridding the world of chemical weapons appointed a senior Argentine diplomat today as its new chief, and he immediately pledged to be responsive to the concerns of the agency's members, including the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CASTELLANO, ANNA
description: CASTELLANO-Anna. Dear mother, we sadly rememember the third anniversary of your death. Love always, Barbara and Robert

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Big Drop In Confidence
description: Confidence in Germany's economy eroded sharply this month, raising the possibility that Germany could slip back into recession, according to an influential research firm, the Ifo Institute. In its monthly survey of 7,000 western German companies, Ifo reported a decline in its index to 89.9, from 91.3. That is the largest monthly drop since September. Shares in Frankfurt ignored a rally by other European markets today, as investors reacted to that report, as well as weak earnings from the HVB Group, Germany's second-largest bank. HVB said it had a loss in the second quarter and would miss its profit goal for 2002. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: IRAN: TV DISPLAYS A DISSIDENT'S CONFESSION State television broadcast what it called confessions of espionage by a liberal dissident jailed serving an 11-year jail sentence for trying to undermine the Islamic Republic. The dissident, Siamak Pourzand, was arrested last year and convicted of having ties to opposition groups in the United States, trying to spread corruption and poisoning the minds of young people.
