Mr. Pourzand, 73, appeared frail but animated during an interview with journalists from state media. Human Rights Watch has called Mr. Pourzand's trial "a continuation of a pattern of repression against reformist and independent figures."

title: BILL ON SECURITY BACKED IN SENATE; VETO THREATENED
description: The White House today threatened for the first time to veto a version of the bill creating a Homeland Security Department that was once embraced by both parties.

title: Pennzoil Swings to Profit
description: Pennzoil-Quaker State said today that it swung to a profit for its second quarter. The company earned $28.7 million, or 34 cents a diluted share, on revenue of $590 million. This was in contrast to a loss of $5.3 million, or 7 cents a share, on revenue of $601 million in the quarter a year ago. In March, Pennzoil-Quaker State agreed to be bought by Shell Oil, the United States affiliate of Royal Dutch/Shell, for $1.8 billion. A shareholder vote is set for Aug. 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASSLER, JEANNE, M.D.
description: KASSLER-Jeanne, M.D. On July 23, 2002. Beloved wife of Robert Meyers, M.D. Loving mother of Charlie and Jeremy. Dear daughter of Regina Golieb. Service Friday, 11AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Manchester: Charges In Failed Abductions
description: A man has been charged with attempting to abduct a 12-year-old girl twice. The man, Gregory Winot, 35, was charged Tuesday with kidnapping, attempted kidnapping, stalking and two counts of risk of injury to a minor. Mr. Winot is being held on a $1 million bond. The 12-year-old girl identified Mr. Winot to police as the man who approached her last Friday and again on Tuesday. In the first incident, Mr. Winot tried pulling the girl into his car, but she escaped after threatening to bite him, the police said. Four days later, Mr. Winot approached her again, and again she eluded him, but this time she wrote down his license plate number, the police said. A man who answered the phone at Mr. Winot's residence declined to comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Students Find New Cause: The Right to Grab a Snack Nearby
description: Avrum Gillespie, student, bought himself a snack yesterday from Mohammed Hannan's food truck on New York Avenue in East Flatbush, a block away from his school. It was an act of radical political solidarity.

title: Talks Fail in Claims of Abuse by Priests
description: More than a month after settlement talks began between the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston and lawyers representing 240 people who claim they were sexually abused by priests, the plaintiffs' lawyers said today that negotiations had broken down and no settlement could be reached.

title: Drug Dogs Sniff Even 6-Year-Olds; Parents Sue
description: The parents of 17 students, some as young as 6, filed a lawsuit yesterday against a South Dakota school board and police department for taking a drug-sniffing dog into a school to check children in every classroom, from kindergarten through high school.

title: Princeton Pries Into Web Site for Yale Applicants
description: At the height of the college admissions season in early April, the director of admission at Princeton and possibly others in his office improperly and repeatedly entered a Web site set up to let Yale applicants know if they had been accepted as students, officials at both Ivy League universities confirmed yesterday.

title: Quick Escapes
description: Rockland, Me.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Air China To Fly To Kennedy Airport
description: Air China, China's national airline, will begin direct flights between Beijing and Kennedy International Airport on Sept. 27, said a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which oversees the metropolitan region's airports. The airline's Boeing 747's will leave Beijing three times a week, Monday, Wednesday and Friday, at 2 p.m., and arrive in New York at 3:30 p.m the same day. Return flights will leave Kennedy Airport at 5:30 p.m. and arrive in Beijing at 7 p.m. the next day. United Airlines is currently the only airline flying between New York and Beijing. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENHAGEN, MARGARET MCCANN ''MARGO''
description: FENHAGEN-Margaret McCann ''Margo''. Age 63, of Pound Ridge, N.Y., died July 24, 2002. Wife of William E. Fenhagen. She is also survived by her children Carolin I. Raleigh, Laura I. Imrie and Douglas P. Irwin. Sister of Franklin W. McCann and Jonathan W. McCann. Memorial service to be held at the Fenhagen home, Pound Ridge, N.Y. Saturday, July 27th, 4PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Bendheim Cancer Center, Greenwich Hospital, 5 Perry Ridge Rd, Greenwich, CT 06830 and the Breast Cancer Alliance, Inc., 1 Hillside Dr., Greenwich, CT 06830.

title: Panel Has Evidence of 2 Gifts To Torricelli, an Official Says
description: As the Senate Ethics Committee weighs charges that Senator Robert G. Torricelli improperly accepted gifts and cash from a political contributor, a government official involved in the inquiry said the panel had received sales receipts, witness testimony and other corroboration of at least two such gifts.

title: Opera to Dance: Events at Lincoln Center Festival 2002
description: Lincoln Center Festival 2002 continues through Thursday. Sites include the Walter Reade Theater, the New York State Theater and the Rose Building, all at Lincoln Center; and La Guardia Drama Theater, 65th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Tickets: $25 to $70. ''The Return of the American Film Theater,'' part of the Lincoln Center Festival, features screenings through Thursday at the Walter Reade Theater; tickets, $9.50, $5 for Film Society of Lincoln Center members; $4.50 for 65+ at weekday matinees; screening information, (212) 496-3809 or (212) 875-5600. Festival Information: (212) 875-5928 or www.lincolncenter.org. Tickets: (212) 721-6500. The schedule of the main events this weekend:

title: Wall Street In Suburbia? A Bad Idea, Mayor Says
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that talk of moving some of the New York Stock Exchange's operations from Wall Street to Westchester made little business sense and would play into the hands of the terrorists who attacked Lower Manhattan.

title: Miles Roll On, But Seor Kitsch Is Steadfast
description: ''LIKE my daughter says, 'Just shoot me now,' '' says Angela Marena, 50, trying to stretch her legs in the parking lot of South of the Border, the sprawling roadside stop off Interstate 95, just south of the North Carolina-South Carolina border.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINKOFF, MARVIN, M.D.
description: SINKOFF-Marvin, M.D. The Mount Sinai Medical Center expresses profound sorrow at the loss of our esteemed colleague and longtime friend. Our deepest condolences are extended to his entire family. Paul E. Klotman, M.D. Chairman, Dept. of Medicine

title: Fight Erupts Over Visits With Umpires
description: The dispute between the baseball commissioner's office and the umpires' union flared on yet another front yesterday.

title: The World, for Less
description: Holland America has reduced fares on its full 108-day round-the-world cruise on the 1,380-passenger Amsterdam in 2003, as well as on two segments. Fares for the full 38-port voyage start at $27,771 a person, based on double occupancy of an outside cabin, a discount of $7,720. The cruise starts in Fort Lauderdale on Jan. 4 and ends in Los Angeles April 22, and the rate for the full trip includes first-class air fare to and from home and shipping of 100 pounds of luggage. Half segments start at $12,306 a person, double (23 percent off). Information: (877) 724-5425 or www.hollandamerica.com .

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Executive Perks
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Happiness Comes in Small Dollops
description: Zhao (Zhao Benshan), a retired factory worker, has decided, late in life, to put an end to his bachelorhood. Although he has lined up a prospective bride -- a roly-poly divorce (Dong Lihua) who lives with her teenage son and stepdaughter -- the 50,000 yuan a suitable wedding would cost is beyond his means. Through a series of fibs and omissions, Zhao has led his fiance to believe that he is a man of substance, and his simultaneous efforts to sustain this imposture and to raise money set ''Happy Times,'' a wise, gentle and sad new comedy by Zhang Yimou, in motion.

title: From a Broken Laser Pointer to an Online Auction Giant
description: THE PERFECT STORE

title: Rise in Mining Deaths Prompts Political Sparring
description: The accident that has trapped nine miners in Western Pennsylvania comes after coal mining deaths across the nation have climbed for three years in a row.

title: Paul Revere, 85, Celebrator Of His Ancestor's Famous Ride
description: Paul Revere, to whom Boston turned repeatedly whenever it wanted to celebrate a direct link to his Colonial ancestor's midnight ride, died on Wednesday at his home in Braintree, Mass. He was 85.

title: Bloomberg's Trip to Caribbean Points to Rising Stature of Latinos
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg flew a delegation of Puerto Rican politicians, mostly City Council members, here on his private jet today for a sweltering celebration of the island's commonwealth status. On Friday he joins a group of Dominican officials in Santiago, Dominican Republic, and after a day of events will escort them back to New York, again on his private jet and at his own expense.

title: AOL Falls 15% as Analysts Express Concern Over Ads
description: Shares of AOL Time Warner fell 15 percent yesterday, to $9.64, as a gloomy outlook for online advertising sales and concerns about accounting prompted half a dozen Wall Street brokerage firms to downgrade its stock.

title: Former Officer Faces Fourth Trial in Torture of Louima
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn said today that they planned to retry Charles Schwarz, the former police officer charged with taking part in the torture of Abner Louima, and a judge scheduled what would be Mr. Schwarz's fourth trial for September.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Profit For Conglomerate
description: The Keppel Corporation, the marine conglomerate controlled by the government of Singapore, said net profit in the first half of this year rose 73 percent to 182.4 million Singapore dollars ($104.64 million) as higher oil prices fueled strong demand from such industry players as Halliburton for its floating rigs and other off-shore production equipment. The sale last year of the company's bank pushed revenue down 21 percent. But profit was helped by contributions from Keppel's oil refining subsidiary, Singapore Petroleum, and its telecommunications unit, Keppel Telecommunications and Transportation. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Scientists Worry Journals May Aid Terrorists
description: The leader of a national scientific organization has sought the advice of the National Academy of Sciences on whether scientific journals should withhold information that may aid bioterrorists or countries contemplating biological warfare.

title: Note Dated 2000 Says Williams Wanted His Remains Frozen
description: A note with the signatures of Ted Williams and two of his children dated November 2000, declaring their desire to be cryonically preserved upon their deaths, was filed with a Florida court yesterday in the battle over Williams's body.

title: Yankees to Give Rivera More Rest
description: Yankees closer Mariano Rivera will rest for a few days after receiving a cortisone injection in his right shoulder yesterday in Tampa, Fla. The Yankees are taking their time in deciding whether Rivera will need to go on the disabled list.

title: Editors' Note; On Stage and Off
description: The On Stage and Off column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Farms For Sale, For Citizens Only
description: President Vladimir V. Putin signed legislation intended to create a legal system for buying and selling Russia's farmlands for the first time since the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917. The legislation, part of Mr. Putin's efforts to revive Russia's agricultural economy, passed the lower house of Parliament last month despite opposition from the Communist and Agrarian parties. In a compromise to win passage, Mr. Putin's government agreed to provisions that prohibit foreigners from buying land, allowing them only to lease it, and that give local authorities considerable power to regulate sales. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Nasdaq to Toughen Company Standards
description: In a bid to restore investors' confidence, the Nasdaq Stock Market announced new rules yesterday to increase the independence of corporate boards and root out conflicts of interest.

title: SHARES OF LEAPFROG RISE 20% AFTER INITIAL OFFERING
description: Shares of LeapFrog Enterprises rose more than 20 percent yesterday after the company, a maker of educational toys, raised $117 million in an initial public offering. LeapFrog rose to $15.85 from its offering price of $13 a share. The company sold nine million shares in its offering. The shares sold represent a 21 percent economic stake in the company, but they carry a voting stake of about 3 percent. Knowledge Universe, controlled by Lawrence J. Ellison, the chief executive of Oracle, with Michael R. Milken, the former junk bond financier, and his brother, Lowell J. Milken, has about 78.4 percent of the vote through its ownership of Class B shares, which carry 10 votes each.

title: Medicare Drugs for Those in Need Sway Democrats in Senate
description: Many Senate Democrats are rallying around a bipartisan proposal to provide Medicare coverage of prescriptions just for people with low incomes or high costs, an idea they rejected as inadequate 10 days ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, SADIE
description: EISENBERG-Sadie. 99, of Miami Beach, formerly of Astoria, NY, July 20, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Julius. Sadie is survived by daughters, Renee Chess and Margy Bielowsky; five grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Services will be held Sunday, July 28, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY, at 11 AM.

title: Pension Funds In New Jersey Face Shortfall
description: Just as New Jersey has patched up its worst fiscal mess ever, the state is staring at another: next year an enormous payment for its shrinking pension funds will come due.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Putin Cautions Russians on Intolerance
description: President Vladimir V. Putin strongly denounced racial and religious prejudice today during a meeting in the Kremlin with a 28-year-old woman who was seriously wounded when she tore down an anti-Semitic sign booby-trapped with a bomb in May.

title: New Chief Named to Lead The Royal Shakespeare
description: The troubled Royal Shakespeare Company announced today that it had appointed Michael Boyd, an associate director of the company, to be its next artistic director. Mr. Boyd, 47, is to take over in March, replacing Adrian Noble.

title: 6 New Starters Give Jets A New Look on Defense
description: Jets General Manager Terry Bradway is an avid baseball fan, so he can appreciate the comparison between the off-season spending spree the Jets embarked on to rebuild their defense and the one undertaken by another local team.

title: How I Got That Story
description: It was the driver's bright idea. Maybe, he suggested, we should talk to the police about our plans.

title: New Video Releases
description: John Q

title: Re: Hello Muddah (You've Got Mail)
description: THIS summer, my son David, 9, went off to camp for the first time, armed with a special correspondence ''minidesk'' that my friend Susan (the expert on all child-related gear) insisted I buy for him. For $24.99, I got a purple plastic box with a clipboard and calculator on the cover and little storage bins inside.

title: Build Plants, Top Energy Regulator Urges
description: New York's top energy regulator called yesterday for the construction of new power plants and greater participation in conservation programs, saying that the near-record electrical use earlier this month illustrates the need for action.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on July 18 about a federally supported school in Queens for artisan bread baking referred incorrectly to its uniqueness. It is New York City's first such baking school, not the city's first baking training program. Other cooking schools have long had baking training programs.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Renault's Profit Rises
description: Renault, the European carmaker, said first-half profit rose 54 percent, helped by higher car sales and its share of earnings from its alliance partner, Nissan Motor. Net income excluding one-time items was 548 million euros ($545.4 million), or 2.17 euros a share, from 355 million euros, or 1.47 euros a share, a year earlier. Nissan contributed profit of 314 million euros, compared with 273 million euros a year earlier.

title: Citigroup's Chief Defends Enron Work To Employees
description: Sanford I. Weill, the chairman and chief executive of Citigroup, told employees yesterday that he regretted the pain they felt over criticism of the bank's involvement with Enron and WorldCom, the largest bankruptcies in American history.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Ask Help In Finding Suspect
description: The police yesterday asked for the public's help in finding a man who they said killed a 16-year-old Brooklyn youth on July 10 in Brownsville. The man, Bethel Jones, 23, left, was apparently aiming for another man with whom he had argued several hours earlier, the police said. Lt. Joseph Ferrara, who oversees the 73rd Precinct detective squad, said Mr. Jones fired several shots from a .380-caliber pistol, one of which struck the teenager, Tequan Rivers, in the back of the head as he sat in a car. The police asked that anyone with information about the killing or the whereabouts of Mr. Jones, who has a lengthy arrest record, call the Crimestoppers at a toll-free number, 1-800-577-TIPS (1-800-577-8477), or the 73rd Precinct detective squad at (718) 495-5429. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Behind a Research Center, a Geek With Great Cars
description: AT the technology-obsessed State University of New York here, the big man on campus this season does not play football. To be blunt, at 5-foot-7 -- on his tiptoes or in his dreams -- he's nowhere near big enough, and at age 46, this grizzled physics professor is past prime time for rough-housing on athletic fields. Instead, he plays around with atoms, invents chip technology, and was point man in the project that is to bring a $400 million computer chip research center, and potentially thousands of new jobs, to Albany later this year.

title: Pope Urges Young People To Worship, and Resist Sin
description: Pope John Paul II urged hundreds of thousands of young Roman Catholics at the church's World Youth Day here to shun materialism, resist sin and embrace Christianity, his steady words giving way at the end to a spontaneous utterance that did not make immediate sense.

title: Accounts
description: * The Snapple Beverage Group, White Plains, part of Cadbury Schweppes, expanded its relationship with Decker, Glastonbury, Conn., by naming the agency to handle its Orangina orange soda account, with billings estimated at less than $3 million. Decker, which also handles advertising for Snapple's Stewart's line of soft drinks, is the first agency for Orangina since Cadbury Schweppes acquired Orangina from Pernod Ricard last year.

title: No Shortage of Speed for the Mets
description: The Mets have not yet seen the bevy of stolen bases and speed-manufactured runs from the top of the lineup that they envisioned when they acquired Roger Cedeo and Roberto Alomar. They have, however, seen it lower in the organization.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Chip Maker's Profit Rises
description: A leading chip maker, the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, had lower-than-expected second-quarter profit and said a recovery in demand was flagging. Net income surged to $279 million from $9.3 million a year earlier but fell short of the $332 million expected by analysts. Sales rose two-thirds, to $1.3 billion. The chairman, Morris Chang, said a recovery in demand from the industry's worst year on record was stalling, with sales set to fall this month from a year earlier.

title: Cuomo Submits Signatures To Qualify for Primary Ballot
description: Today, it became official almost -- that there will be a Democratic primary for governor, as Andrew M. Cuomo produced a six-foot-high stack of petitions to get his name on the primary ballot.

title: Judgment Against Aon Is Upheld
description: The Aon Corporation must pay $6.1 million to a former New York Giants football player, Phil McConkey, who lost a job he took at another insurer after his prospective boss lied about whether the company was a takeover target, an appeals court ruled.

title: On a Harbor Cruise, Under a Rainbow
description: The John J. Harvey, a 130-foot fireboat sold by New York City at auction in 1999 and now on the National Register of Historic Places, is moving slowly up the Hudson River. An announcement booms over the public address system: ''Alice, you have 30 seconds to move anything you don't want to get wet.''

title: Health Care, in the Right Doses
description: To the Editor:

title: Intelligence Review Approved
description: The House voted to create an independent commission to investigate the performance of the nation's intelligence agencies before and after the Sept. 11 attacks. Page A18.

title: Health Care, in the Right Doses
description: To the Editor:

title: Kodak's Profit Increases, but Sales Fall Again
description: The Eastman Kodak Company reported today that its second-quarter profit increased sharply because of a tax benefit and cost reductions. Sales, however, fell for a seventh consecutive quarter.

title: Hershey Is Put on the Auction Block
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation said yesterday that it would put itself up for sale, stunning the quiet, insular town it almost single-handedly created and startling a financial community anticipating that this American icon could end up in European hands.

title: Residential Real Estate; Luxury Rentals Set Near Park Slope
description: A development group with long experience renovating apartments in Brooklyn has built its first residential project, a six-story building on the outskirts of Park Slope that is one of the few new luxury rentals in this neighborhood of condominiums and brownstones.

title: Teenager in Fatal Suffolk Crash Faces Charge of Reckless Driving
description: A Suffolk County teenager who was at the wheel early Tuesday in an automobile accident that killed his two teenage passengers was arraigned yesterday on a charge of reckless driving, a day after the police withdrew their charge of driving while intoxicated.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: JDS Announces Narrower Loss And Job Cuts
description: The JDS Uniphase Corporation, the biggest maker of parts for fiber optic equipment, said its fourth-quarter net loss narrowed to $996.6 million as acquisition costs declined. Sales fell 63 percent, and the company said yesterday that it would eliminate more jobs. The loss narrowed to 73 cents a share in the period ended June 30, from $12.36 billion, or $9.39 a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Sales tumbled to $221.7 million from $601.1 million, the company, based in San Jose, Calif., said in a statement. JDS said slumping demand would force it to make more cost-cutting moves, including an undisclosed number of job reductions and site closings. Shares of JDS fell 48 cents, or 16 percent, to $2.53.

title: Development Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: SHARES OF DUANE READE FALL 38% ON EARNINGS NEWS
description: The drugstore chain Duane Reade warned yesterday that it would fall short of Wall Street's forecast for third-quarter profit, setting off a 38 percent decline in its share price. The company, based in New York, made the forecast as it reported a 59 percent decline in its second-quarter profit. Duane Reade's stock fell $8.95, to $14.60 a share. The company said it earned $2.3 million, or 9 cents a share, on sales of $325 million in the second quarter, which ended June 29. It said it expected to earn 33 to 38 cents a share in the third quarter, below Wall Street estimates of 45 cents.

title: Beautifying Balance Sheets Was Routine. Is It Now a Crime?
description: SOMETIMES the rules change in the middle of the game, and the players don't find out in time.

title: Victorian Homes: Living Like Royalty, Without the Pedigree
description: WHO -- Bobbie Langley, a marketing manager in manufacturing.

title: A Summer of Art: From Japanese Ceramics to Woodcuts
description: The art exhibitions reviewed on this page and Page 33:

title: Two Boys Act as Guides Through Poverty
description: Documentary films can be compelling. Films inspired by true stories can be compelling. So does that mean a film inspired by the true story of the making of a documentary can be doubly compelling?

title: Health Problems of Latino Children
description: One in every six American children is Hispanic, but it's hard to find them in the research on child health. According to the Journal of the American Medical Association, Latino children suffer from a disproportionate number of health problems that have been poorly studied. Diabetes is on the rise, and Latino boys have the highest rates of obesity among young people, but researchers don't know why. They also don't know why Puerto Rican children have rates of asthma higher than those in any other region.

title: A Statesman's Indolent Life, as Told on an Artful Scroll
description: Despite the cultural repression and political turmoil they have faced, Chinese composers of recent decades have demonstrated striking, often courageous, curiosity about Western contemporary music. Styles that mingle Western and Chinese idioms are now common. In the last 10 years, New Yorkers have learned this firsthand because the Lincoln Center Festival has made the city a place where Chinese composers, along with performers and directors, can present their work, old and new, and enjoy a cultural dialogue with their American counterparts.

title: 5 Suspects in Northern Ireland Bombing Face Civil Action
description: LONDON, July 26  Lawyers for the relatives of victims of the 1998 terror bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland, frustrated by the inability of the police to charge anyone directly with the crime, served legal writs today on the five men they blame for the attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRUNSKY, LUCY STAMPLEMAN
description: STRUNSKY-Lucy Stampleman. 91. Died on July 22, 2002 in San Francisco, CA. Long time resident of New York City and political activist for left wing causes. Wife of William English. Mother of Michael. Mother-in-law of Jean Zimmerman. Grandmother of Lara-Joelle and Burke. Memorials are being planned. Contributions can be made to The Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Ave, Montgomery, AL 36104

title: 36 Hours | Santa Barbara, Calif.
description: AN old Spanish mission town sandwiched between the Santa Ynez Mountains and the Pacific, Santa Barbara has climbed up hillsides and spilled out along the coast. Expensive neighborhoods and lavish estates rise in gentle terraces (with Ronald Reagan's old ranch somewhere in the higher elevations), looking down on the coastline, the city center and one another. Thanks to plentiful sunshine, celebrity residents (Oprah Winfrey, John Travolta and Brad Pitt all own houses here) and local building codes ensuring red-tiled roofs, Santa Barbara is sometimes called the American Riviera. But don't let the celebrity factor throw you. Upscale restaurants and trendy galleries abound, but so do funky taco stands, affordable antiques shops and lovely stretches of uncrowded, sandy beaches. Just ignore the oil rigs looming, Darth Vader-like, offshore. JOY HOROWITZ

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Health Care, in the Right Doses
description: To the Editor:

title: Challenger Shows Interest in History
description: Kirk Johnson is a student of recent boxing history who will go into the ring tomorrow night challenging John Ruiz for his piece of the world heavyweight championship. Someday, Johnson said, he wants to learn some older history, about the Underground Railroad, which helped part of his family reach Nova Scotia.

title: A Varied Tour of Connecticut's Indoor Treasures
description: Ah, Connecticut! Leafy trees, green grass, rippling brooks and great views -- not only of nature, but of art. Besides the outdoor bounty, there are indoor treasures at a variety of museums: a splendid corporate collection received as a gift, a show of French decorative masterpieces, a quirky book-art exhibition, the work of a redoubtable floral painter, a wry show about family values, an assemblage of great American nudes and the lyrical woodcut explorations of Helen Frankenthaler. Here are the makings of a tour.

title: Star Digs: Living Like Mick
description: WANT to sleep in Mick Jagger's bed? No problem. Yes, the rich are different from you and me: they're cheaper. Rather than let their splendid houses in paradise sit empty when they aren't using them, some celebrities prefer to rent them out, offering dream vacations to total strangers (or at least those with five-figure vacation budgets).

title: Long Island Shows Take a Look At Homegrown Creativity
description: From west to east, art showcases on Long Island are offering an eclectic mix of aesthetic experiences. Drawing on their own collections, the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton and the Guild Hall of East Hampton have assembled group shows, the first focused on landscape, the other on artists who have contributed to the Hamptons' reputation as a summertime destination for modern sophisticates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVSEY, DAIL CAMERON
description: LIVSEY-Dail Cameron. 64. Sarasota, FL. Died July 21, 2002. Born October 6, 1937 in New York City. Dail grew up in Bedford, NY and was educated at Rippowam Cisqua, Miss Hall's School and Vassar College. An accomplished art historian, Dail served as a docent at The Art Museum of Ontario in Toronto, The Metropolitan Museum of Art and its branch, The Cloisters in New York, The Art Institute of Chicago and The Ringling Museum of Art in Sarasota. She is survived by her husband of 44 years, Brian, daughter Alexandra of San Francisco, son Philip, daughter-in-law Camille, grandchildren Allison and Philip, Jr. of Avon, CT and sister Elaine Hinkle of Naples, FL and her family. A Mass will be held on August 5 at 10:30 AM at St. Martha's Catholic Church, 200 North Orange (at Fruitville) Sarasota, FL. Memorial donations may be made to The Ringling Museum Docent Memorial Fund, 5401 Bayshore Rd, Sarasota, FL 34243.

title: Robert Giard, 62, a Portraitist of Gay Writers
description: Robert Giard, a photographer who took hundreds of portraits of gay and lesbian writers, died on July 16 en route to Chicago. He was 62 and lived in Amagansett, N.Y.

title: An Eye on the Jury
description: To the Editor:

title: Tour Comes Down From the Mountains
description: The Tour de France finished its stay in the Alps today and, as far as Mario Aerts is concerned, good riddance to those mountains.

title: Art Unconfined by City Limits
description: WHAT to see around the New York suburbs this summer? There's plenty, as usual. Several museums are celebrating artists and collectors who have lived or worked nearby. At the Florence Griswold Museum in Old Lyme, Conn., the collection of the Hartford Steam Boiler Inspection and Insurance Company puts American Impressionists, many of whom painted in Connecticut, on view in a new 9,500-square-foot gallery, which itself is worth a look.

title: SWS GROUP DISCLOSES $21 MILLION IN VARIOUS CHARGES
description: The SWS Group, which operates the Internet brokerage firm Mydiscountbroker.com, said yesterday that it spent $21.7 million to shut a poor-performing division, settle lawsuits and write down the value of some investments. SWS, which changed its name from SouthWest Securities, said it moved its online brokerage operations, closed a technology services business and shut an equity trading office in New Jersey. The actions cost the firm $6.4 million, including severance and abandoned leases, the company said. It said it expected to save $4.7 million a year as a result of the consolidation. The firm said it would spend as much as $8.7 million to write down the value of its investment in Comprehensive Software Systems. SWS also spent $2 million to settle legal claims related to the company's prior trust operations.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: POULTRY DEAL Russia agreed to extend America's poultry import certificate, easing the deadlock between the countries over imports of American poultry until mid-September. New rules that would allow trade to begin flowing again will, however, be put off for "an uncertain period of time," said Sergei Dankvert, the first deputy agriculture minister, according to the Interfax news agency. Russia, the biggest foreign buyer of American poultry products, banned imports in March, citing health concerns. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC REDUCES 2002 EARNINGS FORECAST
description: American Electric Power reduced its 2002 earnings forecast for the second time in a week, after second-quarter earnings fell 91 percent on costs from selling assets. Net income fell to $21.9 million, or 7 cents a share, from $231.8 million, or 72 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said yesterday. Revenue rose 7.8 percent, to $15.2 billion. American Electric, based in Columbus, Ohio, cut its 2002 earnings forecast to $3.20 to $3.35 a share, citing declines in power prices. The company, a utility owner, had reduced the forecast by 10 percent, to $3.24 to $3.38 a share, on July 18. Excluding charges from the sale of Seeboard in Britain and CitiPower in Australia, quarterly profit was $181.6 million, or 56 cents a share, better than Wall Street's forecast of 52 cents. Shares of American Electric rose $3.19, or 12 percent, to $29.50.

title: Bush Visits Capitol Hill to Lobby Republicans on Trade Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  Hours after House and Senate negotiators reached a surprise breakthrough on a broad trade bill, President Bush made a rare visit to Capitol Hill today to personally lobby House Republicans to rally behind the measure, which he considers essential for economic growth.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Judge Orders Abstinence Program Changed
description: A federal judge in New Orleans ordered the state to modify a federally financed abstinence education program, finding that it had been used to finance religious activities. The judge, G. Thomas Porteous Jr., ordered the state to stop providing money to organizations that convey religious messages in the course of encouraging sexual abstinence. The American Civil Liberties Union, which brought the lawsuit, said such programs often entangle the government in religious activities in violation of the First Amendment. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: No Retrial For Ex-Sotheby Head
description: A. Alfred Taubman, the former Sotheby's chairman, who was convicted of price fixing, will not get a new trial, a federal court of appeals ruled yesterday. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit also denied Mr. Taubman's request for release pending another appeal. Mr. Taubman was convicted in December of conspiring to fix commission fees and of swindling customers of more than $100 million. Mr. Taubman, 78, was sentenced to a year and a day in prison and fined $7.5 million. His lawyers describe him as being in frail health. He is scheduled to surrender to the Federal Medical Center in Rochester, Minn., on Aug. 1 Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Buenos Aires Journal; For Heavenly Intervention, 'St. Evita' Might Serve
description: The nation is demoralized and adrift, the governing party is torn by internal battles and the approval rating of President Eduardo Duhalde, a Peronist, has sunk to single digits.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: KLM'S Profit Falls
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said its fiscal first-quarter profit fell 42 percent, less than analysts expected, as new fare software partly offset a drop in traffic since the Sept. 11 attacks. Net income fell to 11 million euros ($10.95 million), in the period, which ended June 30, from 19 million euros a year earlier, the company said. The airline slashed fares earlier this month by as much as 40 percent on its 66 European routes to stem passenger defections to EasyJet, now the second-largest carrier at Schiphol Airport in Amsterdam, after KLM. Yield, or revenue per passenger, grew 6 percent. The company's shares rose 7 percent.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Events

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Forecasts 91,000 New Users
description: Nextel Partners, the fifth-largest mobile-phone company in the United States, expects a loss of 30 cents a share in the third quarter as it adds 91,000 subscribers, the chief financial officer, John Thompson, said yesterday. Nextel Partners, an affiliate of Nextel Communications, sells a combined mobile-phone and walkie-talkie service in smaller United States markets. It said yesterday that it added 90,500 customers in the second quarter, for a total of 691,600 customers. The second-quarter loss at Nextel Partners widened to $74 million, or 31 cents a share, from $71 million, or 29 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 87 percent, to $161.1 million. Shares of Nextel Partners fell 60 cents, to $3.40. They have declined 76 percent in the last year.

title: Campbell-Ewald Wins Postal Service Account
description: The United States Postal Service in Washington said yesterday that it had selected Campbell-Ewald in Warren, Mich., as the lead creative agency on its account, with annual billings estimated at $100 million.

title: U.S. Aide Sees Corporate Criminal Cases
description: Larry D. Thompson, the deputy attorney general, said last night that the Justice Department would not hesitate to bring criminal prosecutions against corporations where it was warranted.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about comments by Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe of Sri Lanka on world terrorism referred imprecisely to his visit to Washington. While it was the first official visit in two decades by a government leader from his country, President Chandrika Kumaratunga made a private trip in 1999.

title: A French Trainer Is at Home In Saratoga
description: He is a Frenchman who has always been tugged by his wanderlust -- first to New York, then back to France, off to Hong Kong, before landing in California and then a summer stop here upstate. No matter where he lights, Patrick Biancone distinguishes himself as a horse trainer.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: E-Zpass Discounts May End
description: The New Jersey Highway Authority voted yesterday to eventually eliminate discounts for drivers who use its E-Zpass electronic toll collection system on the Garden State Parkway. Ending the discounts, which are two or five cents, depending on the time of day, will eventually produce $13 million more revenue for the state's debt-burdened E-Zpass system, which also plans to start charging a $1 monthly fee for about one million users. The parkway discounts will continue until at least November. Iver Peterson (NYT)

title: OXFORD PAYS $250,000 TO SETTLE S.E.C. INVESTIGATION
description: Oxford Health Plans, one of the New York area's biggest health insurers, said yesterday that it paid $250,000 to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into whether the company misstated financial results. In addition to the civil penalty, Oxford, which did not admit any wrongdoing, agreed to a cease-and-desist order related to accounting and reporting results, the company said. The S.E.C. began the investigation in December 1997, two months after Oxford said profit would not meet estimates and its shares fell 63 percent. The S.E.C. order did not include any finding of fraud against the company or its executives and directors, Oxford said.

title: Weaver Searches for Comfort Zone in Bronx
description: The Detroit Tigers were stretching near the batting cage at Yankee Stadium last week when Jeff Weaver popped out of the home dugout. Some of the Tigers playfully chided Weaver, razzing him, yelling his name. Two weeks earlier, Weaver had been one of them, buried in last place. Not anymore.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; A Retrospective Examines Kurosawa and His Star
description: It should be enough to get you into Film Forum to say that the theater begins a 12-picture retrospective today of the work of the director Akira Kurosawa and his star Toshiro Mifune, with all new prints.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.+ means discounted tickets were available at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNESS, DAPHNE F.
description: BURNESS-Daphne F. July 25, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Leonard Burness. Adored sister of the late Martin E. Fenton. She will be missed by all who knew her.

title: Day Is Frenetic As Investors Start Looking For Bargains
description: In another day of stock market sound and fury, the Nasdaq composite index took a pounding, but the broader market averages closed with only modest losses.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the composer and cellist Alan Shulman on July 13 misstated his age and the year when his work ''A Laurentian Overture'' was recorded with Guido Cantelli conducting. He was 87, not 86; the recording was made in 1952, not 1951.

title: Tyco Appoints Chief in Effort To Calm Wall St.
description: Tyco International Ltd. appointed Edward D. Breen, the president of Motorola Inc., as its chairman and chief executive yesterday in an effort to restore credibility in the company, which faces continuing investigations and lingering doubts about its accounting practices.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: La Caravelle has been that rare restaurant that can exalt the glorious past without turning its back on the present. Founded in 1960 by refugees from Le Pavillon, perhaps America's first and greatest temple of haute cuisine, La Caravelle has carried the tradition of classic French gastronomy into a new century.

title: Health System Adds to Pain Of Losing Child, Panel Says
description: One of the most traumatic experiences a family can suffer -- the death of a child -- is often worsened by ineffective health care that fails to address the physical, emotional or spiritual needs of the patient and family members, a report released today found.

title: Rendezvous With an Asteroid
description: Thank goodness! Another killer asteroid is on the way, just in time to take our minds off the stock market and foreign affairs. Asteroids, in fact, are just about the perfect peril -- a lot less scary than a close encounter with a shark and a lot more reliable than Saddam Hussein.

title: The Private Interest
description: Since the early months of 2000, the Nasdaq has fallen about 75 percent, the broader S.&P. 500 more than 40 percent. These aren't mere paper losses; they translate into disappointment and even hardship for millions of Americans. Now more than ever we need institutions that provide a safety net for the middle class.

title: Music That's for Listening, Not Defining
description: Nobody has come up with a suitable name for Henry Threadgill's music, though it has aftertastes of gospel, military marches and the quiet, astringent polytonality of some late-60's Chicago avant-garde jazz. (In the early 60's, Mr. Threadgill was making a living by playing in Chicago blues bands and circuses, while working for nothing as a member of Muhal Richard Abrams's Experimental Band.) His music may be weird, but it concretely says something about what kind of American he is.

title: A Get-Rich Scheme Collapses, Leaving Haiti Even Poorer
description: Intoxicated by the promise of easy money, thousands of Haitians here and abroad sold their cars, mortgaged their homes and emptied their savings accounts in recent months to invest in cooperatives that promised astonishing monthly returns of 10 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUSER, ELSIE C.
description: HAUSER-Elsie C. On July 24, 2002. Beloved wife of the late William. Loving mother of Judith Justman and Ann Fishman.

title: European Court Says Nazi Ally Was Denied Fair Trial by France
description: The European Court of Human Rights ruled today that an aged Nazi collaborator, Maurice Papon, was denied a fair trial when France refused to allow him to appeal a 1998 conviction for war crimes stemming from his involvement in the deportation of Jews to German death camps.

title: When Buyers Of Americana Decide to Sell
description: It's called Manchester madness. Each summer Antiques Week in New Hampshire is seven days of shopping mayhem. This year from Aug. 3 to 10 six American antiques shows will be held within a 10-mile radius of Manchester, N.H. In addition, Northeast Auctions has two days of Americana sales with 1,200 lots. The events attract Americana collectors and dealers as well as museum curators, auction house specialists, decorators and bargain hunters.

title: Broadway Company to Convert Former Movie Complex Into Theaters
description: A major Broadway producing organization announced plans yesterday to convert a defunct discount movie house on West 50th Street into a sprawling underground theater complex including five Off Broadway-size theaters.

title: Sinister Intricacy In a Fugue Of Dance
description: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company is beginning its 50th anniversary celebration with appearances, through tomorrow night, at Lincoln Center Festival 2002. On Wednesday night the program included ''Loose Time,'' right, a new work for 16 dancers choreographed by Mr. Cunningham. A fiery and explosive piece, it includes an extraordinary solo that brought down the house.

title: Charter Revision Panel Plans Ambitious 44-Day Schedule
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's commission to study the elimination of partisan elections in New York City met yesterday evening for the first time and laid out an ambitious schedule for the 44 days it has left until it must make its formal proposals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LURIE, JACK
description: LURIE-Jack. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the father of its esteemed Administrative Committee member, Sanford Lurie. May his entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Andrew Mendes, President

title: Weekender | Rhinebeck, N.Y.
description: ''THERE'S something earnest about Rhinebeck,'' said Amy Goldman, a gardener and author who grows 100 varieties of melon in her plots on the outskirts of town. (She wrote ''Melons for the Passionate Grower,'' published in May, because it had been 200 years, she said, since anyone had written ''a good book about melons for the general public.'')

title: China Vexed by Glare of U.S. Investigations
description: Senior Chinese officials are expressing irritation over a series of American actions in the last two weeks but are keeping their public comments fairly low-key as they seek to put a rosy glow on China's position in the world in preparation for the Communist Party congress this autumn.

title: George Biderman, 81, Organizer Against Highway on Fire Island
description: George Biderman, who organized opposition to a plan by Robert Moses for a four-lane highway the length of Fire Island, N.Y., died on July 20 at his home on the West Side of Manhattan. He was 81.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: ST. PAUL COS. SAYS IT WILL SELL $750 MILLION OF SECURITIES
description: The St. Paul Companies, which this month postponed a sale of its reinsurance unit, said yesterday that it planned to sell $750 million of securities to help finance its insurance-underwriting business. St. Paul's shares, down 45 percent this year, fell $1.16, to $24.20. St. Paul shelved a $920 million initial public offering of its Platinum Underwriters Holdings earlier this month as stocks fell, sapping demand for new companies. The sale of Platinum had been part of St. Paul's effort to overhaul the company, which had been hurt by bigger-than-expected losses in its medical malpractice, reinsurance and international businesses. Earlier this week, St. Paul reported a net loss of $223 million after settling an asbestos claim for $1 billion.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Poultry Deal
description: Russia agreed to extend America's poultry import certificate, easing the deadlock between the countries over imports of American poultry until mid-September. New rules that would allow trade to begin flowing again will, however, be put off for ''an uncertain period of time,'' said Sergei Dankvert, the first deputy agriculture minister, according to the Interfax news agency. Russia, the biggest foreign buyer of American poultry products, banned imports in March, citing health concerns. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Hudson Valley Shows Focus on America
description: If you're in a New York state of mind that is more suburban than urban, more natural than cultural, you're in sync with the season. Still, should the art urge strike, four suburban museums in the Hudson Valley are offering several shows worth seeing. Nearly all focus on American art, past or present. Some take a wide-angle group-show view; others zoom in for solo close-ups. And the solo show at Bard College, which sums up an artistic milieu, might be called a wide-angle close-up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURTZ, MELVIN H.
description: KURTZ-Melvin H. Loving husband of Sandra (nee Koss). Adored father of Lisa Kurtz Hatem, Glenn M. Kurtz and Jill Kurtz. Dear brother of Marilyn Miller and Harvey Kurtz. Cherished grandfather of Jessica and Tyler Hatem, and Kevin Kurtz. Beloved father-in-law of Peter Hatem, and Linda Ruma Kurtz. Mel Kurtz was a Chemical Engineer and Attorney. He served as Vice President, Secretary and General Counsel of Chesebrough-Ponds, and was a member of its Board of Directors. He was also Vice President of Law of Unilever U.S. Services today 2:00 PM at ''the Riverside'', 21 W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This report reflects the heightened craziness about admissions decisions. It probably wouldn't subvert the Constitution, but it is competitiveness taken to a dastardly length.''

title: Investors Turn Selective in Frenetic Day on Wall Street
description: In another day of stock market sound and fury, the Nasdaq composite index took a pounding, but the broader market averages closed with only modest losses.

title: Weighing the Costs Of Invading Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: The Moussaoui Mystery
description: The already strange case of Zacarias Moussaoui grew even more puzzling yesterday when Mr. Moussaoui, the only person charged in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, entered and then abruptly withdrew guilty pleas to four of the six federal counts against him. Judge Leonie Brinkema correctly refused to accept Mr. Moussaoui's pleas unless he agreed to every particular of those four counts. Now the case will presumably proceed to a trial, where some of its many disputed facts may at last be clarified.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, FELIX
description: KLEIN-Felix. 1/17/1911 to 7/26/1994. On the 30th anniversary of his founding of The National Society for Graphology, we remember him with love and gratitude. Janice

title: Telecom Giants Retrench in Europe
description: Several large European telecommunications companies announced plans today to retrench from global ambitions nursed during the stock market boom, by writing down the value of assets, agreeing to suspend unprofitable operations and selling some units.

title: Fire Prompts New Debate On Managing The Sequoias
description: The fires that continued to roar today near hundreds of giant sequoias, the towering trademarks of the area around this central California town, have renewed an argument over how best to manage the Sequoia National Forest's resources while preventing the woodland's destruction.

title: NEGOTIATORS AGREE ON BILL TO REWRITE BANKRUPTCY LAWS
description: Congressional negotiators announced today that they had reached agreement on a bill that would rewrite the bankruptcy laws, making it much harder for people to escape their debts when they declare bankruptcy.

title: At Auburn, a Challenge To a Trustee's Reign
description: People like to talk about the university at the heart of this red-brick village as ''the Auburn family.'' That bond has been nurtured over generations at football games, where 86,000 fans screaming ''Warrrrr Eagle!'' turn Auburn into the state's fourth-largest city on fall afternoons; it has been memorialized in the Auburn Creed, which concludes, ''I believe in Auburn, and I love it.''

title: Guthrie Thinks This Year Can Still Turn Out Special
description: Mark Guthrie was chatting with his fellow reliever Jim Mecir in the Oakland Athletics' bullpen early last season when Mecir mentioned playing in the playoffs that fall. The A's had played in the postseason the year before, but Guthrie thought Mecir was now confused, or maybe talking about the past.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Beyond Glamour There's Humor

title: National Briefing | West: Counting Fish, Wild Or Not
description: Adhering to a Federal District Court ruling in Oregon, the National Marine Fisheries Service said that it would count fish bred in hundreds of hatcheries before deciding whether salmon and steelhead populations, primarily in the Pacific Northwest, should be classed as endangered. Even so, the agency said, the decision would be based primarily on how well the species sustains itself through ''natural reproduction in its natural ecosystem,'' not artificial ones. House builders, cattlemen, farmers and loggers have sued to remove the fish from the endangered species list, arguing that their proliferation in hatcheries eliminates the need for special protections for their natural habitats. Greg Winter (NYT)

title: Legislation to Arm Pilots Gains Support in the Senate
description: Senate opposition to arming airline pilots waned further today as two more lawmakers unexpectedly endorsed the idea and positions against it were all but absent at a hearing on aviation security. The only counterargument that the secretary of transportation could offer at the hearing was that the requisite training would cost money.

title: An Olympics Ever So Human
description: When Kon Ichikawa was asked to make a documentary of the 1964 Olympic Games in Tokyo, the Japanese authorities from the emperor on down expected his cameras to stick to business on the track or in the pool and not go wandering off at every little distraction. Yet no sooner does Billy Mills of the United States win the 10,000-meter run than Mr. Ichikawa moves off into the crowd for a close look at the wattles of 60-something men.

title: Genuity Faces Bankruptcy As Verizon Ignores an Option
description: Genuity, the last of the original Big Three Internet carriers, may be about to go the way of its competitors -- into bankruptcy.

title: Treasury Prices Rise On Economic Data
description: Bonds rose for a fifth trading session in six yesterday as stocks fell and the government said that durable goods orders tumbled, adding to evidence the economy's recovery from recession is slowing.

title: South Korea Is Investigating 6 Conglomerates
description: South Korea's Fair Trading Commission confirmed today that it had opened an investigation into illegal dealing at six of the country's largest conglomerates, known as chaebol.

title: Got Lots of Mojo, Needs a Little Love
description: When a movie is as down-and-out funny as ''Austin Powers in Goldmember,'' it's easy to overlook the missed opportunities and fizzled jokes littering the barrage of hilarity. This comic avalanche of raunchy double entendres and pop cultural references tosses in not only the kitchen sink but also the water bed (leaky from strenuous overuse) and the toilet (unflushed and running over). Like its bald, infantile villain, Dr. Evil, it wants to take over the world any way it can. It gleefully flaunts the message that beneath the most blas facade churns the dirty mind of a tittering adolescent.

title: Walter McCrone, Debunker Of Legends, Is Dead at 86
description: Walter C. McCrone, a chemical analyst who used his microscope to conclude that the Shroud of Turin never enveloped the body of Jesus and that a famous ancient map belonging to Yale University is probably a fake, died on July 10 in Chicago, long his hometown. He was 86.

title: Fish Genes Aid Human Discoveries
description: Almost a thousand new human genes have been discovered in the human genome by scientists who have decoded the genome of a very distant relative, the fugu, or puffer fish.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: NCR Discloses Accounting Errors
description: Shares of the NCR Corporation fell as much as 14 percent after the company, the largest maker of automated teller machines, reduced third-quarter and 2002 profit forecasts and said a service division in Canada had made accounting errors. The unit failed to record some costs, NCR executives said, and the unidentified person responsible was fired. Costs for correcting the errors pared second-quarter net income by $10 million. Controls have been tightened, said the chief financial officer, Earl Shanks, who called the situation ''pretty isolated.'' Investors and corporations are paying closer attention to accounting issues amid disclosures of botched accounting at companies like Enron and WorldCom. ''I am extremely disappointed that we did not identify it before this quarter,'' Mr. Shanks said in a conference call. No similar errors were found in about five similar units after recent checks, he said.

title: People Who Can Rebuild A City
description: As planning for the former World Trade Center site enters a pivotal stage, it's clear that more is at stake than designing a memorial. The future of a region is being shaped. While the recently released plans and the reaction to them have sparked much discussion of architectural vision, the real issue is economic. We can't assess whether the plans are sufficiently visionary, or say whether the vision is the right one, until we have a clear sense of how Lower Manhattan is to function in the greater New York economy.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL MOTORS, Detroit, said it had reached an agreement with the union at its plant in So Caetano do Sul, Brazil, to reduce the number of workers who will be dismissed to 108 from 808 and offer early retirement to at least 1,000 employees. G.M. has a work force of 18,000 in Brazil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHMAN, MURRAY
description: ROTHMAN-Murray. Retired organizer for District 65 UAW, died on July 24, 2002 at age 91. Survived by his beloved daughters, Deborah and Judith, and son-in-law Russell P. Reeder III. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation to the organization of your choice. Memorial service to be held at a later date.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Discrimination Suit Advances
description: A gay female sheriff's officer can sue the Essex County sheriff and other officers for discrimination and harassment, a state appellate court ruled yesterday. The suit by the officer, Karen Caggiano, had been dismissed by a lower court because the statute of limitations had expired. The appellate court said it was ''problematic'' applying the two-year statute of limitations in a suit that charged ''cumulative'' acts that the plaintiff said resulted in a continuing hostile work environment. The suit charged that the sheriff, Armando B. Fontoura, and other officers had harassed her and that the department had failed to enforce its antidiscrimination policies. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Cunningham Celebrates In a Fugue for 16 Dancers
description: How does he do it? ''Loose Time,'' the latest dance work to spring from Merce Cunningham's Zeus-like brow, has a fiery and original impact.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about comments by Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe of Sri Lanka on world terrorism referred imprecisely to his visit to Washington. While it was the first official visit in two decades by a government leader from his country, President Chandrika Kumaratunga made a private trip in 1999.

title: The Societal Costs of Surveillance
description: Helena Blazkova had come to kick me out.

title: 2 Former WorldCom Officials May Face Criminal Charges
description: Prosecutors investigating allegations of fraud at WorldCom are expected to bring criminal charges as soon as next week against two former executives at the center of the company's accounting scandal, people close to the case said yesterday.

title: Poll Finds That Baseball's Popularity Has Eroded
description: With major league baseball threatened with a labor shutdown before the regular season ends, a New York Times poll indicates that interest in baseball has dropped significantly since the Mark McGwire-Sammy Sosa home run derby of 1998, that relatively few people are paying close attention to the possibility of a work stoppage and, as in the 1994 baseball strike, more people sympathize with the owners than with the players.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Sleepy Hollow: Club Settles Complaint
description: State Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer has reached a settlement with a health club that sold about 300 prepaid memberships but did not open here as planned in the spring of 2001. The club, Dolphin Fitness, operates 17 clubs in the New York metropolitan region. Dolphin has agreed to pay $20,000 in penalties and costs to the state, and to either refund membership fees, ranging from $279 to $329, or provide an extra three months of membership when the club opens, which is expected to be in September, Mr. Spitzer said. ''We're happy that we were able to resolve the issues and move forward to satisfy the many customers of Dolphin Fitness,' said Tab K. Rosenfeld, a lawyer for the company. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: AOL Falls 15% as Analysts Express Concern Over Ads
description: Shares of AOL Time Warner fell 15 percent yesterday, to $9.64, as a gloomy outlook for online advertising sales and concerns about accounting prompted half a dozen Wall Street brokerage firms to downgrade its stock.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: TAIWAN: CHIP MAKER'S PROFIT RISES A leading chip maker, the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company , had lower-than-expected second-quarter profit and said a recovery in demand was flagging. Net income surged to $279 million from $9.3 million a year earlier but fell short of the $332 million expected by analysts. Sales rose two-thirds, to $1.3 billion. The chairman, Morris Chang, said a recovery in demand from the industry's worst year on record was stalling, with sales set to fall this month from a year earlier. (Bloomberg News)

description: BASEBALL

title: Passion Erupting Amid Political Upheaval
description: ''Lan Yu,'' which opens today in Manhattan, was filmed in Beijing without government permission and is based on a novel published anonymously on the Internet in 1997. The film follows the intermittent love affair between two men, an entrepreneur and an architecture student. American audiences (and those in Hong Kong, where the director, Stanley Kwan, is based) may not find this movie terribly shocking, but its sexual and political frankness have made it virtually unreleasable in China.

title: Still Talking, as if Time Paused
description: A CARDINAL rule of a certain kind of sentimental comedy is that you can't keep a feisty old man down. Punch him, knife him, run him over with a tank or -- God forbid -- stuff him into a nursing home. He will still spring back to his feet, like Rasputin defying his assassins. Seasoned theatergoers know that each resurrection of said feisty old man must be acknowledged with a congratulatory round of applause.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Telecom Loss
description: Alcatel, the largest maker of telecommunications equipment in Europe, reported its fifth consecutive quarterly loss and warned that it saw no signs of a recovery in the market for its products. Despite the grim news, Alcatel did manage to halve its operating loss in the second quarter compared with the preceding one, and posted a loss of 177 million euros ($176.2 million), beating analysts' predictions of a loss of 235 million euros. The company, which is based in Paris, ''is focused on restoring its profit potential in today's adverse environment while preserving its capability to rebound when markets improve,'' Serge Tchuruk, the chief executive, said. In June, Alcatel's credit rating was cut to junk status by Moody's Investors Services and Standard & Poor's. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Free Concert Concentrates On Chinese Chamber Music
description: A quality of classical music that listeners tend to note only in passing, yet that gives it its resilience, is its ability to accommodate an almost limitless range of cultural influences. Back when one could accurately describe classical music as European, the cross-fertilization was mainly regional. In the 20th century the reconsideration of tonality (and then the reconsideration of atonality) along with the maturing of an American compositional world pushed classical music in other directions.

title: German Church Is Learning From U.S. Mistakes on Abuse
description: Michael S., now 33, was an altar boy 24 years ago in a Roman Catholic parish in Bavaria when his priest molested him.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: A.C.L.U. Seeks Ruling On Copyright Law
description: The American Civil Liberties Union filed a lawsuit yesterday that seeks to overturn a key provision of a 1998 copyright law that prohibits the creation or distribution of tools that unlock digital copy-protection schemes. The suit asks a federal judge in Boston to rule that the law, the Digital Millennium Copyright Act, is unconstitutionally broad because it prevents researchers from studying the effectiveness of Internet filtering software or studying the workings of software that is protected by digital locks. The A.C.L.U. is representing Ben Edelman, 22, who served as an expert witness in the organization's successful challenge of the Children's Internet Protection Act earlier this year. Mr. Edelman says filtering software, like the program distributed by N2H2, blocks educational and health Web sites as well as the pornographic sites it is intended to block. He wants to crack the locks on software and publish the list of blocked sites. To do that, he needs to break through N2H2's copy-protection technology, an act that could be seen as a violation of current copyright law. The lawsuit argues that the law must be overturned because it would be within Mr. Edelman's constitutional rights to perform his research. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: Doctor Killed by Car's Exhaust, Officials Say
description: A doctor found dead in his car Wednesday after the car's exhaust fumes drifted into an apartment building was killed by carbon monoxide poisoning, the authorities said today.

Born in Stuttgart, Germany, she was brought to England and then to the United States as a child. She graduated from Queens College. Served as Chairman of the Board of the Scarsdale (NY) Adult School. Also survived by her former husband, J. Robert Moskin. Graveside service at Westchester Hills Cemetery, Ardsley, NY, at 2 PM Sunday.

He came from and returned to Upper Austria, where he was born, not Germany; he moved to Munich in 1913.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Catholic Funeral
description: Thousands of mourners watched as friends carried the coffin of a slain Roman Catholic man through North Belfast and attended the funeral of the man, Gerard Lawlor. He was shot to death by the Protestant paramilitary group Ulster Freedom Fighters on Sunday night while walking home alone from a pub wearing a jersey for a soccer team supported by Catholics. Mr. Lawlor, 19, the father of an 18-month-old son, was the first victim of a sectarian killing in Northern Ireland since January. Brian Lavery (NYT)

description: An American-born man being held without charges or access to a lawyer is an ''enemy combatant'' because he was armed with an assault rifle when captured late last year in Afghanistan, according to a federal court filing made public today.

title: TRIAL MAY SLOW
description: The former Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, suffers from severe heart disease and dangerously high blood pressure, and needs medical treatment and less work in court, the United Nations war crimes tribunal announced today.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Arrest In Killing Of C.I.A. Chief
description: A man who 27 years ago took part in the killing of a C.I.A. station chief in order to announce the existence of the anti-American urban guerrilla group November 17 is in custody, the authorities said. Pavlos Serifis, 46, the man accused in the 1975 killing of the station chief, Richard S. Welch, was arrested Wednesday while vacationing in northern Greece. He was charged with taking part in a terrorist organization. The November 17 guerrilla group has taken reponsibility for 22 other killings, including those of four American officials. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

description: Brushing off Congressional complaints about creating a ''snitch system,'' Attorney General John Ashcroft said today the administration would go ahead to form a corps of truck and bus drivers, port workers, meter readers, letter carriers and others to report suspicious activities around the nation.

title: Bush Urges a Cap on Medical Liability
description: With doctors complaining about rising malpractice insurance premiums, President Bush called today for a major overhaul of the nation's medical liability system, including legislation to cap compensation for pain and suffering at $250,000 in successful malpractice suits.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

description: Laurie Anderson never did get around to revealing the secret of happiness in ''Happiness,'' her two-hour, intermissionless performance piece Tuesday and Wednesday at Alice Tully Hall.

description: Land O'Lakes Inc., a dairy cooperative, said today that its second-quarter profit rose 9.3 percent, helped by $32.7 million in payments stemming from antitrust lawsuits against vitamin makers.

title: On the receiving end : Readers go postal in Europe
description: PARIS  Our report on problems with parcels sent to Europe via the United States Postal Service ("Parcels from U.S. come at high cost," July 4) triggered a wave of correspondence. From France to Italy to Britain to New York, readers wrote of difficulties with the European delivery affiliates of General Logistics Systems, the arm of Consignia that the USPS contracted in October as its single operator for the region.

title: Vote for Security Dept.
description: The House approved the largest reorganization of the federal government in decades, the creation of a Department of Homeland Security.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the front page of Business Day yesterday included an erroneous cross-reference to SportsFriday in some copies. The sports pages were in Section D; the cross-reference to pages in Section C was intended for the newspaper's national edition.

title: Posada Returns After Injury
description: Three days after requiring nine stitches when he was hit on the left side of the head by a batter's backswing in Cleveland, catcher Jorge Posada returned to the Yankees' lineup tonight. Just as he promised.

title: A Shrink With Stage Presence if Not Certification
description: ''I will be your psychotherapist this evening,'' Lisa Levy announces, pacing in front of her brown vinyl psychoanalyst's couch and tissue box. This is ''Psychotherapy Live! Psychotherapy as Performance Art'' (playing monthly at Here, the artists' center just west of Soho). And everything about it screams ''Spoof!'' ''Parody!'' Everything, that is, but the red-haired, onstage therapist, who is in dead earnest, probably.

title: Rudiger Dornbusch, 60, an Economist of Outspoken Views
description: Rudiger Dornbusch, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology whose explanation of why currency exchange rates sometimes fluctuate sharply became a tenet of international economics, died on Thursday at his home in Washington. He was 60 and also had a home in Boston.

title: Rivera Is Third Pitcher On D.L.
description: By the time the Yankees finish this marathon road trip, they expect to have a pitching staff of 11 healthy veterans. But for now, after placing closer Mariano Rivera on the 15-day disabled list today, the staff is thin.

title: In Two Days, Citigroup Chief Traded Halo For Headaches
description: Just three weeks ago, the chief executive of Citigroup, Sanford I. Weill, was being honored by Chief Executive magazine as C.E.O. of the year. Now he is C.E.O. on the spot.

Powell held out the possibility today that he might meet with North Korea's foreign minister at a conference of Southeast Asian nations in Brunei next week in what would be the highest-level contact between Washington and Pyongyang since President Bush took office.

description: The Islanders have re-signed defenseman Eric Cairns to a two-year contract.

Torricelli still unresolved, some public interest groups and Republicans expressed disappointment that the panel apparently plans to end the inquiry without calling any witnesses other than Mr. Torricelli.

title: Ambitious Plans in Disarray at Canada Utility
description: The names of Hydro One's directors have disappeared from the corporate Web site. So has the prospectus that Hydro One, Ontario's dominant power transmission company, filed earlier this year for what was to have been the biggest public stock offering in Canadian history.

title: Religion Journal; For Giant Evangelical Ministry, Midlife Crisis at 25
description: As thousands of people gather in Colorado for this weekend's celebrations of the 25th anniversary of Focus on the Family, the international multimedia evangelical ministry, its founder acknowledges that Focus is at a crossroads.

title: Divided House Approves Homeland Security Bill, With Limited Enthusiasm
description: The House tonight approved the largest reorganization of the federal government in more than half a century, voting to create a Department of Homeland Security intended to marshal and fortify the nation's defense against terrorism.

title: The Secrets to a Successful Sidewalk Sashay
description: The other day, as I approached Bloomingdale's in Manhattan, I sidestepped a bit to the left to enter the subway. Suddenly, a young woman on skates plowed into me, dumping me on my butt before zooming off without so much as a Hi, Guy!

description: The General Electric Company, often criticized for the complexity of its structure and the resulting opacity of its numbers, said yesterday that it would break GE Capital, by far its largest business, into four businesses, effective Aug. 1.

title: Property losses and gains : Selling up?Prepare for a taxing time
description: LONDON  If you are an American expatriate who has bought a home overseas, think carefully before you sell. You may no longer be a homeowner after the transaction is completed, but you may find, to your astonishment, that you have become a shrewd foreign-exchange trader. This unexpected news may come to you from the Internal Revenue Service, and it may cost you dearly.
