description: To the Editor:

title: AVAYA TO CUT 2,500 MORE JOBS IN CONTINUING SLUMP
description: Avaya Inc., the nation's biggest maker of office telephone equipment, said yesterday it would eliminate 2,500 more jobs, or about 12 percent of its work force, amid a continued slump in demand. The company will have about $150 million in fiscal fourth-quarter costs for cutting jobs, closing offices and terminating leases, as well as declining asset values, it said. Avaya, which is based in Basking Ridge, N.J., has cut 7,200 positions since last June because customers reduced spending on telephone equipment. The company reported a third-quarter net loss of $37 million on Monday as sales fell 29 percent to $1.22 billion.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Asbestos Charges
description: Shares in Europe's largest distributor of building materials, Saint-Gobain, fell to a record low after the company said it was taking charges for asbestos liability and that profit would not increase this year. Saint-Gobain, based in France, supplies insulation for about 20 percent of the homes in the United States and paid several million dollars in liabilities related to asbestos last year. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLBERG, EDYTHE
description: STOLBERG - Edythe. The members, Board of Governors & staff of Pine Hollow Country Club mourn the passing of our long time member and good friend. We extend our sympathies to her husband Leo, and the entire family. The Board of Governors Pine Hollow Country Club

title: Edwards Puts Testaverde in Driver's Seat
description: For the Jets, the off-season speculation about Vinny Testaverde and Chad Pennington can be compared to the cartoon monster who keeps regenerating limbs to wreak more havoc. No matter how many ways -- gently or bluntly -- that Coach Herman Edwards stated that Testaverde was his starter, the questions about whether Pennington could challenge for the job, and under what circumstances, never abated.

title: INSIDE
description: 4 Jewish Settlers Killed

title: Even With a W.B.A. Title, Ruiz Is Still Defined by an Untimely Punch
description: The Quietman did not say a single word all through New Jersey, New York and Connecticut. By the time the car reached the Massachusetts Turnpike, Norman Stone was worried about the Quietman, the heavyweight boxer John Ruiz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMPSON, ARDEN KAY
description: SAMPSON-Arden Kay. On July 12, 2002, in NYC. Survived by mother Mary Sampson, sister Andrea Wilson, brother Austin Sampson, niece Terri Wilson and loving friend James Donovan. Memorial Service on Monday, July 29th at 7 PM, at CAMI Hall, 165 W. 57 St, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIMARZIO, ALICE GERTRUDE ALLEN RN.
description: DIMARZIO-Alice Gertrude Allen RN. Born on 14th December, 1907 died on Thursday, July 25th in Plymouth, Massachusetts. She was the wife of Dr. James Lawrence Flynn of Boston, MA and Rafael F. DiMarzio of Plymouth, MA. She was a 1929 graduate of the Mercy Hospital Nursing School in Springfield, MA. She leaves two children, Alice and James and grandchildren Patricia and Christina Tscharskyj. Donations to be made to the Food Allergy Initiative, 625 Madison Ave, 4th Fl, New York, NY 10022

title: Critics Say Design of Queens Museum Is Out of Context
description: The Queens Museum in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, completed in 1939, is a simple, classical stone-and-glass structure that is historically and architectually important enough to be considered a landmark. But now the museum wants to replace its center space with what a judge in an architectural competition called a ''boom-here-I-am scheme.''

title: A Bankrupt Bill
description: It was probably expecting too much to think that Congress's stand-up attitude to big business would last until the weekend. A little more than a day after passing tough corporate-governance legislation, lawmakers rushed to approve an ill-advised overhaul of the nation's bankruptcy laws long sought by credit card companies and other creditors. The House seemed on the verge of approving the bill early this morning, and the Senate is expected to vote on it next week.

title: Cablevision Unmoved by YES's Offer
description: Cablevision said yesterday that a recent offer described by the YES Network as ''an extraordinary compromise'' to end their impasse was not a major breakthrough.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Both Dow and S.& P. Gain, Ending the Week Positive

title: Swedish Mother's Company Changes the Diaper
description: IF ever a woman relished the sheer excitement each morning of changing her baby's smelly, sodden diaper, that woman was Marlene Sandberg.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Gibraltar: Britain Discounts Referendum Plan
description: Gibraltar said it would hold a rush referendum on whether its people wished to remain British or share sovereignty with neighboring Spain, but Jack Straw, Britain's foreign secretary, dismissed the plan as ''eccentric'' and said it would have no bearing on the colony's future. Gibraltar's chief minister, Peter Caruana, announced the vote in an effort to pre-empt current negotiations between London and Madrid that could lead to Spain gaining a say in the colony's affairs. The 30,000 residents are known to be overwhelmingly opposed to any concession to Spain. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Record Sale of Nymex Seat
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange, the world's biggest energy marketplace, said yesterday that a membership that allows trading in its most popular contracts sold for a record $1.1 million.

title: Girl Vanishes at Breakfast; Body Is Found Hours Later
description: A 6-year-old girl vanished from a suburban St. Louis house this morning while waiting for a bowl of breakfast cereal, and hours later her body was found less than a mile away.

title: XCEL ENERGY WILL SELL STOCK TO SAVE SUBSIDIARY
description: Xcel Energy Inc., a utility company owner based in Minneapolis, said yesterday that it would sell $500 million in stock to avert a default by its power-generation subsidiary, NRG Energy. Xcel needs cash to help NRG, which is also based in Minneapolis, buy power plants from the FirstEnergy Corporation and maintain a $2 billion line of credit, the company said. Shares of Xcel, which supplies 3.2 million electricity customers and 1.7 million natural gas clients in 12 states, fell $4.39, or 37 percent, to $7.55 a share.

title: When Princeton Snoops on Yale
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We've got to keep working. We need a little bit of luck.''

title: Milosevic Finds a Friendly Face In the Witness Stand at His Trial
description: For Slobodan Milosevic, it must have been one of the rare happy moments since his trial opened in February. Rade Markovic, one of his most trusted lieutenants, walked into the courtroom at the United Nations war crimes tribunal, nodded at him and took up his place in the witness chair. Mr. Milosevic grinned.

title: U.S. Studying Merrill Lynch In Enron Deal
description: The Justice Department is investigating a December 1999 transaction in which Enron sold a part-interest in electricity-generating barges in Nigeria to a special-purpose entity established by Merrill Lynch.

title: Report on 9/11 Finds Flaws In Response of Police Dept.
description: The New York Police Department's response to the Sept. 11 attack was effective in many areas but suffered from lapses in leadership and coordination and a lack of proper planning and training, according to a draft report by an independent consultant for the department.

title: Brooklyn Woman Kills Daughter, 7, and Stabs a Friend, Police Say
description: A Brooklyn woman who the police said was high on drugs stabbed her 7-year-old daughter to death yesterday morning and critically wounded a friend who intervened in the stabbing, according to the authorities. They said the woman later turned a pair of scissors on herself.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Life Term In Infant's Rape
description: The 23-year-old man accused of raping his ex-girlfriend's 9-month old-daughter last October was convicted and sentenced to life in prison, bringing an end to a sordid criminal case that had at first appeared to be even more horrific. The police in the northwestern town of Louisvale initially said the baby had been attacked by several people, and six men were quickly arrested. In January, all six were freed after DNA evidence cleared them. David Potse, the mother's ex-boyfriend, was arrested in March. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Mel Triplett, 71; Helped Giants Win '56 Title
description: Mel Triplett, the fullback for the Giants' 1956 National Football League champions, died Thursday in a nursing home in Toledo, Ohio. He was 71.

title: Pataki Calls for More Flexibility On Rebuilding at Ground Zero
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey should look beyond the site of the former World Trade Center to other places in downtown Manhattan to rebuild commercial space destroyed in the Sept. 11 attack.

title: Seahawks' Leaf Retires
description: Ryan Leaf, an underachiever with three N.F.L. teams, retired yesterday, ending a career that began in 1998 when he was the second overall draft choice behind Peyton Manning and was considered one of the league's most promising young quarterbacks.

title: $15 Million Settlement in Fatal Casino-Bus Crash
description: Family members of the eight bus passengers killed in the worst accident in the Garden State Parkway's history and survivors of the crash will share $15 million from a settlement reached last week, lawyers in the case said yesterday.

title: Connecticut Rejects Rate Increase for Utility
description: State regulators yesterday rejected a request by Connecticut Light and Power for what it called an emergency rate increase to prevent one of its suppliers from shutting down several generators at a power plant next week.

title: Mayor Opposes Levy Plan For Extra Time in School
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he did not agree that the extra time to be added to the school day this fall should be devoted to the worst-performing students.

title: Jennings Joins Giants in Booth
description: Dave Jennings, the Giants' punter for 11 years, is returning to the team as one of its radio commentators on WFAN and WNEW, working with Bob Papa and Dick Lynch. The deal is being completed and an announcement is expected next week.

title: When Princeton Snoops on Yale
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Israelis and One Palestinian Die in Surge of Violence
description: Palestinian gunmen ambushed two Israeli cars today on a road south of the West Bank city of Hebron, killing four Jewish settlers and wounding two others. A couple and their teenage son were among the dead.

title: Landlord of Missing Manhattan Couple to Be Paroled in Month
description: It has been five years since Camden Sylvia and Michael Sullivan disappeared from their loft in Lower Manhattan. The disappearance of the couple, who are presumed dead, has become one of the most frustrating of the city's unsolved crimes.

title: When Princeton Snoops on Yale
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Listening to the City'
description: To the Editor:

title: After Withdrawn Guilty Plea, a Tough Trial Ahead
description: With the way now cleared for his trial, Zacarias Moussaoui faces the daunting task of trying to convince a jury that while he is a member of Al Qaeda, hates America and was taking flying lessons like some of the people involved with the Sept. 11 attacks, he was not involved with the plot.

title: Earnings and Stock Price Jump at JetBlue
description: Shares in the JetBlue Airways Corporation rose sharply yesterday after the two-year-old discount airline said second-quarter earnings climbed.

title: Got the Giggles? Join the Club
description: On Jan. 30, 1962, at Kashasha village near Lake Victoria in what is now Tanzania, three schoolgirls got the giggles. Tears rolling down their cheeks, they couldn't stop laughing or keep their contagion of chuckles from spreading to almost half the other girls at their boarding school. Some fits were lasting minutes, others hours, some up to 16 days, until exasperated administrators closed the school five months later. Afflicted girls were sent home to their villages around Lake Victoria, where they duly infected more children and young adults with their ''sickness.'' Before the epidemic finally relented, in 1964, it forced the temporary closing of more than 14 schools, all because of unstoppable laughter.

title: Esphyr Slobodkina, Artist And Author, Is Dead at 93
description: Esphyr Slobodkina, a prominent abstract artist better known for her down-to-earth children's book ''Caps for Sale,'' a tale about a peddler and a band of mischievous monkeys, died on Sunday at her home in Glen Head, N.Y. She was 93.

title: Shares of Motorola Tumble As Its President Moves to Tyco
description: Shares in Motorola plunged 10.5 percent yesterday after the company's No. 2 executive, Edward D. Breen, was named chief executive of Tyco International.

title: Up Where Theater Is a Summer Breeze
description: A weekend in the country. How amusing! as Stephen Sondheim put it in ''A Little Night Music.'' How delightfully droll! And here in the Berkshires, where it was possible to take in three stage premieres, so it was.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVSEY, DAIL CAMERON
description: LIVSEY-Dail Cameron. 64. Sarasota, FL. Died July 21, 2002. Born October 6, 1937 in New York City. Dail grew up in Bedford, NY and was educated at Rippowam Cisqua, Miss Hall's School and Vassar College. An accomplished art historian, Dail served as a docent at The Art Museum of Ontario in Toronto, The Metropolitan Museum of Art and its branch, The Cloisters in New York, The Art Institute of Chicago and The Ringling Museum of Art in Sarasota. She is survived by her husband of 44 years, Brian, daughter Alexandra of San Francisco, son Philip, daughter-in-law Camille, grandchildren Allison and Philip, Jr. of Avon, CT and sister Elaine Hinkle of Naples, FL and her family. A Mass will be held on August 5 at 10:30 AM at St. Martha's Catholic Church, 200 North Orange (at Fruitville) Sarasota, FL. Memorial donations may be made to The Ringling Museum Docent Memorial Fund, 5401 Bayshore Rd, Sarasota, FL 34243.

title: Religious Riots Loom Over Indian Politics
description: Here in the adopted hometown of Mohandas K. Gandhi, the great apostle of nonviolence, Hindu mobs committed acts of unspeakable savagery against Muslims this spring.

title: Janitor at WNYC Is Accused Of Stealing Donor Information
description: A janitor at WNYC, the public radio station, has been charged with stealing a list of some of the station's donors and selling it to an identity-theft ring with widespread activities, authorities said yesterday.

title: Man Hurt in Robbery Dies
description: The employee of a handbag store who jumped out a fifth-floor window during an armed robbery on Tuesday died last night from his injuries, the police said.

title: Democrats Say Slow Meat Recall Threatened Consumers
description: A sluggish investigation by the Agriculture Department into evidence that tainted meat had entered the marketplace exposed thousands of consumers to potentially deadly bacteria, possibly contributing to some illnesses, members of Congress said yesterday.

title: Vaughn Gets in Step To Beat Cincinnati
description: Mo Vaughn had already failed twice with runners in scoring position last night. In the first inning with the bases loaded, he grounded into a double play, with a runner being thrown out at the plate. He struck out in the seventh with two men on against the former Met Bruce Chen.

title: School Set Aside for Hawaiians Ends Exclusion to Cries of Protest
description: The modern history of Hawaii is, in the view of many people here, a series of tragedies and crimes. The native population was decimated by Western diseases, its monarchy was overthrown by Western businessmen, and its culture and language were for generations actively suppressed.

title: To Keep The Peace, Study Peace
description: WHEN Ashutosh Varshney, a political scientist at the University of Michigan, decided to study ethnic violence, he ended up looking at something that most experts in the field don't: peaceful cities.

title: National Briefing: South
description: GEORGIA: AN EYEBROW-RAISING CAMPAIGN AD

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-5

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Red Tape Persists
description: Efforts by Russian government reformers to reduce red tape for small businesses have not succeeded, said German Gref, the minister of economy and trade, citing a new study by the Moscow-based Center for Economic and Financial Research. The study, a survey of 2,000 businesses in 20 Russian regions, found that companies have seen little improvement in business conditions since the state simplified the rules. Russia's economy is in its fourth year of growth, but economists say the growth is confined to large companies. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Kuehne Enjoys Smooth Sailing To Lead Through Two Rounds
description: On a day when some players complained about the bumpiness of the greens at Wykagyl Country Club, nothing seemed to bother Kelli Kuehne.

title: TV Wasteland
description: To the Editor:

title: Fool's Goal Is Race Favorite
description: After victories in three major races, Fool's Goal is the overwhelming 9-5 early favorite for tonight's $1 million Breeders Crown Trot at the Meadowlands. The race is the richest of the three Breeders crown events that will be staged.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Prince Ahmed bin Salman, a Saudi Arabian publisher who owned this year's Kentucky Derby winner, War Emblem, misstated the language in which one of his newspapers, Asharq al-Awsat, is published. It is Arabic, not English.

title: Giants Seek Fullback To Replace Comella
description: Tight end Jeremy Shockey is in Miami, still unsigned, but his influence looms large here, apparent each time the Giants' first-team offense prepares for a snap.

title: Jobs for New York, Performed in Ghana
description: To the Editor:

title: Joe Derise, 76, A Singer In Big Bands And Cabaret
description: Joe Derise, a former big band singer and a cabaret artist in New York for many years, died on June 24 in a hospice in Shelton, Conn. He was 76 and lived in Derby, Conn.

title: Brazil Employs Tools of Spying To Guard Itself
description: For as long as Brazil has been a nation, outlaws of every type, from gold smugglers and slave traders to drug traffickers and gun runners, have taken refuge in the Amazon, the world's largest jungle wilderness, secure in the knowledge that they could not be tracked down.

description: AUTO RACING

title: Russia to Go On Building Nuclear Reactors in Iran
description: The Russian government, brushing aside the Bush administration's concerns, indicated today that it planned to continue building new nuclear reactors in Iran like one that American officials have repeatedly warned could be used to develop nuclear weapons.

title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: MARYLAND: GUN SALES DROP

title: Clark Gesner, 64, the Creator Of 'Charlie Brown' Musical
description: Clark Gesner, the composer and lyricist of ''You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown,'' the good-natured and oft-produced musical based on the ''Peanuts'' comic strip, died on Tuesday on a visit to the Princeton Club in Manhattan, of which he was a member. He was 64.

title: A Fourth Trial Is Set In Torture of Louima
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn said yesterday that they planned to retry Charles Schwarz, the former police officer charged with taking part in the torture of Abner Louima in 1997.

title: Retreat That Became a Rout At the Spingold Knockout
description: One of the most exciting sessions in the history of the Spingold Knockout Team Championships was played here Thursday night at the the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, with four world-class teams in jeopardy in the final deals. One survived to reach the quarterfinal stage today, but three did not.

title: Broken Drill Slows Rescue Effort for 9 Coal Miners
description: Stymied through the day after a drill snapped off in the rescue shaft, emergency crews labored tonight to resume their way down toward nine trapped coal miners, with no new signal that the men were still alive in the air pocket where they fled on Wednesday as a flood burst in on them.

title: Yankees' Pitching Battered for 17 Hits, but Offense Provides a Lift
description: On nights like this, it seems as if the rock 'em, sock 'em modern game of baseball has caught up with the Yankees. They can play that style very well; their record is the best in the American League, and they have won 9 of 14 games since the All-Star Game break. But a team used to winning with pitching is having an identity crisis.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Key Arrest In Terror Killings
description: The police have arrested a 50-year-old ceramics merchant, Nikos Papanastasiou, suspected of orchestrating attacks by the terror group November 17. The police have said that another suspect, Pavlos Serifis, 46, has confessed to participation in the assassination of the C.I.A. station chief, Richard S. Welch, in 1975. The group's alleged mastermind, Alexandros Yiotopoulos, was also in police custody. Authorities believe the three men ambushed and killed Mr. Welch. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Ruling on Lumber Tariffs
description: GENEVA, July 27  A panel of World Trade Organization experts has held that the way the United States calculated tariffs on Canadian lumber does not conform with global trade rules. The United States imposed a 19.3 percent duty last August on $6 billion worth of Canadian pine, fir and spruce on the ground that Canadian sawmills were being subsidized by the government to undercut American competitors. The preliminary duty, which was the subject of today's ruling, was replaced by a final 27 percent duty, which Canada also challenged.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Economic Growth
description: Britain's economy grew at an annual rate of 1.5 percent in the second quarter, up from the first quarter's pace of 1.1 percent, powered by a recovery in the manufacturing industry, the government said. Growth was strong in manufacturing after a slump that has lasted more than two decades. The mining, energy and water industries also grew robustly, as did the services sector. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: BELLSOUTH REVISES FREE CASH FLOW DOWNWARD BY 21%
description: The BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter free cash flow was 21 percent less than previously reported because it reduced debt. The company, which provides local telephone service in nine Southeastern states, said free cash flow -- defined as cash flow from operations after capital expenditures -- was $1.1 billion. It had reported $1.4 billion previously, BellSouth said. The company, which is based in Atlanta, said the difference was a result of a redemption of $250 million of debentures on July 1.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: No Arrests Over Kursk Sinking
description: Russia closed its investigation into the sinking of the nuclear-powered submarine Kursk in the Barents Sea nearly two years ago, announcing that no one would face criminal charges because of the disaster, which killed all 118 men aboard. The country's top prosecutor, Vladimir V. Ustinov, said there were errors in the navy's rescue efforts and in the planning of the naval exercise that was under way when an explosion inside a dummy torpedo caused a second larger explosion that doomed the submarine. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: KOHLBERG KRAVIS IN $1.7 BILLION DEAL FOR SIEMENS UNITS
description: In its biggest European acquisition, the leveraged buyout firm of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company agreed yesterday to buy seven engineering units from Siemens A.G. for 1.69 billion euros ($1.7 billion). The Siemens units have sales of 3.5 billion euros and 22,800 employees, said Andrew Nicolls, a spokesman for Kohlberg Kravis. The businesses, including Mannesmann Plastics Machinery and a gas-spring manufacturer, Stabilus, will be put into a new company. Kohlberg Kravis will take control of the plastics unit, the Demag Cranes and Components division, Stabilus, Gottwald Port Technology and several other units.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: ECONOMIC GROWTH Britain's economy grew at an annual rate of 1.5 percent in the second quarter, up from the first quarter's pace of 1.1 percent, powered by a recovery in the manufacturing industry, the government said. Growth was strong in manufacturing after a slump that has lasted more than two decades. The mining, energy and water industries also grew robustly, as did the services sector.   Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, DOROTHY (DOLLY)
description: WASSERMAN - Dorothy (Dolly). 96, of Bensonhurst, died on July 25, 2002. Devoted wife of the late Mack Wasserman. Loving mother of Dr. Burton Wasserman and Deborah Greenberg. Revered mother-in-law of George Greenberg and June Wasserman. Beloved grandmother of Ronald Greenberg, Beth Denitz, Mark Wasserman and Jane Glass. Cherished great-grandmother of Jason, Andrew and Scott Greenberg; Lesley and Matthew Bender; Hannah and Samuel Denitz; Aaron and Rachel Wasserman; Maxwell Glass and Justin Goodman. Former President New York Chapter Cancer Care and A.W.V.S., and 40,000 plus hours as volunteer at Brooklyn VA Hospital, and Channel 1's New Yorker of the Week. A remarkable woman. Funeral services at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, July 28, 10:30 AM

title: Down and Out, but Still With a Spring in Her Step
description: The stage is littered with empty soda cans, dusty phonographs, articles of dowdy clothing and flung shoes. There is nothing quite so tawdry as used-up objects, and that applies as well to the lives of the stage space's three inhabitants. The irrepressible 33 Fainting Spells trio from Seattle provides the full picture in ''Dirty Work,'' a wildly illogical, hilarious and somewhat wearying piece presented Sunday night at the Performing Garage in SoHo.

title: His Horse Comes In, As Does His Ship
description: Sometimes tremendous fortune shows itself in the form of a speedy chestnut colt whose dam was meant to be a mother of champions rather than a racehorse scuffing along at the bottom claiming levels of modest tracks. Ask James Jones. He is a blacksmith by trade, a brilliant one, say the breeders and the trainers on the Kentucky circuit, where he has been shoeing horses for 29 years.

title: Fehr Discusses Labor Issues With Mets and Reds Players
description: Don Fehr had the labor relations version of a two-a-day yesterday: he met with the Cincinnati Reds for about two hours at a Midtown hotel in the morning, then met with the Mets for about two hours at Shea Stadium in the afternoon. Fehr, the executive director of the Players Association, is meeting with players on all 30 major league teams, which is a precursor to setting a strike date.

title: So Few Agencies, So Many Official Seats Unfilled
description: Though a tide of corporate scandals has pushed Congress to reassert its oversight powers, experts and government officials say that several federal regulatory agencies remain crippled by deficits of personnel and enforcement ability.

title: L.I. Man Accused of Impersonating a Doctor
description: Prosecutors charged a Long Island man yesterday with assault and impersonating a doctor after he performed liposuction and cosmetic surgery on the abdomen of a 34-year-old Queens woman, who they said suffered ''severe scarring and disfiguration'' as a result.

title: To Cooperstown With Glove, the Wizard
description: It wasn't so much that Ozzie Smith, the shortstop nonpareil, made spectacular plays on sure base hits, it was more that he ambushed the ball.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, BERTRAM
description: KATZ-Bertram on July 25, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Florence. Loving father of Norman and the late Steven. Dear father-in-law of Gail and Bonnie. Adoring grandfather of Aimee, Michael, Alison and Jaime. Service Sunday 11:30am at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: From Colombia, Music Of Both Terror and Joy
description: The yellow, blue and red of the Colombian flag blanketed Madison Square Garden last Saturday night at ''Pa' Colombia: Un Canto por la Paz,'' billed as the first all-Colombian concert at the arena. Nine leading Colombian bands played salsa, rock and the accordion bounce of the cumbia in a show that merged Colombian patriotism with recognition of the toll taken by civil strife.

title: Sports of The Times; A Long Shot To Become A Jet Receiver
description: HERMAN EDWARDS was in midseason form yesterday as the Jets reported to training camp, his second as head coach.

title: Alliant Energy's Net Falls
description: Alliant Energy, which owns utilities in four Midwest states, said today that its profit fell 83 percent, citing higher costs and a drop in business from units that sell power in Brazil and oil and natural gas.

title: Senate Confirms U.S. Attorney Six Months After Nomination
description: The United States Senate has confirmed the appointment of Roslynn R. Mauskopf as United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York, ending a selection process that highlighted a struggle between Gov. George E. Pataki and Senator Charles E. Schumer over federal nominees.

title: Buying real estate in Japan : An investment you can live with
description: TOKYO  For Japan-based expatriates who enjoy company-paid housing, buying a local property is usually a distant thought. But for long-term residents with large sums of yen savings, real estate that produces a rich yield shows its luster, especially given Japan's zero interest-rate environment.

title: Del Mar Show Wins Handicap
description: Jerry Bailey, aboard Del Mar Show, took advantage of a dawdling pace and outdueled Shaun Bridgemohan aboard Volponi to win the Bernard Baruch Handicap today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the front page of Business Day yesterday included an erroneous cross-reference to SportsFriday in some copies. The sports pages were in Section D; the cross-reference to pages in Section C was intended for the newspaper's national edition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLYE, CACILIA
description: BLYE-Cacilia. On July 25, 2002, at age 88. Beloved wife of the late David Blye. Adoring sister of Joschi. Devoted mother of Eve and Ellen. Honored mother-in-law of Fred and Elliot. Loving grandmother of Audrey, Rebecca, Rachel and Emily. Cherished great-grandmother of Noah. Services Monday, 11 AM, at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Ave, corner 91st St, NYC.

title: Russian Tea Room to Close After Tomorrow's Dinner
description: The Russian Tea Room, that storied preserve of infused vodka, glinting caviar and buttery blini that was for decades a clubby watering hole for the city's bolderati, announced its closing yesterday, less than three years after its spectacular but ill-fated $30 million renovation.

title: Jobs for New York, Performed in Ghana
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Observer; Finally, Let's Train a Generation of Women Electricians
description: One of my least favorite high school memories -- right up there with nearly flunking 10th-grade geometry -- involves my two semesters taking home economics. This was the required course in sewing, cooking, social etiquette and smart supermarket shopping to which girls of my era were routinely subjected while the boys in our grade took an introductory shop class.

title: Ex-Tyco Chief May Have Deferred Taxes on Stock Option Profits
description: The former chairman of Tyco International Ltd., L. Dennis Kozlowski, may have deferred taxes on $208 million in stock option profits using a technique that is under Internal Revenue Service scrutiny.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Industrial Surge
description: Industrial production in Singapore rose 4.7 percent in the first half of this year, led by a 73.1 percent increase in pharmaceutical output. Economists said the jump in drug production, which more than doubled in June compared with the month in 2001, was evidence that the government's nearly $4 billion effort to turn Singapore into a biotechnology hub was paying off. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: UNITED NEAR EUROPEAN APPROVAL FOR AIRLINE ALLIANCE
description: The European commission is about to approve an alliance among United Airlines, Lufthansa and SAS, after the companies volunteered to surrender take-off and landing slots at Frankfurt airport, an official said. Their offer concerns routes from Frankfurt to Washington, Chicago, Los Angeles and San Francisco. The European Union executive also said it would approve a similar alliance between Northwest and the Dutch airline KLM, even though those airlines did not offer to give up any slots. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PERFORMANCE FOOD GROUP CO., Richmond, Va., a supplier of food products to hotels, schools and restaurants, bought Thoms-Proestler Co., Rock Island, Ill., a food distributor, for about $95 million in cash and stock. Performance Food could pay up to $7 million more if certain operating targets are achieved in the next two years.

title: A Cow's Life: Many Moos, and Moods
description: To the Editor:

title: Divers Discover Bones in Wreck Of the Monitor
description: Navy divers have found two old bones, which appear to be human, aboard the wreck of the Civil War ironclad Monitor where it sank 140 years ago off Cape Hatteras, N.C., federal officials said yesterday.

title: Daughter to Continue Fight to Have Williams Cremated
description: The older daughter of Ted Williams said yesterday that a note signed by her father that said he wanted to be cryonically preserved would not deter her campaign to have his body cremated.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SINGAPORE: INDUSTRIAL SURGE Industrial production in Singapore rose 4.7 percent in the first half of this year, led by a 73.1 percent increase in pharmaceutical output. Economists said the jump in drug production, which more than doubled in June compared with the month in 2001, was evidence that the government's nearly $4 billion effort to turn Singapore into a biotechnology hub was paying off.   Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: In 1941, Too, a Wounded, Unprepared America Cast About for Blame
description: A devastating sneak attack that killed and wounded more than 3,000 Americans. Revelations of intelligence failures and ineptitude. Outraged demands for an independent investigation.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 27 about a summer camp for gifted musical students misstated the name of a university that is home to a cello program. It is Indiana University; there is no University of Indiana.

title: Wary About the Economy, Consumers Spend With Extreme Caution
description: Kim Haack, 45, a federal government worker playing golf at Davenport's Duck Creek municipal course, has been stung enough by the stock market's plunge to hunker down.

title: When Princeton Snoops on Yale
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Agency For Children Is Shaken Anew By an Arrest
description: The Florida Department of Children and Families was hit today by yet another damaging disclosure with the news that a child welfare worker had been arrested on suspicion of drunken driving while transporting a 7-month-old girl.

title: Pressure on Companies Using Tax Dodge
description: Pressure on companies that acquire a Bermuda mailbox as part of a strategy to earn tax-free profits in the United States increased yesterday with the California state treasurer and the president of the top labor organization attacking the moves.

title: Polls of Consumers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Sunny Side of the Street
description: What I'm about to propose reminds me slightly of the final scene in ''The Life of Brian,'' in which the faux messiah and his followers, hanging crucified on a row of crosses, burst into happy song: ''Always look on the bri-ight side of life!'' But you don't really have to be in a Monty Python mood to think that the cascade of grim tidings from Wall Street is, in many ways, good for us.

title: The State of Puerto Rico
description: More than three million Americans -- some 800,000 of them New Yorkers -- have roots in Puerto Rico, but to many other Americans the island is an enigma, a place where they are likely to take their passports, which are not needed, but not a knowledge of Spanish, which often is. So it comes as little surprise that as Puerto Rico marked a milestone this week with official fanfare attended by Mayor Michael Bloomberg and a New York City contingent, there was little notice of the event on the mainland.

title: July Confidence Number Revised Upward
description: Consumer confidence fell less in July than previously estimated, according to a University of Michigan survey that shows that Americans may not let tumbling stock prices completely dim their view of the economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOON, JOSEPH R., JR
description: KOON-Joseph R., Jr, passed away July 24, 2002 at the age of 64. Born Janary 24, 1938, he had been a former 56 year resident of New York City. He is survived by his wife Iderlina Acosta, children William Koon, Elizabeth Koon and Christopher T. Koon, and two granddaughters. Service will be held Tuesday July 30, 3pm at the Green Hills Memorial Chapel in Rancho Palos Verdes, CA. Green Hills Mortuary, 310-831-0311.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page article on Monday reported an Iranian defector's assertion that the Iranian government carried out the bombing of a Jewish community center in Buenos Aires in 1994, which killed 85 people, and paid President Carlos Sal Menem $10 million to cover up Iran's involvement. The article, based on independent reporting by The Times, omitted the fact that The Forward, the New York Jewish weekly, had previously published articles about the defector's assertions. The Times's correspondent was not aware of them.

title: Komiyama Is Back in Majors
description: The Mets recalled the right-hander Satoru Komiyama from Class AAA Norfolk yesterday and designated the left-hander Bobby Jones for assignment, exchanging long relievers.

title: Rally Lets Dow and S.&P. 500 Finish Up for the Week
description: Stocks rallied in the last hour and a half yesterday and the push was enough to assure that both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose for the day and finished higher for the week.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Call To Investigate Menem
description: The government's anticorruption commission has requested a new criminal investigation of the former president, Carlos Menem, for ''malicious omission'' by hiding a bank account in Switzerland. A defector from Iran's intelligence agency has said Mr. Menem was paid $10 million in such an account to cover up Iran's involvement in the 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center in Buenos Aires. If convicted of the banking charge, Mr. Menem, who is now a candidate for president, would be prohibited from holding public office. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNURMAN, ELIZABETH
description: SCHNURMAN-Elizabeth, 96. On July 23, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Lester. Aunt of Carol, Frances and Will. Great aunt to Jessica, Naomi, Alexandra and David. Founding Member of East End Temple, dedicated teacher. Service Sunday, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Little Progress Made On Revenue Sharing
description: Money and structure. Those are the two elements of revenue sharing that separate major league baseball's owners and players, and they are the elements that have commanded the negotiators' attention much of this week.

title: Hospital Drops Legal Action To Stem Tide of Bad Publicity
description: Bridgeport Hospital withdrew a lawsuit today that it had filed on Wednesday against a man whose wife died in 1997 from an infection she contracted during cardiac surgery at the hospital. The quick withdrawal of the suit suggested that legal action intended to relieve a public relations headache had created a public relations nightmare instead.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: ARGENTINA: CALL TO INVESTIGATE MENEM The government's anticorruption commission has requested a new criminal investigation of the former president, Carlos Menem, for "malicious omission" by hiding a bank account in Switzerland. A defector from Iran's intelligence agency has said Mr. Menem was paid $10 million in such an account to cover up Iran's involvement in the 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center in Buenos Aires. If convicted of the banking charge, Mr. Menem, who is now a candidate for president, would be prohibited from holding public office. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: PRESIDENT PUSHES TRADE LEGISLATION IN VISIT TO CAPITOL
description: Hours after House and Senate negotiators reached a surprise breakthrough on a broad trade bill, President Bush made a rare visit to the Capitol today to rally House Republicans behind the measure, which he said was essential for economic growth.

title: Clemens May Return Soon
description: Roger Clemens, who has been on the disabled list since July 13 with a tight right groin, will test the injury in a Class A game on Saturday night in Tampa. An injury-free performance would most likely signal Clemens's return to the Yankees.

title: In Iraq, Taking Steps on a Road to Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Captured Qaeda Member Gives Details on Group's Operations
description: A member of Al Qaeda who was involved in plans to blow up the United States Embassy in Singapore is providing federal authorities with important new details about that plot and other aspects of the Qaeda terrorist group's operations, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: When culture has wheels : On foreign roads, just go with the flow
description: PARIS  Why drive in Europe? Some travelers prefer to take a train, plane, hovercraft, riverboat  anything to avoid the Continent's tangle of differing rules, signs and behaviors. After all, Europe offers cheap, comfortable rail travel and, as of recently, bargain airfares. But with a few pointers, driving in Europe can become much less of an obstacle course.

title: Circular Logic; Sure, They're Fun, but Revolving Doors Also Have a Higher Purpose
description: New Yorkers move fast. They like their subways flying, their taxis racing and their doors spinning.

title: Mayor, in Dominican Republic, Visits a Hospital and a Ballpark
description: On the second leg of a whirlwind Caribbean trip, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg touched down here with a bevy of Latino politicians in the first visit by a New York mayor to the island nation's second city.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Mayor's Name Off Ballot
description: The District of Columbia Board of Elections removed Mayor Anthony A. Williams' name from the ballot for the Democratic primary in September, forcing him to run as a write-in or independent candidate. The board cited questions about the gathering of signatures for his petition, said Tony Bullock, the mayor's spokesman. Campaign organizers have said that they could not get volunteers to collect signatures, and were instead forced to hire people, paying them $1 for every signature.

title: A Growing Gap in American Democracy
description: Two years ago the world watched as officials in Florida struggled to explain the mishaps and shoddy practices that had denied thousands of Floridians a chance to vote. They focused on butterfly ballots and hanging chads, but neglected a critical part of the problem: over half a million Florida residents had been prevented from voting by a state law that permanently disenfranchises almost anyone ever convicted of a felony, even those who haven't committed a crime since serving their terms, have jobs and are paying taxes. For like many Southern states, Florida had cemented felony disenfranchisement into its constitution in the post-Civil War years, when legislators were using any means to keep the vote in white hands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVKIN, SAUL
description: RIVKIN-Saul. Passed away peacefully on July 24, 2002. Beloved husband of Joan, loving father of Richard and Andrew, adored grandfather of Amanda, Alexander, Harris, Eric and Elana, and special father-in-law of Jane and Laura. A memorial service will be held at 11:45 AM, on Sunday, July 28, Temple Sinai, 425 Roslyn Rd, Roslyn Heights, NY.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Interest Rate Lowered
description: The Swiss National Bank acted to curb the rise in the value of the franc by lowering its benchmark interest rate for the second time this year. The central bank reduced the target range for the three-month rate to 0.075 percent from 1.25 percent, citing increasing signs in Switzerland and abroad of a delay in economic recovery. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Federal Judge Grants More Time in ImClone Insider Trading Case
description: A federal judge yesterday gave prosecutors and defense lawyers two more weeks to try to reach a plea agreement that would resolve insider trading charges against Samuel D. Waksal, the former chief executive of ImClone Systems.

title: Firefighters Hopeful About Sequoias
description: Five days after a camper cooking hot dogs apparently set off a vast fire that threatened to engulf some of the world's tallest and oldest trees, fire officials appeared close today to overpowering the flames in the most critical area of the blaze.

title: New Sentence Is Ordered For Teacher In Abuse Case
description: A New Jersey appeals court today threw out a probation sentence and ordered a new sentencing hearing for a former teacher who sexually assaulted a 13-year-old student.

title: Portugal Faces Sanctions Over Deficit
description: Europe's monetary union is facing one of its first major tests, as Portugal disclosed late Thursday that its budget deficit had soared above the limit set by the European Union.

title: Clintons Ask for Millions From U.S. in Whitewater Legal Fees
description: Former President Bill Clinton and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York have asked a special three-judge panel to order the United States government to reimburse them for several million dollars in outstanding legal fees from the Whitewater inquiry.

title: Federal Judge Sets 4th Trial For Schwarz
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn said yesterday that they planned to retry Charles Schwarz, the former police officer charged with taking part in the torture of Abner Louima, and a judge scheduled what would be Mr. Schwarz's fourth trial for September.

title: A Sudden Rush To Declare Bankruptcy Is Expected
description: With Congress close to final approval of a bill supported by the White House to overhaul the bankruptcy system, lawyers and consumers groups today predicted a rush of bankruptcy filings by people seeking to erase their credit card bills and other debts before the tougher rules take effect.

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article yesterday about traveling in Egypt misidentified the group held responsible for attacks on tourists there in the 1990's. It was not the Muslim Brotherhood. The Islamic Group claimed responsibility for the attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKERY, EUGENE X.
description: BERKERY-Eugene X. Age 74, of Southbury, CT, died July 26, 2002, in Bethel, CT. He worked as a Vice President for Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, and served in the Army during WWII. Survivors include his wife Margaret (nee Lynch) Berkery, sons Eugene X. Berkery II, of Garden City, NY, Peter Berkery of Center Port, NY, Richard Kiehn of Greensboro, NC, and David Kiehn of Rockville Centre, NY; daughters Betty Fahey of Madison, CT, Lauretta Dustin of Scottsdale, AZ, Carol Kirkey of Oneonta, NY, and Janet Kiehn of Norwalk, CT; one brother Paul Berkery of Laguna Beach, CA, and nine grandchildren. Funeral Mass Tuesday, July 30, 10 AM, at Sacred Heart Church, 900 Main St South, Southbury, CT. Burial with military honors at Sacred Heart Cemetery. Calling hours Sunday and Monday, July 28 and 29, 7-9 PM, at Munson-Lovetere Funeral Home, 235 Main St North, Southbury, CT.

title: Costs of Targeting Civilians
description: The Israeli government's decision to launch an assassination raid on the Gaza City residence of Sheikh Salah Shehada, leader of the military arm of the Palestinian group Hamas, brought immediate and widespread condemnation not only from Muslims but from Western leaders (including the Bush administration) and even elements of the Israeli government. The reason was not Mr. Shehada's death -- he was a senior participant in suicide attacks against Israel -- but the fact that the Israeli military and Prime Minister Ariel Sharon understood that the attack in a densely populated neighborhood, at night, would result in many civilian deaths. The raid was nonetheless ordered -- and the world received its clearest demonstration yet that the Israeli government is prepared to knowingly inflict substantial civilian casualties in its response to Palestinian suicide attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, HERBERT
description: COHN-Herbert. Of McLean, Virginia. On July 26, 2002, at the age of 89. Beloved husband of Kathryn. Brother of Gilbert Corwin and the late Melvin Cohn. Cherished father of Elizabeth Kark Singer (Sanford) and adored grandfather of Robert Charles Kark (Renee) and Michael David Singer. From the sidewalks of New York City, he graduated from Yale and Harvard Law School. At 26, he was caught up in the excitement of New Deal Washington. He joined the SEC in 1936 and won immediate renown by preparing the briefs in the stop order action against the Oklahoma and Texas Trust Company of Denver. Later winning out before the Colorado Circuit Court. He served as a Naval Officer in England during World War II and became an articulate spokesperson for the American Electric Power Company and the electric utility industry. The entire electric utility industry happily soon found him as its spokesperson through the NAEC Edison Electric Institute, and a number of ad hoc groups such as the industry's Clean Air Coordinating Committee of recent vintage. Also, he is a charter member and former Chairperson of EEIS prestigous legal committee. He retired from AEP as Vice Chairperson and Vice President and/or Director of twenty of its subsiding companies to return to Washington where he was of counsel at Morgan Lewis and Bockius and Newman Holtzinger up until a year or two before his death. Funeral services will be held in Cleveland, Ohio, at Berkowitz-Kumin-Bookatz Memorial Chapel (800-448-2210), Sunday, July 28, at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions are suggested to the Jewish National Fund or the organization of your choice.

title: Princeton Investigates Breach Of Web Site for Yale Applicants
description: Princeton University moved quickly yesterday to investigate who at the university had improperly gained access to a Yale computer system for admissions.

title: Minor Leagues Hit the Mark
description: A spiritual touchstone to small-town America, minor league baseball has approached record highs in attendance this summer.

description: YACHNES - Eleanor. So many conversations with family and friends still include, ''what would Eleanor say about this?'' We miss you

description: COPLON-Amy. A true woman of valour. In gratitude for service to all. The Martin Tananbaum Foundation Janet de Winter Elbert Brodsky Florence Levine Barbara Degorge Minnie Tananbaum Minna Levine Maggie Hoffman Ari Degorge

description: The police here have arrested two New Jersey priests, including the former head of a Roman Catholic high school for boys, and charged them with soliciting sex from minors, church officials in Newark said today.

title: Hard to Break
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Wall Street Waves Are a Riptide to Some, a Ripple to Others
description: They winced in affluent Westchester, they shrugged on 125th Street in Harlem, and in suburban New Jersey they headed for the mall, though with a slight buzz of unease and a keen eye for bargains.

description: Senator Robert Torricelli could have had a busy week last week.

description: It is Saturday night in this hardscrabble city of idle shoemaking factories, and the place is jumping.

title: July 21-27: INTERNATIONAL; HEART TROUBLE
description: Judges in charge of Slobodon Milosevic's war crimes trial said that three physicians had found that the former Yugoslav president had a severe heart condition combined with high blood pressure, which put him at risk of a heart attack. The judges said they would take steps to reduce Mr. Milosevic's workload and protect his health. Marlise Simons

title: New Zealand's Premier Wins 2nd Term, but Not Total Control
description: Prime Minister Helen Clark won a second term for her center-left government in general elections today. But four conservative opposition parties drew away enough votes to frustrate her effort to win an outright parliamentary majority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSKIN, DORIS BLOCH
description: MOSKIN-Doris Bloch. 75, resident of Hartsdale, NY, beloved mother of Mark, David and Nancy and grandmother of Isaac, Lillian and Mae Rose, died suddenly July 24th at White Plains Hospital. Born in Stuttgart, Germany, she was brought to England and then to the United States as a child. She graduated from Queens College. Served as Chairman of the Board of the Scarsdale (NY) Adult School. Also survived by her former husband, J. Robert Moskin. Graveside service at Westchester Hills Cemetery, Ardsley, NY, at 2 PM, Sunday.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Kimberly Aaron, Joshua Block
description: Kimberly Paige Aaron, the daughter of Harriet and Allan Aaron of Trumbull, Conn., is to be married today to Joshua Samuel Block, a son of Susan Block and Rabbi Richard A. Block of Shaker Heights, Ohio. The bridegroom's father, who is the senior rabbi at Temple-Tifereth Israel in Cleveland, is to officiate at the Great River Golf Club in Milford, Conn.

title: The Nation; Be Afraid, Be Very Afraid
description: GIVEN the tightening of aviation security, a short hop in the friendly skies could soon feel like a trip through the Wild West on a Wells Fargo stagecoach. Federal marshals are riding shotgun. Members of Congress want to see pilots carrying guns. The government is putting armed guards at ticket counters and other crowded areas in airports following the July 4 shooting in Los Angeles International Airport that ended in three deaths.

title: Developers Favored But Not Books
description: To the Editor:

title: A Negligee for Murals In a Harlem Courthouse
description: In 1936, when the country was in the grip of the Depression and artists were focusing on socially conscious themes, a pair of murals commissioned by the federal Works Progress Administration were installed in a turn-of-the-century Victorian Gothic courthouse on 121st Street in Harlem. The murals, by David Karfunkle, depicted images of conquistadors and slavery, and included two exposed breasts.

title: CAMDEN AID
description: Governor McGreevey last week signed legislation that would give $175 million in aid to Camden, the state's poorest city. The bill also gave the governor veto power over the city school board's hiring and spending and replaced the nine-member elected board with three elected members, three members appointed by the governor and three appointed by the mayor. The Camden Board of Education last week filed a lawsuit, charging that the bill unconstitutionally stripped the power of elected school board officials. Jo Piazza

title: Keeping Peace on the Open Road
description: August is the peak month -- for that familiar vacation refrain: Are we there yet? This time, restless travelers can ward off boredom on the road with a range of cleverly designed and packaged travel games made for children and adults.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LABINGER, MARVIN
description: LABINGER-Marvin, Rabbi. We mourn with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague. He served for thirty years as a career chaplain in the United States Air Force and retired with the rank of colonel in 1990 when he assumed the position of Executive Director of the Pacific Southwest region of the United Synagogue of Conservative Judaism until his retirement in 2000. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Joette, children Gila Freeberg and Zev and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Reuven Hammer, Pres. Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. V.P. Rabbinical Assembly

description: CHRIS MAIER was not much different from many other college students when he went to Disneyland for the first time. The kingdom was pure magic.

description: It was a muggy Monday morning when Snowflake took the plunge. The 4-year-old Siberian husky went bounding into the pool, where a dozen other dogs were already dunking and, yes, dog-paddling in the cool, murky water.

Michael Dominic's ''Sunshine Hotel,'' about one of the last Bowery flophouses, will be shown Friday at 1 p.m. And Peter Sutherland gets some of the city's lightning-fast bike messengers to slow down for his camera in ''Pedal'' (in photo), Aug. 12 at 9 p.m.

title: Home Front; On Wall Street, Present Is Prologue
description: Wall Street continues in feverish, nervous malaise. Its pulse keeps going up to 120 under hourly rumors of defalcation int his or that great corporation, railroad, or others. Faith in financial agents is gone. Every treasurer and cashier is ''suspect,'' and no wonder after the recent epidemic of fraud.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, HARRY
description: WALKER - Harry. Beloved husband of the late Betty. Dearest father of Sandra and Howard, and Marion and Sid Cohen. Darling Poppy of Terri, Melissa, Robert and Liza Cohen, Jonathan, Bridget, Samuel and Stacey Walker. Loving great-grandfather of Ava and Benjamin Cohen. Devoted brother and uncle. He had the strength of a lion and the heart of a lamb. Most of all, he will be remembered for his sweetness and gentleness to all who knew him. May the beautiful example of his life continue to inspire and guide us.

title: Villas and Cottages Rated in Newsletter
description: A new source of information for travelers seeking to rent a cottage or a castle in Europe is the 12-page Countryside Vacation Newsletter, which published its first issue in May and plans to publish five issues a year.

description: KOBA THE DREAD

title: Personal Business; Class-Action Lawsuits Gain Strength on the Web
description: MOST people have heard about the big class-action settlements with the tobacco companies, or other cases involving silicone breast implants and the diet drug combination fen-phen. But there are many more, lesser-known cases out there: by some accounts, at least 10,000 class-action suits are filed each year, and billions of dollars are ultimately awarded to consumers.

title: A Guided Audio Tour of Greenport via Cellphone
description: STEVE BULL is yanking historic Greenport straight into the age of modern technology. He's doing it with a cell-phone audio tour of this 164-year-old village known for its old-fashioned carousel and vintage homes.

title: Estrogen, After a Fashion
description: I am quite sure I am not the only one who has noticed this, but those low, snug jeans that Britney Spears wears with such authority do not flatter anyone else. Still, that is the style of the day, and there is nothing to do but watch the parade of hips and stomachs and wait for them to pass. Whatever is awful in fashion will eventually go away (fashion writers are heralding high-waisted pants for fall), and then, just as reliably, it will return.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about EarthShell, a maker of biodegradable packaging, misstated the business of a prospective customer, Sodexho. That company provides food services to corporations, colleges and other institutions; it does not distribute packaging. The article also misstated the year when Vincent J. Truant, now EarthShell's president and chief operating officer, first joined the company. It was 1998, not 2001.

title: Coleen Kuehn, Robert Malin
description: Coleen Patricia Kuehn, a daughter of Kathleen Moriarty Kuehn and Ronald L. Kuehn Jr., both of Birmingham, Ala., was married yesterday to Robert Lassiter Malin, the son of Gail Lassiter Malin and Robert A. Malin of Summit, N.J. The Rev. Christopher Brdlik performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church in Summit.

title: Sketching, For a Change, On Screen
description: STEVEN SODERBERGH shot to prominence in 1989, when a small, intimate film he had written and directed, ''Sex, Lies and Videotape,'' became a runaway hit. Its success helped to establish the box-office viability of independent films and also to propel a fledgling New York-based film distributor, Miramax, into the major leagues.

title: A Disturbing Jewelry Artist With the Midas Touch
description: THE gold potato not Yukon, but 22-karat -- is a lumpy oval studded with tiny slivers of black coral that bear a disturbing resemblance to mouse droppings. It is contradictory and perverse; it arouses disgust and admiration; it is beautiful.

title: Police to Form Task Forces To Address 9/11 Review
description: The Police Department plans to create seven internal task forces to address problems that were uncovered by a consultant's review of the department's response to the Sept. 11 attack, according to a draft of the study.

title: The Great Wet Way
description: IT was one of those oven-baked days in midsummer when the roaring heat seems to suck the oxygen right out of the air and abduct thought itself. Plans melt, appointments evaporate, and everyone from the FedEx guy to the meter maid is cursing the tyranny of the sun as it trips a primal urge to go soak oneself.

title: An Industry Balancing Danger and Safety
description: JUST down the Hudson River from the Indian Point nuclear plant, noisily besieged by protesters who want it closed and regulators who scrutinize its safety, a chemical business with safety issues of its own is feeling like something of a wallflower.

title: A Name? Bodega Is a Bodega Is a Bodega
description: Finding the Johannis Grocery in Bushwick, Brooklyn, is easy. Just head to the corner of Jefferson Street and Bushwick Avenue and look for the sign that says ''San Miguel Grocery.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPEL, JOHN W.
description: APPEL-John W. July 26, 2002. Dr. John W. Appel, age 91, formerly of Radnor, PA. Husband of Marian K. Appel. Also survived by his children Deborah Appel Chomiw, Kenneth G. Appel, Lydia Appel Forbes and five grandchildren. Funeral services will be held 12 noon, July 31, 2002, at St. Martin's Church, 400 King of Prussia Road, Radnor, PA. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Monadnock Conservancy, PO Box 337, Keene, NH 03431-0337.

title: Dana Crosley, John Naberezny

Rabbi Shimon Berris officiated at the Hilton Rye Town in Rye Brook, N.Y., where the Rev. Francis Maione, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

description: INTERMITTENT closures of the pool at Hommocks Middle School here have left thousands of Mamaroneck, Larchmont and Rye Neck residents hot and unhappy.

title: What's Love Got to Do With It?
description: WHEN the Broadway gypsies joined in the refrain of ''What I Did for Love,'' the hit ballad from ''A Chorus Line,'' they were singing about why a dancer dances. The prolific playwright Joe Pintauro takes the title from there to nowhere.

title: Frankel Is a Big Winner on a Day of Close Calls
description: He has won a single Breeders' Cup race and is still searching for his first Triple Crown victory, but Bobby Frankel may as well place a lawn chair in the winner's circle at Saratoga. He is there a lot. Last summer, he won 10 of 21 races here, with six victories coming in graded stakes.

title: What Happened to Uncle Shmiel?
description: In the 1980's, I returned with my father, who survived Auschwitz and Dachau, to his small village of Ricse, Hungary, hoping also to ''get as close as possible to a terrible crime.'' My father's uncle was Adolf Zukor, founder of Paramount Studios. He made it to the United States in the 1920's, but the rest of his family remained in Hungary. My father lost three younger sisters (all under the age of 10) and his oldest brother, age 21, along with both of his parents. He was 15 when the Jews of Ricse were marched down the street toward the transport trains, to jeers and taunts. That is all the detail he was willing to give us.

title: Investing; As the Dollar Slumps, Whither the Stock Market?
description: AFTER two years of almost relentless decline, the United States stock market has a new source of distress: a falling dollar.

title: Simone Powlis, Robert Cosgrove
description: Simone Tara Powlis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Powlis of Merion, Pa., was married yesterday to Robert James Cosgrove, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Cosgrove of Pelham, N.Y. Msgr. Thomas P. Leonard performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy Trinity in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, ROSE
description: COHEN-Rose. My beloved Grandma. I miss you every day. Freya

description: Rescue workers broke through a coal-mine wall to nine trapped miners and found them all alive and well and aching to be rescued after three days of fighting for survival in a pocket of air in their flooded mine.

title: Harvesting the First Crop of Enron Tales

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 23 about Peter Manso's book ''Ptown: Art, Sex and Money on the Outer Cape,'' misstated the publication dates of two biographies by Mr. Manso. One, ''Mailer: His Life and Times,'' was published in 1985, not 1986, and the other, ''Brando: The Biography,'' in 1994, not 1984. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: MetroStars Come Up Empty on Both Sides of Ball Against Fire

title: Corrections

Because of a 1997 ruling by an appeals court in the First Judicial Department, the obligation does not apply in Manhattan and the Bronx.

title: Death Still Certain, but Taxes May Be Subject to a Loophole

title: What Happened to Uncle Shmiel?
description: Reading Daniel Mendelsohn's article (July 14), I had the thought that one way to quantify the horror of the Holocaust for those who did not experience it is to express it in terms of the Sept. 11 tragedy. Doing the math, the loss of six million lives in the Holocaust is roughly equal to twice the death toll of the World Trade Towers every day for three years. Given the global reaction to the events of Sept. 11, it can perhaps be more easily understood why the Holocaust has generated such relentless analysis.

title: LOTTERY REVENUE
description: Revenue from the 32-year-old New Jersey lottery topped $2 billion for the first time in fiscal year 2002, which ended June 30, lottery officials announced last week. That was an increase of nearly 15 percent over the previous year. Of the $2.07 billion in total sales, $1.14 billion was paid out in winnings. Another $753 million went to education programs and state institutions and $113.5 million was paid in commissions to retailers who sell tickets. The most popular games were the instant games, which generated $773.67 million in sales, and the Pick 3, which generated $456.3 million. Karen DeMasters

title: The Children's Department

But when we heard that thongs were being pitched to 7-year-old girls at the mall, well, it had all gone a bit far. Here on Planet Fashion we are looking for lifers. If children are (silver-) spoon-fed fashion too early, we run the risk that all they'll want is sackcloth by the time they reach style maturity.

description: Two major regulatory agencies have agreed on a margin requirement for trading in single-stock futures, clearing the way for the start of the new vehicles.

The Bronxville-based construction and management company will build 49 rental apartments where the Scarsdale Plaza Theater -- which once featured vaudeville acts and silent movies -- presided for 70 years.

title: July 21-27: ECONOMY; THE PERP WALK
description: John J. Rigas, the 78 year-old founder of the bankrupt cable operator Adelphia Communications and two of his sons were arrested and taken away in handcuffs last week on charges that they looted the company of more than $1 billion. It is one of the largest cases of corporate fraud ever. Prosecutors, who accused the Rigases of using the company as their ''personal piggy bank,'' said they illegally used corporate funds to buy hundreds of millions of dollars of stock, to build a $13 million golf course and to shuttle family members back and forth from a safari vacation in Africa. Andrew Ross Sorkin

description: In a fierce political family feud, President Bush's senior adviser, Karl Rove, has been pressuring Republican lawmakers from farm states not to ease restrictions on travel to Cuba.

description: The Rev. Viorel Dumitrescu says he is a God-fearing pastor and former torture victim who only wants to build a home for his immigrant congregation in a former knitting factory. But the city's Department of Buildings says that in pursuing his goal, he authorized construction without a permit and illegally operated single room occupancy apartments.

title: Relievers Squander Strong Start By Leiter
description: Al Leiter knew he was running out of pitches, so he wanted every last one to mean something. When Adam Dunn checked his swing on a two-strike, two-out curveball in the sixth inning yesterday, Leiter appealed for a strike, even though he knew a begging pitcher is often teased by the opposing players.

title: Airline Food Still in Flux
description: WHEN airlines began cutting back on food service last fall, some analysts predicted it would be only a matter of time before competitive pressures forced a return of the foil-wrapped entree, or some approximation of it. The analysts were right -- sort of.

title: Taking a Chance When There's Nothing at Stake
description: SITTING in a director's chair while make-up is dabbed on his nose, Ben Affleck gets ready for a flurry of television interviews, sips a fruit smoothie through a straw and does what he has come here to do: spin low expectations for the fate of ''Push, Nevada,'' the risky new ABC series he helped create, produce and write. He may wear a red leather superhero's costume in the movie he is shooting, ''Daredevil,'' but at the semi-annual convention of television critics and reporters, which ended on Friday, he wears an executive's suit and tie to explain why he is television's biggest underdog.

title: Peru's Leader Is Struggling As Popularity Falls Sharply

title: Congressional Memo; Bush Claims Victory, If Not Credit, As Deadline Breaks Deadlock on Hill
description: Congress always needs a deadline to overcome its normal state of inertia.

title: Wholesale Name-Dropping
description: IF we baby boomers have been criticized for anything, it is our tendency to live the high life. If we can afford nice things, we buy them. Why stay at a hotel when a resort is nearby? Why watch television on a little screen? We traded our sedans for sport utility vehicles, then got rid of the first models when the luxury carmakers jumped in. Now BMW, Mercedes and even Porsche, for goodness' sake, are putting such powerful engines into their sport utility vehicles that drivers can have it all -- an S.U.V. that is also a sports car. Did they do that just for us?

title: When Water Comes From a Well
description: FOR city dwellers and most suburban homeowners, it might come as a surprise that there are more than 15 million households across the country that rely on private wells for their drinking water. And that New York, with more than 800,000 private wells statewide, and as many as 40,000 on Long Island, places fourth nationwide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, PHILIP H.
description: BERNSTEIN-Philip H. 95, born November 19, 1906, passed away July 26, 2002, in Ft. Lauderdale, FL. Philip graduated from NYU in 1931, where he was a member of the National Championship Track Team. Philip was a major contributor to the textile industry as the originator of crushed velvet bedspreads and draperies and as the former Chairman of the Board and founder of Crown Crafts, Inc. Philip is survived by his wife, Inez, sister Edith, son Michael, daughter Elizabeth, and grandchildren Deborah, Alicia, Diana, Danielle and Sarah. We will remember Philip for his marvelous sense of humor, his strong sense of ethics, and his devotion to his family. Services Monday, July 29, 2002, at 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'' (76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue). In lieu of flowers donations to the Alzheimers Association, 800-272-3900.

title: The World; U.S. and Central America: Too Close for Comfort?

During the 1990's, many of these officers retired to lives as placid as their military careers had been bloody. Dozens moved to Florida to spend their sunset years at quiet retirement communities.

title: How to Break the Ceiling?

Fifty-two percent of the 20,000 women surveyed last spring by World Women in Technology, a global online networking group for businesswomen, felt that their gender kept them from progressing in their careers. When asked what would help them reach a higher level, 57 percent cited a mentor or a coach, while 34 percent said training or education. Thirty-three percent said ''a more supportive work environment'' and 21 percent ''a more supportive boss.'' (Respondents could choose more than one answer.)

Now it appears that the construction scaffolding will come down within a year, leaving only rust stains and the memory of unrealized parts of a monumental plan.

title: Get a Divorce

In our state, all but about $90,000 of our combined assets, excluding house and car, would have to be spent before he could qualify for assistance. I am considering a 'Medicaid divorce' (that is, in name only) so he can receive treatment without running through my modest savings. We both dread the divorce, and I don't want to cheat Medicaid, but I don't want to be driven to poverty. Is such a divorce ethical? B.V.C., Seattle

description: CALLAN-Desmond, M.D. Of Hillsdale, NY, passed away July 22 at home, with members of his family-wife, Georgene Gardner, his daughter Lyndie Callan, and son, Rich Callan, around him. Survivors include sisters Cristine Callan of Cambridge, MA, and Mary Bailey of Concord, MA, stepson Jason Gardner and grandchildren Isaac and Anastasia. He was deeply loved by his family and wide circle of friends, beloved by his patients and esteemed in the community. His long record of public service and his activism on behalf of social justice helped define and shape the field of community medicine in the U.S. He was a decorated U.S. Army veteran of World War II, captured at the Battle of the Bulge and held prisoner of war. title: QUICK BITE/Stone Harbor; The Upper Crust Down the Shore
description: The pizza-eating world has gone through its fads: deep-dish, which is just another reason to go slim on the sauce and hefty on the crust; white pizza, an excuse to keep tablecloths from being stained with tomato; and stuffed crust, which is inexplicable and requires a crane to lift. Then there is Mack's of Stone Harbor, just a couple of blocks south of the border with Avalon on what is known as Seven-Mile Island. Stone Harbor and Avalon have gotten uppity reputations of late, but Mack's is as down home as they come. Try the Wildwood, a simple $17 wonder with sausage, onions, green peppers and extra cheese. The crust is thin, but holds the toppings with just the right amount of firmness. On the other hand, it is not as stiff as the cardboard-like stuff you get at chain pizza joints. You may have to do the old head-back, slide-a-wedge-down-the-gullet trick, but that is the way pizza was meant to be eaten, especially at the shore. The tomato sauce on Mack's pizza is not the usual bland stuff but nicely spiced with oregano and a little garlic. The isn't just a few blotches of white, but covers the entire pie, and there are accompanying pools of grease. The veggies are fresh and the sausage is cut before your eyes. One extra at Mack's is the see-through rotating brick pizza oven. It cooks the pizza evenly, which is all-important in a thin-crust pie. It also keeps the oven tenders from burning their forearms, so you always have a smile coming from your server. Mack's is not one of those new-fangled pizza palaces that has arugula-and-hearts-of-palm salads and pastas you've never heard of. It's pizza and nonalcoholic drinks and that's it. At Mack's, that's enough. If it's not crowded and your children are lucky, they'll get a piece of dough, not crayons, to play with. Robert Strauss

title: Sonnets and More -- or Less
description: There are no traces of the conventional sonnet in Gerald Stern's AMERICAN SONNETS (Norton, $22) -- these poems are lightly metered, unrhymed and without octave-sestet divisions or 14-line limits. The one trace of the form is thematic: sonnets have always been tiny courtrooms for poets to present their claims to what they love. Stern, moreover, who is not the first American poet to usurp the name while forsaking the form (one thinks of Lowell and Berryman), has always been a love poet. But a note of loss has altered the longing for his beloved world into a kind of pre-emptive grief. This sequence of 59 love poems is nearly a continuous elegy. If you love Stern you go to his poetry for its signature gestures -- exuberance for the useless, ecstasy over the discard, a wild need to surround the whole world with a poem. But his work's strength is its understated (and often ignored) intelligence. The ''struggle to describe the smell of / snow in 1940, mixed as it was with / coal fumes and the rawness of locusts,'' from the poem ''You,'' just about summarizes his whole career, going back to his 1973 collection ''Rejoicings,'' where he confessed his desire to ''close the whole world in my grip.'' Stern is still making his inventory of the American sublime and finding it in string beans, a woman whose breath smells like peanuts, Band-Aids, cigars, Woolworth's, incinerators and the singing group the Ink Spots. ''American Sonnets'' records the sudden and chastening difference measured by more than a quarter-century's experience of ''what my ignorance cost and what my stubbornness.'' J. T. Barbarese
