title: Purple Passion
description: In a recent issue of The New York Review of Books, there was an article on Middle Eastern food by the noted historian and Princeton professor Bernard Lewis, in which he quotes a 14th-century Persian writer on the subject of eggplant: ''One day when Sultan Mahmud [reigned 998 to 1010] was hungry, they brought him a dish of eggplant. He liked it very much and said, 'Eggplant is an excellent food.' A courtier began to praise the eggplant with great eloquence. When the sultan grew tired of the dish he said, 'Eggplant is a very harmful thing,' whereupon the courtier began to speak in hyperbole of the harmful qualities of the eggplant. 'Man alive,' said the sultan, 'have you not just now uttered the praises of eggplant?' 'Yes,' said the courtier, 'but I am your courtier and not the eggplant's courtier.'''

title: 'Peter Loon'
description: IN THE FOURTH YEAR OF THE AMERICAN REVOLUTION, A MAN NAMED Ezekiel Peter Black came to the settlement of Sheepscott Great Pond, in the District of Maine, with his daughter Rosemund. There was a great deal of speculation regarding Black and his daughter, these stories being fed by the appearance of the man himself, who was taller than other men and powerfully built; he was swarthy skinned and his beard and his long hair, worn in a queue, were blue-black. It was rumored that his father was Black Peter himself, the African slave who rose up against his tormentors and became a pirate, and that this Ezekiel Black had himself harried the southern coasts and got his daughter by the kidnapped wife of a plantation owner in South Carolina.

title: Kicking Legends' Tires
description: Damon Runyon once said that ''about 95 percent of all sports tradition is pure fiction.'' The Yankees are certainly one of the most storied franchises in sports, but if Runyon was right, stories may be the right term. To shed some light on many long-believed Yankee tales, a panel will meet next Saturday at the Yogi Berra Museum on the campus of Montclair State University. Among questions that will be answered (or at least addressed): Did the Babe really point to predict a home run? Speaking of the Babe, was Leo Durocher traded in 1929 because he stole Ruth's watch? Why did Joe Dimaggio quit the team? The panel will consist of the authors Bert Randolph Sugar, Maury Allen and Richard Tofel, plus Tony Morante, who is the tour director of Yankee Stadium, and Marty Appel, a former public relations director for the Yankees. Reservations are required; call (973) 655-2378. Admission is $10. Of course, truth is relative, or irrelevant. As Berra himself said: ''I really didn't say everything I said.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOSHIMURA, FUMIO
description: YOSHIMURA-Fumio. Artist and teacher, died, July 23 of complications from pancreatic cancer. He was 76. Fumio loved women, baseball, and meals shared with friends; literature, Mozart, and the streets of New York; movies, conversation and the towns of Italy. In his 11 years on the faculty of Dartmouth College, he frequently complained about academic life, but more often he praised the spirit and talent of his favorite students. He leaves a legacy of whimsical kites, elegant drawings, and his famous wood sculptures: ghostly evocations of objects that fascinated him, bicylces and sunflowers, typewriters and fish bones, saxophones and pea pods. He leaves another legacy to the friends fortunate enough to have crossed his path: memories of his warmth, optimism, and intelligence. We will miss him profoundly. Condolences to Carol, his loving wife and caretaker, and to Obadiah Watkinson, his devoted stepson. Jerry Howett

title: Dysfunction For Dollars

He's a vaguely good-looking man, vaguely nerdy, with a squinting, almost spinsterish smile. ''I was shy with girls,'' he says. ''At 21, I had this girl in my room. title: In the Game of The Father
description: Like George W. Bush, Andrew M. Cuomo has much to learn from his less visceral, more contemplative father (Adam Nagourney, July 14). However, even gravitas must be leavened with a dollop of political derring-do if higher office is the endgame. And the elder Cuomo is a poor role model when it comes to daring greatly. Had he sought his party's nomination for the presidency in 1992, Mario Cuomo would in all likelihood have become the Democratic standard-bearer. But he missed his rendezvous with destiny. If he has any sense of history, Cuomo the younger must not play his father's game.

title: Ideas & Trends: Clockwork; Time Travel Isn't What it Used to Be
description: OF all the dreams of science fiction, time travel is the giddiest. To escape time is to escape everything -- history, regret and, above all, death. Fed up with Victorian England? Speed to the distant future, as in H. G. Wells's 1895 classic, ''The Time Machine.'' Miserable as an adult? Fly back to your own happier high-school days, as in two of this fall's new television shows. Angry at the end of life? Then choose cryonics, the most immediately available, if certainly the most inelegant, of time machines.

She is survived by her husband John Lebor, daughter Diana and her husband John Plunkett of Rye, NY, granddaughter Lisa Wallace of Rye, NY, and Hong Kong, two grandsons, Christopher Pollack of Rye, NY, and Todd Pollack of New York City, stepson Andrew Lebor of Callawassi Island, SC, stepdaughter Catherine Scheu of Portsmith, NH, step grandsons Keith Lebor of New Providence, NJ, and Todd Lebor of Chicago, IL, four great-grandchildren and four step great-grandchildren. She was predeceased by her brother James Joseph Patrick. Calling hours will be on Sunday, July 28, from 4-7 PM at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY. title: D-Day for Colin Powell
description: It wouldn't be surprising if Colin Powell were daydreaming about the clout once exercised by secretaries of state like John Foster Dulles and Henry Kissinger, men whose sway over American foreign policy was largely uncontested. Mr. Powell has been bested on a number of important issues in recent months by more conservative and ideological figures in the Bush administration. Like the good soldier and loyal adviser that he is, Mr. Powell has swallowed the defeats, defended the party line and turned to the next crisis. The administration, and the nation, would be better served if Mr. Powell's views prevailed more often. The time has come when he should not be so accommodating. He might even throw a tantrum or two.

We walk and groom dogs and just spend some quality time with the animals at Angel's Gate. My children are learning that giving of yourself and finding meaning beyond Nintendo is of value, and we get back so much more than we give. We truly believe that if we care for all the creatures of the earth, and value life, human beings will treat each other with greater respect.

Dail grew up in Bedford, NY and was educated at Rippowam Cisqua, Miss Hall's School and Vassar College. An accomplished art historian, Dail served as a docent at The Art Museum of Ontario in Toronto, The Metropolitan Museum of Art and its branch, The Cloisters in New York, The Art Institute of Chicago and The Ringling Museum of Art in Sarasota. She is survived by her husband of 44 years, Brian, daughter Alexandra of San Francisco, son Philip, daughter-in-law Camille, grandchildren Allison and Philip, Jr. of Avon, CT and sister Elaine Hinkle of Naples, FL and her family. A Mass will be held on August 5 at 10:30 AM at St. Martha's Catholic Church, 200 North Orange (at Fruitville) Sarasota, FL. Memorial donations may be made to The Ringling Museum Docent Memorial Fund, 5401 Bayshore Rd, Sarasota, FL 34243.

title: Bistro in a Blue Room With a View
description: MANY will remember the new restaurant Blu as the Upstairs Cafe, and more recently Sun, Moon and Spoon. Now new owners have taken over the management and kitchen, streamlining the name, the decr and the menu.

title: A White Made For Aladdin
description: The lithe, vivacious 2001 Baron Herzog chenin blanc is an at-your-service genie in a wine bottle: picnic refresher, aperitif and fish partner. This dry white from California, made by the Royal Wine Corporation, specialists in kosher wines popular in the nonkosher market, resembles a tropical-fruit cocktail with a long finish. It's a $6 bargain at McCabe's, 1347 Third Avenue (77th Street). HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Armstrong Wins Fourth Straight Tour de France
description: PARIS, July 28 -- Having made it look oh so easy for three weeks, Lance Armstrong coasted across the finish line on the Champs-Elysees in Paris today, sealing his fourth successive victory in the Tour de France and sparking speculation about a record-tying fifth and even a sixth.

title: Wonder Woman; The Strongest Woman In The World.
description: Cheryl Haworth, the strongest teenage girl in the world, straddles her croquet mallet. The weight lifter, 5 feet 10 inches and solid as a linebacker, can heft more than 300 pounds, the equivalent of two refrigerators, over her head. But now it's high noon, and we're tapping wooden balls in one of Savannah's city parks, where a rococo fountain throws a chandelier of droplets into the air. Cheryl, in gym-rat attire, seems to relish the odd figure she cuts among the Victorian-dainty wickets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIDERMAN, GEORGE
description: BIDERMAN-George. Writer, activist, conservationist, progressive humanist. After a long illness, and caring for his beloved wife and partner, Beth, to the end, George died peacefully and on his own terms at home July 20, 2002. Trained as a social scientist, worked as a journalist and creative PR man, a master of the written word and eloquent persuasion. Reporter for Advertising Age 1946-47, PR director for Bantam Books 1948-52, ran his own agency 1952-71 with a long list of notable clients. Political strategist and spokesman for the Fire Island Association (president 1972-81), he led the fight against a four-lane highway and spearheaded creation of the National Seashore, preserving the island for generations to come. Founding member, Gateway Citizens Committee, establishing the National Recreation Area. Past board member, Regional Plan Association. Avid fisherman, enthralled fan of jazz, entertaining raconteur and incorrigible punster. Cherished by brother, Albert, admired and loved by daughter, Tina Vartanian, and son, John. Grandfather to Alexandre Vartanian and Lauren Scharf. In activity large and small he tried to make the world a better place and his likes will not again be seen. Donations in memory of George and Beth to The Nation Associates, attn: P. Randall, 33 Irving Pl., NYC 10003.

description: After Alonzo Mourning's kidney illness, players are so concerned about the effects of anti-inflammatory drugs that they are seeking answers as well as help for their pain.

description: To look at him today, Mike would seem every teenager's dream: blond and handsome with a well-honed physique. It's hard to imagine there was a time when this 15-year-old's sunny disposition was clouded with self-doubt.

title: More Buses Connecting Cities
description: AS airport security checks and other potential delays stretch the time for a plane trip far beyond the actual time aloft, ground-based alternatives have become increasingly attractive to frequent travelers, especially on shorter trips. Now a bus company is trying to take advantage of this phenomenon by starting scheduled intercity bus trips with a higher level of service and comforts aimed at business travelers.

title: Elizabeth Vargas and Marc Cohn
description: THREE years ago, the night before the men's singles semifinals at the United States Open in Queens, Andre Agassi spent the evening carbo-loading in style. He had a private concert with his favorite singer, Marc Cohn, at a recording studio in the meatpacking district, filling the place with candles and ordering in pasta from Il Mulino.

title: A Primer That's All About, Ugh, Slugs
description: FOR years, I believed the only positive thing to be said about slugs was that they are resilient. No matter how unfavorable the conditions for them -- droughts are particularly devastating -- their numbers never seem to diminish. After weeks of no summer rain, for example, slugs would somehow miraculously appear after the first downpour and devour all my newly planted lettuce seedlings.

title: Talks on Kashmir Urged by Powell
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell arrived in India today at the start of a weeklong Asian trip to shore up support for the campaign against terrorism, with his first issue the flare-up over Kashmir that has threatened war between India and Pakistan, two nations critical to the campaign.

description: JANOWITZ-Abe. Peacefully passed away in his 95th year in K.C., MO., on July 12. The long-time NYC resident was a revered educator, accomplished lyricist and respected poet. He was a loving husband, father and grandfather. He is survived by his sons Bob Janowitz and Ken Jordan (nee Janowitz); his grandchildren Regina Janowitz, and Kimberly, Lindsay and Bradford Jordan; and his brother, Jules Janowitz. The family is honoring Abe's wish that there be no formal funeral or service. He will be forever remembered in our hearts.

title: When Color Should Count
description: Ward Connerly is the black businessman who spearheaded the successful campaign for Proposition 209, a 1996 ballot initiative that effectively ended public affirmative action in the state of California. He is back in the news again, this time promoting what he calls the Racial Privacy Initiative. Asking citizens to check a ''race'' box on a school or government form forces Americans to pay attention to immutable and meaningless characteristics like skin color and ancestry, Mr. Connerly argues. His basic premise is that people otherwise disinclined to do so ought not be compelled by government to put themselves into a racial category.

title: July 21-27: NATIONAL; CAVEAT DEBTOR
description: Congressional negotiators reached final agreement last week on a bill to make it tougher for Americans to escape their debts by filing for bankruptcy. title: The Folds Hinted More Than They Hid
description: THERE is something faintly subversive about ''Fabric of Vision: Dress and Drapery in Painting,'' the new show at London's National Gallery. Instead of looking at whole paintings, you end up studying their component parts and, yes, the yards of cloth that for centuries provided the mise-en-scne of most figurative art. Indeed, from the Renaissance to the 18th century, more canvas was devoted to the depiction of fabric than to anything else.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: AUTUMN IN FRANCE -- Two November barge cruises in Provence are being sold by eWaterways.com at special prices that include round-trip air fare from many United States cities. A six-day cruise on the 50-passenger Chardonnay leaves Nov. 8; the 50-passenger Provence leaves Nov. 15. Each begins in Aigues-Mortes with visits to Nmes, Arles and Avignon, ending in Lyon. The price -- $2,199 to $2,299 a person, double occupancy -- includes all meals and wine on board, air fare, Paris transfers on the T.G.V. and two nights in a Paris hotel. title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: ACCORDING TO QUEENEY, by Beryl Bainbridge. (Carroll & Graf, $12.) This quirky Novel, which explores the long friendship between Samuel Johnson and his wealthy benefactor Hester Thrale, unfolds through the eyes of Hester's daughter, Queeney, whose complex relationship with her mother dominates her often petty account of the relationship. Last year in the Book Review, Thomas Mallon admired the book's ''sharp, offbeat perceptions, as well as the grotesque comic touches that have always been one of Bainbridge's strongest suits.''

title: Barking Up the Wrong Tree

His owner was pretty cute too, although he didn't have nearly as much hair, and his dog seemed to have a far sunnier disposition. This was our first date (we met online), and his idea of getting together at the dog run in Madison Square Park seemed like a nice idea, even though I don't actually have a dog. Why not let his dog get some air while we were checking each other out? ''Aren't you sweet!'' I said as he (the dog, that is) licked my face. ''Yeah!''

title: NO. 2 IN CAR INSURANCE
description: New Jersey drivers, for the first time since 1993, are not paying the highest average automobile insurance rates in the nation. That distinction now belongs to drivers in Washington, D.C., according to a survey for the year 2000 compiled by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners and released last week. Rates for New Jersey drivers averaged $977.07, compared with $1,033.88 for 1999. The 3.7 percent decrease was the largest among the 12 states where rates went down in 2000. The decline was attributed to a state-mandated 15 percent reduction in some rates. Drivers in Washington paid the highest rates for 2000 at $996.39 and those in North Dakota paid the least at $477.28. Karen DeMasters

description: ''You have the idea that what you see there is a soul leading a body -- a soul pulling a body.''

title: What, Me Worry?
description: LAST Tuesday, Jeffrey K. Dorner, a medical secretary in Manhattan, thwacked a stack of envelopes marked Templeton Financial, Fidelity and American Express onto his desk and gazed at them as if they were a bad hand in a big-stakes poker game.

description: o, Mr. Klauser, should Mami Jane die?"

title: A Summary of the Major Actions of the Legislature's 225th Session
description: The 225th annual session of the New York State Legislature dragged quietly to a tentative close on July 2, after six months of partisan posturing and wrangling and very little real action.

title: DataBank; End of a Drought? The Dow Snaps Higher
description: The Dow Jones industrial average made its biggest weekly gain in 10 weeks as the stock market held onto much of the ground it won in a stunning rally on Wednesday.

title: The Old-Fashioned Kind of Business Errors
description: SUMMERTIME, and the living is easy -- unless, say, you're lounging poolside on a ''Time Out folding mini beach chair,'' which has a propensity to ''collapse, posing crush and amputation hazards to consumer's fingers and toes.'' Or unless you're serving Hagen-Dazs with your Dansk ice cream scoop, whose ''cap at the end of the handle . . . can fly off with substantial force [posing] a risk of impact injury.''

title: Road to Morocco
description: Living Morocco, a new eco-cultural tour company specializing in southern Morocco, is taking $500 a couple off its first group tours, beginning in October. The trips, by Land Rover, visit remote Berber villages, desert and mountains. A 10-day trip leaving Oct. 22 costs $2,645 a person, double, for 5 to 8 people and $2,445 for 9 to 12 people. The same trip with daily yoga, leaving Nov. 2, is $3,250 a person, double, for a maximum of 10 people. Reserve by Aug. 30. Rates include accommodations (small hotels, tent camps or a Marrakesh home), all meals except one dinner, ground transport, guides and admission fees; (800) 378-4555 or www.livingmorocco.com .

title: Giants' Crash Course on How to Play Smarter
description: A chorus of assistant coaches responds each time the head coach, Jim Fassel, blows his whistle to end a play in the Giants' practices, and they loudly cajole and critique and cheer in a training camp where instruction is especially important.

title: Dance Listings
description: BALLET TECH  Summer preview season. Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Ave. at 19th St. (212-242-0800) Mon.-Sat., 8.

title: July 21-27: NATIONAL; TRAFICANT'S FINAL FALL
description: The nearly 18-year-long Congressional career of Representative James A. Traficant Jr. is over. By a vote of 420 to 1 the House voted to expel Mr. Traficant, 61, on charges stemming from his conviction for racketeering, bribery and taking salary kickbacks. It was only the second time since the Civil War and fifth time in its 213-year history that the House has expelled a member from office. Alison Mitchell

title: Introduction
description: Daniel Mendelsohn's article prompted mail from scores of readers moved by his search for information about how his relatives who died in the Holocaust were betrayed and by his discovery that how they lived is what matters. Our Tiger Woods montage drew tips about his tipping policy.

title: Relief Workers, Our Better Selves
description: To the Editor:

title: Up With Downloads
description: Q: In July 2001, a district judge shut down the music file-sharing company you co-founded, Napster, for assisting others in copyright infringement. Recently, all five major record labels that had been suing you agreed to participate in a file-streaming service called Rhapsody on Listen.com that allows consumers to hear music for a fee. What's your view of that development?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYDNEY, LEE
description: SYDNEY-Lee. Of NYC, on July 26, 2002, at the age of 96. Beloved mother of Jim Schorsch and the late Sally Moss. Adored grandmother of Debi Strong of Big Fork, MT, Wendy Lasher of Pittsford, NY, and Linda Schutter of Louisville, CO. Loving great-grandmother of Tracy, Brenna Xiaoxiao, Derek, Scott, Kyle and Skylar. Funeral strictly private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: When Publish or Perish Is More Than Just Words
description: HOW'S this for a disaster in the making? A writer and artist, living and working out of a third-floor walkup, decide to start their own publishing house. They have limited funds and almost no experience in the book business. To make matters even worse, the first two volumes they plan to issue seem to have almost no commercial potential.

title: 'Shadow Mountain'
description: My first memories are of meadows. Evening meadows, when the sun's honey-warm rays turned the long grasses and birch borders into an enchanted and radiant secret. It is the light I mostly remember, when the dark was seducing the day and the shadows would flicker and splinter in a spectacle of courtship. It was the hour of whimsy and expectation. Perhaps it was the melon light that beckoned the deer. They emerged like druids from the forests, miragelike in the tall shimmering grass, unable to resist those last lingering moments of summer sunlight to warm their shadow-cooled backs.

title: A Family Affair With Inventive Dishes
description: HARVEST MOON is a restaurant waiting to be discovered. This tiny storefront gem, along a commercial stretch of the Hempstead Turnpike in a working-class neighborhood of Franklin Square, is the kind of restaurant I dream about. It is a quintessential  La Carte kind of place with an ambitious international menu, an inventive chef, entree prices that never reach the $20 mark and dishes that reveal the natural beauty of fine ingredients. It is a restaurant run by a friendly family from Queens who built it and desperately want you to love the food as much as they do.

title: Dorothy Manning, David Garca
description: Dorothy Thurgood Manning, an art instructor in Oakland, Calif., and Judge David Arthur Garca of State Superior Court in San Francisco were married yesterday in Larkspur, Calif. Judge William Cahill, who is retired from the bridegroom's court, officiated at the Lark Creek Inn.

title: It's Not as Dangerous as It Looks. Really.
description: Last November, the rafting guide Julie Munger and two other women did what no man -- or woman -- had done before. They submersed their bodies in the icy Colorado River and -- over the next 19 days -- kicked, thrashed and floated on riverboards the 300-mile length of the Grand Canyon.

title: A Battle Over Larger Power Lines
description: NORTHEAST UTILITIES has said that unless it can rebuild the backbone of the power grid serving Fairfield County, residents of the southwestern part of Connecticut could soon find themselves in the dark. The company, it said, will simply not be able to meet demand.

title: Investing; Time for Faith in Brokerage Shares?
description: AS investors have grown disenchanted with Wall Street, the stock prices of major brokerage firms have tumbled sharply. While the stocks may well fall further, some analysts say they may be a good value.

title: St. John's Riverside Hospital Takes Over Dobbs Ferry Facility
description: St. John's Riverside Hospital, the county's oldest, has purchased the second oldest hospital, Community Hospital at Dobbs Ferry, for $4.6 million at auction. Community Hospital, which defaulted on its mortgage with the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, will join the St. John's system, based in Yonkers.

title: Business; Timing of E.D.S. Layoffs Proved Costly to Workers
description: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS, the big information technology contractor, picked a pivotal day this month to lay off 300 workers.

title: Jeanne Clothiaux, Mark Solomon
description: Jeanne Amie Clothiaux, a daughter of Clara and Eugene Clothiaux of Auburn, Ala., is to be married today to Mark Solomon, a son of Dr. Renee Solomon of New York and the late Seymour J. Solomon. Jim Prall, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the bridegroom, will officiate on Moscow Mountain, near Moscow, Idaho.

title: Private Sector; What Next? Frank Perdue Pitching for the Yankees?
description: When he crouched for the cameras more than a half-century ago, with his cap pulled down tight and an old puffy mitt pressed into his palm, Frank Perdue could never have guessed that a carving in his likeness would one day be passed out to star-struck fans as a souvenir of their day at the ballpark.

title: The Tiger Files
description: Caucasian, Thai, Indian -- whatever. But he can't possibly be black. This corporate shill hasn't got a hint of soul.

title: July 21-27: ECONOMY; BAD PUBLICITY
description: The reputation and the stock prices of Citigroup and J.P. Morgan Chase, the nation's two largest banks, in terms of assets, plummeted following a Senate hearing that probed the banks' ties to Enron. The committee examined evidence that the two banks had helped Enron, the bankrupt energy company, keep debt off its books. Riva Atlas

title: Golf, Not Government, On Driving Range Site
description: The Town of Greenburgh announced last week that it would not proceed with a controversial plan to buy the Westchester Golf Range and develop a $30 million town hall and library complex there.

title: For Jet Rivals, Caution Here, Swagger There
description: THE jet that its builders say will change the face of commercial aviation sits in an exhibition hall here, bold and sleek and bathed in a golden spotlight.

title: A Few Burglars Help Make a Mini-Crime Wave
description: Crime may be generally low in New York City, but on the Upper West Side this month there were echoes of the bad old days.

title: The Nation: A War Like No Other; The Perilous Search for Security at Home
description: THE ambitious plan to collapse 22 agencies and tens of thousands of employees into a new homeland security behemoth is nothing less than a project to transform American society. The question, as Congress and President Bush wrangle over the details, is into what?

title: Editorial Observer; Women's Suffrage: How Febb Burn and Her Son, Harry, Saved the Day
description: This is a perfect time of the year to contemplate the history of the American suffrage movement -- unless your personal preference leans more to Austin Powers in an air-conditioned theater. Women seem to do pretty well in America when the weather is steamy. It was in July of 1848 that Elizabeth Cady Stanton's nephew climbed through a church window in Seneca Falls, N.Y., to unlock the door that the minister had somehow forgotten to leave open, permitting the first women's rights convention to get under way. And it was in August of 1920 that members of the Tennessee Legislature, after getting rip-roaring drunk in the liquor lobby's hospitality suites, sobered up long enough to make Tennessee the final state needed to ratify the 19th Amendment to the Constitution, giving women the right to vote.

title: Use Any Color Shopping Bag, So Long as It's Red
description: Kevin Chan knows he has his choice among plastic grocery bags. In his travels around the city, Mr. Chan has seen all kinds. White bags with yellow smiley faces. Black bags with gold stripes. Bags with drawstrings and brand names. Bags that wish him a nice day or say, ''Thank You for Shopping With Us.''

title: Corrections

title: Artists In Pairs: Two Ways Of Seeing
description: ONE of the most popular exhibitions on the calendar of City Without Walls shows off the results of Art Reach. Art Reach is a program that matches several New Jersey high school students with professional mentors, artists who instruct and give direction. Sometimes a pair collaborates on a piece, but most often the work of a student and mentor pairing is shown side by side.

title: July 21-27: FRONT LINES; THE MIDDLE EAST AGAIN
description: An Israeli jet dropped a bomb on a house in Gaza City, killing the leader of the Islamist group Hamas and 14 other people, 9 of them children. The bombing brought intense criticism from abroad, and Palestinians killed five Israelis, including one child and a rabbi, in two separate retaliatory attacks. James Bennet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPINNER, PAULA
description: SPINNER-Paula, of Boca Raton, Florida and formerly of North Woodmere, New York, passed away on July 18, 2002 at the age of 68. Devoted wife, loving mother and grandmother, teacher and friend to many. She is survived by Dr. Morton Spinner, her loving husband of 48 years, her three sons and daughters-in-law Judge Jeffrey Arlen Spinner and Alyse Auerbach Spinner, Dr. Robert J. Spinner and Dr. Alexandra P. Wolanskyj Spinner and Mr. Steven J. Spinner and Allison Berry Spinner, her three granddaughters Sydney, Amanda and Rebecca and two sisters, Edythe Fayer and Gloria LeVine. She was a great source of inspiration and strength to many. To have known her is to have been greatly blessed. Donations may be sent to the American Cancer Society and the American Heart Association.

title: Gardenhire and Twins Still Feel Kelly Influence
description: When the year began, the Minnesota Twins named a new manager, but Ron Gardenhire wasn't certain he would have a team to manage. Six months later, the Twins have the biggest division lead in the major leagues, but they and their manager aren't certain they will have a playoffs to play.

Lewis performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Heinz Memorial Chapel at the University of Pittsburgh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDES, JAMES S.
description: LANDES-James S. Born February 29, 1908 died July 22, 2002. A unique man, young despite his 94 years, who sparkled with intelligence, humor, and grace. He was loved and admired by a devoted family, and by all those who provided him with endearing care. He lived a full and remarkable life, and will never be forgotten by those who knew him.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: FISH WARNING
description: The state Department of Environmental Protection issued a warning last week about high levels of mercury in 21 species of freshwater fish. The department said pregnant women and youngsters should avoid eating fish, which include game fish like bass and trout and catfish, caught in different areas of the state, particularly the Pinelands. Mercury can cause interfere with development to the central nervous system in children. The warnings do not apply to commercially caught and distributed fish. A full list of warnings can be found at http://state.nj.us/dep John Holl

title: Making E-ZPass Easier
description: SO Governor McGreevey raised the ante on E-ZPass by a dollar. Want to try to get it back? Grab a pencil, or better yet, scissors.

As a result, the front-page sections of some articles did not match the continuations, and a few articles were omitted or duplicated. The affected articles are available online . The page may also be requested from Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@nytimes.com. title: Suzanne Owen, Pablo Erneta
description: Suzanne Lynn Owen, the daughter of Candace and David Owen of Westborough, Mass., was married yesterday to Pablo Eliseo Erneta, a son of Haydee Erneta of Astoria, Queens, and the late Eliseo Erneta. The Rev. Curtis Brown, a United Methodist minister, officiated at Beechwood, the Astor house in Newport, R.I.

title: A Composer As Spiky As His Music
description: RALPH SHAPEY, a composer of gigantic vision and ingenious skill, was the great curmudgeon of contemporary American music. This should not be surprising. Though his audacious, craggy and complex atonal music has long been embraced by dedicated performers and respected by many critics, it is seldom performed. Shapey's cantankerousness didn't help matters. By his 50's, he already had the look of some fearsome Old Testament prophet, with his unkempt white hair, scraggly beard, stooped shoulders and sour disposition. Yet his complaining had a righteousness about it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISHORR, ESTHER
description: KISHORR-Esther. On Thursday, July 25, in her 91st year. Her brother Ira Stadlen survives her as does her nephew Lewis Stadlen and her many nieces Jessica Fromm, Vicki, Sallie, Maxime and Clare Stadlen and 10 grand nieces and nephews. She was a sickly child but survived to fool them all.

title: Whimsical Celebration On Shelter Island
description: TAKE a Sunday drive on Shelter Island this summer, and you may be counting sheep in broad daylight. Scattered around the island in dozens of front yards is a two-dimensional plywood flock, some in groups, some in pairs and some solo. Many of the sheep are dressed in colors not seen in nature, a few have wings, one is got up as a Scottish golfer, and one wears real cowboy boots and a red bandanna.

title: The Tiger Files
description: Tiger Woods's reluctance to give tips speaks volumes (Michael Sokolove, July 14). Earl Woods did his son a disservice by never allowing him to work and thus get a glimpse of the ''real world'' before his rise to celebrity status.

title: Coming Attractions? An Interactive Circus
description: Volleyball and skateboarding may soon share space with trapeze flying and aerial ballet along a humming stretch of Riverside Park.

title: Invasion of the Consultants
description: To mention consultants is to open the door to a touchy subject. On one side are workers who fear that the presence of a consultant means that their jobs are in jeopardy. On the other side are consultants themselves, well aware that their presence breeds resentment but firm in their belief that they perform a valuable function if given a proper chance.

title: A Hamster With a Mission: To Make Billions, Gently
description: AT less than three and a half inches, Hamtaro is hardly the tallest hero in cartoon land. Even in his own animated world -- a brightly colored suburbia of hamsters, humans and the occasional troublesome feline -- he's no giant, being smaller than his fellow hamsters Boss and Oxnard and much tinier than his owner, 10-year-old Laura Haruna.

title: A Young Cast Boards 'Norman's Ark'
description: EVERY school seems to have an arts program; every theater, an education outreach plan. But seldom do the forces of education and of theater join in the creation and performance of a genuine new Broadway-style musical.

title: Word for Word/Foreign Exchange; Please Accept This Gift With Our, Uh, Compliments
description: IT might be hard to believe that copies of Nazarbayev: My Life, My Times and the Future --the Kazakh president's autobiography --are simply given away. But that's only one of many gifts that President Bush received from various foreign dignitaries in 2001, according to the State Department's annual tally, which was released last Monday.

title: Yankee Bats Fail to Rescue Struggling Weaver
description: There is an easy way to measure Joe Torre's confidence in a pitcher: watch the Yankees' bullpen. If nobody is warming up, it's a sure sign that Torre, the Yankees' manager, likes what he sees.

title: From Sailing Pioneer To Sport's Impresario
description: In 1968, when the 29-year-old British merchant seaman Robin Knox-Johnston set out from England in an attempt to become the first person to sail around the planet alone and without stopping, he was steering a course into uncharted waters. No one, including Knox-Johnston, who was unknown then, had any idea if such a voyage was possible.

title: The 150-Second Sell, Take 34
description: Art Mondrala, a pale, monastic-looking man, is shrouded in the deep gray of his Hollywood office at the Ant Farm, a company that edits trailers for major movie studios. It's an unrealistically sunny day in June, but Mondrala is huddled over his computer, just as he has been since October. He has been working 60-hour weeks cutting the previews for just one movie: ''Signs,'' the new Touchstone film written and directed by M. Night Shyamalan. The sum total of Mondrala's work in all this time has been to edit not only the official 150-second trailer for the film, but also a pair of shorter-format ''teasers'' and a 30-second TV spot that was shown during the Super Bowl. Nine months of work, for less than six minutes of footage.

title: Not Quite Sex and the City
description: CLUB KIRA guards its secrets well. Waiters in tuxedos admit the male customers to this unmarked Japanese haven, tucked into a residential building on East 49th Street in Midtown, only after studying them through a hidden camera. A red awning signals the club's presence with just two stars: ''kira, kira'' means sparkle in Japanese. The businessmen who retreat here to unwind know that the shining stars are emblems of the club's young hostesses.

title: A Designer's Lasting Spirit
description: DOWN a meandering country road, behind a row of hemlock trees, is a little slice of Provence with a $1.325 million price tag.

title: Two Certainties: Death And Property Tax Debates
description: During the wearying debate over the state budget last month, former Assembly Speaker Joe Doria, a Democrat, stood up and offered this late-night wisdom on the vagaries of politics: ''The wheel goes round and round and round . . . Whatever goes around, comes around.''

title: The Secret History of Judges
description: When a judge is nominated to a Court of Appeals, one of the powerful courts a level below the Supreme Court, the confirmation process should include a careful review of his or her past rulings. The trouble is that judges are not required to have their opinions printed in official court publications, and Senate procedures make it easy to miss troubling unpublished cases from a nominee's past. The nomination of Judge Dennis Shedd to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, based in Richmond, Va., demonstrates the flaws in the current system. The nomination is now pending in the Senate Judiciary Committee.

description: MAN WALKS INTO A ROOM

description: Dozens Killed at Air Show

title: Business Ethics Issue Contrasts Candidates' Styles: Aggressive, Measured and Steadfast
description: Last week, as corporate chieftains were arrested and the stock market churned, Andrew M. Cuomo invited reporters to a Midtown Manhattan hotel ballroom stocked with his supporters and delivered a formal half-hour speech based on a four-page proposal on corporate ethics. It was a kickoff to a four-city tour by Mr. Cuomo with appearances by laid-off employees whose savings have evaporated.

title: Some Advice for 'Rent' From a Friend
description: THE Nederlander Theater on West 41st Street, where Jonathan Larson's ''Rent'' has been playing for more than six years, is just two blocks south of the New York Times building. So I pass by often. Having interviewed Larson in the last hours of his life, I've gotten pleasure, and a measure of comfort, from knowing that his show is still going strong in New York and around the world.

title: Low-Cost Airlines Grow And Compete in Europe
description: EUROPE'S low-cost airlines are scrambling for the continent's cheap-ticket market, which has boomed as the traditional flag carriers have suffered after Sept. 11 from the decline in business and trans-Atlantic travel.

title: Summer in a Tall Glass
description: IN 14 years of tending bar, I've lent my personal spin to every drink I come across, but I've never been able to better my father's rendition of the gin and tonic. He is an adroit cook and an inveterate tinkerer, and he was for many years a research chemist; it was only natural that he brought his scrutiny to bear on cocktails. The layman may ask how high one can elevate the pedestrian gin and tonic -- that stalwart reviver of malarial British colonialists in India, with its invigorating bite of juniper, cleansing tang of lime and aromatic spritz of quinine. But the standard-issue gin and tonic is to my dad's G and T as a Ford Taurus is to a Jaguar S-Type.

title: Russian Tea Room Jammed As It Goes Way of Czars
description: The Russian Tea Room, that Faberg egg of a restaurant, too lush to survive these lean times, was packed yesterday. On Friday, its owners announced that they were closing for lack of business, but the crowd less than 24 hours later might have given them cause to reconsider.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLL, FRANK D.
description: CARROLL-Frank D., M.D., Emeritus Professor. The Department of Ophthomology mourns the loss of our esteemed colleague Emeritus Professor Frank D. Carroll, M.D. on July 24, 2002. He had been associated with the Eye Institute throughout his career as a leader in research in diseases of the optic nerve. We will miss him as will many patients whose lives he touched. Our sympathies are with his family: Shirley; Ted, Maureen and Edward; Anne, Alissa and Rebecca. Myles Behrens, M.D. Stanley Chang, M.D. Edward Harkness Eye Institute Columbia University

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPAPPORT, BERNICE
description: RAPAPPORT-Bernice. Darling Bunny, wife of Arnold, mother of Jay (Harriet) and Lynn. Grandmother of Katie and Julie. We are saddened by the loss of Bunny, our dear devoted friend for over 50 years. Our cherished memories from Brooklyn to Belle Harbor to Florida. You will be in our hearts forever. We will miss you terribly. The Feuerstadts, The Rudolphs, The Winikoffs, The Zuckermans

title: Files Searched On Yale Site Included Those Of Lauren Bush
description: When one or more people at Princeton University breached a Yale University admissions office Web site, among the 11 students whose files were scrutinized were Lauren Bush, who appears to be the niece of President Bush, and Ara Parseghian, the grandson and namesake of the famed Notre Dame football coach.

title: Where Towers Cast Shadows, Another Loss
description: LIKE much of New Jersey visible to outsiders, the natural splendor of the peninsula jutting into Newark Bay south of Route 1 and 9 has been sacrificed to the greater good of industry and commerce.

title: Cheese Shop Closes, Taking Part of Brooklyn With It
description: It's the smell that brings Nino Pantano back, the aroma of aged cheese and smoked mozzarella that hung from metal hooks for decades along the tin ceiling at Latticini Barese, an Italian specialty store in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. The store closed yesterday after 75 years as a mainstay of the neighborhood.

title: Don't Hold the Spice
description: Most of New York's Thai restaurants cater to a largely American clientele, leading many to tone down the spiciness that is a characteristic of Thai cuisine. Here are seven places that refuse to compromise.

title: McDyess's Value Rests on Knee
description: While some Knicks fans, still fascinated with Marcus Camby and upset with the loss of a lottery pick, are skeptical about the Knicks' draft-night trade for Antonio McDyess, the consensus in the N.B.A. is that the Knicks did the right thing.

Berry of Burlington, Vt., and Dr. Garrison Nelson of Lynn, Mass. The Rev. Herm Luben, a minister of the Reformed Church of America, officiated at the Old Town Meetinghouse in New Marlborough, Mass.

title: Corrections
description: The Deals and Discounts column in the Travel section last Sunday misstated the nightly rates at the Sheraton Curaao for a package including a one-day car rental. They start at $160 for single or double occupancy, not $160 a person.

description: WALL Street analysts are definitely under the microscope these days. Which makes a sequence of events of last Thursday and Friday involving Goldman Sachs' semiconductor stock analyst very intriguing.

An unemployed quality assurance inspector, she says she worries about her future and the nation's. She is infuriated at Wall Street corporate executives and the politicians she says have protected them.

title: Adaptive Sports Stoke the Competitive Spirit
description: Helene Hines lay still on the ground and tried to feel her legs. A 30-year-old physical education teacher, she stared across the court, where her husband and friends continued to play tennis, wondering what she had snapped in her neck or strained in her nervous system when she moved forward to smack the ball. She felt numbness spreading through her body.

description: Since the Sept. 11 attacks, the government is believed to have detained about two dozen people under the material-witness law. Because such proceedings are almost always secret, little is known about the suspects or their cases.

title: In Defense of Gabfests

description: Appointments of four editors to senior positions were announced yesterday by The New York Times.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Shopkeeper Killed
description: A shopkeeper was fatally stabbed late Saturday in Washington Heights as he argued with a man who had done carpentry work at his grocery store, the police said yesterday. The victim, Melvin Martinez, 35, was pronounced dead at Columbia-Presbyterian Center of New York-Presbyterian Hospital about 45 minutes after the stabbing, which occurred at 9 p.m. on the corner of West 175th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, just outside the store, the police said. The suspect, Onorio Felix, 33, was caught a short distance away and charged with one count of first-degree manslaughter, the police said. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMAN, ELLIOTT

title: Up From Darkness
description: In a summer of grim news, it's hardly surprising that many Americans quickly wrote off the chances of survival for nine miners trapped by flood waters far beneath Quecreek, Pa. The physical conditions looked impossible. Darkness, hunger, isolation and, worst of all, immersion in frigid water that accidentally poured into the mine on Wednesday -- these made the likelihood of a successful rescue look vanishingly small. But early yesterday morning, the miners were lifted one by one, safe and in good health, from the narrow coal seam where they had been crouching for days. It was what everyone had hoped for, almost without daring to hope, in the countryside around Quecreek and in the nation as a whole.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMPTON, COLIN CAMPBELL
description: HAMPTON-Colin Campbell. Of Amelia Island, Florida, a former Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of UNUM Corporation, parent company of UNUM Life Insurance Company, died on Wednesday, July 24, 2002, in a local hospital. Mr. Hampton died after heart surgery. He was 79. Under Mr. Hampton's chairmanship, UNUM became the first mutual life insurance company of size to ''demutualize'' officially converting from a mutual company to a publically owned company listed on the New York Stock Exchange. In the process, the company's surplus was distributed to its policy holders in part in cash and in part in stock amounting to a total distribution of roughly $652 million. Mr. Hampton was a true visionary. From the time he became CEO in 1970, until his retirement in 1988, UNUM's assets substantially increased from $270 million to over $7 billion. Profits increased over this time period from $2.5 million to $125 million. The company gained reputation as the leading seller of Long Term Disability Income and the only insurance company with a dominant position in both Group and Individual Disability Income. Mr. Hampton was born in New Haven, Connecticut, the son of the late George Wellington and Jean Stewart Hampton. He graduated from Vanderbilt University, attended New York University Graduate School of Economics; received an M.B.A. from the University of Maine and an honorary Doctor of Science in Business Administration from Thomas College. He served in the U.S. Air Force in World War II as a First Lieutenant, receiving the European Air Medal with Oak Leaf Clusters. He married his college sweetheart, Marjorie Alice Brown, of Savannah, Georgia, in June 1951. Mr. Hampton first entered the investment business in 1949 in New York as a security analyst with Bankers Trust. In 1956, he joined Union Mutual Life Insurance Company in Portland, Maine, as a security analyst in the Investment Department. Mr. Hampton quickly moved up in the company, finally becoming Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer in 1970. Mr. Hampton served the state of Maine in numerous ways. He was a Director and Chairman of the Chamber of Commerce in the Greater Portland region, Chairman of the Maine Committee on the Judicial Responsibility and Disability, and Chairman for the Greater Portland United Way Campaign and Cumberland County Chairman for the March of Dimes. He served as co-chairman of the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum's ''Campaign to Remember,'' Maine State Campaign, raising a then record $1.3 million. He was the Maine State Chairman for the U.S. Olympics. Mr. Hampton received the Eleventh Annual Pine Tree Distinguished Citizen Award for his outstanding contribution to the community. Mr. Hampton served as a Director of Colonial Life and Accident Insurance Co., American Council of Life Insurance, Life Office Management Association, Central Maine Power Company, Key Trust Company of Maine, Peoples Heritage Bank, Maine Medical Center, Portland Boys' Club and Associated Industries of Maine. He was a senior member of the Conference Board, a Trustee of the Maine Court Facilities Authority, Westbrook College, New England College Fund, Inc., and MGI Properties, Inc. He was Chairman of the Health Insurance Association of America and for Vanderbilt University for the state of Maine. He was a member of the Portland Country Club, the Cumberland Club, the Newcomen Society, the Torch Club of Western Maine, the Cabinet of Vanderbilt University, the Amelia Island Plantation Ocean Club and St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Amelia Island. He was an avid golfer and proud of his two holes-inone. He is survived by his loving wife Marjorie Brown Hampton, a son, Colin C. Hampton Jr., of Sea Ranch Lakes, Florida, and a daughter, Carolyn Hampton LoRusso, of Medfield, Massachusetts, as well as four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM, July 31, at St. Peter's Episcopal Church. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to College of Arts and Science at Vanderbilt University, West End Avenue, Nashville, Tennessee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROMET, MAURICE TURK, M.D.
description: GROMET - Maurice Turk, M.D. On July 26, 2002, after a brief illness in his 93rd year. A graduate of the The George Washington University Medical School (1934) whereafter he was President for many years of its Alumni Association. Under his leadership the G.W. Alumni Association developed a nationwide membership. Dr. Gromet was Chairman of the former Brooklyn Eye and Ear Hospital, where he was Chief for many years, of Ear, Nose and Throat. He also had been Chief of ENT at Caledonia Hospital, Brooklyn Hospital, and more recently, he was on the professional staffs of New York Eye and Ear and Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospitals. Dr. Gromet was a member of numerous medical boards including The American College of Surgeons, a Diplomat of the American Board of Otolaryngology and served on the Kings County Medical Malpractice Committee for many years. During World War II, Dr. Gromet served in the European Theater as surgeon in the 126th Evacuation Hospital until summer of 1945 as Major. Dr. Maury Gromet is survived by his loving, beloved, caring wife and companion of more than 64 years, Estelle (Batkin); they enjoyed travelling together throughout the world; two loved and devoted sons, Roger and Randy, and Randy's wife Barbara, and two granddaughters, adored and adoring Sarah and Elizabeth. Service will be at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NY, NY, July 29, 2002, at 1 PM, with interment to follow at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Help for 9/11 Trauma
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROEBUCK, LAURENCE
description: ROEBUCK-Laurence. 86, of Sunrise, FL, passed away on July 23, 2002. He is survived by his beloved wife Lucille of 61 years; his loving son Dr. Gary (Cindy) Roebuck; grandchildren Michelle (Scott) Rotblat, Lainie and Brett; great-grandchild Austin Rotblat. Services were held on July 25. Donations may be made to South Florida Chapter of Dysautonomia Foundation, 10467 Sunrise Lakes Blvd #

title: Lieberman Critical of Gore for Moving Campaign Off Center
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut said last night that during the campaign for the White House in 2000, Al Gore drifted away from the centrist Democratic appeal that had been at the core of both men's political identities.

title: U.S. Bodyguards Buy Time for Afghan Leader
description: American security guards in T-shirts and jeans, carrying large assault rifles, were prowling the president's office here this weekend. The first half dozen members of an American security force were in place to guard President Hamid Karzai, working alongside their Afghan counterparts.

title: Ashe Takes Top Spot on the U.S. Team
description: Molly Ashe of Wellington, Fla., rode her mare, Kroon Gravin, to a total score of 20 faults over six jumping rounds to win the top qualifying spot for the United States team that will compete at the world equestrian games.

title: F.A.A. Chief Wants Power to Ration Flights
description: The departing administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration is urging Congress to let the agency ration flights at busy airports like La Guardia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGNER, MAX
description: MAGNER-Max. July 27, 2002. Born March 18, 1918, Brooklyn, NY. Adoring and loving husband of Ethel. Father of Norman, Lois and Marge. Father-in-law of Ava and KiHan Kim. Grandfather of Andrew, Matthew, Stephanie and Oliver. New York City police officer for 25 years. Celebrated 60th wedding anniversary in March. Life member Lieutenants Benevolent Association, Shomrim Society and B'nai B'rith. Max will be remembered fondly by all who knew him. Funeral services at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island, Monday, July 29, 2002, at 12 noon.

title: On Mexico Visit, Pope Will Find Divided Catholic Country
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico, July 29  It has been 23 years since John Paul II visited Mexico on his first foreign trip as pope, and now he is to return for what many here quietly consider a final farewell.

title: Budgeting Now for Tomorrow
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg's recent announcement that he might cut the city's work force to balance next year's budget offers a reminder that he is not running for office this year. Gov. George Pataki and the New York State legislators, who are facing the voters, have created a state budget that is built on such financial whimsy that they will almost certainly have to return to Albany after the election to face hard realities. Congress, which is heading for midterm elections, shows no signs of dealing seriously enough with Washington's big new budget deficit and the next stage of tax cuts that will only add to the federal shortfall.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the continuation of a front-page article about a tax loophole was duplicated in some copies yesterday, displacing two other articles. The omitted articles -- on schools around the country that are making elaborate plans to commemorate Sept. 11 and on the dangers to crowds watching a lava flow in Hawaii -- may be found online today at nytimes.com /corrections.html. A corrected copy of the affected page may also be obtained from Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@nytimes.com. (Include a postal address.)

title: Tough Competition Comes From Unexpected Quarters
description: Two unheralded foursomes were involved Saturday in tense Spingold Knockout semifinal matches at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here, each playing against a top-ranked group of stars. One survived triumphantly, but the other fell just short.

title: Triumph of the Producing Class
description: Jonathan Glickman remembers exactly how he broke into the movie business. As a first-year student in the University of Southern California's Peter Stark producing program, he watched a guest lecturer, the producer Joe Roth, step into an elevator in 1993, and suddenly realized the visitor controlled what might be the last available summer internship. ''If I don't run into that elevator with him, someone else is going to,'' Mr. Glickman recalled thinking as he pounced.

title: If You Take Hormones
description: To the Editor:

title: Zambian Anti-Corruption Effort Pits President vs. Predecessor
description: Levy Mwanawasa, Zambia's new president, has big plans for his time in office, and no one is finding that harder to swallow than the man who put him there, his predecessor, Frederick Chiluba.

title: After Roll-of-the-Dice Rescue, a Mine Town Rejoices
description: In their darkest hours down in the mine, the nine trapped men, bedeviled by rising floodwaters, could hear the steady drilling of rescuers above them. But they still thought it imperative to jot down private thoughts and seal them in a lunch bucket as a parting word to family survivors.

title: Rivaldo Signs With A.C. Milan
description: Forward Rivaldo, a star of Brazil's World Cup championship team and the 1999 world player of the year, has agreed to a contract with the 16-time Italian league champion A.C. Milan through 2005, the team said on its Web site. Rivaldo, 30, left Barcelona last week. He will earn $4 million a year, the Web site said.

title: Terrorism in Argentina
description: To the Editor:

title: A Criminal Defamation Verdict Roils Politics in Kansas City, Kan.
description: Politics in Kansas City, Kan., is to standard Kansas politics what the XFL was to the National Football League -- meaner and rowdier, and proud of it. Or so say the region's journalists, lawyers and politicians.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about shows on Long Island misidentified the curator of a Robert Goodnough exhibition at the Pollock-Krasner House in East Hampton. She is Katie Stratis, a guest curator. (Helen A. Harrison is director of the Pollock-Krasner House.)

title: Kafka In Tulia
description: Tulia is a hot, dusty town of 5,000 on the Texas Panhandle, about 50 miles south of Amarillo.

title: Bertelsmann's Chief Is Fired After Clash With the Ownership
description: In the latest eruption of boardroom turmoil at a global media conglomerate, the chairman and chief executive of Bertelsmann of Germany, Thomas Middelhoff, was unexpectedly ousted today after clashing with the family that controls the company.

title: George E. Lindsay, Science Academy Director, Dies at 85
description: Dr. George E. Lindsay, who as director of the California Academy of Sciences helped turn its Natural History Museum into a major institution, died on July 16 at his home in Tiburon, Calif., near San Francisco. He was 85.

title: West Bank Arab-Americans: Force for Change Is Leaving
description: As Najeh Igbara watched his eldest daughter, Nabiha, marry in this quiet Palestinian village the other day, he had the comfort of knowing they would not be living too far apart. She was headed with her new husband to Sunset Park, Brooklyn -- just a bridge and tunnel away from Clifton, N.J., where he was moving with his wife and his six other children.

title: Winning Ugly Does Nothing for Ruiz's Reputation
description: Somewhere in Stockholm, if he was able to see it on television, Lennox Lewis was probably laughing. Lou Duva could only joke after watching one of the ugliest heavyweight title fights in history. His fighter, Kirk Johnson, was disqualified for low blows against John Ruiz in the 10th round here Saturday night.

title: New Economy; Like Narcissus, executives are smitten, and undone, by their own images.
description: THERE'S nothing wrong with a little self-esteem. It's grandiose delusion that causes all the trouble.

title: Bertram D. Cohn, 76, Surgeon Who Created Embolism Filter
description: Dr. Bertram D. Cohn, a pioneering pediatric surgeon and the inventor of an early filter used to prevent pulmonary embolism, a common and often fatal condition, died on July 12 in Greenport, N.Y. He was 76.

title: Sports of The Times; Finding Pessimism Where Hope Abounds
description: GIVEN the crowds these past few days along Main Street in this throwback to a genteel 19th-century village, crowds adorned in baseball caps and jerseys and carrying balls and bats to be autographed, crowds eager to be a part of this Hall of Fame induction weekend, the end of baseball would seem as far-fetched as a doubleheader between Martians on the local Doubleday Field.

title: Mining Music in Breathtaking Mountains
description: I hope the young students at this summer's Aspen Music Festival are taking time from their instruments to meditate on the nearby ghost towns scattered among these blessed mountains. It would be wise to think a little on all those long-ago miners: failed, thwarted and deprived while surrounded by the devastating beauty of black-green mountainsides and towering white aspens.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: A Failure of Democracy, Not Capitalism
description: Congress passed sweeping legislation to reform corporate conduct and governance last week, and President Bush has pledged to sign it. A mere two months ago, the prospects for such broad reform were grim, as Congressional Republicans and the president himself favored a more limited approach.

title: Ziff Davis, its fortunes tied to technology magazines, is said to plan a bankruptcy.
description: ZIFF DAVIS MEDIA, which was a major player in technology publishing with PC magazine and the now-closed Yahoo Internet Life, has been telling advertisers that it will be forced to enter a prepackaged bankruptcy by the end of this week, according to a major advertiser and two publishing executives who are close to the situation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPEL, JOHN W.
description: APPEL-John W. July 26, 2002. Dr. John W. Appel, age 91, formerly of Radnor, PA. Husband of Marian K. Appel. Also survived by his children Deborah Appel Chomiw, Kenneth G. Appel, Lydia Appel Forbes and five grandchildren. Funeral services will be held 12 noon, July 31, 2002, at St. Martin's Church, 400 King of Prussia Road, Radnor, PA. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Monadnock Conservancy, PO Box 337, Keene, NH 03431-0337.

title: Chung's Comfort Zone: On Offense in Colorado
description: Perched on the left flank in midfield with the MetroStars last season, MARK CHUNG could clearly see which way the wind - an idiot wind - was blowing.

title: POPE TELLS CROWD OF 'SHAME' CAUSED BY ABUSIVE PRIESTS
description: Speaking to a public audience about the child sexual abuse crisis for the first time since it engulfed the Roman Catholic Church this year, Pope John Paul II called the crimes and misdeeds of some priests a source of shame today and urged young Catholics not to lose faith.

title: On Wings of Eagles, the Fate of a California Island
description: Eight new residents moved onto Santa Cruz island this week and into homes with some of the most sweeping views in the state.

title: Bailey Captures Go for Wand
description: The Canadian filly Dancethruthedawn, with the red-hot jockey Jerry Bailey aboard, waited patiently for three quarters of a mile and exploded to an effortless victory in the Grade I $250,000 Go for Wand Handicap today at Saratoga.
