description: To the Editor:

title: Voters in Ontario, Calif.
Can I Get A Witness?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Slums of Haiti
description: A decision by the U.S. and European countries to block some $500 million in Haitian aid in order to encourage greater democracy has deepened Haiti's poverty, critics say. Poverty and sewage are breeding in a land where one Haitian says, "only animals should live."

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Income Falls At Bank
description: Kookmin Bank, Korea's largest commercial bank, reported a 36 percent drop in net income in the second quarter from the similar period last year, largely because of exposure to Hynix Semiconductor and to the need to make provisions for consumer loans. Kookmin Bank calculated the loss based on the combined profit from April through May last year of Kookmin and the Housing and Commercial Bank, which Kookmin merged with last November. Kookmin, in the midst of a drive to bring its information technology standards to the same level as those in banks in the United States and Europe, said it earned $410 million in the second quarter this year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, CHARLES A.
description: LEE-Charles A. Of Manhattan, retired AMOCO executive, died Friday of cancer. He was 81 years old, born in Arkansas. Mr. Lee attended USC prior to serving in the Army 12th Armored Division during WWII. Surviving are his two sisters in Jonesboro, AR, ten nieces and nephews and their children. The family will hold a private service.

title: Corrections
description: The Family Fare column in Weekend on Friday, and a related picture caption, misspelled the name of a Mexican restaurant in Greenwich Village that offers free cooking classes for children. It is Calle Nueve, not Neuve.

title: The Tears of Joy at Quecreek, Pa.
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE GROUND: In Seattle; Old Economy Still Vital In High-Technology City
description: High technology, with Microsoft at the helm, has put Seattle on the map. Still, lumber and agriculture formed the city's industrial backbone, and the old economy continues to play an important role in the Puget Sound area. The retailers Nordstrom and Costco are here, as are the insurance giant Safeco (which has acquired naming rights to the home of the Seattle Mariners, Safeco Field) and, of course, Starbucks and its ubiquitous coffee houses.

title: Rescuers Lead 46 Beached Whales Back to Deeper Waters
description: More than 50 pilot whales marooned themselves on a beach on Cape Cod Bay today, but most of them were returned to deeper waters after an intense eight-hour effort by rescuers.

title: U.S.O.C. Nominates Interim Chief to Stay On
description: Trying to restore calm within its leadership, the executive committee of the United States Olympic Committee nominated Marty Mankamyer today to serve as president for the next two and a half years, filling out the term of Sandra Baldwin, who resigned under pressure in May.

title: Health Clues During Pregnancy
description: Women who give birth to premature or low-weight infants should take it as a warning to keep an eye on their own health, researchers say.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Perelman Coup in 2001 Is a Retreat in 2002
description: Ronald O. Perelman's trading coup of 2001 came unwound yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERDY, IRVING
description: BERDY-Irving. On July 28, 2002. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Alan and Judith. Dear father-inlaw of Eleanor. Loving brother of Myrtle Seiden. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to NY Hospital, Department of Otolaryngology. Services Wednesday 11:30am at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Princeton Says a Few Students Had Access to Yale Web Site
description: Princeton University said yesterday that a few people who used campus computers to gain access to a Yale Web site for applicants were not university employees but students, including a Yale applicant.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Cable Fire Stalls Path Service
description: PATH train service between New York and New Jersey was suspended for two hours last night because of a cable fire at the Pavonia station in Jersey City, the Port Authority police said. ''It was a live cable, with electricity in it, and they had to get that shut down to get the fire out,'' said Sgt. John O'Donnell. Service to Journal Square from Manhattan stopped around 8:30 p.m., and service to Hoboken a short time later. The only trains running went between Grove Street and Newark, Sergeant O'Donnell said. Service was restored by 10:39 p.m., the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLIS, CELIA
description: MARGOLIS-Celia. On July 28, 2002 at her residence in the Hebrew Home of Greater Washington. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin Margolis, she is survived by her son David Margolis of NYC, daughter Phyllis Zucker of Potomac, MD, daughter-in-law Bobbie Margolis and son-inlaw Norbert Zucker, six grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Funeral service will be held on July 31, 2002 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street, NY at 10am followed by burial at Baron Hirsch Cemetery on Staten Island. DanzanskyGoldberg Memorial Chapel, Inc. 1-800-281-1471

title: As Career Wanes, Armey's Fund-Raising Waxes
description: Dick Armey may be retiring from Congress, but he is not retiring from Republican fund-raising.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: No Bail For Smuggling Suspect
description: An Egyptian man who successfully sought American citizenship while he was under federal investigation for violation of currency reporting requirements is being held without bail. The man, Alaa Al-Sadawi, 31, of Jersey City, is accused of attempting to smuggle $659,000 to Cairo in his parents' suitcases on April 30, officials said yesterday. On Friday, a federal judge denied bail to Mr. Al-Sadawi because he was deemed a likely flight risk. It is unlawful to transfer more than $10,000 to a foreign country without reporting the transaction to the Treasury Department. Mr. Al-Sadawi, who became a citizen July 8, could face up to 10 years in prison if convicted. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Tunnel Vision; Amazing Secrets of the Third Rail
description: The people who ensure that electric power is supplied constantly and consistently to the New York City subway get very little attention.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Egypt: 2nd Conviction For Dissident
description: Saad Eddin Ibrahim, the Egyptian-American democracy activist, was convicted for a second time of defaming Egypt, among other charges, and rapidly sentenced to seven years in prison. Mr. Ibrahim, a sociology professor, had won a new trial in a case that many rights activists in Egypt viewed as an attempt to still voices of dissent. Various Western embassies and rights organizations condemned the second verdict, with the American Embassy expressing concern for the health of Mr. Ibrahim, who is 63. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

title: Untangling Muddy Waters and His Blues
description: CAN'T BE SATISFIED

title: Creating a New Carmen By Playing Against Type
description: Anne Sofie von Otter's first Carmen, in the new production that opened here this evening, is a shock -- indeed, a double shock. This is the daring triumph of a singer going right against her usual statuesque demeanor and beyond the aloofness communicated by her superb vocal composure. In breaking her own mold, she also reveals a Carmen who is complete yet of a different kind.

title: One Woman's Account Of Two Hotel Experiences
description: A FEMALE business traveler reports on a two-night trip she made recently to the Phoenix area:

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Kathleen Brookbanks was named to the new post of managing director for the Midwest operations of OMD USA, based in Chicago, part of the OMD Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group. She had been managing director at the Chicago office of Mindshare, part of the WPP Group.

title: Drive by Some in U.S. to Hit Iraq Frustrates Jordan's King
description: King Abdullah II of Jordan, stopping here on his way to a meeting with President Bush in Washington, said today that elements of the American government were ''fixated'' on attacking Iraq and that only Secretary of State Colin L. Powell understood the true dimensions of the challenge.

title: Front Row
description: The Party of the Year Returns

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Cart Used to Retake Cockpit On Sept. 11, Book Suggests
description: An assistant United States attorney told relatives of people who died on United Flight 93, the hijacked jet that crashed in western Pennsylvania on Sept. 11, that he believed that the passengers had broken down the cockpit door with a food cart, a book being published on Tuesday says.

title: Lessons From a 'Good' Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEMMERER, MARY ELI ZABETH
description: KEMMERER - Mary Eli zabeth. A former board member and financial supporter of many national, state and community organizations in New Jersey and daughter of noted industrialist Ernest K. Halbach, died on Monday, July 29, 2002, at her home in Basking Ridge, NJ. She was 85 years old. Born in Haverford, PA, Mrs. Kemmerer lived most of her life in Short Hills, NJ, where she was a member of the board of directors of numerous organizations including New Jersey Roadside Council, Millburn Community Council, Millburn-Short Hills Neighborhood House, American Red Cross (the Millburn-Short Hills Chapter) and Short Hills Garden Club. She was active also in such organizations as Garden Club of America, Girl Scouts of America, Christ Church in Short Hills and Overlook Hospital, as well as a sustaining member of the Junior League of the Oranges and Short Hills. Mrs. Kemmerer was a generous and tireless supporter of other charitable organizations such as: Nature Conservancy, Paper Mill Playhouse and the Belize Zoo. Mrs. Kemmerer was the oldest daughter of Ernest K. Halbach, founder of the predecessor company to (GAF) General Analyne and Film Company and a member of the War Production Board during World War II. Wife of businessman John L. Kemmerer Jr., Chairman of Kemmerer Resources and its predecessor companies, Kemmerer Corporation and Kemmerer Coal Company, among numerous other energy and resource companies. She spent summers in Nantucket Island (Maine) for many years and was a parttime resident of Sun Valley, ID. Besides her husband, Mrs. Kemmerer is survived by the couple's three children, Constance A. Kemmerer, Elizabeth K. Gray and John L. Kemmerer III, and six grandchildren and her younger sister, Anne H. Bumsted. A memorial service is planned at Fellowship Village, Liberty Corner, NJ, on Friday, August 2, 2002. The family requests that donations in lieu of flowers be made to American Red Cross (Millburn-Short Hills Chapter).

title: Race Is Seen as Real Guide To Track Roots of Disease
description: Challenging the widely held view that race is a ''biologically meaningless'' concept, a leading population geneticist says that race is helpful for understanding ethnic differences in disease and response to drugs.

title: U.S. Honors an Old Friend
description: Paul-Yves-Roch-Gilbert du Motier was well on his way to becoming an honorary American citizen this month when historians noted that his name was being rendered too short. So Congress made things right by tacking ''Marie-Joseph'' to the beginning of it, fully identifying the man George Washington called simply ''my dear Marqs.''

title: Hernndez Makes Case to Stay
description: Orlando Hernndez pitched before hordes of scouts in spring training, when it seemed likely that the Yankees would trade him. Other teams monitored him again a few weeks ago, after the Yankees traded for Jeff Weaver.

title: Rebellious Bodies Dim the Glow of 'Natural' Biotech Drugs
description: The promise of many biotechnology drugs is that they are the body's own solutions. Human proteins like insulin and growth hormones, the same substances that the body uses every day, are made through genetic engineering and given to people who do not make enough of the proteins on their own.

title: MERRILL REPLACED RESEARCH ANALYST WHO UPSET ENRON
description: In the summer of 1998, when it was eager to win more investment banking business from Enron, Merrill Lynch replaced a research analyst who had angered Enron executives by rating the company's stock ''neutral'' with an analyst who soon upgraded the rating, according to Congressional investigators.

title: Felony Charges Dropped Against Iverson
description: A municipal judge in Philadelphia dropped all the felony charges against Allen Iverson yesterday in connection with an incident earlier this month in which he was accused of breaking into an apartment armed with a gun in search of his wife after a domestic dispute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, MAURICE
description: FEINBERG - Maurice. On July 27, 2002. At age 82. Devoted husband of Carol Jaffa Feinberg. Loving father of Nancy Feinberg and John Tobin, Hope and Paul Schroy and David and Marsha Feinberg. Proud grandfather of Gregory, Brian, Jacob, Rebecca, Charles, Nina, and James. Beloved brother of Frank and Herbert. Adored son of Harry and Dorothy Feinberg, and Charles and May Jaffa. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, July 29, 7-9 PM. Funeral service Tuesday, July 30, 11:30 AM. Interment to follow at Old Mount Carmel Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a biographical sketch on Sunday about a World Trade Center victim, Firefighter Joseph Rivelli Jr. of Ladder 25 in Manhattan, misidentified the area where he lived with his wife, Cheryl. It was Inwood, the town on Long Island -- not the neighborhood of that name in Upper Manhattan.

title: A 'Bland' but Powerful Type of Person Is Taking Over
description: At first blush, Gunter Thielen, a mechanical engineer and economist who is fast approaching his 60th birthday, seems an unexpected choice to replace the once highflying Thomas Middelhoff as chief executive of Bertelsmann, the German giant that is the world's fifth-biggest media company.

title: When Civilians Die: Moral Differences
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Sides With Officer In Killing of Man on Subway
description: A city police officer was justified when he fatally shot an apparently deranged man Sunday who menaced passengers on a subway train in the Bronx with knives and later stabbed a police lieutenant in the arm, according to a preliminary police investigation.

title: Fearing More Than Fear Itself
description: Are some people just born more anxious than others?

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Ex-Leader's Immunity
description: Lawyers for opposition legislators mounted a high court challenge to the judiciary's authority to decide whether the legislature can strip former President Frederick Chiluba of immunity from prosecution. Earlier this month, Parliament voted to lift the immunity of Mr. Chiluba, who left office in January and has been accused of presiding over a government of thieves. Mr. Chiluba challenged the vote, and it was stayed by a high court judge. A ruling is expected on Aug. 16. Henri Cauvin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARPS, RUTH COLLICOTT
description: ARPS-Ruth Collicott. Formerly of New York City, died on July 29, 2002, at Seabury Retirement Community, Bloomfield, Conn., at age 95. Wife of the late Leslie H. Arps, a founding partner of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, she is survived by four nephews. Mrs. Arps was born in Evansville, Indiana, and graduated from Ohio State University in 1929. She was a past President of the Women's Division of the Legal Aid Society of New York, and an active fund raiser for the New York City YWCA. Mrs. Arps also established scholarships at Indiana State University in memory of her parents, Jacob and Lydia Gemmer Collicott and at Ohio State University, College of Education, for graduates of Columbus, Ohio, public schools and at Oberlin College in memory of her mother and her aunt, Esther Gemmer Wattles. A memorial service will be held at Seabury Retirement Community at 2:00 PM, Thursday, August 1, 2002.

description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUSHNER, IRMA SUE
description: KUSHNER-Irma Sue on July 28, 2002, of Fort Lee, NJ. Survived by her beloved husband Alexander, stepsons David and Nanci, and Steven and Lynne, grandchildren Briana, Luke, Jagger and Amelia, and a brother Sherwin and Joyce. Services are today, 10:30 am at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Our Corner of the Universe
description: To the Editor:

title: How They Survived Cold
description: A person immersed in 50-degree water can die within three hours from hypothermia, the loss of body heat. When body temperature dips below 85 degrees Fahrenheit, most people will have seizures, and below 82 their hearts will stop.

title: RAYOVAC IS BUYING BATTERY UNIT OF GERMAN RIVAL
description: The Rayovac Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the consumer battery business of a German rival, Varta, for $256.8 million. Adding Varta's $390 million in sales last year would give Rayovac more than $1 billion in revenue and make it Europe's second-largest battery maker, after Duracell, a unit of the Gillette Company, Rayovac said. The purchase will increase the proportion of Rayovac's sales that are made outside North America to 55 percent from 15 percent three years ago. Rayovac, based in Madison, Wis., said the acquisition would add to earnings in its next fiscal year. Rayovac has not determined whether it will lay people off or close plants.

title: Olympian Sues to Play Football And Keep His Endorsements
description: Can an Olympic skier play college football and still keep the endorsements and acting opportunities he gained as a freestyle champion in moguls skiing? Jeremy Bloom and his advisers say yes. The N.C.A.A., so far, has said no. Now Bloom has sued the N.C.A.A. in what he says is a last-ditch effort to make his ''childhood dreams'' come true.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBY, BARBARA JEAN
description: RUBY-Barbara Jean. Suddenly on July 26, 2002 at age 60. Beloved wife of the late Robert O'Donnell, loving daughter of Alice and the late Elmer Ruby. Here they were led by George Jacobs, who was playing with Ralph Katz, and were the defending champions.

title: Sales Abroad Push Profit 20% Higher At Honda
description: The Honda Motor Company said today that earnings rose 20 percent in the April-June quarter, thanks to strong demand overseas for its minivans and sport utility vehicles. But weaker sales at home, a stronger yen and a potential slowdown in United States clouded the company's outlook.

title: Arthritis: Your 'Reward' for Wear and Tear
description: Nearly 21 million Americans are all too familiar with the pain of osteoarthritis, a leading cause of life-changing disability in this country. It is a chronic condition that can only become more common as the population grows older, since the incidence rises as much as tenfold as people age from 30 to 65.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIERMAN, MARVIN W. MD.
description: BIERMAN-Marvin W. MD. age 64 of Fairfax, VA, formerly of Pomona, NY. Died from Cancer on July 27. He is survived by his beloved wife Baila, children Naomi, Howard and Bernard, son-in-law Richard, and a large circle of loving family and friends. He graduated from NYU Medical School in 1962, completed an internship and residency in Obstetrics and Gynecology at Meadowbrook Hospital, served in the Army Medical Corps, then opened a private practice in Rockland County with Sol Levine, MD. He was a staff member at Good Samaritan and Nyack Hospitals. Dr. Bierman was a devoted, tireless and compassionate physician who brought over 3,000 babies into this world. Memorial service to be held on Sunday August 4th at 1pm, Northern VA Jewish Community Center. A memorial bridge will be constructed at Meadowlark Botanical Gardens; contributions can be sent to: MBG, 9750 Meadowlark Gardens Court, Vienna, VA 22182

title: Denny's Selects a Unit of Publicis
description: The Denny's restaurant chain, part of the Denny's Corporation, said yesterday that it had selected Publicis in Mid America in Dallas, part of the American operations of the Publicis Groupe , to handle its account, with spending estimated at $50 million.

description: Ford Motor gave Mark Schulz, president of its Asia Pacific unit, added responsibility today for South American operations as the company, the second-largest automaker, shifts executive assignments.

description: I am writing this the morning after my last dinner at the Russian Tea Room, the restaurant this newspaper called ''that storied preserve of infused vodka, glinting caviar and buttery blini.''

title: Giants and Shockey Agree
description: Tight end Jeremy Shockey, the Giants' first-round pick, agreed to terms tonight and was expected to participate in practice Tuesday, after missing five days of minicamp.

title: Drug Maker's Profit Rises
description: King Pharmaceuticals said today that its second-quarter profit increased 2.8 percent on higher sales of its Altace heart medicine and Levoxyl thyroid treatment. Net income rose to $58.4 million, or 24 cents a share, from $56.8 million, or 25 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 37 percent, to $282.5 million, from $206.5 million. The company had an expense of $17.6 million to write down the value of convertible notes it holds in a biotechnology company, Novavax, to reflect a drop in the value of Novavax shares, which have fallen 77 percent this year.

Her children, Jane and Peter, Alice and Michael; her grandchildren, Craig and M.J., Karen, Wendy and Liza; her great-grandchildren, Nicholas, Claire and Owen; and her ''Sister Natalia'' will miss her vivacious spirit and ''Auntie Mame'' qualities.

title: Bush Criticizes Senate's Version of Welfare Bill as Harmful
description: President Bush directed unusually harsh criticism at the Senate today for its version of a welfare bill, which he said would hurt the people it was trying to help. Almost immediately afterward, he collected more than $1 million at a Republican fund-raiser.

description: Merrill Replaced Analyst On Enron, Inquiry Finds

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bid For Miner Is Raised
description: The Canadian gold miner Placer Dome said it would add 35 cents a share in cash to its hostile, all-stock bid for AurionGold of Australia. The revised bid values Aurion at 2.97 Australian dollars ($1.59) a share. Aurion's stock closed at 2.88 Australian dollars a share on the Australian stock exchange, down 15 cents. Aurion said it would consider the revised offer, which expires on Aug. 7. AurionGold rejected Placer's initial offer of 17.5 Placer shares for every 100 Aurion shares. It has been seeking a rival bid, but none has appeared so far. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Umpires Enlist Physicists To Fight Computer System
description: Portraying its dispute with the commissioner's office as ''man against the machine,'' the World Umpires Association named a panel of seven nationally known physicists and engineers yesterday to evaluate the computerized system that monitors calls of balls and strikes.

title: Vote on Bankruptcy Bill Is Stalled by Abortion Provision
description: Senate leaders are expected to delay a final vote on a bill to overhaul the nation's bankruptcy rules until at least September, Congressional officials said today.

title: Players Union Is Holding Off On Determining a Strike Date
description: With talk of a strike date swirling everywhere in baseball except at the bargaining table, the union's executive board is expected to address that critical step next Monday or Tuesday at the earliest, a lawyer familiar with the union's thinking said yesterday.

It is Transocean, not Treansocean. Because of an editing error, a list of companies that use offshore addresses or plan to do so misstated the locations for five. Transocean, Global SantaFe and Noble Drilling use the Cayman Islands; Gold Reserve uses Canada; and McDermott International uses Panama. None use Bermuda.

title: Humpty Dumpty Restored: When Disorder Lurches Into Order
description: Not all the universe is falling apart all of the time.

title: Singing Spooky And Brash Blues
description: In common practice, the shortest route to electric blues music is to the good-time kind: wry, midtempo, rocking and made for sports bars. But James Blood Ulmer, a guitarist best known over the last 25 years as a vanguard-dwelling semi-jazz musician, has the power to overthrow that amiability for a spooky netherworld. And he did it at several crucial moments during a performance last Tuesday at Rockefeller Park in Battery Park City.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bank Lowers Forecast
description: Spain's largest bank, Santander Central Hispano, has reduced its 2002 profit forecasts, blaming weakness in Latin America. But weakness there was partly offset in the first half by a recovery in European retail operations and significant cost-cutting. The bank reported a 13 percent decline in first-half earnings, to 1.2 billion euros ($1.18 billion) from 1.38 billion last year, and said 2002 profit, originally forecast to rise 10 percent, would be 2.25 billion euros, a decline of 10 percent. Trading income fell 43.3 percent, to 253 million euros, mostly because of the Latin American economic crisis. Profit from European retail banking rose 21 percent, while the group cut costs 11 percent. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Bush Energy Proposal Seeks To 'Clear Skies' by 2018
description: President Bush announced today that he had submitted to Congress legislation that he said would reduce most power plant emissions by 70 percent by 2018 using market incentives.

title: INSTITUTIONAL PHARMACY AGREES TO BUY RIVAL FOR STOCK
description: Genesis Health Ventures, an institutional pharmacy, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a rival, NCS HealthCare, for $32 million in stock, after the industry leader, Omnicare, said it had made a cash offer for NCS worth almost twice as much a share. Genesis, which owns the nation's third-largest institutional pharmacy business, said it would exchange 0.1 share of its stock for each share of NCS, valuing the company at $1.60 a share, more than twice NCS's closing price on Friday. Genesis will also assume $308 million in NCS debt. The purchase by Genesis, based in Kennett Square, Pa., would create the nation's second-largest provider of pharmacy services to long-term care centers. Omnicare, based in Covington, Ky., said it offered $3 a share on Sunday after NCS refused to meet with it. Omnicare said it still hoped to acquire NCS, based in Beachwood, Ohio.

title: Fiat Reports Loss and Sees No Profit for Year
description: With its money-losing automotive unit continuing to drag down other profitable operations, Fiat reported today a loss for the second-quarter and said that it did not expect to earn any money this year.

title: When P.E. Class Includes Exercise
description: Changing physical education classes so that students spend more class time in motion can yield measurable improvements in fitness, a new study reports.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Concern To Treat Options As Expenses
description: Computer Associates, the world's fifth-largest software maker, said yesterday that it would begin treating stock options as expenses starting in April, trimming annual earnings by 2 cents a share. Computer Associates will treat the options as an expense based on the fair value at the date the options are granted, the company, based in Islandia, N.Y., said in a statement. Critics of omitting stock options from income statements have said that the practice, widely used by software companies, inflates profits by understating expenses. It also encourages executives to use improper accounting to bolster the value of their options, some investors have said. Currently, rules require only an estimate of option costs in accounting footnotes. Shares of Computer Associates rose 60 cents, to $8.70. They have dropped 75 percent this year.

description: After concluding a two-day visit, Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov said North Korea was prepared to resume negotiations with the United States and Japan ''without any preliminary conditions.'' Mr. Ivanov met for five hours with North Korea's reclusive leader, Kim Jong Il, delivering a letter from President Vladimir V. Putin, who appears eager to have Russia act as a broker on the Korean Peninsula peace effort. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Hoping an Outsider Plus a Bottom-Line Approach Equals Reform
description: From the symbolic announcement in the gloriously renovated yet pristinely empty Tweed Courthouse to the rsum of the candidate, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's surprise choice to head a newly centralized New York City school system seems calculated to convey one thing: a deep distrust of professional educators, or at least of professional education as practiced in New York City over the last 33 years.

title: Profit Increases Sixfold at Tyson Foods
description: Tyson Foods Inc., the world's largest meat processor, said today that its quarterly profit jumped almost sixfold on higher chicken prices and the acquisition of beef and pork business from IBP Inc. last year.

title: WAL-MART SAYS JULY SALES WILL HIT LOW END OF FORECAST
description: Wal-Mart Stores said yesterday that its July sales would be at the low end of the company's forecast because sales last week at stores open at least a year were lower than expected. The company forecast an increase of 5 percent to 7 percent, a spokesman, Tom Williams, said. Wal-Mart did not specify its forecast for the week ended Friday, he said. Wal-Mart found it tough to match year-earlier results, when sales were helped by tax-rebate checks, Mr. Williams said. More than $38 billion in federal income-tax rebate checks of $300 to $600 were mailed to consumers last year starting on July 20.

title: National Briefing: Plains
description: NEBRASKA: POLICE SEARCH MINORITIES MORE An examination of traffic stops by the State Patrol found that blacks and Hispanics were far more likely to be searched than whites. Only 1 percent of the white drivers were searched, compared with 7 percent of black drivers and 6 percent of Hispanic drivers. A 2001 law requires all law officers in the state to document the race and ethnicity of those stopped. (NYT)

title: An Untested Air Pressure System, and a Bobbing Lunch Pail, Brought Relief to Miners
description: A corned beef sandwich, two bottles of soda and an air supply system that had never been tried before sustained the nine miners who were trapped for nearly 80 hours underground until Sunday morning, some of them said today.

title: Political Fires
description: While favorable conditions appear to have slowed the mammoth blaze in California's Sequoia National Forest that has been threatening some of the world's biggest and oldest trees, there has been no stopping efforts by the timber industry and opportunistic politicians to exploit Western wildfires for commercial and ideological gain.

description: Two gunmen convicted of killing three people and wounding two others in an execution-style shooting above the Carnegie Delicatessen in Midtown Manhattan were sentenced to life in prison yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: The Bronx: Missing Girl Is Found
description: A 9-year-old Bronx girl was found safe after spending the night alone near a park, the authorities said. The girl, Molly-Ann Abreu, was left near Claremont Park in the Bathgate section Sunday night or early yesterday by her mother, Myrna Diaz, 50, after Ms. Diaz became intoxicated during a Sunday night street festival in Manhattan, the police said. A family found the girl around 6 a.m. and notified the police last night. The police said that the child appeared to be in good health and good spirits. The Administration for Children's Services will determine where she will be placed, and the police said that charges were pending against Ms. Diaz. Deputy Chief Joseph J. Reznick, commanding officer of Bronx detectives, said that Ms. Diaz did not have a police record, but MacLean Guthrie, a spokeswoman for Children's Services, said that there were three substantiated accusations of abuse or neglect of children against her, in 1982, 1984 and 1991. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Suicide Bomber Wounds Five in Jerusalem
description: TAPUAH, West Bank, July 30  Two Israeli brothers from this settlement were shot to death by masked Palestinian gunmen this morning when they stepped out of their tanker truck to sell diesel fuel in a neighboring Palestinian village.

description: TAB Products, a document-storage and tracking company, agreed today to be bought by HS Morgan Limited Partnership for about $34 million.

title: Technology Briefing | Palm Proposes Reverse Stock Split
description: Shares in Palm Inc. fell as much as 19 percent yesterday after the maker of hand-held computers said that if shareholders approved, the Palm board would choose a reverse stock split ratio from 1 for 10 to 1 for 20, and begin it any time before April 1. Palm's stock on the first day of trading was worth 121 times what it was yesterday. The reverse stock split would slash the number of shares outstanding. Shares in Palm, based in Santa Clara, Calif., have plunged as it reported losses during five of the last six quarters, while consumers and businesses spent less on electronics. Shares fell 18 cents yesterday, or 13.2 percent, to $1.18. The reverse split is intended to bolster the stock price ahead of a planned break into two companies: one making operating-system software and the other building computers.

title: Venezuela Inquiry Clears U.S. Aides
description: The State Department's inspector general has concluded that department officials did not act inappropriately during the brief ouster of the Venezuelan president, Hugo Chvez, in April.

description: Even as the Democratic candidates for governor ratchet up campaigning in the final weeks before the primary, their advisers are anticipating a period when they will have to soften the tone, shift the emphasis to leadership and at least evoke a mood of reconciliation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERNUCHIN, PAUL, PH.D.
description: CHERNUCHIN-Paul, Ph.D. Of Palm Beach Gardens, FL. and New York, N.Y. died Saturday, July 27, 2002 at Palm Beach Gardens Medical Center. He was 80 years old. Paul leaves behind his wife Elayne Link, his children, Michael and Cindy and their spouses Janis Diamond and Dan Barsky, his grandchildren, Jennifer and Jordan Barsky, and his sisters Beatrice Schuman and Toby Scholl. Dr. Paul Chernuchin received his B.A. from the University of Michigan, his M.A. from George Washington University, and his Ph.D. from the University of London. Paul headed his own company, Chernuchin Associates, Inc., and was an adjunct associate professor at New York University. He was known for his development of the Chernuchin Pictographs, a psychological projective technique, his love for his family, his zest for life and his sense of humor. We will all miss him. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made in Paul's memory to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, 381 Park Avenue South, Suite 507, New York, NY 10016, 212-689-2860.

description: CONWAY, Ark., July 29 (AP) — An 8-year-old girl was roused from her bed on Sunday by a stranger who told her the house was on fire, then sexually assaulted in her yard as her family slept, the police said.

description: Zach Lind, the drummer for Jimmy Eat World, once confessed that his band had an unusual way of passing time on the tour bus: the four members watch videotapes of past performances, looking for ways to improve.

title: Mayor Bloomberg's Chancellor
description: Joel Klein, Mayor Michael Bloomberg's choice for New York City schools chancellor, is widely known as bright, down to earth and incorruptible. When he was head of the antitrust division of the Justice Department under President Bill Clinton, he took on Microsoft with energy and force. He disabled price-fixing cartels and blocked mergers that did not serve customers well. Since January he has been chairman and chief executive of the American subsidiary of the giant media company Bertelsmann.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Phone Concern Is Selling Assets
description: In its latest move to reduce debt, France Tlcom plans to eliminate its stake in STMicroelectronics, a maker of semiconductors, by selling a $500 million Eurobond that must be exchange for shares in the manufacturer. France Tlcom, which has debt of more than 60 billion euros ($59.21 billion), said last week that it would sell a broadcasting unit, reducing debt by 1.6 billion euros, and plans to reduce debt by a further 800 million euros by selling Casema, a Dutch cable TV company. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Budget Plan Cut
description: Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift vetoed $355 million from the Legislature's budget plan. Ms. Swift said the cuts were necessary for a balanced budget after state revenue shrunk by $2.5 billion in the last year. The budget plan includes a $1.14 billion tax increase, the largest in the nation this year. The Legislature can vote to override the vetoes. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: He Dresses the Goddesses of Broadway
description: The second-act curtain was about to go up on ''Hairspray,'' and though the stage version of the John Waters movie still had two weeks of previews left, it felt like opening night at the Neil Simon Theater. Anne Kaufman Schneider, the daughter of George S. Kaufman, was in the audience. So were Polly Bergen and Betty Buckley. And when the performance ended and the cheering subsided, among those making their way backstage to greet the show's star, Harvey Fierstein, in his soda-pink dressing room was the actress Patricia Neal.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Misses Profit Forecast
description: The Swiss reinsurer Converium Holding reported a first-half net profit of $31.6 million, in contrast to last year's loss of $60.5 million. But the result, hurt by higher write-offs for investment-related losses, was less than the $65 million net profit that analysts had expected. The company, which was spun off from Zurich Financial Services last year, has raised its prices and reorganized itself to improve its bottom line. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Officials Seek More Designers For Downtown
description: Responding to criticism of the plans to rebuild Lower Manhattan, officials overseeing the development said yesterday that they wanted to open up the design effort to more architects and planners.

description: For Ruben Rivera, baseball purgatory was half a season in Tulsa and Oklahoma City. After playing for the Texas Rangers' affiliates in those cities, Rivera was called to the majors on July 11 and has started every game since, including tonight's against the Yankees.

title: National Briefing: South
description: NORTH CAROLINA: EX-TITLIST CITES PHOTOS The former Miss North Carolina says she stepped down on July 23 because her abusive former fiance had told officials of the Miss America Organization about topless photographs of her. The contestant, Rebekah Revels, said on the ABC program "Good Morning America" that her former fiance, whom she would not identify, had taken two pictures while she was changing clothes. Miss America Organization officials said Ms. Revels was not forced to resign, but she said they were going to deny her a chance to win the national title. (AP)

title: British Judge Splits Ruling On Suit by Cantor Fitzgerald
description: A British High Court judge handed down a split ruling today in a bitter dispute of the rival bond brokerage firms Cantor Fitzgerald and Icap, backing Cantor's accusations that Icap unlawfully poached one broker after the firm lost 658 employees in the attack on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHECHTER, ROSALIE CO HEN
description: SCHECHTER - Rosalie Co hen, 88, of Harrison, NY, died Sunday, July 28, after a brief illness. Loving wife of Emanuel and son, Stephen, Rosalie C. Schechter was a member of the Honorary Council of Hadassah and a former National Vice President, National Secretary, Recording Secretary and most recently, Hadassah's United Nations Non-Governmental Organization representative. She was a past President of the Westchester Region and Harrison Chapter of Hadassah. A lifelong advocate for civil rights, she was a former President of the Harrison League of Women Voters, served on the League's Region Board and served on a number of town and schoolappointed committees. A native of Huntington, WVA, she graduated from RandolphMacon Woman's College and was a member of Phi Beta Kappa and Phi Gamma Mu honorary societies. She is survived by her brothers, Bernard Cohen of Chattanooga, TN, Charles Cohen of Houston, TX, and sister, Mickey Goldenberg of Huntington, WVA. Services will be held on Tuesday, July 30, at 11AM at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Hadassah Medical Organization, 50 West 58th Street, NY, NY 10019-2500.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Industrial Output Declines
description: Output at Japan's factories fell for the first time in five months but was expected to rise the rest of the summer. Industrial production declined a larger-than-expected 0.7 percent in June from the previous month, partly a reaction to an unusually large gain in May. The government also expects output to rise 1.6 percent in July and another 1.8 percent in August. Exports of electronics and automobiles to the United States have largely been behind the gains. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Retrieval Efforts Aim to Bring Ironclad Monitor Back to Life
description: After 140 years at the bottom of the sea, the 160-ton gun turret of the Monitor is to be lifted into daylight soon off Cape Hatteras, N.C., in the culmination of a five-year, $14 million effort to save the famous ironclad.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: LOSS AT PUBLISHER Pearson , the owner of The Financial Times and large publishing businesses, reported a first-half loss of 207 million ($323 million), compared with a loss of 118 million in the period a year ago. Sales slumped 3 percent, to 1.8 billion. Marjorie Scardino, the chief executive, who joined Pearson in 1997 with a mandate to reshape the company, has made multiple acquisitions but has so far been unable to shield Pearson from the sharp decline in advertising revenue. Ms. Scardino called the advertising slump the worst in 30 years, but said she expected the educational and consumer publishing businesses to help Pearson withstand the difficult climate.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Belmar: Crane Accident
description: A crane operator yesterday lost control of a 114-ton beam that split in two and sent the crane toppling into a river, a spokesman for the State Department of Transportation said. The operator, whose name was not released, was not injured. He works for AMEC Construction Management, a Florida contractor hired to build a new bridge on Route 35, over the Shark River. Micah Rasmussen, a transportation spokesman, said the operator was helping to install a vertical beam when the beam rolled onto its side. One piece damaged a pedestrian walkway of the drawbridge, while the other fell into the river, he said. The cause of the accident is unclear, Mr. Rasmussen said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

description: With premiums soaring for almost every kind of insurance, more than 60 consumer organizations around the country have banded together to mount a campaign against what they regard as price gouging.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Streets And Agencies Renamed
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed several bills into law yesterday that changed the names of two city agencies and a number of city streets. Streets were renamed for several firefighters who died on Sept. 11, and one was renamed for Amadou Diallo, left, the West African immigrant who was shot to death by the police in the vestibule of his Bronx apartment building in 1999. Wheeler Avenue in the Bronx, where Mr. Diallo lived at No. 1157, is now Amadou Diallo Place. The city's Organized Crime Control Commission was renamed the Business Integrity Commission, and the recently merged Health Department and Department of Mental Health, Mental Retardation and Alcoholism Services was renamed the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: 8 Years After Invasion, Haiti Squalor Worsens
description: Sonia Jean-Pierre's life is one of apocalyptic misery. With hardly any food or work, her only refuge is a concrete cell. The searing sun is blotted out by cardboard pasted over the windows. On the wall by her bed, she has scrawled, ''Jesus Christ is coming soon,'' like a promise of salvation to greet her every morning.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Corning Debt Rating Cut To Junk
description: Credit ratings for Corning were cut to junk yesterday by Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's after the company, the world's biggest maker of optical fiber, said it would sell $500 million in preferred stock to raise cash. Moody's, in a statement, cited concern that a recovery in Corning's telecommunications operations would be delayed until well into 2003 as customers scale back spending. S.& P. cited ''depressed conditions and poor prospects for recovery'' in the fiber business and concern about the company's profitability outlook. Corning, unprofitable for five straight quarters, faces waning demand for its telecommunications products this year. The company is selling stock to raise cash for its businesses and to repay debt. Shares purchased through the offering, which will be priced tomorrow, must be converted into common stock in August 2005, Corning said in a statement. The company will use about $105 million of the proceeds to buy Treasury securities to be pledged as collateral to ensure the company can pay dividends on the preferred stock, a spokesman, Dan Collins, said.

title: In Rare Move, U.N. Reviews A U.S. Attack On Afghans
description: A spokesman for the United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan said today that it had conducted an investigation into the July 1 American airstrikes in Oruzgan Province. Villagers say more than 50 civilians died there.

description: Two years ago, as chairman of the German media giant Bertelsmann, Thomas Middelhoff rented out Radio City Music Hall to introduce himself to the company's thousands of New York employees, including book publishers from Random House, record producers from BMG Entertainment and editors from the Bertelsmann portfolio of magazines, including Family Circle and YM.

description: It is getting redundant: a stakes race here at the Spa, a Bobby Frankel horse involved in a photo finish, and a trip to the winner's circle for both runner and trainer. Yesterday it was Nunatall who persevered by a head to win the Grade III $100,000 Lake George Stakes.

description: After a postseason with several controversial shots at the buzzer, the National Basketball Association approved the use of instant replay for the first time yesterday. Beginning in the preseason, referees will automatically review shots taken at the end of each quarter or overtime period. They will not review plays at any other time.

description: An American attack on Iraq could profoundly affect the American economy, because the United States would have to pay most of the cost and bear the brunt of any oil price shock or other market disruptions, government officials, diplomats and economists say.

description: Stocks shot higher in a rally that sent the three major measures up more than 5 percent. The gain was the third in four sessions for the broad market, which has now made a sharp rebound from its five-year low last Tuesday.

Services today, 10am, at Chabad of Riverdale, 535 West 246 St.

title: Stoking a Stock Market 'Revolution'
description: Raymundo Magliano, the chairman of the Bovespa, Latin America's mightiest stock market, heaved a sigh as he checked the monitor perched on his elegant antique desk one afternoon early this month and summed up the state of Brazil's markets by spelling out a Portuguese word: C-A-O-S.

title: Airborne Announces 2nd-Quarter Profit
description: Airborne Inc., an air delivery service, reported a second-quarter profit of $457,000 today. The company has eliminated jobs and closed offices to reduce costs.

title: Glimmerglass Distills Power Of Acceptance And Faith
description: The Glimmerglass Opera here, on the shores of Otsego Lake, has become a magnet for operagoers since 1975, for all the right reasons. Its repertory -- generally four productions each summer -- is a comfortable balance of the familiar and the unusual, usually with some contemporary opera in the mix. Its stagings prize inventiveness over opulence, and its roster is dominated by young singers who throw themselves fully into their roles.

title: Long-Distance Love Affair in Santa Fe
description: The old American West has never seemed the most obvious setting for Haydn, Mozart and Verdi. But if those composers sounded particularly out of place here last week, it was for reasons musical rather than historical. Old-fashioned melody and harmony were out. Color, texture and sheer sonority were in. Living composers, Kaija Saariaho, a Finn, and Annie Gosfield, an American, were the toasts of the town.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Cable Bidders Selected
description: Deutsche Telekom said it had selected five international consortium bidders for the company's cable television units. Deutsche Telekom also said it still intended to sell the six regional units to a single buyer as demanded in most offers. The unidentified groups, selected from nine applicants, are to make binding offers until the end of September., enabling Deutsche Telekom to complete a sale that it has planned for years. The company plans to use the income, estimated at 2 billion euros ($1.97 billion) to 3.5 billion euros, to reduce debt. Petra Kappl (NYT)

description: A former New York Police Department captain who had been chosen to fight corruption on the job pleaded guilty to reckless manslaughter yesterday in a 1999 drunken driving accident that killed a construction worker on the Throgs Neck Bridge.

description: Pope John Paul II arrived here late this afternoon in preparation for the canonization of Central America's first saint, continuing an 11-day trip that represents a test of his stamina and an affirmation of his determination.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stamford: Second Skakel Sentencing Delay
description: The sentencing of Michael Skakel, left, who was convicted last month of killing Martha Moxley, a Greenwich neighbor, in 1975, has been postponed until Aug. 28, despite an objection from prosecutors. It is the second postponement in the case; the first one was granted last month. The sentencing was to take place on Aug. 9, but Judge John F. Kavenewsky granted an extension yesterday in Stamford Superior Court. Michael Sherman, a Skakel defense lawyer, said that the State Probation Department needed more time to prepare its presentencing report. Mr. Skakel, 41, faces 10 years to life for the 1975 murder.

title: Democratic Aspirants Accuse Bush of Economic Blunders
description: Setting out potential lines of attack to use against President Bush in the 2004 election, a parade of prospective Democratic presidential candidates yesterday assailed Mr. Bush's handling of the economy, accusing him of squandering a thriving economy left for him by President Bill Clinton to pursue policies that benefited wealthy Americans.

title: Sports of The Times; Armstrong Also Climbed Over Bias
description: MANY thousands of French spectators cheered Lance Armstrong these past few weeks, but here in the United States, as the Tour de France neared its end with Armstrong triumphant for the fourth straight year, we kept hearing about those who chanted, ''Dop!'' About those with no evidence to support their outcries condemning Armstrong as another drug cheat in what has been a dirty sport.

title: Alternating Between Soothing Fantasy and Balky Reality
description: When Morcheeba released its debut album in 1996, it seemed to be part of a school of trip-hop bands: all brooding, unhurried vamps and breathy vocals. But it soon climbed out of that niche by bolstering atmosphere with melody and structure.

title: Astronomers Chase a Shadow in Effort to Explore Pluto
description: To learn about Pluto, the solar system's tiniest, most distant planet, the best astronomers can do right now is chase its fleeting shadow.

title: Trend of Noneducators Leading Schools
description: Perhaps the most remarked-upon characteristic of the new New York schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein, is that his career was built not on running a classroom or a school but on running a corporation and setting antitrust policy. In choosing a noneducator for the post, however, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg puts New York among a growing number of cities that have looked outside education for their top education job -- and won good results.

description: WASHINGTON, July 30 - Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that Iraq now has mobile biological-weapons laboratories that would be very difficult to bomb, an example, he said, of why air power alone would not destroy all of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction.

The bottles of hard liquor, the fake palm tree and leather armchairs, the men and women dressed in dark wool suits and babbling away on cellphones -- it all looked about as family-oriented as a burlesque show at the Moulin Rouge.

title: In Argentina, Struggling To Survive A Depression
description: ''The Marriage of Figaro'' has been performed many times at the venerable Teatro Coln, but the premiere of the latest production last month came with a twist that reflected the hard times here. Because the collapse of the Argentine economy in December has meant periodic shortages of paper, no program was available for the opera's opening night.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Police Investigate Teenage Boy's Death
description: A 16-year-old boy was found dead last night in the bathroom of the apartment he shared with his father, and the medical examiner is investigating the cause of his death. The boy, Marcin Fiszer of Beach 95th Street in Rockaway Beach, was last seen alive by his father, who left for work around 8:30 on Sunday night and discovered the body when he returned home at 6:40 p.m. yesterday. There were no signs of trauma, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Storm Strikes 3 States

No one was seriously injured, but thousands of residents were still without power. Officials from the National Weather Service were examining farms in the area for evidence that a tornado may have touched ground. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: Ex-Official Defects
description: Alcibiades Hidalgo, a former Cuban deputy foreign minister, has defected to the United States, saying he does not want to be ''one more peon on Dr. Castro's farm.'' Mr. Hidalgo told El Nuevo Herald in Miami that he arrived Thursday on a raft that sank near the Florida coast. Joe Garcia, executive director of the Cuban American National Foundation, said Mr. Hidalgo had told his debriefers that President Fidel Castro has moved to crush any chance of democratic reforms, despite the recent urgings of former President Jimmy Carter. ''He is a big-level defection,'' Mr. Garcia said of Mr. Hidalgo. ''He brings with him some interesting insights.'' David Gonzalez (NYT)
