title: Implacable Force for Family Planning
description: What a moment for an American to take over the world's largest family planning organization.

title: PILOTS AND ENGINEERS APPROVE CONTRACT WITH ATLAS AIR
description: Atlas Air's pilots and flight engineers ratified their first contract with Atlas, a unit of Atlas Air Worldwide Holdings, with 83 percent voting to approve, the Air Line Pilots Association union said yesterday. Atlas, the largest handler of freight for other airlines, and the union reached the 42-month agreement on June 28. Details have not been released. The vote was announced a day before Atlas, based in Purchase, N.Y., is to report second-quarter earnings. The 631 pilots and engineers rejected another proposal in February.

title: The Tears of Joy at Quecreek, Pa.
description: To the Editor:

title: Coach Brings Some Sense to Special Teams
description: The Giants devoted a full practice to special teams the other day and the eyes of some veterans on the sidelines glazed over instantly, as if they were teenagers in a summer driver's ed class. Don't cross over the double yellow lines, contain and pursue the returner, blah, blah, blah. Coach Jim Fassel yelled repeatedly for everybody to pay attention.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Chechnya: U.N. Halts Relief Effort
description: The United Nations suspended most of its relief operations in Chechnya indefinitely after a Russian aid worker's kidnapping. The victim, Nina Davidovich, led a local aid group called Druzhba, or Friendship, which worked with the United Nations Children's Fund. She was kidnapped on July 23 by gunmen who stopped her car near the Chechen capital, Grozny. The suspension, which affects the delivery of medicine and food, as well as mine clearing, underscored the precarious security in the republic. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Plains: Nebraska: Police Search Minorities More
description: An examination of traffic stops by the State Patrol found that blacks and Hispanics were far more likely to be searched than whites. Only 1 percent of the white drivers were searched, compared with 7 percent of black drivers and 6 percent of Hispanic drivers. A 2001 law requires all law officers in the state to document the race and ethnicity of those stopped.

title: From Almost No More To More Than Enough
description: The Minnesota Twins are not supposed to be alive, much less in first place. Their owner wanted them eliminated last winter, canceled like a bad check. They were destined to become ghosts, shadow remnants of baseball's financial nightmare. Contraction, Commissioner Bud Selig called it, a tidy euphemism, as if he wanted to omit a few letters from a word instead of an entire team with a rich history and two World Series titles.

title: Festivals, Festivals Everywhere; Summer Arts Events Multiply, Testing Limits of Growth
description: They began innocently enough, as high-minded diversions on warm summer nights shared with mosquitoes and lake breezes. But this summer the number of arts festivals nationwide has reached an all-time high of about 3,000, drawing an audience estimated at up to 130 million and accounting, by industry estimates, for close to $2 billion in spending.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Inside Art column of Weekend on Friday about the sale of a Charles Willson Peale portrait of George Washington for $5.3 million in June in Cheverny, France, misspelled the names of two of the three purchasers. The buyers were Thomas Colville (not Coville), Stuart Feld (not Stewart) and Vance Jordan.

title: McGreevey Creates a Corporation to Speed School Repairs and Construction
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey signed an executive order today intended to make it easier for school districts to apply for state aid to repair and renovate old buildings or construct new ones.

title: London-Paris Link
description: Busabout Europe, a network linking 66 European cities in 14 countries, will include a one-way trip between London and Paris (worth $45) with multiday passes bought by Aug. 15. It comes with a Flexipass good for 10 days of bus travel in two months ($399) and up to 25 days in four months ($839). Or there's the Consecutive Pass for unlimited travel, for one month ($499) or more. Buses are air-conditioned and nonsmoking. Passes are sold by STA Travel; www.busabout.com and www.statravel.com .

title: Illegal Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Fans Should Know by Now There's No Easy Solution
description: Fans feel they have such a proprietary interest in baseball that they cannot accept the labor dispute as a legitimate difference of opinion between management and labor.

title: Ed Runge, 87, Veteran Umpire Who Was Partial to Pitchers
description: Ed Runge, an American League umpire from 1954 through 1970 and the father and grandfather of major league umpires, died Friday at a hospital in San Diego. He was 87.

title: Bush Signs Broad Changes in Business Laws
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 - In a sign of how profoundly the nation's business scandals and volatile stock market have rocked his administration, a show of solemn pageantry prevailed this morning as President Bush signed a sweeping bill to crack down on corporate fraud.

title: Full Summer
description: One day last week felt a little like fall in New York -- a gray sky, temperatures in the 60's, a temptation to jump ahead a couple of pages in the calendar. Everyone knew that it was just an intermission before the second act of summer really began. Now, here it is.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, BARBARA
description: GORDON-Barbara. In sorrow we record the passing of our beloved member and Board Member. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Melvin N. Sirner, Rabbi Bertram S. Schwarz, Pres.

title: Berkshire to Buy a Gas Pipeline From Dynegy
description: Warren E. Buffett is buying on the cheap again.

title: Filling In the Blanks on Iraq
description: With the Bush administration openly threatening to overthrow Saddam Hussein, a public airing of the pros and cons of intervention is long overdue. Thanks to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, which has planned hearings about Iraq this week, that national discussion may finally commence.

title: Labor to Press for Changes In Corporate Governance
description: Organized labor will announce plans today to throw its considerable weight -- in lobbying and in shareholder fights -- behind efforts to reform stock options, severance pay and pensions.

title: Most of Mostly Mozart Festival Is Canceled by Orchestra Strike
description: Just hours before last night's opening of the Mostly Mozart festival, Lincoln Center announced the cancellation of 20 of the series' concerts, after contract negotiations with the festival orchestra broke down and the players voted to strike.

title: Deadline Near, Cards Make Deal for Rolen
description: All of baseball knew Scott Rolen was unhappy in Philadelphia and wanted out. The Phillies, finally acknowledging that they were bystanders in the playoff race, made it happen yesterday, sending Rolen to the St. Louis Cardinals two days before the trading deadline.

title: The Pope in Guatemala
description: In Guatemala City, the Pope is canonizing Pedro de San Jose Betancur, a 17th century missionary often called "the St. Francis of the Americas," during the Mass. He will be Central America's first saint.

title: The Art of Math
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: At the Helm of New York Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Stranded Whales Dying Despite Rescuers' Efforts
description: It looked like one of the most successful whale rescues people on Cape Cod could remember. But today those hopes were dashed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINOKUR, BRUCE R.
description: WINOKUR-Bruce R. July 29, 2002. We note with sadness the passing of our esteemed friend and colleague, for whom choral music and computers were abiding joys, and the practice of law was a challenge at which he excelled. Bruce will be sorely missed. All of us at Jackson & Nash, LLP offer our condolences to Bruce's family and his friends. We join Bruce's family in asking those who would care to contribute in his memory to consider the Rottenberg Chorale, where Bruce was an enthusiastic member of the bass section for many years. Call 212501-3362 for Chorale details.

title: A dishwashing liquid capitalizes on cutting the grease on dishes -- and the oil on ducks.
description: DAWN, the country's top-selling dishwashing liquid, is introducing an ad campaign tomorrow that departs from the usual depiction of the product's grease-cleaning power in the kitchen to highlight a rather unusual use -- cleaning birds caught in oil spills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, REVY
description: LEVINE-Revy. Of East Brunswick, NJ (formerly Palisades Park). Beloved wife of the late Alfred, devoted mother of Ruth and Robert Boyarsky, dear sister of Judith Stein, loving grandmother of Andrew and Rosalie, Harvey and Colleen, great-grandmother of Keith, Erin, Jeffrey and Brian. Donations may be made to the Daniel Pearl Education Center at Temple B'nai Shalom, East Brunswick NJ. For information, contact ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' 1-800378-1892.

title: Testaverde Hurts Thumb And Jets Hold Breath
description: Vinny Testaverde has made this throw a million times in 16 seasons: a simple toss in another drill in an early-training-camp practice. But this morning, in the Jets' fifth preseason practice, Testaverde's throwing hand met an offensive lineman's helmet, spraining his right thumb and spinning the immediate future of the Jets' quarterback situation into doubt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROHMAN, MICHAEL, M.D.
description: ROHMAN - Michael, M.D. The Administration, Community Advisory Boards, Auxiliaries and Medical Staff of Jacobi Medical Center and North Central Bronx Hospital mourn the untimely death of Dr. Michael Rohman, Thoracic Surgery, Trauma and Critical Care Attending and Professor of Surgery. Dr. Rohman shall always be remembered for his keen diagnostic ability, superb clinical judgement, outstanding operative skill and flawless integrity. Through a lifetime of dedication and service, he has earned the respect, trust, gratitude and affection of his patients, their families and all staff who had the privilege of working with him. We extend our deepest condolences to his beloved wife Joy, his daughters Lisa and Debra, and his four grandchildren. The Administration of the North Bronx Healthcare Network (NBHN) The Community Advisory Boards of the NBHN The Auxiliaries of the NBHN The New York Medical Alliance

title: In the Clover, A Bee Nirvana
description: JOHN MILLER, an owner of Miller Honey Farms in Gackle, N.D., gave me a choice. He could pick me up and shuttle me out to bee country in a flatbed truck or a Corvette.

title: Early Shots by Two Democrats Challenging Pataki; H. Carl McCall
description: This 30-second commercial is the first in H. Carl McCall's campaign for the Democratic nomination for governor and will be broadcast upstate in major broadcast markets, and on cable in New York City, starting today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EMDEN, HARRY D.
description: EMDEN-Harry D. In cherished memory of a beloved father and grandfather. Passed away July 31, 1971. Forever in our hearts. Howard, Jeffrey, James, Robert

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROMMER, ARI
description: FROMMER-Ari. Congregation Ahavath Torah of Englewood, NJ, mourns the passing of our esteemed member. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shmuel Goldin, Rabbi Jeffrey R. Parker, President

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Investigators Link Cracks To Crash
description: The breakup of a China Airlines flight on May 25 that killed 225 people appeared to have begun near the rear cargo door, but the cause is still unknown, investigators said. Metal fatigue cracks have been found in wreckage from near the door, although the cracks are not enough by themselves to have caused the aircraft to come apart, they said. The back of the plane struck a runway during a sharp takeoff in 1980 and was patched. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Mirant Says It Overstated as Much as $253 Million
description: The Mirant Corporation, the energy trader, reported a second-quarter loss today and said that it might have overstated as much as $253 million in assets and liabilities last year.

title: Pilot Whales Aground
description: In July 1855 a Cape Cod fisherman told Henry David Thoreau that blackfish, the animals we now call pilot whales, ''ran ashore in pursuit of squid, and that they generally came on the coast about the last of July.'' What interested Thoreau in blackfish wasn't their accidental strandings, but the fact that he himself had just seen them purposely driven ashore for their oil, blubber and meat. ''Leaping over the sea like horses,'' the whales were pursued by men and boys ''striking on the sides of their boats and blowing horns to drive them on to the beach.'' Thoreau expressed no sense of kinship with the whales, only a revulsion at the stench.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOLAN, L. DOUGLAS
description: NOLAN-L. Douglas, 79. Died on July 29, 2002, at his residence in East Haddam, CT. The funeral will assemble at 10 AM Thursday at the Fulton-Theroux Funeral Home, 13 Beckwith Lane, Old Lyme, CT., and proceed to a 11 AM Mass of Christian Burial in Christ the King Church, Lyme St., Old Lyme. Entombment will follow in Duck River Cemetery, Old Lyme. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the L. Douglas Nolan Foundation, Inc., P.O. Box 883, Old Lyme, Connecticut 06371.

title: Fox Says It Won't Accept Ads For Its Special on 9/11 Attacks
description: The News Corporation's broadcast and cable news networks, Fox and Fox News Channel, have decided not to accept any advertisements or program sponsorships for their coverage of the one-year anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington. The decisions come at a time when all of the cable news and broadcast networks are having a hard time attracting sponsors to their 9/11 programming. Many advertisers fear their sunny, everyday, 30-second spots will seem crass in contrast to the somber coverage.

title: Giants' Shockey Navigates Rough Day
description: The player expected to transform the Giants' offense sat in a truck stop parking lot at dawn here this morning, stretched across the back seat of a town car, waiting for his first practice. The horse racing season has begun in nearby Saratoga Springs, the state bar exam was held here today and there are no hotel rooms available, even for the millionaire tight end Jeremy Shockey.

title: Bouncing to Extremes: Introducing SlamBall
description: Instant hops. Instant air. Instant gratification.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Racehorse Had West Nile Virus
description: A three-year-old racehorse that became acutely ill last week tested positive for the West Nile virus. The animal, housed at the Fairmont Park racetrack in Collinsville, first showed signs of illness on July 22 and within hours could no longer stand. It was put down 72 hours later, three days before blood tests came back positive for the mosquito-borne virus. West Nile virus causes encephalitis, or swelling of the brain lining, and often results in numbness of the limbs, followed by death. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: The Shame of Egypt
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt describes himself as America's leading Arab ally. Yet his anti-democratic behavior is an embarrassment to Washington and an affront to his own people. The latest example is Monday's re-sentencing of Saad Eddin Ibrahim, a sociologist and human rights activist, to seven years in prison for his efforts to register voters, monitor elections and report attacks on Egypt's Coptic Christians.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MEADWESTVACO CORP., Stamford, Conn., the paper company formed by the combination of Mead Corp. and Westvaco Corp. in January, said it would close an envelope factory in Worcester, Mass., and lay off 150 people to reduce costs. The company plans to cut 400 more jobs this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAROLAN, RICHARD V.
description: CAROLAN-Richard V. Retired Chairman and CEO of Martindale-Hubbell Publishing Company, died Saturday, July 27, 2002, at New York's Memorial Sloan - Kettering Hospital at age 75 after a long battle with prostate cancer. He was a resident of Long Beach Island NJ and Thousand Oaks CA. Mr. Carolan was born in Waterbury CT on September 2, 1926. He served his country honorably in the European Theatre in World War II. He graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree from Rutgers University in 1958. After his retirement from Martindale - Hubbell Publishing Company in 1990 he formed the Tina and Richard V. Carolan Foundation. The charitable organization is dedicated to cancer research and humanitarian relief. He is survived by his wife Tina (nee Peschekerian), son Richard C. Carolan, daughter Kimberly Carolan-Faga and four grandchildren. Private funeral services and interment were held in Sleepy Hollow Cemetery in Tarrytown NY on July 30, 2002.

title: Summer Camp Brought More Than He Bargained For
description: I've always wondered how some young men -- the ones who treat young women with appalling callousness -- justify their behavior. Bucky, the single-named protagonist of Hunt Holman's ''Spanish Girl,'' clears that up.

title: Rwanda and Congo Sign Accord to End War
description: The war for control of Congo appeared to edge a step closer to an end today, with the signing of an accord between two rivals, Presidents Joseph Kabila of Congo and Paul Kagame of Rwanda.

title: Restoration for 'Freedom' Murals at Archives
description: The Declaration of Independence and the United States Constitution are big subjects for an artist, and big is certainly the word for the two giant murals -- each measuring more than 34 feet long and almost 13 feet high -- that hang on the walls of the cavernous rotunda inside the National Archives building here.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Premier Establishes Reserve
description: Prime Minister Hun Sen established a million-acre reserve in the central Cardamom Mountains, filling a gap in a chain of reserves that together now constitute the largest unbroken stretch of wildlife habitat left in mainland Southeast Asia. The Cardamoms remained undeveloped for years because they were the last stronghold of the Khmer Rouge, but loggers and wildlife poachers had been encroaching. International aid agencies and private conservation groups agreed to pay for maintaining and protecting the reserve. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: At the Helm of New York Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: New Leader Of Prosecutors Won't Halt Schwarz Case
description: The incoming United States attorney in Brooklyn said yesterday that she would permit prosecutors to proceed with a fourth trial of Charles Schwarz, the former police officer charged with taking part in the torture of Abner Louima.

title: Microsoft Seen In Wireless Deal
description: Microsoft plans to announce a partnership today with AT&T Wireless Services to offer wireless software and services, a person close to the talks said last night.

title: NURSING HOME COMPANY STARTS INTERNAL BILLING INQUIRY
description: Beverly Enterprises Inc., the biggest nursing home company in the nation, said it was investigating the billing of government programs by its home-medical-equipment business, MK Medical. The company, which is based in Fort Smith, Ark., said it had hired an independent auditor to review the books of MK Medical, which has about $15 million in annual sales paid by government programs. Beverly bought MK Medical, which is based in Fresno, Calif., in October 1998.

title: Sports of The Times; Ex-Hog Offers Jump-Start and Helps Change Lives
description: WITH the barrage of crack cocaine-connected killings in the 1980's came the realization that young people were too often full-fledged players in the violence. That was more evident here than in any other city, said George Starke, who after his career as an offensive tackle with the Washington Redskins from 1973 to 1984 stuck around and decided to make this place more than his home.

title: Red Sox Get Floyd; Expos Get 2 Prospects
description: Less than three weeks after outfielder Cliff Floyd was imported to Montreal to play a pivotal part in the Expos' playoff plans, he was traded to Boston last night to try his hand in what the Red Sox hope will be their postseason plans.

title: Timetable Softened on Gene-Modified Wheat
description: Monsanto has pulled back from its stated timeline for bringing the first genetically modified wheat to market by 2005, company spokesmen said yesterday.

title: Terms Upheld In Auction Case
description: Thousands of clients of Sotheby's Holdings and Christie's International may start getting payments soon from a $512 million settlement of a price-fixing suit now that an appeals court has resolved a key issue, lawyers in the case said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, NORA C.
description: RYAN-Nora C. On July 29, 2002. Beloved wife of the late John F. Ryan. Devoted mother of Brendan, Kate and Jack. Dear grandmother of Mary Courtney, Emily and Sean. Sister of the late Mary Farrell, Richard Cotter and Br. James P. Cotter. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave, (at 20 St), NYC. Wednesday, 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Immaculate Conception Church, Thursday, 10AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family respectfully requests contributions to Immaculate Conception School, 414 East 14 Street, New York, NY 10009

title: Debate Is Shifting on Chemical Commonly Found in Food
description: Weeks remain before the publication of the first study showing that starchy foods contain acrylamide, a potential carcinogen, yet much of the once-acrimonious debate over its appearance in staples like French fries, bread and potato chips has already been quelled.

title: Telecommunications: Lament but Little Repair
description: The government's confusion over how to respond to the growing crisis in the telecommunications industry burst into the open today, as Democrats, Republicans and a regulator offered competing and often contradictory prescriptions for fixing the industry's problems.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Profit At Michelin
description: Europe's largest tire maker, Michelin, announced better-than-expected results for the first half of this year, and said it expected income to grow by about 7 percent in 2002. Michelin's first-half net income increased 16 percent from last year, to 254 million euros ($249 million), helped by lower costs of raw materials. Michelin is eliminating 2,000 jobs in North America as part of a plan to reduce costs by 200 million euros ($196 million) by the end of 2003. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Cosseted Lettuces and Pampered Greens
description: JUDY RODGERS was probably destined for a culinary career, though she certainly did not plan one.

title: Wines of the Week
description: Burgundy provides wine-making inspiration for the wines of Testarossa, Patz & Hall and Paul Hobbs. These three top-notch California producers have all managed to capture the elusive star-quality of pinot noir and chardonnay.

title: Doctor's Death by Car Fumes Is Called Accidental
description: FORT LEE, N.J., July 30  Detectives have concluded that the doctor found dead in his car in an apartment garage last week died accidentally of carbon monoxide poisoning and did not commit suicide, the authorities said today.

title: GUIDANT AGREES TO BUY COOK FOR $3 BILLION
description: The Guidant Corporation, a developer of surgical supplies, agreed to buy the Cook Group, its partner in the development of drug-coated stents, for as much as $3 billion in stock. Guidant and Cook are developing a drug-coated stent that keeps arteries from reclogging and the companies hope that their merger will free them from a legal conflict with a rival, the Boston Scientific Corporation. Boston Scientific won a court judgment last month that a partnership between Guidant and Cook violated a contract Boston Scientific has with Cook. Guidant filed a motion in the case asking the court to declare that the merger renders the contract dispute with Boston Scientific moot. Guidant said the merger was contingent on a favorable ruling. A spokesman for Boston Scientific said his company would oppose the motion.

title: Big Senate Vote on Medicare Drug Benefits Is Set for Today
description: The Senate moved today toward a showdown on legislation to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly, as Democrats raced to round up Republican votes for a proposal that directs assistance mainly to people with low incomes or high drug costs.

title: Economic Growth Slowed Sharply in the 2nd Quarter
description: The pace of economic growth slowed markedly in the second quarter, the government reported today, and revised figures show that the recession that began in March of last year was twice as deep as originally estimated.

title: 1% Increase in U.S. Inmates Is Lowest Rate in 3 Decades
description: The nation's prison population grew last year at the lowest rate since 1972 and had the smallest numerical increase since 1979, before the prison boom began, according to a report issued yesterday by the Bureau of Justice Statistics.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Jobless Rate Unchanged
description: Japan's jobless rate remained at a near-record 5.4 percent. The number of workers who joined the ranks of the unemployed rose 30,000, or 0.8 percent, to 3.61 million. The tough job market is the product of rounds of corporate cutbacks that began in 2001. Falling wages and overtime hours have added to the slump in consumer spending, which has slowed the recovery. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUADRACCI, HARRY
description: QUADRACCI-Harry. The publishing industry has lost a man of integrity, love and a giving spirit. He was truly a special person who will be missed. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to Betty and his family. Nina Link, President and CEO Magazine Publishers of America

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGARRY, COHEN, MARGA RET
description: McGARRY - COHEN - Marga ret. On July 29, 2002. Beloved daughter of Eamonn McGarry and Mary (nee Duffy). Loving wife of Avra Cohen. Devoted mother of Eamon Wallace Cohen. Dear sister of Anne McGarry and the late Michael McGarry. Funeral Thursday, 8:30AM, from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd., Brooklyn. Mass 9:30 AM, Mary Queen of Heaven RC Church. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. Visiting on Wednesday from 2-5 and 7-10 P.M.

title: If Not Mozart, Charity
description: To the Editor:

title: 1,700 Subway Cars to Be Built Under Largest Such Contract in New York History
description: Transit officials approved a plan yesterday to buy as many as 1,700 new subway cars for more than $2.3 billion, the largest car contract in the city's history and one of the largest transit deals in the world.

title: Icelandic Murmurs, Cyberpunk Rhythms
description: When a band walks onstage, the audience usually applauds. But on Friday night, when the Icelandic group mm took the stage at the Knitting Factory, you could also hear another sound, one more in keeping with mm's music: ''Shhh.''

title: Arts Honor For Taylor, McCartney And Others
description: Elizabeth Taylor and Sir Paul McCartney were among five people named today to receive this year's Kennedy Centers Honors in the performing arts.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARGOLIS, DR. ROBERT
description: MARGOLIS-Dr. Robert. 10/3/23-7/31/01. Each life you touched was enriched. Your adoring family remembers you always.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERDY, IRVING
description: BERDY-Irving. On July 28, 2002. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Alan and Judith. Dear father-inlaw of Eleanor. Loving brother of Myrtle Seiden. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to NY Hospital, Department of Otolaryngology. Services Wednesday 11:30am at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Ford Said to Be Close to Ending The Excursion
description: The Ford Motor Company has decided not to build a second generation of the Excursion sport utility vehicle, which is seven feet tall and able to seat a softball team, people close to Ford's future product program said tonight.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Government To Cut Airline Stake
description: Following its campaign pledge to privatize more industries, the newly elected French government announced plans to sell the majority of its stake in Air France, reducing its ownership from 54.4 percent to less than 20 percent. If approved by French lawmakers and unions, the sale is expected to be completed late this year or early 2003, said Francis Mer, the finance minister. The sale could raise more than 1.1 billion euros and could be followed by the sales of national stakes in other companies, such as Renault or Autoroutes du Sud de la France. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: PHILADELPHIA SUBURBAN TO BUY DQE WATER UNIT
description: The Philadelphia Suburban Corporation, a water utility owner, agreed to buy the investor-owned water businesses of DQE Inc. for about $205 million. The acquisition of the AquaSource unit will give Philadelphia Suburban 170,000 new customers, increasing its total 28 percent to 785,000, a spokeswoman, Randi Polanich, said. Philadelphia Suburban, based in Bryn Mawr, Pa., will add customers in North Carolina and New Jersey and expand into Texas, Florida, Virginia, Indiana and Missouri. DQE, which is based in Pittsburgh and is the parent of the Duquesne Light Company, said in May that it planned to sell the water unit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPETENAKIS, BETTY
description: KAPETENAKIS-Betty. The New York Foundation mourns the shocking death of our colleague and friend, The Director of The North Star Fund. Betty's profound commitment to progressive philanthropy, her personal activism, and her unwavering commitment to the struggle for justice, were examples for all of us. Our whole community has suffered an irreplaceable loss.

title: Early Shots by Two Democrats Challenging Pataki; Andrew M. Cuomo
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, the former federal housing secretary and a Democratic candidate for governor, started broadcasting a 30-second advertisement last weekend on New York City stations, which Cuomo aides say reach 70 to 75 percent of likely primary voters. A series of commercials had appeared upstate in recent weeks, focusing on the economy.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Partners Expects To Add Subscribers
description: Nextel Partners Inc., partly owned by the fifth-largest United States mobile-phone company, expects a per-share loss of 30 cents in the third quarter as it adds 91,000 subscribers, the chief financial officer, John Thompson, said yesterday. The company, which is based in Kirkland, Wash., and is partly owned by Nextel Communications, also expects customers' monthly bills to average $68, Mr. Thompson said on a conference call. That was lower than $69 in the second quarter and in line with first-quarter levels. Nextel Partners, which sells a combined mobile-phone and walkie-talkie service in smaller markets, said yesterday that it added 90,500 customers in the second quarter, bringing its total to 691,600. The company raised its forecast for 2002 customer growth to 358,000 new users from 350,000. The second-quarter loss at Nextel Partners widened to $74 million, or 31 cents a share, from $71 million, or 29 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 87 percent to $161.1 million. Shares of Nextel Partners rose 52 cents, to $4.25.

title: A Summer Romance: Apple and Rhubarb
description: The winey tartness of rhubarb adds a nice touch to the apple juice just introduced by Red Jacket Orchards of Geneva, N.Y. The freshly pressed, pasteurized juice has a hint of pink and is excellent over ice or cut with iced tea or lemonade. At cocktail time, it is a felicitous mixer for gin. This summer, the juice is available until around Aug. 10 at the Red Jacket Orchards stand in some Greenmarkets, including Union Square (Mondays) and McCarren Park in Williamsburg, Brooklyn (Saturdays). The juice is $1.25 for the 16-ounce size, $2 for 32 ounces and $3 for 64 ounces. The juice is also available at Gourmet Garage, Healthy Pleasures, King Kullen and Stew Leonard's stores.

title: Urgent Task For Rumsfeld
description: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld's remarks today about what would be required to eliminate Iraq's weapons of mass destruction signaled an advanced state of debate inside the Bush administration -- perhaps a reflection that time is getting short for decisions that have to be made if the goal is to take action early next year, before the presidential election cycle intrudes.

title: Bad Policy, Bad Image
description: To the Editor:

title: Senator Won't Seek to Prevent Guns for Pilots
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings, the Senate's most vocal and influential opponent of letting airline pilots carry guns, said today that he would not stand in the way of a vote on the issue.

title: Acrylamide in Food: How Big Is the Risk?
description: A DISCLOSURE in April that starchy foods cooked at high temperatures contain acrylamide, a potential carcinogen, has produced strange bedfellows.

title: In Attacks on Bush, Kerry Sets Himself Apart
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell was cruising through a Senate hearing on arms control, charming his Democratic adversaries and deftly parrying their questions, when Senator John Kerry, a Democrat from Massachusetts, took the microphone.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Tobacco Stake For Sale
description: Italy plans to sell all of Ente Tabacchi Italiani, the country's biggest cigarette maker, to raise funds to cut government debt, the finance ministry said. The deadline for companies to file an ''expression of interest'' in Eti, a state-owned concern, is Sept. 16, the ministry said. The government is also retaining an option to sell Eti shares to the public, the statement said. Italy may raise as much as 1.4 billion euros ($1.37 billion) from the sale of Eti, the Italian newspaper La Repubblica reported yesterday. The buyer would gain a dominant position in Italy's 13 billion euro tobacco market.

title: Powell Treading a Thin Line In Rallying Antiterror Support
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell arrived here tonight for meetings with fellow foreign ministers aimed at solidifying a second front, in Southeast Asia, in the campaign against global terrorism. But he has had to balance that goal with longstanding concerns about human rights abuses in the region.

description: Do onions make you cry? Blame pyruvic acid. Sweet onions like Vidalias have less of the acid, but that is also why they have less of the typical onion's sharpness and lingering smell. title: Budget Deficit in Philippines Damages Investor Confidence
description: The arrival of American troops in the Philippines to help the country fight Muslim rebels coincided with a surge in investor optimism over the government's economic goals. Six months later, that optimism is fading.

title: Latino Population Growth Is Widespread, Study Says
description: The Hispanic population has spread out across the nation faster and farther than any previous wave of immigrants, with the movement of Latinos from immigrant gateways into the heartland and suburbs possibly exceeding that of European immigrants in the early 20th century and of African-Americans moving from the Deep South in the period before World War II, according to a study released today.

title: Hindery and Art of the Deal: Little Art, No Deal for YES
description: For Leo J. Hindery Jr., the chairman of the YES Network, not getting a deal done is a vexing, alien experience. By his count, he has done hundreds of deals, but his inability to conclude one particular negotiation has turned into a sports soap opera.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBY, BARBARA JEAN
description: RUBY-Barbara Jean. Suddenly on July 26, 2002 at age 60. Beloved wife of the late Robert O'Donnell, loving daughter of Alice and the late Elmer Ruby. Dear sister of David Ruby, and devoted stepmother of Kevin O'Donnell. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Contributions in her memory may be made to: City Meals On Wheels, 355 Lexington Avenue, NY, NY 10017.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Gay Marriage Ruling Faces Challenge
description: Justice Minister Martin Cauchon, left, said the government would appeal a decision by a lower Ontario provincial court earlier this month to extend marriage rights to homosexual couples. Mr. Cauchon said there was no consensus among the general population or in the courts for the society to automatically take such a large step. The Ontario court has given the federal Parliament two years to change laws in order to give homosexuals equal partnership rights. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Ephedra Ban Ordered
description: An herbal diet supplement known as ephedra will no longer be sold to minors, under legislation signed yesterday by Andrew J. Spano, the Westchester County executive. The law, which does not apply to ephedra purchases by adults, goes into effect in 90 days. Ephedra, derived from the Chinese herb ma huang, is an amphetaminelike stimulant popular among people interested in ''herbal'' supplements for body building and weight loss. Also known as ephedrine, ephedra may have serious side effects. Since 1994, the Food and Drug Administration has been studying 81 deaths and instances of heart attack and stroke with possible links to ephedra. In January, Canadian regulators asked manufacturers to recall products containing high doses of the supplement. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: More Variety for Law Students
description: Columbia Law School and New York University Law School may vie for students and professors, but today their deans, DAVID LEEBRON of Columbia and RICHARD REVESZ of N.Y.U., will announce a pilot program to allow their students to take courses at each other's schools. The larger range of courses will make the schools and New York City "more attractive to top law school applicants," their joint statement said. (Law students are not included in a cross-registering arrangement for doctoral students at Columbia, N.Y.U., City University of New York, Fordham, New School, Princeton, Rutgers and SUNY Stony Brook.) The two law deans said that each school would accept up to 20 students annually and that the program would be reviewed in two years to see if it should be expanded.

title: REGIONAL MARKET: The Bronx; Fordham Revival Where Alexander's Once Ruled
description: A large Caldor sign still sits atop the five-story building at 2 Fordham Square on the northwest corner of Fordham Road and the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, even though Caldor vacated the 300,000-square-foot building in 1997, two years after it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Before Caldor moved into the building, in 1993, 2 Fordham Square was occupied by Alexander's department store, which declared bankruptcy in 1992.

title: For Homeland Security Bill, a Brakeman
description: The government's summer urgency to fend off terrorists by reorganizing security agencies seemed to melt away today when Robert C. Byrd walked onto the Senate floor in his seersucker suit and let loose a thundering demand to slow things down.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Consumer Confidence Falls
description: New Yorkers are feeling more uneasy about the economy than at any other time since September, according to a new survey by the Siena Research Institute. The monthly survey, done jointly with the University of Michigan, found a sharp drop in confidence among New York City residents in July, as the index of economic confidence fell to 73.5, from 83.3 in June; it was 72.0 in September. A similar index developed for the Conference Board, a business group, found confidence had fallen to September's level of 83.7, from 84.2 in June in the Middle Atlantic states. Economists said the stock market and corporate scandals have shaken consumer confidence, which may lead them to save rather than spend money. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Mondesi's Crash Course Is Too Much for Texas
description: Raul Mondesi wears a weathered red-and-blue glove during games, and a newer one, with a snazzy gold Rawlings patch over the wrist, during practice. He wears navy blue ankle socks with the Ralph Lauren logo during practice, and his upper body is covered in tattoos.

title: Hooray for Hillarywood!
description: Hollywood agents now advise budding screenwriters how to pitch scripts by using a political analogy.

title: Palestinian Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Concert to Kick Off N.F.L.
description: Jon Bon Jovi will commandeer Times Square to kick off the N.F.L. season on Sept. 5.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: GOVERNMENT TO CUT AIRLINE STAKE Fol- lowing its campaign pledge to privatize more industries, the newly elected French government announced plans to sell the majority of its stake in Air France, reducing its ownership from 54.4 percent to less than 20 percent. If approved by French lawmakers and unions, the sale is expected to be completed late this year or early 2003, said Francis Mer, the finance minister. The sale could raise more than 1.1 billion euros and could be followed by the sales of national stakes in other companies, such as Renault or Autoroutes du Sud de la France. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Oil Giant's Quarter Net Slumps 81%
description: ChevronTexaco said today that its second-quarter earnings fell 81 percent after energy prices slumped and it reduced the value of its investment in Dynegy by $531 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Job Market section on July 21 about dental practices that offer services like massages and DVD screenings to build up business misspelled the surname of the president of the New York County Dental Society, who commented on the trend. He is Dr. Robert Raiber, not Raibur.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNEDDON, KRISTINE FLEISHER, PH.D
description: SNEDDON-Kristine Fleisher, Ph.D, passed away on July 28, 2002, surrounded by her friends and family at her home in Weston, CT. The Sneddon family, long time residents of the Upper West Side, moved to Weston in the summer of 1991 with their youngest children, Jesse and Mika. Kristine became actively involved in the local community, with a special commitment to the Weston public school system. She served as president of the Weston High School ParentTeacher Organization in 1996-1997, working closely with parents, teachers, the Board of Education and the school administration. Her doctorate in Community Psychology and her understanding of group dynamics served her well in her tenure with the PTO. Kristine was selected to serve on the Quality and Diversity Committee for the school system and, as an outgrowth of this endeavor, became involved in facilitating Leadership Conferences with students from local communities. She facilitated seminars with parents and teachers in the school system to help them better understand effective communication skills. The high school also asked Kristine to assist in some difficult and sensitive mediations and conflict resolutions at school. Additionally, Kristine ran a parenting group for mothers of younger children in Hurlbutt Elementary School who asked her to facilitate a group after attending seminars which she conducted. A member of the Academy of Family Mediators, Kristine opened an office for mediation services in 1999 and in addition to mediating family conflicts, she mediated discrimination cases as a certified mediator for the U.S. Postal Service and mediated cases through the Dispute Settlement Center. Kristine was also an active board member for Devil's Den, part of The Nature Conservancy. Kristine's love of nature arose in part from her childhood summers on Fire Island, a tradition that she and her husband David continued with their children and grandchildren. Kristine is survived by her husband David, her children Jesse, Mika, William, Eric and Lloyd, her daughters-in-law Lisa and Linda and her grandchildren Andrea, Kate, and Sara. She is also survived by her father Robert and her brother Marc. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be sent to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, 420 Jericho Turnpike, Suite 320, Jericho, New York 11753. The family will have a private memorial service to celebrate her life.

title: Superfund Makes a Rare Deal With Florida
description: Short of money and struggling to end delays in cleaning up toxic waste sites, the federal Superfund program has entered an unusual arrangement with Florida in which the state will pay for work at a toxic site that would normally be handled by the federal government.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Rally For Teen Abstinence
description: The State Department of Health will sponsor a rally next month to promote sexual abstinence among teenagers. Titled ''Leading Our Generation,'' the rally will include sessions like ''Love vs. Infatuation,'' ''Playing It Smart by Setting Boundaries'' and ''Violence Prevention.'' The rally will be on Aug. 23 and 24 at Harding University in Searcy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUBER, LASZLO, DR.
description: TAUBER-Laszlo, Dr. The Anti - Defamation League mourns the passing of Dr. Laszlo Tauber, a Holocaust survivor and long time ADL supporter. Through his philanthropy, Dr. Tauber demonstrated his commitment to the Jewish people, the State of Israel and to Holocaust education. We extend our condolences to his wife, Diane, children and the entire family. Glen A. Tobias National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman National Director

title: Vanguard Airlines Files for Bankruptcy and Suspends Service
description: Vanguard Airlines said yesterday that it was filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection because it had failed to get financing and had been operating since Sept. 11 on a diminishing pool of cash.

title: Bin Laden Guards Held
description: Some of Osama bin Laden's personal bodyguards have been apprehended and are now being held at the American military base in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, government officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GESNER, CLARK
description: GESNER-Clark. The Princeton University Class of 1960 mourns the passing of one of its most talented members. As the creator of the show ''You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown'', Clark also contributed to 1960's major reunions, leaving his creative imprint on each gathering. His warm humor & engaging presence will be greatly missed by all his classmates. He was a good man, indeed.

title: Bomb Kills 7 in Jerusalem; Hamas Claims Responsibility
description: Abomb believed planted by a Palestinian group exploded in a crowded lunchtime cafeteria at Hebrew University in Jerusalem today, killing at least seven people, the Israeli police said. Estimates of the wounded ranged from at least 30 to 70, some critically hurt.

title: Echoes Feared From Mostly Mozart Strike
description: The strike by orchestra members that led Lincoln Center to cancel most of the Mostly Mozart festival could reshape the character of the festival's ensemble, both sides say, and reverberate throughout the classical music world.

title: Time Is Short For Mets Deal
description: Steve Phillips, the Mets' general manager, has used waivers to his advantage in the past, blocking opponents' moves and trading within the constraints of baseball's system come August. But today's 4 p.m. deadline is unofficially Phillips's last chance to make a bold move to tweak the playoff-caliber team he thought he assembled last winter.

title: For More Japanese, Love Is a Multiethnic Thing
description: With his 50th birthday just around the corner, Masakazu Takagi faced a problem shared by legions of Japanese men in their late 30's and 40's: he had still not found a bride.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAERER, CAROL
description: HAERER-Carol, 69. Prominent abstract New York painter, died of ovarian cancer on July 20 in Bennington, VT. Raised in Nebraska, Haerer won a Fulbright Fellowship to Paris in 1954, and became part of a circle of important American painters working in Paris that included Sam Francis, Joan Mitchell and Shirley Jaffe. Haerer's painting ''breakthrough'' came in the mid 1960s in New York, with ''The White Paintings,'' most recently shown in 1999 at the Mitchell Algus Gallery. Haerer's paintings were exhibited in the Whitney Museum's Biennials of 1969 and 1971. Her work is included in the permanent collections of the Whitney Museum, the Guggenheim Museum, The Brooklyn Museum and many other museums and universities. Haerer taught at many prestigious institutions including Bennington College, the Chicago Art Institute, Fordham University and Parsons School of Art and Design. She is survived by her husband, Philip Wofford of Hoosick, New York; her daughter, Sara of New York City; and her mother and sister, both of Lincoln, Nebraska.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, BETTY
description: GREENFIELD - Betty. Of Hollywood, FL. Beloved wife of the late Murray, devoted mother of Harvey, cherished grandmother of Steven, Stacey, Richard, Lisa, Eddie, Jessica and Alexa, great grandmother of Jake, Casey, Emily, Lorey and Anna. Devoted friend to her care-giver Catherine. She was a true matriarch and a wonderful role model to her entire family. Memorial contributions may be sent to Juvenile Diabetes Association. Services Thursday, 11AM, Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th and Madison.

title: Tutoring Gives Pupils an Edge . . . for Preschool
description: Sophie Spencer, 5 and headed to kindergarten in the fall, has a tutor.

title: Palestinians Kill 2 Israelis in the West Bank
description: Two Israeli brothers from this settlement were shot to death by masked Palestinian gunmen this morning when they stepped out of their tanker truck to sell diesel fuel in a neighboring Palestinian village, Israeli officials said.

title: El Paso Energy's Net More Than Doubles
description: El Paso Energy Partners, a publicly traded partnership controlled by the El Paso Corporation, said today that second-quarter earnings more than doubled with the addition of natural-gas pipelines in Texas and New Mexico.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROOKS, EDWIN SMITH

Devoted son of Marie Crooks and the late Edwin S. Crooks, Sr. Loving brother of Kathleen Ball and Michael Crooks. Cherished grandfather of Evan. Crooks Memorial at the Wildlife Center of Virginia, P.O. Box 1557, Waynesboro, VA. 22980.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Insurer's Profit Rises
description: The Manulife Financial Corporation reported a 13 percent increase in second-quarter earnings to 344 million Canadian dollars ($218.8 million), or 71 Canadian cents a share. The insurance and financial services group, which is based in Toronto and has extensive interests in the United States and Asia, ascribed the improvement to higher revenues, a favorable claims record and containment of costs. Manulife said it had written down loans to WorldCom, MCI and Teleglobe by $220 million, and had set aside another 380 million Canadian dollars to cover future losses in the telecommunications sector. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: AIR POWER ALONE CAN'T DEFEAT IRAQ, RUMSFELD ASSERTS
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that Iraq now has mobile biological-weapons laboratories that would be very difficult to bomb, an example, he said, of why air power alone would not destroy all of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction.

title: Debating Iraq
description: Through tragedy and pain, Americans have learned a great deal this past year about why foreign policy matters. In recent months, President Bush has made clear his determination to remove Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein from power -- a goal many of us in Congress share. But to date we've seen only leaked reports of competing military plans. These have reflected deep divisions within the administration about whether and how to proceed. The time has come for a serious discussion of American policy toward Iraq.

title: Clemens to Pitch Again in Minors
description: The Yankees found another way to use their surplus of starting pitching today. Roger Clemens is healthy but not yet sharp with his pitches, so the Yankees will give him another start in the minors before putting him back in their rotation.

description: Powell Meets North Korean

title: As Currency Sinks, Brazil Seeks Fresh Aid
description: Brazil's battered currency reached a new low today, as concerns grew about the nation's fragile finances.

title: Governor Pataki Weighs In
description: Responding to a wave of public dismay over the first designs for rebuilding Lower Manhattan, Gov. George Pataki has sent word that it's time to go back to the drawing board. It is the right message, sent while it is still early enough to do something constructive about the disappointing quality of the work so far. The governor, like Mayor Michael Bloomberg, now seems committed to creating a better mix of uses for ground zero, and a 24-hour community in Manhattan's downtown.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: SUDAN: AID WORKER DIES IN FIGHTING Sudanese government-backed forces launched a major offensive against rebel-held positions, just one week after the two sides reached an agreement that was hailed as a major step toward ending Africa's longest-running war. One aid worker was killed in the government offensive in the village of Waat and three others were reported missing. The government and the southern rebels agreed last week to allow residents in southern Sudan to vote within six years on whether to break off into a separate country. The two sides, however, did not agree on a cease-fire. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Court Rejects Terrorism Detentions
description: A three-judge panel ruled that an emergency post-Sept. 11 statute used to detain without charges nine foreigners suspected of involvement in terrorism was discriminatory, disproportionate and unlawful. The court said that Home Secretary David Blunkett had been correct in declaring that there was a ''public emergency threatening the life of the nation'' but said that did not entitle the government to take measures against foreigners that it would not against its own citizens. The nine detainees must remain in a London prison pending a Court of Appeal hearing in October. Warren Hoge (NYT)

His wife of 52 years, Mary King Babcock of Old Greenwich & their 6 children survive him: The Reverend Theodore S. Babcock, Warner K. Babcock, Mary N. Babcock, William N. Babcock, Carol B. Perreten, and David S. Babcock. Thirteen grandchildren, four step grandchildren and two sisters, Theodora B. Hoe of Poughkeepsie, NY and Helen B. Hall of Riverside, CT. also survive him. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church Greenwich on Saturday, August 3 at 11 AM. A reception will follow at Christ Church. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to the H. Nash Babcock Memorial Fund at Greenwich Adult Day Care, 70 Parsonage Road, Greenwich, CT. 06830, or a favorite charity.

description: Amtrak this afternoon dragged away the 11 cars damaged in Monday's derailment of the Capitol Limited, but with nearly 100 wrecked cars already awaiting repair and no spares on hand, the financially beleaguered railroad had to cancel a Washington-to-Chicago train scheduled for Wednesday.

description: I.B.M. announced yesterday that it planned to buy PricewaterhouseCoopers Consulting for $3.5 billion. The move will accelerate I.B.M.'s shift from selling just computers and software toward a future of providing information technology to corporate customers as a utility-like service.

title: Suitor Is Said to Be Ready to Rejoin Global Crossing Hunt
description: Hutchison Whampoa of Hong Kong has renewed its interest in Global Crossing, the insolvent communications company, and is expected to submit an offer this week to buy it out of bankruptcy, people involved in the bidding process said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Edison: Postal Center Decontamination
description: The Postal Service announced yesterday that the Hamilton Township center, tainted with anthrax, will be decontaminated beginning as early as October and may reopen as early as next spring. The center, which handles mail for 46 area post offices, has been closed since October, after handling anthrax-tainted letters. At a cost of $20 million, the processing center will be fumigated with chlorine dioxide and fitted with a device to detect toxic biological substances. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: When Makeovers Go Awry
description: AT 10:15 on Sunday night, the last order of the Russian Tea Room's famous chicken Kiev was placed before Mike Bornstein, 84, who picked up his fork and knife and began to slice. Butter oozed, cameras flashed, Champagne corks popped, and applause rang out as waiters and diners cheered.

title: Jeff D'Amico's Pregame Routine
description: Afew hours before his start on Tuesday night, Jeff D'Amico sat at a card table under a bank of televisions in the middle of the Mets' clubhouse at Shea Stadium, devouring everything in sight. In front of him was a laptop computer that showed a continuous loop of Astros hitters, that night's opponent. To D'Amico's left was an open scouting report on the Astros that broke down their tendencies and strengths.

title: Interest Groups May Avoid Election Spending Ban
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  Lawyers for the Federal Election Commission opened the door today to allowing interest groups like the National Rifle Association and the Sierra Club to continue spending unlimited amounts of money on political advertisements, despite new restrictions passed by Congress.

title: Japan Tries to Halt Use of Tainted Herbal Diet Pills From China
description: Japanese health officials, hounded by growing worries about the safety of the country's food supply, have a new concern: how to stop the proliferation of tainted weight-loss supplements that have killed three people and made hundreds more ill.

title: Laszlo Tauber Dies at 87; A Patron in War and Peace
description: Laszlo Tauber, a Hungarian-born surgeon who saved other Jews in the Budapest ghetto during World War II, then made a real estate fortune in Washington and became a major philanthropist while remaining virtually unknown to the public, died on Sunday at his home in Potomac, Md. He was 87.
