description: AUTO RACING

title: Busy Day for the New Guy At the Biggest Blackboard
description: Hours after being named city schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein was on the telephone and firing off e-mail messages yesterday, asking for advice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAINE, SIDNEY P.
description: BLAINE-Sidney P., age 84. of Sarasota, died July 28, 2002. He was born August 28, 1917, New York City and came to Sarasota in 1998 from Orlando. He was the owner of a men's sportswear establishment and had served in the Army Air Force during World War II. He was a member of the City Athletic Club in New York City. Survivors include sisters Grace Grossman of NYC; Ada Bernstein of Laguna Hills, Calif. No services are scheduled. Wiegand Brothers Funeral Home, Sarasota.

title: Bomb Kills 7 in Jerusalem; Hamas Claims Responsibility
description: JERUSALEM, July 31 - A powerful bomb hidden in a bag and left on a table by Palestinian militants tore apart a bustling cafeteria during lunch at Hebrew University here today, killing at least seven people, including three Americans, and wounding more than 80.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microstrategy Plans To Sell 2 Units
description: The maker of data-delivery software, MicroStrategy, said that it plans to sell two business units, Angel.com and Alarm.com, as it focuses on other software products. The company expects the sale of the units to be completed by the end of 2002 and to save MicroStrategy about $2 million a year, it said in a statement. Based in McLean, Va., the company has spent the last two years cutting jobs, closing offices and exiting certain businesses in a bid to revive profits. MicroStrategy also plans to redeem or exchange about $75.5 million in preferred stock, which will generate a gain in the third quarter. The software maker announced a 1-for-10 reverse split of its outstanding shares of Class A and Class B common stock, effective at the close of business yesterday. Company officials could not be reached for comment. The company said it expects to report third-quarter earnings, excluding certain costs, in a range between a loss of $2 million, or 2 cents a share, and a profit of $2 million, or 2 cents, on revenue of $33 million to $37 million. The company was expected to earn 1 cent on revenue of $37.4 million, the average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. MicroStrategy's shares were unchanged at 48 cents yesterday, down from a peak of $333 on March 10, 2000.

title: Power Problem Here to Stay, Experts Predict
description: Fires in electrical transformers like those that have knocked out power around the city in the past few weeks are likely to become more common as utility systems show their age, energy industry analysts say.

title: Pope Sees Moral for Today In New Saint in Guatemala
description: Pope John Paul II canonized Central America's first saint here today at a ceremony that drew attention to both the Roman Catholic Church's struggle for human rights in this troubled nation and the church's concern over Protestant evangelization of indigenous people in Latin America.

title: Corrections
description: A list of major divisions of Bertelsmann on Monday, with a front-page article about the ouster of the company's chairman and chief executive, misspelled the surname of an author whose books are published by the company's Random House division. She is Danielle Steel, not Steele.

title: $6 or $60
description: Reading the papers lately, I've lost track of whether the Pentagon plans to invade Iraq from three sides or four, and whether we will be using Jordan, Kuwait or Diego Garcia as our main launching pad. But one thing I haven't seen much planning for is the impact an attack on Iraq would have on the world's oil market. Depending on how the war went, that impact could be very bad and lead to a sharp spike in oil prices, like $60-a-barrel oil. But -- wait a minute -- it could also be very good, and lead to $6-a-barrel oil that would weaken OPEC and, maybe, also weaken the Arab autocrats who depend on high oil prices to finance their illegitimate regimes and buy off opponents.

title: Maurice Denham, 92, British Character Actor
description: Maurice Denham, a British character actor whose face was familiar in movies and television but who achieved his greatest fame playing a gallery of characters in the hit British radio shows ''It's That Man Again'' and ''Much Binding in the Marsh,'' died last Wednesday in London. He was 92.

title: Corrections
description: The Q&A column in Science Times on June 25, about the development of the biohazard symbol, misstated the authorship of a 1967 article about the symbol in the journal Science. It was by Charles L. Baldwin and Robert S. Runkle, not John Cook. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Marie Claire to Offer Small Sales Cards
description: Marie Claire, published by the Hearst Magazines unit of the Hearst Corporation, is taking a new tack in its October issue to stimulate ad sales. Each copy of the magazine will contain an A.T.M.-size card with a personal identification number that will let readers log on to a Web site with special offers from advertisers.

title: Washington Mayor, Off Ballot, Promises a Write-In Campaign
description: Stunned by his removal from the ballot, Mayor Anthony A. Williams, a popular incumbent with no serious challenger in sight, vowed today to take to the streets and apologetically ask voters to write his name in for the September primary so he can salvage his re-election campaign as a Democrat.

title: From Physical Laws to Hollywood Variety
description: For 40 years, ROBERT H. LIEBERMAN, a senior lecturer in physics at Cornell University, has written novels and directed documentaries in his free time. His first feature film, ''Green Lights,'' recently opened in Los Angeles and received a rave review from Variety, which said it achieved ''spectacularly funny results.'' A tale about a hapless movie location scout who goes to Ithaca, N.Y., and is mistaken for a big-time Hollywood producer, the film uses Cornell faculty members, employees and students as well as professional actors; SIDNEY LEIBOVICH, an engineering professor, plays a moving man. Although Mr. Lieberman has had several offers for national distribution, he said he planned to continue teaching Maxwell's equations and Newton's laws to Cornell undergraduates. Karen W. Arenson

title: Economy Grew Only 1.1% in 2nd Quarter, Less Than Expected
description: U.S. economic growth faltered sharply during the second quarter and began the year at a slower pace than previously thought, the government said Wednesday in a report that also confirmed a prolonged economic downturn last year.

title: Merrill Banker Had Many Direct Ties to Enron
description: For years, Schuyler Tilney, a managing director at Merrill Lynch, had a special relationship with Enron.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: COURT REJECTS TERRORISM DETENTIONS A three-judge panel ruled that an emergency post-Sept. 11 statute used to detain without charges nine foreigners suspected of involvement in terrorism was discriminatory, disproportionate and unlawful. The court said that Home Secretary David Blunkett had been correct in declaring that there was a "public emergency threatening the life of the nation" but said that did not entitle the government to take measures against foreigners that it would not against its own citizens. The nine detainees must remain in a London prison pending a Court of Appeal hearing in October. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Fort Lee: Death Ruled Accidental
description: Detectives have concluded that the doctor found dead in his car in an apartment garage last week died accidentally of carbon monoxide poisoning and did not commit suicide, the authorities said yesterday. After interviewing family members, friends and associates of the doctor, Robert Stenson Jr., detectives are satisfied that he was not gripped by a ''suicidal mind-set'' before his death July 24, said Capt. Steven J. Hervey, a spokesman for the Fort Lee police. He said the detectives believed that Dr. Stenson, 42, fell asleep in his parked, running car after he drove home from a late-night visit to a Teaneck hospital where he has surgical privileges. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Bush Signs Bill Aimed at Fraud In Corporations
description: In a sign of how profoundly the nation's business scandals and volatile stock market have rocked his administration, President Bush signed a sweeping corporate-fraud bill today with central provisions that he opposed just three weeks ago.

title: Turning Up the Sizzle
description: IT'S tough to improve upon a competently grilled steak. But as summer lingers, the no-frills grilled food that was so thrilling in May can use a little added excitement.

title: Schools Chief With Traits That a Mayor Prizes Most
description: A former prosecutor with few education credentials may seem to be a surprising, if not odd, choice as the New York City schools chancellor. But the pick was business as usual for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Ever See a Porterhouse Bow to Brooklyn?
description: SUCCESS, it is sometimes said, is knowing what to imitate. If so, the MarkJoseph Steakhouse has had things right from the beginning. As its model, it took Peter Luger, the Brooklyn institution, which, though I haven't fully completed my research, may well serve the best steaks in the world. MarkJoseph opened only a year and a half ago, which puts it about a century behind. Still, with an owner, Charlie Blair, who used to be a general manager at Luger, it is betting on the burly appeal of the 19th-century steakhouse rather than offering a more refined 21st-century vision.

title: Venerable Studio Reborn as an Indie; United Artists Moves From Hollywood to New York for a 'Different Feel'
description: When news surfaced last year that MGM intended to reanimate its flagging United Artists banner by transforming it into a true specialized film division, few were surprised that Bingham Ray, an indie-film stalwart, had been chosen to run it.

title: One-Stop Shopping For Profiteroles And Sushi to Go
description: Dazzling French confections like Paris-Brest, profiteroles, Mont Blanc and fresh fruit tarts fill the display case in an unlikely place: JAS Food Mart, a Japanese shop that opened last month at 35 St. Marks Place (Second Avenue). They are all made on the premises. The store has sushi, of course, but also ham-and-cheese sandwiches on white bread, pasta and curries, which can be ordered from a hot food counter.

title: More Variety for Law Students
description: Columbia Law School and New York University Law School may vie for students and professors, but today their deans, DAVID LEEBRON of Columbia and RICHARD REVESZ of N.Y.U., will announce a pilot program to allow their students to take courses at each other's schools. The larger range of courses will make the schools and New York City ''more attractive to top law school applicants,'' their joint statement said. (Law students are not included in a cross-registering arrangement for doctoral students at Columbia, N.Y.U., City University of New York, Fordham, New School, Princeton, Rutgers and SUNY Stony Brook.) The two law deans said that each school would accept up to 20 students annually and that the program would be reviewed in two years to see if it should be expanded. Karen W. Arenson

title: Corrections
description: A report by Bloomberg News in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day on Friday about the second-quarter results for Nextel Partners, which sells a combined mobile-phone and walkie-talkie service in smaller markets, referred incorrectly to its size ranking. It is not the fifth-largest mobile phone company in the United States; that is Nextel Communications, with which it is affiliated.

title: Showdown Is Set on Bank Guarantees in Japan
description: About to break for a summer vacation, lawmakers in Japan have already laid the groundwork for their return in September: a battle with Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi over his pledge to remove the public guarantee on large savings accounts.

title: Grandmother's Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Aid Worker Dies In Fighting
description: Sudanese government-backed forces launched a major offensive against rebel-held positions, just one week after the two sides reached an agreement that was hailed as a major step toward ending Africa's longest-running war. One aid worker was killed in the government offensive in the village of Waat and three others were reported missing. The government and the southern rebels agreed last week to allow residents in southern Sudan to vote within six years on whether to break off into a separate country. The two sides, however, did not agree on a cease-fire. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Italian Offsprings

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about NBC's fall schedule referred incorrectly to the phrase ''gay mafia,'' which arose in a discussion of the absence of new gay characters in the networks' lineup. The term came to prominence recently when the Hollywood agent Michael S. Ovitz, in an interview in Vanity Fair, blamed a ''gay mafia'' for his own professional downfall; he did not say such a group ran the entertainment industry.

title: Three Jersey City Women Who Shared a House Are Found Stabbed to Death
description: Three women a pair of sisters and their mother -- were found fatally stabbed in their home early today after their bodies were discovered by the young children of one of the victims.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: More Fighting Along Georgian Border
description: Russian forces battled Chechen fighters for a fourth day along Russia's border with Georgia, inflaming tensions between the countries. Georgia's Foreign Ministry accused Russia of ''aggression against a sovereign neighbor state,'' saying Russian helicopters had launched raids inside Georgian territory. Russian officials denied that but accused Georgia of harboring Chechen guerrillas. At least seven Russians and nine Chechen rebels have been reported killed in the fighting. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bridgeport: Giordano Motion Fails
description: Philip A. Giordano, the former mayor of Waterbury, must face federal charges of child sexual abuse, according to a federal judge, who declined to dismiss a 14-count indictment against him. Mr. Giordano's lawyer had asked the judge, Alan Nevas, to dismiss the charges, saying federal prosecutors lacked jurisdiction. Mr. Giordano, above, was initially charged last year with using an ''interstate facility,'' a cellphone, to entice a minor for sex. Judge Nevas ruled that use of the phone was enough to create federal jurisdiction. Prosecutors have charged that Mr. Giordano sexually abused two girls who were 9 and 11 at the time. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: New Leader for Harlem Program
description: The Harlem Educational Activities Fund, a program that provides academic assistance to students from seventh grade through college, appointed DANIELLE MOSS LEE, left, as executive director this month. She succeeds COURTNEY WELSH, who will serve as consultant for the coming year. Ms. Lee, a former middle school teacher and assistant principal, recently left the Johns Hopkins University Center for Talented Youth. The Educational Activities Fund was originally an extension of the Police Athletic League in Harlem and now works with 650 students, many of whom might not have gone on to college without the tutoring, mentoring and other support it supplies. The fund's president, DANIEL ROSE, chairman of Rose Associates, the real estate development organization, said no student had dropped out of high school or college since the fund was founded in 1990. Lionel Anderson

title: More Variety for Law Students
description: Columbia Law School and New York University Law School may vie for students and professors, but today their deans, DAVID LEEBRON of Columbia and RICHARD REVESZ of N.Y.U., will announce a pilot program to allow their students to take courses at each other's schools. The larger range of courses will make the schools and New York City "more attractive to top law school applicants," their joint statement said. (Law students are not included in a cross-registering arrangement for doctoral students at Columbia, N.Y.U., City University of New York, Fordham, New School, Princeton, Rutgers and SUNY Stony Brook.) The two law deans said that each school would accept up to 20 students annually and that the program would be reviewed in two years to see if it should be expanded.

title: For Mets, It's Not The Heat, It's Futility
description: With each hit reliever Satoru Komiyama surrendered during his unbelievably poor performance last night, the boos grew in volume. Komiyama's father was among the 33,492 fans at Shea Stadium on a sweltering night, watching his son pitch in the major leagues for the first time, and he appeared to have chosen a good time. The Mets felt good about themselves yesterday afternoon and were approaching today's nonwaiver trading deadline with the zeal of a playoff contender.

title: Beating the Heat the Alfresco Way
description: THE five ceiling fans we installed in our un-air-conditioned New York City roost give it the lazy, back-porch aura we intended, but they don't cool things down much. By late July, the fans do little more than circulate kitchen heat throughout the apartment. Nobody accepts our dinner invitations in August, and who could blame them?

title: Such Delicious Hot Chocolate, Dear. Whatever Do You Put in It?
description: The new Claude Chabrol thriller ''Merci Pour le Chocolat'' has been given the English title ''Nightcap,'' which makes sense by the time the climax rolls into view, so don't bother asking yourself why it isn't an accurate translation.

title: Sometimes, Homework Must Take Second Place
description: THERE are, last I heard, still only 24 hours in a high school student's day. Into those hours must be crammed school, homework, chilling with friends, piano lessons, talking on the phone, tennis practice, a bare minimum of sleep and perhaps a few minutes of quality time grudgingly bestowed on parents.

title: The Twang of Red, White and Blue
description: When Kix Brooks and Ronnie Dunn were consulting with the set designer for their current tour, perhaps their instructions consisted of two words: patriotic casino. On Sunday night at the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., they made their entrance on a swiveling podium, in front of a huge American flag, beneath a monstrous longhorn skull tiled with mirrors. The bandstand was bedecked with hundreds of lights that flashed and changed color in time with the music.

title: Autumn in France
description: Two November barge cruises in Provence are being sold by eWaterways.com at special prices that include round-trip air fare from many United States cities. A six-day cruise on the 50-passenger Chardonnay leaves Nov. 8; the 50-passenger Provence leaves Nov. 15. Each begins in Aigues-Mortes with visits to Nimes, Arles and Avignon, ending in Lyon. The price  $2,199 to $2,299 a person, double occupancy  includes all meals and wine on board, air fare, Paris transfers on the T.G.V. and two nights in a Paris hotel. The cruise alone is usually $2,690 a person; www.ewaterways.com .

title: Top Court Again Rejects Sentence Of Death
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court today overturned the death sentence of Leslie Ann Nelson, a transsexual go-go dancer who killed a police officer and an investigator with an AK-47 rifle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISEMANN, ALEXANDER
description: EISEMANN-Alexander. Of Westport, CT. President of NRI Associates. Husband of Sandra Lane Eisemann. Father of Alexander E. Eisemann, Dorothy Eisemann and Kathryn Eisemann. Brother of Helen Eisemann Alexander. Grandfather of two. Memorial services Thursday, August 1, 2PM in the Westport Public Library McManus Room, Westport CT. Memorial contributions may be made to Westport Volunteer EMS, 50 Jesup Road, Westport, CT. 06880.

title: Two Share Named Chair at Bard
description: IAN BURUMA and MARK DANNER will share the new Henry R. Luce chair at Bard College, a professorship in the implications of new media for democracy and human rights. THOMAS KEENAN, director of the Human Rights Project at Bard, said the appointments were a step toward the creation of a formal major in human rights. Mr. Buruma, who will begin teaching at Bard in the spring, is a writer who specializes in Asia; he has also written about how Germany and Japan have coped with the legacies of World War II. Mr. Danner, who will teach in the fall, is a journalist and journalism professor at the University of California at Berkeley and won a MacArthur foundation fellowship in 1999. He has books about Haiti and the Balkans coming out soon. Karen W. Arenson

title: Cavs Trade Miller In a Deal For Miles
description: The Knicks' aggressive pursuit of the coveted point guard Andre Miller ended yesterday when the Cleveland Cavaliers traded him to the Los Angeles Clippers. In a deal involving two of the N.B.A.'s most promising young stars, the Cavaliers sent Miller and Bryant Stith to the Clippers for Darius Miles, a dazzling forward, and Harold Jamison.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: No Relation to the Story

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Electronics Makers Cut Losses
description: The Toshiba Corporation and Hitachi Ltd., two of the world's largest semiconductor manufacturers, both posted smaller losses compared to its results last year. Toshiba lost 18.8 billion yen ($157 million) in the April to June quarter, about half its loss the previous year. Strong sales of flat-panel monitors and computer chips helped shrink the loss. Hitachi lost 8 billion yen ($67 million) in the period, one quarter as much as it lost last year. Hitachi said plant closures and layoffs helped narrow the loss. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about restaurants with menus that credit the fashion designers who make clothes for the staff misidentified the parent company of Thomas Pink, the English haberdasher that supplies Washington Park, in New York. It is LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, not the Prada group.

title: Higher Afghan civilian toll is reported : UN draft survey adds to doubt on U.S. raid
description: A preliminary United Nations report on the U.S. air strike earlier this month that killed dozens of Afghans celebrating a wedding suggests that the casualty figures were far higher than previously thought.

title: UPSTATE: Yesterday's Retreats; Where Summer Just Isn't What It Used to Be
description: People around here can recite the names as though they were family. There was the Dellwood, down in Roundtop. The Mohican House, over in Acra. The Pleasant View, not to be confused with the Pleasant Acres, and the Pine Crest, not to be confused with the Pine Springs. There was the Breezy Knoll and the Alberta Lodge and, of course, the Jolly House.

description: Piedmont on the South Fork

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Stewart Aims to Tie Hambletonian Record
description: Many trainers have had horses in both the Hambletonian and the Hambletonian Oaks, trotting's premier events for 3-year-olds, during the same year.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We've got a pool, but Disney has a pool.''

title: Judge Rejects Man's Call for Leniency for Parental Abductors
description: A man who was kidnapped as an infant in Queens two decades ago, then raised by his abductors as their son, asked a judge for leniency in sentencing the couple yesterday, saying in a hushed courtroom that he was ''losing his parents.''

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Observatory column of Science Times yesterday about competing strains of E. coli bacteria misstated the reason only one strain remained after three were mixed in a solution. That strain, labeled 2, outgrew Strain 1 after Strain 1 killed all of Strain 3. (The column reversed references to Strains 1 and 3.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COTY, C. KENNETH
description: COTY-C. Kenneth. Of Scottsdale, AZ died on July 28, 2002 at the age of 85. Visitation 9-10:30AM, Wednesday, July 31, 2002 at Hansen Desert Hills Mortuary, 6500 E. Bell Rd., Scottsdale, AZ 85254. Graveside services will follow Paradise Memorial Gardens.

title: Our Towns; Condemning A Drug Site (It's CVS)
description: MICHAEL J. NEWHARD has the easygoing personality and heavy, dark-framed eyeglasses of the TriBeCa artist that he once was.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Pricewaterhouse Sells Consulting Firm to I.B.M.

title: Paging Sam Spade: A Gold Coin Fetches $7.6 Million at Auction
description: The 1933 double eagle, a $20 gold piece with a mysterious history that involves a president, a king and a Secret Service sting operation, was auctioned last night for a record price for a coin, $7.59 million, nearly double the previous record.

title: Message To Players: Strike Isn't Sole Choice
description: With the possibility of a strike looming closer on the horizon, Major League Baseball's chief labor lawyer sent this message to the players yesterday: You don't have to strike; you have other options available in these negotiations.

title: Senator Says Merrill Lynch Helped Enron Cook Books
description: Using internal documents, e-mail messages and even a videotape as evidence, lawmakers on a Senate panel argued today that Merrill Lynch, one of the nation's largest and most respected brokerage firms, repeatedly cut corners and compromised its business practices to win more investment-banking fees from Enron.

title: Panel Challenges Bishops on Fighting Abuse
description: The sexual abuse review board appointed to police the nation's Roman Catholic bishops convened today and promptly called on the bishops to lay out the steps they had taken to fulfill promises to protect children.

title: Where Gentrification Meets the Marine Corps
description: Despite its prime location at Interstate 5 and Oceanside Boulevard here, the shopping center sits more than half vacant, its parking lot pockmarked and strewn with gravel. Even Starbucks, which has 90 coffee shops in San Diego County, sees no need to rent space in this mall.

title: Sterling Hitchcock's Lost Season
description: Derek Bell, the former Met, had a penchant for watching "Judge Judy" on the clubhouse television before games. Other players are said to watch "Jerry Springer" religiously. But mostly, pre-game TV viewing is confined to movies (almost always recent comedies) and sports.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: NTT RAISES OUTLOOK The Nippon Tele- graph and Telephone Corporation, the world's largest phone company, raised the profit forecast of its parent company after it sold shares in its mobile carrier, NTT DoCoMo Inc. NTT earned a one-time profit of 148 billion yen ($1.2 billion) from the sale, which was completed Monday. NTT now expects to earn a profit of 100 billion yen ($831 million) in the fiscal year that ends March 31. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: For Sale, a House With Acreage. Connections Extra.; Site of 1957 Gangland Raid Is Part of Auction on Saturday
description: Grab your unmarked bills. A piece of Mafia history is up for sale.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: NTT Raises Outlook
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the world's largest phone company, raised the profit forecast of its parent company after it sold shares in its mobile carrier, NTT DoCoMo Inc. NTT earned a one-time profit of 148 billion yen ($1.2 billion) from the sale, which was completed Monday. NTT now expects to earn a profit of 100 billion yen ($831 million) in the fiscal year that ends March 31. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Salad Vinegar, Sippin' Vinegar
description: Connoisseurs of vinegar taste it by first dipping a piece of white bread into it, or sometimes a sugar cube. But not Erwin Gegenbauer, above, of Vienna, who makes vinegars from fruit, vegetables, wine and even beer. At the Fancy Food Show in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center three weeks ago, he offered samples by the droplet from a pipette. ''Take it under your tongue,'' he said. ''It's the only way to get all the flavor.'' Mr. Gegenbauer's vinegars have uncommon depth. He ferments fruits, like raspberries and tomatoes, into a wine that becomes vinegar, and then ages them up to seven years. He makes what he calls drinking vinegars, to serve as digestifs, from sweet wines. His unusual beer vinegar does wonders for potato salad and is $30 at Dean & DeLuca; other vinegars are $20 to $50 for 8.6 ounces. Also carrying the vinegars are Tuller Premium Food in Brooklyn, Bedford Gourmet in Bedford, N.Y., and Zingerman's in Ann Arbor, Mich. They are also available from www.chefshop.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CABIBBO, MARY
description: CABIBBO-Mary. On July 30, 2002. Loving sister of Bess Cabibbo & Nancy Saraceno. Also survived by nieces. Friends may call at the Nagel Funeral Home, 352 E. 87 St, NYC. Thursday, 2-5PM, 79pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Our Lady of Peace Church. 237 E 67 St, 10 AM, Friday.

title: Upheaval at Bertelsmann May End Plans for Acquisition of Napster
description: Thomas Middelhoff's ouster from Bertelsmann may be a crippling blow for Napster, the bankrupt online music service that Mr. Middelhoff championed, according to people inside the company and industry analysts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAGUARDIA, KENDRICK M.
description: LAGUARDIA-Kendrick M. Age 33 of Orlando. Passed away July 26, 2002 in Orlando. He was born December 10, 1968 in Nyack, NY and has resided in Orlando the past eight years. He attended Florida State University and was a member of Kappa Alpha Fraternity. Ken was a homebuilder and enjoyed airboating and skiing. He is survived by his wife Niki and son Kendrick R, parents John and Lynn Laguardia of Orlando, his sister, Day Gigliotti (John) and nieces Annie & Grayson of Winter Park; paternal uncle, Arnold Laguardia (Susan) of Del Mar, CA; maternal aunt Kendra Merrill (David), cousins Seth and Nathan Merrill all of Burlington, VT.

title: Powell Meets With North Korea Counterpart in Brunei
description: In the United States's highest-level contact with North Korea since President Bush took office, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell met informally for 15 minutes here this morning with Pyongyang's foreign minister, and officials said Secretary Powell would consider further talks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, ROSE
description: FRIEDMAN-Rose, 91. Died July 29, 2002. Beloved mother of Harvey & Judy Friedman, adored grandmother to Andrew and Eric.

title: Senate Panel Seeks to Weigh Risks on War With Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  A former United Nations inspector told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today he believes Saddam Hussein has extensive projects to make chemical and biological weapons, that he may have accelerated his nuclear-weapons programs, and that the Iraqi leader is a dangerous man because of his mental state.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Long Island: Fire Stalls L.I.R.R. Service
description: Service on the Long Island Rail Road was shut down for more than five hours between Lynbrook and Long Beach and between Rockville Centre and Long Beach because of a fire near the tracks in Oceanside yesterday afternoon, said Brian Dolan, a spokesman for the railroad. Service was suspended around 4:30 p.m. About 6,000 passengers were affected, but buses were available to transport them, Mr. Dolan said. He said firefighters asked the railroad not to run trains near the fire. The fire, at Gator Recycling Corporation, was not yet under control at 10:20 p.m. It was not known if there were any injuries, a spokesman for the Oceanside Fire Department said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: In Lieu of Bermuda, Business Is Sold
description: In agreeing yesterday to sell its consulting arm to I.B.M., PricewaterhouseCoopers abandoned its strategy of incorporating the business as a Bermuda company and renaming it Monday Ltd.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Arrow Exterminators, Roswell, Ga., a termite and pest control company, named Match, Atlanta, as the first agency to handle its account, with billings estimated at less than $1 million.

title: Editors' Note; To Our Readers
description: Because of a power failure in Queens on Monday night, some copies of The Arts, Science Times and World Business were not produced in time for delivery yesterday. They are being distributed today. Any reader still missing the sections may call 1-800-NYTIMES (1-800-698-4637).

title: Health Insurers Lose Bid on Case Records
description: Aetna Inc., the Cigna Corporation, Humana Inc. and other health insurers lost a bid to bar plaintiffs' lawyers from obtaining internal records in cases that accuse the companies of skimping on patient care.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Deal With Casinos
description: The Detroit City Council will consider an arrangement with three casinos that would allow them to operate permanently in exchange for a 1 percent tax on revenue to pay for improvements to parks and recreation. The deal, brokered by Mayor Kwame Kilpatrick, is intended to sway Council members who thought that the casinos were not offering the city enough. Jeremy W. Peters (NYT)

title: Bohemians Of the 20's In an O'Hara Of the 50's
description: The Peccadillo Theater Company specializes in dusting off forgotten American works, an admirable enterprise, though some works are better off left undusted in the attic. That's probably true of ''Veronique,'' a misshapen melodrama by John O'Hara that the company is presenting through this weekend at the Bank Street Theater.

title: A Pallid Clean Air Plan
description: President Bush has now unveiled his long-awaited ''Clear Skies'' proposal, which he promises will simplify and strengthen the Clean Air Act without crippling American industry. A debate on how to make the 32-year-old Clean Air Act a stronger and more efficient instrument is surely long overdue. But the Bush plan falls well short of the only other credible proposal on the table, a bill sponsored by Senator James Jeffords of Vermont.

title: Online Courses Are Popular
description: The State University of New York announced last week that 40,000 students, a record, had enrolled in online courses last year, up 56 percent from the previous year. A SUNY survey found that 86 percent said they spent more time studying because of the ''any time, any place'' nature of the courses. SUNY's chancellor, ROBERT L. KING, said the survey also found that 90 percent of the students reported high levels of satisfaction and 99 percent of the faculty members expressed satisfaction. Last year, 53 of SUNY's 64 campuses offered 2,500 courses over the Internet. Karen W. Arenson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSER, STANLEY
description: LESSER-Stanley. The Conservative Synagogue of Fifth Avenue mourns the loss of Stanley Lesser, founding member and long term Trustee. Our heartfelt condolences to his family. Rabbi David Gaffney

title: Studies Suggest Unknown Form of Matter Exists
description: Painstaking observations of a kind of subatomic dance suggest that the universe may contain a shadowy form of matter that has never been seen directly and is unexplained by standard physics theories, a team of scientists working at Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island announced yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Register.Com Shares Plunge
description: The shares of Register.com fell 33 percent yesterday as second-quarter profit fell by more than half at the company, an Internet service provider that registers domain names. Shares dropped $2.39, to $4.86. Net income fell 58 percent to $846,000, or 2 cents a share, from $2.01 million, or 5 cents, a year earlier. Revenue fell 10 percent to $27 million from $30 million, the company said in a statement. Fewer customers renewed domain names, Register.com, which is based in New York, said in its statement. The rate of renewal in the second quarter was about 49 percent, down from 55 percent in the first quarter, the company said.

title: Thomson Is Sued Over Data Use
description: BOSTON, July 30 (Bloomberg News)  The Thomson Corporation , a provider of financial and legal data, was sued by CCBN.com Inc. on charges of using confidential information obtained from CCBN board meetings.

title: 1982 Bordeaux, Still Turning Heads
description: TWENTY years ago this summer, the weather in Bordeaux was magnificent. The flowering of the vines was early, and the number of blossoms was immense. The vines thrived in July, which was hot and dry. August, when just the right amount of rain fell, was followed by an exceptionally hot September. The average daily temperature early in the month was around 85 degrees, and there were a number of days when it went over 100. There had never been a larger crop. Even before a grape was picked, it was clear that 1982 was destined to be an exceptional year for Bordeaux wines.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: CONSUMER CONFIDENCE FALLS

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PARNES, SIDMORE
description: PARNES-Sidmore. Always remembered. Always loved. Davi

title: Kenny Gardner, 89, Guy Lombardo's Crooner
description: Kenny Gardner, the light-voiced, cheerfully smooth tenor who for almost 30 years was the featured crooner with Guy Lombardo and His Royal Canadians, died on Friday in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 89 and lived in Plandome, N.Y.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Chip Maker Posts Profit
description: The United Microelectronics Corporation posted a smaller-than-expected profit in the second quarter and said third-quarter shipments would decline by 5 percent from the previous three months. The company, which is the second-largest supplier of made-to-order chips in the world, reported a profit of $130 million, reversing a loss of $56 million a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, HOPE
description: WEISSMAN-Hope, 58. Wesleyan University Associate Professor of Letters and of Women's Studies, died July 24, 2002. Survived by her mother, Sarah Weissman of Monroe Township, NJ and brothers Robert of Randolph, N.J., and Arthur of Falls Church, VA. Memorial service is planned for the fall at Wesleyan University. Donations may be made to Wesleyan University, attention Hope Weissman Memorial Scholarship Fund, C/O University Relations, 318 High St., Middletown, CT. 06459.

title: Seoul National Assembly Rejects Woman as Prime Minister
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 31  South Korea's national assembly today overwhelmingly rejected President Kim Dae Jung's attempt at appointing a woman as prime minister after a bruising debate that touched on issues ranging from her real estate dealings to her educational background.

title: Road accident galvanizes the country : Deaths in Korea ignite anti-American passion
description: UIJONGBU, South Korea:  On a concrete wall surrounding Camp Red Cloud, a small U.S. Army post here, an identification photograph of Sergeant Mark Walker stares blankly from dozens of posters proclaiming him "wanted" for the "crime of murder."

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a Critic's Notebook article in The Arts yesterday about music in Santa Fe misstated part of the name of the conductor of Kaija Saariaho's opera ''L'Amour de Loin.'' He was Robert Spano. (James F. Ingalls was the lighting designer).

title: A Spicy Indian Spot That Doesn't Care to Fit In
description: THE old saw has it that there is a single communal kitchen under the cluster of Indian restaurants on East Sixth Street from which they all take their food. The arrival in late 2000 of Banjara, a nonfacsimile on the corner of First Avenue, did some damage to this moldy chestnut. Brick Lane Curry House, a spare and casual place that opened next door to Banjara about three months ago, breaks it wide.

title: COURT APPROVES COMDISCO CHAPTER 11 RECOVERY PLAN
description: Comdisco Inc. won the approval of a federal bankruptcy judge for a Chapter 11 recovery plan that will repay bondholders and other creditors almost all of the more than $4 billion they are owed. Under the plan, the technology services company, which is based in Rosemont, Ill., will liquidate during the next three years and use the proceeds to pay creditors. Comdisco has raised about $2 billion from earlier asset sales. The company estimates that creditors will get back about 90 percent of their claims, and shareholders might also see a recovery. Judge Ronald Barliant of United States Bankruptcy Court approved the recovery plan at a hearing yesterday after Comdisco resolved objections from 10 creditors.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Wireless Telecom To Close Headquarters
description: The Wireless Telecom Group, a maker of electronic test-and-measurement equipment, will close its Paramus, N.J., headquarters and move to Parsippany to trim costs. The move to the facility of its Boonton Electronics unit is expected to be completed by Sept. 1, Wireless Telecom said in a statement yesterday. All 35 employees at the Paramus location will move to Boonton's plant, a spokeswoman, Reed DuBow, said. The company has not determined the savings from the move.

title: Delivery Guys Won't Spy
description: I've been reading, with a great deal of concern, about the Justice Department's proposed Terrorism Information and Prevention System, under which ordinary men and women working for utility companies, trucking services or the post office would be asked to report any ''suspicious'' activities they see.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Three Rob Mah-Jongg Players
description: Three young men who asked to join a mah-jongg game in a Queens apartment abruptly announced a robbery and shot one of the players, the police said yesterday. The player, Shui Lin, 46, suffered a graze wound to her head during the robbery in the apartment in Flushing about 10 p.m. Monday, the police said. Investigators theorize the shooting was an accident. The men ordered the 15 people in the apartment to empty their pockets; they fled with an undetermined amount of cash. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Democratic Hopefuls Lift Their Voices and Spirits
description: For Senator John Edwards, Democrat of North Carolina, it was the disappearance of the budget surplus in President Bush's first 18 months in office, a loss that he described yesterday as more of a threat to the nation's future than the drop in the stock market.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: TAIWAN: INVESTIGATORS LINK CRACKS TO CRASH The breakup of a China Airlines flight on May 25 that killed 225 people appeared to have begun near the rear cargo door, but the cause is still unknown, investigators said. Metal fatigue cracks have been found in wreckage from near the door, although the cracks are not enough by themselves to have caused the aircraft to come apart, they said. The back of the plane struck a runway during a sharp takeoff in 1980 and was patched. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: ANHEUSER-BUSCH SEEKING STAKE IN A CHINESE BREWERY
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies and the Tsingtao Brewery Company, China's largest brewer with 11 percent of the market, announced plans for a commercial alliance and said that Anheuser-Busch was negotiating to acquire a stake in Tsingtao. An equity investment would require approval by the Chinese government. The Chinese beer market is growing 6 percent a year as rising incomes make beer affordable to more of the country's 1.2 billion people. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: EARTHLINK NARROWS LOSS TO $40 MILLION The Internet service provider, EarthLink, said yesterday that it lost $40 million in the second quarter as subscriber growth for high-speed Internet access was canceled out by a nearly 7 percent loss of dial-up customers. The net loss, equal to 27 cents a share, was better than the $98.7 million, or 75 cents a share, the company lost in the same quarter last year. Excluding amortization and depreciation costs, the company lost $10.8 million, or 7 cents a share — 2 cents better than the forecast of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. That compares with an operational loss of $35.1 million, or 27 cents a share, in the same April-June quarter of 2001. Revenue at EarthLink, based in Atlanta, rose 10 percent, to $335.5 million, from $303.7 million in the same period of 2001. EarthLink added 72,000 high-speed customers in the quarter, while its dial-up base shrunk to slightly more than 4 million. EarthLink shares rose 2 cents, to $4.75.   (AP)

description: Doing justice to a lobster steamed in the shell means picking out every morsel of meat, dousing each bite with melted butter and sucking on the legs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANREK, SIDNEY
description: KANREK-Sidney. Of Brooklyn, NY, born in Poland in 1906, passed away peacefully at home on July 30, 2002 after a wonderful and eventful life. Beloved husband of the late Aurelia, cherished father of Marilyn and Victoria, devoted grandfather of David, he was always a loving & caring person. Funeral services at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue, NYC at noon on July 31. Interment at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. The family requests that in lieu of flowers donations be made to the UJA/Federation of NYIsrael Emergency Fund.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Holocaust Fund Closing
description: The fund that distributed about $200 million to more than 300,000 Holocaust victims has finished its work and is to close. The Swiss Fund for Needy Victims of the Holocaust, set up in 1997 after a controversy erupted over how Swiss banks had handled accounts of Holocaust victims, distributed money donated by banks, businesses and the Swiss National Bank. The fund is separate from a tribunal established in 1998 to review claims to Swiss bank accounts dormant since World War II. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about the St. Louis Cardinals' acquisition of Scott Rolen misstated the team's record in the 2000 National League playoffs. They were winners in the first round, not losers, defeating Atlanta.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Volkswagen Lowers Outlook
description: Volkswagen, Europe's leading carmaker, lowered its 2002 pretax earnings forecast by 9 percent with profits expected to fall to $3.9 billion from last year's record of $4.4 billion. The company cut production 7.9 percent in the first half as vehicle sales fell 8.4 percent to 2.5 million cars and light trucks. Sales were down 1.7 percent in the United States and 21 percent in Brazil. ''The second part of the year will not be any easier,'' the chief executive, Bernd Pischetsrieder said. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Brian Carty was named executive vice president for corporate development at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. He had been chief executive at Wheelhouse, Burlington, Mass., a marketing services company.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Trade Commissioner Resigns
description: Tumult over garlic tariffs has led to the resignation of the chairman of the Korea Trade Commission as a result of the commission's refusal to heed the demands of farmers for restrictions on the import of garlic from China. The chairman, Jeon Sung Chul, apologized to farmers for the failure of the commission ''to perform independently and free of government pressures.'' The commission rejected the demand of farmers for a four-year extension of restrictions after this year on the import of an average of $9 million worth of garlic a year from China. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Oil Profit Falls
description: The oil giant BP said second-quarter net profit fell 36 percent to $2.18 billion, in line with analysts' forecasts, largely because of lower natural gas prices. The falling price of oil and natural gas is also likely to hurt profits at other big oil companies set to report second-quarter earnings, like Exxon and Royal Dutch/Shell. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARPS, RUTH
description: ARPS-Ruth. The Civil Support Division and the Board of Directors of the Legal Aid Society mourn the loss of our dear friend who dedicated 50 years of service to the Society as a staunch supporter and tireless fundraiser. Mrs. Arps chaired the Women's Division during the mid 1970s. She and her late husband, Leslie will be remembered for their invaluable support to the cause of equal justice. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family and friends.

title: Coach Says Its Quarterly Profit Is Up 87%
description: Coach Inc. , the luxury products retailer, said fourth-quarter profit jumped 87 percent as new products like shoes lifted sales and the company expanded in Japan. The company also raised its forecast for this year.

title: Senate Panel Approves Treaty Banning Bias Against Women
description: The Democratic-controlled Senate Foreign Relations Committee, over the objections of the Bush administration, approved an international treaty today that is intended to eliminate discrimination against women. The vote set up a politically divisive floor fight pitting women's rights groups against religious and social conservatives.

title: W.R. GRACE AND SEALED AIR LOSE RULING IN FRAUD SUIT
description: W. R. Grace & Company and the Sealed Air Corporation lost a court ruling that might make it easier for people alleging asbestos injuries to prove that Grace fraudulently sold a food-packaging company to Sealed Air in 1998. Sealed Air, the maker of Bubble Wrap, fell $15.77, or almost 42 percent, to $22 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. Grace transferred its Cryovac division to Sealed Air in 1998 for $1.2 billion and stock, in a move to shield assets from plaintiffs seeking payment for asbestos-related injuries, according to a lawsuit against Sealed Air and Grace. Judge Alfred Wolin of United States District Court in Newark, N.J., said Grace should have anticipated the asbestos claims when it sold Cryovac. Sealed Air, based in Saddle Brook, N.J., said it would appeal.

title: Justice Dept. Investigating AOL's Accounting
description: AOL Time Warner said today that the Department of Justice had begun a criminal investigation into accounting at its AOL division, following a civil investigation begun by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Senate Kills Plan to Cover Prescriptions Under Medicare
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 — The Senate today killed legislation to provide prescription drug benefits promised to the elderly by politicians of both parties. But it overwhelmingly passed a bill intended to give all Americans greater access to low-cost generic versions of brand-name medicines.
